title: Reagan's Political Aide Quits
description: President Reagan's chief political adviser has resigned and will return to Indianapolis to become executive vice president of the Hudson Institute, the White House announced today.

title: HOFFMAN: A RADICAL IN ALL AGES
description: Abbie Hoffman is enjoying a midlife crisis, touched off, he says, by the decision over what to call his next book. The choices are ''The Drug Hysteria in America'' and ''Steal This Urine Test.''

title: THE MET'S DESIGN GALLERY
description: The 20th-century decorative arts - surveyed in major exhibitions at four New York museums over the last year - are reviewed again in a dramatically different way in the Design and Architecture Gallery that opens Tuesday in the new Lila Acheson Wallace Wing at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: TOPICS
description: FIRST is the surprise. Within me is a 2-year-old agog at the wonder and beauty of life. Also a 5-year-old poking his inquisitive nose into the treasure house of a public library. And an East Harlem 9-year-old learning the mystery and miracle of the natural world in a Union Settlement summer camp at Southfields, N.Y.

title: The Real Sambo
description: To the Editor:

title: COST OF SEABROOK PLANT BEGINS TO HIT CUSTOMERS
description: Ratepayers in 28 Massachusetts communities that invested in the Seabrook nuclear power plant are beginning to see the effect of the construction in their electricity bills, even though they still receive no electricity from the idle plant.

title: SOPRANO, HARPSICHORDIST, A FLUTIST AND 2 PIANISTS
description: Mitsuko Shirai

title: L.I.R.R., BACK IN SERVICE, BRACES FOR RETURN OF RUSH-HOUR RIDERS
description: With a certainty and assurance that hid the effects of a bitter two-week strike, the Long Island Rail Road greeted its riders today with service that passengers, workers and officials said was better than expected.

title: A Historic Wing Chair Sells for $2.75 Million
description: A 200-year-old Philadelphia wing chair - its frame riddled with nail holes, its carved front feet looking like hairy paws - became the most expensive piece of furniture ever sold at auction yesterday in a sale at Sotheby's.

title: Walters Is Uneasy About U.S. Cutbacks at U.N.
description: The chief United States delegate to the United Nations says he is uncomfortable that Washington is not paying its full financial contribution despite measures adopted by the General Assembly to improve budget procedures.

title: Mary Rhinelander Weds Henry McCarl
description: Mary Frederica Rhinelander, a student in the doctoral program at Boston University in the history of the book in America, was married yesterday to Henry Newton McCarl, a visiting fellow in the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences at Harvard University. The Rev. Timothy Dobbins performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Gloucester, Mass.

title: SEAT BELTS BECOMING THE THING TO WEAR IN TEXAS
description: When the Texas Legislature passed a law requiring drivers and front-seat passengers in automobiles to buckle up with seat belts, people hereabouts had a good laugh. That, they said, would work about as well as the one setting the speed limit at 55 miles an hour.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: West Philadelphia, Pa.;
Campbell Soup Serves Up Hope
description: LEAD: WHEN the Campbell Soup Company picks a developer for its $35 million, 225,000-square-foot world headquarters in Camden, N.J., later this month, officials hope it will be the first step in that city's long-awaited commercial revitalization.

title: THE BIG BUCKS IN KNEES AND ELBOWS
description: THE Hughston Sports Medicine Hospital here in western Georgia may not be the Lourdes of ailing athletes, but it is certainly their Mecca.

title: IN WINTER, THE 'BLUES' BECOME PERVASIVE
description: LEAD: LIKE the common cold, depression affects a significant number of New Jerseyans during the anticlimactic post-holiday period between New Year's Day (marking an end to festivities) and the first crocus of spring (heralding renewal).

title: STEWART SHOOTS 69 TO GAIN TWO-SHOT LEAD
description: ''There's nothing really outstanding I do but I do a lot of things really well,'' said Payne Stewart, one of the most consistent golfers on the PGA Tour in recent years.

title: PLANNERS ACT
description: THE Tarrytown Planning Board agreed by a narrow margin last week to ask its Village Board of Trustees to revoke the permits that had allowed a local builder to make major changes in his historic-district property.

title: Identity Crisis
description: Howard Teicher, a member of the National Security Council staff, attended a dinner at the Brookings Institution the other night and the people around the table were asked to state names and hometowns, such as ''Joe Doakes, New York.''

title: Out of Nicaragua
description: Captive Americans may be swapped for munitions in other parts of the world, but Nicaragua continues to give them away. Last week, officials there released Sam Nesley Hall, an American charged with working against Managua, making him the second captured contra - Eugene Hasenfus became the first last year - to be sent home. The Nicaraguans, who had held Mr. Hall 49 days on espionage charges, said they let him go because he was suicide-prone. The 49-year-old Ohioan was contrite. ''I have just one thing to say to the Nicaraguan people: I'm sorry I tried to ambush them,'' he said. He was met in Miami by his brother, Representative Tony Hall, Democrat of Ohio, who took him to a Veterans Administration hospital for what was described as a ''thorough psychological and physical evaluation.''

title: DID THE SUPER BOWL LIVE UP TO THE HYPE?
description: The Super Bowl game surpassed the hype. Perhaps it was because of my deep interest in this particular game, as a Giants fan. However, during the two-week waiting period, the hype, the analyzing, the anticipation all became boring. The writers and television reporters seemed to be overreaching to create stories.

title: In Cars or TV's, Protection Never Works
description: LAST week, Japan announced that it would extend the Voluntary Restraint Agreement limiting Japanese car exports to the United States to 2.3 million units. However, with the backing of the Big Three car makers and the United Auto Workers, the Democratic-controlled Congress is under strong pressure to legislate even tighter curbs. That would be a mistake. The VRA disserves the auto industry, its labor force and American consumers.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
LOONS AND SHIPS
description: LEAD: The Royal Canadian Mint has unveiled two new designs intended for use this year on $1 coins. One, featuring a loon, will appear on an aureate-nickel dollar. It will be released in July as a circulating coin. The other, depicting a ship with an iceberg in the background, will appear on Canada's 1987 commemorative silver dollar.

title: COMEDY ON WRY AND SOME KIPPERS
description: Fawlty Towers Starring John Cleese, Prunella Scales, Andrew Sachs and Connie Booth. Gourmet Night, Waldorf Salad and The Kipper and the Corpse. 90 minutes. The Builders, The Wedding Party and The Psychiatrist. 98 minutes. CBS/Fox Video. $29.98 each.

title: Data Bank: February 1, 1987
A Daughter's Father
description: I WAS APPLYING FOR A PASSPORT FOR MY 18-month-old daughter when I froze at the marital-status question. Give the kid a chance, I thought, she's still in diapers. But the question haunted me for days. I recognized the feeling, which first appeared soon after Annie was born. But it wasn't until that day at the Passport Office that I began to focus on just how radically my outlook has changed simply because my child is a female.

title: HIGHS AND LOWS FOR SUZUKI
description: ASK anybody what is a Suzuki and you are liable to get one of three answers: (a) I don't know; (b) a small fuzzy dog, or (c) a motorcycle.

title: CALIBER OF CAREER
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Janet How Wed To S. F. Accardo
description: The marriage of Janet King How, director of information services for Ernst & Whinney, certified public accountants in New York, to Salvatore Francis Accardo, a senior vice president of the Manufacturers Hanover Investment Corporation, took place yesterday in Christ Chapel at the Riverside Church in Manhattan. The Rev. William Sloane Coffin, senior minister of the interdenominationl church, performed the ceremony.

title: THE SHORTEST MONTH IS BUSIEST ON BLACK HISTORY
description: AS the celebration of Black History Month begins today, historical groups, schools and churches across the state will be offering exhibits, lectures and other programs throughout February.

title: CBS News In Search of Itself
description: At a salary that ''pays him about $3 million a year,'' Dan Rather makes sure that his agent secures for him ''veto power over co-anchor candidates'' but neglects to demand equal control over news quality. This shows you where his priorities lie. PAULINE PIEKARZ Yonkers

title: Extraordinary, Holmes!
description: To the Editor:

title: CHINESE DETAINEES INCLUDE EX-STUDENT IN U.S.
description: A Chinese student educated in the United States has been identified by his wife as one of the demonstrators detained in China's crackdown on political dissent.

title: DID THE SUPER BOWL LIVE UP TO THE HYPE?
description: Absolutely - and then some! A voracious appetite, spawned in the Polo Grounds and weaned at Yankee Stadium, ravished every single word. What a game! What a team! What a season! ED FLYNN New York

title: Beware Phase 1 of S.D.I.
description: Today, as before, the single most marked characteristic of the Reagan Administration is the mismatch between its words and reality -a gap that is hard to explain except by incompetence or duplicity.

title: Quarterback Cluster
description: IT'S going to take all the fingers on one hand to count the quarterbacks on the Chicago Bears after the National Football League draft. Mike McCaskey, the team president who has been acting as his own general manager following the dismissal of Jerry Vainisi, said he planned to take a quarterback in the draft April 28 even though the club has four already - Jim McMahon, Doug Flutie, Mike Tomczak and Steve Fuller.

title: Murphy Promoted
description: ONE man's sudden misfortune can be another man's opportunity, and Mike Murphy has made the best of his unexpected chance. In the eight games since Murphy stepped in as acting coach of the Los Angeles Kings following the expulsion of the Kings' former coach, Pat Quinn, for conflict of interest, the once lagging Kings have compiled a 4-2-2 record, bringing their season record up to the .500 mark, 22-22-6, and winning Murphy the full-time position.

title: 'LBJ' -- A POWERFUL PORTRAIT
description: The most moving scene in ''LBJ: The Early Years'' is this: It is 1955, and Lyndon B. Johnson, the Senate majority leader, recovered from a heart attack, has returned to Washington from Texas. As he approaches the Capitol, Senators and their assistants pass the word. ''The leader's coming,'' ''The leader's coming,'' they say, and spontaneously assemble in a corridor. Lyndon Johnson appears, casting a huge shadow against the sunlit window behind him. It is a mythic materialization; who is this towering figure? Then Mr. Johnson emerges from the shadow. ''What the hell y'all looking at?'' he says testily to the Senators, who break out in applause and cheers. At her husband's side, Lady Bird Johnson begins to cry. Testiness or not, we are meant to know, some people loved Lyndon Johnson.

title: O'ROURKE FILLS 3 POSTS, DETAILS STATE PACKAGE
description: COUNTY Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke filled three cabinet-level positions last week, promoting each official from within the Westchester government, and issued a ''wish list'' of 76 specific programs that he said he hoped the State Legislature would approve.

title: EXCERPTS FROM KEAN'S MESSAGE ON BUDGET
description: Following are excerpts from the budget message released here today that Governor Kean is to give to the New Jersey Legislature on Monday:

title: CHRISTIAN SOLDIERS
description: THE SOUTHERN BAPTIST HOLY WAR By Joe Edward Barnhart. 273 pp. Austin: Texas Monthly Press. $16.95.

title: LEAN, LOW-CHOLESTEROL VENISON MORE COMMON IN THE MARKET
description: OBTAINING venison no longer requires a hunting expedition. It has become more widely available commercially, and many butchers given a few days' notice can supply it. The meat is extremely lean and relatively low in cholesterol.

title: More on Smoking
description: To the Editor: Charles A. Lemaistre creates a badly distorted picture in ''Nobody is Safe if a Smoker is Around'' (Forum, Jan. 4). His assertion that ''involuntary smoking is a cause of disease, including lung cancer,'' is based on conclusions that are highly questionable in light of the evidence.

title: DULL 'ANNE FRANK' AT BECTON THEATER
description: FOR two years, six Jews have been hiding from the Nazis in the garret of a factory. Now the dreaded, ominous pounding is heard on the door downstairs.

title: PUBLIC HAS RIGHT TO KNOW
description: FREEDOM of information - the very words express a noble principle. No more deals agreed to behind closed doors. Let the sun shine on all government business. Citizens have a fundamental right to know how decisions are made.

title: 11 People Hurt in Vermont As Cars Tumble Off Ski Lift
description: Eleven people were slightly injured today when two gondola cars fell from a cable at Mt. Snow Ski Area and others stacked up against a lift tower. The injured included several people who jumped to the ground, a spokesman for the ski area said.

title: PARTYING WHILE GIVING
description: Twyla Tharp at BAM

title: EMILY DICKINSON: THE MOVIE
description: LEAD: ''OUT OF AMHERST'' brings to the screen a little-known period in American literary history. In the year 1855, on the untamed plains of Walden Pond, Emily Dickinson met Henry David Thoreau. Emily, passionate and headstrong, had escaped her severe Calvinist upbringing to create a plantation in the wilderness; Henry was a born adventurer, whom the land claimed as no woman ever could.

title: TAX REFORM CUTTING LOANS TO BUSINESSES
description: LEAD: CONNECTICUT businesses that in the past would have been eligible for low-interest loans from the state to expand now may have to look elsewhere for financing.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
COMEDY ON WRY AND SOME KIPPERS
description: LEAD: Ski New England 60 Minutes. $29.95 Colorado Ski Trips #90 minutes. $29.95 Rand McNally Video Trips. Lightning Video.

title: Two Communisms, One Crossroad
description: It is a spectacle of rare proportions. The 20th century's two greatest experiments in government are consumed by inward struggle. Soviet and Chinese leaders have decided that their nations cannot move forward without moving, in some ways, toward the capitalist economies rejected by their revolutions and without embracing some elements of freedom. But how much and what sort of movement can their Communist systems take without revolution or reaction?

title: TUNING IN ON RARE PANTHERS
description: FLORIDA'S official state animal, the panther, was reported nearing extinction when the State Game and Fresh Water Fish Commission began tracking the survivors by radio to learn more about how they lived.

title: Wendy L. Lowenstein Wed to Jeffery Sandler
description: Wendy Louise Lowenstein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Lowenstein of Rye, N.Y., and New York, was married last evening to Jeffrey Sandler, the son of Dr. Arthur Sandler of Swampscott, Mass., and the late Ruth P. Sandler. Rabbi Daniel Wolk performed the ceremony at the Hotel Pierre in New York.

title: MAKING THE TRANSITION IN NEWARK
description: TO OUTSIDERS, the change seemed negligible when Sharpe James replaced Kenneth A. Gibson last July to become Newark's 35th Mayor.

title: AIDING YOUR NEIGHBORS' ENEMIES
description: IN one of the world's worst-kept official secrets, Pakistan has for years harbored military bases of the guerrilla insurgency in neighboring Afghanistan. To Washington, Pakistan's role is part of an elemental conflict between ''freedom fighters'' and a Communist regime propped up by Moscow.

title: Crane Permits
description: To the Editor: As the Buildings Department examiner on the crane-installation project at 650 Madison Avenue, I was pleasantly surprised to notice the familiar sight on the front page on Dec. 7 under the headline ''A Skyline Stage for New York Cranes.'' Your article on cranes was interesting, informative and largely correct.

title: RUSSIAN MUSIC BEFORE AND AFTER REVOLUTION
description: Russia has lived long and suffered much, but its art has often fed on such misfortunes - creating in its music, for example, a wide capacity to stretch the imagination and dream deeply.

title: DEMOCRATS URGED TO AVOID CENTER
description: Democrats have always enjoyed the folksy humor of Jim Hightower, Texas's Commissioner of Agriculture, but party leaders have generally kept their distance from his brand of populist politics.

title: GREAT PAN WAS A LONG TIME DYING
description: PAGANS AND CHRISTIANS By Robin Lane Fox. Maps. 799 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $35.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 1, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-15

title: WORLD SO HARD TO FIND
description: THE sun is high enough by 7 to light the wings of flying gulls as they glide over the flats left by the ebbing tide.

title: CONGRESS TAKES ON CATASTROPHIC ILLNESS ISSUE
description: THE Reagan Administration is sharply divided over proposals to provide health insurance to the elderly for catastrophic illness. On Capitol Hill there is much more agreement. Without waiting for President Reagan to submit a detailed proposal, members of Congress from both parties rushed last week to endorse the expansion of Medicare, the Federal program that pays for health care for 31 million elderly and disabled people at a cost of more than $70 billion a year.

title: SMOKEY OUTGROWN, AND RETIRING CHIEF SEES GAINS
description: When R. Max Peterson first joined the Forest Service in 1949, the prevailing image of the service in the mind of the public was largely inseparable from that of its icon, Smokey Bear.

title: SCHOOL TEST SCORES RISE FOR BLACKS IN MARYLAND
description: Black students in a Maryland county school system that began a unusual desegregation program two years ago have posted significant gains on national standardized test scores, school officials say.

title: Equality
description: To the Editor: Attributing increased layoffs of black managers to this administration's policies (''The Ax Falls on Equal Opportunity,'' Jan. 4) completely misses the point. These unfortunate setbacks are not the result of the current Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, but rather a case of the racial engineering of the past undoing itself.

title: NAME ERROR ON SHUTTLE PLAQUE
description: After a $36,000 monument was erected in memory of the seven astronauts who died in the space shuttle disaster, city officials were chagrined to discover that the name of one, Judith A. Resnik, had been misspelled.

title: MONSTSERRAT CABALLE TO SING AT CARNEGIE
description: The soprano Montserrat Caballe will give a recital at Carnegie Hall on Feb. 27th. Tickets, from $30 to $10, will go on sale tomorrow at the box office and through Carnegie Charge, (212) 247-7800.

title: OPPOSITION ASTIR OVER ECONOMY IN CHINA
description: PROPELLED by the determination of its senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, China has struggled for the last eight years to energize an economy that had been flattened by the turmoil of the Cultural Revolution. Conventional socialist precepts about central planning, state control of factories, businesses and marketing, and the dominance of party bureaucrats were all challenged by Mr. Deng's insistence that China must adopt some Western economic strategies. Special economic zones have been created where red tape is slashed. Companies have been permitted to issue stocks or bonds to raise money. Cities have issued bonds in Japan to finance construction projects. And some managers have been empowered to hire and dismiss workers and dole out bonuses as incentives.

title: ECONOMIC SHOCKS PUT STABLE ZAMBIA TO TEST
description: SINCE he came to power in 1964, President Kenneth D. Kaunda has been a resilient opponent of South African apartheid.

title: Counting Cars From 'Immigrant' Plants
description: OF OUR $173 billion trade deficit in 1986, Japan alone accounted for more than one-third - almost $60 billion, up from just $12 billion in 1980. Of that, more than half was due to automobiles. The arithmetic is compelling. You cannot lower the trade deficit unless you address the automotive component.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
The Battle to Save Pyramid Mountain
description: LEAD: DEEP in the northeastern corner of Morris County lie 450 acres of rugged woodlands, steep slopes, streams and wildflowers stretching to Pyramid Mountain. The tract, which straddles Kinnelon Borough and Montville Township, has remained untouched for centuries.

title: PEOPLE EXPRESS FLIGHTS END ON A NOTE OF REGRET
description: Capt. Fred Wilcoxson came into work on his day off today.

title: CABARET: JIM MORRIS'S IMPRESSIONS
description: EVER since Vaughn Meader sold millions of records imitating John F. Kennedy, Presidents of the United States have been fair game for comic impressionists.

title: A New Mall for the South Bronx Hub
description: ACROSS the street from a two-acre wasteland in the South Bronx, Gamaliel Santiago painted vibrant cartoon characters on an old storefront last year, then opened a party-supply store. ''I sensed that the area was on its way up,'' he explained a few days ago. ''I see a rosy future.''

title: IDAHO PLATES: A POTATO BIAS?
description: The ''Famous Potatoes'' slogan on Idaho automobile license plates seems to have been around as long as the Sawtooth Mountains or Sun Valley, but one Boisean, Andrew Freese, says it discriminates against other Idaho products, and he is suing the state to have it removed.

title: AND WE DIDN'T EVEN KNOW HIS NAME
description: IT'S not much of a street, fewer than 15 houses, and it lost only one tree during Hurricane Gloria. Two of us cleared the blocked driveway together while others came out and looked at the tree, but most were, as usual, invisible.

title: Senate Links Homeless Aid to Ban on Raises
description: The House and the Senate both voted last week to provide an immediate $50 million to feed and shelter the homeless. But the Senate put the House on the spot: It added on an amendment to block a pay raise for top Federal officials, including members of Congress.

title: An American In China
description: From August 1985 to July 1986, I taught English at the Changsha Railway Institute, and much of what Mark Salzman described in his article rang true to me (''Of Confucius, 'E.T.' and Happiness Candy,'' Dec. 21). But I wonder exactly what sort of signals Mr. Salzman sent out in China and what sort he brought back to put in his book. He tells us that, ''oddly,'' he had never wanted to go to China, and he seems exasperated or befuddled by his contacts with the Chinese. The tone, for example, of his encounter with a student requesting that he tutor his wife's cousin in English is oddly disinterested. After being told that the woman was the leader of her class, head of the Communist Youth League in her school, a voluntary exile during the Cultural Revolution and a beginning medical student, Mr. Salzman declares that ''Little Mi sounds like a terrific bore.'' Only later, when the ''beautiful'' Little Mi arrives do we find out that she's interesting, and we find out what it's like to feel a Chinese girl's cheek pressing through your winter coat.

title: FULL SPEED AHEAD
description: Imposing a 55 miles per hour speed limit on a Grand Prix might seem comical, but the concept has effectively been the policy of the American Contract Bridge League for many years. Players in major national championships have been barred from using scientific bidding ideas just in case they happen to confuse an inexperienced opponent.

title: ARHTUR MILLER: STIRRED BY MILLER
description: The two new one-act plays by Arthur Miller that open at Lincoln Center next Sunday are thematically linked under the title ''Danger: Memory!'', which could be taken as a symbolic warning to the playwright. In 1964, he inaugurated Lincoln Center's first theater season (in its temporary home in a theater near Washington Square) with ''After the Fall,'' a play that fell far short of expectations. Just as Mr. Miller may have a feeling of deja vu, Gregory Mosher, halfway through his second season as artistic director of the new Lincoln Center Theater Company, is unavoidably shadowed by past theatrical constituencies. Since it began, Lincoln Center theater has been a theater in search of itself.

title: Baryshnikov's Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: Layers of Lies on Iran
description: Those who mired America in the Iran-contra arms affair deceived the public, Congress, each other and themselves. That much is established by the Senate Intelligence Committee's new report. Judging from the roseate White House reaction, the self-deception continues. The President is pleased that the report ''is consistent with'' his claim that the Iran deal was a statesmanlike initiative ''from its inception'' and confirms his unawareness that munitions deal profits were diverted to the Nicaragua rebels.

title: TINY CAFE HINTS OF NANTUCKET
description: KUDOS to the new Nantucket Cafe in New Canaan for its imaginative use of interior space. In a room that holds just nine tables and seats 22 people, the ambiance of Nantucket has been artfully evoked.

title: NEW RULES IMPERIL HEMPSTEAD PROJECTS
description: HEMPSTEAD Town and Nassau County officials, under pressure to meet Federal air-quality standards or face a cutoff of funds for road projects, have adopted a tough new environmental stance that could prevent construction, limit the size or increase the cost of major projects planned at Mitchel Field.

title: KIN SAID TO VISIT 2 LEBANESE IN BONN
description: Two Lebanese brothers imprisoned in West Germany, one of whom is wanted by the United States for hijacking and murder, were recently visited in jail by their parents, officials said today.

title: BAD DRIVING IS A WAY OF LIFE ON STATE'S ROADS
description: BY the time we left Iroquois country in upstate New York on our holiday trip, a strange sensation had begun, a distant recollection of another time and place. As the Appalachian plateau of Ohio flattened out into the cornfields of Indiana, it became more than a perception; it was real, proving itself again and again. Most drivers were courteous.

title: 2 Die in Marseilles Car Blast
description: Two people were killed today when their car exploded in front of a school in a suburb here, sources said. The police were said to be investigating whether a bomb had been planted in the car. An incendiary device was reported found in another car parked nearby.

title: Cable TV
description: When the Academy Awards for achievement in film in the year 1985 were announced, eight of the coveted statuettes went to ''Out of Africa.'' Among the awards for the film - to be seen on cable for the first time this week (Sunday at 9 A.M. and 8 P.M. on HBO, on Tuesday at 10 A.M. and 8 P.M. on Cinemax, on Thursday at noon and 11 P.M. on HBO, and on Saturday at noon and 10:15 P.M. on Showtime) - were those for best picture, best director (Sydney Pollack), best screenplay adaptation, best cinematography, best original score, best art direction and set decoration and best sound.

title: HEALTH CODE VIOLTIONS CITED
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 28 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: CONTEMPORARY APPROACH TO AN AGE-OLD TRADITION
description: ELLA T. GRASSO'S statue will remain conspicuous for some time - the pristine white of the Carrara marble that it's carved in guaran-tees that. The sculptor himself, Frank C. Gaylord 2d, allows that it will look like a ''newly painted radiator'' until the acids in Hartford's atmosphere have had their way. But even then it's unlikely that the Governor will have merged with the other figures of state history who occupy most of the niches lining the Capitol's third story and the reason won't be her sex.

title: HOW TO PLOT A TOUR OF BRITISH GARDENS
description: British gardeners have been mucking about in their soil, more or less continually, since Roman invaders showed how easy it was to clip boxwood shrubs into peculiar-looking blobs. So we American gardeners must be forgiven our awe of this landscape, which is littered with naturalistic parklands, structured knots and mazes, gaudy arabesque parterres and flowery herbaceous borders.

title: Nancy Donner Is Married To Gary Martin, an Artist
description: The marriage of Nancy Donner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard I. Donner of New York, to Gary B. Martin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard M. Martin of Baltimore, took place last evening at the Tavern on the Green in New York. Rabbi Mark Loeb officiated.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: HOPSCOTCH, by Julio Cortazar. Translated by Gregory Rabassa. (Pantheon, $8.95.) ''Hopscotch,'' the best-known novel of the Argentine writer Julio Cortazar (1914-84), is the story of a middle-aged Argentine living an expatriate's life in Paris with his mistress. ''The dialogue is brilliant,'' Donald Keene said in The Book Review in 1966, and ''the rapid-fire invention of the language makes every page sparkle, thanks to the translation.'' The work is, in fact, ''a comic novel, sometimes howlingly funny, always acutely ironic.'' Writing in these pages in 1969, C. D. B. Bryan called ''Hopscotch'' ''the most magnificent novel I have ever read. . . . No novel by any living author has more influenced me, more intrigued me, or more enraptured me.'' WISEGUY: Life in a Mafia Family, by Nicholas Pileggi. (Pocket Books, $4.50.) Nicholas Pileggi's portrait of Henry Hill - a small-time gangster and ''mechanic'' for a mob family, the kind of tough thief called a ''wiseguy'' in the business - amounts to an oral history of organized crime in New York. ''Mr. Pileggi molds Mr. Hill's life story into an absolutely engrossing book that rings with authenticity,'' Vincent Patrick said here last year. ''Mr. Hill is a find, a bona fide wiseguy who generally 'earned' at street level but who had unusual access to high-level crime bosses.'' The book evoked for him ''the quality of the best documentary films.'' AN ESTATE OF MEMORY, by Ilona Karmel. (Feminist Press, $11.95.) Ilona Karmel's novel about life in a Nazi work camp in Poland in 1943-44 focuses on four imprisoned women, one of them pregnant, who plot to secretly deliver and to save the baby. ''This is a very good book,'' Elizabeth Janeway said here in 1969, one that conveys ''plausible, possible human experience.'' NO LAUGHING MATTER, by Joseph Heller and Speed Vogel. (Avon, $4.95.) This chronicle of Joseph Heller's struggle against and recovery from the paralyzing effects of Guillain-Barre syndrome ''is so much about the approach of the Grim Reaper that it requires the combined strength of two authors to push him back,'' Anthony Burgess said here last year. ''Good humor holds throughout the book, salted by a genial bloody-mindedness which is part of Mr. Heller's charm.'' AVAILABLE LIGHT, by Ellen Currie. (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $6.95.) Kitty O'Carolan, an advertising fashion stylist, is deserted by her lover, a musician and gambler named Jack Rambeau, in this often funny first novel. The book ''should be greeted with celebration,'' T. Gertler said in The Book Review in 1986. ''Ellen Currie nudges reality and uncovers a vein of the fabulous.'' The ''twists and shifts and curlicues of the book spin along in vibrant prose.'' WHY NOTHING WORKS: The Anthropology of Daily Life, by Marvin Harris. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $7.95.) Originally published as ''America Now: The Anthropology of a Changing Culture,'' this book is a ''concise, angry outcry at the current condition of America,'' our reviewer, Robert Lekachman, said in 1982. The author ''rails eloquently'' against faulty appliances, computer goofs, inflation, unemployment and bloated government bureaucracy. The culprit? The postwar shift from blue- to white-collar employment. PRINCE AMONG SLAVES, by Terry Alford. (Oxford University, $8.95.) Terry Alford's biography of Abd al-Rahman Ibrahima, a West African prince sold into slavery in the late 18th century and freed 40 years later, makes ''absorbing reading,'' reviewers said in 1978. ''The story moves along with the excitement, pace, and emotion of a well-written novel.'' JOHN KEATS: The Making of a Poet, by Aileen Ward. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $11.95.) Aileen Ward's critical biography is free of ''that bland propensity for gush and guesswork'' sometimes displayed by earlier biographers of Keats, Carlos Baker said here in 1963. This one, he said, ''is everywhere studded with illuminating small discoveries.'' THE VOICE AT THE BACK DOOR, by Elizabeth Spencer. (Avon, $4.50.) This novel of a postwar Mississippi sheriff is ''powerful, moving and true,'' Borden Deal said in The Book Review in 1956. The story ''mounts with intensity and an ever surer touch to a tremendous climax.'' The same publisher soon will reissue Elizabeth Spencer's FIRE IN THE MORNING ($4.95), the story of bitter enmity between two families in a small Mississippi town. The author, Hubert Creekmore said here in 1948, ''is dealing with material so completely within Southern experience as to be legendary.'' ALONE IN A CROWD: Women in the Trades Tell Their Stories, by Jean Reith Schroedel. (Temple University, $12.95.) A firefighter, a machinist, a sailor, an electrician and a pipe fitter are among the 25 Seattle-area women interviewed for this collection. In 1985 our reviewer, Alice Kessler-Harris, said: ''Lucid and moving, the interviews portray the pitfalls women face and the accommodations they make in order to learn the skills that guarantee reasonable wages - men's wages.'' SEMINARY: A Search, by Paul Hendrickson. (Summit, $6.95.) In 1965, shortly before he was to take his priestly vows, Paul Hendrickson left the Holy Trinity Seminary in Alabama and began a search for spiritual meaning in the secular world. ''His description of seminary life during the period before the Second Vatican Council rings as true as chapel bells on a windless morning,'' Eugene Kennedy said here in 1983. C, by Maurice Baring. (Oxford University, $8.95.) A picture of upper-class English life in the late 19th century, this novel by Maurice Baring (1874-1945) focuses on Caryl Bramsley (nicknamed C), a nobleman's son whose story unfolds through recollections of friends and through papers left after his death. In 1924 our reviewer, Herbert S. Gorman, said the work is ''revelatory of a confident handling of technique, a precise and careful development of personality, and a triumphant circumscribing of theme.''

title: Jan L. Phillips, an Account Executive, To Marry Charles M. Davis Next June
description: A June wedding is planned by Jan Leslie Phillips and Charles Michael Davis, the parents of the future bride, Howard W. Phillips and Mrs. Donald H. Kallman, both of New York, have announced. Mr. Davis is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Davis of Westport, Conn.

title: UNCLAIMED 'BIRTHRIGHT'
description: IT starts slowly after Christmas, but the pressure builds quickly as the February school vacation nears. Snow time.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in last Sunday's Westchester Guide about Black History Month gave an incorrect location for events in Greenburgh. The story-and-song program at 3 P.M. today will be at the Greenburgh Town Hall; all other events sponsored by the Greenburgh Library will be held at the library, 300 Tarrytown Road in Elmsford. Call 993-1600 for a schedule.

title: Country Drive In Martinique
description: LEAD: In Martinique, an island in the French West Indies, the pace is European, lively and relaxed, even in the smaller towns and fishing villages beyond the busy harbor and capital of Fort-de-France.

title: REVERSE MORTGAGE AIDS AGED
description: LEAD: HELP is on the way for elderly Suffolk County homeowners who want to stay in their homes, but lack the money to meet expenses. The answer may be reverse annuity mortgages.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
UNFINISHED BUSINESS
description: LEAD: THE eight people gathered at the Whitehill Counseling Service offices here might be characters in one of Woody Allen's more serious movies. They are bright, well-educated, introspective. They like to talk and analyze.

title: NURSING CARE IS CLOSED TO AIDS VICTIMS
description: LEAD: NURSING homes are refusing requests by hospitals to take AIDS patients, according to officials of hospitals, nursing homes and health agencies in the state. The reasons cited range from fear of losing staff or patients to assertions that the facilities do not have the medical capabilities to treat the disease.

title: POSTERS FROM THE WAR AGAINST WOMEN
description: IDOLS OF PERVERSITY Fantasies of Feminine Evil in Fin-de-Siecle Culture. By Bram Dijkstra. Illustrated. 453 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $37.95.

title: CHARITY TAPS 'HAPPY EVENTS' TO FEED HUNGRY
description: Leonard Fein remembers vividly the unplanned circumstances that led him to create an organization he named Mazon, the Hebrew word for food, which is helping feed the hungry in the United States and abroad.

title: Reagan Pulls the Plug on Education
description: LEAD: The Administration is pledged to several sound principles in higher education: that an educated people is an essential national resource, that the nation should make the fullest use of its voluntary institutions and that students should, as far as possible, contribute to the financing of their own education.

title: SOMETHING FOR EVERYONE TO DISLIKE
description: On Monday, 23 million registered voters are scheduled to respond ''yes'' or ''no'' to a question that boils down to this: Is the Philippines better off with a flawed constitution or no constitution at all?

title:
DINING OUT;
IT'S CHINESE NEW YEAR, AND SO --
description: LEAD: THOSE who plan to ring in the Chinese New Year with a visit to a Chinese restaurant might try Mr. Tong Hunan Garden, which opened six months ago in East Rutherford. And since it is open most of the day, dinner there could be combined with attending a sports event at the nearby Meadowlands.

title: Dr. Peter Casadei Wed To Dr. Marla J. Fischl
description: Dr. Marla Joan Fischl and Dr. Peter N. Casadei, who have a joint equine veterinary practice in Old Westbury, L.I., were married last evening at the Regency Hotel in New York. Rabbi Charles Davidson and the Rev. Louis L. Gioia, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: An American In China
description: Mark Salzman's article is the most beguiling piece of nonfiction I have read in years. It reminds me very much of early V. S. Pritchett, and of the late Vernon Bartlett. Is there higher praise? W. G. M. HUME, M.D. New London, N.H.

title: NO VIOLATIONS FOUND AT SITE OF BRIBE INQUIRY
description: New York City fire officials said yesterday that no major violations had been found in an examination of fire suppression systems at a huge petroleum-storage facility on Staten Island where renovation work was said to have been facilitated by bribes to fire inspectors.

title: STUDENTS' RIGHT TO WORK DEFENDED
description: I agree when Naomi Given writes [ Jan. 18 ] that ''the undergraduate college [ is ] a very troubled institution,'' but I cannot understand how a professor has such a poor and wrong knowledge of too many college - or even high school - students' situations.

title: A FAMILY'S LEGACY SPANS 3 GENERATIONS
description: LEAD: CARL H. PFORZHEIMER JR., who is 80 years old, remembers the library in his father's big, Tudor-style house in Purchase. ''As a child, I'd see a lot of books, packages, cases there,'' he recalled during a recent interview. ''All in that enormous library.'' ''It was pleasantly and quietly dark and had two windows,'' added his son, Carl H.

title: Can't Doctors Agree on Their Stories?
description: To the Editor:

title: Pigeon: A Delicacy for Cantonese Cooks
description: The birds, Shek-Ki pigeons, are to be found on the menus of Hong Kong's better restaurants along with the expensive and highly prized sharks' fins and birds' nests. For some diners, however, the small and tender birds are perhaps even more desirable, particularly, the Chinese say, if they come from Shek-Ki, a town in Guangdong province.

title: R. C. Sullivan Jr. To Wed Ms. Kan
description: The engagement of Christina Kan to Robert C. Sullivan Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sullivan of Chappaqua, N.Y., has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Kan of Fairbanks, Alaska, parents of the bride-to-be. An August wedding is planned.

title: ISRAELI SAYS DEAL TO SELL IRAN ARMS PRECEDED U.S. ROLE
description: Israel's Defense Ministry approved the sale of $50 million worth of Israeli-made weapons to Iran almost two months before the first reported American request for Israel's help in approaching Teheran, the Israeli businessman who arranged the deal said today.

title: Packers Name Braatz
description: THE Green Bay Packers have named Tom Braatz as executive vice president of football operations, reducing the responsibilities of Coach Forrest Gregg. The move will mark the first time since Vince Lombardi was hired in 1959 that the Packer head coach has not had complete authority over the football operations.

title: Paige H. Klotz Is Wed To Richard Grossman
description: Paige Hilary Klotz, a third-year law student at New York University, and Richard J. Grossman, an associate at the New York law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, were married last evening at La Reserve restaurant in Manhattan. Rabbi Louis Sigel officiated. The bride, a 1982 Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Cornell University, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Klotz of Teaneck, N.J. After receiving her law degree in June, she plans to join the New York law firm of Rosenman, Colin, Freund, Lewis & Cohen. Her father is an engineer at Thomas J. Lipton Inc., the tea and soup company in Englewood Cliffs, N.J. Her mother, Brenda Klotz, is a learning-disability specialist with the Teaneck Board of Education.

title: CAPITOL GETTING A STATUE OF GRASSO
description: IT took six years and $65,000, but a statue of the late Gov. Ella T. Grasso is to be dedicated at the State Capitol Thursday, on the sixth anniversary of her death.

title: NEW YORK'S REGENTS SEEK MORE CANDIDATES FOR POST
description: A special advisory panel has given the Board of Regents the names of five candidates to be the next State Education Commissioner, but the board is unhappy with the size of the list and will seek to expand it, according to several Regents.

title: PIANO: CYPRIEN KATSARIS
description: CYPRIEN KATSARIS'S evening of piano music at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday was fiercely difficult, but less for its physical demands than for its testings of the mind and heart. The Schubert B-flat Sonata and the 12 Grieg Lyric Pieces that followed are exercises in simplicity, though of different kinds. The first has a monosyllabic sweetness whose allusions are mysterious and far-reaching. Grieg's wonderful music is simple just for simplicity's sake yet inspiring for its very innocence.

title: Cut Nuclear-Test Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Carzis to Be Bride
description: The engagement of Maria Carzis and James Gordon Boyes 4th, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Truman D. Boyes of Plainfield, N.J., has been announced by the mother of the bride-to-be, Efthymia Carzis of North Plainfield, N.J., and Athens. Ms. Carzis, the daughter also of the late Peter G. Carzis, graduated from Syracuse University and is the editor of Fashion International and Fashion Calendar. Mr. Boyes, a graduate of the University of Massachusetts, is an environmental engineer for Carlson & Sweatt of New York.

title: POSTINGS: Writing a Law; No Rent Increases
description: It is rare for ordinary citizens to create their own legislation, but that is what the 15 members of the Senior Action Committee in Ridgewood, Queens, have done. They want the state's Senior Citizen Rent Increase Exemption law, known as SCRIE, to be extended to all nonregulated apartments, provided the landlord agrees to participate.

title: JAZZ: ROVA SAXOPHONES
description: THE Rova Saxophone Quartet's favorite sound is a tangled, writhing, pulsating lump of noise - one that might involve repeated phrases, improvised lines, trills, raucous honks or a tightly packed combination of all four. The group writes and plays chamber music laced with improvisation, cross-referencing Stravinsky, Satie, Albert Ayler, Steve Reich and James Brown's horn section. It appeared Wednesday night as part of Sweet Basil's two-week festival of new jazz.

title: NAMING THE LIVING TO HONOR THE DEAD
description: I THINK it is the ultimate honor to name a child after someone who has died. In our case, my husband and I wanted to name our son after my brother Mac, who was killed in a plane crash when he was 22. From the moment we knew I was pregnant, I assumed we would use Mac's name for a boy. As my pregnancy advanced, however, I was increasingly plagued by fear and ambivalence.

title: M. M. Neumeier Weds Miss Prine
description: Annmarie Prine and Matthew M. Neumeier, an associate at the New York law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore, were married yesterday in Novi, Mich.heheevev. Mark ANeNe meier, the brother of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Cross.

title:
ANTIQUES;
GLEN RIDGE SHOW KEEPS ROLLING ALONG
description: LEAD: UNLIKE old soldiers, some antiques shows do not die or even fade away. A case in point is the Glen Ridge Antiques Show, which made its debut in 1946.

title: Why Warrants Are Back in Style
description: THE allure of stock warrants - basically rights that allow investors to buy common shares for an extended time at a fixed price - tends to rise and fall with speculative fervor. The game offers both big rewards and high risks. Indeed, many holders of warrants have done quite well in the recent Wall Street surge. But not all warrant holders have struck gold; many issues covered by warrants are smaller, obscure companies bypassed by the bullish crowd. Stock options, another speculative play, have done much better, on average.

title: Train Derails in Mississippi; 1,000 Flee Toxic Gas Threat
description: A freight train derailed and caught fire today, igniting two cars and a tanker carrying a toxic flammable chemical and forcing the evacuation of up to 1,000 people, the authorities said.

title:
CRITICS' CHOICES;
Photography
description: LEAD: The picture caption verges on the sardonic ''On the 10th anniversary of the Apollo moon landing, Astronaut Neil Armstrong, first man on the moon, reads a car commercial, New York, 1979.'' The photograph shows the astronaut on the screen of a television set in an otherwise empty boardroom high above the streets of Manhattan, and it sets the tone of ''An American Dream,'' Rene Burri's bizarre photographic exploration of America's space and defense programs, on view at the International Center of Photography, Fifth Avenue and 94th Street, through Feb.

title: New Strength for Steel?
description: After spending 1986 in the doghouse, steel stocks have recently given their holders some reason for cheer. Measured by Standard & Poor's industry index, these stalwarts of the industrial economy have risen by about 11 percent so far in 1987.

title: SCIENTISTS OUTLINE VOLCANO HAZARDS
description: Several cities around the world are vulnerable to volcanic eruptions but have failed to do all they can to reduce the dangers, volcano specialists have warned at a conference in Hilo.

title: Insuring Your Trip Against the Unexpected
description: Few areas of the travel industry are more competitive than the sale of emergency assistance and insurance. At least once or twice a year, companies expand or refine their coverage as premiums and small print are readjusted or as one company introduces a new twist and its competitors jockey to match or top it.

title: THE HOWS AND WHYS OF SOLDERING METAL TOGETHER
description: SOLDERING has been used for centuries to join metals and is still one of the simplest and most widely used methods for securing metal joints and seams.

title:
THEATER;
THE AVANT-GARDE IS TAKING A LOOK BACKWARD
description: LEAD: An avant-garde classic may seem a contradiction in terms, but some of the senior enfants terribles of the experimental stage are now celebrating 20th, 25th, even 40th anniversaries in the theater by bringing back ''great moments'' from the cutting edge. This season, LaMama E.T.C. is marking its 25th year as an experimental venue by restaging several 1970's shows, including, right now, Andrei Serban and Elizabeth Swados's ''Fragments of a Greek Trilogy.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: G. R. Taylor 3d to Wed Pamela Anne Harvey
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence D. Harvey of New York of the engagement of their daughter Pamela Anne Harvey to Gerald Radburn Taylor 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Taylor Jr. of Easton, Conn.

title: Sports of the Times; The Education of Sam Jones
description: ''MY college basketball coach was intelligent - I didn't say smart, I said intelligent,'' said Sam Jones. ''Our coach put us with good students. My roommate was number one in his class. He studied, so I studied - or at least I looked at his papers.''

title: Drug Addiction And Anonymity
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: FICTION: IN SHORT
description: LEAD: SHAN. By Eric Van Lustbader. (Random House, $18.95.) This epic tale of international intrigue, involving a struggle for world domination by the Russians, the Americans and the Chinese, takes up the continuing saga of Jake Maroc, the Chinese-American hero of Eric Van Lustbader's 1985 novel ''Jian.'' Here, Jake is entrusted with China's destiny as a world power.

title: STATE PLAN ON WASTE: SOLUTIONS UNCERTAIN
description: LEAD: THE long-awaited State Department of Environmental Conservation solid-waste management plan recommends a broad range of objectives it considers necessary to solve the state's solid-waste crisis. The plan leaves unanswered long-standing questions concerning the feasibility, safety and financing of those objectives.

title: Lisa Stern Plans To Wed in March
description: Lisa Jane Stern and Kevin F. Taylor, cum laude graduates of Union College in Schenectady, N.Y., plan to be married March 28.

title: NICARAGUA IS AIDED BY SISTER CITY PROJECTS
description: IF someone could ask for more trees on East Ninth Street, Joanne Schultz and some friends figured, they could also ask Community Board 3 in Manhattan to support a negotiated peace in Nicaragua. It worked, and in 1985 the Lower East Side, a neighborhood that encompasses the Bowery's skid row, the cutting edge of avant-garde art and a large Puerto Rican and Asian population, became a sister city to Barrio Nueva York, a community of 1,000 in Bluefields, Nicaragua.

title: BALLET: WORKS BY ROBBINS AND BALANCHINE
description: THE theme was variations Wednesday night at the New York State Theater, when the New York City Ballet offered Jerome Robbins's ''Goldberg Variations'' and George Balanchine's ''Four Temperaments.'' Both of these intricate works are musical and choreographic examples of the theme-and-variations form.

title: Stocks Calm Down, In a Jittery Way
description: The turmoil in the stock markets eased a bit, although wild trading, weird gyrations and unchecked program trading became commonplace in another chaotic week. After the 115-point swing of Jan. 23, the Dow Jones industrials settled down, but not before jumping 43.17 points on Tuesday. The Dow hit a record of 2,163.39 before settling back to end the week at 2,158.04, a gain of 56.52. The credit markets have not been caught up in the frenzy, taking a cue instead from the nervous currency markets. Rates rose a bit in uneasy trading.

title: NEW SERVICE OFFERS DATES BY CATALOGUE
description: LEAD: OPENING a new business in Fairfield County may be somewhat risky, particularly if you leave an executive position in a large corporation to get it started. But that is the route that Michael Kenworthy chose to take. With his near six-figure salary as a regional manager for General Electric Credit Corporation now a part of his past, Mr.

title: RYAN AND SCOTT TRADES STILL HAUNT METS
description: NOLAN RYAN celebrated his 40th birthday yesterday, which means it has been 15 years, 224 victories, 3,605Y innings and 3,784 strikeouts since the Mets traded him to the California Angels. No, the swap involving Ryan for Jim Fregosi hasn't got any better for the Mets since the last time anyone looked. It remains one of the most major blunders any team has ever made in the trading market.

title: Comings and Goings
description: THE Southern University Board of Regents voted to cancel the last year of Otis Washington's contract as head football coach, but did not set a date for his dismissal and made no provisions for replacing him. . . . Jay Sigel, an amateur golfer from Berwyn, Pa., was named to the 10-man United States Walker Cup team by the United States Golf Association for the sixth time. The team faces a team from Britain and Ireland in England in May. . . . According to a report in The Philadelphia Inquirer yesterday, the Phillies have rejected the first contract proposal of Lance Parrish, the former Detroit Tiger catcher, a proposal said to be $1.5 million for one year.

title: Finding the Least Costly Adjustable-Rate Mortgage
description: WHILE adjustable-rate mortgages are becoming more standardized, there still are substantial variations in pricing and structure that warrant careful scrutiny. The greatest remaining impediment to comparison shopping is that lenders peg their interest-rate adjustments to a variety of esoteric financial indexes.

title: DUFFY DEETER AND THE GURU OF WHOLESOME ACCEPTANCE
description: ALL WE NEED OF HELL By Harry Crews. 161 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $14.95.

title: Lynda Johnson Plans To Be a Bride in July
description: The engagement of Lynda Jane Johnson and Mark Anthony Miller has been announced by Carol Johnson Bald of Ridgewood, N.J., mother of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harley Robert Miller of Quakertown, Pa. A July wedding is planned.

title: DARIEN CONCERN MAKES TRAVEL PLANS FOR PETS
description: LEAD: ON a recent morning in Darien, Sherlock Holmes, a cocker spaniel from North Carolina, was being prepared for a trip to Tokyo. Spice, Brandy, Muffin and Pearl, four cats also from North Carolina, were leaving for Texas, and Tisha, a boxer from Westport, was on his way to Kuala Lumpur.

title: Skiing in Norway, Museumgoing in Washington
description: Above Oslo: Days on Trails, Nights at Inns

title: CAN'T THE ISLAND JUST BE ITSELF?
description: A LIFELONG resident of Long Island once said, ''A true New Yorker is someone who doesn't know where Long Island is and hasn't the vaguest idea how to get out there.''

title: FRESH START FOR HASKINS AND MINNESOTA
description: AS college basketball coaches frequently do, Clem Haskins changed his place of employment last spring. But it isn't as routine as it sounds. Haskins moved from top 20-bound Western Kentucky, where he was a pioneer and a local hero, to scandal-ridden Minnesota and the unfamiliar chill of a program in crisis.

title: Inside the U.S.F.L.'s Power Struggle
description: If the United States Football League had played a 1986 fall season as originally planned, its championship game would have been played today. But after receiving only $1 in damages in its antitrust suit against the National Football League last summer, the U.S.F.L. suspended operations; its future is uncertain.

title: Classic Modern
description: MOST ARCHITECTS, ka1>even those of international repute, go through major stylistic changes at some point in their careers.

title: GEORGE W. WYCKOFF
description: George W. Wyckoff, a former vice president and governor of T. Mellon & Sons, a Pittsburgh investment management concern, died Jan. 23 at the Latrobe Hospital in Latrobe, Pa. He was 80 years old.

title: MEN'S CLUBS PRESSED TO OPEN DOORS FOR WOMEN
description: ITS facade bears credos vowing enlightenment through education. And inside the University Club, men are fighting to repel invaders.

title: ADDING PEICES TO THE PUZZLE: A NEW CHRONOLOGY OF THE IRAN-CONTRA AFFAIR
description: The report made public Thursday by the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence helps establish the sequence of events surrounding the secret American arms sales to Iran and the diversion of money from those sales to the Nicaraguan rebels. Here is a summary of events showing how the pieces of the puzzle fit together. 1982 - Israel ships non-American arms to Iran, and Israeli middlemen help arrange private deals involving American arms, according to secret studies by American intelligence agencies. These studies apparently are not made available to the National Security Council staff. Late 1984 - The National Security Council begins a reappraisal of United States policy toward Iran. April 1985 - Michael A. Ledeen, a consultant to the National Security Council, tells President Reagan's national security adviser, Robert C. McFarlane, that he plans to visit Israel. Mr. McFarlane agrees that Mr. Ledeen should ask Israeli officials about ''contacts with Iran.'' May 4-5, 1985 - Mr. Ledeen visits Israel and discusses the situation in Iran with Prime Minister Shimon Peres. May 1985 - The Central Intelligence Agency proposes that America's allies be allowed to sell arms to Iran to enhance Western influence. June 5, 1985 - Secretary of State George P. Shultz complains to Mr. McFarlane that Mr. Ledeen had bypassed the State Department in his contacts with Israel. Mr. McFarlane assures Mr. Shultz that Mr. Ledeen was acting ''on his own hook.'' Mr. McFarlane says of the Iran initiative: ''I am turning it off entirely.'' June 29, 1985 - Mr. Shultz says the proposed new policy toward Iran is ''perverse'' and ''contrary to our own interests.'' Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger writes that the proposed policy is ''almost too absurd to comment on.'' July 1985 - Adnan M. Khashoggi, a Saudi Arabian arms dealer, sends Mr. McFarlane a long paper discussing the political situation in Iran. July 3, 1985 - David Kimche, director general of Israel's Foreign Ministry, tells Mr. McFarlane that Iranian officials want to open ''political talks'' with the United States. July 14, 1985 - Mr. Shultz tells Mr. McFarlane that the United States should ''seriously consider the idea of private U.S.-Iran relations.'' Mid-July 1985 - President Reagan, in the hospital for major abdominal surgery, authorizes Mr. McFarlane to make contact with Iran. Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff, said later that he assumed release of Americans held in Lebanon would be a ''collateral benefit.'' Late July 1985 - Mr. Ledeen meets in Israel with Manucher Ghorbanifar, an expatriate Iranian businessman and arms dealer. According to Mr. Ledeen's later testimony, Mr. Ghorbanifar says Iran might arrange for the release of American hostages if the United States helped Iran to buy weapons. Aug. 8, 1985 - Mr. McFarlane briefs Mr. Reagan on ''the Kimche proposal'' to permit the sale of American antitank missiles to Iran through Israel. Mr. Regan says the President did not authorize such sales; Mr. McFarlane says he did. Aug. 30, 1985 - Israel sends 508 TOW antitank missiles through a third country to Iran. The shipment arrives Sept. 13. Sept. 4, 1985 - Mr. Ledeen meets in Paris with Mr. Kimche, Mr. Ghorbanifar and two Israeli arms dealers to discuss ''technical questions'' related to the sale of American weapons to Iran. They also discuss efforts to obtain the release of American hostages in Lebanon. Sept. 14, 1985 - The Rev. Benjamin F. Weir, a Presbyterian minister, is released after having been held 16 months. October 1985 - Islamic Holy War says it has killed William Buckley, the Beirut station chief of the C.I.A., who was kidnapped March 16, 1984. Nov. 22, 1985 - The C.I.A. arranges for the shipment of 18 Hawk antiaircraft missiles from Israel to Iran. Nov. 25, 1985 - According to his later testimony, John N. McMahon, Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, learns of the agency's role in the arms shipments and orders that there be no more such covert activity unless the President explicitly authorizes it. Dec. 7, 1985 - President Reagan discusses his Iran program with Mr. Shultz, Mr. Weinberger, Mr. McFarlane and Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter, who is to succeed Mr. McFarlane at year's end as national security adviser. Mr. Shultz and Mr. Weinberger oppose further arms sales. Dec. 8, 1985 - Mr. McFarlane and an aide, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, meet in London with Mr. Kimche, Mr. Ghorbanifar and Yaacov Nimrodi, an Israeli arms dealer who had served as military attache at the Israeli Embassy in Teheran. Mr. McFarlane tells Mr. Ghorbanifar that the United States does not want to participate in any more arms transfers to Iran. Late December 1985 - Mr. Ghorbanifar meets with C.I.A. officials in Washington. William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, warns President Reagan that Mr. Ghorbanifar's information on Iran ''could be a deception to impress us.'' January 1986 - Mr. Ghorbanifar fails a polygraph examination. The results support the C.I.A.'s contention that he is not to be trusted. Nevertheless, according to the Intelligence Committee report, ''the White House chose to continue to work with him.'' January 1986 - Amiram Nir, an adviser to Prime Minister Peres, urges President Reagan to resume arms shipments to Iran. Mr. Nir and Colonel North discuss the use of money from the Iran arms sales to help the Nicaraguan rebels, according to an account that Colonel North gave to Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d in November 1986. Jan. 7, 1986 - President Reagan meets in the Oval Office with Vice President Bush, Mr. Shultz, Mr. Weinberger, Mr. Casey and other officials. Mr. Shultz and Mr. Weinberger argue strongly against selling arms to Iran. But Mr. Reagan, wishing ''to keep the channel open,'' leaves the issue ''unresolved,'' according to the Senate report. Jan. 17, 1986 - President Reagan signs an order authorizing arms shipments to Iran in an effort to improve relations and secure the release of hostages. Responsibility for arranging the shipments is given to Secretary Weinberger's military assistant, Maj. Gen. Colin L. Powell, and Lieut. Gen. Vincent M. Russo, director of the Defense Logistics Agency. Late January 1986 - Colonel North meets in London with Mr. Ghorbanifar, promises to send more weapons to Iran and offers to provide intelligence on the position of Iraqi troops at war with Iran. The C.I.A. objects to sharing sensitive intelligence data, but is overruled by the staff of the National Security Council. Feb. 15-16, 1986 - The United States sends 1,000 TOW missiles to Israel, where they will be transshipped to Iran. Mr. Khashoggi, who helped finance the transaction, receives $12 million from Mr. Ghorbanifar. Late February 1986 - Prime Minister Peres writes President Reagan, urging him to continue efforts to achieve a ''strategic opening'' to Iran. April 3, 1986 - Unidentified American officials meet in Washington with Mr. Ghorbanifar to discuss a proposed visit to Teheran. Several documents suggest that there was discussion of using profits from the arms sales to help Nicaraguan and Afghan insurgents. April 4, 1986 - A memorandum prepared around this time says $12 million from arms transactions with Iran will be used to purchase supplies for the Nicaraguan rebels. It is unclear whether this proposal was ever approved. April 17, 1986 - The body of an American hostage in Lebanon, Peter Kilburn, is found. His kidnappers say he was killed in retaliation for the American bombing of Libya two days earlier. May 15, 1986 - President Reagan approves a mission to Iran by Mr. McFarlane. May 18, 1986 - Mr. Ghorbanifar assures a C.I.A. official that American hostages will be released when Mr. McFarlane's group arrives in Teheran. May 23, 1986 - The C.I.A. ships 508 TOW missiles to Israel. May 25-28, 1986 - Mr. McFarlane, Colonel North and other American officials arrive in Teheran on a plane carrying spare parts for Iran's Hawk antiaircraft missiles. But the hostages are not released. On the trip back to the United States, Colonel North tells Mr. McFarlane that money from the Iran arms sales has been used to support the contras. July 26, 1986 - The Rev. Lawrence Martin Jenco, a Roman Catholic priest, is released after having been held hostage in Lebanon for more than 18 months. Colonel North says the release is a result of the McFarlane mission to Iran. Aug. 3, 1986 - Iran receives another American shipment of spare parts for Hawk missiles. Sept. 12, 1986 - Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel offers ''a significant quantity of captured Soviet bloc arms'' for use by the contras. Admiral Poindexter discusses the Israeli offer with Mr. Reagan just before the President meets with Prime Minister Peres on Sept. 15. Oct. 7, 1986 - A C.I.A. officer tells Mr. Casey that profits from the Iran arms sales may have been diverted to the Nicaraguan rebels. Oct. 29, 1986 - The C.I.A. arranges for the shipment of 500 TOW missiles from Israel to Iran. This is apparently the last arms deal between the United States and Iran.

title: FUTURISTIC VISIONS IN THE DESERT
description: In the sun-parched griddle of the Arizona desert, Interstate 17 glistens with sleek black puddles. They vaporize as the car approaches. Mirages. Dancing off the rocks, the searing heat plays other tricks. Amid the tumbleweed and cactus, a futuristic space colony materializes on the desert floor, a cluster of vaulting arches and cubic modules and filaments of construction cranes poking into the thin blue sky.

title: POSTINGS: Dutchess County Inn; Offices, With Fireplaces and a Pond
description: For years, local residents used to sit around the fireplace at the Memory Inn in Wappingers Falls, N.Y., listening to the proprietor at the piano. But a fire forced the inn to close in 1980, and last year new owners undertook to restore the 19th century structure and convert it into offices.

title: YOUTH CASES PUT STRAIN ON MENTAL AID
description: MENTAL-health clinics in northern Westchester report that a growing number of children and adolescents are seeking treatment. But as the need increases, some of the nonprofit clinics that provide services at reduced fees are expressing concern about their financial situation.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Exquisite Appellation In his new novel, ''Sphinx'' (Viking), D. M. Thomas mocks an editor who poses as a poet.

title: INSURERS ARE PRESSING FOR AIDS TESTING
description: Despite vigorous opposition from civil rights groups and some state governments, insurance companies, fearing an avalanche of AIDS-related claims, are increasingly asserting that they have a right to require applicants for coverage to take the AIDS virus test.

title: REDMAN LOSE IN OVERTIME
description: Providence College, which had not beaten St. John's in three seasons and had never been in first place in its seven-year tenure in the Big East Conference, accomplished both feats tonight. The Friars needed overtime and superb shooting by Billy Donovan to do it, but they defeated St. John's, 93-81, before a nearly hysterical sellout crowd of 12,140 in the Civic Center.

title: OF GRAMMAR, NOISE AND HOW ONE GETS INTO CARNEGIE HALL
description: In any office there are those who believe that a clean desk betokens a clean mind. They are ruthless in disposing of clutter. Given the proper equipment, they would stay after work and shred the universe. Then there are the rest of us, those whose desks, like our minds, resemble a gigantic In basket. We may occasionally lose a piece of paper, a book, a record, a concert program or a letter, which would cut into the pile. But in cold blood throw anything away? Hardly ever.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: BLACK ARTISTS IN VERMONT

title: Extraordinary, Holmes!
description: To the Editor:

title: A Correction
description: An article about abortion Jan. 22 by Dr. Warren M. Hern stated that Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon, had introduced a constitutional amendment concerning reproductive rights. Mr. Packwood has not offered such an amendment.

title: DID THE SUPER BOWL LIVE UP TO THE HYPE?
description: In response to your question ''Did the Super Bowl live up to the hype?

title: CANADA STEPS UP ITS ACID-RAIN CAMPAIGN
description: JIM BRADLEY, Ontario's Minister of the Environment and one of his country's leaders in the fight against acid rain, came to New York this weekend in his effort to persuade Americans that this insidious killer of fish and other aquatic organisms must be swiftly eliminated.

title: FALL IN BLOOD SUPPLY IS REPORTED TO SHOW NO SIGN OF REVERSAL
description: The shortage of blood that regularly develops during the Christmas holidays has persisted this year and shows no sign of easing, officials of the New York Blood Center said last week.

title: Lori Gale Adler Plans to Marry Dr. Jess Amchin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Adler of Dix Hills, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lori Gale Adler, to Dr. Jess David Amchin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Abraham Amchin of Farmingdale, L.I.

title: FRIENDS INDEED
description: MOTHERS OF FEMINISM The Story of Quaker Women in America. By Margaret Hope Bacon. Illustrated. 273 pp. San Francisco: Harper & Row. $16.95.

title: CBS News In Search of Itself
description: In this era of changing telecast journalism, for CBS to look backward to find itself is hardly a testament to the vision of its president, Laurence A. Tisch, or, for that matter, Dan Rather and company (''CBS News in Search of Itself,'' by Peter J. Boyer, Dec. 28).

title:
DINING OUT;
THAI FARE MOVES TO SCARSDALE
description: LEAD: SIAM ORCHID adds welcome variety to down-county dining. This plain little storefront restaurant, open not quite three months, has already attracted a coterie of diners happy for the opportunity to fork or to spoon up (those eating utensils of Thailand, which, oddly enough, do not include chopsticks) food smacking of lemon grass, lime juice, galangar, Thai curry paste (a fresh mixture quite unlike Indian curry), tamarind, chilies, vinegar, Thai ginger and coconut milk - some of the exotic flavors of Thai cuisine.

title: DEVILS SQUANDER 2-GOAL LEAD
description: The Calgary Flames fell behind by two goals but stormed back with four consecutive goals to beat the Devils, 5-3, tonight.

title: After Challenger, Hope and Trouble
description: For 73 seconds at 11:38 A.M. Wednesday, silence fell in classrooms and in National Aeronautics and Space Administration centers around the nation - a tribute to the brief flight of the space shuttle Challenger and the seven crew members who died when it exploded, just a year earlier.

title: Hillary Haberman Plans To Wed Jeffrey Suchman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul Haberman of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Hillary Haberman to Jeffrey Scott Suchman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Suchman of Harrison, N.Y.

title: Study Voted of Sexuality Plan
description: Delegates to the annual convention of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark today called for a yearlong study of a controversial proposal to recognize and bless nonmarital relationships, including those between homosexual couples.

title: Topics: Bird Colonels / Animal Abuse; Laboratory Pets
description: Most laboratory animals are bred specifically for research. Since their health and genetic history are known, such ''purpose-bred'' animals yield superior data. Still, each year, some 300,000 dogs and cats are bought from animal shelters for laboratory use. Why? They cost less. Congressman Robert Mrazek, Democrat of New York, has introduced legislation to prohibit the National Institutes of Health from funding experiments that use shelter animals. The bill would not alter the laws in 39 states that permit the practice, but it would cut off much of the money used to buy such animals. It's a sound and humane idea.

title: STARS & STRIPES TAKES CUP OPENER
description: Dennis Conner's Stars & Stripes team picked its way through shifting winds today to beat Kookaburra III by 1 minute 41 seconds in the opening match of the America's Cup final.

title: CATERING TO THE PATRIOTIC
description: LEAD: BERNADETTE PETTI'S friends tease her about her patriotism, saying that when she kisses her husband on the cheek, they expect her to leave an imprint of the American flag instead of lipstick marks.

title: CBS News In Search of Itself
description: I was distressed by the full-page picture of Diane Sawyer, seated, facing a man of color wearing a headset. He is telling her something of importance, because he has her undivided attention, but the man's name is not mentioned. He is James E. Wall, and he is the stage manager of ''60 Minutes'' and of the ''CBS Evening News With Dan Rather.'' Mr. Wall is giving people of color an image to look up to, and because he is American Indian, black and Jewish, three groups have been insulted. And people wonder how places like Howard Beach develop.

title: CBS News In Search of Itself
description: There's little doubt that CBS ''personality'' people are more interested in promoting themselves than the news, and in preaching grade-school admonitions that turn important news items into immature object lessons.

title: JIM BAKER'S CAGEY GLOBAL GAMBLE
description: IN a turbulent world economy still riven by national forces, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d is striving to find a way to make the major industrial nations work together in their common interest - and, not incidentally, in the American interest as well.

title: OLD GAS STATIONS: NUISANCES OR SITES OF HISTORIC IMPORT?
description: DESPITE growing community opposition, the State Department of Transportation is continuing with its plans to demolish most of the 12 abandoned gas stations along two area parkways, a department official said last week.

title:
ART;
SHOW REFLECTS ARTISTS' INTEREST IN THE SUPERNATURAL
description: LEAD: IN their search for meaningful forms of expression, visual artists follow many different and often divergent paths. Some aim for descriptive truth, faithfully rendering the appearance of things observed. Others seek esthetic truth in form, color and line, bypassing outside observation in favor of plastic invention.

title: ABDUCTORS IN BEIRUT DEMAND THAT ISRAEL FREE 400 PRISONERS
description: The group that kidnapped three Americans and an Indian last week said today that it would kill them if Israel does not free 400 prisoners within a week.

title: REAL MEN SAIL FOR THE CUP
description: SOONER or later, an expletive will not be able to be deleted. But in permitting a minicamera-microphone on their 12-Meter yachts, maybe that's what the America's Cup skippers had in mind all along. Maybe they're hoping that an expletive or two will let people realize that they're not rich kids born with a silver spinnaker in their mouths, that they're world-class athletes in a true sense of the word in a true world championship.

title: CASINOS SUE TO VOID STATE OFFICE LEASE
description: LEAD: THIS city's hotel-casinos have filed suit to break an agreement under which the state would lease for 10 years space in a proposed 19-story office building.

title: NONFICTION: IN SHORT
description: LEAD: LA TRISTESSE DE SAINT LOUIS: Jazz Under the Nazis. By Mike Zwerin. (Beach Tree/Morrow, $16.95.) Jazz -outspoken, spontaneous and nonconforming - is a perfect affront to totalitarianism, and throughout Europe under the Nazis American swing served as political resistance, emotional release and spiritual salvation.

title: Surviving a 'Palace Coup' at JWT
description: THE showdown began came just after sundown. Nine days ago, Don Johnston, chairman and chief executive of the JWT Group, strode out of the board room on the 20th floor of JWT's Lexington Avenue headquarters, took an elevator to the third floor and walked to an office that he himself had once occupied. There, in a few emotional moments, he confronted and fired his protege, Joseph W. O'Donnell, the man he had recently installed as chairman and chief executive of the J. Walter Thompson Company, JWT's main subsidiary and the world's fourth-largest advertising agency.

title: John Barth Regrets
description: To the Editor:

title: STRICTER AUTO AD RULES GOING INTO EFFECT SOON
description: LEAD: AUTOMOBILE dealers in New Jersey can be fined up to $5,000 if they are found guilty of advertising a car that is not in their possession or committing other deceptive acts outlined in the state's new rules governing advertising practices.

title: POSTINGS: In Bernardsville; Mansion for Sale
description: For now, Harold Hamilton and Loretta Praher, husband-and-wife developers, are luxuriating in the 25-room country mansion in Bernardsville, N.J., that was formerly owned by R. Thornton Wilson. Overseeing the house's restoration, the couple, principals of CHP Developers, can stoke one of 12 fireplaces - three of which are in the master bedroom suite - and watch the deer that grace the property.

title: Summer D. Herman Becomes a Bride
description: Summer Diane Herman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Herman of Port Washington, L.I., was married last night to Dr. Andrew Pramer, the son of Dr. and Mrs. David Pramer of Highland Park, N.J. Rabbi Martin S. Rozenberg, assisted by Cantor Jacob Yaron, performed the ceremony at the Community Synagogue in Sands Point, L.I.

title:
ART;
AN UPDATED HUDSON RIVER SCHOOL AT CLOSTER'S AURORA GALLERY
description: LEAD: AFTER an initial look, the landscape paintings of Peter Homitzky seem to be directly descended from the Hudson River School.

title: G.O.P. LOSING CONTROL OF THE NATIONAL DEBATE
description: If Republicans in Congress seemed especially eager to stomp and cheer for President Reagan during his State of the Union Message last week, they had good reason. If Republicans are to salvage power, many of them believe, Mr. Reagan needs to salvage his Presidency.

title: ALVARADO LOOKS AGAIN FOR A PLACE IN THE SYSTEM
description: THE selection of a superintendent in any of the city's community school districts is invariably a sensitive, politically charged task. On Manhattan's Upper West Side, the process has recently taken on a particularly lively air.

title: STAYING ALIVE BY LEARNING TO WRITE
description: LEAD: UNTIL fairly recently, for a European professor to admit that he or she was secretly doing some ''creative writing'' was tantamount to academic suicide. One could do serious work on writing or writers, but they had better be dead. Knowing something about current literature, if you claimed to be a scholar, implied the proud modesty of not even trying your own hand at it - or it would wither from the sacrilege.

title: COMPANY OFFERS AID TO BLACK BUSINESSES
description: WOULD-BE entrepreneurs don't have it easy.

title: Shoes, Over and Under
description: For two weeks now, a gray sky has hung low over New York City, spitting.
