Mostly it spits snow, sometimes it spits rain and occasionally it spits something that it would be a kindness to call sleet. The sun shows its face only long enough to prove it's still up there. So slush is piled at the curbings, and trying to walk some streets is like trying to traverse the Wollman Rink without skates. Which brings us to feet. New York feet are in trouble.

title: BOSSY'S RETURN INSPIRES ISLANDERS
description: The big surprise, besides the Islanders' first display of competence on their home ice in weeks, was the return of Mike Bossy, who had been absent for six games because of a prolonged back ailment.

title: AIDING THE SEARCH FOR MARROW DONORS
description: LEAD: FOR some Long Islanders suffering from life-threatening blood diseases, a bone marrow transplant is the only means of survival. Yet few may be able to find a compatible donor to rescue them.

title:
THE TALK OF EAB PLAZA;
A CITY UNDER GLASS
description: LEAD: IN developing EAB Plaza in Mitchel Field, the chairman of the DeMatteis Organizations recalled recently that his goal was to create ''a pleasant work environment; to bring something to the suburbs that they didn't have before.'' The plaza is now occupied with nearly 4,000 employees, and some of them agree that Frederick D

title: TALKING: Asbestos; New Rules Involving Co-ops
description: AS a result of new asbestos regulations promulgated by the New York State Attorney General's office and New York City, almost everyone involved in residential cooperatives will need to take actions not previously deemed necessary. The regulations are designed to protect co-op residents from the health hazards associated with exposure to airborne particles of asbestos.

title: For Mamaroneck, Space Is a Rarity
description: OVER the last few years, leaders of the Westchester Town of Mamaroneck have been wrestling with the problem of saturation - the absence of buildable land.

title: DOLLARS AND SENSE, OR COLLUSION?
description: WHEN free agency was created 11 years ago it marked the genesis of an escalation in salaries that has made baseball players as a group the wealthiest athletes in professional team sports. Now, however, club owners are intent on a salary de-escalation, and have made free-agent spending the most glaring target of their effort.

title: STRIDING INTO THE SUNSET
description: PERHAPS not since Roy and Dale rode Trigger and Buttermilk into the sunset has there been so much fringe around.

title: Copter Instructor Faces Trial
description: A military judge dropped two counts of attempted murder against a Fort Rucker flight instructor accused of tampering with 11 Army helicopters, but the instructor, Warrant Officer Louis H. Plunkett Jr., still faces a general court-martial, officials said Friday. Mr. Plunkett has been charged with five counts of damage to government property and one count of violation of Federal law, said Betty Goodson, a spokesman at Fort Rucker. No date has been set for the court-martial.

title: WATER IS TAINTED IN AN L.I. VILLAGE
description: Residents in this village were warned today not to use their tap water. Police officials said caustic soda, which is normally added to the water, was not diluted properly, making the water acidic.

title: DID THE SUPER BOWL LIVE UP TO THE HYPE?
description: Whether the Super Bowl lived up to its hype is certainly debatable. What is known, however, is that almost 60 percent of Americans had an opinion on the game (''Poll Finds Preference for Giants,'' The New York Times, Jan. 25).

title: UCONN ENFORCES ATHLETE RULES
description: WHEN three members of the University of Connecticut men's basketball team - including its best player - Earl Kelley, were declared academically ineligible during the 1985-86 season, inadequate tutoring for athletes was cited as a key cause.

title: PITTSFIELD FAMILY KEEPS GROWING
description: For most people, raising six children of their own would be a struggle. For Mayor Charles L. Smith of Pittsfield and his wife, Patricia, caring for an additional 70 children as foster parents and guardians has not been enough.

title: CONCERT: IMPROVISATIONS BY OLIVEROS, MARSH, PRICE
description: WEDNESDAY evening's concert at the Alternative Museum, 17 White Street, was billed as ''Pauline Oliveros with Tina Marsh and Robert Price,'' the advance publicity consisting entirely of information about Ms. Oliveros. At the actual concert, Ms. Oliveros introduced her friends and joined them at the end for a three-person improvisation, but offered no compositions of her own. Truth in advertising suffered a setback, but the concert turned out pretty nicely.

title: COMEDY ON WRY AND SOME KIPPERS
description: Teacher's Pet Starring Clark Gable, Doris Day, Gig Young, Mamie Van Doren. Produced by William Perlberg; directed by George Seaton. 1958 Kartes Video Communications. 120 minutes. $19.95

title: WOODY ALLEN SAVORS THE DETAILS
description: There's a moment of pure happiness in Woody Allen's new ''Radio Days'' in which the narrator's Cousin Ruthie appears with a towel on her head, doing a little dance. Though not the Latin fireball type - Cousin Ruthie ordinarily wears white anklets and spends time gossiping with her mother about the neighbors - she has done what she can with this improvised turban and some junk jewelry. With a smile of tremendous satisfaction, she is prancing and swaying to Carmen Miranda's ''South American Way'' and lip-synching the song perfectly. And when two of Ruthie's male relatives wander into this scene and see what she's doing, they understand. In the same spirit of delight they begin lip-synching, delivering the ''Ai-yi's'' right on cue.

title: Union Seeks to Avoid Paying Reward in Killings
description: More than 17 years ago the United Mine Workers of America offered a $50,000 reward for the arrest and conviction of the killers of a reform candidate for the union's presidency, a gesture that turned out to have been a ruse by the incumbent president to divert attention from his role in ordering the murder, Now the union, in pleadings in Federal District Court here, is seeking to avoid paying the reward.

title: Leslie P. Kamen To Wed in August
description: Leslie Patricia Kamen, a doctoral candidate in clinical psychology, and Dr. Lawrence Siegel, a fourth-year medical student, both at the University of Pennsylvania, plan to be married in August, the mother of the bride-to-be, Vera Jordan Kamen of New York, has announced.

title: SCULPTOR EXPLORES SPATIAL MOVEMENT
description: LEAD: GROWING up in Sag Harbor, surrounded by woods and water, Edith Kelman was always fascinated by what she calls ''special spaces.'' With branches and twigs or ropes from sailboat riggings, she began building environments out of natural materials, until the process evolved into a ''language'' that became her art.

title: STATE'S CONGRESSIONAL DELEGATION OPPOSES SALE OF AMTRAK
description: LEAD: PREDICTING commuter chaos and a major transportation shortfall along the vital Northeast Corridor, key members of New Jersey's Congressional delegation expressed skepticism last week over the Reagan Administration's latest plan to dismantle Amtrak.

title: DEFENSE AIDE REJECTS CONCEPT OF A WORLD FREE OF ATOMIC ARMS
description: A senior Pentagon official today called suggestions that the world could some day be free of nuclear weapons an absurd folly. President Reagan has often said a nuclear-free world is his goal.

title: Data Update: February 1, 1987
ALTERNATIVE UMBRELLA
description: For nearly four decades, the Council on Foundations, based in Washington, has been the big umbrella for philanthropic nonprofit organizations, lobbying for some 900 affliated groups and serving as a clearinghouse for information.

title: A Cabby's Guide to London
description: To Stanley Roth, London's streets and buildings are fragments in a vast historical mosaic of literature, culture, architecture, people and habits.

title: CROCKETT UNDER ATTACK
description: A coalition of President Reagan's most important supporters is demanding the ouster of Representative George W. Crockett Jr., a Michigan Democrat, as head of the House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Western Hemisphere Affairs, maintaining that he is a ''security risk.''

title: WRITING OFF THE DEEP END
description: WHY are we so interested all of a sudden in a French writer who has been dead for a quarter of a century? Why should there be, just now, three new books by or about Louis-Ferdinand Celine? I think it's partly because we're fascinated by his craziness. We're more accustomed to craziness than we used to be and there's a peculiar pleasure - the reader's revenge? - in seeing the suspected craziness of literature made explicit.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Charlevoix, Mich.;
Preserving The Wetlands
description: LEAD: A PROPOSAL to control development and preserve the esthetic and natural values and high water quality of Lake Charlevoix is nearing completion in this northern Michigan community.

title: ROBIN A. RICE HAS WEDDING
description: Robin Atwood Rice, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anton Henry Rice 3d of Stamford, Conn., was married there yesterday to Steven Paul Voigt, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Paul Voigt of Westport, Conn. The Rev. Richard E. Mayberry performed the ceremony at St. Francis' Episcopal Church.

title: Joanne Niemiera Wed To Timothy R. Martin
description: Joanne Maria Niemiera, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alexander K. Niemiera of Perth Amboy, N.J., was married there yesterday to Timothy Reeves Martin, a son of Col. Thomas S. Martin, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Martin of Alexandria, Va. The Rev. Robert J. Zamorski performed the ceremony at St. Stephen's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Hannah E. Frost Plans to Be Wed To Ronan Ryan
description: The engagement of Hannah Elisabeth Frost to Ronan Patrick Ryan has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William Lee Frost of New York, the father and stepmother of the future bride. Mr. Ryan is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Ryan of Hazel Park, Mich. An April wedding is planned.

title: Suzanne Gould to Marry Wayne L. Maggin in May
description: Announcement of the engagement of Suzanne Gould to Wayne Leigh Maggin has been made by the mother of the bride-to-be, Mrs. Louis F. Gould of Edison, N.J. Mr. Maggin is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Maggin of Rockville, Md. A May wedding is planned.

title: TWYLA THARP, MAVERICK, TAKES A NEW GAMBLE
description: LEAD: Her wispy black hair still damp from a three-hour morning workout in the next-door studio, Twyla Tharp is putting the dancers of her newly revamped company through their paces in ''As Time Goes By.'' The Tharp work, created originally for the Joffrey Ballet in 1975 to music by Haydn, is proving troublesome for the dancers, who must perform a chain of knotty steps while moving in a tight cluster at breakneck speed.

title: Q & A
description: 'Reasonable' Consent Question: In a recent column you wrote that ''the owner of a rent-stabilized co-op may not unreasonably withhold consent to a sublet, and the unit may be subletted for two years out of any four-year period.'' Can you give me an idea of what has been construed to be an unreasonable withholding of consent? Would it be unreasonable to withhold consent if the renter moves to another primary residence? . . . R. P., Manhattan Answer: Under the rent-stabilization law, consent to a sublet may be withheld if the renter is giving up his primary residence, or if the landlord objects to the proposed subtenant on grounds that are deemed reasonable by housing court, said Gary M. Rosenberg, a partner with the law firm of Rosenberg & Estis. The subtenant's criminal record or inability to pay the rent might be such grounds. The landlord has 10 days after the tenant's request to ask for more information regarding the move or proposed subtenant. If, after being denied permission, the tenant sublets anyway, the landlord may bring eviction proceedings. Troubled Waters Question: For more than two years, rusty water has flowed from the faucets in my apartment. The discoloration gets into the laundry and food, as well as my skin and hair. Is rusty water toxic? Who is responsible for removing this trouble - the landlord or the tenants? And to whom should I complain? The landlord says we are lucky - that it is how we can maintain a ''healthy glow'' between Florida vacations. . . . E. K., Manhattan Answer: Roz Post, director of public information for the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, says that galvanized pipes are often found in old buildings, whereas brass pipes, which do not rust, are now the standard. Under the city's maintenance code, it is the landlord's responsibility to replace some or all of the plumbing in the event of discolored water. If you have notified your landlord and he does not take action, you should call the department's complaint hotline at 960-4800. The department will issue a violation for discolored water, and the landlord will have 30 days to make the improvements.

title: AN UNEASY FEELING ABOUT A REACTOR
description: A TRENCH with a concrete roof stretches 3,000 feet into the scrubland around the N-Reactor on the Hanford nuclear reservation in Richland, Wash. In a major accident, water from the Columbia River would be pumped through the core and into the trench. Small amounts of radioactive water are dumped there routinely.

title: PROSTITUTION UP, DESPITE AIDS
description: ALTHOUGH contact with prostitutes is believed to be one of the two principal causes of acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) among heterosexuals (the other is sexual contact with intravenous drug users or intravenous drug use), fear of AIDS does not seem to be deterring patrons of prostitutes in New Jersey.

title: Dance
description: There is nothing quite like the annual benefits held for Performance Space 122, that home for the experimental arts on the Lower East Side. To start, there are the benefits' zany titles. This time it's ''Pipedreams,'' since funds raised from the three-day marathon of benefit performances will be used for such improvements as better backstage plumbing. And some 60 artists will perform this year in six shows, starting Thursday night with with a visit from the ''Alien Comic,'' introduced by Joseph Melillo, director of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival. ''Pipedreams'' will end early in the morning next Sunday with the ''afro-billy'' sounds of the Jole Blonde band, in a show introduced by Kestutis Nakas, a leading avant-garde theater director, actor and writer.

title: WHEN ARE BISHOPS BETTER THAN KNIGHTS?
description: If you take a knight and a bishop and plunk them down at random on an empty board, it is not clear which piece is the more useful.

title: CONCERT: THE NEW MUSIC CONSORT
description: THURSDAY'S assemblage of music by the New Music Consort at Weill Recital Hall seemed touched by a variety of influencing hands, yet all these pieces followed the serious steadfastness of purpose that has marked mainstream 20th-century composition.

title: IRAQ SAYS IT REGAINED 15 SQUARE MILES NEAR BASRA
description: Iraq said today that it had retaken 15 square miles of territory near Basra, but Iran said it had killed or wounded 3,000 Iraqis in crushing the counteroffensive.

title: CUOMO ASSAILED ON AID TO SCHOOLS
description: LEAD: WESTCHESTER school officials and state legislators sharply criticized Governor Cuomo last week for calling education his ''highest priority'' and then offering proposals on state aid that would result in cutbacks in funds for most area school districts.

title: Recent Sales
description: Cranbury $98,500 233 Woodmill Drive 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 4-year-old condominium town house; wall-to-wall carpeting, cathedral ceilings, 1-acre lot; maintenance $85, taxes $2,100. Marlboro $160,000 58 Portland Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new condominium town house; fireplace, central A/C; maintenance $105, taxes $2,400. North Plainfield $167,900 78 Mall Drive 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 17-year-old colonial; wall-to-wall carpeting, brick fireplace, 1-car detached garage; taxes $2,166. Pompton Plains $195,250 7 May Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 66-year-old colonial; fireplace, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,119. Somerville $179,900 175 Rehill Avenue 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 20-year-old split-level; screened-in porch, central A/C, cedar exterior; taxes $2,805. West Orange $325,000 420 Mount Pleasant Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 32-year-old colonial; den, patio, 2-car garage; taxes $5,327. OTHER AREAS Kings Park, L.I. $208,000 176 Avenue B 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 12-year-old colonial; den, fireplace, deck, garage; taxes $3,300. Milford, Conn. $147,000 36 Grapevine Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 33-year-old ranch; garage, basement family room; taxes $1,333. Scarsdale, N.Y. $237,500 63 Lee Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 76-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, study, walk to station; taxes $2,270.

title: COPING WITH ATOMIC DISASTER
description: CHERNOBYL AND NUCLEAR POWER IN THE USSR By David R. Marples. 228 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. Cloth, $35. Paper, $14.95.

title: WITH CAREFUL CAJOLERY, HE GETS THE PARTY TO BUDGE
description: MIKHAIL S. GORBACHEV rrwas at the Kremlin gate last week, tacking up another manifesto for fundamental change in the Soviet Union.

title: Unwinding Beside the Dead Sea
description: With the recent revitalization of some of the world's most ancient baths and the development of new seaside spas, Israel offers a wide range of health- and beauty-oriented vacation spots that also make excellent sites to unwind in after a whirlwind tour. In fact, because of the relaxed atmosphere of most of the establishments and a certain mystique about staying at a spa, many guests leave refreshed without taking any of the formal treatments.

title: LAWMAKERS IRATE OVER $9 BILLION FOR FOREIGN MILITARY CONTRACTING
description: The United States awarded $9 billion in military contracts to foreign companies last year, and some lawmakers charge that the deals hurt both the nation's trade deficit and the struggling American companies that could be doing the work.

title: Drug Tests for Suspected Felons
description: A spokesman for the Civil Liberties Union called it ''a terrible idea'' and the director of the Legal Aid Society's criminal defense division didn't like it either. But city officials are going ahead with a plan to ask suspects arrested on felony charges to undergo drug tests voluntarily.

title: Jersey Official Named in Suit on Dismissal of Aides
description: Five former Essex County officials have filed a lawsuit asserting that they were illegally dismissed by the new County Executive, Nicholas R. Amato.

title: Czechoslovakia
description: To the Editor: As a member of Amnesty International, the human rights organization, I feel that I should pass on to you the fact that reliable reports by the organization indicate that repression has grown considerably worse in Czechoslovakia recently. Czech citizens have been arrested for such ''crimes'' as private letters and conversations critical of official policies, listening to Voice of America broadcasts, distribution of uncensored literature and other expressions of dissent.

title: IT'S 'OLD-TIME' RIVALRY FOR NEHEMIAH, FOSTER
description: For a decade, almost from the time they were high school phenomenons, Renaldo Nehemiah and Greg Foster have been rivals running the high hurdles. At their best, when they competed head-to-head, Nehemiah was the world's best hurdler and Foster the second best.

title: MARKETING REAL ESTATE WITH ART
description: BATTERY Park City could hardly be more successful.

title: Katharine Burks Plans to Be Wed To W. F. Hackett
description: Dr. and Mrs. William Parnelle Burks of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Katharine Seton Burks to William Francis Hackett, a son of Capt. James Edward Hackett Jr., U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Hackett of Portsmouth, R.I.

title: Court Delineates Criminals' Rights
description: The Supreme Court last week turned to two issues central to the Reagan Administration's social agenda. But the actions made no clearer whether White House policymakers would find the ultimate outcomes to their liking.

title: MICHIGAN TOPS IOWA FOR SIXTH IN A ROW
description: Glen Rice scored a career-high 33 points and Michigan took advantage of 26 Iowa turnovers today for a 100-92 upset victory that knocked the Hawkeyes out of a tie for first place in the Big Ten.

title: Q and A
description: Cruises to Mexico Question:Are there any cruises from New Orleans that enable you to see the Mayan and Aztec sites in Mexico? - A. B., Fair Lawn, N.J. Answer:To visit the Mayan sites, passengers need to take a cruise that calls at ports in the Yucatan. The cruise lines arrange guided excursions from the ports to the Mayan ruins by bus and sometimes by plane. Most of the Aztec sites are in central Mexico, relatively distant from ports and are not usually included in cruise tours.

title: C.I.A. SAID TO SEND WEAPONS VIA ZAIRE TO ANGOLA REBELS
description: In a highly secret operation, the Central Intelligence Agency has used an abandoned air base here to airlift arms to guerrillas in Angola, diplomatic and business sources say.

title: NIGHTMARISH SEARCH FOR HOUSING HAUNTS NEW YORK'S WELFARE RECIPIENTS
description: In a city where housing can be an obsession even for the well-to-do, life for hundreds of thousands of people on welfare is a daily encounter with dilapidated buildings, crowded rooms and a housing allowance out of line with the cost of living in New York.

title: GRAND JURY STUDY FAULTS BRONX SCHOOL SYSTEM
description: Politics and patronage are too influential in public schools in the Bronx, according to a grand jury report released by District Attorney Mario Merola.

title: PLEADING A CASE TO SAVE LOVE ON THE WING
description: SOME locally rare species of dragonflies, it appears, are partial to trysting on their own north shore, that of Belvedere Lake in Central Park.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''When you add it all up, the economy isn't booming, and it's not busting based on these numbers. It's just muddling along.'' - Edward E. Yardeni, chief economist, Prudential-Bache, on the durable goods report.

title: HOLOCAUST SURVIVORS TELL CITY PUBLIC SCHOOL STUDENTS OF HITLER'S OPPRESSION
description: The classroom of talkative teen-age girls fell silent when the woman, old enough to be their grandmother, told about the persecution she had lived through when she was a girl.

title:
IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN;
Westerleigh
description: LEAD: ANY director contemplating a sequel to the movie ''Back to the Future,'' a pseudoscientific trip in time back to the 1950's, could do worse than pick Westerleigh as its locale.

title: BEVERLY KEYES MARRIES
description: At the First Congregational Church in Canton, Conn., yesterday Beverly Jean Keyes, a daughter of Grace H. Keyes of Canton and the late James R. Keyes, was married to D. Dana Donovan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel D. Donovan Jr. of Weston, Mass. The Rev. Charles Schleich officiated. The bride, a graduate of Middlebury College with an M.B.A. degree from Dartmouth College, is a treasury specialist at the First National Bank of Boston. Mr. Donovan, a graduate of the Loomis Chaffee School and Duke University, leads tourist expeditions in Africa and Asia.

title: Child Accounts
description: To the Editor:

title: ON THE LAM FROM BOREDOM
description: DESIRE PROVOKED By Tracy Daugherty. 245 pp. New York: Random House. $15.95.

title: 11 NORTH KOREAN BOAT PEOPLE PUT JAPAN IN MIDDLE OF SQUABBLE
description: Eleven North Koreans aboard a ship that developed engine trouble and drifted into Japanese waters more than a week ago have created an unusual diplomatic triangle that resists a swift solution.

title: EXPLORING THE CITY'S MUSEUMS
description: Despite its comparative youth - 1988 is bicentenary year - Sydney has many fine public and private art galleries and museums, with the added bonuses that most charge no admission and lines are rare. The quality and variety of the collections, including, as they do, major paintings from Europe and other parts of the world, as well as Australia, surprise many visitors to the city. One striking element is the comprehensive view the museums and galleries provide of the Australian Continent's natural history and art, both aboriginal and Western.

title: DAY AND A NIGHT AT THE SYDNEY OPERA
description: Even before it opened in 1973 with a performance of ''War and Peace'' by Prokofiev, the Sydney Opera House had achieved a certain notoriety, both for its radical design and for its enormous cost overruns.

title: A LOOK BEHIND TWO PHOTOGRAPHY SHOWS
description: LEAD: EVELYN NESBIT, Mrs. Vincent Astor, the Duchess of Marlborough. Jack Johnson, Bill (Bojangles) Robinson, Adam Clayton Powell Sr. These are a few of the well-known figures photographed by Rudolf Eickemeyer Jr. and James Van Der Zee, two early photographers whose careers span decades and whose works are now on display at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers.

title:
GARDENING;
CLIMATE AND DORMANCY REQUIREMENTS
description: LEAD: ONE is always a bit hesitant to bring up a subject such as the mildness of winter. Like washing one's car only to have it rain, bragging on the weather often seems to trigger a blizzard, heat wave or some other undesirable phenomenon. Nevertheless, the winter has been relatively mild overall, and the plants in our garden show the effects of that mildness.

title: Germans May Destroy Nuclear-Tainted Milk
description: West Germany's Minister for the Environment suggested today that the Bonn Government was considering disposing of 3,000 tons of radioactive powdered milk as contaminated waste and compensating its owners.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: ''HERE IS A MAN WHO would fudge when it suits his purpose.'' So said Australian Justice Philip Powell, with scorn, of the Secretary to Margaret Thatcher's Cabinet, in connection with the trial concerning the attempted suppression of a book about ''the fifth man'' who may have infiltrated Britain's spy service.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Autographed Paper Bags RAYMOND RIVERA of Huntington is still waiting for his first fan letter. Although Mr. Rivera's name can be seen coast to coast on the bottoms of the millions of brown paper grocery bags he helps manufacture, so far only his immediate family considers him a celebrity. ''My wife, Judith, looks for my bags whenever she goes shopping in Pathmark,'' he said proudly.

title: THE PUNGENT PLUS OF WITCH HAZELS
description: LEAD: Figuratively, it is often said that flowers ''unfurl.'' In the case of witch hazels, this is true. The thin petals, four of them, each about a sixteenth of an inch wide, are rolled up like party favors inside a brown, husklike calyx. At the first sign of warmth, the calyx opens to release the coiled streamers.

title: A REMEDY PROPOSED FOR RAIL STRIKES
description: So the L.I.R.R. was struck again -leaving commuters desperately searching for alternate means of transportation.

title: Topics: Bird Colonels / Animal Abuse; Kernel of an Idea
description: The performance of Col. Gregorio Honasan, a leader of the latest attempted coup against the Aquino Government in the Philippines, lends critical mass to a proposal that could go a long way toward stabilizing world affairs. The plan is simple: abolish the military rank of colonel, worldwide.

title: NONFICTION: IN SHORT
description: LEAD: MARIANNE MOORE: The Poetry of Engagement. By Grace Schulman. (University of Illinois Press, $17.95.) Grace Schulman, a poet, professor of English at Baruch College and poetry editor of The Nation, thoroughly evaluates in this book the methodology employed by Marianne Moore (1887-1972). Although Moore's poetry has been criticized as overly concerned with the accumulation of details at the expense of larger themes, it is Ms.

title: STAMFORD SHOP CATERS TO PATRIOTS
description: LEAD: ELIZABETH PETTI'S friends tease her about her patriotism, saying that when she kisses her husband on the cheek, they expect her to leave an imprint of the American flag instead of lipstick marks.

title: The Dow
description: To the Editor: Before the hosannas over the Dow Jones index get out of hand (''Tracing the Ups and Downs of the 20th Century Through the Eyes of Wall Street,'' Jan. 18), it is useful to view the matter with a bit of historical perspective. Herewith what might have been and what has been: Dow's Actual Dow's High C.P.I. Adjusted Year (Approx.) (1967-100) High 1967 1,000 100 1,000 1977 1,000 182 1,818 1987 2,100 320 3,200

title: QUESTIONS RAISED ON RESOURCE RECOVERY
description: In ''Is Resource Recovery the Way to Go?'' (Jan. 11), Steven Pollock of the Ocean County Planning Board argued that solid-waste incinerators were a relatively safe technology. He asserted that the small amount of contamination that issues from them is insignificant when compared to the dangers of landfilling wastes. He wrote: ''Before criticizing resource recovery and ruling out the possibility of using the technology to dispose of increasing amounts of solid waste, one must ask whether these risks are equal to, or worse than, those associated with current disposal methods.''

title: TRACING LITTLE RICHARD TO THE SOURCE
description: Just recently, Warner Bros. released a new record by Little Richard, who is more formally known as Richard Penniman. With his crowing tenor-falsetto, his pompadour and makeup, his flashy suits and flashier piano style, Little Richard was one of the pioneers of rock-and-roll.

title: FICTION: IN SHORT
description: LEAD: AMERICAN TROPIC. By David A. Kaufelt. (Poseidon, $17.95.) David A. Kaufelt's ambitiously long and detailed ninth novel traces the lives of the Cordoba and Levi families in Florida from 1512, just before Ponce de Leon's discovery, to Castro's takeover of Cuba. The first members of these interconnected families -Ramon de Cordoba, a rebellious nobleman; La Floridita, an actress accused of being a witch; and Antonio Levi, a gentle-spirited Jew - are all fleeing the Inquisition in Spain.

title: BEWARE OF AGING GRAY-MARKET FILM
description: LAST week I hiked through the snow and slush to my local West Side camera store, in search of some tungsten-balanced Ektachrome film. The store had the film, I gulped at the price, and I asked for two rolls. No big deal.

title: Artifacts And Sacred Sites
description: As a resident of the Southwest and as a sometime-dealer in antiques and artifacts, I read Derek V. Goodwin's article on the illegal trafficking of Indian ceremonial material with considerable interest (''Raiders of the Sacred Sites,'' Dec. 7). There is surely material to be written about looting and desecrating ceremonial property, but the subject cannot be conveniently wrapped up by peppering a scenario with villains and vigilantes. Mr. Goodwin seemed intent on turning his article into a script for Harrison Ford.

title: HERITAGE MARKS FLORIDA MAYORAL RACE
description: No one can say it is not an even match.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL, IN POLAND, SEES RELATIONS IMPROVING
description: WARSAW, Jan. 31 -

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: IT'S ONE of my earliest memories - the earliest, for all I know.

title: WHEN THE GROUND IS FROZEN, GOLFERS SIMPLY CHANGE STRATEGY
description: LEAD: IT is 7:30 A.M. on a recent Sunday, the temperature is perched just above freezing and the gray of dawn has not fully surrendered to daylight. Still, the golfers have started lining up at the Saxon Woods Golf Course in Scarsdale. By 8:30 A.M. there is a one-hour wait for a tee-off time, a two-hour wait by 10 A

title: JUST WHOSE MONEY IS IN AN EMPLOYEE PENSION PLAN?
description: WHEN United Airlines announced plans to withdraw $960 million in surplus assets from its pension plan, many of the company's retirees protested that most or all of the money was rightfully theirs. Since the money had been set aside to cover retirement benefits, they contended, any amount by which it had appreciated in a bull market should be used to provide cost-of-living increases. The Chicago-based airline insisted at first that it had the right to any extra proceeds, but it later responded to the protests by reducing its withdrawal to $250 million.

title: WOMEN, TOO, HAVE EXCLUSIVE CLUBS
description: IN their way, New York's two best-known women's clubs are progressive. Men cannot be full members, but they are everywhere.

title: SCRUPLES IN THE GAME OF REAL LIFE
description: THE game was called Scruples and my friend Irene had brought it with her for our yearly New year's weekend at Mohonk. Irene always brought games. We had lived through the years of Scrabble, graduated to Boggle and gone on Trivial Pursuits with our entourage of six adults and six teen-agers.

title: COMEDY ON WRY AND SOME KIPPERS
description: Rudyard Kipling's Classic Stories: A Trio of Well-Loved Tales A Stephen Bosustow Production for Learning Corporation of America. LCA Video. 25 minutes. $14.95

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: A DANCER'S PHOTOGRAPHS An exhibition of photographs by Moses Pendleton, co-founder of the Pilobolus Dance Company and founder of the Momix Dance Company, opens today through Feb. 25 at The Silo in New Milford with a reception from noon to 3 P.M.

title: PHYSICIANS JOINING THEIR OWN H.M.O.
description: SO far, 2,800 of the 4,800 physicians who practice in Connecticut have joined the first health maintenance organization in the state that will be owned by doctors, according to Timothy Norbeck, executive director of the Connecticut Medical Society.

title: ARMS NEGOTIATORS PLAN NEW EFFORT
description: American and Soviet negotiators have agreed in Geneva to set up a special working group to discuss what research, development and testing are allowed for defensive systems by the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, Administration officials say.

title: GREENWICH WRITER, 61, TURNS TO FICTION
description: LEAD: MARTIN GROSS, a Greenwich author who knocked doctors and psychologists off their pedestals in his three nonfiction books, has placed a Communist in the Oval Office in his latest work, a fiction thriller.

title: THE 'GOOD NEIGHBOR' OFFERS LITTLE AID, LESS TRADE
description: FOR the Fathom Dive Suits Company of Orlando, Fla., President Reagan's Caribbean Basin Initiative seemed just the right opportunity to begin manufacturing rubber wet suits on the island of St. Lucia.

title: BEAVER DAMAGE BRINGS COMPLAINTS
description: NEAR Route 11 in Salem, beavers have built a dam, 40 feet long and 4 feet high, out of mud and branches. Motorists often stop to admire the dam, which has made a thin, shallow brook into a wide, deep pond.

title: PINS WITH A MESSAGE
description: TOM BINNS, a British jewelry designer, makes pins that speak for themselves. ''This is a fashion accessory,'' one says in gold-plated capital letters. The pins will be available in March at the Bartsch boutique, 456A West Broadway, near Houston Street.

title: A LA CARTE
description: WHEN Summerfield's Cafe (442 Central Avenue, Cedarhurst) opened a few years ago, it was one of the first on Long Island to offer mesquite-grilled food. The restaurant combined expertly grilled entrees, imaginative appetizers and home-baked desserts, resulting in a two-star rating in this column (May 5, 1985). In the last six months, Summerfield's has changed ownership. Gone is the mesquite. The restaurant is quite ordinary now, and the two-star rating no longer applies.

title: CHANGE IS THE ONLY CERTAINTY
description: WALL STREET has nothing on Long Island: mergers, buyouts, acquisitions - all these buzzwords and more are roiling the business waters of our tight little Island, too.

title: Fire Escapes
description: To the Editor: I live next door to the Bentley, featured in ''Escape Route as Design Element'' on Jan. 18, and my apartment looks directly out on that exterior fire escape. One feature of its design not mentioned in your article is that it has exposed fluorescent lights on every floor that glare through neighboring windows. Those of us whose apartments look out on the back of the Bentley are constantly reminded of its ''innovative design.'' LEE HANDLER Manhattan

title: REMOVAL OF SCHOOL BOARD MEMBERS IN DISTRICT SEEN
description: The president of the city's Board of Education, Robert F. Wagner Jr., says there is ''a real possibility'' that the central board will suspend the members of an upper Manhattan school board because of allegations of corruption, poor reading scores and overcrowding of classrooms.

title: Ms. Civiello Engaged
description: Mary Alane Civiello, a daughter of Daniel Civiello of Kansas City, Mo., and the late Gertrude Civiello, and William Thomas Carr, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Francis H. Carr of Spencer, Mass., plan to be married March 21. Ms. Civiello is a reporter for WNBC-TV in New York. Mr. Carr is a senior vice president for corporate finance in the New York office of Bain & Company.

title: STUDENTS' RIGHT TO WORK DEFENDED
description: Isn't Ms. Given equating her students' ''more than half-time'' jobs with their inability to be even half-time students? Isn't she saying that if they didn't hold jobs and, instead, devoted all their time and attention to school, they would be better students?

title: SPLICE MEMORY
description: A NIGHT AT THE MOVIES Or, You Must Remember This. By Robert Coover. 187 pp. New York: Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: FICTION: IN SHORT
description: FAIR AUGUSTO: And Other Stories. By Laura Kalpakian. (Graywolf, Paper, $8.) If variety of setting were the sole criterion of a short story's excellence, Laura Kalpakian's first collection would be superior. With substantial facility she delineates locations ranging from a loch in Scotland to Venice to the Santa Monica pier. These are leisurely, full-bodied, even old-fashioned stories with fairly complete narratives - the antithesis of contemporary minimalism. Yet despite this amplitude, a number of the stories seem bland, familiar, uninspired. The lengthy title story barely avoids soap opera to arrive eventually at a woman's genuine anger over the golden boy of her youth. Ms. Kalpakian's favored protagonists are women without jobs or husbands or the wherewithal to face the trials of daily existence. Though these characters aren't without fictional potential, their plight is portrayed in an all too tidy manner. Voice and point of view are relatively unimportant, with the result that one becomes aware of a consistently colorless, constricting omniscience. What is missing from a majority of the stories are quirks and loose ends that can't be explained even by an all-knowing narrator. Only two stories are told in the first person, and they are among the liveliest. In ''Veteran's Day'' a hairdresser proudly relates the escapes from the police of her brother, a Vietnam veteran whose mission in life is to warn America that its minds are being poisoned by ''Killer Enzymes'' and ''Radio Carbons.'' This and several other stories - including an Armenian couple's first brush with an American Christmas and an atheistic doctor in the midst of a devoutly religious family - exhibit a droll humor and a welcome sense of surprise. As a writer of short fiction, Ms. Kalpakian's best efforts are her freest.

title: Lugging It In Luxury
description: How dismayed I was, after reading Ruth La Ferla's article ''Lugging It in Luxury'' (Men's Style, Jan. 4), to discover that my badly battered luggage would have to be replaced with a few little pieces costing from $250 to $3,600.

title: OVERWORKED JERSEY COURT ASSIGNS 50 CASES TO PHILADELPHIA JUDGES
description: Federal District Court judges in New Jersey are so overburdened with criminal trials that about 50 civil cases have been assigned to Federal judges in Philadelphia.

title: NORTH CAROLINA INJURY
description: North Carolina's starting point guard, Kenny Smith, will miss today's game against Notre Dame and may be out of the lineup for two weeks. Smith underwent arthroscopic surgery on his left knee Friday, and according to the team physcian, Dr. Joseph DeWalt, it could be two weeks before the all-America candidate can return to action. In the meantime, his place will be taken by Ranzio Smith, a 6-1 junior.

title: THE FOCUS ON ISRAEL
description: WHY ISRAEL? IN SEVEN YEARS of reporting from the Middle East, there is no question I have faced more frequently or contemplated more often than this: Why are so many people fascinated with Israel? Or, to put it another way, why is Israel so often the focus of news?

title: NATIONAL RECONCILIATION REMAINS AN ELUSIVE GOAL FOR AQUINO
description: ANTONIO ZUMEL, a negotiator for the Communist insurgents in the Philippines, returned to the underground 10 days ago when the already faltering peace talks with the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino broke down. Mr. Zumel said his life had been threatened.

title: AIRLINES FEEL CHILL OF WINTER
description: LEAD: DURING midwinter on the East End, many businesses close or sharply reduce their hours. However, because of a Federal Aviation Administration rule to regulate congestion at airports, airlines in resort areas such as the Hamptons must continue to operate as though it were the tourist season.

title: Vermont After-Ski Bargain Hunting
description: Shopping is gaining in popularity this year as an apres-ski activity in southern Vermont, and if you know where to do it, you can help cover the cost of a skiing weekend.

title: Extraordinary, Holmes!
description: To the Editor:

title: Extraordinary, Holmes!
description: To the Editor:

title: Nancy E. Neuberger Plans to Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Neuberger of New York and Mamaroneck, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Ellen Neuberger, to Michael Charles Kanterman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Kanterman of Spring Valley, N.Y. The wedding is planned for next month.

title: A FOREIGN POLICY VACUUM IS NOW PERCEIVED
description: FOR a Presidency that has relied strongly on visual imagery, the ceremonial surroundings of the State of the Union Message last week were a boost. The House of Representatives chamber was crammed with members of both houses, the Cabinet, the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the Supreme Court and the diplomatic corps. Ronald Reagan, looking fit and displaying an air of robust command, was interrupted repeatedly by the partisan cheers of his fellow Republicans. He did not look at all like a President who had been wounded by his evident detachment from the details of foreign policy or the heedless zeal of the White House aides who concocted the Iran-contra scheme.

title: YONKERS BUOYED BY PLANS FOR FORMER OTIS PLANT
description: LEAD: IN Yonkers there is a new sense of optimism about revitalizing the city's beleaguered downtown as the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey announced plans to spend $25.7 million to refurbish the former Otis Elevator Company plant.

title: AUSTRALIA DEBATES TOUCHY IMMIGRATION ISSUE
description: A WELL-KNOWN Sydney businessman recently stunned his colleagues by suggesting that Australia quadruple its population by allowing more people to immigrate. Jaws fell further when Kerry Packer, one of Australia's most successful media magnates, added that more Asians, already settling here in record numbers, should be encouraged to immigrate.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
Towns Put Planning on the Front Burner
description: LEAD: ''NOT long ago, our tongues were hanging out for developers to come into this town,'' said Edwin L. Eaton, the Long Beach City Manager. ''We have now reached a point where we have to be stricter constructionists on zoning.''

title: POSTINGS: Golf Course Living; Torrington Condos Abut Fairway
description: Residents of a new condominium complex on Baltic Road in Torrington, Conn., could contend with some surprising elements in the warmer months, like shanked five-iron shots.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Good News for Little Guys?

title: KEMP'S AIDES CONCEDING 'ESTABLISHMENT' TO BUSH
description: Top aides of Representative Jack F. Kemp have conceded that most of the New York Republican ''establishment'' will probably support Vice President Bush for the Presidency even though Mr. Kemp would be politically embarrassed by the rebuff of his fellow New Yorkers.

title: WHEN SHE TALKS, TEEN-AGERS LISTEN
description: MIDGE TURK RICHARDSON of Manhattan and Bridgehampton may be 56 years old, but when she talks, teen-agers listen.

title: STATE HOPES FOR $200 MILLION FROM U.S. HOUSING BILL
description: AS the General Assembly awaits a $100 million housing proposal from Governor O'Neill, state officials are hopeful that Congress will offer help of its own.

title: THE SUBURBAN REVOLUTION
description: THIS winter we are reading and hearing more about New York's homeless, but with spring we will turn to other pursuits. The problems of the poor and the near poor will remain, however, until we recognize that it is in our own best interest to find some means of providing suitable housing for those who cannot provide it for themselves.

In Advice and How-to, five titles are listed because, beyond that point, sales in this category are not generally large enough to make a longer list statistically reliable.

title: BUSKERS AND VALENTINE CONCERT SHARE LIMELIGHT
description: A VALENTINE'S concert on Feb. 8, Sweet Saturday Night on a Thursday, ''Tonight at 8:30'' at 8 P.M., bluegrass tunes at the symphony - it will be a funny fortnight in Connecticut, but it will all add up to a remarkable and delightful diversity.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: A LOW-WAGE EXPLOSION;
The Grim Truth About the Job 'Miracle'
description: LEAD: THE American worker is in trouble. Despite all the talk about job growth in the 1980's, the overall unemployment rate for the past year remains essentially unchanged from its 1980 recession level. Since the early 1970's, average wage and salary incomes adjusted for inflation have been declining for nearly all groups within the population and in most industries.

title: Classical Music
description: Goethe referred to chamber music, and the string quartet in particular, as a discourse between reasonable individuals. Since the Classical era, the form has inspired some of our most celebrated composers to their best work, from the great late quartets of Beethoven - so far ahead of their time that they had to wait until our century for general acceptance - through the quartets of Elliott Carter, the second and third of which have both won Pulitzer prizes.

title: BALLET RAMBERT BALANCES TRADITION AND ICONOCLASM
description: Contemporary English ballet was born when a Polish-born ballet teacher named Marie Rambert prodded an English lad named Fred Ashton into choreographing a ballet for a production she planned. It was a risk. Ashton, today one of the world's master choreographers, had never before created a dance. But it was a risk well-taken, as most of Mme. Rambert's were. And the production marked the birth, too, of the Ballet Rambert, which opens on Tuesday for a one-week season at City Center.

title: A MET MANON IN 1937 VISITS A NEW MET 'MANON' IN 1987
description: It was just two weeks shy of a half-century ago, but Bidu Sayao remembers it as though it were yesterday. ''Who could forget a Metropolitan Opera debut,'' she asked with a laugh as she told the story not long ago during her annual New York visit.

title: HUGH WOLFF SET TO CONDUCT CONCERT WITH MENTOR, ROSTROPOVICH, AS SOLOIST
description: WHEN Hugh Wolff mounts the podium at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night, he will be taking part in something of a family reunion. The 33-year-old conductor will be leading the National Symphony Orchestra, whose members he calls his ''musical mothers and fathers.''

title: COLUMBIA DEFEATS HARVARD AS COUCH SCORES 33
description: Sean Couch scored a career-high 33 points tonight to lead Columbia past Harvard, 88-81, in an Ivy League game.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: FEBRUARY 1, 1987
description: Fiction Weeks On List 1 1 I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN, by Judith Krantz. (Bantam, $4.95.) A rich, beautiful young woman conquers the world of magazine publishing. 2 9 LIE DOWN WITH LIONS, by Ken Follett. (Signet/ NAL, $4.95.) An Englishwoman in Afghanistan, caught between the C.I.A. and the K.G.B. 3 4 THE STORYTELLER, by Harold Robbins. (Pocket, $4.50.) A poor boy from Brooklyn sets out to make it big in the world of glamour as a writer. 4 10 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. (Bantam, $4.95.) Ayla of ''The Clan of the Cave Bear'' resumes her prehistoric adventures. 5 46 THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.50.) A submarine driver brings Soviet nuclear secrets to the United States. 6* 2 THE HANDMAID'S TALE, by Margaret Atwood. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Behind the scenes of a television production. 8 6 ANGELS OF SEPTEMBER, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Geis/Warner, $4.95.) Father Blackie Ryan investigates an art gallery explosion. 9 13 DARK ANGEL, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $4.50.) The story of the haunted Casteel family continues. 10 9 CYCLOPS, by Clive Cussler. (Pocket, $4.95.) Intrigue in 1920's Hollywood. 12 1 THE IMMIGRANT'S DAUGHTER, by Howard Fast. (Dell, $4.50.) A businesswoman is torn between devotion to her husband and her mentor. 14* 62 THE CLAN OF THE CAVE BEAR, by Jean M. Auel. (Bantam, $4.95.)
