title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
SPEAKING PERSONALLY: WHEN A DOUBLE STROLLER IS ON THE WAY
description: LEAD: ''I TRIED for 11 years to have a child,''

title: Parental Leave Would Cripple Small and Medium-Size Businesses
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing Swiss Sweep Downhill: Peter Mueller, taking risks on the tricky Nationale course, upset Pirmin Zurbriggen, the defending champion, and led a Swiss sweep of the medals at the world Alpine championships at Crans-Montana yesterday. It was the first major downhill title for Mueller, a 29-year-old veteran of the World Cup circuit. He mastered the difficult jumps on the 3,112-meter course and posted the excellent time of 2 minutes 7.80 seconds. Zurbriggen had to settle for the silver medal in 2:08.13, and Karl Alpiger took the bronze in 2:08.20. Franz Heinzer added to the Swiss domination by finishing fourth in 2:08.34. Michael Brown of Vail, Colo., the top American finisher, was 21st in 2:10.45. Marc Girardelli of Luxembourg finished seventh, despite suffering his third shoulder separation of the season Thursday. (AP) Golf King Ahead: Betsy King shot a 71 and moved into a one-stroke lead after three rounds of the $200,000 Mazda Classic at Boca Raton, Fla. King, winner of seven tournaments over the last three seasons, carded four birdies and three bogeys on the par-72, 6,472-yard course at Stonebridge Golf and Country Club and reached the 54-hole mark at 213. The leader was the only one among the top nine contenders to break par in breezy conditions that contributed to the steep fall of Cathy Moore, the second-day leader, who shot a 77. Heather Farr, starting her second year on the tour, moved into second place at 73-214. (AP) Casper Shares Lead: Billy Casper carded his second straight par 72 to share the halfway lead with Harold Henning of South Africa at 144 in the $300,000 Seniors Golf Classic at the Gary Player Country Club in Sun City, South Africa. Henning shot a 69, the best round of the day. Despite the 104-degree heat, Henning produced five birdies and only two bogeys. Orville Moody, who had been tied at 70 for the first-round lead with Doug Sanders, was a stroke back with 145 after a 75. (AP) Tennis Flach Upset: Dan Saltz upset Ken Flach, a Davis Cup doubles player, in the second qualifying round for the United States Pro Indoor tennis championship, by 5-7, 7-5, 6-3, in Philadelphia. Saltz, of Los Angeles, is 291st in the world computer rankings, 107 places higher than Flach, a St. Louis native. In another upset of the second-round qualifier, Hugo Nunez of Rockaway, N.Y., eliminated Chip Hooper of Bradenton, Fla., 3-6, 6-1, 7-5. Hooper was a semifinalist in the tournament five years ago. (AP) Horse Racing King's Swan Wins Assault: King's Swan, the favorite, scored a front-running 4 3/4-length victory in the $89,100 Assault Handicap at Aqueduct. Ridden by Jose Santos, King's Swan showed a liking to the sloppy track and covered the mile and an eighth in 1:52 4/5 for his second victory in two starts this year. Scrimshaw closed fast on the rail to edge Feeling Gallant by a neck for second. King's Swan, a 7-year-old son of King's Bishop and Royal Cygnet, paid $3.60 for $2 to win. In the co-feature, Videogenic raced to a three-length victory in the $87,650 Rare Treat Handicap for fillies and mares. Squan Song, who won this race last year, was the runner-up, 1 1/2 lengths ahead of Beth's Song. Videogenic completed the mile and an eighth in 1:55 1/5 and paid $15.20 as the third choice in a field of eight. Auto Racing Duel at Daytona: Al Unser Jr. and Danny Sullivan, both in Porsche 962's, were fighting for the lead at the six-hour mark of the Daytona 24-hour endurance race in Daytona Beach, Fla. Unser, teamed with Derek Bell of England and Chip Robinson of New Jersey, held a lead of less than two seconds over the car shared by Sullivan, A. J. Foyt and Al Unser Sr. The younger Unser beat Sullivan out onto the circuit following routine pit stops on lap 166, five and a half hours into the race. Sullivan had inherited the lead from the Porsche 962 of Jochen Mass and Klaus Ludwig of West Germany and Bruce Leven of the United States during the fifth hour. Leven's car led most of the first five hours before a long pit stop due to a collision with a slower car. (AP) Track and Field Best in High Jump: Stefka Kostadinova of Bulgaria set a world indoor best in the women's high jump at Genoa, Italy, clearing 6 feet 8 1/4 inches. She bettered the standard of 6-8, set by Tamara Bykova of the Soviet Union in Budapest in 1983. Kostadinova tried to surpass her outdoor world record of 6-9 3/4, but she missed at 6-10 1/4. (AP) Bobsledding Canadians Crash: An East German team took the lead in the European four-man bobsledding championships at Cervinia, Italy, on a day marred by a spectacular crash by a Canadian sled. East Germany I, piloted by Wolfgang Hoppe, had the best combined time after two runs. The East Germans, who set a course record of 1 minute 2.97 seconds on the first run, compiled a time of 2:04.69. Switzerland I held second place with a combined time of 2:04.83. The USA I sled was seventh in 2:05.68. The Canada III sled was going 67 miles an hour when it flipped on its side and slammed into the lip of the icy track before skidding to a halt. Three of the four team members were injured and were taken to a local hospital by helicopter. The most seriously hurt was Chris Lori, 24, who suffered a broken left collarbone and left hand, shoulder and rib injuries and cuts on the face. (AP) N.B.A. Bullets 106, 76ers 105: Moses Malone scored the last of his 27 points on two free throws with four seconds remaining as the Bullets rallied for 6 points in the final 24 seconds. The 76ers, reduced to the minimum of eight available players by injuries, led by 103-100 after Charles Barkley sank two free throws with 32 seconds remaining. Malone made two foul shots with 24 seconds left and then John Williams of the Bullets intercepted a pass by Mo Cheeks and put Washington ahead by 104-103. After a basket by Barkley put Philadelphia on top by 105-104, Malone was fouled by Roy Hinson after rebounding his missed shot. The 76ers, playing their fifth game in seven days and out of timeouts, had one last chance to win, but Barkley failed to even hit the rim on a 3-point attempt. Barkley finished with 28 points, 17 rebounds and 8 assists. Jeff Malone scored 25 points for the Bullets, who trailed by 91-81 with 8:14 remaining before Williams and Jay Vincent, both reserves, led a comeback. (AP)

title: MITCHELL PARISH: A WAY WITH WORDS
description: Fifty-eight years ago, when Mitchell Parish was handed Hoagy Carmichael's melody for ''Star Dust,'' he had no idea that their collaboration would result in a song that is still widely regarded as the quintessential American pop standard.

title: MUSIC: HAMELIN IS PIANIST IN ZWILICH CONCERTO
description: ELLEN TAAFFE ZWILICH, the only woman to win the Pulitzer Prize for composition (in 1983), is much in the news these days. Friday night at Carnegie Hall her Piano Concerto, jointly commissioned by Carnegie, the Detroit Symphony and the American Symphony, received its New York premiere.

title: LESLIE N. FRANK IS BRIDE OF RICHARD L. SILVERSTEIN
description: Leslie N. Frank, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Frank of Oyster Bay, L.I., was married last night to Richard L. Silverstein, a son of Marilyn Finkel of East Rockaway, L.I., and Al Silverstein of New York. Rabbi Stanley Platek performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

title: NO SINGLE ANSWER ON SURPLUS SCHOOLS
description: There is no single answer to the problem posed by surplus public school buildings [ ''Let's Save Our 'Surplus' Schools,'' Opinion Page, Dec. 7, and Letters to the Long Island Editor, Dec. 28 and Jan. 18 ] .

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Suffolk Police Inquiry
description: 'The rationalization that the ends justify the means seems to be infecting portions of Suffolk's criminal justice system. Unchecked, it may undermine the county's entire justice system. . . .

title: U.S. AIDE'S OUSTER TIED TO IRAN DEAL
description: A Senate staff report has suggested that Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter engineered the ''improper'' dismissal of a Defense Department aide last April because the official was close to uncovering the sale of American weapons to Iran.

title:
MUSIC;
WESTFIELD: BRAHMS
description: LEAD: TWO distinguished Israeli musicians - the violinist Shlomo Mintz and the cellist Simca Heled - will play Brahms's Double Concerto in A minor, Op. 102, with the Westfield Symphony Orchestra next Saturday. The conductor is Brad Keimach. Also on the program, which starts at 8:30 P.M. in the Presbyterian Church, 140 Mountain Avenue, are Barber's Adagio for Strings and Beethoven's Symphony No.

title: Barnwell Elliott Is Married to Edward W. Lane 3d
description: At St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Jacksonville, Fla., yesterday Isabel Barnwell Elliott, until recently the director of creative services at 'Teen magazine in New York, was married to Edward Wood Lane 3d, a partner in the Jacksonville law firm of Ulmer, Murchison, Ashley, Taylor & Corrigan. The Rev. Barnum McCarty performed the ceremony.

title: Elizabeth Stong Engaged to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Hildreth L. Stong of Tiburon, Calif., of the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Snow Stong to John Shaw Cassidy, the son of Margaret S. Cassidy of South Bend, Ind., and the late John A. Cassidy.

title: CONFINED BY ONE'S OWN TUNNEL VISION
description: WE all change. I don't run as fast any more, my midsection is sprouting a small spare tire and I am starting a family - all as things should be, I suppose. But there are some changes I have become very conscious of recently. As I am about to enter a brand new stage of life as a family provider I have found that my reading has become more and more focused toward financial materials, to the exclusion of most other types of literature. I have subscribed to several business publications, religiously read the financial pages of the newspaper and am on the phone almost daily with my stockbroker. In short, I have developed a tunnel vision in my reading habits that has narrowed my interests.

title: Dr. Allan V. Cox Dies at 60; Geologist and Stanford Dean
description: Allan V. Cox, dean of earth sciences at Stanford University, died Tuesday of injuries suffered in a bicycle accident near his home in Woodside, Calif. He was 60 years old. Dr. Cox, who became a Stanford professor in 1967 and was appointed dean in 1979, was known for his work in paleomagnatism and plate tectonics.

title: ROYAL GOSSIP AND THE MEANING OF FENCING
description: LEAD: OUT OF EGYPT Scenes and Arguments of an Autobiography. By Ihab Hassan. 114 pp. Carbondale: Southern Illinois University Press. $15.95.

title: CONSERVATIVES ASSERT LEGAL PRESENCE
description: Conservative legal scholars, judges and officials who convened here Friday and today to debate constitutional theory and legal philosophy served notice that their push for fundamental legal change would outlive the Reagan Administration and its current troubles.

title: FICTION: IN SHORT
description: SHELTERED LIVES. By Frank Milburn. (Doubleday, $15.95.) Freshly transplanted from the battlefields of Vietnam - where he came within a hair's breadth of offing his fanatical commanding officer - David Winant balks at resuming the self-deluding politesse of his proper Long Island family. ''Tell me about Baghdad,'' prompts his mother, an alcohol-steeped invalid who, for as long as he can remember, has had to be periodically ''put in storage . . . like a fur.'' David faults his father (a banker given to quoting Blake) for failing to show emotions, but he himself appears the helpless inheritor of a ''mild demeanor and good manners'' - predispositions that enable him, once reassimilated, to drift through the heavily foreshadowed suicide of a family member as if draped in cotton batting. His equanimity also, unfortunately, affords the author an opportunity for gray prose; with David poised on the threshold of his lifelong sweetheart's bedroom, Mr. Milburn actually pauses to describe the decor.

title: DID THE SUPER BOWL LIVE UP TO THE HYPE?
description: Even if Moses had come down at halftime and parted the grass at the 50-yard line, the Super Bowl could not possibly have lived up to the hype. TRACY MILLER New York

title: Anne H. Casey, A City Planner, Weds in Jersey
description: At St. Brigid's Roman Catholic Church in Peapack, N.J., yesterday Anne Hodnett Casey and Adriaan Markus van den Bergh were married by Msgr. George M. Brembos. The bride is a daughter of James J. Casey of Peapack and Newport, R.I., and the late Anna Gambrill Casey. Her husband is the son of Gratia Baroness Schimmelpennick van der Oye of The Hague and the late Henri van den Bergh of Wassenaar, the Netherlands.

title: Finding Someone to Pilot Your Portfolio
description: WHEN the stock market seesaws violently, as it has done lately, individuals often find themselves on the wrong end of the swing. ''Most people react after the fact,'' said Glenn R. Dubin of Dubin & Swieca, a New York money management firm in partnership with E. F. Hutton & Company. ''If they see on the cover of Time magazine that the market is going up, they buy, and when there's a correction, they panic and sell.''

title: POLLUTION AFTERMATH SPLITS RESIDENTS OF BLUEBELL LANE
description: THE sign clamped on the rusting steel gate welcomes visitors to Hope Lane. But the surrounding landscape appears devoid of any hope. A line of telephone poles and several Spartan house trailers are the only signs that anyone lives on the mud-caked road in Deer Park.

title: Akabir in Hialeah Upset
description: Akabir scored a two-length upset victory over Theatrical in a roughly run Bougainvillea Handicap today at Hialeah Park. After the race, Theatrical was disqualified from second and placed last.

title: Infant Toll 'Horrendous' in Africa, U.N. Finds
description: Infant and child mortality rates in Angola and Mozambique are now the highest in the world, largely because of the fighting and war-related economic destabilization in southern Africa, according to Unicef, the United Nations Children's Fund.

title: MARKETING REAL ESTATE WITH ART
description: SCULPTOR Elyn Zimmerman remembers standing in front of a half-finished office building on the edge of Chicago last year, gazing at the acre of tundra that the Hawthorn Realty Group had commissioned her to turn into a plaza.

title: FLAWS IN RULE
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: DID THE SUPER BOWL LIVE UP TO THE HYPE?
description: Whether the Super Bowl lived up to its hype is of little consequence. What matters is that at long last the pro football season is behind us and ''60 Minutes'' can start on time every Sunday evening. CHARLES COHEN Valley Stream, L.I.

title: WHO NEEDS SPIES ANYWAY?
description: THE SECOND OLDEST PROFESSION Spies and Spying in the Twentieth Century. By Phillip Knightley. Illustrated. 436 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $19.95.

title: GLINTS OF THE FUTURE IN WEIMAR-GERMANY PHOTOS
description: A PHOTOGRAPHY exhibition now at the Neuberger Museum in Purchase, N.Y., suggests an unusual esthetic parallel - in some cases a source - for much of America's pioneering 20th-century photography: Germany during the Weimar Republic.

title: AMPLIFIERS TEST THEIR LISTENERS
description: In audio and elsewhere, it is easier to test equipment than to test a proposition. In the first case, you merely deal with gadgetry, but in the latter instance you have to tackle larger and more slippery entities, like truth and falsehood.

title: IS PRUDENCE TO BLAME FOR A MORE VOLATILE MARKET?
description: SITTING in his four-room New York City apartment, in the dining room that has long served as his office, Robert Ferguson does not look like a man with the power to create stock market gyrations like the 100-point swing in the Dow Jones industrial average one day late last month. Yet some think he has such power. The 49-year-old executive is one of a handful of financial advisers who devise strategies for managers of pension funds and other huge stock portfolios that will protect them against big losses if stock prices turn down. The approach, known as portfolio insurance, uses stock index futures contracts to offset positions in the stock market to limit their losses to a predetermined proportion of their original investment. (See box.) Many money managers consider this form of hedging less costly and more efficient than simply moving in and out of stocks. ''People always hedged by owning both stocks and bonds,'' said Frederic A. Nelson 3rd, vice president of the Bankers Trust Company.''This is a new form of that.'' It is one of the ironies of this complex computerized age, however, that an approach designed to insure against more losses than they are willing to accept is seen by some as contributing to the very volatility that makes the markets so treacherous for so many investors.

title: MULTIFACETED MENU, SWISS SETTING
description: THE CHALET, an 11-year-old Roslyn restaurant, is housed in a historic 130-year-old Swiss-style structure perched on a hillside. Within, the 19th century is reflected by the cozy downstairs taproom and the quaint upstairs dining rooms. The beamed ceilings, uneven wood floors, fireplace and candlelight would be as much a part of Victorian England or Imperial Germany as Switzerland.

title: In West Germany, Kohl's Victory Is Far From Sweet
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany kept his parliamentary majority and his job last week, but the real victors in the election were two of the country's small parties.

title: PRETORIA FREES LUTHERAN MINISTER
description: A South African Lutheran minister who was held in solitary confinement without charge for two months in Venda, a so-called black homeland, was released last week after a 30-day hunger strike.

title: Correction
description: An article Jan. 18 about students working in the nuclear-freeze campaign misidentified the school Thomas Dobbins attended. He is a graduate of Manhattan College in Riverdale.

title:
MUSIC;
LA SCALA AND MUTI ARE OFF TO AN INTERSTING START
description: LEAD: Some years the opening at Teatro alla Scala is a formal, even staid, occasion, and some years it is downright dull. But once in a while it is a truly gala, electric event. This was one of those years. Relations between La Scala's audience and the theater's management have been - often audibly - strained for some time; and the new musical director, Riccardo Muti, may have felt a misgiving or two when he came out into the pit to conduct the inaugural performance of Verdi's ''Nabucco'' on Dec.

title: FICTION: IN SHORT
description: LEAD: CARLYLE SIMPSON. By Karen Lee Osborne. (Academy Chicago, Cloth, $16.95; Paper, $7.95.) The title character of this engrossing but ultimately unsatisfying first novel is a beer-guzzling slob, a trigger-tempered redneck suffering from a bad back and early retirement. In short, Carlyle Simpson is a hard man to like.

title: KEAN TO PROPOSE A RISE OF 9.6% IN JERSEY BUDGET
description: Governor Kean will propose a $10.1 billion state budget for the coming fiscal year that calls for higher spending for education, welfare and health care - including a dramatic increase to combat AIDS -but contains little help for cities about to lose Federal revenue-sharing funds.

title: BANQUETS WELCOME THE YEAR OF THE RABBIT
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH New Year's Day for the Chinese was last Thursday, festivities are still in full swing. The lunar Year of the Rabbit, one of a repeating cycle of 12 animals, is being greeted with feasting and toasting in Chinese restaurants and homes around the state.

title: A REBEL OF MANY CAUSES
description: THE DAMNDEST RADICAL The Life and World of Ben Reitman, Chicago's Celebrated Social Reformer, Hobo King, and Whorehouse Physician. By Roger A. Bruns. Illustrated. 332 pp. Urbana: University of Illinois Press. $24.95.

title: Miss Diefenbach To Marry in June
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Diefenbach of Rye, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Ann Diefenbach, to Stuart King Gray, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert King Gray of Old Greenwich, Conn. The wedding is planned for June 27.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
OPEN AUDITIONS
description: LEAD: On Tuesday, county teen-agers interested in participating in the arts will have the opportunity to display their talents in the annual audition for the 1987 summer season at the Aaron Copland Music and Arts Program. The auditions will be held by appointment at the Academic Arts Building of Westchester Community College in

title: FRED FRIENDLY ENJOYS PUTTING TALKING HEADS ON THE HOT SEAT
description: Fred W. Friendly beamed with satisfaction as he thought of Lesley Stahl, the veteran CBS News correspondent, nervously gnawing her lip in front of a national television audience and trying to figure a way out of the terrible dilemma Mr. Friendly had created for her.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: BOSTON BANS TOWER DESIGN

title: THE BUSINESS OF MANAGING THE ARTS
description: MARY HELTON ''couldn't say no anymore'' when Virginia Hoff called for the third time to ask her to teach at the Hoff-Barthelson Music School in Scarsdale. That was in 1951, when Ms. Helton was pursuing a career as a chamber music pianist and accompanist in New York City. Today, Ms. Helton directs the school, as she has since 1973.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
SKIING: ARE WE HAVING FUN YET?
description: LEAD: COME February, the ski slopes around Aspen, Colo., resemble the Long Island Expressway as visitors from all over Long Island stream in. And it was in glorious Aspen, with its picturesque mountains, powdery-perfect snow and downhill racer's dream conditions, that I gave up skiing forever.

title: Hope College Names Head
description: John H. Jacobson Jr. has been appointed president of Hope College, school officials said today. Mr. Jacobson is the provost and vice president for academic affairs at Empire State College, which is part of the State University of New York, at Saratoga Springs, N.Y. Mr. Jacobson will become Hope's 10th president in 121 years.

title: WESTHCHESTER GUIDE
description: WEIMAR PHOTO ART In the first three decades of this century Germany produced a prodigious quantity and variety of progressive art, including the art of photography. Opening today, and on display through March 29 at the Neuberger Museum of the State University of New York at Purchase, is an exhibition called ''Photographers of the Weimar Republic,'' in which 100 works by six early 20th-century German photographers are to be seen. They are August Sander, Dr. Erich Salomon, Hugo Erfurth, Laszlo Moholy-Nagy, Albert Renger-Patzsch, and Werner Mantz.

title: TOPICS
description: I WAS taught not to judge a book by its cover, but I can always tell the immaculate people, those with perfect homes and carefully groomed lawns, a mile away. My secret? Appearances are most revealing.

title: Elway's 2d Chance
description: IF at first you don't succeed. . . . A week after he failed to crack the Giant defense in the Super Bowl, John Elway will be getting another chance today. As the quarterback for the American Football Conference squad in the Pro Bowl game in Honolulu, Elway will be facing four Giant defenders who helped stymie him last week. The National Football Conference team has eight Giants, including, on defense, Lawrence Taylor and Harry Carson at linebacker, Jim Burt at nose tackle and Leonard Marshall at end.

title: DEATH DEFYING ACTS' STRESSES LIFE
description: ALTHOUGH seeing classic plays by Shakespeare, Shaw or O'Neill or drama by contemporary masters such as Harold Pinter or Sam Shepard keeps audiences returning to the theaters, it is the new plays making their debuts on nervous energy that keep playwrights coming back. And as the financial problems of Broadway have pushed new American plays into the rear guard, the importance of the regional theater to the continuation of the art form has become paramount.

title: Hoyas Outlast Syracuse
description: Georgetown rallied frequently and frenetically against Syracuse today, forcing the game into overtime and then winning it, 83-81, on a last-second shot.

title: FROM CHINA WITH LOVE
description: IRON & SILK By Mark Salzman. 211 pp. New York: Random House. $16.95.

title: THE RIGHT TACK
description: HUMPHREY BOGART ONCE OBSERVED that he would never trust a man wearing a yachting cap, a reaction that finds parallels even now among yachting's better-known iconoclasts. They include Dennis Conner, the skipper of Stars & Stripes, the United States hope in the America's Cup challenge.

title: DRUNKEN PEANUTS: CRACKING DOWN
description: A ''SORT of Breathalyzer test for peanuts'' was announced by the Federal Department of Agriculture early last year to detect what the department calls drunken peanuts.

title: CONCERTS AT SCHOOLS HIGHLIGHT CALENDAR
description: THE county's halls of learning are frequently our most adventuresome halls of music, a fact well borne out by the concert calendar this week. Let us begin at Manhattanville College in Purchase, where the ''Castle Concerts'' were innaugurated last year.

title: Robert Bradford Browne, 64; Noted as Tropical Architect
description: Robert Bradford Browne, a Miami architect noted for his distinctive designs of tropical homes and buildings in Florida, the Caribbean and Mexico, died Thursday of cancer. He was 64 years old.

title: JAZZ: DONALDSON, SAXOPHONE
description: LOU DONALDSON, the alto saxophonist leading a quartet at Carlos 1 through tonight, is in several respects a remarkable parallel to Don Redman, the brilliant arranger and composer widely credited with inventing big-band jazz when he began writing for Fletcher Henderson's orchestra in 1923.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Vote 'yes' for the new constitution, and the next time maybe my mom will sing for you.'' - Kris Aquino. [ 3:3. ]

title: Children And Divorce
description: It came as no surprise to me, as a marriage and family therapist, that a teen-ager whose mother married, divorced, remarried , divorced and again remarried would never plan to marry (''One Son, Three Fathers,'' by Steven O'Brien, About Men, Dec. 28).

title: A SEA SO GREAT, A RAFT SO SMALL
description: NARRATIVE OF A VOYAGE TO SENEGAL By J. B. Henry Savigny and Alexander Correard. 200 pp. Vermont: The Marlboro Press. Paper, $11.50.

title: OLD ALLIES STILL TALK OF A TRADE WAR
description: A BATTLE over trade between the United States and Western Europe was averted last week but the specter of a war was not banished. In a burst of telephone negotiations with Washington, European Community officials agreed to compensate American farmers for lost markets arising from import duties imposed when Spain joined the Common Market last year.

title: JAIL BY MISTAKE FOR FEMALE ALCOHOLICS
description: Since 1973, scores of alcoholic women who were legally entitled to receive care from the state have instead been jailed with criminals, state officials recently acknowledged.

title: Judge Orders California Murder Trial to Begin
description: The judge in a trial involving a group of rich young men has denied a motion to dismiss a murder charge against the group's leader and has ordered the trial to begin Monday.

title: Mary McCarthy, Account Executive, To Become Bride of Didier Devynck
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Jordon McCarthy of Baltimore have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Sue McCarthy, to Didier Devynck, the son of Odette Devynck of Lille, France, and the late Antoine Devynck. A May wedding is planned.

title: PEACE IS LIFE WORK OF SCARSDALE MAN
description: LEAD: ON an afternoon in early August more than 40 years ago, Wilbur H. Ferry abruptly left his midtown Manhattan public-relations office and wandered to the edge of the Hudson River. He remembers staring at the water for a long time and feeling ''consumed by very deep shame.'' The United States had just dropped the atomic bomb on Hiroshima, killing more than 100,000 people.

title: FOR FORMER ATHLETES, DINNER AND NOSTALGIA
description: IT was a touching moment and evoked a huge ovation. Chico Vejar and Charles P. Davey, the two former college boxers who pounded away at each other during two nationally televised welterweight bouts in 1952, embraced emotionally on the dais at the Italian Center in Stamford on Jan. 19.

title: TAXES DOMINATE THE ISSUES IN TRENTON
description: WHEN Governor Kean and the Legislature created a commission to study state taxes and spending, they agreed to push the reporting date back until next year, a move designed to keep tax issues out of the current legislative election year.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Jan. 11 on the Hotel Bel-Air in Los Angeles misstated its opening date. The hotel was opened in 1941.

title: New Rules for Emergency Care
description: The service that operates New York City's emergency ambulance system said last week that all 43 hospitals in the system would soon be required to maintain fully trained physicians on emergency-room duty around the clock. The announcement followed a series of deaths in recent years that have been blamed on mistakes by poorly supervised interns and residents.

title: Headliners; Victory in Court
description: J.D. Salinger, who is famous for loathing fame, has won a decisive round in a court fight to keep some of his private letters private. A Federal appeals court in Manhattan last week reversed a lower court ruling and blocked the publication of a book that the court said unfairly used some of Mr. Salinger's unpublished letters.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Galena, Ill.; The Right Mix For Tourism
description: THIS Mississippi River town of 4,000, best known as the birthplace of Gen.

title: UNTIL NEXT YEAR
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: BLACK HISTORY EVENTS SET
description: LEAD: A VARIETY of events in art, music and theater will take place throughout the state as New Jersey commemorates Black History Month.

title: DID THE SUPER BOWL LIVE UP TO THE HYPE?
description: The Game is almost an afterthought. How could any event hold up after 14 days of overstrecthing? The Super Bowl should be played one week fter the N.F.C. and A.F.C. championship games. George Arvanitakis Bronx

title: Jersey Officer Seized in Raid
description: A correction officer from Newark, Rodney Pollard, and three other adults were arrested on weapons and drug charges yesterday in a raid on a Harlem apartment that is the center of an investigation of prostitution involving teen-age boys, the police said. Three boys, two of them 15 years old and one 16, were found in the apartment, at 67 Saint Nicholas Avenue, said a police spokesman, Capt. Edward T. Minogue. Cocaine and heroin were also found, as were a submachine gun, a 12-gauge shotgun and a pellet rifle.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: Imports From Ireland And Other Parts Irish Imports in the Scotts Corners area of Pound Ridge - about 23 miles northeast of White Plains - has marked down by 20 to 70 percent many styles of sweaters, coats, capes, crocheted and wool dresses and suits, men's tweed jackets and sportshirts and Australian Outback Clothing.

title: SALVADOR AIR RAID REPORTED IN TOWN
description: The Salvadoran Air Force killed seven civilians in bombing and strafing runs near an isolated peasant village last week, according to accounts from local inhabitants and a videotape of the bombed site.

title: Chrysler to Drop Its 'Amerika' Ads
description: Even before ABC's mini-series ''Amerika'' had begun production, powerful foes were trying to keep it off the air. In 1985, the Kremlin warned ABC's Moscow bureau of possible reprisals if the show ran.

title: MARKETING REAL ESTATE WITH ART
description: BENJAMIN D. Holloway and his colleagues surprised others in the real estate industry a few years ago when they proposed moving the headquarters of their company, the Equitable Life Assurance Society, to a place where no major corporation had gone before - Seventh Avenue in midtown Manhattan.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Warms to Poland A United States official said after three days of talks with Polish leaders that ''we are clearly on a course of improving our relations.'' Page 6. Farewell to People Express Looking back with nostalgia, People Express workers flew their final flights before the company's absorption by Continental Airlines. Page 34.

title: Karl May and Wagner
description: To the Editor:

title: Glasnost And the Churl
description: A certain unwonted sensation, akin I regret to say to churlishness, creeps over me from time to time these days, traceable directly to an overdose of glasnost. Glasnost, we all know, is a Russian word that has entered the English language and is translatable as ''opening.'' It is used to describe the changes Mr. Gorbachev says he is bringing to Soviet society.

title: HOW STATE COPES WITH SNOWSTORMS
description: ALTHOUGH little is certain when it comes to weather, New Jersey generally is said to be coping better with winter storms these days because of more-sophisticated forecasting, better communications and specific plans for handling emergencies.

title: STAMFORD TEEN-AGERS LEARN ABOUT MARRIAGE
description: ABOUT 40 students from Stamford High School filed into the city's Superior Court one recent day to witness a divorce trial.

title: Study in Japan
description: In search of a clearer vision of America, Edmund G. Brown Jr. is checking out the view from Japan. The former California Governor, now 48 years old, said in an interview last week that he came to Japan in August to study Zen meditation and complete a book that he attempted to start writing in Los Angeles.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: 2 SOLOISTS IN PRINCETON A cellist and a clarinetist will be soloists with the Chamber Symphony of Princeton at 3 P.M. today in Richardson Auditorium on the Princeton University campus.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
ADVICE ON AIDS
description: LEAD: In an effort to provide information about current practices in the care of patients with AIDS and about the spread of the disease, two nationally recognized AIDS experts will address residents of the county at 8 P.M. Feb. 10 in the Rye High School auditorium.

title: DESCARTES, NIETZSCHE AND THE SEARCH FOR THE UNSAYABLE
description: FEW lines have more effectively caught the chill of modernity than the conclusion of Wallace Stevens' poem ''The Snow Man:'' ''For the listener, who listens in the snow, / And, nothing himself, beholds / Nothing that is not there and the nothing that is.'' Plagued by the suspicion that we are nothing and haunted by the dread that nothing remains nothing, many regard our epoch as a post age. Postindustrial, postcapitalist, postliberal, posttheological, posthumanist - these posts join in the description of our condition as postmodern. In the postmodern era, God is dead; art is exhausted; philosophy is finished; literature is merely preserved. In Yeats's words, ''Things fall apart; the center cannot hold; / Mere anarchy is loosed upon the world.'' This anarchy is not merely an intellectual matter. Families are torn by violence, cities plagued by crime and countries paralyzed by terrorism. In the absence of stable foundations, global holocaust seems more than an apocalyptic fantasy. Where did modernity go wrong?

title: WAYWARD SCIENTIST ON THE MOVE
description: THE DEFECTOR By Howard Reynolds. 328 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

title: KNICKS WASTE CHANCE IN FINAL SECONDS
description: Some coaches rely on strategy and percentages in the waning seconds when a game is in the balance. Bob Hill says he coaches by ''feel,'' relying on instinct and intuition instead.

title: Signals on 1988: Panel and Polls
description: In the strongest hint so far that he might run for President, Governor Cuomo last week named a panel of corporate chairmen, investment bankers, labor leaders and professors to advise him on the economy.

title: Westhchester Opinion; INEXPLICABLE RECOGNITION: 'IT'S AN EAGLE! AN EAGLE!
description: ''OH, my God,'' exclaimed my 14-year old son, Dutch, using his strongest allowable expletive for around the house. What he uses elsewhere I can't vouch for. ''It's an eagle!'' We were watching the Giants-Redskins game, which had been much touted; I, casually, mainly reading The New York Times Magazine; he, the football player of the family, intently. He had evidently caught the object of his exclamation out of the corner of his eye, through the family-room window.

title: THE HOCKEY ROAD LEADS FROM 'MITES' TO 'MIDGETS'
description: LEAD: AS THEY swarm over the ice at the Mennen Sports Arena here, undaunted by frequent spills, it is all but impossible to tell the hockey players apart.

title: WINSTON-SALEM SADDENED BY REYNOLDS SHIFT
description: The announcement two weeks ago thatthe R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company's parent corporation, RJR Nabisco Inc., would move its corporate headquarters to Atlanta has saddened this cigarette-producing city.

title: LAMENT FOR THE MERRYING OF ENGLAND
description: COASTING By Jonathan Raban. 302 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: A SERIES CONTINUES
description: The United States Postal Service released the 1987 Love stamp last Friday in ceremonies that featured singer Tony Bennett. It went on sale yesterday and is just in time for use with Valentine's Day cards. This latest design should be one of the most popular in this strong-selling series.

title: CUBA'S STRANGE MISSION IN ANGOLA
description: FEW MILES NORTH OF THE CONGO River, the sun is sinking into the South Atlantic. Standing in miniature silhouettes against the orange glow are the palm trees and American-operated oil wells of the Cabinda coast, in Angola's northernmost province. While we watch the sunset, a man speaks to me in the rising and falling rhythms of Caribbean-accented Spanish.

title: Congress Moves To Settle the L.I.R.R. Strike
description: After 11 days on the picket line, 6,600 Long Island Rail Road employees were back at work early Saturday morning, but not before their grievances had seized the attention of 110,000 commuters, New York State's top elected officials, the Congress and President Reagan.

title:
GARDENING;
CLIMATE AND DORMANCY REQUIREMENTS
description: LEAD: ONE is always a bit hesitant to bring up a subject such as the mildness of winter. Like washing one's car only to have it rain, bragging on the weather often seems to trigger a blizzard, heat wave or some other undesirable phenomenon. Nevertheless, the winter has been relatively mild overall, and the plants in our garden show the effects of that mildness.

title: Maine Workers Feel Insurance Rate Squeeze
description: Under the best conditions, logging is a hazardous way to make a living. But these days many Maine logging concerns are taking additional risks by not carrying workers' compensation insurance, which pays for medical care and provides workers a portion of their wages while they recover from injuries received on the job.

title: Dee MacLeod Married To R. H. Lawrence Jr.
description: Dee Elizabeth MacLeod, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick L. MacLeod of Winter Park, Fla., was married yesterday to Richard H. Lawrence Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence of Mount Kisco, N.Y. The Episcopal ceremony was performed by the Rev. Herbert Barrett in the chapel at Overlook Farm, the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: GURNEY'S 'CHILDREN' IN HARTFORD
description: IS it possible to speak of A. R. Gurney Jr. without adding that he is the theater's acknowledged chronicler of contemporary WASP culture and one of our most prolific and oft-produced playwrights?

title: 7-Year Warranty at Chrysler
description: The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it would extend its warranty on the power train of all its domestically made cars and trucks from five years and 50,000 miles to seven years and 70,000 miles. The action by Chrysler, which had been expected, gives the company the longest warranty of any domestic manufacturer.

title:
FILM;
BERTOLUCCI BRINGS BACK IMPERIAL CHINA
description: LEAD: The crowds of Chinese tourists visiting Beijing's Forbidden City were startled, mystified and no doubt entertained to see what appeared to be a temporary restoration of their Imperial past. Ancient Manchu ceremonies were being re-enacted before them by hundreds of elaborately costumed courtiers with long plaited queues as if 20 years of civil turmoil, the Japanese war, the Chiang Kai-shek years and the coming of Mao Tse-tung's People's

title: NONFICTION: IN SHORT
description: LEAD: FIRST ON EVEREST: The Mystery of Mallory and Irvine. By Tom Holzel and Audrey Salkeld. (Henry Holt, $19.95.) When Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay climbed to the summit of Mount Everest in 1953, the world celebrated their feat. Everest, the world's highest peak, had been the scene of at least seven earlier expeditions that failed.

title: AQUINO CAMPAIGNS FOR CHARTER WITH NEW HOOPLA
description: ''Vote 'yes' for the new constitution,'' the President's daughter Kris said at a campaign rally not long ago, ''and the next time maybe my mom will sing for you.''

title: COLOR AND THREAD: A VIBRANT INTERACTION
description: THE vibrancy of color that results from the intersection of threads of different hues is one of the most seductive characteristics of textiles.

title: ACTORS LEND VOICES TO SERIES OF SHORT-STORY READINGS AT SYMPHONY SPACE
description: THERE is no set, just a small red rug and a comfortable armchair. No props - just a carafe of drinking water and a microphone. Dress is casual, and tickets are under $10.

title: Molly Welch to Marry Bronson Hager
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Welch of Barneveld, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Cecelia Welch to Bronson Q. Hager, a son of Mrs. Andrew D. Hart Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late Peter A. Hager of Short Hills, N.J. A July wedding is planned.

title: KUWAIT ARRESTS 11 IN OILFIELD BLASTS
description: The Kuwaiti authorities said today that they had arrested 11 men for bombing the emirate's oil installations on the eve of the Islamic summit conference held here this week.

title: THE CHANCELLOR SENDS A MESSAGE
description: SIX weeks ago Robert F. Wagner Jr., president of the city's central Board of Education, complained of politics and patronage in the community school boards and proposed that they be relieved of some of their authority. Now, on two occasions in two weeks, the Schools Chancellor has moved to do just that.

title: THE LIFE BELOW THE GROUND
description: SUBWAY (Aperture, $29.95) by the photographer Bruce Davidson offers a vivid diary of the people who enter this dimmed, often hostile arena. There are pictures of proud young mothers and children, weary businessmen, despairing bag people, menacing young men, and passionate couples embracing. In most cases the sitters are fully aware of being photographed and yet the confines of the train prevents them from donning the mask one ordinarily sees in posed pictures. Through his deft use of light, Mr. Davidson, the author also of ''East 100th Street,'' reveals more color and texture than one expects to find in these seamy, graffiti-riddled environs. He encourages the eye to concentrate on specific details by using a hand-held flash to illuminate the subject. The background falls away into darkness, enhancing the immediacy and intimacy of the photographs. There is a tension in these pictures, as could be predicted of subjects stalked on the subway by a photographer. The least successful are those that border on sensationalism - a crazed bag lady lifting her skirt or an undercover policeman holding a gun to a mugger's head. The strength of the book is in the photographs in which Mr. Davidson conveys his compassion for the individuals who ride New York City's subways.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THE American Birding Association has named a New Jerseyan as executive director and is moving its executive offices here, at least temporarily.
