title: IRELAND HAS HER MADNESS STILL
description: NO COUNTRY FOR YOUNG MEN By Julia O'Faolain. 369 pp. New York: Carroll & Graf. $19.50.

title: LITERACY PROGRAM TARGETS ELDERLY
description: BECAUSE of the snow last week, 76-year-old Beatrice Taylor's weekly reading lesson with Alice Wiggins, a local public-school teacher and her tutor in a public literacy project here, was postponed.

title: IKE, ROCK AND HISTORY
description: AMERICAN HIGH The Years of Confidence, 1945-1960. By William L. O'Neill. Illustrated. 321 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95.

title: Tightening State's Grip on Housing
description: AT first blush, those familiar with the workings of the state-run rent-control system during and after World War II may think they recognize a familiar beast taking shape in the Cuomo's administration's proposed reform of the rent-regulation systems.

title:
FOCUS: San Francisco;
Pressure On Rental Apartments
description: LEAD: A FEW years ago, this city's supply of affordable rental housing was endangered by a condominium-conversion boom. The problem was apparently alleviated when the condominium market softened and the city imposed yearly limits on conversions.

title: Shultz Talks With Tambo of A.N.C.
description: President Reagan condemned the African National Congress during the debate on sanctions in July for ''acts of terrorism inside South Africa.'' But, the next day, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said he would be willing to meet with the group's leader, Oliver Tambo. That meeting took place last week at the State Department, signaling American willingness to recognize Mr. Tambo and his organization as leading players in the South African drama.

title: India and Pakistan Open Talks on Border Tension
description: India and Pakistan began high-level talks here today aimed at easing mutual tensions, but neither side appeared willing to halt large troop movements along the border that have spread alarm in both countries in the last two weeks.

title: Trident II Dangers
description: To the Editor:

title: August Wedding For Elise Nagler
description: The engagement of Elise Gallaudet Nagler to Ronald Wayne Barrett has been announced by her parents, Elizabeth Gallaudet Gillen Nagler of Valley Stream, L.I., and Lawrence Nagler of Los Angeles. An August wedding is planned. Her fiance is a son of Sharon Wilson Barrett of Cupertino, Calif., and Clifford A. Barrett of Scotts Valley, Calif.

title: Relics of an Age of Crime Enjoy New Life As Art Objects
description: THIS COLLECTION OF PHOTOgraphs, from crime magazines and newspapers of the late 1920's and early 30's, will be exhibited, beginning Tuesday, at Manhattan's Pace/MacGill Gallery. The faces of crime were -and remain - grist for tabloid journalism, and they are shown here with the retouching marks and directions of the original editors, who often enhanced their pictures' visual impact. Publications used to have entire departments to work on photographs.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: THE union wasn't made in heaven, and it's never been blessed by judge or preacher, but divorce is highly unlikely. This is love, true love, deep, abiding, forever love. It cannot be torn asunder by gossip and wicked innuendo. So what if there's some flaking off at inopportune moments, and occasional willfullness, and little, and even big, tantrums. It's all forgiven and forgotten the moment the object of affection decides to smile again.

title: Streaking at Princeton Celebrates a Snowfall
description: Streaking made its annual appearance at Princeton University this month as a group of sophomores marked the first snowfall of the winter.

title: Whatever Happened to Drive-In Movies?
description: AS land gets more valuable in Westchester, low-profit uses are disappearing.

title: FICTION: IN SHORT
description: GHOSTLY POPULATIONS. By Jack Matthews. (Johns Hopkins University, $14.95.) Children tell two kinds of tales: ghost stories and jokes. As they get older the jokes get dirtier and the ghosts are forgotten. But Jack Matthews gives the impression ''of a man listening to his childhood.'' Like the narrator of his title story, he is a collector of ghost stories, and his characters mutter old riddles as though they're mantras - ''What has four wheels, hemorrhoids, and a dream?'' Mr. Matthews's ''ghostly populations'' sit hunched over the haunted puzzles of their past. Old men take cabs to neighborhoods where they haven't lived for years; younger men scan telephone books for the numbers of former lovers; a couple wanders from resort to resort looking for the screened porch over the lake that is ''set like a fishhook'' in the mind. They travel in what one character jokingly calls ''the bush country of memory,'' and more often than not the country is the American Middle West. Still discernible under the shopping malls and subdivisions is an earlier, pastoral landscape; one can ''stand there in the dirty light of evening and stare out upon the pastel-colored ranch houses, occupying a land that was once covered with oak, beech, and hickory, and populated by foxes and squirrels.'' Some of Mr. Matthews's most effective stories hover in this wistful mood, but he has another way of evoking the lost countryside. He assumes the voices of earlier denizens: turn-of-the-century gunsmiths and Bible college students and foremen of Chinese work gangs. They talk in a tall-tale vernacular, laced with good jokes and bad, but with a postmodern twist. One man is described as ''pale as a corpse, phthisic and thin, but straight as a hoe handle.'' These modern ghost stories (by the novelist and story writer whose last collection was ''Crazy Women'') won't scare your pants off; they will tickle those regions of the mind that still itch for the uncanny.

title: CBS News In Search of Itself
description: I do not think that CBS News has to apologize for itself or to search for itself. Dan Rather - ''the bulldog reporter,'' as you call him -has the right instincts to keep CBS News in the proud tradition of Murrow and Cronkite. Anyone who survived Vietnam, Afghanistan and the 1968 Democratic National Convention ought to be able to handle those corporate intrigues quite well.

title: NEW TROUPE PICKS 'MIKADO' FOR DEBUT
description: IN a variation of the Andy Hardy-type scenario in which Mickey Rooney said to Judy Garland, ''Let's put on a show,'' Matthew Parent once said to Jerald Smith-Niles, ''Let's start a theater.''

title: Rio de Janeiro
description: For a long time, Rio de Janeiro has been popping up as the exotic backdrop of movies, wicked novels and midwinter fantasy. But it remained largely in the background rather than figuring prominently in the routes of frequent travelers to the sun. There was good reason. Five thousand miles - from New York to Rio de Janeiro - is a long way to go for fine weather. Stiff air fares added to the discouragement. Diplomats and business people traveling in Latin America have long known how to mold their schedules around weekends in Rio, but tourists usually crowded the city only during the pre-Lenten carnival.

title: SHE SUED TO CONQUER
description: GIOVANNI AND LUSANNA Love and Marriage in Renaissance Florence. By Gene Brucker. Illustrated. 138 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $15.95.

title: NONFICTION: IN SHORT
description: THE FINANCING OF TERROR. By James Adams. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) With an estimated $5 billion in assets and an annual income of $500 million, the Palestine Liberation Organization's gold, stocks, money-market certificates and Swiss bank accounts are the envy of many major multinational corporations. As James Adams, a correspondent of The Sunday Times of London, shows, this wealthiest of terrorist groups is not state-financed, though Arab countries provided most of the start-up capital. Such self-sufficiency, characteristic of the major terrorist groups today, has been disregarded by target countries, whose counterterrorist programs have focused almost exclusively on preventing attacks or resolving them once they happen, rather than on cutting off terrorists' financial support. Mr. Adams does not suggest how this can be done, but amply demonstrates the resources these organizations have. The I.R.A.'s annual budget of $7 million is financed in part by protection rackets in Northern Ireland, with only $200,000 coming from the Irish Northern Aid (Noraid) group in the United States. Mr. Adams credits the United States with prosecuting Noraid's arms trafficking, but the I.R.A. now relies on Common Market smuggling scams, tax fraud, robberies, gambling, extortion and legitimate front operations - with little British or Irish hindrance. The I.R.A.'s economic clout in Northern Ireland is so great that the author asserts it is impossible to eliminate. The lesson for government policy makers, Mr. Adams concludes, is that today's terrorists have become ''better capitalists,'' who manage their own portfolios.

title: Margot Ross Engaged To Paul A. Kunkel 3d
description: Margot Treman Ross and Paul Augustine Kunkel 3d plan to be married in the summer. Their engagement has been announced by her parents, Mrs. Joseph Hill Williams of Tulsa, Okla., and Llewellyn Gerard Ross of New York. Mr. Kunkel is a son of Dr. and Mrs. William Minster Kunkel of Harrisburg, Pa.

title: GETTING A NEW PERSPECTIVE ON STRANDED MOTORISTS
description: HOW many times have you slowed down your car to stretch your neck for a look at a stranded driver and then continued about your business, shaking your head and muttering to yourself, ''Poor guy''?

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: LEAD: JUMP! The Adventures of Brer Rabbit. By Joel Chandler Harris. Adapted by Van Dyke Parks and Malcolm Jones. Illustrated by Barry Moser. 40 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $14.95. (Ages 5 and up)

title: COMEDY ON WRY AND SOME KIPPERS
description: Jack Levine: Feast of Pure Reason Produced by David Sutherland Home Vision 58 minutes. $39.95

title: TRUTH BY INVENTION
description: THE MAGICIAN'S GIRL By Doris Grumbach. 200 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $16.95.

title: VIETNAMESE CELEBRATE TRADITIONAL NEW YEAR
description: Hundreds of Vietnamese gathered joyously yesterday at Public School 124 in Chinatown to celebrate Tet -or the lunar new year - and call for freedom for Vietnam.

title: Recent Sales
description: Larchmont, N.Y. $335,000 15 Concord Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 62-year-old Tudor/ Norman; eat-in kitchen, walk to station, beach rights; taxes $4,762. Putnam Valley $346,000 Lake Oscawana 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 81-year-old stone/frame colonial; eat-in kitchen, deck, dock; taxes $3,758. Scarsdale, N.Y. $237,500 63 Lee Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 76-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, study; taxes $2,270. Madison, Conn. $276,500 370 Horse Pond Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, new Cape Cod; dining room; master-bedroom suite with sitting room, 1 acre; taxes not yet available. Milford, Conn. $147,000 36 Grapevine Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 33-year-old ranch; 2-car garage, family room in basement; taxes $1,333. Wallingford, Conn. $189,900 67 Colonial Hill Drive 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 2-year-old condominium; rural setting, 2-car garage; taxes $2,018. OTHER AREAS West Orange, N.J. $325,000 420 Mount Pleasant Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 32-year-old colonial; den, patio, formal dining room, 2-car attached garage; taxes $5,327. Hauppauge, L.I. $175,000 3 Del Place 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 24-year-old high ranch; eat-in kitchen, laundry room, central A/C, deck, 1-car garage; taxes $3,900. Kings Park, L.I. $208,000 176 Avenue B 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 12-year-old colonial; den, fireplace, deck; taxes $3,300.

title: HUNGER AND BRUISES, AND A CHILD'S HOPE
description: In 1985 the Human Resources Administration's Department of Special Services for Children put together a book, ''Two Hands,'' described in its subtitle as ''a collection of writing and art work created by human beings under the age of 21 who happen to live within the foster care system of the City of New York.'' It was edited by Eileen Shukofsky Randig, who added in a note that most of the material had been gathered from foster children in group care.

title: Select Company
description: JOSHUA WESSON KNELT last year in a French casino watching the approach of a man armed with a sword, a gnarled stick and a silver goblet. ''I didn't know which way I was going to die - run through, conked or poisoned,'' Mr. Wesson recalls. Instead, in a ceremony attended by Dustin Hoffman and several other Hollywood notables, he was knighted by La Commanderies des Cotes du Rhone, the prestigious wine society. It was a reward for winning the French Wine and Spirits Sommelier Competition in America.

title: THE 'MASK MAN' OF BETHLEHEM
description: LEAD: FROM a darkened stage, an eerie assemblage of faces stares out silently into the audience: a placid Buddha, a robotic blockhead with rectangular features, wizened old men and reptilian creatures. It is only with the appearance on stage of Robert Faust, a tall, black-clad figure who calls himself the Mask

title: RUNNING INTO HEAVY TRAFFIC
description: GONE are the days when Americans snatched up Japanese cars almost as fast as they came into the showroom. Today, with the rapid run-up of the yen against the dollar, prices are climbing, inventories of have been growing and profits for some companies have suffered. So, for many Japanese auto makers, the Tokyo Government's decision last week to continue its curbs on automobile exports to the United States for a seventh year was met with resignation, not irritation.

title: Irish Guerrilla Leader's Wife Slain in Attack on Her Home
description: Two gunmen burst into the home of a jailed Irish republican guerrilla leader tonight, killing the man's wife as she was bathing her two children, the police said.

title:
GARDENING;
CLIMATE AND DORMANCY REQUIREMENTS
description: LEAD: ONE is always a bit hesitant to bring up a subject such as the mildness of winter. Like washing one's car only to have it rain, bragging on the weather often seems to trigger a blizzard, heat wave or some other undesirable phenomenon. Nevertheless, the winter has been relatively mild overall, and the plants in our garden show the effects of that mildness.

title: MARKETING REAL ESTATE WITH ART
description: SCRATCH a real estate developer and you are likely to find an exhibitionist.

title: JENNIFER WENTZEL ENGAGED TO WED EXECUTIVE IN JULY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan R. Wentzel of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Lee Wentzel to Charles Frederick Gulden, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Gulden Jr. of Rye, N.Y. A July wedding is planned.

title: Today's Sports
description: Basketball Nets vs. Golden State Warriors At Oakland, Calif., 5 P.M. Television SportsChannel 5 P.M. Radio WNEW 1130, 5 P.M. Hawks vs. Houston Rockets At Atlanta, 1 P.M. Television Channel 2, 1 P.M. College Columbia at Dartmouth, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WKCR FM 89.9, 7:30 P.M. North Carolina at Notre Dame, 1 P.M. Television Channel 4, 1 P.M. Rhode Island at Penn State, 4 P.M. Television MSG, 4 P.M. Seton Hall at Boston College, 2 P.M. Radio WNEW 1130 and WSOU FM 89.5, 2 P.M. Nevada-Las Vegas at Auburn, 2 P.M. Television Channel 7, 2 P.M. Football Pro Bowl A.F.C. vs. N.F.C. At Honolulu, 4 P.M. Television Channel 7, 4 P.M. Golf A.T. & T. Pebble Beach National Pro-Am At Pebble Beach, Calif. Television Channel 2, 3:30 P.M. LPGA: Mazda Classic At Boca Raton, Fla. Television ESPN, 1 P.M. Hockey Rangers vs. Boston Bruins At Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. Television MSG, 7 P.M. Radio WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M. Yachting America's Cup Television Channel 7 tape of second race, at halftime of Pro Bowl. ESPN, third race, 11 P.M. Other Events Boxing Michael Olajide vs. Don Lee middleweights, 10 rounds Television Channel 4, 3 P.M. Harness Racing At Roosevelt, 7:30 P.M. Soccer M.I.S.L. Wichita at St. Louis Television ESPN, 3 P.M. Thoroughbred Racing At Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. Television SportsChannel, 6:30 and 11 P.M., taped. Track P.S.A.L. Meet At 168th Street Armory, 9 A.M.

title: COMEDY ACTRESS PARODIES 50's-STYLE TV
description: ACCORDING to her resume, the fictitious Miss Vicki Oberjeune became a movie star as a child - ''many moons ago'' - in ''X Marks the Spot,'' a tap-dancing musical comedy about ''a young teen-ager and her love for her dog, Spot.''

title: OLD MILL TO BE TEXTILE MUSEUM
description: WHEN the American Thread Company shut down its Windham mill in 1985, it marked the end of the town's once-thriving textile industry.

title: INQUIRIES ON IRAN FACE 3 QUESTIONS
description: Now that the Senate Intelligence Committee report on the Iran-contra affair is complete, the senators and representatives who will continue investigating the matter say they still face three broad unanswered questions.

title: Photo of Jean Gordon (Bachrach) Jean Gordon Plans to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jeremy Gordon of Short Hills, N.J., and Bridgehampton, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Jean Auchincloss Gordon, to Dwight Earle Vicks 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Vicks Jr. of Utica, N.Y.

title:
GARDENING;
CLIMATE AND DORMANCY REQUIREMENTS
description: LEAD: ONE is always a bit hesitant to bring up a subject such as the mildness of winter. Like washing one's car only to have it rain, bragging on the weather often seems to trigger a blizzard, heat wave or some other undesirable phenomenon. Nevertheless, the winter has been relatively mild overall, and the plants in our garden show the effects of that mildness.

title: GIANTS FETE IS CALLED A SUCCESS
description: WHILE thousands of football fans celebrated at Giants Stadium here last Tuesday, a group of NJ Transit and Bergen County police officials huddled in a mobile command post in Hasbrouck Heights, watching traffic movements as well as the homecoming ceremonies.

title: WINTER: GEOGRAPHY IS DESTINY
description: AS major snowstorms slammed into Long Island late last month, many Long Islanders were probably asking themselves, ''Why me?'' The answer is not in our stars, but in our geography.

title: RANGERS TAME FLYERS
description: One Flyer flipped an opposing player on his back. Another Flyer sent a player sprawling with one punch. This was only the between-periods highlight film at the Spectrum, and the strategy worked perfectly. On tape, the Flyers towered over everyone.

title: Ellen Podell Wed To Daniel Crown
description: The marriage of Ellen T. Podell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram L. Podell of New York, to Daniel M. Crown, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Crown of Chicago, took place last evening at the Pierre Hotel. Rabbi Gerson D. Cohen, chancellor emeritus of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, officiated.

title: Deception Charged on Choosing Sex of Babies
description: The Food and Drug Administration has called a company's contentions that its Gender Choice kit can help couples choose the sex of babies a ''gross deception of the consumer.''

title: PROVOCATIVE SHOW RETHINKS BRITISH ART OF THE 20TH CENTURY
description: Our century began, and seems likely to end, with huge exhibitions of a provocative, revisionist and revelatory sort. We remember, in that context, the Armory Show of 1913 in New York and Chicago. We read about the Allied Artists International Exhibition of new art in 1908 in the Royal Albert Hall in London, which had 3,061 items in the catalogue, plus an auxiliary last-minute section from Russia. We think of the great exhibitions in Munich and Berlin before World War I that were marked by a cosmopolitanism and a freedom from prejudice that were soon to be banished from the earth.

title: STATE PANEL NAMED TO REVIEW A PROPOSED PCB BURIAL SITE
description: A long-delayed plan to dredge PCB-laden sediment from the Hudson River moved forward this week when Governor Cuomo named an eight-member board to review a proposed site for burial of the sediment.

title: All Right, Let's Keep It Clean
description: BY the end of January I have usually managed to tackle at last some of the chores that I had resolved to clear away for the new year. High on that list of thankless, postponed tasks is a bit of computer maintenance. I am not talking about changing the ribbon on my printer, nor am I referring to such basic upkeep as standardizing the labeling system for my floppies. No, what I am addressing here is the application of a little elbow grease.

title: IN FALLS VILLAGE CHEESE IS FRESH FROM THE FARM
description: THE cupboard is not bare, but the inventory is certainly down. The herbed cheese is gone, including the nettle, which Mark Burdick was not sure would be popular in Litchfield County but ''got snapped right up,'' he said. Nearby, a new batch of nettle cheese sits, slowly aging. But the cheese can not be rushed. Cheesemaking is a patient science, and Mr. Burdick is learning to be a patient man.

title: AID TO HOMELESS 'MOST IN NEED'
description: THREE Franciscan priests who had set up two permanent homes in Manhattan for the street people they called ''most in need'' - the mentally disabled - received unexpected help last year in their effort to establish a third such residence.

title: WHAT WE NEED
description: Excerpt from ''Today's American: A Complex Challenge'' by Max M. Kampelman, chief United States negotiator at the arms talks in Geneva, published in a new collection of essays written to mark the 45th anniversary of Freedom House, formed to support democratic principles:

title: STEELWORKERS RATIFY USX PACT, ENDING STOPPAGE
description: The United Steelworkers union ratified a contract with the USX Corporation, the nation's biggest steelmaker, that will further erode their wages, union officials said today.

title: NONFICTION: IN SHORT
description: LEAD: LILLIAN SMITH: A Southerner Confronting the South. By Anne C. Loveland. (Louisiana State University, $22.50.) Lillian Smith was a prodigious writer from Georgia and an early civil rights activist. Born just over a generation after slavery was abolished, she lived into the 60's - just long enough to see the South, as she put it, ''in thaw.

title: CLASH ON WALDEN RESTORATION
description: A state environmental agency and a conservation group are at odds over plans to restore the heavily trodden banks of Walden Pond, where Henry David Thoreau was inspired to write ''Walden.''

title: IN SULPTURE, STEEL EPICS AND POP ICONS IN TWO SHOWS
description: For some time now, the big subjects of European and American art have been very different. Contemporary German and Italian art offer the United States a sustained meditation on history and the complexity of European culture, and a longing for healing and transformation. The United States offers Europe an intense, deeply obsessive involvement with popular culture, commodification and the communications industry.

title: NEW CLUES TO THE IMMUNE SYSTEM
description: FOR TWO HOURS, THE MALIGNANT white blood cells are held in a plastic bag. A tube channels the cells, which have been bathed in a drug, directly into an ultraviolet radiation field. The rays of light penetrate the diseased blood, activating the drug, which attacks and maims the cells.

title: No Headline
description: LEAD: TO THE DOGS Almost by way of previewing the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show later this month in Manhattan, two Long Island groups of dog fanciers or breeders put their animals on display today. In Uniondale, at the Nassau Coliseum, the Mid-Island Kennel Club holds a match show - that's an American Kennel Club-sanctioned affair that does not give championship points, but employs the same professional judging criteria - from 9 A.M.

title: A CORRECTION
description: An article in the Real Estate section Jan. 18 on the effect of the porters' union contract on commercial rents incorrectly stated the frequency of the rent increases and which aspects of the wage increases would have an effect on rents. The increases are calculated annually, not monthly. The base salary for a porter in Class A commercial buildings is $10.237 and the new contract calls for salary increases of 52.5 cents in the first year, 52.5 cents in the second year, and 50 cents in the third year. Fringe benefits, sometimes factored into the increases, are calculated separately.

title: Do You Like The College 3-Point Basket?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Paula Neely and Stuart Sinclair Marry
description: Paula Morris Neely, a daughter of Mrs. William E. Neely of Rochester and the late Mr. Neely, was married yesterday to Stuart William Sinclair, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eric F. Sinclair of Edinburgh. The Rev. Alison Cheek performed the Episcopal ceremony at Glen Magna, a historic property in Danvers, Mass.

title: WHEN IS BLACK PAINT MORE THAN BLACK PAINT?
description: THE PHILOSOPHICAL DISENFRANCHISEMENT OF ART By Arthur C. Danto. 216 pp. New York: Columbia University Press. $25.

title: While We Talk, SALT II Beats No Treaty at All
description: To the Editor:

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: IT TAKES A HEAP OF livin' not to feel envious when you read about television newspeople making $1.2 million per year. Fortunately, a heap is the precise amount of livin' I have now undergone. As a result, I felt nothing but pity recently upon reading about the bloated paychecks of certain telenews guys and gals.

title: Christmas
description: To the Editor: As Jan Benzel related in ''Holiday Migrations Old and New'' (Travel, Dec. 21), we too stumbled onto a happy solution to the problem of an expanding family at Christmas.

title: Learned Poetry
description: To the Editor:

title: LOSS OF MAPLES WORRIES SUGAR PRODUCERS
description: IN just over a month, maple sugaring season will arrive and Leon Anstett is ready.

title: CONTRIBUTORS TO NEEDIEST NOTE IMAGES
description: ''We look around and see New York coming to resemble Calcutta, with the well-heeled scurrying past the destitute,'' said Katherine Manning and Carey Dunne of Manhattan with their gift of $50 to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. ''We know this is a drop in the bucket, but it's a start, and we hope it helps.''

title: LEGISLATURES WEIGH MATCHING U.S. TAX CODE
description: Efforts by the states to alter their income tax laws in response to changes in the Federal law enacted last year have led to some major political conflicts in state capitals and raised questions about the future of their taxing policies.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: WHITE HOUSE BACKS NEW MODE FOR KEY RESEARCH
description: In an expanded new approach to performing basic research in the United States, the Reagan Administration is sponsoring the development of a set of science and technology centers at universities to spur industrial and technical innovation.

title: AMID TRAGEDY, CONCERN FOR THE CITY'S MOST HELPLESS
description: THE plight of the most helpless New Yorkers -the babies and children who are orphaned, abandoned, neglected, malnourished, molested, beaten and sometimes killed - was emphasized last week in words and numbers that Nanette Dembitz, a former Family Court judge, called ''heartbreaking.''

title: V.A.T. Refunds
description: To the Editor: Your correspondent M. D. Minichiello and others will be pleased to learn that a mechanism does indeed exist in the United States to deal with sterling-denominated V.A.T. refund checks in a simple and inexpensive manner.

title: Susan Laxton Weds
description: Susan Jean Laxton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Arthur Laxton Jr. of Baltimore, was married yesterday to Martin J. Tandler, the son of Hannah Tandler of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Stephen M. Tandler. The ceremony was performed at the Burden Mansion in Manhattan by the Rev. James R. Petty, a minister of the Manhattan Church of Christ. Mrs. Tandler graduated from Drexel University. Mr. Tandler, a graduate of the University of Wisconsin, is president of Tandler Textile Inc. in New York, a textile importing company founded by his parents.

title: How to Narrow the Day Care Gap
description: Query: If there are 135,000 spaces in licensed day care centers, and about a million children whose parents are out of the house all day, what's the result? Answer: The rotten child care situation in New York City - hundreds of thousands of very young New Yorkers in unlicensed, unregulated facilities or, worse, left to take care of themselves.

title: Patricia Brown Weds David Ethan Bronston
description: Patricia Anne Brown, a daughter of Gerald Robert Brown of New York and the late Carole N. Brown, was married yesterday to David Ethan Bronston, the son of Adele S. Bronston of Jamaica Estates, Queens, and Jack E. Bronston of New York. Rabbi Israel Mowshowitz performed the ceremony at the National Arts Club.

title: A Deal for Pancho Villa
description: More than just a bit late, the Performing Arts Annual for 1986 has just been published by the Library of Congress. It is the first of what the library hopes will be yearly publications calling attention to the rich trove of holdings the library has in the performing arts.

title: C.I.A. Is Said to Oust Its Chief in Costa Rica
description: The Central Intelligence Agency is forcing its station chief in Costa Rica to take early retirement, intelligence sources said today.

title: Miriam Shire Becomes Bride of Michael Wien
description: Miriam Shire, an assistant district attorney in Manhattan, and Michael Wien, a partner in the Manhattan law firm Austrian, Lance & Stewart, were married yesterday at Temple Rodeph Sholom in Bridgeport, Conn. Rabbi Israel Stein officiated. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Shire of Bridgeport, and Barbara N. Wien of Stony Brook, L.I., and New York, and the late Sidney Arnold Wien.

title: Swiss Watch Exports
description: The value of Swiss watch exports, affected by the falling dollar, dropped slightly last year after record 1985 figures, even though the number of exported timepieces rose by 6 percent, to 61 million, the industry said Friday. Exports for the year totaled $2.84 billion, down by 1 percent from 1985, according to the federation of Swiss watchmakers.

title: Commercial Credit Completes Roster
description: Sanford I. Weill said he has his top management lineup complete at the Commercial Credit Corporation, the company he is trying to lift by its bootstraps.

title: FAST-LANE CUISINE
description: Like an army, an endurance racing car crew travels on its stomach. Given the quality of most race track fare, it's no wonder the crews often bellyache about it.

title: Washington Watch; Bank Powers And Fed's Role
description: ''I THINK the Fed is coming under immense pressure from the banks, and for some reason it's caving in,'' said Representative Charles E. Schumer.

title: Star Recruiter
description: According to its players, the Harvard hockey team that is ranked second in the nation has but one star. He is not a forward or a defenseman or a goalie. He is not the head coach. He is Ronn Tomassoni, an assistant coach and chief recruiter.

title: PLAN FOR FARM LOANS STUDIED
description: In an effort to bring more money to the nation's farming sector, the Federal Government and industry groups are studying a plan that would enable small agricultural banks to sell billions of dollars in farm mortgages to Wall Street investors, according to officials and bankers.

title: BLACK WOMEN FIND HISTORY IN THE ATTIC
description: One afternoon a few years ago a group of black women showed up in the Lafaytte, Ind., living room of Darlene Clark Hine, a professor of Afro-American history at Purdue University.

title: THEATER'S LEGACY ON TAPE
description: Sitting in a darkened van with nine television screens and five men might not be most people's idea of the best way to see ''Me and My Girl,'' but for Betty Corwin it's kind of thrilling.

title: DANCE: DAMIEN STEVENS
description: THERE are guests who like to entertain - and entertain and entertain - at parties.

title: OLYMPIAN STILL PULLING HER OAR
description: THE Olympic career of Anita DeFrantz began with an invitation. She was walking across the campus of Connecticut College when ''a large man holding a long, thin boat'' stopped her and said she would be ''perfect'' for the sport of rowing.

title: RUSSIAN BACK FROM BEDLAM STILL HEARS SHRIEKS AT NIGHT
description: A week after his release from the Second Moscow Provincial Psychiatric Clinic, Serafim Yevsyukov's muscles still ache so badly he cannot put on his overcoat without help. His fingers tremble slightly, he has lost 25 pounds and he walks with evident discomfort.

title: J. Walter Thompson Picks 8 New Directors
description: The shaken management of the J. Walter Thompson Company, subsidiary of the JWT Group, announced Friday that it had elected eight new directors, enlarging the board. Only two of its 20 seats had been emptied by the discharge of Joseph W. O'Donnell, chairman, and John E. Peters, president.

title: Ballets of Pennsylvania And Milwaukee to Join
description: The Pennsylvania Ballet and the Milwaukee Ballet have agreed to merge into one company that would perform in both places, with its first production scheduled for this fall, officials have announced. The merger is subject to approval by the boards of director of both organizations.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PHOTO ALBUM The Whitney Museum of American Art at Equitable Center is made up of two handsomely grand galleries on the ground floor of the high-rise with the outsize lobby at 787 Seventh Avenue, at 51st Street (554-1113). The exhibitions at this Whitney, as at other Whitneys, central and branch, are meticulously and tastefully mounted and usually have a theme.

title: 2 More Are Killed in Karachi As Riots Continue for 4th Day
description: At least two more people were killed and 50 wounded in daylong clashes between protesters and the police in Karachi today, raising the death toll in four days of rioting to eight, police sources said.

title: 'PLATOON' WINS 2 AWARDS AT GOLDEN GLOBE CEREMONY
description: ''Platoon,'' an intense film about the Vietnam War, won Golden Globe awards Saturday night for the best dramatic movie of 1986 and the best director.

title: Purchasers Say Growth in January Was Strong
description: The economy's rate of growth increased sharply in January, according to a monthly report of the nation's purchasing managers.

title: Reduced Charges Filed In Great Lakes Sinking
description: Administrative charges of navigational mistakes that may have contributed to the sinking of a fishing tug on Lake Michigan last summer have been filed by the Coast Guard against the captain of a Yugoslav freighter and her American pilot.

title: MET OPERA: TANNHAUSER'S NEW CAST
description: THE principal roles in ''Tannhauser'' changed hands Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera. William Johns took the title role and proved himself capable of getting through what may be Wagner's most arduous tenor part with plenty of voice left for the end. Indeed if he had sung the whole role as well as he did the broken-spirited ''Rome Narrative'' in the last act, one would look forward to hearing him again. But the earlier scenes contain different kinds of music - lyrical phrases that he delivered with crude force and approximate accuracy, and vigorously declaimed passages for which he put a harsh, unattractive edge on his sturdy voice. His dramatic involvement was not especially specific, but vigorous, and the voice is a potentially serviceable Wagnerian instrument; one hopes he will strive for a higher standard as he develops in the role.

title: Luiz Bonfa, Guitarist, Returns to New York
description: The Brazilian guitarist Luiz Bonfa slipped into town for his first New York shows in nearly a decade, a four-night engagement through Sunday at Fat Tuesday's. Mr. Bonfa, who composed the score for ''Black Orpheus'' with Antonio Carlos Jobim, is a subtle, masterly guitarist. His first set Thursday was a collection of exquisite miniatures as he carried lightly syncopated melody, harmony and rhythm on the six nylon strings of his classical guitar. Occasionally a bassist and a percussionist played along; they were all but superfluous.

title: CITY MONITORS S.R.O. HOTELS
description: Teams of city building inspectors, police officers and even volunteer citizens patrolled the streets yesterday to insure that no demolition or construction occurred in single-room-occupancy hotels over the weekend when city protection of the hotels lapsed.

title: Bid Spurned By Benequity
description: Benequity Holdings, a California limited partnership concentrating in the real estate business, on Friday called a tender offer for the company inadequate. The Renouf Corporation International, a subsidiary of the Renouf Corporation Australia Ltd., has offered between $28 and $30 a share for 1.5 million shares of Benequity.

title: POSTLEWAIT DEFEATS KING IN A PLAYOFF
description: Kathy Postlewait sank a 6-foot putt for par on the first extra hole today to win the $200,000 Mazda Classic in a sudden-death playoff with Betsy King.

title: BEANPOT BATTLE FOR BOSTON'S BEST TO BEGIN
description: The opening half of one of college hockey's best displays, the Beanpot Tournament, is scheduled for tonight in a sold out and loud Boston Garden. And the pairings are providential: Harvard-Northeastern and Boston College-Boston University.

title: Flat Profits Linked To Weak Economy
description: A weaker economy is largely reponsible for the flat profits being reported by the nation's leading corporations for the fourth quarter of 1986 and for the full year, according to analysts.

title: CONNER WINS SECOND CUP RACE BUT REMAINS WARY
description: Dennis Conner steered Stars & Stripes to victory in the second race of the America's Cup final today, leaving little doubt that the trophy he lost is within reach.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: If Pete Rose is the player with the most hits ever in baseball and Ty Cobb is second, who's third?

title: MINING THE HEAVENS FOR PROSE: SAMPLINGS
description: These excerpts from ''News! From the Naval Observatory'' show Gail S. Cleere's whimsy: GROUNDHOG DAY

title: DEFENSE DOMINATES AS A.F.C. WINS
description: John Elway threw for the game's only touchdown today and Karl Mecklenburg, Elway's teammate from the Denver Broncos, spearheaded a smothering defense to lead the American Conference to a 10-6 victory over the National Conference in the Pro Bowl.

title: CONFERENCE ON DOLLAR POSTPONED
description: The Group of Five leading industrial nations have decided to put off a meeting they were considering to negotiate a solution for the fallen dollar.

title: FINE-TUNING PLANNED FOR GIANT MACHINE
description: The Giants had hardly won Super Bowl XXI last Sunday before the questions came:

title: Captivating Talk About Area Codes
description: THE cute New York Telephone animated advertising that starts today and features the work of Bob Weber, a New Yorker cartoonist, marks a big break for a fledgling Young & Rubicam writer. His name is John Berners, and he is 25 years old. This effort is not only his first television commercials but also his first full campaign.

title: PRISONS OVERCROWDED, FLORIDA MAY HAVE TO BEGIN FREEING CONVICTS
description: Florida will probably have to start letting convicts out of their cells unless something is done quickly to relieve overcrowding in the state prison system.

title: WHO'S THE HEIR APPARANT? IT'S NOT YET APPARENT
description: In the half-dozen city restaurants where the bureaucratic and political elite have breakfast the talk these mornings is of little else but the selection of Mexico's next President.

title: Washington Watch; New S.E.C. Bid Date on Edgar
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has once again extended the deadline it set for receiving final bids on its electronic filing and retrieval system, known as Edgar.

title: DOCTORS FAULTED IN PATIENT DEATH AT STATE CENTER
description: The medical director of the Manhattan Psychiatric Center on Wards Island said yesterday that two emergency room physicians had ''grossly mishandled'' the case of a patient who fell seriously ill and died in December after being treated only with a painkiller.

title: Bail-Law Decision Can Halt Some Abuses
description: To the Editor:

title: MCENROE'S CHALLENGE: REGAINING NO. 1
description: HE tossed his racquet in mock anger, whacked a tennis ball into the stands so a fan might have a souvenir, signed autographs between games, then playfully crawled under a table near the umpire's chair to hide when the number of autograph- seekers quickly multiplied.

title: KEAN FACES OPPOSITION TO INCREASED SPENDING
description: Governor Kean may have to calm ruffled feelings among some Democratic leaders and convince members of his own Republican Party that he is not spending too freely when he presents his $10.1 billion state budget to the Legislature on Monday.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE FITZGERALDS AND THE KENNEDYS. By Doris Kearns Goodwin. Illustrated. 932 pages. Simon & Schuster. $22.95.

title: 1-2 HIALEAH FINISH FOR SKIFFINGTON DUO
description: Tom Skiffington, who sent out Akabir to an upset victory in the Bougainvillea Handicap here Saturday, came back 24 hours later to saddle Anka Germania and Chaldea to a 1-2 finish in the First Division of the Columbiana Handicap today at Hialeah Park.

title: TWINS GO SEPARATE WAYS ON AND OFF BASKETBALL COURT
description: LEAD: FOR most of their lives, Harvey and Horace Grant have had the rest of the world seeing double. So strong is the facial resemblance between the identical twins, born on Independence Day in 1965, they can barely distinguish whose photograph is whose. Until they were teen-agers, the pair even wore identical clothing and, recalled Harvey, strove ''to be just alike,'' a matter of occasional confusion for teachers.

title: Spaniards Protest Terrorism
description: More than 35,000 people marched silently today behind a huge banner reading ''For Peace and Against Terrorism'' in a protest against violence called by city leaders. On Friday, a car bomb exploded downtown, destroying a military bus, killing one officer and the bus driver, and wounding 28 military personnel and 13 pedestrians. The police believe the attack was the work of the Basque separatist organization E.T.A.

title: BALLET: HELGI TOMASSON'S SAN FRANCISCO TROUPE
description: The shiny new face of the San Francisco Ballet - under Helgi Tomasson's direction - has been shown off to huge success here this weekend.

title: People
description: * Donald V. Gill has been appointed executive vice president at SSC&B:Lintas USA.

title: IN INDONESIA, A LULL WITHOUT A STORM
description: The country is preparing for a national election campaign, and the Government of President Suharto, declaring the event a ''festival of democracy,'' is taking no chances.

title: Outdoors: Cold Reception by Geese
description: MY 1986-1987 waterfowl hunting ended with a three-hour vigil in the stinging cold, during which several flocks of Canada geese glanced at our decoys, honked derisively and departed with the alacrity of a teen-aged churl asked by his mother to mow the lawn.

title: It's Unhealthy for Congress to Earn Big Bucks
description: To the Editor:

title: Norfolk Southern Chief Extends Tour of Duty
description: Robert B. Claytor was to have retired Dec. 31 as chairman and chief executive of the Norfolk Southern Corporation, one of the nation's largest railroads. But circumstances forced him to stay on for a while more, and his last days in command are proving to be busy ones.

title: Europe Backs U.S. Trade Pact
description: The 12 member governments of the European Community gave final approval Friday to a four-year agreement assuring American grain exports to Spain, officials said.

title: WARRIORS TOP NETS IN FOURTH OVERTIME
description: Joe Barry Carroll had season highs of 43 points and 24 rebounds as the Golden State Warriors beat the Nets, 150-147, today in the first four-overtime game in three years in the National Basketball Association.

title: Market Place; Interest Grows In 'New' Sears
description: A DIVIDEND increase by Sears, Roebuck & Company could be announced next Monday or Tuesday at a regular meeting of its directors. While the company is still declining to comment, reports of a small dividend rise, amounting to a possible 2 cents a share quarterly, are making the rounds as part of a new, more positive perception of the world's largest retailer.

title: PRO-AM TO COUPLES-BRETT
description: Fred Couples, the professional golfer, and George Brett, the professional third baseman and amateur golfer, got a best-ball birdie 3 on the third extra hole to win the pro-am team title of the 47th annual Pebble Beach National Pro-Am today.

title: A CONSULTANT'S ROLE IN THE IRAN AFFAIR
description: In October 1985, when the Reagan Administration was forcing down a jetliner carrying the hijackers of the cruise ship Achille Lauro, it turned in desperation to a part-time consultant to reach Prime Minister Bettino Craxi of Italy by telephone.

title: Visitors Start Paying To See Miss Liberty
description: Visitors to the Statue of Liberty will have to pay $1 beginning today to see the monument. The fee, the first charged in the statue's 100-year history, was authorized by Congress as part of a test program.

title: A SLACK TIME FOR TAKEOVERS
description: ''You and I,'' the Wall Street arbitrager said last week to the takeover reporter, ''are out of business.''

title: PARKING RULES
description: Because of the snow, alternate-side parking is suspended in New York City today. All other rules remain in effect.

title: Robert E. Waterman, Chemist
description: Robert Edward Waterman, a research chemist associated with the discovery and mass manufacture of synthetic vitamin B1, died Saturday at his winter home in Delray Beach, Fla., following a brief illness. He was 87 years old and a resident of Morristown, N.J.

title: LAROUCHE SCORES 3 AS RANGERS WIN
description: On the ice last night, Pierre Larouche showed the old grace and some guile, and he showed even more. He barreled his way into the corners. He knocked pucks loose from defensemen, who seemed like great bears next to his 5-foot-11-inch, 175-pound frame.

title: Books: Rock From Then Till Now
description: ROCK OF AGES: The Rolling Stone History of Rock and Roll. By Ed Ward, Geoffrey Stokes and Ken Tucker. Rolling Stone Press/Summit Books. Illustrated. 649 pages. $14.95.

title: Oslo to Cut Its Oil Output
description: The Norwegian Parliament on Friday approved a 7.5 percent reduction in the country's oil production to cooperate with OPEC-led moves to increase crude prices.

title: PBS'S 'SMITHSONIAN' LOOKS FOR BACKING
description: ''Smithsonian World,'' the award-winning television program that has explored subjects ranging from American roadside architecture to the Panama Canal, could lose its financing and be canceled next fall, according to Public Broadcasting Service officials.

title: AN EARLY TEST OF THE POLITICAL TIDE
description: January is supposed to be a quiet month on Capitol Hill. Like two fighters in the opening round of a long match, Congress and the President generally circle each other warily, flicking verbal jabs, testing reactions, feeling out the ring.

title: Wait for the Ravitch Commission
description: Peter Vallone, the New York City Council majority leader, wants to strip the Board of Estimate of its budget-making authority. That could be done by the State Legislature, but if it isn't, the Queens Democrat hints he will seek a citywide referendum in November.

title: The Editorial Notebook; There's Still Race in Racism
description: How should Americans view Howard Beach and Forsyth County, two recent reminders that racism remains alive in the land? The Rev. Jesse Jackson thinks these incidents must be seen in the larger context of class, not just racial conflict.

title: GIFT TO NEEDIEST IS MADE AS TRIBUTE TO DR. KING
description: An anonymous contributor has paid tribute to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. with a $50 gift to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Take a Chance in South Korea
description: President Chun Doo Hwan's repressive South Korean Government doesn't deserve much benefit of doubt. But Mr. Chun has cause now to be more reasonable. He desperately seeks success for the Olympics in his country next year and the legitimacy the games will confer. This gives the democratic opposition real leverage. There could be an opportunity here for opposition leaders to find an accommodation, to establish democracy without a mutually destructive showdown.

title: Treasury Offerings Dominate Week
description: Treasury auctions will dominate the credit markets this week, starting with today's $13.6 billion sale of bills and continuing for three more days of note and bond auctions totaling $29 billion.

title: AIDS AMONG CLERGY PRESENTS CHALLENGES TO CATHOLIC CHURCH
description: Some Roman Catholic officials have begun to acknowledge reports from doctors, social workers and others that members of the Catholic clergy, like Americans in other sectors of society, are suffering and dying from AIDS.

title: L.I.R.R. Is Ready To Face Full Service
description: The Long Island Rail Road said yesterday that it was ready for a full rush-hour schedule for today, its first weekday of service after an 11-day strike.

title: Reebok Account Won By Ammirati & Puris
description: Reebok International, a major shoe company based in Canton, Mass., has decided to take its ad business to Ammirati & Puris in New York rather than to Hill Holliday Connors Cosmopulis in Boston. The billings are about $15 million.

title: Couple Are Murdered At Home in Brooklyn
description: A husband and his wife were found shot to death with their hands taped behind their backs in their apartment in the Gowanus section of Brooklyn last night, the police said.

title: Trump Raises Bally Stake
description: The New York real estate developer Donald J. Trump has exercised an option to buy 2.3 million shares of the Bally Manufacturing Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday, Mr. Trump said that he had paid $47.62 million for the shares. The Bally shares were being held under an agreement with Bear, Stearns & Company, while Mr. Trump sought Federal permission to raise his stake in the Chicago-based casino operator.

title: FACING THE LOSS OF A JOB
description: ROBERT F. McDONALD always thought of himself as a resourceful man. But as he waited last summer to find out who would be affected by yet another round of layoffs at the International Paper Company's offices in New York City he found himself paralyzed with fear.

title: ISRAEL DENIES DIVERTING MONEY OR ARMS
description: Israel, reacting to the Senate Intelligence Committee report on the Iran affair, denied again today that it had been involved in diverting money from the Iran arms sales or transferring weapons to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: STAGE: 'DEATH OF EAGLES'
description: THE program for ''Death of Eagles,'' now at the Neighborhood Group Theater, 420 West 42d Street, contains the following caution from the director: ''In viewing this play, one must not try to apply the rules of logic. The play is a dream . . . a black comedy that circles around and around, creating an absurd parody of America's proud military.'' Fair warning that the field is mined. Proceed at your own risk.

title: Bomb in Kabul Kills 4 Near Indian Embassy
description: A car bomb exploded today near the Indian Embassy in Afghanistan, killing four people, the Kabul radio said. The embassy, which was damaged, is near Afghanistan's Interior Ministry and several other Government buildings.

title: Robert W. Greitzer Wed To Wendy Ann Sherman
description: Wendy Ann Sherman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart K. Sherman of Englewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert W. Greitzer, the son of Harry Greitzer of Rye, N.Y., and the late Elinore Greitzer. Rabbi Peter Weintraub officiated at the Waters Edge Restaurant in Long Island City, Queens.

title: What Is a Meeting?
description: It has been two months since President Reagan appointed the special review board to examine the role of the National Security Council in the Iranian arms sales, and the group has been busy. The board, whose members are former Senators John Tower and Edmund S. Muskie and the former national security adviser Brent Scowcroft, has heard testimony from 40 people and met ''innumerable times,'' says its spokesman, Herbert Hetu.

title: ISLANDERS TAKING SMALL STEPS
description: Unbeaten in their last four games, and apparently content to skate with the defensive caution dictated by their coach, the Islanders finally are receiving some measure of satisfaction from their work. For a team that is rebuilding both its personnel and its confidence, that in itself is a small victory.

title: SHUTTLE TRAINING RESUMES TODAY AMID NEW HOPE
description: They are not sure when they will fly, or how long it will to take to qualify the redesigned booster rockets for the space shuttle, but today astronauts begin months of intensive training for the first mission since the Challenger disaster.

title: Kyung Wha Chung At Avery Fisher Hall
description: Kyung Wha Chung, who is currently celebrating the 20th anniversary of the Leventritt Prize that boosted her into the big-league concert circuit, returned to Avery Fisher Hall yesterday afternoon for a recital with the pianist Jonathan Feldman, a recital that reached its high point in a beautifully accomplished performance of Bartok's Second Violin Sonata. Miss Chung's pinpoint accuracy, rhythmic sharpness and zest for vigorous attack found their counterparts in the work's agitated pages. To the rare beauties of its quiet, exploratory passages she and Mr. Feldman brought sensitive ears and responsive techniques.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing Girardelli Takes Combined: Marc Girardelli of Luxembourg overcame a shoulder injury yesterday to upset Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland and win the men's combined title at the Alpine world championships at Crans-Montana, Switzerland. Earlier, Maria Walliser gave Switzerland its third gold medal by winning the women's downhill, beating a teammate, Michela Figini. (AP) Track and Field High Jump Record Set: In Piraeus, Greece, Patrik Sjoeberg of Sweden set a world indoor record for the men's high jump, clearing 7 feet 10 3/4 inches. The 22-year-old Sjoeberg broke the mark of 7-10 1/2 set in January by Carlo Thranhardt of West Germany.(AP) Coates Wins in Central Park: Budd Coates of Emmaus, Pa., won the 12th annual New York Road Runners Club reversible seven-mile run in 35 minutes 2 seconds at Central Park. Missy Kane of Knoxville, Tenn., won the women's title in 40:35. Auto Racing A Porsche Parade: Porsches swept the first six places as the Holbert Racing Team won its second consecutive Daytona 24-hour race in Daytona Beach, Fla. The winning car, driven by Chip Robinson, Derek Bell, Al Unser Jr. and Al Holbert, set a race record with an average speed of 111.599 miles an hour, breaking the record that the Holbert team set a year ago. A. J. Foyt, Al Unser and Danny Sullivan finished fourth in a Porsche owned by Foyt. The fast pace was forced by Foyt's team, which was running on the same lap as Hobert's with a half-hour to go when the engine in Foyt's car blew a gasket. (AP) N.H.L. Capitals 6, Jets 4: In Landover, Md., Mike Gartner scored two goals, extending his scoring streak to nine games, and put Washington ahead for good at 12:15 of the third period. Gartner's second goal gave Washington the lead, 5-4. Gartner has the longest scoring streak in the league this season.(AP) Sabres 6, Red Wings 1: In Buffalo last night, Mike Foligno scored two of Buffalo's five power-play goals. Dave Andreychuk, Adam Creighton, Scott Arniel and Phil Housley scored the Sabres' other goals as Buffalo won its second straight game.(AP) N.B.A. Rockets 106, Hawks 104: Robert Reid scored 27 points to lead Houston in Atlanta. The Rockets led, 106-100, with 1:51 remaining on two free throws by Rodney McCray, but Atlanta failed to get the tying basket with three shots, two of them tips, in the final seven seconds.(AP) Pistons 94, Bulls 92: In Pontiac, Mich., Adrian Dantley scored 25 points and Isiah Thomas's two free throws with 1:12 remaining provided the decisive points. The Pistons had a 90-78 lead with 5:49 left, but 3-point plays by Michael Jordan and Mike Brown fueled a 12-2 spurt.(AP) Horse Racing Sweep for Santos: Best by Test overcame a slow start to draw away in the final yards while posting a 2 1/4-length victory in the $67,100 Coaltown Stakes for 4-year-olds and up at Aqueduct yesterday. The 5-year-old son of Best Turn-Pom Pom gave his jockey, Jose Santos, a sweep of the day's stakes events. Earlier, he guided Spring Beauty to a two-length victory in the $73,000 Berlo Handicap for fillies and mares 3 years old and up. Best by Test carried highweight of 126 pounds six furlongs on the good track in 1:10 4/5 to earn $40,200 for Cedar Valle Stable and return $4.20 for $2 to win as the favorite. Raja's revenge was second, three lengths ahead of Comic Blush.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ameritech, Chicago, the parent of five Bell telephone companies in the Middle West, appointed Ormand J. Wade president of Ameritech Bell Group, Robert L. Barnett president of Ameritech Enterprise Group, Frank R. Zimmerman president of Illinois Bell and Louis J. Rutigliano president of Wisconsin Bell.

title: Poindexter The Disinformer
description: Larry Speakes, the departing White House spokesman, offhandedly revealed an illuminating fact in one of his farewell interviews.

title: DEMOCRATS IN CALIFORNIA ACHIEVE A STATE OF HARMONY
description: California Democrats, a contentious lot within a contentious party, did something unusual at their state convention here this weekend: They tried, hard, not to pick fights.

title: Biederman Is Keeping Israeli Tourism Account
description: Biederman & Company, after a competition that had involved seven agencies at the start, has held onto the Israel Ministry of Tourism account, which last year billed in the neighborhood of $3 million.

title: AMSTERDAM: AN AVENUE OF CONTRASTS
description: To hear some people tell it, Amsterdam Avenue is blossoming like Columbus Avenue, its glitzier neighbor one block east. Others, however, say the avenue's working-class character and neighborhood feeling is being endangered by the sort of change that has rippled along many other Manhattan streets.

title: RATES PRODUCE A STALEMATE
description: On the eve of quarterly note and bond sales totaling $29 billion, the Treasury market is stalemated, with interest rates little changed since the previous quarterly financing in early November.

title: Washington Watch; Drop in Weapon Exports
description: The importance to corporate America of arms exports has declined under the Reagan Administration, even though the White House has made weapon sales an important part of its foreign policy, according to a new study by the Investor Responsibility Research Center.

title: ATTACK ON HOME IN TOWNSHIP WOUNDS 6, PRETORIA REPORTS
description: Attackers threw grenades and fired automatic rifles at a home in the black township of Soweto Saturday night, seriously injuring a municipal policeman and five children, the Government reported today.

title: WEB OF DEALS WITH EUROPEAN BANKS
description: Arms dealers trying to sell American weapons to Iran as part of what came to be known as the Demavand project had extensive contacts with major financial institutions in Europe.

title: ...BUT WOOL RANCHES THRIVE
description: The bleating of thousands of Merino sheep, the barking of Kelpie dogs, the swearing of shepherds and the whine of mechanical clippers punctuate shearing time on this sheep station 500 miles northwest of Sydney - the payoff of a year's effort by Malcolm and Nancy Robinson.

title: LSGE Will Handle Connecticut Tourism
description: Tourism a little closer to home is going to benefit LSGE Advertising of Avon, Conn., which has become the ad agency for tourism of the Connecticut Department of Economic Development. The department formerly did its own advertising.

title: REASON UNCLEAR
description: An American journalist has been detained in Iran, the Swiss Foreign Ministry said today.

title: Pump Failure Causes Indian Pt. Shutdown
description: The Indian Point 3 nuclear power plant shut down automatically Saturday when one of two pumps that supply water to the plant's steam generators malfunctioned, authorities said.

title: FILIPINOS VOTE PEACEFULLY ON CONSTITUTION
description: Filipinos voted today on a new constitution that was seen as a test of strength for President Corazon C. Aquino. Officials said the turnout was heavy in what appeared to be the most peaceful nationwide vote in years.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday Construction Spending December Tuesday Leading Indicators December New-Home Sales December Wednesday None Thursday None Friday Unemployment December

title: Lobbying Is Not National Security Adviser's Job
description: To the Editor:

title: Holly Reports New Interest
description: The Holly Sugar Corporation, a leading producer of beet sugar, said Friday that Shamrock Holding Inc. and Brookehill Equities Inc. had expressed an interest in acquiring the company. Responding to requests for corporate information by Shamrock and Brookehill, Holly said it had hired Allen & Company and Salomon Brothers Inc. as financial advisers to evaluate and solicit bids.

title: Japanese Investments
description: Japanese investors bought a record amount of foreign shares last month while stepping up purchases of foreign bonds, the Finance Ministry said Friday. Net foreign stock purchases rose to a record $1.55 billion in December from $686 million in November. The previous record was $844 million last July. Net purchases of foreign bonds, excluding all kinds of treasury bills, rose to $8.93 billion in December from $7.76 billion in November.

title: COLUMBIA U. FUND HONORS A VICTIM OF AIDS
description: A drive to create a Columbia College scholarship in honor of Stuart Garcia, a leading member of the class of 1984 who died of AIDS last year, has won the endorsement of the Columbia University Senate.

title: SUNS' DAVIS HAPPY FOR ANOTHER SHOT
description: WALTER DAVIS and his picture-perfect jump shot have appeared in five All-Star Games. A sixth appearance is coming up Sunday at the Kingdome in Seattle. It is likely to be more meaningful than even his first in 1978.

title: LEGISLATURE'S PAYROLL: FEW 'NO-SHOWS,' BUT PATRONAGE PERSISTS
description: A few years back, Assemblyman John C. Dearie recalled recently, a Bronx Democratic Party official approached him with a proposition: If he would hire two staff members selected by the party, the money to pay for them would be added to his legislative payroll.

title: Brother and In-Law of Nipon Are Found Slain in Florida
description: The brother and sister-in-law of the fashion designer Albert Nipon were found shot to death in their oceanfront condominium Saturday morning, the authorities said.

title: Christian Broda of Austria; Helped to End Death Penalty
description: Christian Broda, a former Austrian Justice Minister who fought long and successfully for abolishing the death penalty, died today at his home, apparently after a heart attack, according to relatives. He was 70 years old.

title: NEW YORK AIRPORTS: $3 BILLION PROGRAM
description: The New York metropolitan area's three major airports, struggling under the weight of their own rapid growth, will soon begin extensive expansion and renovation intended to unclog roadways, speed crowds through terminals and reduce flight delays.

title: MINING THE HEAVENS FOR PROSE
description: Each month, the 500 people on the United States Naval Observatory's mailing list get its newsletter, which states the positions of the planets and the stars in ways like this:

title: QUIET WORKSHIP FOLLOWS WEEKS OF CLASHES IN ALL-WHITE TOWN
description: About 50 blacks attended church services without incident this morning here in an all-white county where turbulent civil rights confrontations occurred the previous two weekends.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Books of The Times: 'The Fitzgeralds and the Kennedys'
description: The story is familiar enough.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 2, 1987
description: International Report

title: Saving Dragonflies In Belvedere Lake
description: CENTRAL Park has many users. When its curators drew plans to rebuild the Great Lawn and Belvedere Lake, they accounted for a symphony orchestra, an opera company and dozens of softball teams. Now they have to deal with a diminutive, four-winged constituency that they had not imagined a week ago. On Tuesday, an amateur entomologist, Charles Matson, disclosed that the lake was home to a variety of dragonflies and damselflies - insects of prehistoric appearance, rainbow irridescence and almost unearthly beauty.

title: Tentative Pact in O'Keeffe Will Dispute
description: A tentative settlement has been reached in a dispute over the will of the artist Georgia O'Keeffe, and it calls for distribution of her works to museums and nonprofit institutions, attorneys say.

title: HONG KONG: CHINA 'GATEWAY'
description: It sometimes seems that this capitalist enclave is planning to take over China in just 10 years.

title: REDMEN VS. HOYAS: CRUCIAL, AS USUAL
description: It's fitting that the final month of the Big East season will begin this evening with St. John's as the host to Georgetown at Madison Square Garden.

title: Wife of Congressman Dies
description: Helen Marie Miller, 71 years old, wife of Representative Clarence Miller, Republican of Ohio, died Saturday at Northern Virginia Hospital in Arlington, Va.

title: Giant Facts
description: A victory in Pasadena, Calif., by a New York team based in New Jersey is doing wonders for a Boston publisher. It is spurring sales of ''Giants Trivia,'' a book whose more than 600 questions about obvious events and obscure facts spanning more than six decades of team history can separate the casual fan from the true fanatic - even, it turns out, among the team's official historians.

title: L.I. TRIAL IS SCRUTINIZED TWO YEARS AFTER VERDICT
description: The 1985 trial of James Diaz, a self-described drifter who was charged with the rape and murder of a Port Jefferson nurse, came under renewed scrutiny here this week.

title: WORKERS CALLED BACK TO USX STEEL PLANTS AS STOPPAGE ENDS
description: Union members will begin returning to work at USX Corporation steel mills, some as early as Monday, as the steelmaker begins the complicated process of resuming production after a six-month work stoppage.

title: R.S. Klanfer Wed To Ms. Bloomfield
description: At Temple Sinai in Stamford, Conn., yesterday Joan M. Bloomfield, the director of strategic development for Newsweek Inc. in New York and publisher of Newsweek on Health magazine, was married to Robert S. Klanfer, the chief financial officer of the American Natural Beverage Corporation, manufacturer and marketer of Soho Soda in New York. Rabbi Stephen Pearce performed the ceremony.

title: Tough British Takeover Rules
description: In response to the scandal over the manipulation of Guinness's stock price, Britain's Takeover Panel has drastically strengthened the rules governing corporate mergers to increase disclosures of share trading during takeover bids.

title: SCOURGE OF EAST DETROIT: BLIGHT BY ASSOCIATION
description: A name is a name is a name in most places, but not in this blue-collar suburb.

title: 20TH-CENTURY GALLEY SLAVE
description: IN the America's Cup, the men on the 12-Meters do essentially what men on sailboats have done for centuries. At the wheel, the skipper peers through the salt spray on his bronzed face. Nearby, his tactician and his navigator observe the wind. Other members of the crew handle the sails. And on the deck are the grinders, 20th-century galley slaves who toil together to turn the winches that move the heavy sails. But these galley slaves don't need whips cracking above their heads.

title: FOR NURSES, A FUTURE IN LAW
description: When Mary E. Kelly mentions that her Los Angeles law office is on the Avenue of the Stars, she chuckles.

title: S.E.C. SAID TO DELIVER SUBPOENAS ON DREXEL
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has sent out a new round of subpoenas that focus more narrowly on the role that the investment bank Drexel Burnham Lambert played in several large transactions, according to lawyers and investment bankers with knowledge of the inquiry. The subpoenas are part of the S.E.C. investigation of Wall Street's takeover practices.

title: OPERA: 'LEONORA' BY FRY
description: No opera by a native-born American composer had reached the stage before William Henry Fry's ''Leonora'' played Philadelphia's Chestnut Street Theater in 1845. Fry's piece struggled toward New York and was finally heard here in 1858, but little more had come of it until the Bel Canto Opera company's performance Saturday night at the Fashion Institute of Technology Auditorium, 227 West 27th Street.

title: HAROLD M. FLORSHEIM
description: Harold M. Florsheim, former chairman of the Florsheim Shoe Company, died here Friday. He was 87 years old.

title: ALL THE WORLD'S A SCHOOLYARD FOR STARS
description: HE became basketball's most celebrated player, a relentless workaholic whose mastery of the game sometimes leaves even his peers aghast. But as a young Hoosier in French Lick, Ind., just looking for a game, what Larry Bird relied on most was his finely tuned ears. ''I lived with my grandma, across the street from the old schoolyard,'' the Celtic forward recalled. ''So all I had to do was hear someone bouncing a ball outside and I was gone.''

title: HUGE ILLEGAL DEAL ON ARMS FOR IRAN WAS KNOWN TO U.S.
description: High Pentagon intelligence officials learned more than a year ago that private arms dealers were trying illegally to ship 39 American fighter planes and vast amounts of other weapons to Iran, but the officials did not stop the sales, according to confidential documents and participants who informed the Government.

title: The Steel Gap
description: When President Reagan at the end of 1984 announced his program to protect the domestic steel industry, he said the ''expected result'' was that foreign steel would represent 20.2 percent of domestic consumption. In 1985, the first full year of the program, the foreign share was 25.2 percent, and last year it was 23.1 percent.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 2, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Private efforts to ship arms to Iran became known to Pentagon intelligence officials over a year ago, but the officials did not stop the sales, according to documents and participants who informed the Government. Page A1

title: Gates-G.E. Battery Deal
description: The Gates Corporation said Friday that it had completed the acquisition of the General Electric Company's battery business. Terms were not disclosed. Gates said the purchase includes G.E. plants in Gainesville, Fla.; Juarez, Mexico, and Newcastle, England. The agreement calls for G.E. to continue marketing rechargeable batteries for the consumer market under its name. Gates also would have use of the G.E. name for one year for industrial sales of batteries. Gates said its battery sales were $48 million in 1986 and G.E.'s battery sales totaled $144.3 million.

title: CITY BALLET: 'FANFARE' AND 'MOZARTIANA'
description: THIS season, the New York City Ballet is once again offering an amiable music-appreciation lesson. On Friday night at the New York State Theater, Jerome Robbins's ''Fanfare'' returned to the repertory for the first time since 1978.

title: SUCCEEDED HUSBAND IN CONGRESS
description: Representative Sala Burton, a California Democrat who succeeded her late husband in Congress in 1983 and carried on his liberal policies, died today of complications arising from cancer. She was 61.

title: Ted Bates Assigned Dole Food Account
description: Ted Bates Worldwide has been assigned the $40 million Dole Food Company account. For a year it was handled by the William Esty Company, a sister agency under the Saatchi & Saatchi umbrella.

title: What Else, After All, Is a Men's Club For?
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I've understood since I was a child that people like us would always be in conflict with the political system, it's the whole society.'' Serafim Yevsyukov, just released from the Second Moscow Provincial Psychiatric Clinic. [ A6:3. ]

title: Arms Control Plus 'Star Wars'
description: LEAD: The prevailing wisdom within the Reagan Administration and beyond is that the day will come when the President must choose between his Strategic Defense Initiative and arms control. There is a distinct parallelism between hawks and doves on this point - the former bemoan arms control as the threat to S.D.I., the latter bemoan S.D.I.

title: What Else, After All, Is a Men's Club For?
description: To the Editor:

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Feb. 2, 1987: MONDAY Airborne Freight Gannett Co Coastal Corp Standard Brands Paint Data-Design Labs Xerox Corp TUESDAY Adams-Mills General Housewares Bemis Co IE Industries CBI Industries Kansas City Pwr & Lt Coachmen Indus Monarch Mach Tool Federal-Mogul Corp Timken Co WEDNESDAY Carlisle Co Portland Genl Corp Ingersoll-Rand Thomas & Betts Peoples Energy THURSDAY Dover Corp Mercantile Stores Liberty Corp FRIDAY ASA Ltd. E. F. Hutton Group Allied-Signal Inc Washington Water Pwr Deluxe Check Pinters

title: PRICE GAINS BY OPEC EXPECTED
description: OPEC's resolve in largely sticking to its month-old limit on crude oil production, along with other developments, has significantly increased the group's chances of stabilizing prices in the $18-a-barrel range this year, oil specialists in the United States believe.

title: How Portia Would Argue the Baby M Case
description: To the Editor:

title: A-PLANT QUAKE SURVIVAL QUESTIONED
description: The ability of many nuclear reactors now in operation to withstand earthquakes is unknown, because the builders analyzed the plants on the basis of their design instead of on how they were actually built, a design consulting company has complained to Federal regulators.

title: PAN AM'S UNIONS OFFER WAGE CUTS FOR SECURITY
description: Leaders of four of Pan Am's unions are offering to help the airline solve its financial problems if their members can get more equity in the company and are protected in the event of a merger or acquisition.

title: INSIDE
description: Prayers in Troubled County About 50 blacks attended church without incident in Forsyth County, Ga., site of racial confrontations on two previous weekends. Page A14. Politics and Payrolls The trial of a high-ranking Queens Democrat has illustrated how political patronage affects the payroll of the State Legislature. Page B1. Currency Meeting Off The Group of Five leading industrial nations delayed talks on currency.

title: Yves Allegret Is Dead; Eminent Film Director
description: Yves Allegret, a prominent French film maker, died Saturday, his family announced in Paris. He was 79 years old.

title: Seam of the Matter
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has its share of squabbles. Now, with the collegiate baseball season just getting under way, the official tournament baseball used in the N.C.A.A. seems to have become a political football.

title: BABY M'S 'BEST INTERESTS' MAY RESOLVE A PUZZLING CASE
description: Child-custody experts believe that the judge in the Baby M case will have to rely on New Jersey custody law and its primary tenet - the ''best interests'' of the child - to resolve the bitter tug-of-war over the 10-month-old girl.

title: ON GOLF COURSES IN KABUL: ROUGH GOING ALL THE WAY
description: Long before the Government called on the rebels recently to join in a cease-fire, the war in Afghanistan always paused on Friday mornings in the hills outside this village just beyond the Kabul city limits.

title: Cavani String Quartet At Weill Recital Hall
description: The Cavani String Quartet -young, fresh and extremely eager -came to Weill Recital Hall Saturday afternoon, its thermostat turned high. As a result, Mendelssohn's A minor Quartet, Ellen Taaffe Zwilich's String Quartet 1974 and the Debussy G minor alternately thrived and stumbled under this unremitting heat.

title: VICTORY BY MILLER HIS FIRST SINCE '83
description: Johnny Miller, who said he had thought his winning years on the tour were over, surprised himself and just about everyone else today with his first golf triumph in nearly four years.

title: MYSTERY IN BEIRUT DEEPENS ON STATUS OF ANGLICAN ENVOY
description: The mystery of Terry Waite deepened today as the Archbishop of Canterbury said the Anglican envoy left instructions that no attempt be made to rescue him if he should be taken hostage in Lebanon.

title: IRISH STUN TAR HEELS, 60-58
description: David Rivers scored all of his 14 points in the second half, including a field goal and two free throws in the final minute, as Notre Dame upset top-ranked North Carolina, 60-58, today. It was the fifth time in 13 years the Fighting Irish had beaten a No. 1 team at home.

title: MEEK RISE TO BECOME CITY TERROR
description: In certain parts of this, the nation's fifth largest city, the problem is not urban blight or urban angst. It is urban deer. Whole herds of white-tailed does, fawns and antlered bucks that seem to have bounded right out of ''Bambi.''

title: Head of Glass Venture Sees a Healthy Start
description: One way to compete in a mature industry such as glass containers, says H. Ray Looney, is to put two medium-sized companies together to create one major competitior.

title: The 'Long Arm' Meets the 'Invisible Hand'
description: LEAD: There is a hidden reality out here in America's towns, cities and states that, shaped and projected by a single national voice, could create a new political culture. The 1988 Presidential candidate who sees that possibility can tap into an idea with high political voltage.

title: Bridge: Reader From Kew Gardens Cites a Very Impertinent Bid
description: For the most impertinent bid of this decade, or indeed any other, South's action on the diagramed deal must be a strong candidate. Before considering the auction, however, study this question: is there any way to defeat five diamonds?

title: Ted Fagan, U.N. Interpreter For 30 Years, Is Dead at 66
description: Ted Fagan, a simultaneous translator for 30 years at the United Nations who became the organization's chief interpreter, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 66 years old.

title: SALVADORAN REBELS, RESISTING ARMY DRIVE, ARE SAID TO KILL CIVILIANS
description: Salvadoran leftist rebels, apparently in a determined effort to assert their power, have shot several civilians in the last two months, according to diplomatic, military and human rights officials.
