description: AMERICA'S CUP STARS & STRIPES VS. KOOKABURRA III, at Fremantle, Australia (TV - ESPN, 11 P.M.) BASKETBALL KNICKS VS. BULLETS, at Landover, Md., 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, 7:30 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 6:15 P.M. and 11:15 P.M.)

title: EUDORA WELTY'S 'WIDE NET'
description: MUCH is being made in the publicity for ''The Wide Net'' of the fact that it represents the first television adaptation of a Eudora Welty story. And that does sound like something to look forward to, especially for those of us who have long been complaining about how American television ignores the bulk of fine American literature that might lend itself rewardingly to dramatization. But despite the sincerity that just about oozes from every scene, ''The Wide Net'' doesn't do much to advance the cause. Adapted and directed by Anthony Herrera, the hourlong story, on Channel 13 tonight at 9 o'clock, as part of the ''American Playhouse'' series, meanders along somewhat aimlessly, becoming as gripping as it intends only in a few passing moments.

title: Airline Names Kremer
description: Warren Kremer Advertising, which specializes in travel advertising, has been tapped by BWIA International, the airline of Trinidad and Tobago. The account had been handled by Ketchum Advertising/New York.

title: THE U.N. TODAY: Feb. 2, 1987
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Population Commission - 10:30

title: In Puerto Rico, Labor-Relations Violence Has Become Rare
description: To the Editor:

title: AUSTRALIA WHEAT FARMERS REAP BITTER FEELINGS
description: Donald McGauchie, a third-generation Australian wheat farmer, raced damaging summer rain as he harvested this season's crop on the sun-bleached plains here. But it is not the rain that is the cause of most of his displeasure these days: it is the United States.

title: Youth, 15, Is Fatally Stabbed While Walking With Friends
description: A 15-year-old youth was fatally stabbed while walking with two friends down Barnwell Avenue in the Elmhurst section of Queens last night, the police said.

title: Ford's Plans For Escort
description: The Ford Motor Company plans to continue building its Escort subcompact in the United States, according to a report in The Detroit News today.

title: Not Regicide, but a Commitment to Legality
description: Many Europeans, Israelis and other foreigners see Americans' reaction to the Iran-contra affair as a self-damaging wound, much as they viewed the uproar over Watergate. They shake their heads and wonder about our penchant for regicide.

title: Health-Tex Sets Closings
description: Health-Tex Inc., manufacturers of children's apparel, plans to shut down its production plants in the Maine communities of Portland, Brunswick and Gardiner, and lay off 900 workers. Another mill, at Petersburg, Va., will also be closed.

title: PERELMAN-WEST PLAY IN NEW TROVE AT BROWN
description: As best friends, brothers-in-law and mutual admirers, S. J. Perelman and Nathanael West frequently talked about collaborating on a project. So far as is known, only once did they share authorship over a sustained period. The result was a play called ''Even Stephen,'' a satire on book publishing and mating habits in academia. The play was written in 1934 and was neither produced nor published in their lifetimes.

title: Peru Floods Kill at Least 43
description: At least 43 people were killed and 20 were missing in flash flooding in the foothills of the Peruvian Andes around Oxapampa, civil defense officials said today.

title: SECRECY ON CONTRA TRAINING DENOUNCED
description: As far back as World War II, when the United States has needed a place to train men for a top secret mission, it has turned to this huge tract of pine trees and swamp on the edge of the Gulf of Mexico.

title: In Sleep, Less Is More
description: Less time in bed may mean more sleep for some insomniacs, researchers at the Mount Sinai Medical Center believe. They are testing this idea by prescribing sleep restriction therapy - less time in bed - to some long term insomnia patients who volunteer for the research.

title: Vermont Judges Defy Request From Governor to Step Down
description: Three state Supreme Court justices today refused a request from the Governor that they step down pending an investigation into charges of judicial misconduct.

title: EXPANSION FOR 7 BELL PHONE UNITS IS URGED ON COURT BY JUSTICE DEPT.
description: The Justice Department, calling for expanded competition in the telephone industry, today asked a Federal court here to allow the big regional companies to enter three new areas of business.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After gains from discontinued operations of $8.5 million for the quarter and $10.1 million for the year, and after a charge of $420.2 million from the purchase of Cessna Aircraft for the quarter. c-Net income includes gains from discontinued operations $8.2 million for the quarter and $22.2 million for the year.

description: The Compaq Computer Corporation said today that its earnings rose 62 percent, to $16.2 million, or 57 cents a share, from $10 million, or 36 cents a share, a year ago. Revenues increased 20 percent, to $186.9 million, from $156.3 million a year ago.

description: AMONG the many questions Don Rifkin's play ''Delusion of Angels'' contemplates are the ''true'' interpretation of ''Wuthering Heights,'' the relationship between art and Eros, the propriety of college teachers pursuing sexual liaisons with their students and the ways couples involved in long-term relationships cope with flagging passion.

description: An explosion abroad the British tanker O. T. Gerth in the Seine River estuary today killed a Swedish woman in the crew and injured eight other crew members. A fire tug moved in and put out the fire.

description: To the Editor:

BLACK NATIONS' TRADE ROUTE SEEKS TO BYPASS SOUTH AFRICA
description: The patched and potholed two-lane road leading to this sleepy border post on the frontier with Zimbabwe gives little hint of grand design or bitter struggle.

title: BANK AMERICA IS SELLING SCHWAB UNIT TO FOUNDER
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its Charles Schwab & Company discount brokerage unit to a group headed by the unit's chairman, Charles R. Schwab.

The company also said similar actions resulted in net pre-tax gains of $1.8 million and $6.7 million in the latest and year-ago fourth quarters, respectively.

title: LACROIX, NEW COUTURE STAR, LEAVES HOUSE OF PATOU
description: After a major success in Paris last week with his collection for Jean Patou, Christian Lacroix telephoned friends in New York yesterday to say he was forming his own couture house in July. He said he would add a ready-to-wear collection next year.

title: SPECIES VANISHING FROM MANY PARKS
description: MANY species of mammals are disappearing from North America's national parks solely because the parks -even those covering hundreds of thousands of acres - are too small to support them.

title: EDMUND PENDLETON
description: Edmund Pendleton, organist at the American Church in Paris for 40 years and a composer and choirmaster, died Friday at his Paris home, his family said today. He was 86.

title: LINCOLN SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company went public in March 1986.

title: Such Innocence on Iran
description: Pleading the innocence of ignorance, Reagan Administration officials blame Israel for luring them into the bizarre bazaars of Teheran and the international arms market. Professing loyalty to an ally, Israeli officials blame the Reagan Administration for making them scapegoats. Who led whom into sin?

title: BABY M'S LAWYER URGES GIVING FATHER CUSTODY
description: The court-appointed legal guardian of Baby M urged today that the baby's father, William Stern, receive sole custody of the 10-month-old girl and that the surrogate mother, Mary Beth Whitehead, be denied visiting rights for the immediate future.

title: Q&A
description: Q.Does the nightingale sing only at night? A. Contrary to popular belief, the nightingales sing at all hours -but mainly on clear moonlit nights several weeks after it flies north for the summer, according to bird watchers. Of the two species found in Europe, Asia, and northwestern Africa, the thrush nightingale, Luscinia luscinia, is more accomplished in song than the nightingale, Luscinia megarhynchos, which can sometimes lapse into croaks and chuckles. Q.Does laughing gas have any adverse effects? A.When administered properly, nitrous oxide or laughing gas has no adverse effects on the central nervous system. However, inhalation of pure nitrous oxide for more than a few minutes can deprive the brain of oxygen and result in brain damage or death. This colorless, sweet-smelling gas is used mainly as an anesthetic in short operations and in dentistry where it is adminstered by the trained physician. Because it produces an initial state of exhilaration, nitrous oxide has become known as laughing gas.

description: The MCI Communications Corporation, the nation's second-largest long-distance carrier, said yesterday that it had lost $502.5 million in the fourth quarter, giving it a loss of $448 million for the year.

description: Not many college basketball coaches are interested in 6-foot-2-inch centers. So no one paid much attention to Greg Economou during his senior year at Hendrick Hudson High School in Montrose, N.Y.

title: DROP IN WORKING RIGS
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the Unted States dropped by 11 this week, to 826, according to the Hughes Tool Company's rig count released today. Last year at this time the count was 1,594.

title: VOLCKER FEARS INFLATION IF DOLLAR KEEPS FALLING
description: The Federal Reserve Board chairman, Paul A. Volcker, warned today that the dollar's decline in currency markets was approaching worrisome levels that threatened a revival of inflation and a rise in interest rates.

title: PRODUCTIVITY RATE OFF 1.7% IN QUARTER
description: Business productivity, a key measure of the nation's competitiveness, rose less than 1 percent in 1986 as efficiency gains by manufacturers since the 1981-82 recession began to fade, the Labor Department said today.

description: b-Includes income of $14.9 million and $26.9 million for the quarter and year, respectively, from the liquidation of excess metal inventory, valued on a LIFO basis; $3.1 million of income from the placement of a 25 percent common stock interest in Asarco Australia Ltd., an exploration and gold mining subsidiary, and a charge of $2.6 million for an increase in reserves for bad debts related to accounts receivable for the quarter; and the year includes income of $9 million from a rights offering by M.I.M. Holdings Ltd., an associated company, and a $3.6 million recovery of costs and reduction of Asarco's interests in the Wiluna gold project Australia. The company said the latest year net includes a $4.2 million of charges relating to an increase in bad debt reserves and the previously mentioned $3.1 million of fourth quarter income from the sale of an interest in Asarco Australia. The company said in the latest year preferred dividends exceeded net income. c-Net loss and includes a $14.6 million of LIFO profits for both the quarter and year, and an unusual charge of $4.5 million for the quarter to provide for the anticipated closing of a zinc oxide plant; and the year includes a $16 million credit from the adoption of statement FASB 87 pertaining to the pension costs.

title: NO. 32 IS NO. 1 TO NETS' TRAINER
description: It has been more than a decade since the Nets made one of the worst blunders in franchise history, selling off Julius Erving to the Philadelphia 76ers for the fire-sale price of $3 million after Erving's extended contract dispute with the Nets' owner, Roy Boe.

title: PIANO: ALDO CICCOLINI AT TULLY HALL
description: THE ability to play light music surpassingly well is not given to every good musician, which is one reason why so few concerts and recitals dare venture beyond the well-defined borders of the certifiably serious. But we know it can be done and, in fact, has been done by such masters of the bonbon repertory as Sir Thomas Beecham. Among pianists, Arthur Rubinstein could whip up frothy delights when the spirit moved him, generally at encore time. However, considering how seldom one encounters concerts at which lightness is treated with proper respect, perhaps someone should inaugurate a Helium Award for the best such program each season.

title: HISPANIC GROUPS CHARGE TRANSIT POLICE WITH COVERING UP A BEATING
description: A coalition of Hispanic groups accused the New York City Transit Authority police yesterday of trying to cover up an incident in which the coalition said two women, seeking to ''clarify'' a dispute involving a friend, were beaten and arrested without provocation by transit officers on a subway train.

title: HELDOR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
City Eases Rules On S.R.O. Housing
description: Mayor Koch yesterday signed into law a bill aimed at preserving the city's 52,000 single-room occupancy units while giving landlords a chance to pay to convert them to luxury apartments.

description: Coopervision Inc. said yesterday that its president, John H. Williford, had taken early retirement at age 56. The news sprouted rumors of a possible sale of the eye-care company.

When the two schools couldn't agree on details, the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference set up a conference call involving all its teams, with the result that each side agreed to make concessions that led to this unusual scenario:

title: BRITAIN'S HIGH-TECH BOOKIES
description: Mention the Giants-Broncos Super Bowl game and Ronald Pollard shakes his head in disdain at the kind of betting that it inspired: about $40 million wagered legally in Nevada, dwarfed by illegal betting elsewhere in the United States estimated at more than $1 billion.

description: Economic prosperity and a strong currency are inducing more West Germans to travel abroad, according to a report released today by Dresdner Bank. West Germans spent more than 4 percent of their income abroad last year.

description: Year-ago results are restated to include Sloan Technology Corp., acquired in June 1986 in a pooling of interests.

title: No Progress Seen In Airbus Talks
description: Talks between American and European officials over subsidies for Airbus Industrie, the European airliner manufacturing consortium, made no progress today in what threatens to become a major trade dispute, the officials said. At the same time, Airbus announced in Paris that it had its best January ever, receiving orders worth $5 billion.

description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $76,328,000 for the quarter and $80,920,000 for the year. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $35,911,000 for the quarter and $35,675,000 for the year.

title: The Right Key
description: It was halftime of a basketball game at San Jose City College last year, and the cheerleaders had just finished their routine. A radio was playing over the public-address system when a tall young man walked up, grabbed the microphone and began to sing along.

title: O'ROURKE URGES MORE SHELTERS FOR HOMELESS 881
description: The Westchester County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke, proposed today that the county build emergency housing for homeless people, saying that local communities had failed to develop permanent, affordable housing.

title: UMass Student Fined for Brawl
description: A former University of Massachusetts student has been fined and given a suspended prison sentence for pushing another student during a racial brawl on campus after the final game of the World Series.

title: NOW, THE CITY POSTMAN ALSO RINGS FROM A VAN
description: At 11:20 each morning, Gabriel Serrano fights his way through lunch-time traffic on Park Avenue and angles his van toward the curb outside the National Distillers Building between 39th and 40th Streets.

title: O'NEILL URGES INCREASES IN STATE AID FOR TOWNS
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill, carrying out a promise from his re-election campaign last fall, proposed today a sharp increase in state aid to cities and towns to help them hold down local property taxes.

title: Jays Trade Garcia
description: Damaso Garcia, a two time American League All-Star at second base, and Luis Leal, a right-handed pitcher, have been acquired by the Atlanta Braves from the Toronto Blue Jays in exchange for another right-hander, Craig McMurtry. . . . The Boston Red Sox have signed five players for the the coming season, including their ace relief pitcher, Calvin Schiraldi, and backup catcher, Marc Sullivan, General Manager Lou Gorman announced yesterday. Schiraldi, 24, who moved up from Class AAA ball in Pawtucket last July, was the team's bullpen stopper in the final two months of the season, ending with a 4-2 record and nine saves as the Red Sox won the Eastern Division title.

title: Sonics Defeat Nets
description: Xavier McDaniel scored 20 of his 35 points in the second half and added a game-high 14 rebounds, leaving the Seattle SuperSonics to a 108-100 National Basketball Association victory over the Nets tonight.

title: INDISPENSIBLE ACCESSORY
description: I.B.M.-compatible clones have become true commodity items.

title: 'SPEAKER FROM TEXAS,' ON JIM WRIGHT
description: WHO is Jim Wright, the new Speaker of the House of Representatives? He's an affable, highly ambitious Texan, that's who. ''The Speaker From Texas'' traces his career, although it is as much about politics and politicking as it is about the man. The one-hour documentary, on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight, is still a reasonably candid look at one of the most important people in the country.

title: Woman Calls to Say She Killed Man in '83
description: A woman from Rye Brook confessed in a call early Sunday to the police that she killed her boyfriend in 1983 - a death initially ruled a heroin overdose, the authorities said yesterday.

title: VICTORIA BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: CF&I STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax benefits of $1,306,000 and $4,148,000 for the quarter and year, respectively and gains on the sale of assets of $1,243,000 for the quarter and $1,271,000 for the year. c-After a tax benefit of $1,448,000 for the quarter and $4,205,000 for the year, and the year also includes a gain on the sale of assets of $2,659,000. The company said the year-ago results are restated to reflect effects of changing inventory valuation methods from LIFO to FIFO as of Jan. 1, 1986. The effect of this change was to increase the year-ago fourth quarter loss by $427,000 and the prior year loss by $980,000.

title: DEFENSE STARTS SUMMATIONS IN 'PIZZA CONNECTION' TRIAL
description: Defense lawyers in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial began their summations yesterday by attacking the prosecution's view of wiretapped conversations and surveillance photographs.

title: Careers; Wanted: Experts in Gardening
description: HORTICULTURE, the care of trees, grass and gardens, is one service industry that is doing well, thanks, perhaps, to the yuppies, or young urban professionals.

title: Cattle Prices at High; U.S. Report Is Awaited
description: Cattle futures surged to new highs today as the market awaited a report expected to show domestic inventories at their lowest level in 25 years.

title: New Foreign Relations Chief Is Not a Cream Puff: Senator Claiborne Pell
description: Senator Claiborne Pell chuckled. ''People think I'm namby-pamby, that's the impression people have,'' he said, murmuring. ''People say I'm out-of-touch, remote. Well, I do think time will prove them wrong.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: College Hockey Harvard Upset: Two upsets marked the opening of the Beanpot tournament in Boston Garden last night as Northeastern defeated Harvard, 5-4, in overtime, and Boston College fell to Boston University, 6-3. The 35-year-old tournament has been celebrated for its confounding results and the Northeastern victory was unexpected because this team had won only 6 of 25 games this season. Brian Dowd was credited with the winning goal that slipped past Dickie McEvoy in a scramble in front of the Harvard cage. The defeat was only the second for the Crimson, who had been inactive the last 20 days during a break for examinations. Harvard had won its first 15 games before losing to Yale on Jan. 13. Northeastern (7-16-3) and Boston University (12-12-3) will play for the Beanpot championship Monday night at Boston Garden. Boston College (20-6) had beaten Boston University four times this season, scoring 29 goals. But the Boston University goalie, Terry Taillefer, had a shutout until late in the last period and stopped 35 shots. Horse Racing Six-Length Victory at Aqueduct: Majestic Empire trailed front-running Shine Diulus into the stretch, took over there and drew away to a six-length victory yesterday in the $33,000 allowance feature for 4-year-olds and up at Aqueduct. Shine Diulus lasted to finish second a neck ahead of Aswan High. Majestic Empire went six furlongs on the sloppy track in 1:10 2/5 carrying 119 pounds under Nick Santagata. The 5-year-old son of Majestic Prince-Sensitive Princess earned $19,800 for James Riccio and returned $14.60 for $2 to win. Skiing Zurbriggen Takes Gold: Pirmin Zurbriggen, upset in two previous races, mounted what he said was ''a full-scale attack'' to beat Marc Girardelli for the gold medal yesterday in the first world championship super-giant slalom. ''Now I am a happy man,'' said Zurbriggen, who has won silver medals in the downhill and the combined, but lost his world titles in both events. Zurbriggen was slow out of the gate in the super-giant slalom race, but went through the 43 gates on the 1,553-meter Chetzeron course in 1 minute 19.93 seconds, nearly a second faster than Girardelli. Markus Wasmeier of West Germany, one of the pre-race favorites, nearly lost his balance and had to settle for the bronze with a time of 1:21.08.(AP) N.H.L. Maple Leafs 8, Flyers 4: In Toronto, the line of Peter Ihnacak, Rick Vaive and Steve Thomas combined for four goals and eight assists to help the Maple Leafs end their six-game losing streak. Ihnacak scored twice and had three assists and Thomas had a goal and three assists and Vaive a goal and two assists. The loss was the second in a row for the Flyers, who are starting a four-game trip. (AP) N.B.A. Nuggets 140, Clippers 112: Lafayette Lever scored 16 points and Alex English 14 in the third quarter as Denver tied a league season-high with 47 points in the period. The Nuggets shot 72 percent, 18 of 25, in the period. Lever finished with 23 points, 10 assists and 8 rebounds. English led all scorers with 28 points.(AP)

title: Bernice L. M. Smith Is Dead; Wife of U.S. Arms Negotiator
description: Bernice Latrobe Maguire Smith, wife of Gerard C. Smith, who led the United States delegation from 1969 to 1972 in the negotiations on limiting strategic arms, died of cancer at her home yesterday. She was 74 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is certainly heartening that reports from all over the country so far indicate the voting has been clean, honest, orderly and exceptionally heavy. This proves the maturity of the Filipino people.'' - President

title: Home State Motions Filed
description: Lawyers for two former Home State Savings Bank officials, Marvin Warner and Burton Bongard, have asked a court to dismiss Federal charges accusing the pair of defrauding Home State depositors.

description: Per share earnings are based on the weighted average number of shares outstanding, 7,416,912 for 1986 and 7,200,441 for 1985.

title: 'ORDINARY' IN BEL AIR HAS $3 MILLION ASKING PRICE
description: The neighborhood is Old Bel Air, the most desirable part of the pricey Bel Air section of Los Angeles, where some local real estate brokers say an ''ordinary'' house on an acre of land goes for $3 million. It is there that a group of President Reagan's friends have paid $2.5 million for a home for him and Nancy Reagan in retirement.

description: The company went public Nov. 20, 1985; no year-ago results are available; no revenue figures were reported for latest year. ITT Rayonier Inc., the forest products subsidiary of ITT Corp., owns 74.7 percent of the outstanding class A units of Rayonier Timberlands L.P.

title: JWT Group Subsidiary Names Chief Executive
description: Frank Stanton, who has been chairman of Simmons Market Research in the United States, has also been named chairman and chief executive of its parent company, the international Market Research Bureau Group, by the JWT Group, the holding company for all.

title: On Competitiveness
description: President Reagan's focus on competitiveness has prompted major changes at the Council on International Educational Exchange, a body of 179 colleges and universities with academic programs overseas. For the first time it will be advised by non-academics who will be looking at how the council should expand its international business programs overseas and attract more students and scholarships financed by corporations.

title: REDMEN WIN IN OVERTIME
description: While fans and coaches often refer to a great player as a one-man team, it's rare in any team sport that one player actually wins a game by himself.

title: WITNESS SAYS HE RECEIVED DRUGS TO GIVE FALSE TESTIMONY ON GOTTI
description: A career criminal testified in court yesterday that Federal prosecutors gave him drugs, beer and favors while he was in prison to try to get him to give false testimony against John Gotti, who is accused as the head of the Gambino crime family.

title: Bridge: Greed, for Some Doublers, Turns a Profit to a Big Loss
description: The literature of the game is crammed with examples of players who double game contracts because they have length and strength in trumps and end up apologizing to their partner.

title: REAGAN SET TO ASK SWEEPING CHANGES FOR PENSION RULES
description: President Reagan will soon propose sweeping changes in the Federal pension law, making it easier for companies to take surplus money out of pension funds and use it for their own benefit, Administration officials said today.

title: WELLCO ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $275,000 and $500,000 in the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $22,000 and $44,000 in the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS HAS LOSS IN QUARTER
description: The General Dynamics Corporation yesterday reported a fourth-quarter loss of $326.1 million, reflecting a $420.2 million charge for its investment in the Cessna Aircraft Company. Meanwhile, the Lockheed Corporation, also a big military contractor, reported profits for the quarter of $110 million, down 14.1 percent from a year ago.

title: New Publisher For Sports Afield
description: A Sports Afield alumnus, Thomas F. Braun, 36, is leaving as vice president and associate publisher of Financial World magazine to return to his first magazine employer as publisher. He begins at Sports Afield Feb. 10. His first job there was as a sales representative and that followed a year as an account executive with Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn. In his many-publication career, so far he has also touched down at Geo, where he was an associate ad manager, and at Venture, where he served as an associate publisher.

title: CASEY'S TENURE SEEN AS CREATING STRONGER C.I.A.
description: William J. Casey's six-year tenure as Director of Central Intelligence was marked by major budget increases, improved morale, renewed support for anti-Communist insurgents worldwide and sharp Congressional criticism.

title: 2 AIRLINES FINED OVER COCAINE
description: The United States Customs Service has imposed fines of $2.5 million against a Colombian airline and $640,000 against an Ecuadoran carrier after inspectors seized shipments of cocaine hidden aboard their jets, customs officials said today.

description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $831,000 and a $300,000 special gain. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $389,000 and $1,168,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. All results are in Canadian dollars.

description: A poll of potential voters in the 1988 New Hampshire Democratic Presidential primary, made public yesterday, found former Senator Gary Hart of Colorado ahead and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts running second.

description: Assets represent net assets.

title: CHINESE LIMIT CAMPAIGN TO PARTY
description: Apparently alarmed that the drive to silence critics was being carried too far, the Chinese leadership moved today to confine the campaign against intellectual dissent to the ruling Communist Party.

description: President Corazon C. Aquino appeared headed for an overwhelming victory today in a plebiscite on a proposed constitution that had become a test of her mandate.

description: The Defense Department asserted today that an article in The New York Times this morning about the private sale of arms to Iran amounted to ''a dangerously wrong confusion.''

description: The Cyclops Corporation, a steel producer and retailer, said yesterday that it had received a second offer for the company. Last Friday, Audio/ Video Affiliates Inc. offered $75 a share, or slightly more than $300 million.

title: TREK TURNS BACK 275 MILES FROM SOUTH POLE
description: A dogsled expedition that sought to repeat Roald Amundsen's historic journey to the South Pole in 1911 has turned back after almost reaching the Polar Plateau surrounding the South Pole.

title: STERLING ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BAKER, IN SAUDI ARABIA, TO PLEDGE U.S. NEUTRALITY IN IRAN-IRAQ WAR
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d, who has begun a trip to Saudi Arabia, will pledge that the United States will be ''strictly neutral'' in the Iran-Iraq war and will not try to exchange arms for hostages, according to officials traveling with him.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FANNING OUT

title: U.S. ACTS ON POLLUTION IN JERSEY
description: Law-enforcement officials asked a Federal judge today to impose a $472,000 fine on Woodbridge Township, which, they said, had failed to stop polluting the Arthur Kill and Kinsey Creek, which feed into Raritan Bay.

title: Convertible Issue Due From Wyse
description: Wyse Technology, a manufacturer of video display terminals that is based in San Jose, Calif., yesterday announced plans to offer in the Eurobond market about $45 million of convertible subordinated debentures due in 2002.

title: HIS DEPUTY NAMED TO TAKE HIS PLACE
description: President Reagan today accepted the resignation of William J. Casey as Director of Central Intelligence and nominated the agency's deputy director, Robert M. Gates, a career officer, to succeed him.

title: Fossil Found in Canada Ties Birds to Dinosaurs
description: A rare fossil found in Alberta is providing new clues that modern birds are the direct descendants of dinosaurs, Canadian paleontologists reported yesterday.

title: THE MYSTERY IN BORNEO AT 'THE MASSACRE PLACE'
description: In this almost-forgotten corner of Borneo, someone - no one seems to know who - has succeeded in muting a memorial to the victims of one of World War II's least publicized atrocities.

title: THE OTHER IRAN MIDDLEMAN: ALBERT HAKIM'S MANY DEALS
description: Until last week Albert Hakim, an Iranian-American businessman, was the least known figure in the Iran-contra affair. He has not talked to the press, and the Senate Intelligence Committee could not even find him during its investigation.

title: REAGAN WOULD TURN OVER 'EXCERPTS' FROM NOTES
description: The White House announced today that it would turn over ''relevant excerpts'' from President Reagan's personal notes if they are requested by Congressional panels investigating the Administration's secret arms deals with Iran.

title: JAPAN WAGES UP 3.1%
description: The average monthly wage of a Japanese worker rose 3.1 percent in 1986, the Labor Ministry reported today. The increase, adjusted for inflation, was the highest in 13 years.

The company said its provision for income tax in the latest year was $5.5 million and included a refund with respect to 1979 federal income taxes, including interest, of about $15.6 million; the company's provision for income tax in 1985 was $12.9 million. title: U.S. AIDES COMB THROUGH RECORD OF ARMS TALKS IN DEBATE ON ABM
description: Diplomatic records of Soviet-American talks are being used by critics of the Reagan Administration's arms policy to challenge its assertion that the Russians only recently insisted on a narrow interpretation of the Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972.

title: ALISTAIR MacLEAN DIES; BOOKS SOLD IN MILLIONS
description: Alistair MacLean, author of ''The Guns of Navarone'' and one of the biggest-selling adventure writers in the world, died of heart failure yesterday in Munich, West Germany. He was 64 years old and lived near Geneva.

title: GIFT TO THE NEEDIEST PROMPTED BY A 'TUG AT MY CONSCIENCE'
description: ''A short walk through Penn Station reminded me that it was time to get my check in,'' Maria Romano of Manhattan wrote in a letter accompanying her donation of $20 to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. ''To delay is to forget, and the neediest tug at my conscience too much to make me forget.''

title: ONLY APPLAUSE IN AUSTRALIA
description: In the slanting sun off the Indian Ocean, horns of other boats serenaded Stars & Stripes's return to her dock with a 3-0 lead over Kookaburra III in the America's Cup final.

title: OPPOSITION ACCUSES PRETORIA OF BANNING REPORTS OF ABUSE
description: The largest white opposition party, opening an election campaign, accused the Government today of suppressing reports of psychiatric abuse of political detainees.

title: A Summit On the Budget
description: A trillion, for those who lose track of zeros, is a thousand billion. Use this amount to scale up the old quip - ''A billion here, a billion there, why pretty soon you're talking about real money'' - and you have a decent guide to today's economic plight.

title: 2 Pianists Are Named Winners of Auditions
description: Two pianists have won the 1987 Young Concert Artists International audition, and will be presented in recital next season at the 92d Street Y. They are Hung-Kuan Chen, 28 years old, a Taiwan-born citizen of the United States; and the Israeli-born Rina Dokshinsky, 20.

title: Good Pay, Light Work in Albany
description: A powerful warning resounds from the conviction of Richard Rubin, a former top Queens Democratic Party official, for his involvement in a State Legislature payroll padding scheme. Yet the Legislature's leaders are turning a deaf ear.

title: SOME OF THE LESSONS FROM JAPAN AND RUSSIA
description: THE United States Department of Education, in a recent report, called Japan ''a learning society of formidable dimensions.'' The comment brought to mind a similar assessment in 1959, when an American team of experts, headed by the United States Commissioner of Education, returned from the Soviet Union with the observation that the Soviet people had ''a grand passion for education.''

title: WELFARE REVISION HELD A TOP ISSUE ON AGENDA OF NATION'S GOVERNORS
description: Gov. Michael N. Castle of Delaware said today that revision of the nation's welfare system was being transformed from an unpopular and seemingly insoluble problem to an issue at the top of the governors' agenda for the next two years.

description: b-Includes a gain of 23 cents a share from an accounting change.

title: A.T.&T. Sees 'Chaos and Gridlock'
description: The nation's regional telephone holding companies yesterday lauded a proposal by the Department of Justice that would permit them to enter a variety of businesses from which they are now barred.

title: A DOCTOR DENIES HE EXAGGERATED BUMPURS INJURY
description: The emergency room physician who treated Eleanor Bumpurs after she had been fatally shot in an eviction two years ago defended himself in State Supreme Court in the Bronx yesterday against allegations that he had exaggerated her injuries in a newspaper article he wrote about the case.

title: U.S. ASSAILED ON INFANT MORTALITY
description: The Children's Defense Fund, saying the nation's infant mortality rate was one of the highest in the industrialized world, criticized the Government today as not doing enough to promote basic maternity care.

title: BUILDING OUTLAYS DROP
description: Construction spending dipped five-tenths of 1 percent in December, the second consecutive monthly decline, as widespread weakness in private construction offset a sizable gain in governmental spending, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: SCAN-OPTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FEDERAL AIR SURGEON REASSAIGNED IN CONFLICT ON PILOT CERTIFICATION
description: The Federal Aviation Administration's top medical officer has been reassigned, at his request, after being accused of certifying commercial pilots who were medically unfit to fly.

title: Marita Koch Retires
description: Marita Koch, the East German sprint star who set 16 world records, has announced her retirement. The 29-year-old Koch won a gold medal in the women's 400 meters in the 1980 Olympics but missed the 1984 Los Angeles Games because of the Soviet-led boycott. ''For years I have been plagued by trouble with my Achilles' tendon. I have been forced more and more to break training,'' she said. East German news media quoted Koch as saying she now plans to concentrate on completing her studies and practicing medicine. Koch competed in the 100-, 200- and 400-meter dashes. In 1979, she became the first woman to run the 400 meters under 49 seconds, clocking 48.60 seconds. She bettered that mark in 1985, setting her last world record by running the 400 in 47.60.

title: WAXMAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Jan. 15.

title: Talking Business; Today's World Of Commerce: with Pehr Gyllenhammar of Volvo
description: Pehr Gyllenhammar is chairman of Volvo A.B., Scandinavia's largest industrial company. Known in the United States for automobiles, Volvo also makes industrial, marine and aerospace products and is active in energy, food and banking. Last year Volvo earned $237.9 million before taxes on sales of $12.71 billion.

title: A CAUTIOUS PROFESSIONAL: ROBERT MICHAEL GATES
description: Robert M. Gates, President Reagan's nominee to be the next Director of Central Intelligence, is frequently described as a smart, cautious intelligence analyst.

title: DANCE: TWO PREMIERES BY SAN FRANCISCO BALLET
description: William Forsythe and James Kudelka, although not yet household names, are certainly the most original choreographers to emerge from the ballet world since 1980. It doesn't seem like limb-climbing to venture that they will also prove to be among the very best. Each has just created a superb world premiere for the San Francisco Ballet.

title: Kean Asks Limit On Budget Rises
description: Governor Kean called yesterday in his budget message to the New Jersey Legislature for re-enactment of a statutory limit on annual state budget increases.

L.I. Rail Commuters: 'They Seem Normal'
description: LONG ISLAND RAIL ROAD workers, back on the job after the two-week strike, kept a careful eye out for any angry signals from rush-hour commuters Monday morning. ''They seem normal,'' said the conductor, Emmett Smith. ''They seem a little bit better than normal.''

title: Muller Gains in Tennis
description: Gary Muller, coming back from a four-and-a-half-month layoff with torn knee cartilage, defeated Marcel Freeman of Los Angeles today, 7-6, 1-6, 7-6, in the first round of the $465,000 United States Pro Indoor tennis championship.

description: A battle is being waged by the American paper industry to restore the crumbling oligopoly of the brown paper grocery bag, now threatened by the popularity of the plastic sack. And, coincidentally, environmental concern voiced by members of many women's clubs also favors paper.

title: DONALD LOWITZ, ARMS NEGOTIATOR
description: Donald S. Lowitz, a Chicago lawyer who was the chief United States delegate to the United Nations Disarmament Conference here, died Saturday, apparently of a heart attack, American officials said today. He was 57 years old.

title: Georgia Votes Down Mickey
description: Voters in Georgia would no longer be allowed to vote for Mickey Mouse in state elections under a bill passed today by the State Senate. The cartoon character is a popular write-in choice of voters who choose not to vote for a regular candidate. The measure directs election officials to ignore any write-in vote cast for a person who has not filed a notice of a write-in candidacy.

description: The chairman of the British Broadcasting Corporation protested to the Thatcher Government today over a series of police raids on BBC headquarters in Scotland that resulted in the seizure of film and tapes that the Government views as potentially harmful to national security.

title: Nothing Personal
description: After her first game in the United States, Kaz Berry's coaches and teammates congratulated her on the triple double she had just achieved: 14 points, 11 rebounds and 12 steals.

title: KOOP DEFENDS VIEWS ON AIDS EDUCATION
description: Surgeon General C. Everett Koop, assailing conservative critics, appealed to religious broadcasters Monday to help spread the word about the danger of AIDS and defended his controversial views on sex education.

title: Smooth Adolescence
description: Although approximately 20 percent of adolescents are severely troubled, the vast majority of adolescents are not in rebellion against their families, and have a relatively smooth transition from childhood to adulthood, recent research shows. The image of adolescence as an inevitably troubled time is inaccurate, according to research by Daniel Offer, head of the department of psychiatry at Michael Reese Hospital in Chicago. The research was reported in Psychiatria News.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: RANIA TABBAH SOLH, a designer of handmade beaded dresses, came to New York last week for a fashion show at the private nightclub Doubles. A native of Syria, she entered fashion as a retailer in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, where she now lives.

description: * Bayou Resources Inc., Houston, said it had agreed to merge with Patrick Petroleum Company. The merger must be approved by both companies' boards.

description: POLLYANA was right, new research shows.

INSIDE

title: Pacific Leader Hospitalized
description: Prime Minister Walter Lini of the South Pacific island nation of Vanuatu was admitted today to the George Washington University Hospital with what doctors suspected was a cerebral hemorrhage, American officials said, adding that he was reported to be in stable condition and was expected to remain in the hospital for at least several days. Mr. Lini, who is an Anglican priest, was here to attend an annual national breakfast that brings together world figures to pray for peace.

title: Berbick Defends King
description: Trevor Berbick, who lost his World Boxing Council heavyweight championship title to Mike Tyson, has come to the aid of Don King, the promoter who has come under scrutiny for his handling of much of the $2.1 million purse from that fight. The Nevada State Athletic Commission, meeting Friday, expressed concern over advances of $500,000 given to Berbick and the manner in which $500,000 that went to Carl King, Don's son and Berbick's manager, was paid. Berbick did not dispute that about half of his purse went to King and his son Carl for previous advances and managerial fees but said that made no difference to him. ''I got all the money that was coming to me.'' said Berbick.

title: Polish Trade Weakness
description: Poland recorded a trade surplus with the West of only $1.08 billion last year, compared with a target of $1.6 billion, official figures showed today. The Central Statistical Office also reported that the country's debt to Western countries and banks grew at the same time by $4.2 billion, to $33.5 billion. Food exports were badly hit by a temporary Western embargo last spring when Poland was affected by radioactive fallout from the Chernobyl nuclear power station explosion in the Soviet Union.

title: Yugoslav Sailor Asks Asylum

title: Sutter Out for Season
description: The St. Louis Blues, who have already set a club record for games missed in one season because of injury, announced that Brian Sutter would not return until next season. The 30-year-old left wing suffered tissue damage to his left shoulder when checked by a Chicago Blackhawks defenseman, Jack O'Callahan, on Nov. 15. The injury was to an area in which Sutter suffered a fracture last January. Sutter's latest injury is considered rare. He was examined late in November by Dr. Robert Kerlan, a West Coast specialist, and re-examined last week, the Blues said. . . . Dave Hannan, a Pittsburgh Penguins forward, is scheduled to undergo exploratory arthroscopic surgery on Thursday to examine his torn knee cartilage. If the damage proves to be more extensive than believed, he will require conventional surgery and probably miss the rest of the season.

title: G.M. Plan Seen on Plant

title: Big Bet on Brazil
description: Brazil got a big financial boost from the ''Paris Club'' of creditor governments late last month. These creditors, including the United States, arranged for rescheduling $4 billion in near-term payments without requiring Brazil to reach a formal agreement with the International Monetary Fund. That spares a wobbly democratic Government further domestic humiliation. But it also sets a questionable precedent for less creditworthy borrowers.

Cargo cultists are obsessively devoted to mail as a way of life.

title: DANCE: OHIO BALLET IN TWO WORKS BY LAURA DEAN
description: LAURA DEAN has often been a thought-provoking choreographer. She was so again on Saturday night when the Ohio Ballet danced the premieres of two works by her at the Colden Center for the Performing Arts at Queens College. One was yet another of the rigorous studies in patterned movement for which she is famous. The other was something completely different. Yet ''Gravity,'' the work in Ms. Dean's familiar idiom, was the more choreographically substantial effort.

title: JAZZ: WIND AND THUNDER
description: WIND AND THUNDER, the sextet that performed Sunday night at Sweet Basil, pulls third-world instruments into jazz compositions. Bill Cole, the group's leader, plays woodwinds from Africa and the Middle East, and his pieces recall efforts made in the 1960's to mix jazz and non-Western improvising traditions; the early set included a vamp tune, a modal blues and pieces steeped in hard-bop. The difference was in the arrangements, which brought Mr. Cole's instruments and Hafiz Shabazz's African percussion into the foreground.

title: Dennis Leonard Retires
description: Dennis Leonard, who did what many thought was impossible when he pitched for the Kansas City Royals last season after a severe knee injury, retired from baseball yesterday. The 35-year-old right-hander, who ended nearly three years of rehabilitation by pitching a three-hit shutout in his first start last April, said his retirement was a mutual decision with the Royals' general manager, John Schuerholz. ''In the best interests of myself, the organization and my family it would be a good time to kind of step down a little and retire from baseball,'' Leonard said. ''I did not want to diminish the things I was able to accomplish in my career.'' Leonard won more games, 130, than any other American League pitcher from 1975-82. He won 20 or more games three times, the only Royals pitcher to do it more than once, and compiled a 144-106 record in 12 seasons. He suffered a crippling knee injury May 28, 1983 while pitching to Cal Ripken of the Baltimore Orioles, when he stumbled off the mound and tore the tendon below his left knee. Four knee operations later, Leonard strode to the mound at Royals Stadium before a national television audience on April 16 last season to make his first start since the injury. He threw a three-hitter at the Toronto Blue Jays in a 1-0 Kansas City victory. But the season soured for him as it did for the team as a whole, and he finished 8-13 with a 4.44 earned run average.

title: PDA ENGINEERING reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Two Captives
description: Iran and Lebanon have become swamps into which outsiders venture at their peril. This was well understood by Terry Waite, the Anglican envoy last seen in Beirut on Jan. 20. Indeed, he left instructions that no attempt be made to rescue him if he was taken captive. And every Western correspondent knows the risks of accepting even an official invitation to Iran, with its hostile regime of feuding clerical rulers.

title: 21.38 JUMP PUTS DOW AT 2,179.42
description: Wall Street captured another record yesterday as stock prices rose sharply despite warnings on inflation and other matters from Paul A. Volcker, the Federal Reserve Board's chairman.

title: TRANS FINANCIAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $169,000.

title: COMPETING BID FOR VIACOM EMERGES
description: With a bid that competes with a management buyout proposal, an investor group led by Sumner M. Redstone, the theater chain owner, emerged as a suitor for Viacom International Inc. yesterday.

title: Treasury Issues Fall in Price
description: In the face of tepid demand from domestic and foreign investors for this week's $29 billion of Treasury note and bond offerings, prices of outstanding Treasury issues declined modestly yesterday.

title: BUCHANAN, A TOUGH CONSERVATIVE, IS LEAVING POST AT WHITE HOUSE
description: Patrick J. Buchanan, the White House communications director, today announced that he will resign effective March 1, the latest hard-line conservative to depart as President Reagan begins his final two years in office.

title: INSIDE
description: Economic Indicator Soars The Government reported the best advance in years for December, but analysts said one-time factors made the report too optimistic. Page D1.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A profile yesterday of Robert M. Gates, the nominee to become Director of Central Intelligence, incorrectly identified the home state of David L. Boren, the chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee. He is from Oklahoma.

title: Medical Tests Reported For Marcos in Inquiry
description: Ferdinand E. Marcos was scheduled to enter a Honolulu hospital today to determine whether he is fit to appear before a Federal grand jury in Virginia, according to Reagan Administration officials.

title: HOUSE ACTS TO GET RAISE AND EASE POLITICAL HARM
description: Struggling for a way to preserve a scheduled pay increase for themselves and other Federal officials while minimizing the political damage, the leadership of the House of Representatives embarked on a strategy today that may do both.

title: Sports Today
description: AMERICA'S CUP STARS & STRIPES VS. KOOKABURRA III, if necessary, at Fremantle, Australia (TV - ESPN, 11 P.M.) BASKETBALL NETS VS. PHILDELPHIA 76ERS, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:30P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 7:30P.M. Radio - WNEW 1130, 7:20P.M.) COLLEGES: Pittsburgh at Villanova (TV - MSG, 10:30 P.M., tape delay) Missouri at Iowa State (TV -FNN-SCORE, 8 P.M.) HOCKEY RANGERS VS. WASHINGTON CAPITALS, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. (TV - MSG, 7 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.) ISLANDERS VS. CANUCKS, at Vancouver, 10:35 P.M. (TV -SportsChannel, 10:30 P.M. Radio -WOR 710, 10:30 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS HARNESS RACING: Roosevelt 7:30P.M. Meadowlands, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, 12:30 A.M.) THOROUGHBRED RACING: Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 6:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.)

title: Wrong Voting Rights Burden
description: Black Americans were robbed of their right to vote for a century, until the 1965 Voting Rights Act changed the burden of proof. No longer could states with the worst histories of abuse keep changing their election laws as fast as civil rights lawyers could prove them discriminatory. Congress decreed that new election laws could not take effect until the state or locality proved that they would not deprive minorities of voting power. Now, Attorney General Meese would set back the clock.

title: DONALD ARONOW, BOAT DESIGNER AND CHAMION RACER, SHOT TO DEATH
description: Donald Aronow, a boat builder and champion racer who designed the sleek, speedy Cigarette boat, was shot to death today, the authorities said.

title: Xerox, VMS in Talks
description: The Xerox Corporation said that it was negotiating with VMS Realty Partners Inc. to acquire part of the real estate syndicator but that no agreement had been signed. An article in today's Wall Street Journal said that Xerox had agreed in principle to buy 25 percent of VMS as part of a $200 million transaction, but Xerox would not confirm or deny any such details. Telephone calls to Chicago-based VMS were not returned.

title: Falcons Pick Campbell
description: After a six-week search for someone to replace the dismissed Dan Henning, the Atlanta Falcons found a new head coach within their own ranks yesterday, naming their defensive coordinator, Marion Campbell, to the post. ''We talked a great deal about hiring a name coach,'' the Falcons' owner, Rankin Smith, said. ''The very best man for the job was here all the time.'' This will be the second stint in Atlanta for the 57-year-old Campbell, who took over in the middle of the 1974 season, where he had a 6-19 record. Campbell moved to Philadelphia, where he was an assistant on Dick Vermeil's Super Bowl Eagles in 1981, and succeeded Vermeil, who quit following the 1982 season. Campbell was head coach of the Eagles for three seasons and was dismissed after the 1985 season.

title: THE LATEST PRODIGAL SON
description: First there was Lee Mazzilli, back from his wanderings, reaching base for the Mets in their World Series rallies. Then there was Phil McConkey, fresh from his four-week exile in Green Bay, making three dashing plays in the Super Bowl for the Giants.

title: FACTORY ORDERS UP
description: Factory orders climbed a healthy 1.2 percent in December as demand for civilian goods showed the biggest monthly increase in more than eight years, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Judge Agrees to Quash Two Boesky Subpoenas
description: A Federal district judge in Dallas quashed two subpoenas yesterday that had been issued to the arbitrager Ivan F. Boesky in a civil lawsuit after United States Attorney Rudolph W. Giuliani said they would interfere with criminal investigations under way.

title: TRY AND EXPERIMENT TO FOOL THE SENSES
description: REFINING the palate means tasting, tasting and tasting again. If you do all this tasting at once - as professional food tasters do - then you come up against a problem called sensory adaptation.

title: EMERSON ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LACROIX TO RETHINK STYLE
description: Christian Lacroix, regarded by many as the most exciting couture designer these days, says that in his new salon he will probably abandon the bustles, crinoline petticoats and poufs that propelled him to stardom and pushed style onto a different path.

title: CONGRESS AND THE IRAN FIASCO
description: The creation of select congressional committees to investigate the Iran-contra fiasco should not absolve Congress from its share of the blame for the affair.

title: SINGING UNSUNG WINES
description: A few steps from Jerome Libeskind, export manager for a barrel maker in the Cognac region of France, a platoon of drained wine bottles covered a table. One label read, ''Fenn Valley 1985, Lake Michigan, Johannesberg Riesling''; another, ''Ingleside Plantation, Chesapeake Blanc,'' identifying a nonvintage white from Virginia.

title: BALDWIN TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ABC to Meet Critics Of 'Amerika' TV Series
description: Representatives of one of several groups protesting the upcoming ABC mini-series ''Amerika'' have been invited to meet with network officials this week.

title: GRASS-ROOTS POLITICS FORCED HANOI SHAKE-UP
description: Pressure from grass-roots party organizations forced the sweeping changes in the Vietnamese Communist Party leadership in December, according to a Western diplomat based in Hanoi.

title: U.S. IS CONSIDERING MUCH WIDER TESTS FOR AIDS INFECTION
description: Federal health officials said today that they were considering recommending much wider blood testing for infection by the AIDS virus, including tests for all applicants for marriage licenses and for everyone who is hospitalized or who is treated for pregnancy or for sexually transmitted diseases.

title: GUARDIAN PACKAGING CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Let's End the Westway War
description: LEAD: What is the condition of New York City's West Side waterfront? In a word, paralyzed. The replacement for the old West Side Highway remains unbuilt. The old one continues to decay. The waterfront deteriorates. Development occurs but is unplanned. Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch appointed the private-public West Side Task Force to cut through the web of bitterness and mistrust woven during the decade-long Westway war.

title: Seasoned Oilmen In Shamrock Posts
description: The two men named by the Diamond Shamrock Corporation to head the independent companies it intends to break itself into are relatively new to Shamrock, but they are long on experience.

title: FISERV INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $200,000 from the reversal of a tax credit. c-Includes a tax credit of $720,000. d-Net loss after a loss of $34,000 from the reversal of a tax credit. e-Includes a tax credit of $164,000.

title: KEMPER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains on the sale of investments of $15,071,000 for the quarter and $52,985,000 for the year. c-Includes gains on the sale of investments of $7,370,000 for the quarter and $17,114,000 for the year.

title: The U.N. Today: Feb. 4, 1987
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: Roving Robot Move Into Industry
description: THE mobile robot installed last month at the Orlando, Fla., semiconductor plant of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is unlikely to remind anyone of ballistic missiles or jet aircraft, its technological forebears. Scooter, as A.T.&T. calls the robot, rolls along at a top speed of less than one mile an hour, carries 30 pounds of semiconductor wafers between processing stations, and stops short when it bumps into a toe or other obstruction.

title: SEOUL BARS RALLY FOR DEAD STUDENT
description: The Government said today that it would block a major rally planned here Saturday to mourn the torture and killing of a student protester in police custody.

title: Hearing for S.M.U.
description: Officials of Southern Methodist University said yesterday they will be summoned before the N.C.A.A. Committee on Infractions Feb. 13 in San Diego for a hearing to decide the fate of the school's football program. David Berst, the N.C.A.A. enforcement director, said S.M.U. officials cooperated with the N.C.A.A. to try to get the investigation completed in time. The football program could be suspended for up to two years if the school is found guilty of violations that occurred after the school was placed on probation in 1983 for earlier violations. In addition, there are reports that the N.C.A.A. has been asked to investigate S.M.U.'s recruiting of two Nigerian sprinters, Celestine Okwilagwe and Emeric Pitt, for the track team.

title: CITADEL HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Earnings for 1986 and 1985 were affected by large, unusual legal, consulting and other expenses incurred in connection with the disputed merger and, in 1986, the canceled exchange offer of Great Western Financial Corp. These expenses amounted to $3.2 million in 1986 and $2.6 million in 1985.

title: The Next Act in the Philippines
description: That gripping political drama in the Philippines continues to leave a world audience agape. Only last week, President Corazon Aquino was pursued by mutinous troops and leftist rioters. Egging them on from Hawaii were the Marcoses, waiting to be implored to return from exile once people glimpsed TV pictures of the ex-President flexing his pectorals and his wife shopping for combat fatigues.

title: PENNZOIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $32 million for the quarter and year from the recovery of assets from a retirement plan. The year also includes a charge of $58 million from the writedown of oil and gas properties and a $23.1 million charge in connection with a debenture exchange. c-Net loss d-After a loss of $75 million from discontinued operations for the quarter and year.

title: ROCKEFELLER CENTER PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Rockefeller Center Properties Inc. began operations on Sept. 19, 1985, the reported results for 1985 reflect only 15 weeks of operations.

title: Mmmm?
description: Z is what they call him, but that's not his name. M is, however. Z is just his nickname, short for Zenon. M is short already. Except that he's 6 feet 7 inches tall. Z is, that is, or rather M is. Z M, if you will, except nobody calls him that. His teammates on the Cal Poly-Pomona basketball squad just call him Z. If they wanted to be formal, they'd call him Zenon M, which is really his name. All of it.

title: GOTTI WITNESS INSISTS HE LIED TO AUTHORITIES
description: A Federal prosecutor suggested in court yesterday that a key defense witness was disavowing information he had given earlier against John Gotti because he feared for his safety in jail.

title: TRIBUNE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes nonrecurring charges of $20.2 million, or 50 cents a share, from the disposition of chemical operations and the termination of interest-rate swaps. c-Includes nonrecurring gains of $180.6 million, or 4.47 a share, from the sale of the Los Angeles Daily News, cable television systems and other assets, and the nonrecurring charges of $20.2 million taken in the fourth quarter. Prior-year earnings per share include nonrecurring gains of 9 cents a share from the sale of assets.

title: TRANSCAPITAL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss of $922,000. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $2,644,000.

title: LIBERTY FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Science Unable to Test Creationism's 'Facts'
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCEPT DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a $1,238,000 provision for a loss on the sale of restaurants.

title: EX-WEDTECH AIDES SAID TO IMPLICATE BIAGGI AND SIMON
description: Former top executives of the Wedtech Corporation, a South Bronx military contractor, told Federal investigators last week that they had made payoffs to 20 government officials, including two Bronx Congressmen and Borough President Stanley Simon, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Correction on Quinn
description: Pat Quinn has not been banned from coaching in the National Hockey League until the 1990-91 season. He has only been prohibited from coaching the Vancouver Canucks until that time. The ban had been ordered by the N.H.L. president, John Ziegler, last Friday, and the league sent out a corrected version yesterday. Quinn, in the final year of a three-year contract with the Kings, was expelled from the league Jan. 9 because, while still coaching the Los Angeles Kings, he had accepted money from the Canucks to become their president and general manager next season. Quinn remains barred from all league activities until after this June's annual N.H.L. meetings.

title: Jersey Assemblyman Charged With Fraud
description: A New Jersey State Assemblyman was among nine people and five companies indicted on fraud and corruption charges involving the purchase of military clothing, Federal officials said yesterday.

title: SHOW BY A SOVIET PAINTER BRINGS A CROWD BUT NOT HIM
description: The opening of a show by the Soviet painter Yuri Larin - his first outside the Soviet Union - brought a lively crowd to the tiny upstairs art gallery at Books & Company, 939 Madison Avenue, on Monday night. But one important person was missing: the painter himself. Though he had been invited to attend by the show's sponsors here, the Soviet authorities said the invitation came too late to make the arrangements.

title: FOREMOST CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes investment gains of $733,000 for the quarter and $480,000 for the year. Also, the latest year is after a pre-tax charge of $23 million, or $12.4 million after-tax, pertaining to certain insurance products that the company discontinued. c-Includes investment gains of $110,000 for the quarter and $397,000 for the year.

title: Truth in Legislating
description: On the House floor and in speeches and news conferences elsewhere, Democratic and Republican leaders are often sharply critical of one another, rarely hesitating to take a partisan swing when some political advantage can be seen. But, occasionally, personal interest obscures the compulsion for either combat or candor.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL GETS OFFER
description: A Chicago doctor, Leroy A. Pesch, offered yesterday to pay $1.7 billion in cash for American Medical International Inc. of Beverly Hills, Calif., one of the nation's biggest hospital companies.

title: Revive Public Service
description: LEAD: Although it has not attracted urgent calls for action, the gradual erosion of interest in public service could have dangerous long-term consequences.

title: REAGAN AND ADVISERS MEET ON DEPLOYING OF 'STAR WARS'
description: President Reagan met today with senior members of his Administration to consider Pentagon proposals for the early deployment of a partial space-based missile defense system.

title: MAYORS AND MUNICIPAL WORKERS RALLY IN TRENTON
description: The day after Governor Kean told the Legislature that the economy of the state was booming and said ''these are our glory days,'' a group of urban mayors and 1,300 municipal workers who have received layoff notices rallied at the Capitol today to demand a share of the good times.

title: ARROW AUTOMOTIVE INDUSRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Net loss

title: DISCOVERIES
description: 1.Whimsy in a Pitcher Marco Zanini has reinvented the pitcher. The Italian designer has turned it into an object of whimsy, with a straight edge. The pitcher is white ceramic, with a pale blue handle. It is also available in black or brown for $50 in Chelsea Passage on the main floor at Barneys New York, Seventh Avenue and 17th Street. #2.Drama on the Toes This black leather flat will go anywhere. Sleek and simple, it is finished with a dramatic flourish - a hand-painted ceramic mask that sits atop the toes. Made in Italy, the shoe is also available in white. The price is $165 at Ecco, 324 Columbus Avenue, at 75th Street; 111 Thompson Street, between Spring and Prince Streets; and 94 Seventh Avenue, between 15th and 16th Streets. #3.Watch as Accessory Watch accessories are making fashion news. This one, from Anne Klein, is the centerpiece of a handsome silver-plated chain. It costs $145 in fashion watches on the first floor at Macy's Herald Square (not at branch stores). #4.Bow Tie Chic Hugh Dunford Wood is an English artist whose hand-painted silk bow ties are certain to make a stylish impression. The one shown here is a mix of royal blue, lime green, orange and yellow. For $60 at Jonal, 17 East 67th Street.

title: Claims Court Head Named
description: Governor Cuomo today named Judge Donald J. Corbett Jr. of Rochester as Presiding Judge of the state Court of Claims. Judge Corbett, who was appointed to the court in 1983 by Mr. Cuomo, will succeed Judge Harold E. Koreman. He will be paid $87,500 a year. Judge Corbett, who is 50 years old, is a graduate of the University of Notre Dame and Albany Law School.

title: TWO YOUNG BORTHERS IN JERSEY DONATE $100 TO HELP NEEDIEST
description: Two young brothers in New Jersey have made their fourth annual contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Robert Aaron, 6 years old, and his brother, David, 11, who live in Wayside, gave $100 to the 75th annual appeal.

title: HITTING THE TASTE JACKPOT TAKES PRACTICE AND AN EAGER PALATE
description: CREATING a splendid new dish, spicing a familiar one to perfection or simply savoring another's cooking with the culinary equivalent of a jeweler's eye: These are hallmarks of a great palate. Such gustatory distinction is within the reach of all who dare, according to leading chefs, taste researchers and eaters.

title: Orioles Pursue Guidry
description: Ron Guidry's agent, Reggie Ringuet, said yesterday he would be in Baltimore next Monday to meet with Hank Peters, the Orioles' general manager. The Orioles, who have been the most active of the clubs interested in Guidry, are believed to be ready to offer the free-agent pitcher a one-year contract for a salary between $600,000 and $700,000. Ringuet said he also spoke with Andy MacPhail, vice president for personnel of the Minnesota Twins and tentatively arranged a meeting with him next week. The Twins yesterday traded Neal Heaton, a left-handed starter, to Montreal for Jeff Reardon, a reliever. . . . Joe Niekro, the Yankees' knuckleball pitcher, entered New York University Medical Center, where, the Yankees said, he will spend a few days having his back examined and treated. Lou D'Ermilio, a club spokesman, said Niekro suffered a slightly sprained lower back when he bent over at home in Lakeland, Fla. . . . Gary Gaetti of Minnesota and Mark Davis of San Francisco reached agreement on one-year contracts, reducing to 54 the number of arbitration cases left. Gaetti agreed to a $900,000 salary, the largest given to a player in arbitration this winter.

title: Ashley vs. Rhett
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: YOUNG ADULTS AT HOME
description: Delayed marriage and the high cost of living are keeping more young adults at home with their parents, a new study shows.

title: COLONIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Shamrock Reports $42.2 Million Loss
description: A day after announcing a restructuring intended to fend off a takeover bid, the Diamond Shamrock Corporation said today it lost $42.2 million in the fourth quarter. The loss compared with a profit of $28.7 million in the 1985 quarter.

title: 1 BLUEBLOOD DEFEATS ANOTHER
description: Voters today re-elected to a second term as mayor an incumbent who traces her roots to French kings over a challenger descended from the last of Russia's czars.

title: Shrinking Choices
description: To the Editor:

title: DR. STERN SAYS SHE FEELS SHE IS BABY M'S MOTHER
description: The wife of Baby M's father testified today that she considered herself the mother of the infant and strongly opposed having the baby see her natural mother, Mary Beth Whitehead, until she was a teen-ager.

title: Pepsico Rise of 30.6%
description: Pepsico Inc., citing lower tax rates and fewer shares outstanding, said yesterday that earnings in its fourth fiscal quarter rose 30.6 percent on a 35.1 increase in sales.

title: G.M. TO PRODUCE NEW MINI-VANS IN UPSTATE PLANT
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would assemble a new fiberglass-body mini-van at its plant here, insuring production and thousands of jobs well into the 1990's.

title: Administration Details Cuts In Benefits for Some Veterans
description: The head of the Veterans Administration told Congress today that the Reagan Administration would eliminate money for medical treatment of veterans with incomes above certain levels who did not have a service-related disability.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: A FRIGID Tuesday evening. Mary Ann Jung is crossing East 87th Street. Ahead of her a woman is walking a golden retriever, which, Ms. Jung notices, has something dangling from its mouth. Catching up, she sees that the something is a red suede glove; the woman wears a red suede glove on one hand while her other hand, clenched from the cold, is bare.

title: Leading Indicators Surge 2.1%
description: The Government index designed to predict the course of the economy surged 2.1 percent in December, the biggest gain in nearly four years, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: MOST EMPLOYERS RATE THE DISABLED AS GOOD OR BETTER, SURVEY FINDS
description: A great majority of employers rated the performance of disabled workers as ''good'' to ''excellent'' in a recent poll by Louis Harris & Associates. But only 43 percent of the 921 companies surveyed said they had hired a disabled person in the last year, because of a shortage of qualified applicants.

title: NEWS SUMMRY: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 4, 1987
description: International A2-A9 Brezhnev's son-in-law is being held in Moscow after his arrest on corruption charges, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said. The son-in-law was a top Interior Ministry official until 1984. Page A1 In a deal for Awacs radar planes in 1981, King Fahd and other Saudi Arabian officials agreed to aid anti-Communist guerrilla groups, U.S. officials said. A1 Western journalists in Iran recently observed a regime that has subdued virtually all opposition outside its ranks but that suffers increasingly volatile internal rivalries. A1 Iraq is unlikely to reverse damage -military, political and psychological - that Iran has wrought in its latest offensive despite Baghdad's superior air and firepower, experts say. A6 Attempts to win the release of an American journalist detained in Iran are being undertaken by governments friendly to both the United States and Iran, American officials and diplomatic sources said. A3 Hearings to confirm Robert Gates, the newly nominated Director of Central Intelligence, will not be an occasion for a full-scale public review of the agency's role in the Iran-contra affair, a Senator said. A7 Military analysis: Seizures in Beirut of hostages have prompted a refining of contingency plans for retaliatory air strikes against terrorist camps in the Middle East, Pentagon sources said. A3 Mr. Reagan weighed Pentagon plans for the early deployment of a partial ''Star Wars'' system in a meeting with senior members of his Administration, and reportedly no decision was made. A2 Salvador's soul is in small towns that cover the countryside. The long civil war in which more than 60,000 people have been killed has ground the peasants in these dust-filled hamlets very small. A4 A party shake-up in Vietnam was the result of pressure from grass-roots Communist organizations, according to a Western diplomat based in Hanoi whose impressions were supported by American scholars. A8 NATIONAL A12-21, D24 Wider use of an AIDS test is being considered by Federal health officials, they said. The plan would include testing all applicants for marriage licenses and patients who enter hospitals. A1 The House overrode a veto of a bill aimed at cleaning up the nation's water at a cost of $20 billion. The Senate is expected to take up the measure today, and Democratic leaders predicted a similar override. A1 180 U.S. farms disappear each day, victims of consolidation, changing economics, poor management, bad luck, high interest rates, low crop prices, emotional and financial despair or some of each. A1 U.S. trade figures may be deceiving because it will take more than currency adjustments to close the record $169.8 billion gap between what America bought from abroad in 1986 and what it was able to sell. A1 The House deferred a vote on raises for lawmakers and other Federal officials until after the raises were to take effect, at 12:01 this morning. The vote will thus be either meaningless or the first step in a legal battle to rescind the raises. A13 An amendment on speed limits that would allows states to raise the limit on rural interstate highways to 65 miles an hour was approved by the Senate, 65 to 33. A12 Patrick J. Buchanan will resign from his post as White House communications director effective March 1, he announced. He is the latest hard-line conservative to depart as President Reagan begins his final two years in office. A19 Acid rain poses a serious threat to human health that is too significant to defer protective action, according to representatives of major public health groups who addressed a Congressional panel. A12 Fort Worth is an 'In' place, according to W, the international fashion and society publication that publishes an annual list of such things. But its residents are not overly impressed by the honor. A12 The hallmarks of a great palate, creating a splendid new dish, spicing a familiar one to perfection or savoring another's cooking, are within reach of all who dare, leading chefs and researchers say. A1 New evidence from Howard Beach indicates that white youths chased Michael Griffith onto the Belt Parkway, where he was killed by a car on the night of Dec. 19-20, law-enforcement sources say. A1 765 police officers were promoted to the rank of sergeant, more than three and a half years after they were tested for eligibility and after months of litigation over the exam. B1 Promotions end frustration B6 G.M. will stay in North Tarrytown, N.Y., to assemble a new fiberglass-body mini-van at its plant there, the company announced, insuring production and thousands of jobs well into the 1990's.
