title: Prep Football's Injury List
description: Football is a contact sport, after all, and, as every hand-wringing parent knows, a young player will get hurt from time to time. Until now, however, no one has had a clear idea of just how many injuries high school players suffer, or of what type and severity.

title: IRAQI WAR DAMAGE VIEWED AS DECISIVE
description: Iraq appears unlikely to be able to reverse the military, political and psychological damage Iran has wrought in its latest military offensive despite Baghdad's superior air and firepower, according to assessments by experienced military and political experts in the Middle East.

title: REAL ESTATE
description: WHEN a group of developers announced more than a year ago that they would build on the site of a West 54th Street parking lot between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, their plan was for a mixed-use project that would combine rental apartments and a hotel in the same 46-story structure.

title: INCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. All figures are in U.S. funds. The company said charges for production closings and severance costs totaled $28 million in 1986, compared with $19 million in 1985. Also, currency translation adjustments, which provided a gain of $13 million in 1985, resulted in a $2 million loss in 1986. Inco also said the 1986 results reflect adoption, from Jan.1, 1986, of the pension accounting standard issued in April by the Canadian Institute of Chartered Accountants, which increased after-tax results by $3 million for the latest quarter and $8 million for 1986.

title: DANCE: BALLET RAMBERT AT CITY CENTER
description: ONE of the hallowed names in English dance is that of Ballet Rambert, the company that produced two great choreographers - Frederick Ashton and Antony Tudor - under the aegis of its founder, the late Marie Rambert.

title: UNTRENDY FORT WORTH IS DEEMED 'IN'
description: Steve Fisher is not a regular reader of W, the international fashion and society publication, so he was unaware that it recently included Fort Worth in its much-followed annual list of ''In'' places, people and things.

title: Bird Calls
description: Dick Vermeil wasn't available, and neither was Terry Donahue. Nor were Bill Parcells, Mike Ditka or Dan Reeves. So before Rankin and Taylor Smith finally settled on Marion Campbell yesterday as coach of their football team, cars all over Atlanta had begun sporting this bumper sticker: ''Honk if you've turned down the Falcons.''

title: 'Cinderella' to Return
description: The Lyons Opera Ballet will return to City Center with its highly praised production of ''Cinderella,'' or ''Cendrillon,'' for two weeks starting May 18, with an option to renew for a third week. The full-evening ballet, which sold out most of its performances at the theater last month, was choreographed by Maguy Marin, a French experimentalist. It takes a childlike view of the traditional ''Cinderella'' fairy tale and was set to music by Prokofiev. The company will also perform in the United States in September, when it will appear in the Los Angeles Arts Festival before touring the West Coast.

title: A CHEF'S LITMUS TEST
description: FOR chefs, a finely honed palate is an essential piece of equipment. Their careers hang on their ability to discern, recall and re-create tastes. In recent interviews, The Living Section asked Dorothy Cann, the director of the French Culinary Institute in New York City; Dieter Hannig, the director of Hilton International's food research center, also in New York, and Joyce Goldstein, chef-owner of Square One Restaurant in San Francisco, to address the role of the palate in a chef's education and performance. Excerpts follow. Dorothy Cann Q.How do you define palate? A.From an educator's point of view, it is the instrument that we use to taste. Educators, as opposed to practicing chefs, look at the palate in terms of three different levels.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IT has been said, with only slight exaggeration, that you would need an encyclopedia to outline the many kinds of fish marketed under the name of sole or flounder. In ''The Encyclopedia of Fish'' by A. J. McClane (Holt, Rinehart & Winston, 1977), the section on sole has nearly a dozen entries, including Dover sole, English sole, Rex sole, sand sole and 15 varieties of the type of sole known as flounder, ranging from plaice to turbot. (Yes, flounder is a member of the sole family.) One of my favorite flounders is the one commonly known as halibut. (To make things even more confusing, there are at least four kinds of halibut - Atlantic halibut, California halibut, Greenland halibut and Pacific halibut.) Its delicate flavor and admirable texture give flounder a melt-in-the-mouth quality.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing Walliser Wins Second Gold Medal: Maria Walliser mastered a tough supergiant slalom course with a daring and nearly flawless run yesterday at Crans-Montana, Switzerland, to win her second gold medal at the world Alpine championships. Walliser clinched the gold medal by outracing her teammate, Michela Figini, whom she had beaten in the downhill. Mateja Svet, the rising Yugoslav star who was involved in a car crash three days ago, took the bronze medal in 1:20.23.(AP) N.B.A. Hawks 126, Celtics 123: Dominique Wilkins capped a 54-point performance with a 3-point play with 17 seconds left in overtime, then added a pair of free throws to give Atlanta the victory. Wilkins, who had been bothered by a back injury, didn't get going until after intermission. He scored 13 points in the third quarter, 18 in the fourth and 9 in overtime. It was the third-highest scoring night of his career and his 15th game scoring 40 or more. He scored 16 of Atlanta's last 17 points in regulation, including a basket to tie it at 111 and force the overtime. Then he got the first basket of the overtime. After John Battle's basket, Wilkins stole the ball and scored to give Atlanta a 117-111 lead. Kevin McHale, who wound up with 36 points, got a 3-point play to make it 117-114, but Tree Rollins slammed home a rebound and Glenn Rivers scored to give Atlanta a 121-117 lead. One free throw by McHale and two by Larry Bird made it 121-120. Wilkins got the 3-point play. Bird countered with a 3-point basket to cut the margin to one with 10 seconds to play. Wilkins was fouled on the inbound play and sank two free throws. Bird's 3-point attempt glanced off the back of the rim as time ran out.(AP) 76ers 99, Pacers 94: Roy Hinson and Andrew Toney scored 9 points apiece in the final quarter as Philadelphia rallied to defeat Indiana. It was the Pacers' seventh consecutive loss. Indiana, which led by as many as 9 points in the first half, held an 80-73 advantage with 10:20 left in the game on a rebound basket by Wayman Tisdale. But the 76ers rallied with an 18-10 streak, and Toney gave them their first lead at 91-90 with 4:29 to play. The teams traded points down the stretch until Toney, who had not scored a point until the fourth quarter, broke the 93-93 tie with an 18-foot jumper with 47 seconds left. Tisdale, who had 9 fourth-quarter points for the Pacers, hit one of two free throws to make the score 95-94 with 19 seconds left. But Hinson's two free throws with 10 seconds to play secured the victory.(AP) Nuggets 107, Rockets 105: Lafayette Lever had double figures in points, rebounds and assists for the 10th time this season and Mike Evans scored the go-ahead points with 17 seconds left, giving Denver the victory. The Rockets played most of the game without the starting All-Star forward, Ralph Sampson, who suffered a knee injury in the first quarter. Team doctors said Sampson may have suffered torn cartilage in his left knee. Lever had 26 points, 14 rebounds and 11 assists as the Nuggets rallied from a 10-point deficit late in the third quarter. Sampson went to the sidelines for the first time with six minutes to play in the first quarter. He returned briefly in the second quarter but hobbled off again and did not return.(AP) N.H.L. Nordiques 4, Canadiens 1: Michel Goulet extended his scoring streak to four games with a goal and an assist at Quebec. Anton Stastny, Risto Siltanen and Basil McRae also scored for Quebec, which hasn't lost to the Canadiens at the Colisee in two years. The Nordiques bottled up the Canadiens in the first two periods, outshooting Montreal by 20-12 and taking a 4-0 lead. Stastny opened the scoring at 3:25 of the first period with his 17th goal of the season. A Montreal defenseman, Petr Svoboda, blocked the first shot but Stastny made his second effort count and sent a wrist shot over Patrick Roy's shoulder into the net. The Canadiens were penalized for having too many skaters on the ice late in the period, and the Nordiques took advantage of the manpower advantage when Siltanen took a cross-ice pass from David Shaw and whistled a slap shot past Roy's glove with seven seconds left in the opening period. Quebec doubled the score in the second period. Goulet breezed past Chris Chelios and scored his 30th goal of the season with a slick backhanded shot into the lower right corner at 2:11. About three minutes later, Paul Gillis and McRae broke in on Roy and McRae swept Gillis's pass into the net at 5:23. The Canadiens finally beat Mario Gosselin at 3:36 of the third period when Claude Lemieux batted a rebound into the net.(AP) Oilers 4, Blues 2: Mark Napier and Kevin Lowe scored in the first 13 minutes as Edmonton won in St. Louis for the first time in three seasons. Grant Fuhr's strong goaltending helped. Fuhr, making his first start in eight games since he was injured on Jan. 17, withstood a four-shot St. Louis power play midway through the second period. The saves preserved Edmonton's 2-1 lead and the Oilers pulled away in the final period when Jari Kurri and Craig MacTavish scored four minutes apart. The outcome snapped a four-game unbeaten streak for St. Louis, which finished a homestand with a 3-1-1 record. The loss was the Blues' first at home against Edmonton in three seasons.(AP) Indoor Soccer Blast 8, Dynamo Moscow 7: Dynamo Moscow lost for the fourth straight time in its six-city tour of the Major Indoor Soccer League, falling to the Baltimore Blast despite three goals from Vasily Karataev. The touring Soviet team fell prey to six two-minute penalties, as Baltimore, in third place in the Eastern Division, scored four power-play goals and outshot the visitors, 44-38. (AP)

title: DIET SOFT DRINKS: TOO GOOD TO BE TRUE?
description: LEAD: IN America, where we now drink more soft drinks than any other beverage, the thrill of getting something for nothing - sweetness without calories - is increasingly irresistible. As a result, the number of diet soft drinks consumed leaps higher yearly. In 1985, Americans drank 103 diet soft drinks per person, almost double the per person consumption level of 55 in 1980.

title: Louisville Dropout
description: Kevin Walls, a sophomore who started nine games this season before being relegated to the bench, quit the Louisville basketball team yesterday, Coach Denny Crum said. Walls's move follows his refusal to enter Monday night's game against South Carolina in the last minutes. Walls had played less than one minute in the first half of Louisville's 90-62 victory. ''I told him he has to follow the same rules as everyone else on the team,'' Crum said. ''He chose not to do so and elected to quit the team. It was his decision.'' Walls, who once averaged 44.8 points for Camden (N.J.) High but was averaging only 3.6 this season, could not immediately be reached for comment.

title: Tucson Electric

In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Tucson said it was seeking a seat on Citadel's board and offered to acquire up to 400,000 unissued Citadel shares, or an additional 12 percent of the common stock, for $57 a share. In return, Tucson would agree not to acquire more than 24.9 percent of Citadel's stock. Citadel's chairman, James A. Taylor, declined comment on Tucson's proposals.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE PROPHETEERS. By Max Apple. 306 pages. Harper & Row. Cloth, $16.95; paper, $7.95. MOST satirists are pretty angry fellows - writing, for them, is a way of expressing their rage at the inanities of society and the stupidities of their colleagues in the human race through caricature, pratfalls and simple outrageous humor. Just think of Robert Coover's fierce, obscene portrait of America in ''The Public Burning.'' Max Apple's latest novel, ''The Propheteers,'' sets out to create a similarly mythic portrait of this nation - and it also mixes real people with wholly invented events in a funny, postmodern brew of slapstick farce - but like the author's earlier works, its animating impulse is not rage but amused reverence, its dominant tone tender nostalgia rather than indignance or disgust. The result is a sort of children's cartoon, artfully outlined with sharp brushstrokes, then inked-in in bright, primary colors.

title: Big Operators Give Up
description: No one knows exactly how many Americans have left farms in recent times, voluntarily or not. The Agriculture Department found last June that the number of farms had dropped 65,000 in the previous 52 weeks, to 2.21 million, a loss of one farm about every eight minutes. Experts estimate there are about three people on each farm, meaning nearly 200,000 rural Americans must seek new lives.

title: Safe, Speedy Shucking
description: ANYONE who has watched a master oyster shucker at an oyster bar must marvel at the speed and skill with which the deed is done. Shucking oysters, however, is more than merely separating the shells: there is a right way and a wrong way. The aim is to open the shell cleanly without severing the fragile meat or spilling the brine. The technique illustrated here can make you an expert with a bit of practice. Before starting, rinse the shells well under cold running water to remove any grit and sand that could get into the meat. STEP 1 Hold the oyster over a cutting surface, the flatter side up and the hinge away from you. With a towel, protect your hand against slips of the oyster knife. Insert the blade into the hinge at the narrow tip. Wiggle the knife as you press it farther into the shell. Be sure to hold the oyster flat to prevent the brine from spilling. STEP 2 When the tip of the blade is securely inside the shell, begin to twist it. The hinge should ''pop'' as it separates. Run the blade around the perimeter, always exerting pressure against the top shell - you do not want to cut through the meat. STEP 3 Clean the knife and, just before serving, run the blade under the oyster meat to sever the muscle that holds it to the shell. If you do this too far in advance of serving, the meat will atrophy and lose flavor. A quick mignonette sauce is good with fresh oysters. In a small bowl combine 4 tablespoons of red wine vinegar, 1/2 teaspoon of coarsely crushed white pepper and 1 tablespoon of minced shallots.

description: In the Broadway column in Weekend last Friday, the director of ''Breaking the Code,'' a play starring Derek Jacobi that will be coming to New York this fall, was misidentified.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Loving Calories Goodies for Valentine's Day, 10 days away, run from the sublime to heart-shaped hallah bread. The bread is being made by Au P'tit Pain, 681 Lexington Avenue (56th Street), in sizes that run from small ( 1/4 pound, 80 cents) to medium ( 1/2 pound, $1.50) to large (1 pound, $2.50) to largest (2 pounds, $5), all inscribed with ''Happy Valentine'' in chocolate. Ginger and honey cookies in the shapes of hearts and bears trimmed in pink and red velvet and lace are the handiwork of Ann Arlen.

title: GREAT NORTHERN NEKOOSA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included the reversal of $3.2 million of investment tax credit taken in the first nine months. c-After a pre-tax charge of $41 million in the second quarter for the cost of reducing operations and implementing productivity improvement programs at the company's Great Northern Paper division in Maine.

title: IRAN'S UNPREDICTABLE BEHAVIOR REFLECTS RIVALRIES IN REGIME
description: Eager young men clutching fistfuls of cash line the sidewalks along a stretch of Ferdowsi Street just a hundred yards or so from the main offices of Iran's central bank.

title: YACHTING SOCIETY, AUSTRALIA STYLE: A DISTINCT CHANGES OF CHARACTER
description: The aura of the America's Cup, with its flotilla of sumptuous yachts, lavish parties and jet-set crowds, has changed character in the Land Down Under.

title: HOPES FOR DOLLAR MEETING STIR AGAIN
description: A meeting this month of the United States and other countries to talk about the dollar still appears possible, even though the prospect of a gathering this weekend fell through.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 4, 1987
description: The Economy

title: A NEW DISPUTE THREATENS M.T.A. REBUILDING PLAN
description: A new dispute broke out today over a stalled $8.6 billion program to rebuild New York City's mass-transit system, as a key Legislator accused transit officials of ignoring Senate Republicans' objections to the plan.

title: SHAKLEE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said it changed its annual reporting period from a fiscal year ending Sept. 30 to a calendar year effective Jan. 1. The 1985 three-month results were restated to reflect a change in pension accounting.

title: TRADE DEFICIT: CHEAPER DOLLAR NOT A CURE-ALL
description: In Argentina, thanks to the decline of the dollar, a Caterpillar tractor is now priced competitively with a Komatsu model from Japan. But that hardly matters because Argentina is growing too slowly to buy many new tractors -from the United States, Japan or any other country.

title: Shifts at Crum & Forster
description: Crum & Forster Inc., an insurance company owned by the Xerox Corporation, announced a reorganization of its top management yesterday, including the appointment of a new chief executive.

title: CHUBB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $7.6 million and $53.5 million for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss d-After non-recurring charges of $81.7 million for both the quarter and year, and realized investment gains of $22.6 million and $59.6 million for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Man Is Convicted In Two Slayings
description: A New Jersey man, who has been charged with the murder of a 12-year-old girl last year in Chinatown, was convicted Monday night of two other Manhattan killings by a jury in State Supreme Court.

title: Pride Spills Over At Home
description: Suddenly, everyone here is a sailor.

title: STATE U. APPROVES PLAN TO UPGRADE SPORTS AT BUFFALO CAMPUS
description: The State University of New York at Buffalo has won permission to enlarge its athletic program and move to the highest levels of collegiate sports competition.

title: THE ART OF AN INFORMAL TASTING AT HOME
description: SO you need to buy a jar of mustard. Seems like a mindless task - until you go into a specialty food store and confront more than 50 different brands. Do you buy the one from France, because the French are known to make good mustard? Or the expensive one, reasoning that it is bound to be good? Most of us end up buying a tried and true brand, which might be acceptable, but not outstanding, when, sadly, a great mustard might sit on the shelf right next to it.

title: Koch Says Scandal Didn't Hurt City Services
description: Mayor Koch, who said in September that the municipal corruption scandal had disrupted city government, said yesterday that it had had ''surprisingly little'' or no impact on the delivery of city services.

title: U.S. DRUG SCREENING GETS FIRST CHALLENGE IN AN APPEAL COURT
description: The Government argued in court today that the Federal Customs Service should be allowed to test the urine of employees and prospective employees in a search for illegal drug users.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: THE other night I had a dream about shopping in Saks. I was looking for a dress for a formal dinner and I found exactly the right thing: black velvet, strapless, with a fitted bodice, the kind of dress you imagine but find only in your dreams. Then while I was paying for the dress, I realized that I didn't have the right shoes, so I went to the shoe department and bought black peau de soie pumps with a medium heel. Then I remembered that I didn't have the right stockings and I went downstairs to hosiery.

title: Dole Campaign Is Stirring
description: Republicans backing Senator Bob Dole of Kansas for their party's 1988 Presidential nomination have expressed concern of late that his undeclared campaign seemed to be lagging behind those of Vice President Bush and Representative Jack F. Kemp of upstate New York, but signs of incipient activity are now reported in the Dole camp.

title: MACMILLAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $1.9 million for the quarter and year. The quarter also includes a pre-tax charge of $6 million for trade division reorganization. c-After an extraordinary gain of $700,000 for the quarter and year.

title: WYNN'S INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $23,000 for the quarter, and for the year includes income of $273,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,491,000 for the quarter, and for the year includes a loss of $1,540,000 from discontinued operations.

title: 765 OFFICERS PROMOTED TO SERGEANT
description: More than three and a half years after they took the sergeant's test in the New York City Police Department, 765 officers were promoted to that rank yesterday. The ceremony culminated months of rancorous litigation over the exam and filled a key void in the department's supervisory corps.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
FRIED FISH AND FAT
description: LEAD: FISH practically quiver with nutritional excellence. Generally low in fat and high in protein, fish can be cooked a variety of tantalizing ways, many requiring little or no extra fat.

title: WASHINGTON POST CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring gain of $12.3 million, or 93 cents a share, from the sales of certain cellular telephone and sportschannel interests. The company said that its 1986 earnings were achieved after absorbing dilution of $14.6 million, or $1.14 a share, resulting from the acquisition of 53 cable systems in January 1986. The company also said that adoption of FASB No. 87, Employers' Accounting for Pensions, contributed 34 cents a share to the company's latest- year earnings.

title: FEDDERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $831,000 for the quarter and $3,339,000 for the year, and income from discontinued operations of $91,000 for the quarter and $2,202,000 for the year. c-Includes tax credits of $602,000 for the quarter and $2,264,000 for the year, and income from discontinued operations of $3,124,000 for the quarter and $4,117,000 for the year. The year-ago sales figures have been restated to reflect the spin-off of Nycor Inc., a subsidiary.

title: In the Halls, Artists Come and Go
description: Corridors of the United States Capitol are blossoming as artistic halls of Americana.

title: The President's Notes
description: The personal notes Presidents take in the White House for possible memoir-writing seem to have a way of getting around. Under some pressure from Congress, President Reagan just agreed to make ''relevant excerpts'' from his notes available to investigators dealing with secret transfers of arms to Iran, despite any possible interference with his right of privacy.

title: REAGAN TO UNIFY EFFORT ON DRUGS
description: Policy-making procedures for the Federal Government's war on drugs are being consolidated in the Justice Department under an executive order President Reagan plans to issue, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SHAW UNBOUND

title: Health Maintenance Groups Give Quality Care
description: To the Editor:

title: BRONX AFTER WEDTECH: A BOROUGH UNDER SIEGE
description: With the disclosure that Wedtech officials have testified that they made payoffs to Bronx politicians, almost every major public and party official in the borough is under investigation, on trial or convicted.

title: HEILEMAN, G BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The sales figures exclude excise taxes.

title: Gulf States Utility
description: The Texas Public Utility Commission has granted the Gulf States Utility Company of Beaumont, Tex., a $39.9 million emergency increase in electricity rates, about half of the $82 million increase that had been sought. The commission said, however, the increase had been granted on the condition that the utility secure a $250 million line of credit.

title: CALIFORNIA SEA LIONS ENDING TROUT SPAWNING TRIPS
description: Fewer than a dozen California sea lions here are gobbling up a biologically treasured species of the steelhead, a prize game fish, and fish wardens seem powerless to stop them.

title: STANLEY WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $176,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter, and for the year includes income of $861,000 from discontinued operations. c-Includes a gain of $2,624,000 and $8,089,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Greyhound Lines Deal
description: Union leaders representing 6,000 employees of Greyhound Lines Inc. reached agreement on a three-year contract with a group that plans to buy the bus company. The leaders voted, 20 to 3, to accept a plan that includes incentive pay and guaranteed job security for drivers and mechanics with at least five years' service. Greyhound employees still must vote on the plan.

title: JAY E. GREENE
description: Dr. Jay E. Greene, who three times served as chairman of the New York City school system's Board of Examiners during the 23 years he served on the board, died Friday at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 72 years old and lived in Queens and Palm Beach Gardens, Fla.

title: Afghanistan to Let Red Cross Resume Seeing War Prisoners
description: The International Committee of the Red Cross said today that Afghanistan had agreed to allow Red Cross delegates to resume visits to prisoners of war and to aid the wounded, after a four-year ban.

title: LONE STAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes pre-tax gains on dispositions of assets of $138,645,000 for the quarter and year. c-Includes an extraordinary after- tax gain of $84,000 for the quarter and extraordinary gains from extinguishment of debt and a tax credit from a joint venture of $3,835,000 for the year. d-Includes a pre-tax gain on dispositions of assets of $28,577,000.

title: FISCHBACH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $750,000.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Dec. 26, about steel service centers, incorrectly described the status of Frasse Bassett Inc., a Pennsylvania service center. It is no longer in Chapter 11 proceedings, and it is still in operation.

title: MORTGAGE RATE DROP CONTINUES
description: Mortgage rates continued to fall in January, according to two surveys.

title: DROPOUT RATE SHOWS A DECREASE FOR SCHOOLS IN NEW YORK CITY
description: The number of students dropping out of New York City public schools decreased by 4.6 percentage points in the 1985-86 school year, the city's Board of Education reported yesterday.

title: Yields Rise In Treasury Bidding
description: While securities dealers worried that hopes for lower interest rates may be fading, yields moved up yesterday as market participants began bidding for this week's $29 billion of new Treasury note and bond issues.

title: WHAT FIVE FAMILIES DID AFTER LOSING THE FARM
description: Around the clock through the year, 180 times a day now, another American farm disappears, another victim of consolidation, changing economics, poor management, bad luck, high interest rates, low crop prices, emotional and financial despair, or some of each.

title: AMERICAN PETROFINA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Johnson & Johnson
description: Johnson & Johnson said that unexpected costs from the sale of its diagnostic imaging business, which was completed last August, would result in an additional $45 million after-tax charge against fourth-quarter earnings, to be reported next week.

title: Gourmet's Tale: Not Just Food
description: FOR all of its renown in tummy-related matters, Gourmet magazine has never had a company dining room in which to entertain ad agency and advertiser prospects.

title: ZAIRE, A PARADIGM OF MISMANAGERMENT
description: A Zairian stood recently in front of the rusting and empty cages of Lubumbashi's zoo, once the finest in central Africa. ''With Mobutu's economic policies, people have eaten all the monkeys,'' he said without humor.

title: Pentagon Official to Resign
description: James H. Webb, the highly decorated Vietnam veteran and novelist who became the Pentagon's first Assistant Secretary for Reserve Affairs three years ago, said today that he would step down at the end of the month.

title: AIDS Alarms, and False Alarms
Eating in Kansas City
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: FRANKLIN ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $295,000 for the quarter and $2,211,000 for the year. c-Net loss.

title: Dollar Rise Late in Day Erases Earlier Losses
description: The dollar rallied late yesterday to end essentially unchanged in what currency dealers described as hectic trading.

title: MULTIMEDIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Bolshoi Theater to Close For Extensive Repairs
description: The Bolshoi Theater will close this summer for lengthy work to modernize its stage facilities and restore its faded rococo grandeur, the newspaper Moskovskaya Pravda said today.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: PICTURE a skier jumping hundreds of feet from a cliff to the 75-degree slope below.

title: 3 AREAS IN FLORIDA SEEK FRANCHISES
description: If one calls Pat Williams in Orlando, Fla., the voice at the other end responds with, ''Orlando Magic on the way to the N.B.A.''

title: Rights Abuses Don't Help Turkey's Image
description: To the Editor:

title: The Art of Artspeak: Be Sophisticated
description: WHEN viewing art in galleries and museums, avoid terms like ''incredible,'' ''cool'' and ''totally awesome.'' Even ''interesting'' is preferable - especially when uttered with the head cocked and with a hand cupping the chin in a contemplative pose - although that old routine doesn't really fool many people anymore.

title: SHERWIN-WILLIAMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $19,595,000 from settlement of certain pension obligations and net from discontinued operations of $2,951,000 for the quarter, and for the year includes net from discontinued operations of $9,991,000. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $803,000 and $5,976,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Earnings for latest periods reflect change in method of accounting for certain pension costs. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: ARX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect the 5-for-4 stock split declared yesterday.

title: LOS LOBOS ALBUM'S POPULIST VIEW
description: ''ONE TIME, ONE NIGHT,'' the most powerful song on Los Lobos' new album, ''By the Light of the Moon'' (Slash/Warner Brothers), telescopes several harrowing personal dramas into a canvas of American life that is at once tragic and mystically hopeful. Set to rolling, twangy country-rock in the mode of Creedence Clearwater Revival, its verses sketch a series of related vignettes, each presented in the clipped, unsentimental tone of a news item. One verse describes a shooting. Another tells of the disappearance of a neighbor and his children. A third verse describes a fatal car crash. A fourth commiserates with a woman enduring a hellish marriage.

title: First Boston Net Up 73%
description: Continuing a trend of unusually strong profits on Wall Street, First Boston Inc. said yesterday that its fourth-quarter net earnings jumped 73 percent, to $61.6 million, or $1.68 a share, from $35.6 million, or $1.10 a share, a year ago. Revenues rose 68.6 percent, to $412 million, from $244.3 million.

title: SETON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. REGAINS AMERICA'S CUP WITH 4-0 SWEEP
description: Dennis Conner avenged his 1983 loss of the America's Cup today, sailing a brilliant final race to win back yachting's most prestigious trophy for the United States.

title: ARAMCO TO PAY SAUDIS $18 A BARREL
description: The group of four large American oil companies operating in Saudi Arabia said yesterday that it had agreed to long-term contracts to buy oil at $18 a barrel.

title: STAGE: STEVE TESICH'S 'DIVISION STREET'
description: IN the opening gag of Steve Tesich's ''Division Street,'' a former 1960's radical named Chris drops a tablet of Alka-Seltzer in a glass of water and waits impatiently for it to go to work. ''Fizz!'' Chris orders the recalcitrant tablet. ''You're supposed to fizz!'' But the pill just sits there, inert, and so it goes with what follows. Although substantially revised by its author and affectionately produced by the Second Stage, the second coming of ''Division Street'' is as lacking in effervescence as the short-lived Broadway original of 1980.

title: In Re Excuses
description: Lawyers, by training and nature, have readily available the most plausible and persuasive excuses; distinguished lawyers and judges often do even better. Judge Robert H. Bork of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia was a little late last weekend arriving at a panel discussion sponsored by the Federalist Society, a conservative legal group. Forgiveness was unanimous, however, when he explained: ''The prospect of the intellectual excitement I knew I would encounter this morning was so intense that I ran into another car.''

title: PROMOTIONS END FRUSTRATION, AT LAST
description: To Cheryl D. Williams and Robert E. Walker, three years seemed like forever.

title: SENATE VOTES TO INCREASE SPEED LIMIT TO 65 M.P.H.
description: An amendment allowing states to raise the speed limit to 65 miles an hour on rural interstate highways was easily approved by the Senate today, setting up a confrontation with the House.

title: Cray Shows The Flag, Too
description: The plastic coating developed for Stars & Stripes by 3M may be a thing of technological beauty, but it was only skin deep. It had to be attached to a sleek body, and that was where 3M's crosstown rival, Cray Research Inc., came aboard.

title: MCA HOLDS 9% STAKE IN BELEAGUERED COLECO
description: MCA Inc., the parent company of Universal Pictures and Universal Television, has bought 9 percent of Coleco Industries, the nation's third-largest toy maker, for $20 million.

title: Hispanic Ratio Rises In State's Prisons
description: The proportion of Hispanic inmates in state prisons has more than doubled in the last 15 years, and they now account for nearly one of every three inmates, the Commissioner of Correctional Services said yesterday.

title: AMERICAN CYANAMID CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $5.9 million and a $3 million gain from the sale of discontinued Formica Brand Products Group business. The company said year-ago fourth quarter earnings are after special provisions which had an after-tax effect of about $28.2 million, or 59 cents a share. The company said 1985 year earnings include a gain of $5.5 million, or 11 cents a share, from the sale of the company's titanium dioxide business.

title: Capote Is Rated Best of the 3-Year-Olds
description: Capote, the Seattle Slew colt who is the early favorite for the Kentucky Derby on May 2, was ranked first among 102 colts and geldings who were weighted today in The Jockey Club's annual Experimental Free Handicap.

title: CLEAN WATER BILL PASSED BY HOUSE OVER REAGAN VETO
description: The House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly today to override President Reagan's veto of a bill aimed at cleaning up the nation's water at a cost of $20 billion.

title: RIGHTS AUBSES DON'T HELP TURKEY'S IMAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: ACUSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $3,029,000. c-Includes extraordinary credits of $742,000 and $1,850,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: CHELSEA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Includes a $232,000 non-recurring writeoff of investment tax credits.

title: IN THE WAR FOR 'THE PEOPLE,' THE LEARN TO DUCK
description: The mourning candles are still flickering in the one-room shack where ducklings, fatherless children and hand-hewn beds leave scant space for a visitor.

title: FLEMING COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $10.9 million for restructuring that included closing several company-owned retail stores and a distribution center, and a writedown of assets related to other retail investments.

title: FINANCIAL JOUSTING AT THE FED
description: As eight stretch limousines waited outside the main entrance to the Federal Reserve Board's Eccles Building here today, some of the nation's most prominent bankers and Wall Street financiers jousted with board members over whether or not one of the nation's most basic banking laws should be breached.

title: TENDER LOVING HEALTH CARE SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $110,000 for the quarter and $440,000 for the year. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Progress Seen in Talks By India and Pakistan
description: Pakistani and Indian negotiators were reported tonight to have made progress in their talks on easing tensions in border areas, where the recent massing of troops has spread fears of a military confrontation. An Indian spokesman said that after four days of talks, ''both sides have noted that progress has been made.

title: Not for Everyone
description: To the Editor:

title: Grand Slam
description: Clyde Drexler of the Portland Trail Blazers, when asked to name his favorite kind of dunk: ''The kind that go in.''

title: KEY RATES
IE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
More Revlon Work For Hill Holliday
description: Hill Holliday Connors Cosmopulos, New York, which got its first Revlon assignment in September and its second in December, has just gotten a couple more that could easily bill more than $5 million.

title: 'Survival' Program Looks at Gorillas
description: GORILLAS may not be the most enchanting of creatures, but on television they have their moments. ''Survival: Gorilla,'' a one-hour documentary on Home Box Office today at 5 P.M., presents a few. The 1975 British production shows us gorillas as homebodies, chary of strangers, but kind to one another.

title: Running Uphill On Eggs
description: WITH the Dow well above 2,000 - it almost got up to 2,200 yesterday before falling back - some brokers have begun to tell their customers it will go to 3,600 or 4,000 in the next couple of years. But skeptics think the market is running on eggs and headed for a messy fall.

title: Duff & Phelps Runs Big Fund
description: THE utility market has a new buyer with $1.3 billion in cash earmarked for investment in stocks and bonds of electric, gas and telephone utilities.

title: Texas Governor Vows He Won't Raise Taxes
description: Gov. Bill Clements of Texas said today that he would increase the state budget by 2 percent, to $38.87 billion, through 1988, but pledged not to raise state taxes despite a potential budget deficit of over $5 billion.

title: PERKINS FAMILY RESTAURANTS L P reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are in units. The company, a limited partnership, went public Oct. 16, 1986.

title: CONNER IS LOOKING AHEAD FOR NEW SEAS TO CONQUER
description: Moments after Stars & Stripes won the America's Cup today, the crew of the 12-Meter yacht was celebrating with shouts and champagne in the sunny dazzle of the Indian Ocean when Dennis Conner turned to his tactician, Tom Whidden.

title: IFR SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COLLEGE SEEKS A COMFORTABLE, AND CHEAP, CAMPUS
description: Museums, theaters, gracious old buildings, convenience and the excitement of city living are all here. But eventually every urban dweller looks at the cramped accommodations and wonders if, for the same money, he could not get something bigger and more comfortable, maybe built to order, in a nice quiet suburb.

title: Dempsey Near Terms
description: Rick Dempsey is one of eight catchers, four of them 1986 starters, who remain available in the free-agent market, but he won't be available much longer. Dan O'Brien, senior vice president of the Cleveland Indians, said the club had only to clean up a few details before concluding agreement with Dempsey, who was Baltimore's No. 1 catcher last season. ''We should have it done in the next day or so,'' O'Brien said, adding that Dempsey, 37 years old, would have a chance to be the Indians' starting catcher next season. Dempsey's contract will be for one year plus an option year. . . . The Indians, meanwhile, reached agreement with Mel Hall, leaving them with seven players in salary arbitration. Rich Bordi of Baltimore also agreed to a new contract, reducing the arbitration list to 51 players. . . . Joe Niekro, the Yankees' pitcher with the aching back, was released from New York University Medical Center after spending two days in traction. Results of an X-ray were negative. Niekro suffered a slightly strained lower back last week when he bent over to pick up a piece of wood for the fireplace at his home in Lakeland, Fla.

title: A Question of Diagnosis
description: To the Editor:

title: WICAT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Net income

title: PUBLISHER TO SEEK REHEARING OF SALINGER BIOGRAPHY BAN
description: Random House has decided to file a request this week for a reconsideration of the recent Federal Appeals Court decision barring it from publishing an unauthorized biography of J. D. Salinger. If the request is not granted, a spokesman for the publisher, Annik La Farge, said yesterday, Random House will ask the Supreme Court to hear the case.

title: MESA LIMITED PARTNERSHIP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The Partnership's 1986 results reflect the acquisition of Pioneer Corporation on June 30, 1986, as well as a change to the successful efforts method of accounting. Pro forma results for 1985 assume that the Partnership began operations on Jan. 1, 1985, and have been restated to reflect the change in accounting method. The share earnings represent units.

title: CONSUMERS POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a writedown of a portion of the assets of the Midland generating facility of $331 million for the quarter and $417 million for the year. The company said the year-ago fourth quarter loss includes writedowns of $86 million due to deferred taxes and writedowns of other non- Midland assets, in addition to the $331 million writedown mentioned earlier. Total writedowns for the year-ago quarter were $417 million.

title: Lower West Side Needs Waterfront Parkland
description: To the Editor:

title: OMAHA CITY COUNCIL MEMBER WILL GET OUSTED MAYOR'S JOB
description: After three weeks of maneuvering, the seven members of the Omaha City Council chose one of their own, Bernie Simon, to serve out the term of former Mayor Michael Boyle.

title: NORTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FIRST SERVICE BANK FOR SAVNGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The bank converted from mutual to stock form in August 1986.

title: Accounts
description: * Lidblad Travel Inc., is returning to FBL Advertising, Westport, Conn.

title: Bring Back The Draft
description: LEAD: For 14 years, the United States has relied on a volunteer Army. The military services pay well, provide benefits, recruit aggressively and in the end settle for what they can get. But it is time, for a variety of reasons - demography, cost, competence - to revive the draft as a means of maintaining the size and improving the quality of our armed forces.

title: Stephen E. Kelly Award Semifinalists Named
description: The Magazine Publishers Association has released the names of the ad agencies that created the 24 campaigns that have been selected as semifinalists for the $100,000 Stephen E. Kelly Award for excellence in magazine advertising.

title: DOUGLAS & LOMASON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CETUS INVESTMENT
description: The Cetus Corporation, a biotechnology company based in Emeryville, Calif., said the MIP Equity Fund, based in The Hague, would invest $5 million in the developemnt of Cetus's Western European subsidiary. The unit, EuroCetus B.V., will be based in Amsterdam. MIP Equity, which had played an important role in Cetus's decision to locate the unit in the Netherlands, is making a five-year loan at 6 percent interest in return for warrants to purchase 165,800 shares of Cetus stock at $03 each; the warrants may be exercised after one year.

title: COASTAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $136,000 for the latest year and $426,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: MARIETTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Transamerica Gets Fairmont
description: The Transamerica Corporation said today that its insurance group had agreed to acquire Fairmont Financial Inc. in a stock swap valued at about $150 million. According to the agreement, which is expected to close during the second quarter, Fairmont stockholders will receive 0.555 share of Transamerica for each Fairmont common share, or a total of about 3 million Transamerica shares.

title: CYBERTEK COMPUTER PRODCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Swiss Report on Yamani
description: Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, former Saudi oil minister, has applied for a Swiss residence permit to settle in this Valais ski resort, the newspaper Tribune de Geneve reported Tuesday. The paper, which gave no source for its report, said Sheik Yamani's application was likely to be approved.

title: CONTRA SAYS C.I.A. SUPPLY PROGRAM IS FLAWED
description: A Nicaraguan rebel leader complained today that the Central Intelligence Agency program to deliver military supplies to the contras was not working properly.

title: AMERICAN HOME SEEKS ROBINS
description: The American Home Products Corporation has offered to buy the A. H. Robins Company and take on the huge legal liabilities of Robins's Dalkon Shield birth-control device, the two health-care companies said yesterday.

title: MICHIGAN ENERGY RESOURCES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-After losses of $2,621,000 for the quarter and $3,052,000 for the year from discontinued operations.

title: MANAGEMENT SCIENCE AMERCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1985 results were reclassified for comparative purposes.

title: JAPANESE CHIP BREAKTHROUGH
description: A Japanese company is preparing to make the first public disclosure of a computer memory chip that is far more powerful than the most advanced chips now on the market.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE CO OF COLOADO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary losses of $7,715,000 for the quarter and $101,393,000 for the year.

title: Sears Net Falls by 1.7% As Sales Increase 7.5%
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest general merchandise retailer, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings had slipped 1.7 percent as its revenues rose 7.5 percent.

title: MUTUAL LIFE OF CANADA reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $13 million gain arising from a change in the method of accounting for real estate assets as permitted by the Department of Insurance. c-Includes a U.S. dollar exchange rate adjustment of $18 million.

title: U.S. SAID TO NEAR DECISION ON SENSE OF '72 ABM TREATY
description: The Reagan Administration is close to a decision on whether to put into effect an interpretation of the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty that would allow extensive testing of ''Star Wars'' systems, Government officials said today.

title: SAUDIS WANT OIL KEPT AT $18
description: Saudi Arabia wants oil prices to remain at $18 a barrel for the foreseeable future, senior officials of the Saudi Government said today.

title: Technology Ban Report Is Criticized
description: A senior Pentagon official assailed today a report that said efforts to keep high technology from Soviet-bloc countries had cost thousands of Americans jobs and billions of dollars in lost trade without greatly improving national security.

title: AMISTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
What Is a Bank?
description: Big commercial banks have long had a big itch: to enter markets for financial services reserved for investment bankers, stockbrokers and insurance companies. Now the Federal Reserve Board appears ready to scratch. After a public hearing this week at which Wall Street's heaviest weights are making one last attempt to defend their turf, the Fed is likely to extend the banks' powers to underwrite a variety of securities.

title: FAMILY STEAK HOUSES OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CONSUMERS PLASTICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: TOTAL PETROLEUM (NORTH AMERICAN) LTD(A) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a reversal of a provision for inventory valuation of $7.2 million after tax, which was recorded in the second quarter of 1986. c-Includes a tax credit of $4,394,000 and $33,376,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: ERVING CAN'T RETIRE TOO SOON FOR NETS
description: By the time Julius Erving rejoined his teammates in the dressing room tonight, the cut on his upper lip had been closed by four stitches. He had attempted to fight through a pick early in the third quarter and instead ran into Mike Gminski's elbow. It was part of the game. Erving did not seem bothered.

title: O'NEILL PROPOSES 13.9% RISE IN BUDGET
description: Citing Connecticut's ''unheralded prosperity,'' Gov. William A. O'Neill proposed today a $5.6 billion state budget that would increase spending by 13.93 percent without raising taxes.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table in Business Day on Jan. 28, showing short interest in Nasdaq stocks for the month ended Jan. 15, carried an incorrect total supplied by Imreg Inc. to the National Association of Securities Dealers for that company's class A stock. As a result, the total Nasdaq short interest and the decline for the month were also given incorrectly. The closing short interest for Imreg was 832,048 shares.

title: USX TO SHUT 3 PLANTS, CUT 3,700 JOBS
description: The USX Corporation said today that it would ''indefinitely idle'' three steelmaking operations and part of a fourth. The action reduces USX's steelmaking capacity by more than a fourth and trims its work force by about 3,700 employees.

title: Ard Stays in Jury Pool
description: Billy Ard, offensive guard for the Giants, tried to be excused from serving in a jury pool for a murder trial in New Jersey, but the presiding judge was not swayed. Ard said the jury duty would interfere with his weight training and could cost him money. Since the Giants defeated the Denver Broncos in Super Bowl XXI, Ard said he has had several paid appearances and speaking engagements scheduled. . . . Kenny Hill, strong safety of the Giants, has appealed a $5,000 fine levied against him by Commissioner Pete Rozelle for an illegal hit against Jerry Rice, wide receiver, during a playoff game against the San Francisco 49ers.

title: THRIFT UNIT OUTFLOW
description: The flow of deposits out of federally insured savings and loan institutions narrowed to $3.96 billion last year, compared with $4.26 billion in 1985, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today. Deposits totaled $889.92 billion at the end of December, up from $885.44 billion in November. Deposit outflows in December declined ot $2.07 billion, from $2.85 billion in November, the Board said.

title: ELECTRONIC DATA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'NAGGING DOUBT' DOVERS SOUTH AFRICAN MASSACRE
description: ''NAGGING DOUBT'' works far better than we have a right to expect. One-actor shows with few props and appurtenances are difficult on television; they are better suited for stage. Moreover, ''Nagging Doubt,'' part of Channel 13's ''Channel Crossings'' series, carries what seems at first to be an insupportable burden: its one actor plays 17 characters. That he can do this at all is interesting; that he does it so well is a triumph. ''Nagging Doubt'' becomes gripping.

title: KNOWLEDGE RIDING THE SLOPES
description: As ski equipment and snow-grooming have improved, learning to maneuver skis on snow has become easier. It's fun to just go down the mountain and then back up for more of the same with little regard to skill or style.

title: PEOPLES HERITAGE BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The bank converted to stock form in December.

title: Matchup Reported in Kickoff Classic
description: Iowa and Tennessee will meet in the fifth annual Kickoff Classic to start the 1987 college football season, The Associated Press learned tonight.

title: PAR PHARMACEUTICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: The latest quarter includes income of $128,000, or 2 cents a share, and the year-ago first quarter includes a loss of $216,000 from operations of the company's injectable drug manufacturing subsidiary.

title: STAGE: 'NATIONAL ANTHEMS' IN ROCHESTER
description: The furniture is Italian, the sound system is Danish, the car is a BMW and the backyard will be turned into a Japanese garden. In other words, this is a typical, upwardly mobile American home. A married couple - he's a lawyer, she teaches music and art -recently moved into the good life in a suburb of Detroit, and their privacy is about to be invaded by a neighbor. They represent new money, the neighbor is working-class, and soon the opposites will collide. This is the beginning of Dennis McIntyre's ''National Anthems'' (in its world premiere at GeVa Theater), and, before the play ends, we have experienced a wise and sobering examination of American values.

title: AMCOLE ENERGY CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: IRISH JEWS TRY TO STOP A PLAY
description: Prominent Irish Jews today condemned an effort to stage a play in Dublin that accuses Zionist leaders of collaborating with Nazis in the murder of Jews in World War II. A production of the play was canceled last month in London after protests over its content.

title: Pursue the Boson, and Beyond
description: ''In building the supercollider our nation will be constructing yet another temple to the one-dimensional hierarchy of prestige that equates the most atomistic science with the most blessed.'' That's the grumble of an astronomer, Arno Penzias, at the soaring price of the equipment demanded by his colleagues in particle physics.

title: AMWEST INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Addendum
description: * Joseph Liebman Associates, a consultant in retail sales promotion techniques, has opened at 25 Central Park West.

title: INDIANS QUARREL OVER CUSTOM HOUSE
description: The Museum of the American Indian, which is hoping for Federal legislation to permit it to take over the abandoned United States Custom House in lower Manhattan, has an unexpected opponent - the leaders of a major New York City Indian organization.

title: COMMUNICATIONS & CABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said it reported no figures for the year ended Oct. 31, 1985, saying they were not comparable because of the January 1985 acquisition of Cenvill Development Corp. by First American Bank & Trust of Palm Beach. At that time, Cenvill owned an 80 percent stake in Communications & Cable. The company said income generated from the sale of its investment in cellular telephone activities was the main contributor to 1986 operating results. During October 1986, the company sold its remaining investment, resulting in an after-tax gain of $1,025,000.

BROOKLYN YOUTH ACQUITTED IN SLAYING OF CATHOLIC PRIEST
description: A Brooklyn youth who had told the police that he shot and killed a Roman Catholic priest during a sexual encounter last May was acquitted yesterday of murder charges in the slaying.

title: Carbide Cites Indian Inquiry
description: The Union Carbide Corporation charged yesterday that India's Central Bureau of Investigation had harassed a witness of the December 1984 gas leak at the company's pesticide plant in Bhopal, India, to try to get him to change his testimony.

title: DOCTOR WITH AIDS BACK AT HOSPITAL
description: A doctor with AIDS was suspended from clinical duties at Cook County Hosital Monday but was reinstated today over the objections of the hospital's medical director.

description: Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee sharply attacked the policies of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d today, setting a confrontational tone in the first hearing since the liberal Democrats gained control of the panel.

title: Two Milestones
description: Last Nov. 1, in his first game at the Salt Palace after being traded from Portland to Utah, Kiki Vandeweghe played 21 minutes against the Trail Blazers and came away with no points. That was the first time that Vandeweghe, a 23.4-point scorer as a pro, had been shut out in a 16-year career spanning more than 700 games and dating from junior high school. Now he has big-name company, and close to home. Darrell Griffith went 0 for 6 minutes against Sacramento at the Palace on Tuesday night, his first blanking since he started playing as a schoolboy, also some 700 games ago.

title: Advertising; Caroline Jones Back In Business
description: ARDENT observers of the adver-tising scene read last November that Caroline Jones was leaving Mingo-Jones Advertising and would be starting her own agency. Then all was quiet. Yesterday at a press conference at the Pierre, she announced not only that there was a new agency in town but also that a minority owner of Caroline Jones Advertising would be Lorimar-Telepictures, a publicly held company that is a leading producer of TV programming and also owns Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt and USAdvertising.

title: LIBERACE, FLAMBOYANT PIANIST, IS DEAD
description: Liberace, whose glitzy costumes, giant candelabra and extravagant showmanship made him almost as famous as his piano playing, died yesterday at his home in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 67 years old. His spokesman in New York, Denise Collier, said the cause of death was cardiac arrest due to congestive heart failure brought on by subacute encephalopathy. Encephalopathy is a degenerative disease of the brain. A contributing cause was aplastic anemia, Ms. Collier said.

WHITEHEAD: Bill, I'll, I'll tell you right now if you don't do something, I am going to do something that I am going to be very sorry for -- STERN: What do you mean, you're going to do something you're going to be sorry for?

description: National officials will take over the investigation of the murder of Olof Palme from Stockholm's police chief, who has run it since the Prime Minister was shot nearly a year ago, the Government said today.

It also said it would give a $500 rebate to buyers of cars without those options.

title: KENAN TRANSPORT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Visa Will Join Plus Network
description: In a move that could create a larger nationwide network of automatic-teller machines, Plus System Inc. said it would permit the 17,000 banks that issue Visa cards to join Plus, a network with 13,000 automatic tellers. Plus had been essentially a private network owned by 34 banks, but the Visa link means as many as a third of the nation's automatic tellers could eventually be part of Plus, which could grow to 20,000 tellers by 1990, according to system officials.

title: 10-Year U.S. Notes Bring 7.25%
description: The Treasury auctioned $9.75 billion of 7 1/4 percent 10-year notes yesterday at an average yield of 7.25 percent, the same interest rate obtained at the previous refunding sale last November. Dealers said the result was expected after it became known that Japanese and other foreign investors were strongly interested in this maturity.

title: Low Finance
description: A coin collector we know finds nothing so stimulating as a midwinter thaw. It's not the rising temperature or anticipation of the spring coin show, but the increase in curbside collecting. Melting snow is a gold mine - or at least a copper mine. What others lose in drifts, our friend retrieves in sunshine.

title: White at Citadel Says Hazing Was Harmless
description: A racial hazing incident at The Citadel, the military academy here, inflicted ''no harm or damage whatsover'' on the black cadet involved, one of the five white cadets in the case contends in court papers.

description: b-Includes $955,000 from an extraordinary gain resulting from early retirement of certain long-term debt instruments during the second quarter.

title: 4 White Movie Theaters Are Closed in South Africa
description: A South African film distributor, pressed by American distributors to open its movie houses to all races, said today that it was closing four whites-only movie theaters in Pretoria until the city council voted to make them multiracial.

title: PAN AM WILL GET CITICORP AID
description: The Pan Am Corporation, the parent of Pan American World Airways, said yesterday that it had hired the Citicorp Investment Bank to advise it on any merger talks and that Citicorp would arrange up to $150 million in financing for the airline.

title: KASPAROV, PUBLICIZING CHESS IN BRITAIN, PLAYS TV MATCH
description: Gary Kasparov, the Soviet chess world champion, began a two-day televised challenge match today with the British grand master Nigel Short that was billed as an attempt to project the game for a mass television audience.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ALTHOUGH a home or apartment may seem to have plenty of closet space when you move in, all too often you later discover you need more. Enlarging an existing closet is rarely possible, but often there is room to build another. The easiest place to build an extra closet is in the corner of a room. That way you only have to build two walls for the new closet; the other two are already in place.

description: The head of Mexico's state oil company, Petroleos Mexicanos, will step down to become the candidate of the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party for the governorship of the State of Mexico, the area surrounding Mexico City, a spokesman said Tuesday. The move by Mario Ramon

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SKIING Zurbriggen Wins Giant Slalom: Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland won the men's giant slalom today for his second gold medal at the world Alpine ski championships in Crans-Montana, Switzerland. Zurbriggen got a big break when Joel Gaspoz, who appeared well ahead, fell after hitting the 48th gate of the 50-gate track. Zurbriggen had a combined time for the two runs of 2 minutes 32.38 seconds. Marc Girardelli of Luxembourg was second in 2:32.45 and Alberto Tomba gave Italy its first men's medal since 1978 by clinching the bronze in 2:33.13.(AP) FIGURE SKATING Thomas Takes Lead: Debi Thomas, the world champion, got off to a sensational start in defense of her United States title as she took a big lead over a surprising Jill Trenary in the compulsory figures of the women's competition, at Tacoma, Wash. The 19-year-old is suffering from two sore Achilles' heels, but said she wasn't bothered too much by the injuries last night. Tiffany Chin, who is considered as Thomas's main challenger, was in fourth place after she missed a tracing on a loop in the final figure. (AP) N.H.L. Oilers 6, North Stars 5: Wayne Gretzky sparked a four-goal rally by scoring his 50th of the season and later set up Randy Gregg's game-winner at 2:12 of overtime. This is the eighth straight season in which Gretzky has reached the 50-goal mark for Edmonton. (AP) Canadiens 4, Nordiques 3: Sergio Momesso banked in a shot off Mario Gosselin, the Quebec goaltender, midway through the third period to lead the Canadiens. Momesso was behind the Quebec net when his shot hit the leg of Gosselin for the winner at 11:12.(AP) Sabres 3, Whalers 1: Tom Barrasso, the Buffalo goalie, stopped 23 shots and Clark Gillies scored the game-winning goal with 7:39 remaining as the Sabres won their third straight.(AP) Jets 5, Flyers 3: Dale Hawerchuk scored two goals, including the third-period game-winner on a bad play by the Philadelphia goalie, Ron Hextall. Instead of clearing the puck, Hextall put it right in Hawerchuk's stick at 3:07, and the Jets' captain drilled a shot from the slot over the rookie goaltender's shoulder to give Winnipeg a 4-2 lead. (AP) N.B.A. Celtics 104, Cavaliers 102: Larry Bird scored 29 points, including four consecutive free throws in the final five seconds, and the Celtics withstood a Cleveland comeback from an 18-point deficit for the victory. Kevin McHale connected for 27 points and Danny Ainge scored 15 as the Celtics posted their 22d consecutive home victory over the Cavaliers despite Ron Harper's 40-point performance. Cleveland has not won in Boston Garden since Oct. 13, 1978. (AP)

title: Kunitz Wins Poetry Award
description: Stanley Kunitz, a Pulitzer Prize-winning poet from New York City, has been named recipient of the Walt Whitman Citation of Merit for Poets by a special advisory panel to Governor Cuomo.

title: A PASSION FOR DETAILS: WHERE TRIMMINGS COST LESS
description: LEAD: DECORATORS these days are making lavish use of trimmings such as braids, gimps, cordings, tiebacks and tassels. This is reminiscent of late 19th-century fashion, in which elaborate passementeries were ubiquitous on upholstered furniture and draperies. And the current decorating revival of that period has created a new demand for trimming details.

title: SERENADING THE LOST LAMBS OF THE COUNTERCULTURE
description: Adam Hanuszkiewicz, who was dismissed five years ago as director of Poland's national theater because of his activities in the Solidarity period, has just been invited to the Ministry of Culture for talks about a new job. Films blocked by censors since 1981 are being released, and some artists and writers who shunned Government contact after martial law was declared are being asked to take tea with Gen. Tax Loophole In New Law
description: The Treasury Department and some Senate tax writers agreed today that a loophole in the new tax law should be closed because it could cost as much as $20 billion in lost revenues over the next five years. When the provision was approved last year, Congressional experts estimated the revenue loss at only $300 million.

title: Homosexual Priest Dismissed by Vatican
description: The Vatican has formally dismissed a homosexual Manhattan priest from his Jesuit order for publicly opposing the teachings of the church against homosexual activity.

title: McCarran-Walter Chills the Flow of Ideas
description: To the Editor:

title: COLOMBIA EXTRADITES A MAJOR DRUG FIGURE TO U.S.
description: Soldiers captured a reputed billionaire cocaine trafficker at a rural mansion early today and extradited him to the United States for trial on drug charges.

title: NEW CLASSES OFFER VARIETY OF SUBJECTS
description: FROM giving simple lessons in repairing leaky faucets to managing buildings with computers, continuing education departments around the city are offering new classes this spring.

title: 'A Uniquely Jewish List'
description: A five-pound volume listing the names of 11,000 Soviet Jews who have been denied permission to emigrate is being distributed to members of Congress, the State Department and other Government agencies as a reminder of their plight. The book, ''A Uniquely Jewish List: The Refuseniks of Russia,'' includes only those who have been refused emigration more than once. It is being distributed by the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith.

title: BARNWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bond Granted in Bomb Case
description: A Federal magistrate granted a $95,000 property bond today for a former member of the radical Weather Underground who faces a charge of conspiring to bomb a building at the University of Washington in 1970. Magistrate John Weinberg granted the bond for Silas Trim Bissell, who was arrested Jan. 20 after being a fugitive since 1970.

title: WEAREVER-PROCTORSILEX reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss of $623,000 and $1,165,000 from the prepayment of debt for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,387,000 and $1,977,000 from tax credits for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: HOW TECHNOLOGY CAN BREED BOREDOM
description: THE purpose of better technology, as anyone knows, is to foster laziness and sloth among the populace. That's what's going on with the up-and-coming formats for prerecorded music, the cassette (which now commands considerably more than half the market) and the compact disk. While they've been coming into their own, popular music has encouraged basking rather than rocking out - a tendency that fits right in with the new technology.

title: Landlord Agrees To Building Repairs
description: A Brooklyn landlord who was given a 45-day jail sentence last July for failing to correct housing-code violations has signed an agreement to put four apartment buildings into the hands of an administrator, the authorities said yesterday.

title: MEDICAL GRAPHICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: All sales figures have been adjusted to include service revenue and service cost.

title: BETTE MIDLER AND DISNEY SIGN THREE-PICTURE DEAL
description: Since the death of the long-term contract, Hollywood studios and stars make a deal, do one picture and then go their separate ways. Now, in an arrangement that harkens back to the old studio system, Bette Midler has signed a contract with Walt Disney Pictures to star in three successive movies.

title: UTL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Break-In at Governor's Home
description: Someone tried to break into the home of Gov. Evan Mecham early Tuesday, severing power and telephone lines and cutting a hole in a ceiling, the police said. No one actually got into the house and there were no suspects in the case, said a police spokesman, Marshall Downen. The Governor was in Cleveland and his wife, Florence, was at home alone in this suburb of Phoenix when an alarm was triggered by the cutoff of electricity, Mr. Downen said.

title: Heck's May Seek New Buyout Offer
description: Heck's Inc., a discount department store chain in the Southeast and Middle Atlantic states, said it might restructure or put itself up for sale. The company had previously announced the termination of a $125 million merger agreement with the Toussie-Viner Group, which cited weaker performance by Heck's in the final months of 1986. Heck's said it would report its results later this month.

title: DROPOUT FIGURES TO INCLUDE DATA ON RACIAL BASIS
description: In a reversal of longstanding policy, Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones said yesterday that the New York City Board of Education would begin to collect dropout statistics on the basis of race.

title: Hispanic Woman Wins City Seat in Los Angeles
description: State Assemblywoman Gloria Molina won a special election today for a new seat on the City Council, which was created after the Justice Department sued the city for its lack of minority representation on the Council.

title: BONN PLANS TO DESTROY RADIOACTIVE POWDERED MILK
description: The West German Environment Minister said today that the Government would seek to acquire 3,000 tons of radioactive powdered milk and destroy it.

title: FLIGHTSAFETY INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GAME TROPHIES: WHAT'S GOOD FOR A GOOSE IS BAD FOR A MOOSE
description: Dust your moose regularly, but remember not to carry it by the antlers. Repair a cracked or peeling trout with nail polish, and wipe the grime off a dirty pheasant with a handful of torn bread.

title: Reagan and Pope to Meet
description: When President Reagan goes to Europe in June for an economic conference in Venice with other world leaders, he is also scheduled to meet privately with Pope John Paul II in Rome on June 5 and to visit Berlin on the 12th, according to a source familiar with the arrangements.

title: Prison Opera Troupe Is on Tour in Italy
description: Twelve convicts are spending two weeks outside prison performing opera in theaters in southern Italy.

description: The Economy

BABY M TRIAL HEARS PARENTS IN EMOTIONAL PHONE CALL
description: In a 45-minute telephone conversation fraught with anger, fear and pleadings over Baby M, her biological mother, Mary Beth Whitehead, last July told the baby's father, William Stern, ''I'd rather see me and her dead before you get her.''

title: POLICMAN ACCUSED OF BRIBERY
description: A 34-year-old police officer was arrested yesterday and accused of extorting money from gypsy-cab drivers in the Bronx.

title: Casualty Insurers Seek To Improve Image
description: For the last four years the advertising of the Insurance Information Institute has been promoting various changes that would make our lives and their businesses better.

title: Topics: When Persistence Pays Off; Up Under
description: Does the America's Cup belong to the United States? No, no more than the Davis Cup belongs to Australia. Cups belong to winners. Hats off to Dennis Conner, his splendid crew and everyone else who collaborated in Stars & Stripes' resounding victory in four straight races in the Indian Ocean. With dazzling dedication to excellence, they earned it.

title: INSIDE
description: Liberace Dead at 67 The pianist, known as much for his showmanship as his musicianship, died yesterday at his home in Palm Springs, Calif. Page B6. Bogota Seizes a Drug Baron Colombian soldiers captured a reputed billionaire cocaine trafficker at a rural mansion and extradited him to the United States for trial. Page A9. Iran to Expel Journalist Iran said it had ordered the expulsion of Gerald F. Seib, an American journalist who had been detained and charged with espionage. Page A3.

title: WALLACE AND 3D WIFE ARE GRANTED A DIVORCE
description: Former Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama and his third wife, Lisa, have been granted a divorce, a court official said Monday.

title: PICKENS OFFERS $2 BILLION FOR ALL OF SHAMROCK
description: An investor group led by T. Boone Pickens stepped up today its efforts to acquire the Diamond Shamrock Corporation, making a $2.06 billion cash offer for all the shares of the oil and gas company.

title: PROFITS ARE MIXED FOR TWO SUBSIDIARIES OF G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation's computer services subsidiary, the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, had sharply higher fourth-quarter profits, but earnings for the GM Hughes Electronics Corporation, also a subsidiary of G.M., declined, the auto maker said today.

title: Washington Times Editor Ill
description: Arnaud de Borchgrave, the editor-in-chief of The Washington Times, became ill at his office today and was admitted to a hospital in intensive care, the newspaper said. ''Tests are being conducted at this time to rule out the possibility of a heart attack and the hospital lists his condition as serious,'' the newspaper said in a statement. It said he was taken to the Washington Hospital Center by ambulance but was conscious and alert.

Ride 'em, Robot!
description: Horse racing at Madison Square Garden may sound farfetched. After all, 1,200-pound thoroughbreds are obviously too big for the arena, and such scaled-down mounts as 500-pound hackney ponies are too little to make any speed while carrying 120-pound jockeys.

Judge Justo Arenas denied bail. United States Attorney Daniel Lopez Romo said he has 13 witnesses who allege that Mr. Rivera Lopez incited others to start the fire.

title: HELP IN KEEPING TRACK OF SKI ACHIEVEMENTS
description: CERTAIN skiers like to brag that they logged billions of miles on their weekend ski trips and hit warp speed at least once during each run. Why believe them? Demand proof. Ask to see what their Ski-Dometer said.

title: MUSIC: LIBOVE AND LUGOVOY
description: ALTHOUGH the violinist Charles Libove and the pianist Nina Lugovoy democratically billed their Monday-night program at Merkin Concert Hall as a joint recital, it was Mr. Libove's lean, full tone and dapper technical expertise that made the evening a memorable one.

title: INQUIRY IN TEXAS BOMB KILLING
description: The investigation into the bombing death of the president of a drug company is being treated as a top priority, but no leads or suspects have been found, the authorities said today.

title: Canucks Beat Islanders, 4-1
description: Tony Tanti and Brent Peterson scored 18 seconds apart in the opening period to spark the Vancouver Canucks to a 4-1 victory tonight over the Islanders.

title: PODDUBNY'S GOAL WINS EMOTIONAL GAME
description: They stood in various poses down the long hallway that stretches between the dressing rooms. Bobby Carpenter wore only a towel and an ice pack. Mike Ridley leaned one shoulder against a wall. Kelly Miller sipped a beer. They were collected, it appeared, but Ridley said he felt ''weird,'' and Miller said that although he had reminded himself all day not to feel nervous, he still had ''the jitters.''

Fletcher Challenge In Canadian Move
description: Fletcher Challenge, a large New Zealand company, said it was buying effective control of British Columbia Forest Products, a giant Canadian paper maker, and forming a group that will be the world's second-largest producer of newsprint. Fletcher announced it would pay $381 million for a 47 percent stake in the Canadian company, which is based in Vancouver and has about 7,000 employees.
