Doctor Seeks to Build A Major Medical Chain
description: LeRoy A. Pesch, a doctor-businessman, is seeking to build a major health-care chain with his bid Tuesday to acquire one of the largest hospital companies in the country for $1.74 billion.

title: MUSIC: IVO POGORELICH PIANO RECITAL
description: IN a world overpopulated with steely-fingered athletes of the keyboard, what can a young artist do to set himself apart from the throng? Ivo Pogorelich, the Yugoslav pianist who gave a recital last evening at Carnegie Hall, has solved the problem so successfully that although still in his 20's, he already has a thriving recording career and has acquired a sizable following for his live appearances. Mr. Pogorelich's solution, perhaps drawing on the example of the late Glenn Gould, has been to affect an aloof if not actually contemptuous attitude toward audiences, to make outrageous statements in interviews and to play everything with startling contrasts of tempo and dynamics.

title: CABARET: O.C. SMITH, SINGER
description: O.C. SMITH has led at least three different lives as a pop-jazz performer. In the early 1960's, the Louisiana-born singer replaced Joe Williams as the lead singer for the Count Basie band with whom he remained for three years. Several years later he became a pop star growling out colorfully corny country-pop vignettes like ''Little Green Apples,'' which anticipated Kenny Rogers's rustic yarn-spinning. And on Tuesday, Mr. Smith opened a five-night engagement at Sweetwater's (170 Amsterdam Avenue, at 68th Street) in which he played the role of pop-funk crooner.

description: Canada's official foreign currency reserves, used to protect the Canadian dollar, soared to the highest level in nearly 13 years in January, the Finance Department said today. The figure rose by nearly $2 billion (American), to $6.07 billion.

title: MUSIC: GUILD OF COMPOSERS CONCERT
description: Some choral music by Jacques-Louis Monod provided the most arresting moments of the Guild of Composers concert Tuesday night at Christ and St. Stephen's Church.

title: EGYPTIAN DENIES PLANES OFFER
description: The Egyptian Information Minister has denied a report in The New York Times that Cairo guaranteed money and offered planes in 1985 to private dealers trying to ship 39 American-made F-4 fighters to Iran.

title: TIMES SQUARE: TRYING TO KEEP THE PANACHE
description: That night in November 1965, when the electricity failed, Times Square disappeared. While the rest of the city merely went dark, the square that with appropriate immodesty calls itself the crossroads of the world vanished in a blackness made more stygian because it so contrasted with the usual nocturnal blaze of glory that is its trademark.

title: MOYERS WINS A TOP PRIZE IN BROADCAST JOURNALISM
description: Bill Moyers, who recently left CBS News for PBS, won an Alfred I. duPont-Columbia University Award last night for a ''CBS Reports'' program he prepared about the weakening of the black family.

title: Texas Again Stops Admission To Its Overcrowded Prisons
description: Texas prison officials closed the nation's second-largest corrections system to new admissions today for the second time in a month as the number of inmates topped a limit set by a law to curb crowding.

description: Secretary of Education William Bennett thinks some schools shut down too quickly ''because there's some snow on the ground.'' title: Who Axed Military Raises?
description: Amid all the discussion about big pay increases for members of Congress, judges and top civilians in Government, nobody seems willing to say just who rejected any real effort to get similar raises for top military officers.

The latest quarter is after reversal of a previously recognized investment tax credit in conformance with the Tax Reform Act of 1986 which reduced net income by $30 million, or 15 cents a share. Also, earnings were unfavorably affected by a five-day strike at Delco Electronics, in Kokomo, Indiana, and by related production efficiencies upon resumption of operations. There was a favorable effect in the latest quarter of 9 cents a share related to the adoption of the Statement of Financial Accounting Standard No.87, covering pension accounting. Operating data, earnings and earnings per share of GM Class H common stock have been restated in the first three quarters of 1986 to reflect this accounting change. Application of this Statement had the effect of increasing earnings for the year by $68 million, or 34 cents a share.

title: Stop That Yawning, Reader, And Read This
description: To many Americans, this city produces nothing but hot air, inflated egos, monstrous transfers of money to the undeserving and, now and again, a good law and a true statesman. But more than anything, day in and day out, Washington churns out paper.

title: WINNING TEAM: A LOOK AT THE CREW
description: Stars & Stripes is a product of high technology, but she still needed the minds and muscles of her crew to win back the America's Cup. These are the 12 men who sailed her. (There are 11 sailors in a 12-Meter crew; the Stars & Stripes team alternated crewmen at one of the grinder positions).

title: Comings and Goings
description: Six North Carolina basketball players are either sick or injured and it was not known how many would be able to play in tonight's game against North Carolina State. Among the starters, only J. R. Reid is healthy. The injury list: Kenny Smith (surgical knee), Joe Wolf (flu), Jeff Lebo (flu), Dave Popson (bruised leg), Rodney Hyatt (stress fracture in leg), Scott Williams (bruised thigh). . . . Dave Langevin, a free-agent defenseman, has signed a contract with the Los Angeles Kings for the remainder of the season. . . . Kevin LaVallee, left wing of the Pittsburgh Penguins, will undergo arthroscopic surgery on his right shoulder and be sidelined for at least two weeks. . . . Tony Robinson and Kenneth Cooper will spend six additional months in the Knox County Penal Farm because they violated work-release rules, a judge ruled yesterday. Robinson, the former University of Tennessee quarterback, was serving 90 days at the penal farm, on a six-year sentence after he pleaded no contest last November to charges of attempting to sell cocaine to an undercover narcotics officer. Cooper, who had also been convicted on drug charges, was serving 150 days of an eight-year term.

title: Q&A
description: Q.The siding on my house is rough sawn cedar. I have been told not to caulk the joints where the boards overlap as the siding must breathe. Is this true, and will caulking cause sweating and condensation? A.It probably will not cause condensation, but it is unlikely to do much good: this siding is not meant to be very airtight. The cold air is supposed to be kept out by a watertight and relatively airtight sheathing under the sheathing, such as building paper or felt paper. Q.The outside wall in our bedroom gets wet when it is very cold outside. Our house is brick, with no room between the brick and the wall for insulation. We have painted the wall with a paint that is supposed to aid insulation, but the wall still gets wet. A chemical dehumidifier hung in the room has not helped, either. Have you any suggestions? A.The outside wall is too cold, so when warm moist air from inside touches it, condensation forms. The paint will not help, because it is a vapor barrier: it keeps moisture vapor from passing through the wall from inside, but does not prevent condensation inside.

title: JANUARY AUTO SALES FELL 28.5%

title: SIX YOUNG FASHION DESIGNERS: CREATIVITY ON THE HOME FRONT
description: MIRIAM BENDAHAN, a designer of elegant evening dresses, greeted a guest in the doorway of her three-room East Village tenement walk-up. Or more precisely, in its kitchen, between her bathtub, which holds a dish rack, and a plank supporting a jagged piece of mirror - her vanity. Two shoes, painted silver to match her kitchen walls, were hanging above the door.

title: Sampson Injures Knee
description: This season has not gone smoothly for the Houston Rockets, who are 23-22 after reaching the championship round of the National Basketball Association playoffs last spring before losing to the Boston Celtics. Now things are much worse. Ralph Sampson, Houston's 7-foot-4-inch power forward and center, will probably miss the rest of the season after injuring his left knee in a game Tuesday night against the Denver Nuggets. An examination yesterday showed a large tear in the cartilage, and team officials said surgery might be necessary. But Sampson said a doctor had advised him against such a procedure. ''Right now, he's going on the one opinion he's had,'' said Bill Fitch, the Rockets' coach. ''We are holding off until he talks to the other doctor that is going to be involved. If I had to say, it would be my opinion he's going to take the safe approach.'' Richard Vandervoort, the team trainer, said: ''It is in no way a career-threatening situation. At this point, we don't feel there is any ligament damage.'' Even more frustrating is that shoe polish may have been responsible for the injury. The polish was left on the court at the Summit by a drill team practicing before Tuesday night's game. The scuff marks were removed with turpentine, and players said slippery spots remained at the start of the game. Sampson slipped in the first quarter, left the game, then returned for the start of the second but played less than one minute. ''I wanted to test it,'' Sampson said. ''I thought it had just popped out of joint and would be O.K.'' Tom Chambers, a forward for the Seattle SuperSonics, will replace Sampson on the Western Conference roster in the All-Star Game Sunday.

title: FURNITURE WITH THE LOOK OF SCULPTURE
description: TWO years ago, Angela Nolte began organizing exhibits for young furniture designers and avant-garde artists in Germany. Last year, Mrs. Nolte, top right, moved to New York, where she opened Nolte, which shows the furniture designed by the artists she represents. Her husband, Randolph Nolte, oversees the production, which is mostly sculptural. The steel chair above, by Till Lesser, has a leather seat and costs $2,950. Christian Werner's ash and slate bookcase, right, is eight feet high and is $1,250. The black steel candlelabra beside Mrs. Nolte is $675 and is by Torsten Neeland. The copper desk accessories at right are by Angela Kurrer. They are, clockwise from left, a pleated pen holder ($135); a curved blotter ($110); a holder for letters and envelopes ($65), and a magnetic disk for paper clips ($95). The man who has tirelessly promoted such movements as Pop, Minimal, Conceptual and Neo-Expressionist art, and such talents as Jasper Johns, Robert Rauschenberg, Frank Stella, Andy Warhol, Roy Lichtenstein and Julian Schnabel, confesses that - as he approaches his 80th birthday - he really doesn't ''know where things are going.''

title: MUSIC: CALLIOPE GROUP
description: CALLIOPE, the early-music group, came to Merkin Concert Hall Tuesday night with a program of 13th- to 17th-century works focusing on Spain and on outdoor performance traditions. It was an interesting excursion; we heard more of the buzzy, honking shawms and the merrily piffling pipe-and-tabor than usual. The four members of the group were reinforced by five guests, each player alternating on several instruments; the program offered music published by Susato in 16th-century Antwerp, Burgundian and Iberian selections, a set centered on Heinrich Isaac's instrumental works, and dances in something resembling cobla style (which survives as folk music in Catalonia today).

Does the song's popularity augur a positive sea change in the public consciousness of discrimination? One hopes so.

description: The Justice Department said it intends to file an antitrust suit challenging the Ethyl Corporation's proposed $55 million acquisition of the Dow Chemical Company's Bromine and Brominated Chemicals division.

title: A MONTH OF CELEBRATIONS OF BLACK LIFE IN AMERICA
description: Negro History Week was created in 1926 by Carter G. Woodson, who nine years earlier had founded the Association for the Study of Negro Life and History.

title: Prosecutor to Review Action by Legislator
description: The Albany County District Attorney said today that he might investigate possible state crimes committed by an Assemblywoman who testified last month in Federal court that she had added two ''no-show'' jobs to her office payroll.

title: Arms and the Man's Language
description: What's in a name?

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 379 money market mutual funds increased $1.76 billion, to $236.02 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 91 institutional funds were up $492.3 million, to $65.77 billion. Assets of the 196 general purpose funds were up $475.5 million, to $62.83 billion. The 92 broker-dealer funds rose $789.3 million, to $107.42 billion.

title: Hypocrisy at 55 M.P.H.
description: Arizona, one of two states cited by the Federal Government last year for inadequately enforcing the 55-mile-per-hour speed limit, recently got its lumps: a fine of 1 percent of its Federal highway funds, or $510,000. This slap on the wrist adds to the speed law's history of hypocrisy. The Senate wisely would revise the law, but the House still balks.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 6, 1987
description: Markets The Dow Jones industrial average closed above 2,200 in a surge of trading that also lifted broader-based market indicators to new highs. In a day marked by sharp price swings, the Dow added 10.26 points to close at 2,201.49. Volume was 256.7 million shares, the second-busiest session on record. In the 25 trading days this year, the Dow average has soared 305 points, or 16 percent. By comparison, in all of 1986 the blue-chip indicator gained 349 points. [ Page A1. ] A late rally produced strong gains in the credit markets, as demand from foreign investors and speculators exceeded expectations at the Treasury's auction of 30-year bonds. The three days of Treasury auctions ended with rates not much different from those set at the previous sessions in November. [ D1. ] The investigation of insider trading is focusing on the takeover of Harris Graphics and a $5.3 million invoice to Ivan F. Boesky from Drexel Burnham Lambert, sources close to the case said. [ D1. ] ''War jitters'' in the Middle East pushed energy futures higher. West Texas intermediate crude oil rose to $18.58 a barrel. [ D12. ] The dollar rose, and gold climbed $2, to $404.25, in New York. [ D12. ] Companies G.M.'s earnings fell sharply and Chrysler's were off in 1986. G.M.'s total was $2.95 billion, compared with $3.99 billion in 1985. Yearly sales for the largest auto maker were higher, at $102.81 billion, the first time the $100 billion mark has been surpassed. Fourth-quarter profits at G.M. fell nearly 70 percent. Chrysler's net income for the year was $1.40 billion, compared with $1.64 billion, but its fourth-quarter profit was up 50.5 percent. Annual sales for the No. 3 producer were $22.59 billion. [ D1. ] American Home's bid for A. H. Robins is $1.8 billion to $2.2 billion, sources familiar with the offer said. American Home was also said to be seeking ways to limit the amount of money that could be recovered by women with legal claims involving Robins's Dalkon Shield birth-control device. [ D1. ] G.E. is donating a famous research center to a nonprofit group. The RCA laboratories at Princeton, N.J., the birthplace of color television, will be donated to SRI International. [ D1. ] Retailers reported mixed sales for January, a month that is traditionally a slack time for the industry. Sales at Sears were up 2.3 percent and the rapidly expanding Wal-Mart discount chain posted a 45.2 percent rise. But Penney had a 2.5 percent dip. [ D2. ] CBS News is being asked to cut its budget as much as $50 million, or 17 percent, at the request of Laurence A. Tisch, the chief executive of CBS Inc. [ A1. ] Digital Equipment is expected to introduce a desktop-size computer work station next week. [ D3. ] The Economy Congress began wrestling with trade proposals as legislative leaders stressed that a bipartisan approach was crucial to achieving a bill that the President would be willing to sign. But there were already signs of dissent over a bill filed in the Senate that has 54 co-sponsors. [ D1. ] Dennis R. Patrick will be named the new F.C.C. chairman. Mr. Patrick, who already sits on the commission, is regarded as a strong advocate of deregulation. In addition, Washington sources said that Charles Rule, another supporter of deregulation, would be named chief of the Justice Department's antitrust division. [ C30. ] International The yearlong protest against Rupert Murdoch will be ended, the British printers union has decided. [ A7. ] Today's Columns The expanding role of women in the workplace gets special attention in a White House report. In what has been called ''the greatest economic revolution of our time,'' the percentage of women who work has risen from 20 at the turn of the century to more than 60. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Additional shares of Phillips-Van Heusen have been bought by the financial empire of Caroline Hunt Schoellkopf, who is perhaps the nation's wealthiest woman. Market Place. [ D4. ]

title: BONDS UP IN STRONG DEMAND
description: Greater-than-expected demand from speculators and solid buying by foreign investors at the Treasury's 30-year bond auction yesterday caused prices of outstanding issues to rise sharply.

title: The Highway Bill: Too Dear, Too Slow; Demonstrate Sense, Not Pork
description: Last year the Democratic House and the Republican Senate failed to agree on highway aid, so there was none. Now each has passed its bill again, and despite the change in control of the Senate, the same two issues divide them just as passionately. The Senate still supports relaxing the 55-mile-per-hour speed limit and resists a whole list of pork barrel projects that the House would hand out along with regular highway funds. On both issues, the Senate is right.

title: Energy Efficiency Was Lesson of 70's Oil Shocks; Alaska Is a Big Place
description: To the Editor:

title: RETIRED FIREFIGHTER SHOOTS DOCTOR AFTER PENSION RULING
description: A retired New York City firefighter whose request for a disability pension had just been deferred shot and critically wounded yesterday one of the doctors who made the ruling in a Fire Department office in Manhattan, the police said.

title: Economic Scene; Women Gain, But at a Cost
description: THE annual report of President Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers devotes its final chapter this year to the increasing presence of women in the labor force - a phenomenon that Prof. Barbara R. Bergmann of the University of Maryland calls ''the greatest economic revolution of our time.''

title: Reagan's 76th
description: From available reports, the White House is resisting the opportunity to make ''Seventy-six Trombones'' the theme of President Reagan's birthday of the same number today. Instead of marching bands, there will be a low-key in-house observance, consonant with the President's continuing recovering from prostate surgery last month.

title: CBS CHIEF ASKS $50 MILLION CUT IN NEWS BUDGET
description: The chief executive of CBS Inc. has asked CBS News to cut its budget up to $50 million, or 17 percent, prompting a drastic reassessment of the worldwide CBS News operations.

title: SNAP-ON TOOLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said its latest fourth quarter net was reduced by 5 cents a share due to the elimination of the investment tax credit and an election taken during the quarter relating to its 1986 acquisition of ATI Industries.

title: Conner Is Facing Some Busy Days
description: Dennis Conner took Stars & Stripes for a sail today.

title: BRELAND FINDS PRO STYLE WITH KNOCKOUT PUNCH
description: As an amateur, Mark Breland seemed the perfect specimen.

title: MCDERMOTT INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: The Warsaw Thaw
description: The diplomatic climate between the United States and Poland, frozen by President Reagan a half-dozen years ago over the suppression of the Solidarity labor movement, is continuing to warm as spring approaches. The Foreign Minister of Poland, Jozef Czyrek, has been invited to pay a visit to Washington late this month or early in March, during which he will be officially welcomed by dignitaries at the Capitol.

title: Gannett Profit Rises 11.8%
description: The Gannett Company said today that its fourth-quarter profit rose 11.8 percent, to $88.8 million, or 55 cents a share, from $79.4 million, or 49 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter rose 26.2 percent, to $781.5 million, from $619.5 million.

title: Ultimate Cool
description: The memories of Walt (Clyde) Frazier playing his quietly exciting basketball for the Knicks come back in a flood for any fan, especially now, the day after he has been elected to the Basketball Hall of Fame.

title: RETALIATION FEARS STIR ALERT
description: A former Colombian state senator identified by Federal officials as one of the world's biggest and most violent drug traffickers was placed under heavy guard today in Florida after his late-night extradition from Colombia.

title: For the Love of Helga
description: Last summer, a New York City man who doesn't know much about art but knows what he likes fell head over heels in love with Helga, Andrew Wyeth's fascinating model. Now he's crestfallen. In May, 140 of Mr. Wyeth's Helga paintings will go on exhibit at the National Gallery in Washington and then travel to five other cities. But not New York. The city's curators think New York is too good for Helga.

title: State Board Plans Raise for Jockeys
description: The New York State Racing and Wagering Board has proposed an amendment to its rules that would increase the minimum fees paid to jockeys who ride the second and third finishers in races with purses of $25,000 or more. Riders of second- and third-place horses in these races ar now paid $150 and $100, respectively.

title: France to Sell 1/2 of Network
description: France's Government put up for sale a controlling interest in one of the state's most glamorous holdings, TF1, the country's oldest and most prestigious television network. The announcement, the latest in a series involving the sale of Government properties, said the price would be three billion francs, or about $500 million. Finance Minister Edouard

title: NOBLE AFFILIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $12,720,000.

title: Mariner Wins Case
description: Phil Bradley, the Seattle Mariners' perennial .300 hitter, won his salary arbitration case for the second consecutive year yesterday, becoming the first two-time winner since Mario Soto of Cincinnati won in 1982-83. Neil Gundermann, the arbitrator, awarded Bradley a $750,000 salary over the $550,000 the Mariners sought. Last year Bradley won at $475,000 over the club's $375,000. Bradley, who has batted .300 or better in each of his three full major league seasons, fell off last season, from 26 home runs to 12 and from 88 runs batted in to 50. However, his .405 on-base percentage was second in the American League to the .453 of Wade Boggs. . . . Two other arbitration cases, those of Orel Hershiser of Los Angeles and Bill Doran of Houston, were heard yesterday and should be decided today. Two players who had filed for arbitration, Tony Phillips of Oakland and Tom Waddell of Cleveland, reached agreements on one-year contracts, with Phillips signing for $425,000 and Waddell for $250,000. Forty-seven players remain on the arbitration schedule. . . . Joe Price, a free-agent pitcher, agreed to a one-year contract with San Francisco. He is the 36th of 79 free agents to sign for 1987, the 10th with a club he didn't play for last season.

title: BROADWAY
description: THERE are all kinds of wonderful theater things going on at the moment - in London, it's true, but don't sniff and say ''So what?'' They're all headed here - a few of them fairly soon - and two of the big ones were born in America.

title: JESSE MOORE, A TOP NASA AIDE, QUITS
description: Jesse W. Moore, who gave the final approval to the fatal launching of the space shuttle Challenger, has resigned from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the agency announced today.

title: COUNSELOR TELLS OF HIS SESSION WITH SURROGATE
description: A family counselor who advised Mary Beth Whitehead and her family on the stress from the Baby M custody fight was ordered to testify today, despite strenuous objections by a lawyer.

title: UDC-UNIVERSAL DEVELOPMENT LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pretax gain of $7,239,000 on sale of a subsidiary and an extraordinary item.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: IMPORTANT NONSENSE. By Lionel Abel. 232 pages. Prometheus Books. $22.95 IN the preface to his new collection of essays, Lionel Abel tells us that ''there is a wonderful drawing by the surrealist painter Roberto Matta, entitled Beware, A Fool Is Coming. The drawing is of a window, through which one sees approaching a man with the most fondly foolish face imaginable.'' A harmless enough creature, by the sound of it - why should we be on our guard?

title: G.E. MAKES A GIFT OF RCA LAB
description: Corporations have given almost everything imaginable to nonprofit groups at one time or another. Now an internationally famous research center can be added to the list.

title: ALLIANT COMPUTER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $956,000, or 11 cents a share, and $2,100,000, or 25 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss

title: NUI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HOME SAVINGS BANK NY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The bank converted to stock form in November 1986.

title: FILM: 'BLACK WIDOW,' FROM BOB RAFELSON
description: BOB RAFELSON'S ''Black Widow,'' with its good, flashy star-performances by Debra Winger and Theresa Russell, comes on with the seductiveness of an expensive perfume that inevitably evaporates before the night is over.

title: BOULDER, AN ECLECTIC CITY, TACKLES MATTERS OF TASTE
description: Depending on the point of view, this city's new urban design plan is either a visionary document that will protect historical architecture or a quagmire of unnecessary guidelines remniscent of the anti-business attitudes here in the 1960's.

title: DREXEL INQUIRY IS SAID TO FOCUS ON BOESKY BILL
description: The takeover of the Harris Graphics Corporation last year and a $5.3 million invoice to Ivan F. Boesky from Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. are turning out to be key tests of the theories behind the Government inquiry into Drexel's takeover practices, according to legal and Wall Street sources familiar with the case.

title: HARSCO CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $3.2 million from the repurchase of all $50 million principal amount of 12.5 percent sinking fund debentures.

title: Daisy's Co-founder Assumes Chief's Job
description: The Daisy Systems Corporation, a manufacturer of computer-aided design systems, said yesterday that its board had named its co-founder, Harvey C. Jones, president and chief executive.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We approached the Italians.

title: TELLABS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOUTHERN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Lee Konitz, New School, 66 West 12th Street (741-5667). For an active musician who has played an unusually significant role in the development of jazz, the alto saxophonist Lee Konitz is heard surprisingly infrequently in New York, despite the fact that he lives in the city. In the post-war 1940's, Mr. Konitz was a key member of two groundbreaking groups - Lennie Tristano's adventurous combos and the nine-member Miles Davis ensemble that is credited with creating ''cool'' jazz. At a time when almost all young alto saxophonists were copying Charlie Parker, Mr. Konitz provided a ''different'' voice on alto just as, a decade earlier, Lester Young was a new tenor-saxophone voice different from the established sound of Coleman Hawkins. Mr. Konitz will make one of his rare appearances, with Harold Danko at the piano, tonight at 6 in the Bernard Mayer Auditorium of the New School as part of the ''Jazz at 6'' series. Tickets are $7.

title: 2 Radicals in Bombing Plea
description: Two members of a radical group, tried last month in the shooting death of a New Jersey state trooper, Philip Lamonaco, pleaded not guilty here today to charges of attempting to overthrow the Government through a decade-long string of bombings and bank robberies. The two, Thomas W. Manning and Richard C. Williams, were indicted on those charges last May along with six other members of the United Freedom Front. Mr. Manning was convicted of felony murder in the Lamonaco murder but the jury did not reach a verdict against Mr. Williams. State officials said they would retry him.

title: Ex-C.I.A. Director Is Mugged
description: William E. Colby, the former Director of Central Intelligence, was beaten and robbed while walking near his Georgetown home last Friday, the District of Columbia Police said today. Mr. Colby was approached by four people who demanded money and then knocked him to the ground when he said he had none, said Officer Walter Ferguson.

title: WHAT DID A DOCTOR ORDER?
description: Until June 1985, Dr. Brent M. Pratley was a part-time team surgeon for the Brigham Young University football program whose warnings against excessive use of prescription drugs had led B.Y.U. to tighten controls in the training room. Now he himself stands accused of prescribing - in some cases, indiscriminately so - excessive addictive medication to Cougar players cut off from their former supply at school.

title: HUGE PROJECT ON COLUMBUS CIRCLE IS APPROVED BY BOARD OF ESTIMATE
description: The New York City Board of Estimate voted early this morning in favor of a huge redevelopment plan for Columbus Circle, with only one vote cast against it.

title: ART: QUIETER TIMES FOR EAST VILLAGE'S GALLERIES
description: AS anyone within hailing distance of the New York art world knows, the East Village gallery scene, for several years a testing ground for new and largely non-Neo-Expressionist art, is in a quiet but inexorable state of flux. It is undergoing changes that have been brought on, in no small part, by its own success.

title: 'THE TWO MRS. GRENVILLES' ON NBC
description: NBC'S four-hour production of ''The Two Mrs. Grenvilles'' - being broadcast this Sunday and Monday at 9 P.M. - is a good television movie that, with a touch more gumption, could have been terrific. Based on Dominick Dunne's best-selling novel, which in turn was loosely based on the actual William Woodward Jr. society shooting case in 1955, this is the kind of film that once would have starred Bette Davis or Miriam Hopkins. In fact, the opening credits are displayed against the background of artfully arranged satin that was a fixture in ''serious'' movies several decades ago. Naturally, a piano pounds romantically on the soundtrack. Quick, grab the popcorn. Make no mistake, this is dandy television. With Susan Pollock as executive producer and Preston Fischer (''Lace'') as producer, the accomplished director John Erman has persuaded two splendid actresses to play the Mrs. Grenvilles. Ann-Margret is Ann, the showgirl who marries William (Billy) Grenville Jr., very wealthy and very Social Register. And Claudette Colbert is Alice, William's widowed mother, the matriarch who still calls her grown son Junior. Stephen Collins is Billy, and John Rubinstein is his best friend, Bratsie Bleeker. Elizabeth Ashley is Babette Van Degan, Ann's best friend and herself a former showgirl, and Penny Fuller is Cordelia Grenville, the only one of Billy's three sisters to show Ann the slightest civility.

title: Poppe Tyson Purchase Completed by Lorimar
description: The acquisition of the Poppe Tyson agency from D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles by Lorimar Telepictures was completed yesterday, and the business-to-business agency will now be merged into USAdvertising, a Lorimar subsidiary.

title: ALLIES SURPRISED BY PLANS TO SPEED 'STAR WARS' TESTS
description: Arms control advocates in Congress and among the Western allies expressed concern today about reports that the Reagan Administration may interpret the ABM treaty of 1972 to allow extensive testing of some ''Star Wars'' systems and accelerate their deployment.

title: ALLIED-SIGNAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after a non-recurring charge of $201 million for the spin-off of Henley and an equity loss of $54 million in the Henley Group. The non-recurring charge of $201 million includes a spin-off of Henley, the writedown to net realizable value of certain operations to be disposed of, medical benefits for retirees of disposed operations, and certain environmental liabilities as well as the reversal of taxes provided on second quarter items. The after-tax impact was $434 million, or $2.49 a share. With the $47 million applicable to Henley items, the total was $481 million, or $2.76 a share. c-Net loss and after a non-recurring charge of $182 million for the spin-off of Henley and an equity loss of $66 million in the Henley Group. The non-recurring charge of $578 million for the spin-off of Henley, the writedown to net realizable value of certain operations to be disposed of, medical benefits for retirees of disposed operations, and certain environmental liabilities. This amount is partially offset by a gain of $308 million related to the sale of 50 percent of Union Texas Petroleum in the second quarter items. The after-tax loss on these items was $409 million, or $3.78 a share. With the $47 million applicable to Henley items, the total was $456 million, or $4.22 a share. The company said the 1986 and 1985 figures include the results of the Signal Companies, Inc., consolidated as of Oct. 1, 1985. The 1985 results have been reclassified.

title: A SHANTYTOWN ON CANVAS: LIFE IN PRIMARY COLORS
description: A diminutive man watches contentedly as his enormous wife feasts on a plate of chicken.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Pacers 98, Pistons 93: In Pontiac, Mich., Vern Fleming scored a season-high 24 points last night and Chuck Person added 22 as Indiana beat the Detroit Pistons, ending the Pacers' seven-game losing streak.(AP) Bullets 94, Cavaliers 85: In Landover, Md., Moses Malone scored 13 third-quarter points, including nine free throws, and Manute Bol blocked 12 shots for Washington. Malone led the Bullets with 20 points, despite making only four of 18 field goal attempts. His fourth basket, which gave the Bullets a lead they never lost, came on a pass from Bol. It was Bol's first assist of the season, earned in his 662d minute of play.(AP) Rockets 120, Warriors 110: Akeem Olajuwon responded to the loss of Ralph Sampson by scoring 21 points and getting 11 rebounds and blocking nine shots to lead the Rockets at home. Sampson suffered a knee injury in Tuesday night's loss to Denver and underwent arthroscopic surgery Thursday. He will miss at least six weeks of the season.(AP) Bucks 120, Bulls 105: Ricky Pierce scored a season-high 32 points and Terry Cummings added 29 as Milwaukee, playing at home, broke a three-game losing streak. Chicago's Charles Oakley and Milwaukee's Paul Mokeski were ejected with 1:34 left in the third quarter for fighting after the became entangled under the basket. Mokeski was taken to a hospital for X-rays. (AP) Spurs 117, SuperSonics 111: In San Antonio, Jon Sundvold scored 25 points to lead the Spurs to their seventh consecutive victory. San Antonio had seven players in double figures. The Spurs had not won seven in a row since November 1981. (AP) N.H.L. Bruins 6, Penguins 5: Keith Crowder scored from close range at 19 minutes 7 seconds of the third period and the Bruins edged Pittsburgh in Boston last night despite three goals and two assists by the Penguins' Mario Lemieux. The game ended in a brawl as Pittsburgh's Randy Cunneyworth and Boston's Keith Crowder traded punches after the buzzer. (AP) HORSE RACING Flying Heat Makes Late Charge: Flying Heat made a strong late run to carry 115 pounds under Chris Antley to a 2 3/4-length victory yesterday in the $45,000 allowance feature for fillies and mares 4 years old and up at Aqueduct. The 5-year-old daughter of Private Account and Turn Down the Heat went a mile and 70 yards on the fast track in 1:42:4 to earn $27,000 for her owner, Marcia W. Schott. Reel Easy was up in the final yards to edge Cherry Jubilee for second by a half-length. The victory was the first in two starts this year for Flying Heat, who returned $5.20 for $2 to win. SKATING Boitano Wins Compulsory: Brian Boitano, last year's world champion, took the first step toward his third straight national title yesterday by winning the compulsory figures at the United States Figure Skating Championships in Tacoma, Wash. Boitano, 23 years old, of Sunnyvale, Calif., finished first with all nine judges in the required figures. Daniel Doran of Chicago was second and Scott Williams of Redondo Beach, Calif., took third. (AP) Soviet Sweep: Aleksandr Fadeev of the Soviet Union turned in a near-perfect performance to win his second men's European title and lead the first Soviet sweep of the top three positions in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia. Second place went to Vladimir Kotin, who was second in last year's European championships, and third went to Viktor Petrenko.(AP) SKIING Schneider Takes Slalom: Vreni Schneider of Switzerland won the women's giant slalom at the world Alpine championships in Crans-Montana, Switzerland, yesterday. She edged Mateja Svet, an 18-year-old Yugoslav who had narrowly beaten the Swiss veteran for the bronze medal in the women's supergiant slalom. Third, with a dashing second run, was Maria Walliser of Switzerland. The bronze gave Walliser three medals, two golds, for the championships. (AP) GOLF Sarasota Classic Suspended: Chris Johnson adjusted her swing to cope with the wind and shot a five-under-par 67 to lead by a stroke when the first round of the L.P.G.A.'s $200,000 Sarasota Classic was suspended because of darkness. Johnson, winner of three tournaments in seven years as a professional, birdied the last three holes to finish with six birdies and one bogey on the soggy par 72, 6,124-yard Bent Tree Country Club course. The round was scheduled to resume this morning, when the six will have one hole to play.(AP) Pavin Leads by a Shot: Corey Pavin, last year's winner, finished off a 65 with a birdie on the last hole and took a one-shot lead in Honolulu after the first round of the $600,000 Hawaiian Open. Pavin, who won the Bob Hope Classic three weeks ago and leads the PGA Tour in money-winnings at this early stage of the season, was seven under par on the windblown Waialae Country Club course.(AP)

title: CONGRESS SEEKING HARMONY ON TRADE
description: With trade the declared legislative priority of the year, key members of Congress are touting their new maturity in dealing with the politically potent subject.

title: Energy Efficiency Was Lesson of 70's Oil Shocks
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. Profit Fell 26.1% Last Year
description: Two of the Big Three auto makers today reported earnings declines for 1986, as the industry began to close the books on its fourth prosperous year in a row.

title: 'THE SEASONS': FORCEFUL PAINTINGS FROM JASPER JOHNS
description: FOR some months now, the recent four-part cycle of paintings by Jasper Johns called ''The Seasons'' has been spoken of by those who have seen it in private as a benchmark in the history not only of American art, but of American autobiography. Now that ''The Seasons'' can be seen through March 7 at the Leo Castelli Gallery, 420 West Broadway, at Spring Street, it is clear that this was not an exaggeration.

title: LOWER EAST SIDE A MAINSTAY FOR MUSIC
description: The real-estate boom, the rise in the legal drinking age and increased downtown tourism have taken a toll on the Lower East Side's music scene - particularly on weekends, when clubs fill up with or without live performers. But a few stalwart places continue to present music, and visitors to the Lower East Side are likely to see posters advertising informal events.

title: APPLIANCES, RULES AND POLITICS HAVE SENATORS IN AN UPROAR
description: A testy Senate floor fight erupted today involving a bill on household appliances, parliamentary rules, a hasty car ride from the White House by the Vice President and - most important - a political struggle that placed Democrats on the offensive against Republicans.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BOX STEP FOLLOWS A BIG BAND TO BARNARD
description: ''Side, together, forward. Side, together, back. Quick, quick, slow.'' The instructions had the sound of a dance and deportment class in an elementary school gym. But the students being introduced to the box step were from Barnard and Columbia Colleges, and they applauded when Bruce Powell told them: ''You have just learned the box step, and you must never forget it. It's like learning the first few words in another language.''

title: DANCE: 2 TWYLA THARP PIECES IN NEW INCARNATIONS
description: A CHOREOGRAPHER'S lot is not a finite one, as Gilbert and Sullivan might have said. The two pieces on Twyla Tharp's second program at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Wednesday night have both been seen in previous incarnations.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: MORE than anything else, the various episodes of Woody Allen's ''Radio Days'' are held together by the music of the late 1930's to mid-1940's - the highly structured songs with sweetly genteel lyrics that not only provide background for the film but also establish its emotional center.

title: Randy Lanier Sought
description: Randy Lanier, last year's Indianapolis 500 Rookie of the Year, was being sought in several states yesterday after failing to show up in Federal court in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., Wednesday on charges of racketeering for participating in a marijuana smuggling ring. Lanier has also been named to a six-count Federal grand jury indictment in Southern Illinois contending he engaged ''in an enterprise to distribute'' more than 1,000 pounds of marijuana over a six-year period.

title: On Those Park Fees
description: At a hearing Thursday by the House Subcommittee on National Parks and Public Lands, Representative Peter H. Kostmayer of Pennsylvania congratulated the National Park Service director, William Penn Mott Jr., for deciding not to charge people fees to see Independence Hall or the Liberty Bell in Philadelphia. The Park Service is starting to charge entrance fees at many national parks and historic areas, and there had been talk that that would apply to Independence Hall.

title: VALMONT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Net loss

title: HIGH TECH'S GLAMOUR FADES FOR SOME VENTURE CAPITALISTS
description: The venture capital industry, which has nurtured the growth of hundreds of high-technology companies such as Apple Computer, Genentech and Lotus Development, is shifting its focus to more mundane investments that have little to do with technological innovation or creating new jobs.

title: FILM: 'THE ASSAULT,' A TALE OF WAR
description: IT is an ordinary day in the Netherlands during January 1945, or a day as ordinary as an occupied nation can know. The Steenwijk family, having pulled down its blackout shades and had its paltry dinner, is at the end of a reasonably peaceful evening. Then shots are heard. A well-known and hated collaborator has been assassinated in front of the house next door, and his body has been moved to the Steenwijk's, who will now be held responsible for the crime. Seconds later, Nazi troopers are heard. Father Steenwijk remains seated at the table, his head bowed, as they break down the door.

title: Goldin-Boesky Calls Under Investigation
description: The New York City Department of Investigation said yesterday that it had started a ''formal inquiry'' into telephone calls by City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin to raise money for an investment concern headed by Ivan F. Boesky, the Wall Street speculator.

title: BOMB NEAR OFFICIAL'S HOMES IN CAPE TOWN INJURES WOMAN
description: A bomb blasted the roof off a bus shelter today about 330 yards from President P. W. Botha's house in the Groote Schuur Estate, the police said. A young white woman was wounded. The bus stop is on a main road about 15 feet from the gate to the estate, where several Cabinet ministers live.

title: Diner's Journal
description: ARQUA is a rustic village in northeastern Italy and the home of the 14th-century poet and philosopher Petrarch. It also is the name of an engaging new restaurant housed in a towering former commercial retail space in TriBeCa. Opened five weeks ago, it is quickly gaining a downtown following for its original and lovingly prepared pastas, herb-scented grilled entrees and homemade desserts. The wide-open space has intriguing ocher-toned walls to evoke sandstone churches in Arqua, the hometown of the owner and chef, Leonardo Pulito. The color was achieved through a tedious process that involves dabbing diluted paint onto plaster by hand with sea sponges.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Signed Pat Dodson, first baseman, and Wes Gardner, pitcher, to one-year contracts.

title: BUILDER SAYS THE ACTION IS NOW IN JERSEY SUBURBS
description: For years conventional wisdom had it that the hub of the action was Manhattan if you wanted to be successful in metropolitan area real estate. Commercial properties in center city for sure, and residential as close as possible.

title: Ex-Radioman Accused Of Passing U.S. Secrets
description: A retired Navy radioman was formally charged Wednesday with passing classified information to Philippine police officials while working at a Navy communications center there, a Navy spokesman said.

title: AUCTIONS
description: WRISTWATCHES - one of the most popular collectibles of the 1980's - will be auctioned tomorrow at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. at Sotheby's, York Avenue at 72d Street. Outstanding among the more than 400 examples is a 1909 minute repeater by Audemars Piguet, an ultra-thin platinum dress watch that is a rarity, according to Daryn Schnipper, one of Sotheby's watch specialists. ''Minute repeaters by Piguet are hard to find,'' she said. ''I can think of only three or four that have been sold anywhere -and we know of no other that has been auctioned.'' The presale estimate is $55,000 to $65,000.

title: SMOKING RULES CHANGE FOR U.S. OFFICES TODAY
description: Federal employees will be permitted to smoke only in designated areas, ranging from a couch to a catwalk, under more restrictive smoking regulations taking effect Friday.

title: FILM: GERARD DEPARKIEU IN 'ONE WOMAN OR TWO'
description: HARD as it is to believe, the brilliant director of ''The Return of Martin Guerre'' has now made an idiotic comedy about a paleontologist, some women and some bones. The bones, being silent, have a definite advantage over the other players.

title: RACISM BLAMED FOR BRAWL AT U. OF MASSACHUSETTS
description: A melee among students on the Amherst campus of the University of Massachusetts after the last World Series game was ''predictable, preventable and primarily racially motivated,'' according to a report by a member of the Massachusetts Commission Against Discrimination.

title: INSIDE
description: Soviet Worries About AIDS

title: ITALIANS SEE LINKS TO SYRIA IN 1985 AIRPORT ATTACK
description: An Italian prosecutor's report contends that a 1985 airport attack here was planned in Syria and carried out by the Abu Nidal organization, according to senior judicial officials.

title: KNICKS ENJOY AND EASY NIGHT
description: In the beginning, it was merely a game between teams enduring seasons of trouble. But it became a small ray of hope for the Knicks and just another distressing defeat for the Nets, who have tumbled so far that the annual break for this weekend's All-Star Game has become a welcome relief.

title: 438 PROTESTERS ARE ARRESTED AT NEVADA NUCLEAR TEST SITE
description: More than 400 people were arrested today when they tried to enter the nation's nuclear proving grounds here after nearly 2,000 demonstrators, including six members of Congress, held a rally to protest nuclear weapons testing.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: IN December 1981, Andrzej Czeczot was imprisoned by the martial-law Government in Poland.

title: Frazier Gains Hall of Fame
description: Walt Frazier, the multitalented and unflappable backcourt star who helped the Knicks win National Basketball Association championships in 1970 and 1973, was among five former players elected yesterday to the Basketball Hall of Fame.

title: New Bomber Jackets Spur Ancient Fears
description: IN Newark, the young know when a couple of guys come up and say, ''pass off,'' they mean give up your fur-collared bomber jacket, or you can get shot.

title: Lemieux Gets Clearance
description: Mario Lemieux, the Pittsburgh Penguins center who outpolled Wayne Gretzky in the fan balloting for the National Hockey League All-Star team that meets the Soviet National Team in the two-game Rendez-Vous '87 series next week, has been given medical clearance to play. ''I have three more games to play before Rendez-Vous,'' Lemieux said. ''If I get through these three games without any pain. I'll play.'' He missed 13 games after spraining his right knee Dec. 20, but has scored eight goals and three assists in six games since returning.

title: AFFILIATED PUBLICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $500,000 for the quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $312,000 for the year, and a gain on the sale of discontinued operations of $26,615,000 for both the quarter and year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $319,000 and $1,269,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; and gains on the sale of discontinued operations of $1,728,000 for the quarter and $3,846,000 for the year. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Jan. 23, 1987, and a 3-for-2 stock split paid Jan. 24, 1986.

title: BASEBALL FEVER ON THE RISE IN AUSTRALIA
description: Now that the America's Cup is over, and the touring British cricketers have returned home, many Australian sports fans are turning their attention to the final championship games of a growing phenomenon here: baseball.

title: PACIFIC TELECOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Market Place; Schoellkopf's Apparel Stake
description: AN investment firm that is part of the financial empire of Caroline Hunt Schoellkopf - by some accounts the nation's wealthiest woman - has increased its stake in the Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation, the Manhattan-based apparel company.

title: Ford Widening 6-Year Warranty
description: Officials of the Ford Motor Company said the company's six-year and 60,000-mile powertrain warranty would be extended to light trucks and vans as well as cars. The warranty is retroactive to the beginning of the 1987 model year. ''The warranty war is over,'' said Louis E. Lataif, Ford's vice president for sales. With all three major domestic auto makers now offering warranties of six or seven years, and because most cars are traded in before then, warranty has been removed as a key element in decision making, he said.

title: Corrections
description: The Scouting column in Sports Pages yesterday misidentified a Utah Jazz player who failed to score in a basketball game Nov. 1. He is Kelly Tripucka, who was traded to Utah by Detroit last summer, and not Kiki Vandeweghe, who plays for Portland.

title: BEREFT OF REFS
description: The team from Jersey City State was there, the Kean College team was there, and so were cheerleaders and a couple of hundred fans. In fact, just about everybody you need for a basketball game was present at Kean's D'Angola Gym in Union, N.J., Wednesday night - but not quite everybody. There were no referees, and when it became apparent that they weren't going to show up, everybody else did the logical thing. They went home.

title: OFFICER TELLS OF TWO SHOTS AT BUMPURS
description: Police Officer Stephen Sullivan, who shot and killed Eleanor Bumpurs two years ago during an eviction in the Bronx, defended yesterday his decision to shoot her twice.

title: CARL R. ROGERS, 85, LEADER IN PSYCHOTHERAPY, DIES
description: Carl R. Rogers, a popular author and preeminent American psychotherapist whose influence has spanned decades, died Wednesday night of a heart attack after surgery for a broken hip at the Scripps Clinic in La Jolla, Calif. He was 85 years old. Dr. Rogers, a psychologist, was known for developing the client-centered approach to psychotherapy, in which the therapist maintains an accepting and empathic stance toward the patient and lets the patient take the lead in the focus, pace and direction of therapy.

title: PLAN FOR LAKE AT PARK LAWN IS POSTPONED
description: The dragonflies of Belvedere Lake have won a bureaucratic reprieve.

title: STANADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said net income in the latest quarter and year was adversely affected by the repeal of the investment tax credit under the Tax Reform Act of 1986; after applying applicable transition rules, credits taken in earlier periods were reversed in the latest quarter, resulting in a reduction of net income.

title: GROMYKO SAYS A-TESTS SOUR TIES
description: President Andrei A. Gromyko told former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger today that the latest nuclear test in Nevada was part of an American effort to sour relations with the Soviet Union, the Tass press agency said.

title: CANADIAN GENERAL ELECTRIC CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring charge of $8.8 million from restructuring costs.

title: Imagine Being Unhappy Over a $22,000 Raise
description: The issue that consumed the attention of Congress for the last two weeks may have begun, in the words of Representative Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House, as simply ''a petty and puerile quarrel over who gets paid how much.''

title: The U.N. Today: FEB. 6, 1987
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Organizational session - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: HEAD OF YANKEES FROM '66 TO '73
description: Michael Burke, who when president of the New York Yankess got the city to refurbish Yankee Stadium and kept the team from moving to the New Jersey Meadowlands, died of cancer yesterday in Ireland. He was 70 years old.

title: Exchange With Italy
description: More than 25 artists and groups from New York - representing theater, opera, dance and music - will perform this month in Italy at the Carnival of Venice. Italian artists will take part in the International Festival of the Arts to be held in New York next year. Martin E. Segal, the chairman of the New York festival, and Italy's Consul General, Francesco Corrias, announced the exchange at a press conference yesterday. The New York City Ballet, Bernadette Peters and the soprano Martina Arroyo are among the artists who will perform in Venice and Palermo during the 12-day festival, which begins Feb. 20.

title: Examination for Flatley
description: Patrick Flatley of the Islanders, who injured his left knee Wednesday night during the team's 4-1 loss in Vancouver, returned to New York yesterday with suspected ligament damage. Flatley, who suffered the injury after being checked by a Canucks player, was examined by Vancouver's team doctors after the game and sent home on their recommendation. Dr. Barry Fisher, the Islanders' orthopedist, was expected to examine Flatley today, and the forward could miss the next three weeks if the preliminary diagnosis of stretched ligaments is correct. Flatley, the team's fourth-leading scorer, has 46 points in 53 games.

title: REPORTER'S OUSTER BY IRAN EXPECTED
description: Iran said yesterday that Gerald F. Seib, an American reporter detained on espionage charges, would be expelled within 24 hours, and there were unconfirmed reports last night that he had already left Teheran.

title: 15 of Philadelphia's Judges Suspended Pending Inquiry
description: The Pennsylvania Supreme Court has ordered 15 judges of Philadelphia courts to leave the bench pending an investigation of allegations involving cash gifts from a union local seeking favorable treatment for its members.

title: MERCURY SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said that its provision for losses on loans and real estate was $24,644,000 in the latest quarter, compared with $4,259,000 in the year-ago period. It said $17.4 million of the provision in the latest quarter resulted from two groups of pre-1985, non-recurring transactions.

title: FILM: 'DEAD OF WINTER,' A GOTHIC HORROR TALE
description: THE star plays three women, one of them mostly dead. The setting is a huge, isolated mansion filled with unnerving decorating touches, like the polar bear in the parlor. The town is the kind of place where they give you free goldfish when you buy gas, and nobody thinks that's peculiar. And the villain likes to tell eerie little stories about President McKinley, which are lies. When a director approaches Gothic horror with this much enthusiasm, the results are bound to be as merry as they are frightening. So audiences for Arthur Penn's ''Dead of Winter'' are in for a hair-raising treat.

title: COLUMBIA GAS SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary charges for refunding of high cost debentures and sale of a subsidiary of $8.6 million for the quarter and $12,600,000 for the year. c-Net loss The company said the prior year loss includes a charge of $207 million from establishing a reserve for unrecovered gas-purchase costs and an after-tax gain of $11 million from discontinuance of an FASB rule. The company said the revenue for the prior year and quarter are restated.

title: Energy Efficiency Was Lesson of 70's Oil Shocks; Get on With It
description: To the Editor:

title: Queens High Schools Handled Tensions Well
description: To the Editor:

title: Babbitt Sets a Date
description: Former Gov. Bruce Babbitt of Arizona may not be the first Democrat to formally enter the party's 1988 Presidential competition, but he is the first to announce when he will announce. The word out of Phoenix is that Mr. Babbitt will officially become a candidate on March 11, with an appearance at his national headquarters in the Arizona capital and a cross-country flight featuring speeches in Iowa, where the first Presidential caucuses will be held in mid-February next year, and in New Hampshire, where the first primary takes place a week later. Although he is among the darkest of dark horses in what is likely to be a crowded field, Mr. Babbitt has had campaign offices in both these early-voting states for a month now.

title: Viacom Bid Kept
description: Sumner M. Redstone, who is bidding for Viacom International Inc. through his Arsenal Holdings Inc., has extended the deadline for a response from Viacom's special committee of outside directors until next Wednesday. Mr. Redstone had asked that the outside directors consider his offer and give him a response by today. Wall Street is valuing the Redstone offer at $46.50 a share. A rival bid from Viacom's management was valued at $45.50 a share. Goldman, Sachs & Company is advising Viacom's outside directors.

title: NORTH CAROLINA WINS BY 96-79 AS SMITH RETURNS
description: Last Saturday, North Carolina lost Kenny Smith, its point guard, to arthroscopic knee surgery. The next day it lost at Notre Dame and fell from the top spot in the polls. But tonight, five days after his surgery, Smith was leading the relentless Tar Heels to a 96-79 trouncing of their Atlantic Coast Confer rival, North Carolina State.

title: F.C.C. MEMBER IS NAMED CHAIRMAN
description: President Reagan today named Dennis R. Patrick, one of the Federal Communications Commission's avid supporters of deregulation, to succeed Mark S. Fowler as the agency's chairman.

title: Bridge: Card Table Provides Outlet For Clash of Public Agencies
description: Medieval arguments were sometimes settled by nominating two heroes who would then joust against each other. One can daydream pleasantly about the possibility of settling modern disputes at the bridge table or some other recreational arena.

title: It's No Time to Abandon Manila
description: LEAD: On Sept. 22, 1983, thousands of Filipinos marched to the gates at Malacanang Palace, lashing out against President Ferdinand E. Marcos for the assassination of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. in August. That rally, at which 11 were shot to death, and others like it signaled the rise of a wave of outrage that swept Mr.

title: DIGITAL IS EXPECTED TO INTRODUCE MODEL
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation is expected to introduce next week a desktop-size computer work station able to do the chores that Digital machines as big as a room did a decade ago.

title: METS, GOODEN EAGER TO AGREE
description: The Mets appeared to be avoiding another off-the-field headache yesterday when Dwight Gooden's agent said that it was ''overwhelmingly desirable'' for both sides to agree on a contract without going to arbitration.

title: TWO CABBIES REPORT SEEING HIM
description: Conflicting reports added to the confusion today over Terry Waite, the missing Church of England envoy who has been trying to negotiate the release of foreign hostages.

title: FILM: 'AMULET OF OGUM'
description: ''AMULET OF OGUM,'' opening a limited run today at the Public Theater, is the sort of folkloric though sophisticated film that was so beloved by members of Brazil's ''new cinema'' in the late 1950's and 60's.

title: MOSLEM LEADERS MEET WITH CARDINAL
description: John Cardinal O'Connor discussed his Middle East trip yesterday with seven American Moslem leaders and said afterward that the meeting was held to balance one held two weeks ago with Jewish leaders.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Providence College basketball coach, Rick Pitino, apologized yesterday for berating the officiating crew following the Friars' 67-66 loss Tuesday night to Boston College. ''Officiating college baskeball is probably the most difficult job in the world,'' Pitino said in a statement. ''Although our game was a bitter pill to swallow, my remarks directed toward the men with the whistle were out of line and uncharacteristic of my respect for them.'' . . . Ralph Sampson underwent arthroscopic surgery yesterday to repair cartilage damage in the left knee he injured Tuesday night and Houston Rocket officials are saying that they anticipate the all-star forward will be able to return this season. . . . The St. Louis general manager, Dal Maxvill, said the Cardinals would not open talks with Lance Parrish, the free-agent catcher, because of ''medical concerns'' about the back of the 30-year-old former Detroit player. . . . Another free-agent catcher, Rich Gedman, formerly of the Boston Red Sox, has ended his negotiations with the Houston Astros after rejecting a three-year deal worth $2.15 million.

title: DOFASCO INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: All figures are in Canadian funds and the company is traded on the Montreal and Toronto Stock Exchanges.

title: 2 Latin-Jazz Groups
description: The percussionist Mongo Santamaria and the pianist Michel Camilo will each lead Latin-jazz groups in a double bill tonight through Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). Shows begin at 9 and 11:30 P.M., with a 1:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $15 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, a $7.50 music charge at the bar.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Toll Increase to Begin For Crossings in City
description: Automobile tolls on the major crossings operated by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority will rise to $2 from $1.75 after midnight tonight. Tolls for trucks and other vehicles will also rise proportionately.

title: UNIVERSAL LEAF TOBACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LILLY, ELI & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHAMBER MUSIC AT THE Y
description: Yoav Talmi will lead the New York Chamber Symphony in a program of works by Mendelssohn, Mozart, Beethoven and Barber at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, tomorrow night at 8 and Sunday afternoon at 3. David Bar-Illan will be the soloist in a performance of Mendelssohn's Piano Concerto No. 1 in G minor. Tickets are $13 and $15. Information: 996-1100.

title: Chevron Study Of Angola Unit
description: The Chevron Corporation said yesterday that it was considering reducing its presence in Angola by selling a 9.8 percent interest in Angola's state-controlled oil production operations, in which it has a 49 percent stake.

title: FILM: 'COME AND SEE,' FROM SOVIET
description: THE terrible central event of ''Come and See,'' which takes up about a quarter of the 2-hour, 22-minute Soviet movie now at the Bleecker Street Cinema, is the burning of a Byelorussian village by German invaders in 1943. A line on the screen tells us that hundreds of villages in the Soviet republic east of Poland were destroyed, their people annihilated. The history is harrowing and the presentation is graphic; you feel it through your body as villagers are packed into a barn to be incinerated.

title: Attacking Arms Control, and Arms
description: The Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972 is in peril. Almost alone among arms control agreements, it has helped prevent nuclear war, sharply curtailing the development of a dangerous mix of defensive and offensive forces. Now President Reagan appears ready to launch a double-barreled attack against the treaty. He could do no greater harm to his own stated goals for arms control or to American national security.

title: Dining Out Guide; FAR EASTERN SAMPLER
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: BEVERLY ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $6.5 million from the redemption of $77 million of subordinated debentures. c-Net income

title: 15 INDICTED IN PRIMARY-PETITION FORGERIES
description: Fifteen people have been indicted on charges of forging signatures on primary petitions for two candidates in 1985, the Manhattan District Attorney said yesterday.

title: 2 RUSSIANS HEADED FOR SPACE STATION
description: Two Soviet astronauts were launched early this morning toward a rendezvous with the orbiting space station Mir on Sunday.

title: FILM: 'LIGHT OF DAY,' A ROCK SAGA
description: THERE'S a make-or-break moment in Paul Schrader's ''Light of Day'' in which Joan Jett, the hard-rock singer-guitarist who plays a similar type of musician in the film, announces, ''I've been tryin' to live my life by an idea!'' Part of the audience is sure to find this ridiculous - and not without reason, since the character she plays is an unmarried, unfit mother who spends most of her time in high-decibel dives. But another part will understand what both Miss Jett and the film are getting at. The idea of which she speaks is rock-and-roll at its most raw, rock-and-roll in its purest form.

title: JWT Group to Report Fourth-Quarter Loss
description: The JWT Group, whose chief executive a week ago put down a palace revolt brought on at least partly by the company's financial performance, reported yesterday that the picture might be darker than expected.

title: Iceland Acting on Bank
description: Iceland will go ahead with privatizing Utvegsbanki, the country's second-largest bank, officials said today. The bank lost most of its capital on bad loans last year.

title: Church's Reports Talks With Sonic
description: Church's Fried Chicken Inc., the nation's second-largest fast-food chicken operation, said today that it had been asked to consider the possibility of a takeover bid from Sonic Industries Inc.

title: Abortions and Health
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRYSLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STATE TO SEEK REVERSAL ON WEDTECH PLEA DEAL
description: State prosecutors will try again today to get a judge in Manhattan to accept a complicated plea arrangement in the Wedtech bribery investigation.

title: AMERICAN GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $89,375,000 for the quarter and $131,489,000 for the year. c-Includes capital gains of $1,343,000 and $40,749,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: CUOMO AND STRATEGISTS MEET TO WEIGH PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: Governor Cuomo said today that he had met over the last seven days with key national political strategists and that he would decide within two weeks whether to take preliminary steps toward running for President.

title: KLM ROYAL DUTCH AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: All figures are in Dutch guilders. The company reported the average bank exchange rate was DFL 2.19 to

title: FILM: 'FROM THE HIP'
description: ''FROM THE HIP'' goes out of joint in its first couple of minutes, when Judd Nelson pours ice-cold water over his attractive bedmate (Elizabeth Perkins) in order to get her out of bed and to work on time. In another 20 minutes, cold water has been poured on credibility by the yells, insults and prancings of Mr. Nelson, who is supposed to be a super-smart young lawyer. Instead of getting him ejected posthaste from the courtroom and his classy Boston law firm, the antics bring him success.

title: A SEX BARRIER FOR CANTORS IS BROKEN
description: The Jewish Theological Seminary of America announced yesterday that it would for the first time certify women as cantors to lead services in Conservative congregations around the world.

title: DANCE: BALLET RAMBERT IN THREE ALSTON WORKS
description: BALLET RAMBERT looked casual on Wednesday night. Too casual, perhaps. The program - the second in a weeklong engagement at the City Center Theater, 131 West 55th Street - included three works by the British company's artistic director, Richard Alston. Everyone was amiable in Mr. Alston's ''Java.'' Indeed, to employ a slang term, the dancers even seemed laid back in this choreographic suite to old recordings by the Ink Spots. Just as that vocal group never sounded strained and often delighted in obviously artificial passages of falsetto, so Mr. Alston's dancers moved in a calculatedly easygoing fashion against a silvery backdrop designed by Jenny Henry.

title: MERCURY GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized investment gains of $339,000 for the quarter and $2,352,000 for the year. c-After realized investment gains of $191,000 for the quarter and $563,000.

title: ABC Said to Plan 'Amerika' Disclaimer
description: ABC, which has been criticized by the United Nations for its mini-series ''Amerika,'' has agreed to run a disclaimer at the beginning of the show stating that institutions portrayed in it are fictional, a source involved in negotiations with the network said today.

title: Xerox Unit Buys Stake
description: A newly formed subsidiary of the Xerox Corporation said today that it had acquired a 25 percent equity interest in VMS Realty Partners Inc., a Chicago-based real estate syndicate, for $80 million. Xerox, which is based in Stamford, Conn., had said earlier this week that it was considering such a deal in an effort to expand its financial services business.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: SAY this for Princess Margaret:

title: PRIMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BELL & HOWELL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains of 8 cents a share for the quarter and $4.8 million, or 45 cents a share for the year, resulting from the previously announced sales of several businesses and property, partially offset by a provision for certain asset writedowns and organizational restructuring. c-Includes gains of 18 cents a share for the quarter and $1.9 million, or 18 cents share for the year, due to the sale of the company's Pasadena facilities, after deducting charges for asset writedowns and organizational restructuring.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Maureen McGovern, Freddy's Supper Club, 308 East 49th Street (888-1633). Listening to Maureen McGovern's hit versions of theme songs for 70's disaster movies (''The Morning After'' from ''The Poseidon Adventure'' and ''We May Never Love Like This Again,'' from ''The Towering Inferno''), one could never have guessed that a decade later the singer would be hailed as the most technically accomplished pop-jazz singer on New York's cabaret circuit. For the next two weeks, Ms. McGovern will be at Freddy's, the site of her initial club triumphs, where she will perform classic pop standards from her new album, ''Another Woman in Love,'' a 14-song voice-and-piano record, plus a Gershwin medley. Performances tonight and tomorrow are at 8:30 and 11 P.M., and on Sunday at 3 P.M. There is a $20 cover charge and a two-drink minimum.

title: London Printers to End Fight With Murdoch
description: Britain's largest printing union voted tonight to stop its yearlong protest against the publisher Rupert Murdoch, effectively ending the country's most serious industrial dispute since the coal miners' strike of 1984- 85.

title: AIDS PERIL WORRIES SOVIET LEADERS
description: The threat of an AIDS epidemic in the Soviet Union, publicly dismissed as a remote possibility, has privately become a matter of concern at the highest levels, Soviet officials said today.

title: CROSS, A T CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Judge Orders Atlanta Suburb To Let Klan March Tomorrow
description: A Federal District judge ruled today that city officials in an Atlanta suburb must allow the Ku Klux Klan to stage a march Saturday. The judge, William C. O'Kelley, ruled that College Park, the suburb, must grant the parade permit to the white supremacist group. The town had sought to deny it unless the organization agreed to pay $3,085 for police overtime.

title: Dr. Martin Louis Kaye Dies; 'Specialized in Everything'
description: Dr. Martin Louis Kaye, a general practitioner on New York's Lower East Side for almost 60 years, died Wednesday at University Hospital after a brief illness. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: POLICE ACADEMY '87: ADAPTING TO A CHANGED NEW YORK
description: ''Atteeention,'' the drill sergeant yelled at 200 men and women. One man slouched. Another saluted with his left hand. ''Abooout face.'' A few turned the wrong way. A few more stumbled. The sergeant was not amused.

title: Connecticut Demurs
description: To the Editor:

title: COMMODORE INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $5,800,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss

title: '21' PATRONS: LOST SHEEP, FOR A TIME
description: Felix G. Rohatyn is lunching at his desk more often. Eileen Ford is surviving on Chinese carryout food and deli sandwiches. Pete Rozelle is scouring Manhattan for a new clubby restaurant, and Theodore W. Kheel is showing up everywhere.

title: KROGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After pre-tax LIFO charges of $10,660,073 for the quarter and $23.3 million for the year, and a pre-tax charge to establish a charitable foundation of $20 million for the quarter and year. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $4,275,298 and a pre-tax charge of $164,024,952 for restructuring. d-Includes income from discontinued operations of $10,663,292 for the quarter and $21,186,261 for the year. e-Includes a pre-tax credit of $12,359,481. f-After a pre-tax LIFO charge of $2.8 million. In 1986, Federal tax expenses increased by approximately $12.7 million due to reduced investment tax credits under the new tax law. The 1986 period includes an additional week compared to 1985. Share figures reflect a 2-for-1 split in September 1986.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Can Co., Greenwich, Conn., said it expected to report proceeds after expenses of about $31 million on the public offering of about 1.7 million shares of common stock by its subsidiary, Musicland Group Inc.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 6, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Concern about ''Star Wars'' systems is rising among some members of Congress and Western allies. The Reagan Administration may interpret the 1972 ABM treaty to allow testing of the systems and speed their deployment. Page A1 More than 400 people were arrested as they tried to enter a nuclear weapons testing site in Nevada after nearly 2,000 people, including six members of Congress, held a rally protesting the arms testing. A8 The U.S. will not deploy major arms but will allow some Pentagon research to proceed on the proposed American space station, according to Government officials. A17 In a rebuff to the U.S. on hostages, Britain, France and West Germany have declined to attend a proposed Western conference on coordinated responses to the terrorism, American officials said. A1 A 1985 attack on Rome's airport was planned in Syria and carried out by the Abu Nidal terrorist organization, according to an Italian prosecutor's report quoted by senior Rome judicial officials. A6 Women will be certified as cantors in Conservative Jewish congregations around the world for the first time, the Jewish Theological Seminary of America announced. The seminary first ordained a women as a rabbi in 1984. B1 Two Soviet astronauts flew off for a rendezvous Sunday with the orbiting space station Mir. The launching was shown live on Soviet television, only the second such occurrence in Soviet manned space program. A17 Threats of a Soviet AIDS epidemic, publicly dismissed as a remote possibility, have privately become a matter of concern at the highest levels of the Communist Party, according to Soviet officials. A3 The military ability of the contras in Nicaragua and the Reagan Administration's commitment to a negotiated settlement in Central America were strongly challenged by Democratic senators at a hearing. A3 British printers acknowledged their defeat by the publisher Rupert Murdoch. The nation's biggest printing union voted to stop its yearlong protest over his swift dismissal of 5,500 of its members. A7 A shantytown on canvas A4 U.S. pledges aid to South Africa's neighbors A5 Mystery over Waite grows A6 National A10-19 Nuclear plants such as Shoreham, N.Y., and Seabrook, N.H., whose safety is being challenged by state or local authorities could be licensed for full operation under a rule change drafted by the staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. A1 The Dow Jones industrials broke another mark, closing above 2,200 for the first time. The session was the second-most-active for the New York Stock Exchange, with 256.7 million shares changing hands.
