A1 Venture capital is shifting its focus from high technology companies to more mundane investments, such as pizza companies and employment agencies that have little to do with technological innovation or the creation of jobs. A1 An accused major drug trafficker was placed under heavy guard in Florida after his extradition from Colombia. The suspect, a former Colombian state senator, was captured with 15 bodyguards in a shootout. A10 A dispute on appliance standards prompted Senate Democrats to assail Republicans. At issue is a bill that would set national energy-efficiency rules for major household items and pre-empt state standards. A13 Carl R. Rogers, a psychologist, died at the age of 85. Dr. Rogers, an influential author and a founder of humanistic psychology, was also noted for developing the client-centered approach to psychotherapy. D16 Intelligence on terrorists could be used by immigration officials seeking to deport aliens, under plans being prepared by the Reagan Administration. Officials are studying ways to identify and deport aliens with links to terrorism. A15 Tom Bradley will seek re-election for a record fifth term as Mayor of Los Angeles. The 69-year-old Democrat announced his plan to run in 1989 during a guest appearance on the nationwide Joan Rivers show. A10 The killer of 10 people in Los Angeles last year killed himself last October, the police believe. The man was identified as Marcus Nisby, also known as Michael Player, a 26-year-old with a long record of street robberies. A11 Boulder, Colorado's new design plan is, depending on various points of view, a visionary document that will protect historical architecture or a quagmire of unnecessary, antibusiness guidelines. A10 Top NASA aide quits A17 2 million children stay home alone A19 WASHINGTON TALK A16 Congress's unhappy raise Arms and the man's language REGIONAL B1-4 A 17-percent CBS News budget cut is sought by Laurence A. Tisch, the chief executive of CBS Inc. He asked the group to reduce spending up to $50 million, prompting a drastic reassessment in worldwide CBS News operations. A1 Sexual abuse of a foster-care girl was reported by officials, who said she had been assaulted at two city children's centers and then was returned home although her adoptive father and brother had been charged with raping her. A1 A retired firefighter wounded critically a doctor, Peter C. Rizzo 3d, who had just taken part in a hearing at which a request by the fireman, Peter McNamee, for a disability pension was deferred. B3 New police recruits struggled through their first day of gym class as a drill sergeant shouted, ''About face.'' A few turned the wrong way. A few more stumbled. The sergeant was not amused. B1 Officer tells of Bumpurs death B1 Whiteheads' counselor testifies B2 L.I. County Executives confer B2 Cuomo decision due on U.S. race B4 NEEDIEST CASES B2

title: KEARNEY-NATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,628,000 from the termination of a pension plan, and also non-recurring expenses and losses for a shut-down Mexican facility of $1,106,000, and $1,014,000 for severance and other costs associated with staff reductions. c-Net loss is after losses from discontinued operations of $30,667,000 for the quarter and $29,868,000 for the year.

title: 2 MILLION CHILDREN STAY HOME ALONE
description: More than two million American youngsters spend at least some time unsupervised after school, with the largest share in white upper-income households, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: U.S. MAY SEEK END TO LOCAL VETOING OF NUCLEAR PLANTS
description: The staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has drafted a proposal that would permit the agency to license nuclear plants like those in Shoreham, L.I., and Seabrook, N.H., for full operation over the objections of state or local authorities, the agency said today.

title: PRIAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring charge of $31 million from restructuring of operations. The charge includes a reserve for future lease commitments on certain excess buildings and the writeoff of excess manufacturing equipment. c-Net income and includes tax credits of $804,000 for the quarter and $919,000 for the 6 months.

title: Let the Court Appoint The Expert Witnesses
description: To the Editor:

title: DOMTAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses on disposal of a business of $1.6 million for the quarter and year. The latest year also includes a $10.1 million gain on prior years' tax losses in the United States. c-Includes a special gain of $2 million. d-Includes a $14.3 million tax credit. All figures are in Canadian funds.

title: L.I. 'SUMMIT' PRODUCES JOINT APPROACH TO ISSUES
description: Long Island's top government officials, holding what they called the first-ever ''summit meeting'' between the leaders of Nassau and Suffolk Counties, agreed today to work jointly to solve several regional problems.

title: SENATORS CHALLENGE OFFICIALS ON CONTRAS
description: Two senior Administration officials encountered heated, skeptical cross-examination today from Democratic senators about the military effectiveness of the Nicaraguan rebels and the Administration's commitment to a negotiated settlement in Central America.

title: ALLIES REJECT A U.S. PLAN TO MEET ON HOSTAGES
description: The Reagan Administration has been rebuffed in its plan to convene a conference with six major allies to discuss coordinated responses to the continued hostage-taking in Lebanon, White House and State Department officials said today.

title: OLSTEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
TEMPLE-INLAND INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-earlier quarter and year results include a gain of 29 cents a share from the sale of assets.

title: Parade for Crew Tuesday
description: New York will honor Dennis Conner and his victorious Stars & Stripes crew with a parade up Fifth Avenue on Tuesday, and Donald J. Trump will foot the bill, he and Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: NATIONAL STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The share earnings are not available for the latest quarter. National Steel's latest quarter net was increased by $4.7 million from the liquidation of LIFO inventories and was reduced by an unusual charge of $4.6 million which covers the closing of a coke facility and is net of previously provided reserves. For 1985, National had an unusual charge of $17.3 million to write off a permanently idled coal mine. The net loss for the 1986 year was reduced by $8.2 million from the liquidation of LIFO inventories, compared to a reduction of $18.5 million for the 1985 year. National Steel is 50 percent owned by National Intergroup Inc. and 50 percent owned by Nippon Kokon KK of Japan.

title: ART: 'OUT OF THE STUDIO,' COMMUNITY SETTINGS
description: ''OUT OF THE STUDIO: Art With Community'' is surely the most ambitious attempt to explore the possibilities of art made within a community environment. The artists invited by P.S. 1 have been making work for or in collaboration with a particular community for some time. For each one, the idea of the artist working alone in a studio, making art that can be approached solely within a gallery context, has little or no appeal. Their art has meaning for them only when it is directly inspired by and woven into a particular social fabric.

title: Rosco Gordon to Play
description: The rhythm-and-blues pianist-singer Rosco Gordon will perform tonight and tomorrow at the Abilene Cafe, 359 Second Avenue, at 21st Street (473-8908). Shows are around 9:30 P.M. and midnight, with the Holmes Brothers opening tonight and the blues singer John Campbell opening tomorrow; there is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE CO OF NORTH CAROLINA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Shedding Light on 'The Rock'
description: A YEAR and a half ago Prudential introduced its first corporate ad campaign that was intended to project its new image: that of a financial services corporation with a life insurance base.

title: Allied-Signal Posts Profit
description: Allied-Signal Inc. said yesterday that it earned $69 million, or 38 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1986, in contrast to a loss of $660 million a year earlier.

title: Brazil Eases Price Controls
description: Brazil today dismantled most price controls, a key feature of a nearly year-old battle against rampant inflation, because of widespread shortages and mounting opposition from business executives.

title: AMETEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes pre-tax charges of $8.9 million and $13.2 million for the quarter and year, respectively from plant closings, disposal of assets, asset writedowns, restructuring of operations and contract disputes, as well as an $8 million credit for both the quarter and year to reflect federal tax law changes regarding investments in the form of leases. c-Includes pre-tax gains of $7.8 million on the sale of securities and property. The 1986 results reflects change in method of accounting for certain pension costs.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL COLLEGES: St. John's at Boston College, 8 P.M. (Radio - WCBS 880, 8 P.M.) York at St, Francis (Radio -WYNE-FM 91.5, 7:30 P.M.) Princeton at Columbia (Radio - WKCR-FM 89.5, 7:30 P.M.) BOXING MARK BRELAND VS. HAROLD VOLBRECT, 15 rounds for World Boxing Association welterweight championship, at Trump Plaza, Atlantic City, first bout at 8 P.M. (TV - Showtime, 8 P.M.) GOLF PGA TOUR: Hawaiian Open, at Waialae Country Club, Honolulu. LPGA TOUR: Sarasota Classic, at Bent Tree Country Club, Sarasota, Fla. HOCKEY ISLANDERS VS. OILERS, at Edmonton, Alberta, 9:35 P.M. (TV -SportsChannel, 9:30 P.M. Radio -WOR 710, 9:30 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS HARNESS RACING: Roosevelt 7:30P.M. Meadowlands, 7:30P.M. (TV - MSG, midnight) SOCCER: Express vs. Comets, at Kansas City, Mo. (Radio - WBAU-FM 90.3, 8:45 P.M.) THOROUGHBRED RACING: Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 6:30 P.M. and 1A.M.)

title: Flower Power
description: Uncle Sam may soon sabotage St. Valentine's Day. The International Trade Commission is considering invoking sweeping penalties and duties on imported flowers, which could possibly double the cost of flowers sold on the streets of American cities. This is a nice example of the inane application of our trade regulations and of the idiotic system that could subjugate the interests of millions of consumers to the benefit of a few hundred farmers.

title: CONNORS SHOWS ENDURANCE IN VICTORY
description: His first clenched fist came after the 11th game of the third set, when he broke Scott Davis and was only one game from victory. The fire that Jimmy Connors has stoked for 16 years on the professional tour is slowly being reduced to embers, and even Connors understands it is best to conserve his energy now, saving it for the points that are getting increasingly more difficult to win.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: AN enigmatic portrait of a 1930's starlet by Man Ray, the Surrealist photographer, keeps you slightly on edge as you sit at the bar and sip an aperitif at Chelsea's hottest new bistro. Art Deco light fixtures and spindly wooden bar stools from vintage Paris Metro cars contribute to the period setting, where the focus is on ingenuous French bistro fare that is as warming as a thick pair of wool socks.

title: Value of College Rests on Plenty of Faith
description: To the Editor:

title: Falcons Add to Staff
description: Marion Campbell, hired on Tuesday for his second stint as head coach of the Atlanta Falcons, has hired a couple of former head coaches as assistants for his offensive unit. Rod Dowhower, former coach of the Indianapolis Colts and Jim Hanifan, a former coach of the St. Louis Cardinals, will join Campbell's staff. Dowhower will be the offensive coordinator and Hanifan will be the assistant head coach for offense. The Falcon defensive staff remained intact after Dan Henning was dismissed as head coach Dec. 22, but the offensive staff was let go.

title: TEXAS EASTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $71.9 million and preferred stock dividends of $15.4 million. c-Net loss and includes charges of about $68 million on the value of the company's petroleum services unit, costs associated with early retirement programs and a provision for pending divestitures of certain operations. d-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $106.7 million and preferred stock dividends of $20.8 million.

title: REAL ESTATE AGENCY, IN HONOR OF TENANTS, HELPS NEEDIEST
description: A gift of $2,412 from Mountbatten Equities, a real estate concern, was among those that have been made to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The donation was made ''in honor of the tenants of the Printing House,'' an apartment building at 421 Hudson Street in lower Manhattan.

title: U.S. RULES OUT WEAPONS ON PLANNED SPACE STATION
description: The Reagan Administration will rule out deploying major weapons systems on a proposed space station but will allow some Pentagon research to go forward, Government officials said today.

title: Sooner Sledder
description: When Mike Aljoe, a defensive end and special-teams player at Oklahoma, saw a television commercial in which a bobsled plowed through a huge wall of shaving cream, he was intrigued enough to call the United States Bobsled Federation and ask a few questions. Within five days of Oklahoma's victory in the Orange Bowl last month, Aljoe was encamped at Lake Placid, learning how to be the brakeman on a two-man sled with Randy Will, the American team's rookie of the year for 1985-86, and a pusher, in the third position, on a four-man sled with Will, Brian Wolf and Craig Durck.

title: A SEQUEL IS AUTHORIZED FOR 'GONE WITH THE WIND'
description: ''Gone With the Wind,'' one of the most popular novels and motion pictures of all time, is about to get a sequel. The estate of the author, Margaret Mitchell, has authorized it, the William Morris Agency has found someone to write the book, and when the motion picture or television mini-series based on the new book is written, the agency will handle the arrangements.

title: MARRIOTT CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: The share earnings reflect a 5-for-1 stock split in June 1986.

title: Tenneco Notes
description: The Tenneco Credit Company is offering $250 million of 8 3/8 percent notes due 1997 at 99 7/8 to yield 8.393 percent, or 1.2 percentage points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity, through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. Noncallable for seven years, the notes are rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB+ by S.&P.

title: Article 695687 -- No Title
description: The American Home Products Corporation has offered to pay $1.8 billion to $2.2 billion to acquire the A.H. Robins Company, sources familiar with the takeover proposal said yesterday.

title: SEARS CANADA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $11,745,000 gain on the sale of assets. Figures are in Canadian currency. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Woman, 25, Dies in Plunge
description: A 25-year-old woman from Manhattan, Katherine Alexander, daughter of Shana Alexander, the journalist and author, plunged to her death last night, apparently in a suicide. The body was found in a yard behind the apartment building on Park Avenue at 59th Street where she lived with her mother. According to a police spokesman, Officer Peter O'Donnell, Miss Alexander, who had been under psychiatric care, apparently jumped from an upper floor or the roof of the building.

title: Young Man in a Hurry
description: Wayne Gretzky scored his 50th goal of 1986-87 Wednesday night, in the 55th game of Edmonton's season. After only eight years in the N.H.L., Gretzky now claims four of the 10 earliest arrivals at the 50-goal plateau in league history.

title: Texas Eastern Gives President Added Post
description: The Texas Eastern Corporation announced that Dennis R. Hendrix, president and chief operating officer, would be named to the additional post of chief executive, effective June 1, 1987. Mr. Hendrix replaces I. David Bufkin, who will turn 65 in May. Mr. Bufkin will continue as chairman of the energy pipeline and production company, which is based in Houston.

title: GIRL WAS SEXUALLY ASSAULTED AT TWO CHILD CENTERS
description: A teen-age girl, brought into the New York City child-care system after she accused two members of her adoptive family of raping her, suffered sexual assaults at two children's centers and then was sent back to the home she had fled, law-enforcement sources say.

title: AVANT-GARDE EXTRAVAGANZAS ON THE LOWER EAST SIDE
description: THE Lower East Side has changed since the days when Lois Weaver and Peggy Shaw organized a theater festival sitting on the front steps of St. Mark's Church in the Bowery. ''We set up an office on the street and grabbed people as they went by,'' Ms. Weaver said. That was in 1980. Young performers were trying out new styles and material in basements, storefronts and loft spaces throughout the East Village.

title: MAYOR'S FIFTH-TERM BID SURPRISES LOS ANGELES
description: To many here, it came as a surprise several days ago when Mayor Tom Bradley, in an apparently prearranged exchange, announced his intention to seek a record fifth term in a guest appearance on the Joan Rivers show.

title: FIELDCREST CANNON reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax credit of $3.5 million from the completion of a restructuring. c-After a pre-tax charge of $7.8 million for the restructuring of sheet operations.

title: George W. Woodruff, Atlanta Philanthropist
description: George W. Woodruff, a director of the Coca-Cola Company for 49 years and a major contributor to education and medicine in Georgia, died of pneumonia Wednesday at Emory University Hospital. He was 91 years old.

title: CONCERT: NEW WORKS BY TEITLEBAUM
description: WE still think of electronic music as a brand-new art form, but by now there are composers who have made a life out of it. Richard Teitelbaum, who presented a most appealing concert Wednesday night at the Alternative Museum, 17 White Street, has been involved with electronics as a composer and performer for 20 years and counting.

title: U.S. PLEDGES AID TO SOUTH AFRICA'S NEIGHBORS
description: The senior American aid official today pledged $93 million in new aid to support joint efforts by southern African countries to reduce their economic dependence on South Africa.

title: STANDARD PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Piedmont Aviation Gains
description: Piedmont Aviation Inc. said its fourth-quarter earnings rose 9.1 percent, to $17.5 million, or 78 cents a share, from $16 million, or 89 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose 22.1 percent, to $509.8 million.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday BALINESE DANCE Midwinter Manhattan may seem a long way from the island of Bali, but this weekend the magic of this tropical paradise will be more than in the air. With opulent masks and exotic sounds, Islene Pinder's Balinese American Dance Theater will re-create a journey of demons and deities when the company performs ''Eden'' and ''Night Shadow'' at the Nikolais-Louis Choreospace. Also on the program will be two solo performances, ''Vision of Sound'' and ''Bird Jauk.'' Ms. Pinder's choreography combines the movement and tradition of Balinese and contemporary Western dance forms. Performances at the theater, at 33 East 18th Street, are at 8 tonight and tomorrow and at 3 P.M. on Sunday. Tickets are $8 or a Theater Development Fund voucher ($6 for students and the elderly). Reservations: 581-4136. HOMAGE AT CARNEGIE HALL

title: TRADING SURGE PUSHES THE DOW BEYOND 2,200
description: The Dow Jones industrial average broke another ''century'' mark yesterday, closing above 2,200 for the first time.

title: RTE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of about $5,000,000 related to restructuring.

title: GENERAL MOTORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a special provision related to the previously announced closings, scheduled for the 1987-89 period, of operations at 16 United States plants, and other restructurings, of $1,217,000,000 for the quarter and $1,288,000,000, or $2.20 a share, for the year. The special provision was partially offset by related specific tax benefits resulting in a net reduction in earnings of 92 cents a share in the latest year. c-The company said 1986 results reflected lower pension plan expenses from a change in the method of accounting, incresing quarter earnings by 20 cents a share, and year earnings by $330 million, or 96 cents a share. The company also reported the following on earnings for the year ended Dec.31, 1986. Income was helped by equity income of $1,184,000,000, primarily from the subsidiary General Motors Acceptance Corp., which posted record profits on vehicle financing. Earnings were favorably affected by improvements in operating performance and a net tax credit, which included the combined effect of a reduction in taxable earnings, the continuing amortization of tax credits in the United States, and tax benefits resulting from the restructuring of certain overseas operations. These favorable influences were offset by the costs of establishing reserves for plant closings, sales incentive programs, and the expenses associated with the development of new products and manufacturing systems.

title: 'Hypocrisy' or 'a Good Model to Follow'?
description: Following are excerpts from the House debate on pay increases:

title: Back To the Constitution
description: President Reagan's loss of authority since disclosure of his Iran policy has brought renewed talk that our constitutional system is not working. There must be something basically wrong, it is said, when three Presidents in 20 years win overwhelming election victories only, in time, to lose effective power.

title: A Number on Kemp
description: The Jack Kemp for President Exploratory Committee is backing a 1988 Presidential hopeful who is regarded by many Democrats and even some of his fellow Republicans as so conservative as to exemplify an earlier era in American political life. So when the committee announced the opening of its Arlington, Va., headquarters and the press phone number (247-1936) there, John Buckley, the Kemp press secretary, felt it necessary to add: ''There should be no historical inferences drawn from the final four digits of the press office's phone number.'' The candidate, in fact, was born in 1935 and played no known role in the overwhelming Democratic landslide of the following year.

title: Atom Technician Ends His Fast in Israeli Jail
description: Mordechai Vanunu, the jailed nuclear technician accused of passing Israeli nuclear secrets to The Sunday Times of London, ended a 33-day hunger strike today.

title: CHEMED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit reversal of $540,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $78,000 for the year; a gain of $27,371,000 on the sale of a business for both the quarter and year, and non- recurring charges of $9,302,000 and $9,013,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The year also includes capital gains of $1,804,000 and an extraordinary gain on termination of pension plan of $811,000. c-Includes tax credits of $223,000 and $798,000 for the quarter and year, respectively and a gain of $600,000 for the quarter and capital gains of $3,993,000 for the year.

title: TEMCO SERVICE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Amtrak Inquiry Takes a Turn
description: The National Transportation Safety Board said today that it had asked the authorities in Baltimore County, Md., to search a section of the Gunpowder River for a television set that might be related to the January collision between an Amtrak passenger train and a unit of Conrail engines. A spokesman said the safety board received a tip that a television set had been tossed into the river shortly after the accident.

title: SCIENTISTS VERIFY FOSSILS OF GIANT APE
description: Two American anthropologists say they have verified the existence of a potentially rich trove of fossil relics in the mountains of northern Vietnam, some of which may shed light on the origins of man and his close relatives.

title: GREATER ACCESS TO TERRORISM DATA IS SOUGHT FOR IMMIGRATION AGENCY
description: The Reagan Administration is preparing plans to identify and deport aliens with links to international terrorism who could support or plan violence inside the United States, according to Administration officials and documents.

title: GANNETT CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 split effective Jan.6, 1987.

title: Holocaust Council Chief
description: President Reagan is expected to name Harvey M. Meyerhoff, a Baltimore real estate developer and philanthropist, to succeed Elie Wiesel as chairman of the United States Holocaust Memorial Council. When he resigned the chairmanship in December, Mr. Wiesel said the project needed a leader who knows ''a lot more about management and architecture than I do.'' Preliminary architectural designs for the proposed Holocaust memorial on the Mall are expected to be submitted this spring to the Commission on Fine Arts and the National Capital Planning Board for esthetic and zoning clearance. The council has raised $40 million in cash and pledges for the project against a financing goal of $100 million.

title: GENERAL PUBLIC UTILITIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income from adoption of FASB 90 of $4,450,000, or 7 cents a share, for the quarter and $17.8 million, or 28 cents a share, for the year. c-Includes income from adoption of FASB 90 of $5,150,000, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter and $20.6 million, or 32 cents a share, for the year. General Public Utilities implemented FASB 90 in 1986. Its subsidiaries have restated their financial statements for prior fiscal years for their investments in Three Mile Island Unit 2 and the abandoned Forked River Nuclear Project, to reflect the present value of anticipated revenue to be received to recover those investments. General Public Utilities reported that FASB 90 implementation resulted in a reduction in its retained earnings of $160 million as of Dec.31, 1985.

title: The Tyranny of One-Handed Doctors
description: Webster's dictionary defines ''athlete'' as ''a person trained in exercises, games or contests requiring physical strength, skill, stamina, or speed.'' As both an athlete and a surgeon, I have long felt that surgeons, at least the great ones, possess all of the attributes of athletes.

title: RAIL A QUICK ROUTE TO DEFEAT
description: Track bias, the theory that the surface of a race track on any given day can help or hinder horses with a particular running style or who race along a particular path, is probably one of the sport's most exaggerated factors.

title: Officials Mourn Sala Burton
description: Sixty-three members of Congress and dozens of local dignitaries attended a memorial service today in the San Francisco City Hall rotunda for Sala Burton, the Democratic Congresswoman from California. House Speaker Jim Wright of Texas described Mrs. Burton, who died Sunday at the age of 61, as a ''sort of den mother'' for many Congressional families. Mrs. Burton was buried alongside her husband, Phillip, whose seat she filled in Congress. She was first elected in 1983 to complete her husband's term after his death. She was re-elected in 1984 and again last year.

title: LOS ANGELES POLICE IDENTIFY A SUICIDE AS KILLER OF 10 MEN
description: The Los Angeles Police said today that they had identified a man they believe killed 10 lone men, most of them homeless, in a series of slayings last year, and that the suspect shot himself to death last October.

title: A VALENTINE SHOW THAT SHOOTS ARROWS TIPPED WITH SATIRE
description: WHEN the Ballroom, a staid restaurant-cabaret in Chelsea, recently decided to present comedy as well as music on a regular basis, a brilliant, virtually unknown 18-member troupe of satirists calling themselves Artificial Intelligence stole the show at the club's opening-night marathon. Impersonating a film crew from the fictitious Beacon network and swarming through the club with video equipment, the troupe turned the Ballroom into a make-believe television studio, where it ''filmed'' (though no film was actually rolling) a 1967 variety show entitled ''Vicki's Valentine Thing.''

title: A Classic Battle Over Frontier Models
description: When Philippe de Villiers, Secretary of State for Culture in France's conservative Government, opened a new collection in the Invalides war museum in Paris this year, there was only one thing wrong.

title: RLI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $78,804 and $1,213,300 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes realized investment gains of $78,804 and $216,723 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: INDIANA GUARD SURVIVES ODDS
description: For Keith Smart, a 6-foot-1-inch starting point guard for Bobby Knight at Indiana, the sometimes withering experience of playing for one of basketball's more controversial coaches is nothing compared to what he had to overcome to get there.

title: GOODYEAR UNIT DRAWS INTEREST
description: The Exxon Corporation and the Shell Oil Company are among the companies seriously considering the acquisition of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company's Celeron energy subsidiary, Wall Street and oil industry sources said yesterday.

title: Benefit Performance For Juilliard Dancers
description: The 35th anniversary of the Juilliard Dance Ensemble will be celebrated with a benefit dinner and performance March 26 at 5 P.M. at the Juilliard Theater, 155 West 65th Street. The performance will feature works by noted dancers who were students or faculty members at the school, among them Paul Taylor, Jose Limon and Anthony Tudor. The evening is in honor of Martha Hill, the ensemble's founder and its director for 33 years.

title: PROVIDENT LIFE & ACCIDENT INURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After capital gains of $41,647,000 for the quarter and $66,361,000 for the year. c-After capital gains of $7,884,000 for the quarter and $16,800,000 for the year.

title: CAREERCOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INNOVEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SUIT ALLEGES AMNESTY LAW PUTS MANY ALIENS IN LIMBO
description: Adalberto Garza has lived in the United States illegally since 1975, working for most of the time as a machinist in the Houston area. He is one of an estimated 3.9 million illegal aliens who could be eligible to apply for legal status under the amnesty provisions of the nation's new immigration law.

title: WEDTECH CASE EMBROILS ACCOUNTANTS

The Marshes of Mesopotamia
description: The fog of battle still swirls over the marshes around Basra. Iraq, loaded with weapons and usually loath to commit infantry, seems unable to dislodge the Iranians completely from the outskirts of Basra, its second largest city. If Iraq's counterattacks fail, Iran may yet gain an advantage that threatens America's objective in the war, peace through stalemate. Saudi Arabia, the gulf states, Turkey, even the Soviet Union all stand to lose by an Iranian victory.

PATENTS;

description: LEAD: Improvements to his method of inserting medication through the skin were patented this week by Don Sibalis, president of Drug Delivery Systems Inc. of New York. Patent No. 4,640,689 provides electrodes for the applicator trademarked Powerpatch and adhesive means for passage of an electric current though the skin.

title: FROM ITALY, QUALITY AT A MODERATE PRICE
description: Italian clothes are favored by many American women because the fabrics and workmanship are reliable and the styling is realistic. Max Mara's sportswear fits these qualifications, but it has another asset: moderate prices. An alpaca jacket to sell for $240, a mohair and wool coat for $400 and a cashmere coat for less than $700 are some of the styles in luxury fabrics presented at Nell's, the downtown club in New York, to introduce its fall and winter collection.

title: MAKING LIFE EASIER FOR DEBTOR NATIONS
description: LEAD: With all the attention given the world debt crisis, we are no closer to a solution today than yesterday. Debtor countries that must allocate scarce resources and export earnings for debt service cannot generate new capital investments. This leads to a decline in standards of living, political and economical instability, drug trafficking, illegal emigration, escalating insurgency and increased capital flight.

title: THE HOMELESS BECOME AN ISSUE
description: A new issue has captured the attention of Congress, one that has been around a long time. It is that of the homeless, the ''street people'' who can be seen huddled on steam grates and in doorways in just about every major city in the country.

THE VICTORIANS RECONSIDERED
description: LEAD: Despite the undoubted antiquity of the British monarchy, many of its so-called traditional aspects are in fact no older than the Statue of Liberty. Its broadly based popular appeal, its position above the battle of politics and its incomparably splendid ceremonial - all of which were so much in evidence at last year's Royal Wedding - only date back in their present form to the Golden Jubilee of Queen Victoria, celebrated 100 years ago in 1887.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Invited to spring training Rick Ownbey, Jack O'Connor and Jeff Ballard, pitchers; Dave Van Gorder, Jeff Tackett, Donnie Scott, catchers; Craig Worthington, Pete Stanicek, infielders; and Nelson Simmons and Mike Hart, outfielders. CLEVELAND (AL) - Signed Rick Dempsey, catcher, to a one-year contract. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Signed R. J. Reynolds, outfielder, to a one-year contract. Invited to spring training Moices Alou, outfielder, and Lee Tunnell, pitcher. COLLEGE APPALACHIAN STATE - Dismissed Greg Dolan, center, from the basketball team for failing to follow policies and procedures of the basketball program. CLARION - Announced the retirement of Al Jacks and Charles Ruslavage, assistant football coaches. Named Tim Karrs offensive coordinator and Tim Laurito defensive-backs coach, Hal Hansen golf coach and Tammy Stritenberger softball coach. GLENVILLE STATE - Named Lou Nocida head football coach. LOCK HAVEN - Named Tom Jones, former offensive coordinator at Middle Tennessee, head football coach and Dennis Therrell to the coaching staff. MCNEESE STATE - Announced that Glen Duhon, head basketball coach, and his staff will not return next season. SOUTHLAND CONFERENCE -Placed McNeese State's men's basketball program on two-years' probation, reduced the number of scholarships available through the 1989 season from 13 to 11, barred all members of the current coaching staff from recruiting for two years and ordered the university to forfeit revenues for this season and next season. FOOTBALL ATLANTA (NFC) - Named Jimmy Raye wide-receiver coach and Steve Crosby running-back coach. CINCINNATI BENGALS - Signed Tom Ehrhardt, quarterback, who was cut by the Jets after signing as a free agent from Rhode Island last summer. HOCKEY NATIONAL HOCKEY LEAGUE - Assessed fines totaling $18,400 to the Flyers and Devils for a of postgame fight Jan. 24. PITTSBURGH (NHL) - Recalled Warren Young, left wing, and Roberto Romano, goaltender, from Baltimore of the American Hockey League. Traded Romano to the Boston Bruins for Pat Riggin, goalie. Sent Steve Guenette, goalie, to Baltimore.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-5, 28 Senator Nunn warned the President that the Administration would provoke a ''constitutional crisis'' if it adopted a broad intepretation of the ABM treaty of 1972 without extensive consultation with Congress. Page 1 The Kremlin wants to negotiate and to press ahead with arms control talks but is uncertain of President Reagan's political strength, according to former American officials who spoke to Mikhail S. Gorbachev. 1 A year after Haiti's dictator fled, demonstrations, strikes and lynchings have become commonplace, unemployment has increased and violent crime has soared. But people are free to speak their minds. 1 Military analysis: An Iraqi success against Iranian forces on the outskirts of Basra appears to have given Iraq the upper hand in the six-week-old battle, according to American military specialists. 3 Gerald F. Seib arrived in Zurich after his release from Iran and said he was ''thrilled and thankful'' to be free. The American journalist was seized in Iran last weekend and later accused of espionage. 3 Soviet influence in the Persian Gulf region and throughout the Middle East appears to be increasing, partly as the result of growing strains between the United States and the Arab world. 3 Terry Waite may be freed next week although he is now in captivity, the Lebanese magazine that first reported American arms sales to Iran said in the latest unconfirmed report on the Anglican emissary's fate. 28 The Philippine cease-fire will end tomorrow, and Communist peace negotiators are going into hiding, including 50 rebels who have received safe-conduct passes for the duration of the two-month truce. 4 A feud over a French art collection has unfolded, as the Mayor of Lille has taken on the Government over where a collection of scale models of frontier cities should be displayed. 4 A secret State Department contract of $276,186 was awarded last year to a public relations company that reportedly worked with Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North to rally support for military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels. 5 Two Soviet failures in space were reported by American experts who said the rocket and satellite failures occurred a week before the successful launching of astronauts to the Soviet Union's Mir space station. 8 NATIONAL 6-8, 50 Rules for employers of farm workers must be issued by the Labor Department to require that toilets, drinking water and other sanitation facilities be provided, according to a Federal appeals court ruling. 1 No increase in racial violence has occurred in the United States, according to William Bradford Reynolds, the head of the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division. His speech infuriated civil rights leaders. 1 The unemployment rate stayed pat at 6.6 percent last month, as the new jobs created by the economy were balanced out by more people seeking work, the Labor Department reported. 7 Evacuation plans at nuclear plants were the subject of a proposal submitted to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission by its staff. It warned that state and local cooperation is crucial to make the plans work. 50 The Chernobyl nuclear accident produced no reason to bolster controls over American reactors, a special study group of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission concluded. 50 Anti-smoking rules went into effect in Federal Government buildings, prompting groans in some corners and cheers in others. The new official Government policy prohibits smoking in all but designated areas. 30 Six children held by two men in what was apparently a satanic cult are the focus of an inquiry, spanning several states, that seeks to identify them. The children were found Thursday in a park in Tallahassee, Fla. 6 A lawsuit says the immigration law puts many illegal aliens in jeopardy because, as one immigration lawyer explained, some employers are ''going overboard and laying off people who have been with them for years.'' 6 Stemming Chicago air traffic errors is the goal of new recommendations issued by the National Transportation Safety Board, which said it was not satisfied with Federal Aviation Administration measures. 7 Man in the News: Dennis R. Patrick, President Reagan's choice to become chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, has opinions that are in synch with those of his predecessor, Mark S. Fowler. 50 A move to make the W-4 form easier for people to fill out was promised by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue. The I.R.S. may issue a new set of instructions and worksheet, he said. 33 A man starved himself to death in Grand Junction, Colo., 16 days after a judge granted him the right to die. The man, Hector Rodas, was a quadriplegic who could not speak or move. 6 Atlanta meets its past 6 WASHINGTON TALK 8 The homeless become an issue REGIONAL 29-32 New York anti-smoking rules were adopted unanimously by the State Public Health Council. The regulations would prohibit smoking in most indoor areas and restrict it on the job and in most restaurants. 1 Opening the 63d Street tunnel and three new subway stations by October 1989 are part of a plan approved by the Transportation Authority, which hopes to greatly improve service on the Queens Boulevard line. 1 An abused girl with an I.Q. of 70 was described by prosecutors as ''innocent, vulnerable and easily victimized.'' The 13-year-old was raped in her adoptive parents' home and sexually abused in two city facilities. 29 A Federal agent was shot in the jaw during a raid in the Bronx that the authorities said grew out of an investigation of a multimillion-dollar cocaine distribution ring. The agent was in satisfactory condition. 29 Wedtech executives kept records, including copies of receipts and bills for vacations, for thousands of dollars in bribes paid to Bronx Borough President Stanley Simon, law-enforcement officials said. 29 New York's savings banks are back, thanks to lower interest rates, balance-sheet restructuring, diversification and a removal of usury ceilings. In the early 1980's, regulators thought the industry might crumble. 33 Unemployment in city worsens 7 Eight die in house fires 30 Whitehead's parenting reviewed 30 Postal workers in drug case 31 NEEDIEST CASES 32

title: MCNEESE DECISION
description: The McNeese basketball coach, Glen Duhon, and his staff will not return next season, and the college in Lake Charles, La., will not appeal any of the penalties against its program, according to Ted Brevell, the athletic director. ''Coach Duhon indicated in October that he would not seek a renewal of his contract. My recommendation, and I feel the university's position, will be not to renew any of the present staff's contracts for 1987-88,'' he said. His prepared statement was made public yesterday after the Southland Conference commissioner, Dick Oliver, announced penalties against the McNeese program and all current coaches. Those include two years' probation, loss of all conference basketball revenues for this season and next season, and loss of two of 13 basketball scholarships for the next two years. Brevell said the school channeled money to student athletes through representatives of the university's athletics interests and let a student play basketball while taking less than a full-time course schedule.

title: DEMPSEY JOINS INDIANS
description: Rick Dempsey, who established himself behind the plate in 10 years with the Baltimore Orioles, signed a one-year contract with the Cleveland Indians yesterday and will now have to compete for the No. 1 catching job with Chris Bando and Andy Allanson. The 37-year-old Dempsey earned $442,000 last year with Baltimore, but the Orioles refused to pick up his 1987 option for $600,000. His contract with Cleveland calls for a $400,000 salary, $275,000 of which is guaranteed, with an option year at $550,000. Since Dempsey is a Type A free agent, the Indians will have to relinquish their No. 1 pick in the June draft to Baltimore as compensation. The choice will be the 15th pick over all in the draft. Dempsey hit a career-high 13 home runs in 1986, 10 more than hit by Allanson and Bando combined. In 122 games last year, he batted .208 with 29 r.b.i. During his career he has averaged .238. . . . R. J. Reynolds signed a one-year contract yesterday with the Pittsburgh Pirates. Reynolds, a 26-year-old switch-hitting outfielder, batted .269 last season in 118 games with 9 home runs and 48 runs batted in.

title: CELLTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Langer, Couples Even at Halfway Point: In Honolulu, Bernhard Langer left his driver in the bag on the way to an eight-under-par 64 that lifted him into a tie with Fred Couples for the lead yesterday after the second round of the Hawaiian Open. ''I carried it around just to show off,'' said the West German star, who completed two rounds over the Waialae Country Club course in 134, 10 under par. Langer said he used a 3-wood off most tees because ''I'm hitting it pretty good and I just wanted to keep it in play.'' The strategy helped produce the best round of the tournament, a bogey-free effort that included one string of four consecutive birdies. He was tied with Couples, who shot a 65 while playing in the same threesome as Langer. (AP) Lopez Rallies to Tie: Nancy Lopez shot a six-under-par 66 yesterday to make up a six-stroke deficit and tie Chris Johnson at five-under 139 for the lead after two rounds in the Sarasota Classic in Florida. The seven-birdie round was the best of the two-week-old Ladies Professional Golf Association season for Lopez, who missed most of the 1986 tour to have a baby. She has 34 victories in 10 seasons as a professional and needs one more victory to qualify for the tour's Hall of Fame. Johnson, the first-round leader Thursday after shooting 67 on the 6,124-yard course at Bent Tree Country Club, retained a share of the lead with a 72 yesterday that featured two birdies and two bogeys. Jane Geddes and Kathy Baker, who shot 66 and 68, respectively, trailed by one shot. (AP) N.H.L. Red Wings 6, North Stars 4: In Detroit, Gerard Gallant scored two power-play goals and Steve Yzerman added a goal and three assists last night for the Red Wings. Detroit trails the North Stars by 1 point in the race for the Norris Division lead, with the teams set for a rematch tonight in Bloomington, Minn. Gallant scored his first goal at 14:16 of the second period, converting Brent Ashton's centering pass for his 26th goal of the season to tie at 2-2. Gallant added his second goal, the game-winner, midway through the final period, backhanding a rebound past Kari Takko, Minnesota's goalie, to stretch the Red Wings' lead to 5-3. (AP) Whalers 5, Capitals 2: Sylvain Turgeon scored two goals in 2 minutes 49 seconds in the third period to spark Hartford. John Anderson also scored twice, including an empty-net goal with 1:02 left, as the Whalers moved past Montreal into first place in the Adams Division. The Capitals, playing at home in Landover, Md., wasted a chance to break a third-place tie with the Rangers in the Patrick Division. Turgeon's first goal came on a slap shot from the left point at 2:34 of the third period, which deflected off Greg Smith, a Washington defenseman, and past Bob Mason. Turgeon scored again at 5:23, putting a rebound past Mason after first deflecting a shot by Stewart Gavin. Mason was then replaced in the net by Pete Peeters after that goal, which gave Hartford a 4-1 lead. (AP) Jets 6, Kings 1: In Winnipeg, Paul MacLean had a goal and two assists for the Jets. MacLean assisted on goals by Doug Smail and Dale Hawerchuk to help the Jets pile up a 4-0 lead after two periods, then scored in the third as Winnipeg completed the rout. The game's strangest goal came at 9:31 of the second period. With the teams playing with four men each, Dave Ellett, a Winnipeg defenseman, circled behind the Los Angeles net and threw a pass into the slot. Steve Duchesne, a Los Angeles defenseman, corralled the puck on his stick, then rifled it into his net past his startled goaltender, Roland Melanson. The Jets got other goals from Ray Neufeld and Jim Nill, who scored on a spectacular third-period breakaway. Duchesne was still shaking his head in the locker room after putting the puck into the wrong net. ''That's the worst one there is,'' he said, slumping in his dressing room stall. ''I tried to put the puck in the corner, but I missed. It's my fault.'' (AP) M.I.S.L. Comets 8, Express 5: Dale Mitchell scored four goals to lead Kansas City to victory over the New York Express last night in Kansas City, Mo. Mitchell, 10th in the league in scoring with 28 goals and nine assists, scored once in every quarter. New York (2-21) got goals from Ricky Davis and Pesa in the second half. The Express have lost eight straight. (AP)

title: Baryshnikov Joins Series on Gershwins
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov has joined the roster of noted singers, dancers and actors participating in the opening performance on March 11 at 7 P.M. of a monthlong series at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, devoted to the music of George and Ira Gershwin. Mr. Baryshnikov will dance in three new works choreographed by Dan Siretta to the Gershwin songs ''Nocturne for Lily Pons,'' ''Short Story'' and ''Promenade.''

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS

Tom Erhardt, the free-agent quarterback from the University of Rhode Island who failed in a tryout with the Jets last summer, has been signed by the Cincinnati Bengals. . . . The Pittsburgh Penguins said yesterday that they have traded Roberto Romano to the Boston Bruins for another goaltender, Pat Riggin, and that Riggin would join the team in time for the game tonight in Pittsburgh against the Chicago Blackhawks.

description: Pizza Inn Inc. said that it had received an unsolicited takeover offer from Concept Development Inc. for a combination of stock and cash valued at $13.85 a share, or a total of about $45 million. Under the proposal, Concept Development, a St. Louis-based operator of 125 Panterra's pizza restaurants, would offer Pizza Inn shareholders $3 a share and 1.4 shares in Concept Development stock for each Pizza Inn share. Concept Development, which is traded over the counter, closed at $7.75 a share yesterday, up 25 cents.

title: MATCHUP TEST FOR NAVY
description: David Robinson, Navy's spectacular 7-foot-1-inch center, faces what may be his stiffest test of the season when the Middies play Miami in Baltimore Arena today. For the first time, Robinson will be facing someone his own size in Tito Horford, a 7-1 native of the Dominican Republic who is still learning the game. ''It will be like the teacher against the student,'' Coach Bill Foster of Miami said. ''Robinson is a senior, and Tito is a rookie. But I know Tito is looking forward to it as a challenge.'' Robinson, widely acclaimed as the likely No. 1 choice in the next National Basketball Association draft, has dominated the opposition so far this season while carrying Navy to a 16-5 record. Robinson has averaged 29.1 points and 12.1 rebounds a game, high among the national leaders, and is No. 1 with 99 blocked shots. Miami, in the second year of a program that was abandoned in 1971 and revived in 1985, has an 11-10 record. Since Horford became eligible on Dec. 20, the Hurricanes are 10-6. Horford is averaging 14 points and 8.9 rebounds.

title: A Surplus of Economic White Lies
description: There won't be a special meeting of finance ministers this weekend to do something about the dollar because of ''scheduling problems.'' That news comes from an anonymous ''monetary source.'' When finance ministers agree that they need to meet, they meet. When they disagree, they find ''scheduling problems.''

title: Hamill Quits as Editor Of Mexico City Paper
description: Pete Hamill, the American journalist, has resigned as editor of Mexico's only English-language newspaper, a post he took less than three months ago, after a dispute with the newspaper's publisher over what Mr. Hamill said was an effort to make the coverage biased.

title: OPERA: MALFITANO AT MET IN MASSENET'S 'MANON'
description: Any lingering doubts that the Metropolitan Opera has become a director's house should be dispelled by the staging of ''Manon'' that made its debut last evening. Jean-Pierre Ponnelle, who produced and designed this production, has so encrusted Massenet's pathetic love story with stylistic sequins and painterly images that poor Manon emerges as hardly more than one more theatrical prop in the service of a directorial star-turn.

title: STATE DEPT. SAID TO PAY $276,186 TO PUBLICITY CONCERN FOR CONTRAS
description: The State Department awarded a secret contract for $276,186 last year to a public relations company that reportedly worked with Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North to rally support for military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: MURDOCH ADVANCES BID IN AUSTRALIA
description: Rupert Murdoch was set to clinch the takeover of Australia's largest media group, the Herald and Weekly Times Ltd., for $1.54 billion (American) after a rival bidder, John Fairfax Ltd. agreed to step aside. Fairfax, a leading newspaper publisher based in Sydney, will not go ahead with a proposed $2.5 billion, or $1.67 billion (American), bid for the group, the Herald and Weekly Times chairman, John Dahlsen, announced after a long board meeting. Mr. Murdoch's earlier bid was lower at $2.3 billion (Australian).

title: The Union Was Founded on Slave Compromises; Jefferson and Race War
description: To the Editor:

title: American Ballet Theater
description: American Ballet Theater has announced the promotions of Cheryl Yeager, Amanda McKerrow and Johan Renvall to the rank of principal dancer. Miss Yeager, from Washington, joined the company in 1976. Miss McKerrow, born in Albuquerque, N.M., is a former member of the Washington Ballet and the winner of the gold medal at the Moscow International Ballet Competition in 1981. She joined Ballet Theater in 1982. Mr. Renvall, from Stockholm, performed with the Royal Swedish Ballet before joining Ballet Theater in 1978. He received the silver medal at the Varna International Ballet Competition, also in 1978.

SEPTIEN TRIAL SET
description: A trial date of March 30 on charges of sexually assaulting a 10-year-old girl was set yesterday for Rafael Septien, the place-kicker and leading career scorer for the Dallas Cowboys. State District Judge Sam Houston set the date at a hearing in Denton, Tex. The 33-year-old kicker was indicted Jan. 22 on charges of abusing the daughter of a friend.

title: Disquieting Times for New York Architects
description: LEAD: These are disquieting times for architects in New York. The curious, conflicted historicism of much of our new work, our confused search for validation in publicity and chic, our exceptional readiness to promote and decorate projects that by ordinary standards should not be built at all - these seem signs of a pervasive trouble.

title: JOBLESS RATE STABLE AT 6.6% BUT MORE JOBS ARE CREATED
description: The economy continued to create jobs rapidly last month, but the number of people seeking work also rose, leaving the unemployment rate unchanged at 6.6 percent, the Labor Department reported today.

title: RIVER SEARCH ENDS IN INQUIRY
description: Divers ended a two-day search for a television set that an anonymous caller told investigators was thrown into a river shortly after an Amtrak train collided with a Conrail locomotive near here Jan. 4, killing 16 people and injuring 175. An investigator said the contention that two Conrail crewmen were watching a pro football game in the locomotive cab when the accident occurred was ''highly speculative.''

There were former students, too, both in the audience and on the stage.

description: Prices of Treasury coupon issues declined yesterday, but discount rates on bills rose as the demand for Federal funds remained strong. The rise in bill rates was linked to traders' nervousness about the continued high rates for these funds that banks lend each other overnight.

description: A record number of people were employed in New York State in January and the unemployment rate in New Jersey was the lowest since 1970, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is meeting increased resistance in its far-reaching investigation of Wall Street's takeover business, with many witnesses now invoking the Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination and refusing to make deals for clemency.

description: Shares of the Diamond Shamrock Corporation edged up 12.5 cents, to $14.825, in New York Stock Exchange trading today after two top executives met analysts. Diamond is the object of a $15-a-share, all-cash takeover bid from an investor group led by T. Boone Pickens.

title: COLLECTION AGENCIES AND RIGHTS
description: RACHELLE CAGNER opened her mail last Sept. 26 and found a letter from the Corporate Accounting Office of the Disbursement Center. In exchange for ''confirmation'' of her Social Security number, date of birth, telephone number and address, the letter said the office would forward ''a check'' for ''funds on deposit'' in her name.

title: LEBANESE SHIITES ATTACK ISRAELIS
description: Dozens of Lebanese Shiite guerrillas began a major attack in southern Lebanon today and fought pitched battles with Israeli soldiers and their Lebanese Christian allies.

title: Alvin Ailey Wins $25,000 Scripps Award
description: Alvin Ailey is receive the 1987 Samuel H. Scripps American Dance Festival Award on June 7 at the American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C. Given for lifetime contributions to American modern dance, the $25,000 award is the largest annual prize offered in the performing arts.

title: Service Is Held for Liberace; Body Is Examined for AIDS
description: Hundreds of people mourned Liberace at a memorial service today while a coroner, questioning the pianist's reported cause of death, examined his body for signs of AIDS.

title: DUVALIER'S LIFE OF LEISURE
description: A year after his flight into exile, Jean-Claude Duvalier is living at ease on the French Riviera with no indication that he plans to leave anytime soon.

Yamani Looks to Swiss
description: The former Saudi Arabian oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, has applied for a permit to reside in the Swiss mountain resort of Crans-Montana, a Justice Ministry spokesman told Reuters today.

title: THE DANCE: CITY BALLET IN NEW WORK BY MEJIA
description: ''Sinfonia Mistica,'' a strange ballet by Paul Mejia set to music by Andrezej Panufnik, is one of those works that are more interesting for their ideas than their realization and yet manage to hold one's interest.

title: OPTIMISTIC BEARS
description: Medical reports issued to the Chicago Bears are guardedly optimistic about rehabilitation progress being made by two former starters - Jim McMahon and Leslie Frazier - who are recovering from surgery and hope to play next season. McMahon, the quarterback who underwent an operation on his right shoulder Dec. 12, has made excellent progress, according to Dr. Frank Jobe, who performed the surgery to trim McMahon's right rotator cuff and reconstruct the front of his shoulder. ''All of his muscles are functioning and he is now ready to begin a more vigorous rehabilitation program,'' Jobe said. Frazier, who underwent reconstructive surgery on his left knee a year ago, ran wind sprints for the first time this week.

title: SUN STATES SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CULT LINK SEEN IN CASE OF UNIDENTIFIED CHILDREN
description: The authorities in several states today sought to identify six children who the police said were apparently taken from their parents by two Washington, D.C., men and enlisted in what some have described as a bizarre cult of devil worshipers.

title: Staten Island's War Over Wetlands
description: Staten Islanders can be divided into two groups. Call one group the pioneers, people who cherish the rural character of New York City's last frontier. Call the others the settlers, who build housing and push suburbanization. By misusing a wetlands law, the state Department of Environmental Conservation is pleasing pioneers at settlers' expense.

title: TRYOUT FOR CARLTON
description: Steve Carlton, who built his career totals to 323 victories and 229 losses while pitching for the Philadelphia Phillies, the San Francisco Giants and the Chicago White Sox last season, is still interested in at least one more major league season. Carlton, a 42-year-old left-hander, has been in touch, through his agent, Peter Funsten, with the Cincinnati Reds, who said they were willing to give him a tryout, but don't seem to share Carlton's optimism about his pitching prowess. ''I wouldn't count on what he's got left,'' said Sheldon Bender, the Reds' vice president for player personnel. ''He's counting on his pitching knowledge to get by. I can't feel that we have any interest in him.'' Bill Bergesch, the Reds' general manager, is similarly dubious about Carlton, who had a combined 9-14 won-lost record and a 5.10 earned run average last season.

IN SEARCH OF GOOD CHICKEN SOUP
description: There is little doubt that chicken soup is good for colds - never mind why. But with few parents home to make it, not to mention the millions of people who don't live within chicken-soup-delivering distance, those who take to their beds with chills, fever, sniffles and sore throats often turn to their local chicken-soup makers: the corner delicatessen.

title: QUEENSBORO BRIDGE PLAN TO ADD TO TRAFFIC WOES
description: Congestion on the Queensboro Bridge - already expected to increase as drivers seek to avoid today's toll increase at other East River crossings -will be even more seriously compounded after Feb. 18. On that Wednesday, the city and the state are to begin a reconstruction of half of the bridge's upper roadway that is expected to last at least two years, a city transportation official said yesterday.

title: NEW YORK ADOPTS WIDE RESTRICTIONS ON PUBLIC SMOKING
description: The New York State Public Health Council unanimously adopted regulations yesterday that would prohibit smoking as of May 7 in most public indoor areas in New York and restrict it on the job and in most restaurants.

Canada Jobless Rate Up
description: Canada's unemployment rate rose to 9.7 percent in January after holding steady at 9.4 percent for the previous three months, Statistics Canada said today. But the Government agency said the rise, adjusted for seasonal variations, was largely the result of a strong increase in the labor force rather than a loss of jobs.

title: Foli Out as Manager
description: Tim Foli, the manager of the Puerto Rican team in the Caribbean Baseball Series, was dismissed yesterday after a clash with Felix Millan, the general manager, over the way the club has been playing. ''He was disrespectful to me and it is not the first time this has happened,'' Millan said. Foli was not available for comment after Millan announced the dismissal.

title: SOVIET HEIGHTENS PERSIAN GULF ROLE
description: The Soviet Union, buoyed by growing strains between the United States and the Arab world that have included the uproar over American arms shipments to Iran, has been moving to increase its influence in the Persian Gulf region and throughout the Middle East.

title: BUYOUTS: LOOK BEFORE LEAPING
description: WHEN Donald G. Stauffer, a division manager, received an early retirement buyout offer from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, he decided to accept. ''It wasn't an easy decision for me, because I'm not an independently wealthy person,'' he said. ''But it was just the right time to do it.''

title: Consumers Rein In Debt
description: Americans borrowed $105 million more than they paid off in December, the smallest increase in consumer credit in five years, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The slowdown was attributed to changing borrowing patterns brought on by the new tax law.

title: OPERA: 'CLEMENZA DI TITO'
description: Cast changes at the Metropolitan Opera are not always happy events, but with a substantially new set of singers Wednesday night, Mozart's ''Clemenza di Tito'' thrived.

description: A gift of $500 to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has been received from the partners of the Manhattan law firm of Reid & Priest. Employees of the firm also made a gift totaling $150.

title: GALAXY CARPET MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
IN QUOTES
description: ''When will we see a real correction? Only when the perception of the market changes.'' - Monte Gordon, research director, Dreyfus Corporation, on the surging Dow.

title: Abigail Lounsbery to Marry in August
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. DeWitt Lounsbery Jr. of Rye, N.Y., of the engagement of her daughter, Abigail Lounsbery, to William Rushing Hemphill Jr., the son of Mrs. Hemphill of Austin, Tex., and the late Mr. Hemphill. An August wedding is planned.

title: A New Version Of Events at Howard Beach
description: Prosecutors, saying the scope of their investigation had widened, may have moved closer last week to securing new and more serious indictments in the death of Michael Griffith, a black man who was fatally struck by a car after being chased and beaten by a gang of white youths in Howard Beach, Queens.

title: Incident in the Park
description: MY FIRST memory was walking down the hill in a daze, my shirt torn and my face sticky with blood. I thought it was odd to be walking, because I had a bike. But I didn't have it now, although I had no idea why not. I blundered down the road, the Central Park cyclists whizzing by me, and came upon a patrol car parked in an access road 50 feet away. I tried to report the incident but could come up with only a few fuzzy details, besides the obvious loss of my bike. I had a concussion and a broken nose, two dislodged teeth and a couple of black eyes that would show their true colors the next day. I spent that night in the emergency ward of St. Luke's hos-pital and the next day going to doctors.

title: U.S. AIDES EXPECT DELAY OF DECISION OVER ABM TREATY
description: The Reagan Administration, under intense pressure from Congress and Western allies, is likely to defer temporarily a decision on whether to adopt a view of the Antiballistic Missile Treaty that would allow extensive testing of some new types of ''Star Wars'' systems, Administration officials said today.

title: Dance
description: Feel in the mood for dancing on chairs and mattresses? Curious about a danced history of the American film? Want to know what happens when someone trips the light fantastic in electronically amplified tap shoes? It's going to be a lively week at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater. Steve Krieckhaus, a Missouri-born choreographer who now lives in Philadelphia, is offering a program called ''Missouri Driver's License'' on Monday and Tuesday. An exuberant dancer, Mr. Krieckhaus has been known to bounce against walls and to dance on furniture in solos about encountering the unexpected in ordinary life.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
BEHIND THE STATE SENATE'S REJECTION OF A LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR
description: LEAD: SOME observers have attributed the State Senate's recent defeat of two proposed constitutional amendments creating the office of lieutenant governor to partisan political objectives on the part of Senate Democrats.

title: Our Friends Shake Their Heads
description: To the Editor:

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Washington, N.C.; A Dilapidated Heritage
description: THREE years ago, the Eastern North Carolina Chamber of Commerce initiated an awareness campaign to persuade tobacco-country landowners to raze and remove the ramshackle sharecropper shacks and flue-curing barns that have been rendered obsolete by new and more efficent methods of curing the leaf.

title: A SQUEEZE AT COMMUNITY COLLEGES
description: IN Farmington, community-college courses are held not only in junior and senior high schools, but also even occasionally in the conference room of a nearby hotel.

title: Carolyn Marano Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Marano of Newark of the engagement of their daughter Carolyn Joy Marano to Edward Patrick Benigno, a son of Marie Cutrafello of Mount Kisco, N.Y., and Quido Benigno of Yonkers. Miss Marano, a graduate of Montclair State College, attends the New York Law School. Her fiance graduated from Pace University.

title: ACTORS COMMEND LOCAL WORKSHOP
description: TAKE it from the Mount Vernon actors Crist Swann and Steve Fowler. Once you have fallen under the influence of Tina Sattin, a self-described acting coach, you are bound to become her disciple.

title: PLAN ON ELECTRIC CABLE IS OPPOSED
description: THE New York Power Authority's plan to put part of a 26.6-mile cable under the county to provide Long Island with cheaper electricity may meet stiff opposition from two local communities.

title: IN RAIN, SLEET AND SNOW, THE WEATHERMAN THRIVES
description: A PENETRATING, bone-chilling wind was blowing as Mel Goldstein got into his car at 3:45 one recent morning to drive to work over snow-covered roads. Given the hour and the weather, it seemed like a depressing way to start a day.

title: PERSONAL FINANCE
description: THE Administration made a big deal out of eliminating tax loopholes with the Tax Reform Act of 1986, but nonetheless the new law, which it pushed for so hard, left a few loopholes - or tax incentives, as proponents prefer to call them.

title: A REPORTER'S ODYSSEY IN UNSEEN CHINA
description: TIRED AND DUSTY AFTER A DAY'S driving from the north, three men on a Yangtze River motorcycle pulled into the courtyard of the inn at Guanduping, a village in China's heartland province of Shaanxi. They stowed their helmets in the cycle's sidecar and moved toward a group of villagers seated at tables of hand-hewn slate.

title: INQUIRY SPREADS ON 6 CHILDREN AND CULT
description: Police officials here said today that six disheveled children found in Tallahassee, Fla., might be the offspring of members of a little-known cult, but the officials said they had not ruled out the possibility of kidnapping.

title: SEOUL POLICE CLASH WITH DEMONSTRATORS
description: Despite a Government effort to block them, thousands of demonstrators gathered here Saturday to mourn the death by torture of a 21-year-old student three weeks ago.

title: The New C.E.O.
description: To the Editor: ''Remaking the American C.E.O.'' (Jan. 25) is an unwarranted, unfair and simplistic attack on an entire class of mostly patriotic and hard-working American men and women.

title: MISSILE MUSEUM ATTRACTS THOUSANDS TO ARIZONA SITE
description: Since the Titan Missile Museum opened its doors here last May, more than 19,000 people have donned hard hats to venture into its subterranean world.

title: BANK ASSOCIATIONS TO DISCUSS MERGING
description: ONE of the last differences separating commercial banks and savings institutions in the state could disappear this year, if merger talks starting between the trade associations representing the two business groups are successful.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: CONNECTICUT DOG RACES

title: A SHELTER FOR ABUSED BOYS IS FOCUS OF ZONING DISPUTE
description: LEAD: AN 80-year-old yellow brick building on Ruland Road in Huntington Town, the home of Melville House, has been a refuge for the last 17 years to hundreds of abused teen-age boys.

title: MARIANNE MOORE IN POEM AND OBJECT
description: The objects that inspired Marianne Moore were startlingly diverse: a picture of an Egyptian desert rat, a Kiwi shoe-polish can, a magazine advertisement for Missouri hogs, a mechanical crow, a swatch of emerald-green brocade.

title: THE IMPACT AND INFLUENCE OF JOHN CAGE
description: Approaching his 75th birthday - the date is Sept. 5 -John Cage looms among us, twinkling, patriarchal, inspiring and annoying in all the right ways. It seems almost certain that Mr. Cage's place in musical history will be a significant one. It was he who fathered a whole generation (or two or three) of experimental composers in this country and the world, and who did more than anyone else to introduce the contemplative aura of Oriental religion and philosophy into the highly individuated, careerist sensibility of the Western artist.

title: LEGISLATORS LIST L.I. PRIORITIES
description: A FOURTH lane on the Long Island Expressway; the successful takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company and the closing of the Shoreham nuclear plant; lower property taxes for homeowners, and adequate financing for public schools.

title: Aquino Wins Big On Constitution As Truce Ends
description: Putting aside the guns and knives that played a sinister role in previous elections, Philippine voters gave President Corazon C. Aquino and her Government a ringing endorsement and new legitimacy last week.

title: Architecture View; CROWDING CAN VITIATE DESIGN -- GOOD AND BAD
description: In the ever-mounting struggle between a livable city and the real-estate industry's relentless desire to fill every nook and cranny of midtown Manhattan with a skyscraper, even a well-designed building can be a mixed blessing. A handsome object, in other words, is not in and of itself enough to justify more crowding, more shadows, and more pressure in a part of the city that is already bursting at the seams.

title: FURNITURE WITH MILLION-DOLLAR LEGS
description: A new chapter was written last weekend in an ongoing shaggy-paw story concerning the burgeoning value of a rare furniture style. The chronicle - involving Philadelphia furniture made for Gen. John Cadwalader, a colonial patron of the arts and Revolutionary War hero - was advanced at a New York auction when a 200-year-old wing chair with furry looking feet and a frame riddled with nail holes was sold for the highest price ever paid at auction for a piece of furniture - $2.75 million.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: FEBRUARY 8, 1987
description: FICTION Weeks On List 1 2 I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN, by Judith Krantz. (Bantam, $4.95.) A rich, beautiful young woman conquers the world of magazine publishing. 2 3 THE HANDMAID'S TALE, by Margaret Atwood. (Fawcett, $4.95.) In the America of the future, a k a the Republic of Gilead, men and women perform the services assigned to them. 3 5 THE STORYTELLER, by Harold Robbins. (Pocket, $4.50.) A poor boy from Brooklyn sets out to make it big in the world of glamour as a writer. 4 10 LIE DOWN WITH LIONS, by Ken Follett. (Signet/ NAL, $4.95.) An Englishwoman in Afghanistan, caught between the C.I.A. and the K.G.B. 5 2 THE IMMIGRANT'S DAUGHTER, by Howard Fast. (Dell, $4.50.) The last volume of the Lavette saga tells of a woman involved in today's politics. 6 11 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. (Bantam, $4.95.) Ayla of ''The Valley of Horses'' resumes her adventures in the prehistoric world. 7 2 SEASONS OF THE HEART, by Cynthia Freeman. (Berkley, $4.50.) A businesswoman is torn between devotion to her husband and her mentor. 8 47 THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.50.) A submarine driver brings Soviet nuclear secrets to the United States. 9 15 SECRETS, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $4.95.) Behind the scenes of a television production. 10 5 THE DREAM LOVER, by Lawrence Sanders. (Berkley, $3.95.) Intrigue in 1920's Hollywood. 11 4 LONDON MATCH, by Len Deighton. (Ballantine, $4.50.) Bernard Samson tracks down another traitor in a sequel to ''Berlin Game.'' 12 7 ANGELS OF SEPTEMBER, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Geis/Warner, $4.95.) Father Blackie Ryan investigates an art gallery explosion. 13* 2 A DARKNESS AT SETHANON, by Raymond E. Feist. (Bantam, $3.95.) The war between Order and Chaos ends in the final volume of ''The Riftwar Saga'' fantasy. 14 14 DARK ANGEL, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $4.50.) The story of the haunted Casteel family continues. 15 3 ECHOES, by Maeve Binchy. (Dell, $4.50.) A chance encounter in an Irish town brings romance to two people separated by rigid class barriers. NONFICTION

title: Mattingly-Rice II
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: MAYORAL PANEL CITES YOUTH PREGNANCIES IN POOR COMMUNITIES
description: Teen-agers living in poor neighborhoods give birth in significantly higher numbers than those in the rest of New York City, in some cases accounting for more than one-quarter of all births in a neighborhood, a mayoral panel has found.

title: New Effort to Get A-Plants Running
description: Under a rule change drafted by the staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, state and local officials could no longer prevent the operation of nuclear power plants. Officials in New York and Massachusetts, who have used the existing rule to block the operation of nuclear plants in their states, called the proposal ''outrageous.''

title: Science On the Track of God
description: In his article ''Science on the Track of God'' (Jan. 4), James Gleick searches for ''the evidence of design that cannot be explained away,'' and seems frustrated because ''science does eventually manage to explain.'' There is some confusion here, and it revolves around the word ''explanation.'' Science is made up of theories. Theory and truth are not the same thing. A theory is a movement toward the truth that is useful at a certain level. Sir Isaac Newton ''explained'' what makes the Earth travel around its sun. But, Newton's Laws of Mechanics are wrong. Nonetheless, every science textbook will rightly ascribe to his assumptions the hallowed title of ''laws,'' not because of their correctness but because of their usefulness.

title: Plan to Speed 'Star Wars' Tests Starts a Fight
description: President Reagan and his advisers last week were discussing whether to accelerate testing and deploying parts of the missile defense system known as ''Star Wars.'' To prepare the legal ground, they were considering issuing a broad interpretation of the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty, which was negotiated with the Soviet Union during the Nixon Administration.

title: RECITAL: JESSYE NORMAN
description: JESSYE NORMAN is gifted with a soprano voice of oceanic magnitude and power; she is also, at her best, a moving interpreter. Therefore, her Thursday evening recital at Carnegie Hall came as a distinct disappointment.

title: SLOW GOING FOR LILCO TAKEOVER
description: LEAD: AS the nine interim directors of the newly constituted Long Island Power Authority met for the first time last week to advance a public takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company, one thing was quickly apparent: Nothing, apparently, will happen quickly.

title:
A SPECIAL GUIDE TO CRUISES WORLDWIDE;
A Spring-to-Fall Sailing Directory
description: LEAD: The following directory of cruise ships is arranged by destination and basically covers sailings from March 1 to Nov. 30. Information for the directory was supplied by the individual cruise companies, but dates, ports of call and fares are all subject to change. Unless otherwise noted, fares quoted are for one person in double occupancy, exclusive of port taxes.

title: Brook Naff Plans to Marry Michael Fulton in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Herbert Naff Jr. of Easton, Conn., and Great Harbour Cay, the Bahamas, have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Brooks Naff to Michael Scott Fulton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Anthony Fulton of Greenwich, Conn. A May wedding is planned.

title: Fordham Beats Fairfield Twice
description: It took four weeks and four free throws, but Fordham finally defeated Fairfield in basketball yesterday. In fact, the Rams won twice, and by the same 74-70 score.

title: AT WILLIAM AND MARY, A POST TO HONOR BURGER
