description: The College of William and Mary, chartered by the King and Queen of England nearly a century before American colonists created the Constitution, staged a glittering ceremony here today for Warren E. Burger, chairman of the Constitution's bicentennial celebration.

title: AMERICA'S CUPHDL
description: Even as the America's Cup makes its way back to the United States, lobbying for the next cup series is already under way.

title: HEAD OF SUFFOLK POLICE INVESTIGATION STRESSES PROFESSIONALISM
description: DAVID G. TRAGER, the chairman of the State Commission of Investigation, seemed quietly amused as he thought about the criticism his panel had received following its two days of public hearings into the Suffolk County Police Department and District Attorney's office.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
SAKHAROV AUDIENCE
description: LEAD: ''I think you found, in some ways, the man that you expected, but in every dimension almost more so - more thoughtful, more intellectual, more courageous - and that it was not just what he said but what he represented as a human being that was at least as important as the particular topics we discussed,'' said Alice Stone Ilchman, president of Sarah Lawrence College, referring to her meeting with Dr.

title: HAVE THE METS AND YANKS CHANGED FOR THE BETTER?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Q.&A. With the New Planning Chief of New York
description: Last month, Sylvia Deutsch was sworn in as chairman of the New York City Planning Commission, the agency with broad responsibility for shaping the city's physical environment through zoning and planning. Mrs. Deutsch was a member of the commission from 1972 to 1981, and then became chairman of the Board of Standards and Appeals, the body that reviews requests from developers and property owners for hardship relief from zoning rules. She is married to Leon Deutsch, a Family Court judge in Brooklyn, has three children and lives in Brooklyn.

title: Hershiser Is Loser
description: FOLLOWING a season in which his victory total dropped by five games and his loss total increased by 11, Orel Hershiser, the Los Angeles Dodgers' pitcher who last year won a record pay raise in salary arbitration, established an opposite kind of record yesterday: He suffered the largest pay cut ever allowed in arbitration. That made Hershiser only the second player ever to emerge from an arbitration hearing with a cut.

title: JAPANESE SET SAIL FOR THE CUP
description: SLEEK and shiny, the futuristic yacht with the Japanese flag appeared to have arrived from a James Bond movie. Maybe you noticed it on television just before the start of the second America's Cup race when Stars & Stripes and Kookaburra III sailed around it. Another few feet and it would have created an international incident. But now, floating in its dock at the Fremantle Sailing Club, this $30 million metallic lily pad awaited the arrival of her owner, Masakazu Kobayashi, the real-estate and restaurant billionaire who will finance Japan's challenge for the America's Cup in 1990 or 1991.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN MASSAGE
description: MASSAGE has had a tenuous link with medicine for years. Nurses traditionally administered back massages to soothe the aches of bed-ridden patients, and even today many nurses and physical therapists study massage techniques.

title: WARNING OF SWANS
description: Thank you for publishing my letter in the Jan. 18 issue of Connecticut Weekly. However, I wish to point out an error in the printed letter. I said ''swans do raise their wings as a warning to be left alone.'' You quoted me as saying ''they do not raise their wings.'' SHIRLEY BECKER Branford

title:
DINING OUT;
A BAROQUE ATMOSPHERE IN DENVILLE
description: LEAD: HUNAN TASTE, an eight-month-old restaurant in the Morris County community of Denville, should be on the ''must visit'' list of anyone interested in the baroque. The building, which was obviously constructed at great cost, looks like a red, gold and green pagoda guarded by huge marble statues of foo dogs.

title:
GARDENING;
SOIL PESTS STUNT GROWTH OF YOUNG TREES
description: LEAD: HORTICULTURISTS have long been aware of the difficulty of replacing certain kinds of trees with young trees of the same species, especially apple trees.

title: CLEAN WATER ACT PROMISES RELIEF FOR BROOKLYN
description: When summer comes to Bay Ridge Avenue in Brooklyn, people in the neighborhood often abandon backyards for air-conditioned homes to escape the stench from the nearby Owls Head sewerage-treatment plant.

title: TRUE TO THE COUNTY
description: 'I SHOULD have listened to my numerologist. She said, 'Stay out of Westchester County; it adds up to death and decay.' ''

title: OPEC May Stumble, But It Won't Fall
description: EUPHORIA has overtaken the oil markets in recent weeks, as the OPEC agreement on production limits has demonstrated a surprising staying power. Even the Soviet Union, never a particularly trustworthy partner in these matters, has promised to join the effort to scale back production. And just this week, the four American oil companies that make up Aramco agreed to pay a fixed price of $18 a barrel. While they did this more to assure supply for their refineries than out of a belief that prices may have stabilized, the action helped bolster confidence in the market.

title: FOR 'CHOCOHOLICS,' TWO DAYS OF BLISS
description: THOSE who look forward to Valentine's Day not for the flowers, hearts or romance, but for the opportunity to delve into boxes of bonbons can indulge themselves at two chocolate-oriented events this week.

title: DO YOU LIKE THE COLLEGE 3-POINT BASKET?
description: The college game, unlike professional basketball, has never suffered the sort of slump warranting significant rule changes. Moreover, even if such rule changes were necessary in college basketball, the current 3-point rule would still be inappropriate.

title: NEW RULES AFFECT PRESCHOOLERS
description: LEAD: AT first, it looks like a typical elementary school to a visitor. Corridor walls are lined with colorful drawings, children's voices filter out of classrooms, and a group of youngsters, some holding hands, skip by on their way to the next activity of the day.

title: A JAPANESE TONIC IN WHICH THE MEDIUM IS THE MASSAGE
description: WHAT feels like an army running over your head, a freight train traveling across your neck and a thousand hands tickling your scalp? What disconnects your mind from your body, is stimulating and relaxing and leaves you tingling and refreshed? The answer, say enthusiasts, is the experience of Japanese head massage.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: HAUNTED HOUSES. By Lynne Tillman. (Poseidon, Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $7.95.) In ''Haunted Houses'' Lynne Tillman chronicles the loneliness of childhood and incipient womanhood, the salvation of friendship, and the neurotic chain that binds perpetually needy daughters to their perpetually self-absorbed parents.

title:
ANTIQUES;
A SPACIOUS, ECLECTIC BOUTIQUE IN SUMMET
description: LEAD: THREE years ago, Gerry Plummer combined her interest in antiques with previous retailing experience and opened Plumquin Limited, a spacious boutique at 12 Beechwood Road here.

title: ISRAELI WOMEN PROTEST DIVORCE LAWS
description: LEAD: RENA Avraham, a 36-year-old hairdresser who lives in a Tel Aviv suburb, has been trying to get a divorce for 12 years. Like many other women in her situation, Mrs. Avraham says her husband, Yaacov, has taken a common-law wife and started a new family in another town. He has not seen his wife or their two children in years.

title: IMPASSE AT TRUCK PLANT IN PENNSYLVANIA DRAGS ON
description: Thirteen months ago, Mack Trucks, long a mainstay of this city's economy, threatened to move its biggest assembly plant out of Allentown unless the United Automobile Workers agreed to a long list of economic concessions.

title: ACTION IS CALLED FOR ON ELECTRIC RATES
description: I read, with great interest, your article ''Power Cost Is Down but Still an Issue'' [ Jan. 18 ] . Although I agree that with electric rates down in 1986, the push for cheaper power has lost some momentum, I feel that the fight for reduced Con Ed bills must go on. We pay the highest rates in the nation. Here are some suggestions:

title: AGENDA FOR THE FUTURE: REVISING THE COUNTY CHARTER
description: A GROUP whose decisions could influence the course of county government well into the next century has begun a two-year task of revising the County Charter and Administrative Code.

title: Maureen McEnroe Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. John W. McEnroe of Summit and Stone Harbor, N.J., have announced that their daughter Maureen Patricia McEnroe and Brian Joseph Harkins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Harkins of Montvale, N.J., are to be married March 21.

title: 'BOARDER BABIES' BURDEN HOSPITALS
description: Municipal and private hospitals in New York City are being forced to spend millions of dollars a year caring for babies who are awaiting placement in foster homes.

title: WOODED TRACT STIRS DISPUTTE
description: IN THIS seat of Bergen County, where high-rise apartment houses and Victorian homes are the more-usual landscape, battle lines have been drawn in an unlikely spot: A 14.2-acre tract of virgin woodlands that is a nuisance to some and a garden spot to others.

title: Sri Lanka Reports 24 Killed In Attacks on Rebel Camps
description: At least 24 people were killed today when security forces attacked major rebel camps in northern Sri Lanka, the Government said.

title: THE FERRY PASSENGER MYSTERY
description: WHERE is James Stewart?

title: CAUTIONARY NOTE ON L.I. ECONOMY
description: VIRTUALLY every economist we have heard from and most of the publications and sources we consult in monitoring and anticipating the progress of the Long Island economy have told us that 1987, like 1986, will be another good year for our region.

title: FROM FRANCE, A TASTE OF EUROPE'S AVANT GARDE
description: Innovation and creativity are taken for granted in American dance - in large part because modern dance in this country has been rooted in such principles. Not so in most of Europe. The opera-house network in many countries there frequently goes hand in hand with an establishment taste, with resident ballet companies in those theaters catering to an establishment audience.

title: Spain Rejects Latest U.S. Offer in Base Talks
description: Spain has rejected the latest United States offer in negotiations over cutting American troops, raising questions over the ability of the two countries to reach an ultimate agreement.

title: BILL WOULD LET JOBLESS 'BOOTSTRAP'
description: CONGRESS is looking for entrepreneurs among the unemployed. Under a new ''bootstrapping'' bill backed by Representative James A. Courter, Republican of the 12th District (Hunterdon County and parts of Mercer, Middlesex, Morris, Somerset, Sussex and Warren Counties), jobless workers could draw unemployment checks while starting a small business.

title: DO YOU LIKE THE COLLEGE 3-POINT BASKET?
description: Throughout their histories, colleges have offered a 3.0 for every B a student earns, and but a 2.0 for the less-difficult-to-get C. Seems only right that these principles apply to basketball. Keep the 3-point basket. PETER FILICHIA New York

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: WINDMILLS OF THE GODS. By Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $18.95.) Sidney Sheldon's latest blockbuster kicks off when a demure housewife and Ph.D. in political science is appointed ambassador to Rumania. Okay, so she isn't exactly ambassadorial timber; so she's only been out of Kansas a couple of times. Her articles in Foreign Affairs have inspired the President's new ''people to people'' policy, meant to warm up relations between the United States and the Communist bloc - and that makes Mary Ashley the woman for the job.

title: Jazz
description: Fourteen years ago, on Feb. 5, 1973, Jack Kleinsinger, then a 36-year-old Assistant Attorney General for the State of New York and an enthusiastic jazz fan, became a jazz impersario. Although he had never presented a concert of any kind before, he booked the tiny theater De Lys on Christopher Street for two nights, one month apart, to put on programs he called ''Highlights in Jazz.''

title: RPO STARTS ITS OWN LABEL
description: The Royal Philharmonic, like all the major British orchestras, is supported by private sponsors and government grants. But when it comes to records, the RPO, like the others, has had to fend for itself, dealing with commercial record companies on a commercial basis. Recently, however, the Royal Philharmonic decided it wanted to be able to call the tune, so to speak, on recordings, and formed its own record company, called, of course, RPO Records.

title: ...AND TO THE ISLAND THAT WE CALL HOME
description: WITH cupids and lace and big chocolate hearts, I ask Long Island to be my valentine forever. After spending countless frantic weekends in the city, shopping for holiday gifts in the stores that line Fifth Avenue and desperately trying to hail cabs on frigid days, I bid a fond but definitely happy adieu to the Big Apple.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: WHOEVER said ''take care of the small things and the big things will take care of themselves'' was seriously naive. That doesn't mean, however, that small things shouldn't be taken care of. They definitely should, and the first of the small things to go should be the irritating habits of others.

title: BESTED BY MA BELL
description: LOVING LITTLE EGYPT By Thomas McMahon. 273 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

title: THE EXECUTIVE COMPUTER
description: COMPACT disks have taken the world of recorded music by storm. Their promise in personal computing, however, has failed to materialize. The difference in public acceptance is due in large part to time.

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: HERE IS THE MORNING line on candidates for 1988:

title: TURNPIKE ACCORD IMPERILED
description: LEAD: REJECTION by the Township Council here of an agreement to compensate homeowners whose property stands to be devalued by the proposed New Jersey Turnpike expansion project has cast doubt over whether local residents will receive any compensation at all.

title: ARE CONVENIENCES STILL CONVENIENT?
description: WAS it only last year that leaving the house was a simple process? I would grab my purse and keys and my briefcase if I were going to work. If I were going shopping after work, the newspaper fliers and my envelope of manufacturers' coupons would be taken as well. A quick stop to be sure that the evening's dinner was defrosting in the refrigerator and I was off for the day.

title: Gentrification: The Case of Clinton Hill
description: THERE is always human and political turmoil when a city neighborhood is being retrieved from abandonment and decay and, in this regard, the Clinton Hill section of downtown Brooklyn is no exception. But unlike other minority neighborhoods that have been overrun by middle-income whites in search of affordable housing, Clinton Hill has been propelled into gentrification by an integrated mix of middle-income New Yorkers.

title: RECENT RELEASES ON VIDEO CASSETES
description: Freaks MGM Home Video 113 minutes. $59.95.

title: JEWELS OF WINDSOR
description: ALL CONVERSATION CEASED at a sumptuous Paris ball when the Duchess of Windsor made her entrance. It was 1957, and the Duchess was wearing a dazzling necklace, composed of rows of large cabochon emeralds and diamonds, which everyone in the room began loudly admiring. Everyone, that is, except the

title: Housing Policeman Stabbed In Brooklyn Traffic Dispute
description: An off-duty housing police officer was stabbed in the back yesterday during a traffic dispute in the Flatlands section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: CUOMO CAMPAIGN IN '88 WOULD NOT INCLUDE SON
description: Governor Cuomo said this week that if he ran for President, his son Andrew, who has been his chief political strategist, would not serve a formal role in the campaign.

title: PRESSURES PUT STRAIN ON BUDGET
description: GOVERNOR KEAN'S proposed $10.18 billion budget for the coming fiscal year contains increased financing for education, prisons, welfare and health services, but pressures for still higher spending continue to grow faster than the state's ability to pay for new programs.

title: Alison K. Plotsky Weds D.S. Brown
description: Alison Katherine Plotsky, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Plotsky of Washington, was married there yesterday to David Shelby Brown, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilson Montgomery Brown Jr. of Baltimore and Hot Springs, Va. The Rev. Dr. Vienna Cobb Anderson, assisted by Rabbi Harold White, performed the ceremony in the Great Choir of the Washington Cathedral (Episcopal Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul.) Christina Best Neumann and David Shaver attended the couple.

title: ISRAELI TOLD BUSH CONTACTS IN IRAN WERE 'RADICALS,' NOT MODERATES
description: Vice President Bush was told last summer by an Israeli official that ''we are dealing with the most radical elements'' in Iran because dealings with moderates had proved unsuccessful, an aide to Mr. Bush said today.

title: WEAK DOLLAR FRAYS SAUDI TIES TO U.S.
description: THE hints of the worsening relations between Saudi Arabia and the United States were apparent the moment James A. Baker, the Treasury Secretary, stepped off his plane into the marble-covered royal entrance of the world's biggest airport. Although the airport was designed by Americans, nearly all its equipment came from other countries. Then, on the 20-minute caravan through the capital of Riyadh, Mr. Baker saw only one Cadillac, once a staple of rich Saudis, and that was the American Embassy car he was riding in. His hosts met him in Mercedeses and Jaguars. Saudis of humbler means buy their cars from Japan.

title: Crytoclearance, $6.20, Wins Everglades
description: Cryptoclearance, stretching beyond sprint distances for the first time in his career, dug in the way a promising 3-year-old is supposed to while running down Momsfurrari to win the $108,100 Everglades Stakes today at Hialeah Park.

title: Mobutu Tries to Maintain A Delicate Balancing Act
description: REPORTS that the United States shipped arms through Zaire to the rebels in Angola have complicated Mobutu Sese Seko's delicate balancing act in southern Africa. With nine countries as neighbors and with an economic dependency on South Africa, Zaire's President tries to give the appearance of being everyone's friend.

title: CBS Chief Seeks News for Less
description: Laurence A. Tisch, who was something of a white knight to the CBS News staff when he won a board-room battle for control of CBS Inc. last fall, is now asking for cuts in the news budget of up to 17 percent.

title:
TELEVISION;
WHEN BRITAIN HAD ITS VARIETY, AMERICA HAD ITS VAUDEVILLE
description: LEAD: The English music halls play a major role in the current seven-part ''Masterpiece Theater'' mini-series ''Lost Empires,'' based upon J. B. Priestley's novel of the same title. Viewers have before them a colorful panorama of the most popular entertainment medium of Victorian and Edwardian England. There is the magnificent Laurence Olivier as Harry Burrard, ''the Eccentric Comedian,'' with his piercing, soulful eyes.

title: Q and A
description: Nullifying an Amendment Question: About 50 percent of the residents bought their apartments when our building was converted to a co-op last year. As part of his negotiations with the tenants' association, the sponsor agreed not to apply for major-capital-improvement rent increases for repairs he was planning.

title: E. Robert Livernash Is Dead; Harvard Business Professor
description: E. Robert Livernash, professor emeritus at Harvard Business School, died of cancer Monday at the Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. He was 77 years old.

title: BUSINESS GETS LONG-DISTANCE BREAK
description: OVERALL, the average cost of placing a long-distance call has declined about 30 percent since the breakup of the American Telephone & Telegraph Company in 1984, according to the Federal Communications Commission. But businesses have benefited more from the decline than individual consumers have, though consumers are also paying less for long-distance calls.

title: O'ROURKE PRESSES ISSUE OF HOMELESS
description: COUNTY Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, in one of the strongest messages of his administration, coupled a plea for the municipal construction of affordable housing last week with a threat that the county would condemn property to build emergency housing in seeking to help Westchester's growing homeless population.

title: A PLAY THAT NEVER PLAYED BY 2 MASTERS OF SATIRE
description: The title page of the play is tantalizing: ''Even Stephen,'' by S. J. Perelman and Nathanael West. One can easily imagine the cross-breeding of talent - Mr. Perelman, the quintessential humorist, Mr. West the tragicomic chronicler of the corruptibility of man. Combine the effervescence of Mr. Perelman's New Yorker spoofs, or his zany Marx Brothers screenplays, with Mr. West's mordant novel, ''The Day of the Locust,'' and you have an idea of the potential of their collaboration.

title: ON STAGE, LETTERS FORM THE LITERATI
description: These Amazons now showed themselves qualified for the duty even of foot-soldiers; they stood there till 5 in the afternoon, without either sustenance or evacuation, every now and then playing volleys of thumps, kicks and raps, against the door, with so much violence that the speakers in the House were scarce heard.''

title: U.S. Considers Extending Reach Of AIDS Testing
description: More widespread AIDS testing may be recommended by the Government to help understand and curb the rapidly spreading disease.

title: DEVELOPMENTAL CENTER'S PLAN FOR RESIDENCES
description: My compliments on the Jan. 25 article ''Fears on Mental Center Proposal,'' centering on the interaction between the Long Island Developmental Center's program and the surrounding community.

title: DO YOU LIKE THE COLLEGE 3-POINT BASKET?
description: Over recent years basketball has evolved into 7-foot behemoths pushing and shoving for territory under the basket for easy dunks, tip-ins or layups. Placing a premium (3 points) on 19-foot or greater shots returns a modicum of skill to the sport. Rebounds and tip-ins should be equivalent to a foul shot (which incidentally many of the ''big men'' cannot seem to conquer). VICTOR TCHERTKOFF New York

title: PRESIDENT CUSTER
description: To the Editor:

title: Father Sues School in Son's Suicide at Home
description: The father of a 13-year-old boy who committed suicide at home in 1984 has filed suit against school officials here, charging that teachers and administrators should have known the boy was troubled and likely to harm himself.

title: SOME PRUNES CAN BE SHOW STOPPERS
description: WHY is it we hate prunes so much when we are children? Perhaps it is because they show up in such unflattering circumstances: stewed and served on top of cereal, or with custard for dessert. But prunes are transformed when they become adult food. They go wonderfully with rich winter meats such as pork, venison, duck or goose, and even with chicken or veal.

title:
GARDENING;
SOIL PESTS STUNT GROWTH OF YOUNG TREES
description: LEAD: HORTICULTURISTS have long been aware of the difficulty of replacing certain kinds of trees with young trees of the same species, especially apple trees.

title: NET STARS GATHERING LAURELS
description: THE football Giants may have been monopolizing sports fans' minds of late, and although the big men of the gridiron have been in the spotlight, a girls' basketball team here has been steadily gathering its own laurels.

title: Blue Blood
description: When two descendants of royalty fought it out recently for the mayoralty of Palm Beach, Fla., the main issue appeared to be which of them had the most common touch.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Gorbachev as Peter the Great
description: LEAD: What is Mikhail S. Gorbachev up to, and why is he inviting all those interesting people to Moscow? Much like Czar Peter the Great, Mr. Gorbachev is summoning Western intellectuals to his Kremlin court. Peter brought scores of European artisans, sages and shipbuilders to Russia in the late 1600's as part of a quest to ''civilize'' his backward land.

title: THE GREAT BOARD OF ESTIMATE MARATHON: SOUND AND FURY BUT LITTLE SUSPENSE
description: It was shortly after noon Thursday that the Board of Estimate began its hearing on an ambitious plan to replace the old Coliseum at Columbus Circle with a huge two-tower complex, complete wth indoor atrium and eight movie theaters.

title: WHEN A NOD BECOMES A DIPLOMATIC ACT
description: WHEN Bashkim Pitarka, Albania's new chief delegate to the United Nations, arrived for lunch recently at the French chief delegate's apartment, he seemed upset to see three United States diplomats.

title: Our Friends Shake Their Heads; Privatized Diplomacy
description: To the Editor:

title: LIGHT CAMCORDER ADDS FEATURES
description: Apparently acting in the belief that good things come in small packages, Sony has consistently shrunk the size of its products, the Walkman being emblematic of these efforts. In video, this attitude culminated in the Handycam - a bantam camera-recorder combination that may be regarded as the video version of the Walkman. This breakthrough design - now more than a year old - has done much to win favor for the 8-millimeter format among video fans who like to shoot their own tapes.

title: Taking Shape
description: IT SEEMS LOGICAL THAT FASHION designers should shorten hemlines now.

title: BUCKING THE ODDS IN LAS VEGAS
description: We timed our trip West to arrive in Las Vegas on Friday the 13th. Starting out in Santa Fe on the 5th, we made our way by car to Albuquerque, Gallup, Canyon de Chelly, deep in the 16.5 million-acre Navajo reservation, the Grand Canyon and, finally, Vegas, where I proposed to defy portents and not lose my shirt, particularly the one with the emblem, Universidad de New Mexico, which I had picked up at the school's bustling Albuquerque campus.

title: Court Finds for Farm Workers
description: Saying that Labor Secretary Bill Brock's decision to require the states to issue field sanitation standards for farm workers was an abdication of authority based on a faulty view of federalism, a three-judge panel in Washington last week ordered the Labor Department to issue Federal guidelines that farm worker advocates have been petitioning or suing for since 1972.

title: April 5 Wedding For Diane Harris
description: Diane Harris, a doctoral candidate in classical archeology at Princeton University, and William I. Kline, an architect at Hartman-Cox Architects in Washington, plan to be married April 5.

title: HARLEM IN THE JAZZ AGE
description: FOR THE BLACK ARTISTS, MUSICIANS, POLITICIANS and entrepreneurs who converged on Harlem in the 1920's and created what came to be known as the Harlem Renaissance, it was a time when everything seemed possible - a time, as a former resident recalled, when ''it was truly bliss to be alive.'' Not only did blacks take pride in their African heritage, pride in black folklore, pride in just being black, but it also seemed natural to believe that art could bridge the formidable gap between the black and white worlds, that excellence and merit could produce social change. That extraordinary decade will be evoked on Thursday, when ''Harlem Renaissance: Art of Black America'' opens at the Studio Museum in Harlem. The majority of the show's nearly 200 paintings, sculpture, illustrations, woodcuts and photographs are by five black artists: the painters Palmer Hayden, William H. Johnson and Aaron Douglas (whose woodcut is shown on the facing page), the sculptor Meta Warrick Fuller and the photographer James Van Der Zee. Perhaps more than any other visual artist, it was Van Der Zee (whose photographs appear on these pages), who captured the style and elan of Harlem in the Jazz Age.

title: METS TROUBLES REFLECT PRESSURIZED LIVES
description: RECENT accounts in the popular press of personal and legal problems encountered by a select number of the Mets have once again caused confusion for the typical fan. A national study conducted three years ago showed that 64 percent of American families have children participating in some organized sport and they tend to see sports heroes as persons with some of the most highly prized human qualities.

title: WHITE HOUSE FACING CRISIS OF CONFIDENCE
description: As Ronald Reagan enters the final two years of his Presidency, his White House has started to lose the distinctive aura of confidence and control that contributed heavily to the many achievements of his first six years in office, according to White House insiders and Reagan supporters outside the Government.

title: JAPANESE WITH CHARM AND VALUE
description: THE few Japanese restaurants to open in recent years in Connecticut have been of relatively high quality. One of the oldest, Hatsune in New Haven, is not only going strong, but has also, for the most part, sustained the high level of achievement reached in its early days.

title: TURNING THE UNDERSIDE RIGHT SIDE UP
description: ORIGINALITY, said Ralph Waldo Emerson, ''is being one's self and reporting accurately what we see and are.''

title: KEEPING TAINED FOODS OFF THIRD WORLD SHELVES
description: BAVARIA'S Minister of Agriculture tasted the milk last week and proclaimed it safe. The West German Environment Minister was less confident, saying that it would cause no harm ''unless it entered the food chain.'' Whatever the exact nature of the danger, 3,000 tons of radioactive powdered milk, a legacy of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster 10 months ago, has led to bitter feelings between West Germany and some third world nations.

title: WHERE IS EMERSON NOW THAT WE NEED HIM? OR, WHY LITERATURE CAN'T SAVE US
description: Writing may be either the record of a deed or a deed. It is nobler when it is a deed. . . . - Thoreau, ''Journal,'' Jan. 7, 1844

title: FRIENDLY ENEMIES
description: Even in a game that evinces as much individualism as chess, there are times when rivalries are put aside for the sake of reciprocal benefit. Suppose you come up with the kernel for an original tactic in a complicated, heavily studied opening position?

title: CASTRO RECOILS AT A HINT OF WEALTH
description: LAST spring, Cuba's quixotic leader, Fidel Castro, discovered a garlic farmer making $50,000 a year by privately selling what he had left over after meeting his quota for the state agriculture system.

title: Miss McGuiness Plans to Wed S.P. Webster
description: Eileen Mary McGuinness, a training coordinator in the C.P.C.-Tarrytown division of the General Motors Corporation in Tarrytown, N.Y., and Stephen Paul Webster, the Connecticut district sales manager in the Pepsi-Cola division of Pepsico Inc. in Purchase, N.Y., plan to be married in June. The future bride's mother, Mrs. Robert F. McGuinnesofofhihite Plains, has announced the engagement of her daughter to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth F. Webster of Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: David E. Gernert, Editor, To Wed Nancy L. Martin
description: The engagement of Nancy Loucks Martin to David Everett Gernert has been announced by Mrs. John Garvie Martin of Somers, N.Y., mother of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert E. Gernert Jr. of New Vernon, N.J. A September wedding is planned.

title: Social Security
description: To the Editor: If Social Security payroll taxes discourage employers from hiring and employees from working (''Put a Permanent Lid on Payroll Taxes,'' Forum Jan. 25), they fairly suffocate something else: Initiative.

title: PROSPECTS
description: The W-4 Factor

title: Budgets Up, Taxes the Same
description: The Governors of New Jersey and Connecticut proposed budgets last week with no new taxes or tax increases, but no tax cuts either.

title: IN GUILFORD, MACHINE GUNS FOR HIRE
description: LEAD: ''IF I die tomorrow, I can say I got to shoot an automatic weapon,'' Paul Proto said as held a paper target full of bullet holes. A computer programming analyst from East Haven, he had just spent $25 to experience ''the challenge'' of shooting a machine gun.

title: Running First Women's Bank Is Now a Man's Job
description: MARTIN SIMON is not a woman.

title: Elizabeth Sovern To Marry in June
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Anne Sovern to Raymond Ernest Conley has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Michael I. Sovern of New York and Lenore Sanders of Huntington Beach, Calif. A June wedding is planned. Ms. Sovern, an associate producer in New York of ABC's ''World News Tonight'' with Peter Jennings, graduated cum laude from Barnard College. Her father is the president of Columbia University. Her mother is an account executive at Ashley Aimes Personnel in Santa Ana, Calif.

title: SCATTERED IN PARIS, TINY TREASURE HOUSES
description: Small is beautiful. Aside from such mastodons of culture as the Louvre and the Grand Palais, Paris blossoms with small museums rich with art and offering fascinating curiosities in smaller doses.

title: Katharine Wilheim Weds
description: Katharine Jane Wilheim, the daughter of Denise Wilheim of New York and the late Paul G. Wilheim, was married last evening to Martin M. Segal, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Herman Segal of Boston. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Wilheim, brother and sister-in-law of the bride, in Larchmont, N.Y. The bride is a secretary at the Jewish Community Center of Greater Boston. Mr. Segal is the ritual director of Temple Emanuel in Newton, Mass. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: IN TAIWAN'S SNAKE ALLEY, SUPERSTITION AND SIN In Taiwan's Snake Alley, Superstition and Sin
description: Du Giang-long carefully arranged his pharmaceuticals on a table and began to extol the value of such products as deer antlers, monkey heads and flying lizards.

title: BEST SELLERS: FEBRUARY 8, 1987
description: Fiction Weeks This Last On Week Week List 1 1 WINDMILLS OF THE GODS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $18.95.) The nightmarish experiences that befall a woman and her family after her appointment as Ambassador to Rumania. 2 1 2 THE EYES OF THE DRAGON, by Stephen King. (Viking, $18.95.) A fairy tale, complete with an aged king, two princes, an evil wizard and a mouse. 3 2 28 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The West tries to stave off the Russians in World War III. 4 3 22 IT, by Stephen King. (Viking, $22.95.) Childhood horrors haunt six men and a woman who grew up in a small Maine town. 5* 5 4 NIGHT OF THE FOX, by Jack Higgins. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) A mission to keep D-Day plans from being discovered by the Germans. 6 6 14 WHIRLWIND, by James Clavell. (Morrow, $22.95.) Iran during the month following the Shah's departure. 7* 4 4 BANDITS, by Elmore Leonard. (Arbor House, $17.95.) A gang of three plots to heist millions being sent to the contras in Nicaragua. 8 12 3 THE PANIC OF '89, by Paul Erdman. (Doubleday, $17.95.) A financial wizard undertakes to defuse the crisis besetting the American economy. 9 8 15 FLIGHT OF THE INTRUDER, by Stephen Coonts. (Naval Institute, $15.95.) Navy aviators at war. 10 7 19 THE PRINCE OF TIDES, by Pat Conroy. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) Complex family relationships in South Carolina and New York. 11 1 PATIENCE OF A SAINT, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Geis/Warner, $18.95.) A hard-bitten newspaperman learns a lot about his family and decency while on the trail of a wily politician. 12 13 3 THE COUNTERLIFE, by Philip Roth. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) More about the ambitions and anxieties of Nathan Zuckerman. 13* 10 3 DEATH QUEST, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge Publications, $18.95.) A hit man sets out to kill Countess Krak and seal the fate of the Earth. 14 9 15 A TASTE FOR DEATH, by P. D. James. (Knopf, $18.95.) Inspector Adam Dalgliesh investigates a brutal double murder. 15 11 17 HOLLYWOOD HUSBANDS, by Jackie Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) A top model encounters three of Los Angeles's most dynamic men. 16* 1 SHAN, by Eric Van Lustbader. (Random House, $18.95.) A Chinese-American attempts to realize his father's dreams for Asia. Nonfiction 1 1 6 A SEASON ON THE BRINK, by John Feinstein. (Macmillan, $16.95.) A chronicle of one season spent with the coach Bob Knight and his Indiana University basketball team. 2 2 40 FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Dolphin/ Doubleday, $14.95.) Anecdotes and ruminations from the television star and father of five. 3 3 18 HIS WAY, by Kitty Kelley. (Bantam, $21.95.) An unauthorized biography of Frank Sinatra. 4 4 48 YOU'RE ONLY OLD ONCE! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $9.95.) A checkup at the Golden Years Clinic in pictures and rhyme. 5 6 20 MCMAHON! by Jim McMahon with Bob Verdi. (Warner, $16.95.) The autobiography of the quarterback for the Chicago Bears. 6 8 38 JAMES HERRIOT'S DOG STORIES, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) Fifty tales by a Yorkshire veterinarian about his favorite animal. 7 5 18 THE RECKONING, by David Halberstam. (Morrow, $19.95.) The crisis in the American automobile industry and Japan's role in it. 8* 7 4 THE SEARCH FOR SIGNS OF INTELLIGENT LIFE IN THE UNIVERSE, by Jane Wagner. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) Acerb observations on life today; script of the show starring Lily Tomlin. 9 9 12 DANCING ON MY GRAVE, by Gelsey Kirkland with Greg Lawrence. (Doubleday, $17.95.) The ballerina recalls her checkered career. 10 13 19 ONE KNEE EQUALS TWO FEET, by John Madden with Dave Anderson. (Villard, $16.95.) Observations on football. 11 11 6 ACROSS CHINA, by Peter Jenkins. (Morrow, $18.95.) The author of ''A Walk Across America'' takes his wanderlust to Asia. 12 1 REAGAN'S AMERICA, by Garry Wills. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The President as the product and embodiment of an American mythology. 13 14 4 MARILYN, by Gloria Steinem. (Holt, $24.95.) A biography of Marilyn Monroe, with many photographs by her friend George Barris. 14 10 PAT NIXON: The Untold Story, by Julie Nixon Eisenhower. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The life of the wife of the 37th President, by her daughter. 15 33 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author argues, and we must confront them to grow. 16* 10 12 WORD FOR WORD, by Andrew A. Rooney. (Putnam, $16.95.) A new collection of columns by the journalist and television personality. Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 2 15 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS WITH WINE, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $16.95.) Recipes to be prepared at moderate cost. 2 1 18 MEN WHO HATE WOMEN & THE WOMEN WHO LOVE THEM, by Susan Forward and Joan Torres. (Bantam, $16.95.) How to cope with overbearing men. 3 3 34 THE ROTATION DIET, By Martin Katahn. (Norton, $15.95.) A regimen based on the Vanderbilt University Weight Management Program. 4 4 74 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 5 5 52 THE FRUGAL GOURMET, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $14.95.) A television chef's inexpensive dishes. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. In Advice and How-to, five titles are listed because, beyond that point, sales in this category are not generally large enough to make a longer list statistically reliable. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the bookselling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: HOW TO PUT UP SHELVES AND MAKE SURE THEY'RE LEVEL
description: ONE project that almost everyone tackles is installing shelves.

title: DIDION & DUNNE: THE REWARDS OF A LITERARY MARRIAGE
description: SHE'S SO THIN THAT IF YOU touch her back you can feel the ribs, like ridges on a roll-top desk. He has a paunch. She likes to sit on a stool, her back ramrod straight; he drapes his body across a couch, assuming a languid, informal pose. She moves slowly, gently; talks softly. He moves quickly, his eyes alert to danger or intrigue, his voice booming with good humor, spiked by the energy of a hair-trigger temper. She is California pioneer Protestant; he's from New England, grandson of an Irish immigrant.

title: BRELAND DISCLOSES HE BROKE A HAND
description: Mark Breland said today he he broke his left hand in the first round of the seven-round knockout victory he scored over Harold Volbrecht to win the World Boxing Association welterweight title Friday night.

title: Study Warns of Electronics-Area Catastrophe
description: A new report has warned that the high-technology area south of here is not prepared for a ''catastrophe'' that could result from a major release of highly toxic gases in an earthquake, fire or traffic accident.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: ROSTROPOVICH LEADS NATIONAL SYMPHONY AT CARNEGIE
description: WHEN Mstislav Rostropovich and the National Symphony Orchestra are good, they are very, very good, and they are often at their best in the music of Shostakovich. On Friday night, the orchestra played one of Shostakovich's least known works -the Symphony No. 4 in C minor (Op. 43), written in 1935-36 at the height of the ''great terror'' and immediately after Stalin had denounced the young composer for his ''formalism'' and for writing ''muddle instead of music.''

title: TOKYO AIMS TO RESHAPE ITSELF AS 'WORLD CLASS CITY'
description: Every two decades in this century Tokyo has reshaped itself, and in the late 1980's it is doing so once again, with potentially significant consequences at home and overseas.

title: ONE MORE SEASON FOR ABDUL JABBAR
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar will play in his 16th All-Star Game here Sunday, more than any player in National Basketball Association history. This morning he said that his 17th All-Star Game would be his last.

title: BOGUS MONEY SEIZED BY U.S.
description: Federal agents seized $17.7 million in counterfeit $100 bills last week in California and Idaho in what the Secret Service called the largest seizure of bogus money in United States history, the authorities said.

title: Miss Kindred to Marry David Yewer in March
description: Mr. and Mrs. G. Estabrook Kindred of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Skytop, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dorothy Estabrook Kindred to David Edward Yewer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Yewer of Chenequa, Wis. The wedding is planned for next month.

title: MARYMOUNT'S PRESIDENT ON UNITED WAY PANEL
description: LEAD: ''I SHOULD have said no,'' said Sister Brigid Driscoll, president of Marymount College in Tarrytown, referring to her recent selection to the Volunteer Involvement Committee of the Second Century Initiative for the National United Way and to her tendency to become committed to volunteer projects. But the issues to be addressed by the Volunteer Involvement

title: California Judge Is Installed
description: Malcolm Lucas was sworn in Friday as Chief Justice of California's Supreme Court, succeeding Rose Bird and starting a conservative reorientation of the court. Mr. Lucas, 59 years old, said the court needed time to heal itself after the fall election, in which voters favoring the death penalty helped oust Ms. Bird and two other justices.

title: Seattle
description: To members of a loosely knit group called Lesser Seattle - dedicated in humor to keeping the largest city of the Pacific Northwest tourist-free and underwhelmed - last year was a nightmare. Vancouver's Expo 86, a few hours to the north, and a shower of superlatives from several national travel guides helped to bring a record number of visitors to the far edge of America. With the surge over, Seattle has settled into a winter mood, which is to say its residents are skiing the nearby slopes, sailing urban waters, and once again able to get same-day reservations at the better restaurants. A long-buried treasure of Asian artwork is coming out, the galleries are packed with new work and the theaters are showing midseason vigor.

title:
DINING OUT;
CHEF TRAVELS TO PATTERSON
description: LEAD: THE news that Davis Barnes, the chef that earned our admiration at the old Country Place, now works the stove at L'Auberge Bretonne, was motivation enough for a couple of forays into Patterson. Memories of Mr. Barnes's style - one with a bit of dash, one in which meticulous seasoning elicits vibrant flavors from fine ingredients, his savvy way with fresh herbs and garlic and light sauces - quickened our anticipation to dine at L'Auberge Bretonne, a restaurant that until recently majored in

title: Susan E. Phillips to Marry Robert Joseph Stonehill Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer D. Phillips of White Plains have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Elizabeth Phillips to Robert Joseph Stonehill Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stonehill of New York and Weston, Conn.

title: SEARCH FOR SURVIVORS IN HALTED
description: The Coast Guard has called off an air-and-sea search for 10 people missing from a fishing boat that capsized Thursday. The body of one man has been found and the rest are presumed dead.

title: MONTCLAIR MUSEUM: THE ART OF THE TOYMAKER
description: LEAD: THERE was once a time when a parent could walk a clear path through a child's room without facing a neck-breaking odyssey of ill-placed and forgotten toys. It was a time before Teddy Ruxpin, before Cabbage Patch and Barbie dolls, before television and radio.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
VALENTINES: TO A YOUNG HEARTTHROB...
description: LEAD: THERE must have been a time in my life, eons ago, when I realized that the approach of Valentine's Day did not set my heart aflutter. It simply left me cold.

title: Group Wants China to Free A Student Educated in U.S.
description: A group of Chinese and Americans has set up an organization for the defense of Yang Wei, the first United States-educated Chinese student reported arrested in China's recent crackdown on political dissent.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
Once-Scorned Swamp Draws Developers
description: LEAD: LONG SWAMP, a 30-acre tract of woods and marshes, overgrown with weeds and littered with debris, has been regarded as one of the least attractive sites in the state. It sits in the northeastern corner of Palisades Park along the Fort Lee border in Bergen County and has been idle for decades.

title: IN SHORT:FICTION
description: LEAD: VERTICAL HOLD. By Laurel Bauer. (St. Martin's, $16.95.) Take a left at Bullet Park, head down Revolutionary Road, and you've come to Lynford, Conn., another of those prototypical suburban communities, although with a pronounced Jewish flavor this time around. Lynford becomes the focus of media attention when a television network decides to do a series of ''live remotes'' from this location.

title: Executives Adrift
description: An employer's offer of half-pay until retirement age not to come to work would sound fantastic to some, even without forced layoff. I suspect that many employees might voluntarily elect that option, were it presented to them.

title: 7TH AVENUE LEADS TO PETTICOAT JUNCTION
description: WHO says fashion designers don't have a sense of humor? Take the skirts pictured here. Just kidding. Actually these skirts are exactly what fashion needs, a good-natured poke at the serious functionalism of much of today's women's wear.

title: Last Check Before Moving In
description: JUST before a buyer takes title to a brand-new home, either a condominium or a single-family house, the builder normally arranges for a final inspection of the property to verify that everything is in order. Many buyers are perplexed by this ritual and do not understand what they should be examining and why.

title: Verbatim; The Price of Liberty
description: 'I don't want to pay a dollar. I mean, we got it for free, didn't we?' - Elizabeth Matos High School student from Queens, complaining about a $1 fee for admission to the Statue of Liberty, which went into effect last week.

title: MISS HAAS TO WED
description: The engagement of Nancy Anne Rachael Haas and Philip Velie Jenks has been announced by Dolores Marie Lyons of Ipswich, Mass., mother of the future bride. Mr. Jenks is a son of Thomas Story Jenks of Chadds Ford, Pa., and the late Damaris Velie Jenks and a great-grandson of the late John Deere, founder of Deere & Company, the farm-equipment manufacturer.

title: Chilean Admits Role in '76 Murder
description: United States courts long ago established an official Chilean role in the 1976 murder in Washington of Orlando Letelier, an exiled opponent of President Augusto Pinochet. But the case has never been resolved because Chile has refused to extradite the suspects.

title: Man Linked to Drug Suspect Seized in Panama, U.S. Says
description: Federal agents and Panamanian police have arrested a man they say conspired with Carlos Lehder Rivas, a Colombian who has been accused of running the world's largest cocaine supply ring, a Federal Drug Enforcement Administration agent said today.

title: ALEXANDRA WICKSER MARRIES
description: Alexandra Wickser, a daughter of Mrs. Roy Dikeman Chapin Jr. of Grosse Point Farms, Mich., and the late Robert Livingston Wickser of Buffalo, was married yesterday to John H. Ballantine, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert W. Ballantine Jr. of Brewster, N.Y. The Rev. Stuart Kenworth performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York.

title: ISRAEL'S NAVY SEIZES A BOAT OFF LEBANON AND 50 PALESTINIANS
description: The Israeli Navy today reported seizing a cargo boat with 50 Palestinians described as guerrillas trying to sail to Lebanon.

title: TODAY'S SPORTS
description: Basketball All-Star Game East vs. West At Seattle, 3 P.M. Television Channel 2, 3 P.M. College Michigan at Indiana Television Channel 2, 12:45 P.M. Virginia at North Carolina Television Channel 4, 1 P.M. Notre Dame at Kansas Television Channel 7, 2 P.M. Boxing Vinny Pazienza vs. Roberto Elizondo Lightweights, 10 rounds At Providence, R.I. Television Channel 4, 3 P.M. Golf Hawaii Open At Honolulu Television Channel 4, 4:30 P.M. LPGA: Sarasota Classic At Sarasota, Fla. Hockey Rangers vs. Toronto Maple Leafs At Madison Square Garden, 8:35 P.M. Television MSG, 8 P.M. Radio WNBC 660, 8:20 P.M. Devils vs. Pittsburgh At Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. Television SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio WMCA 570, 7:30 P.M. Tennis U.S. Men's Pro Indoor Final At Philadelphia Television USA, 1 P.M. Other Events Auto Racing NASCAR Busch Classic At Daytona, Fla. Television Channel 2, noon. Figure Skating U.S. National Championships At Tacoma, Wash. Television Channel 7, 4 P.M. Harness Racing At Roosevelt, 7:30 P.M. Skiing World Alpine Championships At Crans-Montana, Switzerland Television Channel 7, 4 P.M. Soccer M.I.S.L. Express at Minnesota Television SportsChannel, 3 P.M. Thoroughbred Racing At Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. Television SportsChannel, 6:30 and 10:30 P.M., taped.

title: CLOSED SHELLFISH BEDS REOPEN
description: LEAD: BRIGHTENING otherwise bleak prospects for some Long Island baymen, New York State has announced the conditional opening of 1,500 to 2,000 acres of closed shellfish beds in Southold, Southampton, Babylon, Brookhaven and Huntington Towns.

title: OPERA: MALFITANO AS MASSENET'S 'MANON,' AT THE MET
description: ANY lingering doubts that the Metropolitan Opera has become a director's house should be dispelled by the staging of ''Manon'' that made its debut Friday evening. Jean-Pierre Ponnelle, who produced and designed this production, has so encrusted Massenet's pathetic love story with stylistic sequins and painterly images that poor Manon emerges as hardly more than one more theatrical prop in the service of a directorial star-turn.

title: How Making Guns Costs Us Butter
description: To the Editor:

title: ZAIRE, ENDING SECRECY, ATTACKS AIDS OPENLY
description: At the AIDS project in Mama Yemo Hospital here, Zairian technicians hunch over computers, tracking the health histories of thousands of local victims of the disease.

title: UNIVERSITIES FACE A CRISIS IN ISRAEL
description: Israel's universities, the reputation and achievements of which have been a source of national pride, are facing a severe financial crisis.

title: A MISTRESS OF HERSELF
description: To the Editor:

title: Duarte Party Stages Salvador Demonstration
description: The governing Christian Democratic Party held a major demonstration here today, apparently in an effort to regain political momentum after months of sliding popularity.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: LEAD: HOW A BOOK IS MADE Written and illustrated by Aliki. 32 pp. New York: Thomas Y. Crowell. $12.95. (Ages 7 and up)

title:
MUSIC;
THE CLEVELAND TO PERFORM AT RUTGETS
description: LEAD: THE Cleveland Orchestra, under its music director, Christoph von Dohnanyi, will perform at Rutgers University Tuesday at 8 P.M.

title: NEWEST JUDICIAL ACTIVISTS COME FROM THE RIGHT
description: AS the prominence of conservative legal thinkers has grown during the Reagan Administration, so has a split about the fundamental issues of constitutional jurisprudence. The division centers on whether judges should take the activist role of striking down a wide range of economic regulations.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: TOLSTOY. By Pietro Citati. Translated by Raymond Rosenthal. (Schocken, $18.95.) This short critical biography of Tolstoy is unsatisfying. Whether he waxes lyrical over the writer's genius, picks apart his mind, or narrates Tolstoy's turbulent life, nothing Pietro Citati writes stands out like the occasional passage by Tolstoy himself.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
LESSONS
description: LEAD: IT is Thursday afternoon at the James H. Henry School of Music. Ten-year-old Christopher Smith and his 14-year-old brother, Lester, are finishing their lessons. Lester, who began with a staccato little classical piece called ''The Spinning Song,'' has just put the final flourishes on something considerably more evocative, the hymn ''What a Friend I Have in Jesus.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: No Perfumed Words for Proust

title: 20 Food Outlets Cited By New York Officials
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 20 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: 64 Escape at Mexican Prison After Gun Battle With Guards
description: Inmates seized rifles from the armory at the Sinaloa state penitentiary last night and 64 escaped after fighting a gun battle with guards, the authorities said.

title: YOUTH PUTS HIS ENERGY IN GYMNASTICS
description: IT didn't take long for Garie Jean Mulcahey of Stamford to realize that she had to find a way to channel her young son's energy, which was being manifested in a number of unusual ways.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE BRIDGE. By Maggie Hemingway. (Atheneum, $13.95.) The jacket illustration for this imaginative first novel is a detail from a painting by the British impressionist Philip Steer. A slender woman, closely watched by a man, stands on a bridge and gazes at the sunset beyond a little harbor. During the 1880's Steer summered, mostly alone, in a tiny village on the Suffolk coast called Walberswick. After 1891 he never returned, and, according to Maggie Hemingway, the quality of his work diminished. He died at 82, a bachelor, leaving instructions that all his papers be destroyed. Ms. Hemingway wonders why he left a place that inspired him to sensual, vital, fresh work. Her novel posits a frustrated Victorian romance for the solitary artist, an untenable passion that made the village ultimately unbearable. She imagines a lonely young matron, Isobel Heatherington, summering at Quay House, near the bridge, on the way to the beach. Isobel is accompanied by her pretty daughters, Maria, Sophie and the mischievous Emma. ''They hovered there in the doorway in a cloud of white muslin, clutching straw boaters with long ribbons and looking . . . like a vision of perfect innocence and sisterliness.'' This is a blurred timescape of the British past that is sometimes Victorian, sometimes actually Edwardian - H. E. Bates territory, in the spirit of L. P. Hartley's ''Go-Between.'' It was most successfully occupied, recently, by Isabel Colgate in ''The Shooting Party.'' Everything is prefigured and genteel. If you like your tea and fiction delicately seasoned and served exquisitely, this short novel may be a perfect midwinter cup.

title: NURSING SHORTAGE HAS BECOME ACUTE
description: AS enrollment in the state's nursing schools has dropped 40 percent; as more and more nurses leave the field to pursue more lucrative careers, and as outpatient clinics multiply around the state, hospitals are acting vigorously to recruit and retain nurses for the growing number of vacancies.

title:
IN SHORT: NON-FICTION;
DIZZY, BENNY, BILLIE AND THE COUNT
description: LEAD: From the 1920's to the 1960's, jazz became the dominant force in American music. These years are recalled in STORYVILLE TO HARLEM: Fifty Years in the Jazz Scene by Stephen Longstreet (Rutgers University Press, $27.95). Mr. Longstreet is a playwright (''High Button Shoes''), a novelist and screenwriter (''The Jolson Story'').

title: DON MARRON'S DREAM SLIPS AWAY
description: DONALD B. MARRON, chairman of the Paine Webber Group, delighted recently in showing a visitor the playful new David Hockney photo montage hanging on the wall next to his desk. At a glance, it was hard to tell if the jumbled image was falling apart, coming together, or in a state of dynamic equilibrium.

title: IN SHORT: NON-FICTION
description: LEAD: LAURA Z: A Life - Years of Fulfillment. By Laura Z. Hobson. (Donald I. Fine, $18.95.) A straightforward approach makes ''Laura Z: A Life - Years of Fulfillment'' as intimate and inviting a book as Laura Hobson's first volume of autobiography. Hobson, best known for her novel ''Gentlemen's Agreement,'' takes us through the making of the film based on that book, her writing of several other novels, her return to ''lean years'' and her set-tos with a sister, son and former spouse.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN MASSAGE
description: THOUGH there are hundreds of massage schools nationwide, one obstacle to massage's acceptance in medicine -and in mainstream America - has been a lack of accreditation standards. This is slowly changing, but to date only 13 states - including New York, Delaware, Ohio and Hawaii - require a license to practice massage. And the criteria for obtaining these licenses vary considerably. In Delaware, practitioners must have a high school education and 1,000 hours of massage training. Ohio requires only 250 hours.

title: TIPS FOR NONSKIERS ON THE SLOPES
description: DO you jump out of bed early on a winter weekend, raring to hit the slopes? Does your spirit soar at the thought of flying over mountain moguls from dawn till dusk?

title: Claiborne And Cholesterol
description: With all the talk of high blood pressure and high cholesterol levels in this country, how in the world can your magazine print such recipes as you did in ''The Homecoming'' (By Craig Claiborne with Pierre Franey, Food, Jan. 4), which contain the exact foods that the experts recommend against?

title: Athens
description: To the Editor: ''Museum Hopping in Athens'' (Travel, Jan. 11) neglected to mention the Gennadius Library, which deserves to be on the itinerary of any visitor seriously interested in the classics or in modern or medieval Greece.

title: FRONTIERSMAN OF THE WESTERN SLOPES
description: The blizzard makes the Swiss flag outside Ernie Blake's window at Taos Ski Valley snap like a loose jib.

title: JUST A TOASTER WITH PICTURES
description: WATCHING TELEVISION A Pantheon Guide to Popular Culture. Edited by Todd Gitlin. 248 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $19.95.

title: J. PHILIP SMITH
description: J. Philip Smith, a former vice president and director of Pfizer Inc., died Friday at his home in Boynton Beach, Fla., after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

title: Ten Seized in Somalia Are Freed in Ethiopia
description: Ten French medical workers in Somalia, who were captured two weeks ago by Ethiopian-backed rebels, were turned over to France here today.

title: Another Way To Judge Trades
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: RECEIVERS DRAW ATTENTION
description: The venerable saying that there is more than one way to skin a cat has not lost its validity. In audio, for example, different approaches often lead to the same end, as in the case of two currently popular receivers - one by Nakamichi, the other by Yamaha. They have been attracting attention because they confront audiophiles with contrasting design precepts. Nakamichi relies on the appeal of a new circuit to maximize the performance obtainable with its modest wattage, plus a set of simple but sufficient operating controls. Yamaha offers ample power from a conventional circuit along with a plethora of clever and useful controls. Yet both attain similar results and both sell in the same price range of about $600.

title: Margot Ross Engaged To Paul A. Kunkel 3d
description: Margot Treman Ross and Paul Augustine Kunkel 3d plan to be married in the summer. Their engagement has been announced by her parents, Mrs. Joseph Hill Williams of Tulsa, Okla., and Llewellyn Gerard Ross of New York. Mr. Kunkel is a son of Dr. and Mrs. William Minster Kunkel of Harrisburg, Pa.

title: THE LIFE OF A 'SNOWBIRD'
description: Carol Cott Gross was right! ''Snowbirds'' who reside in condominium complexes do take advantage of the ''sunset specials,'' do snitch packages of Sweet 'n Low and frequently assign self-appointed ''condo commandos'' to protect their pool, clubhouse and residence. But Florida's ''Condoland'' is more.

title: PASTAS THAT LEAD THE LIST OF HIGHLIGHTS
description: SEMPRE VIVOLO opened in Hauppauge in September. It was scarcely a premiere, for the restaurant is owned by an old trouper in the business.

title: GROWING UP SOULLESS
description: LEAD: THE SHIP OF WIDOWS By I. Grekova. Translated by Cathy Porter. 179 pp. Topsfield, Mass.: Virago/Salem House. Cloth, $13.95. Paper, $7.95.

title: HOW PLANS FOR A NONSEXIST UPBRINGING WERE THWARTED
description: A SMALL monitoring screen attached to an ultrasound device displayed what I thought to be a double image, of a fetus in the fifth month of gestation resting comfortably in my wife's womb.

title: DO YOU LIKE THE COLLEGE 3-POINT BASKET?
description: Yes, but - only if you complete the adjustment by establishing a 1-point zone round the basket. This would reduce the ridiculous priority on height and restore emphasis on skills. The 3-point play is an important first step of the two steps needed. MARTIN LENTZ Philadelphia

title: TOLL RISE PUT OFF AGAIN
description: LEAD: THE 40 percent increase in New Jersey Turnpike tolls, first predicted for last summer and then for this spring, will not materialize, if at all, at least until 1988, according to operators of the superhighway.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
AN SILAND NATION HONORS THE CUP
description: LEAD: The Royal Perth Yacht Club, host in this year's America's Cup race, has authorized a proof set of three precious-metal coins to commemorate the event. The 1987-dated coins are being struck by the Singapore Mint and issued by Western Samoa.

title: PLIGHT OF A SURROGATE COMPLAINER
description: NAN, a neighbor, and I love freezing in April on a beach in Maine (getting a so-called tan), shopping for Christmas on Labor Day, and having icicle duels with our respective husbands in deep winter. We marvel that human beings can be so similar. Except for one thing: Nan can't complain about anything, so I do all the complaining for her. I hate to complain. It makes me grumpy.

title: IN THE DARK, IT'S REALITY THAT WOOS THE AUDIENCE
description: In the opening sequence of Sidney Lumet's ''Morning After,'' Alex Sternbergen (Jane Fonda), a once-promising, still-beautiful, former Hollywood starlet, awakens with a terrible hangover, sharing a bed with a man she doesn't know, who has a kitchen knife stuck in his chest. What will she do or, for that matter, what should she do? There's no point in summoning the paramedics -even Dr. DeBakey couldn't help this one. The man is dead.

title: RECITAL: KIMBALL WHEELER
description: KIMBALL WHEELER'S recital at Merkin Concert Hall Wednesday night offered decent, professional-level music-making, amplified considerably by glamour and personal charm. Ms. Wheeler possesses a mezzo-soprano voice of moderate size, dark hue and naturally affecting timbre. Unfortunately, on Wednesday night her upper register was not secure, her pitch sense lacked authority, and her interpretations were careful rather than inspired.

title: NEW REVUE SPOOFS FILM INDUSTRY
description: ONE of the longest-running cabaret hits in New York is ''Forbidden Broadway,'' the award-winning musical spoof of the people and the shows that dominate Broadway news. Now, Theater Three in Port Jefferson has its own standing-room-only cabaret show in ''Hollywood Exposed,'' a clever musical joke at the expense of the film industry.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
SPOTLIGHT ON NUCLEAR CONFLICT
description: LEAD: Cable this week will demonstrate it has first-strike capability. On Thursday -three days before ABC-TV launches its controversial weeklong mini-series ''Amerika,'' which is set in the United States 10 years after a Soviet takeover -WTBS will begin its presentation of ''Beyond Fear,'' an umbrella title for five specials concerned with nuclear war and superpower relations.

title: Westminster Blends Tradition and Quality
description: Westminster, the most prestigious of the more than 1,000 all-breed dog shows held annually in the United States, opens a two-day run at Madison Square Garden tomorrow.

title: 7 Guilty of Lesser Charge in Texas Fraud Case
description: After a long trial of 10 employees and officers of three companies on charges including racketeering, fraud and theft, including theft from the Government, a jury has convicted seven employees of obstruction of justice.

title: WESTMINSTER: GETTING READY
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH Nell Fox has been showing her Australian terriers at the Westminster Kennel Club show at Madison Square Garden for 30 years, she still gets excited at the prospect.

title: Oral Roberts Fund Drive Gets $1.6 Million in Contributions
description: Oral Roberts, the television evangelist who told viewers last month that he would die unless he raised $4.5 million for medical missionary scholarships by March, has received $1.6 million, a spokesman says.

title: The Istanbul Synagogue Massacre
description: I am one of the few persons in the United States who has engaged in lengthy discussion with Abu Nidal (''The Istanbul Synagogue Massacre: An Investigation,'' by Judith Miller, Jan. 4). During my visit last December to the Middle East, seeking the release of the hostages held in Lebanon, I met with members of Abu Nidal's Fatah Revolutionary Council. Not only did they deny any connection with the Istanbul massacre, as Judith Miller states, they also denounced the massacre, which Ms. Miller fails to mention.

title: BIRD AND JORDAN DO WHAT'S EXPECTED
description: Sometimes the difference between the ordinary and the sublime is created by more than skill. Presence and charisma, intangibles possessed by only a few special athletes, are often more crucial.

title: THE SHOW GOES ON EVEN IF HAWKS LOSE
description: With less than two minutes to play in a game between the University of Hartford and Canisius last month, people were still filing into their seats at the Hartford Civic Center. Very late for the game? Yes. But still plenty early for the concert by Smokey Robinson, the singer, that was to follow the game.

title: Soviet-China Talks Resume
description: A Chinese team led by a Deputy Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, arrived here today to resume border talks that were suspended nine years ago. The talks will deal with jurisdiction over islands in the Amur and Ussuri rivers, which form the border in the Far East. In a speech in Vladivostok last year, Mikhail S. Gorbachev said the Soviet Union had decided to accept the Chinese claim to set the border along the main ship channel rather than along the Chinese bank.

title: FIGHTING CITY HALL WITH PSYCHOLOGY
description: WHEN the building inspector and Zoning Board of Appeals in Groton, Mass., refused to let Thomas Hefele build a house on his property in 1985, he struck back at what he viewed as ''arbitrary authority.''

title: A COMPOSER HEARS A DIFFERENT DRUMMER THE LIVELY ARTS
description: LEAD: ''IF Mozart and, yes, Bach were alive today, how would they write?''

title: The New C.E.O.
description: To the Editor: Steven Prokesch may well have redefined the acronym C.E.O.: Covetousness, Egoism, and Opportunism.

title: IN NORTHEAST, PRICES RISING FASTER THAN FAMILY INCOMES
description: PRESENTING his budget to the Connecticut Legislature last week, Governor O'Neill proposed spending $100 million on a financial commitment that could help guarantee ''the deeply rooted and inalienable right'' of every Connecticut resident to safe and affordable housing.

title: AIRPORT BIRDMAN KEEPS JETS SAFE
description: Sammy Chevalier is the birdman of Kennedy International Airport.

title: When Social Security's Anti-Social
description: Can America afford to acquire more land for national parks or retrain workers displaced by imports? Can it pay for rebuilding the congested air traffic system or protecting South Africa's neighbors from economic collapse? There's a better question: Can a rich nation afford not to make these and other investments in a decent future?

title: Gentrification
description: To the Editor: Your article titled ''Rebuilding From the Grass Roots Up'' on Dec. 21 mentions that homes on a redeveloped Charlotte Street in the South Bronx will be sold for $100,000. It then states that these are ''low- and moderate-income projects.'' Since when are $100,000 houses classified as low- and moderate-income? This type of development smacks of gentrification that benefits nobody but the well-to-do.

title: 'WHERE TWO WORLDS MEET'
description: On behalf of the Young Israel of Lawrence-Cedarhurst, the most rapidly growing Orthodox synagogue in the Five Towns, we wish to thank you for an incisive, positive, portrayal of our community [ ''Five Towns: Where Two Worlds Meet,'' Dec. 28 ] . The treatment of the topic was as fair-minded and balanced as was the topic itself.RONALD GOLDMAN President Young Israel of Lawrence-Cedarhurst

title: FOR SOME WORKERS, TO SERVE A CITY IS TO LIVE THERE
description: LEAD: IN order to keep his job, Hartford City Manager Alfred A. Gatta lives weekdays in Hartford and spends weekends with his family in West Hartford, a few miles away.

title: TRENARY TAKES SKATING TITLE
description: Jill Trenary capped a remarkable comeback from a severe leg injury by upsetting the world champion, Debi Thomas, to win the women's title at the United States figure skating championships today.

title: A PIANIST, A VIOLINIST AND A COUNTER TENOR
description: TWO of the three debut recitals offered in New York last week gave impressions of sturdy, at times inelegant, professionalism. The third perhaps should not have taken place at all. Janusz Skowron

title: 5 OF 27 CARIBOUS IMPORTED TO MAINE DIE
description: Five of 27 caribous brought to Maine recently in an effort to reintroduce the animal to the state have died, two on the trip from their native Canada late last year and three within two weeks after their arrival at a compound at the University of Maine in Orono, the project's director said.

title: WORKING A SQUEEZE WITHOUT THE COUNT
description: In the 60-year history of contract bridge there have been two men, and only two, whose names have become household words.

title: A 'SHARK WATCHER' ON WALL STREET
description: ''I WAS the first shark watcher,'' said Arnold Minsky of Brookville. But don't look for the 48-year-old Mr. Minsky in the waters off Montauk, chumming for great whites. Look for him - figuratively speaking - on Wall Street, trolling for the sort of sharks inclined to feed on stock as they raid tempting targets in corporate takeovers.

title: M.C.I. Increases
description: To the Editor: Your article called the ''Vanishing Supply of Rentals'' on Dec. 28 quotes an executive of a realty management firm complaining about the 6 percent cap on M.C.I. rent increases as a disincentive to landlords contemplating major capital improvements to a building. He felt that way since a 6 percent increase of an average $500 rental would be only $1,800 over the course of the 5-year amortization period that is used (6 percent times $500 times 60 months).

title: NEW TACTICS NEEDED TO HELP DROPOUTS WHO RETURN, SCHOOL OFFICIAL SAYS
description: New tactics are needed to help dropouts who return to school, including extending the four-year period in which students are expected to complete high school, according to a senior official of the New York City Board of Education.

title: LOVE AS A NEUROTRANSMISSION
description: MOLECULES OF THE MIND The Brave New Science of Molecular Psychology. By Jon Franklin. 301 pp. New York: Atheneum. $18.95.

title: THE GRINCH GOES TO CHURCH
description: To the Editor:

title: Naming Names In the Bronx
description: In many political domains, nomination is tantamount to election; in the Bronx, it is beginning to seem that election is tantamount to investigation.

title: Indians Want Part Of Custom House
description: Situated in a deteriorating neighborhood on northern Manhattan, the Museum of the American Indian attracts few visitors. But even those who venture to its 70-year-old site at 155th and Broadway can only see a fraction of what is considered perhaps the world's finest collection of native American art and artifacts. The rest is in storage. This month, the museum seemed close to attaining its long-sought dream of moving to the former United States Custom House on the southern tip of Manhattan. President Reagan has supported efforts to give the abandoned building, one of architect Cass Gilbert's masterworks, to the museum, and Representative Morris K. Udall, an Arizona Democrat, is expected to introduce appropriate legislation. Meanwhile, H. Ross Perot, the Texas billionaire, has dropped his efforts to lure the museum to Dallas.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
'UGLY' IS BEAUTIFUL
description: LEAD: The ''ugliest'' bartender in Westchester, Putnam, Rockland and Orange Counties and the Bronx - Tom D'Errico of Patrick's Pub in White Plains - will receive an award Wednesday night. But Mr. D'Errico, who is by day a computer programmer for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, is not in the least upset by the dubious-sounding honor: on the contrary, he's pleased as punch.

title: KEEPING STATE PARKS GREEN AS FEDERAL FUNDS DWINDLE
description: ''IN the early 1980's, we were hurt quite a bit by cutbacks from Federal sources,'' recalled Gregory Iffrig, director of administration for Missouri's division of parks. The cuts came, he noted, not only in direct grants-in-aid, but also in work programs like the Youth Conservation Corps, which Missouri depended on for help in the upkeep of its 103,000 acres of public recreation and wilderness land.

title: YONKERS SCHOOLS BEGIN NEXT PHASE
description: LEAD: AS the Yonkers School District begins carrying out the second phase of a court-ordered integration plan, school officials say the district has made distinct progress in achieving racial balance.

title: Harnessing the Horses on Job Discrimination
description: To hear Clarence Thomas tell it, employers used to laugh when the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission threatened to come down hard on them for job discrimination.

title:
WEEK IN BUSINESS;
Economic Signals Are Strong, but...
description: LEAD: The economy showed signs of strength in December, but analysts are maintaining a cautious pessimism. Leading indicators rose a strong 2.1 percent in December, the best showing in four years. Sales of new homes spurted 8.9 percent, ending a record year for the housing industry, and factory orders, helped by strong civilian demand, gained 1.2 percent.

title: Mark S. Marani Wed To Judith F. Edwards
description: Judith Ferguson Edwards, the daughter of Mrs. Richard G. Knox of Pinehurst, N.C., and M. Niles Edwards of Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Mark Steven Marani, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Marani of Brookville, L.I. The Rev. Henry C. Duncan, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Village Chapel in Pinehurst.

title: PATHS THAT CROSSED IN THE RING
description: IT was 1983 and, in the dressing room before they fought each other for the first time, Rickey Womack made an impression on Evander Holyfield.

title: SIMON PLAY STAGED IN BRIDGEPORT
description: IT is no wonder that ''They're Playing Our Song'' has become a staple in small theaters. It is a two-character musical, with a disposable chorus of six. It has a sparse score, also disposable, by Marvin Hamlisch (music) and Carole Bayer Sager (lyrics). And the story, which is said to be based upon the once-upon-a-time romantic relationship between the composer and the lyricist, is by Neil Simon. In short, with its glib lines and innocuous songs, the show is simple, safe and, apparently, satisfactory to a lot of audiences.

title: A Game the Saudis Can't Afford
description: LAST week, during his visit to Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d and his Saudi hosts continued to oversupply the world oil market with atmospherics. While confessing that they did not know how long it would last, both sides agreed that $18-a-barrel oil was good for consumers and producers. So much for the talk. What about the economic realities? First, look at what caused the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to unravel last year. As with all cartels, excess capacity became OPEC's Achilles' heel. To impose artifically high prices, OPEC had to reduce output, leaving it with some excess capacity in the early 1970's. The market force of artificially high prices pushed down world demand by 15 percent from from 1979 through 1985. Also, the supply of oil from the non-OPEC interlopers rose by almost 50 percent from 1973 through 1985. Thus, OPEC had to again dramatically reduce its output - to nearly 50 percent below its peak in 1977, leaving it with even more excess capacity.

title: KLANSMEN, CHANTING 'WHITE POWER,' MARCH IN ATLANTA SUBURB
description: About 100 members and supporters of the Ku Klux Klan marched through this suburban Atlanta town today, raising their fists and chanting, ''White power.''

title: CRIME
description: It was about a dozen years ago that the Australian writer William Marshall started writing his Yellowthread Street mysteries. Those were procedurals set in Hong Kong, and were distinguished by a wacky kind of writing in which seriousness was mingled with farce. There have been 11 in that series.

title: Hams Are Recalled By Jersey Company
