description: A New Jersey food distribution company is recalling its three-pound canned hams from stores in six states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, after Federal inspectors found that some of the hams had spoiled, the Agriculture Department announced today.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
THRESHER SHARK
description: LEAD: Alopias vulpinus Size: To 25 feet, including tail, which is about as long as the body.

title: A VALENTINE'S BIRTHDAY
description: YEARS ago, when I was attending Northwest Elementary School in Hartford and Valentine's Day rolled around, it seemed to be common knowledge among classmates that I was born on that day. Decades later, I have never rationalized whether cards for me were tied to my birthday or to the day itself.

title: A Geneva Hostelry With Homey Grace
description: If a hotel can be something more than just the sum of all its parts, then the Beau Rivage in Geneva is one such place.

title: Debra Gingold Is Engaged
description: Debra Robin Gingold, a bond trader at Shearson Lehman Brothers in New York, and Dr. Jeffrey Elliot Mallin, the chief resident in the department of neurology at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine at Yeshiva University, plan to be married in July. Miss Gingold is a daughter of Arlene Gingold of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., and the late Harold Gingold. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Mallin of Merrick, L.I.

title: INSURGENTS REJECT A RETURN TO TALKS IN THE PHILIPPINES
description: Communist negotiators announced Saturday that they would not return to peace talks or extend a 60-day cease-fire that expired at noon today.

title: STRONG WOMEN, DREAMY MEN
description: HIGH GROUND By John McGahern. 156 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday about portfolio insurance misstated the current affiliations of Hayne Leland and Mark Rubinstein. They are professors of finance at the University of California, Berkeley Business School.

title: WINTER'S GLOOM? NO, WINTER'S GIFTS
description: A WINTER'S day, the stillness, the quiet all down the length of Jericho Turnpike, a feeling of bleakness as the seasons turn - to some, these bring complaints of winter's gloom; to me, they bring winter's gifts. Among these gifts is a sense of a return to another time when vast stretches of Long Island's turnpikes were empty roads leading to land that was still free of concrete, still being turned by the farmer's hand.

title: ECUMENICAL FESTIVITIES
description: Church Revival Feb. 18 - After firefighters spent five hours fighting the blaze last May at the Episcopal Church of the Ascension in Jersey City, little remained of the Gothic structure built in the 1870's. Faced with a million dollar rebuilding estimate, the church is extending its appeal for funds to Manhattan with an 8 P.M. benefit performance of ''Billy Bishop Goes to War'' at the Paul Mazur Theater at the Asphalt Green, at 90th Street and York Avenue. A backstage party follows. Tickets, $25 for first three rows, $15 for all other seats, from 201-963-8819, or at the door as available. Awards for Causes Feb. 19 - Frederick S. Gilbert, executive vice president of Citicorp Leveraged Financing, will be honored with the National Humanitarian Award from the Denver-based National Jewish Center for Immunology and Respiratory Medicine at a dinner at the Plaza. Cocktails at 6 P.M. Tickets, $350, from 212-382-0711. Feb. 20 - Secretary of the Navy John F. Lehman Jr. will receive the Distinguished Patriot Award from the Sons of the Revolution in the State of New York at the annual George Washington's Birthday Banquet starting with 7 P.M. cocktails at the Plaza. The evening benefits the Fraunces Tavern Museum. Black or white tie. Tickets, $125 for members of Sons of the Revolution, $250 for nonmembers, from 212-425-1776. Feb. 21 - Kenneth I. Chenault, executive vice president and general manager of the Platinum and Gold Card division of the American Express Company, will receive the Torch of Liberty Award from the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith at a dinner at the Marriott Marquis Hotel. Black tie. Cocktails at 7:30 P.M. Tickets, $350, from 212-490-2525, extension 416. Park Upkeep Feb. 21 - For 80 years, the Washington Square Association has been serving the Washington Square-Lower Fifth Avenue area with a variety of services, including its annual George Washington Ball. Funds are raised at the ball for the Friends of Washington Square Park, which contributes to the upkeep of the park. During the past 12 years, the association has raised more than $70,000 for the Friends of Washington Square Park. The ball, starting with cocktails at 6:30 P.M., will be at the Bobst Library of New York University at 70 Washington Square South, at La Guardia Place. Dinner and dancing follow. Dress is black tie or period costume. Tickets, $100, from 212-764-6330. Piarist Ball Feb. 21 - When a group of Roman Catholic priests founded the Piarist Order in the beginning of the 17th century, they took an additional vow beyond the traditional pledges: to provide free teaching for children. For the 35th year, the Scholarship Fund of the Piarist Schools of America is holding a Piarist Ball starting with 6:30 P.M. cocktails at the Plaza followed by a dinner-dance. Tickets, $85 or $45 for the dance alone at 9 P.M., from 212-744-8594. Cantorial Concert Feb. 23 - The School of Sacred Music of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion will present a public concert, its first since it began training cantors in 1948. The benefit for the school will honor the opera star Roberta Peters, starting with a 5:30 P.M. reception and dinner at the Seagram Building on Park Avenue at 53d Street. The concert is at 8 P.M. at the Town Hall. Tickets are $250 for reception, dinner and performance or $100, $50 or $25 for the concert alone. Call 212-674-5300. Benefit Doubleheader Feb. 27 - Founded on the Lower East Side in 1893 by the nurse Lillian D. Wald, the Henry Street Settlement has provided numerous services in its 94 years, from placing nurses in public schools at the turn of the century to its shelters for the homeless today. It is holding a benefit weekend, which begins with 7:30 P.M. cocktails at Tavern on the Green. Sponsored by Friends of the Henry Street Settlement, the junior volunteer arm of the organization, a black-tie dinner-dance follows and will include a raffle for a new BMW convertible. Tickets, $125 or $100 for those 30 and younger, from 212-472-1637 or 212-505-2848. Feb. 28 - The Henry Street Settlement Benefit Committee's party will start with 6 P.M. cocktails, which will be followed by a dinner at La Picnic Restaurant on Columbus Avenue at 62d Street. There will be an 8 P.M. opening-night performance of the New York City Opera production of Rodgers and Hammerstein's ''South Pacific.'' This is scheduled to be held at the New York State Theater. Tickets, $30 for dinner, $75, $125 or $200 for show, from 212-766-9200.

title: A Year Later, Few Clues in Tylenol Poisoning
description: One year ago today, Diane Elsroth, a 23-year-old stenographer from Peekskill, N.Y., who was staying at the Yonkers home of her boyfriend's parents, took an Extra-Strength Tylenol capsule for a headache and went to bed.

title: DATA BANK: February 8, 1987
Recent Sales
description: Bluepoint $171,500 4 Lacy Court 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 14-year-old ranch; basement, eat-in kitchen, patio, new in-ground pool, 1-car garage; taxes $2,700. Commack $177,500 58 Rensselaer Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 27-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, sunken den, 1-car garage; taxes $2,900. Lawrence $425,000 71 Washington Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 4-year-old colonial; dining room, den, breakfast room, sunken Florida room, fireplace; taxes $3,800. Lake Grove $185,000 63 Brady Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 15-year-old colonial; den, sunroom, skylights, deck, above-ground pool, 2-car garage; taxes $3,600. Mineola $305,000 74 Lincoln Avenue New legal two-family contemporary; two 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath apartments, brick-and-shingle exterior; taxes $3,800. Woodmere $269,000 986 Dartmouth Lane 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 27-year-old split-level; two dens, 2-car garage; taxes $5,700. OTHER AREAS Bridgewater, N.J. $250,075 924 Brown Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 22-year-old colonial; wall-to-wall carpeting, fenced-in yard, pool, 2-car garage; taxes $3,005. Orange, Conn. $242,500 328 Knight Lane 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 26-year-old split-level; multilevel deck, fireplace; taxes $1,779. Hartsdale, N.Y. $240,000 10 Whittier 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 43-year-old frame colonial; eat-in kitchen, family room, new roof, 1-car detached garage; taxes $3,816.

title:
THEATER;
IN PARIS, 2 PLAYS EVOKE SPIRIT OF BRECHT
description: LEAD: Thirty years after the death of Bertolt Brecht two of his most prominent heirs, Giorgio Strehler and Roger Planchon, have put a strong Brechtian stamp upon the 1986-87 Paris theater season.

title: GERMAN RUNS 35-YEAR SHOW OF TALK ON TV
description: If Werner Hofer had had his way, he would never have become the most famous television personality in West Germany.

title: Edwards to Seek 4th Term
description: Gov. Edwin Edwards, who was acquitted last year of Federal mail fraud and racketeering charges, announced Friday that he would seek a fourth term. Mr. Edwards, whose popularity in recent public oponion polls is at a record low, has already drawn at least seven opponents in the Oct. 24 open primary. The Governor told cheering supporters at a news conference here that he would continue to fight for blacks, the working class, the poor and the elderly.

title: MISS HOLMES IS BRIDE OF R. G. TASHJIAN
description: The marriage of Cynthia Nash Holmes, the daughter of Maj. Gen. Robert S. Holmes, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Holmes of San Francisco and Soda Springs, Calif., to Richard G. Tashjian, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Tashjian of Flushing, Queens, took place yesterday. The Rev. Edward Johnson, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Roman Catholic Church in Chestnut Hill, Mass.

title: India-Pakistan Crisis Eases
description: The absence of war between India and Pakistan does not mean that they are ever at peace.

title: Hudson Riverfront Dispute Is Resolved
description: TWO developers who tangled in court over access rights across an old railroad spur on the Hudson River waterfront in North Bergen, N.J., have reached a settlement.

title: NEW LONDON TV STATION BATTLES THE COMPETITORS
description: LEAD: WHEN Neil Denenberg decided five years ago that southeastern Connecticut would be a good place to start a television station, he was looking at an almost open broadcasting market. But when cameras finally began rolling six months ago, Channel 26 ventured into one of the most competitive television markets in the country.

title: TWO MAJOR PIANISTS JOIN IN SOME ELEGANT MUSIC-MAKING
description: Playing piano four hands -that is, four hands at one piano - is part of the growing up of many musicians. In earlier days, before radio, records and television, it was also an integral part of the education of every music-lover. All symphonic and chamber music was published in four-hand versions so that amateur and professional alike could become familiar with the content of the scores, Most four-hand music, aimed at the amateur as it was, did not need a virtuoso technique. The necessary requirements were, and are, musical curiosity, a love for making music and a compatible partner. How many of us, as children or young students, went through the literature - not only original four-hand music, but also arrangements of Mozart and Haydn symphonies and string quartets, Beethoven and Brahms, Bruckner and Mahler! How many amiable arguments there were! Keep out of my way, you clown! Look, I have the solo, not you, so keep that bass down! Ouch! You stabbed my pinkie! Rhythm! Rhythm! Can't you count? Playing two-piano music also is fun, but how many living rooms contain two pianos? Anyway, three recent CD disks combine four-hand and two-piano music. The disk with the two biggest pianistic names also contains two of the most famous pieces of their kind in the literature - Schubert's four-hand F minor Fantasy and Mozart's Sonata in D for two pianos (Columbia compact disk MK 39516; also LP and cassette). The pianists are Radu Lupu and Murray Perahia.

title: FOURTH DEATH REPORTED IN FIRE
description: An 8-year-old Brooklyn girl, critically injured in a fire that had claimed three lives Friday, died early yesterday at Brookdale Hospital Medical Center, Fire Department officials said.

title: EARLY ISRAELI OFFER TO CONTRAS RECALLED
description: A group of former Israeli intelligence officials approached the Central Intelligence Agency nearly five years ago and offered to supply untraceable weapons to the Nicaraguan rebels, according to a senior American official familiar with the affair.

title: Mountain Climbers in Textbook Ordeal
description: AWINTER storm, a series of bad decisions and sheer panic could have claimed the lives of two young men from Massachusetts who were climbing New Hampshire's 3,165-foot-high Mount Monadnock during the middle of last month.

title: In Israel, a Course to Calm the Savage Word
description: Last month, eight centuries after Maimonides's advice on gentle social discourse, rival politicians had a scuffle in Parliament that left one wearing a sling.

title: PASSIONATE BEHOLDER OF AMERICA IN TROUBLE
description: LOOK HOMEWARD A Life of Thomas Wolfe. By David Herbert Donald. Illustrated. 579 pp. Boston:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I guess something is changing in the Soviet Union. It may be that enough has changed so that I can live here.'' - Sergei Grigoryants, newly released from a Soviet prison. [ 10:1. ]

title: Executives Adrift
description: In this age of merger mania and cost-cutting to protect profits, more and more executives are finding themselves adrift prematurely, but few of them have the sense of self that Richard B. Elsberry displays in his article ''Set Free'' (About Men, Jan. 4).

title: LOOKING FOR LINCOLN IN THE 1980'S
description: AT the Gettysburg cemetery, the Abraham Lincoln of Gore Vidal's novel barely gets through his first sentence - about the events in America ''four score and seven years ago'' - when the young Presidential secretary, John Hay, cynically observes that such rhetoric ''will please the radicals.'' Though the national commitment to the noble notion that ''all men are created equal,'' particularly in its Civil War, black-white context, is thereby dismissed, the Gettysburg Ad-dress itself is not. In Mr. Vidal's ''Lincoln,'' it is ''a rifle salute to the dead.'' Each word is fired across the battlefield. The aim -that the ''nation might live.'' Mr. Vidal thus pledges himself to one side of the debate among historians concerning the meaning of Lincoln for our times.

title: Gorbachev Plays a 'Liberator' Game
description: DOZENS of dissidents in Soviet prisons, labor camps, psychiatric hospitals or internal exile have either been released or offered their freedom in the last two weeks. Some Western human rights groups speculate - and hope - that it is the first stage of a widespread release of prisoners.

title: THE JOYS OF THE REAL THING IN A WORLD OF THE ORDINARY
description: There are probably as many ways to experience music as there are pairs of ears to receive it.

title: NATURE'S CONTROLS ON SWAN POPULATION
description: I am responding to Shirley Becker's letter to the editor [ ''Let Nature Take Care of Swans,'' Jan. 18 ] regarding the Jan. 4 article ''Controls on Swans Proposed.'' I share her love of swans, but her conclusion to ''let nature take care of overpopulation'' may be a bit naive. Will nature be able to take care of the overpopulation? For example, man has caused an overpopulation of deer through the elimination of their natural predator, the wolf. Sadly, man often alters nature to the extent that it can no longer respond effectively to population imbalances.

title: Manhattan Valley
description: IT has drug deals going down on street corners, rats attacking mounds of garbage on side streets and dilapidated buildings almost everywhere. Yet because of its prices and location, what seems to be a neighborhood to which no one would give a backward glance has suddenly caught the attention of bargain-conscious New Yorkers as an attractive place in which to seek housing.

title: THE YOUNGEST OLD-TIMER
description: DONALD WATTS still shaves his head, and wears a thick headband on the court, making him look like the planet Saturn in sneakers. At the Dunlap Elementary School in Seattle, his name is Mr. Watts, but yesterday, for a few hours, he was Slick Watts again.

title: TESTS SEEK TO DETERMINE IF LIBERACE HAD AIDS
description: Tests conducted today on Liberace's tissue samples could not determine whether the flamboyant pianist died of AIDS, although he had been exposed to the AIDS virus, officials said.

title: SYMPHONY SAYS MOVE HURT SALES
description: THE Norwalk Symphony, forced two years ago to transfer from its home of 48 years to a building 15 minutes away, contends it has been losing money and subscribers since the move.

title: Jane E. Ezersky Becomes a Bride
description: Jane Ellen Ezersky, a real-estate counsel for CBS Inc., and Gary Lieberman, the executive vice president of Merrill Lynch Mortgage Capital Inc., were married last evening at the Harvard Club in New York by Rabbi Norman Kahan.

title: CAMPAIGN SEEKS TO HELP SLAIN WOMAN'S CHILDREN
description: LYNNE JONES was deeply shaken when she learned that Helle Crafts, a neighbor and an acquaintance, had been found murdered near her home in Newtown. Although she had not known Mrs. Crafts well, each had endured the difficulties of raising children while managing a career as a flight attendant.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: I HESITATE TO QUIBBLE over what many would consider an inconsequential lapse,'' writes Jerrold G. Weinberg of Norfolk, Va., ''but feel constrained to do so by a lawyer's compulsion for precision and a love of Kipling.''

title: IN SEARCH OF THE ISLAND'S PULSE
description: Long Island has several natural features that give it the unity and homogeneity that Sharon Honig-Bear finds lacking in ''Seeking the Pulse of the Island'' [ Opinion Page, Jan. 11 ] .

title: EFFORTS SEEK TO INCREASE NUMBER OF BLOOD DONORS IN COUNTY
description: FOUR men were honored recently for together donating a total of 45 gallons of blood over several years to the Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco. They received plaques and hospital officials spoke at a ceremony designed to mark the unusually large donations.

title: 2 NURSING HOMES FOR VETERANS
description: TEN years ago, nursing home and medical facilities for military veterans on Long Island were woefully inadequate, experts agreed. Studies showed that by 1990 the Island would have 86,000 veterans over the age of 65, the largest concentration in the state.

title: EXPERTS SAY COMPETITION WOULD STIR INNOVATION
description: By loosening restrictions on the seven regional telephone companies known as Baby Bells, industry analysts believe that last week's Justice Department proposal would encourage the development of exotic communications technologies, providing customers with a variety of new services.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: AMBITIOUS MEN: Their Drives, Dreams, and Delusions. By Srully Blotnick. (Viking, $18.95.) Srully Blotnick, a business consultant and author, writes with his numbers instead of his heart. Mr. Blotnick, whose previous books are ''The Corporate Steeplechase'' and ''Otherwise Engaged: The Private Lives of Successful Career Women,'' here analyzes successful men. He finds that in a study he conducted, ambitious men fall into four groups: the working-class man seeking autonomy, the hard-driving entrepreneur seeking respect, the accommodating service worker who wants life to be as social as possible and the creative loner interested in making something original. He idealizes these into types and shows which men are likely to succeed and how, and what their failings are likely to be. Some of his findings are interesting: few men who see business and finance as a dog-eat-dog world went on to become wealthy; the ratio of immigrants among the successful in this study was high. Mr. Blotnick found that those men who were willing to change could eliminate their weaknesses. Despite much interesting information, the author's bloodless approach mitigates his impact. He writes of men as if they existed in a vacuum, affected little by friends or family, less by women. And while carefully defining success in a material sense, it still seems surprising that the ambitious men Mr. Blotnick writes about frequently sound so much like losers.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: DINO DAYS The Yale Peabody Museum has given new meaning to ''The Three B's.'' Bach, Beethoven and Brahms will be displaced, at least from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. Thursday through next Tuesday, by baroque, bagels and brontosaurus.

title: AN UNFUNNY PREMIERE
description: THE setting is an Internal Revenue Service office.

title: MS. MCBRATNEY ENGAGED TO WED FRANKLIN WALLIN
description: Mr. and Mrs. R. Bruce McBratney of Montclair, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Carroll McBratney to Franklin Bogue Wallin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin W. Wallin Jr. of Asheville, N.C. The wedding is planned for May.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 8, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-21 Talks in Manila will not resume, Communist negotiators announced. They said they would not return to peace talks or extend a 60-day cease-fire that expires at noon today. Page 1 A Soviet decree orders the release of many political dissidents from prisons and labor camps, according to evidence from some prisoners recently set free. Dissident sources identified 42 recent releases. 1 Washington may defer a decision on whether to adopt a broader view of the 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty with the Soviet Union that would allow testing of some types of ''Star Wars'' systems, officials said. 1 Zaire is beginning to treat AIDS like any other public health menace after years of being one of Africa's most secretive countries about the disease. Surveys show that more than 100,000 adults are infected. 1 Tokyo is again reshaping itself, as it has done every two decades in this century, with potentially significant consequences at home and overseas. Its goal: to become what its Governor calls a ''world city.'' 14 Arab diplomats say Shiites seized Terry Waite, the Anglican envoy, in West Beirut 17 days ago to bring pressure on the Reagan Administration to resume deliveries of arms and military spare parts to Iran. 16 Vice President Bush was told last summer by an Israeli official that ''We are dealing with the most radical elements'' in Iran because dealings with moderates had proved unsuccessful, Donald Gregg, an aide to Mr. Bush said. Criticism of India's Prime Minister has been prompted by a flurry of personnel shifts, statements and actions taken by Rajiv Gandhi, including some related to India's latest confrontation with Pakistan. 3 Thousands of protesters in Seoul clashed with police as they gathered to mourn the death by torture of a 21-year-old student three weeks ago, despite a Government effort to block the demonstration. 3 The longest-running live talk show in television history may be West Germany's ''Der Internationale Fruhschoppen,'' which has been hosted since 1953 by Werner Hofer, a 74-year-old former radio announcer. 7 NATIONAL 24-36, 51-54 Efforts to develop a space station similar to the Soviet Union's Mir facility face uncertainty because of rising cost estimates, strained negotiations with international partners and ongoing skepticism. 1 A loss of White House confidence is evident as Ronald Reagan enters his final two years in office, according to White House insiders and Reagan supporters outside Government. 36 A surge in foreign investment has begun to curb protectionist sentiments among members of Congress whose constituents are benefiting from jobs created by foreign capital, several lawmakers believe. 30 Illegal aliens are going to Canada in substantial numbers, migrating from the United States because they are ineligible for legal status under the new immigration law. 34 Republicans raised $28 million more in campaigns for the 1986 Senate election than their Democratic opponents, but that was not a determining factor in most races, an analysis of finance reports shows. 28 A Boston police scandal is unfolding in a Federal District Court, where a former top police officer described how he and other officers stole advance copies of promotion exams and sold them. 24 A union struggle with Mack Trucks in Allentown, Pa., continues despite an agreement in which the local union made concessions in return for a guarantee that the company will stay put for six years. 24 Deaths by freezing in Philadelphia have forced residents and authorities to face the homeless issue. In the last two years, at least 43 homeless people have died from exposure or other avoidable problems. 46 Roadside plea gets a job 24 A missile museum in Arizona 30 Search for survivors halted 30 Campaign oratory is curbed 31 5 caribous imported to Maine die 52 WASHINGTON TALK 54 E.E.O.C.: Harnessing the horses on job discrimination REGIONAL 37-44, 47-48 Union officials were paid more than $100,000 to gain labor peace for Wedtech, according to former executives who have worked at the Bronx military contractor that is under investigation. 1 Andrew Cuomo will not serve any official role in a possible Presidential campaign by his father, Governor Cuomo said. Andrew Cuomo ran his father's 1982 and 1986 gubernatorial campaigns and has been his chief strategist. 40 Babies are burdening hospitals as they await placement in foster homes in New York City. Some officials say the millions of dollars that municipal and private hospitals spend on such care each year is a serious financial strain. 37 How the Board of Estimates works and makes decisions and why its meetings often go on into the night are all questions raised by a debate over a plan to replace the Coliseum at Columbus Circle. 38 A toll increase went into effect on five New York bridges and tunnels, where traffic flowed smoothly but drivers were irritated at having to pay 25 cents more. 40 Panel to study racial violence 41 School sued after a suicide 44

title: Lieut. E. P. Lozado Jr. To Wed Nicole Garris
description: Nicole Deirdre Garris, a research associate at Temple, Barker & Sloane, management consultants in Lexington, Mass., and Lieut. Eriberto Patrick Lozado Jr., U.S.M.C., plan to be married March 21.

title: Kathryn Toepfer to Wed H. R. Permut
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth H. Toepfer of Leonia, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kathryn Emelia Toepfer to Howard Roy Permut, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack G. Permut of Great Neck, L.I. A July 12 wedding is planned.

title: Miss Boyd to Wed J. W. Spink in June
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Robert J. Boyd of Weston and Chilmark, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter Sarah Catherine Boyd to James Wyatt Spink, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William O. Spink of Mount Sunapee, N.H. A June wedding is planned.

title: Whipped by Language?
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: Slips for $30,000; Sail Ho! Condo
description: For the future residents of Seaport - a condominium development planned for Toms River, N.J. - returning home won't mean fighting for a parking space, but rather hoisting the centerboard, cleating the bow line and hosing down the deck.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LEAD: GOODBYE AND HELLO When two big names in classical violin stop over at the Tilles Center this week, their appearances will signify ''goodbye'' and ''hello.'' Today, Pinchas Zukerman makes a ''farewell tour'' appearance as music director of the Saint Paul Chamber Orchestra, and on Saturday, Yehudi Menuhin introduces audiences to his Warsaw Sinfonia during its debut tour of North

title: The Istanbul Synagogue Massacre
description: Far too much is made out of shreds of circumstantial evidence in Judith Miller's article. Who is to say that the Soviet-made arms used in the terrorist attacks did not come from somewhere else, perhaps even from Israel's enormous stocks of captured Soviet-made weaponry, some of which have reportedly found their way to the Nicaraguan contras?

title: A JUNKYARD THAT'S EVER SO NEAT
description: MOST people think of junkyards as unwholesome eyesores of smashed metal, glass and rubber in such clutter that nobody could ever know where anything is, but most people are not Wayne Bunting and James Ruocco.

title: Data Update: February 8, 1987

ART;
A RETROSPECTIVE HONORS LATE ARTIST
description: LEAD: FROM the time he joined the art faculty of Dowling College in Oakdale 10 years ago, the late Anthony Giordano dreamed of establishing a gallery on the campus. His dream was realized with the inauguration last May of the college's Visual Arts Center, which houses both an exhibition space and studio facilities.

title: Deborah Ziegler To Become Bride
description: Deborah Elise Ziegler, a vice president of mortgage securities trading for Prudential-Bache Securities in New York, and Lawrence Evan Hilibrand, a managing director in the government securities department at Salomon Brothers in New York, plan to be married March 22.

title: Handily Done
description: BEAUTIFUL craftsmanship is a rare commodity these days, given the dearth of trained talent as well as the high cost of labor and materials. But when the occasional project arises in which machine-age techniques cannot possibly equal what is wrought by hand, there thankfully exists a small group of artisans carrying out their trade with the high standards that were considered commonplace generations ago.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN POP BREAKS OUT
description: When the Grammy Awards are handed out Feb. 24, Paul Simon's ''Graceland'' album will be a strong contender.

title: THE GUIDE
description: ABOUT THE CONSTITUTION Six authorities on constitutional rights will take part in a series of programs celebrating the 200th birthday of the Constitution, beginning this week at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers. Barbara Black, dean of the law faculty at Columbia University, leads off at 7 P.M. Tuesday with a discussion of ''The Constitution in United States History.''

title: WHAT MAKES HOLLYWOOD BID BIG FOR A HOT NOVEL
description: The manuscript of ''Presumed Innocent,'' which was about to become the object of one of the most frenzied bidding wars in recent Hollywood memory, arrived in Los Angeles on Nov. 6, 1986, by Federal Express. By the time Bob Bookman, a thoughtful, soft-spoken literary agent at Creative Artists Agency who was to sell the book to the movies, had unwrapped the package from New York, three teams of movie producers already had secret Xerox copies of the 640-page, unpublished first novel in their possession.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
WASTE-SITING PANEL NEEDS MORE SCOPE
description: LEAD: BACK in 1981, I joined with my legislative colleagues in supporting the creation of a special commission to make the unpopular decisions on where facilities should be constructed to dispose of hazardous waste.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE RELUCTANT EMPRESS. By Brigitte Hamann. Translated by Ruth Hein. (Knopf, $25.) In this biography of Empress Elisabeth of Austria (1837-1898), Brigitte Hamann draws from an impressive array of primary sources - including an unmined collection of the Empress's own poetry - to contrast what she calls Elisabeth's ''desperate efforts'' to express her individuality with her miserable failures as wife, mother and Empress.

title: Forecasting Prices in Manhattan
description: CAN an econometric model predict how resale prices in Manhattan residential real estate will rise or fall? The next few years will tell, because such an model has been established for the first time with data from M. J. Raynes, a large sales organization, and the help of Susan M. Wachter, an economist and associate professor of finance at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania.

title: ISSUES OF SPECIAL CONCERN
description: County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke has asked the members of the Charter Revision Study Commission to give special attention to 11 specific subjects. These are:

title: FOREIGN INVESTMENT IN U.S. MUTES TRADE DEBATE
description: A surge in foreign investment in the United States has curbed protectionist sentiments among members of Congress because constituents are increasingly benefiting from more than 2.5 million jobs created by foreign capital, in the view of several lawmakers.

title: THE ROAD TO FOTHERINGHAY
description: LEAD: Four hundred years ago, on Feb. 8, 1587, was enacted that last tragic scene, when Mary Stuart's head fell to the executioner, and the reverberations of the act have gone on ever since. Not only in history and biography, but also in the arts and letters, in novels, poems, plays, in opera as well as in paintings and depictions and in films.

title:
A SPECIAL GUIDE TO CRUISES WORLDWIDE;
Down to the Seas in Ships
description: LEAD: The Mediterranean is slowly recovering from the slump of the 1986 season, when travelers stayed away because of fear of terrorism.

title: BURNING OF HOSPITALS' WASTE IRKS NEIGHBORS
description: LEAD: For the last five years, laboratories and nursing homes in New York City, barred from burning their waste material in the city, have been quietly shipping tons of infectious waste to Long Island for disposal. The daily loads are burned here or transferred by private commercial operators to incineration sites in upstate New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and

title: Mattingly-Rice I
description: To the Sports Editor: Don Mattingly is a great baseball player, clearly the dominant figure in his sport and surely worth $2 million of George Steinbrenner's money. But let's not get carried away.

title: 'ME AND MY GIRL' ON DISK CAPTURES GIDDY LILT OF SHOW
description: Since it opened on Broadway last August, ''Me and My Girl'' has consistently effervesced at the box office to the tune of more than half a million dollars a week. And the original Broadway cast album (MCA 6196; LP, cassette, compact disk) captures as much of the giddy lilt as a record could reasonably hope to extract from the champagne of nostalgia musicals.

title: DRIVERS IRKED BY TOLL RISE AT 5 BRIDGES AND TUNNELS
description: Traffic flowed smoothly but drivers were irritated after a 25-cent toll increase went into effect yesterday on five New York bridges and tunnels.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: SENATOR Bill Bradley has introduced legislation that would provide $26.2 million to the Pinelands Commission to complete its land-acquisition program and build a Visitors Center.

title: Correction
description: Because of a production error, the Practical Traveler column in some copies of the Travel section today omitted a passage beneath the drawing. Readers wishing copies of the correct page may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: A TRIBUTE OF SEVEN NATIONS MARKS THE CHAGALL CENTENNIAL
description: Aseven-nation omnibus issue arranged by the Intergovernmental Philatelic Corporation of New York leads off what is expected to be a large-scale program to mark the Chagall centennial year. Marc Chagall, the famed artist who spent most of his life in France, was born 100 years ago on July 7 in Vitebsk, Russia.

title: GUARDING THE PLAYWRIGHT'S VISION
description: To the Editor:

title: BLENDS FORM ITALY AND JAPAN
description: ALESSANDRO MENDINI, an Italian architect and editor, and Sinya Okayama, a Japanese designer, worked together when they had furniture exhibitions in Milan and Tokyo in 1984 and 1985. They got along well and had similar design ideas, and that led them to a more ambitious intercontinental collaboration: the design of a series of six objects.

title: Repay College Loans With Income Surtax
description: To the Editor:

title: HOYAS HOLD OFF VILLANOVA
description: Reggie Williams scored 21 points and led a second-half surge that carried Georgetown to an 89-86 victory over Villanova today in a Big East Conference game.

title: PAYOFFS TO UNION TIED TO WEDTECH
description: Former Wedtech executives have told Federal prosecutors that, in addition to bribing government officials, they paid more than $100,000 to union officers to gain labor peace for the company, according to prosecutors and other lawyers familiar with the case.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
Office Development Bustling in Islandia
description: LEAD: AS its second birthday approaches, the Village of Islandia is becoming a thriving center of development of prime office and hotel space.

title: HOT AND BOTHERED IN PARIS AND LONDON
description: PALAIS-ROYAL By Richard Sennett. 274 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: New Directions for Old Railroad Stations
description: AMONG the warmer memories many people harbor from childhood are the sights and sounds of their local railroad - waiting on a platform for a special visitor to arrive, the wistful wail of the whistle as an express rumbles through in the night.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE GREAT EQUALIZER. By Rick Borsten. (Permanent Press, $18.95.) When we meet Benny Horowitz, the narrator of Rick Borsten's first novel, he is the midst of a crisis, asking ''What is the meaning of life?'' The reader pretty much knows what to expect, because immediately upon dropping out of college Benny lands a job in ARC House, a residence for mentally retarded adults.

title: EX-POLICEMAN TELLS OF BOSTON TEST THEFTS
description: Appearing relaxed and almost boastful, a former senior police officer has described in Federal District Court here how he and other officers systematically stole advance copies of civil service promotion examinations and sold them to friends over a six-year period.

title: WHAT COURTS SHOULD DO: 1905 DEBATE
description: The case was limited, but Lochner v. New York, the Supreme Court's 1905 decision invalidating a restriction on bakery working hours, remains a symbol of its age. The dissenters in Lochner, and similar cases that followed, eventually prevailed. Excerpts follow.

title: Art
description: Just a week remains in which to see the exhibition of oils, watercolors and drawings by Oskar Kokoschka (1886-1980) at the Guggenheim Museum. Just before World War I, Kokoschka was one of the most conspicuous young artists in the Vienna that has lately become so fashionable. In Dresden, between 1917 and 1923, he painted landscapes and figure subjects that are among the glories of German art. As a portraitist, he excelled with everyone from the composer Arnold Schoenberg to Fred Astaire's sister Adele, and from Thomas Masaryk, first president of Czechoslovakia, to Agatha Christie. After World War II, when other artists spurned the classic subjects of European humanism, he tackled them on the grand scale, with only an occasional garrulity. As a writer, he was dramatist, storyteller and autobiographer and excelled at all three.

title: ST. PETER'S DEFEATS HOLY CROSS BY 69-66
description: Tommy Berry scored a game-high 19 points to pace St. Peter's to a 69-66 Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference victory over Holy Cross today.

title: DO YOU LIKE THE COLLEGE 3-POINT BASKET?
description: I believe the new 3-point basket could be the beginning of a new and exciting stratagem in collegiate basketball, which if interpolated, could have a major impact on the game in general and the last five minutes of play in particular.

title: GUNMEN IN BEIRUT SEIZE BUSINESSMAN
description: The police said today that a Lebanese-born businessman believed to be an American citizen had been kidnapped by gunmen who might be holding him for ransom. But relatives said that he had been freed and that he was a Lebanese citizen only.

title: IN CONTEST FOR INDUSTRY, INDIANA SCORES
description: FOR decades, as a conservative foothold in the industrial Midwest, Indiana relied on low tax rates and a laissez-faire tradition to lure and keep businesses. But in the recession of the early 1980's, unemployment rose, productivity declined and a series of plants closed, stunning a state that had seemed immune to such troubles.

title: INSIDE
description: A Loss of Confidence The confidence that characterized the Reagan White House in its first six years is fading, some close to the Administration say. Page 36.

title: Amy Zinsser Plans to Wed
description: The engagement of Amy Fraser Zinsser and Robert Ferreira has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Knowlton Zinsser of New York and Old Black Point, Conn. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Anthony Ferreira of Seekonk, Mass., and Jamestown, R.I.

title: THE HOMELESS INSPIRE GIFTS TO NEEDIEST
description: The daily sight of the homeless in Grand Central Terminal stirred Jack Taylor of Norwalk, Conn., to contribute to The New York Times Neediest Cases fund.

title: Ambitions Rise With Skill in Battle and in Arms Deals
description: A COMMANDER of Iran's Revolutionary Guards climbed to the top of an earthen embankment and pointed toward the front lines where his troops were fighting just a few miles from Basra, Iraq's second largest city. ''Our objective is not to take Basra or Baghdad,'' he told a group of foreign journalists. Speaking calmly and with absolute assurance, he insisted that his forces' goal was to ''liberate'' Karbala, a holy city in central Iraq, and Al-Quds, as Jerusalem is known to Moslems.

title: CAMPAIGN ORATORY CURBED IN CHICAGO
description: Every day the major candidates for Mayor of the nation's third-largest city crisscross this sprawling place seeking votes in the forthcoming primary election.

title: ON THE RUN WITH THE 'MONSTER OF MONATMARTRE'
description: LEAD: THE EXILE OF CELINE By Tom Clark. 214 pp. New York: Random House. $16.95.

title: U.S. PRESSES INDIA TO SEEK BEIRUT HOSTAGE'S RELEASE
description: With few options of its own in the Lebanon hostage situation, the United States is quietly pressing India to seek help from Syria and Iran in at least freeing the one captive who is Indian, American and Indian officials say.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: UNEMPLOYMENT MUST BE ATTACKED;
An Austerity That's Wrecking Europe
description: LEAD: IN recent weeks, we have seen the West German Bundesbank reduce interest rates by half a percentage point - but only with the gun of a strongly depreciating American dollar held to its head. Even now, after five years of disinflation, Germany and other Western European nations stubbornly refuse to adopt the obvious and seemingly attractive course of monetary and fiscal stimulus.

title:
GARDENING;
SOIL PESTS STUNT GROWTH OF YOUNG TREES
description: LEAD: HORTICULTURISTS have long been aware of the difficulty of replacing certain kinds of trees with young trees of the same species, especially apple trees.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: LEAD: SOME AMERICAN MEN, by Gloria Emerson. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $8.95.) In more than a dozen essay-profiles, the former New York Times reporter Gloria Emerson portrays what it's like to be male in America at a time when there are few certainties, and roles, identities and emotions are no longer clear-cut.

title: 300 MARCH AT BROOKLYN PRECINCT
description: More than 300 demonstrators chanting ''79th Precinct, Undercover Crack-house,'' marched yesterday from a junior high school in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn to the 79th Precinct station house to protest what they said was police collusion with drug dealers.

title: Headliners; New Blood
description: As some in Washington see it, the newly designated chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, Dennis R. Patrick, might be a sort of re-run of his predecessor, Mark S. Fowler. Like Mr. Fowler, Mr. Patrick, whose appointment President Reagan announced last week, is a firm suppporter of deregulation of the broadcast industry. ''He is really an ideological relative of Mark Fowler,'' said Representative Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat involved in telecommunications issues. ''It's hard to see any substantive difference on issues.'' The 35-year-old Mr. Patrick, who has been a member of the F.C.C. since 1983, was described by an aide as one ''who believes that the commission should stay out of programming.'' As a sitting commissioner, Mr. Patrick can be named chairman without Senate confirmation.

title: Recorded Threats At Baby M Trial
description: The fight over who gets to keep Baby M took a poignant turn last week when a New Jersey court heard a recording in which Mary Beth Whitehead, the surrogate mother, threatened to kill herself and the child.

title: CICADAS PROMISE NOISY SPRING
description: The Northeast will buzz this spring when billions of small insects, commonly and erroneously called locusts, emerge from the ground to mate after 17 years of prolonged youth.

title: SUCKERS FOR ELECTIONS
description: THE CAPTIVE PUBLIC How Mass Opinion Promotes State Power. By Benjamin Ginsberg. 272 pp. New York: Basic Books. $18.95.

title: Smoking
description: To the Editor: Frederick Thayer [ Letters, Jan. 18 ] says that when the Environmental Protection Agency and the Surgeon General join hands to argue that environmental tobacco smoke is a danger to non-smokers, the public should suspect a conspiracy. A more normal reaction would be to have increased confidence in the assertion that passive smoking is a major health hazard.

title: Franchising the Reagan Doctrine
description: Day by day, the news exposes a deep and dangerous dimension to the Iran-contra crisis: privatized diplomacy.

title: BEYOND THE PALE WITH EDGAR ALLAN POE
description: ANYONE aware of the difficulties of Edgar Allan Poe's life must wish to see his reputation prosper. Yet he alone among the Immortals calls up the sort of smirk otherwise reserved for writers who are not only living but also local. Anyone who confesses an admiration for Poe learns quickly that he is not respectable, because he set out to create powerful responses in his readers by methods already conventional when he used them. Such manipulation is not honest dealing. Poe seemed to know it himself, and wrote satires and hoaxes and at his darkest skirted so near parody that it is impossible to know when he was in earnest. For us there is an atmosphere of charlatanism about him, of insinuation, of febrile eagerness to have one's ear. When we cease to be entranced we are embarrassed that we were taken in.

title: Philadelphia Hospital Plan
description: The Navy has proposed closing the 52-year-old Philadelphia Naval Hospital, said two members of Pennsylvania's Congressional delegation, Senator John Heinz and Representative Thomas M. Foglietta. Under a Navy plan, the hospital, which employs 600 enlisted personnel and 230 civilians, would be eliminated over six months. The lawmakers said they did not know what the Navy intended to do with the site.

title: EDINBURGH OFF SEASON
description: Waking early on a winter morning in Edinburgh, you may see stone pavements glistening under street lamps as cars and red double-deckers rumble along Princes Street, Princes Street's gardens a watery green despite overcoat weather. If it's clear, the moon may hang full in an inky sky, paper white in contrast to the yellow headlights playing on the fronts of buildings. As you drink coffee, the moon sets, the lights go off, the sky brightens and day begins - several hours into morning.

title: CHURNS FOR THE BETTER
description: THE THREE ALMOST identical-looking morsels of cream-white cheese are laid out side by side on the counter, surrounded by a dazzling display of cheeses from all over the world. ''But how can you say that West Coast stuff has a rounder, nuttier flavor?'' asks Steven Jenkins, the cheese evangelist of New York City's Fairway Fruits and Vegetables, his voice riper than Limburger with scorn and disbelief. He is attempting to convince me that his favorite American farm-made, aged goat cheese, from sophisticated, high-tech Coach Farm, in Pine Plains, N.Y., is better than my favorite, from the much smaller free-range Yerba Santa Goat Dairy, in Lakeport, Calif.

title: DEAR DON WALACIO
description: SECRETARIES OF THE MOON The Letters of Wallace Stevens & Jose Rodriguez Feo. Edited by Beverly Coyle and Alan Filreis. Illustrated. 210 pp. Durham, N.C.: Duke University Press. $19.95.

title: Bringing Back The Waterfront
description: SPURRED by the success of waterfront redevelopment projects in larger urban areas, this small city is undertaking its own large-scale waterfront project.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Lindbergh Anniversary, Maritime Exhibition
description: Nonstop Flight Recalled on Two Continents

title: James Normile, A Lawyer, Weds Dore Hammond
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York yesterday Dorita Hammond, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. B. Clinton Hammond Jr. of Garden City, L.I., was married to James Sheehy Normile, a son of Margaret Sheehy Normile of Hampton Bays, L.I., and Clearwater, Fla., and the late Daniel Francis Normile. The Rev. Harry G. Schlitt performed the ceremony.

title: SPACE STATION: COSTS AND ALLIES' ROLE RAISE DOUBTS
description: As the Soviet Union prepares to reactivate and enlarge its Mir space station, American efforts to develop a similar station face an uncertain future.

title: A LOT BETTER THAN A WAR
description: THE BERLIN WALL Kennedy, Khrushchev, and a Showdown in the Heart of Europe. By Norman Gelb. Illustrated. 321 pp. New York: Times Books. $19.95.

title: AMERICAN MUSIC FOR PIANO IS FOCUS IN RECENT DISKS
description: One of the three or four most satisfying piano recitals to come this critic's way in the last few seasons was Peter Serkin's at the 92d St. Y, and now the best parts of it are represented on a new recording for New World Records (NW 344). Those are the knotty, intense Passacaglia (1936) of Stefan Wolpe, a work of steadily accumulating power; two clean-lined and inevitable sounding Stravinsky performances, and an engaging new three-part work by Peter Lieberson called ''Bagatelles.''

title: Son-in-Law of Brezhnev Held
description: History, as written by the current leadership of the Soviet Union, is not being kind to Leonid I. Brezhnev, who led the country for 18 years.

title: 11TH-HOUR RESCUE OF A SCULPTURE
description: WORKERS had but six bolts to get out to move an eight-ton bronze sculpture by Henry Moore from a downtown Seattle plaza, but a day before they were to begin, the city ordered the work halted. The Department of Construction and Land Use, invoking a technicality last August, said a demolition permit was needed.

title: The Rewards of Buying Frequent-Flier Awards
description: If you telephone American Airlines and buy a round-trip ticket from New York to Honolulu, it will cost at least $598. At that rock-bottom rate, you would have to make your reservations and pay for your ticket at least 21 days before departure, you could travel only on a Tuesday or Wednesday and you could not make any stopovers on the way. For only $300 more, however, you could go first class, stop over on the West Coast and, in Hawaii, get discounts on hotel and car-rental rates.

title: Taking a Nice Cake on the Iran Mission
description: To the Editor:

title: Recent Sales
description: Branchburg $191,900 17 Maple Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 65-year-old colonial; hardwood floors, 2-level rear deck, wood-burning stove; taxes $1,800. Bridgewater $250,075 924 Brown Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 22-year-old colonial; wall-to-wall carpeting, fenced-in yard, pool, 2-car garage; taxes $3,005. Hillsborough $138,900 299-1C Gemini Drive 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 2-year-old condominium town house; patio, fireplace, loft; maintenance $100, taxes $1,902. Randolph $284,900 10 Meadowbrook Road 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 19-year-old expanded ranch; fireplace in family room, eat-in kitchen, 2-car garage; taxes $3,775. West Orange $143,000 58 Forest Hill Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 52-year-old colonial; porch, formal dining room; taxes $2,495. OTHER AREAS Mineola, L.I. $305,000 74 Lincoln Avenue New legal two-family contemporary; two 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath apartments, brick and shingle exterior; taxes $3,800. Orange, Conn. $242,500 328 Knight Lane 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 26-year-old split-level; multilevel deck, fireplace; taxes $1,779. Hartsdale, N.Y. $240,000 10 Whittier 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 43-year-old frame colonial; eat-in kitchen, family room, new roof, 1-car detached garage; taxes $3,816.

title: GATES FINDS C.I.A. BESET BY PROBLEMS
description: SOME agencies in this city gain prominence because of what they do, others because of whom their leaders know. In the last six years, under William J. Casey, President Reagan's close friend, the Central Intelligence Agency achieved new influence for both reasons. But that very power has contributed to a long list of potentially difficult problems that his newly nominated successor must face - without the benefit of Mr. Casey's clout.

title: Q and A
description: Caribbean Resorts Question: Can you suggest a family resort in the Caribbean with a reasonable price in winter that includes two meals and water sports and on an island with direct flights from New York? - L. K., Larchmont, N.Y. Answer: Many resorts meet these requirements, but the search can be narrrowed somewhat by referring not to direct but to nonstop flights. Direct merely means that there is no change of planes. Another point to remember is that the less luxurious resorts usually charge for the use of some water-sports equipment.

title: SURROUNDED BY SMALL HEARTS
description: HOTEL SAVOY Fallmerayer the Stationmaster. The Bust of the Emperor. By Joseph Roth. Translated by John Hoare. 183 pp. Woodstock, N.Y.: The Overlook Press. $16.95.

title: WHO WEARS THE LEASH?
description: MY DOG TULIP By J. R. Ackerley. 160 pp. New York: Poseidon Press. Paper, $7.95.

title: PITT WINS AS FRIARS' OUTSIDE GAME FAILS
description: Much has been made of Providence's use of the 3-point shot. But this afternoon, Pitt showed the Friars a thing or two about scoring 3 points the old-fashioned way, with muscle.

title: HAVOC AT THE 19TH HOLE
description: STRANGERS IN PARADISE By Lee K. Abbott. 255 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $18.95.

title: IN SHORT: NON-FICTION
description: LEAD: THE IMMORTAL WILDERNESS. By John Hay. (Norton, $14.95.) ''The wise man wonders at the usual,''

title: New Proposal on Pension Plans
description: On the question of just whose money is in an employee pension plan, the Reagan Administration has a decided view, the details of which became known last week.

title: School Gets New President
description: Linda Koch Lorimer, associate provost at Yale University, was named today as the first woman to be president of Randolph-Macon Woman's College in Lynchburg, Va.

title: Contra Political Chief Will Quit Triumvirate
description: Arturo Jose Cruz, a key political leader of the Nicaraguan rebels, has confirmed that he is resigning because of dissatisfaction with other rebel leaders.

title: NEW ALBION: NEW LABEL FOR NEW MUSIC
description: As most major record companies continue to shrink away from even a token commitment to contemporary music, we must rely increasingly on smaller labels to document the sounds of our time. There is Composers Recordings Incorporated, of course - or CRI, as it is customarily abbreviated - at 170 West 74th Street, New York, N.Y. 10023, a worthy and highly serious organization that is now 30 years old. More recently, there has been the New Music Distribution Service (500 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10012), which encourages composers and artists to make their own records, and carries some 3,000 different disks on more than 400 labels.

title: APPELLATE RULING CALLED VICTORY FOR THE HOMELESS
description: LEAD: A COURT ruling last Tuesday, hailed as a victory for the homeless, could affect thousands of families seeking shelter or on the verge of being evicted.

title: THE SINGLE IS COMING INTO HIS/HER OWN
description: ''WESTCHESTER male - 39. Professional, enjoys tennis, reading, seeks bright, compatible female early 30's.''

title: ANTIOCH TEETERING ON PERILOUS EDGE
description: ''Question Authority,'' the command of an irreverent, red-lettered bumper sticker from other days, is securely stuck to the front wall of the largest classroom at the Antioch Law School here, too high over the gritty, paint-peeled lecture hall to be removed without a ladder.

title: DEFINING GOOD DESIGN
description: To the Editor:

title: TOWN PRESSED BY GROWTH SEEKS TO CLING TO ITS PAST
description: LEAD: ON A WALL near the entrance to the historic Red Mill here are the words, ''Every Man Shall Learn From the Past.'' And it is to the vestiges of its past that this rural community of 2,016 in central Hunterdon County clings as it tries to cope with and adapt to the growth around it.

title: Employers Caught in a Pension Plan Squeeze
description: To the Editor:

title: Traci A. Conway, Actress, to Marry
description: The engagement of Traci Ann Conway to Matthew Adams Clinton has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. James J. Conway Jr. of Manhasset and Quogue, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Y. Clinton of Bryn Mawr, Pa. A June wedding is planned.

title: ELIZABETH GARRELS TO WED C. A. CHILDS
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Gwynn Anderson of Englewood, N.J., and Sunset, Me., have announced the engagement of her daughter, Elizabeth Longworth Garrels, to Christopher Alcorn Childs, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Blair Childs Jr. of Suffield, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: THE QUESTION OF CONDOM ADS
description: Should television carry advertisements for condoms? The question is part of a growing debate. In a recent speech in Washington, Dr. Otis R. Bowen, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said that a worldwide AIDS epidemic in the next 10 years would be more devastating than the Black Plague. Meanwhile, there are heated discussions over sex education. Virtually everyone agrees that something is wrong; there is still no unanimity on how to handle the problem. The discussion centers on AIDS, but worries about other sexually transmitted diseases, teen-age pregnancies and matters of religion and morality arise, too. Inevitably, television is drawn into the discussion. It is seen, as always, as both a cause and a cure for the problem. Television, its critics say, merchandises easy sex and encourages promiscuity; if television presents advertisements for contraceptives, some also say, it could help repair the damage.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
MODERNITY IN A ROMANTIC LENS
description: LEAD: A striking photographic portrait of the Irish poet William Butler Yeats is one of the first things a visitor sees on entering Alvin Langdon Coburn's retrospective exhibition at the International Center of Photography. The poet is still young - dark hair, unlined face - and the style and mood of the picture, its rich, smoky atmosphere, its intense seriousness, immediately place it in the decade preceding World War I.

title: WORK STARTS ON CLEAN-AIR BILL
description: LEAD: CONGRESSIONAL subcommittees are beginning work on several bills that would represent the first major amendments to the former Clean Air Act since the 1970's.

title: MUSIC: PHILHARMONIC IN WORK BY MATTHUS
description: THE novelty on the New York Philharmonic's current program, which this listener heard Friday afternoon, was a concerto for orchestra by the East German composer Siegfried Matthus. Entitled ''Die Windsbraut'' (The Bride of the Wind), this 15-minute piece in four movements played without pause belongs to a genre of symphonic work that might be described, not without honor, as ''weather music.''

title: Lisa Ann Haas Weds Dr. Hal Stuart Wasserman
description: Lisa Ann Haas, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andre Haas of Park Ridge, N.J., was married last night to Dr. Hal Stuart Wasserman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Wasserman of Springfield, N.J. Jean F. Kotkin of the American Ethical Union in New York performed the ceremony at the Hilton Inn in Woodcliff Lake, N.J.

title: The Eternal Race For Tourist Cash
description: EVERY year the pursuit of tourist dollars leads to imaginative planning in communities across America.

title: COPING WITH THE NEXT CALAMITY
description: LAST month was crisis time again in Gotham. The Long Island Rail Road went on strike, just in time for the severe snowstorm to hit, which, of course, meant the airports closed and highway traffic snarled.

title: READING FOR FAITH
description: To the Editor:

title: Comings and Goings
description: THE 1958 Heisman Trophy winner, Pete Dawkins, will be the principal speaker at the Jesse Owens Trophy Awards dinner in New York Feb. 24. . . . Vincent dePaul Draddy, the chairman of the National Football Foundation's College Football Hall of Fame said that three deceased players had been elected to the hall. They are Mike McKeever, who played guard with his twin brother, Marlin, for Southern Cal from 1958 to 1960 and died in 1967, two years after an auto accident; Bob Westfall, a Michigan tailback from 1940 to 1942, and Tommy Yarr, a Notre Dame center from 1929 to 1931.

title: UCONN PASSES ON PUPPETRY'S TECHNIQUES AND TRADITION
description: LEAD: IN the spotless laboratories of the University of Connecticut's College of Agriculture, students learn that good results come from unemotional adherence to the laws of nature. But a short distance away, in the dusty and poorly lighted dormitory basement where Prof. Frank Ballard operates his puppet laboratory, success often arises out of the gleeful defiance of natural laws.

title: The President Makers
description: We were sitting around the table after a fine stout lunch, a bunch of us - a couple of Marios, four Bobs, Sam, old George of course, Elizabeth, one Howard and a fellow nobody had expected to be there, Dale.

title: MUSHROOM FARM REVIVED
description: WHEN the Ralston Purina Corporation sold its mushroom farm in Franklin four years ago, it said it was getting out of the business because the Northeast market was oversupplied.

title: TEEN-AGERS IN ATLANTA TOLD OF 'TERRORIST RAID'
description: Plans to stage a mock surprise attack on a group of Jewish teen-agers to dramatize the dangers of terrorism were discarded Friday after objections by parents and the Israeli Consulate to surprising the children.

title: PLANT EXCULPATED IN ILLNESSES
description: LEAD: THE Nassau County Department of Health's environmental health director, Frank Padar, said his office has completed a $500,000 study of the Old Bethpage grade school showing that emissions from a plant incinerating infectious waste eight-tenths of a mile from the site were not responsible for a number of student illnesses in September and October 1985.

title: MISS DE MAYO ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore J. Grieco of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their granddaughter Christine Ann de Mayo to David Edouard Wagner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin J. Wagner of Raleigh, N.C.

title: ROADSIDE PLEA WINS A JOB
description: An unemployed construction worker hit the road to get a job, standing nearly three hours in the safety zone of one of America's busiest expressways holding a sign that read: ''Family Man Needs Job.'' It worked. ''I'm just a regular guy trying to live the American dream and have a job,'' the man, Art Fosle, said Friday night in a telephone interview from his home in Sauk Village, a Chicago suburb.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate 1. Speed Limit: Vote on an amendment to a highway bill that would raise the speed limit on rural interstate highways to 65 miles an hour. Approved 65 to 33, Feb. 3. 2. Billboards: Vote to kill an amendment to a highway bill that would prohibit new billboards in rural areas and limit their size in urban areas. (The amendment was less restrictive than an across-the-board ban approved by the Senate last year.) Approved 57 to 40, Feb. 3. 3. Clean Water Bill: Vote to override President Reagan's veto of a $20 billion bill to clean up the nation's water. (A two-thirds majority in each house was necessary to override the veto.) Approved 86 to 14, Feb. 4. 1 2 3 CONNECTICUT Dodd (D) Y Y Y Weicker (R) N Y Y DELAWARE Roth (R) N N Y Biden (D) Y N Y MARYLAND Mikulski (D) N Y Y Sarbanes (D) N N Y MASSACHUSETTS Kennedy (D) Y N Y Kerry (D) Y N Y NEW JERSEY Bradley (D) N N Y Lautenberg (D) N N Y NEW YORK D'Amato (R) N Y Y Moynihan (D) N N Y PENNSYLVANIA Heinz (R) N N Y Specter (R) N Y Y RHODE ISLAND Pell (D) N N Y Chafee (R) N N Y VIRGINIA Trible (R) N Y Y Warner (R) N N Y HOUSE 1. Horton (R) Y 30. Slaughter (D) Y 31. Kemp (R) N 32. LaFalce (D) Y 33. Nowak (D) Y 34. Houghton (R) Y PENNSYLVANIA 1. Foglietta (D) Y 2. Gray (D) Y 3. Borski (D) Y 4. Kolter (D) Y 5. Schulze (R) Y 6. Yatron (D) Y 7. Weldon (R) Y 8. Kostmayer (D) Y 9. Shuster (R) Y 10. McDade (R) A 11. Kanjorski (D) Y 12. Murtha (D) Y 13. Coughlin (R) Y 14. Coyne (D) Y 15. Ritter (R) Y 16. Walker (R) Y 17. Gekas (R) Y 18. Walgren (D) Y 19. Goodling (R) Y 20. Gaydos (D) Y 21. Ridge (R) Y 22. Murphy (D) Y 23. Clinger (R) A RHODE ISLAND 1. St Germain (D) Y 2. Schneider (R) Y VIRGINIA 1. Bateman (R) Y 2. Pickett (D) Y 3. Bliley (R) Y 4. Sisisky (D) Y 5. Daniel (D) Y 6. Olin (D) Y 7. Slaughter (R) Y 8. Parris (R) Y 9. Boucher (D) Y 10. Wolf (R) Y KEY: Y - Yea; N - Nay; (A) Absent or did not vote; (P) Present.

title: U.S. ARMS EXPORTS DIP IN THE THIRD WORLD
description: AMERICAN weapons manufacturers may be losing their competitive edge in global markets just when the prolonged Reagan military buildup has put their domestic business at a peak.

title: 7-11 STORE STIRS DEBATE ON GROWTH IN SAG HARBOR
description: LEAD: A 7-ELEVEN store is a common feature in many Long Island communities. But in Sag Harbor, the establishment of a second 7-Eleven on the South Fork has met stiff resistance from residents.

title: Dorothy C. Ames Planning to Wed John Cummings
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Joseph Ames of Rye, N.Y., and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Dorothy Christine Ames to John William Cummings, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Thomas Cummings of Stamford, Conn., and Indian Rocks Beach, Fla. An August wedding is planned.

title: Cheaper Help does Better in Jay Bullpen
description: IN the space of seven weeks two winters ago, the Toronto Blue Jays solved their glaring bullpen problem. Or so they thought. They staged a successful foray into the Bay Area and snatched Bill Caudill, right-hander, from the Oakland A's and Gary Lavelle, left-hander, from the San Francisco Giants. Envisioning relief security for years to come, they committed themselves to spending a possible $9.8 million in salaries for the two established pitchers in the next five years.

title:
ART;
ENERGETIC WORK ADDS SPARKLE TO A DIVERSIFIED GROUP SHOW
description: LEAD: WHEN artists form a cooperative gallery, the chief incentive is the opportunity for fully revealing solo showings. From time to time, however, an exhibition of the membership as a whole allows the gallery to make a statement about its quality and often its philosophy as well.

title: CHANGES PLANNED IN TREATING YOUTHS
description: LEAD: THE Adolescent Unit at Trenton Psychiatric Hospital is scheduled to be closed within two years as part of a state plan to restructure psychiatric services for children.

title: Science On the Track of God
description: The concept of scientific inquiry as a path toward knowledge of God is intriguing, if not new. Thomas Paine put forth the idea some 200 years ago in concluding his pamphlet ''The Age of Reason.'' Even he may not have been the first to do so. More interesting yet is Mr. Gleick's attention to the issue of elegant mathematics and great musical works - i.e. are they created or discovered?

title: Miss Capellini Weds James G. Costello 3d
description: Jane Marie Capellini, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Capellini of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to James G. Costello 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Costello of New City, N.Y. The Rev. D. Michael Flynn performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: ON CAMPAIGN FINANCING
description: With political campaigns becoming ever more expensive and political action committees proliferating, the current Congress may now be willing to give serious consideration to extending public campaign financing to the Congressional level.

title: RESIDENTS OPPOSE CONDOMINIUM PLAN
description: THE town of Greenburgh made an unusual proposal last summer - to switch two-thirds of its commercial zoning on 450 acres at 15 sites to residential use. It would do this in the hope of gaining some moderate-priced housing instead of more offices and hotels.

title: PERFORMING-ARTS CENTER IS PLANNED FOR BOSTON
description: Boston's depressed theater district, where pornographic movie houses outnumber cultural outlets and show tickets are sold from a dilapidated trailer, will be transformed into a busy center of dance, music and theater within the next five years, city officials say.

title: STUDENT PARKING ON GREAT NECK
description: The article about the problems that Great Neck North High School students have in finding parking spaces for their Mercedeses, Saab turbo convertibles and other sports cars distresses me greatly. Other world problems - hunger, the Middle East conflict, arms control, etc. - are really rendered pale by comparison.

title: THE EXAMINED LIFE
description: HALFWAY TO HEAVEN The Hidden Life of the Sublime Carthusians. By Robin Bruce Lockhart. Illustrated. 153 pp. New York: The Vanguard Press. $14.95.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE DUCK AT THE DOOR FROM the outside, Susan Rosenberg's home in Merrick looks like many suburban split-levels. But when you knock on the glass storm door and a quacking black duck waddles toward you in greeting, it's obvious that all is not exactly as it seems.

title: HIDDEN DUMP SITES SOUGHT
description: LEAD: SUFFOLK COUNTY and Cornell University have combined on a program that county officials believe will enable experts to locate former dump sites that may be leaking contaminants into the ground water. Many of these sites were formed illegally in the 1940's and 50's, and officials are concerned that some of them may have gone unnoticed by builders.

title: Sam Nunn's Rising Star
description: Phil Gailey says that Sam Nunn ''is so serious, in fact, that when playing Trivial Pursuit with his 20-year-old daughter, Michelle, he has even been known to question the answers on the game cards'' (''Sam Nunn's Rising Star,'' Jan. 4).

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE REGULATION OF SEXUALITY: Experiences of Family Planning Workers. By Carole Joffe. (Temple University, $24.95.) During a yearlong observation of a private, nonprofit family planning clinic, Carole Joffe discovered that ''front-line'' birth control and abortion counselors play a pivotal and largely unacknowledged role in the regulation of sexual behavior.

title: POSTINGS: Showcase for 96th; Restoring a Gem
description: Everything about the mansion built in 1915 for Lucy D. Dahlgren at 15 East 96th Street is decorative - from the Beaux Arts-style facade, replete with carved swags and an intricate wrought-iron balcony, to the grand marble staircase and octagonal dining room with two marble fountains.

title: The Outside View of Inside Trading
description: LEAD: The prosecution of prominent individuals trading on inside information, and the imposition of the largest fines in the history of the Securities and Exchange Commission, dominated the financial news in late 1986. This year promises to be no different: even now, Wall Street is nervously awaiting the next round of indictments.

title: INMATES IN SOLITARY SUE MASSCHUSETTS ON RIGHTS
description: Prisoners who have been kept in solitary confinement for days and sometimes years have sued the state for violating their civil rights.

title: Archeologists Comb an Ancient Villa in Italy
description: After 222 years, archeologists have again entered the Villa of the Papyri at Herculaneum, dreaming that it holds undiscovered treasures.

title: The Istanbul Synagogue Massacre
description: There was one relevant fact that caught my attention precisely because it didn't appear in Judith Miller's article: if Ankara knew of Iran's probable involvement in the attack on the synagogue, then United States Government agencies knew, and if Washington knew, then Jerusalem also knew.

title: ON TEACHING READING: MYTHS AND REALITY
description: The article ''Taking a Different Approach on Reading'' [ Jan. 4 ] contained a statement that unfortunately continues a widely held myth about reading instruction.

title: RACIAL BIAS PANEL NAMED BY CUOMO
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday named the members of his Task Force on Bias-Related Violence and instructed it to ''begin the task of developing specific solutions'' to the kind of racial violence that erupted in Queens in December.

title: REDUCING NUMBER OF HOSPITAL BEDS IS 'POLITICS' AND OVERLOOKS PUBLIC NEED
description: HEALTH-CARE costs are of vital concern to us all. As physicians, we recognize the public's desire that waste be eliminated and duplication minimized in the provision of hospital services. Yet we are fearful that the hastily drawn plans to consolidate hospital services in this region have not carefully assessed the facts, allowed sufficient public input or sought the views, guidance and assistance of practicing physicians in accomplishing those goals while maintaining the public interest.

title: Miss O'Mara Has Wedding
description: At The Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in Manhattan yesterday Margot Courtney O'Mara, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Mowbray O'Mara of Greenwich, Conn., was married to Timothy Phillips Connors, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Phillips Connors of Englewood, Colo. The Rev. D. Bradley Murray, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: THE POLITICAL PENDULUM
description: Ideologues on both the right and left are using the results of the Senate elections in November to draw considerably different conclusions about which way the nation is heading politically.

title: Dr. Michelle E. Ehrlich Weds Fellow Physician
description: Dr. Michelle E. Ehrlich, an assistant professor of neurology and pediatrics at the Cornell University Medical College, and Dr. Samuel Evans Gandy 3d, a research associate at Rockefeller University, were married yesterday in Chesterfield, S.C. Judge Edwin Davis of the Chesterfield County Circuit Court performed the ceremony at the Craig Park Community Church.

title: THE MEN WHO MADE THE SUN RISE
description: THE MAKING OF THE ATOMIC BOMB By Richard Rhodes. Illustrated. 886 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.95.

title:
INVESTING;
Odyssey Stalks Another Prize
description: LEAD: Warwick Insurance Managers Inc. ranks small among property and casualty and workers' compensation insurers - about $31 million in net premiums written in 1986. But the Morristown, N.J., company has attracted a big-name group of New York investors. In recent months, Odyssey Partners has bought about 7.4 percent of Warwick's 3.8 million shares, which trade over-the-counter.

title: Sam Nunn's Rising Star
description: Once more, we are treated to puffery of yet another macho-Democrat - Sam Nunn, whose philosophy amounts to Reaganism without Reagan. Notably missing, by the way, is his sometime espousal of the draft, an electoral disaster at least as potent as any ''tax-and-spend'' tag.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN MASSAGE
description: WHEN Apple Computer Inc. was developing its Macintosh personal computer, engineers on the project sported T-shirts that boasted: ''Working 90 hours a week and loving it!''

title: THE LEGACY OF KLEE IS EVERYWHERE
description: The unemphatic art of Paul Klee has entered the universal language not only of fine art but of advertising, graphic design, high-quality cartooning and communications in general. Short of hiding under the sofa, it would be difficult to pass a day in a big city anywhere in the Western world and not be reminded of Paul Klee over and over again. His way with faces, with the human body (complete or fragmented) and with animals of every kind is all-pervading. So are the big broad arrows, the use of outsize letters, initials or complete words, the all-purpose ideograms and the shorthand architectures.

title: MULTIPLE OFFERINGS SOUTH OF THE BORDER
description: THE ever-increasing number and variety of first-rate musical events in the county continue to be a boon to music lovers who prefer not to fight the traffic, parking and sundry other problems that go with concert attendance in mid-Manhattan. Events in the Bronx, on the other hand, are usually closer and more convenient.

title: Professor in Zionism Affair Is Denied Tenure
description: A professor at the State University at Stony Brook, L.I., embroiled in controversy since he told students in 1983 that Zionism is a form of racism, has been denied tenure by the Chancellor of the State University.

title: Broadcast TV
description: Just about a year ago, moviegoers were treated to one of those occasional delights known as sleepers. In this instance, it was ''Smooth Talk,'' a haunting film about an adolescent California girl that will make its television debut at 9 P.M. Monday on American Playhouse on channels 13 and 49. It will be rebroadcast Saturday afternoon at 2 on Channel 13.

title: G. H. Botwick 3d, Insurance Executive, To Marry Julia K. Westerman in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. William L. Westerman of St. Petersburg, Fla., and Wantagh, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Julia Kathryn Westerman to George Herbert Bostwick 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bostwick Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I.

title: U.S. JOINS INQUIRY ON OYSTER BAY
description: THE United States Attorney for the Eastern District has joined the Nassau County District Attorney in investigating possible corruption in the Oyster Bay town government, according to law enforcement officials.

title: STUDENT PARKING ON GREAT NECK
description: As a 1985 graduate of Great Neck North High School, I feel it is appropriate for me to respond to ''No Parking.'' What exactly is the issue addressed? It is certainly not the lack of parking available to Great Neck students.

title:
GARDENING;
SOIL PESTS STUNT GROWTH OF YOUNG TREES
description: LEAD: HORTICULTURISTS have long been aware of the difficulty of replacing certain kinds of trees with young trees of the same species, especially apple trees.

title: THE ROYAL PROGRESS
description: Mary Queen of Scots, a much-traveled monarch, seems to have spent about half her reign on a horse, and many of the surviving castles she stayed in are being spruced up to mark the anniversary of her death.

title: TRAVELS WITH LEAHY
description: Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, freely admits that he knows ''a lot more about the problems of dairy farmers than wheat, corn and soybean growers or farmers who raise livestock.'' Since Mr. Leahy has just become chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, his selective ignorance has suddenly assumed greater importance. The chairman has faced up to the problem by scheduling a tour of Middle Western states next week to visit farms, meet farmers and tour auction pits and equipment showrooms.
