He is also resigning his seat on the busy Senate Intelligence Committee so he can devote more time to agricultural matters.

title: JOANN E. SIKORSKI TO MARRY IN MAY
description: The engagement of Joann Elizabeth Sikorski to Kerry Batchelor Watterson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen W. Watterson of Bay Village, Ohio, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Sikorski of Northport, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. A May wedding is planned.

title: FLAMES BEAT ISLANDERS
description: Joey Mullen scored one power-play goal and assisted on another tonight as the Calgary Flames defeated the Islanders, 4-1. Mullen's goal was the 199th of his National Hockey League career.

title: 107 G.O.P. MILLIONS DIDN'T SAVE SENATE
description: Republican candidates for the United States Senate raised $28 million more than their Democratic opponents in the 1986 election, but those funds were not a determining factor in most races, an analysis of campaign finance reports shows.

title: New Mandates for Smoke-Free Air
description: Nonsmokers breathed more freely in 6,800 Federal buildings around the nation last week, and the New York Public Health Council promised them the same relief in workplaces and public areas around the state.

title: COURT RULES ON AID TO HOMELESS
description: A state appeals court has ordered the state to lift rules that limit when the homeless are eligible for emergency aid and how long they should be sheltered.

title: A COUNTRY IN MELTDOWN
description: LEBANON'S PREDICAMENT By Samir Khalaf. 328 pp. New York: Columbia University Press. $30.

title:
ART;
A BLITHE MIX IN STAMFORD EXHIBIT
description: LEAD: WHAT has been the Painters' and Sculptors' Annual at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center has expanded this year to include print making, photography and drawing, and so has been renamed the Connecticut Art Annual Competition.

title: YOUNG PLAYERS LEARN FUN OF BASKETBALL
description: LEAD: BRIAN VALENTINE and David Dever aspire to playing for their favorite professional basketball team, the Boston Celtics. Their teachers, Kevin and Jeff Fitzpatrick, are laying the foundation for the boys to achieve that goal - in perhaps 15 years.

title: GROWTH OF CITIES CONCERNS EXPERTS
description: Scores of urban areas in underdeveloped countries are growing at an explosive rate that may create severe economic and social strains, according to experts gathered at the United Nations this week for a population conference.

title: THE LIFE OF A 'SNOWBIRD'
description: I am appalled that you printed the article by Carol Cott Gross on Jan. 11 [ ''Rules for the Florida Visit,'' Opinion Page ] . I think she shows lack of compassion and understanding for older (and probably other) people, and what is supposed to be humorous, I find callous and hurtful. I find no redeeming feature in this article. YVONNE LUTER

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: St. Paul, Minn.;
A Bid to Attract World Trade
description: LEAD: WITH the shell of the 36-story red-granite-and-glass Minnesota World Trade Center completed, work on this city's tallest building is now focused on finishing the offices and a 160,000-square-foot shopping area on the first three floors.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Blacks and Blue Power
description: In Chicago, it used to be routine police practice to sweep up large numbers of young black and Hispanic men on disorderly conduct charges, hold them overnight and release them the next day without prosecution. In 1982, the American Civil Liberties Union challenged the practice in Federal court. In 1983, when Harold Washington took over as Chicago's first black mayor, the city entered into a consent decree to end the sweeps. His predecessor had defended the policy; Mayor Washington apologized for there ever having been such a practice in Chicago.

title: In its Battle With Reagan, Congress is Ahead
description: By week's end, President Reagan's supporters and his opponents were debating whether the scorecard reflects the White House's political vulnerablity or merely political miscalculation. But there was little disagreement about the bottom line. In the assertive 100th Congress's first month, victory in the battle over control of the national agenda has gone to the legislators.

title: LA GUARDIA THEFTS RISE AND YOUTHS TAKE BLAME
description: The number of stolen automobiles, thefts from parked cars and pickpocket incidents at La Guardia Airport increased by 50 percent last year, mainly because of a growing number of younger, bolder thieves, according to the Port Authority.

title: STATE SEEKS HOMES FOR FOSTER CHILDREN
description: FACED with a growing shortage of foster homes, the State Department of Children and Youth Services has started sending teams of social workers into communities to recruit foster parents.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Future Comes To Massachusetts

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: A SEASON ON THE BRINK: A Year With Bob Knight and the Indiana Hoosiers. By John Feinstein. (Macmillan, $16.95.) Bob Knight, the hugely popular (with Hoosiers) and successful basketball coach at Indiana University, is probably best known to casual fans for his periodic departures from ordinary court-side etiquette.

title: POSTINGS: 300,000 Sq. Ft.; Rehab by Trinity
description: Trinity Church strikes a commanding pose on the lower Manhattan landscape, holding landmark status in the realms of architecture, spirit and more earthly matters. But now the church, a significant landowner, is making its presence felt in a new way, with the conversion of an old industrial building on the Lower West Side into office space.

title: NUCLEAR PLANT OPENINGS THREATENED BY POLITICS
description: Among nuclear regulators, the Shoreham nuclear power plant is a prime example of what they term ''the hostage plant'' problem.

title: HEALTH OUTLAY INCREASES TOPPED BY AIDS FUND
description: LEAD: DECLARING that New Jersey would ''lead the way in stopping this dreaded killer in its tracks,'' Governor Kean last week proposed spending up to $22 million in state, Federal and private funds on AIDS in the next fiscal year.

title: RECENT RELEASES ON VIDEO CASSETTES
description: John Coltrane: The Coltrane Legacy With John Coltrane, Eric Dolphy, McCoy Tyner, Elvin Jones, Miles Davis. Produced and directed by Burrill Crohn. Color/black and white. Video Artists International. 61 Minutes. $39.95.

title: PARKING: $200, BUT NO SPACE
description: LEAD: FOR $200 a year, apartment dwellers in the Village of Lawrence can buy the privilege of overnight parking on several designated streets. But angry tenants filled the Village Hall in January, complaining that despite the fee, there are no spaces in which to park overnight near their homes.

title: GANDHI ACTIONS STIR STRONG CRITICISM
description: A flurry of personnel shifts, statements and actions by Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, including some related to India's latest confrontation with Pakistan, have prompted unusually strong criticism of his performance.

title: U.S. Reliance on South African Minerals Cited
description: The State Department has told Congress that the United States economy and the military remain dependent on South Africa for 10 minerals and other raw materials that were not included in an import ban enacted last October.

title: PHOTOGRAPHS FROM THE WEIMAR REPUBLIC
description: THE Weimar Republic was born in 1919, one month after the Treaty of Versailles, and lasted until 1933, when it was deposed by the Nazis. Except for a few years prior to the World Depression, the period was one of political and economic chaos that was in large part the result of the harsh terms imposed on Germany by the treaty.

title: Networks, Not Viewers, Skittish on Condom Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: DO YOU LIKE THE COLLEGE 3-POINT BASKET?
description: It is too short! Players are averaging more points than they should be. Larry Bird and Chris Mullin would have averaged over 40 points a game in college with this line's ridiculous distance from the net. Players do not show that they are capable of playing in the N.B.A. by scoring from this distance. The line should either be N.B.A.-size or disappear. DANNY BEDER Westbury, L.I.

title: ALIENS IN U.S. GAIN REFUGE IN CANADA
description: Illegal aliens who are not eligible for legal status under the new immigration law are migrating from the United States to Canada in substantial numbers.

title: WAITE KIDNAPPING LINKED TO U.S. IRAN ARMS DEALING
description: Arab diplomats here say Shiite Moslem militants seized Terry Waite, the Anglican envoy, in West Beirut 17 days ago to bring pressure on the Reagan Administration to resume deliveries of arms and military spare parts to Iran. [ An anonymous telephone caller told a Moslem radio station in Beirut Saturday night that Mr. Waite had been freed ''somewhere in Beirut,'' Reuters reported, but Mr. Waite had not appeared more than an hour later. The Sunni Moslem station, Voice of the Homeland, said the caller described himself as a ''security source.'' No confirmation was immediately available. ] An anonymous caller purporting to speak for the fundamentalist Shiite group known as Islamic Holy War telephoned a Western news agency in West Beirut, the Moslem part of the city, today and said Mr. Waite, who has been trying to negotiate the release of Western hostages, was in good health. The caller denied recent press speculation that Mr. Waite had been shot and seriously wounded while trying to escape from his captors.

title: Bad Blood
description: Carlos Lehder Rivas, reputedly one of the world's most dangerous billionaires, was captured by authorities in Colombia last week and extradited to the United States to face a long list of drug-related charges in two Federal courts in Florida. Mr. Lehder, who was said by prosecutors to be part of a ring responsible for 80 percent of the cocaine smuggled into the United States, was indicted three months ago in Miami on charges of conspiring to ship 58 pounds of cocaine into Florida. Security was very tight at his arraignment last week, in part, prosecutors said, because Mr. Lehder ''said if he was caught he would kill a Federal judge a week until he is freed.'' Mr. Lehder loudly denied this, saying, ''That's a lie.'' Prosecutors said Mr. Lehder's drug ring was responsible for the murders of about 20 judges and other officials in Colombia.

title: STUDENT PARKING IN GREAT NECK
description: I read and reread the article ''No Parking'' [ Long Island Journal, Jan. 11 ] in disbelief. As a student of the school I must set the record straight.

title: Vote of Confidence
description: THE former Brigham Young University football team surgeon who has been accused of illegally dispensing the addictive pain-killer, Percodan, to seven players over a six-year period, got a vote of confidence from one former Cougar. Robbie Bosco, the acclaimed quarterback now with the Green Bay Packers, said that the surgeon, Brent M. Pratley, had never prescribed Percodan for him even though he was bothered at times by extreme shoulder pain.

title: The Venetian Maskmakers' Art Revived
description: Venice will always be a city of mystery and intrigue, just as she was in those last desperate days of the Most Serene Republic at the close of the 18th century. One has only to walk her splendid fondamenti (canal walkways) or cross her magic bridges counting the shadows after nightfall to know that much. These alluring cornerstones of her character are no better symbolized than in the form of the Carnival mask, the crafting and wearing of which have been reborn in the last six years along with the public celebration of Carnival itself. Her mercantile spirit never flagging, Venice has caught the eye of the foreign visitor by displaying these masks for sale at every opportunity, as she did, no doubt, when travelers on the Grand Tour came to Venice during the reigns of the last doges.

title: DEVELOPER REFLECTS ON CITY RENTALS
description: NEW YORK CITY's Housing Commissioner, Paul A. Crotty, says the city is taking steps to cooperate with private developers to encourage them to build middle-income housing, which he defined as housing for families with annual income between $25,000 and $48,000.

title: SOVIET RELEASING SOME PRISONERS UNDER NEW LAW
description: The Soviet Government has issued a decree ordering the release of dozens of political prisoners, according to evidence provided today by prisoners already set free.

title: VIEWS AND OVERVIEWS OF MUSEUM DESIGN
description: The article about museum designers in Westchester County [ ''A New Approach to Museum Design,'' Dec. 28 ] may well have destroyed more than a decade of effort on my part to rally the resources of the county behind a significant historical institution commensurate with the heritage of this community.

title: DO YOU LIKE THE COLLEGE 3-POINT BASKET?
description: First, the 45-second clock. Then, the 3-pointer. Next, we eliminate defense, team offense, an interestng regular season, and fan enthusiasm. Now, we have another N.B.A.; National Boredom Association, that is. GARY GARFINKEL Long Island City, Queens

title: DEATHS FORCE PHILADELPHIA TO FACE HOMELESS ISSUE
description: Despite at least two calls to the police from neighbors, a 60-year-old man died from hypothermia and alcoholism early this week after he locked himself out of his unheated rowhouse here and tried to sleep on the front stoop of a neighborhood bar.

title: Article 858087 -- No Title
description: WITH his budget message to the General Assembly last week, Governor O'Neill set the stage for a noisy legislative battle over whether Connecticut's state government has suddenly become a big spender.

title: John Leypoldt Is Dead at 40; Former Place-Kicker for Bills
description: John Leypoldt, a former place-kicker for the Buffalo Bills, died today of an apparent heart attack. He was 40 years old.

title: JOY FOR THE SISTER WHO OWNS THE GIANTS
description: This is a Valentine to the Giants and Giants' fans, from one who had the good fortune/misfortune to not only ''own'' the Giants, but love them. After 23 years, I am finally patching up the pieces of a long-broken heart.

title: Volunteers Staff a Broke Town
description: This village remained afloat in a sea of red ink this weekend as about 70 municipal employees, many of them still owed wages from January, accepted token payments of $100 each and stayed on the job.

title: Infante Wins Suit
description: ACIRCUIT COURT jury in Jacksonville, Fla., has awarded Lindy Infante, the Cleveland Browns' offensive coordinator, $87,500 in a ruling that the Jacksonville Bulls of the United States Football League breached Infante's contract in 1986. After more than two hours of deliberation Friday, the jury of four men and four women awarded Infante about half of what he and his attorneys had sought.

title: Recent Sales
description: East Haven, Conn. $485,000 650 Laurel Street 6-bedroom, 3-bath, 50-year-old Tudor; electric burglar-alarm system, 10 acres; taxes $2,728. Hamden, Conn. $179,900 163 Woodlawn Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; 2-car garage, 65- by 132-foot lot; taxes $2,135. Orange, Conn. $242,500 328 Knight Lane 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 26-year-old split-level; multilevel deck, fireplace; taxes $1,779. Hartsdale, N.Y. $240,000 10 Whittier 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 43-year-old frame colonial; eat-in kitchen, family room, new roof, 1-car detached garage; taxes $3,816. Katonah, N.Y. $250,000 60A Moseman Drive 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 12-year-old frame/brick raised ranch; eat-in kitchen, family room, 2-car garage; taxes $3,600. New Rochelle, N.Y. $280,000 95 Emerson Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 22-year-old brick/ frame raised ranch; eat-in kitchen, deck, family room; taxes, $5,265. OTHER AREAS Bluepoint, L.I. $171,500 4 Lacy Court 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 14-year-old ranch; basement, eat-in kitchen, patio, new in-ground pool, 1-car garage; taxes $2,700. Randolph, N.J. $284,900 10 Meadowbrook Road 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 19-year-old expanded ranch; fireplace in family room, eat-in kitchen, 2-car garage; taxes $3,775. West Orange, N.J. $143,000 58 Forest Hill Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 52-year-old colonial; porch, formal dining room; taxes $2,495.

title: In the Mideast, Fear Of an Iran Victory
description: The alarm bells are clanging from Muscat in Oman to Cairo and Tel Aviv. The stately pleasure domes of the Saud dynasty seem to stand just a bit less firmly than they did a month ago. The arms market is booming.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: MISSUS. By Ruth Park. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) As family sagas go, this is shorter than most (247 pages of large type) though it seems a lot longer. What little action there is occurs in Australia way back when, but because of the universal themes concerning Life (Love, Death, Hope, Jealousy, Illness) it could be anywhere.

title: SISTINE RESTORATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Children
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed Martha Elliot's ''On Safari With the Children,'' (Travel, Jan. 4) since my two boys and I had taken a safari through Kenya and Tanzania in July 1985.

title:
FOCUS: OAKLAND;
Trodding The Road To Revival
description: LEAD: THREE concurrent announcements late last month gave mixed signals about the imminence of a long-anticipated retail renaissance in this city across the bay from San Francisco.

title: RANGERS MOVE INTO 3D PLACE
description: At the start, it seemed that this night would be memorable for how Bobby Carpenter was taunted on the occasion of his homecoming. But the Rangers took what might otherwise have been a bleak time and turned it into a gala evening.

title: OH, TO BE SEXUALLY INDIFFERENT
description: LEAD: PATIENCE OF A SAINT By Andrew M. Greeley. 446 pp. New York: Bernard Geis Associates/ Warner Books. $18.95.

title: PLAN ON RAIL CROSSING OPPOSED
description: LEAD: A PLAN by the State Department of Transportation to eliminate the Robbins Lane grade crossing in Syosset by constructing an elevated overpass has attracted surprisingly strong opposition from local residents.

title: HOSTAGES ENSNARED IN A WEB OF OLD BELIEFS AND MOSLEM HATREDS
description: ON what began as a quiet December morning three years ago, a truck turned into the seafront American Embassy compound here, veered into an administration building and exploded. Another suicide truck-bomber hit the French Embassy, and there were explosions at five other sites in this comfortably wealthy little Gulf emirate, including buildings used by the Raytheon Corporation, which was installing American-made Hawk anti-aircraft missiles.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: PADDLESPORT EXPO Paddlesport '87, for people who go boating without benefit of sails or propellers, will offer a day of workshops and browsing in Princeton next Sunday. And whether a paddler enjoys canoeing on a placid lake, bouncing through rapids in a white-water kayak or voyaging to a coastal island in a sea kayak, there will be something of interest.

title: ORCHESTRA MANAGERS: BRIDGING WORLDS OF BUSINESS AND ART
description: LEAD: Despite the black-garbed trappings of tradition onstage, today's symphony orchestra owes as much - at least in its backstage operations - to corporate ideas as it does to Beethoven. In a world of 52-week seasons, jet-traveling music directors and a constant scramble for money, the orchestra has become a big business, and a new breed of manager, most of them younger than managers used to be, has emerged to run it.

title: SIC TRANSIT GLORIA TRANSYLVANIA
description: BETWEEN THE WOODS AND THE WATER On Foot to Constantinople From the Hook of Holland: The Middle Danube to the Iron Gates. By Patrick Leigh Fermor. 248 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $18.95.

title: POP: THE HUMAN LEAGUE PLAYS THE RITZ
description: Take yesterday's disco rhythms, add a slightly flat British singer, and the result can be a pop hit. That's the formula that has made the Human League a regular entry on the pop Top 40, most recently with ''Human,'' a Philadelphia-soul-style ballad about infidelity written by the band's producers, Jimmy Jam and Terry Lewis. Human League opened its sold-out, three-night stand at the Ritz on Thursday - part of its first tour in five years - with a set of old and increasingly superficial new songs.

title: POSTINGS: The City as Collector; Nostalgia for Sale
description: The market for what is becoming known as urban archeology - an old Coca Cola sign or a 1930's refrigerator - continues to grow, and downtown galleries specializing in such merchandise help interior designers looking for kitsch or smoke-screened nostalgia.

title: CORRECTION
description: In last week's column, a computer malfunction caused question marks to appear in several places in the game score. All but one appeared where a dash should have been; one, however, made White's 12th move unitelligible; the move should have been B-N3.

title: THE THRESHOLD OF GOD'S THOUGHTS
description: FEARFUL SYMMETRY The Search for Beauty in Modern Physics. By A. Zee. Illustrated. 322 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $25.

title: A PROMISE FOR ALPINE STRAWBERRIES IS MADE IN WINTER
description: LEAD: Both the musk strawberry (Fragaria moschata) and wood strawberry (F. vesca) produce fruit on dainty, decorative plants. They can be used as edgings, groundcovers or specimens in pots. The plants have white blossoms which stare out above the foliage atop thin flower stalks.

title: AUDUBON POSITION
description: With regard to the Jan. 4 article ''Controls on Swans Proposed,'' this is to inform you that on Jan. 6 the Connecticut Audubon Society's Environmental Issues Committee endorsed the addling of eggs but not the outright killing of swans at this time. JOEY CORCORAN

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE state's Board of Public Utilities will not challenge a $7.7 million American Telephone and Telegraph Company rate increase that took effect last Sunday on long-distance calls made within New Jersey.

title: INVESTING
description: SINCE 1983, the Standard & Poor's 500 index has shamed many money managers. For each of the last four years, the majority of them has failed to do better than the popularly followed index. Corporate executives who hire money managers to run their pension funds, said Byron R. Wien, investment strategist at Morgan, Stanley & Company, ''have lost confidence in the profession.''

title: Devils Surprise Flyers With Two Short-Handed Goals
description: The Devils failed to score during six manpower advantages today, but they scored two goals during manpower disadvantages and managed a 3-2 triumph over the Philadelphia Flyers at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: Bargains in Clothing Benefit Hospital The Twig Organization of the United Hospital in Port Chester encompasses 900 volunteers, including those in other nearby communities -Rye, Rye Brook, Larchmont, Harrison and Mamaroneck - who have helped raise money for new equipment and renovation since 1911. One venture is the Nearly New Shop in

title: AVOIDING THE CURSE OF THE RED EYE
description: ONE of the enduring occupational hazards facing amateur photographers is the dread malady known as red eye. If you've never heard of it, don't worry: it afflicts pictures, not the person taking them.

title: U.S. ASKING ROOM FOR 'BABY BELLS' TO GROW
description: FIVE years ago, in a move that was both surprising and tentative, the Justice Department and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company settled on a way to break up the Bell System's decades-old monopoly of the nation's telephone business. Now the Reagan Administration is offering proposals that would create a handful of miniature A.T.& T.'s.

title: Builders, Insects, Both Win Big
description: An insect in the middle of Central Park and a proposal for two giant towers at the foot of it won favor in the eyes of city agencies last week.

title: POP: MAUREEN MCGOVERN
description: MAUREEN McGOVERN is not exactly foregoing the potential of her four-octave voice or the coloratura effects of which she is capable in her performances at Freddy's Supper Club (308 East 49th Street), where she will perform this afternoon and Thursday night through next Sunday afternoon.

title: A HOME FOR THE HOMELESS
description: LEAD: FOR THE vulnerable homeless fighting to survive, Lifeline, an emergency shelter here, offers refuge - and more.

title: Cessna Strays Near Jetliner
description: The Pilot of a Western Airlines jet with 59 people aboard veered to the left while approaching the international airport here Friday to avoid a small plane that strayed near the airliner, a Federal official said. Lee Fryer, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration, said a single-engine Cessna 172 and a Western Boeing 737 flying from Las Vegas, Nev., had been given final clearance to land on parallel runways. Mr. Fryer said the Cessna came within ''a few hundred feet'' of the jet.

title: FRANCIS WELLS DAVISON
description: Francis Wells Davison, a physician who specialized in disorders of the ear, nose and throat, died Thursday at the Geisinger Medical Center in Danville, Pa. He was 84 years old.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN MASSAGE
description: DON'T say ''masseuse.'' Massage practitioners who are moving their vocation into the mainstream say the term has unfortunate associations with prostitution. They prefer ''massage therapist'' or ''bodywork practitioner.''

title:
HOME VIDEO;
RECENT RELEASES ON VIDEO CASSETTES
description: LEAD: Journey to Adventure: The USA With host Gunther Less. Produced by GLL TV Enterprises. Independent United Distributors. 56 minutes. $29.95.

title: STUDENTS CELEBRATE U.S. CONSTITUTION
description: LEAD: ABOUT 125 high-school students from all over the country, including 25 from Westchester, last week marked the 200th anniversary of the United States Constitution by debating and voting on proposed Constitutional amendments in Washington. The students were delegates to Convention II, the annual model ''Constitutional Convention'' begun 12 years ago by a New Rochelle resident, Boris Feinman, as part of his efforts to focus national attention on the coming bicentennial of the Constitution.

title: Miss Tabell Wed To Steven Nocka
description: St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Pennington, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Sarah Elizabeth Tabell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony W. Tabell of Princeton, N.J., to Steven McKinsey Nocka, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carlo Nocka of Ridgewood, N.J. The Rev. John C. Belmont performed the ceremony.

title: Bell-Dickey Duo Tops
description: BUDDY BELL, the third baseman of the Cincinnati Reds, and Lynn Dickey, who recently retired as quarterback for the Green Bay Packers, combined for a nine-under-par 63 and won the American Airlines Golf Classic by a shot.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Boxing Curry Wins on Disqualification: Donald Curry, the former world welterweight champion, knocked Tony Montgomery down three times yesterday, then captured the United States Boxing Association junior-middleweight title when Montgomery was disqualified in the fifth round for butting at Las Vegas, Nev. Montgomery, who twice had points taken away for butting, was disqualified by Referee James Molinell at 2:29 of the fifth round after he again lunged into Curry with his head. A furious Curry followed Montgomery as Molinell led him away and hit him from behind with a right to the head. The punch started a near-brawl as cornermen from both camps raced into the ring and tried to fight one another before security guards and fight officials managed to gain control. It led the Nevada State Athletic Commission to announce that the purses of both fighters would be withheld pending a viewing of the tape of the bout. Curry, from Fort Worth, is 26-1 with 20 knockouts. Montgomery, from Detroit, lost his first bout in 18 career starts. (AP) Skiing Hess Captures Slalom: Switzerland's Erika Hess made the fastest second run to win the women's slalom at the Alpine Ski World championships and add a sixth -and probably last - gold medal to her record-breaking career. Hess, who says she will retire at the end of this season, sped through the 55 gates in the second-run time of 46.51 seconds to overtake Austria's Roswitha Steiner, at Crans-Montana, Switzerland. Hess finished with a total time of 1:33.30, to Steiner's 1:33.55. Mateja Svet of Yugoslavia took her second bronze and third medal of the championships. The best American finisher was Eva Twardokens of Olympic Valley, Calif., who was ninth at 1:35.59. (AP) Golf Lopez Ahead by 5 Shots: Nancy Lopez opened a five-shot lead after three rounds of the $200,000 Sarasota Classic , firing a four-under-par 68 to fuel her bid to qualify for the Ladies Professional Golf Association Hall of Fame on the same Florida course where she won her first tournament nine years ago. Lopez, who started the day tied for the lead with Chris Johnson, pulled away from the field with four birdies on the front nine of the par-72, 6,124-yard Bent Tree Country course. Lopez won her first tour victory in the 1978 Bent Tree Ladies Classic. Lopez, winner of 34 L.P.G.A. events, added birdies on No. 13 and No. 17 and finished the day with a 54-hole total of 9-under-par 207. Her nearest rivals, at 212, were Cathy Morse and Kathy Baker, who shot 71 and 72, respectively. Lopez needs one victory to qualify for the Hall of Fame. (AP) Stadler Ties Course Record: Craig Stadler matched the course record with a 10-under-par 62 to take a one-stroke lead over Paul Azinger after three rounds of the $600,000 Hawaiian Open at Honolulu. Stadler, who has not won in two and a half seasons, made 10 birdies in the ideal playing conditions - including a string of five in a row - and completed 54 holes in 200, 16 shots under par. Stadler's third-round effort tied the course record held by Hale Irwin and Nick Faldo of Britain, both in 1981. Azinger, who scored his first PGA Tour victory in Phoenix last month, moved into second with a 65 that put him at 201. (AP) Track and Field Atkins a Double Winner: Dianne Atkins, Joe McDonald and Paul Vandergrift turned in impressive performances in the Army interscholastic meet in the West Point Field House. Atkins, a 17-year-old senior at Malverne (L.I.) High School who is considered the leading girls' sprinter in New York State, was a double winner. She took the 55-meter dash in 7.16 seconds and the 200-meter dash in 25.54 seconds. McDonald, competing for Kingston (N.Y.) High School, just missed being a triple winner. The senior had victories in the long jump at 22 feet 9 1/4 inches and the triple jump at 45-10, but he finished second in the high jump at 6-4. Vandergrift, one of the top middle-distance runners in the East from Archbishop Kennedy High School in Conshohocken, Pa., was the winner of the 1,000-meter run in 2 minutes 30.20 seconds. In other events, Tilden of Brooklyn equaled the New York State record in the girls' 1,600-meter relay in 3:54; Ann Letko of North Hunterdon, N.J., registered one of the fastest 3,000-meter times in the country this season in winning the girls' event in 9:58.2; and Steve Edden of DeWitt Clinton in the Bronx took the 800-meter run in 1:56.73. New York Team Excels: New York athletes won 20 of 26 events last night to defeat a Boston team for the third straight year in the Reebok Challenge Cup indoor meet in Yale's Coxe Cage. The New York squad tallied 170 points to Boston's 78. Michele Bush led the New York team with victories in the women's 1,500 meters (4 mintues 22.35 seconds) and 3,000 meters (9:40.91). Nnennah Lynch, a sophomore at Hunter College High School, posted a national class indoor best for 1,500 meters when she ran 4:27.74 behind Bush. The former sophomore mark was 4:30.1 set by Christine Curtin of Bellmore, L.I., in 1982. Horse Racing Quick Closing Rallies: Quick Closing, who raced as part of an entry with Fine Dining, rallied strongly through the stretch to score 1 3/4-length victory in the $72,000 Level Best Stakes for 3-year-old fillies at Aqueduct. Quick Closing, who carried 112 pounds, was ridden by E. T. Baird, who rode four winners on the day. Super Cook, who led into the stretch, held on to be second, a half-length ahead of Center Box. Bold Mate, the even-money favorite on the strength of her victory in the Busanda Stakes Jan. 11, tired badly to finish eighth in the field of nine. Quick Closing returned $27 for $2 to win as the fifth choice. N.H.L. Bruins 8, Maple Leafs 5: Cam Neely had his first three-goal game in the league and Michael Thelven, a defenseman, scored twice, as the Bruins took their ninth victory in the last 11 games. Thelven, who underwent shoulder surgery last fall and had only 1 goal in 13 previous games this season, scored in the first and second periods. (AP) Nordiques 5, Sabres 2: Michel Goulet and Peter Stastny had two goals each for Quebec. Anton Stastny had a goal and two assists for Quebec. He has 5 goals and 6 assists in his last six games. (AP) Penguins 4, Blackhawks 1: Craig Simpson scored two goals to help end a three-game losing streak. Gilles Meloche lost his shutout at 11:02 of the third period when Doug Wilson tapped in a rebound of Denis Savard's shot. A Pittsburgh defenseman, Rod Buskas, was given a match penalty in the second period for intent to injure. Buskas attacked Bob Murray after Murray was given a major penalty for high sticking Simpson. The match penalty carries an automatic suspension pending league review. (AP) Whalers 3, Canadiens 1: Sylvain Turgeon and Dean Evason scored second-period goals and Mike Liut made 23 saves to keep the Whalers atop the Adams Division. The victory, the eighth in the last 11 games, gave the Whalers into a 3-point lead over the Canadiens and Bruins. (AP)

title: MCENROE AND MAYOTTE ADVANCE TO FINAL
description: John McEnroe would prefer that the line on the graph charting his progress was always moving upward, toward what he feels is his untapped potential. Invariably, though, there will be plateaus and even a step or two backward to contend with, times when he will wonder whether he has already played his best tennis.

title: NEW FT. DRUM DIVISION ADDS TO HOUSING PRESSURE
description: An influx of soldiers to Fort Drum - expected to bring unprecedented growth to one of the state's most depressed areas - has squeezed the supply of housing here so tightly that advocates for the poor contend that rents have risen beyond the reach of many longtime residents.

title: ENDING ALTMAN'S LAZY DAYS
description: LAST year, when the two C.P.A.'s planning to buy B. Altman & Company's retail stores took their first close look at the 121-year-old department store chain, they went into a state of shock. The merchandise mix, the huge numbers of non-sales employees, even the amount of office equipment in use, all seemed more attuned to a company seeking a tax loss than one looking for a profit.

title: HOTEL IS FOCUS OF CIVIC PRIDE
description: LEAD: WHEN the Bridgeport Hilton Hotel opens its doors to guests on Thursday, a new chapter in the city's history will begin, say city officials, who view the hotel as the cornerstone of downtown redevelopment.

title: Jordan Hangs a Palestinian For Slaying a P.L.O. Official
description: A Palestinian convicted in the assassination in 1984 of a Palestine Liberation Organization official has been hanged, an Interior Ministry source said today.

title: ALLOCATING PARKING FOR THE DISABLED
description: LEAD: IN June 1976, the county issued the first parking permits to disabled people or those who drive them. In December 1977, all municipalities in the state were given the opportunity to design the procedure they wished to use concerning the issuance of the permit.

title: Killer's Plea Imperils a Greek Leader's Prestige
description: A plea for clemency in an 11-year-old murder case has led to a political dispute that is threatening the prestige and future of President Christos Sartzetakis.

title: HAITIANS MARK THEIR FIRST YEAR WITHOUT DUVALIER
description: Haitians quietly observed the first anniversary of the ouster of Jean-Claude Duvalier today with the head of the provisional Government appealing for unity and support for efforts to bring the impoverished nation to full democracy.

title: UNCHANGED FED POLICY EXPECTED
description: The Federal Reserve is likely to hold monetary policy unchanged at this week's Open Market Committee meeting, where Fed officials and their advisers meet to assess the economy and plot a course.

title: LOSING A MOTHER TO CRACK: QUICK AND TRAGIC PROCESS
description: It happens in stages - but quickly, before the mother understands what has really taken place, said Janet, an 18-year-old woman now living at a Phoenix House center in upstate New York and separated from her 17-month-old son.

title: Infant Receives New Heart
description: A 2 1/2-month-old Canadian girl who underwent surgery to replace her malformed heart was in critical but stable condition today, and doctors were optimistic about her progress. The girl, identified only as Jessica of Calgary, Alberta, received the transplanted heart Saturday at Loma Linda University Medical Center, said a hospital spokesman. The girl is the eighth child under the age of 3 to undergo a heart transplant here since November 1985.

title: THE STAGE: ARTHUR MILLER'S 'DANGER: MEMORY!'
description: THE OPENING one-act play in ''Danger: Memory!,'' Arthur Miller's new double bill at Lincoln Center, is titled ''I Can't Remember Anything,'' but it's Arthur Miller's nature that he can never forget. The horrors that haunt his characters today - the 20th century's police inquisitions, pogroms and wars - are the same specters that hung over ''After the Fall'' and ''Incident at Vichy,'' plays he wrote for the first Lincoln Center theater company, more than two decades ago. What has changed with time is the writer's perspective. In ''I Can't Remember Anything'' and its companion piece, ''Clara,'' characters of Mr. Miller's American generation look back at history's cataclysms and their own liberal crusades to ask what, if any, good came of it all. The answers they find are at best ambiguous - a moral gray area where once the author of ''The Crucible'' and ''All My Sons'' would have found clear-cut blacks and whites.

title: Tunnel Tube Shut After Man's Threat
description: A distraught man with a knife ran into the Holland Tunnel in Lower Manhattan early last night and, threatening to stab himself, forced authorities to close the westbound lanes for 90 minutes until he was captured unharmed.

title: MCA TURNS HAND TO ACQUISITIONS
description: For the last two decades, MCA Inc., the giant entertainment company long known as a cautious spender, was, in the words of one media executive, ''a day late and a dollar short'' when it came to acquisitions. But once-staid MCA is starting to shed its tight-fisted image.

title: OHIO STATE'S HOPSON DAZZLING AND DRAWING NOTICE
description: OHIO STATE'S Dennis Hopson was stalking the backcourt from the point of the Buckeye's 1-2-2 zone press when the man he was eyeing, Darryl Johnson of Michigan State, lobbed a routine cross-court pass.

title: SPANISH PARTY ELECTS NEW CHIEF
description: Spain's main conservative opposition party chose a young and little known provincial leader this weekend to overcome the party's internal divisions and lagging fortunes.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''It is not polible to make any such decision htis year or next year.'' George P. Shultz ''Star Wars'' deployment.

title: STAGE: 'LUST AND UNICORN'
description: A PLAY about a vampire and a female psychiatrist seems to have the makings of a shaggy Dracula story, but ''Lust and the Unicorn,'' now at La Mama, is more ambitious than that.

title: DANCE: THE SOUNDS OF 'TAPNOLOGY'
description: CHARLES MOULTON combined tap dancing with technology on Saturday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. The result was ''Tapnology.''

title: Herk van Tongeren, Sculptor
description: Herk van Tongeren, a sculptor, died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, in Seattle. He was 43 years old and lived in Hopewell, N.J.

title: Topics: Explanations; Mr. Goldin's Seal
description: The Comptroller of New York City is expected to be a dour, single- minded scrutinizer of municipal financial practices, not an investment adviser, and certainly not a trader of favors. Harrison Goldin, New York's Comptroller for 13 years, knows the rules; indeed, he often extols them.

title: Dr. J Eclipsed By New Star
description: THE script was already written for the weekend jamboree: Michael Jordan in the slam-dunk, Larry Bird in the 3-point, the Seattle old-timers in the ''legends'' game and Doctor J would be the most valuable player in the All-Star Game, his last, after all the tributes and the videotapes of his greatest dunks and the standing ovations of the past 48 hours.

title: A Policy on Iran
description: Late last month, the White House submitted to Congress a report entitled ''National Security Strategy of the United States'' over the signature of President Reagan, in an effort to keep the lawmakers up to date on the underlying principles of the nation's foreign policy and their use abroad.

title: U.S. FEARS FOREIGN CONTRACTS IMPERIL VITAL DATA
description: The Pentagon has decided to review military data-processing contracts awarded to foreign companies with a view toward preventing disclosure of sensitive information to foreign governments, according to a Defense Department official.

title: EX-CHAIRMEN AND NOT LOVING IT
description: Power corrupts, Adlai Stevenson once drily observed, but lack of power corrupts absolutely.

title: MAYOTTE DEFEATS MCENROE IN 4 SETS
description: Everything that John McEnroe needed to know about the eventual outcome of the match became clear at break point in the sixth game of the third set today. He whipped a backhand down the line, an apparent winner that would break Tim Mayotte and send both players back to ''Go'' in the final of the Ebel United States Pro Indoor Championships.

title: U.S. Can Help South Africa Oust National Party
description: To the Editor:

title: GORBACHEV'S PLANS IMPRESS FORMER U.S. OFFICIALS
description: Former American officials who met last week with Mikhail S. Gorbachev said yesterday that they believed that his efforts to change Soviet society would have far-reaching effects.

title: CONFLICTS OF YOUTH: PEER MEDIATORS OFFER AID
description: The trouble began at William Howard Taft High School in the Bronx when a sophomore boy threw a piece of chalk at a sophomore girl. Ethnic slurs were exchanged, along with threats, and by lunchtime the girl was on the telephone to fellow gang members. In the office of Project Smart, the coordinator, Dorothea Grant, recalls glancing out and seeing ''a big gang of kids outside the school.''

title: TRADE RULES IN EUROPE
description: Plans to tighten the European Community's rules to stop Japan from selling products in Europe for less than the prices in Japan were delayed by worries the move may not be effective, European Community sources said Friday.

title: MILESTONE IN SIGHT AT BEANPOT EVENT
description: SOMETIME soon, the Boston College hockey team will win another game that will not be just another game. It will be the 556th victory for Coach Len Ceglarski, and no other college hockey coach has been on the winning side that many times.

title: MILACRON INNOVATES...CROSS STREAMLINES
description: The Cross & Trecker Corporation, a major manufacturer of machine tools, has long been plagued by the industry's continuing troubles: flat orders, weakening prices and intensifying foreign competition. Now, a downturn in automobile production, plus predictions of declining capital investment by industry, spell more distress for the company.

title: SLASH TIES, APARTHEID FOES URGE
description: Pressure is growing on American companies to completely sever business ties with South Africa - not just hand over local operations to South Africans.

title: Old News in Odessa
description: LEAD: If Mikhail S. Gorbachev is ushering in a new era in the Soviet Union, changing old habits and opening new lines of communication, the news hasn't made it to Odessa.

title: BOSSY OUT OF ALL-STAR GAMES
description: Mike Bossy, the only Islander named to the All-Star team and the only player from the three metropolitan area teams to be voted All-Star honors, decided yesterday that he would not participate in the games. Bossy, plagued all season by strained muscles in his lower back, said he did not feel his presence at the games would do justice to Team NHL.

title: IN NEW YORK CITY, RENT AND REGULATION WILL GET YOU AN ARGUMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Lewis Is Winner In 60-Yard Dash
description: Carl Lewis got his revenge over the world-record holder in the 60-yard dash, Lee McRae, in The Dallas Morning News Indoor Games and signaled he may be ready to become a force again on the USA-Mobil Grand Prix circuit.

title: MUSIC: CONTINUUM IN TRIBUTE TO IVES
description: THE composer Charles Ives has been abundantly celebrated in recent years; as such, this listener found Continuum's program Saturday night at Alice Tully Hall, ''Ives the Visionary,'' somewhat less engaging than the group's usual performances. At this point, Ives does not need Continuum's advocacy as much as do most of the composers the group takes on (recent concerts have been devoted to new music from Israel, the avant-garde in the Soviet Union, the music of Arvo Part, Alfred Schnittke and the man who elevated the player piano into the world of high Modernism, Conlon Nancarrow.) That said, it is hard to imagine a more loving, intelligently planned and carefully executed tribute to Ives than the one that Joel Sachs and Cheryl Seltzer, the directors of Continuum, put together.

title: EX-CHINESE LEADER IS SAID TO BE AILING
description: Hu Yaobang, who resigned in disgrace as the chief of China's Communist Party three weeks ago, is hospitalized here, according to a Chinese source.

title: Accounts
description: * Information Builders Inc., to Geere, DuBois for Focus, a language/data base management product.

title: In New York City, Rent and Regulation Will Get You an Argument
description: To the Editor:

title: AN AIRPORT FOR BIRDS IN TUPELO
description: In Tupelo, Miss., the problem is blackbirds. Mike Barker, the manager of the Tupelo Municipal Airport, employs a cinematic simile to describe the area's blackbird population on the wing.

title: 2 Large Tax-Exempt Financings Set
description: The municipal bond market faces two large financings this week, both intended to take advantage of the steep drop in tax-exempt bond yields.

title: Atlanta Hopeful on Democrats
description: On the eve of the meeting to decide the site of the 1988 Democratic National Convention, city leaders in Atlanta were cautiously optimistic that they had taken the lead from Houston.

title: MAPLE LEAFS END RANGERS' STREAK, 5-4
description: It seems that the Rangers will never have another mundane night or play another boring game.

title: Major Fact Finding
description: In 1927, a man born George Herman Ehrhardt hit 60 home runs to set a major league record. He had a teammate born Ludwig Heinrich Gehrig.

title: FOR THE ELDERLY, DAY CARE IS FILLING GAPS
description: Every morning Mary Louise Skelton rises at 7, prepares breakfast for Lucille Hays and helps her get dressed. Then she drives her to the day-care center a mile away, gives her a peck on the cheek and goes off to work.

title: Worse Than a Blunder: a Crime
description: Blunder it assuredly was. The Iran-contra arms crisis involved reckless ransoming of hostages and covertly funding the Nicaraguan rebels. But ignorance and ineptitude, the Reagan Administration's first lines of defense, may not excuse its officials even in the eyes of the special prosecutor, much less the investigating Congress.

title: Dome Fights Swiss Action
description: Dome Petroleum, the Canadian oil and gas giant threatened with bankruptcy, has several options in defending itself against Swiss creditors who took court action last week to recover their money, the company said. ''But we're not about to deal our hand in public,'' a Dome spokesman, David Annesley, said on Friday.

title: BOITANO IS COUNTING ON QUADRUPLE LEAP
description: Armed with the knowledge that he can complete four rotations in the air and confident that he will make the first quadruple jump in competition, Brian Boitano is ready to take on all challengers for his world championship.

title: LIGHTER IS FASTER AT DAYTONA
description: Based on Bill Elliott's record winning speed of 197.802 miles an hour in yesterday's Busch Clash, the 150,000 fans who jam the Daytona International Speedway for next Sunday's Daytona 500 can assume that they will see one of the fastest Daytona races ever. Several teams broke speed records for the 2.5-mile high-banked Florida track in pre-season testing, with Kyle Petty's Ford Thunderbird fastest at 209.059 m.p.h.

title: MANILA'S NO. 1 CONGLOMERATE: PANEL SEIZING MARCOS WEALTH
description: In a little less than a year, a presidential commission seeking to recover the ''hidden wealth'' of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos has become in effect the nation's largest and most diversified conglomerate.

title: Acme Supermarket Goes to Thompson
description: J. Walter Thompson, New York, has won the Philadelphia-based Acme Supermarket account, estimated to be in the range of $8 million to $10 million.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. to Review Data Secrecy To keep sensitive information secret, the Pentagon will review data-processing contracts awarded to foreign companies, an official said. Page A13. More Local Tax Power? Cuts in Federal aid have prompted a movement by some state officials to give wider powers of taxation to local governments. Page A14. Lopez Wins 35th Golf Title Nancy Lopez captured the 35th title of her career to qualify for the Ladies Professional Golf Association Hall of Fame. SportsMonday, page C5. Unwanted 'Platoon' a Hit ''Platoon,'' a Vietnam War movie that no major Hollywood studio wanted to do, is the top-grossing film in the country this month. Page C13.

title: 2 Die in Texas Plane Crash
description: A pilot and his passenger were killed Friday night when their twin-engine plane crashed in a remote area southeast of here shortly after the pilot radioed that he was having instrument troubles. They were identified as Kenneth Barton, the pilot, who was chief of the volunteer fire department in Garrison, and Dr. Rufus Sprayberry, vice president for development at East Texas Baptist University in Marshall.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Man Dies in a Blast In Queens Apartment
description: The body of an unidentified man was found lying on the floor of the bathroom in a Hollis, Queens, apartment last night, apparently the victim of a small explosion, the police said.

title: Audrey Greenfeld Weds J. M. Sussman
description: Audrey Ann Greenfeld, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph T. Greenfeld of University Heights, Ohio, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Michael Sussman, a son of Phyllis Sussman of Cypress, Calif., and Gerald Sussman of Miami. Rabbi Ephraim Buchwald performed the ceremony at the Levana restaurant in New York.

title: SHULTZ RULES OUT 'STAR WARS' MOVE WITHIN TWO YEARS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, saying he was reflecting President Reagan's thinking, said today that no decision would made be made over the next two years on whether to start deploying elements of a ''Star Wars'' system in the early 1990's.

title: DANCE: BALLET RAMBERT AND THARP
description: ONE of the highlights of Ballet Rambert's just-ended weeklong season at City Center was ''Soda Lake,'' a solo choreographed by the company's director, Richard Alston. On Saturday afternoon Ben Craft took on the role with notable results.

title: MUSIC: RAS MICHAEL SINGS REGGAE
description: RAS MICHAEL celebrated Bob Marley's birthday on Friday at Sounds of Brazil with reggae at its most devotional, and least pop-directed. Reggae has roots in Rastafarian religion, which includes a sect known as Nyabingi, which has been translated as ''Death to black and white oppressors.'' Nyabingi cult ceremonies include music, which Ras Michael -whose original name was Michael Henry and is also known as Michael Enkrumah - brings to the stage.

title: Shamrock Rejects Latest Offer by Pickens Group
description: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation, as expected, tonight rejected an offer by an investor group led by T. Boone Pickens to acquire the company for about $2 billion in cash, or about $15 a share.

title: TRANSIT PLAN DEADLOCK: POLITICS FUEL CITY-SUBURB CLASH ON TAX INCREASE
description: Just six weeks after it was passed by the Legislature, a five-year $8.6 billion program to rebuild New York City's mass-transit system has ground to a halt - once again caught up in a conflict between the city and its suburbs over which area will pay increased taxes to finance the plan.

title: CRACK ADDICTION: THE TRAGIC TOLL ON WOMEN AND THEIR CHILDREN
description: In the two years since crack first struck New York City's poorest neighborhoods, the powerful form of cocaine has taken an unprecedented toll on women, children and families, according to newly gathered statistics and interviews with drug treatment experts.

title: SCHEER PICKED TO RUN NETS
description: After months of procrastination, the Nets will name Carl Scheer as their general manager next week. He replaces Lewis Schaffel, who resigned before the start of the season to head a group of investors that is trying to bring a National Basketball Association franchise to Miami.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing Upset Victory: Frank Woerndl, a journeyman who was almost dropped from the West German team earlier this year, scored an upset yesterday in the men's slalom at the close of the Alpine Ski World Championships in Crans-Montana, Switzerland. The 27-year-old Woerndl gave West Germany its first gold medal ever in the event and led a medal sweep over the favorites in the final event of the two-week championships. Guenther Mader of Austria, who was picked over Bernhard Gstrein, his teammate, just 24 hours before the race, took the silver to add to his bronze in the combined. Another West German, Armin Bittner, who led Woerndl by one-hundredth of a second after the first run, settled for the bronze. Felix McGrath of Norwich, Vt., the only American among the finishers, was 10th in 1 minute 56.29 seconds. He was less than two seconds behind Woerndl's winning time of 1:54.63.(AP) Auto Racing Elliott Wins: Bill Elliott charged back from an early deficit and pulled away to an easy victory in the $210,000 Busch Clash at Daytona International Speedway in Daytona Beach, Fla. Elliott, driving a new Ford Thunderbird, earned $75,000 for his first victory in the 20-lap, 50-mile dash for the previous season's pole-position winners. He drew the pole position for the short sprint in a blind draw Thursday, but slipped back to sixth in the 10-car field when the defending champion, Dale Earnhardt, Terry Labonte and Ricky Rudd tangled on the first lap just past the starting line. Elliott crossed the finish line about one car-length ahead of Geoff Bodine, who was just inches ahead of Waltrip. (AP) Tennis Noah Edges Nystrom: Top-seeded Yannick Noah of France defeated second-seeded Joakim Nystrom of Sweden, 6-4, 7-5, in the final of the men's $174,000 Lyon Grand Prix tennis tournament in France. The victory was worth $30,000 to Noah. Ranked fifth in the world, Noah had not beaten Nystrom, ranked two places lower, since the Stockholm tournament in 1981.(AP) Maleeva Tops Sabatini: Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria needed only an hour to defeat top-seeded Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina, 6-2, 6-2, in the final of a tournament in Halifax, Nova Scotia, for players 21 years and under. Maleeva, who will turn 20 years old Saturday, broke Sabatini, 16, twice in each set and held her serve throughout.(AP) Potter Ends Drought: In Wichita, top-seeded Barbara Potter won her first title since 1985, defeating second-seeded Larisa Savchenko of the Soviet Union in the final of the Virginia Slims of Kansas tournament, 7-6, 7-6.(AP) Horse Racing Landing Plot Takes Hollie Hughes: After appearing hopelessly blocked entering the stretch, Landing Plot found room along the rail in the final furlong and got up in time to edge Paris Venture by a half-length in the $69,700 Hollie Hughes Handicap for New York-bred 3-year-olds and up at Aqueduct. The 4-year-old son of Instrument Landing, who carried highweight of 119 and Jose Santos, went six furlongs in 1:11 on the fast track to record his eighth victory in 26 career starts. He earned $41,820 for Arthur Wendell, his owner and trainer, and returned $4.60 for $2 to win as the favorite of the crowd of 15,339. N.H.L. Oilers 6, Blues 2: Wayne Gretzky scored two goals and set up two others as Edmonton won at home. Gretzky scored in the first period and then set up Jari Kurri and Kevin Lowe in the second to give Edmonton a 3-2 lead going into the third. Gretzky scored his 52d goal on a breakaway 66 seconds into the third period. Kevin McClelland made it 5-2 before Kurri stung the Blues with a short-handed breakaway goal at 18:36. The Gretzky, Kurri and Esa Tikkanen line finished the night with 10 points. Kurri had an assist to go with his goals while Tikkanen had three assists.(AP) Nordiques 2, Bruins 1: Randy Moller scored on a 40-foot shot on his own rebound 18 minutes 33 seconds into the third period to give Quebec the victory in Boston. The Nordiques, who lead the league in penalty-killing, withstood six Boston manpower advantages in defeating the Bruins for the first time in five games.(AP) Sabres 7, Blackhawks 4: Adam Creighton scored two goals and Wilf Paiement added a goal and two assists as Buffalo won at home.(AP) M.I.S.L. Strikers 4, Express 2: In Bloomington, Minn., two goals by Steve Kinsey paced Minnesota. The loss was the ninth straight for the Express, who dropped to 2-22. The Strikers are 14-11.(AP)

title: BUSH AIDES WIDEN DISPUTE OVER IRAN
description: Aides to Vice President Bush asserted today that other senior officials at the White House knew last summer that contacts were under way with radical, not moderate, elements in Iran seeking to free American hostages in Lebanon.

title: SOUTH KOREA WELCOMES FAMILY FLEEING NORTH
description: Eleven North Koreans who escaped by boat to Japan arrived in Seoul today to a hero's welcome, marking a rare defection by North Korean civilians to the South.

title: N.F.L. Catch-22
description: The National Football League is said to be increasingly concerned at not having a single black head coach among its 28 teams, even though more than half the players in the league are black. That concern cannot have been eased by the Atlanta Falcons' announcement this week of their new head coach.

title: SAUDI OIL WEAPON IS FACTOR IN WAR
description: Saudi Arabia is walking a tightrope trying to balance its economic interests with its desire for political stability in the Persian Gulf, according to Saudi and diplomatic sources.

title: LANDMARKS PANEL FACES UNCERTAINTY OVER MEMBERSHIP AND RULES
description: Dedicated to New York City's past but anxious about its own future, the Landmarks Preservation Commission may find itself by year's end with many different members and new ways of doing business.

title: Picking a Neighbor
description: The Hotel Washington, with more than 80 years at the corner of Pennsylvania Avenue and 15th Street N.W., is naturally interested in keeping up the tone of the neighborhood. Fully aware that there will be a new tenant in the White House, just a block away, in less than two years, the hotel is asking all its customers these days: ''Who should be our neighbor in 1988?''

title: Arbitrator Rules Against Padres
description: After deciding for the clubs in two cases, Raymond Goetz, the arbitrator, awarded Andy Hawkins, a San Diego pitcher, a $535,000 salary yesterday over the Padres' figure of $450,000.

title: Symphonic Music Needs More Fanfare
description: To the Editor:

title: Panel Finds Advertiser Misuses the Word 'Free'
description: The interpretation of the word ''free'' has called for the creation of a panel by the National Advertising Review Board, the supreme court of the advertising self-regulation system.

title: TIMES NAMES AD EXECUTIVE
description: Jack Lucey has been named advertising director of operations for The New York Times, Erich G. Linker Jr., The Times' vice president for advertising, announced last week.

title: CORAL GABLES PREPARES FOR FUTURE BY DRAWING ON ITS GRAND PAST
description: This suburb of Miami is preparing for the future by dusting off its past, encouraging a civic facelift by promoting the old instead of the new.

title: Yamani Looks to Swiss
description: The former Saudi Arabian oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, has applied for a permit to reside in the Swiss mountain resort of Crans-Montana, a Justice Ministry spokesman said Friday. The request was being examined, he said.

title: LEBANON CAPTORS REPEAT THREAT TO KILL HOSTAGES
description: A clandestine group that last month kidnapped three American professors and an Indian academic here today repeated its threat to kill them unless 400 Arabs held in Israeli jails are freed.

title: President For Calet, Hirsch
description: RONALD K. SHERMAN joins Calet, Hirsch & Spector today as president. In doing so, he is once again in the company of Glen W. Fortinberry, chairman and president of Ross Roy Inc., Detroit, the parent company of C.H.&S. The two had worked together in the Detroit office of J. Walter Thompson until 1975, when Mr. Fortinberry became president of the agency's Eastern establishment, including the New York office, and Mr. Sherman became general manager in New York.

title: RITTER AND SELLECCA IN 'THE LAST FLING'
description: IT'S all a matter of style. ''The Last Fling,'' tonight's television movie on ABC at 9, tries hard, and often rather amiably, to be what used to be known as a romantic romp. Billy Wilder, in his ''Some Like It Hot'' period, would probably have pulled it off with great dollops of panache. Television, insistently clumsy, gives us silliness that keeps toppling into stupidity. Corey Allen gets credit for the direction but this is clearly another television production pasted together by committee.

title: The U.N. Today: FEB. 9, 1979
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Not So Simple
description: To the Editor:

title: Audio Chain Leader Likes Smaller Cities
description: Stuart A. Rose started in 1980 with four electronics stores in Dayton, Ohio, and has turned them into a company with 106 stores in 16 states. Now he wants his business to get bigger.

title: Army Copter Crash Kills 4
description: Four Army soldiers were killed Friday night when their helicopter crashed in a remote, swampy area as they were flying to assist civilians who were injured in a traffic accident, officials said. The identity of one of the victims was withheld pending notification of his family. The others were First Lieut. James Belcher, 23 years old, of Mayodan, N.C., the pilot; Specialist 4 Jerome Barchel, 23, of Midway, Ga., and Sgt. First Class Doyle Cannon, 40, of Elmhurst, Ill. Officials would not speculate on the cause of the crash.

title: LEGAL AND ILLEGAL, GOLD PROSPECTORS SLOG INTO BORNEO JUNGLES
description: Indonesia is caught up in gold fever.

title: On Changing the Senate
description: One of the more radical programs for reform of the United States Senate in recent years has been put forward, to the astonishment of some of his colleagues, under the name of Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, the States Rights candidate for President in 1948, a pioneer among Southern Democrats-turning-Republican (1964) and an established pillar of conservatism.

title: PREMIUMS SLACKEN, WORRYING INSURERS
description: Despite two years of rapidly rising premiums, the property and casualty insurance industry is jittery again.

title: Moynihan Pledges To Support Cuomo
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan yesterday pledged his support for Governor Mario Cuomo if the Governor decided to seek the Presidency.

title: Angotti Gets KLM
description: The two-year-old agency Angotti, Thomas, Hedge has been awarded the more than $5 million KLM Royal Dutch Airlines account. The previous agency, Ogilvy & Mather, had handled the account for the last 25 years.

title: MUSIC: ROSTROPOVICH AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: AT Carnegie Hall Saturday night Mstislav Rostropovich continued this month's extended celebration of his 60th birthday with all the expansiveness and exuberance we have come to expect.

title: STATES ACT TO GIVE LOCALITIES MORE POWER TO COLLECT TAXES
description: Many city and county governments have been so weakened by cuts in Federal aid that state officials around the country, despite a history of bitter relations with their cities and counties, have begun a movement to persuade their legislatures to give the local governments broader taxing powers.

title: LIABILITY RATES FLATTENING OUT AS CRISIS EASES
description: The insurance crisis that stalled many everyday activities across the country last year because of coverage cancellations and sharp premium increases is ending as abruptly as it began.

title: ALFRED LION, 78, THE FOUNDER OF THE BLUE NOTE JAZZ LABEL
description: Alfred Lion, who founded the influential Blue Note Records jazz label, died last Monday of heart failure at Pomerado Hospital in the San Diego suburb of Poway. He was 78 years old.

title: Ex-Officer of Times Co. Will Join Rothschild Inc.
description: Sydney Gruson, a former vice chairman and director of The New York Times Company, plans a new career in investment banking. On March 2, he will join Rothschild Inc. as a senior adviser.

title: Budd's Injuries Jeopardize Career
description: Zola Budd will fly to West Germany this week for treatment for injuries that could end the runner's career, British press reports said today.

title: Rotation for Fed Panel
description: This week's key meeting of the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee to establish monetary targets for 1987 will be the last before the panel's annual rotation of regional presidents occurs March 1. The shift assumes additional importance because of two current vacancies on the Federal Reserve Board. Until they are filled, there are only 10 votes on the market committee - five board members, four rotating presidents and the president of the New York Fed, a permanent slot.

title: Pavin Wins in Extra Holes
description: Corey Pavin topped a six-stroke comeback with a 20-foot birdie putt on the second playoff hole and successfully defended his title today in the Hawaiian Open golf tournament.

title: KONTOS GOALS BEAT DEVILS, 2-1
description: In a defensive struggle between teams trying to avoid last place in the Patrick Division, Chris Kontos scored 2 minutes 12 seconds into overtime to give the Penguins a 2-1 triumph over the Devils tonight at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Analysts Find JWT In a 'Somber' Mood
description: The mood at last Thursday evening's meeting of securities analysts called by the JWT Group Inc. was, according to Vance Brown, an analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., ''somber at best.''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A TRIPLE DELIGHT A trio of operas, performed by the After Dinner Opera Company, awaits the venturesome music-lover today at 4 P.M. at Lincoln Center. The company is presenting concert versions of three short American works in the Bruno Walter Auditorium of the Lincoln Center Library, 111 Amsterdam Avenue, at 65th Street.

title: JUDGE ROBBED AS MANY WATCH
description: Several late-night moviegoers watched while a judge was assaulted and robbed near a downtown newsstand but none of them helped her, the judge said today.

title: End the Sanctions Against Poland
description: Poland remains a police state, but once again it tolerates the most freedom in Eastern Europe. Its Government is still widely loathed, but now tries harder to court popular opinion. Polish democrats are still hounded, but now face heavy financial penalties rather than jail.

title: MUSIC: MATHIS AND MANCINI
description: JOHNNY MATHIS and Henry Mancini, who recently collaborated on an album of songs from Hollywood musicals, both preside over a pop tradition that seems increasingly valuable the more it becomes eclipsed by rock and synthesizer music. Thirty years after he had his first hit, ''Wonderful, Wonderful,'' Mr. Mathis still interprets richly orchestrated pop ballads with a breathlessly enraptured intensity that is adolescent in its fervor yet sophisticated in its intonation and dynamics. Mr. Mancini's pioneering film scores helped to bring big-band jazz as well as a more flexible, intimate pop chamber approach to the creation of movie and television soundtracks.

title: WILLIAM CHILTON 3dm FIREBRAND PUBLISHER FROM WEST VIRGINIA
description: William E. Chilton 3d, the firebrand publisher of The Charleston Gazette, died of a heart attack Saturday while playing in a squash tournament in Washington, D.C. He was 65 years old.

title: In Defense of a Raise
description: Senator Ted Stevens, Republican of Alaska, has a very simple explanation for his support of the Congressional pay increase that went into effect, at least temporarily, last week. When he was appointed to the Senate in 1968, Mr. Stevens recalled at a dinner with reporters, he exchanged a private salary of about $100,000 a year for a public one of about $30,000. Although members of Congress have since been brought in stages to $68,000 a year, he calculates that he is now receiving $27,000 a year in 1968 dollars, or a reduction of 10 percent for his 18 years of service, experience and increasing seniority.

title: 'TV TOYS': DEBUT AND DEBATE
description: A new generation of electronic toys designed to be used by children as they watch specific cartoon shows on television are to be featured this week at the New York Toy Fair.

title: A RECOUNT: 1,060 PAIRS, NOT 3,000
description: One of the mysteries of Manila's ''hidden wealth'' investigation is the origin of the report that Imelda R. Marcos owned 3,000 pairs of shoes.

title: Santucci Investments: 3 Queens Properties
description: District Attorney John J. Santucci of Queens said recently that he and his family own three pieces of income-producing property - stores and apartments - in Richmond Hill.

title: Correction
description: The Talking Business column in Business Day on Tuesday, about Volvo and international business, gave an incorrect figure for the Swedish auto maker's 1986 profits. It earned $1.14 billion before taxes.

title: OUT OF OBSCURITY: SANTUCCI UNDER SEIGE
description: After a decade of relative obscurity as the District Attorney of Queens, John J. Santucci now finds himself in a whirlwind of controversy that has focused attention on his record and judgment as a prosecutor.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday None Thursday Retail Sales January Friday Producer Prices January Inventory-Sales Ratio January

title: OUTDOORS: GEARING UP IN OFFSEASON
description: FOR the first time in several years, I have made an early start at readying my fishing gear for the forthcoming season, at practicing that which I so glibly preach.

title: Briefcases
description: The Energy Department, which will disclose tomorrow its site-selection process for the $4.4 billion supercollider atom smasher, is said to be interested in using this as bait to induce Texas, Nevada or Washington State to accept a nuclear waste repository.

title: Market Place; Views Differ As I.B.M. Rises
description: THE stock price of the International Business Machines Corporation fell 22 percent in 1986, while the Dow Jones industrial average was climbing 22 percent. Last month, after I.B.M. released another lackluster earnings report, its shares sagged to $115.75.

title: Moves at Sonic Pay Off As Chief Seeks Church's
description: As the discussions of a potential takeover of Church's Fried Chicken Inc. progressed last week, it became clear that C. Stephen Lynn, the 39-year-old chairman, president and chief executive of Sonic Industries, was the man to watch. Sonic is an Oklahoma City-based drive-in hamburger chain.

title: INDIANA WINS BIG AS ALFORD SCORES 30
description: It took a while for Indiana's Steve Alford to start scoring against Michigan today, but once he did there was no stopping him.

title: LOPEZ WINS TO QUALIFY FOR HALL OF FAME
description: Nancy Lopez shot a 2-over-par 74 and weathered a challenge from Kathy Baker to win the $200,000 Sarasota Classic by three strokes today, a victory that qualifies her for induction into the Ladies Professional Golf Association Hall of Fame.

title: BUSINESS DEIGES: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 9, 1987
description: The Economy The liability insurance crisis appears to be over after two years of coverage cancellations and sharp increases in premiums. Companies that could not buy coverage at any price are now finding it, and premiums have leveled off. But coverage is more expensive, and less extensive, than before. [ Page A1. ] Net income of many insurers should rise 20 percent or more this year, but signs of softening are expected soon, analysts said. [ D5. ] No change in Fed policy is expected at this week's meeting of the Open Market Committee, but the Fed's report to Congress next week will be closely read for hints of what to expect. [ D1. ] Anti-apartheid groups are increasing pressure on local governments to tighten their laws to make U.S. companies leaving South Africa completely sever ties with all businesses there. [ D1. ] Companies The domestic machine tool industry has shrunk considerably since 1982. Cincinnati Milacron is turning attention to making robots, laser devices and plastic-processing equipment. [ D1. ] Advanced systems are getting some attention at Cross & Trecker, but the company contends that streamlined operations can still profitably produce traditional machine tools. [ D1. ] Diamond Shamrock's board rejected a $2 billion offer by an investor group led by T. Boone Pickens. [ D2. ] A new generation of electronic toys that coordinate with television shows are to be featured at the New York Toy Fair. [ D3. ] International Brazil's anti-inflation program has collapsed 11 months after it began. With interest rates soaring, financial experts say the country is facing either hyperinflation or a deep recession. [ D1. ] West Germany seems reluctant to stimulate its economy, despite lower growth projections and higher unemployment. [ D4. ] Indonesian gold deposits are attracting international mining companies and thousands of fortune seekers. [ D4. ] Today's Columns A proposal for leniency for troubled thrift institutions has the backing of Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House. The proposal is part of a long-stalled bill to recapitalize the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation. Washington Watch. [ D2. ] I.B.M. regained ground last week, but opinion about the company remains divided. Most of the bad news may already be known, several analysts say, but they still cannot work up much enthusiasm about the shares. Market Place. [ D6. ]

title: Get Off the Floor
description: The media used the occasion of Mr. Reagan's 76th birthday to clobber him.

title: TOLL FROM CHILD-ABUSE IS CORRECTED BY KANSAS
description: Kansas officials say they overstated the number of children who died of abuse or neglect in their state last year. They said there were 12 deaths, not 21 as reported.

title: NEWS SUMMERY: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 9, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-A12 Deploying ''Star Wars'' elements will be not be decided upon over the next two years, according to Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who said he was reflecting President Reagan's thinking. Page A1 Andrei D. Sakharov sees change in the Soviet handling of human rights but does not know how far it's going to go. He said in an interview, ''Something real is happening.'' A1 White House officials knew in 1986 that the United States was dealing with radical, not moderate, elements in Iran to gain the release of American hostages in Lebanon, aides to Vice President Bush said. A1 Leading senators are divided over the propriety and wisdom of the Reagan Administration's policy of soliciting money from foreign governments to help the Nicaraguan rebels and other guerrilla groups. A8 A threat to kill hostages in Beirut came from a clandestine group that kidnapped three American professors and an Indian scholar last month. The group seeks the release of 400 Arabs held in Israeli jails. A8 A hostage's family is 'holding on,' according to the American wife of Alec Collett, a 65-year-old British journalist working for the United Nations who disappeared almost two years ago in Lebanon. A8 In Manila, finding the 'hidden wealth' of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos is the task assigned to a presidential commission that, in less than a year, has become in effect the nation's largest conglomerate. A1 Mrs. Marcos left 1,060 pairs of shoes and slippers behind, according to a new inventory, including one battery-run pair that glows in the dark. It had been reported that she owned 3,000 pairs. A12 A party power-struggle in Britain is under way, as Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her opponents position themselves for a general election that could reshape party politics. The election date has not been set. A3 Botswana has lived under a shadow of what some call ''demonstration sanctions'' by its neighbor, South Africa, for almost two months. A South African tribal ''homeland'' has in effect demanded recognition by requiring Botswana citizens to obtain visas. A4 Hu Yaobang is in a Peking hospital for an undisclosed illness, according to a Chinese source, three weeks after he resigned in disgrace as the chief of China's Communist Party. He was said to be ''distraught.'' A3 NATIONAL A13-16, B12 The cost of medical care rose 7.7 percent last year, or seven times as fast as overall inflation, according to new Government data that indicate medical inflation remains a serious problem. A1 The U.S. insurance crisis is ending as abruptly as it began. Last year, liability insurance was hard to get because companies, citing coverage cancellations and sharp premium increases, refused to renew policies. A1 Teen-agers who mediate conflicts are the mainstay of Project Smart, which has outposts in six New York City high schools and is part of a national movement to tap the positive force of peer pressure. A1 The Pentagon will review contracts on military data processing given to foreign countries in the hope of preventing leaks of information to foreign governments, a Defense Department official says. A13 More local taxing powers for cities are being pressed by state officials around the country because cuts in Federal aid have so weakened many city and county governments. A14 A Miami suburb is getting a facelift by promoting the old instead of the new. An ordinance adopted last year created special districts within Coral Gables, Fla., to encourage development in its Mediterranean style. A14 A new bridge across the Tampa Bay in southwest Florida, the Sunshine Skyway Bridge, connects St. Petersburg with Bradenton and Sarasota, making largely rural portions of the state easily accessible. A15 Philadelphia's court system is mired in a crisis, plagued by corruption charges and a growing backlog of cases.
