Officials say these factors could force the city to start releasing inmates from jail next month. A16 A charge of child stealing has been made against an Illinois mother who, with her husband, was honored by the state in 1982 as ''Adoptive Family of the Year.'' She has been jailed in Tijuana, Mexico. B12 'Platoon' is the top-grossing movie in the country this month, showing that America's relationship to the Vietnam War has changed drastically in recent years. ''It's touching a nerve,'' said one film executive. C13 WASHINGTON TALK B6 A battle over drug fight's cost They who were Senate chairmen REGIONAL A17, B1-4, D11 Crack has stricken families, women and children in particular, since it first struck New York City's poorest neighborhoods two years ago, according to newly gathered statistics and interviews. B1 A child loses mother to crack B2 Queens' District Attorney is unsure if he will seek a fourth term. That is what John J. Santucci says after being caught in a whirlwind that has focused attention on his record and judgment as a prosecutor. B1 Thieves at Cardinal O'Connor's home ransacked his bedroom, rifled a desk in his private office and rummaged through several other rooms. Both thieves escaped. B1 Jury selection in a civil rights case brought against The Daily News by four black journalists three years ago is scheduled to begin today. Representatives of both sides predict a bitter courtroom battle. B2 News analysis: Transit politics B2 Landmarks panel faces uncertainty B3 Salmonella traced in Connecticut D11 NEEDIEST CASES A17

title: Three Killed and 26 Wounded By Bomb in Pakistan Bazaar
description: A bomb exploded today in a crowded bazaar here, killing three people and wounding 26, a hospital spokesman said.

title: Battle Over Utility Refunds
description: A fierce lobbying battle has emerged over what to do with about $15 billion that utilities have collected from their customers for tax payments that will no longer be owed. The $15 billion has been accumulated by electric, gas, water and telephone companies on the assumption that their Federal income-tax rate would be 46 percent. Under the Tax Reform Act of 1986, however, the corporate rate drops in July to 34 percent and customers, all parties agree, are due refunds.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE DINNER PARTY. By Howard Fast. 250 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $17.95.

title: MAKING FRIENDS LATE IN LIFE
description: ''LAST year was a good year for me because I made two new friends,'' said Eva Katz, a 77-year-old widow who lives in the Bronx. ''Their companionship and emotional support added a lot to my life.''

title: Van Kampen Gets New Chief
description: John C. Merritt has been named chairman and chief executive of Van Kampen Merritt, the investment banking arm of Xerox Financial Services Inc.

title: CHARLES BUSCH IN BENEFIT
description: Charles Busch, the author and star of the comedy ''Vampire Lesbians of Sodom,'' will appear in a benefit performance on Feb. 16 at 8 P.M. at the Provincetown Playhouse, 133 Macdougal Street. The evening will feature Mr. Busch in his one-man show ''Alone With a Cast of Thousands.'' Proceeds will benefit the AIDS Resource Center and the Gay Men's Health Crisis. Tickets are $100. Information: 477-5048.

title: THE DANCE: RANJANA
description: RANJANA HAKSAR WATSON describes her company as ''all-American.''

title: Nonbanks and Nonbank Nonbanks
description: LEAD: The 100th Congress is faced with a question: ''What is a bank?'' The Congress, the courts and the public cannot agree.

title: Federal Power Over Nuclear Power
description: Should nuclear power be regulated by the Federal Government or the states? Only Washington has the technical expertise and the duty to weigh the national interest. But states including New York and Massachusetts refuse to cooperate in emergency evacuation plans for the plants at Shoreham and Seabrook, effectively blocking their start-ups. The staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission now proposes to remove this veto power. That would be a welcome and overdue step.

title:
COLLEGE BASKETBALL;
CAROLINA SAVED BY REID IN OVERTIME
description: LEAD: The North Carolina Tar Heels were in serious trouble today when, with less than two minutes remaining in overtime, Mel Kennedy of Virginia scored a rebound basket to force the eighth tie of the Atlantic Coast Conference game.

title: Canada Jobless Rate Up
description: Canada's unemployment rate rose to 9.7 percent in January after holding steady at 9.4 percent for the previous three months, Statistics Canada said Friday. But the Government agency said the rise, adjusted for seasonal variations, was largely the result of a strong increase in the labor force rather than a loss of jobs.

title: Briton Sets Mark In Breast-Stroke
description: Adrian Moorhouse of Britain set a world best time for 25-meter pools in the 100-meter breast-stroke today, clocking 59.75 seconds. It was the first time a swimmer broke the one-minute barrier for the 100-meter breast-stroke at a 25-meter pool meet.

title: Fed Charges Iowa Bank
description: The financially troubled Hawkeye Bancorporation, once one of the country's biggest agricultural lenders, has been charged by the Federal Reserve Board with unsafe banking practices because the holding company refused to save one of its banks from collapse.

title: Savings Bond Sales Increase
description: Sales of United States savings bonds totaled $710 million in January, as the total amount of savings bonds held by the public reached a record $93.11 billion, the Government reported.

title: BRAZIL ECONOMY: FAITH TURNS TO FEAR
description: One evening last week, a successful local businessman who has always preached ''faith in Brazil'' sat glumly in a restaurant and confessed almost apologetically: ''This afternoon, I canceled a major investment.''

title: Hurling Sabbatical
description: Pitching at Yankee Stadium last May 2, Ed Correa allowed just three hits in a 7-0 Texas victory, the only shutout the Yankees would suffer until the last game before the All-Star break. His performance was first rate, but the 20-year-old Ranger wasn't feeling first rate. ''I don't know how I did it,'' he said the other day. ''I was fighting myself. My mind wasn't really there.'' Correa felt uncomfortable because he was pitching on a Friday night and thus violating a tenet of his Christian denomination. A Seventh-day Adventist from birth, he has never felt right playing on his Sabbath, and at the end of a 12-14 rookie season last fall he talked about it to the front office. This year the Rangers plan to juggle their rotation so that Correa won't play Friday nights or Saturday afternoons.

title: LANE OF PITT FINDING REWARDS IN A ROLE WITH LITTLE GLAMOUR
description: EARLIER in the season, one of the easiest ways to get on Jerome Lane's bad side was to call the University of Pittsburgh sophomore forward a great garbage player.

title: 3 PUBLISHING VETERANS OPEN BOOK COMPANIES
description: Three veteran book publishers who were edged out of top jobs at major houses are returning as the heads of their own small companies. And one of them - Barney Rosset, the founder of Grove Press - is returning with a new work by Samuel Beckett, the Nobel laureate.

title: Reagan's SALT II Folly
description: President Reagan's reaffirmation, in his State of the Union Message, of the importance of protecting our country was deeply ironic, coming on the heels of his decision to violate the SALT II treaty. This decision marked the first time either superpower has violated the treaty sublimit on missiles and bombers, thereby risking an accelerated nuclear arms race. Few Americans want the Russians to have thousands of extra nuclear warheads, yet that is where our current course will take us.

title: GIFTS TO NEEDIEST SENT BY PEOPLE WHO HAD PUT OFF DONATIONS
description: Several people who had put off giving to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have finally done so with gifts to the 75th annual appeal.

title: Japan's Raises Seen at a Low
description: Japanese workers, the world's highest paid, will probably receive their smallest wage increase ever this year, economists say.

title: 'MODEL' ADOPTIVE PARENT IS JAILED ON CHARGES OF CHILD STEALING
description: An Illinois mother honored as an adoptive parent has been jailed in Tijuana, Mexico, charged with child stealing.

title: Hal Riney's Latest
description: Hal Riney & Partners, San Francisco, which has won the heart of America with its commercials for Bartles & Jaymes wine coolers and Gallo wine, will be turning its creative talents loose on the computer products of PC's Limited of Austin, described by Business Week as ''the hottest little computer maker in Texas.'' The company is two years old. Its founder, Michael Dell, is 21. And the budget is $5 million.

title: SOVIET SPACECRAFT REACHES LAB
description: Two Soviet astronauts aboard a Soyuz spacecraft docked Saturday with the orbiting space station Mir, the official news agency Tass said.

title: Dr. Lloyd Loft Is Married to Diane S. VanDerster
description: Diane Susan VanDerster, a daughter of Mrs. Robert M. Bernstein of Rye Brook, N.Y., and the late George Joseph VanDerster, was married yesterday to Dr. Lloyd Mark Loft, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel M. Loft of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Bernhard H. Rosenberg performed the ceremony at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J.

title: A TEST FOR CRYPTOCLEARANCE
description: Things should be looking sunny for Cryptoclearance. The 3-year-old Fappiano colt passed the most important test of his career with style here Saturday, digging in through the stretch to win the Grade II Everglades Stakes in the final yards in his first race over a mile. The problem is timing: The Kentucky Derby, his major goal, is still a dozen weeks away.

title: BRITISH POLITICS: ONE EYE ON A 3D FORCE
description: Although the date of the general election has not been set, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her major opponents are now engaged in a serious struggle to position themselves for a contest that could reshape party politics in Britain.

title: Literary Tenants
description: ''I am not going to close another bookstore in this city,'' Suzanne Zavrian declared recently, with considerable resolve, while she sat among the fine books that crowd the diminutive Pomander Bookshop at 252 West 95th Street. As she spoke, a young customer bought a scholarly anthology of ancient Chinese poetry - on impulse.

title: STUDIOS AGREE ON TV PACKAGE FOR CHINA
description: Two American studios have signed a major television licensing agreement with China's only national television network, an arrangement that will beam such shows as ''Star Trek'' into Chinese households.

title: MEDICAL-CARE COST ROSE 7.7% IN '86, COUNTER TO TREND
description: The cost of medical care rose 7.7 percent last year, seven times as fast as the Consumer Price Index for all items, according to new Government data.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''I want to deploy it - I believe that the President wants to deploy just as soon as we can.'' Caspar W. Weinberger. A11:1

title: CHAMBERS REWRITES ALL-STAR PLOT
description: There was talk throughout the weekend about a storybook finish, as if the hero of pro basketball's annual playground game was preordained.

title: SOVIET DISSIDENTS ASK IF RELEASES ARE A REAL SHIFT OR JUST A GESTURE
description: Andrei D. Sakharov stood in his hallway today and weighed the question: Is there evidence yet of a real shift in the Soviet handling of human rights, or have there been only gestures designed to deceive the West?

title: THE MATTER OF MONEY AND FIGHTING DRUGS
description: ''It's absolutely unconscionable, terrifyingly stupid,'' remarked Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL COLLEGES: Syracuse vs. Pittsburgh, 7:30 P.M. (TV - ESPN, 7:30 P.M.) Franklin Pierce at C.W. Post, 6:00 P.M.

title: STUART T. SAUNDERS, DRIVING FORCE BEHIND PENN CENTRAL, DIES AT 77
description: Stuart T. Saunders, a railroad merger specialist who was a driving force in the creation of the Penn Central Railroad and who served as its chairman, died Saturday of heart failure at Stuart Circle Hospital in Richmond, Va. He was 77 years old.

title: Karrinyup Kangaroos
description: NEAR the third tee at the Lake Karrinyup Country Club, black swans, pelicans, cranes and ducks could be seen splashing. Off in a eucalyptus tree, a kookaburra laughed, understandably. Three wandering Yanks, turning a lay day into a play day, were about to swing their drivers. With a loopy lunge, one who shall be known as Kindred Spirit pushed his tee shot toward trees and palm bushes. Watching the ball's flight, Fenway George, who sees the world better with one eye than most people do with two, sighted them first.

title: Man Linked to Drug Suspect Seized in Panama, U.S. Says
description: Federal agents and the Panamanian police have arrested a man they say conspired with Carlos Lehder Rivas, a Colombian who has been accused of running the world's largest cocaine supply ring, a Federal Drug Enforcement Administration agent said Saturday.

title: PRETORIA TURNS UP HEAT AND BOTSWANA SWEATS
description: For almost two months now, this quiet, sparsely populated land has been living under the threatening shadow of what some here call ''demonstration sanctions'' by its looming southern neighbor, South Africa.

title: PHILADELPHIA COURTS FACE QUANDARY
description: The municipal court system here, plagued by charges of corruption and a growing backlog of cases, is mired in a crisis that could force the city to start releasing inmates from jail next month, court and state officials say.

title: U.S. Aide Urges South Korea To Alter Its Political System
description: A high-ranking State Department official has called for ''a more open and legitimate political system'' in South Korea, terming it essential for that nation's long-term stability.

title: Taiwan Trade Surplus
description: Taiwan's trade surplus surged in January, officials said Friday, and economists said they were optimistic about prospects for further growth in the first quarter. The surplus rose to $1.41 billion last month, from $1.39 billion in December and $1.26 billion in January 1986. Trade volume totalled $5.25 billion, compared with $5.95 billion in December and $4.94 billion in January 1986.

title: CONNECTICUT HEALTH EXPERTS TRACE TAINTED FOOD OUTBREAKS
description: Using a new personal computer, analysts at the State Health Services Department here are trying to sort out who ate what, who became ill and who did not last weekend at a popular West Hartford restaurant where an outbreak of salmonella poisoning infected more than 100 patrons and workers.

title: N.H.L. TRIES SOMETHING NEW
description: About 18 months ago, when the management of the Quebec Nordiques was approached with the idea of being host to the National Hockey League All-Star Game, Marcel Aubut had an idea of his own.

title: WARREN ARTHUR BAHR
description: Warren Arthur Bahr, a former chief operating officer of the advertising agency Isidore Lefkowitz & Elgort Inc., died at his home in North Salem, N.Y., on Friday. He was 62 years old.

title: Defense! Defense!
description: In an era when the National Collegiate Athletic Association's enforcement caseload seems to grow by the hour, a number of member schools are turning to outside legal specialists to help them cope with the complex thicket of N.C.A.A. regulations and the intricacies of the infractions process.

title: Trooper Killed in Missouri
description: A Missouri highway patrolman was shot and killed here today as he sat in his patrol car, the authorities said. Russell W. Harper, 45 years old, of Springfield, an 18-year veteran, was killed by one of several bullets that pierced his car, said Sgt. Sam Kaunley, a highway patrol spokesman. Sergeant Kaunley said a witness told the police that a white man wearing camouflage trousers, a dark sweatshirt and a blue and white cap got out of a red pickup truck and fired shots at the patrol car.

title: President Resigns From Spendthrift
description: Robert R. Hagopian, president and chief executive officer of the financially troubled Spendthrift Farm Inc., resigned Saturday, the thoroughbred operation announced.

title: SENATORS SPLIT ON WHITE HOUSE POLICY OF SOLICITING CASH FOR CONTRAS
description: As details increase on how the Reagan Administration solicited money from foreign governments to help the Nicaraguan rebels and other anti-Communist insurgent groups around the world, leading senators remain divided over the propriety and wisdom of the unorthodox policy.

title: BITTER FIGHT IS PREDICTED IN DAILY NEWS RACIAL DISCRIMINATION TRIAL
description: Jury selection is scheduled to begin today for the trial of a combined group of civil rights suits brought almost three years ago against The Daily News by four black journalists. Representatives of both sides predict a bitter courtroom battle.

title: NO FIGHTING IS REPORTED
description: A 60-day cease-fire with the Communist rebels ended today, and although both sides said they were prepared to return to war, there were no immediate reports of military engagements.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Has there ever been a team triple-crown winner in the major leagues, one that in the same season had one player win the league's home run title, another player win the runs-batted-in title and a third player win the batting title?

title: 2 RANSACK RESIDENCE OF CARDINAL
description: Two intruders ransacked John Cardinal O'Connor's bedroom, rifled a desk in his private office and rummaged through several other rooms behind St. Patrick's Cathedral last night, the police said.

title: Bridge: New Functions Are Found For Doubles and Redoubles
description: Bridge theorists, like economists, worry about unemployment. In the past decade they have found uses for several unemployed doubles and redoubles.

title: 17 SPECIALTIES SET WESTMINSTER STAGE
description: Although 17 specialty shows at 10 sites in the metropolitan area caused the principal excitement among dog fanciers yesterday, they were only a prelude to the main event. That show, the 111th annual Westminster Kennel Club event, begins at Madison Square Garden this morning and ends late tomorrow night.

title: Geoffrion Released From Hospital
description: Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion was released from Hotel Dieu hospital today, less than a day after collapsing at a Hockey Hall of Fame exhibit.

title: HEXTALL MAKING HIMSELF HEARD
description: HE is slightly eccentric, but that seems fashionable among the National Hockey League's goaltenders who, rookies or not, are an uninhibited breed. Ron Hextall, the 22-year-old all-star newcomer who is arguably the most successful goaltender the league has to offer at the moment, is also, and without question, its noisiest.

title: TACTICS IN BABY M TRIAL
description: For five days last week, negative upon negative about Mary Beth Whitehead's life was piled into the court record of the Baby M custody case.

title: NEW TAMPA BAY BRIDGE CALLED SYMBOL OF PROGRESS
description: Seven years after a tanker rammed the Sunshine Skyway Bridge, killing 35 motorists, a sleek new span across Tampa Bay has been dedicated.

title: Why the Minimum Wage Should Be Raised
description: To the Editor:

title: DAVIDSON DUNTON
description: Davidson Dunton, a former journalist and retired president of Carleton University, died in a hospital here Saturday. He was 74 years old.

title: Condoms Handed Out During Church Service
description: A Unitarian Universalist minister distributed condoms to his congregation during a worship service Sunday, saying the spread of AIDS must stop and condoms would help.

title: DANCE: RALPH LEMON AND COMPANY
description: RALPH LEMON AND COMPANY opened a new series this weekend that will present a New York showcase for experimental work developed over the summers at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, Mass.

title: Nicaraguans Feel Disdain for Contras
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESSES SEEK CACHET OF A PRICETON ADDRESS
description: Physical Princeton covers only a few square miles just west of U.S. Route 1. But a kind of metaphysical Princeton, part prestige, part post office box number, has cast its boundaries far and wide.

title: CAPTIVE TWICE REPORTED DEAD, WIFE IS 'HOLDING ON'
description: It has been almost two years since Alec Collett, a 65-year-old British journalist working for the United Nations, disappeared in Lebanon, but his American wife says she and their 13-year-old son are ''holding on.''

title: Hart and Dole Ahead In Iowa, Survey Shows
description: Gary Hart was the first choice for President among Iowa Democrats, while Senator Robert Dole was the leader among Republicans, according to a poll published today.

title: CITY BALLET: SILENT 'MOVES'
description: THERE seem to be a remarkable number of dancegoers with bronchitis at each performance of ''Moves,'' a ballet by Jerome Robbins that was presented by the New York City Ballet last Wednesday at the New York State Theater. And the ballet's performers always seem to seethe coolly with emotion. The reason seems to lie in the fact that the ballet is performed in silence.

title: Washington Watch; Wright Pushes Thrift Unit Aid
description: JIM WRIGHT of Texas has begun using his enhanced influence as the new Speaker of the House to bargain on behalf of crippled savings and loan associations, many of which are in his home state. As many as 65 Texas associations, the highest concentration in the nation, are said to currently have a negative net worth.

title: UNWANTED 'PLATOON' FINDS SUCCESS AS U.S. EXAMINES THE VIETNAM WAR
description: ''Platoon,'' a movie that no studio wanted to make, is the top-grossing movie in the country this month. Over the weekend ended Feb. 1, the Vietnam War picture sold $8.3 million worth of tickets at fewer than 600 theaters, an average of more than $14,000 a theater.

title: HOPES FOR A GERMAN SHAKE-UP
description: What do James A. Baker 3d and Diether Klingelnberg have in common?

title: Toward an Ideological Scorecard
description: Once upon a time in American politics you did not need a program to tell the players or their ideas.

title: JEFFERSON-PILOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $2,631,000 for the quarter and $6,106,000 for the year. c-After a capital loss of $12,849,000. d-Includes a capital gain of $303,000.

title: SANDUSKY PLASTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $179,000.

title: MENCKEN SHOW REBUTS RACISM CHARGE
description: The ghost of H. L. Mencken, the iconoclastic journalist and acerbic social critic who appointed himself - and, in his opinionated fashion, became - the nation's angry conscience in the decades between the World Wars, is being rehabilitated here in a way that even his curmudgeonly specter might approve.

title: STERLING DRUG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a nonrecurring after-tax charge of $44.3 million related to the divestiture of a chemical business. The company said that in the latest fourth quarter it adopted a new method of accounting for pension expense for its plans in the United States, Canada and the United Kingdom; adoption of this method, retroactive to Jan. 1, 1986, had the effect of increasing net income for 1986 by $3.1 million, or 5 cents a share; while there was no effect on net income for the fourth quarter, the first three quarters of the year have been restated to reflect the change.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss)

title: SANDSTROM EXCELS IN A QUIET MANNER
description: In the peacefulness of the Ranger locker room the other night, after a half-dozen TV crews and some 40 reporters had left, the equipment staff and the laundry crew moved without talking, sorting out the uniforms, running a vacuum across the blue carpet. The players had separated for their all-star week hiatus, and now it was time for their locker stalls to be straightened and their mail to be stacked.

title: Q&A
description: Q. How do bullet-proof vests work? A. Most lightweight bullet-resistant garments are made of Kevlar, a material developed by the Du Pont Company. Kevlar, once described as ''the step beyond nylon,'' is formed of fibers of aromatic polyamide, ultra-strong chains of carbon atoms. The material resists penetration by low-velocity projectiles like shrapnel and pistol bullets. A bullet fired at a Kevlar garment first encounters a few yarns of the fabric, and the yarns spread the impact energy of the bullet to other yarns until the entire garment is engaged in resisting the bullet. Eventually, the bullet deforms or flattens. Bullet-resistant garments contain 10 to 30 layers of Kevlar depending on the degree of protection required. As the number of layers increases so does the degree of protection. Kevlar vests used by police officers typically weigh about three pounds. Garments made of a combination of ceramic and hardened steel backed by Kevlar can resist high-velocity rifle bullets. The steel blunts the bullet and the Kevlar catches it. These are used by soldiers and SWAT teams. Q. What are the causes of albinism? A. There are several kinds of albinism, or the lack of normal pigmentation. Its most extreme form, universal albinism, is a hereditary disease caused by the lack of melanin, the dark brown pigment normally present in the skin, hair and eyes. The inability of melanocytes, or pigment cells, to produce melanin is believed to result from a lack of tyrosinase, an enzyme necessary for its production. When a person lacks the gene responsible for the normal production of tyrosinase and inherits a gene for no pigmentation from both parents, albinism occurs. There are two other kinds of human albinism: ocular albinism, affecting only the eyes, and localized albinism, in which small areas of the body lack pigment. Complete albinism occurs in about one in 20,000 people and affects all races.

The Wrong Risk in Nicaragua
description: Never become ''so obsessed with failure,'' President Reagan warned us in his State of the Union Message, as to refuse to take risks ''that could further the cause of peace and freedom.''

title: DORSEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,312,000 for the quarter and $1,254,000 for the year, and after a charge of $830,000 related to the elimination of the investment tax credit for the quarter and year. c-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $853,000 for the quarter and $3,590,000 for the year. The company said 1985 figures have been restated to reflect Dorsey Trailers as a discontinued operation, since the company has signed a definitive agreement to sell the cargo trailer operation.

title: PIANO: LAZAR BERMAN
description: THERE was a great deal of extramusical excitement surrounding last night's piano recital at Carnegie Hall by Lazar Berman, and, of course, some musical interest as well. An appearance by the Soviet virtuoso, his first here in seven years, was certain to generate curiosity. However, before the music could begin, the entire audience was kept standing outside in the bitter cold for as much as 25 minutes while an electronic security check was run, airport-style, by guards stationed immediately inside the hall's doors. The precautions were taken because the management had been warned that demonstrators planned to disrupt the program.

title: Pilot Is Killed as Helicopter Explodes off Waikiki Beach
description: A tour helicopter exploded and crashed just after takeoff from a helipad on Waikiki Beach Sunday, killing its pilot. Four passengers were rescued by surfers, canoists and beachgoers, the authorities said.

title: Advertising; Champion Spreading Its Logo
description: IF you are willing to listen, executives of the Champion Spark Plug Company of Toledo, Ohio, will tell you that, with the exception of Coca-Cola, their name is the best known in the world.

description: b-After a charge of $2,823,000 from the early retirement of debentures. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the latest 9 months.

title: Western Union
description: The Western Union Corporation said that it expected to report a substantial charge against fourth-quarter earnings to reflect the write-down of certain communications facilities. The financially troubled company said that, before the write-down, it earned about $17 million, which includes a gain of about $40 million from the sale of its interests in Airfone Inc. and Cellular Communications Inc. In the fourth quarter of 1985, the company reported a loss of $336 million, which included a $265 million write-down of equipment.

description: LOW petroleum prices in recent years have all but halted American development of alternative energy sources, but in Norway and several other countries, the extraction of electrical energy from ocean waves has become a reality.

description: Renewed attention is being focused on questions about AIDS testing. Who should be tested? Should it be voluntary or mandatory? Should test results be kept confidential or made public?

description: John M. Hightower, who won a Pulitzer Prize and other honors as a diplomatic correspondent for The Associated Press, died today of cancer. He was 77 years old.

description: Hollywood is teaming up with French scientists and a Texas oilman to gather artifacts from the Titanic and open three safes on live television, despite pleas that the wreck be preserved as a deep-sea tomb.

description: Several hundred prominent professors, artists, scientists and statesmen from the West have been invited to Moscow next weekend for a three-day forum on nuclear disarmament.

description: President Reagan and senior Administration officials are scheduled to meet on Tuesday to discuss the direction of the ''Star Wars'' program and how to go about consulting with Congress and the allies on the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, officials said today.

description: The Semiconductor Industry Association called today for President Reagan to impose trade measures immediately against Japan. The trade group contended that Japan had failed to carry out provisions of a semiconductor trade agreement reached by the two countries on July 30.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: BUBBLES and bows. That's the word on what's selling in the stores as the new spring styles hit the racks. At Bergdorf Goodman, bubble-shaped skirts by Bruce Oldfield, Vicky Tiel and Fabrice are floating out of the store. Bloomingdale's reports that crinolines and petticoats of all kinds are selling, mainly in above-the-knee lengths, though Donna Karan's calf-length poplin skirt boosted by petticoats is also a success.

title: EXPLORING THE SOURCE
description: The guy next door insists that our electronic world is flat and that we'll fall off into the ether if we go off prowling through outside databases. Pure piffle; just ask any personal computer owner who has hoisted a modem, cast out the telephone lines and sailed forth into the electronic universe. True, there are hideous dangers out there, such as accidentally patching into an electronic ''chat'' session among 30 amorous teen-agers or stumbling into the electronic counterpart of Home Shopping Network, but there are wondrous places, too.

title: LONE STAR TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The latest quarter and year include a pre-tax gain of $51.9 million from termination of pension plans. The year-ago quarter and year are after a pre-tax charge of $164 million from the writedown of assets.

title: A Legal Battle on Judges
description: The Washington Legal Foundation falls at the other end of the political spectrum from Public Citizen, a Ralph Nader organization, but the two groups have joined forces in a legal battle with the Justice Department over the role of the American Bar Association in the appointment of Federal judges.

title: SUPPLY OF GROWTH HORMONE BRINGS HOPE FOR NEW USES
description: HUMAN growth hormone, long available in minuscule amounts to help abnormally short children reach normal adult height, is finally being produced in mass quantities by genetic engineering techniques, opening the door to a wealth of potential new medical uses. But experts fear that plentiful supplies may also encourage abuse - that practitioners of ''cosmetic endocrinology'' will use the hormone to increase athletic prowess or to increase the height of children in the belief it will improve their social and economic prospects.

title: Owens Boar To Meet on Bid
description: The board of Owens-Illinois Inc. is scheduled to meet Thursday to decide whether the company ought to be acquired by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company in a bid valued at $3.6 billion. But there were rumors on Wall Street yesterday that the meeting had been moved up.

description: b-Includes results for Convergence Corp., since its acquisition in September. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in August.

title: U.S. MAY RELAX EXPORT CONTROLS FOR TECHNOLOGY
description: The Commerce Department today announced sweeping proposals to streamline the nation's system of export controls.

title: THIOKOL LOSES CONTRACT FOR MILITARY BOOSTERS
description: MORTON Thiokol Inc., the maker of the space shuttle's booster rockets, has lost a key contract to make boosters for a fleet of unmanned military rockets, industry officials said yesterday. The rockets are to launch military satellites grounded by the shuttle disaster a year ago.

title: Support for Chemistry
description: A survey conducted on behalf of the American Chemical Society has found that the overwhelming majority of Americans lack ''the slightest idea'' of what chemistry is about, but nevertheless regard chemistry as an important and useful science.

title: Business and Health; H.M.O. Drive Falters in Area
description: HIGH-INTENSITY marketing of health maintenance organizations has produced disappointing results for some of the main players in the New York mega-market of 17.8 million people. The prepaid health plans, known as H.M.O.'s, spent well over $10 million on the first burst of commercials. But fewer than 100,000 new subscribers have signed on, according to preliminary figures obtained recently from the four H.M.O.'s that made most of the headway.

title: JERRY WEINTRAUB PLANS LARGE STUDIO VENTURE
description: Jerry Weintraub, the concert promoter and movie producer who resigned as the head of the United Artists Corporation last year, is now taking the wraps off a new project: a high-risk effort to establish another big Hollywood studio.

description: A familiar problem relates to the opening lead against a slam contract in a suit: is it appropriate to lead an ace?

title: LYNDA CARTER STARS IN 'STILLWATCH'
description: ''STILLWATCH,'' on CBS at 9 tonight, was adapted by Laird Koenig and David Peckinpah from a novel by Mary Higgins Clark. The executive producers are Zev Braun and Lynda Carter, once television's ''Wonder Woman.'' Ms. Carter is also one of the stars, playing Patricia Traymore, a television news reporter who arrives in Washington to produce an in-depth profile on Senator Abigail Winslow, who is on the verge of becoming the next Vice President of the United States. Senator Winslow is played by Angie Dickenson, once television's ''Police Woman.''

title: 3 ISRAELIS MAY LOSE IMMUNITY IN POLLARD SPY CASE
description: The Justice Department has notified three Israelis that it will seek to revoke their immunity from prosecution in the Jonathan Jay Pollard spy case and has told a prominent Israeli Air Force officer that he may soon be indicted, Reagan Administration officials said today.

description: Fifteen years after a disabled Hercules LC-130F transport plane was declared a total loss and abandoned to Antarctica's snow and ice, a team of six Americans has freed the craft, which now awaits repair work and a return to the skies.

description: The Reagan Administration's relations with its partners in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization have become increasingly troubled. In the past 10 days alone, the allies made clear their wish to be consulted before the United States decided on an early deployment of the Strategic Defense Initiative, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher announced that West Germany was ready to help the Soviet Union modernize its economy and the likely new leader of the opposition Social Democrats called for Bonn's withdrawal from NATO's military command if it is not given more say in decisions concerning West German territory.

title: National Distillers Stake Purchased
description: An investment group led by Robert M. Bass of the wealthy Fort Worth family has purchased a 5.6 percent stake, or 1.73 million shares, of the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Bass group said it had bought the shares for investment purposes.

title: U.S. JUDGE RETRACTS CRITICISM OF A JUROR
description: A Federal judge who appeared to criticize a juror two weeks ago for holding out for acquittal in the trial of an organized-crime figure told the juror in a personal letter yesterday that there was ''no possible basis for criticism of your conduct.''

title: That Vanuatu Party
description: When a delegation from the tiny Pacific nation of Vanuatu came to Washington recently for talks with Secretary of State George P. Shultz and a meeting with scholars from the Smithsonian Institution's Wilson Center, it did what any other diplomatic group would do: It threw a party on Embassy Row.

title: 'A CAROL BURNETT SPECIAL' ON ABC
description: ONCE upon a time, variety shows were a television staple. Hardly a night passed without some performer or personality being host of an hour or so of comedy and music. ''The Ed Sullivan Show'' led the way on Sunday evenings for years. And then, suddenly, there were none. Perhaps the public had heard all the jokes and seen all the production numbers. Ratings plummeted, and programmers turned almost exclusively to sitcoms and action-adventures. A measure of what was lost can be glimpsed, tonight at 10 on ABC, in ''A Carol Burnett Special . . . Carol, Carl, Whoopi & Robin.'' The executive producers are Marcy Carsey and Tom Werner from ''The Cosby Show.''

title: GRUMMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KEY RATES
Careers; Improving Employee Morale
description: FOR the past two years consulting firms have been helping companies dismiss thousands of hourly workers as well as many middle managers. Now, consulting firms are being hired to advise on ways to keep the remaining skeleton forces motivated and loyal at a time when middle management cynicism and pessimism have never been higher.

title: A SAD JOYCE CAROL OATES FORSWEARS PSEUDONYMS
description: Pronouncing herself surprised and very disappointed that her literary cover had been blown, Joyce Carol Oates said she would never again try to write a book under a pseudonym. She tried it this once, she said yesterday, because ''I wanted to escape from my own identity.''

title: OFFICIALS ON CASE ASSERT WEDTECH FALSIFIED REPORTS FOR A LONG TIME
description: For at least four years before filing for bankruptcy last December, executives of the Wedtech Corporation prepared falsified financial statements that likely misled bank lenders, stockholders and bond investors, according to law-enforcement officials working on the case.

title: Anheuser's Net Increases 18.3%
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies, the parent of the world's largest brewery, said today that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 18.3 percent over the comparable period in 1985.

title: Sjoberg Joins Meet
description: Patrik Sjoberg of Sweden, holder of the world indoor high jump record at 7 feet 10 3/4 inches, is planning to compete in Saturday night's United States Olympic Invitational track meet at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena, according to the meet director, Ray Lumpp. Competing against Sjoberg will be Jimmy Howard, the American-record holder, and Dennis Lewis, the defending champion. Lumpp said he has rejected a request by Eamonn Coghlan of Ireland to run the 3,000 meters in order to qualify for next month's World Indoor championships in that event at Indianapolis. Coghlan will run the mile on the Meadowlands arena track, where he set the world indoor best time of 3:49.78 in 1983. Evelyn Ashford, 1984 Olympic gold medalist in the women's 100-meter dash, has withdrawn from the 55-meter sprint because of the flu. Valerie Brisco, a triple gold medalist at the 1984 Olympics, has pulled out of the 400 but her coach, Bob Kersee, said she would run a 200-meter dash if Lumpp adds that event to the meet.

title: HURDLE HEADS FOR METS, SIGNS TIDEWATER PACT

Hollace Brown, vice president of advertising for the client, would only say that the ad budget was in seven figures. And she made it sound like the healthy seven figures.

title: Allotments Cut In Paribas Sale
description: Private investors, promised at least 10 shares each in the Government's sale of the state-owned bank group Paribas, will have to settle for four shares because of heavier than expected demand.

title: FROM PARIS, SHORT BRIGHT NIGHTS
description: Spurred by the success of the bubbles and poufs in their fall and winter collections, Paris couture designers opened up an important category of fashion for spring and summer: the short evening dress. Sometimes very short indeed - Yves Saint Laurent showed a number of puckered clingy black dresses that barely cleared the top of the thighs -these styles added to the youthful look that is bringing new relevance to the couture.

The married couple walked away from the Leningrad Music Hall performing troupe and into the United States Embassy while the group was on tour in the Seychelles.

title: Kings Dismiss Coach
description: The Sacramento Kings yesterday dismissed Coach Phil Johnson and replaced him with one of his assistants, Jerry Reynolds. The Kings also dismissed another assistant coach, Frank Hamblen. They replaced him with Don Buse, a former N.B.A. player. It was the second time the Kings had dismissed Johnson as head coach. He coached the club, then in Kansas City, from 1973 through 1978, and returned to the head coaching post in 1984 after working as an assistant in Chicago and Utah. The Kings managing general partner, Gregg Lukenbill, said Johnson and Hamblen were let go because ''we need a new direction'' and that the team was not playing up to its potential under Johnson. The team currently has a 14-32 record. Neither Johnson nor Hamblen was available for comment. Lukenbill said that the Kings' especially poor showing last Wednesday against the Los Angeles Lakers ''brought things to a head,'' but that a coaching change would have been made anyway. The Kings set several dubious N.B.A. records in the first quarter of that 128-92 loss to the Lakers. The Kings missed all 18 shots from the field in that period, trailed by 29-0 at one point, and ended the 12-minute quarter trailing, 40-4.

title: Sanwa Bank's Note Offering
description: The New York branch of Sanwa Bank Ltd., Japan, is offering $100 million of 7.30 percent deposit notes due in 1992 at par through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Smokeless, but Not Relentless
description: Millions of New Yorkers will breathe easier starting May 7; that's the effective date for the State Public Health Council's new rules regulating public smoking. Restaurants will no longer echo to ''Would you mind pointing your cigarette in another direction?'' Cab drivers can stop posting signs that read ''Driver is Allergic.'' The person at the desk on the right won't have to complain that the smoke from the person at the desk on the left is ruining her day, her concentration and her health. Finito!As of May 7, the smoker is odd man out.

title: IS THIS AMERICA?
description: She is 22 years old, a student in San Diego, Calif. She was born in Ramallah, in the West Bank, came to this country at the age of 3 and is an American citizen. On the telephone, she sounds like California. I shall call her Evelyn Bitar: not her real name.
