title: M/A-COM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $17,350,000, or 47 cents a share, reflecting a gain on the sale of the company's information systems division. c-After a loss of $460,000 from discontinued operations.

title: BRITISH GUARD IS UP ON BANKS
description: The leading merchant banks have long been the pillars of the London financial establishment - advisers to prime ministers and royalty, alumni clubs for Eton and Harrow, as British as Big Ben.

title: MIDWAY AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $2,424,000 for the quarter and $4,235,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: T ROWE PRICE ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dept. of Panhandling
description: The other day an earnest but disheveled fellow with his hand out at the corner of Connecticut Avenue and K Street looked intently at a dime a passer-by had given him, turned to an equally disheveled companion and said, ''Man, we got to find some new way to panhandle.''

title: DRY CITIES OF WEST BUY UP FARM WATER RIGHTS
description: For more than a century, farmers here have taken the cool brown water of the Arkansas River, channeled it into their fields in shallow ditches, and watched the land explode with color and crops.

title: IMMUNOMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: HEEKIN CAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $553,000.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Given President Reagan's distraction on Iran, Gorbachev has got to do something before September. After that, you are into the political season, and there is no chance of getting anything through the Senate.

title: MUSICC: IN-DEPTH BEETHOVEN EXPERIENCE
description: By now, original-instrument performances of Baroque and Classical music are commonplace. And there is no logical reason why such an approach cannot be extended right through the 19th century. Familiar masterpieces by Beethoven, Schubert, Mendelssohn, Brahms and Wagner would sound very different if played with the instruments and in the performing style common when they were composed.

title: GOULDS PUMPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Caption Funeral Service for Slain Doctor
description: The coffin of Dr. Peter-Cyrus Rizzo 3d being carried into St. Patrick's Cathedral before service yesterday. Dr. Rizzo, chairman of a three-doctor panel reviewing Fire Department pension requests, was shot Thursday by a retired firefighter. He died Friday at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center, where he had been director of orthopedics for 10 years. Peter McNamee was charged in the murder and ordered held without bail. The case is being presented to a grand jury this week. (NYT/Chester Higgins Jr.)

title: Grumman Net Up by 7.3%
description: The Grumman Corporation said yesterday that its fourth-quarter net income rose by 7.3 percent as sales increased by 12.9 percent.

title: PICKENS GROUP GIVES UP DIAMOND SHAMROCK BID
description: T. Boone Pickens today abandoned his third attempt to acquire the Diamond Shamrock Corporation, leaving analysts uncertain about whether he intends to attempt yet another bid or will turn his sights on a different energy company.

title: THOSE STODGY SAILORS
description: The America's Cup race emerged as one of the great studio sports of all time. Some studio - the entire Indian Ocean - but how else explain this recent phenomenon?

title: OSHKOSH TRUCK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Revenue represents net shipments.

title: American Medical Rejects Pesch Bid
description: American Medical International Inc., the big West Coast hospital chain, said yesterday that it had ''no interest in pursuing'' a $1.74 billion takeover bid from LeRoy A. Pesch, a Chicago physician.

title: TEMPLE IS WINNER IN OVERTIME, 73-70
description: Mike Vreeswyk made two free throws with 13 seconds left in overtime tonight to help Temple defeat Penn State, 73-70, in an Atlantic 10 game.

title: CANADIAN PACIFIC LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $103 million on the sale of its stake in Cominco Ltd. for the quarter, and the year is after $230 million of net special charges. c-Net income and restated. The company said the restatement of 1985 results arose from the retroactive adoption of its Pancanadian Petroleum Ltd. subsidiary of a change in its full-cost accounting method. The company said for 1986, the primary effect of the change was a charge of $82.6 million against consolidated earnings, reflecting Canadian Pacific's share of Pancandian's writedown from the new accounting method on its non-Canadian operations resulting from the significant decline in oil prices in 1986. The company said the $230 million of extraordinary charges in 1986 included a $362 million charge from the writedown in value of certain assets, especially bulk shipping operations and steel and industrial products, as well as gains of $103 million on the sale of Canadian Pacific's investment in Cominco Ltd. in the fourth quarter and $29 million on the divestment of Canadian Pacific Hotels' Flight Kitchens earlier in the year.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Relationships column on the Style page on Feb. 2, about the prospect of losing a job, misstated the employment status of Dr. Leonard Moss, a psychiatrist. He is a consultant to the Mobil Oil Corporation. His hours were reduced during a reorganization, but he was never a full-time employee and was not laid off.

title: AIR EXPRESS INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax benefits of $263,000, or 33 cents a share and $743,000, or 17 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss.

title: RESOURCE EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Soviet Docking in Space
description: Two Soviet astronauts aboard a Soyuz craft have linked up with the orbiting station Mir, and Soviet space officials expressed satisfaction with the performance of the crew and a new docking technique.

title: RIGHTS LEADER ARRESTED IN GEORGIA
description: The Rev. Hosea L. Williams, who led two recent civil rights marches in this all-white community, was arrested here today while attempting to picket the taping of a syndicated talk show discussing racial hostility in this area.

title: Chess: Kasparov, Returning to Play, Wins Brussels Tournament
description: Now that Gary Kasparov is enjoying a respite from his world championship matches with Anatoly Karpov, the 23-year-old titleholder has seized the opportunity for an auspicious return to tournament play. Kasparov has won the elite OHRA International Tournament in Brussels with a 7 1/2-2 1/2 score.

title: When Great Isn't Good Enough
description: Suppose a country weak in basketball - England, perhaps - decided to launch a national program to upgrade the sport. Suppose Julius Erving took up residence in London and offered his help as a coach. ''Hold on, Julius,'' the English say. ''You can't coach here if you don't have one of our coaching licenses.'' So they give him a series of exams on basketball theory and practice, devised and marked by a group of obscure English coaches. And they fail him.

title: REAGAN SAID TO BACK MEASURE TO BAR ANY FEDERAL AID FOR ABORTION
description: President Reagan has endorsed a new legislative proposal for a permanent ban on all Federal assistance for abortions, according to Congressional and Administration sources.

title: STATE JUSTICE DECLARES OFFICE OF SUFFOLK EXECUTIVE VACANT
description: The official status of the Suffolk County Executive, Michael A. LoGrande, was placed in doubt yesterday when a state judge ruled that the job of Suffolk County Executive was vacant and that the Governor could appoint a successor, or mandate a special election to fill the post.

title: Stewart Group Irked By M.T.A. Report
description: A group organized after the 1983 death of Michael Stewart, a Brooklyn man who had been arrested by the transit police for scrawling graffiti in a subway station, yesterday criticized a report by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority on the incident.

title: HONG KONG STOCK PEAK
description: The Hang Seng index closed at another record high today, rising above the key chart point of 2,700 points on strong demand from overseas institutions, brokers said. The index gained 40.10 points, to 2,713.67.

title: ANGOLANS FLEE BOTH SIDES IN CIVIL WAR
description: Wood shavings curled up from a board Moises Lucama was planing into shape for a window frame. But while his hands worked on construction, his thoughts dwelled on destruction.

title: QUIET TALKS FOR BASEBALL
description: In terms of dollars, the largest television sports contracts being negotiated are those involving the National Football League and the three major networks.

title: Star Chambers
description: Tom Chambers's performance Sunday gave him a tie for third place on this list of the players who've scored the most points in an N.B.A. All-Star Game. Wilt Chamberlain, 1962 42 Rick Barry, 1967 38 George Gervin, 1980 34 Julius Erving, 1984 34 Tom Chambers, 1987 34 Elgin Baylor, 1962 32 Walt Frazier, 1975 30 Julius Erving, 1977 30 Bob McAdoo, 1977 30 Isiah Thomas, 1986 30

title: Major Quake Strikes Villages On Papua New Guinea Coast
description: A major earthquake struck near the coast of Papua New Guinea in the southwestern Pacific today, leveling villages and leaving at least 1,000 people homeless, officials said. A second tremor struck the area some hours later.

title: Drug Suspect Ordered Held
description: A man described by prosecutors as among the world's leading and most dangerous cocaine traffickers was ordered held without bond today on drug charges. Security at the hearing was so tight that the nails in people's shoes set off a metal-detector alarm. The defendant, Carlos Lehder Rivas, 37 years old, was being held on 11 drug-smuggling counts. Federal Magistrate Harvey S. Schlesinger entered not-guilty pleas on behalf of Mr. Lehder on all the charges.

title: VOLPLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary charges of $4,480,000. c-Net income

title: G.M. Talks Collapse
description: The negotiations between the Hungarian truck maker Raba Eto and the General Motors Corporation for a barter deal have collapsed, Budapest radio said. Under the plan, Hungary would have imported Opel cars from G.M. A Budapest newspaper quoted a Raba executive as saying that G.M. asked too much for the Opels and offered too little for Raba goods.

title: Home State Bank Trial
description: Marvin L. Warner, the former owner of the Home State Savings Bank, testified today that he was not responsible for some questionable deals with a Florida securities company whose closing led to the 1985 collapse of the thrift institution. Mr. Warner, a former United States ambassador to Switzerland, testified for the first time in his trial on charges stemming from the 1985 collapse of Home State, which helped touch off a statewide crisis among privately insured Ohio savings and loans. The trial of Mr. Warner, 67 years old, and two co-defendants is in its 13th week at the Hamilton County Common Pleas Court.

title: REAGAN EXPECTED TO BACK PROPOSAL ON MAJOR ILLNESS
description: President Reagan is expected to support a health insurance program for catastrophic illness that would expand Medicare coverage of elderly people, Administration officials said today. The decision would end more than two months of debate that produced an impasse within the Administration.

title: 2 DOCTORS TESTIFY SHOT LEFT BUMPUR'S GRIP INTACT
description: Two plastic surgeons testifying as expert witnesses said yesterday that a 66-year-old Bronx woman could have continued to slash at police officers who were trying to subdue her, even after a shotgun blast had torn away part of her hand that held a knife.

title: VICON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax provision for takeover defense costs of $629,000 in connection with an unsuccessful tender offer for the company. c-Net income

title: CENTURY PAPERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BPI SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains from tax credits of $497,000 for the quarter and $500,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income.

title: NERCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago figures restated for changes in accounting methods for oil and gas operations and minerals exploration.

title: CLAUDIO VILLA
description: Claudio Villa, the Little King of Italian song, died late Saturday in a hospital where he had heart surgery last month. He was 61 years old.

title: CHICAGO-LONDON FUTURES LINK IS SET
description: The Chicago Board of Trade and the London International Financial Futures Exchange agreed yesterday to link each other's futures contracts.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN OF BROOKSILLE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Circus Chief Charged In Bleacher Collapse
description: The president of a traveling circus pleaded innocent to assault and reckless endangerment charges yesterday when he was arraigned on 19 counts stemming from a bleachers collapse that injured 68 people last June.

title: ELMIRA SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $171,707 for the quarter and $616,519 for the year. c-Includes tax credits of $60,764 for the quarter and $262,121 for the year. The bank went public in March 1985.

title: Kaiser Aluminum
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, based in Oakland, Calif., said the previously announced sale of its subsidiary Kaiser Aluminium Europe Inc. to Hoogovens Groep B.V. provides for the Dutch steel and aluminum concern to pay $175 million in cash at closing. The sale has a total value of about $280 million, a Kaiser spokesman said.

title: ASTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SERVICEMASTER LIMITED PARTERSHIP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SEIBELS BRUCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $1,619,252 and $3,946,154 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes capital gains of $5,190,212 and $5,339,830 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a loss from discontinued operations of $475,475 for the quarter, and for the year includes income from discontinued operations of $45,549,344.

title: STUART HALL CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect the 10 percent stock dividend paid on Aug. 15, 1986.

title: AUTO-TROL TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 10, 1987
description: International A3-15 A high-level meeting on 'Star Wars' and on how to go about consulting with Congress and the allies on the 1972 ABM Treaty is scheduled for today between President Reagan and senior Administration officials. Page A1 News analysis: The U.S. and Europe have had a cluster of disputes that are spreading malaise within the Atlantic alliance and raising questions about the Reagan Administration's command over foreign policy. A1 Afghan guerrillas shot down a plane in the eastern part of the country and said 43 military men on board were killed. But Afghanistan's Soviet-backed Government said victims were mostly women, children and elderly men. A1 Kidnappers extended a deadline ''until further notice'' for Israel to release 400 Arab prisoners. Three American professors and an Indian scholar are held hostage. A15 India contacts Iran on hostage A15 No changes for the better in Beirut could be seen by a Lebanese man who returned after six weeks abroad. Used cars imported from European countries speed through the streets, dodging garbage strewn everywhere. A14 A definition of an Iranian moderate was attempted by the White House, where the spokesman said that term was used to describe ''people who would have some reason to be friendly to the United States.'' A3 Systematic killings by the contras were described in a report by Americas Watch, a human rights organization, which also reported widespread rights violations by the Nicaraguan Government. A10 A West German coalition collapsed when a cabinet member from the environmentalist party in Hesse, the first to hold office in West Germany, was dismissed by that state's Premier. The coalition had lasted 14 months. A8 Japan's interest in heart transplants is reviving amid widening debate over when and how a doctor may declare a patient dead. Japan's first and last heart transplant was two decades ago. A4 National A16-21, B20 Support for catastrophic illness insurance is expected from President Reagan, for a program much like one proposed by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Administration officials said. A1 Selling water rights is more common in the arid West as the demand for water in urban areas outpaces supplies in mountain rivers and reservoirs, and the increase has prompted debate. A1 Streamlining export controls that the nation maintains chiefly to keep high technology out of Soviet hands is the goal of sweeping proposals that were announced by the Commerce Department. A1 The dollar was battered in waves of heavy selling after Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d said no meeting of the Group of Five finance ministers was planned to stabilize the currency. D1 A Vatican commission of 3 bishops has been appointed to evaluate the governing arrangement in Seattle, where Archbishop Raymond G. Hunthausen was superseded by an auxiliary bishop in a disciplinary move. A16 A ban on Federal aid for abortions or to groups that counsel clients about such services is the crux of a new legislative proposal that the President endorsed late last month, sources said. A20 No evidence of a cult kidnapping has been found in an investigation of six children found last week in Tallahassee, Fla., the authorities said, adding that the group that was raising them does not seem to be involved in child abuse. A21 Orange County, Calif., is Republican through and through, a place where loyalists still root for Mr. Reagan and never think he is wrong. ''This is Reagan Country,'' one resident said. A16 The importance of child care to employers who want to keep experienced workers on the job is likely to grow, a new study indicates. A18 A discovery of a Freud manuscript, ''A Phylogenetic Fantasy,'' which had long been thought lost, promises to touch off a new round of debate about the influences that spawned psychoanalytic thought. C1 Washington Talk A22 Toward an ideological scorecard Acting lessons for political world Regional B1-4, B15, B17, B19 Queens youths face murder charges, after 12 of them were indicted by a grand jury in the racial attack last December that resulted in the death of a black man in Howard Beach, officials said. A1 Lilco lacks the legal authority to carry out an emergency evacuation plan at its Shoreham nuclear plant, a state appeals court ruled, saying such action would be a ''usurpation of the state's police power.'' A1 A judge wrote to a juror saying that the judge's apparent criticism of the juror was not appropriate. The juror had cast the lone vote for the acquittal of a reputed member of the Gambino crime family. B3 The Blizzard of '87 was not, as a compact coastal storm brushed by the New York City region, but buffeted much of southern New Jersey and parts of the New England coast with high winds and heavy snows. B1 Baby M's biological mother testified, tracing good times and bad in 13 years of marriage and describing moments of happiness and anguish with Baby M. ''The only skill that I know I do well is being a mother,'' she said. B1 Riverside's Dance Festival will close in June, after 12 years at the Theater of the Riverside Church, because of a $900,000 deficit at the church. The festival's director was dismissed in January. C13 Neediest Cases B19

title: Exposure to Paints Prompts Lawsuit
description: A former shipyard worker has filed what is believed to be the first product liability lawsuit stemming from exposure to glycol ethers in paints.

title: PARIS BUSINESS FORMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company went public in March.

title: Details Given on Sale Of Spielvogel Office
description: Gary Bayer, president of the Chicago office of Backer & Spielvogel, yesterday disclosed the names of the three other admen who will join him in buying the office from Britain's Saatchi & Saatchi. Papers should be signed in two weeks, after which the former office of the New York agency that was originally the house agency of Quaker Oats will be known as Bayer, Bess, Vanderwarker & Flynn.

title: RIVERSIDE DANCE TO CLOSE
description: The Riverside Dance Festival, now in its 12th year at the Theater of the Riverside Church, will close in June. Joan Bacchus, director of communications at Riverside Church, cited a $900,000 deficit at the church as a reason for the termination of the festival, part of a program of cutbacks at Riverside. The festival's director, David K. Manion, was dismissed in January.

title: MOORE MCCORMACK REOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $4,533,000 and a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $89,929,000. c-After net from discontinued operations of $1,165,000 for the quarter and $4,147,000 for the year. d-Net income

title: Milwaukee Searches For a Symbol of City
description: A 1,000-foot high fountain in Lake Michigan, a ''Great Wall of Milwaukee'' and a solar-heated geodesic dome that would house the world's largest indoor playground have been suggested as Milwaukee searches for a symbol that would draw worldwide attention.

title: 'MANCHILD REVISITED' OFFERS VIEWS ON CRIME
description: ''MANCHILD REVISITED,'' subtitled ''A Commentary by Claude Brown,'' isn't quite what you expect. In the 1965 book ''Manchild in the Promised Land,'' Mr. Brown wrote about growing up in Harlem in the 1940's and 50's. In ''Manchild Revisited,'' on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight, he talks about violent crime. Book and television program, however, have at least one common denominator: hardheadedness.

title: PROFESSIONAL AGRICULTURAL MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: THE TROUBLE WITH QUOTAS
description: AMERICAN colleges face growing charges that they are using secret quotas in admissions. The prime target, according to critics, are students of Asian descent. Women may be next, these critics say.

title: 2 PHONE CONCERNS POST PROFITS
description: The GTE Corporation and United Telecommunications Inc., which formed the long-distance carrier U S Sprint last year, yesterday both reported increases in earnings for the fourth quarter and the year.

title: Our Sons Are Taught to Play With Guns
description: To the Editor:

title: Child Care Connected With the Workplace Makes Good Business Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOT'S ARCH PERFORMS BETTER THAN RUNNING SHOE
description: BRITISH experimenters have discoverered that the arch of the human foot compresses and recoils like a spring, providing a significant amount of the energy used in running.

title: WESTERN WASTE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflects a one-time charge of about $250,000 due to the reversal of previously recorded investment tax credits under new federal law legislation.

title: CHAMPION SPARK PLUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes non-recurring after-tax charges of $8.4 million, due to the company's worldwide restructuring program, and a $7.8 million provision for deferred income taxes relating to undistributed earnings for foreign subsidiaries. c-Net income and includes non- recurring after-tax charges of $4.7 million, primarily for salaried personnel reductions. The company said the 1986 results were due, in part, to the negative effects of a 10-week strike by U.S. and Canadian employees, which ended in mid-April.

title: Lord of the Birds
description: For the kindly people who set out feeders of bird seed in winter, February's snows have brought a sense of reward. Resident birds have been crowding around the handouts and have been joined by northern birds not always seen hereabouts. There are pine siskins by the flock; there are evening grosbeaks and redpolls, and nearby there are mouse-eating snowy owls, wintering on Long Island.

title: SOUTHMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for the 15 percent stock dividend declared in April 1986.

title: WHAT'S AN IRANIAN MODERATE? THE WHITE HOUSE VIEW
description: The White House tried today to explain what an Iranian moderate is.

title: SIMMS RECEIVES REWARDS AS M.V.P.
description: Phil Simms, the Giants' quarterback, was presented yesterday with the rewards for being named the most valuable player of Super Bowl XXI last month, a new car valued at $17,000 and $10,000 to donate to the charities of his choice.

title: Horse Cents
description: For generations, horseshoes has been a serene country recreation, a backyard and barnyard sport in which stakes are of little consequence except to be thrown at. Now it appears headed for far greener pastures.

title: BEYOND FIREWORKS: NEW YORK'S CEREBRAL SALUTE TO 1787
description: On Feb. 21, it will be exactly 200 years since the Confederation Congress, sitting in New York, called for a national convention in Philadelphia to revise the Articles of Confederation.

title: Boesky Investors Agree To Distribution Payout
description: The investors in Ivan F. Boesky's investment firm have agreed to terms for distributing the firm's remaining capital, sources familiar with the negotiations said yesterday.

title: TV Sale Hits Snag in France
description: The French Government's plan to sell the nation's most popular television network has suffered a setback: A leading contender pulled out, calling the purchase too expensive.

title: Surgery for Nehemiah
description: Renaldo Nehemiah, the world-record holder in the 110-meter hurdles, was scheduled to undergo surgery today for removal of a bone spur on his left heel. Dr. Tony Daly, a sports medicine specialist who will perform the surgery at Daniel Freeman Marina Hospital in Marina Del Ray, Calif., said Nehemiah could be sidelined for two and a half months. ''The spur has been bothering him and getting progressively worse,'' Daly said, adding that the spur had hampered Nehemiah's performances this winter. Nehemiah had dominated the hurdles event before a stint with the San Francisco 49ers. This winter, Greg Foster has beaten Nehemiah in both their meetings indoors at the Sunkist Invitational at the Los Angeles Sports Arena on Jan. 16 and the Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden two weeks later.

title: HUNTINGTON INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: All figures are in pounds sterling and dollars conversion is at the rate of U.S. $1.4825 equals 1 pound sterling. The company said the share earnings in U.S. dollars are 49 cents for 1986 and 26 cents for 1985.

title: Captors Drop Deadline; Beirut Bomb Kills 17
description: Kidnappers holding four Western hostages reiterated that they would kill their captives at midnight tonight unless 400 Arab prisoners were freed by Israel, then, as the deadline passed, announced that it had been extended ''until further notice.''

title: SEATING ORDER
description: Darnell Coles, Detroit's third baseman, after being invited to try out a Frank Lloyd Wright-designed chair that Tom Monaghan, the Tiger owner, recently bought for $198,000: ''I really wanted to sit in a chair that costs more than I do.''

title: Thermal Energy Gusher
description: An experimental geothermal well being drilled in Honduras by scientists from the Los Alamos National Laboratory has produced a gusher that promises the production of cheap electricity for the poor Central American country.

title: ORANGE COUNTY CLAIMS FRONT-ROW SEAT AMONG CALIFORNIA REAGAN FANS
description: When you arrive at Tom Fuentes's office here, you get the message even before he opens his mouth.

title: STAGE: DIDEROT COMEDY
description: A NECESSARY footnote:

title: B.J.K.&E. Health Unit Names a Chairman
description: Robert J. Leverte, 50, has been named chairman of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt Health Care, of which he was already chief executive.

title: Dogs' Deaths Halt Tests On Hearts
description: RESEARCH on an experimental operation that created an auxiliary heart from a dog's own back muscle has been temporarily halted at the University of Pennsylvania until scientists devise an approach to prevent the formation of blood clots that have complicated the procedure.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table in Business Day on Jan. 22, showing short interest in New York Stock Exchange shares for the month ended Jan. 15, carried an incorrect total supplied by the First Pennsylvania Corporation for its stock. As a result, the total Big Board short interest and the decline for the month were also incorrect. The closing short interest for First Pennsylvania was 2,794,276 shares. For the month, the Big Board's short interest fell by 11.9 percent, or 55.5 million shares, to 410 million.

title: DEMOCRATS ARE SAID TO CHOOSE ATLANTA FOR '88 CONVENTION
description: Atlanta has been selected by the Democrats to be the host for the party's 1988 national convention, sources close to the Democratic National Committee said today.

title: FAIRHAVEN SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes $693,593 from the Mutual Savings Central Fund. c-Includes $606,524 for the quarter and $711,287 for the year from the MSC Fund. The bank converted to stock form in October 1986.

title: ANALYSIS & TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MUSIC: 3 PIANISTS
description: AFFILIATE ARTISTS and its supporters at the Xerox Corporation have had the happy idea of wedding new performers to new music. Another of these affairs - featuring three emerging pianists and two world premieres - happened at Weill Recital Hall on Sunday.

title: LILCO LACKS AUTHORITY TO OVERSEE SHOREHAM EVACUATION, COURT SAYS
description: A state appeals court ruled yesterday that the Long Island Lighting Company, as a private corporation, does not have the legal authority to carry out an emergency evacuation plan at its Shoreham nuclear plant.

title: LIVES RECLAIMED AND LUNCH LINES ON THE SIDEWALKS OF NEW YORK
description: To the Editor:

title: 12 YOUTHS INDICTED IN QUEENS ATTACK THAT LED TO DEATH
description: A Queens grand jury has voted criminal indictments - including several murder charges - against 12 youths in the racial attack last December that resulted in the death of a black man in Howard Beach, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: RYDER SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A TRANSPLANT TRAUMA: IS SOUL-SEARCHING ENDING?
description: One sultry summer day in 1968, a teen-age boy drowned in waters off the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido.

title: THE STAGE: 'MOMS'
description: FOR 50 years, Jackie (Moms) Mabley was a top headliner on the black vaudeville circuit. In her squashed hat, baggy housedress and drooping socks, looking not too far removed from a shopping-bag lady, she won laughs with her attitude of total disrespect. Late in life (she died in 1975), she began to break through to a wider public. However, in common with Satchel Paige, another pioneer, so many of her best years were a secret from the world at large.

title: GTE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $14 million primarily due to the retroactive repeal of investment tax credits. The company reported net income would have been $282 million excluding this charge. c-Net loss. d-After non-recurring after-tax charges of $1.3 billion, primarily for costs associated with the formation of the U.S. Sprint joint venture with United Telecommunications Inc., and the repositioning of GTE's Communications Systems unit in light of the joint venture with SiemensA.G. The company reported net income would have been $283 million without these charges. The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split payable to shareholders of record on Jan.14, 1987. The company said revenue for the fourth quarter of 1985 includes sales from businesses transferred to the Siemens joint venture prior to the 1986 fourth quarter. On a comparable basis, sales for the 1986 quarter increased 7 percent. Both the latest quarter and full year revenues exclude operations transferred to the U.S. Sprint joint venture, which is being accounted for on the equity basis. The two periods also exclude the revenue from assets transferred to the Siemens joint venture.

title: AIDS POSES A CLASSIC DILEMMA
description: AS Government officials struggle to control the lethal spread of AIDS, they are confronting a classic dilemma in public health: how to balance the individual's right to privacy with the public's right to take stiff measures to thwart an epidemic. Similar clashes have arisen in the past. But acquired immune deficiency syndrome has added new dimensions because of enormous public attention and the stigma and discrimination faced by people known simply to be carriers of the AIDS virus.

title: PITT ALONE AT LAST ATOP BIG EAST
description: After Pittsburgh dismantled Providence's 3-point offense last Saturday with a punishing inside attack, the Panthers were aware that they would have a tougher time tonight against Syracuse in a showdown for first place in the Big East.

title: Ex-Guard Is Shot at Hotel
description: A former security guard at the Holland Hotel on 42d Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, where many welfare families are housed, was shot and critically wounded last night. The guard, Malik Muhammad of 350 West 56th Street, was found on the seventh-floor hallway floor with gunshot wounds in the head and the left arm.

title: Baseball Ruling Favors Free-Agent Players
description: Baseball's impartial arbitrator cleared up part - but only a small part - of the controversy surrounding free agents yesterday, ruling that clubs that are not eligible to sign free agents until May 1 may not negotiate with them until then.

title: DAY-CARE OWNER ACQUITTED OF RAPE AND SEXUAL ABUSE
description: A Mount Vernon woman who ran a day-care center in her home was acquitted today of rape and sexual abuse charges involving 18 children in her care.

title: VATICAN CHOOSES PANEL OF 3 TO EVALUATE SEATTLE DIOCESE
description: The Vatican announced yesterday that it had appointed a commission of three bishops to evaluate the governing arrangement in the Seattle Archdiocese, where Archbishop Raymond G. Hunthausen was superseded by an auxiliary bishop in a disciplinary move.

title: President Resigns Post At American Standard
description: It is the rare executive who can concede that his own job is redundant. But yesterday, William G. Roth, the president and chief operating officer of American Standard Inc., did just that.

title: ELDEC CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
The U.N. Today: Feb. 10, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Special Committee on the United Nations Charter - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: LEVINE ASSOCIATE SENTENCED
description: Robert M. Wilkis, a former investment banker, was sentenced yesterday to two concurrent prison terms of one year and one day for participating in an insider trading scheme with Dennis B. Levine.

title: Precious Blood
description: The snowstorms buffeting New York have slowed blood donations to a mere trickle as schools, businesses and churches cancel blood drives. That means depletion of supplies already at a dangerously low level. The result is a blood emergency. The five-day blood inventory normal for this time of year is down to only one day. Regular blood deliveries to hospitals have been sharply curtailed.

title: DOLLAR FALLS SHARPLY IN HECTIC DAY
description: The dollar was battered yesterday in waves of heavy selling after Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d said no meeting of the Group of Five finance ministers had been planned to stabilize the currency.

title: Chairman of Clabir Sees Deal Fall Through
description: Henry D. Clarke Jr., chairman and chief executive of the Clabir Corporation, has built a company with successful acquisitions, but he has also had his share of deals that fell through.

title: ONE-OF-A-KIND DINNER JACKETS
description: Cyndi Lauper, Vanity, Debbie Harry, Rick Derringer and Bob Geldof, along with MTV ''veejays'' and Mick Jagger's companion, the model Jerry Hall, are some of the notables of the rock-music world who own wearable art designs by Jon Planas.

title: Dow Falls by 10.13; Dollar Drop Cited
description: Trading volume was light yesterday on Wall Street and stock prices drifted lower after a sharp drop in the dollar's value brought on new fears that the Federal Reserve's ability to cut interest rates might be hampered.

title: Yankee Signings
description: The Yankees announced yesterday that two players had signed one-year contracts for this season: Brad Arnsberg, a right-handed pitcher, and Mitch Lyden, a catcher. Arnsberg, regarded as a candidate for the Yankees' starting rotation this spring, appeared in two games for them last season, starting in one, but did not have a record. He suffered a broken nose last week working out in California, but a club spokesman said it was not expected to keep him from reporting for training camp at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., next week. Lyden batted .302 last season for Albany, the Yankees' Class AA team in the Eastern League. . . . Ray Knight, upstaged by the weekend success of his wife, Nancy Lopez, has postponed until tomorrow his decision on a contract offer from the Baltimore Orioles. Lopez not only won the Sarasota Classic, but because it was her 35th victory in 11 seasons as a pro, she automatically qualified for the Ladies Professional Golf Association Hall of Fame. Knight reportedly is ready to accept an offer from the Orioles that includes $470,000 in guaranteed pay plus $130,000 in incentives. . . . Four more players who had filed for salary arbitration agreed to one-year contracts, thus avoiding hearings: Mike Davis with Oakland for $780,000, Juan Samuel with Philadelphia for $640,000, Phil Niekro with Cleveland for a guaranteed $500,000 and Chris Bando with Cleveland for $305,000. Mike Moore reached agreement with Seattle during the weekend on a $500,000 contract.

title: The Contras Minus Arturo Cruz
description: When Congress reversed itself a year ago and voted $100 million in military aid for the contras, what tilted the balance was the joint appeal of three rebel leaders: Adolfo Calero, Arturo Cruz and Alfonso Robelo. Mr. Cruz, a left-of-center democrat, carried the most weight. Yet now, he seems ready to break with other Nicaraguan rebel leaders. Without him, the contras lose much of their political credibility.

title: AUTHORITY OF PANEL IS DOUBTED IN SETTING ANTI-SMOKING RULES
description: A joint oversight commission of the State Legislature declared today that New York health officials exceeded their legal authority in enacting tough new statewide anti-smoking regulations.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DOGFIGHTS They don't make 'em like that anymore and you can check it out yourself at today's double feature in Theater 80, the movie house of total recall, 80 St. Marks Place, between First and Second Avenues (254-7400).

title: UNITED TELECOMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $781,000 for the quarter, and for the year includes a loss from discontinued operations of $6,654,000. c-Net loss and includes net from discontinued operations of $23,000. d-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $5,580,000.

title: CORONER CITES AIDS IN LIBERACE DEATH
description: Liberace died of a disease caused by AIDS, the Riverside County Coroner said today, and he accused the entertainer's doctors of covering up the cause of death.

title: Lives Reclaimed and Lunch Lines on the Sidewalks of New York
description: To the Editor:

title: LOST PAPER SHOWS FREUD'S EFFORT TO LINK ANALYSIS AND EVOLUTION
description: THE recent discovery of a wildly speculative manuscript by Freud, which had long been thought lost, promises to touch off a new round of debate about the influences that spawned psychoanalytic thought.

title: NOBILITY HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: G. K. CHESTERTON. By Michael Ffinch. 369 pages. Illustrated. Harper & Row. $18.95. DAYLIGHT AND NIGHTMARE. Uncollected Stories and Fables. By G. K. Chesterton. Selected and arranged by Marie Smith. 144 pages. Dodd, Mead. $14.95. G. K. CHESTERTON wrote an engaging autobiography that throws light on a great many things in passing, even on G. K. Chesterton; but the finest autobiography is no substitute for a biography. After his death Maisie Ward wrote a life of Chesterton that is exceptionally good of its kind; but it was written, so to speak, from the inside, by a friend who had been part of his world and shared most of his values. A new biography, written from the outside, has been long overdue.

title: FOR THE COUPON CLUB, SHOPPING IS AN ART
description: SOME suburban coupon clubs are cutthroat, but the Elmont Coupon Club has never been that way. ''There's another group - I won't mention who they are,'' said Jo Ann Mehnert, the Elmont president. ''They're so organized, they have all their coupons in loose-leaf notebooks.''

title: Federated Names Chief for I. Magnin
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. said yesterday that it had named Barbara Bass as chairman and chief executive of its San Francisco-based I. Magnin & Company.

title: IRAN THRUSTS A FLEDGLING NEWS SERVICE INTO SPOTLIGHT
description: The scramble for news last week after Iranian officials arrested Gerald F. Seib, a Wall Street Journal reporter, worked to the advantage of a fledgling news agency.

title: Parade Today
description: The parade to honor the crew of Stars & Stripes, winner of the 1987 America's Cup, begins at 11:30 A.M. today on Fifth Avenue at 43d Street, moving to 56th Street and ending about 1 P.M.

title: ANHEUSER-BUSCH COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split on Sept. 12, 1986, and a 3-for-1 stock split on June 14, 1985. Sales represents gross sales. The company said it adopted a new accounting method during the fourth quarter of 1986 for reporting pension expense. The annual financial effect of adopting FASB No. 87, Employers' Accounting for Pensions, is to increase the reported net income for 1986 by $23 million and the share earnings by 8 cents a share.

title: DREXLER TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,325,000.

title: Carlos Clarens Is Dead at 56; Movie Historian and Author
description: Carlos Clarens, a movie historian, died of a heart attack Sunday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: EATON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $40.6 million from the writedown of assets in the third quarter. The adoption of a change in accounting for pensions increased earnings for the latest quarter by $2.8 million and for the latest year by $10 million.

title: MS CARRIERS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ASSOCIATED HOSTS INC reports earnings for 13wks to Dec 25
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $196,000 on the sale of a restaurant.

title: Meat Output Seen Easing
description: World beef and veal output is expected to fall slightly this year, bringing relief from years of overproduction and improving prospects for a firmer market, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade has predicted.

title: Soviet-Chinese Border Talks Are Reopened After 9 Years
description: The Soviet Union and China resumed border talks today after nine years.

title: THT LLOYD'S reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the latest quarter is the first full quarter that includes results of its newest subsidiary, Lloyd's Electronics Corp.

title: NETWORK SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL KNICKS VS. CAVALIERS, at Richfield, Ohio, 7:30 P.M. (Radio -WNBC 660, 7:30 P.M.) COLLEGES: St. John's vs. Seton Hall, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 9 P.M. (TV - Channel 9, 9 P.M. Radio - WCBS 880, 9 P.M.) Iona at Fordham (Radio - WFUV-FM 90.3, 8 P.M.) Georgia Tech at Maryland, (TV - ESPN, 9 P.M.) DePaul at Marquette (TV - USA, 11 P.M.) DOG SHOW WESTMINSTER KENNEL CLUB, at Madison Square Garden (TV -MSG, 8 P.M) OTHER EVENTS HARNESS RACING: Roosevelt, 7:30 P.M. Meadowlands, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, midnight)

title: MAGICSILK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $200,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $28,100 and a tax credit of $120,000.

title: BIG-SERVE GAME STIRS DEBATE
description: In a trend conscious world, we have heard all about the power lunch, the power breakfast and the power tie -the yellow number with the little polka dots. Now, we are entering the age of power tennis. And questions are being raised about whether this is especially good for the sport.

title: THE DANCE: PILOBOLUS, IN NEW AND PAST WORKS
description: THE program that Pilobolus offered Sunday night at the Joyce Theater included ''The Lure,'' a solo choreographed last year by Peter Pucci and not seen in New York before this season. Though brief, it exemplified some of the company's achievements.

title: Murdoch Sells Several Units
description: The News Corporation, which is controlled by Rupert Murdoch, said today that it had sold its television operations and several other media properties to the Westfield Capital Corporation of Sydney for about $555 million.

title: Good Timing
description: Walt Frazier, on playing last Saturday in the National Basketball Association's Legends Classic: ''It's great to be a legend, especially in my own time.''

title: ISRAELI TROOPS SHOOT AT ARAB PROTESTERS, LEAVING 9 WOUNDED
description: Nine Palestinians were wounded by Israeli soldiers today in two West Bank confrontations described as the worst outbreak of violence this year in the tense occupation zone, Israeli officials said.

title: Researchers See Child Care on the Job as Vital
description: Child-care programs, a crucial problem for working couples, will become increasingly important to employers who want to keep experienced workers on the job, according to a new study.

title: We Need a Defense Against Ballistic Missiles
description: To the Editor:

title: LEFT SOVIET FOR CANCER TREATMENT
description: Inna Kitrosskaya Meiman, the wife of a Soviet dissident, died yesterday at the Lombardi Cancer Research Center of Georgetown University Hospital in Washington, three weeks after she was allowed to go abroad for treatment of an inoperable tumor on her neck. She was 53 years old and had been waiting years for permission to travel.

title: ALLEN ORGAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SAFETY-KLEEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $3,706,000 from a change in accounting for investment tax credits.

description: b-After pre-tax charges for writedowns of the company's investment in Towle Manufacturing Co. of $804,000 for the quarter and $2,866,000 for the year. c-Include a pre-tax charge for the writedown of the investment in Towle Mfg. Co. of $13,362,000 for the quarter and year.

title: U.S. GROUP FINDS NO IMPROVEMENT IN CONTRAS' HUMAN RIGHTS RECORD
description: A human rights organization issued a report today citing systematic killings by the Nicaraguan rebels and widespread human rights violations by the Nicaraguan Government.

title: Acting Lessons For the Political World
description: Dave Modai, a 32-year-old lawyer and lobbyist, stands in front of a dozen people. He is speaking gibberish, gesticulating wildly, faking accents, throwing out snatches of foreign languages, improvising phrases like ''bla bla bla.'' He is selling toy dolls. Selling toy dolls?

title: Market Place; Shorting A Mutual Fund
description: INVESTORS with a penchant for taking market risks have always been able to sell individual stocks short, but soon they will be able to try their hand at shorting a mutual fund.

title: Forger's Sentence Commuted
description: Gov. Roy Romer today commuted the sentence of a convicted forger who escaped from a Colorado prison in 1965 and has since lived a crime-free life in North Carolina.

title: U.S. Envoy Denies Discussing Any Arms Shipments to Iran
description: Maxwell M. Rabb, the Ambassador to Italy, denied in a New York courtroom yesterday that he had discussed arms shipments to Iran with a defendant in a criminal case.

title: POLICE SAY UNIDENTIFIED CHILDREN IN FLORIDA ARE NOT VICTIMS OF CULT
description: Local police officials announced here today that six children found last week in Florida had apparently not been kidnapped and that there was no evidence to show that the secretive group that has been raising them is a cult involved in child abuse.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ambrit Inc., Clearwater, Fla., the maker and distributor of Klondike ice cream bars, appointed Thomas G. Dixcy chief executive of Ambrit's Isaly Klondike Co.

title: POGO PRODUCING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes pre-tax writedowns of $95.8 million on the value of its assets. c-After pre-tax writedowns of $169.3 million on the value of its assets for the quarter and year.

title: STORE MANAGER DIES WHEN THIEF PUSHES HIM IN FRONT OF VAN
description: The manager of a clothing store in Greenwich Village, who chased a man who had stolen a leather jacket from his shop, was killed yesterday afternoon when the man pushed him in front of an oncoming van, the police said.

title: Boston U. Wins Beanpot
description: Mike Kelfer's goal 5 minutes 28 seconds into overtime tonight lifted Boston University to a 4-3 victory over Northeastern in the championship game of the 35th annual Beanpot hockey tournament.

title: EASTGROUP PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes gains from the sale of investments of $9,000 for the quarter and $1,980,000 for the year. c-Includes gains from the sale of investemtns of $298,000 for the quarter and $4,597,000 for the year.

title: GRI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $250,000 for the quarter and year, and a gain from discontinued operations of $227,000 for the quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $273,000 for the year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $25,000. d-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $6,709,000.

title: GIFTS OF THE HEART
description: 1. Compact of Gold The heart-shaped golden compact shown here is a romantic purse accessory. Made in the 1950's, the case is decorated with an old-fashioned key and is engraved with leaves and flowers. The price is $175 at Muriel Karasik, 1094 Madison Avenue, near 82d Street. 2. Flowing Color ''Be Mine'' is the message of this pretty silk scarf by Flora Kung. It is a splash of color - red, shocking pink, teal, navy, slate and white. The scarf measures 36-by-36 inches and costs $54 in accessories on the main floor at Bonwit Teller, 4 East 57th Street. 3. Sweet Romance Chocolatier Manon is serving Valentine sweets on romantic trays designed by Terrafirma Ceramics. The trays, which come in a variety of colors, feature a heart-shaped ''doily'' baked into the design. Each is handmade, signed and dated. The tray shown here costs $70, and you can add your own selection of chocolates. At Chocolatier Manon, 872 Madison Avenue, between 71st and 72d Streets. 4. Dramatic Decorations This dramatic silver necklace is decorated with three large Italian-made hearts (the beads were made in this country). The price is $185 in fine jewelry at Abraham & Straus, 420 Fulton Street at Hoyt Street in Brooklyn, and all branch stores. Matching heart-shaped earrings for pierced ears are available for $40.

title: AUSTRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss)* Loss in year-earlier period.

title: KHOMEINI, IN FIRST SPEECH IN 3 MONTHS, PLEDGES WAR UNTIL VICTORY
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, in his first public speech in nearly three months, declared today that Iran's long conflict with Iraq was a holy crusade and that his fundamentalist Government would make ''war until victory.''

title: Knight and Orioles May Reach a Deal
description: Ray Knight, the unemployed hero of the World Series, has a chance to end his free fall from the Mets today by accepting a one-year contract to play third base for the Baltimore Orioles.

title: WARNER COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $22,082,000, or 16 cents a share, for the quarter, and for the year includes a pre-tax gain of $39,797,000 on the sale of investments and net from discontinued operations of $22,082,000, or 16 cents a share. c-Includes a gain of $94 million, or 70 cents a share, after-tax, on sale of investment for the quarter, and for the year includes a net gain of $102,400,000 from the sale of investments.

title: Lawless and Foolish
description: The same President who already has violated the Limited Test Ban and the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaties, and repudiated SALT II, now is debating whether to make a dead letter of the Anti-ballistic Missile Treaty. For this recklessly imperial President, it's as if there were no limits of law or sound policy on his personal predilections.

title: Hutton Units' Sale
description: The First Capital Holdings Corporation said it had entered into a definitive agreement to buy E.F. Hutton Group Inc.'s insurance units for $300 million. The sale is expected to be completed in the spring. E.F. Hutton Insurance Group Inc., which owns the E.F. Hutton Life Insurance Company and the World-Wide Reassurance Company of Britain, has assets of more than $2.9 billion and posted revenues of more than $700 million in 1986. First Capital, based here, owns the Fidelity Bankers Life Insurance Company and Pilgrim Group Inc., which distributes mutual funds.

title: CITICORP BUYING 50 SEARS UNITS
description: Citicorp agreed yesterday to buy 50 savings and loan branches in Southern California from Sears, Roebuck & Company.

title: INMAC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 24
description: The company went public in October 1986.

title: A Video Camera for Children
description: Budding film makers take note: At the New York Toy Fair this week, the Fisher-Price toy company demonstrated a $150 camera that can record 11 minutes of black and white video images on a regular 90-minute audio tape cassette. To play back the recording, the user simply plugs the camera directly into a television set; a video cassette player is not required.

title: AMGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ENVOYS AT LATIN TALKS SAY PEACE FADES
description: Differences between Nicaragua and its neighbors are sharpening, making a negotiated settlement of regional disputes more distant than ever, according to delegates at a meeting here called to discuss Central American issues.

title: U.S. Says It Considers Plan To Upgrade Jordan Missiles
description: Government officials said today that the United States was considering a plan to help Jordan upgrade its antiaircraft missiles, in part to stop Jordan from turning to Moscow for arms.

title: CONCERT: AN DIE MUSIK AT MERKIN
description: AN DIE MUSIK, the chamber-music group, finished its 11th season at Merkin Concert Hall Sunday afternoon with every evidence that its roots grow stronger and deeper in New York's concert life. This program, inventively planned, played to an audience that filled Merkin's auditorium and spilled up onto the stage; the balance and substance of the music was largely matched by the performances.

title: Klansman Says Superior 'Suggested' 1981 Slaying
description: A former member of the Ku Klux Klan serving a life term for his part in the 1981 murder of a black youth testified in a $10 million civil rights lawsuit today that the crime was ''suggested'' by his Klan superiors.

title: Real Estate; Developer's New Twist In Hartford
description: SINCE 1976, Robert Sheridan has carved out a niche for himself on the national residential real estate scene by converting rental apartments into cooperatives and condominiums in such places as Chicago, Philadelphia, Atlanta and New York City.

title: FIRST AMERICAN SAVINGS FA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company converted from mutual to stock form last May.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: New Chef for '21'

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Nets, burdened by injuries and by the worst record in the Eastern Conference, signed Chris Engler to a contract for the remainder of the season. Engler, a well-traveled 7-foot center who earlier signed two 10-day contracts. He is averaging 1.7 points and 1.3 rebounds as a replacement for James Bailey, who broke his left hand Jan. 19 and was placed on the injured list. . . . A former Nets player, Mike O'Koren, has been reactivated by the Bullets after he was placed on the injured list Jan. 8 because of lower back spasms. Before the injury, O'Koren had appeared in 13 games and averaged 2.1 points for Washington. . . . Claude Humphrey, a six-time all-pro defensive end during his 10 years with Atlanta, has been named a defensive coach of the Falcons by Coach Marion Campbell. . . . Bobby Knight has exercised the option to extend his contract as basketball coach at Indiana for an additional five years, through June 30, 1997.

title: SOUTHERN ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company was formed July 1, 1986, in order to acquire Southern Electronics Distributors Inc.; year- ago figures include the effect of debt issued in the transaction.

title: BDM INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Honeywell Has Deficit in Quarter
description: Honeywell Inc. lost $492.8 million in the fourth quarter of 1986 because of huge, one-time charges for restructuring, write-downs and asset sales, the company said today.

title: SWEET PRAISE FOR LOWLY BEETS
description: LEAD: PERHAPS in an era of instant food, it is a bit quixotic to offer a paean to a vegetable famed for staining the hands bright red and taking forever to cook. Yet the beet, now in its cool-weather prime, is too worthy to ignore. Beets' rich, earthy flavor, agreeable texture and great sweetness - low in calories, although beets may be as much as 10 percent sugar - can be savored in traditional or imaginative ways.

title: THE STAGE: 'CIRCUS'
description: HUCK SNYDER'S ''Circus'' is a contender for the title of the smallest show on earth. Next to it, the one-ring Big Apple Circus is spectacular. It is the tiniest top - one-tenth the size of ''Le Cirque Imaginaire,'' the Victoria Chaplin show seen earlier this season - and festooned with fanciful delights.

title: PEOPLE'S SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a dividend of $332,000 from the Massachusetts Central Fund for the quarter and year. c-After dividends of $307,000 for the quarter and $361,000 for the year from the Fund. The per share earnings are not available; the company went public in October 1986.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE CO OF NEW MEXICO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
OFFICIALS SEE LAWYERS FOR BIAGGI
description: In an effort to head off a possible Federal indictment in Brooklyn against Representative Mario Biaggi, lawyers for the Congressman met yesterday in Washington with Justice Department officials.

title: Blimp's Invitation Revoked
description: Officials have revoked an invitation for the Goodyear blimp to join the city's centennial celebration so as not to offend Uniroyal-Goodrich, the city's largest employer and Goodyear's competitor. Having the blimp ''would be like having the big, bright Texaco star fly over Bartlesville,'' home of Phillips Petroleum, City Manager Craig Weinaug said Monday. The Centennial Commission invited the blimp to join the July 25 birthday gala two years ago.

title: Four Fig Leaves on Iran
description: When President Reagan held his last news conference, on Nov. 19, he was asked about the Iran arms deal and he gave a four-part defense: The United States had shipped only a token number of ''defensive'' antitank missiles to Iran. The Government had not condoned arms shipments by third countries like Israel. The weapons were not traded for hostages. They were used, rather, to promote a dialogue with Iranian ''moderates.''

title: Remarrying Congress and the C.I.A.
description: Next Tuesday, Robert M. Gates will appear for his confirmation hearing as Director of Central Intelligence. He will surely be confirmed, as surely he ought. But his appearance could accomplish more than that. It could reconstitute a relationship between the intelligence community and Congress that was building beautifully until it came apart this winter. And it could be the beginning of the larger process of reconciliation we must now get on with.

title: 12 DEFENDANTS IN ATTACK CASE: A DIVERSE GROUP
description: The 12 Queens teen-agers indicted yesterday in the Howard Beach racial attack are a varied lot of close friends and casual acquaintances. One studies management; another wants to be an artist. Some attend high school; others have entered college.

title: A DEATH STIRS FEAR OF AIDS ACROSS JAPAN
description: A wave of anxiety over AIDS has spread across Japan, sending Japanese to clinics for blood tests and prodding the Government to start special programs to keep the disease in check.

title: INTERSTATE CELLULAR TELEOMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $80,399 from the sale of the Telephone Interconnect division. c-Net loss.

title: PATRICK INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
4 Members of Family Die in House Fire
description: Four members of a family, including two children, were killed early yesterday in a fire in an apartment building that investigators said was being repaired to correct housing code violations.

Comfortable as a Person
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Ms. Quindlen's column contained a common stereotype that I've been noticing more and more during the past several years, which I would like reconsidered.

description: b-Net income The company said latest-quarter results were impacted by non-recurring legal expenses and investment banking fees in connection with the impending acquisition by Trico of Paccar Inc., as well as the write-off of goodwill related to the sale of a supply store owned by Trico.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 11, 1987
description: The Economy

title: 11 Artists and Authors Elected by Arts Group
description: The American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters has elected 11 new members to fill vacancies in its ranks, John Hollander, secretary of the institute, announced yesterday.

title: APOSTLE OF FRANCE'S 'LESSER GREAT WINES'
description: WHEN American buyers failed to turn up for last year's auction of Burgundy wines from the vineyards of the Hospices de Beaune, Rebecca Wasserman decided the writing was on the wall.

title: PLAINS PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Fighting the Fight On Gun Control: Sarah Brady
description: A determined-looking woman gazes from a poster being circulated by Handgun Control Inc.

title: INDUSTRIAL TRAINING SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
QUALITY SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
VETERANS OF VIETNAM FOUND TO HAVE A HIGH DEATH RATE
description: Within five years of returning to civilian life, Army combat veterans who served in Vietnam had an overall death rate 45 percent higher than a comparison group of veterans who served elsewhere in the same period, according to a Government study about to be published.

title: Europe to Cut Butter Stocks
description: The European Community's agriculture ministers agreed today to spend $3.7 billion to dispose of nearly all of the trading bloc's surplus butter, which totals more than 1.3 million tons and costs more than $1 billion a year to store.

title: EXECUTIVE AT UNILEVER TO HEAD CHESEBROUGH
description: Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. said yes-terday that its longtime leader, Ralph E. Ward, would retire and that Morris Tabaksblat, a Unilever executive, would become chairman and chief executive effective March 1.

title: LAWYER FAULTS THE DAILY NEWS FOR RACIAL BIAS
description: A lawyer for four black journalists said in Federal court in Manhattan yesterday that The Daily News had a long-established pattern of racial bias that had ruined the careers of his clients.

title: Helicopter Gunships Return To Army Service After Repair
description: The Army has completed inspecting a grounded fleet of 750 AH-1 Cobra helicopter gunships and returned them to service after replacing more than 100 main rotor blade fittings, a spokesman said today.

title: 'Well, I'm a Gentleman'
description: When Michael Burke worked as a sports executive in this town, he always seemed a throwback to the age when gallantry was expected, when brave gestures were not just a page out of Hemingway.

title: A.M.C. Warranties
description: The American Motors Corporation said it had extended its engine and transmission warranties on 1987 Renault cars to six years or 60,000 miles, from five years or 50,000 miles. A.M.C. also extended rust protection to six years or 100,000 miles. The powertrain warranty is identical to those announced by the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company.

AMERICAN GUARANTY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Trimming a Fillet of Beef
description: A WHOLE fillet of beef can be an elegant and relatively simple entree if you are cooking for 10 to 12 guests. It can be roasted whole and carved just before serving with the sauce of your choice, or sliced into individual fillets for pan-frying or broiling. The fillet of beef, also called the tenderloin, often comes untrimmed from the butcher. Use the following technique to remove the fat and membrane. If you want to roast it whole, it should be tied with twine as illustrated so that the meat keeps its shape and cooks evenly. STEP 1: To remove the thick layer of fat that covers the top of the fillet, use a sharp boning knife to separate the fat from the meat at one end, as illustrated. Grab the fat with your other hand and peel it back while working the knife underneath until all is removed. STEP 2: Carefully remove any of the translucent membrane on the surface of the meat by running the knife under it -do not slice away any meat in the process. Work with the knife and your fingers to clean the fillet. STEP 3: One end of the fillet will be smaller and narrower than the other. This is called the tail. Flip the thin tail under the fillet and then tie it securely with kitchen twine. This is done for esthetic as well as practical reasons; the tail will cook more evenly this way. Make several loops with the twine along the rest of the fillet. It is now ready to be brushed with vegetable oil and seasoned with salt and pepper. Roast a four-pound trimmed fillet for about 20 minutes in a 450-degree oven, then flip it over and roast at 400 degrees for another 10 minutes.

title: STAGE: 'FELL OFF A TRUCK,' FOR CHILDREN
description: IN the anthropomorphic world of the Paper Bag Players, the New York-based children's theater company that has just begun its 29th season, inanimate objects lead secret lives of which most of us remain oblivious. Rebellious chairs reposition themselves when their owners aren't looking. Innocuous-looking boxes turn into vaudevillian performers. And when a lonely right shoe meets a matching left shoe, they happily team up to become a pair.

description: b-Includes a gain of $397,000 and $510,000 from sale of property for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes a gain of $335,000 from sale of property.

title: Rating the Proposals
description: The antismoking proposals that are expected to be considered this year divide into several categories:

title: Death Sentence in 3 Killings
description: A jury today ordered the death penalty for a man who said he hacked three women to death with a hatchet after he tired of hearing them argue. The man, David Martin Long, 33 years old, previously told the state district court panel he wanted the death penalty and was afraid he would kill again. He was convicted Saturday of capital murder in the Sept. 27 deaths of Donna Sue Jester, 37, Dalpha Lorene Jester, 64, and Laura Lee Owen, 20, in the house they occupied in Lancaster, a suburb of Dallas.

title: OWENS ACCEPTS KOHLBERG'S CASH BID
description: After a fruitless monthlong search for another buyer, Owens-Illinois Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the investment firm, for more than $3.6 billion in cash.

title: America's Cup Book Set
description: St. Martin's Press has paid a six-figure advance for Dennis Conner's story of his triumph in the America's Cup, and expects to have the book in stores in May, the publishing house announced Monday. Titled ''Comeback: My Race for the America's Cup,'' the book, told to Bruce Stannard, an Australian journalist, is to contain more than 50 full-color photos, the publisher said.

title: Viacom Rejects Bid By Redstone Unit
description: Viacom International Inc. yesterday rejected an offer from Arsenal Holdings Inc. to acquire the diversified media company for more than $2 billion.

The company said that 1985 fourth- quarter and year-revenue figures have been restated to include commodity transactions on a gross profit basis.

title: Nippon Phone Shares Trading
description: After long anticipation, shares of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone began changing hands on Japanese stock exchanges today, trading at about 1.6 million yen a share, or $10,460.93.

title: KEAN AND GROUP OF MAYORS AGREE ON PACKAGE TO RAISE URBAN AID
description: After hours of negotiations with legislative leaders and several mayors of big cities, Governor Kean said this evening that substantial agreement had been reached on an urban-aid package that would avoid layoffs and provide property-tax relief.

title: RELIANCE GROUP HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $40,901,000 from the early extinguishment of debt. c-Net loss In the latest quarter, preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income. Share-earnings figures are after deducting dividends and accretion of discount on preferred stock of $7.8 million in the latest and year-ago quarter and $31.1 million and $31 million in the latest and prior years, respectively. On Jan. 8, 1986, the company sold the capital stock of Pilot Insurance Co., a wholly owned foreign property and casualty insurance subsidiary, for $143.6 million in cash; premiums earned exclusing Pilot were $499.6 million and $1.84 billion for the quarter and year ended Dec. 31, 1985. The company said the improvement in operating results for the fourth quarter was attributable to an increase in gain on sales of investments and an improvement in property and casualty underwriting results.

title: YOUTH COOPERATES IN BREAKING CASE
description: Charles J. Hynes, the special state prosecutor who investigated the Howard Beach racial attack, said yesterday that the break in the case occurred on the holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., when one of the young men involved in the attack came forward.

title: STANFORD TAKES 'AUDACIOUS' STEPS TO DIVERSIFY AT 102
description: In 1885, when the railroad magnate Leland Stanford was trying to figure out how to create a university, he and his wife visited Charles Eliot, the president of Harvard, to find out how much endowment would be required.

description: To the Editor:

A Division Assignment For Omnicom's Watson

He will report to Barry E. Loughrane, chairman and chief executive, who made the announcement.

Boesky, also held financial interests in two other companies controlled by Mr. Boesky, according to information provided yesterday by Mr. Goldin's office.

description: It was the first time the Soviet and American teen-agers had ever met, but they skipped the usual banter about rock stars and got right to a topic close to their hearts: ballet toe shoes.

title: VATICAN, ITS DEFICIT GROWING, ORDERS 1987 SPENDING FREEZE
description: The Vatican, pressed by a swelling budget deficit, has ordered a spending freeze for 1987, church officials said today.

description: The British, publicly held WCRS Group, which last year acquired both the HBM/Creamer and Della Femina, Travisano & Partner ad agencies in the United States, has now reached an agreement in principle to buy the Australian-based Ball Partnership for $11 million.

description: Suffolk County government, tumultuous in the best of times, was thrown into pandemonium today after a judge's decision that declared the County Executive's office vacant.

description: Cattle futures prices advanced yesterday despite lower wholesale beef prices. Pork declined, with some pork belly deliveries suffering limit losses.

description: A man and a woman were found stabbed to death in an apartment in Greenwich Village yesterday morning, and the police said they did not know whether the slayings were a double murder or a murder and a suicide.

description: AS a professional chef, I find it easy to comprehend today's blending of Oriental flavors with those of the West. I find myself using a good deal of so-called Asian flavors, including fresh ginger, fresh coriander, bean and chili paste and, of course, soy sauce.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis No Pushover: Stefan Edberg of Sweden, the No. 2-ranked player in the world, held off a determined Richey Reneberg to take a 7-6, 2-6, 6-4 victory last night at the United States Indoor Tennis Championships in Memphis. ''He played well. I was a little surprised,'' Edberg said after his match with Reneberg, a junior at Southern Methodist. Edberg, the tournament's No. 1 seed, won the first set on a 7-5 tiebreaker before Reneberg, an amateur ranked 340th internationally, took the second set. ''I lost my concentration in the second set for a while,'' Edberg said.

title: Possible Alaskan Oil That No One Needs
description: One of the great land battles of the decade is about to begin. At stake are 2,300 square miles on the Arctic Ocean in the northeastern corner of Alaska. If the Reagan Administration has its way, the famed wildlife there will have to make way for oil rigs and pipelines. Drilling would be both destructive and unnecessary.

description: Fernao Bracher, the president of Brazil's central bank since August 1985, has resigned, a Government spokesman said today.

title: 'METROLINE' EXAMINES MENTALLY ILL ON THE STREET
description: ''METROLINE,'' that useful local public-affairs program, goes into the wintry streets -''February is the worst month,'' says one of the bewildered street people -for a humane and positive presentation of the problem of the mentally ill homeless. The half-hour documentary, ''Sane Asylums,'' will be broadcast tonight at 8:30 on Channel 13.

title: HOTTEST KIDS' CLASS PUTS SMALL FRY IN THE KITCHEN
description: LEAD: AT 3:45 on a cold, blustery afternoon not long ago, nine Upper West Side chefs were hard at work, mixing the batter for the perfect chocolate chip cookie. ''These cookies are delicious,'' one announced prematurely, licking his index finger. ''It's gooey, but it's good,'' agreed his assistant. ''Mmmmm, let me lick some, too,'' said a third chef, who then paused in the sampling to ask, ''This is how real bakers make chocolate chip cookies, right?

title: Later Release Of Trade Data
description: Trade balance reports will come out later each month to give fuller data and avoid revisions, the Government said today. Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said monthly reports on the gross national product would also be delayed, partly to include the more complete trade data.

title: First Clash With Rebels Is Reported by Manila
description: Troops battled Communist rebels today in the first clash since a cease-fire ended two days ago, and a military report said 18 people were killed, including 12 civilians caught in the crossfire.

title: CALIFORNIA STORE WOOS HISPANIC COMMUNITY
description: When Von's Grocery Company opened its 191st supermarket, mariachis mingled with beauty queens and dignitaries. The scene was part civic event, part business deal, with politicians and businessmen talking about market shares, demographics and the size of the produce section.

title: 2 Men Sentenced in Scheme To Sell Airplane Parts to Iran
description: Two brothers convicted in a multimillion-dollar scheme to smuggle stolen Navy jet parts to Iran were sentenced to long Federal prison terms and $100,000 fines Monday.

title: LANE FINANCIAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

The two played the first half of the season with the Devils and were demoted Jan. 26. Anderson had 2 goals and 4 assists in 33 games and Hiemer had 6 goals and 14 assists in 40 games.

title: Texas Accepts New Inmates
description: The Texas prison system began accepting new inmates today after its population fell below a ceiling mandated by the state, but officials warned that this week's influx could force another cutoff. About 390 new inmates were accepted by midafternoon and about 125 were released at the same time, according to a spokesman for the Texas Department of Corrections. The prison system, the nation's second-largest after California, closed Feb. 4 because of overcrowding.
