description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $23 million, relating to the early extinguishment of debt, for the quarter and year.

title: SIZE OF BUDGET CUT AT CBS CONFIRMED
description: Despite denials by CBS that its news division had been asked to cut spending by up to $50 million, CBS News executives have reconfirmed that figure, and they are considering plans to make substantial cuts.

title: Taylor's Credo
description: At a luncheon yesterday at Gallagher's restaurant, where Lawrence Taylor received the Seagram Sports Award as pro football's defensive player of the year, the Giants linebacker answered many questions. But he has never discussed last winter's rehabilitation from chemical dependency, and he bristled when asked what advice he would give to youngsters about dealing with drugs. ''I don't give advice to people,'' he said. ''I live the life I live. Sometimes, people are going to find out what's right and what's wrong and will make their own decisions.''

title: 7 INDICTED IN VIOLENCE AT MARCH
description: Seven whites were indicted today for their roles in an attack on civil rights demonstrators who were pelted with bottles, stones and debris when they marched last month through a county where no blacks live.

title: Home Rule
description: With 46 straight victories on its own court, Kansas has the longest such current streak in Division I basketball. But the Jayhawks are well short of a ranking on history's top-10 list of major colleges that made the most of familiar suroundings.

title: FRIENDS' VIEWS OF MCFARLANE: FAILED HIMSELF
description: Robert C. McFarlane's sense of having failed to live up to his own standards, rather than his fear of pending investigations, prompted his apparent suicide attempt, in the view of people sympathetic to the former national security adviser who are familiar with his mental outlook.

title: U.S. BONDS CONTINUE TO SLIDE
description: Prices of Treasury bonds fell sharply yesterday for the second consecutive day, again in response to higher short-term rates and weakness in the dollar.

title: OLIVE GROVE BRINGS ARABS AND JEWS TOGETHER
description: A simple grove of olive trees brought Arabs and Jews together today to protest the Israeli Government's plan to uproot trees long tended by the Arabs.

title: MORE ARE STUDIED
description: The Soviet Union has pardoned 140 prisoners convicted of subversive activities, and a comparable number of cases are being reviewed, the Government said today.

title: Senator on Drug Patrol
description: Senators don't often have an opportunity to participate personally in programs financed by appropriation bills they sponsor. Which is why Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, got such a kick out of flying a drug surveillance and interdiction mission with the Civil Air Patrol off Florida 10 days ago.

title: VALIUM, OFTEN A SUICIDE STEP, SELDOM WORKS
description: The minor tranquilizer diazepam, best known under the trade name Valium, is commonly used in suicide attempts but seldom causes death, experts say.

description: To the Editor:

title: EMANUEL HELLER
description: Emanuel Heller, professor of marketing and dean of students at Pace Unversity's Manhattan campus, died Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan.

WICOR INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Could We Have Less Progress in Central Park?
description: To the Editor:

title: COMING SOON: COMPETITIVE SOLAR POWER
description: Even though the breakthrough is still several years away, new solar technologies are already beginning to move out of the laboratory and into commercial application. Several companies are finding ways to cut the cost and increase the production of photovoltaic panels, hastening the day when solar power will become practical on a large scale.

title: Bridge: A Fatal Blow Was Delivered By 'Suicidal' Defensive Play
description: Perhaps the weirdest move in card play is the Grosvenor Gambit. It is a suicidal defensive play that gives the declarer a chance to score a trick he is not entitled to. The defender is confident that the declarer will not take advantage of the gambit because he will assume sanity rather than generosity.

title: GUGGENHEIM MUSEUM PROPOSING SCALED-DOWN DESIGN FOR ADDITION
description: Officials of the Guggenheim Museum, conceding that an earlier plan to add a cantilevered tower to the museum's celebrated Frank Lloyd Wright-designed building on Fifth Avenue had won little support while incurring the resentment of community groups and preservationists, presented a new, scaled-down design yesterday. The new Guggenheim tower, 10 stories high, would be one floor lower than the first plan. In its overall design, however, it differs more dramatically, and is now a discreet backdrop to the museum rather than a competing element.

title: CHATEAUS ARE CHARMING, BUT HIGH TECH PAYS BILLS
description: This is the kind of southern French town, in the dry hills near the Mediterranean coast, that is often regarded by those who do not live here as old fashioned and steeped in archaic habits, virtually a symbol of the things that do not change in France.

title: DEMOCRATS, LOOKING SOUTH, PICK ATLANTA FOR '88 CONVENTION
description: The Democratic Party decided today to hold its national convention in Atlanta July 18-21, 1988, underscoring the political importance of the Deep South in next year's Presidential election.

title: Lieberman Traded
description: Nancy Lieberman, who became the first woman in professional sports to compete in an all-male league when she averaged 1.7 points and 1.3 assists with the Springfield Fame in the United States Basketball League last season, has returned closer to home. In exchange for second- and third-round draft choices, the 5-foot-10-inch point guard from Far Rockaway, Queens, and Old Dominion College was obtained yesterday by the Long Island Knights of the U.S.B.L. She received a three-year contract to play for the Knights, who are based at State University at Old Westbury. The eight-team league runs from May 15 to July 19. ''Nancy has one of the greatest attitudes of any basketball player I've ever coached,'' said Coach Dean Meminger, a member of the Knicks' 1972-73 championship team, who previously coached Lieberman in semipro leagues. Meminger also coached the New York Stars to the Women's Basketball League championship in the league's final season of 1980.

title: Commercial Paper Shifts by Salomon
description: Salomon Brothers announced a new program to eliminate some of the distinctions between commercial paper issued domestically and internationally.

title: Two Issues By Sallie Mae
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association is offering two issues of fixed-rate notes totaling $525 million. Both issues are priced at par.

title: STATE DEPT. GIVES MOSCOW A RARE PAT ON THE BACK
description: The Reagan Administration gave Moscow a rare pat on the back today, welcoming the Kremlin's decision to free 140 political prisoners as ''an important step'' and urging further releases as a way toward improving Soviet-American relations.

title: Digital Equipment
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation, as expected, introduced two new models of its popular VAX line of computers, one of which will sell for half the cost of previous low-end models. The new models are aimed at the engineering, educational, scientific, government and commercial markets. The VAX Station 2000 is a free-standing desktop computer that has high-performance graphics capabilities, the company said. The cheapest version of the VAX Station 2000 will be priced at $10,500. The other new model, the Microvax 2000, consists of a central processing unit that can be connected with up to four terminals. It is priced at less than $10,000.

title: A-Plant Leaks Gas, Forcing Cut in Power
description: An ''unusual event'' was declared today at the Oyster Creek Nuclear Generating Station after operators detected leaking radioactive gas and reduced power, officials said.

description: b-Includes gains related to the sale of marine vessels and other year-end adjustments. c-Includes a writedown of assets of $488,733,000, reflecting a reduction in the value of the assets and related investments. d-After charges from a provision to settle a lawsuit related to the South Texas nuclear project of $40,000,000 for the quarter and $368,012,000 for the year. The year also includes a writedown of assets of $195,008,000, reflecting a reduction in the value of the assets and related investments.

MANY EXPERTS DOUBT 'STAR WARS' COULD BE EFFECTIVE BY THE MID-90'S
description: A growing number of experts say they are skeptical that even a rudimentary system to shoot down attacking missiles could be deployed effectively within the next decade, as the Reagan Administration is considering.

The company also adopted F.A.S.B. 87 relating to pensions, which increased net by $4 million in the latest quarter and $16.6 million for the year. The net for the latest fourth quarter did not cover preferred dividend requirements.

title: Economic Scene; The Dollar Tug-of-War
description: THE foreign exchange markets have been nervous and confused about where the dollar is going. One day it rallies, the next it plunges, sending shock waves through the bond, stock and futures markets, and then it rallies again, as investors struggle to interpret the Delphic remarks of Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d.

description: THE Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center presented a light, engaging program of music by Antonio Soler, Manuel de Falla, Franz Doppler, Beethoven and Dvorak at Alice Tully Hall at twilight on Sunday.

description: Secretary of Education William J. Bennett handed out mixed grades today in his annual report on schools nationwide and called the results ''a hangover after the binge'' of recent improvements.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Sacramento Municipal Utility District is tentatively offering $408 million of electric revenue refunding bonds with a maximum yield of 7.131 percent for bonds due in 2011, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Let's Get the Facts on the Arms Talks
description: Debate swirls in Washington over a pair of arms deals with the Soviet Union. The public is confused. Read the opinion pages of a few newspapers and you will see why.

title: Stanley Kunitz Wins Bollingen Poetry Prize
description: Stanley Kunitz has won the Bollingen Prize in Poetry of the Yale University Library. The $5,000 prize, announced yesterday, is given every two years to one or more living American poets for the best collection published in that period, or for a body of poetry written over several years. Mr. Kunitz, who is 81 years old, and whose ''Selected Poems'' (1958) won the Pulitzer Prize, was cited for the ''growth and vigor'' of his own work, his support as a ''nurturing spirit for scores of younger poets,'' and his influence on such poets as Theodore Roethke and Robert Lowell who, the judges said, probably became ''better poets than they would have been without his friendship.''

title: Higher Yield Lifts Sales Of Jersey Pike's Bonds
description: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority is reissuing about $2 billion of bonds it originally sold in late 1985 with floating interest rates or short maturities of five years or less.

title: No Overtime
description: The National Basketball Association has an avid following in Israel, so avid, in fact, that the nation was one of only half a dozen abroad whose television networks carried Sunday's All-Star Game live, starting at 10:30 P.M., Israeli time. This is not to suggest that everybody in Israel is an N.B.A. fan or, as it turns out, cares a whit for those who are.

title: YOUNG, WIDOWED AND NEW TO SELF-HELP
description: ''I spent my first anniversary alone,'' said Ira Nerken, a 35-year-old Washington lawyer whose wife was killed in a car accident five months after their marriage. ''We'd just bought a house, and suddenly all our plans were shot,'' Mr. Nerken said. ''We never had a chance to live our dreams.''

title: ADT INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $900,000 gain from discontinued operations and a gain of 4 cents a share from a change in accounting for pensions. c-Net loss and includes a $3.2 million loss from discontinued operations and a $22 million loss from a change in accounting principle.

title: BEIRUT SOURCES SAY ISRAEL TALKS WITH KIDNAPPERS
description: Arab diplomats and local radio stations said today that behind-the-scenes contacts were under way to work out a deal that would involve the release of four kidnapped professors and an Israeli Air Force navigator in exchange for 400 Arab prisoners held by Israel.

title: Dollar Rallies After Fall Tied to Baker Remarks
description: The dollar rose a bit yesterday after Monday's plunge. Trading continued to be hectic.

title: Contel-Comsat Merger Approved
description: A telecommunications merger valued at about $2.5 billion was approved by stockholders of both the Contel Corporation and Comsat, but Federal regulators must approve the deal and it also may be examined by Congress.

title: CHARGE IS MURDER FOR 3 OF YOUTHS IN QUEENS ATTACK
description: Three white teen-agers from Queens were charged yesterday with murder and nine others were charged with lesser crimes in the second attempt by authorities to identify and prosecute participants in the Howard Beach racial attack.

title: PACIFICORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Floods Strike Soviet Georgia
description: More than 16,000 people have been evacuated from areas of Soviet Georgia after floods and avalanches, the press agency Tass said today.

title: The Patient's Peril on the Sea of Medical Care; A Dollar Value on Life
description: To the Editor:

title: MIAMI LOSES DESPITE HORFORD'S 20 POINTS
description: The description did not seem to fit the public perception of the young basketball player who had ventured from one campus to another before finally settling down at the University of Miami in Coral Gables, Fla., last year.

title: Mondale in Marble
description: The Constitution specifies that the Vice President shall be president of the Senate, although he normally appears there only when a close vote is in prospect. But as a sign of ceremonial respect, the Senate commissions a bust of each Vice President, and 37 of them are now displayed in corridors of the Capitol.

title: DANIELS IS BARRED AFTER DRUG ARREST
description: Lloyd Daniels, a highly rated basketball prospect from New York, has been arrested here on drug charges and has been banned from playing for Nevada-Las Vegas, whose team he had hoped to join next season.

title: SUDDENLY FREE, THEY REACH OUT TO EACH OTHER
description: ''Some of the voices on the telephone are completely unfamiliar,'' Larisa Bogoraz said. ''This is Lev Mikhailovich Timofeyev,'' one caller began.

title: A Senator Who Put His Country Before Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: AMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the 1986 results are unaudited and subject to further adjustment, 1986 net income was increased by 4 cents a share by its election to apply the principles of FASB No. 87 to the determination of pension expense.

title: The U.N. Today: Feb. 11, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Special Committee on the United Nations Charter - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A San Francisco dispatch on Feb. 2, about AIDS among Roman Catholic clergymen, misidentified a priest and his affilation. He is the Rev. Bernard Lynch, an order priest who counsels AIDS patients in New York. He has no association with the Archdiocese of New York.

title: Schooled in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: GOLDEN VALLEY MICROWAVE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $391,000, or 8 cents a share.

title: Oval Office Fright
description: Gene Hackman, the actor, was in Washington last week to promote his new film, ''Hoosiers,'' and officials of the Motion Picture Association of America took him by the White House in case President Reagan might be free for a personal greeting. They kept reassuring Mr. Hackman, who betrayed symptoms of stage fright, to remember that the President was ''one of us, an actor.'' But when he emerged from the Oval Office, Mr. Hackman was still somewhat shaken. ''I don't care if he came from Hollywood,'' he said. ''When he's behind the desk in that room, he's the President of the United States. I haven't been that nervous in 20 years.''

title: CALGENE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said it acquired Agro Ingredients in May 1986.

title: Cult's Farm Searched For Human Remains
description: A plot on a farm that was used by a cult was excavated today after the authorities received information that human remains might be buried there, but nothing was found, the police said.

title: RJR NABISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $10 million and $16 million for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $3 million and $25 million for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said that in the latest quarter per-share earnings from continuing operations increased over the prior period reflecting the favorable effect of lower preferred dividend payments and the result of early retirement of two classes of preferred stock; in the latest quarter, preferred dividend payments were $9 million compared to $41 million in the prior quarter. The company, which reported improved net from continuing operations for 1986, said that excluding the effect of an investment-tax credit reversal under the new tax law, net per share earnings from continuing operations in the latest year were $4. The company also said that its net earnings from continuing operations and net earnings per share for the year were adversely affected by charges of $76 million, or 30 cents a share, related to the early retirement of high-cost debt and a one-time corporate restructuring and streamlining program. Results from continuing operations do not include Kentucky Fried Chicken Corp., which was sold on Oct. 1.

title: THREE EXPERTS SAY BABY M'S MOTHER IS UNSTABLE
description: Three mental-health experts who have recommended denying custody to Baby M's biological mother, Mary Beth Whitehead, contended today that Mrs. Whitehead exhibited signs of emotional instability and should be denied access to the girl for at least five years.

title: FILM: 'THE GOOD FATHER'
description: THOUGH he makes a good living as a marketing executive with a London publishing house, Bill Hooper (Anthony Hopkins) lives in self-imposed squalor in a dingy bed-sitter near some railroad tracks. Bill, divorced and the father of a small son, is furious with the world and everybody in it, especially with the self-sufficient Emmy, his former wife, who now lives with another man, and even with the child, whom he blames for coming between the parents.

title: Market Place; Opinion Mixed On Tobaccos
description: TOBACCO stocks, the market's best-performing group last year, ran into a slight selling squall yesterday. ''Some people were cashing in their chips after big gains enjoyed by the tobaccos,'' said Emanuel Goldman of Montgomery Securities in San Francisco.

title: WHERE I.B.M. HURTS THE MOST
description: Last month the International Business Machines Corporation reported its largest quarterly earnings decline since the company began selling computers, and Wall Street and the computer world were eager to find out what went wrong.

title: PRICE'S 13 IN 2D HALF HELP DEFEAT KNICKS
description: Mark Price, a rookie guard playing his first game since undergoing an appendectomy a month ago, came off the bench and scored 13 second-half points tonight, rallying the Cleveland Cavaliers to a 100-95 National Basketball Association victory over the Knicks.

title: Group Urges Closing of 8 'Unstable' Reactors
description: An antinuclear group said today that it had asked the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to close eight nuclear reactors of the Three Mile Island design until they could be made more stable.

title: OUTSIDE VENTURES TRANSFORM LAW FIRMS
description: Arnold & Porter's 230 lawyers have always ranked among the best in Washington, but these days the firm's non-lawyer professionals are almost as prominent. For Arnold & Porter is no longer just a law firm: It has a wholly owned subsidiary that offers a wide range of consulting services and a joint venture with William Isaac, the former chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

title: I.O.C. Set to Hear North Korea Plea
description: North Korean sports officials gathered today to discuss with International Olympic Committee leaders Pyongyang's insistence on sharing the 1988 Summer Olympics with South Korea. The meeting is set for Wednesday.

title: Fight Drugs With Work Camps
description: The national hysteria over drug abuse appears to have faded. Even the White House, having recently promised ''a sustained, relentless effort to rid America of this scourge,'' now talks of chopping drug enforcement funds. And in truth, the drug legislation hustled through Congress last year leaned more heavily toward spending than imagination. That's all the more reason to applaud a new spark of drug enforcement imagination in New York called work camps.

title: INTERNATIONAL RECTIFIER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $109,000 for the quarter and $123,000 for the 6 months, and includes income from discontinued operations of $295,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income and includes tax credits of $94,000 for the quarter and $136,000 for the 6 months.

title: The Chain Gang Of Basketball
description: The entire school day after every game, Tom May, the coach of the girls' basketball team at Crown Point (Ind.) High School, requires the starter with the game's lowest proficiency rating to lug around a bowling ball chained to her ankle. The ball, chain and padlock together weigh about 20 pounds.

title: TRANSNET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ATHEY PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Soviet vs. N.H.L: Best vs. Best
description: Before the cheerful backdrop of the brightly colored lights and ice sculptures of a wintertime ritual, an all-star team from the National Hockey League and the national team of the Soviet Union today approached the business of a two-game series that will revise the sport's balance of power.

title: LAWMAKERS ASK DELAY ON FOOD IRRADIATION
description: Bills to block new Federal rules allowing the use of radiation to preserve pork and produce were recently introduced in the House and Senate by lawmakers who said the procedure had been approved prematurely. Representative Douglas H. Bosco, Democrat of California, said neither he nor Senator George J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maine, were ''saying that food irradiation shouldn't happen.''

title: DEALER IN MORMON FRAUD CALLED A MASTER FORGER
description: He was shy, tentative and sometimes spoke so softly that he was barely audible. A kind of scholarly country bumpkin, Mark W. Hofmann flew to New York from the hinterlands bearing precious documents unearthed from America's past, or so it seemed, and he fooled everyone.

title: WINE TALK
description: LONG before graduating to wine, most of us begin with milk, which, of course, brings us to our first vintage-dating: The carton says ''Sell by Feb. 11.'' But wine is wine and milk is milk, and never the twain shall sensibly meet in a glass. Yet the twain come close to meeting when a half ounce of Cognac (brandy distilled from wine), a half ounce of heavy cream and a half ounce of creme de cacao are shaken together with cracked ice and strained into a cocktail glass. Voila! A Brandy Alexander. Irish cream liqueurs - a blend of Irish whisky, cream and such flavorings as chocolate and coffee - are near-relatives of the Brandy Alexander. They have been available in the United States since 1979, five years after distillers in Ireland created them. When the creams first arrived, they were fashionable, but sales generally have since cooled down.

title: DANCE: BALINESE AND AMERICAN STYLES
description: IN choreographing for her Balinese American Dance Theater, Islene Pinder combines Western modern dance with Balinese dance. Her cultural borrowings resulted in two types of works -sketches and dance-dramas - when the troupe appeared Sunday afternoon at the Nikolais-Louis Studio. The sketches were particularly effective.

title: Low-Budget Movies Get A High Gloss
description: The American public's appetite for feature films is growing rapidly, in large part because of the phenomenal popularity of video cassettes. The cost of making those feature films, though, is rising even more rapidly. In 1985, the last year for which figures are available, the average production cost of a feature film was $16.8 million, according to the Motion Picture Association of America.

title: BALLY MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the change in the tax law related to the investment tax credit reduced 1986 net by 15 cents a share. The company said the results of MGM Grand Hotels Inc., acquired in April 1986, and Bally's Park Place Inc., acquired in June 1986, are included from the purchase dates.

title: MET TO OFFER NEW VERSIONS OF 3 OPERAS
description: The Metropolitan Opera will present three new productions during its 1987-88 season, the company announced yesterday. Two will be installments in its continuing cycle of Wagner's ''Ring des Nibelungen,'' scheduled for completion the following season. New next season will be ''Das Rheingold'' Oct. 9 and ''Siegfried'' Feb. 12, along with Verdi's ''Trovatore'' Nov. 12.

title: ORIOLE HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $682,000.

title: KOOP URGES TV CONDOM ADS TO FIGHT AIDS
description: Surgeon General C. Everett Koop, saying that condoms offered the best protection from the deadly AIDS virus for those who ''will not practice abstinence or monogamy,'' today called for condom advertisements on television.

title: A 'POLITE' CELEBRATION FOR THE BEST IN YACHTING
description: It was a polite parade. Even the losers quite enjoyed it. ''Pretty good, but it should be in Sydney,'' said Matt Warburton, an 18-year-old student from Australia, who was waving his nation's flag at 48th Street and Fifth Avenue. Still, he said, ''People are nice. They yell, 'G'day, mate.' ''

title: 'Platoon' and 'Fortune' Are Box-Office Leaders
description: ''Platoon,'' Oliver Stone's Vietnam War saga, remained the No. 1 film at the box office last week on the eve of Academy Award nominations.

title: LACLEDE GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''I can say to you that there are comrades who think, the harsher the better. But at the moment we are heading into a softening, so that we may have fewer people behind bars and behind barbed wire.'' - Gennadi I. Gerasimov, the Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman. [ A12:4. ]

title: 3 MANHATTAN BUILDINGS ARE NAMED LANDMARKS
description: The monumental former home office of the New York Life Insurance Company, the oldest surviving structure built as a synagogue in New York and a once-luxurious Upper West Side hotel all became official landmarks yesterday.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report on Jan. 3 in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page mis stated the period in which the brothers Robert and Edward Kennedy served together in the Senate. It was 1965 to 1968.

title: ANDREW CUOMO SAYS CONSTRUCTION IS SET FOR MODEL BROOKLYN SHELTER
description: After months of delay, Andrew Cuomo, the Governor's son, announced today that construction was about to begin on a Brooklyn shelter for homeless families - a model for other family shelters he hopes to build throughout New York City and the state.

title: Nureyev Said to Desire Engagement in Soviet
description: Rudolf Nureyev was quoted today as saying he would like to dance again in the Soviet Union after living more than 25 years in the West.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE STORY HOUR

title: PROSECUTION ENDS IN FILMING DEATHS
description: The prosecution in the manslaughter trial over the filming of ''Twilight Zone: The Movie'' completed its case today with a visit by jurors to an arid Los Angeles park where the crash of a helicopter amid special-effects explosions killed three actors in 1982.

title: Bolivia Acts Against Strikes, Arresting 20 Labor Leaders
description: Authorities arrested 20 trade union leaders and theatened tough action against a wave of strikes sweeping the country, Interior Minister Fernando Berthelemy said today.

title: TELEPROBE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $94,000 and $133,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: VITRAMON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $78,000 and $313,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $11,000 and $227,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Hydrogen Chloride
description: To the Editor:

title: CONTINENTAL MEDICAL SYSEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $21,000 for the quarter and $124,000 for the 6 months. The company said there are no comparative results for the prior year periods since the company commenced operations on March 15, 1986, and it had its initial public offering in November.

title: EASTERN AIR AGREES TO PAY HUGE FINE
description: Eastern Airlines announced today that it had agreed to pay a $9.5 million fine, by far the largest civil penalty ever imposed against an airline by the Federal Aviation Administration, after a special audit found more than 78,000 violations of maintenance and safety regulations.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: 'Starlight Express' Delayed
description: Mechanical problems with the staging have delayed the opening of the new musical ''Starlight Express,'' by Andrew Lloyd Webber and Richard Stilgoe. It is now to begin previews Feb. 19 and open March 5 at the Gershwin Theater, said Bill Evans, spokesman for the show. The musical, directed by Trevor Nunn, was to have begun previews next Tuesday and to have opened on Feb. 26.

title: FILTERTEK COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in May 1986.

title: MIXED MUSIC THE FARE AT THE KITCHEN
description: ''WHEN I think of the role of the Kitchen,'' said Arto Lindsay, who is now the music curator at New York's avant-garde institution, ''it's been in finding what's happening next and trying to help that happen.'' Mr. Lindsay has been active in New York's new music since the late 1970's, playing compacted noise in the band DNA, quasi-jazz in the Lounge Lizards and fractured Brazilian music with the Ambitious Lovers. His first series of bookings at the Kitchen (512 West 19th Street, 255-5793) begins tonight, and in the course of double bills Wednesday through Saturday this week and next week the club will present improvisation, jazz, rap, Latin music, noise, and some new, category-busting hybrids.

title: ST. JOHN'S TRUIMPHS IN OVERTIME
description: Opponents say he isn't that fast and that he isn't that quick. But Mark Jackson, who is on the way to one of the most remarkable seasons in recent St. John's history, is proving that he is fast enough and quick enough for any competition he is likely to meet this season.

title: AVX CORP reports earnings for 13wks to Dec 31
description: The company said the loss for 1986 includes a pre-tax $4.5 million provision for disposal of the company's hybrid circuit product line (including $2 million of goodwill) and a $2 million gain on the sale of a 75 percent interest in a foreign subsidiary.

title: MEXICAN PRICES SURGE
description: Comsumer prices rose 8.1 percent in January, according to Mexico's central bank, thus starting another year of what could be triple-digit inflation. In 1986, Mexican inflation soared to a record 105.7 percent. Although the Government hopes to reduce that by 20 or 30 percentage points this year, some private analysts warn that it could reach 120 percent. Among the biggest price increases last month was 12.4 percent for health care.

title: U.S. TANKS SABOTAGED? LUXEMBOURG SHAKEN
description: ''Until now,'' a worried Government official said, ''we haven't had anti-American acts in Luxembourg.''

title: SALOMON'S NET FALLS 38.6% IN QUARTER
description: Salomon Inc., one of the nation's leading investment banking houses, reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings fell 38.6 percent.

title: DOW DECLINES 18.70 MORE, TO 2,158.04
description: Stock prices fell on Wall Street for the third straight session yesterday as the weakening dollar once again gave investors an excuse for converting some of their paper profits into cash.

title: CLEVETRUST REALTY INVESORS SBI reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $199,000 from the early extinguishment of debt. c-Net loss

title: LIBERTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $1,389,000 for the quarter and $6,546,000 for the year, and also includes a gain of $2.9 million from the sale of the company's four radio stations for the year. c-After a capital loss of $363,000 for the quarter and a capital gain of $3,739,000 for the year.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FOE. By J. M. Coetzee. 157 pages. Viking. $15.95.

title: 'AMERIKA' STAR WILL APPEAR IN U.N. PUBLIC-SERVICE SPOTS
description: Kris Kristofferson, one of the stars of the ABC mini-series ''Amerika'' -which starts Sunday and which some say defames the United Nations -will visit that organization today to film public-service announcements praising United Nations peacekeeping forces.

title: 'HONEST SOUL' IS SALUTED IN GIFT TO THE NEEDIEST
description: A gift of $100 to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has been received from Dan Wedge of Sussex, N.J., honoring ''the honest soul'' at the American Male clothing store at 80th Street and Broadway in Manhattan who found and returned a lost purse containing valuables and refused a reward.

title: TRIDEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income of $1.7 million from c contingent payment on the sale of the company's relay division.

title: BEIRUT CAPTIVE RANSOMED
description: A wealthy Lebanese-American kidnapped four days ago was freed unharmed today after his family paid a ''sizable ransom,'' the police said.

title: PEOPLE
description: * Nadeen Peterson, already an executive vice president, has been named executive creative director at Saatchi & Saatchi Compton.

title: TIPPERARY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain from the retirement of debt of $18,223,000.

title: Paraguay Breaks Up Rally for U.S. Envoy
description: United States marines escorted Ambassador Clyde Taylor from a rally in his support on Monday night after the police broke up the crowd with tear gas, witnesses said today. The police said there were no injuries or arrests.

title: NEECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PERSONAL HEALTH
description: MILLIONS of Americans have taken seriously recent studies suggesting that diet may help to prevent certain devastating diseases. Among the nutrients that have most captured consumer attention are calcium to prevent osteoporosis, fish oils to prevent heart disease and vitamin A to prevent cancer.

title: DEVELOPERS NAMED FOR HUDSON COMPLEX
description: A development team headed by Julien J. Studley, the real-estate broker and developer, has been selected to build a huge, $636 million hotel and apartment complex on a 13-acre platform above the Hudson River just west of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

title: ALLIS-CHALMERS TO SPLIT OPERATIONS
description: The Allis- Chalmers Corporation said it planned to split its worldwide operations into two separate companies. It said the realignment was part of its efforts to become more competitive in international markets.

title: REAGAN POLITICAL CONFIDANT IS LIKELY TO GET A TOP WHITE HOUSE JOB
description: President Reagan, facing the most serious crisis of his Presidency, is bringing Stuart K. Spencer, one of his oldest political confidants, into the White House to serve as a senior staff member, a source close to the President said tonight.

title: CBS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $3.2 million for the quarter and net of $13.8 million for the year; gains of $187.7 million and $185.6 million for the quarter and year, respectively on the disposal of discontinued operations, and losses on the extinguishment of debt of $2.4 million for the quarter and $14.1 million for the year. c-After net from discontinued operations of $2.2 million for the quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $34.6 million for the year, and losses of $11.5 million and $132.3 million for the quarter and year, respectively on the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: AMAX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes pension gains of $110 million recorded during the year. c-Net loss and includes a $360 million provision for losses on properties and investments. The company said the latest quarter results include a charge of $45 million for a reduction in the carrying value of the El Mochito Mine in Honduras and a $44 million tax benefit from the reversl of Alumax deferred taxes. The company said the year-ago quarter results include a charge of $45 million for losses on Tungsten and Base Metals Properties and Investments, a loss of $45 million on the anticipated disposition of the agricultural chemicals business, and a gain of $45 million from the sale of the iron ore business.

title: DRUG SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a non-operating loss of $2,636,000.

title: Chairman of GCA Revises Equity Plan
description: Richard P. Rifenburgh, chairman and chief executive of the GCA Corporation, says he sees himself as a turnaround person. ''I do like a particularly difficult situation, and GCA was it,'' he said yesterday.

title: Hockey Bans Urged
description: According to General Secretary Jan-Ake Edvinsson, a five-man disciplinary committee of the International Ice Hockey Federation has recommended disqualification from international tournaments for periods of up to three years of all 19 players (excluding goaltenders) in a Soviet-Canada brawl at the world junior hockey championships Jan. 4. It also blamed the Norwegian referee, Hans-Ivar Ronning, for losing control of the game from the first period and recommended that the coaches for the two teams - Canada's Bert Templeton and Pat Burns and Vladimir Vasiliev and Valentin Gureev of the Soviet Union - be barred from all international competition until Dec. 31, 1989. The recommendations will be considered at the next federation general congress, during the world championships in Vienna in April. The Canada-Soviet Union game, played in Piestany, Czechoslovakia, was suspended at 13 minutes 53 seconds of the second period when players from both teams squared off after a shoving and pushing match in the Soviet end of the ice. Both team were disqualified from the tournament and their records were erased.

title: DOWNEY SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Advertising; Durfee, Solow and, Now, Roth
description: DURFEE & SOLOW ADVERTISING, founded, owned and operated by two of the better known copywriters of the exciting 1960's, has been making ads since its founding in 1982 without the help of a top marketing person to import strategic considerations, aggressively seek out new business and, basically, handle the business side of the business.

title: STANDARD LOGIC INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $312,600 and $537,212 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Seeking Labor's Blessing
description: Although some Democrats question whether the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s endorsement did Walter F. Mondale any good in the 1984 election, there seems to be no lack of interest among potential 1988 contenders in securing labor's blessing. With the labor federation's executive council holding its annual meeting in Florida next week, even two of the darker Republican dark horses will join several Democratic candidates in dropping by to pay their respects.

title: Amundsen Had No Planes to Fetch Him
description: To the Editor:

title: DePAUL BEATS MARQUETTE FOR 21ST VICTORY
description: Rod Strickland scored 24 points and Kevin Edwards had 10 of his 14 in the first four minutes of the second half tonight to lead fifth-ranked DePaul to a 88-76 victory over Marquette.

title: FIRST CAPITAL HOLDINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized gains on investments of $526,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $5,643,000 for the year. c-Includes realized gains on investments of $120,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $90,000 for the year.

title: BAIRD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: b-Net loss

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL KNICKS VS. MILWAUKEE BUCKS, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30P.M. (TV - MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WNBC 660, 7:30 P.M.) HOCKEY N.H.L. ALL STARS VS. SOVIET UNION, at Quebec City, 7:30 P.M. (TV - ESPN, 7:30 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS HARNESS RACING: Roosevelt, 7:30 P.M. Meadowlands, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, midnight) SOCCER: M.I.S.L. All Star Game, at Los Angeles (Radio - WBAU-FM 90.3, 10:50 P.M.) THOROUGHBRED RACING: Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 6:15 P.M. and 11:15 P.M.)

title: Dust Balls, Vacuums And Library Stacks
description: ''POMPIDOU'' by Rouanet was absolutely disgusting.

title: Neil Simon Leaves Hospital
description: The playwright Neil Simon, recovered from adrenal-gland surgery, was discharged from Cedars Sinai Medical Center Sunday, the hospital announced. Mr. Simon, 59 years old, underwent the surgery Feb. 2 as a follow-up to an operation performed last year.

title: SEALING A COURT FOR JURY CHARGE IS RULED ILLEGAL
description: A state appeals court in Manhattan ruled yesterday that sealing a courtroom for a judge's instructions to a jury - a practice that is almost universal in New York's courts - is unconstitutional because it diminishes public and press access.

title: REGIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 11, 1987
description: International A3-17 The Kremlin pardoned 140 prisoners convicted of anti-state activities, and a comparable number of cases are being reviewed for possible release, the Government said, as part of a review of the Soviet criminal code. Page A1 Soviet dissidents have paid respects, since their unexpected release from labor camps, to the nerve centers of their movement - Andrei D. Sakharov and Yelena G. Bonner, and Larisa Bogoraz, the widow of Anatoly T. Marchenko. A12 Washington applauded Moscow for its decision to free 140 political prisoners, calling it ''an important step'' and urging further releases as a way toward improving Soviet-American relations. A12 Robert McFarlane's sense of failure at living up to his own standards, rather than his fear of pending investigations, prompted his apparent suicide attempt, say people sympathetic to the former national security adviser who are familiar with his mental outlook. A1 When Mr. McFarlane overdosed on drugs, he was attempting suicide, the police say, but they said they had ended their investigation because there were no grounds for criminal charges. A16 Valium seldom causes death but is commonly used in suicide attempts, experts said. One doctor said it was ''the best thing for a would-be suicide to take,'' because it can leave a person with another chance at life. A17 Washington's policy on South Africa has failed, according to a panel appointed by the Reagan Administration to evaluate America's ''constructive engagement'' policy toward South Africa. A1 Using Mexico as a U.S. entry point is becoming more common for citizens of countries as far away as India, China, Yugoslavia and Lebanon, according to American and Mexican Government officials. A3 Anxiety over AIDS in Japan has spread, sending Japanese to clinics for blood tests and prodding the Government to start special programs to keep the disease in check. A11 National A19-24, B10-14 Experts doubt that a 'Star Wars' defense system of even a rudimentary nature could be put in place in the next decade, as the Reagan Administration is considering. A1 'Star Wars' session inconclusive A13 Eastern Airlines will pay $9.5 million as a fine, the largest civil penalty the Federal Aviation Administration has ever imposed against an airline, for more than 78,000 maintenance and safety violations. A19 Vietnam veterans' death rate within the first five years of their return from combat to civilian life was 45 percent higher than that of veterans of the same era who did not serve in Vietnam, a new study said. A20 A forger fooled the Mormon Church and scores of document collectors around the country with forged historical papers. He has pleaded guilty of killing two people to keep his forgeries a secret. A20 Stanford began a fund-raising drive to raise $1.1 billion in five years, the largest amount ever sought by an American university from private sources. The school's president called the move ''audacious.'' B11 Television condom advertisements were advocated by the Surgeon General, C. Everett Koop, who said condoms were the best protection from the AIDS virus for those who ''will not practice abstinence or monogamy.'' A1 The Democratic Party chose Atlanta as the site for its 1988 national convention, calling it ''the hub, heart and capital of the South'' and underscoring that region's political importance in the Presidential election. B14 A plea to close eight nuclear reactors of the Three Mile Island design until they can be made more stable came from the Union of Concerned Scientists, which also requested public hearings on the plants. A24 One of Mr. Reagan's old confidants is being brought into the White House to serve as a senior staff member, a source close to the President said. The confidant, Stuart K. Spencer, is a master political operator. B14 The dollar has declined enough against the Japanese yen, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d suggested. His remarks were seen as designed to put pressure on West Germany to reach a currency accord similar to one with Japan. D5 Starting over after losing a spouse early in life can carry added nuances of tragedy, from guilt to debt to alienation, says to a book by the director of Sinai Hospital's Widowed Persons Service in Baltimore. C1 Washington Talk B10 The politics of smoking Sarah Brady's fight on guns Regional B1-9 Murder charges for 3 Queens youths were part of an indictment unsealed in the Howard Beach assault case, which also charged nine other teen-agers with crimes ranging from manslaughter to inciting to riot. A1 The break in the Howard Beach case occured on the holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., when one of the youths suspected in the attack came forward, according to the special prosecutor who investigated the attack. A1 A Brooklyn shelter for the homeless is about to be constructed, Andrew Cuomo announced. It is a model for other family shelters he hopes to build throughout New York City and the state. A1 Builders of a $636 billion hotel and apartment complex on a 13-acre platform above the Hudson River have been selected. The team is headed by Julien J. Studley, the real-estate broker and developer. B1 A new design for the Guggenheim Museum's expansion was presented that is one floor lower than a previous plan that had incurred the resentment of community groups and preservationists. C19 Turmoil for Suffolk government B1 Urban aid pact in Jersey B2 3 buildings named landmarks B2 Two found stabbed to death B3 Simon reviews pension rights B3 Experts call Whitehead unstable B4 Assembly petitions investigated B6 Neediest Cases B9

title: HEI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LORIMAR-TELEPICTURES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes pre-tax charges of $37 million from an increase in bad debt reserve and downward revision of income forecast for certain television programming for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income d-Includes a tax-related charge of $75,000.

title: INTELLIGENT BUSINESS COMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: The company siad it has completed the transition from a development stage enterprise to an operating company, and anticipates an operating profit of about $1.4 million for its first quarter ending Jan. 31.

title: NO SHIFT EMERGES IN 'STAR WARS' PLAN
description: President Reagan met with senior officials today to resume discussions about the conduct of the ''Star Wars'' program and its relationship to the Antiballistic Missile Treaty.

title: REAGAN WON'T ORDER TESTIMONY
description: President Reagan has refused to order Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North to appear before the commission reviewing the activities of the National Security Council, the White House said today.

title: HONEYWELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from disposal of discontinued operations of $407.7 million for the quarter and year, and also a gain of $12.4 million for the quarter and a loss of $3.3 million for the year from discontinued operations. c-Net income includes gains from discontinued operations of $33.1 million for the quarter and $55.8 million for the year, and gains from disposal of discontinued operations of $6.2 million, for the quarter and year.

title: Lewiston's Team
description: Most years, The Morning Tribune of Lewiston, Idaho, devotes the major share of its college basketball coverage to Washington State and the University of Idaho, both within 30 miles of Lewiston. By late January this season, though, sports-page readers were falling asleep, owing largely to State's nine-game losing streak and Idaho's sub-.500 record in the Big Sky Conference.

title: GREYHOUND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a one-time gain of $79.7 million, or $1.78 a share, from the sale of Greyhound Capital Corp. c-Includes net nonrecurring gains totaling $102.5 million, or $2.28 a share. This is comprised of gains of $89.5 million on sale of Conagra Inc. shares, $79.7 million on sale of Greyhound Capital Corp., and also includes losses of $14.8 million on special provisions for Greyhound Lines terminal conversion program costs, European shipping loan losses of $43.8 million and an anticipated loss of $8.1 million related to Pine Top Insurance Co.-Illinois. d-After an unusual charge of $19.4 million resulting from a special loss provision made by Greyhound Financial Corp. The company said without these nonrecurring and unusual items, net income for 1986 was $83.7 million, or $1.84 a share, and net income for 1985 was $139.6 million, or $2.89 a share.

title: Officer Charged With Stealing 30/
description: An off-duty New York City police officer was charged with larceny yesterday after a homeless man accused him of stealing about 30 cents from him on the steps of a subway station on the Upper East Side Monday night, the police said.

title: Politics of Smoking: Don't Hold Your Breath
description: Legislation designed to curb smoking is more than a health issue in the House and the Senate. It involves economics, the budget, individual rights, the Constitution, social issues and the old-fashioned trading of votes.

title: NEW ENGLAND CRITICAL CARE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $231,000 for the quarter and $1,153,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: Outclassed
description: John Angelus, basketball coach at the academically elite University of Chicago, on the blowouts that can result when the Maroons stray from Division III: ''It's tough playing against kids who don't have science lab twice a week.''

title: UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $58,000 and $269,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and a tax credit of $942,000 and $1,495,000 for the same periods, respectively. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $482,000 and a tax credit of $796,000 for the quarter, and for the year includes net from discontinued operations of $651,000 and a tax crdit of $1,198,000. The company attributed the improved earnings to the improved results of Transworld Systems, part of its financial services unit.

title: RECITAL: LEONA MITCHELL
description: LEONA MITCHELL'S recital Sunday evening at Alice Tully Hall was both tasteful and musical, a convincing display of the soprano's versatility.

title: FOOD LION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
Insider-Case Sentencing
description: Randall D. Cecola, a former junior analyst at a Wall Street investment bank, received a five-year suspended sentence yesterday and was put on probation for six years for his role in an insider-trading ring.

title: FREDA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
How to Be Constructive in Africa
description: Already the next wave of human suffering breaks over Africa, this time the southern third of the continent. Here, in Angola and Mozambique, are the highest infant mortality rates in the world. Here, in the nine black-ruled states near South Africa, war, ethnic rivalry and drought threaten starvation and wrenching migrations.

title: FAIR LANES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ASSEMBLYMAN'S ELECTION PETITIONS ARE EXAMINED IN A FRAUD INQUIRY
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's office is investigating allegations of fraud and forgery last year in the Liberal Party and independent nominating petitions of Assemblyman Roger L. Green, chairman of the Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus.

title: The Patient's Peril on the Sea of Medical Care; New Kinds of Plans
description: To the Editor:

title: GERMAN SHEPERD TAKES 'BEST' AWARD
description: A German shepherd, Ch. Covy Tucker Hill's Manhattan, stood alone in the center of the brown-carpeted ring in Madison Square Garden last night as the supreme winner of the 111th annual Westminster Kennel Club show.

title: INTERNATIONAL AMERICAN HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $110,000.

title: ZYMOS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: NOT long ago, Stella Isaacs, who was born in Russia 84 years ago and now lives on the Upper West Side, received a photocopy of a letter that began: ''Kiss someone when you get this letter and make magic. This paper has been sent to you for good luck. You will receive good luck and a surprise within four days of receiving this letter, providing you send it back out. Do not send money as fate has no price.''

title: XL-DATACOMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a one-time charge of $1,619,000 from the retroactive loss of investment tax credits. c-Net income

title: RAYMOND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. PANEL ASSERTS THE REAGAN POLICY ON PRETORIA FAILED
description: A panel appointed by the Reagan Administration to evaluate American policy toward South Africa said today that the Administration's policy of ''constructive engagement'' had failed.

title: KEY RATES
U.S. PLANS TO PICK SITE FOR ATOM SMASHER IN 1989
description: The Energy Department said today that it would try to select a site by January 1989 for a proposed $4.4 billion atom smasher, the most sought-after Federal scientific installation in decades.

title: Pies and Pork
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: I stopped at Mary Thomas's shop [ ''Pies That Made Mary Thomas Famous,'' Jan. 7 ] on the way to Memphis, and the pies were devoured before we could get to the outskirts of Memphis. My favorite was the apple-fried pie. It was unlike anything I have ever tasted, North or South.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: MY elder boy admits to having a girlfriend. I am sure it is Rebecca. No? What about Alexia? No again. Sonia? Jo-Ann? Sarah? No. No. No.

title: EATON FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in September.

title: SUNVOLD AND BERRY LEAD SPUR REVIVAL
description: After the first two months of the National Basketball Association season, the San Antonio Spurs had an 8-22 record and resembled a team headed for the lottery, rather than one that has suddenly moved into contention for one of the eight Western Conference playoff berths. The Spurs took a seven-game winning streak, their longest since 1981, into the All-Star Game break.

title: SIMON, AMID AN INQUIRY, REVIEWS PENSION RIGHTS
description: Borough President Stanley Simon of the Bronx yesterday began a review of his pension rights, but his lawyer said Mr. Simon had no plans to resign in the face of allegations that he accepted a $50,000 bribe.

title: M'FARLANE INQUIRY CLOSED, POLICE SAY
description: Police officials said today that the drug overdose taken by Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser to President Reagan, was apparently a suicide attempt but that they had ended their investigation because there were no grounds for criminal charges.

title: CHARLES DESMOND, RETIRED CHIEF JUDGE, DIES
description: Charles Stewart Desmond, who was Chief Judge of New York from 1960 through 1966, died Monday at Mercy Hospital in Buffalo. He was 90 years old and lived on a farm in Eden, N.Y., near Buffalo.

title: 4-FOOTED SET'S HEALTH FOOD FAD
description: A GROWING number of ardent pet owners are scrapping traditional pet food, including homestyle potluck, and feeding their dogs and cats so-called natural brands.

title: Cray Develops 4 Computers
description: Cray Research Inc. said yesterday that it had developed four new models of its supercomputers. The Minneapolis-based company said one entry-level model, at $2.5 million, would be the lowest-priced supercomputer ever.

title: Gillette Consolidates Personal Care Agencies
description: The Gillette Company's Personal Care division has consolidated its ad agencies, a move that has been good for N. W. Ayer and bad for Young & Rubicam.

title: JAPANESE HERO DOING THINGS HIS WAY
description: The Japanese have a word for people like Hiromitsu Ochiai. The word is ''goketsu.'' It is not a quality Japanese parents encourage in their sons.

title: Pentagon Security Tightened
description: The Defense Department has reduced the number of people with security clearances by almost 40 percent since June 1985 through a program touched off by the John A. Walker family spy scandal.

title: TII INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $204,000 and $290,000 from equity in the income of an affiliate for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes a charge of $672,000 and $1,284,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. d-Net loss

title: RJR Nabisco Net Falls 6%
description: RJR Nabisco Inc. said today that its fourth-quarter earnings fell 6 percent, but the full year showed a record.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 12, 1987
description: Companies

title: What Next For Pickens?
description: THE Texas oilman T. Boone Pickens, who struck out on his own with $2,500 in 1959, is known around Wall Street as the prototypical deal maker of the 1980's - wily, inventive, persistent and almost always in the money.

title: PENTAGON FIGHTS TO STOP LOSS OF VAST AMOUNT OF ARMS AND SUPPLIES
description: The armed forces are confronting a growing problem over the loss of hundreds of millions of dollars in arms, ammunition and explosives through theft, breakage, mistakes in record-keeping and other abuses, according to investigators for the Defense Department and Congress.

title: Students Removed From Burning School
description: A two-alarm fire at an intermediate school in Harlem yesterday forced the evacuation of about 350 students and 60 staff members, fire officials said.

title: Curran Hospitalized
description: Brian Curran, the Islander defenseman who received minor injuries in the Detroit car accident on Jan. 21 that left Tomas Jonsson with a fractured jaw, was hospitalized Tuesday when it was determined that a cut suffered in that accident had recently become infected. Curran, who had played in all five games since returning to the team Jan. 30, will miss the game Saturday with Buffalo but should return next week.

title: Close the Design Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: OBSCENE CALL LAW IS OVERTURNED
description: The Oregon Supreme Court has again overturned a state law against making obscene telephone calls.

title: NEW AND OLD IDEAS FROM FRANCE
description: IN 1979, the French Government decided to revitalize its furniture design industry and to try to bring it to the forefront of international design. The French Ministry for Industry established the Committee to Promote Innovation in Furniture Design (V.I.A., for Valorisation de l'Innovation dans l'Ameublement) and chose the furniture designer Jean-Claude Maugirard, left, as its director. V.I.A.'s aim was to encourage new designs and to provide the money for re-editions of early-20th-century designs. It will exhibit 75 tables, chairs and lamps through March 13 at Furniture of the Twentieth Century. After that, the furniture will be permanently in stock. In the last few years, over 500 products from 150 manufacturers have been made. The round black and white splatter table, right, has a top of crackled enameled metal, and a steel base and costs $400. The galvanized steel chair, Chaise A, top right, is $150. The walnut captain's chair, above, comes with woven canvas and is $375. The gunmetal gray chair with the concave seat, above left, was designed by Christian Duc, and is $450. Furniture of the Twentieth Century is at 227 West 17th Street; hours are 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.

title: BAXTER TRAVENOL LABORATOIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $2 million for the quarter and the year includes net from discontinued operations of $321 million and an extraordinary loss of $58 million. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $5 million and $19 million for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said in the year-ago fourth quarter, preferred stock dividends exceeded the net from continuing operations and equaled the final net. The company said the latest results reflect the November 1985 acquisition of American Hospital Supply Corp. Results for 1985 have been restated for the sale of the company's Flint and American Critical Care units, which have been accounted for as discontinued operations.

title: GIANTS VIDEO: THRILLS, SPILLS AND A FINALE WITH 101,000 EXTRAS
description: Last Sunday, the prestigious Monterey (Calif.) Film Festival presented a retrospective of the films of Andre de Toth, the French director best known for ''House of Wax.'' It showed the work of the Dutchman Theo Van Gogh. And there was, for the first time ever in this festival, a sports film, ''Giants Among Men.''

title: ADVERTISING
description: People

title: KULICKE & SOFFA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago results were restated.

title: The U.N. Today: Feb. 12, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Special Committee on U.N. Charter - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: HERSHEY FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $8,422,000. Share figures reflect a 3-for-1 stock split effective Sept.15, 1986, and the purchase and retirement of 3,825,000 common stock shares effective Nov.14, 1986.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: MOST people will agree that an open fireplace can be a cheery and warming sight on a cold winter night. But if it is constantly smoking, allowing smoke and soot to drift into the room and letting fires smolder or die, the fireplace is more of a nuisance than an attractive asset.

title: STAGE: SERET SCOTT, A NEW PLAY
description: IN plays such as Ray Aranha's ''My Sister, My Sister,'' Seret Scott has repeatedly demonstrated her sensitivity as an actress. Lately, she has been testing her skills as a playwright and director. Unfortunately, the point of her new play, ''Pardon/Permission'' (at the Family Repertory Company) remains the author's secret. This wispy one-act gives the impression of being an actors' improvisation - one scene after another, without a feeling of dramatic pace. Under Ms. Scott's direction, ''Pardon/Permission'' drifts dangerously close to aimlessness.

title: Too Quiet 'Post-Reagan' Talk
description: LEAD: Like many Americans, you may not have noticed that Congress has quietly begun to explore military strategies for the ''post-Reagan'' era.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: BRIEFING
description: While disputes swirl around the television series ''Amerika,'' in which he stars, the actor Kris Kristofferson will weather the storm in an unlikely place - the Soviet Union.

title: AMERFORD INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Foreign Currency Issues Increase
description: Bond issues denominated in foreign currencies continue to proliferate in the American market, as investors look for higher interest rates and currency diversificiation.

title: SIR JOHN BURGESS
description: Sir John Burgess, chairman of Reuters from 1959 to 1969, died Tuesday after a short illness. He was 74 years old.

title: NMR OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $304,952 from the writeoff of an unamortized loan discount. The latest quarter results reflect a reduction in the provision for bad debts to reflect improvements in the company's collection experience. The year-ago results are restated to conform to 1986 presentation.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $45 million for the quarter and $380 million for the year. The company said the sales increase was recorded despite the disposition during the year of its Technicare and Ultrasound Diagnostic Imaging businesses, which provided about $275 million in sales in 1985. In 1986, these businesses provided no sales after the first quarter.

title: CENTRAL PENNSYLVANIA FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Vermeer Quartet to Play In Place of the Berg
description: The Alban Berg Quartet, because its cellist has developed tendinitis, has canceled a two-month tour of North America. The Berg ensemble was to have appeared at Carnegie Hall Monday evening at 8, with Shlomo Mintz as guest soloist, but instead the Vermeer String Quartet will appear, playing works by Haydn, Janacek and Mendelssohn. Tickets for the Berg Quartet will be honored; remaining seats, at $15, $13.50, $11 and $9, are available at the box office or through Carnegie Charge, 247-7800.

title: SHIITES IN BEIRUT STOP FOOD CONVOY
description: Two people were reported killed and 15 others wounded today in the Burj al Brajneh district of southern Beirut, where a 15-week siege by Shiite militiamen is said to have left some Palestinian residents near starvation.

title: ROBERTSON TESTS THE CANDIDATE VOICE
description: The Rev. Pat Robertson spoke on drugs and sex at a Christian parochial school, but he did not mention his support of voluntary school prayer until a student raised the question. He visited a crisis pregnancy center operated by opponents of abortion but did not berate the Supreme Court for legalizing abortion. Instead, he patted the babies cuddled by volunteers and praised the center's work in promoting ''the dignity of life.''

title: MOUNT SINAI ADMITS FAULT IN TRANSPLANT
description: The Mount Sinai Medical Center has admitted responsibility for an unauthorized heart transplant performed there last August and has been fined $8,000 by New York State.

title: PORTLAND GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax extraordinary charge of $74,937,000 resulting from unrecoverable costs of certain abandoned nuclear projects for the quarter and year. c-Net income d-Includes an extraordinary charge of $6,979,000 for the quarter and year. The company said results for 1985 also included a net gain of $37 million from its unit's sale of an interest in the Boardman Coal Plant and a portion of the Pacific Northwest intertie and an after-tax loss of $7 million from the settlement of litigation surrounding the abandoned nuclear projects.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Burnham Service Corp., Columbus, Ga., an electronics and household mover, named Calvin J. Martin president and chief operating officer, succeeding Raymond E. Crowley, who remains chairman and chief executive. Mr. Martin was also named a director.

title: McFARLANE'S MOOD CALLED GOOD
description: The state of mind of Robert C. McFarlane was said to have improved today as Washington officials, from both the past and the present, closed ranks behind him.

title: POP: CAMPER VAN BEETHOVEN
description: WHILE dozens of other bands are seriously reviving 1960's folk-rock and psychedelia, Camper Van Beethoven serves up folksy material with deadpan, wise-guy wit. At the Cat Club on Tuesday, Camper Van Beethoven reached into a grab-bag of Celtic, country, rock and Middle Eastern music - a mix that recalls the late-1960's California band Kaleidoscope - in songs that teetered between flippant cynicism and sidelong satire.

title: Progress Seen On Baker Deal
description: The Baker International Corporation and the Hughes Tool Company are close to meeting the conditions set for their merger by the Justice Department, Baker's president, James D. Woods, said today.

title: PHYSICIANS DIFFER ON CONFIDENTIALITY IN AIDS
description: The public has no right to know that Liberace had AIDS or that a hospital doctor suffers from the deadly disease, a top executive of the American Medical Association said today.

title: PLIGHT OF POOR PROMPTS GIFTS TO NEEDIEST
description: Concern for homeless people is a theme repeated by contributors to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Night Trading Hours
description: Members of the Chicago Board of Trade voted today to become the first big United States exchange to have evening trading hours. Under the program, the trading floor would be open from 5 P.M. to 9 P.M., central standard time, Monday through Thursday. Board of Trade officials said they hoped to begin the program in April, pending approval from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. Board officials said four contracts would be traded during the evening session: Treasury bond futures, Treasury note futures and options on both instruments.

title: GUARD ARRESTED
description: A uniformed security guard in a dormitory at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center was arrested yesterday and charged with raping a 29-year-old medical student in the basement, the police said.

title: Edna Manley, an Artist And Patron in Jamaica
description: Edna Manley, a Caribbean artist and art patron and the widow of Jamaica's first Prime Minister and the mother of another, died Monday at her home, according to a family spokesman. She was 86 years old.

title: Breland's Trainer Is Back for a 3d Time
description: When Mark Breland won the World Boxing Association welterweight title last week, it was also a big night for Joe Fariello, his trainer.

title: INTRUDER ATTTACKS 2 OFFICERS OUTSIDE LONDON PALACE
description: A man attacked two officers with a knife and hammer in the Kensington Palace garden early today but did not get inside, where the Prince and Princess of Wales and other members of the royal family slept, the police said.

title: INDEPENDENT INSURANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a capital loss of $4,645,000 in the quarter and a capital gain of $2,750,000 in the year. c-Net loss after a capital loss of $14,856,000. d-After a capital loss of $12,586,000.

title: LAMAUR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. ACCUSES CITY CONTRACTOR OF $6 MILLION FRAUD
description: Two brothers who operate an electrical contracting company were charged yesterday with defrauding New York City of $6 million for work on several major projects and buildings, including Police Headquarters and the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: CALIFORNIA IN DEBATE ON PRIVACY AND AIDS
description: California, faced with a forecast of 50,000 cases of AIDS and 34,000 related deaths in the state by 1991, is debating how to halt the disease but still maintain the confidentiality of medical information and do tests only with the patient's informed consent.

title: AMERICAN MAIZE-PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $425,000 from the early retirement of debt. c-Net loss The latest periods' figures reflect a reduction of about $2,500,000 in pension expense as a result of the company's adoption of FASB No. 87.

title: MORLAN INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TOWER PANEL DATA SAID TO LINK N.S.C., PRIVATE REBEL AID
description: A White House commission has uncovered information linking the National Security Council to private efforts to aid the Nicaraguan rebels while such activity by the Federal Government was banned, according to sources familiar with the commission's work.

title: Reagan to Visit Canada
description: President Reagan will make an official visit to Ottawa April 5 and 6, the White House announced today. The trip will be Mr. Reagan's fourth meeting with Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada.

title: EX-F.B.I. AGENT REBUTS TESTIMONY FOR GOTTI
description: A former F.B.I. agent testified yesterday that a man arrested in 1977 told him he had carried out a bank robbery with the authority of John and Peter Gotti and that Peter Gotti later took $10,000 of the $30,000 robbery procceeds as the brothers' share.

title: Testimony Ends On Bumpurs's Death
description: Testimony ended yesterday in the manslaughter trial of the police officer charged with shooting an elderly woman in an eviction dispute two years ago.

title: Airborne-TNT
description: TNT Ltd., an Australia-based freight company, said that the Airborne Freight Corporation had expressed an interest in a possible joint venture. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, TNT, which holds a 17.6 percent stake in Airborne, said that talks on a joint venture began after Airborne rejected a TNT takeover bid of $172 million, or $29 a share. Robert S. Cline, the chairman of Airborne, which is based in Seattle, said the talks about a venture are ''very preliminary and very conceptual.''

title: Topics: Reasonable Doubts; Direct Confusion
description: New York City Comptroller Harrison Goldin acknowledged that he called friends about stock ownership in an investment partnership controlled by Ivan Boesky. But the Comptroller asserted through a spokesman that he had ''no personal money invested'' with the convicted inside trader.

title: MONARCH CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After capital gains of $4,498,000 for the quarter and $31,683,000 for the year. c-After a capital loss of $2,415,000 for the quarter and a capital gain of $9,903,000 for the year. Both year-ago periods' results include a gain of $6.8 million, or 79 cents a share, from the sale of Fidelity Bankers Life Insurance Co.

title: CHRIS-CRAFT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 3-for-1 stock split in November 1986.

title: AIDS Victims Upheld In California Bias Case
description: A state commission has ruled that an employer cannot discriminate against people who have AIDS, saying that the disease is a physical handicap under state law and cannot be transmitted by casual contact.

title: REUTERS HOLDINGS PLC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The figures represent the U.K. sterling results of Reuters converted to U.S. dollars at the rate on Dec. 31, 1986 of US$1.48 to 1 pound (UK). Share earnings represent per American Depository Share (one A.D.S. equals six B ordinary shares).

title: BOEING TO REPLACE CRACKED 747 PARTS
description: The Boeing Company said today that it would offer a major parts replacement program to eliminate hairline cracks in the frames of its 747 jets.

title: LETTERS: ABOUT HUMILIATION
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Troika of Directors To Run Wheeling
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation's board, after days of meetings, announced yesterday that it had named a troika of directors to run the company while the position of chairman remains vacant.

title: FORTUNE SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $471,000 on the sale of a German subsidiary. c-Net loss.

title: TELEFLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
Photo of stage design for ''Missiah''
description: Emboldened by the success of Luciano Pavarotti's concert appearances at Madison Square Garden and other large stadiums around the world, the tenor's manager, Herbert H. Breslin, is planning a series of classical music events that may well rival the presentations of P. T. Barnum, David Belasco and Max Reinhardt for spectacle.

title: TRUSTEE'S REMARK RENEWS CHARGES OF RACIAL INSENSITIVITY AT WELLESLEY
description: A Wellesley College trustee's remark that blacks preferred pushing drugs to working in a factory has precipitated an emotional debate on this bucolic campus already grappling with charges of racial insensitivity.

title: CUMMINS ENGINE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: The Poverty of NASA's Dreams
description: A country with a $4 trillion gross national product can afford a vigorous space program that meets practical needs and stirs people's sense of adventure. NASA's musty plans and cramped vision lack both utility and imagination. The space agency will spend $9.5 billion for next year's space show. Instead of reaching to stretch man's grasp, NASA's engineers plan more plumbing.

title: Truly an Ironman
description: He doesn't expect to win, but Pat Griskus figures to have an easier time of it in today's 86-floor, 1,575-step Empire State Run Up than he does at the Ironman Triathlon in Hawaii. That's because he won't have to change legs on the way up.

title: British Air Stock Opens
description: British Airways stock rose sharply in heavy volume today as shares of the formerly state-owned company began trading publicly. The shares rose to $:1.20, about $1.80, on the London Stock Exchange before falling back to close at $:1.07.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart yesterday listing the hostages in Lebanon and their captors included one name erroneously. Aurel Cornea, a French television soundman, was freed on Dec. 24. In addition, the chart misstated the date on which Do Chae Sung, a South Korean Embassy official, was kidnapped. It was Jan. 31, 1986.

title: Johnson & Johnson Has New Sweetener
