description: Johnson & Johnson sought approval yesterday to sell a new sweetener that could compete with aspartame, the sugar substitute marketed by the Monsanto Company under the Nutrasweet brand name.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: TUESDAY BASEBALL CINCINNATI (NL) - Invited Terry Francona, first baseman-outfielder, to spring training. CLEVELAND (AL) - Invited Turner Gill, infielder; Don Schulze, Reggie Ritter, Kurt Kepshire, Kent Murphy, Gibson Alba and Bryan Oelkers, pitchers; Dain Syverson, Kevin Buckley and Ron Tingley, catchers, and Rod Allen, outfielder, to spring training. MONTREAL (NL) - Signed Herm Winningham, outfielder, and Rodger Cole, pitcher, to one-year contracts. TEXAS (AL) - Announced Larry Parrish, designated hitter-third baseman, had agreed to a contract extension through 1988. TORONTO (AL) - Signed Jose Mesa and Jeff Musselman, pitchers; Santiago Garcia, Nelson Liriano and Mike Sharperson, infielders, and Silvestre Campusano and Glenallen Hill, outfielders, to contracts for the 1987 season. BASKETBALL

title: Hoyt Leaves Prison
description: LaMarr Hoyt was released yesterday from a Federal prison camp at Eglin Air Force Base in Florida where he served 38 days of a 45-day sentence on a misdemeanor drug conviction. While Hoyt was serving his sentence, the San Diego Padres waived the 32-year-old right-hander, contending that he voided his contract by violating a good citizenship clause in his pact. A former Cy Young Award winner, Hoyt had three years left on a contract paying him approximately $1 million a year. The Major League Players Association has filed a grievance on behalf of Hoyt against the Padres.

title: FIRST CONNECTICUT SMALL BUSINESS INVESTMENT CO reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Net income represents represents net investment income.

title: FROM BRITAIN, THE BITTER 'YOSSER'S STORY' ON 13
description: FOR a couple of years, British acquaintances have been singling out something called ''The Black Stuff'' and its five-part sequel ''Boys From the Black Stuff'' as examples of television in their country at its biting best. Written by Alan Bleasdale, the plays follow the lives and sagging fortunes of a group of Tarmac layers in Liverpool. Tragedy is deftly spiked with black humor. Unfortunately, the entire BBC series is yet to be broadcast in this country. But one episode of ''Boys From the Black Stuff'' has been acquired by WNET's adventurous ''Channel Crossings'' series and can be seen at 11 this evening.

title: STEWART INFORMATION SERVCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes provisions for unusually large claims of $1.8 million and $2.6 million for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Q & A
description: Q. We recently moved into a brownstone and in one room there appears to be a lot of the original wainscoting on the walls. Unfortunately, there are many layers of paint over this and they have almost completely hidden the surface texture. Is there any way I can remove this paint without damaging the wainscoting, and preserving its orginal texture? A. Many owners of older houses have done this by using a chemical paint and varnish remover. The work is tedious, and you will need a lot of the remover. Buy one of the semipaste brands that is nonflammable and can be washed off with water.

title: EASTERN AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Net income The company said results include capital gains of $1.9 millin in the latest quarter and $28.4 million in the latest year. The company is a unit of Texas Air Corp.

title: Proving a Point
description: So who needs to rest during an All-Star break? Of the 24 players who took part in the National Basketball Association's showcase game Sunday, 20 returned to regular action Tuesday night, and eight of them scored 30 or more points each. The average for these eight (led by Dominique Wilkins, with 46 points) was 35.3, and for the 20 as a whole 25.5.

title: DOLLAR MOVES HIGHER AMID SHORT COVERING
description: The dollar moved higher yesterday, largely because traders who had sold the currency short earlier began buying out of their positions late in the day. Dealers said the late demand came after a day of lackluster trading in which prices overseas and in New York had moved in extremely narrow ranges.

title: Hoyas Destroy 1,000th
description: Reggie Williams scored 34 points tonight as Georgetown rolled to its 1,000th basketball victory, a 78-50 Big East decision over Connecticut.

title: FLOW GENERAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $40,000 for the quarter and year. c-Net loss.

title: KNICKS COLLAPSE IN THIRD QUARTER
description: The feeling of helplessness did not escape Bob Hill. He stood on the sideline last night, watching the Milwaukee Bucks put together a staggering run of 17 straight points. Patrick Ewing sat on the bench with four fouls, and the Knicks were almost continually being slowed by a vigorous press.

title: Chiat/Day, New York, Resigning Beer Account
description: Chiat/Day, New York, announced yesterday that it was resigning from its two-year-old Miller Brewing Company assignment for Plank Road Original Draught Beer, which is still in test market.

title: MDC HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Tar Heels Register No. 600 for Smith
description: Jeff Lebo scored 22 points as North Carolina defeated Wake Forest, 94-85, in an Atlantic Coast game tonight to give Dean Smith his 600th career coaching victory.

title: A Fairchild Magazine Seeks Dual Audience
description: Fairchild Publications, which in recent years has added a number of successful consumer titles to its roster of trade publications, will make a bold attempt at combining the two.

title: EVOCATIVE GOTHIC: REVIVAL AMID THE GLOOM
description: GOOD evening. This is a tale of obsession, of sublime passion, deep and everlasting.

title: HOWARD BEACH: A MOOD OF AMBIVALENT DISMAY
description: when it is all going to end.

title: AMERICAN CRUISE/LINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said it restated the losses for both 1986 and 1985 periods but said that the revenue for both periods remained the same.

title: HANNAFORD BROTHERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: Latest quarter and year earnings were reduced by 12 cents a share by the repeal of the investment tax credit. The latest year included 53 weeks, compared to 52 weeks for the year ended Dec.28, 1985. The latest quarter included 14 weeks, compared to 13 weeks for year-ago period.

title: CUOMO PLANS TAX SHIFT TO RAISE TRANSIT FUNDS
description: Governor Cuomo today announced a new plan for financing mass-transit and highway improvements by restructuring state automobile and mortgage-recording taxes.

title: ENHANCING THE LOOK OF SPOOL FURNITURE
description: LEAD: End grain, the wood exposed by a cut at right angles to the direction of growth, is not easy to cope with, particularly with finishes. Depending upon the hardness or density of the wood, stain applied to end grain is soaked up so rapidly that those areas tend to become darker than the rest of the work.

title: U.S. AIDE ASSESSES CHANGES IN SOVIET
description: A State Department official said today that the Soviet Union was exhibiting a trend toward artistic and literary liberalism and that American officials had a ''basically positive'' view of Soviet human rights moves.

title: 10 POSSIBLE SITES SELECTED FOR MX
description: The Air Force has selected 10 bases in eight states, stretching from Louisiana to Washington, for consideration as sites for 50 additional MX intercontinental missiles, the Defense Department said today.

title: Transit Worker, 43, Is Slain On a Street Near City Hall
description: A 43-year-old track worker for the Transit Authority was stabbed to death in an argument with an 18-year-old messsenger on a busy street one block west of City Hall yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Macmillan Offer
description: Macmillan Inc., the publishing company, is offering $125 million of 5 1/2 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2012 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The issue is rated Ba-1 by Moody's and BBB+ by Standard & Poor's. Noncallable for two years, the debentures are convertible into Macmillan's common stock at a price of $69 a share. In addition, a sinking fund beginning in 1998 will retire 70 percent of the issue by maturity. The company's stock closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at 53 5/8, down 1/2.

title: Shepherd Is a Winner in Crowd or Ring
description: A German shepherd, Ch. Covy Tucker Hill's Manhattan, reigns supreme in the dog-show world.

title: NATIONAL EDUCATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $972,000 from the sale of property and the company's home health-care operations.

title: 2 Charged in Mugging A Philadelphia Judge
description: Two men have been charged in the mugging of a prominent judge and snatching of her purse while 100 bystanders looked on, the police said today.

title: Mortgage Bonds
description: The Home Owners Federal Savings and Loan Association is offering $75 million of 7 1/2 percent mortgage-backed bonds due in 1992 at a price of 99.84, to yield 7.54 percent, through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company. The bonds, rated Aaa by Moody's Investors Service, are backed by Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation mortgage participation certificates worth 130 percent to 140 percent of the bonds. The issue is not callable and yields about 7/10 percentage point more than Treasury notes of similar maturity.

title: NORTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $125,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary loss of $8 million on the redemption and purchase of debentures for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $12,800,000 for the quarter and $15,500,000 for the year. The quarter net also includes a $6.1 million after-tax gain on the sale of the company's investment in Transway International Corp. The share earnings reflect a 1-for-3 stock dividend paid in December.

title: C3 INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the latest 9-month results reflect a $7.6 million settlement of a contract dispute with the Army that was partially offset by a $3.7 million gain on the sale of a parcel of land.

title: MORGAN LIBRARY TROVE SHEDS LIGHT ON LINCOLN
description: Between now and the next Inauguration, most of the 1988 Presidential candidates will invoke the name of the 16th President and, accurately or inaccurately, quote his words. All political candidates - Democratic or Republican - can find passages in the Lincoln record to match their own ideas.

title: GORBACHEV DRAWS A MIXED REACTION
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's espousal of greater openness in Soviet society has met a mixed response from his Eastern European allies, from applause in Poland to apparent unease in Czechoslovakia.

title: Goldman Stake
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company has purchased a 5.5 percent stake in the First Pennsylvania Corporation, the parent of the third-largest bank in Philadelphia. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the New York investment firm said that it had bought the 1.3 million shares ''in connection with arbitrage and other activities.'' First Pennsylvania has agreed to be acquired by Marine Midland Banks Inc., but banking laws will prevent the merger from being completed until 1990.

title: TITAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $4,420,000, a loss of $1,604,000 from redemption of senior notes at face value and a charge of $485,000 from reversal of tax credit for the quarter; and for the year includes a loss from discontinued operations of $4,888,000, a loss of $1,604,000 from redemption of senior notes at face value and a tax credit of $1,004,000. c-Net income and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $298,000. d-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $9,427,000. Results for 1985 have been restated to include the results of operations of Spectron Development Laboratories Inc. and California Research & Technology Inc., which were merged with Titan during the second quarter of 1986 and are accounted for as poolings of interests; the 1985 results are also restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: CONCERT: GARY BURTON QUINTET
description: THE core of Gary Burton's current quintet, which is playing at Fat Tuesday's, Third Avenue near 17th Street through Sunday, is the combination of Mr. Burton's vibraharp and the piano of Makoto Ozone, who has been with Mr. Burton for four years.

title: THE DANCE: CITY BALLET IN 2 BALANCHINE WORKS
description: GEORGE BALANCHINE'S ''Prodigal Son'' and ''Stravinsky Violin Concerto,'' danced Tuesday night by the New York City Ballet at the State Theater, would seem to have little in common.

title: Lonrho Mining
description: The British holding company Lonrho P.L.C. said it had increased its stake in Western Platinum, a South African mining company, to more than 99 percent, at a cost of $75 million. Lonrho, which already had 50.4 percent of the company's shares, said it had bought another 49 percent from Falconbridge Ltd., one of Canada's largest mining companies, under an agreement signed 17 years ago. Lonrho said it had acted to prevent the stake's being sold to what it called an unsatisfactory partner in South Africa.

title: OFFICIAL FAULTS ELECTION INQUIRY BE MORGENTHAU
description: State Assemblyman Roger L. Green of Brooklyn yesterday charged that the Manhattan District Attorney's office was trying to intimidate him and his supporters by investigating allegations of fraud and forgery in petitions he submitted last year for the Liberal Party and independent nominations.

title: Note and Bond Prices Mixed
description: The Treasury sector followed the lead of the currency and overnight loan markets yesterday, with prices falling early in the day as the dollar weakened and overnight rates rose. But as the dollar strengthened and overnight loan rates fell, prices rebounded for Treasury issues.

title: INTELLIGENT BUSINESS COMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: The company said it has completed the transition from a development stage enterprise to an operating company, and anticipates that for the first quarter ending Jan.31, it will report the first operating profit in its five years on revenues of approximately $1.4 million. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: DEFIANCE PRECISION PRODCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Includes $959,645 from plant start- up and certification for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income

title: ZAIRE, HOSTAGE TO A RAILROAD, SEEKS TO CUT SOUTH AFRICA TIE
description: At the Dallas food store here, cans of peaches, boxes of breakfast cereal and bottles of red wine all bear the same label of origin: ''Product of South Africa.''

title: Cry for Help
description: My frequently expressed view of Robert C. (Bud) McFarlane has been that of a man out of his depth as national security adviser, bitterly disappointed at never receiving the respect and acclaim accorded to a Kissinger or Brzezinski, who was straining to match the strategic achievement of a China opening or a Camp David agreement with his own reaching out to ''moderates'' in Iran.

title: BROWN, ROBERT C & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bridge: Bidder Makes Unusual Leap From One No-Trump to Six
description: A player who makes any natural no-trump bid is in principle barred from taking strong action subsequently. That makes South's action on the diagramed deal - one no-trump followed by six no-trump -quite extraordinary.

title: VICTORIAN CURTAINS IN LACE DESIGNS
description: IN the renovation of Victorian houses, lace curtains are often an important grace note - not just any lace curtains, but period designs that add credence to the overall look.

title: AMERICAN LEARNING reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Taylor-Gordon Getting Coca-Cola Watch Task
description: Coca-Cola Watch, a division of Swatch Watch USA, at 608 Fifth Avenue, which did its own advertising, has decided to move its nearly $1 million budget next door to Taylor-Gordon, Aarons & Company, at 604.

title: Retired Firefighter Is Indicted in Slaying
description: A 49-year-old retired firefighter was indicted by a grand jury yesterday on second-degree murder and weapons possession charges for the shooting death last week of a Fire Department doctor.

title: Clabir to Pursue Bid for Atlantic
description: The Clabir Corporation, a military contractor, said that it intended to pursue its efforts to acquire the Atlantic Research Corporation. Atlantic Research, which is based in Alexandria, Va., makes rocket motors and high-technology products. It has rejected Clabir's acquisition proposal.

title: MALE PROSTITUTE IN MISSISSIPPI PUT UNDER QUARRANTINE ORDER
description: State officials today issued a quarantine order against a male prostitute who tested positive for exposure to the AIDS virus.

title: Ohio Bus Service Resumes
description: Bus service for 90,000 daily riders resumed Tuesday after a court order provided at least a three-day break from the two-month-old strike by drivers and mechanics over wages and the use of part-time workers. But both sides in the dispute said resumption of service did not mean a resolution of differences. The strikers returned to work under an order issued Sunday by Judge Frederick T. Williams of Franklin County Common Pleas Court, who ruled that the strike might be a threat to public health and safety. The order expires at 12:01 A.M. Friday.

title: WELFARE SPENDING UP SLIGHTLY IN '84, U.S. SAYS
description: Federal, state and local governments spent $672 billion on social welfare programs in the fiscal year 1984, a Federal researcher says.

title: ORBIT INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MILLIPORE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BARYSHNIKOV BARS MOSCOW VISIT NOW
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov said yesterday that he will not take part in a three-day conference on science and the arts that begins Saturday in Moscow.

title: Shirley Prefers to Be Floyd, by 2-to-1 Vote
description: Shirley should be Shirley no longer, say its residents, who in a nonbinding referendum have voted about 2 to 1 to change the community's name to Floyd Harbor.

title: 'ROOM WITH A VIEW' AND 'PLATOON' LEAD OSCAR LIST
description: ''A Room With a View,'' a comedy of manners set in Edwardian England, and ''Platoon,'' an infantryman's view of the agony of the Vietnam War, led the list of films nominated today for the 59th annual Academy Awards.

title: Anti-Frost Bacteria Test
description: Advanced Genetic Sciences Inc., a biotechnology company in Oakland, Calif., has received final approval from the Environmental Protection Agency to conduct a field test on its genetically altered bacteria that is intended to protect plants from frost damage. The bacteria, called Ice-

title: Payout Outlook At Bell Spinoffs
description: THE stock market does not offer many safe bets, but it seems a virtual certainty that all seven regional Bell telephone companies are going to raise their cash dividends again this year.

title: Refco May Change Name
description: Refco Partners, one of 40 primary dealers in Treasury securities recognized by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, may soon change its name, a source at the company said yesterday. The name change could come within a month and would follow a move by Refco Inc., a separate company, to pull $22 million of capital from the New York firm.

title: IN THE LAND OF THE MOORS, NEW TROUBLE FOR SPAIN
description: Just who provoked the scuffle remains unclear. Armed with a sawed-off rifle and a pistol, a Christian man and his son took on a group of Moslems last week. The son was stabbed and four Moslems were shot, one fatally.

title: EASTERN CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said in 1986 it adopted FASB 87, regarding accounting methods for pension costs, which resulted in a slight change in the year's results.

title: KEAN PROPOSES NEW INITIATIVES FOR THE G.O.P.
description: Governor Kean told 1,500 New York Republicans last night that the Republican Party must aggressively seek the support of blue-collar workers and minority groups and also lead in the environmental movement if it hopes to lead the country through the end of the century.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: BRIEFING
description: For a very long time, a photograph of James V. Forrestal, the nation's first Secretary of Defense, has hung in the Secretary's office. The other day a longtime Washington hand who had not visited the office in some time noticed that the rather stern-visaged countenance was missing from its place on the wall. It turned out that Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger had had the portrait removed and stored in a vault. ''I just didn't want to look a that tight-lipped expression every morning,'' Mr. Weinberger explained.

title: STATES' STATUTES VARY ON ASBESTOS HAZARDS
description: Thirty-two states have passed legislation dealing with asbestos hazards, three-fourths of them in the past two years, a survey has reported.

title: Red Sox Beat Hurst
description: Bruce Hurst beat the Mets twice for the Boston Red Sox in last season's World Series, but he couldn't beat the Red Sox this week. Bernard Meltzer, an arbitrator, yesterday selected the Red Sox figure of $700,000 as Hurst's 1987 salary. The pitcher, who last season earned $495,000, had sought $845,000 in the salary arbitration hearing that was held Monday. Eight cases have been heard, and clubs have won five. Thirty-three players still have to settle their cases or have them heard by an arbitrator. One of those is Jack Morris of Detroit, who will try to win an arbitration-record $1.85 million salary today.

title: TEXAS AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $11,966,000 and $30,466,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; and for the year includes Continental Airlines' 1986 net income of $17.9 million, a gain in excess of $50 million realized by New York Air on the sale of certain assets to Pan Am Corp., and a portion of the losses incurred by Eastern and People Express during 1986. c-Net loss and includes a tax credit of $13,918,000. d-Includes a tax credit of $42,366,000. Latest-year per-share figures reflect the accrual of dividends on certain Eastern Airlines preferred shares acquired by Texas Air. Texas Air Corp. said its acquisitions of Eastern Airlines and People Express were finalized during the fourth quarter of 1986 and as a result, its net income for the nine months ended Sept. 30 has been restated to reflect a loss of $22.7 million related to its ownership of Eastern and People Express. Texas Air said that as restated, net income for the nine months is $51 million. For the nine months ended Sept. 30, Texas Air had previously reported net from operations of $55,152,000, or $1.93 a share. After a tax credit of $18,500,000, the company reported final net of $73,652,000, or $2.65.

title: Teleglobe Canada
description: The Canadian Government, in its latest move to reduce its holdings of state-run enterprises, said that it would sell Teleglobe Canada Inc., which handles the country's overseas telecommunications. Memotec Data Inc., a small Montreal-based company, is making the purchase for $608.3 million, or $456 million (United States). Memotec, which specializes in data communications and data processing, has assets of $83 million, which is equal to $62.3 million.

title: Apartheid's Foes Look to Their Plowshares
description: Life hums a gentle rhythm in a lush pastoral setting north of this southern African capital city.

title: Energy Chief Yields to Congress on Waste Storage
description: The Secretary of Energy has told Congress he will drop proposed changes in the Department of Energy's long-term plans for storage of nuclear waste if it tells him to do so.

title: NFS FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The year-ago net includes the recovery of $3,390,000 on a loan previously written down and on planned losses of $2,624,000 on sales of mortgage loans and mortgage-backed securities, which were taken as part of a restructuring of the association's loan portfolio prior to going public. The prior year's share earnings not available because the company went public August 1986.

title: CONSOLIDATED-TOMOKA LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A VARIETY OF BELLS
description: IF the children are out skating and it's time to warm up with hot chocolate, what better way to call them indoors than with a dinner bell? From the traditional farm variety to a decorative one in the shape of a house, these bells come in many sizes and designs.

title: KNIGHT, AN ORIOLE, TAKES A CUT
description: Ray Knight, the World Series hero who spurned an offer of $800,000 to return to the Mets, finally found a home yesterday - with the Baltimore Orioles for $300,000 less.

title: Yields Are Mixed
description: Falling interest rates paid at banks and thrift institutions appear to have stalled for the moment, as the overnight rate for banks loans in the Federal funds market, a closely watched benchmark for other short-term interest rates, continues to hover above 6 percent.

title: China Borrows Abroad
description: China made a rare appearance in the international loan market today, obtaining a credit of 200 million marks, or $110 million, from three West German banks.

title: COSTAR CORP reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $139,000 and $1,792,000 for the latest year and year-earlier periods, respectively, and the latest year also includes a loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $776,000. The company said the prior year results are restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: CONSUMERS WATER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net gains on property sales of $640,000 for the quarter and $882,000 for the year. c-Includes net gains of $1,000 and $1,925,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, on property sales. The company said results reflect a merger with Interstate Water Co. that was accounted for as a pooling of interests. Shares earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in September 1986.

title: NASHUA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of 7 cents a share from the sale of a plant in Australia. The latest quarter and year nets were reduced by $1.5 million, or 15 cents a share, by retroactive elimination of investment tax credits.

title: AIFS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MEDICARE EXPANSION UNDER FIRE
description: Private insurers object to the proposed expansion of Medicare that would offer protection to the elderly against catastrophic illness.

title: Lincoln's Birthday
description: Parking - Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation - No collections; no street cleaning. Governmental offices - Open. Post offices - Regular schedules. Banks - In New York City, open; In New Jersey and Connecticut, optional closing. Financial markets - Open. Transportation - Subways, buses, Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North on regular schedules and N.J. Transit on regular schedules; N.J. Transit buses are on adjusted weekday schedules. Schools - In New York City, closed; in New York State, New Jersey and Connecticut, optional closing. Libraries - Closed.

title: CUOMO IS SEEKING SHIFT IN FUNDS TO REFLECT STATE FISCAL SITUATION
description: The state's equine drug testing program would receive $400,000 more and the new Challenger Scholarship program $1 million if the Legislature approves the extra appropriations requested today by Governor Cuomo.

title: ACQUINO ORDERS ARMY INTO ACTION
description: President Corazon C. Aquino said today that the new Constitution was in ''full force'' and that the army would resume operations against Communist rebels, but she did not order a full offensive.

title: INSIDE
description: Portraits of 12 Suspects

title: CAPITAL CITIES' NET UP SHARPLY
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. said yesterday that it earned $80.3 million, or $4.90 a share, in the fourth quarter despite a significant operating loss at its ABC television network.

title: C.B.O.E. HELPS DEFUSE 'TRIPLE' DAYS
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange said yesterday that it would move the expiration of its Standard & Poor's 500-stock index option contract to the opening of trading on ''triple witching hour'' Fridays.

title: Ovett Out of Mile
description: Steve Ovett, the English miler, said he had not recovered fully from bronchitis and withdrew from the Vitalis/ Olympic Invitational indoor track meet Saturday night in East Rutherford, N.J. Still, the mile field is strong with Eamonn Coghlan, Marcus O'Sullivan, Ray Flynn and Frank O'Mara, all from Ireland; Steve Scott and Jim Spivey of the United States and Jose Abascal of Spain.

title: MUSIC: CLEVELAND ORCHESTRA AT CARNEGIE
description: MATCHING symphony orchestras to music directors is more art than science. Sheer luck also may have something to do with it. Certain highly gifted conductors never seem quite at home in front of their orchestras, no matter how long their acquaintance. Lorin Maazel and the Cleveland Orchestra, for instance, always struck one as a classic mismatch, despite his long and generally successful tenure as music director of the ensemble he inherited from the late George Szell.

title: HOW MANY HELD IN SOVIET? FIGURES VARY
description: The pardons being extended to prisoners convicted of subversive activities have revived a debate about just how many such prisoners there are in the Soviet Union.

title: Cox & Greenwald
description: Cox & Greenwald has become agency for United States Lines, the largest American-flag carrier and a company that has filed under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code. The whole point of the assignment, according to Michael Cox, chairman of the agency, is to convince the carrier's customers to remain loyal while it is reorganizing. The former agency, Poppe Tyson, came aboard in the summer of 1985.

title: LODGISTIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: TGI FRIDAY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Rubik (of the Cube) Robbed
description: Burglars have broken into the villa of Erno Rubik, inventor of the Rubik cube, the Government daily Magyar Hirlap said today. The police believe the intruders were seeking designs for new puzzles as all Rubik's papers were disturbed. Despite the presence of valuable equipment in the home, only a video recorder was stolen.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE NEXT LEFT: The History of a Future. By Michael Harrington. 197 pages. Henry Holt. $17.95.

title: Cooper Technicon
description: The Cooper Development Company said that its affiliate, Cooper Technicon Inc., would sell its worldwide industrial systems business, which produces spectroscopy equipment, to Alfa-Laval A.B. of Sweden for about $51 million. The industrial unit, based in Tarrytown, N.Y., has annual sales of about $50 million and employs about 200 people.

title: SOO LINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax charge of $73 million for restructuring, which includes $19 million related to surplus freight charges and $54 million in costs related to workforce reductions.

title: FREE APPRAISALS OF COLLECTIBLES
description: Appraisals and Auction, Phillips Auc tioneers and Appraisers, 406 East 79th Street, 212-570-4830.

title: ENERGAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a one-time charge of $585,000 related to the loss of investment tax credits.

title: U.S. Competitiveness and World Unemployment
description: To the Editor:

title: 25 Are Subpoenaed In Inquiry on Simon
description: A Federal grand jury has subpoenaed 25 current or former employees of Bronx Borough President Stanley Simon in an investigation into accusations of corruption, according to officials familiar with the investigation.

title: G.M. CHIEF SEES PROFIT GAIN SOON
description: Roger B. Smith, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, predicted today that his company's cost-cutting efforts would start to improve earnings this year, but many analysts doubt that big short-term gains are likely.

title: Whither the Budget And Deficit? 'It's a Mess'
description: There is a deepening cynicism on Capitol Hill about the Federal budget and the odds on reducing the deficit.

title: KEY RATES
MANY BARGAIN AIR FARES TO PRIME SPOTS SELL OUT
description: Two weeks after the latest air-fare wars erupted, many of the cheapest tickets from New York to the most popular vacation destinations are sold out through early April, according to travel agents and airline executives.

title: 'PIZZA CONNECTION' FIGURE SHOT IN GREENWICH VILLAGE
description: A defendant in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial was shot several times in the back yesterday while walking with his wife on a busy avenue in Greenwich Village, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: A report last Sunday on the wedding of Dr. Michelle E. Ehrlich to Dr. Samuel Evans Gandy 3d misstated the location of the ceremony. It took place at the Craig Park Community Center in Chesterfield, S.C., not at a church.

title: Gains for Public Workers Top Private Sector's
description: Employees of state and local governments who were covered by union contracts negotiated last year received nearly double the rate of pay increase won by union and nonunion workers in private industry, Government figures indicate.

title: HOLIDAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: b-Includes pre-tax property gains of $33 million, including reserves established for properties identified for future disposition. The company said it incurred expenses associated with a proposed recapitalization plan of $12.9 million, and the latest quarter also includes one-time charges in connection with a restructuring of its hotel division's staff activities. c-Includes pre-tax property gains of $95.7 million, including gains from the sale of 35 hotels. d-Includes an extraordinary credit of $8,738,000 for the quarter and year. e-Includes pre-tax property gains of $46.1 million from transactions which included the sale of 25 hotels. f-Includes property gains of $86.5 million, including gains from the sale of 35 hotels.

title: At 40, 'Albert Herring' To Be Staged at Juilliard
description: The American Opera Center of the Julliard School is to observe the 40th anniversary of the premiere of Benjamin Britten's opera ''Albert Herring'' by giving two performances of the work at the Juilliard Theater, 155 West 65th Street, next Wednesday at 8 P.M. and Sunday, Feb. 22, at 3. There will be a different cast for each performance; Andreas Delfs is to conduct from the piano, as did the composer at the first performance.

title: ARVIN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PLEAS OF NOT GUILTY MADE FOR MEN SEIZED ON CHILD NEGLECT CHARGES
description: Pleas of not guilty were entered today for two men associated with a commune in rural Virginia who were charged with child neglect after they were found with six unkempt children in a city playground.

title: VM SOFTWARE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 50-percent stock dividend paid Dec. 19.

title: THE REVOLUTION WROUGHT BY TOLL-FREE CALLS
description: IT seemed like a gimmick when it was introduced 20 years ago, but that first toll-free, long-distance telephone call unleashed a revolution in telecommunications, marketing, information services and personal dialing habits beyond even the wildest dreams of most telephone-industry executives. The 800 number - that 10-digit tie line to a mind-boggling array of products and information - has mushroomed into a multibillion-dollar business and is entrenched in American popular culture.

title: CONTRA AID APPEAL WILL BE POSTPONED
description: Prospects for a renewal of Congressional aid to Nicaraguan rebels are so bleak that the Reagan Administration has decided to postpone its formal request for several months, Administration officials said today.

title: IN IRISH CAMPAIGN, THE MOOD MATCHES THE WEATHER
description: This is a Fianna Fail town, so the Fine Gael campaign staff was heartened by the lively crowd that turned out for Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald's ''walkabout.''

title: The Place of Violence in South Africa, as Once in the 13 Colonies
description: To the Editor:

title: SCIENTIFIC MICRO SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Suzanne Farrell Undergoes Hip Surgery
description: The New York City Ballet said yesterday that Suzanne Farrell, a principal dancer with the company, underwent hip replacement surgery yesterday.

title: WALSH IS WIDENING INQUIRY OF CONTRAS
description: The special prosecutor in the Iran arms case, Lawrence E. Walsh, has widened his investigation by assuming control of at least three Justice Department inquiries into the private American supply network for Nicaraguan rebel groups, according to Federal law-enforcement officials.

title: Trial Set in San Juan For Three in Hotel Fire
description: The trial of three men on Federal charges arising out of the New Year's Eve fire that killed 96 people at the Dupont Plaza Hotel here will begin April 27, a United States Attorney said today.

title: The 39th Witness
description: In the early morning of March 13, 1964, a woman named Catherine Genovese walked to her home on Austin Street in the borough of Queens and was stabbed to death. Her killer attacked her once, ran when she screamed, returned again, attacked again and then once more. And while she screamed her young life out on Austin Street, 38 people, by police count, heard her. Some raised their windows. Not one did anything to come to her help or even called the police.

title: A WEEK OF 'DONAHUE' TAPED IN SOVIET UNION
description: HOW do the United States and Soviet Union lessen world tension and avert a terrible war? By allowing people of both countries to meet one another, a school of thought holds; everyone will find they have lots in common. Phil Donahue, who may be television's most prominent advocate of that school, taped five episodes of ''Donahue,'' his syndicated talk show, in the Soviet Union last month. They are being shown on Channel 4 at 4 P.M. each day this week.

title: WARD DEFENDS POLICE ON RACIAL CASE
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward, in his first lengthy interview in eight months, yesterday defended the New York Police Department's handling of the Howard Beach case, criticized some black leaders for attacking the department and said it was committed to improving race relations in the city.

title: CONDOMS, AIDS AND MORALS: NEW CONCERN ALTERS DEBATE
description: The increasing public discussion of the condom, a birth-control device that was once an unmentionable in many homes, has stirred debate among educators, religious leaders and parents.

title: Vangelis Plays 2 Works In London High Court
description: Vangelis, the Greek composer who has given only five public recitals of his electronic music in the last 12 years, performed today in London's High Court in a copyright case.

title: Juror's Trial
description: Jury service, an important civic duty, can also be onerous, but in the Federal courtroom of Judge John Bartels recently it became an outrage. After a mistrial caused by one juror's holdout vote for acquittal, the judge denounced the lone juror as ''more guilty'' than the defendants.

title: F.D.R. for the Aeons
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN FRUCTOSE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the 1985 year.

title: MICRO DISPLAY SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: GAF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $30.5 million from the sale of 5 million common shares of Union Carbide Corp. c-Includes extraordinary credits totaling $212,475,000. These include a gain of $201.4 million from the exchange of 3.5 million common shares of Union Carbide under Carbide's January 1986 exchange offer, and gains from Union Carbide's third quarter special dividend and from the sale of 5 million common shares of Carbide in the fourth quarter. The credits also include a tax credit of $11.1 million. d-Includes an extraordinary credit of $1,188,000. e-Includes a tax credit of $23,285,000.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Louisiana, hit with declining tax revenues and lower bond ratings, is taking advantage of lower interest rates on tax-exempt bonds to sell $1.13 billion of new bonds and refinance outstanding issues sold when rates were higher.

title: SCREEN: 'OVER THE TOP'
description: IT took colossal crust - more specifically, it took Sylvester Stallone - to make a film that is largely about arm-wrestling. It isn't that exciting to watch, and it's not the sport of kings, either. But Mr. Stallone saw the potential for something Rockylike in this subject, as indeed he sees it everywhere. So ''Over the Top,'' which opens today at the Criterion and other theaters, tells of a modest, bashful trucker named Lincoln Hawk - Mr. Stallone sure can write names for himself - whose gift for arm-wrestling may just take him to the top.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: NAVY CURBING USE OF RADAR AIRCRAFT TO BOLSTER WINGS
description: The Navy said today that it had started to ground or restrict operations of its E2-C Hawkeye radar planes because of concerns about fatigue cracks in the wings.

title: LEMIEUX PROVES HIS POINT AS N.H.L. ALL-STARS WIN
description: For a long time, he wondered if he would be here. But after a debate of the importance of a sprained right knee against Canada's role as a world hockey power, Mario Lemieux rescued a country's pride tonight.

title: BRITON FORMS COMPANY FOR COMMERCIAL PLAYS
description: Sir Peter Hall, who said last month that he would leave his post as artistic director of Britain's National Theater when his contract expired at the end of 1988, yesterday announced the formation of a partnership to produce plays for the commercial theater in London and New York and for international touring.

title: RECITAL: STEPNER AND CARLIN
description: THE violinist Daniel Stepner and the fortepianist Seth Carlin played an admirable joint recital at Merkin Concert Hall Monday night on modern replicas of antique instruments. Mr. Stepner's violin was a copy of a Stradivarius, and Mr. Carlin played a 1984 instrument copied from a Graf piano, circa 1827, the year Beethoven died.

title: ROBERTSON, H H CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes charges of $18,537,000 for plant shutdown expenses, start-up costs of new plants and facilities, settlement of a patent infringement suit, cost-related to strikes at two plants, and the writedown of inventories and equipment at closed plants. c-Includes charges of $9,034,000 from the realignment, restructuring and termination of certain operations.

title: Use of Condoms As an AIDS Bar
description: The AIDS virus has been documented to spread only through direct exchanges of blood and through anal and vaginal intercourse with those who carry the virus, according to many research studies. Some scientists suspect that the AIDS virus can spread in oral sex.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Today's meeting discussed the National Security Council process and the development and execution of the Iran policy and the President's role. The President answered all of the board's questions.'' Marlin Fitzwater. [ A10:1. ]

title: MUSEUM VILLAGE SEMINAR
description: In an age that places a premium on new ideas and technologies for the home, many find comfort in more old-fashioned surroundings.

title: TUSSIE-MUSSIES FOR FRAGRANT VALENTINES
description: DEAR Valentine, how do I love thee? With a tussie-mussie, a tuzzie-muzzie, a nosegay or a posy? An Anglo-Latin dictionary of 1440 gives the three terms as interchangeable for a small fragrant bunch of flowers. Today a posy is defined as a nosegay or bouquet, nice to smell, and a tussie-mussie as a fragrant hand-held cluster or knot of flowers.

title: CYANIDE IS FOUND IN JERSEY STORE AFTER CALLER TELLS OF TAMPERING
description: A tea bag containing a lethal dose of cyanide was found in a Princeton Township supermarket on Tuesday after an anonymous caller told a store employee that he had also poisoned some store cheese and left the tea bag as proof of his visit, the authorities said today.

title: UNITED INSURANCE COS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EMPIRE OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $3 million from the reversal of tax loss carryforwards for the quarter, and the year included a $12 million tax credit and a gain of $21,807,000 from the forgiveness of accumulated income capital certificate income payments. c-Net income The company converted to stock form in November.

title: ISOLATION FOR SUSPECT IN RACIAL ATTACK
description: Jon L. Lester, one of the three white youths accused of murder in the Howard Beach attack, spends 23 hours of every day alone, for his own safety.

title: HOME GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $10.5 million and realized investment losses of $1.6 million. c-Includes a tax credit of $33.6 million, a credit of $32.3 million from adoption of new pension accounting methods and realized investment gains of $97.7 million. d-Net losses after realized investment losses of $1.7 million for the quarter, and realized investment gains of $48.4 million for the year. The year is also after a charge of $17.2 million attributable to the company's discontinued life, accident and health insurance operations.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE SAILOR AS PHOTOGRAPHER

title: FINNIGAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. c-Includes a tax credit of $398,000.

title: On Average, He Wasn't
description: Julius Erving heads into retirement with the third-highest scoring average in the history of the N.B.A. All-Star Game. The leaders (minimum of four games played):

title: Long Distance Lobbyist
description: Peter Vallone, majority leader of the New York City Council, hired a lobbyist to represent the Council's interests in Albany. It turns out that the $30,000-a-year lobbyist, Alan Warshauer, considers it a seldom-show job, doing more to embarrass than represent his Council clients.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, the Food Notes column in The Living Section yesterday misstated the ownership of the ''21'' Club. The restaurant's sole owner is Marshall S. Cogan; Stephen Swid is no longer his partner.

title: Second Nuclear Test of '87
description: A nuclear device was detonated in a weapon test beneath the Nevada desert today, the second of six such tests scheduled for a two-month period. The device was listed as having an explosive force of less than 20,000 tons of TNT. Six protesters gathered on a road leading to the test site gate, and one demonstrator was arrested for trespassing.

title: R. V. CARLETON
description: R. V. Carleton, an aviation pioneer and retired Braniff pilot and executive, died at a hospital Tuesday after a long illness. He was 81 year old.

title: GARBAGE LANDFILLS IN HALF OF THE STATES APPROACHING CAPACITY
description: In Massachusetts, three-fourths of the 199 landfills now receiving garbage will be used up in three years. In New York, less than 10 years remain for all existing landfills. More than half of Alabama's sites will close in five years.

title: THE HUMBLED SAUDI ECONOMY
description: Early in the 1980's, when Saudi Arabia was riding the oil boom, stories circulated about Saudis who traded in their cars when the ashtray filled up. Today, however, many cars on the roads of Riyadh look three, four and five years old.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL NETS VS. HOUSTON ROCKETS, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:30P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 7:30P.M. Radio - WNEW 1130, 7:20P.M.) COLLEGES: Mississippi State at Auburn (TV - USA 7 P.M.) Arizona at U.C.L.A. (TV - ESPN, 11 P.M.) GOLF PGA TOUR: Shearson Lehman Brothers Andy Williams Open, at Torrey Pines Golf Club, La Jolla, Calif. OTHER EVENTS BOXING: Avery Rawls vs. Rufus Hadley, heavyweights, 10 rounds at Showboat Hotel, Las Vegas, Nev. (TV - ESPN, 8:30 P.M.) HARNESS RACING: Roosevelt, 7:30 P.M. Meadowlands, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, midnight) THOROUGHBRED RACING: Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 6:15 P.M. and 11:15 P.M.)

title: Release of Dissidents More Than a Gesture
description: The Soviet Union has turned a major corner in its handling of human-rights cases with the pardoning of dozens of imprisoned dissidents, Western diplomats and Soviet officials say. Although not satisfying

title: NATIONAL ENTERPRISES BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the latest fourth quarter and the 1985 year.

title: Palestinian Protesters Clash With Soldiers in West Bank
description: Israeli troops fired tear gas and rubber bullets at rock-throwing Palestinians today, and children in a refugee center set fire to piles of garbage they heaped in the streets.

title: SHULTZ SAID TO WARN REAGAN OF CASEY'S VERSION
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz angrily confronted President Reagan last November after learning that the Director of Central Intelligence was about to make innaccurate statements to the Senate about the provision of arms to Iran, a senior Reagan Administration official said today.

title: CAPITAL CITIES/ABC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $265,746,000. The company said the 1985 results do not reflect the acquisition of American Broadcasting Cos. on Jan. 3, 1986. The company said the 1986 results reflect the fair market valued assigned to ABC's assets. Adjustments related to the determination of the fair market value of entertainment programming and sports rights at the ABC Television Network benefited 1986 earnings by about $5.60 a share. Results for 1986 also include a charge of $3.19 a share for the amortization of intangibles arising from the ABC acquisition.

title: Vice Chairman Quits Hutton
description: Scott Pierce, vice chairman of the E.F. Hutton Group, said yesterday that he had resigned.

title: MUSIC: LINDA TILLERY
description: LINDA TILLERY, a pop-soul singer who has worked in the San Francisco Bay Area since the late 1960's, has performed twice in New York City during the past year. In her most recent appearance, on Tuesday at the Bottom Line, she shared the bill with Teresa Trull, a fellow performer on the West Coast women's music label, Redwood Records.

title: Search Is Already On For Simon Successor
description: BRONX Democratic leaders are not questioning whether Borough President Stanley Simon, who prosecutors say is a target of a Federal grand jury investigation, will resign - but when.

title: U.S. Troops to Start Exercise in Honduras
description: Paratroopers of the 82d Airborne Division prepared today to embark on a mock airborne invasion of Honduras on Thursday.

title: AT THE NEW YORKER, TIME TO CHANGE GUARD
description: William Shawn's 35-year reign as editor of The New Yorker, a reign as distinguished and as total as any in the annals of modern journalism, is expected to end without fanfare tomorrow when the legendary 79-year-old editor passes the torch to Robert Gottlieb, who is 24 years his junior.

title: True Enough
description: Yesterday was the first day on which this year's football recruits could formally commit to the colleges of their choice, and so the University of Mississippi set up a special telephone number that would enable followers to keep track of Rebel signings. Because of a misprint in the local newspaper, though, fans instead reached a phone-sex service that offered a female voice vividly describing an imaginary encounter with the caller. ''All we can do is undergo the embarrassment of it,'' said Langston Rogers, sports information director for the Rebels, who hadn't known how right they'd be when they promoted their 900 number as a ''hot line.''

title: Introducing a New Way To List New Products
description: The year has gotten off to a fast start, at least where product introductions are concerned. According to the first issue of the revamped DFS-Dorland New Product News, January saw 552 new items introduced nationally, compared with 445 in January 1986. The publication notes that much of the increase is the result of a new tabulating method: Each item in a new line of products is now recorded as a separate product; previously the whole line was counted as just one new product.

title: About Humiliation
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: SPECTER OF A RECESSION IS SEEN IN FALLING DOLLAR
description: Last Friday, Edward M. Marwell's small factory in Mount Kisco, N.Y., shipped its first forklift truck parts to a Japanese manufacturer. He credits this small coup to the sharp decline of the dollar relative to the yen, which made his product more competitive.

title: OLYMPIC INTERNATIONAL BANK reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $8,400. The prior year figures are for 7 months. The company began operations in May 1985 and went public in July 1986.

title: JERSEY OFFICIALS APPROVE PERMIT FOR 12th CASINO
description: The New Jersey Casino Control Commission voted 5-0 today to license Showboat Inc. and its 17 top officers and directors to operate Atlantic City's 12th casino.

title: Allies' View on ABM Belittled by Adelman
description: Kenneth L. Adelman, director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, said today that the Western allies had no business telling the United States how to interpret the Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972.

title: ELBIT COMPUTERS LTD CP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods' results are based upon income after provision for taxes on income in the amount of $1.9 million, or 14 cents a share, in the quarter, and $4.8 million, or 36 cents a share, in the 9 months.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Chemical Bank Appointments
description: Chemical Bank will soon name Thomas S. Johnson, now head of its capital markets group, as president, banking sources said yesterday.

title: Miami Herald Names Editor From Colorado
description: Janet Chusmir, president and publisher of The Daily Camera in Boulder, Colo., will become executive editor of The Miami Herald in May, Richard G. Capen, the publisher of The Herald, said today.

title: Creativity: A British Viewpoint
description: BRITISH advertising is consistently better than the work being done in the United States, according to Len Sugarman, who has been a creative director on both sides of the ocean.

title: DURR-FILLAUER MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Kaiser Chief Will Retire
description: Walter E. Ousterman Jr., chairman, president and chief executive of the Kaiser Cement Company, plans to retire next month after Kaiser is acquired by the Hanson Group.

title: The Place of Violence in South Africa, as Once in the 13 Colonies; Selective Morality
description: To the Editor:

title: Paterno Honored Again
description: Joe Paterno, whose undefeated Penn State team won the national championship of major college football by beating Miami in the Fiesta Bowl, was selected winner of the 19th annual Joseph M. Sheehan Memorial Award as major college coach of the year in the East. This is the seventh time and second year in a row that Paterno has won the award from the New York Football Writers Association.

title: JAMES MADISON LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said it acquired First Continental Bank of Maryland, now known as Madison Bank of Maryland, and United National Bank in 1986, and that they were accounted for as a pooling-of-interest. The company acquired McLean Bank on Dec.31, 1986, which was accounted for as a purchase.

title: IMPRESARIO PROMOTES LAUGHS
description: Stand-up comedy plays in New York and Hollywood, but what interests Richard Fields is how well it plays in the likes of Peoria and Poughkeepsie.

title: Latest Scores From the Capitol
description: When Congress completed action on last year's tax legislation, Senator Russell Long of Louisiana and Representative Jake Pickle of Texas came away with a pair of plums.

title: NEW YORK TAKES PHOTOS OF ITSELF FOR POSTERITY
description: In the last four and a half years, photographers employed by the City Finance Department have walked down every street, stood on every corner and photographed every building in the city's five boroughs, as well as every vacant lot where a building once stood or may one day stand.

title: Skiers To Blaze a Trail
description: Eventually, the Catamount Trail will be a self-guided cross-country experience for anyone who wants to ski Vermont from end to end. In the meantime, 100 or more skiers will cover the route in a series of daily relays beginning Feb. 27 -just to prove it can be done.

title: Honest, Abe Had Athletic Ability
description: Once upon a time Bill Stern, an exceedingly creative sports radio personality, related a tale in the 1940's about the time a man was playing baseball when a committee called to inform him that he had just been nominated for President of the United States. And ''in shirtsleeves,'' recalled Stern, the man ''made the dignitaries wait on the sidelines until he had had his lick at bat.''

title: WASHINGTON TALK: BRIEFING
description: John M. Snyder, editor of Point Blank, house organ of the Citizens Committee for the Right to Keep and Bear Arms, has come up with an especially hard-line argument against the latest efforts to control handguns. ''If only one life is lost because a victim did not have a handgun with which to defend himself against a criminal because of a handgun purchase waiting period requirement,'' he maintains, ''the perpetrators of that requirement will have the life of that innocent victim on their consciences for the rest of their lives.''

title: LAUREL ENTERTAINMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $403,173. c-After tax credits of $431,720 for the quarter and $398,243 for the 9 months.

title: To License or Not
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: If Jefferson et al Could See Us Now
description: Forrest McDonald is a conservative Republican who says he is ill at ease in Washington, even the Washington of Ronald Reagan. But he is not ill at ease talking about the Constitution and the Federal Government that has evolved from it. He is an expert on that subject.

title: EASTERN, CONTINENTAL AND TEXAS AIR IN BLACK
description: Eastern Airlines yesterday reported a profit of $6 million for the fourth quarter, a sharp turnaround from its loss of $67.4 million in the fourth quarter of 1985.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 12, 1987
description: International A3-19 A panel has uncovered new data linking the National Security Council to private efforts aiding the Nicaraguan rebels at a time when such activity by the Government was illegal, according to informants. Page A1 Prospects for new Congressional aid to the Nicaraguan insurgents are so bleak that the Reagan Administration may postpone its formal request until September, Administration officials said. A1 Walsh widening inquiry on Contras A9

title: Merrill Lynch Cuts Hong Kong Link
description: Merrill Lynch & Company announced today that it had sold its 25 percent stake in one of Hong Kong's major stock companies, Sun Hung Kai.

title: WOODSTREAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes for the quarter increased tax expense related to the reversal of $90,000 of previously recorded investment tax credits, and for the quarter and year includes restatement of previously reported results to reflect $141,000 after-tax reduction of pension expense in the first nine months of the year. Pension expension was reduced by $47,000 and $188,000 after-tax for the quarter and year, respectively, as a result of the adoption of new FASB rules for pensions. The latest-year net reflects expenses of $180,000 associated with the repurchase of 110,000 common shares. Share earnings are computed on the basis of average number of common shares outstanding after providing for preferred dividend requirements.

title: Community Colleges Open Door to Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Gains 13.92 to Close at 2,171.96
description: A dip in interest rates, a firmer dollar and new-found enthusiasm for technology stocks gave Wall Street what it needed yesterday to break a three-day slide.

title: A BORROWER'S MARKET FOR HOME-EQUITY LOANS
description: IF you're one of the thousands of homeowners who have decided to renovate or remodel their current dwellings, you couldn't have picked a better time.

title: SPECTRADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reduced by $1,415,000, or 15 cents a share, due to a reduction of investment tax credits as a result of new tax laws.

title: WESTBRIDGE CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes $11.8 million, or $2.82 a share, of charges from a writeoff of deferred acquisition costs and settlement of a lawsuit. c-Net income and includes tax benefits of $1.6 million, or 37 cents a share.

title: JACLYN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share figures are restated to reflect the 4 percent stock dividend paid in June 1986.

title: YOUTHS NEIGHBORS STUNNED BY THE CHARGES IN ATTACK ON BLACKS
description: The 12 youths charged in the Howard Beach racial assault have histories similar to those of middle-class white youths around the city, and the attachment of their names to charges of murder, manslaughter, assault and riot stunned those who know them differently.

title: ENDATA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $194,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $933,000 for the year. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $6,139,000 and $8,679,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: A Price Is Right
description: Mark Price of the Cleveland Cavaliers, looking on the bright side of an appendectomy that kept him sidelined a month: ''That's one injury that can never happen to me again.''

title: WHEELING-PITTSBURGH STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes reserves of $210,216,000 for the shutdown of the company's rail mill and related Monessen, Pa. facilities, and $33,642,000 for the intended rejection or modification of certain raw material supply contracts for the quarter; and for the year includes restructuring charges totaling $327,100,000. c-Includes a provision of $49,927,000 for the permanent closing of portions of four plants and a $21.4 million provision for an expected excise tax resulting from the failure to meet minimum pension funding standards for the quarter; and for the year includes restructuring charges of $141,165,000.

title: Chip Orders Remain Flat
description: Orders for semiconductors remained flat during January, an industry trade group said yesterday. But the book-to-bill ratio increased for the fourth month in a row, providing a further sign that the American chip industry is recovering.

title: N.B.A. Talks Begin
description: The prospect for long and tough negotiations was evident yesterday after the National Basketball Association and its players union held their first bargaining session for a new contract at the St. Regis hotel in Manhattan. The present four-year pact expires 24 hours after the league champion is crowned in June. ''Obviously, the parties were far apart in their positions,'' said Russ Granik, the N.B.A.'s executive vice president. ''However, we have begun bargaining earlier than ever before, and both sides are dedicated to working toward an agreement. We gave no demands. We told them the owners are not going to give them any agreement that does not include, in some form, a salary cap, the retention of right of first refusal for free agents and the college draft.''

title: BOWL AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
Utah Power President Resigns After Shake-Up
description: In an unusual shake-up at a large utility company, the Utah Power and Light Company yesterday announced the resignation of James C. Taylor as president and chief executive. Mr. Taylor, 61, also stepped down from the company's board, and will be replaced temporarily by Frank N. Davis, president of the company's Energy National Inc. subsidiary.

title: Trial Ends in Alabama Suit Against the Klan
description: Witnesses testifying in a $10 million lawsuit against the Ku Klux Klan said here today that a Klan leader had called the sight of a black teen-ager's hanged body a ''pretty sight.''

title: DRUG SUSPECTS SAY U.S. KNEW OF DEALS
description: People indicted on drug charges are increasingly arguing as a defense that they have been supplying arms to the Nicaraguan rebels with the knowledge of Federal agents, according to law-enforcement officers.

title: HAITIAN CHIEF FAULTED FOR NOT BREAKING WITH PAST
description: To mark the first anniversary of the fall of the Duvalier dictatorship, Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy, the head of Haiti's provisional Government, rode in a dark blue Maserati sedan to a national historical museum near the presidential palace to dedicate a memorial plaque.

title: Sutter Has Surgery
description: Bruce Sutter, the Atlanta Braves' reliever, has undergone surgery in Denver to repair nerve damage to his right shoulder in the hopes of returning to baseball in 1988. Sutter underwent a three-hour operation Tuesday at the University of Colorado Health Sciences Center. Dr. Steven Ringel said it would be several months before doctors know whether they were able to regenerate damaged tissue in Sutter's pitching arm.

title: Bo Diddley to Perform At 2 Benefit Concerts
description: The rhythm-and-blues guitarist Bo Diddley is to stage a pair of benefit concerts next week to bolster this western Colorado town's slumping revenues.

title: HERS
description: LEAD: WHEN I was in college, I considered a number of possible career paths. The first was nuclear physics.

title: Times Square Redevelopment Marches On
description: To the Editor:

title: ENCORE COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 24
PLAN TO AVERT AIR TRAFFIC DELAYS ON EAST COAST IS STARTING TODAY
description: Seeking to avert the delays that have affected many airline flights, the Federal Aviation Administration today is putting into effect a major change in East Coast air traffic flows.

title: HOUSEHOLD INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $87.6 million for the quarter and $109.7 million for the year, and an extraordinary charge of $39.2 million for the year. The quarter's discontinued operations include an after-tax gain of $155 million from the sale of National Car Rental System Inc. The quarter's net also includes after-tax restructuring charges of $152.7 million, including an extraordinary charge of $39.2 million. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $12.9 million for the quarter and $56.4 million for the year.

title: DURHAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $1,437,000 for the quarter and $5,775,000 for the year. c-After a capital loss of $700,000 for the quarter and a capital gain of $5,329,000 for the year.

title: BEIRUT ISLAMIC GROUP AGAIN WARNS OF U.S. ATTACK
description: A Moslem group holding two Americans hostage here announced today that it had ordered its members on full alert in anticipation of an American troop landing, and an Armenian underground faction threatened to end a four-month-old truce with France.

title: Reuters Net Climbs 47%
description: Holdings P.L.C. said today that its net income rose 47 percent in 1986 on a surge of new orders, favorable currency rates and a lower tax rate. The news agency's after-tax profit totaled $:80.7 million, or $119.4 million, up from 1985's $:54.9 million. Revenues rose 43 percent, to $:620.9 million, or $918.9 million, from $:434.1 million.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday about the designation of three Manhattan buildings as landmarks misidentified the current owner of the former Tiffany & Company building at Fifth Avenue and 37th Street. It is News World Communications. In addition a picture with the article was published in error; it showed showed the synagogue of Congregation Beth Hamedrash Hagodol at 60 Norfolk Street, not Anshe Chesed Synagogue at 172-76 Norfolk Street, which was declared a landmark on Tuesday.

title: Khao I Dang: Refugee Job Not Finished
description: In announcing the closing of the Khao I Dang refugee camp Thailand pleads with the West: Resettle these 15,000 Cambodians as you have pledged or back they go to the border with Cambodia. The West needs to heed the message if it is to protect the carefully assembled international structure for handling refugees.

title: FOR DWINDLING DEBUTS, THE ORIGINAL PURPOSE
description: ONLY the closest observers of New York's concert life -perhaps only those in or near the music business itself - will have noticed the sharp drop-off in formal debut recitals this season. These are the only people who pay much attention to such concerts anyway, and that is one reason for the drop. This critic's unscientific sampling suggests that the debuts are also getting better. The trends are worth discussion because they point to developments of more general interest to classical concertgoers.

title: DeBartolo
description: The Edward J. DeBartolo Corporation, the nation's largest builder of shopping centers, has acquired Mayfair in the Grove, a high-fashion retail and mixed-use development in Miami, for an undisclosed amount of cash. DeBartolo, which is based in Youngstown, Ohio, bought the interest in the eight-year-old project held by Kenneth Treister, the Miami architect who designed the center, and Joseph A. Garfield, a Miami real estate developer. DeBartolo had managed the center, which contains a Burdine's department store, 100 smaller stores and a 185-room luxury hotel known as Mayfair House.

title: CENTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. Assails Import Plan
description: A proposal by the European Community to ban imports of meat from hormone-treated animals could increase trade tensions between Europe and the United States, American trade officials said today. The ban, if enacted, would mean the loss of about $80 million for American meat producers. Reagan Administration officials warned that the community's proposed ban constituted a violation of trade rules and could spark retaliation by the United States. ''This will constitute a non-tariff trade barrier,'' said Donald Houston, administrator of the Agriculture Department's Food Safety and Inspection Service. The proposed ban is the result of mounting public concern in Europe over the use of hormones in animal production.

title: OLIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and includes income of $25 million from discontinued operations. The results for the 1986 periods include a gain of $16.8 million, after taxes, from the sale of land and a benefit from the third quarter adoption of F.A.S.B. 87. The 1985 results include a $330 million pre-tax special charge, or $230 million after taxes, for the company's restructuring program.

title: Secular and Religious Sikh Leaders in Open Split
description: A serious split between secular and religious Sikh leaders in India opened today when the religion's five head priests said they had excommunicated the moderate Sikh elected leader in Punjab state for defying their political orders.

title: Sea-Land Deal By CSX Approved
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission voted unanimously to approve the CSX Corporation's planned $803 million acquisition of the Sea-Land Corporation, the first merger between a railroad and an ocean shipper. The merger means that Richmond-based CSX would operate 27,000 miles of railroad tracks, along with barges, pipelines, trucking and global shipping.

title: FIRST EXECUTIVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized gains from investments of $1,961,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $16,381,000 for the year. c-Includes realized gains from investments of $4,961,000, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter and $26,515,000 for the year.

title: Kemp at the Net
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp of upstate New York, onetime quarterback of the Buffalo Bills, is known for his prowess on the football field, but he is also a mean hand on the tennis court. So is John W. Warner, the senior Senator from Virginia, who, by the way, turns 60 next Wednesday.

title: GLATFELTER, PH COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings figures adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in May 1986.

title: Shamir Still Rules Out Mideast Peace Parley
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, reacting to a United States message, restated his opposition today to an international Middle East peace conference.

title: Implant for DiMaggio
description: Joe DiMaggio has undergone a heart pacemaker implant at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Miami Beach, Fla., and is scheduled to be released today, the hospital reported. DiMaggio, 72 years old, checked into the hospital Feb. 3 after being diagnosed as having an abnormally slow heartbeat and Dr. Philip Samet, chief of cardiology at Mount Sinai, peformed the implant last week.

title: TIMES MIRROR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $29.6 million from the sales of Graphic Controls Corp. and A. M. Gousha Co. for the quarter, and for the year includes gains on sales of assets of $2.64 a share in 1986 and 27 cents a share in 1985. c-Includes a pre-tax loss provision of $13.1 million and a pre-tax gain of $7.3 million. The company said employers' pension accounting under SFAS 87 resulted in a pretax benefit of $50.6 million for 1986, or $25.3 million after taxes.

title: PHYSIO TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: CUOMO IN WEST, REPEATS THEMES OF AID TO POOR
description: Governor Cuomo today began a series of trips around the country - trips being watched closely for evidence of his national political strength - bringing here his theme that those who share in the American dream have an obligation to help the millions who do not.

title: Troubled Times for Big Banks
description: In the fourth quarter, the nation's biggest commercial banking companies were plagued by continued weakness in lending, a decline in investment-banking income and a disturbingly high level of special items. As a result, the year turned out to be one of the harshest for the banks since deregulation began in the late 1970's.

title: CONTEST FOR HOUSE GROWING COMPLEX
description: A contest here to fill the unexpired term of Representative Sala Burton, who died Feb. 1, is turning into an unpredictable free-for-all, threatening the Democratic organization that has dominated the city's political affairs for much of the last 20 years.

title: REBUFF RECALLED IN RACIAL ATTACK CASE
description: A lawyer for one of the 12 youths indicted in the Howard Beach assault asserted yesterday that the prosecution had twice failed to respond to the lawyer's efforts to discuss the case.

title: CYCARE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company adopted FASB No. 87, dealing with pension costs, Jan. 1, 1986. The effect was to increase share earnings about one cent a share for the quarter and three cents a share for the year. Last December the company acquired Physicians Bookkeeper Inc.

title: Charges for 5 Officers Are Dismissed by Judge
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan, citing technical flaws, has dismissed an indictment against five police officers from the 77th Precinct in Brooklyn who were among 12 accused last year in a corruption scandal.

title: Hoechst to Sue Community
description: Hoechst A.G., the West German chemical company, said today that it would sue the European Community in a test of the community's ability to enforce law in member states.

title: EAST GERMANY RESISTS CHANGE
description: East Germany's Communist leadership has strongly signaled that it is unenthusiastic about Mikhail S. Gorbachev's calls for ''openness'' and ''democratization'' and that it does not intend to imitate the Soviet Union's outlined reforms.

title: Death Sentence in 3 Killings
description: A jury ordered the death penalty Tuesday for a man who said he hacked three women to death with a hatchet after he tired of hearing them quarrel. The man, David Martin Long, 33 years old, previously told the state district court panel he wanted the death penalty and was afraid he would kill again. He was convicted Saturday of capital murder in the Sept. 27 deaths of Donna Sue Jester, 37, Dalpha Lorene Jester, 64, and Laura Lee Owen, 20, in the Dallas suburb of Lancaster.

title: WHICH PROJECTS PAY OFF
description: WHAT remodeling projects will pay off the most? If you're planning to sell your house within a year after the project, an interior face lift -such as repainting or wallpapering - will give you the most return on your investment, according to the National Association of the Remodeling Industry in Arlington, Va. The industry group says that its annual survey of real-estate appraisers indicates you should get back 107 percent of your investment if you sell within 12 months.

title: Bush Praises Reagan Record
description: Vice President Bush, starting a two-state swing, focused on the Reagan Administration's accomplishments in a speech here tonight, saying, ''These are good times to be a Republican.''

title: Bidders Listed For French TV
description: The British-French financier Sir James Goldsmith and the French press magnate Robert Hersant are the only bidders for the private television channel La Cinq, the French Government said Tuesday night. The National Commission for

title: FOR HORTICULTURISTS, WRITING FLOURISHES
description: THE evidence is plain in my mailbox every week: letter writing is a dying art. Some old friends write a note from time to time. At Christmas, others send a printout omnibus letter about their lives since last Christmas. Sometimes these computerized letters have a small personal touch at the end, but even with that, they remain letters to no one in particular. It is the telephone, not the postage stamp, that keeps me bound to friends and kinfolk from Texas to Massachusetts.

title: Church's Chief Resigns To Join Bid for Company
description: The president and chief executive of Church's Fried Chicken Inc., Richard F. Sherman, resigned yesterday to ''participate in an offer to acquire'' the fast-food restaurant chain, the company announced.

title: CONTINENTAL AIRLINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
