description: b-Includes gains of $13.1 million and $24.9 million for the quarter and year, respectively, on the sale of aircraft; $2.1 million for the quarter and $9.6 million for the year from the termination of a pension plan and charges of $4.3 million and $84 million from Chapter 11 reorganization expenses for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss d-Includes charges of $17.8 million for both the quarter and year from severance pay for former striking pilots, and charges of $4 million and $24 million for the quarter and year, respectively, for Chapter 11 reorganization expenses. The company said it did not report share earnings for the latest periods and the prior year because Texas Air Corp., Continental's parent, recently acquired all of Continental Airlines' minority shares. This transaction was completed on Feb. 6, 1987.

title: College Is Not A Product
description: LEAD: I am pleased that the Secretary of Education, William J. Bennett, has finally disclosed that universities are wasteful and inefficient. As a university president, I have always been ashamed to admit this fault, but I now feel that public confession is permissible. Perhaps abject admission will lead to fiscal absolution or solvency.

title: RESULT PLUS
description: Tennis McEnroe Advances: John McEnroe posted a 6-3, 6-4 victory yesterday in his opening performance of the United States Indoor Tennis Championships in Memphis, but said he was still not playing at top form. ''The mental and physical combination is not there yet, but I believe deep down that it can get better,'' McEnroe said after he defeated Paul Annacone. McEnroe, ranked 11th in the world, said he had not fully recovered from a six-month layoff last year.

title: Boys Will Be Boys
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: PRO TENNIS STARS MIGHT PLAY IN SEOUL
description: The broadening of Olympic eligibility continued today when the executive board of the International Olympic Committee unanimously approved a code of tennis eligibility that would permit the sport's millionaire stars to play in the 1988 Games.

title: MUSEUMS AND COLLECTORS AGAIN PURSUE THE MEDIEVAL STYLE
description: THE Gothic style, revived many times and in many countries since it first appeared in the late Middle Ages, is once again being exhibited by museums and pursued seriously by collectors and dealers. The versions most enthusiasts seek today are those from the mid-19th century that echo the architecture of medieval cathedrals, awash with pointed arches, quatrefoils, finials, crockets, rosettes, crenelated moldings and clustered columns.

title: NORTHEASTERN MORTGAGE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes about $390,000 from the sale of loan-servicing rights.

title: CABARET: ARLENE SMITH OF CHANTELS
description: AMONG the brash, fearless adolescent voices that animated rock-and-roll music in the late 1950's, none were more fervent than Arlene Smith, the lead singer of one of the earliest ''girl groups,'' the Chantels. Along with Frankie Lymon, Ms. Smith helped to inaugurate a pubescent rock-and-roll belting style that has since been adapted by dozens of singers, including the young Michael Jackson and Madonna.

title: Aiwa to Sell Digital Recorders
description: The Aiwa Company of Japan became the first concern formally to announce a marketing date for a consumer digital tape recorder - a controversial high-fidelity product that could swing customers away from compact disks. Aiwa will begin selling its digital recorder in Japan March 2, but has no plans now for marketing overseas, a spokesman, Kazuhiro Hoshi, said. The list price will be 188,000 yen, or $1,225.

title: CONCURRENT COMPUTER reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
FUNERALS FOR AIDS VICTIMS: SEARCHING FOR SENSITIVITY
description: Driving a station wagon with tinted windows, Timothy O'Brien recently carried the corpse of a man who had died of AIDS from a funeral home in East Harlem to another in Queens where a wake would be held.

title: FOOTE, CONE & BELDING COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes writedowns and reserves totaling $2,750,000, and the latest year includes an after-tax gain of $1.3 million from the sale of Deutsch, Shea & Evans, North Castle Partners and Carl Byoir Associates. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,979,000 from reversion of a pension plan.

title: Dow Slips by 6.18 in Heavy Trading
description: Stock prices fell slightly in heavy trading yesterday, a day when Wall Street was stunned by the arrest of three executives on insider trading charges.

title: Merc's Price Limit Plan Dismays Many Traders
description: In a move that surprised and dismayed many futures traders, board members of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange voted late Wednesday to install daily price ranges on its widely used Standard & Poor's 500-stock index futures contract.

title: Yearning to Breathe Free
description: It is a basic constitutional right in this country to read and express political ideas, however unpopular. We can subscribe to Pravda. We can distribute literature calling for replacement of Israel by a Palestinian state, or calling for a Greater Israel with its Arabs expelled.

title: Automatic Data To Marcoa DR Group
description: Marcoa DR Group, a direct marketing company within the Omnicom Group, has become agency for the Automatic Data Processing Corporation of Roseland, N.J., which has a $5 million ad budget.

title: ART: IN BLECKNER SHOW, AN ARRAY OF PAST MOTIFS
description: ROSS BLECKNER is an artist who has held our attention by never quite staying put.

title: Youth Not Served at Hialeah
description: A young woman from Manhattan who is visiting Florida this week has been barred from attending the races at Hialeah. What classifies her under Florida state law as an undesirable is neither a race-fixing rap nor a bookmaking conviction, but her age - 13 months.

title: U.N. Report Estimates Iran Executed 7,000
description: A United Nations report issued here today estimates that 7,000 people, most of them opponents of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's Government, were executed in Iran after the ouster of the Shah in 1979. It charged that torture and summary executions remained widespread.

title: THE LEADERS
description: The Leaders, an all-star jazz group that includes the saxophonists Chico Freeman and Arthur Blythe, the trumpeter Lester Bowie, the pianist Kirk Lightsey, the bassist Cecil McBee and the drummer Don Moye, will appear tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street. Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $7 minimum tonight and tomorrow, a $10 cover and a $6 minimum Sunday. Information: 242-1785.

title: Paribas Shares Up 18% in Price
description: Institutional investors trying to buy shares in Cie Financiere de Paribas bid the price of the banking group's shares up by 18 percent on the first official day of trading. Paribas is one of 24 major concerns that Prime Minister Jacques Chirac aims to return to private ownership over the next five years.

title: Patriots Under a Dome?
description: The possibility of a domed stadium for the New England Patriots arose yesterday when a spokesman for Edward G. (Buddy) LeRoux confirmed that the part owner of the Boston Red Sox and the Suffolk Downs thoroughbred race track was considering the purchase of the Patriots along with Sullivan Stadium and the adjacent harness racing track in Foxboro, Mass. ''There have been ongoing discussions for about two months,'' said George Sullivan, vice president for Belle Isle Limited Partnership, which was formed by LeRoux for the purchase of Suffolk Downs and 200 acres of land last year. ''Buddy will have nothing to say until something is finalized.'' Bob O'Malley, general manager of Suffolk Downs, also confirmed that LeRoux and the Patriots' general manager, Patrick Sullivan, (no relation to George) had been talking for a few weeks about possible purchase of ''the entire package.'' The package would include the National Football League team, 60,000-seat Sullivan Stadium, and the lease on the harness track. Speculation has put the price at $90 million and $100 million. The Boston Herald quoted unidentified sources as saying LeRoux wanted to buy the Patriots and convert Suffolk Downs into an 80,000-seat domed stadium. If he buys the Patriots, LeRoux would have to relinquish his interest in the Red Sox because N.F.L. rules prohibit an owner from also owning a baseball club.

title: ON THE HUNT FOR THE UBIQUITOUS MAN-MADE EAGLE IN MANHATTAN
description: THE bald eagle, an endangered species, is at roost all around Manhattan - in stone, in bronze, in paint, in stitchery, on sidewalks and rooftops, canvas and quilts, on monuments and office buildings, in parks and museums.

title: CLEARINGHOUSE CREATED
description: Kidder, Peabody & Company is offering $750 million of collateralized mortgage obligations, in a financing that typifies the willingness of dealers and investors to devise varieties of mortgage-backed securities.

title: Investment Institute Starting a Magazine
description: The five-year-old Investment Management Institute, a sponsor of more than 25 annual seminars for financial professionals and business executives, is going to try its hand at publishing.

title: DOTRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: HEALTH CARE REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Police Report Few Clues in Shooting in the Village
description: Investigators said yesterday that they had not established a motive in the Greenwich Village shooting of a defendant in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial, and that they could not question the victim because he was in critical condition.

title: Saatchi Transferring 2 From London
description: Edward L. Wax, the president of domestic operations at Saatchi & Saatchi Compton, reported yesterday that Jeffrey Stark, a creative man, and Richard Hedger, an account type, will be coming to New York from London to join the agency. The former will report to Robert H. Levenson, vice chairman and chief creative officer, and Mr. Hedger to Mr. Wax.

title: BUSH, IN MIDWEST, PUSHES IRAN ISSUE OFF A BIT MORE
description: Vice President Bush, apparently seeking to deflect the political liabilities of the Iran arms affair, said today that he had voiced ''certain reservations'' about it as it was developing.

title: BRT REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain on sale of investments of $303,000 for the latest period and the year-ago period is after a provision of $130,000 for possible loan losses. The share earnings and shares outstanding for the year-ago quarter have been restated to reflect a 1-for-3 reverse stock split effected in August 1986.

title: Bass Wins Arbitration
description: Kevin Bass, Houston's right fielder, won his salary arbitration, but Gary Pettis, California's center fielder, lost for the second successive year. Bass, who earned $310,000 last year, gained a 1987 salary of $630,000; the Astros' offer was $560,000. It was the Astros' second loss in three cases. Pettis had a $300,000 salary last year after losing in arbitration and went up to $400,000 with his loss this time. He had sought $550,000. The $400,000 salary is still less than the $425,000 he tried for last year. Clubs have won six cases and players four. A possible 28 cases remain. . . . Two players who had been scheduled to go before arbitrators yesterday agreed on one-year contracts. Brook Jacoby and Cleveland settled on a $612,500 contract (their figures were $750,000 and $575,000) and Candy Maldonado and San Francisco agreed on $415,000, halfway between their arbitration figures of $440,000 and $390,000.

title: HIGH RISE STIRS FIGHT IN YONKERS
description: A planned 15-story condominium tower has yet to rise on a steeply sloping site in Yonkers overlooking the Hudson River, but it has for months been stamped on the minds of neighboring residents whose river views it would obstruct. Next week those residents will get a chance to voice their objections in court.

title: City Election Worker Arrested in Inquiry
description: A Board of Elections worker has been indicted in an investigation of potential fraud in Assemblyman Roger L. Green's acceptance of a Liberal Party nomination last year and the gathering of independent nominating petitions on his behalf.

title: HIGH VOLTAGE ENGINEERING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,051,000 for the quarter and $1,456,000 for the year. c-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $10,000 for the quarter and $21,000 for the year, and the year also includes a gain of $1,782,000, or 34 cents a share, from the sale of an operating division.

title: Purdue Beats Iowa In Big Ten, 80-73
description: Everette Stephens had a career-high 23 points, including hitting five of five 3-point field goals, as Purdue beat Iowa, 80-73, tonight in a Big Ten game.

title: JACK HENRY & ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest year results include operations of Finser Capital Corp. and its subsidiaries, acquired on Nov.1, 1986. This acquisition was accounted for as a purchase, thus Finser's results are not included in the 1985 results.

title: TEXACO LOSES PLEA IN TEXAS
description: A Texas appellate court today upheld a historic judgment by a lower state court, agreeing that Texaco Inc. illegally persuaded the Getty Oil Company to back out of a merger three years ago with the Pennzoil Company.

title: FILM: BANCROFT IN '84 CHARING CROSS'
description: WORKING carefully and with the least sleazy of intentions, some very good people have taken Helene Hanff's popular epistolary memoir, ''84 Charing Cross Road,'' which records the New York writer's 20-year correspondence with a London bookshop, and made a movie guaranteed to put all teeth on edge, including George Washington's, wherever they might be.

title: BERNARD CHAUS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said 1985 net income and share earnings results have been adjusted to eliminate the amount of stockholders-officers compensation paid in excess of the $780,000 total base salaries annually payable under employment agreements and for provision for income taxes based on pro forma income as if the company had formally not been subject to S Corporation tax status, which terminated on June 30, 1986.

title: THE DANCE: 'BALLARE,' A PREMIERE BY THARP
description: ''BALLARE,'' Twyla Tharp's final premiere in her company's season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is an experiment in fusing the choreographer's modern-dance sensibility with some elements of ballet technique.

title: U.S., HURT BY IRAN AFFAIR, IS COURTING ARABS ANEW
description: In an effort to repair damage done to its reputation in the Arab world by the Iran affair, the Reagan Administration has proposed new arms sales and begun some subtle diplomatic maneuvering in the region.

title: TIMOTHY L. TABOR
description: When Federal marshals finished arresting three prominent arbitragers in its latest round of insider-trading charges, word spread quickly yesterday from trading desk to trading desk on Wall Street. But that was not so much because the scandal had grown, but rather that the individuals named seemed to be among the least likely to be charged.

title: JERSEY POLICE DIRECTOR IS INDICTED IN A CITY LAND-PURCHASE SCHEME
description: The Police Director of New Brunswick and the former head of the city's Law Department have been indicted and accused of helping to persuade city officials to buy land in which the two men held a hidden interest, United States Attorney Thomas W. Greelish announced today.

title: Sensible Welfare Reform
description: For 20 years, the problems of the Federal-state welfare system have become increasingly apparent. Among them are its incentives for single motherhood and broken families, high and increasing costs, paternalistic and unresponsive bureaucracies, staggering economic obstacles in the way of departing the system for remunerative work, constant intergovernmental friction, a bewildering array of inconsistent regulations and the strong suspicion that the system is perpetuating a dependent welfare class that threatens to persist over generations.

title: Still Around: Ghosts of Lincoln And His Era
description: President Reagan, referring to a racial attack in Queens and to confrontations in an all-white county in Georgia, said in a Lincoln's Birthday speech today that ''racism is still with us, North and South.''

title: FILM: 'DUET FOR ONE'
description: IT took half a dozen extra characters and a very large tree to open up Tom Kempinski's two-character play ''Duet for One'' and bring it to the screen. But the focus is still Stephanie Anderson, a brilliant violinist (modeled, to some extent, on the cellist Jacqueline Du Pre) who is married to a celebrated conductor and has multiple sclerosis. Stephanie's illness becomes an occasion for her to re-examine her life as she describes it to Dr. Louis Feldman (Max von Sydow), a psychiatrist who is something of a friend and fan. It also becomes an occasion for Mr. Kempinski to elicit the audience's pity in a far too easy and automatic way.

title: MOYERS PULLS REPORT SERIES FROM PBS
description: ''News Minutes,'' a planned nightly series of reports on the Constitution and one of Bill Moyers's first projects since leaving CBS for public television, has been scrapped after a dispute between the Public Broadcating Service and some PBS stations over the program.

title: Holiday Monday
description: George Washington's birthday will be observed Monday in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Following are holiday schedules. Parking - Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation - No collections; no street cleaning. Governmental offices - Closed. Post offices - Closed; special delivery and express-mail delivery only. Banks - Connecticut, closed; New York and New Jersey, optional closing. Financial markets - Closed. Transportation - Subways and buses on Saturday schedules; Long Island Rail Road, Metro-North and N.J. Transit buses on holiday schedules; N.J. Transit trains on Saturday schedules. Schools - In New York City, closed; in New York State, New Jersey and Connecticut, local option. Libraries - Closed.

title: MELVILLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $9,646,000 and a gain on disposal of $646,000. The latest fourth quarter net was reduced by 10 cents a share from the disallowance of the investment tax credit.

title: Condom Stock Gain Continues
description: PRIMARILY reflecting the health threat of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, the stock prices of publicly owned manufacturers of condoms continue to soar to record levels.

title: Times Co. Net Up 15.2%
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 15.2 percent, helped by a strong performance in all its main groups: newspapers, magazines and broadcasting and cable television.

title: NEWMONT GOLD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is a 95 percent owned subsidiary of Newmont Mining Corp.

title: AUCTIONS
description: ''WHEN the doors were swung back, one was struck by the remarkable smell of 18th-century French morocco,'' Sotheby's medieval-book specialist, Dr. Christopher de Hamel, said in a telephone interview from London, recalling his first trip to one of the world's finest private libraries on hunting, shooting and fishing. The collection of nearly 600 manuscripts and books, assembled by Marcel Jeanson, a French industrialist, is to be auctioned by Sotheby's in Monte Carlo on Feb. 28 and March 1. The house expects the sale to bring more than $4.5 million.

title: G.E. TV Order Shifted to U.S.
description: The General Electric Company said today that it would begin to make midsize color television sets at a plant in Bloomington, Ind. The sets were previously made overseas.

title: BLACK DEMOCRATS MAP MARCH ON ALABMA CAPITOL
description: Less than a month after George Corley Wallace left the Governor's mansion and closed an era in Alabama politics, an influential group of black Democrats is feuding bitterly with the new Democratic leadership in the Legislature as well as the new Republican Governor.

title: WARSAW LEARNS A NEW WORD: 'DEMOCRATIZATION'
description: Among the most commonly used words in Polish Government pronouncements these days is ''democratization.''

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Boys of the Lough, Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street (864-5400). One of the leading traditional Celtic folk ensembles, the Boys of the Lough play highland music that is by turns delicate, buoyant and martial. Formed over a decade ago, the quintet now includes Cathal McConnell (flute, tin whistle, vocals), Aly Bain (fiddle), Dave Richardson (mandolin, tenor banjo, cittern concertina), John Coakley (guitar, piano, fiddle, tin whistle, bodhran) and Christy O'Leary (uillean pipes). The group's approach to the tradition is austere, with arrangements that want to recapture the past more than they want to modernize it. Tonight's performance is at 8:30; tickets are $14 and $12.

title: REAGAN ASSAILED ON JUDICIAL RECORD
description: Senator Patrick J. Leahy, chairman of a Senate judicial screening panel, charged today that the Reagan Administration had a ''shameful'' record on appointing women and members of minorities to the Federal bench and warned that the courts might become ''an enclave of white male exclusivity.''

title: ART: TOWARD DEFINING 'CONTEMPORARY CUTOUTS'
description: THE cutout, an advertising device, became high art after its appropriation by the Pop movement, but without the scholarly attention that usually accompanies such promotions. This has now been rectified by ''Contemporary Cutouts,'' a show organized for the Whitney Museum's Philip Morris branch by its director, Susan Lubowsky.

title: REAGAN PROPOSES HEALTH INSURANCE FOR MAJOR ILLNESS
description: A new program of Federal health benefits for elderly people became virtually certain today when President Reagan proposed expansion of Medicare to cover the costs of catastrophic illnesses.

title: CALIFORNIANS WHO ASSESS CUOMO FIND HIM LIKABLE BUT ENIGMATIC
description: Governor Cuomo of New York flew home today after a quick visit to California, leaving an impression among many voters that he was an interesting but still mysterious alien who had yet to define himself in the eyes of Californians.

title: RED PAPER, CRAYONS AND WORDS OF LOVE
description: How do I love thee? With three tiny hearts decorated with smiley faces, with four noodles pasted nearby, and a big red cutout heart next to the words ''I like you and I love all of you.'' ''It's special if you make it yourself,'' said Jeremy Wang-Iverson, who is 6 years old, as he critically surveyed the valentine collage he was constructing at his desk.

title: Government Executive
description: The National Journal, since last year a property of the Times Mirror Company, yesterday announced the acquisition of the 17-year-old monthly magazine Government Executive from its owner, C. W. Borklund. Government Executive has a circualtion of 70,000 on the Federal, state and local levels.

title: COORS, ADOLPH CO reports earnings for 12wks to Dec 28
description: The company said it adopted the provisions of FASB No. 87, employers' accounting for pensions, in 1986. The effect of this change was to increase net income by approximately $600,000, or 2 cents a share, and $2,500,000, or 7 cents a share, for the 12 weeks and 52 weeks ended Dec. 28, 1986, respectively.

title: S.I. COLLEGE BARS TEAM'S PLAYING IN TOURNAMENTS
description: The president of the College of Staten Island of the City University has barred its championship basketball team from postseason tournament play because some of its white members participated in a brawl with black fans that he said had racial overtones.

title: FILM: 'NO MAN'S LAND'
description: ''No Man's Land'' was shown as part of the 1985 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times Oct. 5, 1985. The film opens today at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: LARRY CORYELL, GUITAR
description: The guitarist Larry Coryell is leading a quartet - with the pianist Stanley Cowell, the bassist Buster Williams and the drummer Beaver Harris - tomight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street. Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $10cover and a $6 minimum. Information: 255-4037.

title: INTERNATIONAL ALUMINUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $93,000 for the quarter and $514,000 for the 6 months.

title: Oldsmobile Tests Ads By Region
description: GENERAL MOTORS' Oldsmobile division is in the midst of a test in a variety of markets to find out if additional headquarters dollars put behind locally originated and oriented advertising can have a dramatic effect on sales. It will be working with regional dealer advertising associations that have their own agencies.

title: ATLANTIC RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,129,000 related to the sale of Tri-Seal International Inc.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: GOLF PGA TOUR: Shearson Lehman Brothers Andy Williams Open, at Torrey Pines Golf Club, La Jolla, Calif. HOCKEY N.H.L. ALL STARS VS. SOVIET NATIONAL TEAM, at Quebec City, 7:30 P.M. (TV - ESPN, 7:30 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS HARNESS RACING: Roosevelt, 7:30 P.M. Meadowlands, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, midnight) THOROUGHBRED RACING: Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 6:15 P.M. and 11:15 P.M.)

title: LINCOLN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized investment gains of $27,802,000 for the quarter and $70,389,000 for the year. c-After realized investment losses of $15,893,000 for the quarter and realized investment gains of $23,700,000 for the year, and a loss of $7,100,000 for the quarter and net of $5,036,000 for the year from discontinued operations.

title: THAT ELUSIVE CURRENCY PACT
description: The United States and its four principal economic allies may be edging toward agreement on stabilizing their currencies but they are still a considerable distance from an accord, American and foreign officials said here today.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Joe DiMaggio was released yesterday from Mount Sinai Medical Center in Miami Beach following a nine-day stay for a pacemaker implant. The 72-year-old Hall of Fame member had checked into the hospital for treatment of arrhythmia, an abnormally slow heartbeat. . . . The University of Georgia has named Dr. Charles Knapp as its new president and the 40-year-old Tulane University administrator will succeed the interim president, Henry King Stanford, July 1. Stanford replaced Fred Davison, who resigned last year after Jan Kemp, an English teacher, received a $1.08 million settlement of a lawsuit in which a jury agreed she had been improperly dismissed for protesting preferential treatment of athletes at Georgia.

title: DAVID BROMBERG, GUITAR
description: The guitarist David Bromberg will lead a big band this weekend at the Botton Line, 15 West Fourth Street. Shows are at 8:30 and 11:30 tonight, 8 and 10 P.M. Sunday; tickets are $12. Information: 228-6300.

title: HELIX TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $575,000.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''THE GOOD FATHER'' stars Anthony Hopkins as a middle-aged man fighting for what he might call ''male liberation.'' It depicts the fury of a liberal British publishing executive whose wife has left him for another man and who is forced to see his 6-year-old child only on weekends.

title: Poland Bank Note Plan
description: After five consecutive years of double-digit inflation, the National Bank of Poland has announced plans to start printing 10,000-zloty bank notes, double the denomination of the largest bank note now circulated, the official Polish press agency, P.A.P., said today. Earlier this month, the Government said prices rose by 18 percent last year, compared with a 15 percent inflation rate in 1985. The largest bank note currently in circulation, a 5,000-zloty note, was introduced in 1982 and has a portrait of the Polish composer Chopin. The new 10,000-zloty bank note, worth $42 at the official exchange rate, would bear the portrait of the late Polish painter and playwright Stanislaw Wyspianski.

title: 'Doctor Zhivago' to See Print in Soviet in '88
description: A commission reviewing the work of Boris Pasternak received a written promise today that his novel ''Doctor Zhivago'' will be published serially beginning early in 1988, according to commission members.

title: THE SAN FRANSISCO
description: The San Francisco Symphony, under the direction of Herbert Blomstedt, will play the New York premiere of Charles Wuorinen's ''Golden Dnce,'' tonight at 8 o'clock at Carnegie Hall. The program includes Brahm's Symphony No. 1 and the ''Firebird'' Suite by Igor Stravinsky. Tickets are $12.50 to $16; information: 247-7800.

title: UCCEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $182,000 and a tax credit of $2,533,000. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $7,556,000 and a tax credit of $7,355,000. d-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $408,000 and $425,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a tax credit of $2,364,000 and $5,044,000 for the same periods, respectively. Year-ago periods are restated to reflect non-software operations that were sold and discontinued by the company.

title: IOSIF BEGUN, A DEFIANT MAN
description: Iosif Z. Begun once wrote to his wife, after one of her requests to visit him in Chistopol prison had been turned down, that he was doing his best to avoid bothering the authorities so that they would relent.

title: SCOUTING
description: Give Dean Smith his due, by all means, for 600 victories. Fact is, though, he takes a distant backseat to Dick Baldwin.

title: AIDS DOUBTS CITED IN LIBERACE DEATH
description: There was enough doubt about whether Liberace had AIDS to justify his doctor's decision to protect the showman's privacy by reporting heart failure as the cause of death, the physician's attorney said today.

title: The 1099 Drought of 1987
description: There's more tax frustration this year because of the Internal Revenue Service's Form 1099 - or rather the lack of it. The nine different versions of 1099 are the slips on which employers, banks, dividend-paying corporations and other payers tell recipients every February how much money they received in the previous year. A copy goes to Internal Revenue, whose computers match them up with individual tax returns in order to detect discrepancies.

title: ARBITRAGERS WORRIED BY ARRESTS
description: Although Wall Street had been bracing for months for a new round of charges in the insider-trading scandal, the news yesterday of the arrest of three arbitragers from two of its most prestigious investment-banking firms set off a wave of shock and fear.

title: Sammy Price, Blues
description: The blues pianist-singer Sammy Price will perform tonight and tomorrow at the Abilene Cafe, 359 Second Avenue, at 21st Street. Shows are at approximately 9:30 P.M. and midnight, with Little Mike and his Blue Band opening; there is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum. Information: 473-8908.

title: Jewish Center Names 74 as Suspected Nazis
description: A Jewish center said today that it had turned over to the Justice Department the names of 74 people suspected of being Nazi war criminals who came to the United States after serving in German military units that murdered tens of thousands of Jews in Eastern Europe in World War II.

title: Judge Approves Pact For Nassau Police
description: A two-year dispute between the United States Justice Department and Nassau County over the treatment of blacks in the county's Police Department appeared to be resolved today.

title: STANDARD REGISTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. INQUIRY WIDENS
description: Three top financial professionals on Wall Street have been arrested and charged with insider trading that Federal prosecutors said had produced millions of dollars in illegal profits.

title: BRUNSWICK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect the 2-for-1 stock split effective Feb. 14, 1986. The company said the 1985 fourth quarter increased by $6.1 million, or 14 cents a share, due to a change in the annual effective tax rate to 38.5 percent for the year from the estimated rate of 43 percent used for the first nine months.

title: Chairman Chosen At A.C. Nielsen
description: John C. Holt yesterday was named chairman and chief executive of the A. C. Nielsen Company, a subsidiary of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation that is best known to the public as a monitor of television viewing tastes.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday ONE MAN'S VISIONS

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: 2 From Vermont Bench Deny They Violated Ethics Canons
description: A Vermont Supreme Court justice and a former assistant judge accused of misconduct have denied that they broke any canons of judicial ethics.

title: OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted. The results in both years include after-tax gains from asset dispositions and the adjustments of certain reserves of $222 million in 1986 and $731 million in 1985, of which $9 million, or 6 cents a share, and $241 million, or $2.29 a share, respectively, were included as extraordinary items, reflecting the federal income tax benefit realized from the applications of a capital loss carryforward to offset capital gains. The 1986 year earnings included net gains of $115.8 million from the sale of various foreign and domestic oil and gas properties in addition to other items. The company said earnings for the 1985 fourth quarter included $35 million of net gains from asset dispositions, less provisions for certain reserves, including an extraordinary gain of $19 million, or 17 cents a share. The 1985 earnings included net gains of about $479.2 million, of which $22.8 million occured in the fourth quarter from the sale of various foreign and domestic oil and gas interests, adjustment of certain reserves and the writedown of certain properties. Occidental said its corporate results in 1986 included a net gain of $106 million in interest and other income from the sale of its 20 percent interest in Southland Corp. The benefit of this gain was more than offset by the reduced equity earnings from Southland and Canadian Occidental Petroleum Ltd., and by reduced interest income. The Tax Reform Act of 1986 increased Occidental's fourth quarter 1986 tax provision by $16 million.

title: PENN ENDS REQUIRED STUDIES FOR THE PREMEDICAL STUDENT
description: In another effort to broaden the undergraduate education of the country's premedical students, the University of Pennsylvania has eliminated all course requirements for admission to its School of Medicine and will no longer even recommend undergraduate courses.

title: Bondholder Pact With Boesky
description: A limited partnership concern established by Ivan F. Boesky said today that it had reached agreement with all but one of its bondholders to pay off $640 million in borrowings, plus some interest.

title: THE MANY FACETS OF PAUL KLEE, AT THE MODERN
description: PAUL KLEE'S inventiveness, imagination and wit have made him a popular, if not beloved, figure. Of all the 20th-century artists, perhaps only Picasso and Matisse have clearly been more influential. Klee's ability to work figuratively and abstractly, to make a few lines read like a dramatic script and to make the same color freeze, throb and glow inspired Joan Miro, Andre Masson, Saul Steinberg, Mark Rothko, Adolph Gottlieb, Robert Motherwell and many others.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 13, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Moscow protesters were punched by plainclothesmen in the firmest crackdown on public dissent there in more than a year. The demonstrators were seeking the release of a Jewish dissident, Iosif Z. Begun. Page A1 ''Dr. Zhivago'' will be published serially beginning next January in a Soviet literary periodical, according to a written promise received by a Moscow panel reviewing the work of Boris Pasternak. A5 The U.S. is falling behind Japan in the quality of technology and innovation in integrated circuits, a Pentagon panel said. It said the nation's edge in semiconductor technology must be restored. A1 Bubonic plague struck 41 villages in Brazil, killing five people. Health authorities in Brazil also report high and growing levels of malaria, tuberculosis, leprosy, polio, yellow fever and venereal diseases. A3 If the contras don't perform better, the American people will stop backing them, according to Adm. William C. Crowe Jr., chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. A3 The U.S. has proposed arms sales to some Arab countries. But early signs suggest the initiative may be sufficient only to raise Israeli objections and insufficient to mollify the Arab countries. A14 About 7,000 Iranians were executed after the ouster of the Shah in 1979, according to a United Nations report issued in Geneva. It charged that torture and summary executions were still widespread. A13 A growing Syria-P.L.O. split was reflected in the storming of the office of a Marxist Palestinian group in Damascus and the arrest of one of its leaders by troops, according to Beirut radio stations. A12 Pretoria has jailed black children aged 11 or younger, the Government acknowledged. It said that 4,000 detainees included 281 children, 3 of them under 12, 18 under 13 and 91 under 14. A10 NATIONAL A16-19, D18-19 Insider trading charges assertedly involving millions of dollars were leveled against three top Wall Street financial professionals. Those arrested are Robert M. Freeman, Richard B. Wigton and Timothy L. Tabor. A1 The abrupt arrests of three Wall Street figures indicates that the Government feels it now has enough evidence on insider trading abuses to bring charges against important individuals whether they cooperate or not. A1 New health benefits for the aged became virtually certain as President Reagan proposed expansion of Medicare to pay for catastrophic illnesses. Lawmakers from both parties strongly back such legislation. A1 Cocaine has made billionaires of a handful of little known Colombians. One suspected titan, Carlos Enrique Lehder Rivas, is under heavy guard somewhere in Florida, facing decades in prison. A1 An all-white jury awarded $7 million in damages against the United Klans of America and six past and present Klansmen in the 1981 slaying of a black youth, 19-year-old Michael Donald, in Mobile, Ala. A1 Judicial appointments made by the Reagan Administration were assailed by Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont. He said the Federal courts could become a white-male ''bastion of mediocrity.'' A17 More premed liberal arts courses are urged by the University of Pennsylvania. It has dropped all course requirements for admission to its School of Medicine and will not recommend undergraduate courses. A16 A Titan 3B rocket was launched by the Air Force. The successful launching of a classified payload by the rocket came after two consecutive failures in the last 18 months. A17 A virus that infects cats is similiar to the one that causes AIDS in humans, according to researchers who discovered the virus. They said there was no indication that the feline virus could infect humans. B4 The Navy Secretary is resigning, the Pentagon announced. The departing Secretary, John F. Lehman Jr., is expected to work for the Republican Presidential campaign of Vice President Bush. D18 George Bush voiced reservations about the Iran arms affair to high officials carrying out the policy, the Vice President said. Mr. Bush also said he was ''man enough to take the associational guilt.'' A16 Californians view Mario Cuomo as interesting but mysterious. After a short visit there, many Californians said the New York Governor was articulate and appealing but at times arrogant and thin-skinned. B2 Liberace death report defended D20 WASHINGTON TALK A18 The Miranda ruling: Complain, complain, complain Lincoln and his ghosts REGIONAL B1-5 A ban on homosexuals' use of some Roman Catholic facilities in Brooklyn and Queens has been ordered by Bishop Francis J. Mugavero. He told his 850 priests to bar groups that condone homosexual activity. A1 An undertaker embalms AIDS victims for 20 other funeral directors who refuse to touch the bodies, the undertaker, Timothy O'Brien, said. Many people praise him for handling AIDS victims without insult or extra charge. B1 A mob-drug trail will continue in Manhattan despite the critical shooting of a defendant, Pietro Alfano. Lawyers for 19 defendants in the 16-month-old ''pizza connection'' trial had sought a mistrial. B1 Hundreds fled a fire that destroyed 102 apartments in a three-story complex in Edgewater, N.J. No one was reported injured as 700 firefighters battled the blaze, which raged out of control for four hours. B2 Cuomo's visit to California B2 Citizens panel presents awards B2 Drop in alcohol sales to youths B2 Postseason play canceled on S.I. B3 Neediest Cases D20

title: Interest Rates Stage a Retreat
description: Interest rates declined for short- and long-term issues yesterday on the strength of buying by some speculators and investors who had been active sellers earlier in the week and signs that the Federal Reserve is not pushing short-term rates higher as some analysts feared.

title: Philips, Sony Set Audio-Video Plan
description: Philips N.V. of the Netherlands and the Sony Corporation of Japan, two of the world's largest electronics concerns, have agreed on specifications for the marketing of a combined audio-video compact disk player, Philips said. Philips said the two companies had set a world standard specification for the new combination player, just as they did two years ago for compact disks and players. A spokesman, Jan Geel, said the new player would enter the market in the Netherlands this summer, priced from $735 to $980.

title: RUSSIANS ROUGH UP PROTEST GROUP RALLYING 4TH TIME FOR A DISSIDENT
description: Demonstrators protesting on behalf of an imprisoned Jewish dissident today were shoved and punched by plainclothesmen in the roughest crackdown on dissent in Moscow in more than a year.

title: NOT SCHOOL PRAYER, BUT A CONSTITUTIONAL MINUTE
description: To the Editor:

title: Pentagon to Test MX Today
description: The Air Force has scheduled the 16th flight test of the MX missile on Friday at the Vandenberg Air Force Base in California, the Pentagon announced today. The missile, which is capable of carrying 10 nuclear warheads, will be launched from an underground silo and be aimed at the Kwajalein Island missile test range in the Pacific Ocean.

title: UPJOHN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a net gain of $102,000 on sale of discontinued operations. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,549,000 and a gain on sale of discontinued operations of $1,311,000. The company said it had pretax foreign exchange losses of $5.8 million in 1986 compared with pretax foreign exchange gains of $4 million in 1985. The company also said the effective tax rate for the fourth quarter of 1986 was 26 percent, down from 30.5 percent in the fourth quarter of 1985, increasing share earnings by six cents; the tax rate for the full year was 29 percent down from 32 percent in 1985, increasing share earnings by 17 cents.

title: JAPAN TRADE SURPLUS WIDENS
description: Japan's seasonally adjusted trade surplus jumped 19 percent in January from a month earlier, indicating that the turnaround in world trade imbalances is taking longer than expected.

title: RELIANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Reliance Group Inc. is a unit of Reliance Group Holdings Inc.

title: LANE CO AND WOOD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: The latest quarter and year results include an after-tax gain of $353,000, or 4 cents a share, from the sale of assets and a charge of $408,000 relating to the proposed merger of Lane with Interco Inc. The prior year net includes a gain of $900,000, or 11 cents a share, from the sale of assets.

title: NEWMONT MINING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes $50.3 million charge to reduce the carrying values of certain unprofitable copper operations and investments. c-Includes $77.4 million of non- recurring gains and $50.3 million charge mentioned in quarter. d-Includes $56.5 million provision for losses on properties and investments. e-Net loss and includes $58.6 million provision for losses on properties and investments.

title: Embassy in Soviet Reassigns Marines for Currency Crimes
description: Several Marine guards were reassigned from their postings at the American Embassy here after an internal investigation indicated they had been involved in illegal currency transactions, Ambassador Arthur A. Hartman said today.

title: CITIZENS COMMITTEE HONORS NEW YORKERS FOR SERVICE TO PUBLIC
description: The house next to Edna Robinson's on 97th Street in Corona, Queens, burned down in 1976. Garbage began to pile up on the lot. ''I couldn't even open my window there was so much stench,'' she said.

title: ENERGY FACTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Answering Phones And Gaining Power
description: The phone rang one afternoon this week. It was the Nuclear Regulatory Commission calling and Nora Bredes was there to answer it.

title: CIGNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $28.6 million and $156.8 million for the quarter and year, respectively, and extraordinary tax credits of $83 million for the quarter and $125.6 million for the year. c-Net loss and after capital gains of $70.6 million for the quarter and $122.1 million for the year.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Courting Arabs Washington has proposed new arms sales to Arab countries and begun some subtle diplomatic maneuvering in the Middle East. Page A14.

title: NETS KEEP SLIDING, 121-99
description: Nothing changed. The Nets, a team trapped in a losing streak with no apparent end, faded again tonight. Now, even the excuses have become familiar.

title: THE PLAGUE IS PART OF A BRAZIL CRISIS
description: In the dry scrublands behind the coast of northeast Brazil, where peasants have been hardened by famines, drought and the premature death of loved ones, the churches have filled again with supplicants.

title: DOLE SEEKS BUDGET INCREASE FOR AIR SAFETY
description: Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole asked Congress today for more money to expand the nation's aviation system and to hire more air traffic controllers.

title: What Heisenberg Was Uncertain About
description: To the Editor:

title: RESTAURANTS
description: YOU enter the dining room at Chez Louis and pass a long serving station where waiters hack away at sizzling roast chickens and divvy up portions of hulking prime ribs and wildly aromatic suckling pig. A perusal of the premises, where tables fairly sag under the weight of he-man portions, reveals that this year-and-a-half-old restaurant is for serious no-holds-barred eaters. Quantity, though, is not its only distinguishing feature. Most of the food is very good.

title: STATER BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
HEALTH-CHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $60,000 for the quarter and $259,000 for the year, and includes gains on the disposal of discontinued operations of $237,000 for the quarter and $157,00 for the year. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $175,000 for the quarter and $632,000 for the year, and also after a loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $2,252,000 for the quarter and year. Year-ago figures are restated to reflect the sale of the Vincent Lippe division last October.

title: Pan Am Estimates $400 Million Loss
description: C. Edward Acker, chairman and chief executive of the Pan Am Corporation, estimated that the airline company's losses for 1986 would total more than $400 million. With the carrier having lost $265 million in the first nine months, he said, Pan Am would probably lose more than $135 million in the fourth quarter, or slightly more than some analysts had predicted.

title: FILM: 'FACES,' TWO IVORY COAST TALES
description: DESIRE ECARE'S ''Faces of Women,'' opening today at the Lincoln Plaza Cinema, is a technically rough, cheerfully rude, folkloric comedy about the status of women in the Ivory Coast, where Mr. Ecare was born and raised. It is, in fact, two separate fables with a common frame, that of a street festival where the singing and dancing is nonstop.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: Assets of the nation's 379 money market mutual funds decreased $15.8 million, to $236.01 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 91 institutional funds were down $452.6 million, to $65.32 billion. Assets of the 196 general purpose funds were up $156.1 million, to $62.99 billion. The 92 broker-dealer funds rose $280.7 million, to $107.71 billion.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THEY first met in an elevator at Time magazine. The relationship did not get off the ground, however, until they met again at the Moondance Diner on April Fools' Day. Now, four years later, Alexa Grace and Robert Stevens - she's an artist, he's a photo editor at Time -are to be married at dusk on Saturday, Valentine's Day, in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.

title: U.S. MARSHALS ARREST SUSPECT IN 2 ARGENTINIAN KIDNAPPINGS
description: A fugitive wanted in Argentina on charges of kidnapping and making $2.5 million in extortion demands was arrested yesterday on a midtown Manhattan street, the United States Marshals Service in Manhattan said.

title: Lott Considers the Senate
description: By WAYentative Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican whip in the House of Representatives, is telling friends that he almost certainly will run next year for the Senate seat now held by John Stennis, a Democrat.

title: REAGAN ALLY SHUNS JOB IN WHITE HOUSE
description: Stuart K. Spencer, a longtime political associate of President Reagan, turned down an offer of a White House job today, saying he had ''too many personal commitments to keep'' in California.

title: DINING OUT: SUNDAY
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AMBASSADOR GRILL, 1 United Nations Plaza, First Avenue at 44th Street (355-3400) - * (Oct. 3, 1986) Smoky glass panels and starry lighting contribute to the modern urbane setting at this East Side hotel restaurant that is open for dinner on Sunday evenings. Half the menu is devoted to the foods of Gascony in the southwest of France, the region of ducks, geese, foie gras, confit and truffles. The best starter is the warm duck foie gras salad, which has rare-grilled salmon paired with the foie gras. Other good choices are poached shrimp in Sauternes sauce and tartar of two salmons. Main course selections include duck cassoulet; grilled John Dory rolled around a stuffing of shrimp and scallop mousse with mustard sauce; poached Black Angus filet with fresh herb and sabayon sauce; and lamb chops with minced vegetables. Prix-fixe dinner $24. Fridays, noon to 2:30 P.M. and 6 to 10:30 P.M.; Saturdays, 11:30 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. and 6 to 10:30 P.M.; Sundays, 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. and 6 to 10:30 P.M. THE BLACK SHEEP, 344 West 11th Street (242-1010) - * (April 22, 1983) A romantic charm permeates this informal and convivial West Village bistro, which makes a pleasant setting for a Sunday evening meal. Appetizers are grilled sweet peppers and eggplant with homemade sausage and polenta; sea scallops and mussels in a fumet broth with julienne of carrots and leeks; and glazed baby artichokes with ham, white wine and fresh herbs. Main dishes include duckling cooked two ways - the dark meat is braised in red wine and the skinned breast is grilled - with an Armagnac demigloss, apricots and prunes; roasted loin of veal stuffed with garlic, rosemary and chanterelles, and roast rack of lamb with white beans and smoked bacon.

title: AN ALL-AMERICAN FEAST OF MUSIC ON WNYC
description: When do classical-music radio stations broadcast a lot more than just mainstream classical music? When they're WNYC, the venturesome public-radio station at 93.9 on your FM dial, and especially when they're WNYC in the midst of an annual American Music Festival week.

title: Foote, Cone Net Falls
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications reported its fourth-quarter earnings yesterday. On revenues of $86.85 million, down 1.5 percent from the $88.2 million in the fourth quarter of 1985, there was a net income of $4.1 million, or 98 cents a share, a drop of 48.1 percent from $7.9 million, or $1.89 a share, a year earlier.

title: MUSIC: IMPROVISING TRIO OPENS SERIES AT KITCHEN
description: FOR 15 years, the Kitchen has counted as a center for ''downtown'' performing arts.

title: U.S. and Allies to Reopen Talks on Space Station
description: The United States and its potential partners in a planned orbiting space station concluded a critical two-day meeting in Washington yesterday with an agreement to resume negotiations aimed at developing a facility that would be used for ''peaceful purposes'' and establishing the basis for long-term cooperative ventures in space.

title: A SUBWAY WALKER SEARCHES THE LABYRINTH FOR PROBLEMS
description: When Charles L. Stanford wants to take a walk, he often heads for the subway. As chief engineer of the Transit Authority's track and structures department, the tunnels are his domain and his feet the preferred means of conveyance.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Can Co., Greenwich, Conn., promoted Michael I. Roth to executive vice president.

title: SOME CHINESE BACK OLD SOVIET PLANS
description: Many of the senior Chinese officials who appear to have profited from the forced resignation last month of Hu Yaobang as Communist Party leader are supporters of traditional Soviet-style economic planning and ideological control.

title: Toyota Is Hurt By Strong Yen
description: The Toyota Motor Company's sales and earnings fell in the first half of its fiscal year for the first time since the mid-1970's, the company said today. In the six months ended Dec. 31, sales were down 4.6 percent and net income was down 44.4 percent.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A listing yesterday of holiday closings for Lincoln's Birthday misstated the schedule for public schools in New York City. They were open yesterday but are closed today.

title: New Deal in Moscow
description: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policies have caused real confusion in the United States. After the last plenum of the Central Committee, for example, we gave far too much significance to a meaningless suggestion about a secret ballot in party elections but ignored the simultaneous publication of a law on joint ventures based on foreign investment, which could be absolutely crucial.

title: U.S. DECISION IS NEAR ON ENDING POLISH SANCTIONS
description: President Reagan will decide in the next two weeks whether to restore trade benefits to Poland that were suspended in 1982 in response to the outlawing of the Solidarity movement, according to high-ranking Administration officials.

title: DUQUESNE LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said two refunds approved by the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission represented nearly 40 cents of the overall decrease of 47 cents a share in 1986.

title: Rick Pitino: Reviving February
description: It was only last year that the Big East Conference was a victim of its own excesses. Friends from Georgetown and St. John's and Villanova could relax through the most murderous midseason game, making plans to share a house at the Final Four, which happened in Kentucky in 1985. Who gets the upstairs bedroom with the Jacuzzi?

title: PIANO SINGER WHO STILLS THE ROOM
description: THE basic task of the typical cabaret singer-pianist is modest: to fill silence by unobtrusively establishing a mood of nostalgic conviviality. But Ann Hampton Callaway is one of a handful of young singing pianists who, with little fanfare, can bring a crowded room to a hush. The Chicago-born singer, who is ensconced in the main dining room at the Backstage Restaurant and Cabaret (318 East 45th Street) Thursday through Saturday evenings, has appeared in 40 to 50 restaurants and clubs around the city over the last seven years. In that time, she has refined piano-bar entertainment into a very personal art.

title: NORTH FROM THE BATTERY, SEEKING WASHINGTONIANA
description: NEW YORK was once George Washington's town. He drank at Fraunces Tavern, commanded the Continental Army from the Morris-Jumel Mansion, took his Presidential oath at Federal Hall and prayed at St. Paul's Chapel. Two centuries later these places still stand, with furnishings and relics that reveal varied facets and some little-known facts of the official and personal life of the first President.

title: HOME FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (SAN DIEGO,CALIF) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a one-time gain from the sale of the company's $333 million credit card portfolio. The company did not disclose the size of the one- time gain.

description: b-Net income and includes tax credits of $1.6 million for the quarter and $20.6 million for the year.

description: To the Editor:

title: Richard B. Wigton
description: When Federal marshals finished arresting three prominent arbitragers in its latest round of insider-trading charges, word spread quickly yesterday from trading desk to trading desk on Wall Street. But that was not so much because the scandal had grown, but rather that the individuals named seemed to be among the least likely to be charged.

title: Chamber Symphony
description: The New York Chamber Symphony will play music by Boyce, Vivaldi, Bach, Telemann and Lully tomorrow night at 8 o'clock at the 92d Street Y. Anthony Newman will conduct from the harpsichord; soloists will include the violist Jean Dane and the oboist Randall Ellis. Tickets are $12.50 to $17.50. Information: 996-1100.

title: SCOUTING
description: To what extent has Wayne Gretzky dominated the N.H.L.? It's been six years since the league instituted player-of-the-month awards, and their distribution now looks this way: Wayne Gretzky 23 Mike Bossy 5 Pete Peeters *1 1/2 Bob Froese *1 1/2 Charlie Simmer 1 Mike Rogers 1 Dan Bouchard 1 Marcel Dionne 1 Mario Gosselin 1 Rejean Lemelin 1 Don Beaupre 1 Mario Lemieux 1 Brian Hayward * 1/2 Pelle Lindbergh * 1/2 *Fractions indicate a shared award.

title: VERTICAL MARATHON AN ELEVATING EVENT
description: Al Waquie won his fifth straight race up the Empire State Building yesterday, climbing the 1,575 steps in 11 minutes 56 seconds on a bad knee.

title: ARRESTS INDICATE GET-TOUGH VIEW OF OFFICE CRIME
description: The abrupt arrest of three prominent figures on Wall Street indicates that the Government now feels it has the upper hand against insider trading abuses, having gathered enough evidence to bring charges against important individuals whether they cooperate or not.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: PAST TENSE. Volume I. Diaries. By Jean Cocteau. Introduction by Ned Rorem.

title: SYRIAN ARMY RAIDS PALESTINIAN GROUP
description: Troops in Damascus stormed the office of a Marxist Palestinian group today and arrested one of its leaders in another sign of the growing split between Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization, Beirut radio stations reported.

title: TAMBRANDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $4,266,000 from a product replacement program.

title: CELANESE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain on the sale of assets of $12 million, as well as an after-tax costs of $20 million related to the company's pending merger with American Hoechst Corp.

title: MUSIC: 'STILL LIVES'
description: PHILIP GLASS, Laurie Anderson and do-it-yourself electronic minimalists were among the subjects that the experimental composer William Hellermann amusingly twitted in his performance art music piece ''Still Lives'' at the Alternative Museum on Wednesday evening.

title: DOUBLE WHAMMY
description: To the Editor:

title: CLEVELAND ORCHESTRA
description: The Cleveland Orchestra, under the direction of Christoph von Dohamanyl, will play Berg's Chamber Concerto for Piano, Violin and Thirteen Wind Instruments and Beethoven's Symphony No. 7 tonight at 8 o'clock at Avery Fisher Hall. The soloists in the Berg work will be the pianist Joela Jones and the violinist Daniel Majeske. Tickets are $12 to $25; information: 874-2424.

title: Corporations Can Play A Role in Education
description: To the Editor:

description: The latest quarter and year nets include an after-tax restructuring provision of $4 million, or 9 cents a share.

description: When Federal marshals finished arresting three prominent arbitragers in its latest round of insider-trading charges, word spread quickly yesterday from trading desk to trading desk on Wall Street. But that was not so much because the scandal had grown, but rather that the individuals named seemed to be among the least likely to be charged.

title: Partners Sought In Bid for Lucky
description: The New York investor Asher B. Edelman said that he had asked third parties to join him in a renewed attempt to seek control of Lucky Stores Inc. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Edelman, the chairman of the Datapoint Corporation, did not disclose the names of the parties with which he held the ''preliminary discussions,'' and he said no agreements had been reached.

title: COMPROMISE ON OLYMPIC SITES
description: Juan Antonio Samaranch, the president of the International Olympic Committee, said today that North Korea had agreed in principle to a compromise proposal for sharing the 1988 Summer Games with South Korea.

title: Ishmael and Isaac
description: To the Editor:

title: RETAIL SALES IN JANUARY PLUNGED A RECORD 5.8%
description: The nation's total retail sales dropped a record 5.8 percent last month as auto sales plunged an unprecedented 22.4 percent, the Government reported today.

title: SCOUTING
description: Gaspar Moschera, one of the leading trainers at Aqueduct, would be well advised to take a little less interest in his job. After the stewards banished him from the grounds for 30 days at the beginning of the year for failure to provide worker's compensation insurance for his backstretch help, he made the mistake of answering the phone at his barn while on a surreptitious visit Jan. 29. The steward at the other end of the line saw to it that the suspension was extended 15 days.

title: PULLMAN COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $894,000, or 2 cents a share. The results for the year-ago quarter have been restated for discontinued operations which reflect the fiscal 1986 sales of certain manufacturing businesses and an equipment leasing company. The results in fiscal 1986 included the operations of Peabody International Corp. which was acquired in October 1985. The company was formerly named the Pullman-Peabody Co.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: CUOMO PUTS HUMOR TO WORK ON CALIFORNIA TRIP
description: The story, as Governor Cuomo told it here Wednesday night, went like this:

title: Brooklyn Man Held in Rapes; Police Link Him to 10 Attacks
description: A 20-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday and charged with raping and robbing six women over the last two years, the police said. He is a suspect in four other rapes.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We see in recent incidents in Hoawrd Beach, N.Y., and Foryth County, Ga., that racism is still with us, North and South.

title: SCHLUMBERGER LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $312,295,000 and $363,021,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the quarter and year losses from continuing operations includes non-recurring charges of $1.74 billion; latest-quarter loss from discontinued operations includes unusual charges of $464 million, and the year loss from discontinued operations had unusual charges of $486 million. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $543,122,000. d-Net income and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $626,614,000. The company said its loss from discontinued operations in the latest quarter and year represents those operations of Fairchild Semiconductor.

title: You Must See My Collection
description: LEAD: Not long ago, I met a couple who has amassed a startling collection of artifacts shaped like snails or bearing snail designs. They have around 1,000 of these objects: carpets depicting snails, snail-shaped loaves, snail cuff links, snail pendants, snail brooches, etc.

title: HODGSON HOUSES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Burger Considers Gulag
description: At a briefing on the progress of the observation of the Constitution's 200th birthday, Warren E. Burger, the chairman of the bicentennial commission, remarked on the right of Americans to criticize their government. He compared that right favorably with the limited freedom enjoyed in the Soviet Union, even with the recent moves by the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, to release some political dissenters from prison.

title: VERDICT IN ALABAMA COULD RUIN KLAN GROUP, EXPERT SAYS
description: The $7 million verdict by an Alabama jury against the United Klans of America threatens the organization's financial survival and its popularity among potential members, an expert on Klan activity said yesterday.

title: SHOOTING BRINGS A MOTION FOR MISTRIAL IN MOB CASE
description: Defense lawyers in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial pleaded for a mistrial yesterday, arguing that an ''atmosphere of fear'' afflicted the case after the shooting of a defendant on Wednesday.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Hamiett Bluiett and Ed Blackwell, Jazztrack, Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street (645-2387). Hamiett Bluiett is, without question, the leading baritone saxophonist of the 1980's, with a big, blustery tone, astonishing fluency, a command of upper octaves only he knows how to reach and a style steeped in the blues. He'll be playing duets with the drummer Ed Blackwell, whose beat was behind many of Ornette Coleman's finest records - and who makes odd, asymmetrical rhythms swing as simply as rat-a-tat-tat. Tomorrow at 8 and 10 P.M.; tickets are $10.

title: CONTINENTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized capital gains of $42.5 million for the quarter and $226.4 million for the year. c-Net loss d-After realized capital gains of $64.9 million and $115 million for the quarter and year, respectively, and the quarter also includes a loss from discontinued operations of $300,000. The company said in the year-ago fourth quarter it took a charge of $220 million against operating earnings to strengthen reserves and to provide for doubtful reinsurance recoverable.

title: STANDARD COMMERCIAL TOACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $189,000 and $271,000 in the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $633,000 and $1,433,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Share earnings have been adjusted for the 3-for-2 stock split effective February 1986.

description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY
