title: Coghlan Aims to Top His Best
description: Last Monday, Eamonn Coghlan tried to talk his way out of tomorrow night's Meadowlands Mile. Now he says his workouts this week have been so good that he will run the mile and thinks he can better his world indoor best.

title: Hill Holliday Connors Gets 3 Gillette Products
description: Hill Holliday Connors Cosmopulos in Boston has been named agency for three brands from Gillette's Personal Products division: Good News Toiletries, which had been at Young & Rubicam; Aapri, a facial scrub formerly at N. W. Ayer, and Deep Magic Cleansing Lotions, which Gillette hopes to revive.

title: West German Economy Flat
description: The West German economy stagnated at the end of last year, as the dollar's fall against the mark reduced the nation's exports, the nation's central bank said today.

title: Mesa to Keep Its 50/ Payout
description: T. Boone Pickens, general partner of Mesa Limited Partnership, said today that Mesa intends to maintain its 50-cent quarterly cash distribution at least through the first quarter of 1988 even though a cutback in its natural gas output would reduce revenues this year. The commitment means

title: N.H.L. STARS STICK TO SIMPLE GAME PLAN
description: Normally at this point of the National Hockey League season, when selfishness is sometimes rewarded and those with imposing statistics wear stars on their uniforms for a night, the consolation prize for unrecognized effort is a day or two at a distant beach.

title: San Francisco Mayor Shuns Race for House
description: Nancy Pelosi, who has raised millions of dollars for the Democratic Party, announced her candidacy for the House of Representatives today, a few hours after Mayor Dianne Feinstein said she would not enter the race.

title: THERMO ELECTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 50-percent stock dividend paid Oct. 31, 1986.

title: New York City's Program to Recycle Waste Is Well Under Way
description: To the Editor:

title: A NAVY WEDTECH MEMO MISSTATED NOFZIGER POST
description: A 1984 Navy memorandum describing an inquiry by Lyn Nofziger on behalf of the Wedtech Corporation identified him as ''the President's Political Advisor'' even though he had left the White House staff 13 months earlier.

title: RESEARCHERS DISCOVER AN AIDS-LIKE VIRUS IN CATS
description: Researchers have discovered a virus that causes diseases in domestic cats and is similar to the one that causes AIDS in humans, a development that they say could make the cat a useful animal model for research on acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

title: Black-History Events This Weekend
description: Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street. ''Harlem Renaissance:

title: Kaiser Steel Files Chapter 11 Petition
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation, once a key element of the industrialist Henry J. Kaiser's business empire, said today that it had filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: ADVERTISING
description: People

title: First U.S. Biathlon Medal
description: Josh Thompson of Gunnison, Colo., became the first American ever to win a medal at the biathlon world championships when he captured the silver medal today in the men's 20-kilometer event behind Frank-Peter Roetsch of East Germany.

title: CAMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said in May 1985 it sold its American Technology Corporation subsidiary to Citicorp International Trading Company. An after-tax gain of 10 cents a share was recognized in the second quarter of 1985 as a result of this transaction.

title: ASPIN CRITICIZES BOMBER COST
description: The $802 million requested by the Air Force to fix the B-1 bomber is only part of what will be needed, and the final cost may be more than $3 billion, Representative Les Aspin, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said in a statement released today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary on Jan. 29 of Frank M. Katz, a New York philanthropist and chairman of a sales promotion and advertising company, misidentified the architectural firm to which he was apprenticed. It was McKim, Mead & White.

title: Teams Moving Away From Rough Play
description: College hockey appears to have reversed a trend toward rough play and violence this season, according to coaches and administrators. If this continues, and the college game resumes its emphasis on speed and stick-handling, it will again set itself apart from the National Hockey League.

title: 'AMERICATHON' SCHEDULE
description: Monday's admission-free Americathon 1987 concert at the New School Auditorium, 66 West 12th Street, will consist of a series of interviews with composers, interspersed with a brief concert of each subject's music. The number for information is 669-7748, but the office will be closed tomorrow and Sunday.

title: IN THE CAPITAL: LECTURES, CANAPES AND MAYBE A DATE
description: As one couple was greeted at the door of the Renwick Gallery on a recent evening, the man, with a nod in the direction of his companion, said: ''I'm with her.''

title: G.M. to Eliminate 3,500 More Jobs
description: The General Motors Corporation, America's biggest car maker, said it would lay off 3,500 more workers, effective Feb. 16, as part of its overall cost-cutting and restructuring strategy. The announcement came a day after G.M.'s chairman, Roger B. Smith, reassured shareholders he planned to trim the company's operating costs by $10 billion a year by 1990 and increase earnings.

title: CHAMPION PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BARNES GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $4,324,000. The company the latest fourth quarter results were affected by a $759,000 one-time penalty for the early retirement of high-cost debt, and by the retroactive elimination of the investment tax credit, which reduced net income by $506,000.

title: GENUINE PARTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain from discontinued operations $1,274,000 and a gain on the disposal of discontinued operations of $4,523,000.

title: IN A LAND OF PALACES, SAUDI KING'S IS SPECIAL
description: Even though the oil slump has forced an unfamiliar economic restraint on this country, the building of palaces continues, and one in particular is worth note. It will be the new main home and offices of King Fahd, the seat of a dynasty that started in tents.

title: Fight Corporate Raiders Two Ways
description: Merger mania continues - and along with it, allegations of widespread insider trading on Wall Street. Arrests yesterday of three more securities traders in the Boesky case should add to the pressure for a legislated fix. But poorly targeted legislation could prove worse than no legislation at all.

title: 3M Deal Gives Stock a Bounce
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company sent its stock surging early yesterday when it said it would be announcing a ''major positive business transaction.'' But the stock fell back with the news of the deal, which was relatively small by Wall Street standards.

title: A PENTAGON STUDY URGES U.S. AID FOR THE EMBATTLED CHIP INDUSTRY
description: A Defense Department panel called today for the immediate creation of a Government-industry consortium to restore the country's edge in semiconductor technology.

title: COMPUTER CONSOLES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the year-ago fourth quarter and year include $17.5 million in restructuring charges and inventory writedowns of $5.3 million.

title: BROADWAY
description: JASON ROBARDS is returning to Broadway next month in ''A Month of Sundays.'' The comedy, about a cynical widower who enjoys tormenting the nurses and aides in a retirement home, will be directed by Gene Saks. Mr. Robards will, naturally, play the devilish widower, a considerable change of pace from his last starring role on the Great White Way - his 1985 portrayal of Hickey in ''The Iceman Cometh.''

title: Withholding Clarity - and Forms; What's the W-4 For?
description: The new W-4 withholding form for Federal taxes has infuriated taxpayers and sent the Internal Revenue Service, chastened, back to the drawing board. A new new form or revised instructions, or both, will issue soon. The exercise offers the public and Internal Revenue an important lesson. Reforming the tax process isn't simple.

title: KEY RATES
description: *Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for belwether issues.

title: THE GETTY REPORTS A SCANDAL
description: The J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., acknowledged on Wednesday that Jiri Frel, head of the department of antiquities at the museum, was relieved of his ''curatorial responsibilities'' in April 1984 after an extensive investigation disclosed ''serious violations of the museum's policies and rules regarding donations to the antiquities collection.'' The acknowledgement was made by Harold Williams, president and chief executive officer of the Getty, in a letter to Thomas Hoving, editor of the magazine Conoisseur.

title: COLGATE-PALMOLIVE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a loss of $62,450,000 from disposal of discontinued operations for both the quarter and year, and the year also includes income from discontinued operations of $4,091,000.

title: Guinness in 'Monsignor Quixote'
description: WHILE ABC prepares Sunday night's premiere of the $40 million, 14 1/2-hour production of ''Amerika,'' which presents the specter of a Russian-occupied United States, public television tonight offers a modest, two-hour drama about a Roman Catholic priest and a Marxist politician who come to understand and even love each other. ''Monsignor Quixote,'' based on a story by Graham Greene, is by far the more eloquent of the two presentations. Part of the ''Great Performances'' series, it can be seen at 9 P.M. on Channel 13.

title: TITAN ROCKET, AFTER TWO FAILURES, LAUNCHES SATELLITE FROM AIR BASE
description: The Air Force successfully launched a Titan 3B rocket late Wednesday after two consecutive failures in the last 18 months, Pentagon officials said today. The Defense Department declined to disclose the nature of the rocket payload, saying it was classified.

title: Loss for Norsk Hydro
description: Norsk Hydro A.S., the state-controlled energy concern that is Norway's biggest company, said today that it lost money last year for the first time since 1944. The company, a producer of North Sea oil and gas, fertilizers and aluminum, said it lost 324 million crowns, or $46.9 million, in 1986, in contrast to a profit of 2.08 billion crowns - $301 million - in 1985.

title: NEW YORK TIMES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes equity in earnings of associated companies of $5,497,000 for the quarter and $19,560,000 for the year. c-Includes equity in earnings of associated companies of $4,985,000 for the quarter and $21,387,000 for the year. The latest year results include a second quarter non-recurring interest charge of $8.5 million relating to a June 1986 court decision arising from the company's 1981 acquisition of two cable television systems. The 1985 results include a first quarter non-recurring gain of $2.8 million, or 3 cents a share, from the sale of property in New York City. All share earnings are adjusted for the 2-for-1 stock split in September 1986.

title: BROOKLYN BISHOP LIMITS CHURCH USE BY HOMOSEXUALS
description: The Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn has told his 850 priests that groups that condone homosexual activity will no longer be allowed to use churches, hospitals or colleges for meetings or religious services. The ban applies to the two boroughs in the diocese, Brooklyn and Queens.

title: Miranda Ruling: Complain, Complain, Complain
description: Eighteen months ago Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d denounced as ''infamous'' and ''wrong'' the Supreme Court's ruling in Miranda v. Arizona that the police must tell arrested suspects of their rights to remain silent and to have legal counsel.

title: C-COR ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $938,000 and $1,117,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: SCXOUTING
description: For one recruit it snared, Penn State can thank God, literally. Dave Daniels, a wide receiver from Sarasota, Fla., says he struggled for a while to choose among pursuing schools. ''So I asked God to help me,'' he told The Centre Daily Times of State College, Pa. ''That night I had a dream. I dreamed I walked out on a football field for warm-ups, and when I looked up at the head coach it was Joe Paterno.''

title: PRAVDA MIRRORS THE NEW OPENNESS, UP TO A POINT
description: These are demanding times for Viktor G. Afanasyev, the editor of Pravda. Some readers have their own ideas how the Communist daily should do its job.

title: TEXT OF STATEMENTS BY REAGAN AND WHITE HOUSE
description: Following are the text of a statement issued today by President Reagan on a plan for health insurance for catastrophic illness and a White House statement describing the proposal: REAGAN STATEMENT

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: WHENEVER I peek into a new restaurant to see if it might be worth investigating I focus on two things: the food and the expressions on customers' faces. Both were encouraging at Pasta Presto, a bright and cheerful new pasta house on Second Avenue between 33d and 34th Streets, where a satisfying three-course dinner with wine can be had for $15 or less. No wonder everyone was smiling.

title: Pat Nixon Released From Hospital
description: Pat Nixon the former First Lady, left Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan yesterday, two days after surgery to remove a small cancerous tumor from her mouth, a hospital spokeswoman said.

title: Reorganization At DDB Needham
description: DDB Needham Worldwide, the result of the merger of the Doyle Dane Bernbach Group and Needham Harper Worldwide under the Omnicom Group, has done a bit of restructuring and title-bestowing under the direction of Keith Reinhard, the chairman and chief executive, and John Bernbach, the president and chief operating officer.

title: CENTRAL HOLDING reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JULES BERGMAN, 57, SCIENCE EDITOR OF ABC NEWS FOR 25 YEARS, DIES
description: Jules Bergman, science editor of ABC News for more than 25 years, was found dead yesterday in his apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was 57 years old. The police said Mr. Bergman's body was found by a maid, Argelia Torres, in a bathtub with scalding water running. A spokeswoman for the police, Sgt. Diane Kubler, said that the drain was open and that Mr. Bergman appeared to have died of natural causes.

title: CHINA, XEROX IN VENTURE
description: The Xerox Corporation and a Chinese computer research institute opened a center today that will use laser printers and a multilingual computer system to produce documents in almost any language, including Chinese.

title: COASTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest year results reflect the effect of a $52 million first quarter loss resulting from the drop in oil prices. Outstanding debt and preferred stock were reduced by $380 million in 1986.

title: ZIGGY MARLEY, REGGAE
description: Ziggy Marley, Bob Marley's son, will lead his reggae band, the Melody Makers, Sunday at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street. Shinehead will open at 9 P.M., with the Melody Makers on at about 10:30; tickets are $13.50 in advance, $15 Sunday. Information: 254-2800.

title: A Contract's Worth
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS McEnroe Ousted: Johan Kriek followed a blistering serve to a 7-5, 6-4 victory last night over John McEnroe in the third round of the United States Indoor Tennis Championships in Memphis. ''Things just don't seem to be going my way recently,'' said McEnroe, who was seeded fifth. Kriek, seeded 11th, ended the match with three aces in a row. He had 12 for the match, and McEnroe had six. In a preceding match, Jimmy Connors came back from a four-game slump in the second set to take a 6-1, 4-6, 6-1 victory over Eliot Teltscher. Connors, seeded second, had easy going in the opening set and stood at 2-1 in the second before Teltscher made his run to go up by 5-2. Stefan Edberg of Sweden, seeded first, had easier going against Ramesh Krishnan of India, taking a 6-3, 6-2 victory. In afternoon play, Mikael Pernfors took a two-set victory over Amos Mansdorf of Israel. (AP) N.B.A. Pistons 113, Cavaliers 109: In Richfield, Ohio, last night, Adrian Dantley scored 25 points, including two free throws that snapped a 109-109 tie with 34 seconds left, as Detroit moved into a tie for first place with Atlanta in the Central Division. Detroit led by 13 points early in the fourth period but the Cavaliers tied it at 107-107 when Brad Daugherty hit a short hook with 1 minute 20 seconds to play. Bill Laimbeer of Detroit and Ron Harper of Cleveland exchanged jump shots before Dantley hit the foul shots that put Detroit ahead for good. (AP) Bucks 106, SuperSonics 104: In Milwaukee, Jack Sikma tipped in a missed shot at the buzzer to give Milwaukee the victory. Ricky Pierce scored 30 points for the Bucks, who withstood a late Seattle rally led by Tom Chambers, who had 14 points in the fourth quarter. Chambers hit a 3-point goal with 40 seconds left to cut Milwaukee's lead to 104-102, then tied the game with two free throws with seven seconds left. John Lucas of Milwaukee rushed the ball to the other end and his shot was deflected by Alton Lister, but Sikma tipped it in. (AP) Bullets 121, Nuggets 115: Moses Malone scored 38 points, 26 in the second half, and the Bullets blew a 14-point lead early in the fourth quarter before rallying for the victory in Denver. It was the first time all season the Bullets won after playing the night before. They had lost 12 previous games under similar circumstances. Washington led, 89-75, heading into the final quarter but a 12-0 Denver run, capped by Danny Schayes' 3-point play, helped even the game at 95-95 with 7:25 left. Darwin Cook's lay-up 58 seconds later gave the Bullets a 99-97 lead, and they never trailed again. (AP) GOLF Burns Leads by One: George Burns birdied nine holes en route to a nine-under-par 63 that gave him a one-shot lead after the first round of the $500,000 Andy Williams Open golf tournament in La Jolla, Calif. J. C. Snead, who scored consecutive victories in this tournament in 1975-76, made an eagle 3 on the final hole for a 64 that tied him with Lon Hinkle for second. Hinkle also scored an eagle, holing out a wedge shot for a 2 on the fourth hole. Burns's effort set a record on the North course at Torrey Pines, at 6,659 yards the shorter and easier of the two courses used for the first two rounds of this tournament. (AP) Rodriguez Leads Seniors: Chi Chi Rodriguez shot a two-under-par 70 to take the first-round lead in the $260,000 PGA Seniors Championship at Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. Rodriguez, a three-time winner in 1986, his first full season on the Senior PGA Tour, was one stroke ahead of Joe Jimenez and Jack Fleck, former PGA Seniors champions. (AP) HORSE RACING High Brite Takes Whirlaway Stakes: High Brite stalked the pace-setting favorite, Light Prospect, into the stretch and went on to score a 2 1/4-length victory in the $69,000 Whirlaway Stakes for 3-year-olds at Aqueduct. Carrying 117 pounds under Chris Antley, High Brite, a son of Best Turn and Spray, went a mile and a sixteenth on the fast track in 1:45 3/5 to earn $41,400 for his owner, Joseph Allen. The victory came in the first start of the year for High Brite, who paid $9.40. AUTO RACING Schrader, Parsons Win Daytona Preliminaries: In Daytona Beach, Fla., Ken Schrader beat Bill Elliott in a photo finish and Benny Parsons held off Bobby Allison by one second to win the twin 125-mile qualifying races for Sunday's Daytona 500. A. J. Foyt was knocked unconscious after a crash in the opening race. The 52-year-old Texan was conscious by the time he reached the infield care center and was taken to Halifax Medical Center for X-rays. He suffered a strained right shoulder and was released with his arm in a sling. The races determined the third through 30th starting positions. (AP)

F.C.C. REFUSES TO INTERVENE IN SCRAMBLING OF TV SIGNALS
description: The Federal Communications Commission unanimously agreed today not to intervene in a controversy involving the scrambling of television transmissions via satellite to keep owners of dish antennas from viewing pay television programs without paying.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 13, 1987
description: The Scandal on Wall Street

title: TALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cheers, and Kicks, in Moscow
description: The mass release of Soviet political prisoners poses an interesting problem for Westerners: finding the right response between churlishness and gullibility. A good formula for praising the opposition was once advanced by Randolph Churchill. By all means do so when deserved, urged Winston's father, but accompany every kiss with a kick.

title: MIDLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ruland Out for Season
description: The Philadelphia 76ers have resigned themselves to the fact that Jeff Ruland, their injured 6-foot-10-inch center, will be out for the season. Ruland, who was acquired in a deal last April that sent Moses Malone to the Washington Bullets, has been ordered to rest his left knee completely. Cartilage in the knee has eroded. Dr. Kenneth DeHaven, who performed arthroscopic surgery on the knee Nov. 19, instructed the player not even to exercise. The doctor examined Ruland yesterday and said that as long as pain persists, Ruland cannot play. . . . Wayne (Tree) Rollins, the Atlanta Hawks center, will be sidelined for about three weeks because of a fracture in his right foot. Rollins was examined for pain from what he thought was a stubbed big toe. Instead, doctors found a large chip that had broken away from the inside corner of the first joint of the toe. ''It will take six weeks to heal,'' said Joe O'Toole, the team's trainer. ''It is conceivable that he could play in three weeks.''

title: FILM: A COMEDY, 'MANNEQUIN'
description: SOMETIMES it's possible to find out everything you need to know about a film in the first minute or two. It's possible with ''Mannequin,'' anyhow. ''Mannequin,'' which opens today at the National and other theaters, starts with an animated credit sequence that looks suspiciously like a Saturday-morning cartoon. Then it has a cute title. (''Edfu, Egypt. A really long time ago. Right before lunch.'') Next there's a scene between a pretty young mummy and what seems, oddly enough, to be her Jewish mother. This scene is played comically but isn't funny.

title: Publisher Asks Reversal On Salinger Biography
description: Random House asked the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit yesterday to reconsider its Dec. 29 decision barring publication of a biography, ''J. D. Salinger: A Writing Life,'' by Ian Hamilton. The court held that the author made unfair use of some 70 unpublished letters written by Mr. Salinger.

title: A REVIVAL OF PROBLEMS IS EXPECTED FOR TEXACO
description: The decision yesterday by a Texas appeals court could create serious problems for Texaco Inc., according to industry analysts and specialists who have followed the struggle.

title: Contra Suppliers Seen As Vowing Not to Talk
description: Americans who took part last year in a purportedly private operation to supply the Nicaraguan rebels had to promise the Government not to divulge secret information they might learn, The Boston Globe reported today.

description: Stars of the stage, movies and television will take part in a gala tribute to Neil Simon and his work, Sunday, March 1, at the Shubert Theater, in a production by Joseph Papp for the benefit of the Yivo Institute for Jewish Research.

title: Game Called Due to Traffic
description: The Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference basketball game scheduled for tonight between St. Peter's and Army was postponed because the bus carrying the Peacocks was stuck in traffic on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway. The team from St. Peter's, which is in Jersey City, was unable to reach the United States Military Academy because of the huge volume of traffic caused by an accident. No date was announced for the makeup game.

title: SHULTZ IN AID PLEA
description: Adm. William C. Crowe Jr., Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, warned here today that the American people would stop supporting the Nicaraguan rebels unless they performed better.

title: SCOUTING
description: Not to spoil anything for those who believe in miracles or love suspense, but much of the 1990 college football season is already history. Wednesday was the day on which this year's prep recruits were allowed to start signing letters of intent, and high school talent specialists say it was Pittsburgh, Texas A&M, Notre Dame, Florida and Oklahoma that came up with the cream of the crop.

title: ALEXANDER BROWN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Few Treaty Violations Found
description: A Stanford University group issued a report here today that found little evidence to support Reagan Administration charges of Soviet cheating on arms control agreements.

title: CHRIS CONNOR, SINGER
description: The singer Chris Connor will give a free concert tonight at 7:30 P.M. at the Fulton Market Building of the South Street Seaport, 10 Fulton Street (732-7678)

title: NEW DONOR TO THE NEEDIEST FULFILLS A PROMISE
description: Each year, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund receives letters from first-time contributors, some of whom have for years intended to help the drive.

title: New York Merc Head To Relinquish Position
description: Michel D. Marks, who is credited with saving the New York Mercantile Exchange after disasters in potato contracts almost put it out of business, said yesterday that he planned to give up the post of chairman of the exchange.

title: Evader Wins One From IRS
description: A convicted tax evader has been awarded $13,000 from the Internal Revenue Service after a Federal judge ruled that one of its agents harassed the man. The plaintiff, Daniel Neal Heller, of Miami, had been convicted on charges of evading income taxes on $250,000 in fees from clients. A 1983 conviction was thrown out after a juror reportedly made racist remarks, but Mr. Heller was convicted again in September. In his opinion, Federal District Judge Alcee Hastings wrote that the I.R.S. agent who investigated the original case, Lawrence S. Plave, had told Mr. Heller's clients and others that he would be indicted, even though a grand jury had not yet been empaneled. The judge said the action showed a ''lack of integrity.''

title: GROLIER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $3.4 million for the quarter and $4.9 million for the year, and the year is after a loss on bond redemptions of $1,712,000. c-Includes tax credits of $900,000 for the quarter and $3.2 million for the year.

title: Man Exposed to AIDS Put Under Quarantine
description: State officials issued a quarantine order Wednesday against a male prostitute who tests showed had been exposed to the AIDS virus.

title: SOUTH AFRICA ACKNOWLEDGES DETENTION OF BLACKS UNDER 12
description: The Government acknowledged today that it had jailed black children 11 years old or younger, and it was challenged to say precisely how many people it had detained in an eight-month-old crackdown on black protest.

title: YOUTH'S BUYING OF ALCOHOL FELL IN '86
description: In the first year after the drinking age in New York State was raised to 21, alcohol purchases among 16- to 20-year-olds declined by half, according to a five-year study released today by the state.

title: On Weather, Time and Space
description: A pedestrian approaching the snow-dusted corner of Fifth Avenue and 24th Street yesterday. Evident was the fact that others, somewhat earlier, had traversed the same small piece of the city.

title: INDIAN MUSEUM TO MAINTAIN A PRESENCE IN HARLEM
description: The Museum of the American Indian has agreed to maintain a satellite museum at its present site, 155th Street and Broadway, even if it takes over most of the historic United States Custom House in lower Manhattan.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Cheney Considers Braille
description: Lynne V. Cheney, chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, wrote an Op-Ed page article recently in which she described her agency's role in trying to assure that every American gets a copy of the Constitution in this bicentennial year. ''Underlying what went on in Philadelphia in 1787,'' Mrs. Cheney wrote in The Washington Post, ''was the notion that this document would belong to the general populace.''

title: 4 Killed and 13 Wounded in Philippine Fighting
description: Four civilians were killed and 13 wounded today when Communist rebels raided a village and bombed a police station, the military said. The deaths raised to 42 the death toll in rebel-related violence reported since a 60-day cease-fire ended Sunday.

title: Disney 'Valentine' Tonight on Channel 4
description: For curmudgeons who complain that popular music has gone to the dogs, that the singers of today are guilty of caterwauling, proof at last is at hand. Look no farther than Channel 4 tonight between 8 and 9 o'clock. There's an hour of popular music, and the screen is filled with dogs and cats.

title: FROM CENTER OF COCAINE TRADE TO A FLORIDA JAIL
description: Carlos Enrique Lehder Rivas rose from peddling marijuana on New York street corners to become one of the titans of the cocaine industry, commanding, officials say, legions of gunmen, racing boats, airplanes, a ranch with a racetrack and even his own small neo-facist party.

title: A Partner's Wild Optimism Can Lead to a Difficult Task
description: An old argument concerns the desirability of two types of partner.

title: BURGLARY SUSPECT DIES AFTER STRUGGLE WITH POLICE
description: A burglary suspect, taken into custody after a violent struggle with police officers, collapsed in a holding cell in a Queens station house early yesterday and was pronounced dead a short time later, the police said.

title: 200 HOMELESS IN JERSEY RIVERFRONT BLAZE
description: Hundreds of people fled into the cold early this morning when a fire engulfed a three-story garden apartment complex here, destroying 102 apartments.

title: ART: 14 PICTOGRAPHS FROM ADOPH GOTTLIEB
description: ONE of the classic devices of picture-making in the middle of our century was the pictograph - the boxed or gridded set of disjunct images that gave us plenty to look at and allowed the painter to work with contrast and paradox. Someone who did these things with notable success was Adolph Gottlieb, whose current show at Knoedler & Company, 19 East 70th Street, consists of 14 pictographs, dated from 1945-51.

title: OFFER TO BUY ROBINS IS DROPPED
description: The American Home Products Corporation said yesterday that it had withdrawn its offer to buy the A. H. Robins Company and to assume the huge legal liabilities of Robins's Dalkon Shield birth-control device.

title: LEHMAN RESIGNING AS NAVY SECRETARY
description: John F. Lehman Jr., the combative Secretary of the Navy, is leaving the Reagan Administration, the Pentagon announced today.

title: Is a Currency Deal Possible?
description: THE United States is still going round and round in a clumsy waltz with its partners in Japan, West Germany, France and Britain over when to hold the next Group of Five meeting. At the start of the week, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d said that no special G-5 meeting had been scheduled, alarming the foreign exchange markets.

title: Marcus Aurelius Rides Again
description: The second-century bronze statue of Marcus Aurelius and his horse will be restored and returned to its place on Capitoline Hill. City officials said Wednesday that they would spend $460,000 to complete restoration of the Emperor's statue, which was removed from the square in front of City Hall in 1981 because of air pollution and other damage.

title: Rubik Theft: Puzzle Solved?
description: Two burglars who broke into the villa of Erno Rubik, inventor of Rubik's Cube, have been arrested, the Hungarian press agency MTI reported today. The men were said to have taken a video recorder from Mr. Rubik's house in January while he was in Japan. They were identified as Tibor Csorba, 27 years old, and Istvan Csaba, 30, both of Budapest. The Government newspaper Magyar Hirlap said earlier that the men may have been in search of new puzzle ideas. It was not known if any were taken.

title: Mattingly Negotiations
description: The Yankees said they were continuing to negotiate with Don Mattingly, their first baseman, on a contract but are preparing to go to arbitration Monday. ''There's still the possibility an agreement could be reached,'' Woody Woodward, the Yankee general manager, said yesterday, ''but both parties are close enough to the arbitration date that it's now time to prepare for it.'' Mattingly, who earned $1,375,000 last season, submitted a salary of $1,975,000, compared with the Yankees' figure of $1,700,000. Jim Krivacs, Mattingly's agent, was not available for comment. . . . Seven players were signed by the Yankees to one-year contracts yesterday, including Pete Filson, a left-handed pitcher who was acquired in a trade from the White Sox.

description: For six months Lloyd Daniels was a talent without a team. But after his latest setback, Daniels, a 19-year-old who starred at Andrew Jackson High School in Queens, may be a talent without much hope.

The exhibition will be closed Monday because of the holiday but will be open 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. weekdays until Feb. 27.

title: More Trade Wind
description: The Senate trade bill, with the wallop of more than 60 co-sponsors, points to protectionist action this year. While too rigid, the bill has two points in its favor. It is mercifully free of specific restrictions on imports or countries and it's less protectionist than the House bill.

description: The movie industry's rating board gave an X rating to Alan Parker's new film, ''Angel Heart,'' last week; today an appeals board narrowly upheld the X.

title: MNX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Topics: HEARTS AND TOWERS; A Valentine for 1987
description: Shy lovers send a heartfelt card, unsigned; The bolder take out ads to air their ardor. On this confession day, O Valentine, Teen-age or temperate, every heart beats harder. Life's pump incarnadine is your regalia; The saint you're named for had no earthly history; In Roman times you were the Lu percalia: Fertility, not romance, was your mystery. We've changed your name, trans mogrified your theme Often to sentiment or mere affec tion Gushed out in pastel tones, words saccharine. Yet still you guide the lover's predi lection; Let critics carp - they only mock your dream Who never felt love's ruby laser beam.

title: EXPERTS SAY VERDICT ON KLAN MAY CHASTEN OTHER RACISTS
description: The $7 million verdict returned by an Alabama jury against the United Klans of America was hailed today by civil rights leaders around the South, while experts on the Klan said it sent a powerful signal to similar extremist groups.

title: Clabir-Atlantic Tie

In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Clabir said that between Feb. 9 and Feb. 12, it bought 80,000 Atlantic Research shares for prices ranging from $32 to $32.625 a share. Clabir reiterated that it is still interested in acquiring Atlantic, even though the diversified high technology firm has said it is ''absolutely not interested'' in such a merger.

title: FALLEN DEAL MAKER REGARDED AS TOP CORPORATE PROTECTOR
description: Often enough in recent years, whenever a corporation came under a takeover attack, its executives were on the telephone with Martin A. Siegel. In the process, the 38-year-old whiz kid made a reputatiion as an adroit protector of corporations, and made himself a fortune. Yesterday, his prestige, and much of the fortune, was gone. In Federal District Court in lower Manhattan, Mr. Siegel admitted that he had committed two felonies, conspiracy and tax evasion, as part of an insider trading scheme. He agreed to give up $9 million.

title: FOR AGED NAVY CARRIER, A PROUD PAST AND AN UNCERTAIN FUTURE
description: Aboard the aircraft carrier Coral Sea, wear and tear are constant adversaries.

title: MOSCOW FAMILY CALLS OFF ITS PROTESTS
description: The family of an imprisoned Jewish dissident called off public demonstrations today after plainclothesmen attacked protesters again on a Moscow pedestrian mall.

title: PETTIBONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and the 9 months includes loss from discontinued operations of $7,025,000 and a loss on disposal of $32,405,000.

title: MURA DEHN, A CHOREOGRAPHER AND SPECIALIST IN BLACK DANCE
description: Mura Dehn, a Russian-born dancer and choreographer who became known as a film maker and a specialist in American black dance, died Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 84 years old.

title: INQUIRY IS ORDERED IN FILIPINO DEATHS
description: The cutoff of a cease-fire five days ago has brought the highest level of reported killings since President Corazon C. Aquino took office a year ago, along with charges today of a military massacre of civilians.

title: ENRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $124.2 million for the quarter and $138.6 million for the year. c-Net loss includes gains from discontinued operations of $33.5 million for the quarter and $37.9 million for the year, and after an extraordinary charge of $218 million for the quarter and year. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the latest quarter. In 1986 Enron had nonrecurring charges associated with its severance and relocation programs, asset writedowns, building lease obligations and buy back of some of its common stock.

title: GORMAN-RUPP CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a reduction of $75,000 from the reversal of investment tax credits. c-Included a gain of $513,000 from the adoption of new pension accounting rules. The results or the first three quarters of 1986 were restated to reflect these new pension rules as of Jan.1, 1986.

title: DIMENSIONAL MEDICINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said it did not have year-ago third quarter sales because it was still a development stage company.

title: Norway Seeks Oil in Barents
description: Norway's oil minister said today that the nation would expand the search for oil and gas in the strategically sensitive Barents Sea, close to the Kola Peninsula base of the Soviet Navy.

title: PERCEPTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Running A Hard Road
description: Bruce Babbitt is a pleasant, thoughtful, youthful-looking fellow, maybe a little intense. At 48 and after two terms as the Democratic Governor of Arizona, he wants to be President of the United States. All things considered, he must want it pretty badly.

title: A Concept Option On Pizza Inn Stock
description: F. J. Spillman, chairman, president and the largest shareholder of Pizza Inn Inc., said that he had granted an option to sell his share of the company's stock to Concept Development Inc. Concept Development, a St. Louis-based operator of 125 Panterra's pizza restaurants, has offered to acquire Pizza Inn for a combination of cash and stock valued at $15.78 a share, or about $67.8 million.

title: HOLY CROSS DROPS B.C.
description: The Boston College-Holy Cross football rivalry, one of New England's oldest and most intense, was terminated yesterday by Holy Cross, which is committed to the new Colonial League. In announcing the ending of the 90-year-old series, the president of Holy Cross, the Rev. John E. Brooks, said, ''This decision is not to be interpreted as de-emphasis . . . but rather a rearrangement of our schedule in line with our determination to provide coaches and players with opportunity to compete in an environment that encourages balance and fair competition.'' The ability of Holy cross to continue to compete with Boston College, a major Division I-A independent, became doubtful following the last game, won by the Eagles here, 56-26, last Nov. 22. The Crusaders went into that contest undefeated after 10 games.

title: BOOLE & BABBAGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $34,000 for the latest quarter and $75,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Respect, Please, for Nicaraguans' Rights
description: LEAD: Thomas Jefferson would be at ease in Nicaragua. He understood the need for revolution and an authentic Constitution. Unlike those who see all other forms of government as a mortal threat, Jefferson believed, ''Each generation has the right to choose for itself the form of government it believes the most promotive of its own happiness.

title: JACK TRUDEAU ARRESTED
description: Jack Trudeau, the rookie quarterback from the University of Illinois who started 11 games last season for the Indianapolis Colts, is scheduled to appear in an Indianapolis court Tuesday after being arrested early yesterday morning on charges of disorderly conduct and battery on a policeman. Trudeau was arrested when, the police said, officers attempted to break up a fight outside a bar between him and another man. According to the police, both men refused to obey orders and R. Dean, a police officer, reported that he had been struck in the head by Trudeau, who was taken into custody and released six hours later on his own recognizance.

title: UNITED TELEVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes pretax income from ownership of Warner Communications Inc. securities of $1,925,000 versus $4,803,000 for the latest and year-ago quarters, respectively. c-Includes pretax income from ownership of Warner Communications securities of $5,404,000 versus $6,626,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Some Asians Gain in Admissions to Berkeley
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Bethlehem Steel Corp., Bethlehem, Pa., said it was modifying its previously announced price changes, effective April 5, on carbon and high-strength low-alloy plate. The company said the price changes would result in an average increase of $10 to $15 a ton.

title: 0.6% JANUARY RISE IN PRODUCER PRICES LED BY OIL SECTOR
description: A record surge in gasoline prices helped push the Producer Price Index for finished goods up six-tenths of 1 percent in January, its biggest advance since late 1985, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Boulez and Taxes
description: The world-renowned music director and conductor Pierre Boulez - who is so described in a judgment by a panel of the United States Court of Appeals in Washington - will apparently have to renegotiate a tax settlement with the Internal Revenue Service as a result of a ruling by the court yesterday.

title: By H. J. MAIDENBERG
description: After three mood changes, the stock market closed higher yesterday in active trading.

TELEVISION TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

METRO DATELINE;
Flight Control System With Manual Option
description: LEAD: For the Rockwell International Corporation, a builder of aircraft, there has been invented a system of automatic flight control that permits a pilot to take over temporary manual operation and permits safe return to the preset altitude and navigation procedure. The invention was made under a contract with the Coast

title: OMISSION OF AIDS IN LIBERACE REPORT IS DEFENDED
description: There was enough doubt about whether Liberace had AIDS to justify his doctor's decision to protect the showman's privacy by reporting heart failure as the cause of death, the physician's attorney said Thursday.

title: PAIN OF TWO L.I. PEOPLE YIELDS SPECIAL FRIENDSHIP
description: People might not realize that Ginger L. Jackson and Arnold R. Hartman have a whole lot in common.

title: AMERICA IS ABUZZ ON 'EVIL' SCANDAL
description: Barbara Spokes, a young housewife in suburban Minneapolis, worried that the growing insider-trading scandal on Wall Street might undermine America's free-enterprise system.

title: THREE LOST AND 25 RESCUED AS STORM BATTERS A FREIGHTER
description: A West German freighter that picked up distress signals in the night rescued 24 men and a woman from a stricken Turkish merchantman in a battering Atlantic storm early yesterday, but three other seamen were lost when their lifeboat capsized at the brink of deliverance.

title: Medical Initiation Rite Endangers the Public
description: To the Editor:

title: Amfac Unit Sale
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 13 -

title: CHURCH'S FRIED CHICKEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: NIPPON STEEL SETS CUTS OF 19,000 JOBS IN JAPAN
description: The Nippon Steel Corporation, the world's leading steelmaker, today announced a dramatic belt-tightening plan that includes shutting down five blast furnaces and cutting 19,000 jobs over the next four years.

title: Aluminum Price Soaring
description: The price of aluminum has been soaring in London, as traders speculate that buyers of the metal from the United States would soon react to surging demand by shopping in Europe. Over the past month, aluminum has climbed about $:80, or $120, on the London Metal Exchange to around $:850, or $1,290, a metric ton.

title: HAWAIIAN ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MCGRATH RENTCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The repeal of the investment tax credit retroactive to Jan. 1, 1986, resulted in a one-time reduction of net income of about $692,000, or 17 cents a share.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE ENTERPRISE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest year net includes an after-tax charge of $183.8 million from application of statement 90 FASB 90 relating to treatment of disallowances and prior plant abandonments. The 1985 earnings were restated.

title: THE TROUBLED LIFE OF AN EX-ISLANDER TAKES A DARKER TURN
description: In a cubicle he shares with another detainee in a West Palm Beach, Fla., jail, Brian Spencer, the former Islander and free spirit who drifted far from hockey's limelight after his playing career ended in Pittsburgh in 1980, awaits trial for a killing that occurred five years ago - a crime he swears he did not commit.

title: G.E. Stock Split
description: The General Electric Company said its board had voted to recommend a two-for-one split of its common stock and an increase in the number of authorized common and preferred shares, subject to approval of the shareholders at the annual meeting April 22. The company, which has 457.1 million shares outstanding, said its board also declared an cash dividend of 63 cents a share, payable April 25 to holders of record March 6. The board added that it plans to consider an increase in the dividend, to 33 cents a share after the split, at its May meeting. The company's stock rose $5.375 a share today, to $103.50, in New York Stock Exchange trading. More than 1.7 million shares changed hands, making it the fifth most-active stock.

title: NASA CONSIDERS TURBULENCE TESTS FOR SHUTTLE
description: The space agency is studying recommendations to subject the space shuttle to even more rigorous preflight testing because of growing concern about the ability of the craft to withstand the stresses of wind turbulence and other dynamic forces.

title: A CURATOR UPSETS THE GETTY
description: Museum officials and others in the esoteric field of antiquities have expressed varied reactions to the news that Jiri Frel, head of the department of antiquities at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., was relieved of his curatorial duties for helping donors obtain overvalued appraisals of their gifts for tax purposes.

title: MUSIC: AT THE KITCHEN, A NIGHT OF ODD NOISES
description: Thursday was the night for noise in the Kitchen's music series, with solos by Boris Policeband and duets by Christian Marclay and Fred Frith. Their music revolves around timbre - most often discordant, abrasive sounds.

title: VISHAY INTERTECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A GROWING SPLIT IS SEEN IN SICILIAN MOB ALLIANCE
description: What Federal prosecutors have charged was a Sicilian Mafia ring that smuggled nearly a ton of heroin and cocaine into the United States is increasingly splitting into two warring factions, according to investigators and lawyers.

title: Matsushita Plans Job Cuts in U.S.
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, victimized by the strong Japanese yen, said it would cut about 250 jobs at a television plant in suburban Franklin Park, Ill., by the end of February. The cuts will come through 170 layoffs and 80 early retirements, said Justin Camerlengo, a spokesman at Matsushita's American headquarters in Secaucus, N.J. The Franklin Park plant employs about 1,400, he said.

title: LIFETIME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: b-Includes tax credits of $106,000 for the quarter and $662,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $108,988 for the quarter and $474,329 for the 9 months. The latest quarter and 9 months include the results of Kimberly Services, acquired July14, 1986, and Hospital Capital Corp., acquired May30, 1986.

title: PROPERTY CAPITAL TRUST (BOSTON) (A) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
HUNGARIANS, EYEING KERMLIN, SWAGGER MORE THAN A LITTLE
description: Hungarian Communist officials, openly elated over the signs of a more liberal Soviet course under the leadership of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, have been putting on a show of modesty as they seek to refrain from boasting that they were there first.

title: '88 BOYCOTT NOT FEARED
description: The head of the International Olympic Committee said yesterday that he was certain Communist-bloc countries would ignore any call by North Korea to boycott the 1988 Summer Games in Seoul. Speaking at a news conference in Lausanne, Switzerland, Juan Antonio Samaranch, the I.O.C. president, said his organization was unwilling to add any sports to the four from the Seoul Games it has proposed placing in North Korea. He called the I.O.C. offer ''a very generous proposal, a historic one.'' North Korean officials said Thursday night that they had accepted the four-sport plan ''in principle'' but that they wanted an additional five or six sports. They have threatened to lead a boycott of Seoul if their demands are not met.

title: Burgess by Burgess
description: LITTLE WILSON AND BIG GOD. By Anthony Burgess. 460 pages. Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $22.50.

title: Aid Bill Signed
description: President Reagan signed emergency legislation Thursday providing $50 million to help the homeless.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 10.

title: G.M. Adds Trucks To New Warranty
description: The General Motors Corporation has extended its new six-year warranties to include light-duty trucks, becoming the last of the Big Three auto makers to do so. The six-year, 60,000-mile powertrain warranty and 100,000-mile rust protection warranty would cover all 1987 Chevrolet and GMC light trucks including those sold since Oct. 1, said Robert Stempel, a G.M. executive vice president.

title: Police in Peru Detain 795 in Campus Raids
description: The police raided five university campuses in Lima early today, arrested 795 people suspected of being terrorists and seized 650 pounds of explosives, a ranking police official said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 14, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-5 Material from the N.S.C. computer suggests that the secret operations conducted by the council staff were far more extensive than investigators of the Iran-contra affair previously thought, officials familiar with the material say. Page 1 Shots halted a food convoy in Beirut as the United Nations trucks approached an embattled Palestinian district. It was the latest setback in efforts to relieve the siege around the district. 1 Vietnam was told of new horrors after 15 boat people recently ventured ino the moody South China Sea and survived a harrowing five-week voyage that led to a desperate act of cannibalism. 1 Protests were called off in Moscow by the family of an imprisoned Jewish dissident after plainclothesmen attacked protesters again on a Moscow pedestrian mall. 3 Hungary's more liberal course may have served as an example for the initiatives recently undertaken by Mikhail S. Gorbachev in the Soviet Union, some Hungarian Communist Party officials have suggested. 3 Health experts meeting in Nairobi at a ''Safe Motherhood'' conference began an international campaign to conquer a third-world health problem that has been largely overcome in the West - deaths of women in childbirth. 5 A bitter struggle in Genoa, Italy, is unfolding over its port. Once the third city, along with Turin and Milan, in the triangle of northern Italian prosperity, it has become a place of disappearing jobs and diminishing hopes. 4 Inquiry in Filipino deaths 3 A Contra chief calls for overhaul 5 NATIONAL 6-8, 15, 28 Martin A. Siegel pleaded guilty to criminal charges involving insider trading that could subject him to a 10-year jail term. He agreed to give up more than $9 million in cash and assets in civil penalties. 1 Mr. Siegel is a 38-year-old whiz kid who was one of the foremost deal makers on Wall Street. He won a reputation as an adroit protector of corporations that did not want to be taken over. 1 A record surge in gasoline prices helped push the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods up six-tenths of 1 percent in January, the Labor Department reported, but analysts said it should not be seen as a worrisome sign of inflation. 1 A signal to other extremist groups has been sent by the award of $7 million returned by an Alabama jury against the United Klans of America. 6 Gary Hart told the A.F.L.-C.I.O. that he would welcome the labor federation's endorsement in his quest for the 1988 Democratic presidential nomination in an attempt to mend his relations with union leaders. 7 Howard Baker has almost decided to seek the Republican Presidential nomination in 1988, he has told supporters. The former Senate majority leader is expected to declare his intentions publicly by early March. 7 Governor Cuomo added three trips to his planned travels outside New York, including one to New Hampshire, which will hold the first Presidential primary elections. The intent seems to be to increase his name recognition in other states and to test the reaction. 7 More rigorous preflight shuttle tests are being considered by the space agency because of growing concern about the ability of the vehicle to withstand the stresses of wind turbulence and other dynamic forces. 15 The N.R.C. will allow an exception to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's procedures when it permits the Governors of New York and Massachussetts to appear before it this month to oppose its proposal to ease the licensing of nuclear power plants. 28 Homeless people in Washington, D.C., survive in the shadows of the monuments and great buildings that are symbols of the richest country on earth. There are an estimated 10,000 ''street people'' in the capital. 6 A Navy relic, the carrier Coral Sea, has recently returned to sea after months of maintenance. Officials are showing off the ship to demonstrate why they want to keep building costly nuclear-powered carriers. 6 A former Guam Governor, convicted yesterday of bribery and extortion in connection with favors he performed in office for campaign contributions, could theoretically receive 130 years in prison and $2.5 million in fines. 7 The V.A. disciplined 33 physicians and other employees of the Veterans Administration after closing an internal investigation into the acceptance of gratuities and payments from a drug company. 50 Reagan call brings aid to boy 7 Liberace death report defended 7 Reagan shielded from journalist 8 WASHINGTON TALK 8 Profile: Clayton K. Yeutter REGIONAL 29-32 Arrests in an apparent Mafia murder attempt were made less than 48 hours after a defendant in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial was shot on a Greenwich Village street. Three suspects were seized in New York and New Jersey. 1 An L.I. woman found a dead rare bird in her backyard in December that has never been seen in flight north of Venezuela. Hers may be the first sighting of the species, the Azur gallinule, in North America. 1 Sir Rudolf Bing and his new wife, who have fled to Anguilla in defiance of a court order, are followed by allegations that the bride of the 85-year-old former general manager of the Metropolitan Opera is not capable of managing her own affairs, let alone his. 9 A halt in grants to religious schools was ordered by New York State Comptroller Edward V. Regan until a Federal court decides whether the special ''members-item'' aid violates the constitutional principle of separation of church and state. 29 A West German freighter rescued 25 people, 24 men and a woman, from a stricken Turkish merchantman 720 miles east of New York at the heart of a winter storm 400 miles wide. Three other seamen were lost. 29 A reputed Sicilian Mafia ring is split into two warring factions and the tensions are growing, according to investigators who have charged the group with smuggled nearly a ton of heroin and cocaine into the United States. 31 Pain yields friendship for two 29 Coping with Hudson growth 30 Morale down at Eastern Airlines 30 Simon shifts his pension plan 31 Cocaine found in dead suspect 31 NEEDIEST CASES 15

Turkey Caller Has Removable Mouthpiece

title: Yankees Sign Cerone
description: Rick Cerone, the onetime Yankee catcher who engaged in a couple of brief feuds with George Steinbrenner before he was finally traded to Atlanta in 1984, returned to his former team yesterday after it appeared his career might be nearing a premature end.

title: 2 Ex-Jersey Officials Sentenced for Drugs
description: Two former Manville Borough councilmen were sentenced to prison yesterday for operating a cocaine ring that the authorities said took in $16,000 a week.

description: Martin A. Siegel's list of callers was long, and it was studded with some important names - such as Gordon P. Getty.

description: The Dow Chemical Company is selling its manufacturing plant in South Africa, saying that persistent racial unrest made it senseless to do business there.

description: The British rock singer Peter Murphy, former leader of Bauhaus, will lead his new band tonight at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street. Golden Dawn will open at 11 P.M., followed at about 12:30 A.M. by Mr. Murphy. Tickets are $13.50. Information: 254-2800.

Kidder Could Face Suits, Stiff Penalties
description: Kidder, Peabody & Company may face a host of lawsuits and financial penalties as a result of insider trading charges against its employees, corporate lawyers say. Indeed, these experts think the Federal Government could force the firm to pay back all illegal profits derived from the trading, plus triple damages.

title: Atlantic Air Fare Pact
description: The United States and 13 of the 22 member states of the European Civil Aviation Conference have signed an accord on trans-Atlantic air fares to replace existing arrangements that expire in April. The Europeans said today that, under the new memorandum of understanding, aeronautical authorities of the signatory states will automatically approve North Atlantic fares filed by airlines within specified pricing zones. The 13 members of the conference that have signed the memorandum are Belgium, Finland, France, West Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Britain and Yugoslavia.

title: MONCRIEF ACTIVATED
description: A Milwaukee Bucks guard, Sidney Moncrief, who has missed all but 13 games this season with tendinitis of the right knee, including the last 23, will be activated for tonight's game against the Houston Rockets. Moncrief, an eight-year pro who has played in five National Basketball Association All-Star Games, averaged 15.8 points a game this season before being sidelined. . . . The Los Angeles Lakers have acquired a forward-center, Mychal Thompson, from the San Antonio Spurs for two reserves, Frank Brickowski and Petur Gudmundsson, two draft choices and cash, Jerry West, the Laker general manager announced yesterday. The 6-foot-10 Thompson had been averaging 12.3 points and 5.9 rebounds with the Spurs.

title: OLSON IS ENDURING A SEASON OF LOWS
description: Looking at the record book, you get the impression that Billy Olson is bigger than life. Looking at his career, you get the impression that anything that can go wrong will go wrong if it hasn't gone wrong already.

title: CHOLOATE LOVERS COME HOME
description: First she looked at the velvet-covered, heart-shaped boxes filled with chocolates, then at the two-ounce truffles, but finally Linda Robinson picked out a one-pound box of Godiva chocolates with cream, caramel and cherry centers for $20.

title: Nuclear Agency to Let Cuomo Testify on Shoreham
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that it would permit Governor Cuomo of New York and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts to appear before it later this month to oppose its proposal to ease the licensing of nuclear power plants.

title: RAY KNIGHT SOUNDS OFF
description: In his first news conference in Baltimore, Ray Knight, the most valuable player with the Mets in the World Series, made a strong pitch yesterday to become the most voluble player of the Orioles this season. The 34-year-old third baseman's rapid-fire delivery had veteran Baltimore reporters comparing him with a former Oriole pitcher, Jim Palmer, now a broadcaster. One reporter suggested that Knight had already talked to the press more than the first baseman, Eddie Murray, had in 11 years. ''That's it in a nutshell,'' Knight said at one point, after a lengthy explanation of his futile negotiations with the Mets before he became a free agent. Knight, who turned down a one-year, $800,000 offer from the Mets after failing to get a two-year contract, accepted a one-year pact with the Orioles for $500,000 and incentives that would include an option year. ''Hank made me feel wanted,'' Knight said of the Baltimore general manager, Hank Peters. ''He made me feel appreciated, and to me that's so much more important than money.''

title: STERLING SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S.-Soviet Radar Dispute Tests Treaty Good Faith
description: To the Editor:

title:
METRO DATELINE;
Restraining the Body Of Sleeping Astronaut
description: LEAD: Means for restraining the body of a sleeping astronaut in the absence of gravity received a patent this week for Agence Spatiale Europeenne, Paris. Patent 4,641,386, granted to Stoewer Heinz and another Dutch inventor, says that sleep is frequently interrupted by the disturbing feeling of being in a state of free fall.

title: Kaiser Coal Units File Chapter 11
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation said five of its coal subsidiaries have filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. Kaiser, based in Colorado Springs, Colo., and its Cottonwood Canyon Land Company subsidiary filed for Chapter 11 protection in separate petitions earlier this week. Kaiser controls several small coal units, four of which were not affected by today's filing.

title: CATALYST ENERGY DEVELOPENT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said it made several acquisitions in 1986, the most significant of which was the aquisition of Alamito Co., completed in June. Inclusion of Alamito's results of operations for seven months accounted for much of Catalyst Energy's increase in revenue and earnings.

title: SAVANNAH FOOD & INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the primary reason for the earnings decline in the latest quarter and year is a LIFO adjustment. The company also said earnings were adversely affected by lower beet sugar earnings.

title: CALCIUM, FAT AND SODIUM: CAVEATS FOR TEEN-AGERS
description: The dairy industry has taken up the battle against osteoporosis with vigor. After years of being criticized for emphasizing nutritious but fattening products - whole milk, ice cream, etc. - the industry has seized upon the opportunity to campaign for increased consumption of calcium to prevent the crippling bone disease that afflicts older women.

title: Monetary Policy Stayed Steady in Mid-December
description: Policy makers at the Federal Reserve left monetary policy unchanged at a meeting in mid-December, according to minutes of the session released today.

title: COCAINE FOUND IN DEAD SUSPECT
description: A burglary suspect who died early Thursday after a violent struggle with several police officers had a ''high level of cocaine'' in his blood and ''no significant physical injuries,'' the authorities said yesterday.

title: PRIMEBANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a credit of $102,000 from the termination of a pension plan. c-After a credit of $201,000.

title: Children's Chairs Recalled
description: Children's chairs sold in Texas, Missouri and Arizona are being recalled because the paint on them contains too much lead, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said today. About 9,000 wooden chairs imported from Mexico in 1985 by De Llano's Mexican Products of Laredo, Tex., are involved in the recall, the commisssion said. No injuries have been reported from the chairs, but the lead content in the paint exceeds the Federal limit. Consumers who need further information can call De Llano's Mexican Products at 512-722-1775 or the Safety Commission at 800-638-CPSC.

title: Moscow Sets Grain Goal
description: The Soviet Union has set a 1987 grain harvest target of 232 million metric tons, which would be the country's second- largest yield ever, the official news agency Tass said today. Agricultural experts at Western embassies said it was the first time in recent years that the Soviet Union had published an annual grain target in advance of the harvest, although it provides five-year-plan targets. The current five-year plan, covering 1986 to 1990, calls for grain production of 250 to 255 million tons by 1990. Output last year reached 210.1 million tons, the highest yield since a record crop of 237 million in 1978.

title: Alive and Well on Health Policy
description: President Reagan's endorsement of a new health care plan marks a victory for the elderly who fear bankrupting illness and a victory for common sense over nervous orthodoxy. Credit the President and his Health and Human Services Secretary, Otis Bowen, for both.

title: NOVAMETRIX MEDICAL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

description: The Scandal on Wall Street

title: STAR SAPPHIRE CALLED 'INSIGNIFICANT STONE'
description: Experts are disputing the $2.28 million appraisal given a stone bought for $10 by a Texan who said it was the biggest star sapphire known, according to a report published today.

title: Pact on Yugoslav Debt
description: Yugoslavia signed an agreement with the United States today for the refinancing of $220 million of official debt due between May 1986 and the end of 1988, the official Tanjug news agency said. The agreement, signed in Washington, means Yugoslavia can ''resume the regular fulfillment of obligations toward Governments of 16 industrial countries'' under a multilateral accord signed in Paris last May, the agency said. Yugoslavia owes about $19 billion to the 16 countries.

title: 3 Wedtech Figures Plead Guilty to Theft
description: Three former executives of Wedtech, a Bronx military contractor at the center of a broad corruption inquiry, pleaded guilty to theft charges in a Bronx courtroom yesterday as new details about their plea bargains emerged.

description: b-Reduced by $315,000, or 3 cents a share, as a result of the repeal of investment tax credits by the Tax Reform Act of 1986, and also includes $336,000, or 3 cents a share, from the reduction of LIFO inventories. c-Reduced by $1,350,000, or 14 cents a share, for the latest year, as a result of the settlement of a patent infringement suit, and the 1985 period includes $1,457,000, or 15 cents a share, from the sale of assets. title: Topics; HEARTS AND TOWERS; Scrambled Logic
description: Television signals are private property and ''theft of private property is wrong.'' That's the clear, simple and sound judgment of Dennis Patrick, newly designated chairman of the Federal Communications Commission. And that's why the agency wisely refrains from interfering with scrambled television signals. People who bought expensive satellite dish antennas in order to pirate shows from the sky have been in an uproar since Home Box Office and ESPN announced that they would code their signals. Dish owners must now buy decoders, thereby providing the signal owners with fair compensation.

title: Auto Sales Down 1.3% But Outshine January
description: Sales of new domestically produced cars totaled 170,134 in February's first 10 days, down 1.3 percent, the eight manufacturers reported today.

title: A Letter to Gorbachev
description: Fifty-eight United States senators have signed a letter to the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, expressing concern that new emigration procedures purportedly intended to make it easier to leave the Soviet Union appear to have had the opposite effect.

title: BLACK HILLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,248,000 from an accounting change.

title: INVENTORIES OFF IN DECEMBER
description: Business sales, aided by a year-end spurt of car buying, jumped 2.9 percent in December and inventories fell five-tenths of 1 percent, the largest decline in more than three years, the Commerce Department said today.

title: A Hot Seller: Tax Videos
description: JACK FELDMAN, manager of the Video Shack store on Broadway and 49th Street in Manhattan, finds that many of his customers are buying videotapes on taxes and financial planning. ''They come around asking for the films by name,'' he said. ''People need some help.''

description: b-After capital gains of $4,550,000 for the quarter and $14,218,000 for the year. c-After capital gains of $535,000 for the quarter and $6,183,000 for the year.

title: PRODUCTION ROSE 0.4% IN JANUARY
description: The nation's industrial production increased for the fourth consecutive month in January, the Federal Reserve reported today. But many analysts were unimpressed by the size of the advance, a slim four-tenths of 1 percent.

title: Air Force Cancels $1.2 Billion Project
description: The Air Force took the unusual step today of canceling a $1.2 billion program to equip its F-111 fighter bombers with radar-jamming gear because it disliked the prices of three competing bids.

title: BOAT PEOPLE: FRESH FACES, NEW HORRORS
description: The story is best told in Nguyen Van Du's own words.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: College Basketball Columbia 81, Yale 72: Sean Couch scored 29 points and Matt Shannon added 16 last night to lead Columbia to the Ivy League victory. The loss ended Yale's five-game winning streak and dropped the Elis out of a first-place tie in the Ivy League with Cornell. Yale is 13-8 over all and 6-3 in the league. Columbia (8-12 and 3-6) had lost three in a row. Columbia moved to a 38-17 lead before Chris Dudley pulled Yale within 40-28 at halftime. Dudley, the second-leading rebounder in the nation, finished with 25 points and 13 rebounds. (AP) Princeton 73, Harvard 63: In Princeton, N.J., Alan Williams scored 16 of his 24 points in the first half as Princeton (11-8, 4-4) took a commanding lead and held off a late rally in another Ivy League game. The Tigers jumped out to a 26-6 lead with 6 minutes 47 seconds left in the first half. Harvard fell to 8-12 and 3-5. (AP) N.B.A. Clippers 110, Spurs 96: In San Antonio, Mike Woodson scored a season-high 37 points to lead Los Angeles. The Clippers led the entire way as they won for just the eighth time this season against 40 losses. San Antonio, after winning seven straight before the All-Star Game break, dropped its third in a row. (AP) Bulls 106, SuperSonics 98: Michael Jordan scored 45 points and teamed with Mike Brown for 16 consecutive fourth-quarter points to rally the Bulls at home. Jordan put the Bulls ahead to stay at 89-88 with 5:36 to go when he made one of two free throws. Jordan had 11 of the next 15 points and Brown added four before the SuperSonics scored again. (AP) Celtics 131, Blazers 116: Kevin McHale scored 37 points and Danny Ainge added 26 as Boston won at Portland, Ore. The Celtics, who won their third road game in four nights, took control of the contest by scoring 8 straight points to build a 91-79 lead with 3:10 left in the third quarter. Boston pulled away after that and stretched the advantage to 21 in the final minutes. (AP) Suns 105, Jazz 98: Larry Nance scored 26 points and blocked six shots as Phoenix won at home. The Suns saw their 49-43 halftime lead erased as Utah used a 10-0 run to gain a 53-53 tie with 8:36 left in the third quarter. The lead then see-sawed until Ed Pinckney's free throws with 54 seconds remaining and Nance's stuff with 28 seconds to go put the Suns up by 80-77 entering the final period. After the Jazz pulled within 97-96 with 1:57 left in the game, Walter Davis sank two foul shots and Nance hit a jumper. (AP) Tennis Connors in Semifinal: Jimmy Connors neutralized the power of Kevin Curren with a scrambling net game yesterday to post a 6-4, 3-6, 6-3 victory and advance to the semifinal round of the United States Indoor Tennis Championship in Memphis. Connors, seeking his eighth United States Indoor title, meets Mikael Pernfors of Sweden in today's semifinal round. Pernfors rallied in the third set to defeat Greg Holmes 6-4, 3-6, 6-3 in yesterday's opening match. Brad Gilbert defeated Johan Kriek in straight sets, 6-2, 7-6, and will meet top-seeded Stefan Edberg, who eliminated Tim Mayotte, the seventh-seeded player, 6-3, 6-4. (AP) Golf Stadler, Burns Tied: Craig Stadler's 10-under-par 62 yesterday earned him a share of the lead at the halfway point of the Andy Williams Open. He completed 36 holes - one round over both the North and South courses at Torrey Pines in La Jolla, Calif., - in 131, 13 strokes under par. He was tied for the lead with George Burns, who shot a 63 on the North Course on Thursday and added a 68 over the South yesterday. Burns has now gone through two rounds without a bogey. (AP) Auto Racing Driver Killed at Daytona: One driver was killed and another seriously injured yesterday in the Komfort Koach 200 subcompact race at Daytona International Speedway. Joe Young of Richmond, 38 years old, died in the six-car crash and Duell Sturgill of Staffordsville, Ky., reportedly suffered fractures to both legs. Young was pronounced dead at Halifax Medical Center. Sturgill, who was in the intensive care unit, was reported in serious condition last night. Young, an auto mechanic, is survived by his wife, Dolores, and two children. Larry Caudill, who started from the pole, won the race. (AP) Bodine Victorious: Geoff Bodine took the lead at the halfway point and held off Dale Earnhardt and Darrell Waltrip to win the opening event of this year's International Race of Champions series at Daytona International Speedway. Driving one of 12 identically prepared Chevrolet Camaros, Bodine led a sweep by Nascar stock-car drivers of the first four positions. (AP) Skiing Schneider Takes Slalom: Vreni Schneider of Switzerland won yesterday's women's World Cup giant slalom at Megeve, France, posting the fastest times in both heats. The victory kept Schneider atop the giant slalom standing and moved her into second place in the overall World Cup standing, behind Maria Walliser, a teammate, who was third yesterday. Schneider's time was 2 minutes 36.26 seconds. Blanca Fernandez-Ochoa of Spain finished second in 2:37.21, followed by Walliser in 2:37.31. Debbie Armstrong of Seattle was the best American, placing 11th in 2:39.34. (AP)

title: 18 Reported Dead as Troops Clash With Salvador Rebels
description: Eight soldiers and 10 rebels died in a seven-hour night battle for the town of Delicias de Concepcion in eastern El Salvador last night, the armed forces press office said today.

title: AT TOY FAIR, CHATTING DOLLS AND GHOSTLY KNIGHTS
description: The toy buyers came to town this week for the 84th annual American International Toy Fair. Most of the men wore red or yellow power neckties, and much of what they saw were dolls that had batteries and/or chips in their bodies, enabling them to converse with other dolls.

title: Holiday Monday
description: George Washington's birthday will be observed Monday in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Following are holiday schedules: Parade - Begins 9 A.M. at Fifth Avenue and 35th Street, moving north to 50th Street and ending about noon. Parking - Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation - No collections; no street cleaning. Governmental offices - Closed. Post offices - Closed; special delivery and express-mail delivery only. Banks - Connecticut, closed; New York and New Jersey, optional closing. Financial markets - Closed. Transportation - Subways and buses on Saturday schedules; Long Island Rail Road, Metro-North and N.J. Transit buses on holiday schedules; N.J. Transit trains on Saturday schedules. Schools - In New York City, closed; in New York State, New Jersey and Connecticut, local option. Libraries - Closed.

title: NOTE AND BOND PRICES DECLINE
description: Treasury note and bond prices drifted lower yesterday, but short-term interest rates were little changed as trading activity subsided in advance of a long weekend.

title: NO U.S. RETALIATION IN AIRBUS DISPUTE
description: The Cabinet today decided against initiating a confrontation with Europe over the Airbus, an airliner that American aircraft companies say is unfairly subsidized by the European governments that own it, Reagan Administration officials said.

Shares of the former government-owned telecommunications monopoly dropped 100,000 yen, about $650, to 1.76 million yen, about $11,429.

title: Morris Wins a Big One
description: Eight weeks ago the Yankees rejected an invitation to sign Jack Morris as a free agent and have an arbitrator determine his 1987 salary. Yesterday an arbitrator, Richard Bloch, decided that the Detroit Tigers should pay the pitcher $1.85 million.
