title: Von Bulow's Lawyer Must Help in Suit
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that Alan Dershowitz, the lawyer who helped get Claus Von Bulow's conviction of attempted murder overturned, relinquished his right to attorney-client privilege by writing a book on the case.

title: Great Western, Celtic in Talks
description: The Great Western Financial Corporation said today that it was discussing the possible sale of its insurance operations to the Celtic Group Inc., a closely held insurance group based in Chicago. No agreement has been reached.

title: DECEIVING GASOLINE PURCHASES
description: HOW do you know when you fill up your car that the premium gasoline you pay for isn't just regular at a premium price? How do you know that when you pay for 10 gallons, you get 10 gallons and not 9, or 8? And how do you know that when the pump says unleaded, it's really unleaded? You don't. But your car does. When a car that is used to running on premium gets regular gas, which has a lower octane rating than premium, it loses power and the engine knocks, often within a few minutes of filling up. If you get 8 gallons instead of the 10 you paid for, your car demands a refill sooner. And if you get leaded when your car uses only unleaded, it throws off the engine's timing, damages the spark plugs and clogs the catalytic converter, an air-pollution-control device, stopping the car cold. Replacing a catalytic converter can cost $1,500.

CABLE CHANNEL OFFERS TV SHOWS FROM MOSCOW
description: Many American television viewers will have a chance during the next week to sample Soviet programming. The Discovery Channel, a cable network, will offer 66 hours of programs from Moscow.

description: Alfonso Robelo, a key moderate leader of the Nicaraguan rebel coalition, said today that he could no longer share power with Adolfo Calero, the leader of the rebel coalition's largest group.

title: Corn Prices Fall Again, Touching 15-Year Low
description: Corn futures were down sharply today on the Chicago Board of Trade, losing 1.5 cents a bushel, to cap a week that saw the price fall a total of 12 cents, to levels last touched 15 years ago.

The equipment includes transmitters and receivers that operate simultaneously in both directions. The patent covers a technique that allows them to synchronize.

title: Morse Shoe Bid
description: An investment group led by Asher B. Edelman, the New York arbitrager, said that after three months of slowly acquiring shares of Morse Shoe Inc, it was ''interested in acquiring'' the company, which is based in a Boston suburb. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Edelman group disclosed that it has requested a meeting with the Morse Shoe management on Feb. 24 ''to discuss a negotiated purchase.'' Between Feb. 6 and Feb. 9, the Edelman group raised its stake in Morse Shoe to 9.1 percent, from 8.7 percent, with a purchase of 21,800 Morse Shoe shares for prices ranging from $33 to $34.12 a share. The Edelman group acquired its first Morse shares in November.

title: AMFAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations $28,324,000 and $53,157,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $4,923,000 for the quarter and $10,240,000 for the year. The company said losses from discontinued operations in the latest periods reflect operating results from Amfac Supply, Fisher Cheese operations and a reserve for the divestiture of the Amfac Supply operations. The Amfac Supply reserve includes, in addition to the estimated cost of divestiture, the estimated losses for the operating period prior to divestiture.

title: HART MOVES TO MEND FENCES WITH LABOR LEADERS
description: Several years after alienating key leaders of the nation's labor movement, former Senator Gary Hart appeared before the A.F.L.-C.I.O. today and said he would welcome the labor federation's endorsement in his quest for the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: HOMELESSNESS AMID SYMBOLS OF NATION'S PLENTY
description: Once daybreak comes, Willy says, you can't sleep, not in the small triangular park across the street from the State Department. The sky brightens and the cars begin rolling in and the heels of the early workers hurrying toward the big Government buildings scrape noisily on the sidewalk.

title: Local Phone Rate Impasse
description: State and Federal telephone regulators could not agree today on whether to increase the $2-a-month ''subscriber line charge'' residential customers pay for local phone lines.

title: MILTON PETRIE, 84 YEARS OLD, STILL IMPRESSES OPPONENTS
description: The trend in society toward late retirement, or nonretirement, is matched in the bridge community. Many players seem able, and eager, to go on forever.

title: Raising Death Benefits
description: Representative Mario Biaggi, the Bronx Democrat who was for 23 years a New York City policeman, has introduced a bill to double the $50,000 Federal death benefit that is paid when public safety officers are killed in the line of duty.

title: NETS CONSIDER WILLIAMS
description: Bothered by injuries and 15 losses in their last 16 games, the Nets were evaluating yesterday the possibility of hiring Ray Williams for a third time in his nine-year pro career. Williams, a 32-year-old guard who has had back and knee problems, has undergone a series of examinations by the Net team doctors. According to Jim Lampariello, director of public relations, there is a 50-50 chance that Williams will be signed to a 10-day contract. Williams, the Knicks' first-round draft choice in 1977, first played for the Nets in 1981 when they signed him as a free agent after the Knicks agreed not to exercise their right of first refusal in exchange for Maurice Lucas. After averaging 20.4 points a game in 1981-82, Williams was traded to the Kansas City Kings for Phil Ford. Williams played five games for the Nets last season after they claimed him on waivers, but was not eligible for the playoffs. The Nets did not re-sign him.

description: A BATHING suit made with fabric that changes color with the temperature of the wearer and gives a distinctive appearance was patented this week. The thermally sensitive material contains cholesterol liquid crystals that display the color pattern.

INTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $57,800,000. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $10.3 million for the quarter and $2.7 million for the year, and also an extraordinary loss of $2.1 million for the year. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded income in the latest quarter.

title: KUHLMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in May 1985. The company said 1986 results were favorably affected by tax credits of $312,000, which includes credits relating to investments in new equipment and research and development.

title: SANDS REGENT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sikh Sought in Hindu Deaths Killed by the Police in India
description: A Sikh wanted in connection with the massacre of 22 Hindus was killed today in a shoot-out with the police, the authorities said.

title: CHECK TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: CITY BALLET: 'COPPELIA' IS REVIVED
description: The New York City Ballet's production of ''Coppelia,'' which returned to the State Theater on Thursday night after a four-year absence, is predicated - more than most other versions - on the idea of festivity.

title: Mission Insurance
description: The Mission Insurance Group Inc., which agreed last week to a reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, said today that it was discussing the resuscitation of its Mission American Insurance Company unit with a group of its public bondholders. Mission American, which was taken under state conservatorship Feb. 2, is Mission Insurance Group's principal subsidiary. The bondholders, who control a majority of Mission's public debt, have offered to make a $50 million capital infusion to Mission American if the state Insurance Department releases the unit from conservatorship.

title: PLANS PREDICT SPURT IN HUDSON CROSSINGS
description: The growth in jobs and housing in the New York metropolitan region is sending New Jersey commuters across the Hudson River in rapidly increasing numbers and taxing transportation systems.

title: MSI ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BAKER IS NEARING BID ON CANDIDACY
description: After months of vacillation, Howard H. Baker Jr. is telling supporters that he is ready to announce his candidacy for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination as soon as he determines that he can raise enough money for a late-starting campaign.

title: DR. HENRY B. HASS IS DEAD AT AGE 85
description: Henry Bohn Hass, a specialist in organic chemistry who is credited with the discovery of gas chromatography, one of chemistry's most powerful analytic tools, died of pnuemonia yesterday at Long Island Jewish Hospital, Manhasset, N.Y. He was 85 years old and lived in Queens.

title: V.A. DISCIPLINES DOCTORS FOR ACCEPTING FEES FROM DRUG COMPANY
description: The Veterans Administration has disciplined at least 33 physicians and other employees after closing an internal investigation into the acceptance of gratuities and payments from a drug company.

title: Pay for Repairs With East River Bridge Tolls
description: To the Editor:

title: SANDSTROM INJURY A BROKEN ANKLE
description: Tomas Sandstrom, who gives and takes more punishment than any other European in the National Hockey League, may be lost to the Rangers for the remainder of the regular season because his right ankle is broken as well as sprained.

title: Early Effort Thwarted
description: Shooting broke out today as the two United Nations trucks loaded with food approached Burj al Brajneh. Witnesses said the trucks' tires were shot out by unidentified gunmen and the vehicles were abandoned yards from their destination.

title: THIRD-WORLD CONCERN: DEATHS DURING CHILDBIRTH
description: International health experts here began a campaign today to conquer a third-world health problem that has been largely overcome in the West: the death of women in childbirth.

title: SPECIAL GRANTS FOR RELIGIOUS SCHOOLS HALTED
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan today ordered a halt to millions of dollars in special state grants to religious schools until a Federal court decides whether the grants violate the constitutional principle of separation of church and state.

title: TEXACO STOCK FALLS ON RULING
description: Texaco Inc.'s latest setback in its long-running legal fight with the Pennzoil Company generated a strong reaction in the securities markets yesterday.

title: GENE FOUND THAT MAKES DEPOSITS IN ALZHEIMER VICTIMS' BRAIN CELLS
description: Researchers said today they had isolated a gene largely responsible for the abnormal deposits that clog the brains of people with Alzheimer's disease.

title: ADD IT UP, AND ROMANCE CUTS QUITE A FIGURE
description: Numbers may not be the measure of a holiday's importance, but if they were, Valentine's Day would have few equals. The holiday for lovers is not only a multibillion-dollar bonanza for purveyors of candy, flowers and greeting cards, but it also generally heralds a flurry of weddings and other amorous adventures, telephoning and restaurant-going, and, if the past is any guide, perhaps even a dip in the crime rate and an upswing in the stock market.

title: BUSINESS MEN'S ASSURANCE CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an investment loss of $661,000 for the quarter and an investment gain of $10,333,000 for the year. c-Includes investment gains of $999,000 and $12,197,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. d-Net income

title: INSIDE
description: School Grants Halted Comptroller Edward V. Regan, acting on a court ruling, halted millions of dollars in New York State grants to religious schools. Page 29. New Turn in Bing Affair Sir Rudolf Bing and his wife, who have fled to Anguilla, are followed by allegations that she is unable to manage her affairs, let alone his. Page 9.

title: Ex-Choate Student Admits Guilt on Drug
description: A former student at the Choate Rosemary Hall School pleaded guilty yesterday to a cocaine-smuggling charge in Federal District Court after arriving from Venezuela and surrendering.

title: MORRISON-KNUDSEN CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE DANCE: CITY BALLET WITH ROBBINGS'S 'MOVES'
description: Jerome Robbins's ''Moves,'' presented by the New York City Ballet on Wednesday at the New York State Theater, is a beautifully wrought work that communicates strong emotions through stark moves and gestures performed in silence. Coming after ''Moves,'' as it did on Wednesday's program, Mr. Robbins's ''Four Seasons'' looked more madcap than ever. Drawn from Verdi's notes for the opera-ballet score to which the dance is performed, the ballet's occasionally silly and slightly vulgar thematic touches looked even more insubstantial. But at its best, ''The Four Seasons'' remains a delightful and even thought-provoking romp.

title: MET OPERA: AGNES BALTSA IN 'CARMEN'
description: A year ago, when the Metropolitan Opera introduced its latest version of ''Carmen,'' a lack of singing made opening night hard to bear. The Don Jose, Luis Lima, suffered from throat problems and had to talk his way through much of the evening, while Maria Ewing, with no such problems, did much the same in the title role. On Thursday night, when Sir Peter Hall's production returned to the Metropolitan, singing was again a weak link, owing at least in part to the unrealistic theatrical demands that this grimly veristic and often intentionally crude staging puts on the principal voices.

title: Camping? Loge or Box?
description: Few people other than seasoned campers realize it, but the best way to guarantee a campsite at a number of national parks is to make a reservation the same way you book a Broadway musical - through Ticketron. The National Park Service has just renewed its contract with Ticketron Inc. for five more years of bookings at eight parks with 3,324 family campsites. Charges vary from $8 to $10 a day. Reservations are taken by mail or in person at any Ticketron outlet; none are taken by phone. William Penn Mott Jr., director of the Park Service, says the nationwide computer system makes it possible for families to assure themselves of a place to sleep when they arrive at a crowded park.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: OVER THE RAINBOW

title: Pressman Critically Injured In a Robbery at The Times
description: A 63-year-old pressman was critically injured in a robbery yesterday in a sub-basement locker room of The New York Times building at 229 West 43d Street, and an apprentice pressman was arrested, the police said.

title: To Cut Court Calendars
description: In an effort to combat the crack epidemic and to reduce backlogs in the New York City Criminal Court, Sol Wachtler, Chief Judge of the New York State Court of Appeals, announced last September that many judges then serving on the Civil Court in New York City would be transferred to the Criminal Court.

title: Russian Can't Attend Wife's U.S. Funeral
description: Naum Meiman, a Jewish dissident and mathematician, said today that Soviet authorities had refused to allow him to attend the funeral of his wife, Inna, who died of cancer in Washington.

title: SOVIET TIES SERIES ON 2ND-PERIOD SURGE
description: For all the remarkable attention to detail that went into the year of planning for the Rendez-Vous '87 series between the National Hockey League all-stars and the national team of the Soviet Union, there was one detail the organizers failed to consider. They ordered only one trophy.

title: JOHN J. MEEHAN
description: John J. Meehan, a New York lawyer, died Tuesday at North Shore University Hospital as the result of injuries he suffered earlier in a fall outside his home in Plandome, L.I. He was 70 years old.

title: AUDIT QUESTIONS BOTNICK'S TRAVEL EXPENSES
description: A preliminary state audit has found that Victor E. Botnick, a former top aide to Mayor Koch, had failed to properly document 67 out-of-town trips in five years at a cost of more than $57,000.

title: THE AGE OF EXILE
description: LEAD: FOUR LIVES IN PARIS By Hugh Ford. Foreword by Glenway Wescott. Illustrated. 286 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. $19.95.

title: U.S. MORALS AND SOUTH AFRICA'S METALS
description: MUCH of American foreign policy is driven by the engine of economic necessity.

title:
PERSONAL FINANCE;
SORTING OUT THE AFFAIRS OF AN ESTATE
description: LEAD: ERLING L. Solstad, a New York brownstone renovator, was not surprised when the doctor called one evening to tell him that his father had died after a long illness. Still, the news is never easy to take. In a mild state of shock, he called his lawyer. ''I didn't know where to start and nobody tells you what to do,'' he recalled recently.

title: U.S. IS LAGGING ON FORECASTING WORLD WEATHER
description: United States weather forecasters are lagging significantly behind their European counterparts in the international competition to improve global forecasts, according to meteorologists on both sides of the Atlantic.

title: 4 Beirut Captives Said to Face 'Civilized' Fate
description: When a militant Moslem group today withdrew its offer to exchange three American professors and an Indian scholar for 400 Arab prisoners held by Israel, it did not fix a new date for killing its captives.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
Offices Blooming in Rural Hunterdon
description: LEAD: WITH a number of new office complexes already dotting its fertile valleys and rolling hills, Hunterdon County is considered one of New Jersey's next big important commercial growth centers.

title: TURNPIKE TO EASE BERGEN TRAFFIC
description: LEAD: THE New Jersey Turnpike Authority has announced plans to add an exit and expand an existing interchange in the vicinity of the Meadowlands Sports Complex in East Rutherford.

title: The Company Is Watching You Everywhere
description: LEAD: The USG Acoustical Products Company, based in Chicago, recently announced that employees at any of its nine manufacturing plants who smoke, whether at work or at home, might soon be out of a job unless they quit smoking. After a grace period of several months, the company said it would monitor employee health using a test that measures lung capacity, and any employees still believed to be smoking could be fired.

title: BRUSSELS PUPPETS PLAY THE CLASSICS
description: Stiff and wooden acting is sometimes a form of art. In Belgium, the seemingly rigid Toone Marionettes are the smallest, oldest and most dashing of all the inhabitants of Brussels. They dwell in the maze of carless streets next to the Grand-Place that contains some of the city's most-frequented seafood restaurants, whose windows are adorned with centerpieces of crayfish, crabs and lobsters. A little farther, through the little alley called Schuddevelde (meaning cattle field), is the Toone (pronounced tone) Marionette Theater.

title: HIGH-GLOSS JAGGER AND A 'BORIS' TO BE CHERISHED
description: A Woman of Distinction With Rosalind Russell, Ray Milland, Edmund Gwenn, Janis Carter, Mary Jane Saunders. Produced by Buddy Adler. Directed by Edward Buzzell. 1950. RCA Columbia Pictures Home Video. 85 minutes. $69.95.

title: STATE MEDICAL PROGRAM FOR THE NEEDY ASSAILED
description: LEAD: NEW JERSEY'S much-heralded Medically Needy Program is bogged down in red tape, covers too few clients and services and is plagued by high administrative costs, according to state and county officials and client advocates who testified before a State Senate committee here last week.

title: OLD 'PETS' FIND NEW HOMES
description: A bloodhound, a whippet, several setters and a pair of hunting dogs - garden sculptures all - helped make the recent Winter Antiques Show an unqualified success. These zinc, bronze, lead and stone canine figures - life-sized and larger - sparked smiles and lots of laughter throughout the nine-day fair - the first anyone could recall at which there was such a large gathering of dogs. By the time the show ended two weeks ago, virtually all of the dogs were sold.

title: POSTINGS: Tug-of-War on Staten Island; A Battle for a Colony of Condominiums
description: A former Augustinian academy that later became a retreat house -a sprawling Spanish-style structure in the Grymes Hill section of Staten Island - once epitomized tranquility. But it is now caught in a fierce tug-of-war between two developers, both fighting to acquire the 19-acre site to create a vast colony of condominiums.

title: HAVE THE METS AND YANKS CHANGED FOR THE BETTER?
description: Are the Mets stronger? I think not.

title: ARTIST REMEMBERS HEYDAY OF THE '50's
description: LEAD: THERE are times, Stanley Twardowicz said, when he wishes he had made it as big as some of the fellow painters he used to drink with, debate with and even box with at the Cedar Tavern in Greenwich Village.

title: CLEANUP ALLOTMENT UNCERTAIN
description: LEAD: SEVERAL recent developments have led to uncertainty over the amount of aid Long Island will receive from the state's $1.45 billion Environmental Quality Bond Act.

title: IRAN SALES LINKED TO WIDE PROGRAM OF COVERT POLICIES
description: The Reagan Administration's clandestine dealings with Iran and the Nicaraguan rebels grew out of a well-concealed program established in the White House at least four years ago to conduct covert foreign policy initiatives, according to many present and former Government officials.

title: Terrorists in Rome Kill 3 and Steal $900,000
description: In a clockwork assault that authorities said bore the handwriting of terror organizations, a postal van was robbed in a residential neighborhood here today, and three police guards were slain by assailants who made off with $900,000.

title: NORTHEASTERN STATES HOPEFUL OVER EXTENSION OF FEDERAL CLEAN WATER ACT
description: Poor, rural towns in Maine will no longer dump untreated wastes into once-pristine streams and rivers. Tumors will no longer grow on flounder at the bottom of Boston Harbor.

title:
STAMPS;
RECOGNITION FOR TWO AMERICANS
description: LEAD: The United States Postal Service has announced two February additions to its Great Americans series.

title: LESLIE MILLER IS BRIDE OF R.B. WORLEY
description: The marriage of Leslie Anne Miller to Richard Brown Worley, the son of Mrs. Martin Kamhi of McLean, Va., and the late Lieut. Comdr. L. B. Worley, U.S.N., took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Miller, parents of the bride, in Dillsburg, Pa. President Judge William W. Vogel of the Court of Common Pleas of Montgomery County in Norristown, Pa., performed the ceremony.

title: WORKERS AT SHELTERS PREPARE FOR ARRIVAL OF HOMELESS PEOPLE
description: Workers at the 23 shelters for the homeless operated by New York City prepared last night for a heavy influx of people driven off the streets by the cold weather.

title: Recent Sales
description: Bedminster $450,000 17 Union Grove Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, century-old colonial; hardwood floors, fireplace, greenhouse, 2-car garage; taxes $2,914. title: TRAVELS OF A ROCK
description: THE newest attraction at the Rockefeller State Park Preserve in North Tarrytown is a giant jagged chunk of rock at least 600 million years old. This mass of free-standing gneiss, almost 20 feet high and 65 feet in circumference, is probably the largest ''glacial erratic'' to be found anywhere in the county.

title: IN ADDING TO THE GUGGENHEIM, A LITTLE LESS GOES A LONG WAY
description: Those who believe that the Guggenheim Museum should have no addition whatsoever - that to tamper with Frank Lloyd Wright's masterpiece in any fashion would be akin to adding a few square inches to one of the Picassos or Braques that repose within it - will not be satisfied with the museum's latest plan, announced last week. The museum's architects, Gwathmey Siegel & Associates, are once again proposing to build a tower just behind the existing building; once again, the addition would rise higher than the dome atop Frank Lloyd Wright's great rotunda, and once again the result would be a marked change in the way in which we perceive one of the great buildings of the 20th century.

title: VYING FOR CONTROL OF THE PUBLIC CORPORATION
description: THE arrests last week of three prominent traders on Wall Street renewed concern about the takeover frenzy and the temptations of its huge profits. Much of the debate centers on how best to slow the torrid pace of hostile bids. But there is also a continuing argument about the extent to which the voice of the shareholder is heard in the board room.

title: CORNELL DEFEATS YALE, 86-74
description: Dean Kartsonas scored 26 points to lead Cornell to an 86-74 victory over Yale tonight to remain atop the Ivy League. The Big Red, 14-8 over all and 8-2 in the league, won its sixth straight game to go a game and a half in front of Penn. Yale fell to 13-9 and 6-4 in the league. Kartsonas hit 10 of 11 shots from the field and 4 and 4 from the free-throw line for Cornell. John Bajusz added 23 for the victors. Chris Dudley led the Elis with 23 points. Army 67, Holy Cross 66

title: JUDITH D. ALTSCHULER IS WED
description: Judith D. Altschuler Is Wed Judith Debra Altschuler, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Morton Altschuler of Silver Spring, Md., was married yesterday to Bruce Jeffrey Zalbe, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira M. Zalbe of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Mark Diamond officiated at the Greenbelt (Md.) Hilton. The bride, a graduate of Rider College, is a physician's assistant in Washington. Mr. Zalbe, who graduated from the University of Maryland, is an advertising account executive at Smith, Burke & Azzam in Baltimore.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
Helping the Young and Old to Buy Homes
description: LEAD: SURGING land costs on Long Island, a problem that even Federal housing subsidies have not offset, have made it all but impossible to build affordable housing.

title: Winds of the Antilles
description: STARTING WITH SICHUAN, moving on to Mexican and flourishing in the riffs of New Orleans, American tastes in food have been moving steadily south and becoming significantly spicy. Consequently, food watchers and eaters have not been surprised that among the new eats in town is Caribbean cuisine.

title: FIREWOOD: A DELIGHT TO ALL THE SENSES
description: WOOD warms you twice.

title: WHEN THE FOCUS TURNS TO FINANCE
description: THE problem with a CD-ROM-stored data base, as I mentioned last week, is that while it is fine for someone delving into history, it will not do for up-to-the-minute information like stock quotations or just-breaking news stories. For that kind of timely data, one's computer needs access by modem to an on-line data base. But here one encounters high connect charges and telephone bills, items leading all too easily to the taxi meter syndrome, wherein the user becomes acutely aware that every question put to the data base costs money and that every mistake seriously compounds the expense.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 15, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-25 A secret White House program established at least four years ago to conduct a variety of covert foreign policy initiatives was the origin of the Administration's dealings with Iran and the contras, officials say. Page 1 Brazil's souring economic situation has seriously eroded political and popular support for President Jose Sarney, tumbling the country into its worst crisis since civilian rule returned here two years ago. 1 Relief agencies are worried by the sudden relocation of many refugees under Khmer Rouge control in Thai-Cambodian border camps, a United Nations official said. 3 The earth's ability to sustain the pressures of population growth and economic expansion is beginning to be exceeded, warned a new report by the Worldwatch Institute, a Washington-based research group. 4 Andrei D. Sakharov appealed to the Soviet authorities to expand civil liberties and emigration during an officially sponsored conference. 8 Aleksandr Pushkin is still loved by thousands of Russians, a century and a half after the duel that took his life. ''He has become a household figure, almost a blood relation,'' one Pushkin scholar said. 7 A Beirut refugee district is desparate still. Despite the arrival of some relief supplies in the besieged Palestinian compound, thousands of people are said to be suffering from malnutrition. 13 A stop to the turmoil in the dollar and other currencies could be near, according to Saudi Arabia's top Government banker, who said the major industrial countries were ''coming close'' to accomplishing that goal. 15 Paul Simon performed in Zimbabwe, as close as he could get to South Africa's black townships where he found the harmonies and rhythms for his best-selling ''Graceland'' album. More than 20,000 Africans danced for six hours. 22 Corsican tax collectors are on strike because the French Government, which says it is fed up with tax evasion on the Mediterranean island, plans to make them pay the taxes they fail to extract from the population. 18 Few option seen to free hostages 11 NATIONAL 26-38, 50-54 Giving states authority to waive laws that define eligibility for benefits under health, education, welfare, housing and veterans' programs is the thrust of a White House proposal that has divided the Administration. 1 U.S. forecasters are lagging behind their European counterparts in the international competition to improve global weather prediction, according to meteorologists on both sides of the Atlantic. 1 Wall Street itself is on trial, along with the four executives who faced insider trading charges last week, for its role in the unprecedented corporate takeover boom of recent years, evidence suggests. 1 Japanese are moving to the midwest in record numbers, turning weed-filled lots into automobile plants and bringing sushi and shabu shabu to small-town America. 1 The issue of tobacco advertisements has become the focus of the American Bar Association's midyear meeting, pitting some of the nation's leading constitutional scholars against each other. 26 MX missiles are being put on alert in silos buried under the bleak prairie in southeast Wyoming. Since September, 11 of the intercontinental ballistic missiles, each with 10 warheads, have become operational. 35 Retirees are flocking to Colorado towns along the western slope of the Rockies, an area that was once expected to shrivel and die as a result of the collapse of the oil shale boom in the early 1980's. 26 Last August Rev. Pat Robertson won nearly as many delegates as Vice President Bush in Michigan's precinct voting, strategists for Mr. Bush concede, acknowledging that they overestimated their candidate's strength. 28 Duke University is debating whether to accept a large gift, $20 million, to establish a human futures institute because the donor wants a role in screening potential faculty members for the institute. 30 AIDS: Questions and answers 1 Nuclear tests called irreplaceable 34 WASHINGTON TALK 62 Feuding over criminal sentences REGIONAL 39-46, 56-58 Problems at the Javits Center, including electrical outages, poor supervision of service employees and long delays in loading exhibitors' wares onto trucks, have persisted since it opened last April, many exhibitors complain. 42 An AIDS victim renewed his vows of marriage with his wife at St. Patrick's Cathedral more than a month after the rector had refused to allow the ceremony. John Cardinal O'Connor welcomed the couple. 42 Reserving part of the lower west side as two districts offering tax and other incentives to tenants is the goal of a New York City real-estate association that wants to prevent corporations from putting their computer operations in the suburbs. 42 Alvarado rejected for school post 40 NEEDIEST CASES 60

title: Alexandra Mayleas to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Ruth Rothschild Mayleas of New York of the engagement of her daughter, Alexandra Rothschild Mayleas, to Peter Lindsay Heth, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Heth of San Diego. The wedding is planned for April 11. Ms. Mayleas is a daughter also of William M. Mayleas of Laguna Niguel, Calif. Her mother is a program officer in charge of arts for the education and culture program at the Ford Foundation in New York. Her fiance's father is an industrial engineer for the General Dynamics Corporation in San Diego.

title: Sakharov, in Public Forum, Asks More Rights
description: The Soviet authorities gave Andrei D. Sakharov an official forum to speak his mind here today, and he used the unusual occasion to appeal for more civil liberties and an easing of emigration curbs.

title: A May 9 Wedding For Betsy Zeltner
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Zeltner of Pound Ridge, N.Y., and Boca Grande, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Zeltner to Lawrence Brian Sorrel, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Sorrel of Scarsdale, N.Y. A May 9 wedding is planned.

title: STUDENTS' USE OF LIQUOR AND DRUGS SAID TO DROP
description: LEAD: THE number of New Jersey high school students who regularly use alcohol and marijuana is declining, according to a survey by the state's Department of Law and Public Safety.

title: TALKING: Small Outlets; Setting Up Shop at A Mall
description: AN artist or craftsman working alone often cannot afford the kind of retail space that will best expose his work to the buying public. With the cost of leasing even a small store on a main shopping thoroughfare prohibitive, his only outlets have been craft fairs, outdoor markets or perhaps - at the expense of a share of the profits - a consignment arrangement with a local art dealer or craft shop.

title: Miss Montgomery to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lawrence Montgomery of Irving, Tex., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Jane Montgomery, to Tyler Hans Hofinga, a son of Shirley Philippine Dixon of Riverside, Calif., and Peter Hans Hofinga of Irvine, Calif. Miss Montgomery is the director of media development and a product manager for Amscan Inc., a party goods company in Harrison, N.Y. Mr. Hofinga is a market support administrator for the information systems group of the International Business Machines Corporation in White Plains.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Los Angeles; Resurrecting A Failed Mall
description: SHOPPING centers age fast, especially in Southern California, and updating old ones often costs more than they are worth. But in the Crenshaw area of this city, a local developer and the city hope to confound that problem at a cost of $100 million by reviving and expanding the state's first regional shopping mall. In so doing, they hope to bolster the economy of a predominantly black community.

title: THE NEW C.E.O.
description: To the Editor:

title: FROM LEAD TO STEEL, SWITCHING THE SHOT
description: EVEN if you do most of your waterfowling in an area in which steel shot will not become mandatory for another few years, you shouldn't dawdle in facing up to the challenge posed by the Fish and Wildlife Service's announcement last year that such shot will become mandatory for duck and goose hunting throughout the nation by the 1991-1992 hunting season.

title: ROBERTSON GAIN SEEN IN MICHIGAN
description: Strategists for Vice President Bush, acknowledging that they overestimated their candidate's strength, now concede that the Rev. Pat Robertson won nearly as many delegates as the Vice President in the state's precinct voting last August.

title: Recent Sales
description: Bronxville, N.Y. $560,000 16 Courseview Road 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 52-year-old stucco Mediterranean; breakfast room, pantry, maid's room, playroom; taxes $8,210. Waccabuc, N.Y. $290,000 Chapel Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 33-year-old frame Cape Cod; pond, 9 acres; taxes $3,353. White Plains, N.Y. $270,000 98 Bolton Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 36-year-old stone/ frame split-level; eat-in kitchen, fenced yard, Florida room; taxes $2,767. Canton, Conn. $173,000 4 Colony Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 20-year-old colonial; sauna, walk to schools, 148- by 151-foot lot; taxes $2,285. Farmington, Conn. $255,000 28 Crosswoods Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 2-year-old contemporary; sunken living room; taxes $2,202. Richfield, Conn. $545,000 229 Ivy Hill Road 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 6-year-old converted barn; wide floor boards, heated swimming pool, 2.7 acres, taxes $5,601. OTHER AREAS Commack, L.I. $228,000 4 Town Line Road 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new contemporary; eat-in kitchen, dining room, den, fireplace, skylights, loft; taxes $5,100. Woodmere, L.I. $265,000 634 Hungry Harbor Road 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 25-year-old high ranch; eat-in kitchen, maid's room, 2-car garage; taxes $3,900. Closter, N.J. $174,900 21 Center Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; wall-to-wall carpeting, patio, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,559.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: W-o-r-c-e-s-t-e-r: No Free Rides

title: Article 387987 -- No Title
description: BY the year 2010, Connecticut faces the prospect of adding six new lanes to Interstate 95 and four lanes to the Merritt and Wilbur Cross Parkways unless steps are taken to ease the rising flow of traffic through the state's southwest corridor.

title: MCREYNOLDS AND REARDON DEALS GAVE SPICE TO A DULL WINTER
description: SIXTEEN weeks after they completed a runaway season by winning the World Series with an unforgettable comeback, the Mets head into spring training this week as the team that had to improve the least and probably improved the most.

title: Bishops Denounce Condoms
description: More than 150 Roman Catholic bishops meeting here have concluded that abstinence and marital fidelity are better weapons to fight AIDS than are condoms, which they believe create a false sense of security, a bishop said Friday. The group determined that health officials, in promoting condoms, might be misleading the public since condoms do not always prevent transmission of the disease, said Bishop Leroy Matthiesen of Amarillo. At the conference, Dr. Lamber N. King of St. Vincent's Hospital in New York presented a paper citing studies that showed condoms offered 70 percent protection from AIDS.

title: TOPICS: Urban Rites; Subway Song
description: Deep into the grimy city's bowels stride the subway riders. Purses jammed under arms, tokens jammed in hands. Jaws set. Eyes straight ahead.

title: Landmarks
description: To the Editor: The article about American landmarks (Travel, Jan. 18) mentioned the St. Louis railroad station and its conversion into hotels, shops and restaurants. That is an excellent conversion. I remember the station in the 1940's when it was active and contained a very large U.S.O. center for servicemen and women. It was one of the largest service centers in the nation, and I am sure many thousands of other World War II veterans remember it that way.

title: NEXT WAVE TRUNS A NEW CORNER
description: With its sixth season recently completed, the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival - the most publicized and popular American showcase for the new performing arts - is making plans that include more emphasis on European dance companies and increased roles for theater and opera. Very visibly at the peak of its success, the festival - it was called a series in 1981 and 1982, rechristened a festival in 1983 - appears to be at a turning point.

title: INFLUX OF JAPANESE CHANGING STYLE OF MIDWEST
description: Facing unionism, pork farms, country music and Yankee pride, a record number of Japanese are moving to the industrial Middle West, turning weed-filled lots into automobile plants and bringing sushi and shabu shabu to small-town America.

title: Poll Finds TV News Anchors More Trusted Than Reagan
description: Americans trust their spouses and television news anchors more than they trust their President, according to a poll released today.

title: How to Make Welfare Pay
description: Work can be oversold as a fix for welfare and a cure for poverty. Just ask the three million Americans who work full time and still can't escape poverty. Nevertheless, self-sufficiency through work properly remains the fulcrum of welfare reform. The challenge is to be realistic about just how much can be achieved through work, both for society and for individual welfare recipients.

title: St. Louis Board Favors Raise
description: Rejecting arguments that the city cannot afford it, St. Louis Aldermen have voted in favor of a bill giving them 48 percent pay increases. The measure, approved Friday 18 to 10, would raise salaries for the part-time positions from $12,500 a year to $18,500. The board must vote one more time next week, but the bill is expected to pass.

title: HIGH-GLOSS JAGGER AND A 'BORIS' TO BE CHERISHED
description: Mick Jagger: ''Running Out of Luck'' CBS/Fox Video. 88 minutes. $79.98.

title: THE AFFLICTION OF AFFLUENCE
description: HER fringed boots disappeared into the shiny black BMW. Attracted by the ''spoiled rotten'' sign conspicuous on the car's rear window, I watched her speed senselessly through the crowded parking lot.

title: Dario Then and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: LEARNING TO COPE WITH ILLNESS
description: ANYONE who has ever been ill for even a few weeks is likely to experience some depression, anger and feelings of dependency. For the chronically ill, whether they suffer with heart disease, arthritis, kidney failure, diabetes or any other long-term illness, these feelings are intensified, often overwhelming and potentially destructive to the treatment process.

title: BACARDI'S GLASS IS HALF EMPTY
description: A MAN, taking notes, hovers near the bar at Biscayne Babies, a popular haunt for young revelers in the Coconut Grove section of Miami. In Miami's Casablanca-like climate of international intrigue, he could be mistaken for a spy as he strains to hear exchanges between the bartenders and waitresses above the background din of rock music.

title: How David Salle Mixes High Art and Trash
description: Every year around this time you present an article on artists (or the life style which surrounds them) who, for the most part, are of one type, Basquiat, Clemente, Salle et al - what you consider the avant-garde (''How David Salle Mixes High Art and Trash,'' by Paul Taylor, Jan. 11).

title: PROTECTIONISM
description: To the Editor:

title: EXPERTS PONDER SPRAWL ALONG U.S. 1
description: ONE key to avoiding sprawl and gridlock along the Route 1 corridor region may be adopting ''centers'' as the basic building blocks of regional planning and zoning.

title: A WRITER'S FICTION
description: Joyce Carol Oates has been successsful in a wide range of literary genres, but she has failed to carry off her latest try at something different: a two-word fiction, the pseudonym Rosamond Smith. The author's longtime agent and her editor at E.P. Dutton were flabbergasted last week to learn that Miss Oates had signed with Simon & Schuster to publish ''Lives of the Twins'' under the false name. ''I'm quite stunned at this piece of news,'' said the editor, William Abrahams. Blanche Gregory, the agent, said, ''I just can't understand it.'' Her cover blown, Miss Oates, who has written nearly 40 books, explained that she wanted ''a fresh reading'' on her work.

title: HARTFORD STORYTELLER TAILORS THEMES TO THE OCCASION
description: LEAD: WITH more than 100 chidren sitting on the gymnasium floor, Gertrude Blanks tells the story of Rabbit, locked out of his house by an unseen but terrifying creature that threatens to ''crunch him and munch him.'' She hops about as Rabbit, jumps as Frog, transforms her arms into an elephant's trunk and slithers along the floor as the dreaded Caterpillar.

title: Reagan, in Radio Talk, Pushes His Health Plan
description: President Reagan, devoting his weekly radio address to the plan for insurance to cover catastrophic illnesses, said today that it would mean ''peace of mind'' for the elderly.

title: LITERATURE LOST IN THE THICKETS
description: UNTIL Henry David Thoreau in the middle of the 19th century, America had no great literature of place and scarcely even the beginnings of such a tradition. Here is an extraordinary cultural phenomenon once we begin to think about it, since it tells us that Americans after 200 years had not yet learned to make significant artistic use of the magnificent lands they called their own. Instead, their energies were expended in obliterating as much as possible of that original landscape and transforming the eastern portion of the country into a recognizable facsimile of the Old World. By the time of the Romantic movement here those who, like Thoreau, wished to celebrate American places were inheritors of a littered, occasionally even blasted landscape bearing scant resemblance to that encountered by the first whites. Before American places had ever been celebrated many of them had been so altered that no one could remember what they had once been like, nor could anyone recall what had happened in them. Americans believed they lived in a historical landscape and behaved accordingly, and so instead of poems and paintings memorializing their lands they would have for their monuments toll roads, treeless villages with the names of antiquity slapped across them, and stump fields. This is not to say that before Thoreau there were not a great many literary descriptions of American places, but these descriptions belong to the vast literature of exploration and settlement, and in it there is a persistent negativity: the emotional compass bearings of its authors remained on those places of the Old World from which they or their immediate forebears had come. In the Spanish accounts of shipwreck and disaster, the perils of the French Jesuit priests (the ''black robes''), the terrific hardships of settlers, the whole huge genre of the captivity narrative, and indeed most of the literature of the early republic, the modern reader, searching for some authentic sense of place, some Continued on page 34 assent to the land, becomes a kind of wilderness wanderer himself, lost in a thicket of resistance. He feels that for these literary pioneers the real world was always elsewhere, not wherever in America they were suffered to be. IF, however, we were to draw a more generous and accurate definition of American literature so as to include the oral literatures of Native Americans, then we would also have a strong, early tradition of the literature of place. For in these tribal literatures there are hundreds of narratives and songs that are truly born of particular places. Emergence myths, in which either a people or its cultural hero comes right up out of a particular soil, are common in the tribal lore of every region of America except the Northwest. So too, myths wherein the land speaks to the people and informs them of their place in the grand scheme of creation. In a Seneca myth, for instance, the people are instructed in the history of the world and of their place in it by a boulder that speaks to them in a forest clearing. Here, quite literally, the people identify themselves by a place, the totality of which they must subsequently come to understand.

title: SIMPLY SAILING
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Highway A1A
description: To the Editor: My father started coming to Florida around 1904. I myself have known the area around Melbourne intimately since 1925. Therefore, I was very interested in Henry Leifermann's article ''Florida's Grand Old Highway'' (Travel, Dec. 14). However, it is inaccurate to say of A1A: ''It was called Dixie Highway then . . . and it was the original U.S. 1 in Florida.''

title: WATCHING THEM WATCHING US WATCHING THEM
description: DEEP BLACK Space Espionage and National Security. By William E. Burrows. Illustrated. 401 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: AN OLD FEAR, A GOOD LAUGH
description: ONE second I was standing square on my feet, shoveling a light covering of snow. The next I was sprawled on my behind, sliding down the driveway. I did what a lot of other people have done in the last few weeks. I fell down.

title: A GROUPIE FOR GREATNESS
description: SUNFLOWER By Rebecca West. Afterword by Victoria Glendinning. 276 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: ROSTOPVICH'S CONTEMPORARY ROLE
description: Mstislav Rostropovich's ongoing 60th birthday party is somewhat larger than life, like his cello playing and his image, embodying the genial, sentimental aspect of the Russian bear. By the end of the New York phase, which began last weekend at Carnegie Hall and will run to March 21, he will have played 15 cello concertos in five programs with three orchestras, conducted four symphonies and the massive War Requiem of his beloved Benjamin Britten and played all six of the Bach cello suites for good measure. There are also celebrations in Boston, Tokyo, London, Berlin, Paris and, of course, Washington, where Mr. Rostropovich is marking his 10th season as music director of the National Symphony Orchestra.

title: COMEDIES WITHOUT LAUGHS MERIT CRIES OF PROTEST
description: As of this writing, about $71 million has been spent nationwide on tickets to see ''The Golden Child,'' starring Eddie Murphy. If ticket prices are assumed to be $6 in all parts of the country (though they're sometimes lower), and if discounts for various age groups are overlooked, that gives a low estimate of at least 11,833,333 tickets sold. Even if one quarter of these viewers were recidivists paying ''The Golden Child'' return visits, that would still mean approximately 8,874,999 men, women and children have seen this film. It may be that not one of them has laughed while watching it, not even once.

title: BUILDING SIZE CUT, BUT PLAN IS DEBATED
description: LEAD: DESPITE a compromise between the builder and some neighbors that has reduced the size of a proposed office building at a busy intersection on the Hewlett-Lynbrook border, other residents still oppose the building because they fear an increase in traffic and safety problems.

title: POLISH ODYSSEY: WARSAW TO OFF BROADWAY
description: ''Why do you write?'' I was asked by an officer of the secret police in Warsaw. ''An intelligent man does not write. An intelligent man does not leave any traces.''

title: HATS OFF TO HATS IN EVERY SHAPE FOR EVERY TASTE
description: BESIDES keeping heads warm, hats are providing a note of needed cheer these dreary winter days. On second thought, perhaps cheer doesn't quite cover the gamut of what hats are now providing, so let's add some words, like drama, adventure, flair and hoot - as in, ''That hat's a hoot.''

title: Victims' Testimony Key to Child-Abuse Cases
description: The conviction of a Mount Vernon man in a child-abuse case, after 18 children testified, came despite a national climate that experts say has developed against basing such convictions on the testimony of children.

title: 'Amerika' - an Irresponsible TV Series
description: LEAD: By now, most people know that today ABC will begin airing the first segment of a 14-hour mini-series called ''Amerika,'' depicting the United States in 1997 after 10 years of Soviet occupation. The series raises profound questions about the responsibilities of the mass media, especially of television, in the nuclear age.

title: NEW INSTALLMENTS IN MAHLER CYCLES ISSUED
description: Mahler continues to ride serenely along at the crest of his mainstream popularity (at least one trusts it's the crest; with all due respect to his music, it's daunting to imagine it even more popular than it is today). Even with the record companies devoting so much of their energies to compact-disk reissues, new Mahler symphony recordings continue to pour forth, unstoppably. Recent months have brought a steady flow of Mahleriana, all of it installments in complete cycles.

title: We Join the Great Line of Ages of Transition
description: To the Editor: I concur in Michael Harrington's confutation of the stereotype that people on welfare are simply lazy (''Jobs, Not Welfare,'' Op-Ed, Feb. 5). Yet I cannot but question his implicit argument that employers are simply lazy in failing to ''provide decent jobs for all.''

title: Maura D. Wray to Marry John W. Leddy on June 20
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Robert Wray of Greenfield and North Falmouth, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Maura Dianne Wray to John Walter Leddy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Francis Leddy of North Falmouth, Mass. The wedding is planned for June 20.

title: DOOR-TO-DOOR MEANT BUSINESS WITH A FLOURISH
description: I THINK of those old fellows -commercial pioneers, really -with the onset of the Lincoln-Washington birthday sales. I mean those ubiquitous gentlemen of yesteryear, ''the dollar-down, dollar-a-week'' men.

title:
TELEVISION;
THE SUNDAY MORNING SCRAMBLE
description: LEAD: It is 9 o'clock on Sunday morning and things are so quiet at the television networks that you can actually hear the call of a roseate spoonbill. Or an Eskimo curlew. Or a trumpeter swan. CBS is the only broadcast network to offer programming at this hour and, on this particular day, its acclaimed magazine series ''Sunday Morning'' is devoting a full 13 minutes to a passionate essay about birds.

title: 'Voice' Marks 40 Years of Broadcasting to Soviet
description: On Feb. 17, 1947, perhaps as few as 200 -maybe as many as 10,000 - Soviet citizens tuned in, using short-wave radios to listen to the Voice of America's first Russian-language broadcast.

title: WARREN AIR BASE ADJUSTS TO THE MX
description: Steadily, the Air Force is placing on alert the long-disputed MX nuclear missile in silos buried under the bleak prairie here in southeast Wyoming near Cheyenne.

title: POSTAGE-SIZE PROPAGANDA
description: Buying arms from the West, waging a protracted war against Iraq, taking hostages - Iran is and has been very much in the news. But Peter J. Chelkowski, professor of Near Eastern studies at New York University, has been interested in Iran for quite another reason. He has been studying its stamps, and he's not a philatelist.

title: SHOPPING CENTER EXPANSION OPPOSED
description: LEAD: THE Town of Southampton is receiving protests from residents over a proposed 132,000-square-foot expansion of the Plaza East Shopping Center in Bridgehampton. If approved, the new complex, to be called Bridgehampton Commons, would become the largest shopping center on the South Fork.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
RUTGERS IS TAKING A DETOUR ON THE ROAD TO 'EXCELLENCE'
description: LEAD: WHEN Rutgers announced that its $338 million building program would mean a 15 percent tuition increase this year and 7 percent more in 1988-89, opposition was vocal, as it usually is when college costs go up.

title: 120 JOBS MAY REST ON EFFECT ON FISH
description: The Little Androscoggin, a slip of a river that winds through Mechanic Falls in the hills outside Auburn, has become the focus of a fight between state environmentalists hoping to protect the river's brook trout and town residents hoping to see an idle paper mill reopen.

title: THE BARBARIC STEEL TRAP
description: I would like to express my gratitude for Elise Bell's compassionate article in which she voiced her surprise that the bill outlawing the use of the cruel steel-jaw trap recently adopted by the Suffolk Legislature is the first such restriction enacted in New York State [ ''The Barbarism of the Steel-Jaw Trap,'' Opinion Page, Jan. 18 ] .

title: WEALTH OF RICHES UNDER OUR FEET
description: HAVING safely passed the scrimp-and-save stage of my life, I have earned the right to be extravagant. Sometimes I am even a little wasteful. I am no longer a penny-pincher. I am, however, a penny picker-upper.

title: LAWYERS SING SELF-HELP SONG
description: LEAD: JOAN RIVERS reportedly wants them, as does People magazine, ''L.A. Law,'' Regis Philbin, Ted Turner and the Bally Casino in Atlantic City. Joe Franklin, State Senator Frank Padavan, Assemblyman Tom DiNapoli, Booth Memorial Hospital and the Long Island Board of Realtors have already been host to them.

title: NO STRIPED BASS? THERE ARE OTHER FISH IN THE SEA
description: THE absence of one of the most prized food fish from this area, the Atlantic striped bass, is to be lamented. Levels of PCB's in the fish led to a Government ban. What is the cook to do?

title: 'AMERKIA' - SLOGGING THROUGH A MUDDLE
description: The 14 1/2-hour production of ''Amerika,'' beginning a weeklong run tonight at 9, has been a costly exercise for the ABC Network division of Capital Cities/ABC Inc. In dollars, the mini-series, set in a Soviet-occupied United States in 1997, has added up to at least $40 million, or somewhere around $2.8 million per 49-minute (before commercials) hour. In terms of corporate image, the network is, with good reason, being forced to fend off charges that the project represents a cave-in to right-wing interests who loudly objected to the antinuclear message of ABC's ''The Day After.''

title: The Amerikan Way on TV
description: No American commercial television production has ever come remotely close to the sustained quality of British miniseries like ''Brideshead Revisited,'' ''I, Claudius'' or ''Ascent of Man.'' What networks do give us is elephants like ''Amerika.'' This 14 1/2-hour political melodrama, costing at least $40 million, begins tonight and tells a good deal about how ABC Entertainment regards the average viewer's intelligence.

title: Ms. Wennergren Is Wed To Theodore A. O'Leary
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York yesterday Sharon Wennergren, a systems analyst at Shearson Lehman Brothers in New York, was married to Theodore Arthur O'Leary, an assistant vice president of the New York Life Insurance Company. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title: CLIMB AND TELL OR, IT'S A LONG WAY FROM ANNAPURNA
description: THE dispatches of those who returned from exotic mountain ranges used to sound pretty much the same, waxing expansive on the fellowship and courage exhibited during some bold gamble in which everyone behaved marvelously. Even a saga as exciting as ''Annapurna,'' the story of the 1950 French ascent of that treacherous 26,504-foot-high Himalayan peak, celebrated selflessness, as when the veteran mountaineer Lionel Terray yielded>ju his chance at the summit to the author, Maurice Herzog.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: A MALAPROPISM IS a word or phrase that is amusingly off the mark. For example, a recent pamphlet circulated by the Department of Health and Human Services dealt with ''inpatients'' but stated that ''hospital insurance covers impatient hospital care.'' (Inpatient is a retronym based on outpatient; used to be, a person receiving treatment in a hospital was merely a patient, and only the hatchet-faced head nurse was impatient.) The eponymous -ism was formed from ''Mrs. Malaprop,'' a character in a 1775 play by Richard Brinsley Sheridan who used reprehend for apprehend and oracular for vernacular. Today, the word applies to any goofy linguistic mistake, like the unintentional irreverence in the simile ''drunk as the Lord.''

title: OIL SPILL'S LEGACY: BIRD RESCUE CENTER
description: There was an air of anticipation as Dr. Gregg Hesseltine gently removed the bandages from his patient's severely mangled leg. There was only a chance in a hundred that the operation was successful.

title: East Germans Sweep
description: East Germany swept the top three places in the 10-kilometer World Cup biathlon championships today at Mount van Hoevenberg.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THE Federal Environmental Protection Agency has renewed permits allowing New York City and the Army Corps of Engineers to burn wood on barges off the New Jersey coast.

title: ECONOMIC CRISIS ERODES SUPPORT FOR BRAZIL CHIEF
description: A sudden souring of Brazil's economic situation has seriously eroded political and popular support for President Jose Sarney, tumbling the country into its worst crisis since civilian rule returned two years ago.

title: Stephen Milstein Plans To Wed Eve Ohringer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Ohringer of ewlett Harbor, L.I., and New York have announced that their daughter Eve Irene Ohringer and Stephen Milstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Monroe G. Milstein of Mount Holly, N.J., are to be married March 14.

title: POSTINGS: 47 Town-House Units; New Co-op For Merrick
description: Some 250 buses still roll in and out of the terminal in Merrick, L.I., run for the last 30 years by Harran Transportation Company. But by April, when the company moves to West Babylon, L.I., the only vehicles seen at the three-acre site will be trucks hauling building materials as a cooperative development called Barclay Townhouses at Merrick begins its second phase.

title: Diana M. Hutz Wed To Mark E. Hoscheit
description: At St. Mary Magdalen Roman Catholic Church in Wilmington, Del., yesterday Diana Morris Hutz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolf Edward Hutz of Wilmington and Kennebunk, Me., was married to Mark Edmond Hoscheit, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Hoscheit of Hobe Sound, Fla. The Rev. Stephen Breen performed the ceremony Mary S. Alden was her cousin's maid of honor. Jon C. Hoschiet was his brother's best man.

title: CAN POLITICAL REPORTING BE OBJECTIVE?
description: THERE are many people who, from time to time, blame a biased and partisan press for unwanted election results. And for a few high-intensity races, that is conceivably true.

title: AS THE STAKES IN THE ART WORLD RISE, SO DO LAWS AND LAWSUITS
description: LEAD: Even to the untrained eye the trend is clear -both litigation concerning art and legislation to regulate it are growing at a rapid pace. A two-volume book, ''Art Law,'' by Stephen E. Weill and Franklin Feldman, discusses 146 court cases concerning the arts that have been brought since 1797, the year of the earliest English case.

title:
ANTIQUES;
FUN AND GAMES FROM BYGONE DAYS
description: LEAD: A RETROSPECTIVE exhibition of antique games, many of museum quality, will highlight the semiannual Bucks County Conservancy Antiques Show and Sale Saturday and next Sunday at the Middle Bucks Technical School here.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORTS;
RELEASED FROM FATHER'S EXPECTATIONS, A SON CAN FOLLOW HIS OWN PATH
description: LEAD: IT was the middle of Joey's second season before I saw him play soccer for the first time. About two dozen parents congregated near the team on the sidelines. Joey said they were all regulars. Not knowing that I was Joey's father, the man next to me nodded toward Joey and said to a friend, ''that's the grandson of Joe Lapchick.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
PITCH PINE
description: LEAD: Pinus rigida Size: Rarely over 80 feet, usually 40 to 50 feet tall.

title: HIGH-GLOSS JAGGER AND A 'BORIS' TO BE CHERISHED
description: Cornell Plantations: ''A Year in the Garden'' Cornell University Audio-Visual Center, 8 Research Park. Ithaca, N.Y. 14850. 19 minutes. Rental, $16 for three days. $70 to purchase.

title: KEY TO IRISH ELECTION: REAGAN-THATCHER ECONOMICS
description: The conservative economic ideas often identified with President Reagan and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher have become a key part of the campaign debate in Ireland this year.

title: SURVIVAL BEGINS AT THE DAIRY COUNTER
description: THE radio and television had threatened us with possibly 10 inches of snow. I knew my duty and dressed quickly for the siege on the supermarket. Where else does one head when disaster looms?

title: Count Rhode Island In
description: To the Editor: The New York Giants' Super Bowl victory was a sweet ending to an outstanding season for the team and its millions of fans. You should be aware that ''The Giant Apple'' (editorial, Jan. 27) underestimated the size of that apple. We in Rhode Island comprise a large and loyal group of ''New England Giants'' fans, even though the Giants have never played a game in Rhode Island. JEFFREY JARRETT North Kingstown, R.I., Jan. 28, 1987

title: Is This the Government Americans Deserve?
description: To the Editor: United States citizens are responsible for the frequent abuse of power by their Presidents.

title: 3 MILLION FISH AND 1,500 BIRDS FOUND DEAD AT NEVADA REFUGE
description: An estimated three million fish and 1,500 migratory birds have been found dead at a Federal wildlife refuge in Nevada, and scientists are searching for the cause.

title: 10% INSPIRATION AND 90% MARKETING
description: AS the inventors told it, the biggest problem isn't coming up with ideas, or even executing them, but getting creations to market. ''I have more than 200 ideas, I just need the right contacts,'' said Abbas Husain, a New Jersey doctor who received a patent this year for a ''safer nail clipper.'' By the end of the conference, more than a dozen of the inventors were convinced they had found a contact on the speaker's platform, or at least someone who could help them make a connection.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in The Times Magazine today titled ''Sakharov's List'' describes the events that followed Andrei D. Sakharov's delivery of a list to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, citing 14 men confined by Moscow because of their political or religious views. Dr. Sakharov argued that the men should be freed.

title: BOXER SHORTS AT THE BEACH
description: THE feistiest new fashion in underwear-as-outerwear is the boxer short. Even women don them for dancing and beach cover-ups, or layer them to peek out over trousers.

title: AQUINO TRIUMPHS, BUT HAS YET TO SUCCEED
description: ''SURVIVAL,'' said President Corazon C. Aquino's executive secretary, Joker Arroyo, with a disdainful flick of his hand.

title: CARNIVAL IN AUSSEERLAND
description: At carnival time in the Ausseerland, the lake district of Austria, nobody goes to school or work for three whole days. These are the Heiligen Faschingstage, or the Holy Days of Carnival, the Sunday, Monday and Tuesday before Ash Wednesday (March 4 this year), during which everybody indulges in a moveable feast of frivolity and carousing before the rigors of Lent.

title: MEMORIES OF A LOVE AFFAIR WITH CADILLAC
description: EVERYBODY has a weakness.

title: The Dash of Clash
description: Perhaps it's a reaction to the jangle of life - fashion is often identified as a mirror to the times. But whatever the incentive, there is a blast of brash design for spring. Realized mostly in accessories, but also in some clothes, this gust consists of vivid combinations of colors, mismatched patterns or punchy shapes and appliques -even all three. And, unexpectedly, it is showing up in some traditionally staid locales. While Karl Lagerfeld has been prodding the dowager image of the Parisian house of Chanel for some seasons, he has gone all-out this time, suggesting that familiarly shaped scarves, bags, hats, blouses and even jackets be made of fabrics that look as though they have been printed alongside the comics. In New York, a similar breakout is visible in a corner of the second floor of Tiffany & Co. There, in the newly enlarged leather department, are some of the most original handbags anywhere. Designed and produced in Paris, and made of the finest materials, they are examples of chic, if bold, fashion. Some of the new kicky designs will probably look passe posthaste, but many will not. It is quite plausible, for example, that several of the Tiffany handbags will remain a woman's signature for seasons to come, even achieving heirloom status.

title: MCI REPLIES
description: To the Editor:

title: A ROMANTIC COMEDY IN NEW YORK PREMIERE
description: THE setting is an Internal Revenue Service office.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: CLASSES IN NATURE Children can still be enrolled in Pace University's nature program, scheduled from 1:30 to 3:30 P.M. Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. The popular sessions, which are limited to 15 participants, have been operated by the university's Environmental Center for more than a decade, introducing children 5 to 7 years old to some of the finer points of animal, plant and aquatic life. This week's program was scheduled to accommodate the overflow.

title: OLFACTORY SOLUTION TO FACTORY ODOR
description: OFFICIALS tackled the matter scientifically when neighbors of a fried-fish plant in Doylestown, Pa., complained by the hundreds that the operation was giving off an offensive, biting odor. An ''odor panel'' was set up to sniff the air.

title: BENEFICIAL PARTIES IN TOWN
description: To Reduce a Deficit Feb. 19 - In its 18 seasons, the Circle Repertory Company has been in the forefront of presenting outstanding dramatic productions in New York. Marshall W. Mason, the artistic director of the company, and Lanford Wilson, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright, have collaborated on 20 productions, including ''The Hot L Baltimore,'' ''Talley's Folly,'' ''Fifth of July'' and ''Angels Fall.'' But the company has also managed to accumulate a deficit of about $450,000, so a deficit-reducing benefit performance of Mr. Wilson's latest play, ''Burn This,'' will be held at 7 P.M. at the Theater 890, Broadway near 19th Street. A backstage buffet will follow. Tickets, $500 or $1,000, from 212-691-3210. School Benefit Feb. 19 - As controversial as they are ephemeral, the works of the artist Christo have included wrapping the Pont Neuf in Paris and building a 24 1/2-mile-long fabric fence in California. The works may benefit from some clarification, however, and the artist will oblige with a movie and commentary at 7 P.M. in the Great Hall of Cooper Union. A Champagne supper will follow at the Grace Church School, 86 Fourth Avenue (10th Street). The evening will benefit the scholarship endowment fund at the 93-year-old school, which now enrolls 300 youngsters. Tickets - $100 or $15 for the Christo presentation alone and $10 for students - from 212-475-5609. Humanitarian Awards Feb. 19 - Five New Yorkers will be honored with the Roy Wilkins Humanitarian Award, named after the leader of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People who died in 1981. The New York State Conference of the N.A.A.C.P. will present the awards at a benefit cocktail party and buffet from 6 to 8:30 P.M. at Club 101, Park Avenue at 40th Street. Tickets, $75 and $100, from 212-704-0255. Asian Arts Feb. 21 - Asian CineVision, a community-based media-arts center, will hold a benefit reception with Indian and Thai hors d'oeuvres and Japanese beer and sake from 5 to 7 P.M. at the Pen and Brush Club, 16 East 10th Street. Asian CineVision, at 32 East Broadway, was founded in 1976 to serve film and video artists and promote interest in Asian and Asian-American arts by holding film festivals and other events. Benefit tickets, $5 at the door; raffle tickets for meals, concerts, lectures and art will be sold at $10 each. Information: 212-925-8685. Southampton Party Feb. 23 - A dinner dance for the Southampton Hospital, a nonprofit hospital founded in 1909 that serves the South Fork at the eastern end of Long Island, will be held at Maxim's, Madison Avenue at 62d Street. The black-tie benefit starts at 7:30 P.M. Tickets, $100, from 212-355-1214. Telephone Help Feb. 24 - A national telephone line for information, referrals and counseling on AIDS is maintained by the Fund for Human Dignity. (The toll-free number is 800-221-7044 for all states except New York, where the number is 212-529-1604.) To finance the information lines, the fund is holding a benefit at the 8 P.M. performance of ''Mona Rogers in Person'' at the Cherry Lane Theater, 38 Commerce Street, west of Seventh Avenue South. A Champagne reception will follow. Tickets, $20, from 212-529-1600. For the Fleming School Feb. 24 - The nonprofit Fleming School on East 62d Street will hold a benefit evening that includes a 6 P.M. reception at the Grand Hyatt Hotel and tickets to the 8 P.M. preview performance of ''Starlight Express'' at the Gershwin Theater. Tickets, $100, from 212-752-3025. Dance Party Feb. 25 - Cocktails at 7 P.M., followed by a 7:45 P.M. performance of the Stephen Petronio Company and a 9:15 P.M. buffet at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, 219 West 19th Street, will benefit the 23-year old Dance Theater Workshop, a showcase for avant-garde choreographers. Tickets, $60, from 212-691-6500. Wine-Tasting Benefit Feb. 26 - A 6 to 8 P.M. wine tasting at the Amateur Comedy Club, 150 East 36th Street in Sniffen Court, will benefit Cancer Care, a nonprofit social-service agency that provides emotional and financial support to cancer patients and their families. Tickets, $15 from 212-221-3300 or $17.50 at the door. Keeping in Touch Feb. 27 - Every day, scores of volunteers read newspapers and magazines aloud for transmissions over the In Touch Network, a closed-circuit radio network that reaches thousands of blind people around the country. Founded in 1977 by a stockbroker who was going blind, the network is holding its annual benefit party with an evening that includes a performance of the New York City Opera's revival of ''South Pacific'' at the New York State Theater. Cocktails at 6 P.M. precede the 8 P.M. performance. Tickets, $150, from 212-873-6770.

title: Military Cargo Helicopters Grounded for Gear Problems
description: All Navy and Marine Corps CH-53E Super Stallion helicopters were grounded today for inspection of a gear box problem that was found after a forced landing Oct. 21, a Marine spokesman said.

title: MUSIC: WUORINEN PIECE BY THE SAN FRANCISCO
description: ANYONE wondering why a major orchestra would travel 3,000 miles to give New York yet another performance of Stravinsky's ''Firebird'' Suite or the Brahms First Symphony might have found the answer in the other piece on this program Friday night. The orchestra was the San Francisco Symphony, that third work was Charles Wuorinen's ''Golden Dance,'' and what seemed to be transpiring at Carnegie Hall was one of those cat-and-mouse games symphony managements like to play with their listeners.

title: New Hampshire Weighs End To Longtime Law on Adultery
description: After 208 years, the New Hampshire Legislature may be ready to say adultery is no crime.

title: IN TERRORIST DEALS, IT'S EVERY COUNTRY FOR ITSELF
description: IN recent years, terrorists have systematically kidnapped foreigners as a means of extracting concessions from governments. In reacting, more governments have adopted new laws, ordered tighter defenses, shared information and resources and publicly vowed never to yield to terrorist blackmail.

title: Japan Outraged at Manila Abduction of Executive
description: For the last three months Japan has been mesmerized, appalled and frustrated by an overseas hostage situation of its own: the abduction of a trading-company executive in the Philippines.

title: Transported to America
description: To the Editor:

title: AN AMBITIOUS SAVINGS EXPERIMENT COMES TO AN END
description: I.R.A.'s are pro-family and pro-America. - Senator William V. Roth, Republican of Maryland

title: LIBRARY FINANCING
description: Donna Greene's excellent article on the current dispute between the Westchester Library System and the White Plains Public Library stated that Kenneth W. Leisch, president of the White Plains Board of Trustees, ''pointed out that the Mount Vernon Public Library got a $300,000 allocation from the central system because it had been formally designated as the central library.'' That statement contains two inaccuracies:

title: GOOD NOVELISTS, BAD CITIZENS
description: Finally there is something to say about Mona Lisa's smile. A current theory holds that ''La Gioconda'' is a self-portrait - Leonardo without his beard - and that the smile is, in fact, a trickster's derisive glimmer, a transvestite joke: five centuries of pulling the wool over everyone's eyes.

title: Bulgaria Accused of Persecuting Ethnic Turks
description: More than 1,000 people have been killed and 40,000 imprisoned during a campaign of ''forced Bulgarianization'' of ethnic Turks in Bulgaria, a former member of the Bulgarian Parliament said last week.

title: No Vermont Death Penalty
description: The Vermont Senate today rejected a bill calling for the reinstatement of the death penalty. The vote was 21 to 8. The roll-call capped more than a year of intense lobbying by proponents of the death penalty. Senators on both sides of the issue took careful note of the fact that public opinion in the state seems to be strongly behind the death penalty.

title: CONCERT: CZECH WORKS FROM MUSIC SPECTRUM
description: MUSIC SPECTRUM, a chamber-music series presented for the last three seasons by the Russian-Israeli pianist Boris Berman in cooperation with the Yale School of Music, offered an excellent if rather overflowing concert of Czechoslovak music Thursday night at Merkin Concert Hall.

title: Armed Forces Could Be a Chance to Start Over
description: To the Editor: Almost as an article of faith, James W. Davis, in his call for renewal of the draft (''Bring Back the Draft,'' Op-Ed, Feb. 5) asserts ''the armed forces, however, cannot go out and recruit the middle-aged.''

title: IN FIRST MAJOR EXHIBITION, ANOTHER GIFFORD COMES TO LIGHT
description: THERE used to be only two 19th-century Giffords to consider - the well-known Sanford Robinson (1823 to 1880) and the comparatively obscure Robert Swain (1840 to 1905). Now there are three, because the work of Charles Henry Gifford (1839 to 1904), uncovered by the historian John I. H. Baur, is having its first major exposure in the show that has just arrived at the Katonah Gallery from the New Bedford Whaling Museum in Massachusetts.

title: FOOD TAMPERING SOLUTION IS ELUSIVE
description: A FEDERAL official and two university professors say that no amount of Federal regulation can protect the public against anyone intent on tainting or tampering with food and drugs, as was done last week with a tea bag in a Princeton, N.J., supermarket.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Bourgeois Lips

title: INTIMATIONS OF TRIVIALITY
description: SOMEBODY ELSE'S LIFE By Morris Philipson. 298 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $16.95.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Collaring the White Collars

title: Elizabeth Stark, an Editor, Engaged to John C. Dugan
description: Justice and Mrs. Thomas M. Stark of Aquebogue, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Mary Stark to John Cunningham Dugan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Dugan of Potomac, Md. A spring wedding is planned. Miss Stark, a graduate of the College of William and Mary, is an assistant editor of Psychology Today in Washington. Her father is a justice of the Appellate Term of the New York State Supreme Court in Riverhead, L.I.

title: Highway A1A
description: To the Editor: We at the Nature Conservancy are grateful that Mr. Leifermann found the Blowing Rocks Preserve special enough to mention, but several statements about the preserve were misleading. Blowing Rocks is not a ''State Nature Preserve.'' The Blowing Rocks Preserve is owned and managed by the Nature Conservancy, a private, nonprofit conservation organization devoted to the preservation of natural areas and the plants and animals that depend on these areas for their existence.

title: ROCKY MOUNTAIN TOWNS REJUVENATED BY RETIREES
description: When the oil shale boom collapsed here in the early 1980's, a lot of people thought this tiny mountain community in western Colorado would shrivel up and die.

title: ALUMINUM WIRING MAY NEED ALTERNATION FOR SAFETY
