description: DURING the 1960's and early 70's when copper was in short supply and costs had risen considerably, thousands of homes were built with aluminum wiring instead of the traditional copper wiring. Although this was (and in most cases still is) perfectly legal and in conformance with electrical codes at the time, aluminum wiring has led to problems, and in some cases to hazards.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: A PRIVATE EYE'S VIEW;
WHY WALL STREET IS RIFE WITH CRIME
description: LEAD: The new series of arrests and guilty pleas on various insider trading charges last week left a lot of people wondering how hard the securities industry is concentrating on security.

title: Deaf Woman Files Suit On Her Jury Dismissal
description: A woman barred from serving on a jury because she is deaf has sued the Blair County judge who dismissed her, alleging she was a victim of discrimination.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: TWO EUROPEAN 'VISITS' Andre de la Varre Jr., a tour guide and filmmaker, will show his travelogue ''Switzerland and the Alps'' Friday evening at Snug Harbor on Staten Island. On Saturday afternoon, at the Williams Carlos Center for the Arts in Rutherford, he will present his film-lecture ''Vienna - Memories and Reality.''

title: WINDMILLS INSPIRE RESTORATION DRIVE IN NORTH CASTLE
description: LEAD: ''THERE are, indeed, few merrier spectacles than that of many windmills bickering together in a fresh breeze over a woody country,'' Robert Louis Stevenson once observed. Windmills, he wrote, ''put a spirit of romance into the tamest landscape.''

title: WEIGHING VALUES
description: 'The routine promotion of condoms through network advertising has been stopped by networks who are so hypocritically priggish that they refuse to describe disease control as they promote disease transmission. While portraying thousands of sexual encounters each year in programming . . . television is unwilling to give the life-saving information about safe sex and condoms.' - Representative Henry A. Waxman Democrat of California, at a hearing on condom advertising and AIDS.

title: HAVE THE METS AND YANKS CHANGED FOR THE BETTER?
description: The Mets will not win their division by 21 1/2 games this year, not because they have weakened, but rather because the Phillies, the Cardinals and Pirates will not all collapse at once.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: COUSINS. By Meto Jovanovski. Translated by Sylvia Wallace Holton and the author. (Mercury House, $12.95.) This slender novel by the president of Macedonian PEN, in Yugoslavia, tells the story of two young Macedonian peasants who try their best to avoid becoming entangled in disputes between armies at the end of World War I.

title: BOXING NEEDS NATIONAL BODY
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Austria
description: To the Editor: May I take the liberty of bringing to your attention errors in ''Austrian Pastry at Teatime'' (Travel, Jan. 25):

title: 2d Maine Senator Divorcing
description: Senator William S. Cohen and his wife, Diana, have filed for divorce, his office said. ''It is our intention to resolve all matters amicably and with mutual consent,'' the 46-year-old Maine Republican said in a prepared statement made public Thursday in Washington. Maine's other senator, George J. Mitchell, a Democrat, and his wife of 28 years, Sally Heath Mitchell, filed for divorce six weeks ago.

title: ESSEX TO HONOR 2 FROM STARS & STRIPES
description: ESSEX is a town where, in order to be considered a native, a person must have been born in the small village and lived there at least 300 years, said First Selectman John A. Johns.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: WITH Tomas Sandstrom out at least six weeks because of a broken ankle, the Rangers have recalled the right wing, Chris Jensen, from New Haven. Jensen, who was sent to the American Hockey League team two weeks ago, has appeared in 31 N.H.L. games this season with 5 goals and 7 assists. . . . After spending six years as an assistant for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, Howard Tippett has been named defensive coordinator at the University of Illinois. . . . Pat Quinn's temporary suspension from hockey for signing as general manager of the Vancouver Canucks while working as coach of the Los Angeles Kings has been upheld by the National Hockey League Board of Governors. Under the terms of the suspension, originally imposed by the N.H.L. president, John Ziegler, Quinn will be allowed to join the Canucks in June.

title: BRADLEY WARNS OF FOREIGN-DEBT IMPACT
description: THE foreign-debt crisis translates directly into lost jobs at home and lost sales abroad, according to Senator Bill Bradley.

title: SOVIET VIGILS HELD WIDELY FOR PUSHKIN
description: ''On this day, at this hour and at this minute, the heart of Aleksandr Sergeyevich Pushkin ceased to beat,'' the solemn voice intoned through the sound system at Pushkin Square here on Tuesday.

title: FOCUSING WITH A SINGLE-LENS REFLEX
description: THE current stampede to automatic-focusing cameras among single-lens-reflex users brings into bold relief one of photography's less-than-well-kept secrets: for as long as conventional single-lens-reflex cameras have been built and sold, their owners have found them darned difficult to focus.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the Practical Traveler column in some copies of the Travel section last week omitted three lines beneath the drawing. Readers wishing copies of the correct page may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: IN THE FLESH. By Clive Barker. (Poseidon, $12.95.) Those staples of recent American horror tales are nowhere to be found in the four novellas here; this prize-winning British author has no need for bloody limbs or disembodied heads, for ax murderers or nubile camp counselors. Instead, Clive Barker plays upon our unconscious terrors - a man transmutes into a woman after a strange sexual encounter, leaderless world governments are on the verge of running amok, a man realizes he has the potential to commit murder - and also on our innate fascination with the lurid.

title: REID DOMINATING AS HE LEARNS
description: LEAD: BEFORE its first practice session each autumn, the North Carolina basketball squad gathers for a meeting that Coach Dean Smith says ''sets the tone'' for the coming season. As part of the day's events, freshmen sit by with eyes closed while the other players decide which newcomer will carry the coaches' aged film projector on road trips.

title: Bic Sued in Lighter Accident
description: A man who says his wife died as a result of a butane lighter that ''exploded'' in her hands has filed an $11 million lawsuit against the Bic Corporation. Francis H. Smith contended in the suit, filed Thursday, that his wife, Ethel, died July 15, 1985, two days after her lighter burst into flame when she tried to light a cigarette. He blamed the lighter's defective design and inadequate safety features for his wife's death.

title: COMPUTER ADVISES ON ARTHRITIS
description: ELDERLY people who suffer from arthritis are being urged to take to the computer keyboard to learn strategies to fight their disease.

title: Regensburg
description: To the Editor: Readers of the article on Regensburg may well consider a visit there between May 16 and Aug. 9 of this year, when they can also view a spectacular exhibition devoted to Regensburg manuscript illumination (traced from the eighth century to the Renaissance). The exhibition, held at the Stadtische Galerie Regensburg, will be open daily from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. There will also be related exhibitions at the same time.

title: TODAY'S SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Cleveland Cavaliers At Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 3 P.M. Radio WNEW 1130, 3 P.M. Los Angeles Lakers vs. Boston Celtics At Inglewood, Calif. Television Channel 2, 3:30 P.M. College Duke at Notre Dame Television Channel 4, 1 P.M. Michigan at Michigan State Television Channel 7, 2 P.M. Golf Shearson Lehman Bros. Andy Williams Open At La Jolla, Calif. Television Channel 4, 4 P.M. Hockey Rangers vs. Pittsburgh Penguins At Madison Square Garden, 8:35 P.M. Television MSG, 8:35 P.M. Radio WNBC 660, 8:30 P.M. Oilers vs. Washington Capitals At Edmonton Television ESPN, 8 P.M. Other Events Auto Racing NASCAR: Daytona 500 Television Channel 2, noon. Boxing Frankie Warren vs. Gene Hatcher welterweights, 10 rounds Television Channel 4, 3 P.M. Ski Jumping At Oberstdorf, West Germany Television Channel 7, 4 P.M. Soccer Sockers vs. New York Express At San Diego Television SportsChannel, 9 P.M. Tennis U.S. National Indoor At Memphis Television ESPN, 1 P.M. Thoroughbred Racing At Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. Television SportsChannel, 6:30 and 11 P.M., taped.

title: BURGLAR IS EXILED IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: A judge who banished a thief from his hometown for three years says the punishment has worked out fine so far, but one victim says the man has been sneaking back.

title: Cruises
description: To the Editor: We have just returned from the island of Anguilla in the West Indies where we have vacationed at the same hotel for 10 years. This year we witnessed a most unfortunate wrinkle in the world of package cruises. Early one morning a large cruise ship dropped anchor in the bay near our hotel. The ship's tour operator, unfazed by the fact that Anguilla has no port facility except for commercial cargo, was not deterred. This vessel, equipped with its own portable dock and ferrying service, was self-sufficient. Four hundred or so passengers are carried to a beautiful beach for a day of food and fun.

title: Shultz's Way
description: What a curious piece on George Shultz. The nation cries for integrity in its public officials. When Professor Steel finds it, he calls it vanity. When an offhand answer is given to a fuzzy question, professorial pique erupts.

title: STATE FISCAL CHIEF CALLS CITY AID LOW
description: The state's Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, called this weekend for increased state aid for New York City, which, he said, has not asked for enough.

title: Pistons Draw Record Crowd
description: A crowd of 52,745, the largest regular-season turnout in National Basketball Association history, was on hand tonight as the Detroit Pistons scored a 125-107 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
GETTING BACK TO THE BASICS IS WHAT'S NEEDED IN GIVING BIRTH
description: LEAD: I WAS born in Buenos Aires on a hot summer night in February. My birth took place in my parents's bedroom, in the same bed where I was probably conceived. In attendance were the midwife, who also happened to be my aunt, and my father. My mother was 42 at the time and, unlike today, she was not considered a candidate for high-risk birth because of her age - just a pregnant woman.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: BRUISED FRUIT. By Amy Ephron. (Doubleday, $13.95.) Perhaps to differentiate herself from the bittersweet comic writing practiced by her sisters Nora and Delia, Amy Ephron has gone in another direction - toward bittersweet tragic writing. Her second novel, ''Bruised Fruit,'' is composed of the sort of affectless prose associated with stories about disengaged women by writers like Jean Rhys. Ms. Ephron has gotten world-weariness down on the page extremely well. So well, yet without making it her own - without making the impulse behind the narration convincing - that it is difficult to shake off the feeling that ''Bruised Fruit'' is intended as a sly sendup. But unfortunately, it probably isn't. Ms. Ephron's zonkette, Kate Bailey, is more or less trying to pull her life together after her lover's murder, in which she is a prime suspect. She does a number of things to pass the heavy time - lolls about the pool; moves in with a man named Stephen Carver, whose business is shadowy; goes after a part in a movie. Kate and chums drink Mersault, Calvados, Evian water, and pick at color-coordinated meals. Nouvelle cuisine - a little placed neatly on an oversized plate amid gray and pink restaurant walls - is an apposite emblem for a tale told by means of sentences like this: Stephen ''didn't leave a note, just a single stem of bougainvillea, pale purple bougainvillea with tissue-paper petals that resembled origami, on her pillow.'' Maybe Stephen is a Japanese flower arranger. Eventually the murder gets solved, but somehow the finally-flushed-out murderer seems much less a villain to Ms. Ephron than that vulgar color, red. The anemia in ''Bruised Fruit'' is so contagious that when you finish it, all you want to do is lie down and inhale.

title: CHURCH GROUP TO HELP NEW LONDON POOR BUY OWN HOMES
description: LEAD: MORE than a dozen churches in the New London area will soon be helping low-income families become homeowners.

title: REAGAN, APOSTLE OF LESS, ASSURES EXPANDED HEALTH CARE FOR ELDERLY
description: RONALD Reagan, twice elected on a promise to cut back social programs, may be remembered as the President who set in motion a historic expansion of Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for 31 million elderly and disabled people.

title: ROBERT STARER NOW AUTHOR, TOO
description: Many composers have written spirited memoirs - one thinks immediately of Hector Berlioz, Richard Wagner and, in our time, Aaron Copland, Virgil Thomson and Otto Luening. Next month the composer Robert Starer month the composer Robert Starer thors, with the Random House publication of ''Continuo: A Life in Music.''

title: With New Senate, New Vulnerability
description: IF speculation about Governor Cuomo's Presidential prospects has given him increased stature, it has done the same for some other players in state government as well. There is a feeling here among Republicans and even Democrats that this is a vulnerable time for Mr. Cuomo and that he can ill afford either an embarrassing legislative defeat or the appearance that he is not in full control of government. The result is that some legislators seem to have taken on a new assertiveness.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: FADEAWAY. By Richard Rosen. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) Harvey Blissberg of Richard Rosen's ''Strike Three You're Dead'' - an Edgar Award winner - is now in Boston making an uneasy career change from outfielder for the Providence Jewels to freelance detective. His sportscaster roomie, a gorgeous tomboy, is having her own job blues and can offer wisecracks but little help.

title: DOING BATTLE WITH LIFE
description: LEAD: THE AGELESS SELF Sources of Meaning in Late Life. By Sharon R. Kaufman. 208 pp. Madison: The University of Wisconsin Press. $22.50.

title: LAW OF CRICKET
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Virginian Paul Revere
description: To the Editor:

title: MUTUAL RESPECT AND COEXISTENCE
description: In the end, there was the sight of Valery Kamensky, the 20-year-old center and leader of the new generation of hockey talent in the Soviet Union, manufacturing a goal with a brilliant individual effort once considered uncharacteristic of his team's precise, group-oriented style.

title: BEST SELLERS: FEBRUARY 15, 1987
description: FICTION 1 1 2 WINDMILLS OF THE GODS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $18.95.) The nightmarish experiences that befall a woman and her family after her appointment as Ambassador to Rumania. 2 2 3 THE EYES OF THE DRAGON, by Stephen King. (Viking, $18.95.) A fairy tale, complete with an aged king, two princes, an evil wizard and a mouse. 3 3 29 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The West tries to stave off the Russians in World War III. 4 5 5 NIGHT OF THE FOX, by Jack Higgins. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) A mission to keep D-Day plans from being discovered by the Germans. 5 4 23 IT, by Stephen King. (Viking, $22.95.) Childhood horrors haunt six men and a woman who grew up in a small Maine town. 6 8 4 THE PANIC OF '89, by Paul Erdman. (Doubleday, $17.95.) A financial wizard undertakes to defuse the crisis besetting the American economy. 7 6 15 WHIRLWIND, by James Clavell. (Morrow, $22.95.) Iran during the month following the Shah's departure. 8 7 5 BANDITS, by Elmore Leonard. (Arbor House, $17.95.) A gang of three plots to heist millions being sent to the contras in Nicaragua. 9 9 16 FLIGHT OF THE INTRUDER, by Stephen Coonts. (Naval Institute, $15.95.) Navy aviators at war over Vietnam. 10 10 20 THE PRINCE OF TIDES, by Pat Conroy. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) Complex family relationships in South Carolina and New York City. 11 14 16 A TASTE FOR DEATH, by P. D. James. (Knopf, $18.95.) Inspector Adam Dalgliesh investigates a brutal double murder. 12 11 2 PATIENCE OF A SAINT, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Geis/Warner, $18.95.) A hard-bitten newspaperman learns a lot about his family and decency while on the trail of a wily politician. 13 12 4 THE COUNTERLIFE, by Philip Roth. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) More about the ambitions and anxieties of Nathan Zuckerman, who resembles the author in some things, sometimes. 14 1 WATCHERS, by Dean R. Koontz. (Putnam, $17.95.) Two creatures emerge from a secret government laboratory - one to spell doom, the other to spread love across the land. 15 13 4 DEATH QUEST, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge Publications, $18.95.) A hit man sets out to kill Countess Krak and seal the fate of the Earth; sixth volume in the ''Mission Earth'' series. NONFICTION 1 1 7 A SEASON ON THE BRINK, by John Feinstein. (Macmillan, $16.95.) A chronicle of one season spent with the coach Bob Knight and his Indiana University basketball team. 2 2 41 FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Dolphin/ Doubleday, $14.95.) Anecdotes and ruminations from the television star and father of five. 3 1 THE FATAL SHORE, by Robert Hughes. (Knopf, $24.95.) Australia from penal colony to its gradual emergence as a flourishing nation. 4 4 49 YOU'RE ONLY OLD ONCE! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $9.95.) A checkup at the Golden Years Clinic in pictures and rhyme; the first Dr. Seuss book for adults. 5 3 19 HIS WAY, by Kitty Kelley. (Bantam, $21.95.) From Hoboken to superstardom: an unauthorized biography of Frank Sinatra. 6 8 5 THE SEARCH FOR SIGNS OF INTELLIGENT LIFE IN THE UNIVERSE, by Jane Wagner. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) Acerb observations on life today; script of the show starring Lily Tomlin. 7 7 19 THE RECKONING, by David Halberstam. (Morrow, $19.95.) The crisis in the American automobile industry and Japan's role in it. 8* 12 2 REAGAN'S AMERICA: Innocents at Home, by Garry Wills. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The 40th President as the product and embodiment of an American mythology. 9 15 34 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author argues, and we must confront them in order to grow. 10 6 39 JAMES HERRIOT'S DOG STORIES, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) Fifty tales by a Yorkshire veterinarian about his favorite animal. 11 13 5 MARILYN, by Gloria Steinem. (Holt, $24.95.) A biography of Marilyn Monroe, with many photographs by her friend George Barris. 12 9 13 DANCING ON MY GRAVE, by Gelsey Kirkland with Greg Lawrence. (Doubleday, $17.95.) The ballerina recalls her checkered career. 13 5 21 MCMAHON! by Jim McMahon with Bob Verdi. (Warner, $16.95.) The autobiography of the quarterback for the Chicago Bears. 14* 11 7 ACROSS CHINA, by Peter Jenkins. (Morrow, $18.95.) The author of ''A Walk Across America'' takes his wanderlust to Asia. 15 1 ECHOES IN THE DARKNESS, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Morrow, $18.95.) A case involving the murder of a Pennsylvania high school teacher and the disappearance of her two children. ADVICE, HOW-TO AND MISCELLANEOUS 1 1 16 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS WITH WINE, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $16.95.) Recipes to be prepared at moderate cost. 2 2 19 MEN WHO HATE WOMEN & THE WOMEN WHO LOVE THEM, by Susan Forward and Joan Torres. (Bantam, $16.95.) How to cope with overbearing men. 3 3 35 THE ROTATION DIET, By Martin Katahn. (Norton, $15.95.) A regimen based on the Vanderbilt University Weight Management Program. 4 4 75 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 5 5 53 THE FRUGAL GOURMET, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $14.95.) A television chef's inexpensive dishes. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. In Advice and How-to, five titles are listed because, beyond that point, sales in this category are not generally large enough to make a longer list statistically reliable. * An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the bookselling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) THE MAKING OF THE ATOMIC BOMB, by Richard Rhodes. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) Short on heroes and villains, long on drama and suspense, this book offers both a close-up look at nuclear scientists and an overview of the century's pivotal event. WATCHING TELEVISION: A Pantheon Guide to Popular Culture, edited by Todd Gitlin. (Pantheon, Cloth, $19.95. Paper, $9.95.) Interesting and raucous essays about the tube. The consensus: it replaces the authentic with the artificial whenever possible. HIGH GROUND, by John McGahern. (Viking, $15.95.) High seriousness and low comedy coexist in the work of this Irish writer. His stories invoke passionate conflicts - between fathers and sons, men and women, Roman Catholics and Protestants. STRANGERS IN PARADISE, by Lee K. Abbott. (Putnam, $18.95.) Fourteen short stories, mostly about residents of a small town in New Mexico, written in an exuberant and inventive prose. MOLECULES OF THE MIND: The Brave New Science of Molecular Psychology, by Jon Franklin. (Atheneum, $18.95.) A provocative discussion of exciting research in neuroscience. Especially good is the compassionate reporting on the plight of the mentally ill. FEARFUL SYMMETRY: The Search for Beauty in Modern Physics, by A. Zee. (Macmillan, $25.) Science approaches religion when it assumes a grand design for the universe. Mr. Zee describes in detail the role of unity in modern physics and accurately conveys the religious beliefs of theoretical physicists. HOTEL SAVOY. Fallmerayer the Stationmaster. The Bust of the Emperor, by Joseph Roth. (Overlook, $16.95.) A darkly moving novella that portrays dislocated lives in Europe after World War I. The book also includes two of the author's short stories.

title: BUSINESS TRAINING FOR DISADVANTAGED
description: LEAD: WHEN a welfare worker told her about the business training program being started by the Regional Council on Education for Employment three years ago, Jerri Barker, a 40-year-old New Haven mother of three who was on welfare, applied and was accepted into the first class.

title: COMPLAINTS ABOUT SERVICE PERSIST AT JAVITS CENTER 10 MONTHS AFTER OPENING
description: Almost a year after its opening, the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center is still plagued by problems, trade show organizers and exhibitors say.

title: ISN'T IT TIME THAT SOCIETY DID SOME HEAVY THINKING?
description: COPING with terror is daily fare for oversize people. We peek around corners, anticipating threats to our dignity every time we leave the security of our homes. Stress and anxiety in public places are as familiar to us as tuna and cottage cheese.

title:
ART;
COMPUTER IMAGING: THE PAINT OF THE 21st CENTURY?
description: LEAD: SUSPICION and distrust often accompany public reaction to radically new art methods, particularly those that offer substitutes for the artist's hand. With computer art, however, our respect for the technology and our awareness that most everything else is electronically assisted lead us to want to give it every consideration.

title: WHEN QUENNS MULTIPLY
description: Positions that feature multiple queens must be handled in slam-bang style, since so much firepower makes slow maneuvering impossible. What counts is whose move it is, who gets to fire the first shot, who has the attack.

title:
DANCE;
JAZZ BALLET TO HAVE ITS PREMIERE
description: LEAD: HARMONICA and piano blues and boogie-woogie are the musical inspiration for a new jazz ballet that Robert North has choreographed for the New Jersey Ballet Company.

title: BRINGING SOWETO SOUND NEXT DOOR TO PRETORIA
description: It was in South Africa's black townships that Paul Simon found the harmonies and rhythms for his best-selling ''Graceland'' album, and today he brought that music as close to back home as he could.

title: No Headline
description: A review Feb. 8 of ''Watching Television: A Pantheon Guide to Popular Culture,'' edited by Todd Gitlin and published by Pantheon Books, contained incomplete price information. The book is available in hard cover at $19.95 and in paperback at $9.95.

title: LIBRARY CONTROVERSY
description: I am very concerned about several aspects of the controversy between the Westchester Library System and the White Plains Public Library [ ''No Accord Yet in Dispute on Libraries,'' Jan. 25 ] . First, the stories as presented to certain newspapers have been at best slanted and misleading, and, secondly, I have had people tell me that signs had been posted in the White Plains Library about curtailing services to nonresidents, when I had received no communication about this from the White Plains Library.

title: Highway A1A
description: To the Editor: Mr. Leifermann certainly did his share to perpetuate the Blowing Rocks State Nature Preserve as ''one of the least known'' beaches in Florida. I read the article while on vacation in Deerfield Beach, Fla., and was intrigued by the idea of visiting this attraction. I consulted the Pompano Beach office of the American Automobile Association for further information on Blowing Rocks and found that none of the travel advisers who were consulted, some of whom were longtime residents of the area, had heard of the preserve. The A.A.A. Tourguide book similarly made no mention of it. However, the directions in the article seemed to be quite clear, so my wife and I set out for a visit, newspaper in hand.

title: GROWTH, YES: INFLATION, MAYBE
description: Following last week's economic reports, the White House issued its customary response. ''Virtually all of the economy's vital signs point to a healthy 1987,'' Marlin Fitzwater, President Reagan's spokesman, said, forecasting ''continued prosperity under the Reagan expansion.'' On the question of expansion, there was little disagreement from private analysts. As Mickey D. Levy of the Fidelity Bank in Philadelphia, put it, ''the economy is set to break out'' of its recent pattern of slow growth.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: AND MY CHILDREN DID NOT KNOW ME: A History of the Polish-Americans. By John J. Bukowczyk. (Indiana University, Cloth, $27.50; Paper, $8.95.) This book is a valuable addition to the literature of our American immigrant experience. ''And My Children Did Not Know Me'' describes the historical forces that brought so many Poles to these shores, the difficulties of adjust ment, the close-knit Polish communities, the strong Catholic ties, the frugal habits that enabled Poles in a short time to buy homes and bring relatives here.

title: TALENT CAN CERTAINLY HELP, BUT A HIGH E.Q. IS ESSENTIAL
description: For ordinary success in music, almost everyone would agree, irreducible amounts of talent and training are important. But for extraordinary, flabbergasting success, nothing can take the place of a high E.Q., or Exploitability Quotient. Some musicians come by a high E.Q. naturally, some acquire it through diligent study and yet others have it thrust upon them by canny managers. No matter, a high E.Q. is arguably the firmest foundation for a major career in the world of serious music today. No one, of course, would question that it is so in the world of popular entertainment. Without an overdeveloped E.Q., the late Liberace himself might have been doomed to a life of playing Liszt and Grieg at community concerts.

title: MANY SEE SNOW, THINK SKI, FILL SLOPES
description: SKI OPERATORS are fond of saying that, ideal as conditions might be, most people have to look out in their backyards and see snow before they ''think skiing.''

title: PERTH AMBOY CHURCH IS 302 AND COUNTING
description: ST. PETER'S Episcopal Church here is preparing to celebrate its 302d year. It is the oldest Episcopal parish in New Jersey, dating from 1685, or nearly a century before the nation was born.

title: Westchester Rentals: A Dying Breed?
description: ''RENTAL housing is like a dinosaur,'' said Chester P. Soling, a landlord who has converted 3,000 apartments to cooperatives.

title: Article 947987 -- No Title
description: A philanthropist has withdrawn a $2.5 million pledge to finance a temporary pavilion for observances of the bicentennial of the Constitution because of a dispute with organizers over fund raising.

title: JAZZ: A SEXTET OF LEADERS
description: THE six jazz musicians who make up the group called the Leaders -because, in theory, they normally lead groups of their own - have not entirely separated themselves from the privileges of leadership in their performances at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, between Grove and Bleeker Streets, where they are appearing through today.

title: HISTORIANS CITE MONUMENT'S ERRORS
description: AS the nation celebrates George Washington's birthday this week, there is one series of events associated with the Father of the Country that some Dobbs Ferry residents might like to forget - and historians would like to correct.

title: STATE LOOKS AT FISHERS FOR A COMEBACK EFFORT
description: OVERHUNTING and the loss of habitat caused the fisher to become extinct in Connecticut. But it might come back next winter, with some help from the State Department of Environmental Protection.

title: INDIANA MAN'S 1977 AUTO COMPLAINT COSTS G.M. $19 MILLION
description: Arlie G. Skelton Jr. of Boonville, Ind., is no longer speaking to his neighbor.

title: Nancy Margolis Wed To Robert E. Risman
description: Nancy Ellen Margolis, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rodney H. Margolis of Houston, was married at Temple Beth Israel there last night to Robert Edward Risman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. George Risman of Birmingham, Ala. Rabbi Samuel Karff, assisted by Rabbi Dr. Hyman Judah Schachtel and Rabbi Dr. Henry Bamberger, performed the ceremony.

title: A GALLERY OF AMERICAN ORIGINALS
description: AT the expo held across the street from the conference last weekend, the emphasis shifted to the inventions themselves and the inventors were as proud as students at a school science fair.

title: Imprisonment Rates Similar In U.S., Canada and England
description: Adults arrested for robbery in the United States, Canada and England face a similar risk of serving jail or prison sentences, a study prepared for the Justice Department said today.

title: A CORRECTION
description: The caption with a photo of Mayor Sharpe James of Newark and Gustav Heningburg that appeared on the Opinion Page of Feb. 1, to illustrate an article by Howard Quirk did not credit the photographer. The photo was taken by Suzanne Poor.

title: 'PIZZA CONNECTION' FIGURE IS SHOT
description: Wednesday's shooting on a busy Greenwich Village street of a defendant in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial set off reverberations of fear in the New York underworld.

title: LEARNING TO MESH MIND WITH MACHINE
description: IN the operation of complex, modern technologies, the weakest link is often the human mind.

title: COMPUTERIZED TOWN DATA VANISH
description: All the computerized financial records of this Rocky Mountain community have been erased, leaving officials with no idea how much money has been spent this year or how much cash the town has left.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
SEEING SOVIETS ON THEIR TV
description: LEAD: Two radically different visions of life within the Soviet system are going head-to-head this week, and the battleground is American television. As ABC-TV broadcasts its mini-series ''Amerika,'' the controversial 14 1/2-hour speculation about what life would be like in the United States after a Soviet takeover, The Discovery Channel will show how Soviet television represents life within the Soviet Union to its own people.

title: Ms. Rothberg Engaged To Andrew S. Rowen
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Rothberg of St. Louis have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Anne Rothberg to Andrew Samuel Rowen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Rowen of New York. The wedding is planned for May 24. Ms. Rothberg, who graduated from Stanford University, is a candidate for an M.B.A. degree at Harvard University. She was formerly an account executive for the J. Walter Thompson Company in New York. Her father is the founder and president of the Manhattan Distributing Company, a wine and liquor concern in St. Louis.

title: AID OFFICIALS TROUBLED BY MOVES ON CAMBODIA BORDER
description: The sudden relocation of large numbers of refugees under Khmer Rouge control in a closed Thai-Cambodian border camp is worrying relief agencies, a United Nations official said today.

title: SONGS FROM THE NOMADIC HEART
description: VEILED SENTIMENTS Honor and Poetry in a Bedouin Society. By Lila Abu-Lughod. Illustrated. 317 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $35.

title: In Italy, a Drive to 'Revive' Study of Marxism
description: ''A Specter Is About in the Communist Party,'' the headline said, evoking the opening line of the Communist Manifesto of 1848.

title: CHANGERS FOR CD'S GIVE MUSIC BY THE DAY
description: Were special honors to be awarded for dubious achievements, the new compact-disk changers would rank among the leading contenders. Spinning stacks of CD's for hours on end, they stretch out the music beyond anyone's attention span and make it all seem vapid. Hailed for their nearly interminable running time, these longwinded changers are the culmination of a trend that - up to a point - made sense.

title: NEW ORDINANCE IN NORWICH OUTLAWS RAMSHACKLE
description: IN Norwich, keeping properties spruced up is now the law. A new city ordinance specifies that all buildings in the city ''shall reflect a level of maintenance in keeping with the standards of the community and not constitute a blighting factor for adjoining property owners.''

title: COURT HANDS TEXACO A CHEAPER DEFEAT
description: Texaco lost its appeal to get a $10.53 billion award to Pennzoil overturned, but the Texas appeals court reduced punitive damages to $1 billion, from $3 billion, making the total $8.5 billion, plus about $4 billion in interest. The award had been for ''wrongful interference'' in a Pennzoil deal to acquire Getty in 1984. The ruling puts greater pressure on Texaco and its chief executive, James W. Kinnear, to try once more to settle out of court. In addition, Texaco is awaiting a Supreme Court decision on whether the $1 billion bond it had to post should be increased to $12 billion - which Texaco said would force it into liquidation or bankruptcy.

title: GUNMEN OPEN FIRE IN QUEENS CHINESE RESTAURANT, INJURING 5
description: Four men entered a Chinese restaurant in Queens early yesterday, blocked the entrance and opened fire on a small group of diners, injuring five, one of them seriously, the police said.

title: TOPICS: Urban Rites; Spring Chicken
description: February brought a Brooklyn woman daffodil leaves standing up a couple of inches in her garden -since frozen - a pair of black and white ladderbacked downy woodpeckers and, best of all, a rooster gorgeously appointed with red cockscomb, full rufous ruff, red feathers shading into iridescent greens toward the tail.

title: ANSWERS ABOUT NEW YORK'S NEW RULES FOR SMOKING
description: Beginning on May 7, smoking will be banned in most public indoor areas in New York State and restricted on the job and in most restaurants.

title: THE RHINE STRUGGLES TO SURVIVE
description: For tourists, the Rhine will always be a broad brown ribbon running through the soul of Europe. In the mountain reaches, like the region between Mainz and Coblenz, it winds through wooded hills, its banks lined with sloping vineyards and green gorges capped by turreted castles.

title: IN RE PEOPLE V. PACS
description: Common Cause, the 260,000-member ''people's lobby,'' believes the current Congress may at last be receptive to some meaningful change in the campaign finance laws and procedures to curb the enormous growth, and presumed influence on policy, of political action committees. Under the aegis of an ad hoc group called People v. PAC's, Common Cause has mailed out nearly two million pieces of mail containing petition forms and requests for contributions to combat the ''undue influence PAC$ have on Congress and on Congressional decisions.''

title: DARIO THEN AND NOW
description: To the Editor:

title: FOUR WHO LOST JOBS -- AND HOW THEY FARED
description: LEAD: GRACE REEVES, 37 years old, of Asbury Park, who lost her job when a Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company plant in Freehold closed last May, attends a school for dental technicians.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
REVOLUTION
description: LEAD: Modern warfare may be a matter of fighter bombers and atomic threats, but in Revolutionary times it was considerably more personal. Women often followed their husbands to battlefields, children in tow - hence the term camp followers. They cooked for the men, dressed their wounds, and, when the battle was raging, often perched on hillsides and watched.

title: NON-MEXICANS SLIPPING INTO U.S.
description: Last year there were about 1.6 million apprehensions of would-be illegal immigrants trying to cross the border between Mexico and the United States. Most of these were Mexicans, but by no means all.

title: ISLANDERS NOT IN SCORING MODE
description: The Islanders are starved for goals, and tonight their hunger cost them another game, a 5-1 loss to the Buffalo Sabres.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
RETURN WITH US NOW TO COLDS OF YESTERYEAR
description: LEAD: THEY don't make colds the way they used to.

title:
GARDENING;
WHY SOME SHRUBS IGNORE THE CALENDAR
description: LEAD: IF you think that people sometimes become confused, what about spring-flowering shrubs that consistently come into flower in the winter while there is still snow on the ground. This happens not just occasionally or to one kind of shrub.

title:
THE N.S.F.'S MARVERICK CHEIF: ERICH BLOCH;
PUSHING IVORY-TOWER SCIENTISTS INTO THE HIGH-TECH RACE
description: LEAD: USED to be, only a handful of scientists and academics paid the National Science Foundation much mind. They had to - as the clearing house for Federal grants to universities for scientific research, the N.S.F. often held the purse strings for their pet projects. But to the rest of the world, the foundation was an ivory tower of esoteric research, nice to have but not very useful in terms of dollars and cents.

title: REAGAN AIDES SPLIT OVER BENEFIT PLAN IN HANDS OF STATES
description: The Administration is deeply divided over a White House proposal that would give states broad new authority to waive Federal laws defining eligibility for benefits under health, education, welfare, housing and veterans' programs.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: CROSS COUNTRY SKI INNS OF THE EASTERN U.S. AND CANADA By Marge Lamy, with photographs by George W. Gardner. 124 pages. The Stephen Greene Press, distributed by Viking Penguin. Paperback. $12.95.

title:
ART;
NEWARK: 'AFRO-DISPORA' SHOW, 'WITH AND WITHOUT ACCLAIM'
description: LEAD: ALJIRA ARTS is a large and airy loft space here dedicated to showing the works of emerging visual and performing New Jersey artists.This month, 17 visual artists have been brought together under the title ''With and Without Acclaim'' as part of Black History Month. They form a black and Hispanic grouping from the United States, and some have Caribbean or South

title: LOST IN THE JUNGLES OF THE 'SIMPLIFIED' TAX
description: MY husband and I sit here in our den surrounded by files, pads of paper, pencils and two calculators, preparing for our favorite annual event. The preparation of our taxes.

title: MANNING'S 26 LEAD KANSAS PAST SOONERS
description: Danny Manning scored 26 points and Cedric Hunter hit a key free throw in the final seconds today as Kansas took sole possession of first place in the Big Eight with an 86-84 victory over Oklahoma.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: Spring and Summer Captured in Silk The Corham Silk Flower Outlet in White Plains is spring and summer rolled into one despite what the weather outside is doing. Silk and dried flowers and grasses, foliage and ferns that stay green, thriving plants and trees that need no watering and decorative floral arrangements in every conceivable shade are available here.

title: Guitar: Pedro Baez, Latin-American Works
description: THE Argentine guitarist Pedro Baez, who presented a program of Latin-American music at Weill Recital Hall Friday night, is better with ''the big picture'' than he is with small details. His playing has a certain scope and formal grandeur - his interpretations have beginnings, middles and endings, and one rarely forgets where one is. But his passage work is not always as smooth as it might be: notes pinged and exploded when all should have been cantabile, and lyrical passages did not have the sonorous grace that typifies the most eloquent playing in this genre.

title: Lynn Brandi to Wed in June
description: The engagement of Lynn Brandi to Alvin Woodrow Bunis Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bunis of Cincinnati, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. E. Bruce Brandi of Scarsdale, N.Y., parents of the future bride. A June wedding is planned.

title: INCENTIVES URGED TO KEEP DATA JOBS IN MANHATTAN
description: The real-estate association that represents New York City's biggest landlords and developers is urging the city to offer special incentives in two districts on the west side of lower Manhattan to prevent corporations from putting their computer operations in the suburbs.

title: HIGH-GLOSS JAGGER AND A 'BORIS' TO BE CHERISHED
description: The Medicine Man Featuring Jack Benny, Betty Bronson and George E. Stone. Directed by Scott Pembroke, from a play by Elliott Lester. 1930. Video Yesteryear. Phone orders only: (800) 243-0987. 67 minutes. $29.95 plus $3 for shipping and handling.

title: WITH KEY EXECUTIVES' ARREST, WALL STREET FACES CHALLENGE
description: Four top financial executives stood before a Federal judge last week on insider trading charges. But it is becoming more and more evident that it is Wall Street itself, and its role in the corporate takeover boom of recent years, that is facing trial.

title: OPERA: SOEDERSTROEM IN 'DER ROSENKAVALIER'
description: ELISABETH SOEDERSTROEM played the Marschallin in ''Der Rosenkavalier'' at the Metropolitan Opera Friday night. As the schedule stands, the soprano's three performances in this role - Strauss's classic portrait of an aristocratic woman at the conclusion of a love affair and the threshold of thinking about the passage of time - will conclude her final season at the Met.

title: How to Pay for Welfare
description: The welfare system was designed 50 years ago for a different America. To conclude that the system isn't working may be the easy part. How to rebuild it is another matter.

title: SEOUL REJECTS OFFER BY NORTH
description: South Korea called on North Korea today to reopen suspended talks between the two Governments and rejected a proposal from Pyongyang for a new high-level political and military meeting, officials said.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HIDDEN SYMPTOMS. By Deirdre Madden. (Atlantic Monthly, $14.95.) Although Deirdre Madden's first novel is set in Belfast in 1969, it is more about familial love than Ireland's political struggles. In her view, however, the two are united: the loyalties between parents and children can easily be perverted into the sectarian hatreds that divide the country. Ms. Madden, an award-winning young Irish author, explores this theme through three characters: Theresa, an embittered university student whose twin brother was brutally murdered by Protestant terrorists; Robert, a disaffected journalist in his late 20's who has turned to atheism; and Kathy, Theresa's best friend and Robert's lover. All three are suffering from something hidden, just as Ireland, writes the author, used to contain its madness in small eruptions. For Theresa, the harsh secret is her brother's violent death. Robert, who considers himself removed from politics, conceals his need for his family's love with contempt. Kathy, at first the most easygoing of the three, discovers a darker side to her own nature when she uncovers a secret about her father. These characters evoke the reader's empathy even when their passions seem murky. Ms. Madden, for example, reveals too little of the nature of Theresa's desperate, almost incestuous love for her dead twin. And while the symmetry of their situations sometimes seems contrived, Ms. Madden writes movingly and often lyrically of the differences that lead these three to wound one another. It is their final inability to make peace that gives her brief novel its sorrowful impact.

title: Ex-Convict Is Accused In Miami Tourist Death
description: A man with an extensive police record has been charged with murdering a Canadian tourist who stopped to ask him directions to the Miami boat show.

title: FARM HOLIDAY FINNISH STYLE, IN WISCONSIN
description: To the lumberjacks who worked in Wisconsin's north woods a few decades ago, it was simply the Farm, where some of them passed the summer after spending winter in the logging camps. They found comfortable beds, hearty Finnish meals and good conversation around the kitchen table.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
MASKS
description: LEAD: NOW is the time of the Ceremonial of Midwinter of the Iroquois Nations. The members of the Society of Faces - were they here - would don their great magic masks. Over their real flesh, these medicine men would place pieces of wood carved into twisted grimaces. Then, wielding rattles made from turtle shells, they would go to the long house where their people dwell and blow ashes on them and dance and chant to rid them of disease.

title: MT. SIANI ADMITS FAULT
description: In a statement that left several important questions unanswered, the Mount Sinai Medical Center last week acknowledged that it had knowingly permitted an unauthorized - though successful - heart transplant operation last August on an indigent 26-year-old man from Puerto Rico. Presbyterian Hospital is the only institution in New York State with heart-transplant authorization, and although Mount Sinai has applied to the state for similar permission, the application has not yet been considered.

title: DEVILS' DEFENSE FALTERS IN ROUT
description: Tim Higgins, Dave Barr and Gerard Gallant scored within 1 minute 43 seconds in the second period to help carry the Detroit Red Wings to a 5-1 victory today over the Devils.

title: TREATING INVENTION AS AN ART FORM
description: JACOB RABINOW, 77, an electrical engineer, works as a part-time consultant to the National Bureau of Standards, which sets official standards for all units of scientific measurement. But he spends most of his time improving hinges or locks or ''just doing something in my head.'' Among his inventions are the automatic regulator once used in car clocks, the letter-sorting machine used by the United States Postal Service, an improved reading machine that digitizes printed characters for use in computers and the ''straight line'' phonograph, which replaces the traditional swinging arm with a system that produces better sound.

title: DETAILS OF CERONE PACT
description: THE former Yankee catcher Rick Cerone called George Steinbrenner and asked for an invitation to the Yankees' spring camp as an unsigned player. Instead, Steinbrenner gave him a $250,000 non-guaranteed contract. Part of that money, though, is guaranteed because just for showing up in spring training, Cerone is assured a 30-day share of that salary. If he is released at the end of spring training, Cerone will receive $61,813. That's more than the $50,000 that separated the Yankees and Ron Guidry on a two-year contract.

title: Miss Hudson Plans to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Donald Hudson of Boston and Peru, Vt., of the engagement of their daughter, Lauren Jean Hudson, to Roderick David Raabe Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raabe of Tokyo and Chathamport, Mass. A July wedding is planned. Miss Hudson and her fiance expect to receive M.B.A. degrees in June from the J. L. Kellogg Graduate School of Management at Northwestern University. The future bride graduated from the Hotchkiss School and Yale University. Her father is president of Transgenic Sciences Inc. in Worcester, Mass., and a founder of Integrated Genetics in Framingham, Mass., both biotechnology companies.

title: OYSTER BAY'S ROLE IN WATER PROTECTION
description: On Jan. 18 an article appeared in the Long Island section titled ''Nassau's Water Needs Protection'' [ Opinion Page ] . The piece asserted that Suffolk County officials are ''shrewdly'' pursuing Environmental Quality Bond Act money with which to purchase environmentally sensitive acreage while Nassau County and its municipalities are not.

title: MA'S PERFECT KILLER
description: BROTHERS By William Goldman. 310 pp. New York: Warner Books. $17.95.

title: 'I DROP BOMBS. THAT'S MY JOB'
description: THOSE WHO FALL By John Muirhead. Illustrated. 258 pp. New York: Random House. $18.95.

title: RIDING OUT SLUMPS IN A VOLATILE MARKET
description: WALL Street's unprecedented surge has made a lot on investors very happy - and very nervous. Those not content merely to take their gains and run are often forced to ride out the storms of a highly volatile market, hoping that the latest trough is not the start of a prolonged slump. Some brokers argue that such investors can have their cake and eat it too, by hedging their portfolios with put options. Such options give investors the right to sell a stock at a particular price over a set time frame, and will normally increase in value as an underlying stock sags.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: A BIT OF SPRING Just when we need it most, the Bartlett Arboretum has scheduled its annual Open Greenhouse from 1 to 3 P.M. today. A display of bulbs and flowers forced into early bloom may be seen at the arboretum association's headquarters at 151 Brookdale Road in North Stamford.

title: Elizabeth W. Mulligan To Marry L.R. Jaques
description: The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. John Mosher Mulligan of Islamorada, Fla., and Keene Valley, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Walker Mulligan to Lawrence Russell Jaques, a son of Mrs. Lee Jaques of Keene Valley and the late Mr. Jaques. A June wedding is planned.

title: LOOSENING UP EXPORT CONTROLS
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige has been fighting with the Pentagon for years, seeking to loosen United States export controls that he blames for billions of dollars of business lost to Europe and Japan.

title: TOURISM LURE FINALLY GRIPS A REMOTE ISLAND
description: A plan to begin helicopter tours to what Hawaiians call ''the forbidden island'' is being opposed by those who fear the flights would destroy the state's last enclave of native culture.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Chicago; Factory Comes Back Into Play
description: AFTER several false starts, an effort to revive an idled 650,000-square-foot Playskool plant on this city's economically scarred Northwest side is finally taking shape.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Nashville;
A Square That Won't Be
description: LEAD: A TOUCH of Hollywood and of Boston's Faneuil Hall is coming to this home of the Grand Ole Opry with the $25 million Fountain Square project. It is under development by Aladdin Resources, a local concern, and William Jackson Ewing of Baltimore.

title: MAKING OLD '21' YOUNG
description: ON A RECENT Saturday night, quite a few of the regulars of the ''21'' Club saw fit to knot their funeral ties and come over to the midtown restaurant to pay their respects. At the end of the evening, the restaurant would close its doors, only temporarily, to be sure - it will reopen in early April -for restoration, not renovation, as the new management is careful to claim. Still, a suspicion lingered among the assembled faithful that the night would be the last hurrah. It wouldn't do to miss it.

title: ISRAEL'S PIONEERS RETURN ON FILM
description: Hizma, Israeli-occupied West Bank Just outside this tiny Arab hamlet in the Judean hills, a hand-painted sign reading ''Dreamers Commune'' points the way to the newest Israeli settlement in occupied territory. Perched on a hardscrabble hillside 10 miles north of Jerusalem, this stockade-like settlement, with a watchtower at its center, looks to be more out of the Wild West than the West Bank. But, in fact, it is a replica of one of the original Jewish settlements of the 1920's, and it serves today as the backdrop for an international film production about the earliest Zionist visionaries who came to Palestine.

title: STRIKING THEATER PIECE EMERGES AT CROSSROADS
description: AN ELOQUENT performance by Herb Downer elevates the Crossroads Theatre Company's production of ''Williams & Walker'' from mildly instructive to mild entertainment to a striking theater piece.

title: HOW READERS READ
description: NATIONAL security and newspapers, often portrayed as at odds, may both benefit from technology developed by a Massachusetts company and being marketed with the help of the Princeton-based Gallup Organization.

title: PIER DEVELOPMENT PLAN AROUSES BOSTON PROTEST
description: As far back as many South Boston residents can remember, the large, semicircular pier that juts out from the northern tip of their neighborhood toward the city's downtown financial district has been used as a parking lot by people who work in nearby factories and warehouses.

title: DIOGUARDI OUTLINES GOALS FOR L.I. SOUND
description: AS a child, Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi said, he loved to fish in Long Island Sound with his uncles, but he fears his children may never get to cherish such memories.

title: Shultz's Way
description: I read with increasing distress Ronald Steel's attack on Secretary of State George Pratt Shultz (''Shultz's Way,'' Jan. 11). It is one thing to differ with a man's policies; it seems quite another to question his integrity because he differs from you on political issues.

title: NOTES FROM AN INVENTORS CONVENTION
description: NOBODY had built a better mousetrap, but there were plenty of other ideas among the inventors who gathered last weekend in Arlington, Va., for the Seventh Annual National Inventors Conference. Under the aegis of the United States Patent and Trademark Office, more than 50 inventors from around the country displayed their newly patented creations - ranging from a fortune-cookie folding machine to a shoe that allows its wearer to virtually walk on water - in hopes of attracting some commercial interest.

title: Lisbon
description: There's a fresh exhilarating spirit about old Lisbon. The Portuguese seem to have discovered that old is beautiful and brought new life to the fading city center. Some of the main streets have been closed to traffic, creating lively esplanades with open-air cafes and handcraft stands.

title: U.S. BILL PROPOSES LEAVES FOR CHILD CARE
description: AS Congress considers legislation aimed at protecting the nation's families, a measure that would guarantee unpaid leave for parents to care for their children is expected to become a hotly debated issue.

title: ON MY MIND
description: This is one of the pleasantest of cities, full of grace and the taste of history, capital of a country splendid in mountain and sea, and center of a society that captured the attention of all the Americas when it turned from military dictatorship to political freedom eight years ago.

title: PIANO: GUSTAVO ROMERO IN RECITAL DEBUT
description: AN interesting and perhaps important debut recital took place at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night. Gustavo Romero's choice of music was predictable, and it was cast in a predictably Romantic style. But this young New York pianist has qualities that elevate him a little above the faceless musicality we have come to expect from such events.

title: Revving Up
description: WHO WOULD HAVE THOUGHT THAT VIDEO GAMES - the sport of cola-swigging adolescents - would find a place in the ascetic, achievement-oriented world of beauty and fitness? With their promise of motivating, entertaining and amusing body-conscious exercisers, the new electronic fitness equipment is nudging jump ropes and stationary bicycles to the back of the gym.

title: KEILLOR SAYS HE WILL QUIT RADIO SHOW
description: Garrison Keillor, the host of the popular public radio show ''A Prairie Home Companion,'' told his audience last night that he would leave the air in June to return to writing.

title: 71 AIDS Cases Recorded in India
description: Indian health officials said Friday that at least 71 cases of AIDS had been recorded in this nation, and scientists said they were worried by the high number of women who are prostitutes among the total.

title: Road to Tibet
description: To the Editor: How we enjoyed reading ''The Roof of the World by Bus, Car and Foot'' (Travel, Jan. 18)! Last October my husband and I experienced that route from Katmandu to the 18,000-foot pass and under circumstances not much better.

title: TRANSPORTED TO AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE'S THEATERS NURTURING NEW WORKS
description: WHILE the state of the new play is imperiled on Broadway, it appears to be flourishing in Connecticut's theaters.

title: Shultz's Way
description: Ronald Steel's portrait of George Shultz depicts a reactive Secretary of State, largely unable to initiate policy and to anticipate problems before they arise. A reactive, problem-fixer Secretary of State with Mr. Shultz's background as a seasoned negotiator might thrive under a President who is himself masterly at formulating foreign policy. But when neither President nor Secretary take a very decisive proactive stance, it is small wonder that terrorism succeeds in controlling the agenda. WILLIAM E. COOPER Professor of Psychology, University of Iowa Iowa City

title: THEY GET LETTERS
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, read in Time last week that the magazine had received 46,000 letters on various topics last year. He had a staff member check his own constituent mail and discovered that Time was not even in the race. He received 537,886 letters on all sorts of topics. The most mail, an aide ventured, was probably on the tax bill.

title: Kemp Visits New Hampshire
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp made the customary pilgrimage to the site of 1988's first Presidential primary this week, speaking here and in Hanover on Friday. The New York Republican said he plans to announce his candidacy on April 6. Mr. Kemp allied himself strongly with the Reagan Administration, but said there would be some differences between a Kemp White House and the Reagan White House.

title: TRYING TIMES FOR A POPULAR PRIME MINISTER
description: BOB HAWKE is a casual, down-to-earth kind of Australian, a former union leader who in 1954 set a world beer-drinking record by guzzling two and a half pints in 12 seconds. Soon, he will try to set another record by becoming the first Prime Minister from the Labor Party to win a third term.

title: 'INSTANT PUBLISHING' MAKING ITS MARK
description: TWO weeks after the Giants'

title: CONCERT: INTERLOCHEN ACADEMY ORCHESTRA
description: THE Interlochen Arts Academy in Michigan celebrates its 25th anniversary this year. Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall, the academy threw itself a grand party, with a concert featuring the Interlochen Arts Academy Orchestra and the violinist Ida Kavafian (Interlochen '69) in a program that included Beethoven's ''Coriolan'' Overture, Mendelssohn's Violin Concerto in E minor, and Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 6 in B minor (Op. 74, ''Pathetique''), under the direction of Benjamin Zander.

title: THE UNSEEN WOMAN
description: ALL my life I've had this little problem. I seem to be invisible. When I look in the mirror, a wide-eyed woman stares back at me, but in groups I'm unnoticed. No, it's worse than that; I'd say unpresent.

title: PROFESSOR'S FREEZER RIDS BOOKS OF BUGS
description: LEAD: A YALE entomology professor who collects insects in his backyard and preserves them in his freezer has developed a technique for fighting book-loving insects.

title: POSTINGS: New Housing Judge; A Friend Of the Court
description: Working from the outside, Bruce J. Gould has devoted much of his career to upgrading Housing Court. But with his swearing-in last week as a judge for New York County, one of five new appointments to the court, he finally becomes a beneficiary of his own efforts.

title: Ms. Mead Is Wed To John Sullivan
description: The marriage of Jennifer Mead, a daughter of Donald Edwin Mead of Upper Saddle River, N.J., and the late Sonia Richon Mead, to John Sullivan took place yesterday at the Sara Delano Roosevelt Memorial House in New York. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Healy Sullivan of Cuernavaca, Mexico. The Rev. Dr. Melvin A. Hawthorne, chaplain at the Church Center for the United Nations, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Q and A
description: Troublesome Teen-Ager Question: Most of the families in our 20-unit co-op are quiet and responsible. In the last few years, however, the teen-age son of often-absent parents has progressively degenerated into an apparent drug addict. He looks and acts frightening and is physically repulsive. Our superintendent and doormen are on full alert when he is home. His parents travel for months at a time and seemingly do not want to get involved in his problems. The co-op board is very concerned, yet feels powerless to act because of legal repercussions. How can we proceed before this boy commits a crime in our building? . . . M. S., Manhattan Answer: Despite the difficulty of the situation, you are wise to proceed cautiously. Unless the youngster has done something that violates the law or the rules of the co-op, the board would have no grounds to seek an eviction. It cannot put out a family simply because it fears the son may cause trouble. ''If the situation ends up in court,'' said Stuart Saft, a lawyer who is a vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives, ''I think it would be difficult to convince a judge that, under these circumstances, the board acted with cause.''

title: INSIDE
description: Tobacco Ads: Legal Debate A plan that would prohibit the advertising of tobacco products has started a lively debate at the American Bar Association's convention. Page 26.

title: BULLISH ON DNA
description: BIOTECHNOLOGY The University-Industrial Complex. By Martin Kenney. 306 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $23.95.

title: Mexico
description: To The Editor: What was to have been a perfect family vacation in Ixtapa, Mexico, suddenly turned into a nightmare due to the onset of a life-threatening virual infection that attacked my daughter. The infection, incidently, was of a homegrown U.S.A. variety.

title: Aid Is Ordered for Girl's Surgery
description: A Federal judge today issued a preliminary injunction requiring Medicaid in Virginia to pay for the liver transplant of a 4-year-old girl who was denied aid because of the state's criteria on liver diseases.

title: The Low-Income Housing Effort
description: THE Koch administration is often accused of not doing enough to house low-income families, and when the vast housing needs of those families are measured against the city's programs, that judgment seems reasonable.

title:
ART;
IN HARTFORD, A VIVID CHRONOLOGY OF BLACKS IN AMERICA
description: LEAD: ''AFRO-AMERICANA: Images of Black American History From the Simpson Collection'' has been on view at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford since Independence Day of last year. It closes at the end of this month, the culmination of the nationwide observance of Black History Month, and so its virtues have even more luster during the last days of its run.

title: DO LOCAL SCHOOL BOARDS HELP OR HINDER?
description: COMMUNITY School Board 19, in the East New York section of Brooklyn, is composed of people with fairly standard backgrounds for a local New York City school board. Most of them work for, or are related to, or were once themselves politicians. There is a former assemblyman, two staff members of two assemblymen, the former staff member of a congressman, the sister of a New York City councilwoman and the chairwoman of the local planning board. Of the nine members, three - which is three more than last year - have children in the 27 schools that the board runs.

title: DOING BATTLE WITH LIFE
description: A CLIENT CALLED NOAH A Family Journey Continued. By Josh Greenfeld. 371 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $18.95.

title: COUNTY EXPANDS SERVICES FOR THE DEAF
description: WHEN Leslie Elion of Mount Kisco wanted to send flowers to a hospitalized friend in Chicago recently, she called the Westchester County Office for the Disabled.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
BIG, BIGGER, BIGGEST
description: LEAD: Think you've got a big tree in your backyard? Check out the white oak that's growing in Peekskill, a 90-foot mammoth with a circumference of 21 feet and 100-foot crown spread. The tree is ''probably 400 years old, maybe even 600,'' said Ted Kozlowski, the County Forester with the Department of Parks, Recreation and

title: Heroin Addiction Big New Problem in India
description: The two boys, grimy and in torn clothes, huddled in a corner of the cramped, dilapidated room, carefully opened a tiny white paper packet and emptied its brown, powdery contents onto an aluminum foil patch.

title: THE WHITEMAN CONCERT OF 1924 LIVES ON
description: Paul Whiteman's ''Experiment in Modern Music'' at Aeolian Hall in February 1924 has been remembered until now only because it introduced George Gershwin's ''Rhapsody in Blue,'' which Whiteman had commissioned for the occasion. Most of the rest of the program was an attempt by Whiteman to demonstrate the ways in which he was making ''discordant jazz'' palatable. The attempt was misguided, at least in part, because Whiteman's concept of the ''true form of jazz,'' even as late as 1924, was the original Dixieland Jazz Band's 1917 recording of a bit of howling, barking barnyard hokum, ''Livery Stable Blues,'' with which he opened the program.

title: DESPITE BOOM, PLANT CLOSINGS DISPLACE MANY
description: LEAD: TWO years ago, at age 43, John Barbee of Jersey City lost his $30,000-a-year job as a senior laboratory technician at Hoffmann-LaRoche in Nutley when the pharmaceutical company laid off 1,000 employees. He had worked there 18 years and was proud of the two-year associate's degree he had earned at Morgan State College in

title: NUCLEAR TESTS ARE TERMED IRREPLACEABLE
description: A top official of a Federal laboratory for the design of nuclear weapons said today that no computer simulations, however advanced or powerful, could ever replace the need for the explosive testing of nuclear arms beneath the earth.

title: ISRAELIS UNEARTH ANCIENT CITY WITH BULLDOZERS AND TROWELS
description: An ancient Roman city is quickly emerging here from a high-speed archeological dig in which the hated bulldozer is peeling back time alongside the painstaking pick-and-brush workers.

title: Blazing Ahead
description: THE NAVY BLAZER, ONCE AS PREDICTABLE as the gray-flannel suit, has undergone a subtle shift in character. Easygoing and informal in its previous incarnations, it has acquired a new urbanity that is evident in broad, exaggerated shapes and luxurious fabrics such as doeskin flannel, lightweight serge or silk.

title: THE FORGING OF A PACKAGE FOR URBAN AID
description: IT WAS difficult to keep track of the movement of legislative leaders and five urban Mayors around the State House last Tuesday, as well as the shape of the various urban-aid packages they were discussing. However, when the day ended at about 8 P.M. the Mayors, at least, thought they had achieved success.

title: AMERICAN,S SCULPTURE WILL TOP WEST BERLIN GATE
description: BUILT in 1907 in honor of King Frederick I of Prussia, almost destroyed by Adolf Hitler in the 1930's and by Allied air raids in the 1940's, and partially restored in the 1960's, the Charlottenburg Gate in West Berlin reflects the rich and turbulent history of the city. Now the Baroque-styled gate is to be embellished with modern art, American style.

title: Armed Forces Could Be a Chance to Start Over; The Use of Draftees
description: To the Editor: When James W. Davis laments the shrinking pool of volunteers for the armed services, I'm forced to recall the complexion of my outfit in Vietnam in 1969-70, when I was an Army draftee in Pleiku Province.

title: Chicha, Peru's Favorite Drink
description: If you want to see how incomplete was Pizarro's conquest of the Incas, go to Cuzco. Step inside the cathedral on the Plaza de Armas, walk past the altar of beaten silver with its monstrance of solid gold, and pause before a 17th-century painting of the Last Supper. Here Jesus and his disciples sit down to a meal not of bread and wine, but of cuy and chicha - guinea pig and corn beer.

title: Body of a Baby Girl Is Found Behind Building in Brooklyn
description: A 6-month-old baby girl was found dead yesterday afternoon in a two-wheeled cart behind a building in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Miss DeCrane Becomes Bride
description: Stephanie Ann DeCrane, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred C. DeCrane Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Paul Kevin Cavanor, a son of Frank Spafford Cavanor of Minneapolis and the late Shirley Dungan Cavanor. Msgr. James M. Connolly performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE SEED OF ABRAHAM: Jews and Arabs in Contact and Conflict. By Raphael Patai. (University of Utah, $29.95.) The seemingly endless antagonism between Israel and her Arab neighbors is particularly tragic when we remember how a common Judeo-Islamic culture, so-called by S. D. Goitein, the late Jewish Arabist, flourished during the many centuries that Islam held sway over Spain and the Near East.

title: Susan FitzPatrick Becomes a Bride
description: Susan Anne FitzPatrick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. FitzPatrick of Plattsburgh, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Bruce Leonard Pellerin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard H. Pellerin, also of Plattsburgh. The Rev. Gilbert B. Menard performed the ceremony at St. John's Roman Catholic Church.

title: COUNTY AND STATE PRESS EFFORT FOR AIDS CENTER
description: FOUR months after County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke convinced the Westchester County Medical Center that it should apply to the state to become the regional center for the treatment of victims of AIDS, the future of the center remains uncertain.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title:
GARDENING;
WHY SOME SHRUBS IGNORE THE CALENDAR
description: LEAD: IF you think that people sometimes become confused, what about spring-flowering shrubs that consistently come into flower in the winter while there is still snow on the ground. This happens not just occasionally or to one kind of shrub.

title:
MUSIC;
A GUITAR CONCERTO'S SPECIAL PROBLEMS
description: LEAD: Aaron Copland once told a prominent guitarist he couldn't accept his commission for a concerto because he didn't have the faintest idea how to begin to write for the instrument. That was 20 years ago, and things aren't any easier today for the six-string guitar, whose brief history and gentle nature also conspire against a concerto repertory.

title: Of Time And Place
description: OF THE REVIVAL STYLES THAT burgeoned during the 19th century, Gothic Revival is perhaps best remembered in this country for the so-called Carpenter Gothic, or gingerbread, houses built in the mid-19th century. Characterized by steeply pitched roofs adorned with decorative details, both the architecture and interior design were inspired by medieval English sources. Even today, this style remains among the finest exmples of American craftsmanship.

title: China Turning Juggling Into a State Industry
description: Some days, Zhang Chunlong said, are harder than others.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: IT USED to be that Exit 82 on the Garden State Parkway marked the beginning of South Jersey, siphoning off the last of the New York metropolitan traffic. Everything south of Route 37 was Philadelphia's fief.

title: Sloane Elman Wed to Barry G. Radick
description: The marriage of Sloane Elman, associate general counsel for the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan, and Barry G. Radick, a partner in the New York law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, took place last night at the Carlyle Hotel in New York. Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg performed the ceremony.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: KATIE MORAG AND THE TWO GRANDMOTHERS Written and illustrated by Mairi Hedderwick. Unpaged. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $10.95. (Ages 3 to 8) KATIE MORAG AND THE TIRESOME TED Written and illustrated by Mairi Hedderwick. Unpaged. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $10.95. (Ages 3 to 8)

title: Donor Shares Fixed Income By Giving to Neediest Appeal
description: ''A pension established in 1971 and Social Security do not leave a great deal to be shared with others,'' said Donald Bartlett of Chazy, N.Y., with a gift of $20 to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. ''I do this for the first time and feel better already.''

title: ALVARADO REJECTED AS CANDIDATE FOR SCHOOLS POST
description: Anthony J. Alvarado, the former New York City Schools Chancellor, has been rejected by Community Board 3 as a candidate for superintendent of public schools on Manhattan's West Side.

title: Spain Expelling 2 Libyans
description: Spain has told two Libyans suspected of fomenting an independence movement in the Canary Islands that they must leave the islands within 30 days, the Madrid newspaper Ya, a Roman Catholic daily, reported today. On Friday, the chief Government spokesman and Culture Minister, Javier Solana, said the Libyans' residence permits had been revoked for ''certain contacts'' on the Canary Islands, but he would not elaborate.

title: CORRECTION
description: The position of Senator Norman J. Levy, Republican of Merrick, on a gasoline tax to improve Long Island's roads was misstated in last Sunday's Long Island Weekly section. A spokesman for Mr. Levy, James V. Moriarty, said the Senator was opposed to such a tax.

title: TOWNS SPURN HOUSING AID AS CITIES CITE BURDEN
description: THOUGH the General Assembly will consider making available $100 million in housing aid this year, towns have still not taken full advantage of $35 million of the aid appropriated last year.

title: Some Developers Are Shifting From Condos to Rental Units
description: EARLY last year, less than a month before the sales office was to open for business at Grand Pavilion, a 480-unit condominium under construction on Broadway and West 56th Street, Jack Resnick & Sons, the developers, did an about-face.

title: RESIDENTS IN CAMDEN GET ALARMS
description: LEAD: A NEIGHBOR'S warning shouts and a beeping smoke alarm in a house on Garden Avenue here began at exactly the same moment last December.

title: COUNTY EXECUTIVES' TENURE AT ISSUE
description: THE contrast was stark. First, Long Island residents saw Suffolk County Executive Michael A. LoGrande standing shoulder to shoulder with Thomas S. Gulotta, his Nassau County counterpart, as they both declared a new era of regional cooperation.

title: POSTINGS: Class A Space; Offices for Lafayette St.
description: Lafayette Street, which runs southward from Astor Place just to the east of lively lower Broadway, has been undergoing its own renaissance in recent years with residential development, stylish new restaurants such as Indochine and the continued allure of the Public Theater.

title: STATE IS ORDERED TO FIND HOME FOR BOSTON HERMIT
description: The state has the right to evict a hermit living in a makeshift wigwam on public land, but it must find him a home where he can be close to nature and preserve his independence, a Housing Court judge has ruled.

title: Braving Epilepsy's Storm
description: I can't describe what strong emotions Kurt Eichenwald's article ''Braving Epilepsy's Storm'' (Jan. 11) evoked in me. I am a physician, and I, too, have epilepsy. Shortly after I graduated from medical school, in 1985, I experienced three seizures.

title: WHAT THE L.I.R.R. STRIKE DID TO MY MARRIAGE
description: IT was the answer to a housewife's prayer.

title: MUSIC: AURORA QUARTET
description: FOR reasons that are not entirely clear, California is home to a disproportionate number of young, excellent string quartets. On Wednesday night at Weill Recital Hall, the violinists Sharon Grebanier and Amy Lozano, the violist Basil Vendryes and the cellist Margaret Tait collectively proved that the Aurora String Quartet must be counted among the Pacific elite.

title: TAKING A STAND FOR DIXIE'S 1988 VOTE
description: ALTHOUGH it is still not certain whether a Southerner will be running for President, there is little doubt that the South looms large in the politics of 1988. Democrats decided last week to hold their national convention in Atlanta; the Republicans voted last month to take theirs to New Orleans.

title: MENUHIN TO START RESIDENCY AT HARTT AND 6-DAY WHIRLWIND
description: WHEN Yehudi Menuhin arrives tomorrow at the Hartt School of Music, his six-day residency in Hartford will include master classes, private coaching and rehearsals for two concerts with the Hartt Symphony Orchestra and Chorus, the first on campus Thursday and the other Saturday in Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Every shoe that drops I'm sure is heard in Washington.'' -Daniel J. Good, head of merchant banking, Shearson Lehman, on the crackdown on insider trading.

title: CONTRAS LOSING BATTLE FOR NEW AID
description: The contras seemed to be losing the battle in Washington last week.

title: DATA BANK: February 15, 1987
Inmate's Complaint Sets 2 U.S. Agencies at Odds
description: A bureaucratic dispute that began with an attempt by a Federal inmate to block punishment for his actions in complaining of hazardous conditions has brought two Government agencies to a Cabinet-level confrontation.

title: A SKID SCHOOL FOR DRIVERS
description: LEAD: DURING his early days as a stand-up comedian, Bill Cosby did a bit where he recalled pushing his luck by speeding on a wet road. ''I went into a bad right skid,'' he would say, ''and as soon as I went into the skid, I tried to remember the safe-driving manual: 'To save your life if you go into a skid, turn in the direction of the skid' .

title: Thatcher Son Marries Texan
description: Mark Thatcher, the son of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, married a Texas millionaire's daughter today in a private Valentine's Day wedding. The 33-year-old bridegroom is a Dallas auto executive. The bride, Diane Burgdorf, 26, is a bank employee.

title: AIDS Victim Married at St. Patrick's
