description: With John Cardinal O'Connor standing in the background, Maria and David Hefner renewed their wedding vows yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral, more than a month after the rector refused to allow the ceremony to take place because Mr. Hefner is dying of AIDS.

title: JORDAN HUMBLES KNICKS
description: The Knicks have grown used to waiting. It has almost become a pastime for several players, those who are hoping to be playing for another team before pro basketball's trade deadline arrives at midnight tonight. So the feeling wasn't new to them, even though the reason was.

title: Paul Hardin Wed To Melanie Hardy
description: St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Kinston, N.C., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Melanie Wilson Hardy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Noel Hardy Jr. of Kinston, to Paul Russell Hardin, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul Hardin 3d of Madison, N.J. The Rev. Claude Phillip Craig performed the ceremony. He was assisted by Bishop Paul Hardin, the bridegroom's grandfather and a retired bishop of the South Carolina Area of the United Methodist Church.

title: HEARTBREAK IN THE MONKEY PARK
description: ZERO DB And Other Stories. By Madison Smartt Bell. 179 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $15.95.

title: SURPRISE!
description: THERE have been scores of horror stories told about them, including the most famous, and doubtless apocryphal, one about a couple being summoned downstairs of an evening by a telephone call reporting an emergency. When they turned on the lights, they were greeted by a chorus of voices shouting ''surprise,'' but who was more surprised was moot because the couple had raced down without a stitch of clothing.

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: A WALKER IN JERUSALEM by Samuel Heilman. Summit Books. 366 pages. $18.95.

title:
GARDENING;
WHY SOME SHRUBS IGNORE THE CALENDAR
description: LEAD: IF you think that people sometimes become confused, what about spring-flowering shrubs that consistently come into flower in the winter while there is still snow on the ground. This happens not just occasionally or to one kind of shrub.

title: NEW NICHE: GRAFFITI REMOVAL
description: IF there are those in New Rochelle seeking the fame that came to Keith Haring as a so- called graffiti artist, chances are that they will remain unknown.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: AMERICA'S PRODUCTIVITY 'CRISIS';
A MODEST DECLINE ISN'T ALL THAT BAD
description: LEAD: AT THE heart of the debate about flagging United States ''competitiveness'' lies the anxious fear that the nation is suffering from a long-term slowdown in productivity growth. This trend, in turn, is said to be creating chronic trade deficits and widespread unemployment as more efficient foreign manufacturers gradually supplant American producers - in short, the process of ''deindustrialization.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: TREASON IN TUDOR ENGLAND: Politics and Paranoia. By Lacey Baldwin Smith. (Princeton University, $25.) Lacey Baldwin Smith goes further than the title of his book and argues that ''Tudor England imagined political life to be so exposed to naked villainy and so devoid of friendship and loyalty that only a James Bond could have hoped to have survived.'' Focusing on three notorious but bungling conspirators - court groupie Gregory (Sweet-Lips) Botolf, would-be king-napper Thomas Seymour, and the flamboyantly mad Dr. William Parry, who sought to time his planned murder of Queen Elizabeth with an invasion by Scotland - Mr. Smith maintains that Tudor society was obsessed with fingering pathetically unstable figures who were of no real threat to the crown. Even Tudor schools, he maintains, conditioned children to a paranoid style of thought, leading to what he identifies as the primary flaw of the Tudor age - failure to conceive of a loyal opposition. But paranoia is a psychological term, and Mr. Smith's attempts to explain historical events in its context become dubious. Was Robert Devereux, the Earl of Essex, a paranoid personality, as Mr. Smith suggests? Not if one considers that he may have suffered from syphilis and that he had a powerful enemy at court in Robert Cecil. But if Mr. Smith, a professor of English history at Northwestern University, sometimes fails to persuade, he never ceases to be witty and spirited. It would be a pity if his provocative theory were to obscure what is in fact a wide-ranging, splendidly detailed history.

title: CONSIDERING WHETHER TO PLAY OR DEFEND
description: In the world of bridge, as in society at large, arguments about public smoking have been going on for many years. The non-smokers appear to be on the verge of victory.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: RECITATIVE: Prose by James Merrill. Edited and with an introduction by J. D. McClatchy. (North Point, Cloth, $25; Paper, $12.50.) J. D. McClatchy, a poet and the poetry editor of The Yale Review, has collected here a strange yet intriguing potpourri of the poet James Merrill's prose - essays, lectures, short stories and even interviews with him.

title: LAWYERS DEBATING BAN ON TOBACCO ADVERTISING
description: A personal crusade against tobacco advertising by a lawyer from White Plains, N.Y., has catapulted the issue to center stage at the American Bar Association's convention here.

title: OFFICIALS SEEK TO CURB TAINTED FOOD OUTBREAKS
description: AFTER three outbreaks of salmonella illness in three months, health officials and lawmakers in the state are looking for measures to counter this type of food poisoning.

title: UNDER SIEGE IN LUANDA
description: ANOTHER DAY OF LIFE By Ryszard Kapuscinski. Translated by William R. Brand and Katarzyna Mroczkowska-Brand. 136 pp. San Diego: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $14.95.

title: A Time for Watches
description: THE SOUND IS ALWAYS with me - an insistent, rhythmic series of short happy chirps. Like a loyal, friendly cricket, it follows me wherever I go. I hear it at the opera when I rest my head in my hand. It perches beside my bed, singing as I go to sleep, as I wake up. It is my link to the world, my conscience, a reaffirmation of order and integrity in the face of hideous gaping chaos. It is my watch. My Swatch watch.

title: FEW OPTIONS SEEN TO FREE HOSTAGES
description: Administration officials said today that gaining the release of eight American hostages held in Lebanon might be impossible.

title: STUDENTS PRESENT HISTORY PAPERS
description: WHEN scholars get together to discuss their research, it is usually at the college or graduate-school level. But last Wednesday 175 seniors from six high schools in the county participated in a daylong European History Colloquium at the New Rochelle High School. The students - from Scarsdale, Pelham, Dobbs Ferry, Hastings-on-Hudson, Mamaroneck and New Rochelle, gathered to present and discuss papers they had written during the fall in their advanced-placement European-history courses.

title: Elderly Homeowners to Get Help With Repairs
description: BECAUSE of the often prohibitive cost of paying for major energy-related and other home repairs, the New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development is starting a demonstration program to provide low-interest deferred loans for qualified elderly low- to moderate-income homeowners.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: LEAD: THE completed merger of the Midlantic Corporation, an Edison-based bank holding company, with Continental Bancorp Inc. of Philadelphia on Jan. 30 made Midlantic the largest such holding company in New Jersey.

title: Shultz's Way
description: Ronald Steel's article contains an error which an astute Wagnerite would pick up. His reference to Mr. Shultz as an ''improbably stolid Siegfried'' is improbable mostly because it is Siegfried's father, Siegmund, who drew the sword from the tree.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a map on Jan. 18 of Istanbul incorrectly showed the locations of two restaurants, and the caption for a photograph incorrectly identified a restaurant. The Ziya and Samdan (there are other restaurants also called Samdan in Istanbul) restaurants are in the modern city, and the restaurant identified in the caption as the Samdan was actually the Hidiv Kasri.

title: AN IRISH ROVER COMES HOME TO THE ABBEY
description: In a remarkable essay entitled ''A People's Theater'' (1919), W. B. Yeats, the founder of the Abbey Theater, described two seemingly opposed yet integrally related traditions in modern Irish drama. The first was that of the social realists who, by focusing on the problems faced by people in their daily lives, had helped Irishmen to gain a greater understanding of themselves in relation to the life of Ireland as a whole.

title: Q and A
description: Motor-Home Trip Question: Would it be possible to rent a trailer in San Diego large enough for two people (both 65) and leave it in Seattle? How can we make arrangements for such a tour? -A. J. G., Ormond, Fla. Answer: Yes, but there is a drop-off charge. Travelers planning to set out on a long tour aboard a recreational vehicle for the first time should study some of the advisory material that is available. One source of information is the Recreation Vehicle Industry Association (Post Office Box 2999, Reston, Va. 22090), which issues what it calls the R.V. Life Style Publications Catalogue. The catalogue, obtained by sending a self-addressed, stamped envelope, lists about 30 publications, some of them free, that can be ordered from the association. But it charges $2 postage for some of the books on its list, and these can be purchased at many bookstores. Among these are four campground guides, including ''Trailer Life's R.V. Campground and Services Directory'' (Rand McNally, $13.95) and ''Woodall's Campground Directory,'' which comes in two volumes, one for the East, one for the West ($7.95 each). ''Who's Who in R.V. Rentals'' ($4), which lists renters all over the country, is available for $4, including postage, from its publisher, the Recreation Vehicle Rental Association (Suite 500, 3251 Old Lee Highway, Fairfax, Va. 22030; 703-591-7130 and, out of state, 800-336-0355). In addition to renters' addresses, the rentals guide describes the various vehicles available and lists their equipment.

title: RIVETING ATTENTION ON CHARITY DRIVE
description: AFTER trying such themes as ''Love Thy Neighbor,'' the United Way in Burlington, Vt., went in for shock effect in its charity drive last fall - ''reality,'' the group called it.

title: BABY M ADDS URGENCY TO SEARCH FOR EQUITABLE LAWS
description: SURROGATE motherhood presents such troublesome ethical and legal dilemmas that most state legislatures have declined to confront the issue. Those that have tried have been discouraged in their attempts to regulate the practice. Most bills have died in committee, while those that have survived have gone on to defeat.

title: CORSICA DEATH AND TAXES: ONLY FORMER IS INEVTIABLE
description: ''Look what a tax collector in a mountain village just received!'' shouted Francois Pacquere, a young man with a mustache and darting black eyes.

title: OLD MOVIE HOUSES EVOKE AN ERA
description: LEAD: TO view the lavish productions rolling out of Hollywood in the 1930's, Long Island entrepreneurs built elegant movie palaces.

title: IT'S ALMOST LIKE A VISIT TO ITALY
description: WHEN you walk through the door of Tre Amici in Babylon, you forget you're on Long Island. The brass railings, fresh flowers on the bar, the antique breakfront and the espresso machine all say Italy.

title: FACT, THEORY AND MYTH ON THE SPREAD OF AIDS
description: As AIDS continues its spread, mounting fear over the epidemic has been matched by persistent confusion over how the virus that causes the disease is transmitted.

title: GESTATION WITH A VENGEANCE
description: THE LAST SONG OF MANUEL SENDERO By Ariel Dorfman. Translated by George R. Shivers with the author. 450 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: MEASURE OF FAME
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LEAD: HAVE MUSIC, WILL TRAVEL For the record, it's known as the Sea Cliff Chamber Players. But that's only because of an accident of birth. The group, one of the Island's leading and more venerable chamber ensembles, was organized by two professional musicians, Herb Sucoff and Barbara Speer, who just happened to live in that quaint North Shore village and described themselves geographically.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: FATE OF LONG BEACH TENANTS: A CLUE TO CITY'S FUTURE?
description: THE cold wind whipped off the ocean, sending frigid sea spray in the direction of the few who ventured out on the Long Beach boardwalk. A few hundred feet away, on the second floor balcony of a small garden apartment, Susan Montana proudly surveyed her ocean view.

title: Boy, 11, Shot to Death; 2d Shooting Injures Girl
description: An 11-year-old boy was killed and a 12-year-old girl was critically wounded in unrelated shootings yesterday afternoon in Brooklyn and Queens, the police reported.

title:
DINING OUT;
CHINESE DISHES IN PELHAM
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH parking can be a trial, once inside the restaurant, most diners will agree that General Tsao makes a soothing spot for a meal. Dark green walls hung with pleasant modern Chinese paintings and calligraphy, pin lights and greenery and comfortable chairs reinforce the pretty greenhouse motif.

title: Cable TV
description: What's in a movie title? ''House'' (1986), for instance, conveys nothing, yet it's a perfect fit for the original, entertaining suspense yarn that will be shown on Sunday at 12:45 A.M., Wednesday at midnight and Saturday at 1:40 A.M. on HBO. This is a brisk thriller about a big Victorian dwelling that inflicts mayhem on its tenants. It's good fun, with a bright, trim look about it, some sturdy playing - William Katt and George Wendt head the cast - and surprises aplenty. And if you missed ''Cat's Eye'' (1985), this nifty thriller trilogy by Stephen King returns Friday at 7:30 P.M. on Cinemax. The first story is marvelous, the other two are very good indeed.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''A more open and democratic Soviet Union would be a great safeguard to peace.'' - Andrei D. Sakharov. [ 8:1. ]

title: CHRISTIE'S 'LOVE FROM A STRANGER'
description: DAME AGATHA CHRISTIE is, by any standard, queen of the mystery. During her productive career she turned out a prodigious amount of work, including novels, plays and short stories. In fact, ''The Mousetrap'' is the longest-running play in the history of theater, and it is still going strong in London's West End.

title: Two Killed and One Wounded In Bronx Apartment Shooting
description: A man and a woman were killed and another man was critically wounded in what was believed to be a drug-related shooting in an apartment in the Bronx, the police reported yesterday.

title: Nicole Anderes Plans to Be Wed To Bond Broker
description: Nicole Debrunner Anderes, a municipal bond analyst for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. in New York, and John Wilson Walter 2d, an assistant vice president of Titus & Donnelly Inc., muncipal bond brokers in New York, plan to be married in September.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: TEACHER TICKLES FUNNY BONES

title: TODAY, AMERICAN FORCES ARE HARDLY EVER AT EASE
description: AFTER two weeks of military maneuvers and political speculation, the threat of a United States strike against terrorists in the Middle East seemed to recede last week. Despite that, large numbers of troops in each of the four military services did not relax.

title: ELDERLY IN MORRIS ASSURED OF AID
description: THE Morris County Board of Chosen Freeholders has unofficially approved a $1.183 million package that would maintain services for the elderly, ranging from Meals on Wheels for the homebound to minor home repairs for those too frail to do their own.

title: COPTER SHARING IS PRAISED BY POLICE
description: EASTERN Connecticut's regional police helicopter program, the first time that several communities in the state have shared a rescue and patrol copter, is working well for participating towns and is attracting the attention of other communities.

title: ON BLOCKING EXTRA PAY
description: Ralph Nader's public interest lobby and legal agency, Public Citizen, is pondering legal action to try to block the pay increases that recently took effect for members of Congress, Federal judges and senior Government officials. But its lawyers are in a quandary over how to do it. One of the problems is that any lawsuit would almost inevitably be decided by a judge whose own raise could well depend on his own ruling.

title: Maureen Healy Wed To Arthur V. Hazlitt
description: Maureen R. Healy and Arthur V. Hazlitt, 1983 graduates of St. John's University School of Law, were married yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset, L.I. The Rev. James P. Swiader performed the ceremony.

title: ART IMITATES POLYGONS
description: LEAD: FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT LETTERS TRILOGY Edited by Bruce Brooks Pfeiffer. Letters to Apprentices. Illustrated. 211 pp. Cloth, $17.95. Paper, $8.95. Letters to Architects. Illustrated. 227 pp. Cloth, $18.95. Paper, $9.95. Letters to Clients. Illustrated. 320 pp. Cloth, $21.95. Paper, $12.95. Boxed set, Cloth, $39.

title: Look: Liberalism!
description: It's poking up everywhere like daffodils through the melting snows of the Reagan revolution. Six months ago, it was still the L-word, the political philosophy that dared not speak its name. Careful believers called themselves ''progressives.'' Even brave ones dared no more than ''neo-liberal.'' Old liberalism - social-program liberalism - was discredited.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: BALTIMORE GLASS DISPLAY

title: DATA UPDATE: February 15, 1987
HOW DO YOU FEEL ABOUT SPRING TRAINING?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: CONSTRAINTS UPON OUR FEELINGS
description: MY mother told me the grim details in our Sunday night long-distance call. Her neighbors were at home when it happened. Louise was gardening, Jim was painting and the older kids were outside. Jim went up to check on Bobby and there he was, in his usual posture, standing in his crib looking out the window. Jim went to him and saw that he was in fact, not standing, but suspended midair in front of his favorite lookout, the cord from the blinds wrapped tightly around his neck. He was 2 years old. They buried him privately, their grief so great they could share it with no one.

title: ITALIAN WITH AN OPERATIC SETTING
description: IF you were naming a restaurant, you might have qualms about calling it Rigoletto's, after the ill-starred and vindictive jester of the tragic Verdi opera. Perhaps the proprietor of Rigoletto's, a new Italian eatery in New Canaan, recalls the opera differently, for the menu states that ''the character of Rigoletto . . . typifies the feeling that my restaurant expresses . . . camaraderie, humor, warmth, a friendly gathering place.''

title: HIGH-GLOSS JAGGER AND A 'BORIS' TO BE CHERISHED
description: Boris Godunov By Mussorgsky. The Bolshoi Opera with Yevgeni Nesterenko as Boris. From a 1978 live performance. Kultur. 181 minutes (2 cassettes). $69.95.

title: THE EFFECT OF LOSS ON THE LOSER
description: IN TIME AND PLACE By John Hollander. 101 pp. Baltimore: Johns Hopkins University Press. Cloth, $16.50. Paper, $7.95. LAND OF SUPERIOR MIRAGES New and Selected Poems. By Adrien Stoutenburg. Edited by David R. Slavitt. Foreword by James Dickey. 122 pp. Baltimore: Johns Hopkins University Press. Cloth, $16.50. Paper, $7.95. THE CHESTNUT RAIN By William Heyen. 100 pp. New York: Available Press/Ballantine Books. Paper, $4.95.

title: SCHOOLS TO GET CURRICULUM ON AIDS
description: LEAD: AN AIDS curriculum guide with lesson plans aimed at teen-agers is soon to be made available to Connecticut schools.

title: Gotti Lawyers Seek to Discredit Prosecutors
description: Lawyers for John Gotti and his six co-defendants have taken the offensive in recent weeks at their Federal racketeering trial, asserting that the prosecutors had gone to extreme and unfair lengths to win convictions.

title: STRAIGHTENING OUT THE OREGANO PUZZLEMENT
description: LEAD: The herb garden's pizza connection has something of an identity crisis. Although practically everybody calls the culinary herb oregano, they are often talking about different plants.

title: Armed Forces Could Be a Chance to Start Over; No Cause for Alarm
description: To the Editor: James W. Davis manages to ignore some financial and political realities that need to be considered in discussing the issue of a draft.

title: IMMIGRANT ARTISTS TAKE VARIED PATHS
description: LEAD: BY coincidence, all three winners of ''Expo VI,'' the sixth annual national juried competition sponsored by Northport Galleries, are foreign-born artists now living and working in the United States.

title: Charlotte Donlin Marries Clay L. Hoes in Arizona
description: Charlotte Francesca Donlin, a daughter of Mrs. Joseph Michael Donlin of Litchfield Park, Ariz., and Casper, Wyo., and the late Mr. Donlin, was married yesterday to Clay Livingston Hoes, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John Spotswood Hoes of Cooperstown, N.Y., and Portsmouth, N.H. The Rev. Thomas Hever performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Aquinas Roman Catholic Church in Litchfield Park. He was assisted by the Rev. W. Jackson Wilson, an Episcopal priest.

title: 'Star Wars' May Destroy Strategic Defenses
description: Surely no national security issue has had such a brief yet bizarre history as the Strategic Defense Initiative.

title:
GARDENING;
WHY SOME SHRUBS IGNORE THE CALENDAR
description: LEAD: IF you think that people sometimes become confused, what about spring-flowering shrubs that consistently come into flower in the winter while there is still snow on the ground. This happens not just occasionally or to one kind of shrub.

title: STRATEGISTS OFFER MARIO CUOMO SOME UNSOLICITED ADVICE
description: AS speculation mounts about Mario M. Cuomo's potential Presidential candidacy, so, too, does the advice he receives - solicited or not -from around the country. Declare now. No, wait until late summer. Carry the banner of the traditional liberal Democrat. Don't be silly, think of the South. Drop the scholarly image - it scares some voters. No, no, reinforce it, it's your stock in trade. But not everyone who has thoughts on the matter is whispering into the Governor's ear. Jeffrey Schmalz, who covers Mr. Cuomo for The New York Times, sought comments from some political experts, including Republicans and Democrats the Governor is not consulting, for a view from outside the Cuomo camp. Although some of their comments are admittedly self-serving, they reflect strategies that other candidates might try to employ against the Governor should he choose to run and that he would almost certainly have to confront. Excerpts follow. ROGER STONE A former strategist for President Reagan and now a consultant to Representative Jack Kemp, Republican of Buffalo, who is expected to announce his Presidential candidacy formally in April.

title: Pop Music
description: One of the most startling musical events of 1950 was the emergence of a 22-year-old Quechua Indian from the Peruvian Andes with a five-octave voice who sang contralto, mezzo soprano, soprano and coloratura, using growls, chirps and a variety of wordless effects when words would not suffice. Her first album, ''Voice of Xtabay,'' hit the top of the pop best-seller list at the end of 1950. Her background seemed so mysterious that she was variously alleged to be a Brooklyn girl named Amy Camus (Yma Sumac spelled backwards) or an Inca princess who was a chosen maiden of the Sun God.

title: Miss Kurjan Engaged To Ethan H. Schwartz
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Marvin A. Kurjan of Woodmere, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Roberta Lee Kurjan to Ethan H. Schwartz, a son of Rabbi Dr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Schwartz of Evanston, Ill. An October wedding is planned.

title: Miriam Buegeleisen to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. David M. Buegeleisen of Southfield, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter Miriam Susan Buegeleisen to Matthew Bryan Jedla, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan A. Jedla of Brooklyn. The wedding is planned for July.

title: Iran Opposition Says Attack Wounded President's Brother
description: An Iranian opposition group said Friday that its guerrillas had wounded the brother of Iran's President in an attack with hand grenades and machine guns in a northeastern Iranian city.

title: CROSSROADS IN PANAMA
description: For North Americans, Panama usually starts with the canal, but it should not end there. There is plenty to do on this isthmus linking South America to Central America, where Indians, the original inhabitants, have blended with later arrivals -- Spanish, Chinese, Africans, French and North Americans.

title: Police Dog Gets Two Medals
description: A New Orleans police dog, shot in the face Oct.5 after tracking two suspected car thieves to their hiding place under a house, received two medals Friday as the city Police Department honored its officers. In a shootout with police, one suspect was killed and the other wounded. Zeiko, a rottweiler, received the Medal of Merit, the department's second-highest award and the department's Wound Award.

title: COSTLY REVERSAL OF A U.S. PROJECT
description: A $150 million plan was under consideration in Florida last year to make a river crooked again after the Federal Government had spent $21 million to make it straight.

title: SAKHAROV'S LIST
description: A FEW DAYS AFTER Andrei D. Sakharov was released from internal exile in Gorky last December, the 65-year-old theoretical physicist and human-rights activist sat in his Moscow apartment, bundled in an American warm-up jacket, and proposed a modest litmus test of the liberalization ostensibly taking place in Soviet society.

title: Braving Epilepsy's Storm
description: The ''storm'' of epilepsy must be endured on many levels: biologically and medically, psychologically and socially. Hiding epilepsy, which even one of Mr. Eichenwald's physicians erroneously advocated, is the outcome of societal stigma. It is perpetuated by a society that is frightened by the loss of control and powerlessness that the disorder represents. For a person with a seizure disorder, finding one's way out of the maelstrom has as much to do with society's fears as with the problems epilepsy can pose. JUDITH W. KINGSLEY Danbury, Conn.

title: JAPAN'S GETAWAY ISLANDS
description: The night ferry from Takeshiba Pier on Tokyo Bay slides away at 10 o'clock from fluorescent-lit buildings, oil refinery flares and the roar of Haneda Airport and heads out into the Pacific Ocean. Seven hours later, as the vessel approaches Oshima, the first of the seven Izu Islands, flying fish lunge from the bow wave and skim on silver wings across a sea tinted pink by sunrise; wild flowers and evergreen shrubs exhale a delicate perfume.

title: Iran Reports Civilian Deaths as Iraqis Raid Cities
description: Iraq said its warplanes bombed the Iranian capital, Teheran, and nine other cities today. Iran disputed the report of a bombing of Teheran but confirmed Iraqi raids on eight other cities and reported civilians were killed or wounded in them.

title: Youth Faces 16 New Charges In Denver Golf-Club Attacks
description: New charges have been filed against a youth who was accused last month of attacking several people with a golf club.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: COME AS YOU ARE: The Peace Corps Story. By Coates Redmon. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $22.95.) Anyone who has known Peace Corps volunteers in the field cannot help but be impressed by their dedication and diligence. But readers curious about the first generation of Americans to take on third world deprivation hand-to-hand won't find much of an account in ''Come as You Are.'' This detailed volume concentrates instead on the cocktails, lunches, Hyannis Port weekends, memo writing and furious office politics that attended the birth of the agency in the Camelot era. As Padraic Kennedy, an early senior staffer, puts it: ''It was exciting, it was fun, and boy, did the press love it.'' ''Come as You Are'' might have worked as a sort of belated expose, unmasking the Peace Corps' true origin as a public relations gimmick and the plaything of ''America's first royal family'' and their courtiers. But this revelation emerges only inadvertently. Sargent Shriver, the first Peace Corps director, notes without apparent concern that, according to the author, the agency ''was like a rocket. It was sitting on the launching pad and no one knew where it was going to go or what it was going to do.'' Willliam Haddad, another top official, writes in a letter that what the Peace Corps needed was ''go-getters, guys who can charge around the world, make deals.'' What they often got were guys like Donovan McClure, the Peace Corps representative in Sierra Leone, who candidly admits: ''I had never heard of Sierra Leone before, and plenty of others at the Peace Corps hadn't either. I mean, most of us had never heard of most of the places where the Peace Corps was going.'' Could such factors help explain why the agency has been so much more successful as an outward bound program for liberal arts majors than as an instrument for economic development and the communication of democratic values? Ms. Redmon, a former Peace Corps senior writer, never even raises the question.

title: DAVIDS ISLAND
description: THE United States Coast Guard will hold a public hearing at 7 P.M. Wednesday at the New Rochelle City Hall on a proposal to develop Davids Island, an 80-acre piece of land 3,500 feet offshore, by building 2,000 condominiums and a marina for 850 boats.

title: Duke University Balks Over $20 Million Gift
description: When the New York financier Disque D. Deane pledged $20 million to Duke University two months ago, Duke's president, H. Keith H. Brodie, hailed it as a ''landmark gift.'' But now university officials are debating whether to accept the gift because of a condition Mr. Deane attached to it.

title: OWLS LEARNING TO GIVE NOTHING AWAY
description: DURING a luncheon at a restaurant on the edge of the city last week, John Chaney, the basketball coach at Temple University, stood before 100 guests who had gathered to honor the city's best high school athletes.

title: Miss Hoffman Weds R. K. Samperton
description: The marriage of Kimberly Anne Elizabeth Hoffman to Richard Kyle Samperton took place yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in Lafayette Square, Washington. The Rev. Dr. John C. Harper performed the ceremony.

title: FEUDING OVER CONSISTENT TREATMENT FOR CRIMINALS
description: Two years ago, after tortuous negotiations, Congress and the Reagan Administration reached agreement on a plan to reduce the wide disparity in criminal sentences imposed by Federal judges. A law was enacted creating the United States Sentencing Commission, which was to abolish the Federal parole system, standardize punishments and thereby remove much of the broad discretion that Federal judges had usually exercised in dealing with criminals.

title: HAVE THE METS AND YANKS CHANGED FOR THE BETTER?
description: The Mets have definitely changed for the better, at least physically, with the addition of Kevin McReynolds and a full year of Dave Magadan. I question how they've changed emotionally in view of the newsworthy winter some of the Mets experienced.

title: More Towers On the Hudson
description: A $636 million hotel and apartment complex will rise on a 13-acre platform over the Hudson and 12 acres of riverfront land between 35th and 40th Streets if the development team chosen by the Koch administration last week survives some community opposition and wins the approval of the City Planning Commission and the Board of Estimate. The team, headed by Julien J. Studley, plans three hotels and two apartment buildings ranging from 24 to 42 stories tall; also a marina, stores, restaurants, a performing arts center, a 600-car garage, a ferry slip, an esplanade, a new city car pound for towed cars, and - if wanted -more exhibition space for the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center just to the east.

title: MORE PARK, OR MORE PARKING SPACES
description: LEAD: A VALLEY STREAM neighborhood has won the first round in a controversy over a strip of land behind the Peninsula Shopping Center that the owners say they need for additional parking spaces and a truck driveway. But the shopping center plans to fight on in the courts.

title: How David Salle Mixes High Art and Trash
description: In his article on David Salle, Paul Taylor appears to be confusing a media event with an original artistic interpretation of that event. The assassination of Lee Harvey Oswald may, indeed, be public property, as Mr. Salle claims, but Cockrill/Judge Hughes's line drawing of the event is not public property. Mr. Taylor's assertion that we ''made the drawing from Robert H. Jackson's photograph'' is misleading and legally irrelevant.

title: Bess Thrope Wed To Fellow Lawyer
description: Bess Ellen Thrope, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin M. Thrope of Great Neck, L.I., was married last night to Stuart Jeffrey Goldring, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Goldring of Birmingham, Mich. Rabbi J. Leonard Romm performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck.

title: European Tradition, American Innovation
description: Music and Old Masters In Amsterdam

title: BEIRUT REFUGEES'S PLIGHT TERMED GRIM DESPITE ARRIVAL OF AID
description: Despite the arrival of some relief supplies in a besieged Palestinian refugee district here today, conditions in the district were described as desperate, with thousands of people suffering from malnutrition.

title: 'KVETCH' ASKS 'WHY COMPLAIN?' AND REPLIES 'WHY NOT?'
description: To kvetch, Leo Rosten wrote in his dictionary-cum-cosmology, ''The Joys of Yiddish,'' is, literally, to squeeze (''Don't kvetch the peaches''); in its verb form it can mean to fuss, to fret, to delay or to shrug, though it has entered the American lexicon as the more generic to complain or gripe.

title: STEPPING UP TO 11,300 FEET
description: LEAD: The alpine breed of cross-country skiing called back country has been gaining in popularity over the last few years. Unlike modest trails that loop golf courses or city parks, these back-country routes - and there are now several mountain-trail systems in the United States - push into mountain wilderness, winter landscapes typically accessible only to rabbits or deer.

title: 12 ARE CHARGED IN HOWARD BEACH RACIAL ATTACK
description: It was the second attempt, and it took the intervention of Governor Cuomo to bring it about, but last week a dozen white teen-agers were indicted in the attack on three black men in Howard Beach that shocked the nation and heightened racial tensions in New York.

title: Troubles of U.S. Labor Unions Eased in 1986
description: American labor unions, weakened in the early 1980's by rapidly declining membership and concessions on wages and benefits, held their ground in some key areas in 1986.

title: MISS HAMBRICK PLANS TO BE WED
description: The engagement of Patricia Lynne Hambrick to Scott Alden Rossborough has been announced by Doris Dana Hambrick of Pleasanton, Calif., and Kenneth Edward Hambrick of Walnut Creek, Calif., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Rossborough of Spruce Head, Me.

title: Kew Gardens
description: To the Editor: Your article on Kew Gardens [ ''Foundation Dug for Long-Delayed Queens Project,'' Jan. 18 ] implies that ''community leaders have taken a pragmatic view'' and are only concerned with the multiplex-cinema threat to the community. In fact, the community is prepared to fight the project in its entirety if it cannot accommodate Kew Gardens' needs on parking, traffic flow, zoning restrictions and other vital matters.

title: Archetypes And Ex-Lovers
description: As a male, I frankly have grown tired of reading about men who are unable to commit to relationships (''The Truth Is Not Simple,'' by Robert Ragaini, About Men, Jan. 11). It's old news.

title: SCIENCE AND PSYCHOLOGY OF THE WIND CHILL FACTOR
description: COLD and windy feels worse than cold and calm.

title: Summery Sicily Captured in Cloth
description: There is something in the air in Sicily that stimulates the foreigner to creativity. The best Sicilian art -the Greek temples, the Byzantine mosaics, the Arab-Norman churches - bears witness to the fullness of expression that foreign cultures attained after they had invaded the island.

title: A CELLIST, AN ORGNIST AND A PIANIST
description: ALL three debut recitalists under consideration share Latin descent, but their degree of closeness to the musical life of this country varies widely. Andres Diaz

title: COCONUT 'PERFUME'
description: A WHIFF of suntan lotion found under the seat as I clean my car in February sets me off. Instantly I'm transported to June, surrounded by sea gulls at Jones Beach.

title: Should Jimbo Go For Gold?
description: THE late Supreme Court Justice Potter Stewart once wrote that he could not define hard-core pornography, but that ''I know it when I see it.'' The same is true for defining athletic professionalism. We know it when we see it, and his name is Jimmy Connors.

title: RACIAL VIOLENCE TRACED IN REPORT
description: Forty-five cases of arson and cross-burnings have occurred after minority families have moved into mostly white neighborhoods around the country in the last two years, a national legal and educational group said in a recent report.

title: BASKETBALL SLUGFEST
description: BASKETBALL may not have the same brawling tradition as professional hockey, but a Continental Basketball Association game between the Charleston Gunners of West Virginia and the Cincinnati Slammers at the Charleston Civic Center Friday night had all the makings of a National Hockey League free-for-all.

title: OTTAWA'S BACKYARD WILDERNESS
description: Imagine 88,000 acres of rolling hills, forests and lakes set aside as a natural habitat for white-tailed deer, beaver, the odd wolf and other wildlife. Imagine it covered by a northern winter's accumulation of snow and frosted with a night's deposit of fluffy new powder. Then imagine it overlaid with 125 miles of groomed cross-country ski trails - all on the doorstep of Canada's capital.

title: A BISHOP'S BAN
description: To homosexual Catholics in the diocese that is composed of Brooklyn and Queens, the news was a surprise.

title: Ex-Envoy for Pretoria Vows To Campaign for Black Rights
description: Denis Worrall, who resigned as South African Ambassador to Britain, returned home today and announced that he would campaign for black political rights in the May 6 election.

title: Ms. Kirkland Is Wed to Federal Judge
description: The marriage of Katharine Kirkland, the managing editor for adult books at Viking Penguin in New York, to Judge John Mercer Walker Jr. of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, took place yesterday in Manhattan. Bishop Paul Moore Jr. of the Episcopal Diocese of New York, assisted by the Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Heavenly Rest.

title: HOW TO MAKE TRACKS ALL OVER
description: As cross-country skiers step onto their skinny skis in woodlands, meadows and national parks this winter, a major topic of conversation is skating. Pushing outward with each ski alternately, a technique known as the V-skate, is filtering down from racing to the recreational level. Some recreational ski tourers are switching to skating from the slower, traditional stride. The traditional stride is called diagonal because when the right foot is pushed forward the left arm is back, and vice versa.

title: The Algarve
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed Paul Lewis's article on the ''Highlands of the Algarve'' (Travel, Nov. 30). His descriptive touches took me on a nostalgic trip through my native land. For this I'm thankful to him. I would like, however, to set the record straight as to the whereabouts of Prince Henry the Navigator's Nautical School.

title: Laker Dream
description: WHEN he was a student at the University of Minnesota, Mychal Thompson dreamed of playing for the Los Angeles Lakers, a franchise that originated in Minnesota. The Lakers would probably have been willing to give the 6-foot-10-inch center-forward a try, too, but there was just one problem: Thompson and the Lakers were too good for each other. By the time the high-ranked Lakers got a turn in the 1978 draft, Thompson was long gone, snapped up on the very first pick by the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: THE RESIDUE OF RAIL STRIKE
description: A WEEK after the Long Island Rail Road strike ended, I still had a stiff neck and a lingering inclination to snap people's heads off. I got that way riding a school bus nearly every morning for two weeks.

title: Architect's Reply
description: To the Editor: Two letters you published Jan. 25 about the Noble House, one from Edward X. Canning and another from Robert J. Richter, unfairly criticize me as architect and construction manager and the owner, Henry Noble, based upon the letter-writers' misjudgments, unsupported by the facts as briefly summarized in the Dec. 21 article, ''Custom Building with an Architect.''

title: CASINO SUCCESS STORY THAT STARTS IN NEWARK
description: LEAD: CONTRARY to popular belief, all the highly competitive gambling casinos here are not dominated by executives who got their experience in Las Vegas, Reno or the Bahamas.

title: A SECRETARY'S DEPARTURE
description: Like his tenure, John F. Lehman Jr.'s departure from the Navy is somewhat bumpy. The announcement last week that the Secretary would leave this spring was made by a Defense Department spokesman; there was no letter of resignation, no word of Mr. Lehman's plans and no mention of a successor - though it was said that Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger had tried to talk him out of leaving. Mr. Lehman had guided the Navy out of its post-Vietnam slide, despite frequent clashes on Capitol Hill prying enough money out of Congress to assure President Reagan's goal of a 600-ship fleet. His career strategy was perhaps less successful: Some of his associates said Mr. Lehman decided to quit when it became clear that he did not have a shot at Mr. Weinberger's job.

title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 14 FOOD OUTLETS FOR HEALTH OFFENSES
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 14 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Miss Dowling Is Married to E.P. Logue
description: Anne Melissa Dowling, an officer in the securities department of the Travelers in Hartford, was married yesterday to E. Patrick Logue, a senior consultant in the financial division of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company in Hartford. The Rev. John Shugrue, assisted by Msgr. John Kennedy and the Rev. Dawson Trenchard, performed the ceremony at St. Peter Claver Roman Catholic Church in West Hartford, Conn.

title: NEW YORK, LOOKING BACK WITH PRIDE, BEGINS TO CELEBRATE U.S. CONSTITUTION
description: Declaring that New York's early laws ''set the pattern for the national Constitution,'' Governor Cuomo this week marked the beginning of a three-year state celebration of the United States Constitution with a display of rare state documents in Albany.

title: EASTERN GIVES IN ON RECORD FINE
description: Eastern Airlines agreed last week to pay the full $9.5 million fine imposed by the Federal Aviation Administration, 11 months after a comprehensive inspection found more than 78,000 violations of agency rules.

title: Janice Feiden Is Bride
description: Janiece Lee Feiden, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter B. Feiden of Jackson Heights, Queens, was married last evening to Lance Stewart Gad, the son of Claire Gad of Peekskill, N.Y., and the late Martin H. Gad. Rabbi Neal Borovitz officated at L'Escargot restaurant in Manhattan. The bride is a research assistant at James D. Wolfensohn Inc., investment banker in New York. Mr. Gad is a financial adviser to the William Rosenwald family in New York. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: HIGH-GLOSS JAGGER AND A 'BORIS' TO BE CHERISHED
description: Guide to Central Florida Rand McNally Video Trips. Annette Funicello, host. Lightning Video. 60 minutes. $29.95.

title: Dance
description: The Dance Center is offering a provocative-sounding program by six quite different choreographer-performers Sunday night at the Emanu-El Midtown Y. The choreographers are Janis Brenner, Sheila Kaminsky, Jimena Lasansky, Daniel West, Anthony Stafford and Pam Quinn and Michael O'Connor, a two-person choreographic cooperative. Their themes include game playing and competition, homeless derelicts and the performer's subconscious.

title: Victoria A. Oliver, Senior Copywriter, Plans to Marry Gordon Cohen in April
description: The engagement of Victoria Anne Oliver to Gordon Geoffrey Cohen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Norman Cohen of New York and Greenwich, Conn., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John Lee Oliver of New York and Amagansett, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be.

title: PROTECTIONISM
description: To the Editor:

title: FATE OF RACEWAY HANGS IN BALANCE
description: ROOSEVELT RACEWAY, once one of the nation's most profitable sports facilities, is today generating large losses and little interest at the box office.

title: Art
description: Nick Ghiz is a sculptor who has a way with abandoned and ephemeral materials. For some time he worked with wood. In the last few years he has been building with paper and glue around a wire scaffolding. He does not want his work to be in any way heavy. He does want it to be magical.

title: Evelyn Douglas to Wed Peter Saulnier
description: James A. M. Douglas of Bedford, N.Y., has announced the engagement of his daughter Evelyn Douglas to Peter Saulnier, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark McArdle Saulnier of Summit, N.J. An August wedding is planned.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: WOMEN IN THE WORLD: AN INTERNATIONAL ATLAS. By Joni Seager and Ann Olson. (Simon & Schuster, Cloth, $19.95; Paper, $12.95.) It's troubling to find such a slim volume bearing this title. The implausibility of covering a subject of such scope in 128 pages - even pages laden with statistical information - is a problem, and one the co-authors anticipated to some extent.

title: JUDGMENT AGAINST KLAN IN ALABAMA
description: One member of the United Klans of America had been sentenced to death, and another to life in prison, for the 1981 murder of a black teen-ager whose battered body was left hanging from a tree. Last week the Klan itself was held to account.

title: SHOREHAM IMPASSE PITS U.S. VS STATE
description: LEAD: THE impasse over the Shoreham nuclear power plant is advancing questions about the constitutional compact that binds together the states and the Federal Government.

title: Marcia Hakim a Bride
description: Marcia A. Hakim, the corporate secretary and associate general counsel of Trans World Airlines in New York, was married yesterday to Carl H. Hewitt, a vice president and assistant general counsel of Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, a securities trading firm in New York. Jean Somerville Kotkin, a leader of the American Ethical Union in New York, performed the ceremony at the couple's home in New York. Previous marriages for both bride and bridegroom ended in divorce.

title: CHANGING TIMES IN TRENTON
description: IN 1985, The Trenton Times dropped the ''Trenton'' and became, simply, The Times, a move intended to show that the paper was not for Trenton only.

title: NEW YORK JUDGE PROPOSES RANDOM AUDITS FOR LAWYERS' ESCROW ACCOUNTS
description: A leading New York State appeals judge has recommended random audits to deter lawyers from stealing money that has been temporarily entrusted to them by their clients.

title: PAUL SCHRADER PLUMBS GRASSROOTS ROCK
description: Early in Paul Schrader's new film, ''Light of Day,'' the director jumps from a sequence of a rock-and-roll band performing in a Cleveland bar to short shots of the musicians at their day jobs. Two of them work in a metal-pressing plant, and just before the camera leaves the scene it shows the factory's current product, commemorative trays of Prince Charles and Lady Diana. The lives of the royal couple could hardly be more distant from those of the assembly-line workers minting their image. And that moment comes as one of the first subtle clues that ''Light of Day'' will be anything but Hollywood's usual starry-eyed view of popular music.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE SACRED COW AND THE ABOMINABLE PIG: Riddles of Food and Culture, by Marvin Harris. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $6.95.) Hindus won't eat beef, while Jews and Moslems avoid pork and Americans quake at the idea of consuming cockroaches, thought a delicacy in some cultures. Marvin Harris examines the reasons people eat what they do in this book, originally titled ''Good to Eat.'' In 1986 our reviewer, Richard Flaste, found it ''marvelously readable.'' While the author's point of view (people eat what they do because of an acute sense of costs and benefits) can be exasperating, he said, ''Mr. Harris writes well and has a good ear for stories.'' AGAINST INTERPRETATION: And Other Essays, by Susan Sontag. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $7.95.) A collection of early-1960's essays and reviews on art, litera-ture, film and drama, ''Against Interpretation'' is ''a ponderable, vivacious . . . and quite astonishingly American book,''

title: Archetypes And Ex-Lovers
description: The truth is quite simple: Robert Ragaini is propagating the worst type of sexism in an effort to justify his own neurotic behavior. Fear of intimacy has not been shown to be genetically linked to the Y chromosome, as far as I know. Continuing the myth that women are naturally more emotional and that men are, as he puts it, ''more goal oriented'' is no different from saying that black people naturally have rhythm. Racism may be easier to spot than sexism nowadays, but cultural stereotypes always leave the stereotyper on top, feeling right and justified about his or her actions. IRENE HAWKS New York City

title: 55 Pounds of Heroin Seized And 2 Brooklyn Men Are Held
description: Fifty-five pounds of heroin was seized by agents of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration and the United States Customs Service on Friday, leading to the arrest of two Taiwanese men in a Brooklyn apartment.

title: New Rentals Sprouting in Manhattan
description: THREE weeks ago, Pamela S. Jaffe settled into a new apartment in the East Village, ending her odyssey through a numbing stream of rental offices and model apartments uptown, downtown and in between.

title: ORCHESTRA NEW ENGLAND IN FINANCIAL TROUBLE
description: ORCHESTRA NEW ENGLAND, known in Connecticut for its innovative ''Colonial Concerts'' and summertime ''Stars and Stripes'' series, has filed for reorganization under bankruptcy laws.

title: HOLYFIELD RETAINS TITLE ON KNOCKOUT
description: Evander Holyfield, a born-again Christian, came into the ring today with a reference to a biblical citation stitched to his trunks and ''Jesus Loves You'' on the back of his white satin robe.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Floyd Gains Tie With Eagle on Last Hole: Ray Floyd's last-hole eagle lifted him into a share of the third-round lead yesterday with J. C. Snead in a day of remarkable shooting at the Andy Williams Open in La Jolla, Calif. Floyd's eagle finished off a 6-under-par 66. He was tied at 199 with Snead, who also shot 66 on the South course at Torrey Pines. Their 17-under-par totals for three rounds matched the largest under-par total for 54 holes on the PGA Tour last year. (AP) Douglass Takes Lead: Dale Douglass fired a 3-under-par 69 to vault to a five-shot lead heading into the final round of the PGA Seniors Championship at Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. The second-round leader, Chi Chi Rodriguez, slipped to a 76 on the 6,550-yard Champion course. Douglass pulled away from the other contenders with his three-day total of 7-under 209. Harold Henning and Bobby Nichols are tied for second at 214 after posting scores of 67 and 68 in the third round. (AP) Tennis Connors Gains Final: Jimmy Connors, using his big edge in experience to good advantage, scored a 6-7, 7-5, 6-3 victory over Mikael Pernfors of Sweden yesterday to advance to the final of the United States Indoor championship in Memphis. The 34-year-old Connors outlasted the 23-year-old Pernfors in the 2 hour 47 minute match by using a steady baseline game and a flashy assortment of shots at the net. Connors will be seeking his eighth United States Indoor singles title today when he meets Stefan Edberg, who was extended to a tie-breaker by Brad Gilbert, but was in control during much of his 6-4, 7-6 victory. (AP) Garrison Wins: Scrambling Zina Garrison upset top-seeded Hana Mandlikova, 7-5, 4-6, 6-2, yesterday to gain the finals of the Virginia Slims of California tournament in San Francisco. In the other semifinal, second-seeded Kathy Rinaldi met unseeded Sylvia Hanika. Garrison, the No. 3 seed, used speed and timely passing shots to beat Mandlikova. (AP) Skiing Stenmark Captures Slalom: Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden won the men's World Cup slalom race yesterday at Markstein, France. The 30-year-old Stenmark was clocked in 1 minute 36:39 seconds over two foggy courses. The heats were beset by intermittent rain and snow, making for less than perfect conditions. Armin Bittner of West Germany took second place, finishing a fraction of a second behind Stenmark in 1:36.47. Stenmark now has won 40 World Cup slaloms and 45 giant slaloms. No United States skier qualified for the second run. (AP) Schneider Gets Second Victory: Vreni Schneider of Switzerland posted her second ski victory in two days yesterday, winning the women's World Cup slalom race at Saint Gervais, France, and moving to the top of the overall standing by a point, 230-229. Schneider, 10th in the first heat, finished with a total time of 1:36.15 seconds. She was trailed by another Swiss, Corinne Schmiedhauser, who was timed in 1:36.79. Schneider won Friday's giant slalom in Megeve, France, bringing her victories this season to five. Tamara McKinney of Olympic Valley, Calif., remained in the lead in the World Cup slalom standing with 99 points. She finished seventh. (AP) Norwegian Takes Nordic Combined Title: The World Cup leader, Torbjoern Loekken of Norway, came from behind to capture the Nordic combined title at the world Nordic championships at Oberstdorf, West Germany, yesterday, while an American, Kerry Lynch, finished a surprising second. He moved up from 19th place and from more than two minutes behind in the 15-kilometer cross-country race. The Norwegian had trailed after the jumping portion of the event on Friday. Loekken finished with 423.80 points, gaining on the field with the best time of 36 minutes 29.0 seconds in the cross-country race. Lynch, from Silver Creek, Colo., took the first medal ever for a United States Nordic combined athlete. He was second with 422.75 points. (AP) Bobsledding U.S. Sled in Good Position: Posting the two fastest times in the heats yesterday on the Mount van Hoevenberg course at Lake Placid, N.Y., Matt Roy of Saranac Lake, N.Y., put his United States sled in a good position to repeat his two-man World Cup championship today. Roy went into the final today leading his nearest challenger, Britain's No. 2 sled driven by Mark Tout, by nearly a full second. Driving the newly designed USA No. 1 sled with Jim Herberich of Winchester, Mass., on the brake, Roy raced down the 1,600-meter run in 1 minute eight-tenths of a second and 1:00.97. Brent Rushlaw, with Hal Hoye of Malone, N.Y., on the brake, drove USA No. 3 into third place, four-tenths of a second behind the British sled. (AP) Boxing Cooper Stops de Wit in Second Round: Bert Cooper of Philadelphia unleashed a two-fisted flurry, floored the Canadian heavyweight champion, Willie de Wit, four times and knocked him out in the second round of their nontitle fight yesterday in Regina, Saskatchewan. The bout ended two seconds from the end of the round with de Wit slumped on the canvas and bleeding profusely from the nose. The loss was his first in 17 fights as a professional. Cooper's record is 16-1. (AP) Horse Racing Lover's Cross Handicap Winner: Lover's Cross never trailed yesterday in winning the $86,850 Stymie Handicap for 3-year-olds and up at Aqueduct. The 4-year-old son of Explodent and Girl in Love, ridden by Ruben Hernandez and carrying 116 pounds, turned back a strong challenge by favored King's Swan nearing the stretch and then drew away to a 2 3/4-length victory. Proud Debonair edged King's Swan for second by a head. The triumph was the first in three starts this year for Lover's Cross, who was last in a field of 14 in the Bougainvillea Handicap on grass at Hialeah in his previous start. He went a mile and an eighth on a fast track in 1:50 to earn $65,610, including a $13,500 Breeders' Cup Award, for Kinghaven Farms. He returned $17.20 for $2 to win as the third choice in the field of six. Track and Field St. Anthony's Wins Trophy: A fourth-place finish in the final event, the one-mile relay, gave Iona Prep a tie for first place with St. Anthony's in the 60th annual Catholic High Schools Boys Indoor Championships in Manhattan. Each team had 30 points. However, the tie was broken for the team trophy when St. Anthony's, of Smithtown, L.I., showed four second-places to one for Iona. St. Anthony's had tallied 23 of its points in the earlier field events while Iona had 21 in the field. Paul Whittaker of Xaverian was named the meet's most valuable performer. He won the 1,000-meter run in 2 minutes 33.7 seconds and anchored Xaverian to its upset victory over Loughlin in the 2-mile relay. N.H.L. Canucks 3, Penguins 3: Barry Pederson scored with 4:39 left in the third period to give Vancouver the tie last night at Pittsburgh. Pederson fired a rebound into a wide-open net with the Penguins' goalie, Pat Riggin, trapped out of position. The score came 1:21 after Lee Giffin gave the Penguins a 3-2 lead with his first N.H.L. goal when he deflected a shot by Mario Lemieux past the Vancouver goalie, Richard Brodeur. (AP) Canadiens 5, Jets 2: Ryan Walter scored two goals and Mats Naslund had three assists as Montreal won at home. Chris Chelios, Sergio Momesso and Claude Lemieux also scored for the Canadiens, who extended their home-ice winning streak to four games and took sole possession of second place in the Adams Division. Doug Smail and Andrew McBain scored for the Jets, whose three-game winning streak came to an end.

title: INQUIRY CITED IN SCIENTIST'S DEATH
description: The suicide of a scientist at the National Institutes of Health was related to an investigation into possible fraud in a manuscript on genetics research, his widow said Friday.

title: PATIENCE IS PAYING OFF FOR POLAND'S JARUZELSKI
description: BOTH his admirers and critics say that Gen.

title: METS' MISSION FOR 1987: SHAPE UP
description: DWIGHT GOODEN is on probation for three years after having pleaded no contest to two felony charges: violently resisting arrest and battery on a Tampa police officer. His former fiancee, Carlene Pearson, was arrested two weeks ago for carrying a loaded two-shot derringer at La Guardia Airport, where she was to meet the Mets' right-hander for a reported reconciliation.

title: ELITE POLICE UNIT'S TRAINEES STRIVE TO MASTER HORSEBACK PATROL IN NEW YORK
description: In a rambling stable near Pelham Bay Park in the Bronx, where hoof picks and poultice jars tumble from lockers and steam puffs from the chimney of an old-fashioned forge, a select group of New York City police officers are taught how to practice their profession on horseback.

title: MONETARY CHANGE IS SAID TO BE NEAR
description: Saudi Arabia's top Government banker said today that the major industrial countries were ''coming close'' to devising a new way to try to stop the turmoil in the dollar and other currencies.

title: FOR CARDINAL, WIESEL VISIT PROVED A CALM IN STORM OVER TRIP
description: On the day last month when John Cardinal O'Connor met with Jewish leaders to smooth over differences regarding the Cardinal's trip to the Middle East, another, less publicized, meeting was held - between the Cardinal and the man he calls ''the Prophet of the Holocaust,'' Elie Wiesel.

title: Nearby References to Faraway Places
description: Ponder these questions: ''I'm thinking of going to Samoa.

title: DAYTONA RACER DIES
description: JOE YOUNG, a 38-year-old driver from Richmond was killed Friday, and Dr. Duell Sturgill suffered two broken legs in a wild six-car pileup during a 200-mile race for four-cylinder subcompacts at the Daytona International Speedway. Young, who was killed instantly, was the 16th driver to die at Daytona since the 2.5-mile track was opened in 1959. Sturgill, a 33-year-old dentist from Staffordsville, Ky., was recovering at Halifax Medical Center, where he was listed in serious condition yesterday.

title: AT A MANHATTAN LOFT, ART AND LAW COEXIST IN PEACE AND PROFIT
description: AT a lower-Manhattan law office, where attention is usually focused on depositions, three young artists have been busily installing watercolors, acrylics and sculpture - one so large it had to be hoisted through a third-floor window - for an exhibition called ''Summertime'' that begins Friday.

title: After Almost 200 Years, Sally Hemmings Still Dogs Jefferson
description: To the Editor: In his Feb. 7 letter, Judge Bruce McM. Wright cites as historical fact the story of Thomas Jefferson's slave mistress, Sally Hemmings. It is simply ridiculous that this patent lie should still be seen in print. Its origin is almost as old as our Republic.

title: A.T.& T TRIES TO UNSNARL ITS FUTURE
description: NEARLY three years ago, James E. Olson, then vice chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, proudly announced his company's entry into the computer business.

title: OBLIGING THE NOBLESSE
description: The female figure in the Italian Renaissance was not only idealized as a Neoplatonic manifestation of ''heaven on earth,'' but seen as the embodiment of intellectual refinement. And with this elevation of the flesh came a new cultural phenomenon - that of the ''honest courtesan.'' These highbrow mistresses, companions to princes, painters, ambassadors and merchants, writes Lynne Lawner in LIVES OF THE COURTESANS: Portraits of the Renaissance (Rizzoli, $35), were at once financially autonomous and perpetually enslaved. Bejeweled and draped in the latest fashions, they wrote verse, recited the classics and, unlike their poor cousins in the brothels, entertained clients in their private palaces. Ms. Lawner, a poet and art historian, argues that the courtesans' most intriguing aspect was their ability to project images of themselves that were at once elusive and eminently tangible. Drawing on the diaries, plays, letters and paintings of the period - including journal entries written by the courtesans themselves - Ms. Lawner probes the causes of this intentional ambiguity. She investigates everything from beauty routines to sartorial habits, to the sexual symbolism of certain gestures and objects in such paintings as Palma Vecchio's ''Bella,'' Raphael's ''Fornarina'' and Titian's ''Venus of Urbino.'' The result is an exceedingly handsome, well-designed art book dedicated to images of Renaissance female beauty. But most arresting are its revelations about the qualities of character that have shaped Western ideas about femininity and romantic love.

title: Mimi Dalbey To Be Bride
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. R.Thomas Dalbey of Denver of the engagement of their daughter Marie Overton Dalbey to Marc Tabah, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Tabah of Demarest, N.J., and Cabris, France. The wedding is to be June 13.

title: WHAT'S IN THE BAG? ABOUT 100 PARTS AND THE MARK OF STYLE
description: ''WE make everything from soup to nuts,'' said Judith Leiber of Manhattan and East Hampton. ''We make large totes in snakes and alligators; we make medium-size day bags in every possible reptile you can think of: snakeskin, lizard, alligators.

title: CONCERT: PENDERCKI WITH THE PHILHARMONIC
description: THE New York Philharmonic, so often lambasted for conservative programming, has a powerful if austere bill for its current subscription program, the fourth and last concert of which will be Tuesday night at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: ALL IN THE FAMILIES
description: THE FITZGERALDS AND THE KENNEDYS By Doris Kearns Goodwin. Illustrated. 932 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.95.

title: Diana Krumholz Becomes a Bride
description: Diana Krumholz, a doctoral candidate in art history and archeology at Columbia University, and Kevin McDonald, a managament consultant at Fletcher & Company in Boston, were married yesterday at the Church Center for the United Nations in New York. The Rev. John Burens of All Souls Unitarian Church performed the ceremony.

title: ASIAN CRIME VICTIMS ENDING SILENCE
description: Vietnamese immigrants who have settled in Philadelphia over the last decade have often been silent victims of assault, robbery and extortion by a small gang of Vietnamese youths. But that silence appears to be ending, say the police, who attribute several recent arrests to the cooperation of Vietnamese crime victims.

title:
INVESTING;
STILL A COSTLY TO BUY COINS
description: LEAD: How are the gold and silver American Eagle bullion coins, which were quickly snapped up last fall when they made their debut, doing now?

title:
NUMISMATICS;
ARE PENNIES MAKING A COMEBACK
description: LEAD: Copper coins, long overlooked by investors, may be on the verge of a market breakthrough. They are being touted by a growing number of dealers including some who have never recommended them.

title:
IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN;
Carmel
description: LEAD: PEOPLE have always been drawn to Carmel by the many spring-fed lakes that sparkle among its wooded hills.

title: JOBS GUIDE
description: To underline the need for the business community to work with teachers in preparing students for future employment, the County Chamber of Commerce in White Plains has compiled and published a job-hunting guide based on a survey of vocational opportunities in Westchester.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: THERE'S probably not a home in New Jersey - or, for that matter, in any other state -that has not had on its shelves an item made by Johnson & Johnson, the New Brunswick-based health-products manufacturer.

title: DANCE: CLAUDIA GITELMAN
description: CLAUDIA GITELMAN examined states of weakness, power, confidence and vulnerability in ''Merge,'' the program of solos she danced Friday night at the Nikolais/Louis ChoreoSpace (33 East 18th Street). She merged dance with theatrical trappings - including lighting by Ruth Grauert and costumes by Frank Garcia - and electronic music, much of which was composed for her by Gerald Otte. Yet the result was not an extravaganza.

title: EVENTS FOR CHILDREN ON VACATION
description: LEAD: MANY activities have been scheduled for children on school vacation this week. Some events are entertaining, some physical or intellectual and a few of the programs blend all three qualities.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: SENSE AND SENSUALITY. By Rosalind Brackenbury. (Taplinger, $14.95.) The British author Rosalind Brackenbury's latest novel takes the seemingly ordinary life of a poet and transforms it into a lyrical adventure. Through a dazzling use of language, Alice Linnell's early years explode with the vibrant images of summer holidays spent in the company of her extravagant grandmother.

title: Laing Rogers to Wed John Michael Sisto Jr.
description: The engagement of Rebecca Laing Rogers to John Michael Sisto Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sisto of Watchung, N.J., and Hillsboro Beach, Fla., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Paul Grant Rogers of Washington and West Palm Beach, Fla., parents of the future bride. A May wedding is planned.

title: COGHLAN, MCRAE WINNERS
description: Eamonn Coghlan won the Meadowlands Mile tonight, which surprised no one. Lee McRae, and not Ben Johnson or Carl Lewis, won the 55-meter dash, which surprised many people.

title:
FOCUS: Pittsburgh;
Suburban Housing Surges
description: LEAD: THE Asswikale Indians once camped on the broad plain of the Sewickley Valley and, later, settlers en route to the Northwest Territories frequented its inns and taverns. Late in the 19th century it became a refuge for industrial barons seeking respite from the smoke and noise of their mills and factories in

title: HAVE THE METS AND YANKS CHANGED FOR THE BETTER?
description: With a pitching staff headed by Rasmussen and Rhoden, the Yankees would appear to have changed for the better. But wait! How have they changed? They lost Ron Guidry, their most versatile, dependable and successful pitcher for the last 10 seasons. With 15-20 victories gone, the enormous void must be filled by the likes of Hudson, Filson and Tewksbury. No, that is not a law firm. The biggest ''change'' that benefits the Yankees is the inability of the Red Sox to sign Rich Gedman. With less punch in the Boston lineup, and an unusual case of mediocrity hitting Baltimore and Detroit, the Yankees will be a contender. ANDREW SIFF Middletown, Conn.

title: PROVIDENCE DEFEATS REDMAN
description: St. John's hopes for a late-season rush to first place in the Big East were dashed by Providence last night. The Friars, who defeated St. John's in overtime last month, beat the Redmen, 79-78, at Alumni Hall.

title:
ABOUT MEN;
A Promise of Renewal
description: LEAD: AFTER 16 YEARS IN THE FILM business, the glamour I once associated with making movies has completely disappeared. The grinding 14-hour days, the relentless pressure of budgets and scheduling, the dirt and grime in the studios, the incessant rhythm of building up and tearing down - all these things have so encrusted the Oscar, so to speak, that when it comes to movie stars and all that hoopla,

title: INVESTIGATORS FIND NEW WHITE HOUSE IRAN DOCUMENTS
description: The White House commission looking into the Iran-contra affair turned up a trove of previously unknown documents last week and decided to prolong its investigation for a week to evaluate them.

title: STATE DETAILS PLAN TO RAISE BRIDGES
description: ''I THINK it was the rapport between labor and management at the North Tarrytown plant that finally decided them,'' said Vincent Tese, the state Director of Economic Development.

title: GOODBYE, NASHVILLE
description: After more than half a century in Nashville, the headquarters of the United States Business and Industrial Council, an outspoken organization of 1,500 conservative business people around the country, is moving to Washington. The main reason, it says, is to lobby more effectively on trade issues.

title: Nancy Weber and N. Lee Sasser, Lawyers, Marry
description: Nancy Susan Weber and N. Lee Sasser, partners in the law firm of Sasser & Weber in Orlando, Fla., were married last evening at the Tavern on the Green in New York by Acting Justice Shirley R. Levittan of State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title:
DINING OUT;
UPSCALE CLONE IN BERKELEY HEIGHTS
description: LEAD: IN A TRIM, cheerful Berkeley Heights storefront, Om Bathla has opened Neelam, a slightly upscale clone of his Kenilworth establishment of the same name. A native of Punjab, Mr. Bathla and his cooks, who specialize in tandoori and northern Indian cooking, are adding some spice to the gastronomic options of the Summit area.

title: Moderate Quake Hits Town That Was Devastated in '83
description: A moderate earthquake shook furniture and rattled housewares Friday night in this central California farming town, which was devastated by a quake in 1983, officials said.

title: RAUSCHENBERG AND JOHNS: MR. OUTSIDE AND MR. INSIDE
description: It is by a conspicuous coincidence that a show devoted to Jasper Johns's paintings of ''The Seasons'' should be on view through March 7 at the Leo Castelli Gallery, 420 West Broadway, while simultaneously there can be seen in the new Lila Acheson Wallace wing at the Metropolitan Museum what may well be the single largest work of contemporary art ever to be mounted in a great American museum. The work in question is ''1/4 Mile or 2 Furlong Piece'' by Robert Rauschenberg, who rather more than 30 years ago was jointly responsible with Jasper Johns for a historic shift in the ambitions of art. Quite apart from that coincidence, major early paintings by both Rauschenberg and Johns can be seen through March 7 in Part 1 of Leo Castelli's 30th-anniversary show at 142 Greene Street. Quite clearly, therefore, this is a good moment at which to look back at careers that have left a permanent mark upon the history of 20th-century art.

title: Picasso for Scholars
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: Because of editing errors, the recipe for Chiu Chow braised duck in the Jan. 25 Food column is wrong in part. The duck should not be added to the braising liquid until step three, the garlic in step four should be minced, and the cheesecloth bag of spices should not be removed unless the liquid is to be stored for an extended period.

title: CRACK MURDER: A DETECTIVE STORY
description: The events described in this article are true, the people are real. However, because the case has not yet gone to trial, the name of the deceased and the names of witnesses and suspects have been changed at the request of the New York City Police Department.

title: FOR WALL STREET, HANDCUFFS AND NEW PRESSURE
description: With each new charge of insider trading, pressure is mounting in Washington to legislate a policing structure to compensate for what some on Capitol Hill are calling ''a real breakdown in the self-regulatory mechanisms on Wall Street.'' Last week's events, which stunned even the traders who had been talking for months about shoes dropping, are only expected to heighten the sense of urgency.

title: DEBORAH T. HICKS TO MARRY IN MAY
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Milton Hicks of Jacksonville, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Deborah Tyler Hicks to Stephen Renato Quazzo, a son of Jacqueline Stamato of Essex Fells, N.J., and Rome and Ugo Quazzo of New York and Chester, Vt. A May wedding is planned.

title: ARBITRATION LOSS
description: ALEJANDRO PENA, the Los Angeles pitcher who came back slowly last season from 1985 shoulder surgery, yesterday became the fourth player whose salary was reduced in arbitration this year and the fifth over all. Don Sears, the arbitrator who heard the case Friday, chose the Dodgers' figure of $280,000 over Pena's $367,500.

title: PRINCETON ACTS TO CUT ASSAULTS ON CAMPUS
description: LEAD: CAMPUS patrols have been increased as a result of recent assaults on Princeton University students.

title: LAUNCH A PEGASUS CAPTURES WIDENER
description: Launch a Pegasus set an astoundingly slow pace and then drew off through the stretch to win the $200,000 Widener Handicap today at Hialeah Park.

title: RUTGERS GIVES HUMANITIES A LEG UP
description: LEAD: ''THINGS are popping now,'' Dr. George Levine, director of Rutgers University's new Center for Critical Analysis of Contemporary Culture, said recently as the center moved into new offices in University Hall on the New Brunswick campus.

title: STAMFORD SETS DEC. 31 PARTY
description: WITH New Year's Eve now a memory barely seven weeks old, some Stamford residents and civic leaders are already making plans for a special celebration next Dec. 31 - a downtown party with a costume parade and arts performances, both indoors and out and many of them free.

title: MAN SAID TO TAX EARTH'S SYSTEMS
description: The pressures of population growth and economic expansion are starting to exceed the ability of the earth's natural systems to sustain such activity, a new report by the Worldwatch Institute warned today.

title: Regensburg
description: To the Editor: John Dornberg's fine sketch of the historical city of Regensburg (Travel, Jan. 18) stirred memories of a delightful incident of a few years ago.

title: GORBACHEV CALLS FOR CIVIL RIGHTS, BUT WILL THEY BE ENFORCED?
description: WHILE scores of political prisoners were getting out of Soviet jails and labor camps last week, a Government commission was at work on a sweeping revision of the Soviet criminal code that, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, Gennadi I. Gerasimov, promised, will make it harder in the future to put people ''behind bars and behind barbed wire.'' The release of the dissidents - 140 were freed, and a like number of cases are being reviewed - appeared to be for foreign consumption and the intelligentsia. Mr. Gerasimov briefed foreign correspondents, but the Soviet press made only a passing reference to it. And by week's end some of the good will had been dampened by a brutal crackdown on protesters appealing for the freedom of a dissident not included in the pardon.

title: DEALING WITH THE LAWS OF THE LAND
description: I have never been robbed abroad, save for an incident in Ghana in which two soldiers with machine guns took some cash. That was more like taxation than thievery, however, because the perpetrators were soldiers on duty at a roadblock. So I never have been properly robbed abroad. Yet I do worry a bit when I am overseas about the security of my cash and passport. A couple of incidents over the last few years have confirmed that there can be reason to worry.

title: TARKANIAN CASE: LONG ROAD NEARS END
description: IT would be incorrect to say that either Jerry Tarkanian or officials at the National Collegiate Athletic Association have been waiting with bated breath for the outcome of a lawsuit involving them. If they were, they would have turned blue long ago.

title: Recent Sales
description: Bayport $180,000 60 Oakwood Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 110-year-old colonial; fireplace, basement, wraparound porch, barn, 1 acre; taxes $3,700. Commack $228,000 4 Town Line Road 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new contemporary; eat-in kitchen, dining room, den, fireplace, skylights, loft; taxes $5,100. Kings Park $160,000 16 Bruce Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old split-level; family room, dining room, pool, 1-car garage; taxes $3,400. Smithtown $170,000 6 Colonial Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 15-year-old ranch; 0.5 acre, corral and stable; taxes $2,400. Village of the Branch $221,500 4 Rice Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 22-year-old colonial; dining room, finished basement, den, 1-car garage, 0.5 acre; taxes $4,900. Woodmere $265,000 634 Hungry Harbor Road 3-bedroom, 3-bath 25-year-old high ranch; eat-in kitchen, maid's room, 2-car garage; taxes $3,900. OTHER AREAS Closter, N.J. $174,900 21 Center Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; wall-to-wall carpeting, patio, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,559. Waccabuc, N.Y. $290,000 Chapel Road 4 bedroom, 2-bath, 33-year-old frame Cape Cod; pond, 9 acres; taxes $3,353. Richfield, Conn. $545,000 229 Ivy Hill Road 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 6-year-old converted barn; wide floor boards, heated swimming pool, 2.7 acres, taxes $5,601.

title: Koop Says Reagan Rejected Plan to Lead Anti-AIDS Drive
