description: President Reagan has rejected a proposal to combine warnings about AIDS with his anti-narcotics campaign, the Surgeon General of the United States says.

title: EUROPEAN TRADE BLOC'S CRISIS
description: ''I am not a horse trader,'' Jacques Delors, president of the European Community's Executive Commission, insisted recently. ''I don't ask for 10, expecting to get 5.''

title: WHAT EARLIER PRESIDENTS WOULD HAVE DONE ABOUT NICARAGUA
description: To the Editor:

title: New Look Is Urged At Military Contracts
description: Manhattan District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau said yesterday that because of the corruption scandal involving the Wedtech military contractor in the Bronx, a Congressional committee should look into the defense procurement business, particularly as it involves minority enterprises.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 16, 1987
description: The Economy Japan's six chip makers were asked to honor an agreement with the U.S. The request by the Ministry of International Trade and Industry follows charges by U.S. trade officials that Japanese companies are continuing to ''dump'' computer chips - selling them below the cost of production - despite the agreement reached last July 31. [ Page 43. ] Corporate profits showed modest overall improvement in the fourth quarter, partly as a result of the weaker dollar and low oil prices and interest rates. [ 46. ] Some industries, including energy and automotive equipment, suffered a sharp overall drop in earnings, while food concerns and publishing companies showed strong growth. [ 47. ] Retail sales in 1986 were the strongest in three years in New York and the surrounding suburbs, despite the closing of two major chains, Gimbles and Ohrbach's. Increased purchases by affluent consumers were cited for the year-to-year average sales gains of 6.9 percent in the city and 6.7 percent in the metropolitan area. [ 43. ] The U.S. Farm Credit System is expected to post a loss of between $2.3 billion and $2.4 billion for 1986, making a Federal rescue likely, Government officials said. [ 45. ] Older workers are more likely to remain employed, now that laws eliminating mandatory retirement have been enacted. Despite the change, more Americans are taking early retirement. [ 43. ] International

title: Books of The Times; Mosaic of the Mind
description: THE SOCIETY OF MIND. By Marvin Minsky. Illustrated. 339 pages. Simon & Schuster. $19.95. What on earth is a ''society of mind''? By choosing this phrase for the title of his new book on how people think and feel, Marvin Minsky, the artificial-intelligence expert, is trying to convey his belief that each mind is made of many smaller processes, which he calls ''agents.'' ''Each mental agent by itself can only do some simple thing that needs no mind or thought at all,'' he writes. ''Yet when we join these agents in societies - in certain very special ways - this leads to true intelligence.'' Hence, ''The Society of Mind.''

title: A Neglected Avenue Is Blossoming Again
description: OUT from decades of gloom and neglect, a powerful and palatial stretch of the Avenue of the Americas - where New York's great department stores once nestled shoulder to sumptuous shoulder - is returning to life.

title: DANCE: 'OUT OF THE BLUE'
description: ''Out of the Blue: Six Startling Views,'' an imaginative program of dances presented on Saturday by the Dance Center of the Emanu-El Midtown Y, lived up to its title for much of the evening. This was dance with an eye firmly fixed on the world around it. These were dances that were notably provocative and polished.

title: MUSIC: SHARROCK QUARTET
description: In the 1960's, the guitarist Sonny Sharrock translated the Dionysiac frenzy of free-jazz saxophone to the electric guitar. He used high volume, fuzz-tone distortion and fusillades of notes - a combination of tremolo strumming and high-speed fingering - as analogues of John Coltrane's ''sheets of sound'' and Pharoah Sanders's honks and cries.

title: TILL DEATH OR DINNER US DO PART
description: WHEN it comes to couples' social lives, a kind of Noah's ark syndrome has long held sway: everything has happened two-by-two - theater tickets, dinner invitations, even friendships. ''Both members of the couple have had to go together,'' said Karen Shanor, a clinical psychologist in Washington. ''Otherwise, neither person was considered a valid presence.''

title: ELLIOTT WINS AS BODINE'S HOPES SPUTTER
description: Bill Elliott won his second Daytona 500 as Geoff Bodine, losing a gamble, ran out of gas three laps from the end today at Daytona International Speedway.

title: East Berlin Bank Plan
description: A major commercial bank said that it was being denied permission to become the first West German bank to establish an office in East Berlin. A spokesman for Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale (WestLB) said Friday that the bank had been told by West German banking authorities that the application would not be approved. WestLB said earlier this month that it wanted to open an office in East Berlin to expand its activities in financing trade between East and West Germany. However, West Berlin officials feared the move might lead to a decline of the city as a commercial center if other companies and banks followed WestLB's lead and moved to East Berlin.

title: Posner Retrial Site Disputed
description: Federal attorneys have objected to a motion by the industrialist Victor Posner to move his retrial on income tax evasion charges to New York.

title: SURVIVORS FROM A LOST SHIP RECALL THEIR ORDEAL AT SEA
description: Mourning the loss of three comrades but glad to be alive, 24 Turkish seamen and a woman from a ship abandoned in a howling Atlantic storm sailed into New York yesterday aboard a West German freighter.

title: Profits Rise a Bit in Quarter
description: Corporate profits showed modest improvement in the fourth quarter, a result of the weaker dollar and continued low oil prices and interest rates. Still, economists said the earnings remained below expectations and indicated continuing sluggishness in the economy.

title: CUOMO MISSES MINORITY CAUCUS AFFAIR
description: Governor Cuomo canceled a meeting today with the Rev. Jesse Jackson and an appearance at a dinner sponsored by black and Hispanic legislators so that he could depart a day early on the second of his national trips, to New Orleans.

title: Cheers and Jeers
description: Compared with say, football, which produces thousands of serious injuries a year, cheerleading is a safe pursuit. When it turns unsafe, though, the accidents can be extreme. Now two well-publicized incidents last fall - the death of a cheerleader at North Dakota State and the paralysis of another at Kentucky - have prompted one major university to impose a severe restriction on cheerleading stunts and to persuade its conference to begin a detailed study of the activity.

title: A Speech Maker
description: Robert C. McFarlane, President Reagan's former national security adviser who has been embroiled in the arms-to-Iran investigation, apparently made a very successful start as a public speaker after he left the White House. Industry sources say Mr. McFarlane earned more than $250,000 in 1986 making speeches on foreign affairs around the country and was similarly booked this year when he was hospitalized a week ago for an overdose of Valium in what the police reported as a suicide attempt.

title: AFTER PARADES AND PROMISES, DUARTE FLOUNDERS IN SALVADOR
description: Jose Napoleon Duarte was lauded at a major political demonstration a week ago, as thousands of Government workers, peasants from state-run co-operatives and others dependent on Government patronage were trucked into El Salvador's capital for a show of his ruling Christian Democratic Party's political machine at work.

title: For Farm Workers, for Decency's Sake
description: In 1972, America's farm workers asked the Federal Government to insure them the basic dignities to which virtually all other American workers are entitled. They wanted drinking water in the workplace, which in their case is the fields. Fewer than half are provided with it. They wanted to be able to wash pesticide residue off their hands. One-fifth had no place to wash up. They wanted toilets. More than a third had to resort to ditches. These sound like modest requests. But achieving them has taken more than 14 years - until last week, when a Federal appeals court put an end to what it characterized as ''this disgraceful chapter of legal neglect.'' A three-judge panel ruled that the Labor Department had acted improperly in failing to issue Federal standards to protect field hands from the hazards of communicable diseases and heat stress.

title: This Old House
description: For a school that's getting a brand-new $8.5 million gym next season, Williams College is making an awful lot of fuss about the old one. All former Williams basketball players have been invited back to bid farewell to the old gym when the Ephmen play their final game there Feb. 28, and many are expected to show up this Saturday for the game against the college's chief rival, Amherst.

title: U.S. PRODS SEOUL RIVALS TO SETTLE RIFT
description: The United States has begun a vigorous campaign to nudge South Korea's rival political parties toward a compromise that would lead to a more democratic government.

title: OUTDOORS: SERENITY OF SMALL GAME
description: THOSE who enjoy hunting when guns are not coughing incessantly in the surrounding hills, when it is possible to spend a day in the woods without encountering anyone, save, perhaps, a snowshoer or a cross-country skier, should remember that this is such a time of year. And in some states there are two major species of small game - the ruffed grouse and the snowshoe rabbit - that still may be pursued.

title: AT ORAL ROBERTS U., EVANGELIST'S DIVINE PLEA CAUSES NO ALARM
description: The evangelist Oral Roberts may have drawn widespread criticism when he told his television audience he would die if he could not raise $4.5 million by April. But there are few signs of any storms raging on the futuristic $500 million campus he has created here.

title: OFFICIALS SEEK MARKETS FOR RECYCLED GARBAGE
description: Northeastern state officials want to create stronger markets for recycled products in an effort to deal with the growing problem of garbage disposal.

title: China to Establish 6 Airlines
description: China will set up six independent airlines by 1988 to operate international and domestic flights, the official New China News Agency quoted Hu Yizhou, director-general of the state-owned airline company, as saying on Saturday.

title: RICHARD KENDRICK
description: Richard Kendrick, a retired actor, died at the Bellevue Hospital Center last Tuesday after suffering a stroke. He was in his early 80's and lived in Manhattan.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: WRITERS WHO READ This is the fourth season for the series of short-story readings called ''Writer Nights.'' There will be three programs in all and the first is tonight at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center. Each night four writers read their own stories.

title: BRONX CLERGY CALLS FOR REMOVAL OF BOROUGH CHIEF
description: Hundreds of Bronx religious leaders at a rally yesterday called on Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch to replace Borough President Stanley Simon with an ''interim administrator'' while Mr. Simon fights criminal allegations against him.

title: Latin America Debt Warning
description: Latin America will have to get better terms in its foreign debt rescheduling or it will be forced to limit debt service to a percentage of export earnings, officials said Friday.

title: NEW LAWS ALLOW MORE TO WORK AFTER AGE 70
description: Marian Johnston, a 71-year-old word-processing secretary at Bradley Hospital in Riverside, R.I., is happy about the new Federal law that bans mandatory retirement because of age. ''I don't know what I would have done if they hadn't hired me last August,'' she said.

title: Sharing of Archives
description: Officials of the National Archives and their counterparts in the Soviet Union may begin exchanging copies of the two countries' official records for the first time under an international agreement to be signed this week. The agreement, between the American Council of Learned Societies and the Main Archival Administration of the Soviet Council of Ministers, would create a Commission on Archival Cooperation to carry out the exchanges.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Washington dispatch Feb. 7 on a letter from Senator Sam Nunn, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, to President Reagan about the consequences of a failure to consult with Congress on the Antiballistic Missile Treaty incorrectly quoted from the letter. Mr. Nunn wrote that a failure to consult would lead to a ''constitutional confrontation of profound dimensions.''

title: U.S. DRUG SEARCHES SNARL BORDER TRAFFIC AND VEX BUSINESS
description: The trucks stretch for miles across the Mexican border, farther than the eye can see, creeping forward by the inch with their cargoes of auto parts, video cassettes, fresh tomatoes and toys to cross the bridge and clear United States Customs. And as the lines grow longer each day on the Mexican side, tempers grow shorter on the American side.

title: Homeless Man Killed On the West Side
description: Two homeless men were stabbed, one fatally, yesterday as they slept on a loading dock on Manhattan's West Side, the police said.

title: 'Oracle,' a Work By Howell and Tavares
description: ''Oracle'' by Donald Howell and Albert Tavares - an hourlong piece for voices and electronic keyboards presented Saturday at Mr. Tavares's studio on Eighth Avenue - is based on phonetic syllables derived from ancient chants and on ''text material . . . generated using psychosynthesis, a new psychology developed by Roberto Assagioli as a method of integrating various aspects of the personality through the use of symbolic images created in a meditative state,'' according to the program. The work seemed basically to be a lyrical, quasi-artistic appreciation of a group therapy experience of some kind, with intermittent musical background.

title: INSIDE
description: Pushing Back Retirement New laws barring age discrimination are likely to encourage older workers to stay on the job, earning incomes and paying taxes. Page 43.

title: Washington Watch; A.B.A. Backs Proxmire Plan
description: The prospects for major banking legislation this year appear to have improved sharply with a decision by the American Bankers Association to support Senator Proxmire's version of what should be done.

title: Catching Up
description: * Remember Bob Wieland, the legless Vietnam veteran who took more than 99 excruciating hours to complete the New York City Marathon last November? He's still on the go. Wieland, a weight lifter who propels himself by using his arms to lift and drag his 123-pound body, is now entered in the Los Angeles Marathon, and this time he hopes to win. That's right, win. He's received approval from race organizers to begin the course Feb. 25, four days before the official start. If all goes well, he'll reach the finish line just about the time it's crossed by his world-class competitors.

title: BIAGGI: EMBATTLED BUT STILL CONFIDENT
description: Mario Biaggi sits in a rocker in his office here, his silvery hair framed by the Capitol dome that rises beyond the window.

title: Aqueduct Forced To Cancel a Race
description: A malfunction of the starting gate resulted in cancellation of Aqueduct's ninth and final race yesterday and necessitated a refund of $923,507 in triple, exacta and straight bets.

title: What Earlier Presidents Would Have Done About Nicaragua
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNORS DEFAULTS WITH KNEE INJURY
description: Top-seeded Stefan Edberg won his second United States Indoor tennis championship in the past three years today when a knee injury forced second-seeded Jimmy Connors to retire in the second set.

title: A.B.A. SPLIT OVER PROPOSALS TO REVISE TORT SYSTEM
description: Lawyers are at odds as the American Bar Association prepares to take up proposals for improving the system of recovering damages for personal injuries.

title: Panel Chides Reagan On Parley in Iceland
description: President Reagan was poorly prepared for the summit meeting in Iceland last October and the two-day meeting ended with ''an astonishing degree of confusion'' about potential nuclear arms control agreements, the House Armed Services Committee said today.

title: HOPING TURMOIL WON'T RETURN
description: DAVE JOHNSON says he will warn them. Frank Cashen says he will lecture them. Gary Carter says he will watch them. Keith Hernandez says he will monitor them. And, if necessary, he will give them the message: ''Put it behind you.''

title: OPEC Pricing Review
description: The Price Differentials Committee of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will meet March 9 in Vienna to review the official prices it set last December, according to an oil official of the United Arab Emirates. The prices went into effect on Feb. 1.

title: WHAT HAVE YOU DONE LATELY?
description: DEAR GEORGE:

title: Let's Move to End Apartment Warehousing
description: To the Editor:

title: SCALIA PROPOSES MAJOR OVERHAUL OF U.S. COURTS
description: Associate Justice Antonin Scalia of the Supreme Court said today that the Federal judiciary was being transformed from an ''elite'' into a vast bureaucracy by a flood of routine cases, and called for a major overhaul.

title: Party's Planner
description: Donald L. Fowler of South Carolina, a veteran Democratic leader and rules expert, has been chosen as the chief executive officer of the party's national convention to be held in Atlanta in mid-July next year. Mr. Fowler, selected for the job by the national chairman, Paul G. Kirk Jr., will be in charge of all planning and organization for the convention for the next 17 months.

title: SOVIET ANNOUNCES A JEWISH DISSIDENT HAS BEEN RELEASED
description: Iosif Z. Begun, the Jewish dissident whose continued imprisonment set off violent demonstrations in downtown Moscow last week, has been freed, a senior Soviet official said today.

title: NETS HALT STREAK AT NINE LOSSES
description: Call it the law of averages. Maybe it was the Cleveland Cavaliers' road losing streak - 11 games before today.

title: CONCERT: CLEVELAND ORCHESTRA
description: ALEXANDER VON ZEMLINSKY had the misfortune of being born sane in an extravagant age. Eminent composer of his day, conductor, teacher of Schoenberg, colleague of Mahler, Zemlinsky did everything with enormous technique and thoughtful care; yet he has sunk into musical history, pulled down by the inertia of forgetfulness and neglect.

title: Markets, Banks Closed
description: The nation's stock and commodity markets are closed today in observance of Presidents' Day. Government offices, most banks and many businesses are also closed.

title: Rescued Sailors Reach New York Harbor
description: The West German freighter Colombo sailing toward the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge yesterday. Aboard were 24 Turkish seamen and a woman who were rescued by the Colombo after their merchant ship sank in a storm in the Atlantic on Friday. Three members of the crew were lost in the sinking. Page 30. (United States Coast Guard/Randy Midget)

title: EVALUATING BESS MYERSON'S 4 YEARS AS CULTURAL-AFFAIRS LEADER
description: Four years ago this month, after having been turned down by Jacqueline Onassis and Beverly Sills, Mayor Koch named Bess Myerson commissioner of the city's Department of Cultural Affairs.

title: Letter; ON POLICE: OFFICERS' DEFENSE IN THE STEWART CASE
description: To the Editor:

title: Andrea K. Frey Weds Matthew Howard Bass
description: Andrea Kanon Frey, a product manager for the American Home Products Corporation in New York, was married yesterday to Matthew Howard Bass, the television production cost analyst for DFS-Dorland Worldwide, an advertising agency in New York. Rabbi Harlan Wechsler performed the ceremony at the Water Club restaurant in New York.

title: NEW BREED OF SCHOOL DROPOUTS IS SEEN EMERGING
description: Many public-school dropouts are ranked in the top quarter of their class and some are less than 14 years old, according to a study of the nation's fourth-largest district.

title: SECURITY GUARD IS SHOT TO DEATH IN WELFARE HOTEL
description: A security guard at a Manhattan welfare hotel was killed yesterday with a shotgun blast to the face when he tried to break up a couple's dispute.

title: Egyptian Oil Price Cut
description: Egypt is cutting the export price of its crude oil benchmark Suez and Ras Bahar 35 cents, to $17.25 a barrel, Hammad Ayoub, of the Egyptian General Petroleum Corporation, said today.

title: SUDDENLY, A SOVIET VEIL IS LIFTED, REVEALING SCENES OF BITTER YOUTHS
description: On Soviet movie screens, punk rockers spray-paint hostile graffiti on building walls. In one Soviet journal, a drug addict's diary describes watching a fellow addict slit his wrists and die, and in another a sociologist drily chronicles greed and disaffection among Soviet youth.

title: 4 LATIN LEADERS ASK NICARAGUA FOR JOINT TALKS
description: The presidents of all the major Central American countries except Nicaragua met here today and invited the Nicaraguan Government to join them in a new regional peace conference within 90 days.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Offering Low-Cost Legal Advice
description: Most A.F.L.-C.I.O. members became eligible today for low-cost legal services ranging from free consultations and document reviews to discounts on lawyers' fees.

title: MOVES NOT MADE COULD BE COSTLY
description: IT was still winter outside his New Jersey home, and the only thing on Lou Piniella's mind was escaping to the warm breezes of Florida and his second spring as the Yankees' manager. He had spent part of the winter skiing in Colorado, part of it in organizational meetings back home, part of it simply considering the moves that awaited him when camp opens Friday in Fort Lauderdale.

title: IRISH DEFEAT DUKE IN OVERTIME, 70-66
description: Donald Royal hit two free throws with 24 seconds left in overtime to break a 66-all tie and Scott Paddock made two more foul shots as Notre Dame edged Duke, 70-66, today.

title: SMALL LABEL MASTERS THE BLUES
description: This city is famous for many things but only the tiny and esoteric Alligator Records has been able to successfully mine one of the city's most precious treasures - the blues.

title: WINTER'S TWO FACES: EXHILARATION AND DESPAIR
description: In New York, Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn's observation took on a new meaning this weekend when arctic winds swept across the region, and plummeting temperatures divided the city into two camps: those who view the cold as exhilarating, and those for whom the cold is a brutal - and sometimes lethal - hardship.

title: MEDICAID TOLD TO PAY FOR GIRL'S TRANSPLANT
description: A Federal judge issued a preliminary injunction Saturday requiring Medicaid in Virginia to pay for the liver transplant of a 4-year-old girl who was denied aid because of the state's criteria on liver diseases.

title: STATE ACCUSES METRO-NORTH OF USING ILLEGAL WASTE SITE
description: New York State environmental officials have charged that the Metro-North Commuter Railroad is illegally using a lagoon near the Hudson River to store more than a million gallons of water containing toxic wastes.

title: Record Amid Mild Hoopla
description: Yes, Dick Baldwin, the basketball coach at Broome Community College in Binghamton, N.Y., swept past the legendary Adolph Rupp of Kentucky in career coaching victories over the weekend.

title: Judge an Ideal by Those Who Live Up to It
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL'S HOT TOPIC: STARS STILL OUT IN COLD
description: BASEBALL'S Uncertain Spring starts Friday.

title: Carriers Help Keep American Sea Power Ready
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Watch; Volcker Loses Leadoff Spot
description: EVER since 1978, when the Full Employment and Balanced Growth Act first required the Federal Reserve to present semiannual reports of its monetary policy goals to Congress, the Fed's chairman has had a near-monopoly on members' attention. But this time around, things will be different, much to the annoyance of Paul A. Volcker.

title: Conquistarose Gets A Major Setback
description: Tropical rain turned a sunny afternoon of formful racing at Hialeah Park into a dark and humid twilight zone of strange results, capped by the defeat of Conquistarose, the 1-to-5 favorite, in the Citation Stakes.

title: FARM CREDIT CRISIS: BAILOUT DEBATE NEAR
description: The United States Farm Credit System is expected to report a 1986 loss of $2.3 billion to $2.4 billion, virtually assuring that a Federal rescue will be needed this year, according to Government officials. The report is to be issued Wednesday.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: In major league baseball, which has occurred more frequently, a no-hitter or a batter hitting for the cycle? Although both are scarce, over the years, it has been slightly easier for a starting pitcher to keep an opposing team hitless for nine innings than it has been for a batter to rap opposing pitchers for a single, double, triple and home run in one game. Since 1900, there have been 179 no-hitters pitched in the majors (91 in the American League), the most recent one by Mike Scott of the Astros against San Francisco last Sept. 25 in the game that clinched the National League West for Houston.

title: GOODEN AND METS REACH AGREEMENT
description: While Don Mattingly and the Yankees negotiated unsuccessfully before their salary arbitration hearing today, Dwight Gooden and the Mets canceled their Friday arbitration date by reaching agreement yesterday on a new contract.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Briefing column on the Washington Talk page Tuesday incorrectly described the function at which the Canadian Embassy played host to visiting officials from the South Pacific nation of Vanuatu. The event was a prayer meeting for representatives of countries in the Oceania region, not a diplomatic reception.

title: Jeffrey Bercow Is Wed To Julie Lowell Russin
description: At Temple Beth Shalom in Miami Beach yesterday, Julie Lowell Russin, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David J. Russin of Miami Beach, was married to Jeffrey Bercow, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul S. Bercow of Scotch Plains, N.J. Rabbi Gary Glickstein performed the ceremony.

title: FINE TIME FOR FANS
description: FROM Miami to Mesa, baseball returns to the national scene this week when 18 spring training camps open in Florida and eight others in Arizona. And, until the season starts on April 6, they will be the oases for tourists, travelers and other souls who have been wandering since Jesse Orosco of the Mets struck out Marty Barrett of the Boston Red Sox to end the World Series three and a half months ago.

title: Head of Stone Container Capitalizes on Mergers
description: It was not until his last two years of college that Roger W. Stone decided to join his family's business, the Stone Container Corporation. If the company's commitment to the paper industry was ever in doubt in those early days some 20 years ago, those doubts now have been put to rest.

title: STAGE: 'DAZY,' A MUSICAL
description: Late in the second act of ''Dazy,'' a musical set in midtown Manhattan, a homeless man assures the audience, ''You've got to be a romantic to live out on the street.'' The pronouncement, which flies in the face of evidence that most New Yorkers encounter every day, exemplifies the colossal wrongheadedness of a show that portrays street people as muddled bohemian eccentrics down on their luck. ''You can join me right here any time in the rainbow of my mind,'' goes the lyric of their collective theme song.

title: Nancy A. Zarett Becomes a Bride
description: Nancy Ann Zarett, an associate at the New York law firm of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler, was married yesterday to Dr. George William Niedt, a fellow in the division of dermatopathology at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. Judge Seymour Schwartz of the Civil Court of the City of New York performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: Politicizing Art
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOD FETISH FROM AUSTRALIA
description: One of the mysteries of this country, to an American, is the Australian fondness for a black yeast spread called Vegemite. It sometimes seems virtually the national food, spread on toast, mixed with hot water to make a drink or added to stews.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Feb. 15, 1987: MONDAY Dana Corp NAFCO Fin'l Group Hazleton Labs Wendy's Intl Minnesota Mng & Mfg Zurn Indus TUESDAY Allen Group Kellwood Co Amer Cyanamid Ohio Edison Briggs & Stratton Sherwin-Williams Cincinnati Milacron V F Corp Coleman Co Whirlpool Corp Foote Cone & Belding Wynn's International WEDNESDAY Centex Corp Marine Midland Banks Fireman's Fund Mohasco Corp First Bank System Morse Shoe Intl Minerals & Chemical Northrop Corp THURSDAY Champion Intl K N Energy Dresser Indus Kollmorgen Corp Florida Progress Sterling Bancorp Greyhound Corp Sundstrand Corp Halliburton Co Torchmark Corp Illinois Pwr Van Dorn Co FRIDAY Barnes Group Pulte Home Corp Brown & Sharpe Mfg Reynolds Metals Edwards Inc South Jersey Indus Grubb & Ellis Texas Utilities Illinois Tool Works

title: RISE IN RETARTED CHILDREN PREDICTED FROM CHERNOBYL
description: Up to 13 of the 300 Soviet children born since the reactor accident at Chernobyl to women who lived nearby are expected to suffer mental retardation because of exposure to hazardous levels of radiation, an American physician who recently returned from the contaminated area said here today. But none of the children have been observed to have any physical defects, he said.

title: CITY BALLET: 'SINFONIA MISTICA'
description: Ib Andersen took over the leading male role in Paul Mejia's ''Sinfonia Mistica'' at the New York City Ballet's performance Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater. It was a role originally intended for him, but an injury prevented him from dancing it at the premiere, on Feb. 5.

title: MICHIGAN TOWN'S 'RED DEVIL' DUE A FACE LIFT
description: The devil is getting a face lift in this small northern Michigan community of 2,000 people.

title: Esprit Sport President Appointed to New Posts
description: Esprit, the San Francisco-based sportswear company, has named Corrado Federico president and chief operating officer, a new post.

title: REAGAN SHELVING TREATY TO REVISE LAW ON CAPTIVES
description: In a move intended to deny international legal protection to terrorists and anti-Western guerrillas, President Reagan has decided against ratification of part of a major revision of the 1949 Geneva Conventions on treatment of combatants and war victims, according to Administration documents.

title: Import Limits Called Costly
description: Restrictions on foreign trade cost Americans $50 billion a year, according to Daniel Oliver, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission.

title: PLANTING TIME ON THE KIBBUTZ, AND WORRY TIME
description: The utopian world of the kibbutz movement moved into the shadows of a full moon and critical indebtedness this weekend, heading resolutely into another cycle of planting and reaping.

title: BICENTENNIAL PANEL IN CALIFORNIA ASSAILED OVER 'RACIST' TEXTBOOK
description: Angry state legislators have demanded that Gov. George Deukmejian dismiss his appointees to California's Bicentennial Commission for approving for sale a history textbook that includes an essay on slavery that refers to black children as ''pickaninnies'' and says that the ''constant fear of slave rebellion'' made life for Southern whites ''a nightmare.''

title: THEODORE M. WEIS
description: Theodore M. Weis, a trumpet player with several classical ensembles in New York, died, apparently of a heart attack, at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital on Saturday. He was 66 years old and lived in Englewood.

title: A Tax Hotline In Michigan
description: A computerized telephone service that will let Michigan taxpayers learn the status of their refunds was introduced Friday by the state Treasurer, Robert Bowman.

title: The Party, Like Reagan's Era, Is Over
description: LEAD: Jimmy Carter, where are you now that we need you? What we need now is a re-rendering of your ''malaise'' speech. Maybe a whole series of them. We are discovering, on the domestic front, that feeling good is not enough.

title: New Lafarge Chief Sees Quicker Pace
description: The corporate restructuring announced last week by the Lafarge Corporation should help cut costs and improve market position, according to Bertrand C. Collomb, the company's new vice chairman and chief executive officer. But in a sluggish industry, it may be some time before the improvements begin to show for the Dallas-based cement producer.

title: TWO MONTHS OF PROTEST BY YOUTHS BRINGS HAVOC TO SPAIN'S SCHOOLS
description: He is known as El Cojo - the crippled one - and the image of him shown repeatedly on national television and in the nation's newspapers in recent days has been both sad and brutal.

title: ASSESSING THE CRISIS OF FARMS
description: Asserting that it is not enough to have sermons, songs and nice poems about farmers, a group of nearly 100 Christians and Jews has just concluded a two-day conference here on the social impact of the continuing farm depression.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Amherst Group, Cambridge, Mass., named Charles W. Shields executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: RISING PRESSURE IN CRIMINAL COURT: THE VIEW FROM THE BENCH
description: On a typical day in Judge Renee White's courtroom, a procession of defendants passed before the bench - accused crack users and crack dealers, young men charged with washing motorists' windows without permission, Senegalese accused of peddling without a license.

title: Chun Violin Duo At Weill Recital Hall
description: Practically every conceivable element of the Chun Violin Duo's concert at Weill Recital Hall Saturday afternoon conspired against its success. First, the nerve-jangling acoustics of this renovated space gave the sound of two violins playing in their upper registers a badly distortive glare.

title: DANCE: 'PICCOLO BALLETTO'
description: Some ballets look better the second season around and Jerome Robbins's ''Piccolo Balletto'' for the New York City Ballet is certainly a case in point.

title: Earning the Pay
description: Members of Congress are very sensitive about their recent raise to $89,000 a year, fearful that the voters might believe they were over-rewarding themselves. But Representative Daniel E. Lungren, Republican of California, believes the American people ''are not really upset with us over the rate of pay we receive but with the perceived failure to perform after we get paid.''

title: NEW OUTBREAK OF FIGHTING SHAKES BEIRUT
description: Four separate gunbattles raged in Beirut today in one of the worst days of violence in the Lebanese capital in months.

title: Mendelssohn Quartet And Namesake's Music
description: The Mendelssohn String Quartet concentrated on music of its namesake at Merkin Concert Hall Saturday evening, and played as though determined to defend the composer against the impression that he was oversupplied with delicacy, elegance and grace, and a little short on true grit. This listener found himself wishing the performers had embraced the former qualities more fully. Both the Andante and the Scherzo (from the loose ends published as Opus 81) and the big Quintet in A, Opus 18, were played with love and vigor, but also with a lot of stabbing accents, the kind in which the stroke of the bow is accompanied with a great shake of the head and a little liftoff of the player's body from the chair. Sometimes the tone was so muscular and gritty that proper blending of the harmonies was elusive, and sometimes the vigor seemed associated with brief carelessness about intonation.

title: STAGE: 'THE LITTLE FOXES'
description: Speaking of animals, ''The Little Foxes'' is a sturdy mount that, with some whipping, has made it into the winner's circle in seasons past. But after almost a half century, it needs more of the whip than is applied at the Equity Library Theater. Under the restrained direction of Thomas Edward West, it starts a bit slow, shows its stuff around the Act II-turn, and fades in the stretch.

title: France Likely To Buy Awacs
description: France is expected to follow Britain's lead and agree within a month to buy at least three Awacs radar planes, Pentagon officials said Friday.

title: O'CONNOR SUPPORTS BAN ON A HOMOSEXUAL GROUP
description: John Cardinal O'Connor said yesterday that he agreed fully with the action taken by Bishop Francis J. Mugavero of Brooklyn in banning a group of homosexual Roman Catholics from holding masses or meetings on property of the Brooklyn Diocese.

title: METS STILL WIN IT
description: AND so we sat the other night, in the dead of winter, watching Mookie Wilson do his midnight dance.

title: FOR EARLY TOURISTS, A TEPID WELCOME AT JERSEY RESORT
description: It was a few beers past midnight at the Quarter Deck Inn. Outside, the wind-chill factor pushed 10 degrees, and the weather forecast called for light snow. Inside, the bar was elbow-to-elbow with smartly sweatered out-of-towners, and the band was earnestly bopping its way through a current hit, ''It's Hip to be Square.''

title: ROUNDUP OF QUARTERLY EARNINGS AND SALES AT 295 COMPANIES
description: (Loss) * not applicable, loss in 1985 period. .... Loss in latest quarter. (1) Quarter ending in Sept.(2) Quarter ending in Oct. (3) Quarter ending in Nov.(4) Quarter ending in Jan. 1987

title: MARLA BAZAR IS MARRIED
description: Marla Bazar Is Married Marla Anne Bazar, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Bazar of Franklin Square, L.I., was married yesterday to Philip Howard Edelstein, the son of Alfred Edelstein of Kew Gardens, Queens, and Anita Edelstein of Bayside, Queens. Rabbi Alan Lavin officiated at Temple Sholom in Brooklyn. The bride, a graduate of Cornell University, is a home economist for Thomas J. Lipton Inc. in Englewood Cliffs, N.J. Mr. Edelstein, a graduate of New York University, is the New York sales representative for the Ambrust Chain Company of Providence, R.I.

title: Beethoven Symphonies By Vienna Philharmonic
description: The Vienna Philharmonic is to play the complete Beethoven symphonies and piano concertos in a six-concert series at Carnegie Hall next month, under the direction of Claudio Abbado and with Maurizio Pollini as soloist. The performances would be the orchestra's first in New York since 1976.

title: DANCE: BYRD'S 'REHEARSAL'
description: Donald Byrd has tackled racism, the pain of rejection as an artist and the loss of innocence in his dances. In ''The Rehearsal,'' a new work performed by Donald Byrd/The Group on Friday at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, Mr. Byrd has created a flawed but often evocative fable, to music by Carman Moore, about a choreographer and his dancers.

title: Colombian Wins Flyweight Title
description: Fidel Bassa of Colombia won the World Boxing Association flyweight title with a unanimous 15-round decision over the champion, Hilario Zapata, of Panama Friday night. There were no knockdowns. Bassa, 24 years old, fighting in only his 17th bout, is the sixth Colombian to win a world boxing title.

title: Corrections
description: The Sports World Specials column in SportsMonday last week reported an erroneous finding by a committee of baseball researchers. The committee, which said it had turned up evidence that Babe Ruth was born with the surname Ehrhardt, now acknowledges that this belief, which apparently first surfaced in the 1920's, has since been authoritatively discounted.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday Capacity Utilization January Wednesday Housing Starts January Thursday Gross National Product (rev.) 4th qtr. Friday Personal Income January

title: Sandra Irwin, a Teacher, Wed to Bradley Kaufman
description: The marriage of Sandra Irwin, an elementary school teacher at the E. M. Baker School in Great Neck, L.I., to Bradley A. Kaufman, a real-estate associate at the New York law firm of Bachner, Tally, Polevoy, Misher & Brinberg, took place yesterday at Temple Beth-El in Great Neck. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson performed the ceremony.

title: ADELPHI SUSPENDS COACH, ASSISTANT
description: After suspending its basketball head coach and assistant coach over the weekend for possible violations of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules and regulations, Adelphi University announced yesterday that one of its players, Charles Webb, was being held out of yesterday's game with Mount St. Mary's.

title: MINING EL DORADO AT 45 BELOW
description: When John Zigarlick Jr. arrived at this remote spot 65 miles below the Arctic Circle recently, he dined on beef stroganoff and strawberries in the mine cafeteria before heading off to the racquetball court for an evening game.

title: JOHNSON'S 39 LEAD LAKERS PAST CELTICS
description: Earvin (Magic) Johnson scored 39 points and led Los Angeles back from a 17-point third-quarter deficit to a 106-103 victory over the Boston Celtics, giving the Lakers the best record in the National Basketball Association.

title: SEMINARY CONSIDERING CONDO PROJECT
description: Amid questions about its Christian mission and its role in the neighborhood, Union Theological Seminary is cautiously exploring whether to raise money by allowing a developer to build a luxury condominium tower on its Collegiate Gothic campus just north of Columbia University.

title: BRAZILIAN DEBT CRISIS FLARES AGAIN
description: Already struggling to contain the highest inflation rate in the country's history, the Brazilian Government is now bracing itself for a new foreign debt crisis brought on by a dramatic slump in its hard currency reserves, according to Government officials.

title: Bridge: New Book by Marty Bergen Contains His Creative Ideas
description: The hardest-working bridge theorist in North America, most experts would agree, is Marty Bergen of White Plains. His creative ideas have been shown to work in his partnership with Larry Cohen of Little Falls, N.J., and have been set out in two books entitled ''Better Bidding With Bergen.''

title: DESIRE TO HELP THE DESTITIUTE CITED IN GIFT TO THE NEEDIEST
description: ''We are only sorry this gift is so late and so little when one considers the immense need of destitute people,'' said the family of Jennifer and David Saltman of Hillsdale, N.Y., with a $50 contribution to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: TWO JOBS FOR BIDEN: NO MOONLIGHTING, THIS
description: For the moment, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. holds two of the most demanding jobs on Capitol Hill - chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee and 1988 Presidential candidate.

title: New York's Anthem
description: To the Editor:

title: ISLANDERS' COACH LOOKING FOR SPARK
description: AS the hockey season follows its logical progress toward the frenetic stretch drive that portends April's playoffs and payoffs, the rookie coach is continually reminded that he didn't expect this job to be fun.

title: Black Rock Coalition Presents Eight Bands
description: In its short existence, the Black Rock Coalition has created showcases for little-known black musicians and has raised the right questions about the stereotypes that black performers still face. It also insists that the music business, in its shortsightedness, is missing out on the commercial prospects of black rock - and to prove the point, it put on a showcase of eight bands Wednesday and Thursday at CBGB. The show on Thursday was mixed, with some strong, innovative rock alongside music clearly modeled on current pop formulas. At some point, the coalition may have to choose between fostering experiments or just grabbing a slice of the commercial pie.

title: STUDENT, CAUGHT WITH BEER, RAMPAGES AND IS SLAIN
description: A prep school student upset because he had been caught drinking went on a shooting rampage on campus, wounding an administrator and a teacher before being shot to death by the police, according to police and school officials.

title: Knicks Stand Pat At Trade Deadline
description: Bill Cartwright had already spoken to a real estate agent about selling his house. Trent Tucker was trying various tennis racquets for a possible change of venue to a warmer climate. Pat Cummings wondered what would become of his Manhattan apartment. And Jawann Oldham was envisioning himself as some team's starting center.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 16, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-7

title: BURNS WINS BY 4; STADLER DISQUALIFIED
description: George Burns won $240,000 in the Andy Williams Open golf tournament today. Craig Stadler lost $37,333.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL KNICKS VS. PHILADELPHIA 76ers, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, 7 P.M.; Radio - WABC AM 660, 7:20 P.M.) NETS VS. MILWAUKEE BUCKS, At Milwaukee, 8P.M. (TV - SportsChannel and WTBS, 8 P.M.; Radio -WNEW AM 1130, 7:50 P.M.) C.B.A.: Rockford Lightning at Topeka Sizzlers (Television -ESPN, 4 P.M.) COLLEGE: St. John's vs. Fairleigh Dickinson, at Madison Square Garden, 2:30 P.M. (Radio - WCBS AM 880, 2:30 P.M.) C.U.N.Y. TOURNEY: Men: at Hunter College Sportsplex, 68th Street and Lexington Avenue; Lehman vs John Jay, 1 P.M. (Radio - WNYE FM 91.5, 1 P.M.); Hunter vs City College, 3 P.M. (Radio - WNYE FM 91.5, 3 P.M.); Medgar Evers vs Baruch, 6 P.M. Women: at City College, 138th St. and Convent Avenue, York vs Baruch, 4 P.M.; John Jay vs. Staten Island, 6 P.M.; N.Y.U. at Columbia, 8 P.M. (Radio - WNYU FM 89.1, 7:50 P.M., WKCR FM 89.9, 8 P.M.) Fairfield vs. St. Peter's at Madison Square Garden, 12:30 P.M., Holy Cross at Iona, 8 P.M. (Radio -WRTN FM 93.5, 7:55 P.M.) Syracuse at Villanova (Television - ESPN, 7:30 P.M.; Radio--WNYE FM 91.5, 7:30 P.M.) Indiana at Wisconsin (TV - ESPN, 9:30 P.M.) Cleveland St. at Southwest Missouri St. (TV - FNN-SCORE, 7 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS HARNESS RACING: Roosevelt, 7:30 P.M. Meadowlands, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, midnight) THOROUGHBRED RACING: Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. $60,000 Sporting Plate Handicap (TV - SportsChannel, 6:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.)

title: Dry Up Political Slush With Sunshine
description: Corruption investigations in Queens and the Bronx illuminate the dimmer financial dealings of party organizations and the need to subject party ''housekeeping'' accounts to closer scrutiny.

title: MEXICAN STUDENTS VOTE TO END 18-DAY STRIKE
description: Students at Mexico's largest university voted today to end an 18-day strike after the university administration agreed to reconsider plans for sweeping changes in policies.

title: TV: A LOOK AT DUCHAMP
description: Outside a cafe in Cadaques, Spain, the artist Marcel Duchamp is playing chess. As a camera closes in, he describes the game as part of his passion for play: ''If you play with life, you are just as alive as people who believe in religion or art.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The question is not whether the Federal courts should be changed but rather whether that change, through inaction, will take the form of continuing deterioration, or of some structural alteration that will preserve the essence of a valuable institution. I hope the bar will have the foresight to give thoughtful consideration to this.'' Antonin Scalia, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court. [ 12:5. ]

title: Why Phone Bills Go Up, and Down
description: Imagine the day it will cost just pennies more to phone across the country than across the street. It's no fantasy; cost-cutting technology could make it a commonplace in a few years. But getting there will require public forbearance.

title: TEAM REPORTS BREAKTHROUGH IN CONDUCTIVITY OF ELECTRICITY
description: In a scientific advance with potentially valuable commercial application, researchers at the University of Houston and the University of Alabama in Huntsville have produced a superconductive compound that loses all resistance to electricity when cooled to the temperature of liquid nitrogen, the National Science Foundation announced yesterday.

title: FROESE CONTINUES SPELL ON PENGUINS
description: The penalty killers for the Rangers were vastly responsible last night at Madison Square Garden in helping Bob Froese continue his remarkable record as a goaltender against the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: Medical Convention
description: For a farewell salute to Julius Erving at their home game against Philadelphia on April 6, the Knicks have chosen as their theme ''Is There a Doctor in the House?'' They expect the answer to be a thunderous yes. On Friday, invitations went out from Madison Square Garden asking the following to join the soon-to-be-retired Dr. J at pre-game ceremonies: Ruth Westheimer, Richard Chamberlain (Dr. Kildare), Vince Edwards (Dr. Ben Casey), Joyce Brothers, Dr. Seuss, Frank Field, Johnny Berardino (Dr. Steven Hardy of ''General Hospital''), Bill Cosby (Dr. Clifford Huxtable), Dwight Gooden, Henry Kissinger, DeForest Kelley (Dr. McCoy of ''Star Trek''), Ferdie Pacheco, Robert Young (Dr. Marcus Welby) and Bernard Meltzer.

title: WOMEN IN THE CLERGY: STRUGGLE TO SUCCEED
description: Mimi Williams, 32 years old, always longed to be ordained into the clergy. But because she was a Roman Catholic and the Catholic Church still refuses to ordain women, ''I knew there was no hope,'' she said.

title: Pastor Seeks Inquiry Into Suspect's Death
description: The Rev. Herbert Daughtry, a Brooklyn minister active in civil rights cases, called yesterday for a special prosecutor and an independent autopsy in the death of a Queens burglary suspect who collapsed last Thursday in a police holding cell shortly after a violent struggle with eight police officers.

title: A CALIFORNIA COUNTY STRUGGLES AS AIDS MOVES BEYOND THE CITY
description: Blessed with open space, stunning scenery and a benign climate, the biggest problem facing people in this part of Northern California, it would seem, is protecting the region from urban growth. But the bucolic charm of Sonoma County was chilled last week by an announcement that it faces a public health emergency because of AIDS.

title: Inflation Slowed in '86
description: The average increase in consumer prices in 24 industrialized Western countries last year was the lowest in 22 years, according to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. It said on Friday that prices rose an average 2.8 percent in 1986 for the smallest increase since a 2.4 percent advance in 1964. The O.E.C.D. said that the marked slowdown of inflation in 1986 reflected the drop in energy prices. Average consumer energy prices in the 24 countries belonging to the organization fell by 8.6 percent last year. The United States had an inflation rate of 1.1 percent last year, the O.E.C.D. said, while prices in Japan fell two-tenths of 1 percent and 1.1 percent in West Germany.

title: USED U.S. CLOTHES A BEST SELLER IN AFRICA
description: The latest garments for sale at a marketplace in Kinshasa are displayed by a saleswoman brandishing a sharp knife. She cuts open a 100-pound bale and, as customers eagerly surge forward, out spill pastel polo shirts, khaki short-sleeve shirts and cotton pants - all secondhand.

title: Infant Dies in Fire In Brooklyn Project
description: An infant was killed in his crib in a fire that started in his bedroom in a ninth-floor apartment in a city-owned housing project in Brooklyn, authorities said.

title: Washington Watch; Briefcases
description: * The Securities and Exchange Commission holds an all-day conference tomorrow on the internationalization of the markets.

title: The Winter Game
description: Fred Perry, a former junior-college coach who's the baseball director at the new 135-acre Boardwalk and Baseball amusement complex in Orlando, Fla., is determined to make the game a year-round thing. That might seem an ambitious undertaking in itself, but Perry, who has visions of turning the park's six diamonds into a baseball mecca, attracting college teams 12 months a year, is even more ambitious than that. He has vowed to make baseball an everyday sport by staging at least one game daily beginning April 3, the eve of the park's official opening.

title: AREA RETAIL SALES BEST IN 3 YEARS
description: In 1986, a year that saw the closing of two major retail chains, Gimbels and Ohrbach's, retail sales in New York and the surrounding suburbs were the strongest in three years.

title: 'I Was Not Told'
description: On Friday, Jan. 17 of last year, when Ronald Reagan or his autopen signed the ''finding'' submitted by Admiral Poindexter sending arms to Iran without notifying Congress, the two officials who ordinarily handled secret arms transfers had not yet returned from a trip to China.

title: KAROLOS KOUN
description: Karolos Koun, a Greek theater director whose lively staging of ancient Greek plays won him acclaim in Europe, died last Saturday after suffering a heart attack, according to friends in Athens. He was 78 years old.

title: Susan B. Comes Out Ahead
description: LEAD: My daughter Kelly gets angry this time of year.

title: Postal Holdup in Rome Is Condemned by Pope
description: Pope John Paul II today condemned a shooting and robbery here early Saturday in which two policemen were killed and a third was seriously wounded. A terrorist group has claimed responsibility.

title: Books; The Conductor As Superstar
description: UNDERSTANDING TOSCANINI. By Joseph Horowitz. 492 pages. Illustrated. Alfred A. Knopf. $30. JOSEPH HOROWITZ, a former music writer for The New York Times who is now the program annotator for the 92d Street Y, has written a laudably serious book about the most famous of all conductors, Arturo Toscanini. During his lifetime (1867-1957), no musician was more venerated than Toscanini, but now his star has dimmed. Younger musicians and music fans profess a greater interest in his rival and antipode, the mystical German Wilhelm Furtwangler, and RCA Victor has done a poor job of keeping Toscanini's finest performances in print and in the best possible LP and CD transfers.

title: TV: RESETTLING THE ELDERLY IN 'MISTAKEN CHARITY'
description: A fairly familiar story these days is the one about well-meaning children taking their elderly parents away from traditional surroundings and placing them, perhaps at considerable cost, in a presumably safer, more comfortable environment. Far too often, the transplanted old folk end up unhappy and decidedly unappreciative. The situation is similar in ''A Mistaken Charity,'' tonight's ''American Playhouse'' presentation on Channel 13 at 9. There is, however, a significant difference. Adapted from a story by the New England regional writer Mary Wilkins Freeman, this tale is set in the late 19th century. Some things, apparently, never change.

title: JAPAN ASKS CHIP-PACT COMPLIANCE
description: With tensions over semiconductor trade increasing, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry called in the heads of Japan's six semiconductor companies on Friday and asked them to honor an American-Japanese semiconductor agreement.

title: Military Cargo Helicopters Grounded for Gear Problems
description: All Navy and Marine Corps CH-53E Super Stallion helicopters were grounded Saturday for inspection of a gear box problem that was found after a forced landing Oct. 21, a marine spokesman said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Blackhawks 6, Nordiques 4: In Chicago, Denis Savard scored his 25th goal of the season and Bob Sauve turned away 34 shots and earned an assist yesterday. Chicago wrapped up the victory in the opening 5 minutes of the final period as Curt Fraser collected his 19th goal and Troy Murray his 22d. With the Blackhawks short-handed in the first period, Sauve stopped a shot by Risto Siltanen, then cleared the puck to Keith Brown, who spotted Troy Murray. Murray beat Mario Gosselin, and Sauve picked up an assist. (AP) Capitals 5, Oilers 3: Bob Gould scored two goals, including a key one late in the game, as Washington won on the road. Gould scored both his goals on breakaways created by passes from Gaetan Duchesne. His second of the game and 17th of the season came at 15:58 of the final period to give Washington some breathing room. (AP) Skiing Zurbriggen Closing on Title: In Todtnau, West Germany, Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland overcame a pair of mistakes and poor visibility on the foggy Ahornbuehl course yesterday to win the next-to-last giant slalom on the tour and all but clinch the World Cup overall title. Zurbriggen led after the first run and held on in the second heat despite some problems to clinch his third consecutive World Cup giant slalom race with a two-run winning aggregate of 2 minutes 38.95 seconds. Marc Girardelli of Luxembourg was second in 2:39.16. (AP) Swiss Woman Wins: Corinne Schmidhauser of Switzerland skied the fastest second heat before jubilant home fans in Fluehli to win her third World Cup slalom. The Swiss skier's victory, by 1-hundredth of a second, deprived Monika Maierhofer of posting the first victory of the season by an Austrian woman. The slalom world champion, Erika Hess of Switzerland, came in third, 34-hundredths of a second behind her winning teammate. (AP) Austrian, Italian Take Nordic Medals: In Oberstdorf, West Germany, Andreas Felder of Austria and Marco Albarello of Italy won gold medals at the world Nordic ski championships. Felder captured the 90-meter ski jumping with a total of 216.0 points, beating Norway's Vegard Opaas, who was second with 208.3 points. Albarello, who hadn't placed better than 14th this year, took the 15-kilometer cross-country race in 43 minute 1.8 seconds. (AP) Bobsledding U.S. Sled Takes Cup: In Lake Placid, N.Y., yesterday, Matt Roy of the United States piloted a redesigned sled to victory in the World Cup two-man bobsled races. Roy posted a comfortable winning margin of more than a second over the British sled driven by Mark Tout. The East German, Swiss, Swedish and Soviet teams did not compete. (AP) Track and Field Hurdles Record Reported: Yordanka Donkova of Bulgaria ran the 60-meter hurdles in 7.74 seconds to set a women's world indoor record, Bulgaria's state press agency, BTA, reported yesterday. BTA said Donkova set the mark Saturday at an indoor meet in the Bulgarian capital of Sofia. The time would break the record of 7.75 set by Bettine Jahn of East Germany in Budapest on March 5, 1983. (AP)

title: CONTRA AID PROTESTERS FOUND GUILTY
description: Eighteen people were found guilty here last week of parading in and obstructing the rotunda of the Capitol, in a case stemming from the arrest of 112 demonstrators who last August protested United States aid to the Nicaraguan insurgents.

title: Kawasaki Steel Sets Job Cuts
description: The Kawasaki Steel Corporation plans to reduce its work force by 5,000, bringing it down to 21,000 workers, local news reports said on Saturday.

title: Why Tar Arabs and Islam?
description: LEAD: I am perturbed by the continuing tendency of the American media to utilize the simplistic equation ''Moslem-terrorist-Arab.''

title: ENERGY DEPT. AIDE TO HEAD SCIENTIFIC GROUP
description: Alvin W. Trivelpiece, Assistant Secretary of Energy for energy research, has been named Executive Officer of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the association announced today.

LASER INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: GOODE, DESPITE TROUBLES, DECLARES FOR SECOND TERM AS PHILADELPHIA MAYOR
description: W. Wilson Goode, a front-runner despite dark clouds that are gathering once again over his frequently troubled administration, tonight declared his candidacy for a second term as Philadelphia's first black mayor.

title: Trust-Fund Rules Are Urged for Judges
description: The rules for judges' management of trust funds for minors should be stricter, to prevent potential abuses, according to a report yesterday by District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn.

description: b-Net income

title: Business And The Law; Sale of Robins Poses Problems
description: WHEN the American Home Products Corporation withdrew its bid for the A. H. Robins Company last week, most people speculated that the deal collapsed because of concern about potential liability to thousands of women with claims related to Robins' Dalkon Shield contraceptive device.

description: THE REAL THING

title: ALASKA REFUSES TO TIGHTEN BELT IN HARD TIMES
description: Despite a stunning decline in state revenues caused by falling oil prices, Alaskans seem determined to resist any cuts in their state's impressive list of gifts to them.

title: UNITED STRUGGLES IN THE PACIFIC
description: When United Airlines took over the Pacific routes of Pan American World Airways a year ago, it seemed poised to shake up and eventually dominate the far-flung and lucrative market in Asian air travel. Established carriers there were apprehensive at the entry of a competitor with so vast a domestic network and such considerable resources.

title: COHU INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest quarter loss resulted from a $1,100,000, $530,000 after-tax, provision for the disposition of certain assets related to the broadcast microwave market.

CORRECTION
description: A chart Saturday with an article about a $7 million judgment against the United Klans of America in a 1981 slaying incorrectly identified one division of the Klan. The group based in Fayetteville, N.C., is the Southern National Front, formerly known as the Confederate Knights of the Ku Klux Klan.

title: ISRAEL OPENS CASE IN DEATH CAMP TRIAL
description: The man accused of being an attendant at the Treblinka death camp entered a courtroom here today with a wave, a big smile and a booming ''Good morning!'' spoken in Hebrew: ''Boker Tov!''

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: ''LOOK sexual, common, cheap,'' a photographer directed a pouty model wearing a froufrou party dress by Oscar de la Renta at a Valentine's week shooting for a Bergdorf-Goodman advertisement.

title: MET FANS' BUS FROM VIRGINIA IS FOUND (70,000) MILES LATER
description: A 47-seat tourist cruiser that carried a group of loyal Met fans from Virginia to New York was found yesterday, six months after the $185,000 bus was stolen from a parking lot of a Queens hotel.

title: A.B.A. REJECTS PLAN ON TOBACCO AD BAN
description: The American Bar Association rejected a proposal today that it join efforts to seek a Federal law barring all advertising of tobacco products.

title: FALSE STOCK REPORTS BY AUSTRALIAN
description: Trading was suspended today in the shares of a company headed by Alan Bond, the Australian financier, after he admitted that he had made misleading statements about the value behind the securities.

title: CANDELA LASER reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Euramerica Prepares A Condom Commercial
description: The camera shows a pair of male hands opening a small gift-wrapped package. As the 30-second commercial progresses, we understand that the hands belong to a young fellow who is probably off at college. As the package opens, we hear his father's voice narrating the note that accompanied the gift - a box of a dozen Ramses Extra Condoms.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL COLLEGE: Seton Hall at Providence (Radio - WNEW 1130, 8 P.M. WSOU-FM 89.5, 7:30 P.M.) Arizona at U.S.C. (TV - ESPN, 11 P.M.) Kansas at Iowa State (TV - USA, 8 P.M.) HOCKEY ISLANDERS VS. PHILADELPHIA FLYERS, at Nassau Coliseum, 8 P.M. (TV -SportsChannel, ESPN 8 P.M. Radio - WOR 710, 8 P.M.) RANGERS VS. DETROIT RED WINGS, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. title: RECITAL: GAITHER-GRAVES
description: MAREDA GAITHER-GRAVES'S recital Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall was consistent in its satisfactions and limitations. The former stem from a wide-ranging and heartfelt sympathy for the songs she chose. What the soprano seems to lack is the ability to produce a free-flowing, attractive sound at dynamic levels above the softest. How far this is a problem of technique and how far one of basic vocal endowment would be difficult to say; in any case, Miss Gaither-Graves seems to have come to terms with it and built a style that is, on those terms, convincing.

title: 13 TO SHOW DOCUMENTARY THAT PBS REFUSED TO AIR
description: A much-disputed documentary about the making of ''Sun City,'' an anti-apartheid music video and recording, has been scheduled for broadcast by Channel 13 after being refused air time by the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: SAHLEN & ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $154,391 and $295,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $57,000 and $110,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: New York City's Municipal Hospitals Speak of Public Conscience
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: Book by George Rosenkranz Addresses a Neglected Topic
description: Some areas of the game have been neglected in the literature because they are difficult for both players and writers.

title: THIS ALL-STAR IS BLUE-COLLAR
description: When Rick Green was introduced to the crowd at Le Colisee in Quebec for the first of two games he played last week, tiny bluish-white lights that had been strung across the ceiling twinkled at the mention of his name. Spotlights followed his strides until he took his place along the blue line occupied by the National Hockey League all-stars. It was a place he had never known.

title: LOTS OF TALK BUT NO TRADES FOR KNICKS
description: ''What did I tell you two months ago?'' Scotty Stirling said.

title: MARTIN PROCESSING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $174,000 from the disposal of discontinued operations for the quarter and year, and a loss of $225,000 for the quarter and net of $18,000 for the year from discontinued operations. c-After net from discontinued operations of $192,000 for the quarter and $398,000 for the year. The quarter also included an extraordinary charge of $483,000 and the year a tax credit of $1,142,000.

title: ONE VALLEY BANCORP OF WEST VIRGINIA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit after tax of $565,000 from the sale of an office building.

title: KNICKS PATHETIC AGAIN, DROPPING 13TH IN LAST 16
description: Charles Barkley came to Madison Square Garden last night with a large, infected gash in his left elbow. It was serious enough to send him to the hospital six days ago for treatment. It even forced him to miss a game. But it was not serious enough to keep him from wrecking the anemic Knicks.

title: REPORT LINKS ACID RAIN TO 30-YEAR DECLINE OF BLACK DUCKS
description: NEW research shows that acid rain may have contributed to the mysterious decline of black ducks in the last three decades and may be causing serious and widespread damage to the breeding grounds of many other water birds, according to a report released today by the Izaak Walton League of America, a private conservation group.

title: Impressive Cast
description: Zhu Jianhua, the Chinese high-jumper, and seven Rumanians, led by the 1984 Olympic 3,000-meter gold medalist Maricica Puica, will participate in the Mobil Indoor Championships at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 27, meet organizers announced yesterday. Zhu won the bronze in the Los Angeles Olympic Games and is currently tied for the fifth-best jump in history at 7 feet 10 inches. Besides Puica, Rumanians who have entered the meet include Doina Melinte, who ran the fastest 800 meters in the world last year at 1 minute 56.2 seconds; Valy Ionescu, who ranked fifth in the world in the long jump last year with a best of 23-3 1/2; Mitica Junghiatu, who was clocked in 1:57.87 for 800 meters in 1986; Margareta Keszeg, who ran the 1,500 meters in 4:04.29; and two high jumpers: Sorin Matei, who has cleared 7-7 1/4, and Eugen Poescu, who has a best of 7-7. Stefka Kostadinova, the world-record holder in the women's high jump, leads six Bulgarians who have entered. Kostadinova has cleared 6-8 1/4 indoors and 6-9 3/4 outdoors. She is the reigning European champion and won the World Cup in 1985. Other entries from Bulgaria are three sprinters, Yordanka Donkova, Ginka Zagorcheva and Anelia Nuneva, a pole-vaulter, Atanas Tarev, and a triple jumper, Khristo Markov.

title: CARDIAC RESUSCITATOR reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DANCE: MCCARTHY AND HOEFFEL IN 6 SKETCHES
description: THE choreographic sketches that Katie McCarthy and Margaret Hoeffel offered Sunday night in the parish hall of St. Mark's Church were all unpretentious. Fortunately, they were seldom insubstantial. Part of what was billed as a ''no frills'' series of performances sponsored by the Danspace Project, the presentation was surely just the sort of program the project's directors had in mind.

title: British Bank Board
description: Britain plans legislation to tighten controls on the Bank of England by adding a sixth independent member to the board of banking supervision and by doubling the maximum insolvency deposit to $:20,000, the Treasury said. Independent members, who sit on the supervisory board along with top Bank of England officials, would be appointed jointly by the Chancellor of the Exchequer and the governor of the Bank of England, it said in a statement.

title: Charity by 49er
description: About 180 homeless people in San Jose, Calif., received free shoes from Bubba Paris, and the San Francisco 49er lineman said the giveaway made him feel great. ''I was able to make a dent in a large wall,'' Paris said Sunday after indigent men, women and children surrounded his van at a downtown park and were handed the black leather athletic shoes. Paris had planned to give away 100 pairs of shoes, provided by the company with which he has an endorsement contract. Area shoe outlets added 95 pairs for women and children, and all but 15 pairs were snapped up.

title: Draft-Iacocca Effort Halts
description: A political organization seeking to draft Lee A. Iacocca, the chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, as a Democratic Presidential candidate in 1988 is disbanding, one of the people involved said today. ''He won't be available until 1992,'' said Morley Winograd, who had been pushing for an Iacocca candidacy.

title: NEW BID REPORTED FOR FREEING WAITE
description: The Lebanese Druse leader Walid Jumblat traveled to Damascus today amid reports that efforts to free Terry Waite, the missing Anglican envoy, had been renewed.

title: Inside Baseball
description: Charlie Samuels, the Mets' equipment manager: ''We're going to schedule three spring-training games against the state pen, just in case we want to visit some of our guys.''

title: Night Watchman Is Stabbed to Death
description: A night watchman at a Bronx supermarket was beaten with a pipe and fatally stabbed by a burglar who robbed the store of $15,000, the police said yesterday.

title: ENERGYNORTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A NEW APPROACH TO PROTECTING SECRETS IS DISCOVERED
description: MATHEMATICIANS and cryptologists have discovered a way for people to prove that they possess secret information - from their credit card numbers to military access codes - without giving any of the information away.

title: Dr. Leonardo Santamarina, Douglass College Professor
description: Dr. Leonardo Santamarina, professor emeritus of Spanish language and literature at Douglass College in New Brunswick, N.J., died Thursday at the Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital in New Brunswick. He was 74 years old and lived in Franklin Township, N.J.

title: Labor Officials Deny Link to Covert Project
description: Several labor leaders insisted today that there was no connection between a covert program carried out by the National Security Council and the National Endowment for Democracy, which gives Federal money to democratic institutions abroad.

title: INDIANA SURVIVES 3 OVERTIMES
description: Dean Garrett hit a follow shot with four seconds left in the third overtime as Indiana escaped with an 86-85 Big Ten victory over Wisconsin tonight.

title: White House Secretariat?
description: History itself may not be enough of a teacher for future Presidents, according to the Center for the Study of the Presidency. The group, based in New York, proposes the establishment of a ''small, permanent, nonpolitical advisory secretariat'' in the White House, to provide ''an institutional memory'' from one administration to another.

title: LIQUI-BOX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect the 2-for-1 stock split distributed on Sept.1, 1986.

title: THE FUTURE JOINS THE PAST ON WORTH AVE.
description: ''Worth Avenue is not what it used to be, now the blue jeans crowd is here,'' said Mimi Thorne as she strolled along Palm Beach's main shopping street Saturday. But the Chanel crowd is also here, and the Gucci crowd and the Hermes crowd. What was once a quaint little street of shops catering to the conservative rich who lived here and the conservative rich who visited in season has come to resemble Rodeo Drive and Madison Avenue, with an array of Madison Avenue boutiques, antique shops and fine jewelry stores.

title: MOSCOW KIN AWAIT WORD ON DISSIDENT
description: The family of the Jewish dissident Iosif Z. Begun said today that he was reportedly still in Chistopol prison in the Tatar republic, despite the assurance of a Soviet official on American television Sunday that he had been freed.

title: More Than Bureaucrats on the Bench
description: Not long after being elevated to the Supreme Court, Justice Antonin Scalia has come out fighting for the judges he left behind on the lower rungs of the Federal judiciary. The Federal bench is losing its appeal as a high calling for lawyers, he says. Judges are getting increasingly bogged down in ''trivial'' cases that overwhelm and bore them. Justice Scalia is right to look out for the judges' interests, but he skims too quickly past what makes a judicial job great.

title: FOR POMPIDOU CENTER AT AGE 10, THE SCREAMS HAVE TURNED TO CHEERS
description: Georges Pompidou, banker, politician, art lover and President of France, did not live to see the modern art and culture center in the middle of Paris that bears his name.

title: 'FREUD UNDER ANALYSIS' DOCUMENTARY ON 'NOVA'
description: AS demonstrated by tonight's offering on ''Nova,'' the ideas of Sigmund Freud remain as provoking nearly a half-century after his death as they were during his life. ''Freud Under Analysis,'' on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock, begins in Vienna before the turn of the century and takes us up to current attacks on Freudianism's scientific pretentions. It's a model of the expository documentary. The producer, Susanne Simpson, weaves together home movies of Freud and his disciples with comments on his work by today's critics and defenders. (A psychoanalyst who had his own analysis under the master in the 1930's remembers greeting him, ''Herr Professor, I had some really good dreams last night.'') The program doesn't try to do too much, but what it does, it does intelligently and fairly.

title: CONSERVATIVE LAW SCHOOL'S CHANGING FACE
description: OVER the past few years, the University of Chicago Law School has suffered an unusual brain drain.

title: Pointless Search
description: Dale Brown, Louisiana State's basketball coach, after a 60-52 loss to Alabama: ''I don't know where the missing persons bureau is, but if we go there, maybe we can find our of fense.''

title: FRANKLIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized gains on investments of $103,076 for the quarter and $41,822 for the 9 months. c-Includes a realized gain on investments of $95,531 for the quarter and a realized loss on investments of $314,102 for the 9 months.
