title: BUCKS SET BACK NETS, 128-124
description: Sidney Moncrief, in his second game since returning from an injury, scored 20 points and passed the 10,000-point mark tonight, helping the Milwaukee Bucks score a 128-124 victory over the Nets.

title: Keeping Families Together Is Also Welfare Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: ARMATRON INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $125,000.

title: A Respectful Press?
description: There are always Americans unhappy with our tradition of a free and aggressive press. The country could be run so much more effectively, they argue, if you in the press did not keep raising doubts about the Government. Why can't you show some respect?

title: Account
description: * Vogue to Biederman & Associates for trade advertising and special sales promotion.

title: Using the Contadora Solution
description: LEAD: In his State of the Union Mes-sage, President Reagan reaffirmed in the strongest language his commitment to the overthrow of the Nicaraguan Government. Undeterred by the Iran-contra arms scandal, he promised to fight any attempt to cut off aid to the contras. No one should assume that he will lose.

title: SUBPOENAS FOR KIDDER, GOLDMAN
description: Kidder, Peabody & Company and Goldman, Sachs & Company have been subpoenaed by the United States Attorney as the Government widens its investigation of Wall Street's takeover practices, sources with knowledge of the inquiry said yesterday.

title: G&K SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
MICRO HEALTHSYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: STAGE: 'CLEVELAND AND HALF-WAY BACK'
description: AS Leslie Lyles's ''Cleveland and Half-Way Back'' begins (at the Ensemble Studio Theater), Cynthia Nixon is washing a vast quantity of laundry -shirts, shorts and straitjacket. That last item is the first clue to the setting, a mental institution catering to disturbed young people. As long as Ms. Nixon and Keith Reddin, as a fellow resident, are confined in the institution - not very long - the evening has a certain spark of eccentricity. But almost as soon as the couple escape and take to the open road, the play starts to wander. Eventually it swerves entirely out of control.

title: U.S. OIL SHORTAGES SEEM UNAVOIDABLE TO MANY ANALYSTS
description: Despite higher prices and a more stable market, the United States is almost inevitably headed toward new oil shortages that could be as disruptive as those of the 1970's, according to increasingly urgent warnings by Government policy makers and other analysts.

title: DOZENS OF FACTORS CRITICAL IN BONE LOSS AMONG ELDERLY
description: WHILE calcium wars rage in pharmacies,health food stores and supermarkets throughout the country, research in osteoporosis is revealing that only a minority of cases of this bone-wasting disorder result from diets deficient in calcium.

title: Announcements Expected on Two Note Sales
description: Treasury auctions this week are limited to the weekly sale of new three-month and six-month bills. The bill auctions were delayed until today because of the Presidents' Day holiday yesterday.

title: INCENTIVES FOR PENNZOIL-TEXACO DEAL
description: The threat of a bankruptcy by Texaco Inc. may be the most compelling reason for the Pennzoil Company to lower its demands and accept a settlement soon in their landmark, three-year legal battle, according to lawyers close to the case.

title: PSICOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LOUD NOISES TIED TO LOSS OF BRAIN CELLS
description: Animal studies suggest that newborns may be particularly vulnerable to inner ear damage from loud noises, and that the damage could result in loss of some brain cells linked to the ear, a researcher says.

title: SABINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax asset writedown of $14,881,000 for the latest year, and 1985 includes a pre-tax gain on assets of $2,023,000. c-Net income

title: Elderly Couple Killed As Heater Explodes
description: A kerosene heater in a basement apartment in Brooklyn exploded Sunday, setting a fire that killed an elderly couple.

title: Angry Words From Canada
description: Less than a month after Vice President Bush visited Ottawa and took a lashing from Prime Minister Brian Mulroney on President Reagan's environmental policies, the Administration was scolded by another Canadian official on the same topic.

title: CONCERT: MENUHIN AND WARSAW SINFONIA
description: YEHUDI MENUHIN was back in New York Sunday night playing his violin and conducting the Warsaw Sinfonia at Carnegie Hall. Mr. Menuhin is at once the most satisfying and elusive of musicians. His serenity and sincerity of purpose, that is, remain constant, even when the technique does not.

title: 4 MEASLES CASES PROMPT STATE U. TO BAN SPORTS
description: Four cases of measles at the State University of New York at Albany have prompted college and health officials to suspend intercollegiate sports on campus and take other steps to keep the highly contagious disease from spreading.

title: ANDOVER TOGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said the results include losses from an investment in a discontinued joint venture of 2 cents a share in the latest quarter, 3 cents a share in the latest year, and 2 cents a share in the previous year.

title: ACROSS ICE, IN A 26-WHEEL RIG: CANADA'S INTREPID TRUCKERS
description: At 10:30 A.M. the other day, the sun hauled itself above the horizon, a vaporous orange ball barely visible through the mists. Ahead, the road ran runway straight, featureless save for jagged fissures marking ''pressure ridges'' in the blue-green ice.

title: Dairy-Deli Association Picks Lempert Agency
description: The Lempert Company, an ad agency in Belleville, N.J., that is particularly skilled at advertising products in the supermarket milieu, has become the agency for the Dairy-Deli Association of Madison, Wis., which plans to spend $6 million to get consumers to buy more in dairy-deli sections of their supermarkets.

title: Denied: A Shield for Terrorists
description: President Reagan has faced more important but probably no tougher decisions than whether to seek ratification of revisions to the 1949 Geneva Conventions. If he said yes, that would improve protection for prisoners of war and civilians in wartime, but at the price of new legal protection for guerrillas and possible terrorists. He decided to say no, a judgment that deserves support.

title: THE U.N. TODAY: FEB. 17, 1987

A California Highway Patrol team that specializes in major traffic accidents was investigating the crash, which occurred Saturday night in the southern San Joaquin Valley, said John Sanchez, a dispatcher for the Highway Patrol.

The rabbit, Coghlan told Ray Lumpp, should run each of the first three quarter-miles in 58 seconds, for splits of 0:58, 1:56 and 2:54.

We have had commissions on Central America, on nuclear missiles, on defense procurement and on trade. There may have even been other commissions that I do not know about.

title: China-Teresat Deal
description: China will insure its launch of a communications satellite for Teresat Inc. of the United States, the New China News Agency quoted Cheng Wanzhu, vice president of the People's Insurance Company of China, as saying. Now under discussion with some foreign insurance companies, the deal would be China's first insurance agreement for a satellite launch, he said, but gave no details.

title: DOCTORS, IN RHODE ISLAND FEE PROTEST, REFUSE POOR PATIENTS
description: Two of the five obstetricians on Aquidneck Island are turning away pregnant women on welfare who come to them for prenatal care, and the three other obstetricians here say they will shut their doors in the next few days in a dispute over the Medicaid fee paid by the state.

title: Foss Premiere to Have Composer as Soloist
description: A chamber music piece by Lukas Foss, written on commission from three institutions, is to be given its premiere today at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. The piece, for piano and chamber ensemble, is to be played Wednesday at Carnegie Hall in New York City.

title: WHEN WRITING IS TAUGHT BY ROTE
description: COMMERCIALLY packaged systems of writing instruction can demoralize able teachers and deprive children of the joy of writing by turning it into a standardized drill, a leading expert in the teaching of writing has charged. The expert, Mary K. Healy, co-director of the Bay Area Writing Project at the University of California at Berkeley, said packaged teaching materials should be scrutinized by government or other agencies the way other consumer products are.

title: THE 1972 ABM TREATY: 2 WAYS TO READ KEY PARTS
description: Following are, in column one, excerpts from the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty and, in column two, summaries of the traditional interpretation of the treaty and the current Administration view. The summaries are based on Congressional testimony, public statements and interviews. The Soviet Union says it backs the traditional view, held by the United States until late 1985. Provisions Article II For the purpose of this Treaty an ABM system is a system to counter strategic ballistic missiles or their elements in flight trajectory, currently consisting of: (a) ABM interceptor missiles, which are interceptor missiles constructed and deployed for an ABM role, or of a type tested in an ABM mode: (b) ABM launchers, which are launchers constructed and deployed for launching ABM interceptor missiles; and (c) ABM radars, which are radars constructed and deloyed for an ABM role, or of a type tested in an ABM mode. Article III Each Party undertakes not to deploy ABM systems or their components except . . . (a) within one ABM system deployment area . . . centered on the party's national capital . . . and (b) within one ABM system deployment area . . . containing ICBM silo launchers. [ The 1974 Protocol amends Article III as follows: Each party shall be limited at any one time to a single area out of the two provided in Article III of the treaty for deployment of ABM systems or their components. ] Article V 1. Each Party undertakes not to develop, test or deploy ABM systems or components which are sea-based, air-based, spaced-based or mobile land-based. Agreed Statement D:

The deal, said to be valued at about $300 million, represents a move by the bank to tap a wider middle-market commercial loan business. The principal unit of Norht American is the Long Island Trust Company, which has $1.8 billion is assets and operates 46 branches. With this addition to its more than $22 billion in assets, the Bank of New York will have 189 branches in the New York metropolitan area.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why is the distance between stars measured in light years? And how long, in miles, is a light year? A. The stars are spaced so far apart that any measurement of the distance between them in familiar units would be unwieldy, according to Dr. Joe Patterson, professor of astronomy at Columbia University. So scientists created a more manageable astronomical unit called the light year, which is the distance it takes light to travel in one year, at a speed of about 186,200 miles a second. One light year is about 6,000,000,000,000 miles. The closest star to earth, Alpha Centauri, is 4.2 light years. This is the average distance between most stars. Q. What causes wrinkles in the skin? A. Wrinkles are caused mainly by ultraviolet radiation from the sun, according to Dr. Allen Lawrence, a Chicago dermatologist. Over time, the ultraviolet rays break down the middle layer of skin, the dermis, causing it to loosen and allowing wrinkles to form. With extreme age, the dermis loosens on its own accord, Dr. Lawrence said. To decrease the extent of wrinkling in the skin, one should limit exposure to direct sunlight, such as by using sunscreens, he added. Wrinkles are more likely to occur among people of lighter skin or who have thin layers of skin.

title: MALAYSIA'S LIVELY ISLE: A NATION'S CONSCIENCE?
description: On a map of the world, Penang Island is all but invisible, a speck lying off an unfamiliar and not particularly important coast of Malaysia. Yet somehow, it became and remains the country's most dynamic and spirited corner.

title: MUSIC: NEW WORLD CONSORT
description: THE New World Consort, a four-member early-music group originating in western Canada, came to Corpus Christi Church Sunday afternoon with the discovery of the Americas as the theme of its program. Thus the references to early Spanish, French and English explorers made a nice excuse to play and sing the music that might have surrounded them on their trips home. Evoking John Cabot as a citizen of Venice was perhaps a bit farfetched, but it did allow the inclusion of some lovely items from the Italian Renaissance.

On practically every desk, at least on the five or six floors visible from this lowly vantage point, sits a personal computer.

title: Shoemaker Back
description: Willie Shoemaker, riding in his first race since undergoing knee surgery, guided Louis Le Grand to a 3 1/2-length victory over Zoffany yesterday in the $164,100 San Luis Obispo Handicap at Santa Anita in Arcadia, Calif. With a sprint to the finish, Louis Le Grand overhauled Zoffany and Eddie Delahoussaye and won going away. Schiller finished third in the eight-horse field. The 55-year-old Shoemaker underwent arthroscopic surgery on his left knee Feb. 3. He had been scheduled to return aboard the favored Temperate Sil in Saturday's San Vicente Stakes and then ride Seldom Seen Sue in Sunday's La Canada Stakes. But Charlie Whittingham, the trainer, scratched both horses because of track conditions. Shoemaker was also scheduled to ride Simply Majestic in Monday's seventh race, but that horse was scratched. Shoemaker finally made his return before 38,643 fans on another Whittingham-trained horse. ''The leg feels a thousand percent,'' the jockey said. The victory was No. 8,631 for Shoemaker.

Its chief executive officer was Lieut. Col. Oliver North, and its name, incredibly, was Project Democracy.

title: Lea Seeks Comeback
description: Charlie Lea, the one-time ace of the Montreal pitching staff, has signed a minor-league contract with the Expos' Class AAA team in Indianapolis. The move circumvented an arbitrator's ruling last week that prohibited clubs from dealing with their own unsigned free agents until May 1. The 31-year-old Lea, who missed the last two seasons with a rotator cuff injury, will now be able to attend Montreal's major-league training camp beginning in West Palm Beach, Fla., next week as an invitee. He became a free agent when the Expos refused the option year of his contract, but found that his comeback attempt did not attract any interest from other clubs. Lea last pitched in 1984, when he posted a 15-10 mark and a 2.89 earned run average. . . . Pascual Perez, the pitcher released by the Atlanta Braves in April 1986, has been signed to a minor-league contract with the Expos.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 17, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 The Soviet Union needs stability on an international scale so that it can turn inward to concentrate on domestic concerns, Mikhail S. Gorbachev said in an address. Page A1 A Soviet dissident is still confined in Chistopol prison in the Tatar Republic, his family said, despite the assurance of a senior Soviet official on American television Sunday that he had been released. A10 How to interpret the ABM treaty is the central arms-control issue, affecting negotiations in Geneva, relations between the United States and its allies and relations between the Administration and Congress. A1 Hours after a cease-fire expired, 17 Phillipine civilians and one soldier died in a brief fire fight in Namulandayan last Tuesday. The incident threatens to aggravate strains between the Government and its military. A1 A Nicaraguan rebel leader resigned from a governing position in a power struggle that threatens the future of Washington-backed anti-Sandinista forces. He said it was an effort to unify the rebel movement. A1 Truckers can get rich in Canada, plying some of the most remote and potentially dangerous roads in North America, ones that are slowly pushing development into the continent's last frontier. A3 Penang Island off Malaysia's coast has become and remained the country's most dynamic and spirited corner. The small island seems to attract and nurture artists, intellectuals, reformers and dissidents. A4 National A13-21, D19 New U.S. oil shortages may be ahead, despite higher prices and a more stable market, that could be as disruptive as those of the 1970's, Government policy makers and other analysts warn. A1 Tax season will be much the same this year. Most of the new tax law's provisions became effective only at the beginning of 1987, so individuals will not encounter sweeping changes until next year's filing ritual. A1 The A.B.A. will not to seek a law barring all advertising of tobacco products, The American Bar Association's policy-making arm decided, rejecting a proposal that it join efforts in Congress to do so. A14 W. Wilson Goode will run again, he said, seeking a second term as Philadelphia's first black mayor. ''I do not claim that we have done everything right,'' he said, ''but we have always tried to do the right thing.'' A14 A movement toward safer sex is gathering momentum among heterosexuals, as AIDS and the fear of it infect the nation, which may promise to change male-female relationships and bedroom behavior. A21 An inquiry into the arrest of 8 aliens in Los Angeles has been requested by a top Immigration and Naturalization Service official. The immigrants are said to be linked to the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine. A19 A bill to raise the minimum wage is expected to be approved in Congress this year, said the Senate and House Majority Leaders, who added that they would support efforts now underway to raise the miminum wage of $3.35 an hour. A15 A dispute over Medicaid fees paid in Rhode Island has resulted in some obstetricians turning away pregnant women on welfare who come to them for prenatal care. The doctors say the fees do not cover their costs. A14 The Navy has suspended a program to equip warships with drone aircraft after losing four of the five pilotless reconnaissance planes sent out recently with the battleship Iowa, military sources report. D19 Alaskans are resisting any cuts in their state's impressive list of gifts to them, despite a stunning decline in state revenues caused by falling oil prices. The Governor has said the state is in financial chaos. A13 Governor Cuomo condemned policies espoused by the Reagan Administration on many issues, from arms control to the environment. The Governor, speaking in New Orleans, was on the second in a seris of trips outside New York States, as he decides whether to run for President. A16 Jonathan Pollard gave many secrets to Israel, including detailed information that expedited Israel's raid on Tunisia in 1985, according to a news account in Jerasulem. A17 Research in osteoporosis has shown that only a minority of cases of this bone-wasting disorder result from diets deficient in calcium, despite assertions about over-the-counter calcium supplements. title: PERKINS, AFTER BUILDING HIS DREAM HOUSE, MOVES OUT
description: When the swirl of rumors began blowing Ray Perkins out of Alabama long before he would actually leave, he hadn't been considering changing jobs at all. He was happy in Tuscaloosa, successful with the football team and making somewhere around $500,000 a year. As he told the world when he left the Giants in 1982 to succeed Paul (Bear) Bryant and become athletic director and head coach at his alma mater, this was a ''dream job.''

title: POLITICAL GRAFT TRIAL ENDS IN BONN WITH 3 NOTABLES PUNISHED LIGHTLY
description: Two former West German Economics Ministers and the former deputy chairman of the giant Flick holding company were convicted of income tax evasion today but cleared of graver charges of corruption.

title: In a Word, Wicked
description: PGA West, widely criticized as too severe by the touring pros who played it in the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic last month, ranks second on this list of the country's toughest golf courses.

title: NORWAY QUESTIONS ISRAELI USE OF NUCLEAR MATERIAL
description: Norway plans to ask Israel to let international inspectors decide if Israel is adhering to an agreement not to use Norwegian ''heavy water'' to produce nuclear weapons, Norwegian officials said today.

title: ICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SCIENCE AND POLITICS: 'NUCLEAR WINTER' CLASH
description: Climate specialists and other scientists clashed sharply today over the role scientists have played in the debate over predictions made four years ago of global freezing and possible human extinction after a nuclear war.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Lindy Ruff, the Buffalo captain and left wing who suffered a broken collarbone Saturday in the Sabres' 5-1 victory over the Islanders, will be out of the lineup for six to eight weeks. . . . The Atlanta Falcons announced the signing of Al Groh, the former Wake Forest head football coach, as an assistant coach in charge of special teams and tight ends.

title: AMERICAN TECHNICAL CERAMCS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Barclays Has Talks in Zambia With Anti-Apartheid Leaders
description: Barclays International, a British bank that pulled out of South Africa last year, held talks here today with the African National Congress, the the anti-apartheid group said.

title: Edwin M. Appel, 70; Led Accounting Firm
description: Edwin M. Appel, a founder and senior partner of the accounting firm of Oppenheim, Appel, Dixon & Company and a philanthropist, died of cancer Sunday in Desert Hospital in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 70 years old and lived in New York.

title: SEIS PROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
China Wage Policy
description: State concerns should have full control over wages they pay workers, according to a proposal by the State Economic Commission, one of China's top planning bodies. The China Daily said the new wage policy is vital to the success of economic reforms aimed at revitalising companies.

title: POSITION OF MOON AND EARTH OFFERS RARE CHANCE TO PROBE MILKY WAY
description: An unusual alignment of the Earth, the moon and the core of the Milky Way galaxy is giving astronomers a rare opportunity to study that core, a mysterious region hidden from sight where processes not found elsewhere in the galaxy are at work.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Jazz 109, Celtics 89: Karl Malone scored 25 points and pulled down 15 rebounds, and the Utah reserves outscored the Boston bench, 56-6, at home. Larry Bird scored 26 points to lead Boston, which lost its second in a row, matching its longest losing streak this season. (AP) Cavaliers 105, SuperSonics 94: In Cleveland, Ron Harper scored 28 points and the Cavaliers held Tom Chambers and Xavier McDaniel to a combined 16 points. Chambers, averaging 23.9 points, scored 11. McDaniel, scoring at a 22.4 pace, hit his first points with 2:55 to go. (AP) Kings 140, Bulls 120: Eddie Johnson scored 7 of his 17 points in overtime, and Reggie Theus hit two clutch free throws with 12 seconds remaining last night to lift the Sacramento Kings to a over the Bulls in Chicago. Michael Jordan led all scorers with 43 points. (AP) Pacers 112, Warriors 93: The Pacers used Chuck Person's 25 points and a club record 40-point first quarter to post a victory over Golden State in Indianapolis. (AP) N.H.L. Flames 5, Flyers 0: Joe Mullen scored his 35th and 36th goals of the season and Rejean Lemelin stopped 23 shots as Calgary snapped a 15-game streak without a victory at the Spectrum. The Flames, who posted their fourth straight victory, had not won at Philadelphia since Oct. 22, 1978, when the team was based in Atlanta. (AP) Maple Leafs 1, Kings 1: Rollie Melanson faced 35 Toronto shots, many in two-on-one situations, and turned away all but one, a goal by Steve Thomas with 32 seconds remaining in the first period. Allan Bester faced 40 Los Angeles shots. The only goal for the Kings came by Luc Robitaille on a power play at 5:24 of the opening period.(AP) Skiing Finn Wins Gold: Marjo Matikainen of Finland survived the threat of disqualification to claim the gold medal in the women's 5-kilometer cross-country race at the Nordic ski world championship in Oberstdorf, West Germany. The 22-year-old Finn, who captured the silver in the 10-kilometer race, won the race in 14 minutes 45.7 seconds. Anfisa Rizcova of the Soviet Union took the silver in 14:49.3, and Evi Kratzer gave Switzerland the bronze in 14:52.5. Television coverage showed that Finland's coaches covered the course with pine branches to clean excess snow and wax from the skis of the team's racers, but the technical jury ruled there was no illegal help. (AP) Horse Racing Comic Blush Wins at Aqueduct: Comic Blush took the lead at the start and maintained a clear advantage throughout to post a four-length victory in the $66,500 Sporting Plate Handicap for 3-year-olds and up at Aqueduct. Carrying 114 pounds and ridden by Tony Graell, the 4-year-old son of Blushing Groom-Istria went six furlongs on the fast track in 1:10 to register his first victory of the year.Paris Venture chased the winner throughout to be runner-up 5 1/2 lengths ahead of Cutlass Reality. I'm Sweets Rallies in Stretch: I'm Sweets rallied strongly through the stretch to win the Poinciana Handicap at Hialeah Park in Florida and end her trainer's run of second-place finishes in the holiday weekend stakes races. The 4-year-old daughter of Alydar and Too Many Sweets circled the field turning for home and score by 1 1/2 lengths over Tea Room.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 17, 1987
description: The Economy

title: ESPEY MANUFACTURING & ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chess: 2 Grandmasters Tie to Win A Tournament in Jerusalem
description: The Jerusalem International Tournament saw the grandmasters Simen Agdestein of Norway and Dmitry Gurevich of Brooklyn share first place with 8-3 scores.

title: PIANO: MITSUKO UCHIDA IN RECITAL AT TULLY HALL
description: MITSUKO UCHIDA, who made her international reputation principally -and her young American reputation almost exclusively - as a Mozart pianist, played Schubert, Schoenberg and Chopin Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall. All of it was first-rate, but the real surprise was the Chopin Third Sonata. I cannot recall ever hearing such a spirited, affirmative, beautifully conceived performance of this wonderful work before.

title: Justice Scalia, in Public, Considers a Hypothesis
description: It is rare for a member of the Supreme Court to engage in an animated public debate and submit to interrogation on disputed legal issues. It is even rarer for one to discuss in such a forum how he would resolve a hypothetical case.

title: INFANT GIRL DIES IN FIRE IN QUEENS APARTMENT
description: An infant girl was killed but her older brother and her grandmother, who was baby-sitting them, were rescued in a fire that destroyed an eighth-floor apartment yesterday morning in Elmhurst, Queens, the police said, A police spokesman, Sgt. John Venetucci, said the fire began just after 11:30 A.M. at 81-11 45th Avenue in the Elmhurst Towers while the girl, Rajini Rao, who was just under 3 years old, her 5-year-old brother, Rahul, and her grandmother, Vasanta Rao, 75, were sitting on a bed watching television. Sergeant Venetucci said firefighters were able to lead the boy and the woman to safety. The girl, however, died in the blaze before the firemen could reach her.

title: P.L.O. AIDE OUSTED BY JORDAN BACK FOR TALKS ON ARAB FUND
description: A top leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, expelled seven months ago in a rift with King Hussein, is back in the Jordanian capital for official talks.

title: Cagey Veteran
description: Next time somebody starts raving about 39-year-old Kareem or 37-year-old Dr. J, tell him about Thomasina Robinson. She's all of 46, and she plays basketball too.

title: BRIEF U.S. SUPPRESSION OF PROOF STIRS ANGER
description: NO one at Israel's Weizmann Institute of Science knew more about secrets than Adi Shamir.

title: MHP MACHINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $12,000.

title: INSIDE
description: Anti-Tobacco Plan Loses The American Bar Association rejected a proposal that it help seek a Federal law barring the advertising of all tobacco products. Page A14. Findings on Bone Loss Factors ranging from hormones to inactivity play a larger role in osteoporosis than calcium, researchers say. Science Times, page C1. Advance in Keeping Secrets Mathematicians find a way for someone to prove possession of a secret, like his credit card number, without revealing it. Science Times, page C1. New Wall Street Subpoenas Kidder, Peabody & Company and Goldman, Sachs & Company were subpoenaed in the Wall Street Take-over inquiry, sources said Page D1.

title: FLAMEMASTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings were adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in 1986.

title: NAVY GIVING UP DRONE PLANES ON LOSING 4 OF 5, OFFICIALS SAY
description: The Navy has suspended a program to equip warships with drone aircraft after losing four of the five pilotless reconnaissance planes sent out recently with the battleship Iowa, military sources report.

title: GOODEN GETS $1.5 MILLION PACT
description: At least the winter wasn't a total loss for Dwight Gooden.

title: HEPBURN WRITES A BOOK ABOUT 'AFRICAN QUEEN'
description: Katharine Hepburn, whose name has adorned countless movie marquees, will soon have her name on the cover of her first book. Scheduled for publication next fall by Alfred A. Knopf, the book is tentatively titled ''The Making of the African Queen, or How I Went to Africa With Bogey, Bacall and Huston and Almost Lost My Mind.''

title: HOWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ANDROS ANALYZERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
'CANDID CAMERA' MARKS 40 YEARS WITH A SPECIAL
description: THE old shows are used in university psychology courses to show people caught in the act of being themselves. The cast of characters included everybody from Harry S. Truman, taking his walking constitutionals in Manhattan, to Woody Allen, a young comic looking to make an extra dollar. The program is, of course, ''Candid Camera,'' and tonight at 8 on CBS, it celebrates its 40th birthday with an hourlong special produced and directed - largely pasted together -by Bob Henry for Allen Funt Productions. Mr. Funt, creator of the show, is the host, as usual, and he is still laughing along with the thousands who, usually after being caught doing something ridiculous, were told to ''smile, you're on 'Candid Camera.' ''

title: SAVING JOBS IN BUFFALO: VICTROY AND LOSS
description: When labor and management gathered here the other day at Trico Products Inc., one of the country's largest makers of windshield wipers, it might have seemed that a promising new chapter was being written in the tragic decline of manufacturing in western New York and the nation at large.

title: CUOMO, IN A VISIT TO SOUTH, OFFERS FIRST STATEMENT ON ISSUES FOR '88
description: Governor Cuomo, in the second in a series of trips outside New York State this year, today condemned the Reagan Administration's policies on issues ranging from arms control to the environment.

title: ARMS DEBATE NOW CENTERS ON ABM PACT
description: The question of how to interpret the Antiballistic Missile Treaty has emerged as the central arms-control issue, affecting the Soviet-American negotiations in Geneva, relations between the United States and its allies and relations between the Administration and Congress.

title: ARREST OF PALESTINIAN ALIENS IN LOS ANGELES TO BE REVIEWED, U.S. AIDE SAYS
description: The top investigations official of the Immigration and Naturalization Service has requested an inquiry into the arrest of eight immigrants here, purportedly affiliated with the radical Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, and their planned deportation on the ground of subversive activity.

title: Uniformed Gunman Robs Ticket Agency
description: A gunman posing as an express-mail courier yesterday stole $73,000 in cash and more than $40,000 worth of tickets for theater, concerts and other performing-arts events from a Times Square ticket vendor, police said.

title: Remedial Work for School Boards
description: Robert Wagner Jr., president of New York City's Board of Education, thinks community school boards are so steeped in politics and patronage as to stifle education reform. His views are echoed in a Bronx grand jury investigation of local boards. Mr. Wagner proposes appointed rather than elected boards, stripped of authority to hire and dismiss principals and other administrators. These and other remedial proposals warrant careful examination by the State Legislature.

title: U.S.-Japan Chip Pact
description: The European Community is to ask the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to set up a panel to examine a trade accord on computer chips between the United States and Japan, a European Community spokesman said. He said the request would be made at the next GATT council meeting in Geneva on March 4 and would concern only the Japanese part of the agreement. The community charges that the five-year accord between Washington and Tokyo, signed last July, calls into question international trade rules. The community said the agreement, intended to stop Japanese dumping on the American market, effectively raises the prices for chips in third world countries, including Europe, and unfairly gives American producers privileged access to the Japanese market.

title: More Than One Claimant to French Throne
description: To the Editor:

title: CENTENNIAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said in the latest quarter it took a special provision for income taxes of about $83,000, plus related expenses, due to an income tax assessment for fiscal 1982.

title: ZYGO CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Ex-Head of F.C.C. Named for Intelsat
description: Dean Burch, a former chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, has been nominated by the United States to head Intelsat, a nonprofit group of 112 nations that runs a worldwide satellite communications network.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: BKW SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
PUTTING A MODEM TO THE TEST
description: THERE I was, at 11 P.M., trying to access the Dow Jones News/Retrieval Service with a software package I was reviewing, but something was distinctly suspicious. I could tell from the fact that all I could hear was the winter wind roaring in the ice-covered trees outside. The word ''dialing'' flashed on the monitor screen before me, but no sound emanated from the PC's Limited 286 computer except the rather excessively loud whir of the fan. I should have been hearing the click, click, click of the modem imitating a rotary telephone dial as it called. Sure enough, an error message appeared on screen.

title: GRANT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FOR SAUDIS, A $45 BILLION CITY
description: On 340 square miles of what was a barren desert only a decade ago, Saudi Arabia has built the world's biggest new industrial city. Jubail is an odorless, litterless, smog-free community with hotels, an airport, highways, schools, mosques, shopping centers, a hospital, baseball diamonds and more than 100,000 imported trees that are irrigated with water reclaimed from the sewers.

title: Textile Bill Is Sought
description: Congressional supporters of the textile industry said today that they are planning a new effort to legislate import curbs designed to build a broader coalition than last year, when a Presidential veto of textile quotas was nearly overriden.

title: The U.N. Today: Feb. 18, 1987
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: OWNER: DEVILS ARE NOT MOVING
description: Despite a continuous decline in attendance and losses of $8.5 million since moving to New Jersey for the 1982-83 season, John McMullen, the owner of the Devils, said today the franchise had no plans for leaving New Jersey.

title: LUCKY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $182,050,000 for the quarter and $183,561,000 for the year, and an extraordinary charge of $7,315,000 from early retirement of debt for the quarter and year. c-After net from discontinued operations of $13,684,000 for the quarter and $37,876,000 for the year.

title: DAILY TASK: TAKING ON JORDAN
description: He is 6 feet 6 inches tall, wears the uniform of the Chicago Bulls and has speed, quickness and can leap. He's not Michael Jordan, just his shadow.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
POTENT POTASSIUM
description: LEAD: FOR most people, potassium deficiency will never be a problem. But this important mineral can be lost through nondietary causes, with grave consequences.

title: BY PUBLIC DEMAND, AN ENCORE FOR ENCORE
description: Monday night, in ''L'Elisir d'Amore'' at the Paris Opera, Luciano Pavarotti sang one of his favorite arias, ''Una furtiva lagrima.'' The public liked it, and he sang it again.

title: DEFENSE RIDICULES ISRAELI TRIAL
description: The defense at the trial of a man accused of being a Nazi death-camp murderer denounced the proceeding today as a a ''show trial'' reminiscent of Soviet propaganda court cases.

description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

description: All of the following kinds of milk contain a variety of vitamins and minerals, among them calcium, iron, magnesium, phosophorus, potassium, zinc, ascorbic acid (vitamin C), vitamin A, thiamine, riboflavin, niacin and vitamins B6 and B12. title: BANNER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $210,000 for the quarter and $1,510,000 for the 6 months.

title: U.S. OVERTURNS SCORING FOR FEMALE FIREFIGHTERS
description: A court-ordered scoring system intended to increase the number of female firefighters in New York City was overturned yesterday by a Federal appeals court.

title: LAWYER IS ARRESTED AS INSIDER
description: Israel G. Grossman, a 34-year-old New York lawyer, was arrested yesterday on criminal charges of stealing inside information from a law firm he worked for and passing it along to six relatives and friends. The six were charged yesterday in a civil complaint.

title: 46 DEAD, 111 HURT AS 2 TRAINS COLLIDE IN SAO PAULO SUBURB
description: Two crowded commuter trains collided on the outskirts of Sao Paulo today, and officials said 46 people were killed and more than 100 injured.

title: 16 LAROUCHE AIDES INDICTED FOR FRAUD
description: A Virginia grand jury today indicted 16 followers of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., the conspiracy theorist, on securities fraud and other felony charges.

title: HOUSTON'S INNOVATIVE SOLUTION TO A PRESSING SEWER PROBLEM
description: FEW people have much idea what happens to their sewage, but Houstonians know all too well. Every time it storms in this flat, low-lying city, the inadequate sewers back up, the streets flood, the bayous overflow. Building has been stunted in many parts of town because the city has had to impose a limit to the number of taps entering each sewer line; developers trade their ''toilet rights.'' Even so, the city is facing heavy state fines for dumping untreated sewage into the bayous, making the city's sobriquet, the Bayou City, less appealing than it sounds.

title: DEXTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes results from Research Polymers International Corp. acquired in October 1986 for both the quarter and year, and the year also includes a charge of $2.5 million from disposal of a product line.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: DURING our college years, I asked the man who is now my husband for the same gift for Valentine's Day, my birthday and Christmas. He would say, ''What do you want?'' And I would reply, ''An engagement ring.'' And he would laugh.

title: ABUSE CASE AGAINST 2 UPHELD
description: A state judge ruled today that the District Attorney did not discriminate against Raymond Buckey and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, when he ordered them to stand trial on charges that they sexually abused children at the McMartin Preschool institution.

title: PLAN TO SELL TV RIGHTS ON PAPAL VISIT ASSAILED
description: A plan by Roman Catholic officials to auction television rights for coverage of a September visit by Pope John Paul II has set off an uproar among broadcasters and some church leaders.

title: GLEASON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax restructuring and disposal charge of $1,937,000 for both the quarter and year. The charge includes a pre-tax loss of $3,193,000 and an income tax benefit of $1,256,000. c-Net income

title: Third-Rail Fire Halts 6th Ave. PATH Line
description: Rush-hour service on PATH trains to Hoboken, N.J., and Jersey City was halted for more than an hour yesterday afternoon when third-rail insulation caught fire under the Avenue of the Americas, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said.

title: 20 ARE INJURED
description: A slow-moving Metro-North commuter train collided last night with an empty train returning to Manhattan at a switching point in the South Bronx, injuring 20 passengers and halting service to and from Grand Central Terminal, officials said.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: FISCHER & PORTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest fourth quarter includes a pretax, and after tax, charge of $600,000 against earnings for an unfavorable court decision in a suit against the company's former insurance carrier.

title: Bridge: Par, a Complicated Concept, Can Be Counted Three Ways
description: Par is a simple concept for golfers but a complex one for bridge players.

title: SHULTZ AND SHAMIR DISAGREE OVER PARLEY
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz clashed today with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel over whether an international conference, possibly including the Soviet Union as a participant, should even be considered as a vehicle for starting peace negotiations in the Middle East.

title: American Air Altering Fares
description: American Airlines plans to raise its cheapest discount fares and stiffen ticket cancellation penalties, beginning March 2, it said yesterday.

title: Finally, Comegys Plays Like Demon
description: DePaul keeps on winning, so, like the old days, Al McGuire brought his cameras into practice to shoot a feature for NBC Sports. The player he talked to was Dallas Comegys, who has hoisted the Blue Demons onto his back this season after three years of dancing away from the call.

title: VF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MCREYNOLDS LOSES IN RULING ON SALARY
description: On a day when the Yankees made the biggest news and spent the most money, the Mets were content to fashion their own modest but winning box score on labor matters yesterday: one victory in arbitration, two signings without arbitration.

title: AMID PROTEST, BUMPURS CASE NEARS ITS END
description: Summations in the six-week manslaughter trial in the Eleanor Bumpurs case were completed yesterday in a noisy session interrupted by a 25-minute demonstration in a packed courtroom in the Bronx.

title: ELDON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for 12wks to Dec 27
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American International Investment Corp., Greenwich, Conn., said it had elected Nicholas B. Tournillon as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: COMPANIES STUDY INSIDER VIOLATIONS
description: Several companies whose stock was reportedly traded by Wall Street insiders said yesterday that they were only just beginning to consider their legal options.

title: TWO KRISHNA EDUCATORS ACCUSED OF CHILD ABUSE
description: The principal and a teacher at a school the Hare Krishna movement once operated in West Virginia were charged yesterday with child molesting in an investigation by Federal, state and local officials into charges of criminal conduct in the movement.

title: Billboard Industry's Campaign
description: IN recent years, the billboard industry has been inching through difficult days of the kind unknown since its business boomed after cigarettes were forced off TV in the early 1970's. In response, the Outdoor Network USA, advertising representatives for 36 operators whose billboards are visible to about 85 percent of the nation's population, is beginning its own trade advertising campaign next Monday to stimulate interest in the national advertising marketplace. The advertising, done by the Bloom Agency, New York, will appear on television and in print to reach national advertisers who use those two media for local support.

title: Our Greedy Colleges
description: Many of our colleges are at it again. As they have done annually for the past six years, they have begun to unveil tuition increases that far outstrip the inflation rate. Next year, tuition is expected to rise 6 percent to 8 percent - even though inflation during 1986 was about 1.8 percent.

title: LAST-MINUTE MANEUVERS CAN REDUCE TAX BILLS
description: This time of year, as April 15 draws closer, is when the motivation to find ways to trim income tax bills is greatest, though the options available for legally outwitting the tax collector are the smallest.

title: PROVIDENCE EDGES SETON HALL
description: Billy Donovan had 23 points, 10 assists and 5 crucial free throws over the final 25 seconds as Providence beat Seton Hall, 91-87, tonight in a Big East Conference game. But just as impressively, Donovan played the last 10 minutes with a bloody nose.

title: In the West's Interest
description: Hard-line American observers of the Soviet Union for years have insisted, with much evidence on their side, that the heirs of Lenin presided over an inherently expansionist nation but a failing society -economically unworkable, bureaucratically paralyzed, viciously repressive, so rigidly and fearfully controlled by a small elite that its people could develop nothing like the skills and initiative to compete in the modern world.

title: Cauthen May Return
description: Steve Cauthen, who rode Affirmed to victory in each of the 1978 Triple Crown races and has ridden in England in recent years, may have a homecoming in the Jim Beam Stakes March 29 at Turfway Park in Florence, Ky. Clive Brittain, the British trainer and a friend of Cauthen's, has nominated Bengal Fire and Rumboogie for the $500,000 guaranteed Beam Stakes, a major preparatory race for the Kentucky Derby. If Brittain's horses are selected to run in the 12- horse race for 3-year old thorougbreds, it is possible that Cauthen, a native of Walton in Northern Kentucky, might ride. Brittain entered Bold Arrangement in last year's Blue Grass Stakes, where the colt finished third before finishing second in the Kentucky Derby. Steve's younger brother Doug helped Brittain prepare the horse for the Kentucky races last year.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: MYSTERY IN MANILA: SINGLAUB'S QUEST
description: Maj. Gen. John K. Singlaub, a retired United States Army officer who has played a major role in advising and raising money for the Nicaraguan rebels, is now spending much of his time on what he describes as a treasure hunt in the Philippines.

title: Power Agency Sets Refunding
description: The M-S-R Public Power Agency of California, which services Modesto, Santa Clara, and Reading, is tentatively offering $271 million of refunding revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 6.91 percent for bonds due in 2019 through underwriters led by E.F. Hutton & Company.

title: The Deficit Still Drives the Dollar
description: Treasury Secretary Baker demonstrates extraordinary skill as a diplomat and as a politician with his campaign to persuade Japan and West Germany to stimulate their economies. By threatening to let the dollar fall unless he gets his way, he undercuts protectionist pressures at home and simultaneously reminds the allies of their dependence on American markets.

title: MUSIC: AMERICAN ORCHESTRA
description: THE New York debut of a promising young conductor, Andrew Litton, was the highlight of the American Symphony Orchestra's Sunday afternoon concert at Carnegie Hall.

title: EASTMAN KODAK CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-After unusual pre-tax charges of $142 million for the quarter and $520 million for the year. c-Net loss d-After unusual pre-tax charges of $551 million and $563 million for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said the share earnings for the latest quarter would have been 97 cents share except for changes relating to investment tax credits and special charges, principally including costs associated with the reduction in-force program.

title: KEY RATES
CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Saturday about cable television's presentation of a sampling of Soviet television programs and a column in the Arts and Leisure section Sunday commenting on the programs misstated the process by which some American universities obtain the broadcasts. The Orbita Technologies Corporation developed and sells the equipment to receive broadcasts from Soviet television satellites. Orbita also supplies copyright clearance for the programs from Gosteleradio, the Soviet state committee for television and radio broadcasting.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ORAL HISTORY

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: NOMINEE FOR C.I.A. SAYS AGENCY ERRED ON IRAN ARMS DEAL
description: Robert M. Gates told a Senate committee today that the Central Intelligence Agency had actively avoided gathering information about how the Nicaraguan rebels were raising money.

title: Interpublic Net Up
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies released its fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, which showed that revenues were up 16.5 percent, to $240.4 million, from $206.4 million in the 1985 period. Net income came to $14.6 million, or 67 cents a share, up 2.8 percent from $14.2 million, or 65 cents a share, a year ago.

title: Birds at Nevada Refuge Are Killed by Cholera
description: An outbreak of cholera was responsible for the deaths of some of the 1,500 birds at a wildlife sanctuary, but officials still do not know what killed more than three million small fish.

title: INTEREST RATES RISE MODESTLY
description: Short- and long-term interest rates rose modestly in quiet trading yesterday as market participants focused on changes in the dollar and overnight interest rates while waiting for tomorrow's Congressional testimony by the Federal Reserve's chairman, Paul A. Volcker.

title: TRUS JOIST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MUSEUM TRIBUTE TO IGMAR BERGMAN
description: YOU are not likely to be seeing the Museum of Broadcasting's current tribute to Ingmar Bergman on your television screen anytime soon, but the exhibition is significant as a reminder to viewers that television quality need not be limited to a schedule monopolized by sitcoms, action-adventures and mini-series. That's what the commercial networks might have you believe, but the overall record says otherwise.

title: CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE NEEDIEST
description: The hard times of the Depression were recalled by a contributor to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: KEMP FORMS GROUP TO SHOW SCOPE OF REPUBLICAN BACKING
description: In an effort to demonstrate broad-based support that has yet to appear in the public opinion polls, Representative Jack F. Kemp of upstate New York today announced the formation of a Presidential steering committee. It is composed of 800 prominent Republican elected officials, state party workers, conservative activists, sports figures and executives of major corporations.

title: For Free Elections in Pakistan
description: A state of anarchy is developing in Pakistan. Its consequences should be cause for alarm to Congress and to the American people.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL COLLEGE: Connecticut vs. St. John's, 8 P.M. at Alumni Hall (TV - Cablevision Channel 20, 10 P.M., tape delay Radio -WCBS 880, 8P.M.) Pittsburgh at Georgetown (TV - ESPN, 8 P.M.) Illinois State at Bradley (TV - ESPN, 10 P.M.) C.U.N.Y. TOURNAMENT semifinals, men at Hunter College Sportsplex, 68th St. and Lexington Ave.; women at City College, 138th St. and Convent Ave. Iona vs. DePaul, 7 P.M. and Notre Dame vs. Fordham, 9 P.M. at Madison Square Garden (TV - MSG, 7P.M., FNN-SCORE, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WRTN-FM 93.5, 6:55 P.M., WFUV-FM, 90.7, 9 P.M.) N.Y.U. at Merchant Marine (Radio -WNYU-FM 89.1, 7:45 P.M.) Army at Fairfield (Radio -WFAS 1230, 8P.M.) HOCKEY ISLANDERS VS. CANADIENS, at Montreal, 7:30 P.M. (TV -SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WOR 710, 7:30 P.M.) DEVILS VS. HARTFORD WHALERS, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. (Radio - WMCA 570, 7:30 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS HARNESS RACING: Roosevelt, 7:30 P.M. Meadowlands, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, midnight) THOROUGHBRED RACING: Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. (TV -SportsChannel, 6:30 P.M. and 11:30 P.M.)

title: JURORS SELECTED FOR TUROFF TRIAL IN A FRAUD CASE
description: Three present and former city officials were listed as possible witnesses yesterday as jurors were selected in the trial of Jay L. Turoff, the former head of New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission who is accused of participating in a bribery scheme.

title: THEATER: 2 VIVID PORTRAITS OF BOOKER T. WASHINGTON
description: HE was a consummate politician who denied ever being political. He was also a brilliant orator who publicly stood for a saintly humanism while secretly pulling strings to undermine radical opponents with whom he emotionally sympathized. Those are the complex, double-edged portraits of Booker T. Washington presented by two gripping new plays that have recently opened in celebration of Black History Month.

title: IN INDIO, IT'S THE DATE THEY REMEMBER
description: LEAD: In this tiny desert town in the Coachella Valley, a date is more than just a passing fancy. From last Friday through next Sunday, it is the raison d'etre of the National Date Festival, a local tribute to the rich, sticky fruit that put Indio on the map. With its Arabian Nights theme and county-fair atmosphere, the celebration offers visitors an excuse to watch ostrich and camel races, see the local beauty queen and sample dates in every conceivable form.

title: CONSOLIDATED NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PERSONAL HEALTH
description: IT wasn't easy for the 6-year-old boy to tell his mother that her stepbrother was abusing him physically and sexually. It was even harder when she told him to stop telling lies. Only when the boy eventually told a teacher, who intervened, did the mother take her son seriously and force the stepbrother to move out.

title: LIMITED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted for June 1986's 3-for-2 stock split.

title: GANDHI, WITH JEEP AND MAP, TOURS THE SOUTH
description: On a rutted and isolated forest road, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi finally found what he was looking for, a tiny village he had spotted on a map and decided to visit because it was not on his itinerary.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mike Boddicker of the Orioles and Gene Nelson of the A's, pitchers awaiting arbitration, reached agreement with their clubs. . . . Brian Tribble, who is awaiting trial on drug charges stemming from Len Bias's death last June, is wanted by the police in Hyattsville, Md., on charges of reckless driving, and fleeing and eluding a police officer in connection with a chase in Maryland yesterday.

title: America's Cup Displayed
description: The America's Cup, recaptured from the Australians earlier this month, went on display here today at City Hall.

title: OFFICIAL URGES STRONGER PENALTIES FOR TAMPERING WITH RAIL DEVICES
description: The head of the Federal Railroad Administration asked Congress today for authority to punish railroad employees who tamper with safety equipment, saying that such tampering was widespread and that the Government was unable to curb it.

title: Future Earnings Held Part of Divorce Accord
description: Judges can order large alimony settlements, including a percentage of future earnings, when one spouse supports the other through medical school and later gets divorced, the Massachusetts Supreme Court ruled today.

title: Louisiana-Pacific
description: The Louisiana-Pacific Corporation said that its accounting firm, Arthur Andersen & Company, would qualify its opinion on the Portland, Ore.-based forest-products company's financial statements. The company said the move is a result of the high number of asbestos-related claims affecting the Fibreboard Corporation, a subsidiary. Louisiana-Pacific said that 11,500 claims were filed in 1986, up from 10,500 in 1985. The claims are related to asbestos insulation produced by Fibreboard until 1971.

title: 'SUPERMOM'S DAUGHTER'
description: LEAD: THE ''Afterschool Special'' on ABC today at 4 P.M. is another of those prepackaged TV lessons that are just a lttle too tidy to be real. ''Supermom's Daughter'' focuses on the problem of a gifted high-school student who balks at following a career plan envisioned by her high-powered mother.

title: Becor Western To Go Private
description: Becor Western Inc., a Milwaukee-based mining equipment manufacturer, said yesterday that it had agreed to be taken private in a $238 million leveraged buyout following the sale of its aerospace unit to Lucas Industries.

title: Pretoria Bout in Doubt
description: James Broad of the United States reportedly is refusing to fight Gerrie Coetzee of South Africa, the former World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, in Pretoria because of a Pretoria high school's decision to bar a black youth from a track meet. The fight, billed as crucial to Coetzee's hopes of a comeback, was scheduled for March 21. But The Citizen, a South African newspaper, yesterday quoted the promoter, Gert van der Walt, as saying that Broad, who is black, would not fight in Pretoria because of the exclusion of a black, Nkululeko Skweyiya, from a weekend meet at Pretoria's Menlo Park High School. Van der Walt was quoted as saying Broad might be willing to fight elsewhere in South Africa, but he said the bout's sponsor was a Pretoria company that did not want to change the venue. The 31-year-old Coetzee, who lost his title in 1984 to Greg Page, last fought March 5 and was knocked out in the first round by Britain's Frank Bruno, dropping his career record to 30-4-1.

title: Necessity Is the Mom of Invention
description: Daniel Randall finally got fed up with tripping over his untied shoes, so the five-year-old from Northfield, Vt., put magnets on the tips of his shoelaces and the toes of his sneakers. Now they stay securely attached until mom ties them again.

title: EXPORT THRUST A REAGAN GOAL
description: President Reagan said today that he would travel around the nation in the weeks and months ahead to promote a legislative program aimed at making America more competitive in the world marketplace.

title: HARVARD HOCKEY: AMONG THE ELITE
description: As an 18-year-old prep school senior, Chris Biotti was the first draft choice of the Calgary Flames in 1985. Two seasons later Biotti is not out in the provinces learning the hockey trade with a minor league team, he is at Harvard.

title: RISE IN ELDERLY CHANGING FACE OF RURAL AMERICA
description: It happened long before she expected. It found her totally unprepared. But Betty Eggland, like thousands of other elderly residents of rural America, has discovered that she is alone in her life but not in her predicament.

title: Market Place; Fund Diversity In Managers
description: MOST money managers believe in diversifying their investments, but George F. Keane, president of the Common Fund, which oversees $2.1 billion in endowment assets, carries that principle one step further. He believes in a diversified portfolio of managers.

title: Indians: Past, Present and Future
description: It's not hard to understand why officials of the Museum of the American Indian are annoyed with Rosemary Richmond. Just as they are about to consummate delicate negotiations to acquire the old United States Custom House for the museum, she demands space in it for her American Indian Community House.

title: LAW FIRMS ACTIVELY LEASING OFFICE SPACE IN MIDTOWN
description: Law firms took more office space in midtown Manhattan last year than any other category of tenant, nearly tripling their demand over the previous year, according to a new study of 1986 leasing activity.

title: FILM: 'SUNAM FORTRESS'
description: IN ancient Georgia, apparently, you had to break eggs not only to make an omelet, but to make a fortress, too. Anyhow, a basket of eggs, picturesquely mashed, is one of the ingredients that goes into ''The Legend of Suram Fortress.'' But another ingredient, which remains a mystery until the end of the tale, is more crucial, since it provides the plot of the new movie from the Soviet Union, now at Film Forum 1.

title: AN ALBUM OF HTE DOOMED: THE ART OF AUSCHWITZ
description: Compared with the volumes of reminiscence and commentary that have been written about Auschwitz, the drawings, paintings and graffiti daubed and scratched on the walls of the death camp by its inmates are enigmatic and incomplete. And yet these marks, which an American photographer has systematically searched out and recorded, are among the few enduring expressions that prisoners and victims left of their suffering.

title: NUTRITIONISTS TAKE AIM
description: DESPITE its near-mythic status, milk is a food to be evaluated in the diet like any other, experts say. Is the richness of whole milk worth the extra 8 grams of fat (72 calories) per cup, compared with skim milk's 0.4 grams of fat? Is milk, or its products, responsible for widespread, unexplained gastric discomfort?

title: THE NEW STYLE IS FIZZY
description: THEIR penchant for sweet carbonated beverages gave rise to scores of soft drinks and to fruit-flavored, low-alcohol wine coolers. In the next year or so, baby boomers may have a new drink designed with their taste preferences and health conerns in mind: carbonated milk in an array of flavors - strawberry, orange, coconut, pina colada, mint, cola, even rum. Milk for the Pepsi generation? ''It's a fun kind of casual, sporty drink,'' said Marilyn Wilkinson, speaking for the United Dairy Industry Association in Rosemont, Ill., which represents 95 percent of American dairy farmers. ''It's the dairy industry's entry into the casual snack market, as well as into the restaurant and fast-food industry.''

title: Oliver Renninger Dies at 103; Survived the First Air Crash
description: Oliver H. Renninger, a survivor of the first reported airplane crash, died Sunday of kidney failure at the Lebanon Veteran's Administration Medical Center. He was 103 years old.

title: TASTY BAKING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Oct. 17, 1986.

title: Banker Pleads Guilty To $2.6 Million Theft
description: A 35-year-old Queens man pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court in Queens to embezzling $2.6 million from the bank where he worked, according to the District Attorney's office.

title: U.S. PLAYS DOWN SPLIT IN CONTRAS
description: The State Department contended today that the Nicaraguan rebel alliance was undergoing ''growing pains,'' but it denied suggestions that divisions among its leaders threatened its existence.

title: DO DIPLOMATS MAKE NICE NEIGHBORS?
description: In Sheridan-Kalorama, a section of northwest Washington already known for a proliferation of foreign missions, several foreign governments are planning to expand their holdings.

title: Festival of New Plays From Africa to Open
description: The Ubu Repertory Theater, a company founded in 1982 to acquaint Americans with new French theater works in English translation, opens its festival of new plays from French-speaking Africa today with ''The Daughter of the Gods,'' a tale written by the Senegalese playwright Abdou Anta Ka and based on an African folk legend. The staged reading will be given at the Ubu Theater, 149 Mercer Street, at 8 P.M.

title: NORFOLK BID BACKED AT PIEDMONT
description: Piedmont Aviation Inc., the parent of Piedmont Airlines, announced yesterday that it had received takeover offers from two companies and that a committee of its board members had recommended approval of a $65-a-share all-cash bid by the Norfolk Southern Corporation.

title: GENERAL DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said year-ago results are pro forma; the company had been a subsidiary of City Investing Co. it was purchased from City Investing in September 1985.

title: NORTHROP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1985 net income had benefitted from two non-recurring items totaling $96.5 million. These included the receipt of $50 million as part of a settlement of claims and contractual disputes and $46.5 million in insurance proceeds from the loss of F-20 aircraft. The 1986 net was down primarily due to the provision made during the fourth quarter for all costs chargeable to the F-20 Tigershark program and a $90 million margin adjustment on a research and development contract.

title: New Delay of Previews For 'Starlight Express'
description: The first preview for ''Starlight Express,'' the new musical by Andrew Lloyd Webber and Richard Stilgoe, has again been postponed, from this Thursday until Tuesday, Feb. 24, according to a spokesman for the show, Bill Evans.

title: U.S. IS PRESSING NEW ABM VIEW IN THE GENEVA ARMS NEGOTIATIONS
description: American negotiators have been telling Soviet officials in Geneva that Washington's new, broader interpretation of the 1972 ABM treaty is justified, officials said today.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Lloyd Wins in Return: Chris Evert Lloyd, playing in her first tournament in five months, coasted to a 6-4, 6-2 victory over Elna Reinach of South Africa last night in the $250,000 Virginia Slims of Florida, at Boca Raton. Because of an ailing knee, Lloyd had not competed since a loss to Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia in the semifinals of the United States Open last September.

title: THE STAGE: 'HATS,' A PLAY ABOUT HARRIET TUBMAN
description: IN Saundra Dunson Franks's portrayal of Harriet Tubman during the last years of her life, the 19th-century fighter for black freedom and women's suffrage is a sharp-witted, downright funny character. At first this conception is startling; much of Mrs. Tubman's life was agony. But she had to have the gift of laughter Ms. Franks gives her or she could not have survived 92 years and accomplished so much. And the merriment of Ms. Franks's monologue in ''Hats,'' her one-woman tribute to Mrs. Tubman at the New Federal Theater, does not hide Mrs. Tubman's ordeals; it makes her triumph over them an inspiration.

title: MATTINGLY WINS $1.975 MILLION IN ARBITRATION
description: Don Mattingly, who had been prepared to accept a negotiated two-year contract for $3.85 million, learned yesterday that he is more than halfway to that total. He won his salary arbitration case against the Yankees with a $1,975,000 salary, the largest ever gained in the 12-year history of arbitration and the largest ever earned by a player in the 85-year history of the Yankees.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Plea to Taco Bell

title: NEWEST SOVIET REVELATION: A CASE OF POLICE BRUTALITY
description: The police in a North Russian city tortured suspects by beating and slow suffocation to extract false confessions, according to a Soviet magazine this week.

title: CITY AGREES ON HOUSING IN THE BRONX
description: The Koch administration and a coalition of the city's leading developers said yesterday that they had reached agreement on a plan to build 1,015 new condominium apartments for middle-income New Yorkers in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx.

title: POLAROID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RORER GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $13,448,000 from discontinued operations in the latest quarter, and for the year includes income of $122,152,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net income d-Includes a loss of $4,028,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter, and for the year includes income from discontinued operations of $826,000. Results for 1986 periods include operations of the prescription drug businesses acquired from Revlon Inc. in January 1986. The company said that results for the latest quarter also were reduced by an abnormally high tax rate and $13 million of increased taxes on a previously recorded gain from the sale of its surgical products business.

title: Placid Oil Budget Dispute Resolved
description: A dispute over the amount of operating funds to be made available to the Placid Oil Company has been temporarily resolved by a Federal judge, who issued an interim budget for the energy concern. Federal Bankruptcy Judge Harold C. Abramson handed down the order after lawyers for Placid and its creditors failed to agree on a budget for the company, which is in Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings.

title: EXPRESS GRINDS TO HALT AS SOCCER TEAM FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: The Major Indoor Soccer League suffered another setback in the metropolitan area yesterday when the New York Express filed for bankruptcy under Chapter XI.

title: Public Radio Co-host To Fill Keillor's Slot
description: A co-host of the National Public Radio program ''All Things Considered'' has been hired by Minnesota Public Radio to fill the void when the humorist Garrison Keillor leaves the ''Prairie Home Companion,'' the off-beat variety show he created 13 years ago.

title: New System Industries Chief
description: Less than a month after rejoining System Industries, the company's founder, Edwin V. W. Zschau, stepped down as chairman yesterday. In addition, James K. Dutton resigned as president and chief executive officer.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR Diary:

title: The Man Behind the Medicare Expansion Plan: Thomas R. Burke
description: When President Reagan proposed a new health insurance program for catastrophic illness, it was widely seen as a victory for Dr. Otis R. Bowen, the Secretary of Health and Human Services.

title: RELUCTANT MILLIONAIRE CLAIMS LOTTO WINNINGS
description: A 20-year-old college student from Brooklyn finally stepped forward yesterday, shyly and almost fearfully, to become a millionaire.

title: IS NOTHING SACRED? MILK'S AMERICAN APPEAL FADES
description: LEAD: MILK the good, the nourishing, the pure. Milk, the hard-to-digest, the high in fat. Countries and cultures have viewed milk both ways, but it is a fact that milk has left a large white mustache glistening over America's collective upper lip. Perhaps nowhere else is milk so glorified.

title: Dressing Up a Cucumber
description: IN the sparse months of winter, cooks must often make do with vegetables that are limited in variety and quality. Winter tomatoes, for example, which are shipped unripened thousands of miles, are usually too pallid to add to green salads. Cucumbers may not be at their peak of flavor in February, but to my taste they are preferable. The following quick technique gives them a special visual flair. STEP 1 Scrape the skin from the cucumber and cut the flesh into four sections crosswise. STEP 2. With a paring knife cut a thin ribbon of cucumber flesh about one-eighth-inch wide, using a spiral motion from top to bottom until you reach the seeded core. You should have one long strip. STEP 3 Roll the strip into a coil and slice it into little rings as illustrated. Place the rings in serving bowls and garnish with parsley, carrots or any vegetable that adds color contrast. Sprinkle with a light vinaigrette sauce.

title: CINCINNATI MILACRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a credit of $600,000 from adoption of a change in accounting for pension costs for the quarter, and the year includes an after-tax benefit of $3 million, or 13 cents a share, from the reduction in pension costs resulting from an accounting change. c-Net loss and includes an after-tax charge of $46,300,000 from the restructuring of manufacturing operations.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1987
description: MARKETS Stock prices soared to further records as Wall Street chose to ignore the latest insider-trading scandal and concentrated instead on positive economic signals. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 2,237.49, after rising 54.14 points, its largest one-day climb ever. Trading was a brisk 187.8 million shares, as the market got a push when word spread throughout Wall Street that Robert Prechter was predicting that the Dow would advance to the 2,300 level before any correction. [ Page A1. ] Interest rates rose modestly in quiet trading as participants focused on changes in the dollar and overnight rates. [ D21. ] Conrail filed a registration statement with the S.E.C. for a public offering totaling 58.7 million shares. [ D21. ] The dollar was mostly lower in quiet trading. In New York, gold fell $3.40 an ounce, to $392.10. [ D22. ] Cattle futures prices advanced while coffee prices declined sharply. [ D22. ] Companies Piedmont directors recommended accepting a takeover bid by Norfork Southern in preference to two proposals by USAir. The rail company offered $65 a share in cash, or $1.49 billion in all, while USAir offered $71 a share in stock or $68 in stock and cash. Analysts questioned the fit between Piedmont and Norfolk Southern. [ D1. ] I.B.M. put the one-megabit chip in a personal computer, hinting at technological changes expected in other products. I.B.M. said the chip would increase the machine's speed and lower its cost. [ D1. ] Ford reported that it earned $3.3 billion in 1986, which was the first year since 1924 that it was more profitable than General Motors. Ford's profits rose 9 percent in the fourth quarter, in contrast to G.M. and Chrysler, which reported declines. [ D1. ] Martin Marietta pleaded guilty to two mail fraud charges and making a false statement in a scheme that defrauded the Pentagon out of at least $1.35 million in travel expense rebates. [ D5. ] Compaq introduced a high-powered computer that is smaller and lighter than earlier models. [ D19. ] Dixons Group of Britain agreed to acquire Cyclops for $90.25 a share. The offer topped a bid from Audio/Video Affiliates. [ D5. ] Eastman Kodak and Polaroid reported higher earnings for the fourth quarter. [ D5. ] The Scandal on Wall Street

title: Theus Extends Pact
description: Reggie Theus, the nine-year pro out of Nevada-Las Vegas, has signed a three-year contract extension with an option on a fourth year with the Sacramento Kings. Including the fourth year, the contract is valued at $750,000 a year, according to team officials. ''I'm just happy we got it done,'' Theus said about the pact signed last Sunday night in Chicago after eight months of negotiations. ''I'm celebrating because it means security in my life and because it means I don't have to go through the summer babying my body. That's one reason I wanted to get to it. I didn't want to spend my summer walking on eggshells.''

title: WASTE MANAGEMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a non-taxable gain of $234,031,000 from the public offering of 18.9 percent of Chemical Waste Management Inc., in October 1986, and an after-tax charge of $85,343,000 as a result of non-recurring restructuring charges.

title: RANGERS IN 2D PLACE IN PATRICK DIVISION
description: He was lying on his side, perhaps first visualizing what he would have to do to stop the puck that already seemed to have flown past him. John Vanbiesbrouck must have been dreaming, for there was no logical way to explain how he stopped the puck and made his most spectacular save of the year for the Rangers.

title: White House Tries to Shortchange Research
description: To the Editor:

title: 500 Blacks Boycott Schools
description: About 500 black students stayed home today to protest the school board's failure to name a black as assistant school superintendent, boycott leaders said. The 1,650-student school system is 34 percent black, and protest leaders said 95 percent of the black students stayed home. The Rev. Michael Cathey, a spokesman for a group of black parents, said the school board had ''renegged'' on a promise to appoint a black as assistant superintendent. The white board members say they pledged only to consider qualified blacks for the post, but could not find one.

title: P.L.O. IS BOLSTERED BY KUWAITI MONEY
description: A new influx of Arab money will bolster the Palestine Liberation Organization's political base in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, in a move seen here as undercutting King Hussein of Jordan.

title: WENDY'S INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a net charge of $51,800,000 in connection with a realignment. c-Net income

title: SPACE CENTER COMEBACK SEEN
description: The director of the Kennedy Space Center said today that by the end of 1987 the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and its contractors would have refilled all 2,000 center jobs lost as a result of the space shuttle Challenger's explosion.

title: Pro-Palestinian Group Is Shut Down in Israel
description: The Israeli police, in an unusual action against Jewish critics of the Government's human-rights record, have closed the offices of a Jerusalem information agency sympathetic to Palestinians and arrested four workers.

title: MUSIC: AT TOWN HALL, PHILHARMONIA VIRTUOSI
description: ALTHOUGH Rodrigo's ''Concierto de Aranjuez'' stands as one of the most popular works in the history of the phonograph, the classic guitar is an instrument easily bruised when it comes into contact with a live orchestra. Its peculiarly seductive sound, at once intimate and distant, tends to lose its power to enchant when thrown into competition with heavier voiced instruments. As a result, important concertos for guitar and orchestra are scarce, even in this period of the instrument's flowering.

title: Energy Dept. Rejects Rallies At Nevada Nuclear Test Site
description: Because of growing incidents of civil disobedience, antinuclear protesters will no longer be allowed to demonstrate on a section of the Nevada Test Site, the Energy Department announced today.

title: Dept. of Ties and Tails
description: When some small-town politicians get elected to the United States Senate, they feel compelled to try to move up to a new social echelon and dress accordingly. But not Warren B. Rudman of Nashua, N.H. When a columnist invited Senator Rudman the other day to the March dinner of the Gridiron Club, he declined - solely, he said, because he would have been required to don white tie and tails for the occasion.
