Mr. Rudman told his would-be hostess that he had also refused at least three opportunities to dine with his fellow-Republicans, President and Mrs. Reagan, at the White House be-cause he does not go to black-tie events either. Senator Rudman has at least one distinguished sartorial predecessor from Capitol Hill, albeit a Democrat. In his 34 years in the House, Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the former Speaker, resisted all entreaties to attend the Gridiron dinner on the same stated grounds: He refused to appear in public and risk being photographed in what he regarded as the uniform of plutocrats, white tie and tails.

title: Reagan Likely to Lift Polish Sanctions Soon
description: An Administration official said today that President Reagan was expected to lift trade sanctions against Poland and might announce his decision this week.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Clean, Constructive - and Temporary
description: The three-story row house could be the pride of its blue-collar Brooklyn neighborhood. The freshly painted facade suggests the home of hard- working families.

title: Hospital Criticized In Care of Youth
description: A state health department investigation found that a Brooklyn emergency room failed to administer oxygen to an 18-year-old Brooklyn youth who was rushed there by ambulance while suffering an acute asthma attack on Dec. 8, City Council president Andrew M. Stein said yesterday.

title: Europe Shaping Response to Gorbachev's Moves
description: With West Germany taking the lead, Western European nations have started to shape a response to Mikhail S. Gorbachev's program of change in the Soviet Union, in the hope of exerting influence.

title: CUOMO APPLAUDED FOR DETAILED COMMENTS ON POLICY ISSUES
description: Governor Cuomo of New York won generally favorable reaction today for his most detailed policy comments yet on issues from a defense against missiles to foreign trade.

title: TWO MORE MEN SEIZED IN 'PIZZA' CASE SHOOTING
description: Two more suspects in the shooting of a defendant in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial on a Greenwich Village street were arrested yesterday, bringing to five the number of men held in what authorities say was an attempted murder for hire at a price of $40,000.

title: A Tax Dispute Stalls the Japanese Parliament
description: Growing opposition to a plan to overhaul Japan's tax system has brought Parliament to a standstill and threatens to weaken the political strength of Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone.

title: MORE POLICE ADDED TO WASHINGTON SQ.
description: More police officers, including some on scooters and others with dogs trained to sniff out drugs, have been assigned to patrol the Washington Square Park area in Greenwich Village in a stepped-up effort to control drug sales there, police officials said yesterday.

title: White House Tries to Shortchange Research; Encouragement Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: MANY TOP LEADERS SHIFTED IN VIETNAM
description: Vietnam reorganized its Government today, replacing the Interior and Defense Ministers along with at least a dozen other officials, according to the Hanoi radio.

title: Queens Fire Kills Mother and Child
description: A fire that may have started in a clothes dryer enveloped a house in smoke yesterday, killing a Queens woman and her 18-month-old daughter.

title: CHICAGO PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $1,268,000 and $7,186,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes extraordinary credits of $3,731,000 for the quarter and $19,131,000 for the year. The company said the latest fourth quarter and full year include the results of Hoover Co., which was aquired November 1985, the Rowenta Group, acquired July 1986 and Furniture Group America Inc., acquired August 1986. The company said the 1985 revenues and earnings came primarily from the liquidation of the railroad assets and from interest income on invested funds. The extraordinary credits were from tax loss carryforwards.

title: Brooklyn Man Is Found Slain In His Ransacked Apartment
description: A 45-year-old Brooklyn man was found stabbed to death last night in his ransacked apartment in the Bensonhurst section, the police said.

title: NEW LIFE IS ENVISIONED FOR HISTORIC SYNAGOGUE
description: Built in splendor by a German congregation, kept in its waning days by a Polish congregation and finally abandoned, New York's oldest synagogue building is now owned by a Spanish sculptor who dreams of turning it into an artists' colony.

title: DIAGNOSES OF MOTHER SAID TO ERR
description: An expert on psychiatric disorders testified today that experts hired by Baby M's legal guardian were incorrect in diagnosing the child's mother, Mary Beth Whitehead, as mentally disabled and in need of therapy.

title: A SMALLER COMPUTER INTRODUCED BY COMPAQ
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation introduced a high-powered portable computer yesterday that is smaller and lighter than the company's earlier models.

title: For the Records
description: Monday night was one for the books in women's basketball. Or three for the books, actually. In San Jose, Calif., Cindy Brown of Long Beach State, a 6-foot-2-inch senior forward, scored 60 points in a 149-69 rout of San Jose State, a game in which two N.C.A.A. women's records were eclipsed: most points by a player (58, by Lorri Bauman of Drake three years ago) and by a team (139, by Grambling against Jarvis Christian last season).

title: Justice Official Asks Panel Restore to Death Penalty
description: The Justice Department today urged a Congressionally created panel to issue guidelines that would restore the death penalty for certain Federal crimes, including treason, espionage and assassination of a President.

title: BIG BRITISH RETAILER TO ACQUIRE CYCLOPS
description: Dixons Group P.L.C., Britain's largest electrical-equipment retailer, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Cyclops Corporation, the Pittsburgh-based steel-products maker and specialty retailer, for $384 million in cash.

title: Auto Fuel Economy, Please
description: On the same day that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries announced it would cut crude oil production and raise prices to $18 a barrel, a Presidential Task Force on Regulatory Relief, whose chairman was Vice President Bush, issued a proposal to abolish corporate average fuel economy standards for new automobiles. The coincidence of these events last December is ironic.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Agency people, and I would say here from the Director on down, actively shunned information. We didn't want to know how the contras were being funded, in part, because we were concerned it would get us involved in crossing the line imposed by the law. And so we actively discouraged people from telling us things. We did not pursue lines of questioning.

title: PENTAGON AIDE MAY GET NAVY POST
description: James H. Webb Jr., better known for his novel on the Vietnam War than as the current Assistant Secretary of Defense for Reserve Affairs, is expected to be nominated to replace John F. Lehman Jr. as Secretary of the Navy, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Liberty Does Not Say, 'Give Me Your Dollar'
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK'S HIGH COURT UPHOLDS CITY LAW BARRING CLUBS' SEX BIAS
description: The state's highest court today unanimously upheld a New York City law that could force several of the city's most prestigious all-male clubs to admit women.

title: Trudeau Trial Set
description: Jack Trudeau, the starting quarterback for the Indianapolis Colts, is to go on trial April 2 on charges of disorderly conduct and battery on a police officer arising from a fight outside an Indianapolis bar. Trudeau, 24, and a friend, Joseph C. Venkus, 25, were arrested early last Friday. After they pleaded not guilty, Trudeau was released on his recognizance, and Venkus, a law student, was freed on $500 bond. Trudeau maintained that he and his friend were attacked by three other men, who fled the scene and were not pursued by the police. The police said that Trudeau struck Officer Ricky L. Dean when he tried to break up the altercation.

title: 2 Hertz Notes Total $150 Million
description: The Hertz Corporation, a subsidiary of UAL Inc., is offering two note issues totaling $150 million through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A diagram in Science Times yesterday with an article on osteoporosis carried two misplaced labels. It is osteoclasts that play a role in normal bone breakdown; osteoblasts are involved in the rebuilding of bone.

title: A CLOCK, A BEAST, A BIRD
ISLANDERS SHOW FLAIR, BUT FALL
description: After the game, Denis Potvin patiently explained the reason why the Islanders may have outplayed the Philadelphia Flyers and yet were unable to beat them. First he spoke with his younger teammates, who wondered why their efforts went unrewarded, and then he sent a similar message to whatever members of the news media had clustered within earshot.

title: MARCHING ON RACISM: PRACTICAL OR PASSE?
description: In the wake of recent racial confrontations in urban New York and rural Georgia, civil rights experts are questioning whether the methods that defeated institutional racism in the 1950's and 1960's can prevail against the more subtle racism of the 1980's.

title: FARM HOUSE FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $2,888,000 for both the quarter and 9 months related to adjusted long-term obligations and reserves and the effect of tax loss carryforwards.

title: CALLING THE WORLD! HAM RADIO IS BACK BUT IN NEW WAYS
description: ''THIS is November, Two, Boston, Tango, Sierra calling CQDX.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Washington Talk page Feb. 7, about homelessness as a Congressional issue, misidentified the home state of Representative Stewart B. McKinney. He is a Connecticut Republican.

title: CONCERT: JENS NYGARD
description: JENS NYGAARD has developed a real following for his chamber-orchestra concerts at Alice Tully Hall with the Jupiter Symphony, and after attending Monday's string-orchestra program, one can understand why. Not everything was perfect, but all of it was seriously intended, and the best was positively buoyant.

title: Body Checks
description: The coveted left shoulder (the one that shows up in so many action shots as she completes her left-handed serve) is covered, but if you don't mind being on the off side, Martina Navratilova's right shoulder is still available. It's been bare since she and Porsche parted company a while back, leaving Computerland, the outfit that owns the rights to her left shoulder, with the only commercial on her entire body.

title: Economic Scene; Japanese View U.S. Industry
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN met with a group of top business leaders in the East Room of the White House yesterday to discuss America's loss of competitiveness in world markets - and what can be done about it. The Scottish poet Robert Burns suggested that we should see ourselves as others see us, and nobody seems to see the problems of American industry more clearly these days than do the Japanese. With their growing stake in the United States economy, not only as a market but also as a site for production and investment, the Japanese companies are studying the American scene more intensively than ever.

title: House Loser Asks Lost Pay
description: If you had run for Congress as a Democrat in downstate Illinois last fall, challenging the re-election of Representative Robert H. Michel, the House Republican floor leader, and if you had been buried under a 68 percent majority, you might feel like trying to recover a little something. That is exactly what happened to Jim Dawson in the 18th District of Illinois, and it has led him to a legal test of a novel theory of political compensation.

title: A Wrinkled Peasant In Skin Care Promotion
description: A number of ad agencies are getting inspiration these days from the ancient Soviet citizens who appeared in the Dannon Yogurt commercials shot a decade ago by Marsteller, now HCM.

title: JUDGE FREES 8 ALIENS BY U.S. TO RADICAL PALESTINIAN GROUP
description: A United States immigration judge, saying that eight aliens could not be held solely on the basis of their purported affiliation with a radical Arab group, today ordered them released until a deportation hearing April 28.

title: The Bird Watch
description: To the Editor:

title: Coolidge Was Eloquent Without Welliver
description: To the Editor:

title: A 'BUG' GOES TO THE AID OF PLANTS
description: RESEARCHERS reported last weekend that they had successfully used a novel biotechnological approach to increase the tolerance of plants to insects, viruses and herbicides. The advances have potential application in commercial agriculture.

title: ENNO W. ERCKLENTZ
description: Enno W. Ercklentz, a retired banker and industrialist, died Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Caterpillar Plans To Close Plant
description: Caterpillar Inc., a leading manufacturer of construction equipment, said that it would close a plant in Davenport, idling 1,393 hourly and salaried workers. The Peoria, Ill., company had said last month that it might close the plant.

title: Nighttime Isn't Knight Time
description: For a coach whose team had just eked out an 86-85, triple-overtime victory, Bob Knight was sure steamed after Indiana's game at Wisconsin on Monday night.

title: FORD MOTOR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in the form of a 50 percent stock dividend declared on April 10, 1986. The company said the full-year effect of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 was recognized in the latest fourth quarter, reducing net income by 44 cents a share.

title: WINE TALK
description: DAWNINE SAMPLE DYER and Bill Dyer drink the American equivalent of Champagne throughout dinner at least twice a week in their Napa Valley home. ''You can't beat it as an everyday house white,'' Mrs. Dyer said.

title: DIAL-A-RESTAURANT
description: DIAL AND DINE, an eight-month-old restaurant-referral service, invites people to call for ''up to the minute'' advice about more than 1,000 Manhattan establishments. The service also makes reservations, ''assuring you a table that might not otherwise be available,'' according to its advertisements. The New York Restaurant Hot Line, a similar service that will start soon, tells callers it can help select a restaurant ''that suits your tastes and your budget.''

title: COOPER TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
20 May Be Indicted In Wedtech Inquiry
description: The Bronx District Attorney, Mario Merola, said yesterday that a bribery and corruption investigaton into the Wedtech Corporation, a South Bronx military contractor, may eventually lead to as many as 20 indictments.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Sports Pages yesterday about the St. John's-Fairleigh Dickinson basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden on Monday omitted the result of the first game.

title: Goldin to Study Impact Of Boesky on Pensions
description: Trustees of the city's police pension fund directed City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin yesterday to determine what impact Ivan F. Boesky's financial dealings might have had on the fund's $1.4 billion in equity holdings.

title: HOUSTON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WARD, CITING SUSPECT'S DEATH, ISSUES BAN AGAINST HOGTYING
description: Five days after the death in police custody of a burglary suspect whose shackled hands and feet were trussed behind his back, Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward issued an order yesterday banning the practice.

title: Hambrecht Aide Plans Expansion
description: As head of his own small investment banking company, John A. Fisher was the architect of many of the mergers and acquisitions of California's premium wineries. His deals included the purchases of Ridge Vineyard Inc. and Chateau St. Jean by Japan's Otsuka Pharmaceutical Ltd. and Suntory Ltd., respectively.

title: Mother Is Found Not Guilty In Suffocation of Her Child
description: A Federal judge found a woman not guilty by reason of insanity today in the suffocation death of her 18-month-old daughter while both were stowaways aboard a cruise ship.

title: Pakistani to Visit India
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan will visit India this weekend for talks with Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, an Indian spokesman announced today. Tension arose between the two countries last month when both massed their armies along their border. At a meeting in New Delhi two weeks ago, the two Governments agreed to a partial withdrawal of troops.

title: Martin Marietta Pleads Guilty
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation pleaded guilty today to two mail fraud charges and making a false statement in a scheme that defrauded the Pentagon out of at least $1.35 million in travel expense rebates.

title: VIOLINIST'S COOKING MAXIM: IMPROVISE
description: ''I CARE about food'' - the violinist Itzhak Perlman paused to ponder le mot juste -''in an intense way.'' As he spoke his ebullient wife of 20 years, Toby, was circling her index finger near her head. ''Sick!'' she whispered sotto voce. ''Ill!''

title: RJR Nabisco Study Of Tobacco Spinoff
description: RJR Nabisco Inc., a major food and tobacco company, confirmed that it was studying the possible spinoff of its tobacco business into a limited partnership. The company had denied Wall Street speculation last month that it might get out of the tobacco business, which has stagnated because of health concerns.

title: Basketball Balloons Burst
description: American University has received several million dollars in gifts from Adnan Khashoggi, the Saudi arms dealer, and accordingly named its gymnasium for him. So when students were preparing for their recent basketball game with the United States Naval Academy, they had balloons made carrying the rallying cry ''Adnan's Army.'' But university officials, sensitive about Mr. Khashoggi's involvement as an intermediary in the arms-to-Iran imbroglio, were not amused when they discovered the plan, and the balloons never appeared at the game.

title: LEADER'S RESIGNATION IS DESCRIBED AS PART OF U.S. CAMPAIGN TO SHORE UP REBEL CAUSE
description: A contra leader's resignation from a top political position Monday was part of an effort promoted by the Reagan Administration to overcome Congressional doubts and address the movement's continued failings, according to American officials and leading contras.

title: GOVERNORS URGE TYING WELFARE BENEFITS TO JOBS
description: The chairman of the National Governors' Association said today that President Reagan's plan for revising the welfare system was inadequate. He said the nation should instead look to a plan being formulated by the governors that would immediately require a large number of those on the welfare to go to work.

title: DOCTORS END MEDICAID THREAT
description: Three of Acquidneck Island's five obstetricians have dropped their plans to turn away Medicaid patients, citing the state's decision to more than double reimbursements for treatment.

title: CROWN CORK & SEAL CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest quarter results include a credit for adoption of a new accounting rule and a charge for pension costs resulting from the planned closing of plants.

title: Heck's Cutbacks
description: Heck's Inc., a discount store chain, said that it would close 29 of its 158 stores, cut its headquarters staff and eliminate stock dividends in an attempt to stem its losses. Heck's said that the cutbacks would save it more than $4 million. The retailer has not reported an annual profit since 1983. The chain operates in Indiana, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Maryland, West Virginia, Virginia, North Carolina, Kentucky and Tennessee.

title: 9.9% Calny Stake
description: The Taco Bell Corporation, a fast-food unit of Pepsico Inc., has purchased 9.9 percent of Calny Inc., and said it might seek control of the company, which is its largest franchisee. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Taco Bell of Irvine, Calif., said it acquired 469,017 shares of Calny for $11 a share on Feb. 6. San Mateo, Calif.-based Calny operates 145 Taco Bell restaurants.

title: White House Tries to Shortchange Research; Imperfect Results
description: To the Editor:

title: ALLEN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $11 million for restructuring of operations for both the quarter and year. c-Net income The company said the purpose of the $11 million reserve was to cover costs incurred as a result of overhead reductions, the closing of several facilities and other planned restructuring actions.

title: AN INDEPENDENT PUBLISHER SLOWLY CHANGES ITS WAYS
description: Though offered $275,000 elsewhere recently for his first novel, Scott Turow decided to sign for $200,000 with Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

title: CONRAIL REGISTRATION IS FILED WITH S.E.C.
description: The Consolidated Rail Corporation, in a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commisssion, indicated yesterday that it expected to raise between $1.29 billion and $1.52 billion in the public sale of the Government's 85 percent interest in the railroad.

title: U.S. INDUSTRY IN JANUARY AT 79.7% OF CAPACITY
description: American industry operated at 79.7 percent of capacity in January, the best showing in almost a year, as the manufacturing sector continued to provide signs that the worst of its trade problems may be ending.

title: POLAROID AND KODAK POST PROFITS
description: The Eastman Kodak Company and the Polaroid Corporation, the two leading American photography companies, today reported improved results for the fourth quarter of 1986 and for the year.

title: L.I.R.R. AND SIGNALMEN REACH TENTATIVE PACT
description: The Long Island Rail Road and the Brotherhood of Railroad Signalmen reached agreement yesterday on a tentative contract, leaving only a coalition of four craft unions without a contract accord.

title: Senate Backs Arms Stance
description: Anyone trying to determine the position of Congressional Democrats on arms control yesterday was in for some confusion. At the behest of its new Democratic leadership, the Senate, 93 to 2, approved a resolution expressing ''full support'' for the Reagan Administration's arms control position, only days after House Democrats had voted unanimously to cut off funds for further tests of all but the smallest nuclear weapons.

title: IS NOTHING SACRED? MILK'S AMERICAN APPEAL FADES
description: FOLLOWING are types of milk that are available commercially. Unless otherwise noted, the definitions are from the National Dairy Council.

title: FORD LEADS IN U.S. CAR PROFITS
description: For the first time since 1924 the Ford Motor Company is back as the most profitable automobile company in America. Ford reported today that it earned $3.3 billion, or $12.23 a share of common stock, in 1986. That made the year the first in more than 60 years that the No. 2 auto maker was more profitable than its archrival, the General Motors Corporation, which earned $2.95 billion.

title: People
description: * Robert Schrijver and Ronald Brello have joined Calet, Hirsch & Spector as senior vice presidents and management supervisors.

title: SOVIET OFFERS TO ALLOW CHEMICAL-ARMS INSPECTIONS
description: The Soviet Union said today that it would allow on-site, international inspection of its chemical weapons stockpiles. The Soviet move was made during the longstanding negotiations on a ban on chemical weapons at the 40-nation Geneva Conference on Disarmament.

title: SENATE APPROVES BILL ON APPLIANCE EFFICIENCY
description: The Senate, working out a deal with the White House to avoid a Presidential veto, overwhelmingly passed legislation today to set national energy efficiency standards for large household appliances.

title: New York City Government Reform Is Possible
description: To the Editor:

title: Mass Murderer Held Sane
description: The Pennsylvania Supreme Court ruled today that George Banks was legally sane, and it upheld his conviction for murder and his death sentence in the slayings of five of his children and eight other people in 1982. The court, voting 5 to 2, said that Mr. Banks ''suffered from a mental defect'' but ''was legally sane and competent to stand trial.'' Mr. Banks, the illegitimate son of a black father and white mother, testified at his trial that when he shot the people to death it was ''the culmination of 40 years of racist hatred.'' Four of the adults were the white mothers of his children.

title: BOWIE KUHN LIVES
description: The Old Commish is back. Abandoning the stuffed shirt in which the image-makers portrayed him, Bowie Kuhn has put on his flannel wood-chopping shirt to flail away at some of the owners - particularly the benefactors of our local playpens.

title: Amateurs on Stage, Semiamateur Critics
description: THEY have actually had to use a hook to remove bad acts from the Apollo Theater stage on amateur nights. This practice stopped when one particularly unpromising young performer sued for whiplash.

title: Flickering 'Nova
description: Villanova - 14-11 over all, 6-7 in the Big East and facing some tough games ahead - is likely to miss out on the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament, bringing to an end one of the greatest current streaks of consecutive seasons with a tourney berth. The longest such streaks at present: North Carolina 12 Georgetown 8 Kentucky 7 Villanova 7 Alabama-Birmingham 6 Alabama 5 North Carolina A&T 5 St. John's 5 Illinois 4 Maryland 4 Nevada-Las Vegas 4 Oklahoma 4 Purdue 4 Syracuse 4

title: PRODUCTION RETURNING TO U.S.
description: Armed with new technology and eager to shorten supply lines, some American manufacturers have started to bring overseas operations home or switch from foreign to domestic suppliers. The homeward move has been augmented by the fall of the dollar against foreign currencies, notably the Japanese yen.

title: ANTHONY R. DiPAOLA
description: Anthony R. DiPaola, a former first deputy commissioner of the New York City Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity in the 1950's, died of a liver ailment last Wednesday at New York University Medical Center. He was 78 years old and lived in Queens.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ONE of the most heartening advances in American taste within recent years has been the acceptance of certain fish long associated with particular cultures, such as Italian, French and Greek.

title: AIDE TO PRESIDENTS
description: Bryce N. Harlow, a Presidential counselor and speechwriter who held key positions in the Eisenhower and Nixon Administrations, died today. He was 70 years old.

title: WEST BEIRUT FIGHT KILLS AT LEAST 24
description: Shiite Moslem militiamen fought an alliance of Druse and Communist gunmen for a third day today in the fiercest factional fighting in West Beirut in three years.

title: DMITRI KABALEVSKY, RUSSIAN WHO COMPOSED 'COMEDIANS'
description: Dmitri Kabalevsky, a Soviet composer best known for his suite ''The Comedians'' and the Overture to his opera ''Colas Breugnon,'' has died at the age of 82, Tass, the official Soviet press agency, said yesterday. Tass provided no details of Mr. Kabalevsky's death but said that leaders of the Soviet Government and the Communist Party had signed an obituary describing him as ''innovative and brilliant.''

title: 2 Donors Pledge $7.5 Million For New Princeton Complex
description: Princeton University has received two anonymous pledges totaling $7.5 million for the construction of a building to house the school's economics department and Center of International Studies, officials said Monday.

title: INTERPUBLIC GROUP OF COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from exchange and translation of foreign currencies of $1,781,000 for the quarter and $2,685,000 for the year. c-Includes losses from exchange and translation of foreign currencies of $1,501,000 for the quarter and $2,497,000 for the year. Revenue represents gross income.

title: A.B.A. URGES MODEST LIMITS ON LAWSUITS OVER INJURIES
description: Pressed to take a stand on an issue that has touched off heated debate in legal circles nationwide, the American Bar Association today proposed a relatively modest set of changes in the system of recovering damages for personal injuries.

title: Apartheid Pullout By Kentucky Fried
description: The Kentucky Fried Chicken Corporation said that it was joining a growing number of American companies leaving South Africa because of apartheid. The fast-food chain, a subsidiary of RJR Nabisco Inc., said that it would withdraw its assets, although no date was given for departure.

title: DEFEAT IS PRECICTED FOR THE GOVERNMENT
description: Irish voters cast ballots in a general election today, with opinion polls forecasting defeat for Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald and his Fine Gael party.

title: COCA-COLA ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest fourth quarter loss reflects interest expense of $50 million and elimination of investment tax credit. The company said the actual figures includes results of acquired bottling companies from dates of acquisition, except Louisiana Coca-Cola Bottling Company, which was acquired in February 1986 and consolidated as of Jan. 1, 1986, and the Barron Companies, which were acquired during July 1986 and consolidated as of July 1, 1986.

title: U.S. - SOVIET TIES: A SENSE OF INERTIA
description: Even as Mikhail S. Gorbachev takes dramatic steps to liberalize some aspects of Soviet society, the Soviet-American relationship seems overcome by a strange sense of inertia, apparently immune to the momentum of change occurring in the Soviet Union.

title: Man Held in Burglary Is Tied to 22 Holdups
description: A man arrested Monday and charged with the burglary of a hotel room in Greenwich Village was wanted for 22 bank holdups in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn, the police reported last night.

title: JAMES RIVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
description: b-Reflects a negative adjustment from an increase in income tax expense of $4.4 million for the quarter and $23.8 million for the year from the Tax Reform Act of 1986. The quarter also includes $5.2 million related to the sale of Gaylord Container. The year-ago periods' results are restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effected June 23, 1986, and the early adoption of required changes in accounting for pension cost.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1987
description: International A3-12, B24

title: AFGHAN WAR: IN YEAR SEVEN, A DEADLY STALEMATE
description: With the Afghan war now in its seventh year, and with serious fighting having ebbed for the winter, neither side appears any closer to winning than they were when Soviet troops joined the fray in December 1979, military experts say.

title: STOCK RECORDS SET IN FACE OF SCANDAL
description: Stock prices soared to another record yesterday as Wall Street shrugged off the anxiety generated by its latest insider-trading scandal.

title: Fake Birth Control Pills Lead to Indictment of 6
description: Six Florida residents have been indicted in a scheme to distribute one million counterfeit birth control pills, the United States Attorney's office said today.

title: DELAY IN ANOTHER
description: Soviet authorities said today that the imprisoned dissident Anatoly Koryagin had been freed by a decree, but that Iosif Z. Begun remained in prison pending a decree approving his release.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: LOOK HOMEWARD. A Life of Thomas Wolfe. By David Herbert Donald. Illustrated. 579 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $24.95.

title: ADVANCED CHIP FOR I.B.M. UNIT
description: The International Business Machines Corporation today became the first personal computer maker to put the vanguard one-megabit memory chip in one of its desktop machines - a precursor of some major technological changes expected in the computer giant's products.

title: 2 Farm Banks Win Ruling
description: A Federal judge today struck down regulations requiring two solvent Farm Credit districts to use unallocated reserves to bail out troubled segments of the nation's Farm Credit System.

title: Salomon Official To Try Real Estate
description: Raymond L. Golden has left his job as chief financial officer at Salomon Brothers Inc. to join the Trammell Crow Company, the big real estate company based in Dallas.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: IT'S only February, but one of the year's most important jazz albums has just been released: the alto saxophonist-composer Tim Berne's ''Fulton Street Maul.'' The album is a major event both for Mr. Berne's music - which is by turns wild and woolly, intimate and thoughtful, in about equal proportions - and for the fact that it has been released by Columbia Records, a major label that rarely issues such uncompromising music. On Saturday, Mr. Berne will perform at the Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street, with his new quintet, which includes bass, drums, cello and trumpet. ''Fulton Street Maul'' uses a quartet of saxophone, electric guitar, cello and percussion.

title: Baker International
description: Baker International Inc. said it had agreed to sell the domestic operations of its electrical submersible pump division to Trico Industries for an undisclosed amount. The sale of the unit would move Baker a step closer to completing its previously announced plan to merge with the Hughes Tool Company. That deal awaits approval from the Justice Department, which had objected on antitrust grounds. The department had said Baker would need to sell two of its operating subsidiaries. A buyer for the company's domestic tricone drill-bit unit is still being sought, Baker said.

title: Lomas & Nettleton Stake Purchased
description: The American Can Company has purchased 2.62 million shares, or 9.2 percent, of the Lomas & Nettleton Financial Corporation, one of the nation's largest mortgage banking firms. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, American Can said that it had purchased the Lomas shares as an investment.

title: INSIDE
description: Paying for a Papal Visit A California diocese's plan to charge admission and to auction broadcast rights for a papal mass next Sept. 17 has created a controversy. Page A16.

title: Connors Optimistic
description: Jimmy Connors, whose right knee was injured in the final of the United States Indoor championships in Memphis last Sunday, will be sidelined for only a short period of time, according to his attorney. ''Jimmy had the knee examined and X-rayed by doctors in St. Louis Monday, and there appears to be no ligament or cartilage damage,'' Irving Blumberg, the attorney, said in a statement released by ProServ, the company managing Connors's business affairs. ''The injury has been diagnosed as a sprained knee. Connors will be sidelined on a day-to-day basis, pending results of physical therapy,'' Blumberg said.

title: Children's Museum to Grow
description: A planetarium and a four-level addition will be part of a $14 million expansion plan for the Children's Museum here, museum officials announced Monday. The expansion will add 78,000 square feet of exhibition, office and storage space to the 228,000-square-foot building.

title: MICROS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEVADA POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PLAN FOR LIVE SOVIET TV IN U.S. SHIFTS
description: International legal tangles are altering The Discovery Channel's plans to broadcast more than 60 hours of Soviet television programs live to an American audience each week. Instead, the channel is relying heavily on tapes of the Soviet programs.

title: DEDUCTION SEEKERS FIND BENEFITS AND BARRICADES
description: Over the next few weeks, millions of Americans will see the fruits of their year-end maneuverings to take full advantage of the transition from the old tax system to the new one. But for some, the savings may be less than expected.

title: LEAR SIEGLER SELLING SEVERAL OF ITS UNITS
description: The new owners of Lear Siegler Inc. said today that they would sell several of the company's recreation and agriculture subsidiaries.

title: HEARTLAND EXPRESS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Piniella Starts Fresh
description: The door to the manager's office was shut. Behind it, Lou Piniella gathered with his coaching staff, engaged in another planning session that is designed to make the early days of spring training productive for the Yankees. On the eve of the first day of his second season as the Yankee manager, Piniella is arming himself with preparedness.

title: HADRON INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
We Can't Afford the Health Plan
description: The American family has a dilemma. Our grandparents face the possibility of catastrophic illness, and we are asked to help pay for care that we cannot afford.

title: Honeywell Sees 2 Profitable Years
description: Edson W. Spencer, chairman of Honeywell Inc., told analysts the company is ''committed to exceeding earnings of $6 a share in 1988.'' Mr. Spencer also repeated a projection that 1987 earnings would exceed $5 a share.

title: RECOGNITION EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
XIOX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ENGRAPH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of about $225,000 from reversal of investment tax credits and a gain of $171,000, or 3 cents a share, from a change in pension accounting for both the quarter and year.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL KNICKS VS. CLEVELAND CAVALIERS, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.) NETS VS. GOLDEN STATE WARRIORS, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:30 P.M. (TV -SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNEW 1130, 7:30 P.M.) BOSTON CELTICS VS. ROCKETS, at Houston (TV - WTBS, 8:05 P.M.) COLLEGES: Robert Morris at L.I.U. (TV - Channel 25, 9 P.M., tape delay) Providence at Syracuse (Radio - WNYE-FM 91.5, 7:30 P.M.) U.N.L.V. at Long Beach State (TV - FNN-SCORE, 10 P.M.) South Carolina at Memphis State (TV -ESPN, 7 P.M.) North Carolina State at Duke (TV - ESPN, 9P.M.) U.C.L.A. at Oregon State (TV - ESPN, 11 P.M.) GOLF P.G.A. TOUR: Los Angeles Open, Riviera Country Club, Pacific Palisades, Calif. L.P.G.A. TOUR: Tsmura Hawaiian Ladies Open, Turtle Bay Country Club, Oahu, Hawaii HOCKEY RANGERS VS. BLACK HAWKS, at Chicago, 8:35 P.M. (TV - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS HARNESS RACING: Roosevelt, 7:30 P.M. Meadowlands, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, midnight) THOROUGHBRED RACING: Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. (TV -SportsChannel, 6:30 P.M. and 11:30 P.M.)

title: Independent Millsport
description: Millsport, a sports marketing unit that was established within Doyle Dane Bernbach in 1981, has become an independent company. title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14, A18 Halting U.S. aid for the contras was backed, 11 to 9, by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. However, the bill will be vetoed by President Reagan if it eventually passes both houses of Congress. Page A1 Radical changes in the contras are sought by Arturo Cruz, the Nicaraguan rebel leader who is seeking to control the anti-Sandinista movement. He seeks an expanded civilian directorate with complete control of funds. A6 Lebanese militiamen fought battles in Beirut unrivaled in their fury, using heavy artillery and tank assaults to seize key positions. Officials said 50 people had been killed and 120 wounded. A1 Robert M. Gates seemed headed for Senate confirmation as Director of Central Intelligence after hearings that reflected Congressional anger over the Reagan Administration's Iran dealings. A1 News analysis: Data on N.S.C. misdeeds uncovered by a Presidential panel are likely to include disclosures that could lead to criminal prosecutions, according to officials who have seen the panel's report. A1 400,000 Mozambicans may starve to death, according to Mozambican and Western aid officials. They said up to one-third of the population was suffering sever food shortages resulting from guerrilla warfare. A18 Cambodians still face abuses in refugee camps in Thailand, according to the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights. The group said the refugees were often victimized by heavily armed Cambodian bandits. A3 American Rembrandt scholars think that five paintings in American museums are by the Master. Dutch experts have downgraded the works and have removed them from the canon of works entirely by him. A1 Opposition victor in Irish election A3 Woman with mission in Brasilia A4 U.S. and Soviet review arms stand A9 Iran chokes on German joke A12 National A16-17, A20-28, B6 Donald T. Regan's future as White House chief of staff was the subject of new speculation. President Reagan, in an informal exchange with reporters, said that Mr. Regan's future was ''up to him.'' A1 Opponents of Central America policy have been burglarized 50 times. The victims fear they are under attack by the Reagan Administration or by conservative groups possibly working with Government officials. A1 The Reagan Administration will issue guidelines today for widespread testing of Federal employees to determine if they have used illicit drugs, Administration officials said yesterday. A1 The ozone shield must be protected by a global agreement, members of Congress said. They backed a bill to gradually eliminate Americans' use of chemicals that destroy the earth's atmospheric ozone. B6 The secrets sold to Israel by Jonathan Jay Pollard, a former Navy intelligence analyst, dealt as serious a blow to national security as any other espionage case in American history, prosecutors said. A21 A pilot program using polygraphs to screen applicants for Pentagon security clearance has been conducted in a way that makes it impossible to judge the validity of the tests, a report ordered by Congress said. A27 The U.S. death penalty was assailed by Amnesty International in its first major criticism of America. The organization called the penalty the ''ultimate form of cruel, inhuman and degrading punishment.'' A17 John Landis acknowledged breaking a California law by hiring two child actors without permits. The director testified against charges in the deaths of three actors while filming ''Twilight Zone: The Movie.'' A20 Powerful Mexican diet pills have dangerous side effects, American officials say. They are trying to halt the flow of a drug called Redotex, which includes a stimulant, a laxative and a tranquilizer. A24 Many taxpayers rushed to make extra-large charitable contributions and otherwise seek deductions as 1986 ended. Some of these actions will benefit them greatly, but others face stricter rules. D1 At-home shopping is increasing significantly among Americans. The growth of the phenomenon has been fueled by catalogues, electronic shopping via computers and television shopping services. C1 Fine woods are winning rising favor with architects and designers. The trend is reflected in new libraries in the Ralph Lauren store, the Rizzoli bookstore and the National Academy of Design. C1 Atlanta in frenzy over convention A2 Wrong E.P.A. priorities cited B6 Washington Talk A28 Q&A: Daniel Patrick Moynihan The Buchanan aggravation Regional B1-4 Human error caused the crash of a Metro-North northbound train carrying 400 passengers and an empty southbound train that injured 27 people, according to Peter Stangl, the head of the commuter railroad. A1 Four cultural centers overstated attendance figures they submitted to the New York City agency that gave them grants of $40 million a year in 1984 and 1985, a state audit said. They are the Bronx Zoo, the Botanical Garden, the Museum of Natural History and the Metropolitan Museum. B1 Two suspects were held without bail on Federal murder-for-hire charges involving the shooting and critical wounding last week of Pietro Alfano, a defendant in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial. B4 A police official has been cleared in an internal inquiry of any wrongdoing concerning his ties with a reputed crime figure. The official is Peter J. Prezioso, a former Intelligence Division chief. B4 A revolutionary was sentenced to life in prison for the murder of New Jersey State Trooper Philip J. Lamonaco. The term for Thomas W. Manning must follow a 53-year term he is serving for bombings. title: MUSIC: SYLVAN QUINTET
description: WOODWIND quintets have proliferated in this age of conservatory overachievement, with so many talented young players being poured out into the marketplace. title: Surgery for Dawkins
description: Darryl Dawkins, the Nets center, underwent surgery at Lenox Hill Hospital yesterday to correct back problems that have sidelined him for all but six games this season. Dawkins underwent microsurgery on his back last May to repair nerve damage. ''We're hopeful the operation was successful and Darryl can play again,'' said Coach Dave Wohl in a statement. Dawkins played in only 39 games in the 1984-85 season after a back injury and missed the final 31 games last season with another back injury before returning for the playoffs. Dawkins's problems this season started Nov. 13 when he slipped in his shower at his home. Dawkins is in the final year of a five-year contract that reportedly paid him $800,000 a year.

title: THE STAGE: 'KVETCH,' STEVEN BERKOFF COMEDY
description: ''KVETCH,'' as in the title of Steven Berkoff's new comedy, is a complaint, which, if allowed to fester, can become an anxiety attack. title: Focus on Bosworth
description: A stir was created yesterday when photographs of Brian Bosworth appeared in advertising for a group of fitness centers. A school official said that the photographs appeared to violate National Collegiate Athletic Association rules and could make the all-America linebacker ineligible for a final season with Oklahoma. But the president of the Tulsa-based fitness center that used the pictures said that the promotion was planned without Bosworth's knowledge or permission. ''We didn't realize what a commotion or stir-up could be caused,'' said Jim Benien, president of the All American Fitness and Racquetball Center. ''We never even talked to Bosworth.'' Gary Reall, director of advertising for the center, told The Tulsa Tribune that the photos were used with Bosworth's knowledge, but later said he had spoken only with a friend of Bosworth and had not received permission for use of his photo. Bosworth was not available for comment yesterday.

title: CORRECTIONS

title: TAGGING FISH OFFERS NETFUL OF REWARDS
description: As you are sorting out and refurbishing your saltwater angling gear for the coming season, you might give thought to becoming a tagger of fish. Last year was the busiest in almost a decade in the American Littoral Society's fish-tagging program, and the organization would like to see an even more active 1987.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Custom storm windows that were installed last year sweat on the inside in cold weather. Is this normal, or is the installation faulty? Can I do anything? A. Usually this is caused by a lack of adequate weatherstripping on the prime (original) windows. This lets warm, moist air from inside seep around the sash into the space between the two windows. The storm window is colder than the inside window, so the moisture in the warm air condenses on the surface of the colder glass - much as a pitcher of ice water sweats in the summer.

title: Welfare and the Politics of Poverty
description: For 20 years, Daniel Patrick Moynihan has cautioned in books and lectures about the disintegration of poor American families and the need to create a national policy to rescue them. Recently the Democratic Senator from New York took a big step in this direction.

title: The Curious Case of the Incurious C.I.A.
description: The Central Intelligence Agency, the nation's professional eyes and ears on the world, can also be good at seeing no evil and hearing none. Robert Gates, former deputy to William Casey and nominee to succeed him as C.I.A. director, has told the Senate Intelligence Committee that the agency avoided learning how the Nicaraguan rebels were getting their money. Why? ''In part because we were concerned it would get us involved in crossing the line imposed by the law.''

description: Hogtying is regularly practiced on farms, ranches and in slaughterhouses to weigh, butcher and otherwise restrain four-legged creatures. A variant is irregularly practiced by the Mafia: a thick cord is wrapped around the victim's throat and then fastened to his hands and feet, which are bound behind his back. As the victim's arms and legs weaken, he gradually strangles.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Celtics 113, Mavericks 96: Kevin McHale scored 28 points as Boston snapped a two-game losing streak last night. Boston, which avoided its first three-game losing streak since 1983, silenced the sellout crowd of 17,007 fans in Reunion Arena early. The Celtics surged to a 67-46 halftime lead after outscoring the Mavericks by 37-17 in the second period, and they built a 31-point lead midway through the third quarter. Dallas cut the lead to 14 points with a 13-0 run in the final quarter but the rally ended when McHale re-entered the game and scored two baskets.(AP) 76ers 114, Warriors 103: Andrew Toney, Maurice Cheeks and Charles Barkley combined for 75 points as the 76ers held off a late Golden State rally in Philadelphia. Toney scored 27 points, Cheeks had 25 and Barkley 23 as the 76ers handed the Warriors their 11th loss in 14 games. Barkley also grabbed 18 rebounds and Cheeks had 14 assists. The Warriors were assessed six technical fouls, including four for illegal defenses, one againsst George Karl and another on Floyd. Philadelphia dressed only nine players, with Julius Erving, Cliff Robinson and David Wingate sidelined with various ailments.(AP) Cavaliers 129, Kings 119: Brad Daugherty scored a season-high 33 points, 10 of them in the final five and a half minutes, to help the Cavaliers snap the Kings' three-game winning streak. Daugherty and two fellow rookies, Ron Harper and John Williams, scored 6 points apiece during a 22-6 run that rallied the Cavaliers from a 104-97 deficit to a 119-110 lead with just over two minutes to play in Richfield, Ohio.(AP) Pacers 105, SuperSonics 88: John Long scored 29 points and four other Pacers scored in double figures as Indiana gained its fifth victory in its last seven games. The Pacers, playing at home, led from start to finish as they jumped to a 8-0 lead. Chuck Person had 10 of his 15 points in the first period.(AP) N.H.L. Oilers 9, Maple Leafs 2: Wayne Gretzky scored once in the first period and set up four second-period goals to pace Edmonton. The 5 points gave Gretzky 9 in two games against Toronto this season and 75 career points against the Leafs. Gretzky's goal was the 534th of his career, moving him ahead of Frank Mahovlich, a former Maple Leaf, and into sole possession of eighth place on the career scoring list.(AP) Sabres 4, Bruins 3: Dave Andreychuk, John Tucker and Mike Foligno scored Buffalo's first three goals during a 3:07 span early in the third period in Buffalo. Phil Housley scored the eventual winning goal for the Sabres. Greg Johnston, Steve Kasper and Ken Linseman tallied for the Bruins. It was Boston's fourth straight loss; the Sabres have won six of their last seven.(AP) Skiing Lewis and Fletcher Win: Doug Lewis and Pam Fletcher, two United States Ski Team veterans who have endured nonproductive seasons on the World Cup circuit, captured the men's and women's downhills yesterday on the opening day of the United States Alpine championships in Crested Butte, Colo. Lewis, 23 years old, of Salisbury, Vt., was timed in 1 minute 23.80 seconds on a relatively short men's course. Andreas Rickenbach, 20, of Pleasanton, Calif., was second in 1:24.07, followed by Alan Lauba of Bellevue, Wash., in 1:24.82. Lewis, acknowledged as America's best downhiller here in the absence of the injured Bill Johnson, had paced the final men's training run on Tuesday by nearly two seconds, although officials later said he had missed a gate. Fletcher, 24, of Acton, Mass., finished more than a full second ahead of the defending national downhill champion, Hilary Lindh. Fletcher was clocked in 1:22.32. Lindh, 17, of Juneau, Alaska, had a time of 1:23.41, followed by Carter Payne, 18, of Aspen, Colo., in 1:23.60.(AP) Soviet Women Take Title: Paced by an unknown, late addition to its team, the Soviet Union took the women's 20-kilometer relay title and captured its first gold medal at the Nordic world championships in Oberstdorf, West Germany. Racing third, Nina Gavriluk stole the spotlight from her better known teammates by posting the fastest individual stage and leading a Soviet rally. The Soviet time was 58 minutes 8.8 seconds. Norway took the silver in 58:46.1 and Sweden gained the bronze medal.(AP) Horse Racing Belocolus First by a Nose: Belocolus took the lead from pace-setting Alioth in midstretch yesterday and then barely lasted to withstand the late rush of Road to Ponder to score a nose victory in the $45,000 allowance feature for 4-year-olds and up at Aqueduct. Belocolus went the mile and a sixteenth under Jerry Bailey in 1:44 1/5 on the fast track to record his second victory in four starts this year. The 4-year-old son of Big Spruce returned $5.40 for $2 to win as the favorite.

title: A.B.A. Picks President-Elect
description: Robert D. Raven, a lawyer from San Francisco, was selected Tuesday to become president of the American Bar Association next year. Mr. Raven, a 63-year-old senior partner in the firm of Morrison & Foerster, was named president-elect of the 330,000-lawyer group. He will succeed Robert MacCrate, a New York lawyer who will take over as the association's president in August.

title: HUMAN ERROR CITED IN RAIL CRASH
description: Human error caused Tuesday evening's crash in the Bronx of two Metro-North Commuter Railroad trains that injured 27 people and delayed throngs of commuters, the railroad's president said yesterday.

title: Ready for Comeback
description: Mitchell Wiggins, the former Houston Rockets' guard who was banned from the National Basketball Association after having tested positive for cocaine, said he was ready to resume playing. Wiggins, who completed a rehabilitation program, said he hoped to sign with a Continental Basketball Association team. ''I want people to know that I'm on the path back, not just in terms of basketball but in terms of getting my life straightened out,'' Wiggins said while on a visit to the Rockets' offices. Carl Scheer, the C.B.A.'s commissioner, said no decision had been made on whether Wiggins would be welcome. Wiggins, who was banned Jan. 13 with a teammate, Lewis Lloyd, cannot seek readmission to the N.B.A. until January 1989.

title: LIFTING POLISH SANCTIONS IS PART OF NEW POLICY

title: HIGHCHAIRS COMBINING FUNCTION AND STYLE
description: HANDSOME and functional highchairs are sometimes hard to find. The most useful are made of materials that are easy to clean and will not absorb the food that a baby inevitably spills. To be avoided are chairs upholstered in cloying pastels or animal patterns that clash with a room's decor. A search of stores turned up five highchairs that vary in style from a simple molded plastic bucket seat to an elaborate turn-of-the-century wicker version.

title: Shipyard Orders Drop
description: The number of merchant ships on order from shipyards worldwide was 3.6 percent lower at the end of 1986 than it was three months earlier, Lloyd's Register of Shipping said today. There were 2,168 vessels on order at the end of December, compared with 2,249 at the end of September, the London-based trade publication reported. The December tonnage on order was 21.36 million, down from 23.41 million tons in September. Japanese shipyards led the number of orders, with 6.57 million tons and 333 vessels, followed by South Korea with 4.22 million tons and 112 vessels.

title: STAGE: MUSIC AND PUPPETS IN 'DEFENDERS OF THE CODE'

Now she expands her canvas in order to probe and to test everything from creation myths to theories of eugenics.

Beginning March 1, ceramic vessels with wooden handles, batik clothing, hand-woven shawls and silver, ceramic and beaded jewelry will be among the works shown by New York artists. Hours, 1 to 5 P.M. Wednesday through Friday and Sunday; 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Saturday. Antique and Collectible Show and Sale, Garden State Plaza, intersection of Routes 4 and 17, Paramus, N.J., 201-262-3063. Tuesday through Saturday, 10 A.M. to 9:30 P.M., period furniture, vintage linens and clothing, 30's radios, estate jewelry and silver. Appraisals daily, 3 to 9 P.M. Free admission. Popular Art Deco, New School for Social Research, 66 West 12th Street, 212-741-5690. Tonight at 7:45, a lecture with slides by John Gilman and Robert Heide. Collecting well-designed dime-store memorabilia of the 30's, and movie and cartoon collectibles will be among the subjects discussed. Fee $10. The American Movie Palace, Flushing High School library, 35-01 Union Street, at Northern Boulevard, Flushing, 718-939-0647. Saturday at 1 P.M., an illustrated lecture sponsored by the Queens Hstorical Society will focus on the elegant movie houses rof the past, with special attention to the surviving R.K.O.-Keith in Flushing and the St. George on Staten Island. Architecture, interior design and history will be discussed in the one-hour lecture by Frank Cronican. Fee, adults, $1; children under 12 years old, 25 cents. Garden Lecture, Bridgehampton Community House, Main Street, Bridgehampton, L.I., 516-267-6025. Saturday, Feb. 28, at 7:30 P.M. the Horticultural Alliance of the Hamptons will sponsor an illustrated lecture, ''Garden Influences in My Life,'' by the author Rosemary Verey about English gardens and those she has visited in her travels. A $5 donation is suggested. Dual-Function Furniture Exhibition, the Gallery at Workbench, 470 Park Avenue South, at 32d Street, 212-481-5454. From Feb. 26, the exhibition ''Double-Up'' will show the works of 12 furniture artists, including a mahogany armchair that can be turned into a library ladder, a settle table that serves as a settee and a dining table, and a zigzag coffee table with storage drawers. Through April 5. Hours, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Monday through Saturday; 10 A.M. to 8 P.M. Thursday; noon to 5 P.M. Sunday. Doll Houses and Miniatures Show, the Cathedral House, 50 Cathedral Avenue, near Sixth Street, Garden City, L.I., 516-746-7567 or 516-746-7554. Saturday, Feb. 28, from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. a show of doll houses will include houses in a range of period styles as well as contemporary houses and shops. Miniature furniture, kitchen appliances, wallpapers, curtains, quilts and doll families will be displayed and for sale. Entries are welcome; call for entry guidelines. Prizes for doll-house decoration by adults and children will be awarded. Proceeds will benefit the physician training program at Winthrop University Hospital in Mineola. Admission, adults $2.50; children under 12, $1.50. Free parking.

title: FAUCETS SAY 'TOO HOT'
description: YOU are standing at the sink, washing the dishes, when your neighbor flushes the toilet, robbing the tap of its cold water and turning it hot. Before you can jerk your hands from the water, the temperature soars to somewhere near the boiling point, turning your hands fire-engine red.

description: * Magna International Inc., Markham, Ontario, said its Concord Group unit would build a $20 million plastic injection-molding assembly plant in Pickering, Ontario.

title: DATAREX SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Little by Little
description: A surprising number of sub-6-footers have made a big impact in college basketball this season.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL LOS ANGELES (NL) - Signed Franklin Stubbs, first baseman-outfielder; Ralph Bryant and Jose Gonzalez, outfielders; Brian Holton and Balvino Galvez, pitchers; Craig Shipley, shortstop; and Jeff Hamilton, third baseman, to one-year contracts. METS (NL) - Signed Keith Miller, infielder, to a one-year contract and Andre David, outfielder, to a minor-league contract. BASKETBALL INDIANA (NBA) - Fined Chuck Person, forward, $91 for showing up late for practice. COLLEGE LAKE SUPERIOR STATE - Named Jim Fallis, interim athletic director, athletic director. TULSA - Announced suspension of Don Royster, center, from the basketball team. FOOTBALL LOS ANGELES (NFC) - Named Ernie Zampese offensive coordinator. MINNESOTA (NFC) - Named Rollie Dotsch assistant offense coach. SAN DIEGO (AFC) - Named Dave Levy, offensive line coach, offensive coordinator and Roger Theder quarterback coach.

title: Amnesty International Assails U.S. on Executions
description: Amnesty International announced yesterday that it was opening a worldwide campaign against the death penalty in the United States, calling it the ''ultimate form of cruel, inhuman and degrading punishment.''

title: J. RAYMOND YLITALO
description: J. Raymond Ylitalo, former United States Ambassador to Paraguay, died of cancer on Feb. 10 at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington. He was 70 years old and lived in Washington.

title: VARO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $2,625,000 for the quarter and $3,160,000 for the 9 months.

title: A LOOK AT BLAIR HOUSE IN MID-RESTORATION
description: When the draperies were removed five years ago from the windows of Blair House, the President's guest house for visiting heads of state, they disintegrated. Also, the gas boiler nearly exploded and a chandelier came crashing down, fortunately on an empty bed.

title: Michaels Protests
description: Walt Michaels, the former coach of the Jets, has reportedly told National Football League officials that he suspects collusion among the 26 owners has prevented him getting another coaching job. Michaels, who has not coached in the N.F.L. for four years, met Tuesday at the league's offices in New York with Don Weiss, the league's executive director, and Jay Moyer, counsel to Commissioner Pete Rozelle, The New Haven Journal Courier reported. During the meeting, Michaels reportedly said that there had been false reports that he had suffered from drug and alcohol dependency. ''I have to believe,'' Michaels was quoted as saying after the meeting, ''that there's somebody who, for personal reasons, wants to keep me out of coaching and who is circulating a false and malicious story which attacks my character.''

title: FAIRFIELD-NOBLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RCM TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Colorado Avalanche Kills One
description: A large avalanche swept down a mountainside near the Breckenridge ski area today, killing at least one person.

title: PARKWAY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BAIL IS DENIED 2 IN SHOOTING IN 'PIZZA CONNECTION' CASE
description: Two suspects were held without bail yesterday on Federal murder-for-hire charges involving the shooting of a defendant in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial.

description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. on South Africa. GENERAL ASSEMBLY Special Committee on U.N. Charter - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. title: YANKEE COS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $120,000 and $4,165,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and an extraordinary loss of $569,000 for both periods. c-Net income and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $13,000 and $136,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and an extraordinary gain of $550,000 for both periods. The company said that during the fourth quarter of fiscal 1986 it changed the method of recording earnings for its Eskey Inc. subsidiary from the equity method to the consolidated method for the entire fiscal year. The company said that 1985 amounts are restated to reflect a change in the method of accounting from the full cost method to the successful effort method for oil and gas producing activities during fiscal 1986.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1987
description: COMPANIES

title: CONCERT: FRESK QUARTET
description: THE Fresk Quartet, which hails from Sweden, is best known in the United States for its recording of the complete string quartets of Wilhelm Stenhammar. On Sunday afternoon at the Frick Collection, the quartet played Haydn's Quartet (Op. 64, No. 5, ''Lark''), Debussy's Quartet in G minor (Op. 10), an unfamiliar 20-year-old work by a contemporary Swedish composer, Jan Carlstedt, and, as a lagniappe, a Ballade by Stenhammar.

title: SUPERIOR HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $108,000 from the extinguishment of debt for the quarter, and for the 9 months includes an extraordinary credit of $789,000.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $207,000. c-Net loss
