CORRECTIONS
description: The Executive Changes listing in Business Day yesterday misstated Susan M. Boyle's new position at the Xerox Corporation. She is senior vice president of Xerox Financial Services Inc.

title: What's So Mere About an Illustrator?
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: ALLEGIS It's pronounced uh-LEE-jis, but what is it? Business Day, page D1. Doubts on E.P.A. Priorities The priorities at the Environmental Protection Agency have been questioned in an internal report by senior staff members. Page B6.

title: 700 U.S. PARATROOPERS FIGHTING MOCK BATTLES IN HILLS OF HONDURAS
description: American paratroopers are engaged here in the most extensive training exercise of its kind in four years, to be ready if they are ordered to fight in Honduras or elsewhere in Central America.

title: WITH THE DEMOCRATS COMING, IMAGE MANIA GRIPS ATLANTA
description: The expected arrival of 15,000 journalists would shake even the cockiest city. In Atlanta, which has spent the past 100 years selling itself to a somewhat skeptical North, it has caused a kind of civic-minded mania.

title: Civil Remedy
description: It's not unusual for corporations to correct dangerous practices because they fear civil damage suits. The risk of multimillion-dollar judgments attracts their attention in ways that even criminal charges against individual officers might not. What is unusual is for such a judgment to be rendered against a corporation called the United Klans of America - and for it to come from an all-white jury in Alabama.

title: HUDSON GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Col. North Said to Get Foundation Financing
description: A conservative fund-raiser set up a foundation to finance trips to Central America by Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North when he was on the staff of the National Security Council, ABC News reported today.

title: How About Espo '88?
description: Phil Esposito should reconsider, perhaps, his decision to quit the bench at season's end. After exactly 2,000 games in the history of the franchise, the standing of all the Rangers' head coaches is: W L T Pct.* Phil Esposito 15 5 0 .750 Emile Francis 342 209 103 .602 Lester Patrick 281 216 107 .554 Larry Popein 18 14 9 .549 Bernie Geoffrion 22 18 3 .547 Herb Brooks 131 113 41 .532 Fred Shero 82 74 24 .522 Phil Watson 118 124 52 .490 Craig Patrick 37 45 13 .458 Doug Harvey 26 32 12 .457 Jean-Guy Talbot 30 37 13 .456 ynn Patrick 40 51 16 .449 Ted Sator 41 48 10 .465 Tom Webster 5 7 4 .438 Ron Stewart 15 20 4 .436 John Ferguson 43 59 19 .434 Muzz Patrick 46 66 27 .428 Frank Boucher 179 263 83 .420 Neil Colville 26 41 26 .419 Bill Cook 34 59 24 .393 Red Sullivan 58 103 35 .385 Alf Pike 36 66 21 .378 Eddie Giacomin- 0 2 0 .000 Wayne Cashman * Total points divided by total possible points.

title: MOUNTAIN MEDICAL EQUIPENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: SENATE UNIT BACKS HALT IN REBEL AID IN NICARAGUA NOW
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted today to halt funds for the Nicaraguan rebels in the first major test in the new Congress of the Reagan Administration's policy toward Central America.

title: Some Antitrust Laws Apply to Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: DIRECTOR OF COOPER-HEWITT PLANS TO RESIGN
description: Lisa S. Taylor, who as director of the Cooper-Hewitt Museum for nearly two decades increased the public's awareness of historical and contemporary design, said yesterday that she planned to resign because of ill health.

title: UNRIVALED CLASHES RAGING IN STREETS OF WESTERN BEIRUT
description: Militiamen fought street battles today that were unparalleled in their intensity for factional disputes in Moslem West Beirut, using heavy artillery and tank assaults to occupy key positions.

title: Air France to Buy 7 Airbus A340's
description: Air France, the French state airline, said it would buy seven A340 jetliners produced by Airbus Industrie, the European consortium. The airline, the only carrier aside from West Germany's Lufthansa to commit itself to the project, said terms of the purchase were not completed.

title: STUDY SHOWS SHARP RISE IN COCAINE USE BY SUSPECTS IN CRIMES
description: Cocaine use among men arrested for serious crimes in Manhattan almost doubled in two years, to nearly 80 percent, according to projections from a federally financed study completed last fall.

title: UNITED STOCKYARDS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results for 1986 have been restated to reflect United's policy adopted during 1986 of valuing its current marketable securities portfolio at market value.

title: RYMER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $303,000 for the latest quarter and $286,000 for the year-ago period. Preferred dividend payments were about $100,000 higher in the year-ago first quarter.

title: Palestinian Driver Dies In Clash With Israelis
description: A Palestinian taxi driver was killed today when he ran down and injured two Israeli soldiers, was shot at by other patrolmen and ran his car into a wall in the Askar refugee center in the West Bank, a military spokesman said.

title: Night Trading Set By Chicago Board
description: The Chicago Board of Trade's directors have set April 2 as the target date to begin night trading, pending approval of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

title: A Russian Sailor Defects
description: A Soviet sailor who told the Swedish police he did not like the Soviet system defected when his ship's crew was allowed ashore for shopping. A police spokesman said the man was 28 years old and had a wife and 3-year-old son in the Soviet Union.

title: PENNEY, J C CO INC reports earnings for 14wks to Jan 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary charges on debt restructuring of $17 million for the quarter and $52 million for the year. The latest periods included 14 weeks for the quarter and 53 weeks for the year, compared to year-ago 13 weeks and 52 weeks, respectively.

title: AN ARTIST'S JOURNEY FROM OBSCURITY TO SUCCESS
description: In the fall of 1981, the artist Ross Bleckner showed his newest paintings at the Mary Boone gallery in SoHo. They were unusual works -mostly paintings of vertical stripes that resembled Op Art - and the show was a flop. Not a single major critic reviewed the show, and only one of the works sold.

title: 1987 SEASON OF CITY OPERA INCLUDES 4 NEW PRODUCTIONS
description: The New York City Opera's 1987 regular season will open July 7 at the New York State Theater and continue for 130 performances of 17 operas until Nov. 15, the company announced yesterday. There will be four new productions of six programs - two of them double bills.

title: PONDERING BEETHOVEN'S METRONOME
description: IN Beethoven's later years, the metronome was becoming recognized as a valuable tool for a composer to indicate preferred tempos. Deaf and ill-tempered, complaining about the trouble it took, Beethoven nonetheless worked away at the task of supplying his publishers with tempo indications not only for the music he was composing, but also for scores he had already composed.

title: AMERICAN MANAGEMENT SYSEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Happiest Laker
description: The standard practice among professional sports teams is to administer a thorough physical to any player obtained in a trade. Any unexpected problem, such as a weak knee or perhaps a previously undetected back ailment, usually voids the transaction. No questions asked.

title: DYNALECTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,538,000 and $4,277,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: NOMADS' TENTS AS ART FORM
description: LEAD: THE landscape inhabited by pastoral nomads in the great swath from North Africa to Central Asia is stark and bleak. But the interiors of their tents are a dazzling explosion of color and decoration. Perhaps in compensation for the harsh surroundings, even the simplest utilitarian objects are lovingly embellished.

title: DePAUL OVERPOWERS IONA, 96-82
description: Gary Brokaw, the Iona College coach, knew going into last night's game that in terms of talent and size, his team had little chance of defeating once-beaten DePaul.

title: Bush Names New Press Aide
description: Vice President Bush named a new press secretary Tuesday. He is Larry Thomas, a former political writer for The San Diego Union who has been spokesman for Gov. George Deukmejian of California since 1982. Mr. Thomas, who is 39 years old, succeeds Marlin Fitzwater, who replaced Larry Speakes earlier this month as the chief White House spokesman.

title: HPSC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-After a charge of $1.7 million due to the retroactive repeal of the investment tax credit.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: IT would be easy to hang shelves, cabinets, large mirrors or other heavy objects on a hollow interior wall if you could always place the objects directly over vertical studs inside the wall - that way, you could just drive in nails or screws long enough to go through the plaster or dry wall and into the stud.

title: Lucky to Sell Chain
description: Lucky Stores Inc. said it had agreed to sell its Yellow Front Stores subsidiary for about $50 million to a corporation owned by Kenmare, a private company controlled by Daniel J. Sullivan. Yellow Front, based in Phoenix, operates 104 general merchandise stores in eight Rocky Mountain states. The sale is the latest of several divestitures by Lucky, a grocery chain based in Dublin, Calif., which is restructuring in an attempt to avoid a takeover by the New York investor Asher B. Edelman. Last week Mr. Edelman disclosed that he had resumed buying Lucky shares and that, with partners, he held about 6.7 percent of its stock.

title: CABARET: YMA SUMAC
description: HORDES of Manhattan's more exotic ''celebutantes'' packed the Ballroom (253 West 28th Street) Tuesday night for the return of Yma Sumac, the 59-year-old Peruvian vocal acrobat who was making her first Manhattan appearance in 14 years.

title: METRO TEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DIRECTOR TESTIFIES IN 3 FILM DEATHS
description: The film director John Landis testified today at his trial on manslaughter charges that he knowlingly violated California labor law by having two children work on the set of the movie ''Twilight Zone'' at night without permits. The two children were killed in the filming, along with the actor Vic Morrow.

title: A Nomination in Peril
description: In six years in office, President Reagan has been able to appoint many conservatives to Federal judgeships, enjoying the Republicans' control of the Senate, which passes on such nominations. But now that the Democrats have regained the majority in the Senate, they have served notice on the White House that nominations for judgeships will be subjected to the closest scrutiny, and one may already be headed for some trouble.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a transmission error, a dispatch on Feb. 10 from Palo Alto, Calif., about Stanford University and an accompanying picture caption misidentified the wife of the university's founder. She was Jane Stanford.

title: VARI-CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 4-for-3 stock split in the form oa a 33.3-percent distribution issued September 1986.

title: SHAMIR AND CONGRESS REACH ACCORD ON RULES FOR INQUIRY
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir reached an agreement with Congress today on the procedures for the Congressional investigation of the Israeli role in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Boyd Loses Pay Bid
description: Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd lost his salary arbitration case and will receive $550,000 this season, the Boston Red Sox announced. The 27-year-old right-hander, who had a career-high 16 victories last season against 10 losses with a 3.78 earned run average, was seeking $695,000. Boyd earned $375,000 in 1986 in helping Boston win its first pennant since 1975. But the season had its stormy elements. In July, after learning that he had been left off the American League's All-Star team, Boyd threw a tantrum in the Red Sox clubhouse and was suspended for three days without pay. ''We just stuck strictly to statistics, we kept away from all the personal things,'' General Manager Lou Gorman said. ''And Dennis seemed in a very good frame of mind. I kidded him at one point for sitting throughout the four-hour hearing. I'd never seen him sit for so long.'' . . . Jesse Barfield, scheduled to go to arbitration today with the Toronto Blue Jays, agreed on a one-year contract. Terms of the contract were not released. Barfield, baseball's home-run leader last season with 40, had bid $1,350,000 in arbitration, and the Blue Jays had offered $1,125,000.

title: Chief Justice Who?
description: Opening his speech to the American Bar Association convention in New Orleans the other day, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist said he had just seen a public opinion survey, conducted for the Hearst Corporation, showing that his name had been designated by 43 percent of those asked to identify the current Chief Justice of the United States from a list of four names.

title: Islands Without Fear
description: This column is about a large bunch of wonderfully hideous marine iguanas, some herds of sea lions, a few penguins and how meeting them gave me the most unexpected and exhilarating sensation in decades of travel. Even if you do not particularly care for animals do read on because psychic and social significance are lurking lower down.

title: In Moscow: Louder Than Words
description: Mikhail Gorbachev has found the way to begin persuading his own people and the West of his sincerity. He doesn't merely give speeches about peaceful intentions abroad and glasnost - openness - at home. He frees Russians who have been unjustly imprisoned. The other day it was the release of Anatoly Koryagin, who blew the whistle on the use of phony psychiatric institutes to punish dissenters. Yesterday it was the promise to free Iosif Begun, whose crime was to teach Hebrew and to seek emigration.

title: THE CORDIAL CONFLICT ON REMBRANDT CONTINUES
description: No matter what the Dutch say, American Rembrandt scholars believe that five disputed paintings in American museums - including two at the Metropolitan Museum of Art - are indeed by Rembrandt himself.

title: BABY M'S MOTHER EXAMINED ON HER FAMILY AND FACTS
description: Mary Beth Whitehead underwent five hours of intense cross-examination today on subjects ranging from her veracity to her marital and financial history; her brothers and sisters, and the impact on her daughter, Tuesday, of her fight for custody of Baby M. Under persistent and detailed questioning by Gary N. Skoloff, a lawyer for the baby's father, William Stern, Mrs. Whitehead was drawn into a number of inconsistencies in comments she has made on divorce, bankruptcy and the 87 days she spent in hiding in Florida last year with her husband, their two children and the infant girl.

title: Interest Rates Fall Modestly
description: Interest rates declined modestly for short- and long-term Treasury issues yesterday, as traders were encouraged by lower prices for oil and other commodities, as well as a drop in overnight interest rates.

title: NEWHALL LAND & FARMING reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INTEGRATED COMPUTERS GRAPHICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $54,477 for the quarter and $197,948 for the year. c-Includes tax credits of $80,332 for the quarter and $172,671 for the year.

title: Top Guru Sees A 3,600 Dow
description: WITH the Dow Jones industrial average having climbed to dizzying heights - up 18 percent this year alone - nervous investors keep wondering what they should do. Yesterday, the Dow edged ahead 0.14, closing at a record high of 2,237.63.

title: SMITHFIELD FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss of $2,097,000 and $4,533,000 for the latest and year-ago 9 months, respectively, and the year-ago 9 months also include a non-recurring gain of $2,682,000 from the termination of two pension plans. Results for 1985 periods are restated for adoption of FAS Nos. 87 and 88. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid October 1986.

title: HARMON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DECO APPLIANCES, NEWLY COLLECTIBLE
description: LEAD: COLLECTORS have begun to look with fresh eyes at irons from the 30's and 40's and other streamlined household and kitchen appliances.

title: Chemical Bank Begins Major Reorganization
description: The Chemical Bank yesterday announced a major management reorganization, establishing a corporate office of its four top executives and making Thomas S. Johnson the sole president of the bank and its holding company, the Chemical New York Corporation.

title: A Wimpy Winter
description: As New York winters go, this one has been undistinguished, showing no direction and not much will. The tipoff came in early December when forsythia bushes wishfully started to flower, either with laggard yellow blooms from last spring or impatient blooms for next. Later in the month some obligatory snow came, and then quickly went, leading some snowdrops to pop up prematurely and then be stiffened by a cold spell. Last weekend was bitter cold, as the homeless know better than anyone, but it was only a weekend. Statistically, this winter has been a little colder than last year but a little warmer than normal.

title: STATEN ISLAND WINS IN COURT, ON COURT
description: The basketball team of the College of Staten Island, which had been barred by its president from the City University tournament after a brawl that the president said had racial overtones, was reinstated into the tournament yesterday.

title: LAWTER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: STARTS OF HOUSING DIP 0.2%
description: Housing construction showed surprising strength in January, helped by unusually mild weather at the beginning of the month, the Government reported today.

title: Free, but Also Fair
description: To the Editor:

title: The Buchanan Aggravation
description: Patrick J. Buchanan, the White House director of communications, has been criticized before, but perhaps never with such passion.

title: Damaging Disclosures ON N.S.C. Expected
description: White House officials are growing increasingly apprehensive as the special Presidential commission studying the National Security Council completes a report that officials say is likely to include damaging new disclosures that could result in criminal charges.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. POLITICAL HOPES ON RISE
description: It has been little more than six years since Ronald Reagan took office as President, and not a few labor leaders here say that these have been the toughest years in the history of trade union movement in the United States.

title: POREX TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $26,534,000 on the exchange of subsidiary stock.

title: IRAN CHOKES ON GERMAN JOKE: LINGERIE HEAPED ON KHOMEINI
description: The West German Government said today that it regretted a television satire that showed the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini being showered with women's underwear, and the comedian responsible for it apologized to the Iranian Ambassador to Bonn.

title: THE CUP AND CHUCK RAYNER
description: Somehow the specter of the Stanley Cup the Rangers haven't won since 1940 seems to haunt this frustrated franchise even in its upbeat moments. For the first time in three years at this stage of the season the Rangers were skating in second place in the Patrick Division, but after a diligent 6-2 triumph over the Detroit Red Wings on Tuesday night, Chuck Rayner, Eddie Giacomin and John Davidson formed a common denominator of disappointment as they chatted in the Rangers' dressing room.

title: ALPINE INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary charges of $404,000 and $237,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: INTERNATIONAL RECOVERY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DEMOCRATS AND REPUBLICANS FORM PANEL TO HOLD PRESIDENTIAL DEBATES
description: The two major political parties today announced the creation of a bipartisan commission to sponsor Presidential debates in the 1988 general election campaign.

title: CLINICAL DATA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: REDLAW INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $1,249,000 special gain.

title: The Next President?
description: The other evening, after a lapse of four or five years, Robert S. Strauss, a former Democratic national chairman, revived his chili party for the Washington press corps at the Madison Hotel. The host's speech was uncharacteristically brief and nonpolitical, but when one guest asked him informally who would be the next President, he said, ''I wouldn't be surprised if it was Bob Dole.'' Another guest, intrigued by his mention of the Republican Senator from Kansas, accused Mr. Strauss of promoting the Dole candidacy. ''Nonsense,'' he replied. ''You know I am always for the Democrat.''

title: KAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago quarter results are restated in connection with the distribution of Kay's investment in Kay Jewellers Inc. These results exclude Kay Corp.'s equity in earnings of Kay Jewellers in 1986 and 1985, as well as non-recurring items in 1985.

title: THERMAL PROFILES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: DECISION REPORTED IN THE BEGUN CASE
description: The son of the Jewish dissident Iosif Z. Begun said today that a Soviet official told him that a high-level decision had been made to release his father.

title: EX-STOCK EXCHANGE OFFICIAL
description: J. Truman Bidwell, former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange and an exchange member for 55 years, died Tuesday in the Naples (Fla.) Community Hospital after suffering a stroke two weeks earlier. He was 83 years old and lived in Naples.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Tuesday about Katharine Hepburn's book on the making of ''The African Queen'' misstated the number of Academy Awards the actress has won. It is four.

title: Energy Dept. Rejects Rallies At Nevada Nuclear Test Site
description: Because of growing incidents of civil disobedience, antinuclear protesters will no longer be allowed to demonstrate on a section of the Nevada Test Site, the Energy Department announced Tuesday.

title: An Inner-City Trip On 30's-Style Trains
description: THOSE for whom the words ''Newark'' and ''subway'' summon a vision of urban despair may find a trip on the Newark subway a good way to dispel it. Unlike that other subway system to the east, which on its good days merely moves people, Newark's anachronism of a line can also transport the spirit.

title: COMPUTER FACTORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
White House Tells of Choice To Replace Secretary of Navy
description: The White House announced today that President Reagan would nominate James H. Webb Jr. to succeed John F. Lehman Jr. as Secretary of the Navy.

title: AS SPECULATION PERSISTS, PRESIDENT TERMS REGAN'S FUTURE 'UP TO HIM'
description: President Reagan today raised new questions about Donald T. Regan's future as White House chief of staff when, in an informal interchange with reporters, he said any decision was ''up to him.''

title: U.S. Campuses Will Be Wooed by Japanese
description: Administrators representing 90 universities in the United States will weigh offers of land, buildings and other enticements next week as Japanese recruiters mount a campaign to attract American campuses to set up branches in their country.

title: O'BRIEN ENERGY SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Troubled Guinness Fills 2 of Top Jobs
description: Anthony Tennant, deputy chief executive of the Grand Metropolitan hotel and leisure group, is to succeed Ernest Saunders as chief executive of Guinness, the troubled British brewing giant.

title: MID-AMERICA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: USAIR LIFTS OFFER FOR PIEDMONT
description: The USAir Group raised the stakes yesterday in the struggle for Piedmont Aviation Inc. with a sweetened $1.65 billion merger offer.

title: HESSTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The loss for 1985 includes a $2.2 million charge related to transfer of production from Illinois plant to Hesston, Kansas.

title: PRAXIS PHARMACEUTICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE 'SCREWY' WORLD OF THE NOVELIST HARRY CREWS
description: The novelist Harry Crews talking: ''I get up in the morning, that's one of the hard parts, drag myself over to the old typewriter and sit down -that's even harder - and then I tell the Lord, 'I ain't greedy, Lord, just give me the next 500 words.' ''

title: MOLECULAR BIOSYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: CENTRAL VERMONT PUBLIC SERVICE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HEALTHWAYS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company did not report year- ago quarter revenue.

title: LANCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THOR INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
CUOMO ASSAILS GRANTS TO LAWMKERS' PROJECTS
description: Governor Cuomo today called for an end to the longstanding system of ''member item'' appropriations, a practice that has allowed lawmakers to allocate millions of dollars to special projects in their districts outside normal state procedures.

title: KAPPA NETWORKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: WESTERN CAPITAL INVESTMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $20,332,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net income and includes a loss of $1,039,000 and $4,719,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: The New York We Leave the Next Generation Depends on Us
description: To the Editor:

title: UNITED ASSET MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said earnings for full- year 1985 include a $700,000, or 8 cents a share, tax loss carryforward.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL TREATMENT & TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $276,000 from a tax credit. c-Includes gains from tax credits of $498,000 and $1,613,000 for the quarter and year, respectivley.

title: Dome Debt Plan
description: The board of Dome Petroleum Ltd. has approved in principle the company's plan to reschedule $6.1 billion in debt, a company spokesman said. The spokesman declined to comment on details of the proposal, saying Dome would issue a statement when the plan is sent to the company's principal lenders at the end of next week. Those lenders have agreed to waive debt payments until June 30, under an interim plan that gives the company time to complete negotiations.

title: GORBACHEV PRESSES FOR VOTE WITH CHOICE OF CANDIDATES
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that experiments would be conducted this year in what he called democratic elections in Communist Party cells, local government bodies and and factory managements.

title: OBSCURE STATUTE USED TO ARREST FOUR LANDLORDS
description: Four Brooklyn landlords were arrested yesterday on charges of violating a little-known law by ignoring orders to correct hundreds of unsafe building code violations.

title: DIRECTOR IN FILM DEATHS TESTIFIES ON CHILDREN'S PERIL IN FATAL SCENE
description: The director John Landis testified today that he did not tell the parents of two children who were killed in the filming of the movie ''Twilight Zone'' how large the special effects explosions would be on the movie set or how close the children would be to those explosions.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Pierce Turner, the Old Town Bar, 45 East 18th Street, and Kenny's Castaways, 157 Bleecker Street. An Irish folk vaudevillian, Pierce Turner writes Celtic-flavored folk-rock songs suffused with affection for his hometown of Wexford. Recently he recorded a delightful solo album of his tunes, ''It's Only a Long Way Across'' (co-produced by Philip Glass and Kurt Munkacsi), that evocatively mixes his barroom reveries with snappy electronics. Mr. Turner is currently embarked on a 12-club Manhattan tour that continues through March 17. He will be at the Old Town Bar tomorrow at 11 P.M. and at Kenny's Castaways on Sunday at 8 P.M. Tickets are $5 for both shows. Reservations: 569-1375.

title: IRISH VICTOR FALLS 3 SHY OF MAJORITY
description: Charles J. Haughey's incomplete victory - three seats short of a parliamentary majority - in the national election Tuesday has brought him to the crossroads of the most dramatic career in modern Irish politics.

title: DOLLAR IS MIXED IN U.S. AFTER EUROPE REBOUND
description: The dollar closed narrowly mixed yesterday in hectic trading as currency markets in Europe and New York reacted to the news that the finance ministers of seven leading industrial nations would meet this weekend in Paris.

title: SURINAME STUDENTS BATTLE POLICE
description: Students throwing rocks clashed with policemen in downtown Paramaribo, the capital, today as protests against the military Government of Lieut. Col. Desi Bouterse intensified, according to witnesses.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL LOS ANGELES LAKERS VS. BULLS, at Chicago (TV - WTBS, 8:05 P.M.) COLLEGES: C.U.N.Y. Tournament final at Hunter College Sportsplex, 68th St. and Lexington Ave., 8 P.M. Columbia at Penn (Radio - WKCR-FM 89.9, 7 P.M.) GOLF P.G.A. TOUR: Los Angeles Open, Riviera Country Club, Pacific Palisades, Calif. L.P.G.A. TOUR: Tsmura Hawaiian Ladies Open, Turtle Bay Country Club, Oahu, Hawaii HOCKEY RANGERS VS. BUFFALO SABRES, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, 7 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.) COLLEGE: Bowling Green at Michigan (TV - SportsChannel, 7:30P.M.) OTHER EVENTS HARNESS RACING: Roosevelt, 7:30 P.M. Meadowlands, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, midnight) INDOOR TRACK: Los Angeles Times/GTE Indoor Games (TV -ESPN, midnight) THOROUGHBRED RACING: Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 6:30 P.M. and 11:30 P.M.)

title: Koch Names Payne New Probation Chief
description: James A. Payne, an assistant corporation counsel, was named the city's probation commissioner yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: Myers Chamber Opera
description: The composer-keyboardist Amina Claudine Myers will present her chamber opera ''When the Berries Fell'' tonight at 8 o'clock at the Triplex at Manhattan Community College, 199 Chambers Street (618-1980). It is scored for keyboards, percussion and Ms. Myers's Voice Choir. Tickets are $8; $6 for students

title: VOLCANO IN OCEAN ASTOUNDS SCIENTISTS
description: A team of oceanographers has piloted a small submarine into the eye of an underwater volcano near Hawaii and reports finding a strange new world.

title: M'Farlane Account
description: Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, told a Presidential review board in his hospital room today that he had taken part in an effort by White House aides to hide President Reagan's key role in the initiation of the Iran arms sales, according to a source familiar with the board's investigation.

title: SPECIAL TOYS FOR SPECIAL PLAY
description: Six-year-old Douglas Masterson, who has cerebral palsy, used to watch while his younger brother Joey played with toys that flashed, made interesting noises and moved across the floor of their home in Levittown, L.I.

title: Market Place; Cautious Tack For Hot Fund
description: MANY mutual funds with ''aggressive growth'' as their investment objective are pouring money into the stock market these days. But the Strong Opportunity Fund - a big winner last year with a total return of 59.9 percent in this venturesome category - has switched lately to a more conservative tack.

title: NEW YORK POLITICIANS ARE SURPRISED
description: Governor Cuomo's announcement last night that he would not seek the Democratic Presidential nomination caught many Democratic and Republican leaders throughout New York State by surprise.

title: Management Science Goes to Tucker Wayne
description: Tucker Wayne & Company, Atlanta, won the account of Management Science America, an independent supplier of computer software, last week. Today its first ad, on three consecutive pages, is scheduled to appear in The Wall Street Journal and a number of trade publications.

title: 'HOMELAND' LEADER IS TARGET OF RAID
description: More than 20 men armed with machine guns, mortars and grenades attacked the presidential palace in the black homeland of Ciskei early today but were repulsed by guards, the authorities said.

title: TV Shopping Plan By Dayton Hudson
description: The Dayton Hudson Corporation plans to start a live, one-hour television show this spring offering viewers a chance to buy just about everything sold in its Dayton's stores except furniture and appliances. Dayton Hudson thus joins a growing list of major reatilers getting into the televised shop-from-home business.

title: Warner to Buy Theater Stake
description: Warner Communcations Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire 50 percent of Gulf and Western's domestic movie theater operations. While the companies refused to disclose the amount of the investment, analysts estimated that Warner would spend about $145 million. Gulf and Western owns Mann

title: Article 269387 -- No Title
description: A former executive of the Mitsubishi Bank of California was charged today with embezzling $44.9 million from the bank and conducting almost $1 billion in fraudulent transactions to cover up the scheme.

title: Newspaper Switch By Agency
description: HOLLAND & CALLAWAY, an ad agency that has evolved into a media promotion specialty shop, has resigned The Daily News account to work on the promotion of New York Newsday. Jim Callaway, the president, said his new client should be billing as much as the old, and that was around $5 million.

title: The U.N. Today: Feb. 20, 1987
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: Blue Retires
description: Vida Blue retired yesterday, less than a month after signing as a free agent with the Oakland A's. A team spokesman, Jay Alves, said the decision was a surprise. The 37-year-old left-hander helped the A's to world championships in 1972, 1973 and 1974 and had a career record of 209-161. ''My physical condition is good, so while I am still in good health I have decided to retire,'' Blue said.

title: 'Platoon' Is History
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 White House aides sought to hide President Reagan's key role in the initiation of Iran arms sales, according to a source quoting Robert C. McFarlane, a former national security adviser. Page A1 A Danish tie in the Iran-contra affair is clearer because of a Copenhagen court case. A Danish ship-chartering concern was a crucial link in the clandestine National Security Council staff operation. A1 Calming volatility in currencies will be the object of the Group of Seven industrial democracies in Paris this weekend. Economists said Washington would not act to bar a further erosion of the dollar's value. A1 The U.S. lifted sanctions on Poland. President Reagan called the economic initiative a reward for Warsaw's release of political prisoners and other conciliatory domestic actions. A1 Anatoly Koryagin was reunited with his wife in Kharkov, friends told a Western rights group. They said the dissident psychiatrist was pale and emaciated from six years in prison and labor camp. A10 A contra leader dropped a threat to resign. The Nicaraguan rebel official, Arturo Cruz, vowed to fight to give the guerrilla movement a ''democratic political dimension which it lacks.'' A11 A South African tribal clash was reported by the authorities. They said more than 20 armed men had attacked the presidential palace in the black homeland of Ciskei and were repulsed by guards. A3 Beirut fighting defies cease-fire A7 Irish victor falls 3 shy of majority A10 Judge bars tactic in war crime case A12 NATIONAL A14-18, B6-8 Mario Cuome will not run for the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination. The New York Governor made the unexpected announcement in a radio call-in program.q A1 The drive to limit smoking in public is creating serious tensions in the nation's workplace and complicating personal relationships as more and more employers respond to employees demanding curbs. A1 Aliens are apparently being deterred from entering the United States illegally because of a new immigration control law. Agents on the Mexican border report fewer Mexicans and other foreigners making the crossing attempt. A1 A gain on Alzheimer's disease was reported by scientists studying the the mysterious brain disorder. They cited strong evidence that a defective gene causes the inherited form of the disease. A1 A Federal antidrug program will require 1 million Government workers to submit urine samples under strict controls, including in some cases the direct observation of urination. A17 Skiing outside the boundaries of slopes is an increasingly common practice that has made this one of the deadliest years for skiing in Colorado. Three skiers died in an avalanche Wednesday. A14 Two major civil rights bills will be top priorities for the Democratic-controlled 100th Congress, a bipartisan coalition of key legislators, joined by nearly 200 organizations, announced. B7 A national policy on child care leaves and a bill requiring employers to give 18-week, unpaid time off to parents of newborn or newly adopted children was debated at its first Senate hearing. B7 A film director gave more testimony at his trial in the deaths of three actors. The director, John Landis, said he was unaware of an explosive martar and a helicopter flew in an unrehearsed position. B6 Chicago's Democratic mayoral primary next Tuesday will give Harold Washington or Jane M. Byrne the opportunity to spend six weeks in another grueling municipal campaign against an array of candidates. A14 Investors who sold billions of dollars' worth of assets last year, before capital gains rates went up, face more difficulty than usual in calculating their tax liability this time around. D1 An underwater volcano near Hawaii provided oceanographers in a small submarine with a strange and exotic world that stunned and delighted them. One said, ''There were beautiful red terraces.'' B8 Washington Talk A18 Public remarks now secret Bush remembers the Alamo REGIONAL B1-4 Major transit schedule changes are planned for New York City. Officials plan to shorten subway trips but increase waiting for some buses in the greatest number of changes since the service cuts of the 1970's. B1 A one-judge, one-case court plan begun a year ago in New York City has speeded the pace of criminal cases but left what officials say is a growing number of more difficult cases clogging calendars. B1 The role Harrison J. Goldin played in a 1985 corporate takeover battle that benefitted both New York City's pension funds and Ivan F. Boesky is under investigation, law-enforcement officials said. B1 Four Brooklyn landlords were seized on criminal charges of violating a little-used 1972 state law by ignoring orders to correct hundreds of unsafe building-code violations. B1 Mary Beth Whitehead's name was signed in an emotional 11-page plea for understanding that was sent to the judge in the Baby M case. Testimony yesterday revealed it was not written by her, but by a close friend. B3 Manhattan's cabaret world will have a busy week for comebacks and retrospectives. Yma Sumac, the Peruvian singer with a five-octave range, is returning to New York with a three-week engagement. C1 Life without phones in Brooklyn B3 Suspect named in bombings B3 Witness assailed in Turoff trial B3 Mafia informers are ridiculed B3 Albany Mayor's papers freed B4 Sharanskys protest at Soviet Mission B4 Neediest CasesB6

title: NETS' RALLY COMES UP SHORT
description: During the first timeout of tonight's game, with the Nets ahead by 13-11, George Karl, the Golden State Warriors' coach, tried to bolster his struggling club. He described the Nets as a ''depressed team.''

title: IN BROOKLYN, LIFE WITHOUT TELEPHONES
description: For Alfred Rodriguez, having a phone could mean getting a job. For Miriam Maldanado, it is the difference between fear and a sense of security. And for the Victoria Insurance Agency, it is vital for business.

title: CATHARINE W. HOPPIN
description: Catharine Wellington Hoppin, an educator and former head of the Professional Children's School in New York, died Feb. 7 at her home in Stonington, Conn. She was 89 years old.

title: INSIDE
description: Faster Subway Rides

title: Bush, Bullets Hot, Recalls the Alamo
description: When Vice President Bush said last week that ''there might be a little bit of friction'' in the future between some of his policies and those of the Reagan Administration, some who take an interest in such political affairs saw it as the equivalent of fleeing the Alamo just as the bullets started flying.

title: KNICK'S NEW CAST PRODUCES SMASH HIT
description: Coach Bob Hill, who had been relying on the younger Knicks to carry the team toward its uncertain future, turned to some forgotten veteran players last night, and the result was the end of a four-game losing streak.

title: FRENCH CINEMATIC TREATS AT THE MODERN
description: SINCE invitations to advance screenings are reserved for the special few, the rest of us can be very grateful to the Museum of Modern Art for its ''Perspectives on French Cinema'' series, which offers previews of a batch of movies fresh off the plane from Paris. This year's edition, which opens today, offers a dozen features, 11 of which will be shown twice through March 3 at the museum's Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1.

title: FILM: 'EAT AND RUN'
description: A BALD and very fat man, supposedly an extraterrestrial named Murray, stomps through ''Eat and Run'' devouring every Italian he meets, after which he belches loudly and spits out a button or two. ''Eat and Run'' doesn't get any funnier, and not much of it even measures up to that comic pinnacle. As co-written and directed by Christopher Hart, this comedy specializes in schoolboy humor at its most mirthlessly stupid. On those rare occasions when Mr. Hart does stumble onto something funny, he's apt to kill the joke by running it into the ground.

title: Small Risk, Devastating Consequences of AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: City Salutes Giants
description: The Giants, who were not given a ticker-tape parade at city expense, nevertheless got a salute from New York yesterday. In a ceremony at City Hall attended by a few players and club officials, Mayor Koch, who once called the Giants a ''foreign team,'' said: ''These champions are so mighty that they can plant one foot west of the Hudson and the other east of the Hudson.'' He added, ''America's team is the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut Giants.'' Representing the Giants were their co-owners, Wellington and Tim Mara; General Manager George Young and four players: Sean Landeta, Vince Warren, Kenny Hill and Eric Dorsey.

title: Early Retirements At I.B.M. Center
description: Nearly half of the employees at the International Business Machines Corporation's distribution center in Greencastle have chosen to retire early rather than transfer when the plant closes next month. Dale K. Bennett, a spokeswoman for I.B.M., said that about 400 employees planned to take early retirement and that 500 had decided to take jobs at other I.B.M. locations. Fewer than 50 have resigned or will, she said. The center had 985 workers, which was the most employees ever affected by an I.B.M. plant closing.

title: Janice Stultz Marries Thomas Roddenbery
description: Janice Elaine Stultz, director of development at Barnard College, was married yesterday to Thomas Peale Roddenbery, plant manager of the Jacobus Pharmaceutical Company in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Howard MacFarland Fish, chaplain at the Lawrenceville School and a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: SHORT-TERM RATES PLUNGE
description: Short-term interest rates fell sharply yesterday as traders were encouraged by statements from Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, that the central bank had not tightened monetary policy.

title: OPERA: 'ALBERT HERRING,' BY BRITTEN, AT JUILLIARD
description: BENJAMIN BRITTEN'S ''Albert Herring'' is a farce with serious undertones and the Juilliard American Opera Center, in staging it on Wednesday evening, properly bore down on the broad comedy but did not overlook subtler aspects of this 40-year-old chamber opera. First staged at Glyndebourne in 1947 and given its American premiere at Tanglewood two years later, it was Britten's first attempt at comic opera and a surprisingly mature attempt at that. British critics have mentioned ''Albert Herring'' in the same breath with ''Cosi Fan Tutte,'' which seems a trifle insular of them, but does suggest the ideal of seriocomic ambiguity that Britten must have had in mind.

title: Drawing the Curtain on Arms Control
description: Considering that we are a litigious society, it is hardly surprising that the debate over the future of the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty has turned into a legal wrangle.

title: BROWN MAKES A PERSONAL CALL
description: Did Kansas attempt to recruit the well-traveled Lloyd Daniels after his recent arrest? According to sources at Nevada-Las Vegas, Kansas contacted the Brooklyn-born Daniels within days of his arrest on drug charges in Las Vegas. In an interview yesterday, Larry Brown, the Kansas coach, said that contact had indeed been made, but that the purpose of the call was not to recruit Daniels.

title: DREXEL IS SUED BY STALEY
description: Staley Continental Inc. filed a $200 million suit against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. yesterday, charging that the investment banking firm tried to ''extort'' the company into a leveraged buyout.

title: ECONOMIC GROWTH AT 1.3% RATE
description: The economy grew at a slower rate in the fourth quarter than previously thought, the Government reported yesterday. But some analysts saw a hint of a silver lining in the news.

title: Heating Costs Decline
description: Milder than normal weather over the North Central states helped Americans save $300 million on heating costs in January, the Government said today. January temperatures ranged from 1 degree to 6 degrees Fahrenheit above normal in the upper Midwest and northern Plains region. That helped cut the average heating bill in the region by between $13 and $22, according to the Climate Assessment and Information Services Center, a Federal agency. Nationally, January heating cost $9.1 billion, or $126.72 per household, which was $4.32 less than would have been expected if the weather had been normal, according to the center.

title: Small Risk, Devastating Consequences of AIDS; Increase Rate Falls
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about Ford Motor earnings misstated the Chrysler Corporation's performance for the fourth quarter. Its earnings rose $108.6 million above the fourth quarter of 1985.

title: Beirut Fighting Defies New Cease-Fire Effort
description: There was more heavy fighting in West Beirut today as regular Syrian and Lebanese soldiers took up positions at main intersections to try to enforce a cease-fire.

title: New Grievance by Union
description: While several prominent and talented free agents remain unsigned, the Players Association is about to intensify its conspiracy case against the owners. The association will file a second grievance today, charging that the clubs violated the labor agreement by acting in concert with each other on free agents.

title: GROUPS OF FINANCIAL ANALYSTS SENDS LARGE GIFT TO NEEDIEST
description: Financial analysts with Wall Street investment concerns have contributed $28,956.50 to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Suspect Pleads Guilty In Idaho Bombing Case
description: A former associate of a white supremacist group has pleaded guilty to bombing and murder charges and agreed to tell the authorities about his colleagues.

title: CUOMO SAYS HE WON'T RUN FOR THE PRESIDENCY IN 1988
description: Governor Cuomo, in a surprise announcement, said last night that he would not be a candidate for the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Arms and Shamir
description: At a breakfast Thursday with Yitzhak Shamir, the Israeli Prime Minister, a reporter asked what Israel's current policy was with respect to selling arms to terrorist nations. ''Israel is the only country fighting terrorism,'' he replied. ''We are successful.'' As for the arms shipments to Iran in which Israel assisted, he added: ''The Iran affair was an exception. Every rule must have an exception.''

title: JWT Reports Loss; Profit Down at Grey
description: Both the JWT Group and Grey Advertising released their fourth-quarter earnings yesterday. The most interest, of course, was in JWT because agency watchers, already warned to expect the worst, wanted to know just how bad it was.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
A 3-WAY CONTEST ENDS FOR MATTEL'S TOP POST
description: LEAD: John W. Amerman was named yesterday as chairman and chief executive at Mattel Inc., ending an apparent contest for the top spot at the large toy company.

title: DR. HENRY BLUMENTHAL
description: Dr. Henry Blumenthal, a historian of Franco-American relations at Rutgers University for many years, died Tuesday at the New York University Medical Center. He was 75 years old and lived in South Orange, N.J.

title: SCHEDULE CHANGES PLANNED TO SPEED SUBWAY TRIPS
description: The Transit Authority plans to make subway trips speedier, but increase waits for some buses in what officials are calling the most comprehensive series of schedule changes since the service cuts of the 1970's.

title: SECOND DUE TODAY
description: The dissident psychiatrist Anatoly Koryagin, pale and emaciated from six years in prison and labor camp, was reunited today with his wife on a street in Kharkov, friends told a Dutch rights group.

title: VOLCKER SEES SLIGHT '87 GAINS
description: The Federal Reserve expects the economy to grow by 2 1/2 percent to 3 percent this year, slightly faster than in 1986, while unemployment drifts down a bit from current levels, Paul A. Volcker, the Fed chairman, told Congress today.

title: MAFIA INFORMERS RIDICULED BY DEFENSE IN 'PIZZA' TRIAL
description: A defense summation in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial yesterday ridiculed two Mafia informers, portraying one as a fearful liar and the other as a professional killer.

title: THEATER: 'THE MADERATI' BY RICHARD GREENBERG
description: ''THE glitterati were as thick as porterhouse steaks,'' says Rena deButts, a contemporary hostess with the mostest, on the morning after throwing a party for all the rising young novelists, artists and photographers in Manhattan. According to ''The Maderati,'' Richard Greenberg's new comedy about Rena (Mary Joy) and her soigne crowd, the glitterati are actually thicker than porterhouse steaks and a great deal tougher besides. Mr. Greenberg's characters are the sort who produce just enough ''art'' by day to garner one of the longer captions in Vanity Fair, then spend each night on the prowl for ever more publicity and ''shiftless moneyed friends.'' They're esthetes who pretentiously bemoan ''this terrible sickness of being alive'' even while happily pursuing ''a life of hollowness and shellac.''

title: NEW U.S. LAW APPEARS TO DETER ILLEGAL ALIENS
description: The new immigration control law appears to be having a marked and growing effect in deterring Mexicans and other foreigners from entering the United States illegally.

title: RULING ORDERS ALBANY TO RELEASE DOCUMENTS
description: New York State's highest court ruled unanimously today that Albany officials must give the public ''maximum access'' to an estimated 900,000 pages of records from the administration of Erastus Corning 2d, who served as Mayor here from 1942 until his death in 1983.

title: Contra Leader Withdraws Threat to Resign
description: Arturo Cruz, the Nicaraguan rebel leader, today dropped a threat to resign and pledged he would fight to give the guerrilla movement a ''democratic political dimension which it lacks.''

title: CREDIBILITY OF PROSECUTION'S KEY WITNESS IN TUROFF TRIAL IS ASSAILED
description: Defense lawyers yesterday attacked the credibility of the government's key witness in the fraud trial of the former head of New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission, telling jurors that the witness was desperately trying to stay out of jail and at one time said he wanted to ''blow up'' a credit union to hide his criminal transactions.

title: CALCULATING THE LIABILITY IN CAPITAL GAINS RUSH
description: This tax filing season is likely to prove a bit more agonizing than usual for investors who unloaded billions of dollars' worth of stocks, mutual funds and other assets last year before capital gains rates went up.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture on Monday with a television review of ''Marcel Duchamp: In His Own Words'' was published in error because of an incorrect caption supplied by WNET. It showed the artist Hans Richter, not Duchamp.

title: REAGAN FILLS POSTS IN COMMUNICATIONS AND POLITICS
description: President Reagan filled two vacancies at the White House today. He named Frank J. Donatelli, a Washington lawyer, as political director and selected John O. Koehler, a former executive with the Associated Press, a news agency, as communications director.

title: A GUIDE TO SLIDING, GLIDING AND RIDING ON A WINTRY DAY
description: AS winter moves into its final month this weekend, New Yorkers may already be dreaming of spring. Nevertheless, many cold-weather pleasures still await the intrepid outdoor explorer. The crowds are gone from the area's parks and gardens, and if tranquillity is ever to be found in the city, this is the time to look for it. Nature - seemingly frozen into a still, majestic pose - also takes on a singular beauty in these waning days of winter.

title: Bronx Chant: 'Gator! Gator!'
description: In the Yankee clubhouse on the first day of spring training, there were handshakes all around - the casual reunion handshakes of old friends and the firm introductory handshakes of new teammates.

title: CZYZ EAGER FOR A CHAMPION'S REWARDS
description: When he knocked out Slobodan Kacar last September and won the International Boxing Federation light-heavyweight title, Bobby Czyz was back in the boxing limelight.

title: SENATE HEARING SPLIT ON PARENTAL BILL
description: A bill requiring employers to give time off to parents of newborn or newly adopted children received its first Senate hearing today. Supporters and opponents differed over the need for a national policy on leaves for child care, as well as over whether the 18-week, unpaid leave provided by the bill would place an undue burden on small business.

title: FILM: 'BILLY GALVIN'
description: JACK GALVIN, the title character's father in the family drama ''Billy Galvin,'' likes to watch the Muppets on television. He calls people ''Yardbird,'' and can't stand it when his wife forgets to close the kitchen cabinet door. These details, in John Gray's simple, big-hearted and essentially familiar film, are meant to say a good deal more about Jack's character than they actually do. But then, surprise is less central to ''Billy Galvin'' than sentiment, anyhow. Scratch any one of the principals - Billy, his parents, his barmaid girlfriend, kindly mentor or helpful roommate - and there's a wistful speech lurking just beneath the surface.

title: How Public Remarks Became Classified Data
description: The Government has long made liberal use of its authority to classify information as ''secret.'' But a question has arisen over whether it recently went a few steps too far.

title: TANGLED TRAIL ENDS TODAY FOR LEVINE
description: When Dennis B. Levine telephoned one of his secret insider-trading confederates soon after being arrested last May 12, the confederate was less than eager to talk. But Mr. Levine, who had used his considerable charm to recruit a handful of Wall Street professionals into his scheme, assured the other person that his call was safe. After all, he pointed out, he was calling from a telephone booth.

title: Surgeons Don't Have to Be Ambidextrous
description: To the Editor:

title: Only Poor Chumps Need the Miranda Warning
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW GUARD, NEW WAYS IN OLD PALM BEACH
description: To most people, Palm Beach conjures images of dowagers and diamonds, of parties and mansions, of heiresses and scandalous liaisons. Some of that is still true, but it is no longer the whole story.

title: Wetlands Wipeout
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil to Cut Payments
description: The Brazilian Government, facing an acute shortage of hard-currency reserves, has decided to reduce interest payments on its foreign debt, Government officials said today. They said the reduction would be made while Brazil negotiates long-term arrangements with commercial creditors.

title: Dining Out Guide: Seafood
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. THE DOLPHIN, 227 Lexington Avenue, near 33d Street (689-3010) - ** (April 12, 1985) Exceptionally fresh and well-prepared seafood is presented at this trim, neat Murray Hill restaurant with brick along one wall and blond wood paneling on another. Several appetizers are recommended: oysters on the half shell with a tart mignonette sauce, cherrystone clams, and clams casino with thin strips of tomato crowned with well-browned chunks of bacon.

title: 'My Dear Alex'
description: Richard M. Nixon, who does not issue book endorsements every day, wrote: ''Not since George Orwell, to my knowledge, has there been a broad political satire to match 'My Dear Alex.' This book not only affords reading pleasure; it illuminates and provokes. It should command a wide audience and serious critical attention.''

title: U.S. FAULTS TEHERAN AND MOSCOW IN REPORT ON RIGHTS ABUSES IN '86
description: Iran's human rights record last year was marked by ''serious abuses,'' including political killings, torture and violent repression of religious minorities, the State Department said today.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 381 money market mutual funds increased by $168.4 million, to $236.18 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 91 institutional funds were up $516.1 million, to $65.83 billion. Assets of the 198 general purpose funds were down $241.9 million, to $62.75 billion. The 92 broker-dealer funds' assets decreased by $105.8 million, to $107.60 billion.

title: Plea Made in Gun Case
description: Carlene Pearson, the former fiancee of Dwight Gooden, pleaded guilty yesterday to attempted criminal possession of a weapon. She will be given five years' probation when she is sentenced April 3. Three weeks ago she was arrested at La Guardia Airport when the police said they found a loaded, stolen two-shot derringer pistol in her handbag. She was originally charged with criminal possession of stolen property and criminal possession of a weapon.

title: OLD CROTON AQUADUCT FOR WALKERS, NOT WATER
description: The Old Croton Aqueduct no longer carries New York City's water supply from a river in northern Westchester County to a reservoir on 42d Street, 41 miles south. Instead, hikers, joggers and cross-country skiers travel on top of this 19th-century engineering marvel, part of which is a linear park.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''ROBERT CARMEL is here,''

title: U.S. TOLD TO SPEED A MISSION TO MARS
description: Two leading proponents of exploration of Mars urged Congressional committees today to reject plans of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to delay an unmanned mission to the planet.

title: The Real Threat
description: Many estimable people have protested the ABC television network's political soap opera ''Amerika,'' trying to keep the series off the air. I think they have missed the point.

title: Still Upward Upstate
description: Potsdam (N.Y.) State, the Division III basketball titan, gained its 54th consecutive victory Tuesday night and is closing in on San Francisco's streak of 60 straight (1955-57), the second-longest run in N.C.A.A. history. (U.C.L.A. won 88 in a row from 1971 to 1974.) Just as impressive, Potsdam is aiming to become an unbeaten N.C.A.A. champion for the second straight season, a feat achieved only by U.C.L.A. in nearly half a century of tournament competition. The unbeaten titleholders to date:

title: STATEN ISLAND REACHES THE FINAL
description: Yesterday was by far the easiest day the College of Staten Island's basketball team has had in a while. The only thing the Dolphins had to worry about was basketball.

title: City Expands Program On the Use of Condoms
description: An expanded New York City Health Department program to promote the use of condoms was announced yesterday by the Health Commissioner, Steven C. Joseph.

title: LEBANESE SENTENCED IN MILAN
description: A court in Milan today convicted a Lebanese of smuggling explosives into Italy and sentenced him to 13 years in prison.

title: Archie Shepp
description: The tenor saxophonist Archie Shepp will lead a quintet - with the trombonist Grachan Moncur 3d, the pianist Dave Burrell, the bassist Cameron Brown and the drummer Beaver Harris - tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $7 minimum tonight and tomorrow, a $10 cover and a $6 minimum Sunday.

title: IN A FAR CORNER OF INDIA, A SECT YEARNS FOR ISRAEL
description: The sign above the door of an old factory building here says ''Shion Shalom Prayer Hall'' in Hebrew and English. Inside, worshipers in prayer shawls and yarmulkes read from the Torah at Saturday Sabbath services.

title: New Italian and downtown Indian.
description: SOMETIMES I get the feeling that New Yorkers could survive quite adequately without restaurant critics. This disquieting thought came to mind several weeks ago during an exploration on the East Side in which I ''discovered'' Primola, a seven-month-old Italian restaurant that, as it turned out, had already been uncovered long before by legions of amateur restaurant scouts. To be beaten to the punch like this was akin to Balboa slogging his way to the Pacific Ocean only to encounter a bustling Club Med on the beach.

title: FILM: BRAZIL'S 'BARRAVENTO'
description: ''BARRAVENTO'' (''The Turning Wind''), opening today at the Public Theater, is the first feature by the highly regarded Brazilian director Glauber Rocha, who died at the age of 42 in 1981. The film, made in 1961, is about the efforts of Firmino, part revolutionary, part devil, to free the fishermen in his native Bahian village from capitalist exploitation and the religious superstition that prevents social change.

title: Orlando String Quartet
description: The Orlando String Quartet will play Beethoven's String Quartet in F (Op. 59, No. 1, ''Razumovsky'') and Dvorak's Piano Quintet in A (Op. 81), with the pianist Lilian Kallir, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art tomorrow night at 8 o'clock. Admission is $12; information: 570-3949.

title: YANKEE PITCHERS GO TO THE VIDEOTAPE
description: They filed in slowly but surely this morning, first Rick Rhoden and then the others: Al Holland, Charles Hudson, Rod Scurry, Joel Skinner, Rick Cerone, Mike Armstrong. It was the day for pitchers and catchers to report, and also the day for the Yankee manager, who is beginning his second season, to offer a state of the spring message in his most encouraging terms.

title: TRIAL HEARS WHITEHEAD DID NOT WRITE TO JUDGE
description: An emotional 11-page plea for understanding signed with Mary Beth Whitehead's name and sent last May to the judge in the Baby M case was not written by Mrs. Whitehead, but by a close friend, testimony revealed today.

title: Noncallable Debentures Of Seagram Yield 8.41%
description: Joseph E. Seagram & Sons is offering $200 million of 8 3/8 percent debentures due in 2007 at a price of 99 5/8 to yield 8.41 percent. Goldman, Sachs & Company heads the underwriters.

title: PAKISTAN'S NUCLEAR AIMS WORRYING U.S.
description: Senior United States officials have begun expressing new concern that Pakistan is moving toward the development of a nuclear bomb, in spite of pledges that it has no such intentions.

title: METRO DATELINES;
description: The family of a 23-year-old woman from Peekskill who died a year ago after taking an Extra-Strength Tylenol capsule laced with cyanide sued its maker and a distributor yesterday for $94.5 million.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Lloyd Upset in Florida: Chris Evert Lloyd's comeback to tournament play ended quickly as Kate Gompert upset the world's second-ranked player, 3-6, 6-4, 6-2, last night in the third round of the $250,000 Virginia Slims of Florida, at Boca Raton. In the other late match, second-seeded Steffi Graf of West Germany needed only 34 minutes to beat Sara Gomer of England, 6-0, 6-0, allowing 19 points in the 12 games. The tournament was Lloyd's first since a five-month layoff forced by a knee injury. After getting a first-round bye, the top-seeded Lloyd defeated Elna Reinach of South Africa, 6-4, 6-2, Tuesday.(AP) N.B.A. Pistons 117, SuperSonics 105: In Pontiac, Mich., Adrian Dantley and Isiah Thomas scored 28 points apiece last night to lead Detroit over Seattle, handing the SuperSonics their eighth consecutive loss. The victory, Detroit's fourth in its last five games, gave the Pistons (33-17) a one-game lead over idle Atlanta in the Central Division. (AP) Celtics 99, Rockets 92: Boston's Robert Parish scored 30 points and grabbed 12 rebounds as the Celtics capitalized on Akeem Olajuwon's foul problems, in Houston. The Celtics used a 10-2 spurt to take the lead for good midway in the third quarter, although the Rockets charged early in the fourth period. But Olajuwon picked up four quick fouls in the fourth quarter and the Celtics held on to stifle the Rocket challenge.(AP N.H.L. Penguins 4, Flyers 4: Dave Poulin scored two third-period goals to give Philadelphia a tie, extending the Penguins' victoryless streak to 36 games in Philadelphia. The Penguins have not won in Philadelphia since Jan. 20, 1974. Since that time they have gone 0-33-3 on the Flyers' home ice.(AP Blues 6, North Stars 2: Mark Hunter, Greg Paslawski and Cliff Ronning scored two goals each and Bernie Federko had three assists as the Blues snapped a five-game winless streak with a victory at home over Minnesota. St. Louis got four goals in the final 12:53 of the first period, and it was enough to blunt Minnesota's attempt to take over first place in the Norris Division.(AP) Golf Wadkins Takes Lead: Bobby Wadkins shot a five-under-par 66 to take the first-round lead in the Los Angeles Open. Wadkins, who has not won in 13 years on the PGA Tour, moved to a one-shot lead over Larry Rinker and Jeff Lewis at Riviera Country Club. Doug Tewell, the tournament's defending champion, opened with a 71. (AP Arizona Pair Ahead: Despite gusty winds and scattered showers, Alice Ritzman and Chris Johnson of Arizona shot four-under-par 68's to take the lead after yesterday's first round of the $300,000 L.P.G.A. Tsumura Hawaiian Ladies Open. Ritzman, of Phoenix, shot a steady game, finishing with a two-under-par 34 on the first nine holes and duplicated that on the back nine of the 6,220-yard Turtle Bay Hilton course. Johnson, of Tucson, had a roller coaster day, shooting eight birdies and four bogeys.(AP) Horse Racing Dale's Folly Wins at Aqueduct: Dale's Folly prevailed in a driving finish to take the $27,000 allowance feature for 4-year-olds and up yesterday at Aqueduct. The 4-year-old son of Key to the Mint and Before Bedtime raced six furlongs carrying 117 pounds in 1:12 2/5 on the fast track to reach the wire a neck ahead of Attribute under the ride of Nick Santagata. It was another head to Wicked Wike, whose entrymate, Curraughmoor, finished fast to be only a nose farther back. Skiing Fletcher Gains 2d Title: Pam Fletcher, capturing her second national title in two days, and Tiger Shaw won the supergiant slalom races yesterday at the United States Alpine championships at Crested Butte, Colo. The 24-year-old Fletcher won the downhill Wednesday. Fletcher was clocked in 1 minute 37.31 seconds, about a half-second faster than Debbie Armstrong of Seattle. Tori Pillinger of Park City, Utah, was third. Shaw, 25, of Stowe, Vt., edged Doug Lewis, winner of the men's downhill. Shaw was clocked in 1:36.14, and Lewis, of Salisbury, Vt., had a 1:36.43. Andreas Rickenbach of Pleasanton, Calif., who was second in the downhill, finished third.(AP

title: The Editorial Notebook; Silencing Liu the Just Judge
description: Andrei Sakharov, Yelena Bonner, Natan Sharansky. Americans know these names: they are heroes fighting the evil Soviet system. Their Chinese counterparts, also courageously fighting repression, are nameless and unknown. That's partly because Americans pay so much attention to the Soviet Union. It's also because Americans think of the Chinese as the good-guy Communists. Yes, their system has been repressive, but it's opening up. Things are improving, life is becoming freer, more just.

title: THE STAGE: 'NEVER IN MY LIFETIME'
description: The continuing brutality of the conflict between the English and the Irish is captured with empathetic awareness in Shirley Gee's ''Never in My Lifetime.'' The play, winner of the 1984 Susan Smith Blackburn Prize, is having its American premiere here by the Hartman Theater Company. As expected, there are no villains or martyrs in this war-torn stretch of Northern Ireland. Everyone becomes his brother's enemy.

title: FILM: 'IRA,' DOCUMENTARY
description: YOUR response to ''Ira, You'll Get Into Trouble'' is likely to be related to your feelings about the student commotions of the late 1960's. Stephen A. Sbarge's cinema verite documentary, completed in 1970 and now at the Thalia, follows an attractive group of New York City high schoolers who try to organize against what they view as a repressive establishment. We see them sitting-in rather ineffectually at the offices of the United Federation of Teachers, rallying, being chased by the police, putting out an underground newspaper and rapping, rapping, rapping.

title: JUDGE BARS TACTIC IN WAR CRIME CASE
description: The defense lawyer in Israel's trial of a war crimes suspect from a Nazi camp questioned today whether ''wishful thinking'' might have motivated the accusations of survivors of the Treblinka death camp.

title: Small Risk, Devastating Consequences of AIDS; Which Researchers?
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene; Japanese Stress Regions in U.S.
description: WHERE American economists commonly believe that the way to eliminate this nation's huge trade deficit is to lower the value of the dollar, Japanese economists maintain that the basic answer to America's trade problem lies in more vigorous industrial growth and better-balanced regional development.

title: A.T.&T. to Develop New Unix Model
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said that it plans to develop with the Microsoft Corporation a new version of its Unix computer operating system for the 80386 microprocessor built by the Intel Corporation. Unix is an advanced software system that enables users to manage a variety of data through its multi-tasking and multi-user functions.

title: A NEW LURE BY BUILDES: THE CONDOP
description: Roused by the termination of special property tax breaks 15 months ago, Manhattan developers rushed nearly 12,000 new apartments onto the high-priced end of the residential market.

title: ART: THE INK DRAWINGS OF PETER DRAKE IN SHOW
description: WITH all the attention paid to Neo-Expressionist painting, relatively little notice has been taken of the number of younger artists whose approach is rooted in German Expressionist drawing and graphic art. The ink drawings of Peter Drake (at the Curt Marcus Gallery, 578 Broadway, at Prince Street, through March 4), as well as the work of artists like Sue Coe and Paul Marcus, offer a purer, less self-conscious form of expressionism than any branch of Neo-Expressionist painting. Ms. Coe and Mr. Marcus use line, expressive distortion and sharp contrasts to provoke social and political concern.

title: INQUIRY GROWS IN GOLDINE LINK WITH BOESKY
description: New York City's Department of Investigation is examining the role that City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin played in a 1985 corporate takeover battle that benefited both the city's pension funds and Ivan F. Boesky, the Wall Street speculator, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: At Last, a Little Help for the Homeless
description: It's been 18 months since the philanthropist Leonard Stern offered a $1 million challenge grant to push Help I, a shelter for families now living in welfare hotels. From that day, Andrew Cuomo, the Governor's son, has put his energy and resourceful leadership into the effort. Yet only now is the project starting to move at last, and it will take an additional year before the first occupants arrive at their new transitional home.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Geneva dispatch on Feb. 13 about a United Nations report on executions in Iran characterized the Bahai International Community incorrectly. It is not an opposition group but a religious group whose members have been persecuted in Iran.

title: BLACK HISTORY EVENTS
description: Hudson Guild Theater, 441 West 26th Street. ''The Last Passion Play,'' a drama by Kenshaka Ali. Today, 7:30 P.M. Admission free on a first- come, first-served basis. Informa tion: 760-9810. Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity, 157 Montague Street, Brooklyn Heights, Brooklyn. Tomorrow at 7:45 P.M.: Sweet Honey in the Rock, a chorus of five women singing a capella. Admis sion, $15. Information: (718) 875- 9710. Westbeth Gallery, 55 Bethune Street, between Washington and West Streets. Sunday, 3 P.M. The final Black History Month program in a tribute to Mother Hale. Lecture- demonstration and piano solos by Stanley Cowell, the pianist and com poser, and Marilyn Worrell, the lyric dancer. A panel discussion, moderated by the actress and jour nalist Joan Harris, ''The Black Art ist: Experience and Contribution to American Culture.'' Participants will be Dan Concholar, painter and art historian; Marta Moreno, direc tor of the Caribbean Cultural Cen ter; John A. Williams, novelist; Clayton Riley, writer and critic, and Loften Mitchell, playwright and theater historian. Tickets, $8. Infor mation: 675-6919. Donnell Library Center, 20 West 53d Street. Sunday, 2:30 P.M. A screening of Gordon Parks's autobiographical documentary, ''Moments Without Proper Names.'' Mr. Parks is a photographer, composer, poet and film maker. Admission is free, on a first-come, first-served basis. Information: 621- 0618. The Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street, between Adam Clayton Powell Boulevard and Lenox Avenue. Sunday, 4 P.M. Ex cerpts from Shauneille Perry's musical ''Celebration,'' a musical journey highlighting black people's achievements. Admission, $5, $3 museum members and seniors, $1 children. Information: 864-4500. Harlem School of the Arts, 645 St. Nicholas Avenue, at 141st Street. Tomorrow, 11 A.M., a lecture by Una Mulzac of the Liberation Book Store: ''Discovering Quality Litera ture for the Young Reader.'' 2:30 P.M., performance concert by Har lem School of the Arts faculty and students. 4 P.M., a panel discussion, ''Langston Hughes and the Amer ican Theater,'' with Alice Childress, playwright and actress; Arnold Rampersad, Hughes's biographer; Maxwell Glanville, actor, and Doris Abramson, theater historian. Sunday, 2 P.M., jazz and poetry of Hughes by the Vincent Shields en semble. 3 P.M., musical tribute to Hughes, concert and lecture by Julius Stith, soprano. Admission free. Information: 926-4100. Lehman College Art Gallery, Fine Arts Building, Bedford Park Boule vard West and Goulden Avenue, Bronx. ''Give Me Your Tired, Your Poor . . .? Voluntary Black Migra tion to the United States.'' The Schomburg Center's exhibition for the Statue of Liberty centennial ob servance organized by Roy Bryce- Laporte, the guest curator and au thor of the display's introduction. Through March 15. Admission free. Information: 960-8731.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: IN ''Duet for One'' Julie Andrews plays Stephanie Anderson, a virtuoso concert violinist whose brilliant career and seemingly successful marriage are both cut off when she contracts multiple sclerosis. The role is a milestone in Ms. Andrews's career for many reasons - it is one of the most emotionally demanding and dramatic parts she has played and it exposed her to the suffering of a group of people she came to respect and admire. But it did one thing more. With this part, the actress has, after 23 years, finally and definitively buried Mary Poppins.

title: Addendum
description: * Harrison & Star is a new health-care ad agency at 70 West 36th Street.

title: TAMPA RELEASES GOODEN DATA
description: The City Attorney today released copies of a report on the arrest of Dwight Gooden and four companions who fought with Tampa police officers last December after his car was stopped by the police.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Scouting column in Sports Pages yesterday misstated the number of games the New York Rangers have played since their founding. The game last night was their 3,944th.

title: Timeworn Tim
description: Coach Tim Baab of John Carroll University, bemoaning the length of the basketball season: ''I love the game, but I love my mother-in-law too, and I wouldn't think of living with her for six months.''

title: 2 New York Stations To Accept Condom Ads
description: Both the New York stations of the CBS and NBC television networks announced yesterday that effective immediately they would accept condom advertising as long as it was related to combating AIDS.

title: Japan Investment in U.S.
description: Japan ranked third in direct investment in the United States during a 12-year period beginning in 1974, a trade organization said in a report released today. The Japan External Trade Organization said Japan made 1,154 direct investments, or 14.2 percent of the total, in the United States from 1974 through 1985. Canada topped the list with 1,438, followed by Britain's 1,405. Fourth was West Germany with 883.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: POISON. An 87th Precinct Novel. By Ed McBain. 264 pages. Arbor House. $16.95. CHILD'S PLAY. A Dalziel-Pascoe Murder

title: New Old Crosley
description: Ever since round and gray Riverfront Stadium opened in 1970, Cincinnatians have missed the quaint atmosphere of the Reds' previous home, Crosley Field.
