So when the suburban town of Blue Ash developed a 12-diamond amateur baseball complex that included two professional-sized fields, City Manager Marvin Thompson asked, ''Why not make one like Riverfront and one like Crosley?''

title: DECISION SAID TO RESHAPE CONTEST IN '88
description: Governor Cuomo's decision not to run for President has drastically altered the shape of the contest for the Democratic Presidential nomination, political experts said last night, and has left Gary Hart as the party's one candidate with truly national backing.

title: A Tale of 2 Suburbs: Racism and Realtors
description: RACISM is easy to spot when it is dressed in a white robe and pointy hat. But the racism that keeps one suburb lily-white, while a neighboring suburb quietly grows more and more black, is a trickier, more elusive racism.

title: Disposable Camera Plans
description: The Eastman Kodak Company and Fuji Photo Film U.S.A. Inc. said separately yesterday that they planned to market disposable color cameras.

title: SOVIET MISSION IS PROTEST TARGET FOR SHARANSKYS
description: As demonstrators chanted behind police barricades, Natan Sharansky, the Soviet dissident now living in Israel, stood with his family and friends yesterday in a ''prison cage'' near the Soviet Mission to the United Nations on East 67th Street.

title: E.H. RYNEARSON OF MAYO CLINIC
description: Dr. Edward H. Rynearson, a retired Mayo Clinic physician who argued against prolonging the lives of those with incurable diseases, died here Tuesday in an automobile accident. He was 86 years old.

title: 'A Little Princess' On Channel 13
description: In this age of the silicon-veined microchip, the unfriendly takeover and the arbitrager rampant, what could be more tempting than to dismiss as a wallow in Victorian sentiment the three-part ''Wonderworks'' presentation of ''A Little Princess,'' scheduled to begin tomorrow at 8 P.M. on Channels 13 and 21?

title: Barred Journalist Sues for Information
description: Lawyers for Patricia Lara, the Colombian journalist detained and then expelled from the United States in October, filed suit in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday seeking to obtain Government documents pertaining to her case.

title: GUNMEN BLOW OUT BEIRUT'S WINDOW ON WAR
description: The parrot by the bar imitated the whistle of incoming shellfire; Fat Tommy, the huge, surly cat, slept wedged between the Reuters and the Associated Press news tickers in the lobby, and the telephones and telexes usually worked.

title: 7 BIG NATIONS SEEK STABLE CURRENCIES
description: Seven of the biggest industrial democracies are to meet this weekend in Paris, where they are likely to adopt a new method to calm volatility in their currencies, official sources and economists said today.

title: ART: MET BOCHNER SHOW AT SONNABEND GALLERY
description: MEL BOCHNER, who started his career as one of the premier Conceptual artists of the late 1960's and early 70's, has evolved over the past decade into a maker of abstract paintings. His path has not always been easy to follow, and this makes the artist's current exhibition at Sonnabend Gallery (420 West Broadway, at Spring Street) a particularly welcome and useful one. In 15 works dating from 1969 to the present, this exhibition, on view through March 7, traces a step-by-step transition, revealing a thread of continuity that has never been made so clear.

title: 10 Die in Pakistan Bombing At Afghan Guerrillas' Office
description: A bomb exploded outside the office of an Afghan guerrilla group today, killing 10 people and wounding 62, the authorities said. Angry Pakistanis later attacked Afghan refugees, and up to four people were reported killed.

title: A SURPRISING SOPRANO AT TOWN HALL
description: The Surprising Soprano was as surprised as anyone, he insists, when his career in operatic parody opened up in 1969. ''It was not my idea. I didn't know I could do these things,'' said Michael Aspinall shortly after his arrival from Rome last week. The blame, he alleges, lies with ''a friend of mine who wanted to do it, and wanted me to try to sing duets with him. He was rapidly discarded; he had no talent at all.''

title: Wall Street and Our Business Students
description: The timing of the latest wave of arrests in the still-unraveling Wall Street insider trading imbroglio could not have been more painfully poignant for students in the nation's leading business schools.

title: Mexico Pays Off Loan
description: Mexico has paid off a $1.1 billion bridge loan from central banks of 16 countries and the United States Treasury Department, the Government said today. The credit, approved last August, provided funds while Mexico negotiated a new long-term loan agreement with foreign commercial banks. Nearly half the bridge loan was provided by the United States, with the Treasury Department contributing $272 million and the Federal Reserve Bank, $273 million. The Bank of Japan provided $75 million, and the central banks of Argentina and Brazil $60 million apiece.

title: NEW YORK COURT STUDY SAYS SYSTEM IS FASTER
description: A year-old program intended to streamline justice in New York City by assigning all stages of a case to one judge has speeded the pace of criminal cases through the courts, administrators said yesterday. But they said it has also left a growing number of more difficult cases clogging court calendars.

title: William Esty Gets 2 Cigarette Accounts
description: The William Esty Company, which last year lost Salem cigarettes, the mentholated brand it had introduced for R. J. Reynolds Tobacco, has now been assigned Kool, an even better-known menthol from Brown & Williamson, as well as Kim, a new cigarette product in this country.

title: Serving Notice on the Contras
description: No matter what happens in Nicaragua, the fellow who seems to speak for the State Department is General Micawber: Something hopeful is always about to turn up.

title: Stocks Rise to Record for Third Day
description: The stock market rose modestly yesterday to its third record in a row, as speculation grew over the direction of interest rates and the dollar's value.

title: Conner Is Welcomed
description: The sharks, sensing bad blood, were out in force at the New York Yacht Club yesterday as Dennis Conner, the skipper who lost the America's Cup to Australia in 1983, paid his first visit to the trophy's former home on West 44th Street since reclaiming the cup earlier this month -for the San Diego Yacht Club.

title: MOUNTING DRIVE ON SMOKING STIRS TENSIONS IN WORKPLACE
description: The mounting drive to limit public smoking is complicating many personal relationships and creating some serious tensions in the nation's workplace.

title: NOVEL BAILOUT OF A TEXAS BANK
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced today that it had arranged an innovative bailout of the troubled BancTexas Group of Dallas that would transfer management control of the holding company and its 11 banks to a little-known merchant banking concern called Hallwood Group Inc.

title: Inquiry on Hutton Unit
description: A Federal grand jury is investigating whether the E. F. Hutton Group violated reporting requirements of the Securities and Exchange Commission at its Providence, R.I., office between 1981 and 1984, the company disclosed yesterday. It made the disclosure in an S.E.C. filing.

title: BIPARTISAN COALITION TO PUSH TWO RIGHTS BILLS IN CONGRESS
description: A bipartisan coalition of key legislators, joined by nearly 200 organizations, announced today that two major civil rights measures would be their top priorities for the 100th Congress.

title: FILM: RACHEL WARD IN 'THE GOOD WIFE'
description: ''THE GOOD WIFE,'' set in the long-ago 1930's, is Marge Hills (Rachel Ward), an earnest, reliable friend to anyone in need in the rural New South Wales town where she lives with her husband, Sonny (Bryan Brown), a hard-working logger. When a baby's expected in the community, Marge becomes the unpaid midwife. She remembers birthdays. She's polite, cheerful and always has a nice word to say about everybody.

title: Jay Hoggard
description: The vibraphonist Jay Hoggard will lead a quartet tonight and tomorrow at Visiones, 125 Macdougal Street (673-5576). Sets are at 9 P.M., 12:30 and 2 A.M.; there is a $6 minimum.

title: ART: 72 OF THE NEWEST OF MODERN'S DRAWINGS
description: IT is six years since the drawings department of the Museum of Modern Art last mounted a show of new acquisitions. During the period in question, 554 drawings by 217 artists were acquired. Seventy-two of the drawings in question - roughly one-eighth of the total intake - are in the current show of recently acquired drawings acquisitions at the museum. They include some outright classics of the modern movement, together with many others that inform, seduce or provoke. Yet it would be interesting to know how many people not professionally concerned with art could name even five or six of those 554 recent entrants to the museum off the tops of their heads.

title: Roberta Peters
description: The soprano Roberta Peters will sing works by Scarlatti, Schubert, Meyerbeer, Faure and Noel Coward at the 92d Street Y tomorrow afternoon at 3 o'clock, accompanied by the pianist Jakov Kreizberg and the flutist Paul Dunkel. Tickets are $12.50 to $17.50. The 92d Street Y is at 1395 Lexington Avenue. Information: 996-1100.

title: Among the '88 Aspirants
description: Announcing a Presidential candidacy these days has become a major production, particularly for lesser-known hopefuls eager to become better-known. On Monday, for example, a chartered DC-9 will carry 20 members of Congress and assorted reporters from Washington to St. Louis for the noon announcement of Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri that he is a candidate for the 1988 Democratic nomination. Then the candidate and entourage will fly on to Des Moines, where the Gephardt steering committee for the Iowa caucuses will be unveiled.

title: Periodicals Collection Gets $1 Million Gift
description: The New York Public Library's periodicals collection has received a gift in excess of $1 million to endow the position of chief librarian for periodicals and journals. The endowment is also to provide for an annual award for ''excellence in journalism,'' with details to be announced.

title: Egypt-I.M.F. Accord
description: Egypt has agreed to a package of economic reforms with the International Monetary Fund in order to receive $250 million to $300 million, diplomats said today. Under the agreement, Egypt would have to increase prices on a range of subsidized consumer goods, a sensitive subject in view of riots 10 years ago that forced the late President Anwar el-Sadat to cancel price increases.

title: REPEAT: JOHNSON SAYS METS WILL WIN
description: For the first time since Jesse Orosco struck out Marty Barrett and wiped out the Boston Red Sox 115 days ago, there were Mets on a baseball field in uniform today.

title: Amerika The Dull
description: The main point of the television series ''Amerika'' so far is to reconfirm that propaganda is its own nemesis, by dint of boredom. The idea of the United States falling under Soviet occupation, without resistance, sounded provocative. But now one wonders why all the controversy. The film simply falls flat.

title: Crossland Savings
description: The Crossland Savings Bank of Brooklyn said it has agreed in principle to take over the Western Savings and Loan Association, a troubled savings institution based in Salt Lake City. In return for control over Western's $400 million in assets and 13 branches in four states, Crossland agreed to inject Western with $50 million in fresh capital. Crossland said it planned to merge the Utah company with its two Florida thrift units, Crossland Savings of Bradenton and Crossland Savings of Gainesville, to create a $1.7 billion multistate institution called Crossland Savings FSB.

title: Bridge: New York Event Will Pair Top Players and Amateurs
description: Once a year some of New York's less experienced tournament players have the opportunity to play with experts. The event is the Greater New York Bridge Association's Pro-Am event, scheduled for 7:30 P.M. tomorrow at the Penta Hotel, 33d Street and Seventh Avenue in Manhattan. Reservations are needed. Call (212) 988-1542 for information.

title: Housed in Connecticut, but Taxed in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: AFFLUENT VOTERS WOOED ON CHICAGO'S LAKEFRONT
description: The mountainous waves of a brimming Lake Michigan that pounded this city's lakefront in recent weeks could serve as an apt symbol of Chicago's current political season.

title: DIOCESE DROPS TV PLAN ON POPE
description: Roman Catholic officials, yielding to complaints from broadcasters and some church leaders, today dropped a plan to auction television rights for coverage of the visit of Pope John Paul II in September.

title: DARLING JOINS MILLIONAIRE CLUB
description: Ron Darling won his bid for $1.05 million in salary arbitration yesterday and immediately noticed a bizarre pattern.

title: FLAMINGO HEADING FOR A LAST WHIRL
description: The last Flamingo. Like such titles as ''The Last Picture Show'' or ''The Last Convertible,'' the phrase suggests the end of an era and an institution. Pessimists are applying it to the Flamingto Stakes here Feb. 28, the first of the year's seven Grade I prep races for the Kentucky Derby and possibly its last edition as racing fans know it.

title: U.S. DETAILS RULES FOR DRUG TESTING
description: The Reagan Administration announced details today on a sweeping drug-detecting program that will require about a million Federal workers to submit urine samples under strict controls to prevent cheating, including direct observation of urination in some cases.

title: U.S. SEEKING PYROTECHNICS EXPERT IN BOMBINGS AT ABORTION CLINICS
description: A fireworks expert who worked at last year's Statue of Liberty celebration is being sought in the bombings of several New York City abortion clinics, Federal officials announced yesterday.

title: Diner's Journal
description: THE ornately tiled vaulted ceiling supported by stout columns and ceramic covered walls is reminiscent of a New York subway station before spray paint was invented - which, in fact, it was at the turn of the century. This fanciful room later became a rathskeller in the Vanderbilt Hotel, 4 Park Avenue, at 33d Street. The elegant Vanderbilt became an apartment complex in 1967, and the rathskeller has seen several incarnations as bars and restaurants. Last month the room reopened as Fiori, an Italian restaurant and bar serving salads, pasta, pizza and grilled entrees.

title: Mother Is Accused Of Role in Girl's Rape
description: A Bronx woman was arrested yesterday and charged with restraining her 6-year-old daughter while three men raped the girl on separate occasions and then gave the mother money or drugs, the police said.

title: HENRY-RUSSELL HITCHCOCK DEAD AT 83
description: Henry-Russell Hitchcock, one of the country's most distinguished architectural historians and teachers, died of cancer yesterday in New York. He was 83 years old.

title: David Shuler, Organist
description: The organist David Shuler will play a program of 20th-century music, including the premieres of works by Charles Wuorinen and Gunther Schuller, at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Sunday at 3 P.M. Admission is $3. St. Bartholemew's is at the corner of Park Avenue and 51st Street. Information: 751-1616, extension 226.

title: SOVIET SOCIOLOGIST CANDID ABOUT OFFICIAL DISREGARD FOR HER SCIENCE
description: A highly critical assessment of Soviet sociology that was recently published in Pravda is remarkable for its candor even in this era of openness under Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 20, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL The Group of Seven industrial nations will meet in Paris this weekend, and they are likely to adopt a new method to calm volatility in currencies, officials and economists said. But they said the United States would not commit itself to propping up the dollar. The finance leaders will discuss the concept of reference zones, which would set guidelines for how much a currency should rise or fall in relation to other currencies. [ Page A1. ] The dollar surged in Europe on news of the Group of Seven meeting but later waned in the U.S. In New York, gold rose $7.50, to $400. [ D14. ] A cut in Japan's basic interest rate is expected to be announced today. [ D20. ] West Germany is likely to agree to new steps to bolster its economy, experts predicted. [ D20. ] Brazil has decided to reduce interest payments on its foreign debt. It faces a shortage of hard currency. [ D8. ] The Economy The nation's fourth-quarter growth rate was slower than previously thought. The Commerce Department said the economy, after accounting for inflation, expanded at a 1.3 percent rate in the period, compared with a previous estimate of 1.7 percent. For the year, G.N.P. grew 2 1/2 percent. [ D1. ] The Fed expects economic growth of 2 1/2 to 3 percent this year, while unemployment drifts down a bit, Paul A. Volcker told Congress. He also disclosed that a target range would not be set for the M-1 money supply. [ D1. ] The F.D.I.C. has arranged a bailout of the BancTexas Group that would transfer management control of the holding company and its 11 banks to a merchant banking concern. [ D4. ] Markets

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Friday BOOKS, BOOKS, BOOKS

title: SYRACUSE THWARTS PROVIDENCE, 90-81
description: Sherman Douglas scored 8 of Syracuse's final 10 points and finished with 26 to help hold off Providence, 90-81, in a Big East Conference game tonight.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Sewerage Bonds From Wisconsin
description: The Milwaukee Metropolitan Sewerage District is offering $100 million of tax-exempt bonds with yields ranging from 4.90 percent for those maturing in 1993 to 5.50 percent in 1997 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Jack Gilford, Downstairs Theater Bar at the West Bank, 407 West 42d Street (695-6909). On this weekend 48 years ago, Jack Gilford was part of the opening show at the legendary Greenwich Village nightclub Cafe Society, along with Billie Holiday, the blues singer Joe Turner, the boogie-woogie pianists Albert Ammons, Meade Lux Lewis and Pete Johnson, and a band led by the trumpeter Frankie Newton. Mr. Gilford, who served as both comedian and master of ceremonies at Cafe Society, is preparing a program of highlights of his career, which will draw on the now-classic comedy routines he developed at the club, and on musical-comedy bits created by E. Y. (Yip) Harburg and the team of John Kander and Fred Ebb, as well as new material. He will perform this program for a week in April at the Pasadena Playhouse in California. To break in the new material and polish the old bits, Mr. Gilford will make a rare return to cabaret for two evenings, tonight and Monday at the Downstairs Theater Bar at the West Bank. Performances both nights are at 8:30. Admission is $6 and there is no minimum.

title: '97 Notes Issued By Bear Stearns
description: The Bear Stearns Companies yesterday offered $100 million of 8 1/8 percent senior notes due in 1997 at a price of 99 7/8 to yield 8.15 percent, or 95-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury notes of similar maturity.

title: JACKSON CHALLENGES CADETS TO RETHINK ROLE
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson challenged the next generation of American military leaders tonight to assess the nation's security in domestic as well as international terms.

title: IN NEW YORK CARARETS, THE OLD IS STRIKINGLY NEW
description: PROBABLY more than any other area of popular music, cabaret venerates show-business traditions and the accumulated wisdom of life as expressed in popular song. Or, to quote the title of a Peter Allen-Carole Bayer Sager song, in cabaret ''Everything old is new again.'' ''New'' can mean many things, from a personal vision that has mellowed and deepened over several decades to an artist like the 30-year-old singer-pianist Michael Feinstein, who interprets pop standards with a simplicity and urgency that makes them seem utterly fresh.

title: FILM: 'SQUARE DANCE,' STARRING JASON ROBARDS
description: AS anyone who took square dancing at summer camp knows, ''home'' is the position from which all steps originate and the spot to which a dancer returns after do-si-do-ing. This is the signally simple metaphor that hangs over ''Square Dance'' like a heart-shaped, helium-filled balloon with a slow leak.

title: PIEDMONT AVIATION BOARD INVITES FURTHER BIDDING
description: After deliberating for six hours yesterday on two competing takeover offers, the board of Piedmont Aviation Inc. opened the bidding to all interested parties.

title: When Prices Outstrip Hope
description: WHAT does it mean when a pair of 17th-century gilded silver salvers, a French commode, a 19th-century rosewood cabinet, a Regency vase and a Victorian partners' desk are all sold for prices far in excess of the auction houses' estimates? Have the professionals goofed, is the current buoyancy of the art market responsible, are low presale estimates a ploy to attract potential buyers or was it a bidding war between two collectors?

title: CONCERT: ROSTROPOVICH WITH THE PHILHARMONIC
description: IF music were ever reinstated as an Olympic event, Mstislav Rostropovich might walk away with all the gold medals. As a way of celebrating his 60th birthday, the ebullient cellist, conductor and pianist is in the midst of a strenuous two-month series of concerts in New York, Boston and Washington that should qualify him to be known as music's marathon man. Last evening, for instance, he staged a kind of concerto triathlon with the New York Philharmonic, playing works for cello and orchestra by Krzysztof Pendereck, Haydn and Tchaikovsky. And, one may add, playing them all with the enormous tone, ravishing phrasing and almost reckless ardor that are as much his trademarks as the oddly bent cello pin that sets his instrument at just the proper angle for his needs.

title: RODINO LIKENS IRAN ARMS SALE TO WATERGATE
description: The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, Peter W. Rodino Jr., today compared the Iran arms affair to the Watergate scandals and warned against White House efforts to ''cover up.''

title: KEY RATES
Comings and Goings
description: Jimmy Arias, Aaron Krickstein, Ken Flach and Robert Seguso have been named to the United States Davis Cup squad that will face Paraguay next March in Asuncion in the opening round of competition. . . . The Jets said a contract would not be offered to Charles Jackson, a starting linebacker last season. . . . Mean Joe Greene was named defensive-line coach of the Steelers. . . . The Islanders called up Randy Boyd from Springfield to replace Ken Morrow, the defenseman who suffered bruised ribs Wednesday at Montreal and will miss tomorrow's rematch of the clubs. Dale Henry, a left wing, was also brought back from Springfield.

title: TYPE OF ALZHEIMER'S TIED TO GENE
description: A potentially crucial clue to the cause of Alzheimer's disease was reported yesterday by scientists studying the mysterious brain disorder.

title: Beyond Tragedy
description: Fighting continues in Beirut: Once, the words made the heart sink. Now, they have echoed for a dozen years; too long.

title: BROADWAY
description: TWO months ago, Martin Richards, one of the producers of ''Roza,'' said there was no talk of moving it to Broadway and no interest in doing so. Mr. Richards is still saying part of the same thing but not quite all. Now there's talk, sort of, and interest in, certainly, but absolutely no commitment to the Great White Way - until and unless everything works out well at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles. The musical, directed by Hal Prince and starring Georgia Brown and Bob Gunton, set a box-office record at the Center Stage in Baltimore last month and is to begin performances on the West Coast on April 18. It is based on a novel by Romain Gary, as was the movie ''Madame Rosa.'' Set in an immigrant quarter of Paris, it's about an aging Jewish prostitute who makes her living raising her colleagues' children, and her close relationship with one of her charges, a young Arab boy. Julian More is responsible for book and lyrics and Gilbert Becaud for the music.

title: Arms Operation Made Wide Use of Danish Ships
description: A Danish connection to the Iran-contra affair has become clearer in the last week, largely as a result of a court case here.

title: Convertible Debt: 2 More Offerings
description: The recent surge in stock prices has encouraged more offerings of convertible debt issues, including two yesterday totaling $200 million.

title: FROESE THROWS GLOVE AT REFEREE IN ROUT
description: All night they came at him, infringing on the area that he believed was rightfully his, and they hemmed him in. So he pushed at the opposition and he railed at the officials and finally, with one angry motion, Bob Froese let his temper go. The Ranger goalkeeper threw his glove at the referee.

title: British-Dutch Truck Venture
description: Britain's troubled state-owned Leyland Trucks, once a takeover target of the General Motors Corporation, will be combined with the Dutch company DAF under a joint venture announced today.

title: ART: JANET FISH STILL LIFE NOT SO STILL
description: WHEN the outside world began to penetrate Janet Fish's still lifes in the late 1970's, it was as a mere bit player. Her oversized glass objects were still the center of interest. Plates by the stack, legions of tumblers, bowls and other containers, they reposed on their tables coruscating in bright daylight - no dishwashing problems here, but then no food or drink to cause them, unless it was the fruit and vegetables that materialized about the same time as the inserts of urban and rural landscape.

title: Hewlett Profits Increase 6.4%
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said today that it earned $116 million, or 45 cents a share, in its first quarter, up 6.4 percent from $109 million, or 43 cents a share, a year ago.

title: FILM: 'DEATH BEFORE DISHONOR'
description: THE movies are looking for a few good men, to change the face of American foreign policy and out-Rambo Rambo in the process. The latest of these hopefuls is Gunnery Sgt. Jack Burns, who in ''Death Before Dishonor'' is a marine with a mission. Stationed in the fictitious Middle Eastern country of Jemal, Burns (Fred Dryer) must stand by helplessly while his commanding officer (Brian Keith) is kidnapped by Arab terrorists. The terrorists' actions, reprehensible as they are, exist chiefly as an excuse for Burns to do what he does best: get fighting mad.

title: Wanted: Middle-Aged Rambos
description: A growing number of Americans are calling for a revival of military conscription, partly on the grounds that the present volunteer Army is not drawing enough applicants qualified to handle today's sophisticated weaponry.

title: L.I. WORKES BRAVE ELEMENTS TO GET IN A SMOKE
description: A bucket overflowing with cigarette butts hangs outside the office of United-Guardian Inc. here.

title: RISK LURED 3 COLORADO SKIERS PAST SAFE AREA TO DEATH
description: Three skiers who died in an avalanche near Breckenridge Wednesday were taking additional risks by skiing outside the boundaries of downhill ski slopes, an increasingly common practice that has made this one of the deadliest years for skiing in recent Colorado history.

title: FILM: FREDI M. MURER'S 'ALPINE FIRE'
description: LIKE its title, Fredi M. Murer's ''Alpine Fire'' is ultimately a lot more corny (and a lot less meaningful) than one wants to believe while watching it. The Swiss film is the first fiction feature to be made by Mr. Murer, who, until now, has specialized in documentaries, and who clearly knows how to photograph scenery and weather under difficult conditions.

title: Peskanov Recital
description: The violinist Mark Peskanov will play works by Mozart, Richard Strauss and Aaron Copland at Alice Tully Hall Sunday night at 8 o'clock, accompanied by the pianist Rita Sloan. Tickets are $10; information: 362-1911.

title: Shultz and Shamir Ask Soviet To Ease Its Emigration Curbs
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel and Secretary of State George P. Shultz called on the Soviet Union today to relax restrictions on emigration.

title: Panel Assails Trade Policies
description: The Reagan Administration encountered unexpectedly sharp criticism of its trade policies from a Senate committee today, signaling the harsh treatment the White House can expect for the 1,600-page trade bill it has just sent to Congress.

title: Advanced Genetic
description: Advanced Genetic Sciences Inc., a biotechnology company based in Oakland, Calif., said that it had received preliminary approval from the California Department of Food and Agriculture to conduct field experiments on Frostban, genetically altered bacteria that protect fruit and nut crops from frost damage. The Environmental Protection Agency approved tests for three sites last week.

title: JACOBS SET TO BEGIN TENDER BID FOR BORG
description: The investor Irwin L. Jacobs, renewing his four-month-old bid for the Borg-Warner Corporation, said today that he intends to begin a tender offer for no less than $44 a share in cash, if a friendly merger cannot be arranged soon.

title: Japan Rate Cut Appears Near
description: The Bank of Japan is expected to announce a cut in its basic interest rate Friday.

title: REAGAN LIFTS POLISH TRADE CURBS, CITING PROGRESS ON HUMAN RIGHTS
description: President Reagan lifted economic sanctions against Poland today, calling the action a reward for the release of political prisoners and other moves toward reconciliation with supporters of the banned Solidarity movement and the Roman Catholic Church.

title: A Hard Swallow In St. Louis
description: For a man who has been pressing St. Louis to build him a 70,000-seat domed football stadium, Bill Bidwill, the Cardinals' owner, has come up with a curious demand. He wants the city fathers to ban beer there, an idea akin to banning speeches in Washington.

title: Coke's Net Up by 66.1%
description: The Coca-Cola Company said today that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 66.1 percent, largely because of a hefty gain from the initial public offering of stock in its bottling operations.

title: Critics of U.S. Policies Testify at House Panel
description: Representatives of organizations opposed to United States policies on Central America asserted before a House panel today that they were victims of political burglaries in which files were searched but valuables were left untouched.

title: 'December Flower'
description: PUBLIC television's ''Great Performances'' is on an impressive drama roll these days, thanks to a number of wonderful performances. Last Friday, Sir Alec Guinness and Leo McKern brought countless touches of grace to Graham Greene's ''Monsignor Quixote,'' a story set in Spain about a simple village priest and the local Communist politician. Tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 13, Jean Simmons and Mona Washbourne positively illuminate ''December Flower,'' an hourlong tale about a newly widowed woman coming to take care of her bed-ridden, 85-year-old aunt. The 1984 film, produced by Roy Roberts for Britain's Granada Television, is directed by Stephen Frears, acclaimed here last year for the movie ''My Beautiful Laundrette.''

title: CUOMO REMARKS BARRING RACE FOR THE PRESIDENCY
description: Following is an excerpt from a transcript of Governor Cuomo's question-and-answer session last night on a statewide radio broadcast: Q. We have about four minutes left Governor. If we can get back to what I asked you at the beginning of the broadcast and you said maybe we'd talk about it later; it's almost later. Have you made a decision and what is your decision concerning your interest in the Presidency? A. I think it's a little bit deceptive to say, have I made a decision. I have been telling people for a long, long time that I had no plans to run for the Presidency and I didn't have any plans to make plans to run for the Presidency. Despite that, there was an awful lot of speculation about it and I promised that I would make a statement on the subject before the end of February and this is as good a time to do it as I've had, with so many New Yorkers listening in.

title: Soccer for Youth
description: To acquaint young Americans with Brazil and its renowned soccer talents, Pele is organizing a program to send 80 youth soccer teams from the United States to play in Brazil this summer. Pele and Julio Mazzei, his friend and adviser, said the players would be between the ages of 12 and 18, with eight teams going to Brazil every week from June 19 until the end of August, and each guaranteed eight games there. Each player will be charged $1,499.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Northrop Names A New President
description: LEAD: Kent Kresa has been named president of the Northrop Corporation, succeeding Frank W. Lynch, who has been named vice chairman, the aerospace and electronics company said yesterday.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: BRIEFING Kemp Opens Fire, Sort of
description: A year before the first votes of the 1988 Republican Presidential competition, it is too early for rivals of Vice President Bush to criticize him openly. That might look like an attack on President Reagan. But it is always possible to open fire on a secondary target close to Mr. Bush, on the theory that the Vice President might suffer some incidental damage.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 52.

title: HEICO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $441,000, or 24 cents a share, on the sale of a manufacturing facility.

title: Drug Tests Are Urged For Transport Workers
description: Secretary of Transportation Elizabeth Hanford Dole urged today that Congress swiftly pass laws requiring random drug testing of aviation and railroad employees.

title: Poor Lands' Debts Up 1%
description: Debts of poor countries will total $1,080 billion this year, a small increase reflecting the shrinkage of financing for the third world, the World Bank projected today.

title: SHARED MEDICAL SYSTEMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes $20 million in costs associated with the company's international operations.

title: INDIA AND PAKISTAN UNITED BY CRICKET FEVER
description: For the last three weeks, everyone has felt the tension build as India and Pakistan confronted each other and pressed for total victory.

title: LESLIE FAY COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: The results for the 52 weeks in 1986 were affected by non-recurring pre- tax charges of $1,690,000, which Leslie Fay incurred in connection with the early repayment of its bank term loan. The company said its results prior to Aug. 1, 1986, when it succeeded to the Leslie Fay business, give retroactive effect to the succession as if it had occurred prior to the beginning of the reported periods. The results are pro forma. Corrected from Thursday, Feb. 19, editions.

title: GERALD HAHN
description: Gerald Hahn, a painter and associate professor of art at Queens College, died of Hodgkin's disease on Monday at the Westchester County Medical Center. He was 48 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Consumer Spending Plunges 2%
description: Consumer spending plunged a record 2 percent in January as Americans put away their pocketbooks after an auto-buying spree, the Government reported today. Personal incomes were unchanged.

title: GENERAL BINDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CANADA MOVES TO STEM INCREASING FLOW OF ALIENS SEEKING REFUGE
description: Canada tightened its liberal immigration procedures today to try to stem the growing tide of aliens seeking refuge, including thousands of Salvadorans and Guatemalans who have been living illegally in the United States.

title: WOLVERINE TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BANCTEXAS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said that all of 1986, its loan loss provision amounted to $115.1 million, compared with $43.5 million in 1985.

title: PLAYERS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
100,000 Rally For Punjab Politicians
description: More than 100,000 Sikhs rallied in the state of Punjab today in support of secular political leaders who face a challenge from religious figures for leadership of India's Sikhs.

title: COMBINED INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an investment loss of $3,603,000 for the quarter and an investment gain of $63,039,000 for the year. c-After an investment loss of $365,000 for the quarter and an investment gain of $20,959,000 for the year. The company said the latest quarter and year figures include fully consolidated results for Life of Virginia since its acquisition April 29, 1986.

title: INTELOGIC TRACE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 24
PERINI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,115,000 and $2,415,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,734,000. d-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $22,407,000.

title: HARSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $2,926,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary charge of $3,212,000 from the repurchase of $50 million principal amount of 12 1/4 percent sinking fund debentures for the year.

title: SUREST SIGN OF SPRING: STEINBRENNER WARMS UP
description: It is one of the rites of every Yankee spring: George Steinbrenner, perched on the steps of his trailer, delivering a nonstop monologue as his team conducted its first official workout under a warm Florida sun.

title: FORWARD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ENDEVCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a writedown of assets of $3,623,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net income

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Lakers 110, Bulls 100: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, becoming the first National Basketball Association player to score 36,000 career points, connected on a skyhook and hit two key free throws in the final 2 minutes 32 seconds last night for the Lakers in Chicago. The Lakers insured the outcome on two baskets in the final 54 seconds by Magic Johnson, who added 28 points. Abdul-Jabbar, with 17 points and a career total of 36,002, hit 36,000 with the skyhook for a 100-94 lead. (AP) 76ers 123, Kings 91: In Philadelphia, Andrew Toney scored a season-high 32 points for the 76ers, who twice led by 42 points. Trailing by 12-6 early in the first quarter, Philadelphia went on a 13-2 run, with Toney scoring 10 points. (AP) Pacers 107, Hawks 105: Steve Stipanovich scored a season-high 30 points and made two decisive free throws with 21 seconds remaining as Indiana overcame an 8-point deficit in the final two minutes. The victory snapped the Pacers' 16-game losing streak at the Omni. (AP) College Basketball Princeton 69, Cornell 63: Mike Harnum, a reserve guard, scored 16 points, including 9 in a row in one stretch, to help beat first-place Cornell in an Ivy League game last night in Princeton. John Bajusz led Cornell (14-9 over all, 8-3 in the league) with 21 points. Princeton is 12-9 and 5-5. (AP) Penn 94, Columbia 73: Bruce Lefkowitz had 27 points and Barry Bromwell had 25 in the Ivy League game in Philadelphia. The pair combined to make 19 of their 26 field-goal attempts as Penn (10-12, 7-3) shot 62.5 percent. Sean Couch led Columbia (10-13, 4-7) with 20 points. (AP) Darmouth 83, Brown 73: In Hanover, N.H., Bryan Randall scored 19 points and Jim Barton added 15 for Dartmouth (13-8, 5-5) in the Ivy league game. Todd Murray led Brown (8-16, 3-8) with 15 points. (AP) Yale 88, Harvard 76: Chris Dudley scored 22 points and grabbed 22 rebounds to lead Yale (14-9, 7-4) in the Ivy League game. Harvard fell to 8-14 and 3-7. (AP) Golf Sander Leads by 1: Bill Sander, an alternate in the $600,000 Los Angeles Open, shot a second-round five-under-par 66 to take a one-stroke lead. Sander, who was added to the field after Andy Dillard and Leonard Thompson withdrew, led Danny Edwards, Rick Fehr and T. C. Chen of Taiwan after 36 holes on the par-71, 7,029-yard Riviera Country Club in Los Angeles. (AP) Tennis Sabatini Advances in Florida: Sixth-seeded Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina ended the surprising run of unseeded Kate Gompert, 6-2, 6-1, last night in the quarterfinals of the $250,000 Virginia Slims of Florida championships in Boca Raton. Gompert upset top-seeded Chris Evert Lloyd last Thursday and 11th-seeded Carling Bassett last Monday. The 16-year-old Sabatini needed just an hour to win. Second-seeded Steffi Graf survived her first real challenge of the week, beating a fellow West German, Claudia Kohde-Kilsch, 7-6, 6-2. (AP) Edberg Advances: Top-seeded Stefan Edberg of Sweden won his quarterfinal match at the $435,000 Pilot Pen Classic tournament at Indian Wells, Calif., rallying to defeat seventh-seeded Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia, 4-6, 6-4, 6-2. Edberg will meet fourth-seeded Mats Wilander of Sweden, who defeated Jakob Hlasek of Czechoslovakia, 6-3, 6-0. (AP) Track Foster Wins in Los Angeles: Greg Foster continued his outstanding indoor season with a 7.48-second clocking to win the 60-meter hurdles last night in the The Los Angeles Times/ GTE Indoor Games. Foster, slow out of the blocks, caught Mark McKoy at the final hurdle and leaned ahead at the wire. McKoy, from Canada, was clocked in 7.50 and Stephane Caristan of France was third in 7.56. (AP) Skiing McGrath Takes Giant Slalom: Felix McGrath surpassed his competition with the fastest time in both runs yesterday to win the men's giant slalom at the United States Alpine championships in Copper Mountain, Colo. McGrath, one of America's top technical skiers, was more than a full second faster than Tiger Shaw after the first run over the short, 40-gate course. Rather than sit on his lead, he skied a solid, quick second run which was seven-hundredths of a second faster than that of second-place finisher Troy Watts. Shaw, seeking a third straight national giant-slalom title, wound up third. Watts, fifth after the opening run, took the silver medal at 2:06.80, and Shaw came in at 2:07.46. (AP) Czechoslovak Soars to Victory: Jiri Parma of Czechoslovakia soared 89.5 and 87 meters to win the 70-meter ski jumping title yesterday at the world Nordic championships in Oberstdorf, West Germany. Parma collected 224.5 points to give his country its first gold medal of the competition. Matti Nykaenen of Finland, had to settle for the silver medal with a score of 216.5 points. (AP)

title: Fly Williams Shot
description: James (Fly) Williams, a former standout in college and the American Basketball Association, was listed in guarded condition in Booth Memorial Hospital in Queens with gunshot wounds. He was shot by an off-duty court officer after a dispute Tuesday night with a third man over money. A companion of Williams, Derrick Washington, was also shot and both men were charged with attempted robbery, unlawful imprisonment, weapons possession and menacing, according to the police. Williams, a star at James Madison High School in Brooklyn, was fifth in the nation in scoring for Austin Peay College in 1972-73. He played for the St. Louis Spirits of the A.B.A.

Announcer Recovering
description: Harry Caray, the veteran Chicago Cubs baseball announcer, was resting comfortably in fair condition in a Palm Springs, Calif., hospital after suffering a mild stroke on Tuesday. ''He seems to be a little better,'' said Bill Wills, a spokesman for the Tribune Company, which owns the Cubs, The Chicago Tribune, WGN Radio and WGN-TV. ''He's in a lot better spirits, very lucid and very upbeat. He's a lot like the old Harry Caray. The prognosis is good, and that's the key. Doctors see him coming back to the game, but the question is when,'' Wills said. The 67-year-old Caray, who has a winter home near Palm Springs, suffered the stroke while playing cards at his country club.

description: Southern Methodist University officials said today they expect to learn by Wednesday whether the school's football program will be shut down for two years for violating National Collegiate Athletic Association rules while the Mustangs were on probation.

description: A chart in some copies of Business Day yesterday, with an article about international financial meetings this weekend in Paris, incorrectly described one proposed way of keeping currencies within trading ranges against other currencies. If the dollar strengthened beyond the top limit of a proposed range against the yen, for instance, the countries involved might try to bring the dollar back down by selling dollars or buying yen; if the dollar weakened too much, the countries might buy dollars and sell yen.

Miss Hall, 30 years old, companion of the rock musician Mick Jagger, was arrested Jan. 21. She testified this morning that a package containing marijuana that had been sent from nearby Mustique Island was not hers.

description: A French business executive with ties to the Communist Party said today that he had signed a deal on two-way trade with the Soviet Union worth $1 billion. He said some of the goods going to the Soviet Union would be supplied by his own business and others by French and foreign subcontractors.

title: Pat Cummings Injured
description: Pat Cummings of the Knicks suffered a torn ligament in his right index finger during Thursday night's 120-105 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers at Madison Square Garden. The forward will miss at least two games. According to Dr. Norman Scott, whether surgery will be necessary will not be determined until the swelling subsides, which probably won't occur until the middle of next week. Bill Cartwright of the Knicks was diagnosed as having ''Achilles' tendinitis'' after an X-ray was taken at Lenox Hill Hosptal. He sat out yesterday's practice, as did Gerald Henderson (bruised thigh), Bob Thornton (sore right knee) and Patrick Ewing, who was simply given the day off. . . . X-rays yesterday on Orlando Woolridge's bruised left shin were negative. The Net forward was injured in a collision late in the game. His availability for tonight's game against the Knicks at Byrne Meadowlands Arena is questionable.

title: CUOMO PROPOSING A $1.7 BILLION CUT IN PERSONAL TAXES
description: Governor Cuomo today proposed a new $1.7 billion cut in New York State personal income taxes, a sudden announcement that came just a day after the stunning declaration that he would not seek the Presidency in 1988.

title: Allied Bancshares To Combine Units
description: Allied Bancshares Inc. said that it would combine its 20 subsidiaries within Harris County, which encompasses Houston, into a single institution. The new bank, to be called Allied Bank N.A., is expected to have assets of about $7.12 billion and deposits of $5.5 billion, according to Jay C. Crager, Allied's chief financial officer.

title: Indictments Issued In Thrift Unit Case
description: Two real estate developers and three former executives of the Sunrise Savings and Loan Association of Boynton, Fla., were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of misapplication of funds.

title: Carlton Optimistic
description: Steve Carlton, who for years did not talk to the news media, said in an interview that he expected to win a job with his old team, the Philadelphia Phillies. ''I have no qualms of being able to win a job,'' the 42-year-old left-hander was quoted yesterday in USA Today. Of his pitching problems in 1986, the four-time Cy Young Award winner said: ''I can't explain it in simple terms, but the only two problems I had the last two years were range of motion and mechanics. After I straightened that out at the end of last year, I threw as good as I've ever thrown. That's the reason I didn't quit, because a little man inside me never went away. I knew I could do it because I used to go in the outfield and throw the ball 300 feet. That's the reason I didn't quit, because a little man inside me never went away.''

title: Agency Cancels Plan to Award Ambulance Bid
description: The New York City hospital system yesterday dropped plans to award a $10.5 million contract for new ambulances to the sole bidder.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mike Brown, a Pittsburgh Pirate outfielder, has signed a contract for a reduced salary. Brown, who made $225,000 in 1986, will earn $212,500 for the coming season under a settlement reached by the team and his agent, Steve Greenberg. ... The California Athletic Commission approved a boxing license for a former heavyweight boxing champion, George Foreman, at a full commission hearing yesterday, according to his promoter. Foreman, 38, is making a comeback and will fight for the first time in 10 years on March 3 against an opponent to be approved by the commission.

title: Battle Over Lilco's Evacuation Plan Turns on the Issue of States' Rights
description: For both foes and advocates of the Shoreham nuclear power plant, this has been a puzzling month.

title: BRIGHTON BEACH: VIEWS OF GORBACHEV
description: Across an ocean and with the perspective of a lifetime, the Russians of Brighton Beach are watching the changes in Mikhail S. Gorbachev's Soviet Union.

title: When to Shift Family Assets
description: DAN FORBES, a New York City businessman, and his wife, Eileen, decided recently to put their jointly owned family home in Glen Head, L.I., in her name. They are in the process of doing the same with some of their securities as well.

title: Howser Returns
description: For the first time since being diagnosed as having brain cancer, Dick Howser is back on the job as manager of the Kansas City Royals. ''It's a special feeling,'' said Howser, who officially reported to spring training at Fort Myers, Fla., Thursday. ''But to tell you the truth, not from day one in the hospital did I ever feel like I would not be here. This is where I belong. Managing is what I do best. I don't want to be treated any differently than before. When I walk onto that field, I want to hear the boos and the cheers.''

title: VERDIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Grievance Is Filed Over Parrish Talks
description: The dispute between baseball's players and club owners over the charges of a free-agent conspiracy intensified yesterday when the players union filed two more grievances.

title: Lawyer Says His Client Fought Mob Drug Sales
description: A defense lawyer told the jury yesterday in the ''pizza connection'' trial that the main defendant was driven out of the Mafia in a brutal war because he was opposed to drug trafficking.

title: P. Harvey Chase Dies at 57; Specialized in Rheumatology
description: Dr. P. Harvey Chase, former chief of medicine at Brooklyn Jewish Hospital, now Interfaith Medical Center, died of cancer Wednesday at North Shore University Hospital, Manhasset, L.I. He was 57 years old and lived in Roslyn, L.I.

title: Unfortunate Split Can Make No-Trump a Good Choice
description: Players who elect to play in six no-trump, rejecting a 5-3 fit in a major suit, usually do it for match-point reasons: they are hungry for the extra 10 points.

title: JWT GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The year-ago figures are restated to reflect a pooling of interests of Gray & Co., which was merged with Hill & Knowlton in October 1986, and reclassified to conform with the 1986 presentation. The results for 1986 include charges for severance payments, acquisition costs, writedowns of investments in European operations and provisions for duplicate leases, bad debts and relocation charges. In all, JWT said, these charges, net of a $2.6 million gain from the curtailment of a defined benefit pension plan, totaled about $12 million pretax, including almost $11 million in the fourth quarter.

title: LEHMAN BEATS S.I. FOR CUNY TITLE
description: The College of Staten Island was knocked out of the City University of New York basketball tournament for the second time last night, losing to Lehman College in the championship game.

title: WHITE HOUSE SUPPORTS AIDE WHO HAD NAZI TIE AT AGE 10
description: The White House today reiterated its support for its new communications director, John O. Koehler, after he acknowledged belonging to a Nazi youth group when he was a boy in Germany.

title: LONETTE MCKEE LEAVES 'LADY DAY' OVER HEALTH
description: Lonette McKee has withdrawn from the title role in ''Lady Day at Emerson's Bar and Grill'' for health reasons, the actress said yesterday in a telephone interview from her Brooklyn home. The show, which re-creates a performance by the singer Billie Holiday near the end of her life, has been a hit at the Off Broadway Westside Arts Theater since last September.

title: COLORADO SEARCHERS DISCOVER A 4TH SKIER KILLED BY AVALANCHE
description: Searchers using infrared and metal detectors to scan the site of an avalanche today found the body of a fourth man who was killed when tons of snow thundered down a mountainside.

title: DRESSER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $1.8 million. c-Net income The company said the latest quarter loss reflects $30.2 million in gains related to pension reversions of excess assets and the settlement of certain U.S. pension liabilities. It also includes recognition of a $6.6 million gain on the sale of office buildings. Year-ago first quarter results are restated to include additional net earnings of $5.4 million for pension plan cost adjustments recorded in July 1986.

title: L.S.U. Names Dean
description: The Louisiana State University Board of Supervisors named Joe Dean athletic director from a field of four nominated by a search committee. A former L.S.U basketball star, Dean, 56 years old, succeeds Bob Brodhead, who resigned under pressure in December after two months under suspension for two violations of the state ethics code. Dean, a successful businessman, has also been the analyst on broadcasts of Southeastern Conference basketball games. Other finalists were Larry Jones, the interim athletic director; Eddie Jones, president of the New Orleans Saints, and David Wagner, athletic director at Georgia Southern.

title: THERMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: MR. CUOMO'S BIG MO, AND BIGGER NO
description: Momentum: Among the things he had going for him, George Bush said in 1980, was the Big Mo. A victory in Iowa, progress in the polls, magazine covers, ceaseless television - much the way Jimmy Carter rocketed out of nowhere in 1976.

title: Appeal to Block Bar on Hogtying Denied by Judge
description: A Manhattan judge yesterday denied a New York City police union's request to block a departmental ban on hogtying prisoners.

title: NORSTAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After gains from tax credits of $125,000 for the quarter and $289,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $250,000 for the quarter and $906,000 for the 9 months.

title: Five Children Killed In Apartment Blaze While There Alone
description: Five children, age 2 and younger, who were left alone in an apartment were killed today when fire broke out at a public housing project, the authorities said.

title: Appeals Board Upholds 'Angel Heart' X Rating
description: An appeals board has decisively upheld the X rating given two weeks ago to Alan Parker's new movie, ''Angel Heart,'' and narrowly upheld by a different appeals board last week. Tri-Star, the distributor of ''Angel Heart,'' has already announced that the movie will be re-cut for an R rating.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''A million dollars is a lot of money where I come from. It's a lot where anybody comes from.'' - Ron Darling, the Mets pitcher. [ 49:1. ]

title: Charles C. Wei Dead; A Top Bridge Theorist
description: Charles C. Wei, a shipping executive and a leading figure in contract bridge, died in New York Hospital yesterday from complications resulting from diabetes. He was 72 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Houston.

title: TERA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $2.3 million from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and includes an extraordinary loss of $2,440,000. Comparable full-year 1985 results are not available because in 1985 the company switched from a fiscal year ended June 30 to a calendar year. Effective Dec. 31, 1986, Tera Corp. was restructured as a master limited partnership, Tenera L.P.

title: DAY INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,592,000. The company said that because of an October 1986 restructuring, there aren't meaningful comparisons between the latest quarter and the year- ago quarter. However, it said it made a comparison to the year-earlier first quarter results of Dayco Corp., the predecessor company to Day International, to comply with S.E.C. requirements.

title: EXPERT RETRACTS STAND ON RIGHTS IN BABY M CASE
description: A psychological expert hired by Baby M's legal guardian testified today that he had changed his opinion on preserving the parental rights of the baby's mother, Mary Beth Whitehead, after a session with a lawyer for the infant's father.

title: A PERSONAL VICTORY
description: Mario Cuomo's announcement that he will not be a Presidential candidate should not have been as surprising as it apparently was to most political buffs. His boomlet was mostly in the eyes of expectant beholders and for months he had been telegraphing in numerous ways that he was reluctant to run, and felt perhaps that he would not.

title: BIG V SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest quarter earnings were adversely affected by about $500,000 as a result of the repeal of investment tax credits under the new tax law. It said pre-opening costs in 1986 from certain stores offset an unspecified realized gain in the latest quarter from the sale of the company's store and shopping center in Vestal, N.Y.

title: WINNERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax provision of $2,370,000 for anticipated losses from the closing of six restaurants and the disposition of other properties, of which $800,000 was recorded in the fourth quarter.

title: SLOWING DOWN OUT-OF-CONTROL COLLEGE COSTS
description: To the Editor:

title: WHERE THE TITANIC BELONGS
description: A Texas oilman in cahoots with a French Government research institute plans a return to the Titanic for treasure and live TV. Picking over shipwrecks in international waters is legal, but these remains need care and control.

title: GILLETTE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes one-time charges of $165.3 million after tax from restructuring costs, accounting changes and other costs for both the quarter and year. c-Net income

title: Nunn Rejects '88 Bid For at Least 6 Months
description: Senator Sam Nunn told Georgia Democrats tonight that he would not mount a Presidential campaign over the next six months, but he refused to rule out the possibility of later entering the race.

title: MET MUSEUM DID WELL TO REFUSE WYETH SHOW
description: To the Editor:

title: PLESSEY COMPANY PLC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $5.1 million. Share earnings are per American Depositary Receipt. The translation from pounds sterling into dollars is at the rate of $1.47 to the pound, the approximate rate at Dec. 26, 1986.

title: POLICE USE A NEW TACTIC TO DETER DRUG BUYERS
description: ''You got boom-boom?'' asked the driver of a yellow taxi as he pulled up to a street corner well known here for marijuana dealing.

title: Manning a Threat to Redmen
description: St. John's and Kansas will take a break from their respective conference races this afternoon for a contest that should evolve into an interesting intersectional match.

description: b-Reflects a liquidating dividend of $307,000 from an investment.

description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $426,000 from the retirement of debt.

title: Canada Inflation Eases
description: Canada's annual rate of inflation fell to 3.9 percent in January from 4.2 percent in December, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today. In this week's federal budget, Finance Minister Michael Wilson projected that inflation would average 3.9 percent for 1987, down from 4.1 percent in 1986.

title: EGYPT-U.S. PLAN TO RAID LIBYA REPORTED
description: Early last year, President Reagan approved a secret directive under which United States military forces would support Egypt in the event of a ''pre-emptive'' attack on Libya, and the two countries continued to prepare for this contingency throughout 1986, Adminstration officials said today.

title: DIGIORGIO CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $2,392,000 for the latest year and $835,000 for the year-ago period. The company said the 1985 sales have been restated to exclude discontinued operations.

title: ALASKA GOVERNOR PROPOSES STATE USE OF OIL FUND
description: The Alaska Permanent Fund, one of the most unusual public finance devices ever concocted in the United States, will earn enough this year to give the state $150 million to help it through a financial crisis, salt away $100 million or so to repair inflation's nibbles at principal, and still give every man, woman and child in Alaska about $675 to spend, save or toss into the wind.

title: Darling's Million-Dollar View
description: Ron Darling, the fifth and newest millionaire on the Mets, made his first appearance at the team's locker room on the eve of spring training today. He sat lacing six pairs of baseball shoes, but tried instead to focus on the impact of the arbitration ruling that awarded him a salary of $1.05 million at the age of 26.

title: Bid for AirCal Goes Forward
description: Federal transportation authorities gave tentative approval today to American Airlines' planned $225 million acquisition of AirCal Inc.

title: G.M. South Africa Gets a New Name
description: The local company that is acquiring the General Motors Corporation's South African assets said it would change its name to the Delta Motor Corporation from General Motors South Africa Ltd. G.M. officially pulled out of South Africa on Jan. 1, citing a slowing economy and the slow pace of reform for the nation's apartheid system of racial segregation.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 21, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-4

title: Hoechst Near Celanese Link
description: The Federal Trade Commission cleared the way today for the American Hoechst Corporation to complete its $2.8 billion takeover of the Celanese Corporation, following Hoechst's promise to sell a variety of assets to ease Government antitrust concerns.

title: PLACER DEVELOPMENT LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a non-extraordinary $45.9 million writedown of U.S. oil and gas assets in the fourth quarter which partly offset a previously reported gain of $90.1 million on the sale of a partial interest in the company's Placer Pacific Ltd. unit.

title: DOW DROPS 8.85 POINTS, ENDING RECORD STREAK
description: Stock prices ended moderately lower yesterday on a late wave of profit taking and computerized selling.

title: TELECOMMUNICATIONS NETORK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $127,000 charge for previously recognized investment tax credits due to the repeal of the investment tax credit under the Tax Reform Act of 1986.

title: Dollar Dips In Advance Of Talks
description: The dollar fell slightly yesterday in light, cautious trading as traders waited to see what finance ministers would accomplish this weekend in their attempt to stabilize currency markets.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL BUILDING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,205,062 for both the quarter and year. c-Includes a loss of $2,334,921 from discontinued operations for both the quarter and year.

description: *Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for belwether issues.

title: Norway Oil Output Up
description: Norway's North Sea oil output rose to 1.06 million barrels a day in January, from 1.049 million in December, its highest level since production began 16 years ago, operators said today. The total is expected to fall this month as Norway carries out a voluntary 7.5 percent output cutback on all its fields in support of measures by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to increase oil prices by curbing supply to world crude markets.

title: China Shows Growth of 9%
description: Industrial growth in China in 1986 declined to just over 9 percent, from a runaway 18 percent in 1985, thanks to better control of the economy, Chinese officials said today.

title: Trouble Spots Listed For Weekend Traffic
description: The city's Department of Transportation said these would be among the most severe traffic trouble spots in the region this weekend:

title: SOVIET TO RESUME BLASTS, IT TELLS SCIENTISTS
description: Soviet authorities told American scientists today that the Soviet Union would detonate a nuclear device within several days, ending an 18-month moratorium on nuclear testing.

title: PRESIDENT RECEIVES ROUSING RECEPTION FROM G.O.P. CONSERVATIVES
description: Republican conservatives gave President Reagan a rousing ovation today only hours after cheering an attack on his Secretary of State by Representative Jack F. Kemp of upstate New York, one of the Republicans bidding to succeed Mr. Reagan.

title: GF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $319,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,198,000 for the quarter and the year includes net from discontinued operations of $1,405,000; extraordinary gains of $2,171,000 and $2,712,000 for the quarter and year, respectively and a tax credit of $3,126,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: FLORIDA MELEE LAID TO SUSPECT'S DEATH
description: Violence broke out for a second night tonight in a mostly black neighborhood where a melee Thursday followed the death of a young black man subdued by a white officer using a chokehold.

title: FOSTER, L. B. CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $21.3 million restructuring charge and a writedown of $7.8 million. The company said the 1986 results include the operations of the its architectural hardware and banking equipment units, which were acquired in February 1986.

title: J.A.L.-Boeing Deal
description: The Boeing Company said Japan Air Lines had ordered three 747-300 jetliners and four 767-300's, and had upgraded an earlier order in a deal totaling $575 million. The orders include the substitution of two 767-300's for two previously ordered 767-200 models of the wide-body twinjet. The lengthened 767's are to be delivered between next September and June of next year, while one 747 is for delivery in December and the other two next year.

title: THE BLENDING OF 2 PAINT STORES
description: In its 118 years in business, the paint store S. Wolf's Sons has become a New York City institution, supplying paint that coated ocean liners, the exterior of the Empire State Building and many of the benches in Central Park.

title: CARIBBEAN SELECT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company began operations on June 14, 1985. Effective date Sept. 30, 1986, Liberty Acquisitions merged with Virgin Islands Beverage Distributing Co., creating Caribbean Select. The results reflect this merger as if it had taken effect on June 14, 1985.

title: MOTHERS MARCH, BUT TO 2 DRUMMERS
description: Every Thursday, in the small plaza facing Argentina's dusty-rose presidential palace, the Mothers of the Plaza de Mayo still march, reminding their countrymen of the thousands who disappeared here a decade ago.

title: INTEGRATED CIRCUITS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Novelist in Nicaragua
description: THE JAGUAR SMILE. A Nicaraguan Journey. By Salman Rushdie. 171 pages. Viking. $12.95.

title: Budget Warm-Ups
description: Democratic leaders say they plan to get a budget resolution through Congress before the statutory April 15 deadline. If they do, they will take a political weapon away from President Reagan, who has been known to complain in the past that the White House had been able to meet the deadline for proposing a budget but that the process had been hindered by the molasses-like pace of Congress, especially its Democrats.

title: Appeal for Aid
description: Lebanon's Prime Minister and other Moslem leaders formally asked Syria today to send more troops to West Beirut to end the worst factional fighting the Moslem part of the capital has seen in 12 years of civil war.

title: ERBAMONT N V reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in U.S. dollars.

title: BAVARIANS ARREST AMERICAN AS A KNOWING AIDS SPREADER
description: A former United States Army sergeant with AIDS has been arrested in the Bavarian city of Nuremberg on suspicion of knowingly spreading the disease to his sexual partners.

title: GEORGE F. TIBBLES
description: George F. Tibbles, a composer and television writer who put Woody Woodpecker's laugh to music and got an Academy Award nomination for the effort, died last Saturday at the Eisenhower Medical Center. He was 73 years old.

title: Kodak Will Sell Fox Retail Labs
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said it plans to sell the retail labs of Fox Photo, the photofinishing company it bought three months ago for $95.5 million. But Kodak will retain Fox's 20 wholesale photofinishing labs, which are among the biggest users of Kodak color paper.

description: To the Editor:

title: BRAZIL TO SUSPEND INTEREST PAYMENT TO FOREIGN BANKS
description: The Brazilian Government, struggling to protect its rapidly diminishing supply of hard currency, tonight suspended the payment of interest on its debt to foreign banks.

title: Japan to Reduce Rate
description: The Bank of Japan, as expected, today announced a half-point cut in its basic interest rate, to an all-time low of 2.5 percent.

title: LET THERE BE LIGHT IN TIMES SQUARE
description: LEAD: The Board of Estimate's approval this month of a bill that would preserve Broadway's glitter is rather like a dowager trying on a jaunty party hat. The impulse is commendable, but it doesn't quite work.

description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $23.4 million and $160.9 million for the latest quarter and year-ago period, respectively. c-Net income The latest fourth quarter loss included restructuring charges of $183.4 million, after taxes. The company said that as part of its restructuring costs it charged $34.5 million for the difference between the price paid and a market price of shares purchased from Sir James Goldsmith and $37.6 million for expenses of the Sir James Group. The company also said it took a $110.8 million after-tax writedown of oil and gas reserves in the first quarter due to depresses oil prices. The 1986 full-year also included an after-tax gain of $152 million from settlement of a significant portion of the company's pension obligation. The company said the sale of Arizona Properties contributed $8 million, with the balance of that gain to be recognized this year. It was also said that the investment tax credit on its crude oil pipeline added $22.8 million to 1986 profits, compared with $32.9 million for 1985.

title: U.S. CONTROL OF ARMS SALES WEAK AND INEFFECTIVE, SENATE UNIT TOLD
description: Control of American arms sales is so weak that convicted felons can obtain export licenses and officials do not track billions of dollars in weapons sold overseas, a Senate panel was told today.

description: The Pan Am Corporation, which started its shuttle service in the Northeast Corridor just five months ago, has told its employees that it may sell the service unless it can make a profit.

title: Reagan Caught in Feud Between Wife and Aide
description: Two of President Reagan's closest advisers, Nancy Reagan and Donald T. Regan, have apparently reached the point where they cannot stand each other.

title: THE DANCE: SUSAN ROSE
description: It is hard to come by good dance that is also informed by wit, intelligence and terse but glowing humanity. But that was what shone through a program by Susan Rose and her pleasantly casual Danceworks company on Thursday at the Theater of the Riverside Church, where the Boston-based dancers will perform again tonight and Sunday night.

title: IRAQ'S PRESIDENT IS NOT A BARGAINING CHIP
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTON SIMON'S ART IS SLATED FOR U.C.L.A.
description: An ''agreement in principle'' has been reached between the California industrialist Norton Simon and the University of California at Los Angeles for the transfer to the university of the vast art collection owned by two Simon foundations. According to the university's chancellor, Charles B. Young, the gift would be worth more than $750 million, making it the largest donation of any kind ever given to an American university.

Amtrak Train Kills Driver on Tracks
description: A man was killed early yesterday morning when an Amtrak train with 11 passenger cars rammed his pickup truck and dragged it a quarter of a mile, the police said.

title: Queens Man Held In Officer's Killing
description: A Queens man said to be a member of a Manhattan crime group known as the Westies has been arrested and charged with the murder of a New York City housing police officer who disappeared in November 1985, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: POLITICAL CHANGES FORCE EARLY CANDIDATE MOVES
description: Why would Governor Cuomo - or anyone else - have to make a decision on running for President nearly 21 months before Election Day of 1988?

title: No Headline
description: A report on Feb. 10 in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page incorrectly described a gathering that took place in Washington for the visiting Prime Minister and Foreign Minister of Vanuatu. And a correction in this space on Feb. 16 misidentified the site. The event was a prayer meeting, at the Australian Embassy.

title: THE NEW GALANOS: FANTASY IN FASHION
description: James Galanos is expanding the frontiers of fashion in the spring and summer collection he is showing at the Plaza Hotel for the next week. The Los Angeles-based designer has captured the current feeling of fantasy and often transformed it into a deceptively simple look.

title: Soviet Dissident Freed After Week of Doubts
description: The Jewish dissident Iosif Z. Begun was freed and reunited with his family today after more than three years in prison and a week of conflicting reports about his fate, relatives in Moscow reported.

title: Bankers Pragmatic On Brazil Debt Halt
description: Top bankers in North America said that Brazil was bowing to the inevitable yesterday in suspending interest payments on much of its $108 billion foreign debt. But they held out hope for a negotiated solution to keep the move from hurting their earnings.

PATENTS;
New Bioherbicide

title: On Renaming the Omni
description: By the time the Democratic National Convention in Atlanta rolls around in 1988, the name of the Omni, the auditorium where the big political gathering will be held, probably will have been changed to include CNN, for the Cable News Network, which has the contract to operate the auditorium. And if the newscasters in the network anchor booths are going to be accurate, they will have to mention the name of their upstart competitor every time they say where they are speaking from.

title: SFE TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
Broncos Seek Jackson
description: The Denver Broncos will try to acquire Bo Jackson before the National Football League draft in April, according to Coach Dan Reeves. Jackson, the 1985 Heisman Trophy winner from Auburn, earlier turned down the Tampa Bay Buccaneers to pursue a baseball career. He is under contract to the Kansas City Royals but has a buyout clause that would allow him to play pro football. ''There are a lot of clubs who would be interested'' in Jackson, Reeves said in an interview with The Rocky Mountain News. ''We'll cover all avenues.'' The Broncos' running game has been weak in recent seasons. Reeves said the Broncos would contact the Buccaneers this month, and if they get permission from Tampa Bay, which drafted Jackson last year, Denver would then seek a meeting with Jackson or his agent, Tom Zieman. The Broncos could either sign a contract with Jackson and then make a deal with the Buccaneers, or wait until this year's draft when he becomes available to all 28 teams again, said Reeves. Jackson declined a five-year contract worth $7 million from Tampa Bay and has said he is committed to baseball.

title: 7th Resignation in Ottawa
description: The Minister of Public Works, Roche LaSalle, has become the seventh member of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's Cabinet to resign under pressure from allegations of influence-peddling.

title: A WOBBLY WIN FOR IRELAND'S HAUGHEY
description: It was the economy, not the ''national question,'' that mattered most in Ireland's election this week. Voters clearly blamed Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald for bad times and a jobless rate that is now second worst in the European Community. His defeat was not a repudiation of his Government's landmark agreement with Britain on Northern Ireland. That is borne out by former Prime Minister Charles Haughey's careful handling of the issue in his political comeback. Not incidentally, his party won fewer votes than in 1982, and is three seats short of a majority.

title: PUTTING THE PLEASURE BACK INTO GROCERY SHOPPING
description: The size of Manhattan supermarkets will never change. With rare exceptions, there will never be room for more than two shopping carts per aisle. But their style, quality, cleanliness and sometimes their service are changing, generally for the better. A price must be paid, of course, and it is added to the cost of the food.

title: CONTRA CHEIF SAYS NORTH ARRANGED FOR PAYMENTS
description: A top contra official, Arturo Cruz, said today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had questioned him twice in recent months about the role Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North played in arranging a $7,000 monthly allowance for Mr. Cruz for most of last year.

title: UNUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $1 million and $13.9 million for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes realized investment losses of $4.3 million for the quarter and realized invesmtment gains of $3 million for the year. Unum converted from a mutual to a stock company in November 1986.

title: PICTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said that although it went public in November 1984, it did not ship its first product until August 1986.

title: INSIDE ALBANY, A POLITICAL HANGOVER
description: Like a cheerleading squad that has just discovered it is chanting for the wrong team, Albany today wore a sheepish expression.
