title: SAGE SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
AMERICAN CENTURY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GEICO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $33,988,666 for the quarter and $98,477,843 for the year. c-Includes capital gains of $38,941,104 and $92,939,880 for the quarter and year, respsectively.

title: WHY WOMEN ARE OUTSIDERS TO INSIDER TRADING
description: LEAD: Why is it that no women were among the professionals indicted in the recent Wall Street insider trading scandal? A dozen male investment banking or legal professionals have been indicted so far, but no women. Why? Approximately one-quarter of the Street's professionals, and a larger share of corporate lawyers, are women.

title: KIDDE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $25 million from discontinued operations. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $6,372,000 fro the quarter and $24,598,000 for the year. The company said discontinued operations for 1986 includes a charge, net of related tax benefits of $10 million, in connection with a patent infringement suit related to a former subsidiary. The company said the 1985 amounts for discontinued operations is comprised of the results for the divested building hardware and banking equipment segment and includes a net gain on the sale of that segment of approximately $150 million which was offset by reductions in book values of previously discontinued operations and provisions for carrying and other costs related to those operations.

title: MOORE MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
BREAK-INS BY F.B.I. DENIED BY OFFICIAL
description: A top official of the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified today that the bureau was ''not involved in any capacity'' in break-ins against churches and organizations opposed to the Government's activities in Central America.

title: POLYMER INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $217,000 and $501,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and tax credits of $19,000 and $310,000 for the same periods, respectively.

title: BAD NEWS FOR AUTOMOBILE BUYERS
description: LEAD: Japan's ''temporary'' quotas on auto exports to the United States celebrate their sixth birthday soon: appropriately, on April Fool's Day. Though the restrictions were originally intended to last three years at most, Detroit auto executives and Japanese bureaucrats seem determined to nurse them well into their teens.

title: TEXAS UTILITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INTERPROVINCIAL STEEL & PIPE LINE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results are in Canadian currency.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: The company said in the latest quarter and 6 months, earnings were lowered by $7.5 million due to a change in the accounting method for advertising expenses.

title: N. Philip Bastedo, 78; Led Hospital Trustees
description: N. Philip Bastedo, a lawyer and former president of the trustees of the Hospital for Special Surgery, died Thursday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: REAGAN UNAWARE OF ANY 'COVER-UP', A SPOKESMAN SAYS
description: President Reagan ''was not aware'' of any ''cover-up'' of his role in the Iran arms affair, his chief spokesman said today, and the President said he was not worried about what a commission investigating the operation would say when its report comes out next week.

title: THE DANCE: 'PRODIGAL SON'
description: Peter Boal's debut in the title role of George Balanchine's ''Prodigal Son'' at the State Theater on Wednesday night is typical of the increased opportunities given to young dancers in the New York City Ballet.

title: GERBER SCIENTIFIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said that effective May 1, 1986 it began capitalizing certain software development costs with accordance with FASB No. 86 and this change increased net by one cent a share in the latest quarter and by 3 cents a share in the 9 months.

title:
PATENTS;
Cooling A Nuclear Reactor
description: LEAD: EQUIPMENT designed to collect and cool the core elements of a nuclear reactor in case of overheating has been invented for the Department of Energy.

title: Northwestern Steel Rejects a Merger
description: The Northwestern Steel and Wire Company said its directors had reviewed and decided to reject a revised offer to merge with a company to be formed by Bennett Lebow, a private investor. Negotiations have been discontinued.

title: Levine Gets 2-Year Jail Term
description: Dennis B. Levine, the former investment banker whose arrest last May led to the unraveling of the most serious insider-trader scandal in Wall Street history, was sentenced here today to two years in a Federal prison and ordered to pay $362,000 in fines.

title: NAVISTAR INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $113 million and an extraordinary gain of $6 million. c-Net income and after an extraordinary gain of $14 million.

title:
PATENTS;
Anti-Snoring Device
description: LEAD: An electronic anti-snoring device was patented this week by a resident of Vaucluse, Australia. Patent 4,644,330, granted to Anthony R. Dowling, explains that the instrument is mounted on the outer ear. When it detects snoring sounds, it generates what is called an aversive audio signal, which irritates the sleeper and causes the snoring to stop.

title: GO METRIC AND STAY IN THE ECONOMIC FAST LANE
description: To the Editor:

title: SEMICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $699,000 for the quarter and $1,280,000 for the 6 months, and a loss of $2,418,000 related to provisions for disposition for both periods. c-Includes a gain of $220,000 from distribution from venture capital investments for both periods, and includes losses from discontinued operations of $363,000 and $693,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: WHERE 'AMERIKA' HITS CLOSE TO HOME
description: Some women got together at Alice's Restaurant the other morning, as they do every day in this central Wisconsin town. They talked about the warm spell, the upcoming Alice in Dairyland contest and, between sips of coffee, the ABC mini-series ''Amerika.''

title: CUOMO REMARKS ON DECISION NOT TO RUN IN '88
description: Following are excerpts from comments today by Governor Cuomo in an interview with The New York Times and at a new conference on his decision not to seek the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination: INTERVIEW

title: Argentine Warning on Debt
description: A top Government official said tonight that Argentina could suspend payments on its $45 billion foreign debt if commercial banks refuse to provide financing needed to meet the country's growth targets.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE ENTERPRISE GROUP INC reports earnings for 12mo Jan 31
description: Year-ago net is restated for accounting changes for disallowances and prior plan abandonments. Results for all periods include the continuing effect of the application of Statement No. 90 of the FASB 90; this reflects, among other factors, the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities direct disallowance of $431.5 million of Public Service Electric & Gas Co.'s cost to build the Hope Creek generating station. The company is listed on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange.

title: SIR HUGH GREENE, 76, DIES IN LONDON
description: Sir Hugh Carleton Greene, a former director general of the British Broadcasting Corporation and a brother of Graham Greene, the novelist, died of cancer Thursday at a London hospital. He was 76 years old. Sir Hugh headed the BBC television and radio networks from 1960 until 1969. He joined the BBC in 1940 as head of its wartime broadcasts to Germany after having served as chief correspondent in Berlin for The Daily Telegraph until shortly before the outbreak of World War II.

title: GULF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains of $219 million, mainly from the sale of petroleum refining and marketing downstream assets, and an extraordinary charge of $90 million related to debt redemption. c-Includes a gain of $93 million from the formation of a partnership and a loss of $80 million related to the sale of refining and marketing assets.

title: KING IS ELECTED TO TENNIS HALL OF FAME
description: This week has brought a flood of memories, Billie Jean King said, recollections of her youth spent playing tennis on public courts in southern California, of the unquenchable thirst she had for learning all she could about the history of the game.

title: THE RIGHT TO LIE?
description: More than 100 law enforcement agents are now searching for Dennis Malvasi, a suspect in recent dynamite attacks against New York City abortion clinics. He is a fireworks expert who worked on last year's Statue of Liberty celebrations and is described as ''clever, elusive and experienced.'' A similar description could well be applied to other ''pro-life'' zealots, to judge by a recent hearing before a House subcommittee. These activists prefer deceit to violence.

title: CUOMO CITES FACTORS IN DECISION: FAMILY, JOB AND GRUELING RACE <
description: Governor Cuomo said today that the demands on his family, the burdens of heading the state government and the grueling full-time effort that a White House campaign would entail were some of the major factors in his decision not to seek the Presidency.

title: Atari Profits Up 54.4%
description: Buoyed by strong sales of its ST personal computer and a resurgence in the video game market, the Atari Corporation today reported fourth-quarter earnings of $23 million, or 87 cents a share, up 54.4 percent from $14.9 million, or 64 cents a share, a year ago. Fourth-quarter 1986 results include an extraordinary credit of $11 million. Sales rose 41.7 percent, to $92.7 million, from $65.4 million a year ago. For all of 1986, Atari earned $44.5 million, or $1.89 a share. In 1985 it had a loss of $14.3 million. Sales for the year rose 81.8 percent, to $258.1 million, from $142 million in 1985.

title: Turkey
description: To the Editor: My husband and I, having spent a week on the Anatolian coast of Turkey last October, certainly share Mr. Raphael's enthusiasm for Turkey. We only regret that more was not said about the coastal resort town of Bodrum and the beauty of the Anatolian landscape. We rented a car in Izmir in order to go south to Bodrum for a few days, and the drive through the mountains and the broad, cotton-growing valleys was marvellous, going past great herds of black goats and the occasional camel. Moreover, Bodrum itself more than fulfilled all our expectations.

title:
MUSIC;
'SOUTH PACIFIC', THE SHOW THAT COULDN'T MISS
description: LEAD: When the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical ''South Pacific'' burst upon Broadway 38 years ago amid a torrent of advance publicity, it became one of the theater's historic megahits, opening with what was then a record-breaking advance sale - nearly $500,000. It had all the right ingredients: a Pulitzer Prize-winning book by James Michener for its source, music and lyrics by the men responsible for ''Oklahoma!

title: La SALLE TIES FOR FIRST BY STOPPING ST. PETER'S
description: La Salle kept St. Peter's scoreless for almost four minutes toward the end of the game tonight to post a 68-61 victory that enabled it to tie the Peacocks for first place in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference.

title: Cathy Reid Is Engaged To James Stranberg Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Gavin Reid Jr. of Mendham, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Cathy Elizabeth Reid to James Edward Stranberg Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stranberg of Boston. The wedding is to be in May. The future bride, a graduate of the American School in London and Ithaca College, is a candidate for a nursing degree at Boston University. Her father is president of the Exxon Company, International, in Florham Park, N.J., a subsidiary of the Exxon Corporation.

title: Turkey
description: To the Editor: ''Where History's Sweep Conquers the Visitor'' by Frederic Raphael (Travel, Jan. 18) was really a delight (Turkish). It warmed the cockles of our hearts. My wife and I have been vacationing in Turkey for about six years. Wherever we traveled, always by public bus, we were befriended by the warmest, most caring people we have met in our travels. That includes England, France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Greece and China. The friendships we formed are our most precious rewards.

title: HIGHER EDUCATION: ONGOING CHALLENGE
description: T. EDWARD HOLLANDER, the state's Chancellor of Higher Education and one of the most senior education chancellors in the country, was to be named to his third five-year term last week by the Board of Higher Education.

title: Raising the Stakes In North Dakota
description: NORTH DAKOTA, which bans most Sunday shopping and has no state lottery, moved cautiously to expand its charity gambling in 1981 by authorizing blackjack. For the first three years the take from the card game climbed steadily. Then it dropped sharply.

title: Rangers Are Regrouping
description: The Rangers had been looking ahead in grand terms. Some players had even talked about challenging the Flyers for the top of the Patrick Division. That's what six victories in seven games and a second place standing can do to a team's self-image. But a small backslide has humbled the Rangers.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Students are expressing diminished confidence in their ability to shoulder the responsibilities of adulthood. More and more I hear students say: It's the administration's responsibility to take care of us. Ten years ago most students would have laughed at that notion.'' - Edgar F. Beckham, dean of the college at Wesleyan University. [ 1:6. ]

title: A CORNER OF INDIA STIRS HOPE FOR UNITY
description: Christian churches scattered in the hills of this remote corner of India summon their worshipers with a resonant brass gong. Hymns are sung slowly to the beat of old tribal drums.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: WOMEN WRITING ABOUT MEN. By Jane Miller. (Pantheon, Paper, $8.95.) Women have long written about men as fathers, brothers, lovers, sons, heroes and, as Adrienne Rich said, ''the phantom of the man-who-would-understand'' - the double. But because female writers have needed, according to Jane Miller, ''to be extremely circumspect'' in these portrayals, many critics have assumed that women write only of themselves. Ms. Miller, who teaches at the University of London Institute of Education, demolishes this condescending misreading in ''Women Writing About Men.'' Feminist discussion of novels by women has usually focused on female characters; in considering male characters created by women, Ms. Miller attempts more than a gallery stroll past the Mr. Rochesters and Daniel Derondas of literature. Studying Jane Austen's fictional fathers, the author analyzes how women have rationalized their own subordination. Reviewing the male characters of Maxine Hong Kingston and Toni Morrison, she questions the view of ''patriarchy'' as an abstract term separate from those that designate other forms of oppression. Central to Ms. Miller's book is her recognition of women's ''learned androgyny,'' a way of thinking that allows them as readers to enter into stories such as ''Moby-Dick'' that exclude them. The author offers a powerful insight into why feminist criticism strikes some women as narrow, since it requires them to see male characters as ''other.'' She urges women readers to ''unlearn androgyny,'' not only to appreciate portraits of men by women but also to sensitize them to exclusionary situations in life.

title: Phyllis E. Kaplan Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Kaplan of Smithtown, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Phyllis E. Kaplan to Martin Stephen Kalish, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Kalish of Short Hills, N.J. Ms. Kaplan is president of Ziba Designs in New York and Bennington, Vt., a designer and manufacturer of fabrics, wall coverings and rugs. Her fiance is a photographer who owns Photographer's Eye in Manchester, Vt.

title: WHERE DECONSTRUCTION BEGINS
description: To the Editor:

title: ARTISTS IN THE HOUSE
description: The Esthetic Movement in America in the decade from the 1870's to the 1880's has been neglected until recently by scholars of the decorative arts. Among the major American art figures working then were the painter James McNeill Whistler, the glassmaker Louis Comfort Tiffany and the architect H. H. Richardson, who designed Trinity Church in Boston. Now, thanks to the catalog for a recent major exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, such independent artists are treated for the first time as an integral part of a design movement that encouraged hand-crafted objects in the belief that beautiful domestic interiors would affect their inhabitants in a positive way. IN PURSUIT OF BEAUTY: Americans and the Aesthetic Movement (Metropolitan Museum of Art/Rizzoli, $60), explores a period inspired by a British movement that had reacted against the Industrial Revolution's machine-made products. The 11 essays by scholars range from general social history to such specific crafts as stained glass and metalwork. We learn that some of the country's greatest museums - the Metropolitan itself, the Boston Museum of Fine Arts and the Philadelphia Museum of Art, for example - were founded during these years in which art schools and publications burgeoned, women in the arts rose to prominence and, in American cities, a new profession emerged, that of the interior decorator. A ''Dictionary of Architects, Artisans, Artists, and Manufacturers'' compiled by Catherine Hoover Voorsanger, a research associate at the Metropolitan, gives a brief, invaluable account of the major personalities of the decade - when art was meant to be useful, not just beautiful.

title: Rio de Janeiro
description: To the Editor: Anyone going to Rio de Janeiro who remembers Carmen Miranda, the ''Brazilian Bombshell,'' in those wonderful 1940's movie musicals might want to visit the little-known Carmen Miranda Museum. We found it in the public park along Flamingo Beach about a 10-minute taxi ride from our hotel on Copacabana Beach.

title: 'ENTREPRENEURS NIGHT'
description: ''Entrepreneurial Success -- Making It Happen'' is the theme of an ''Entrepreneurs Night'' program sponsored by the Westchester Small Business Council, an affiliate of the County Chamber of Commerce. It is scheduled for 5:30 to 7:30 P.M. Wednesday at the Chase NEW Division Bank at 31 Mamaroneck Avenue in White Plains.

title: AND IN THE RUNNER-UP SPOT
description: Many players have won more than one world team championship, but very few indeed own more than one world pair title. Only one of them, Mary Jane Farell of Los Angeles, has done so with different partners. She captured the Mixed Pairs in Amsterdam in 1966, with Ivan Erdos, and the Women's Pairs with Marilyn Johnson four years later in Stockholm.

title: BUT HELP IS ON THE HORIZON
description: STATE Senator John A. Lynch, Republican of the 17th District (parts of Middlesex and Union Counties), the Senate majority leader and also Mayor of New Brunswick, has asked the state's Capital Budget and Planning Commission to review his proposal for a cultural capital-improvement fund, a $90 million bond issue that would provide grants for art centers and historic buildings operated by the state.

title: Pop Music
description: The worlds of rock-and-roll and show music converge happily in the music of Marc Shaiman, the composer of the Off Broadway shows ''Dementos'' and ''Livin' Dolls'' and the musical director, arranger and accompanist for a host of cabaret performers. At the Bottom Line (15 West Fourth Street) on Monday, Mr. Shaiman will bring back the delightful revue of his songs, ''Marc Shaiman: The First 50 Years'' that he presented at the club for one night just over a month ago to enthusiastic acclaim.

title: Dr. Beth Lori Carlson Will Marry Next June
description: Dr. Beth Lori Carlson and Dr. Bruce Ganem plan to be married in June, the mother of the future bride, Marian Carlson of West Chester, Pa., has announced.

title: Brutality Cases Decline in 1986
description: After a steady rise in the 1980's, the number of brutality complaints filed against New York City police officers decreased slightly last year, according to the department's Civilian Complaint Review Board.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Excited (Stuffed?) Shirt

title: Tales Of Taxation
description: If Andrew Tobias's idea of tax heaven is just a smaller bite, he has found it in Florida. If he thinks he has found a paradise in which tax liability is clear and logical, he just hasn't reckoned with DR-601l (to start the confusion, that last digit is not a one, but a small L). This is the Individual and Fiduciary Intangible Personal Tax Return.

title:
ANTIQUES;
ENTHUSIASM FOR BOOKPLATES REVIVES
description: LEAD: What once was predominantly a European preoccupation - the collecting of bookplates - recently has made some American inroads. Bookplates, specially designed labels pasted into books to signify ownership, sparked interest in this country at the turn of the century and in the 1920's and 30's. But the World

title: IS 'OLD NASSAU' SEXIST? PRINCETON EXAMINES ITS SCHOOL SONG
description: Which alma mater should Princetonians sing, the old ''Old Nassau'' or the new ''Old Nassau''?

title: THE DRIVE TO EXCEL
description: THEY KNOW DAVID Kuo well in the mathematics department of the Bronx High School of Science. They have known him since the first day of his first year, when he told the chairman that he understood everything in freshman geometry. They gave him a test and discovered he was right; he answered all the questions correctly. So they told him he would be placed in sophomore math. ''I know that, too,'' said David. So they gave him another test, and then another. Finally, they placed him, 14 years old, loose-limbed and lanky as a newborn colt, in honors pre-calculus, an advanced junior math class. At the end of the term, his grade was 100.

title: Monitor Relics Going To Virginia Museum
description: More than 100 artifacts from the Monitor, the Civil War ironclad warship, will be placed in the Mariners' Museum here and will give Virginia a national reputation in its maritime history, according to the the museum executive director.

title: BRAVING THE YAMASHITA 'CURSE'
description: The Yamashita treasure, a hoard of stolen gold and jewelry said to have been hidden in the Philippines by a Japanese general during World War II, has the reputation of laying a curse on anyone possessing it. That did not stop John K. Singlaub, the retired American Army general, from requesting permission to hunt the hoard in 209 locations. Some Filipinos say treasure-hunting may be ''a cover activity'' for General Singlaub, who was in Washington last week to testify about his role in the Iran-contra affair. In the Philippines, he has reportedly been meeting with right-wing groups, urging them to defend themselves against Communists and purported leftists in the Aquino Government. American Embassy and Philippine officials dismissed the political theories, and General Singlaub insisted he was just looking for treasure as part of a venture to try to boost the local economy.

title: Deirdre Gibbons Is Wed in Jersey
description: Deirdre Elizabeth Gibbons, the daughter of Judge and Mrs. John J. Gibbons of Short Hills, N.J., and Hyannis, Mass., was married yesterday to John Anthony Kvartunas, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley J. Kvartunas of Glastonbury, Conn. The Rev. Gerald Greaves performed the ceremony at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills.

title: WHERE DECONSTRUCTION BEGINS
description: To the Editor:

title: HEARING TO FOCUS ON REACTOR PLAN
description: In 40 years as the regulator of what President Eisenhower once called ''the peaceful atom,'' the Government has not seen the likes of the public debate on commercial nuclear power that it will stage here Monday.

title: GETTING A TASTE OF HARVARD
description: Visitors to Cambridge, Mass., can sample Harvard, tasting a bit of the undergraduate extracurricular experience for the price of a dinner. At the Hasty Pudding Club, one of Harvard's original secret societies, a restaurant called Upstairs at the Pudding is open to the public.

title: Politicians Are Always Party Leaders
description: I read your Jan. 25 front-page article, ''Mondello's Dual Role: Voter Reaction Feared,'' with great interest. There is not one line of proof in your article concerning possible voter reaction.

title: Raise Taxes Instead
description: To the Editor:

title: Blowing Up the 60's
description: THIS REALLY HAPPENED. I'm not kidding.

title: WASTE BILLS: MIXED REVIEWS
description: LEAD: A New York City-based environmental research organization has given only mixed reviews to a package of bills introduced in the State Senate last month to encourage industry to reduce the production and disposal of hazardous waste.

title: CONTRAS FIGHTING EACH OTHER AGAIN
description: The leaders of the Nicaraguan rebels kept up the fight last week -with each other.

title: Bonus on Hold
description: THE New York Racing Association has been forced to delay and possibly withdraw the promotion, announced Thursday, that would have added a bonus to certain Pick Six payoffs. Gerard J. McKeon, president of the N.Y.R.A., announced Friday that, because of an objection to the planned promotion lodged by the Offtrack Betting Corporation with the New York State Racing and Wagering Board, the board would review the matter and announce a decision some time this week. In a phone call to McKeon, Richard Corbisiero, the wagering board chairman, asked that the promotion, which was scheduled to take effect yesterday, be put on hold temporarily. OTB's complaint is based on its belief that adding a bonus to any Pick Six payoff would create differing payoffs on and off the track. The N.Y.R.A. contends that, because the bonus money would come from its promotion budget, not the parimutuel pool, there would be no such inequity.

title: HOW DO YOU FEEL ABOUT SPRING TRAINING?
description: How would I feel about being a billionaire? It can't happen soon enough! VICKI GREENWALD Riverdale, N.Y.

title: Coaching The Referees
description: In his article ''Will Instant Replay Trip the Ref?'' (Jan. 25), Malcolm Moran poses the question: ''On close plays at the highest level of professional sports competition, is just under 90 percent accuracy a passing grade?''

title: PHILIP LAWRENCE, STAGE ACTOR
description: Philip Lawrence, an actor and director noted for his work in Shakespearean and other classical stage productions, died Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan of complications resulting from diabetes. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CARDINAL PARECATTIL
description: Joseph Cardinal Parecattil, retired Roman Catholic Archbishop of Ernakulam in southern India, died Friday in Cochin, the United News of India reported today. He was 74 years old.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia;
From a Church Into Offices
description: LEAD: EDWARD S. BROWN, a local developer, plans to convert the historic Church of the New Jerusalem at the western end of the city office core into a 21,300-square-foot office building.

title: GANDHI AND ZIA MEET IN INDIA
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan and Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India conferred at dinner this evening and expressed satisfaction at the way they had defused a crisis over troop buildups on their border last month.

title: U.S. PLANS TO INCREASE WAR GAMES IN LATIN AMERICA
description: The commander of United States forces in Latin America, Gen. John R. Galvin, says he plans to expand the American military presence in his region next year.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL Oliver North's secretary acknowledged, under a grant of immunity, destroying National Security Council documents in the hours before the Justice Department planned to review the colonel's files, her lawyer said. Page 1 Instructions to U.S. arms negotiators from President Reagan include not negotiating limits on defensive systems that would be more restrictive than the Administration's new interpretation of the treaty, officials said. 1 A new Soviet weapons test policy has been indicated by Mikhail S. Gorbachev. He said the Soviet Union would announce its next nuclear weapons test in advance instead of maintaining silence, as in the past. 20 A large cache of Soviet-made arms sitting unclaimed in a warehouse in Honduras is one of the latest mysteries emerging from the Federal and Congressional investigations of the private network to arm the Nicaraguan rebels. 16 International talks on the economy and stabilizing currency values open in Paris this weekend. Indicators show that economic growth in Europe and Japan has new signs of weakness, largely a result of the dollar's recent fall. 1 Latin America's financial instability has been the focus of attention since Brazil's decision Friday to suspend most debt payments. Indebted nations have been unable to recover the sustained growth needed to lighten their burdens. 11 A greater presence in Latin America is planned next year by the commander of United States forces in the region, Gen. John R. Galvin, who said sustained support could enable the contras to defeat Nicaragua's Government. 16 Some 4,000 Syrian troops near Beirut struck camp and an unconfirmed report said their scouts were in a suburb of the capital. Their arrival was sought by Moslem leaders to quell a week of fighting among Moslem factions. 17 The British-Irish agreement's future is in doubt because of the victory of Charles J. Haughey in Ireland. Despite official assurances that the agreement will hold, some are against it. 3 Pressure on the left in Madrid 3 A Soviet no-exit list. 5 NATIONAL 22-31, 44-48

title: When the Jungle Turns to Wasteland
description: FROM New York's Columbus Avenue to the world's tropical forests, the life and death of trees occupied the attention of many scientists at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science last week in Chicago. They assessed the effects of acid rain in the Adirondacks, issued dire updates on the spread of deserts in sub-Saharan Africa and discussed the benefits of agroforestry, the practice of growing crops side by side with nitrogen-fixing trees. The keynote speaker, Peter H. Raven, argued that one of the world's most pressing problems is the destruction of tropical forests and its effect on climate, biological diversity and human well-being. Following are excerpts from the conference. A BIOLOGICAL CATASTROPHE

title: Power and the Congressional Aide
description: Behind every member of Congress stand aides who, depending on the issue and the member of Congress, can wield a heady amount of power.

title: Comings and Goings
description: He hasn't fought in 10 years and at 38 he may seem a bit old to be staging a comeback, but not according to the California Athletic Commission. It approved a license for George Foreman, the former heavyweight champion, who plans a March 3 bout in Sacramento against an opponent to be selected. . . . Dan Reeves, the coach of the Denver Broncos, confirmed that he had held informal discussions with the Tampa Bay coach, Ray Perkins, about the possibility of trading for the rights to Bo Jackson, the former Auburn running back and Heisman Trophy winner who turned down a Tampa Bay offer and chose to play baseball for the Kansas City Royals. But Reeves scoffed at the notion that Jackson would give up baseball to play for the Broncos. The chances of that happening, Reeves said, are ''slim and none and slim just went out the door.''

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: Miss Gregory Plans to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Eugene Morris Cheston Jr. of Darien, Conn., and William Hamilton Gregory 3d of Glen Cove, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Lovering Gregory to John Stephen Wehrle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Lackey Wehrle of Ladue, Mo. The wedding is to be April 25. Miss Gregory, manager of international marketing at Prudential-Bache Securities in New York, graduated from Miss Hall's School and Skidmore College and received a master's degree from the American Graduate School of International Management in Glendale, Ariz. She made her debut in 1973 at the Autumn Ball in Tuxedo Park, N.Y. Her father is a partner in Delta Capital Management, an investment management firm in New York.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
Activity Accelerates at Old Drive-In Site
description: LEAD: FOLLOWING years of delay, construction is about to start on one of the Island's most valuable undeveloped commercial sites, a 41.7-acre parcel on Route 110 in Melville.

title: WINTER'S TALE: TOO LONG, TOO COLD
description: THIS is the winter of my discontent, and like failing eyesight, forgetfulness, and cellulite, it is very much a byproduct of middle age. I used to love winter. The brisk weather, the beautiful snow, and the opportunity to ski were welcome, but too brief, changes in the cycle of the year. I don't love winter now.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: POINTING THE WAY The final week of Black History Month will be observed at Westchester Community College with a symposium that addresses the unusual issues facing black children in suburban schools and communities. A panel of four educators will discuss the issues at 11 A.M. Wednesday in Room 102 of the Science Building. Admission is free.

title: Television
description: Getting James Baldwin's ''Go Tell It on the Mountain'' to television took a great deal of time and dedication on the part of its producers, Robert Geller and Cal Skaggs, but the effort was worth it as can be seen once again on American Playhouse, Monday at 9 P.M. on channels 13 and 49. It is a lovely film, rich in detail and emotional reverberations. Mr. Baldwin's partly autobiographical story is told through the eyes of a boy living in Harlem in the 1930's. John Grimes (James Bond 3d), approaching his 14th birthday, lives in a world circumscribed by school, where his white teachers recognize his writing talent; by church, where the black experience explodes in hypnotic sermons and songs; and by home, where his father Gabriel (Paul Winfield) uses the Bible to warn of the sins of the world and of white folk in particular. Stan Lathan directs a superb cast that also includes Olivia Cole, Rosalind Cash, Ruby Dee, Alfre Woodard, C. C. H. Pounder, Linda Hopkins and Douglas Turner Ward. The final church scene alone is reason enough not to miss this film. Religious experiences are not readily accessible to peering cameras, but Mr. Lathan and his photographer, Hiro Narita, have caught the drive and energy of the gospel music in images that are mesmerizing. Young John's spiritual experience is not only convincing but thrilling as we climb his personal mountain with him.

title: JAZZ: ELSON AND HORNS
description: STEVE ELSON and the Borneo Horns, a trio of saxophonists, make their livings in recording studios and funk bands, supplying soul-style riffs and terse, bluesy solos. But on his own, Mr. Elson also composes pieces that combine his studio skills - precise articulation and machine-tooled ensemble riffing - with forays into extended harmony, shifty rhythms and wry humor. He played some of those pieces Monday and Tuesday at Dance Theater Workshop with the trio (Mr. Elson, Alex Foster and Lenny Pickett on saxophones of all sizes) plus Mark Helias on bass and David Rosenberg on drums. It was amiable music that balanced ambition and entertainment value.

title: Looks as Different as Night and Day
description: FOR all the elegance a tuxedo imparts, when men put on black tie for a formal evening, they are really just changing from a suit to, well, another suit.

title: IN DEFENSE OF THE BLACK MARKET
description: HERNANDO DE SOTO HAS NEVER TAKEN MUCH for granted.

title: KEEPING A CLOSER WATCH ON CONTRACTORS
description: WHEN Kenneth Conboy accepted his new assignment as Commissioner of Investigation a year ago, soon after the start of New York City's corruption scandals, he made the city's contracting procedures a high priority. He expected to find them, he said, ''suffused with the grossest kind of political influence and profiteering.''

title: CALIFORNIA ON A COZY SCALE
description: If you want toys or bicycles in Half Moon Bay, a coastal farming community about 30 miles south of San Francisco, you go to the small blue house on Main Street just across the Main Street Bridge. This is The Toy Pedaler, a five-room cottage stocked to the rafters with kites, kaleidoscopes, hand-cranked carousels, trail bikes, thingamabobs and gadgets. Though my five-month-old son Nathaniel and I had been in only once before, we both seemed to find what we were looking for: he found bright plastic blocks and I found sand buckets and toy boats in the bathroom, which of course won me over.

title: DEVILS END THREE-GAME SLIDE
description: Andy Brickley scored twice in the first period, and the Devils held on to end a three-game losing streak with a 6-5 victory tonight over the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: VOTE FOR AUTHORS
description: A contest for the most popular author in Westchester is going on in county libraries and bookstores, where readers can vote until March 15 for their favorites among 21 local writers whose books have been published in the last two years.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: FLIPPING FOR IT. By Daniel Asa Rose. (St. Martin's, $14.95.) This first novel feels like a detective story, though it's about the pains of divorce. The dialogue is matter-of-fact; the action, over a four-week period, moves episodically; the secondary characters are colorful and talk cynically, with dark humor. The main character even gets to spend a lot of time in a nightclub drinking and staring at women. Not unlike some detective novels, this one begins with an unexpected revelation. Thomas, a young zoologist, is told by his wife, Jane, that he must move into the guest room - immediately - and that she has already seen a lawyer. Her reasons are vague: ''It's just that some women don't want men to tie them down to any commitments any longer.'' Her motives don't become much clearer with time, though Thomas tries desperately to uncover them. When the inevitability of the breakup finally dawns on Thomas, the custody of his two children becomes a main issue. He hires a famous, cold-blooded divorce lawyer. Frustrated, lonely, weakened, he does absolutely everything he is told not to do in order to insure a favorable outcome in the case. Despite a penchant for histrionics, Daniel Asa Rose, a winner of the O. Henry Prize for short fiction, wants to say some rather simple things about hurt and loss. For the most part, he succeeds. In the end, the quesions Thomas asks about the divorce -Why? Whose fault is it? - are blurred and practically meaningless. We are left with the drama of two people sundering their lives. This old subject is told with freshness, humor and, when the author puts affected writing aside, great openness of heart.

title: TOOTH FAIRY PUTS THE BITE ON DAD
description: GREG had waited for this day for a long time. He had witnessed his older brother, Chris, losing several baby teeth, followed by the inevitable visit from the Tooth Fairy. Finally, one of his own teeth had fallen out, and at last he could look forward to the reward being under his pillow.

title: Former Governor Will Seek Top Post in Kentucky Again
description: John Y. Brown Jr. has entered the Democratic race for his old job, ending months of speculation about whether the former Governor would attempt a political comeback.

title: Marist Sets Back Wagner by 80-64
description: Ron McCants scored 18 points and Rik Smits and Miroslav Pecarski added 14 each as Marist coasted to an 80-64 victory over Wagner yesterday at Madison Square Garden.

title: PEERING INTO THE ENERGY FUTURE AND SIGHTING GAS SHORTAGES
description: THE United States will start to run out of gas, many analysts agree, in as little as three decades.

title: What Price Progress on the Hudson?
description: DRIVING within sight of the river's edge from the George Washington Bridge south to the marsh grass and reeds of Caven Point in Jersey City, it is possible, in less than an hour, to get a good measure of the rapid development under way along the New Jersey side of the Hudson River.

title: Kidder Faces Life After Siegel
description: IN the days when Martin A. Siegel was riding high as one of the country's top takeover specialists, junior associates at Kidder, Peabody & Company admiringly called him the barracuda. ''He was pretty, he was smooth and he was fast,'' one of them explained.

title: Adopt Pension System
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Wilmington Club Rejects Women

title: Patricia M. Wiley Marries Robert Suhr in Louisville
description: Patricia M. Wiley, director of new product development at the National Distillers Products Company in New York, was married yesterday to Robert Suhr, president of Southeastern Dairies in Louisville, Ky. The Rev. Neil Sessions performed the ceremony at the Hustborne Baptist Church in Louisville.

title: WHEN ROOFS COLLAPSE ON MEMORY
description: ORDINARILY, my wife never speaks before her second cup of coffee. And when she does, it's usually to the coffee pot. But this morning began quickly with her plaintive lament: ''Oh, no. Oh, no. Oh, no.''

title: AN ADOBE MAZE FOR MODERN EXPLORERS
description: On a bright day in winter the ruins of Casas Grandes are deserted except for a caretaker hoeing weeds around one of the unexcavated mounds. He comes to collect the admission charge of 120 pesos (about 13 cents) from the foreign visitors, expresses regret that the government in Mexico City has not yet sent brochures to replenish his stock, and goes back to work, leaving us with the ancient plazas, the ceremonial mounds and the adobe maze all to ourselves.

title: HOW WE CAN ENCOURAGE GORBACHEV'S CHANGES
description: To the Editor:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Lake Milton, Ohio;
Uncertainty For a Dry Spot
description: LEAD: IN 1982, the largest muskellunge caught in North America was pulled out of Lake Milton. It was the only lake in Ohio where muskie spawned.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest:

title:
GARDENING;
UNPALATABLE PLANTS MAY DISCOURAGE DEER
description: LEAD: AS the suburbs expanded during the 50's and 60's, a frequently heard lament was that of the demise of certain forms of wildlife as their habitat was absorbed into the growing megalopolis. All sorts of animals began to disappear from the developing areas, including deer.

title: HOW DO YOU FEEL ABOUT SPRING TRAINING?
description: For me, spring training means that maybe, just maybe, the world will stop talking about the 1986 World Series. As recently as Feb. 16 The Times rean an article about the Mets' victory in game 6, complete with a photo of the famous ball-between-the-legs play. Poor me. Poor Red Sox fans everywhere.

title: Q and A
description: Nonpurchasing Tenant Question: What would be my position if the owner of my rent-stabilized apartment in a nonevict co-op defaulted in maintenance payments?. . . P. C., Manhattan Answer: If the owner of your apartment failed to make maintenance payments, the co-op board would take legal action against the owner, not against you. Your status as a rent-stabilized tenant would remain intact even in the co-op board found it necessary to take over the apartment and sell it to another investor. Transferring Space Question: We own two apartments in a nonevict co-op building - the one we live in and the adjacent unit, which is occupied by the original rent-stabilized tenant. Can we renovate the two units to take some space from the rental unit and add it to ours? If we lower the tenant's rent by an amount commensurate with the reduction in space, is her consent necessary? If not, whose approval would be necessary for such a renovation other than the co-op board's? . . . K. N., Manhattan Answer: If your tenant objects, you cannot do such a renovation, said Thomas R. Viola, spokesman for the state's Department of Housing and Community Renewal. If your tenant were to agree to such a plan, you would have to file an application with the agency for ''reduction in rent pursuant to reduction in service,'' including a description of what the agreement entails.

title: Pirates Better, Thrift Says
description: Syd Thrift, attempting to rebuild a losing team with young talent, said today that the Pittsburgh Pirates would show enough improvement this season to justify his rehiring as general manager.

title:
FILM;
10 YEARS INTO THE STALLONE ERA: WHAT IT, UH, ALL MEANS
description: LEAD: There are many ways to assess movie greatness. If measured by box-office receipts alone, there's been nobody greater during the past decade than Sylvester Stallone, a.k.a. Rocky Balboa, John Rambo, Marion (Cobra) Cobretti and, most recently, Lincoln Hawk of ''Over the Top.''

title: THE MIDWIVES' TALES
description: THE SEVEN AGES By Eva Figes. 186 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $14.95.

title: Touch for Tennis
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: RECENT CASSETTES
description: Gilbert and Sullivan: Their Greatest Hits Vivian Tierney, soprano; Patricia Leonard, contralto; Geoffrey Shovelton, tenor; Peter Pratt, baritone; Alan Ayldon, bass-baritone. Hertfordshire County Youth Orchestra and massed choral voices led by the Royal Choral Society. Marcus Dods, conductor. Vestron MusicVideo. 54 minutes. $29.95.

title: MOTHER TESTIFIES AT MURDER TRIAL
description: Her son was attentive, she told the jury, sending her Valentine's Day cards, roses, notes and gifts. Had he been alive this Valentine's Day, he would have certainly called her, she testified.

title: PUBLISHER'S MINORITY MISSION
description: IN 1965, when John R. Miller 3d of Asharoken was working as a sales and marketing executive for Procter & Gamble in the Midwest, he hired and trained the company's first black salesman. ''I remember being thrown out of stores,'' Mr. Miller said. ''People were calling him names.''

title: Freeda Cathcart Plans To Be Married in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Armstrong Cathcart 3d of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Freeda Lynne Cathcart to Clinton Brady Stoneking, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Melvin Stoneking of Winchester, Va. The wedding is to be July 11.

title: TARGET QADDAFI
description: EIGHTEEN AMERICAN WARPLANES SET out from Lakenheath Air Base in England last April 14 to begin a 14-hour, 5,400-mile round-trip flight to Tripoli, Libya. It is now clear that nine of those Air Force F-111's had an unprecedented peacetime mission. Their targets: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and his family.

title: UPSTAGED BY PARENTS
description: LEAD: ONLY YESTERDAY By Julian Gloag. 170 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $15.95.

title: Midwinter Interludes
description: Martha Graham Party Feb. 23 - The Martha Graham Dance Company is 60 years old, and next on the list of projects for that legend of modern dance is the Martha Graham Dance School in Florence. A ''Diamond for Martha'' benefit auction at Christie's will celebrate the dual occasion, starting with cocktails and a buffet at the auction house at 6:30 P.M. An auction of items and events, including works by Andy Warhol and a walk-on part in the next Woody Allen movie, will follow, and the evening will conclude with a 9:15 P.M. supper next door at Regine's. Tickets, $300, or $50 for cocktail buffet and auction alone, from 212-832-9166. Preparing for Summer Feb. 27 - The fifth annual ''Hatter's Ball'' will be held in the Burden mansion at the Convent of the Sacred Heart at 7 East 91st Street. The 7-to-11-P.M. dance, with an open bar and hors d'oeuvres, will benefit scholarships for the summer creative arts program at Sacred Heart; the project offers, for boys and girls from 8 to 15 years old, courses in art, music, drama, dance, photography, film, video, computers and athletics. Cliff Robertson will receive an award. Tickets $40, from 212-722-4745, or $45 at the door. Helping Science Feb. 28 - The Weizmann Institute of Science in Rehovot, Israel, will benefit from an evening of live music, food, an open bar and entertainment at Harkness House, 4 East 75th Street. The black-tie dance starts at 9 P.M. Tickets $75, from 212-752-1300. Dinner at Four Seasons March 2 - Founded in 1920 to treat children with rheumatic fever, the Irvington House Institute for Medical Research has gone on to broader work in diseases and dysfunctions of the body's immune system. A black-tie benefit dinner for the institute will be held at the newly redecorated and renamed Bar Room - now the Grill Room - at the Four Seasons. Cocktails at 7 P.M. Tickets $500, from 212-758-8250. Nine-Party Benefit March 2 - Since its founding in 1971, Playwrights Horizons has promoted the works of contemporary American playwrights, presenting more than 200 readings, workshops and productions and winning numerous awards along the way. The organization will benefit from nine dinner parties in nine Manhattan homes, at which guests will dine with playwrights including Robert Anderson (''Tea and Sympathy''), John Guare (''The House of Blue Leaves''), James Lapine (''Sunday in the Park With George'') and Wendy Wasserstein (''Isn't It Romantic''). Party times vary. Guests may select a party attended by a specific playwright. Tickets $225, from 212-564-1235. Duke Ellington Tribute March 3 - Town Hall will reverberate to the music and memories of Duke Ellington when the pianist Bobby Short presents DancEllington, a company founded to promote tap dance and directed by Mercedes Ellington, the Duke's granddaughter. Performances will include ''Pretty and the Wolf,'' Ellington's musical fable, which will be danced to his own recorded narration. Following the concert, there will be a champagne supper-dance with music by the New Deal Swing Band across 43d Street at the New York-California Club. The evening benefits the Duke Ellington Memorial Fund, founded by Mr. Short in 1979 for the purpose of erecting a memorial to Ellington planned for the northeast entrance of Central Park at Fifth Avenue and 110th Street. Tickets $75 and $100, from 212-874-2390, or $10 and $25 for the concert alone, at the box office. Theater Party March 3 - A cocktail buffet at Sardi's from 6 to 7 P.M., then a bus ride to the Gershwin Theater for a preview showing of ''Starlight Express,'' followed by dinner in a private home will benefit the New York Infirmary-Beekman Downtown Hospital. Tickets $200 for buffet and performance and $500 to include the after-theater dinner, from 212-697-9575. Volunteers' Night Out March 4 - Now 30 years old, the New York City School Volunteer Program provides 30,000 volunteers who tutor and provide other help to children of all ages in the city's school system. A benefit for the group will start with a 6 P.M. cocktail buffet at the Equitable Tower on the 50th floor of the new Equitable Building, on Seventh Avenue at 51st Street. A preview performance of ''Les Miserables'' at the Broadway Theater will follow. Tickets $500 and $300, or $125 for performance alone, from 212-213-3370. French Accent March 5 - At Christie's there will be a New York celebration of the recent opening of the Musee d'Orsay in Paris, a magnificent structure that was once a railroad station and now houses a collection of artworks from 1850 through 1910. Prof. Robert Rosenblum of New York University will lecture at 6 P.M. on 'Painting,'' after which a champagne buffet will be served. An auction of rare maps, prints and books ranging from about $60 to $25,000 will follow. The event will benefit La Maison Francaise of Columbia University. Tickets $50, from 212-546-1121.

title: GHOSTLY THRONGS IN HALLS OF CULTURE
description: The Phantom of the Opera was at least there, at the opera house. Last week a report by the State Comptroller disclosed that attendance figures compiled by New York City cultural institutions had included thousands of phantoms who weren't there at all.

title: Q and A
description: French Canals Question: Where can we obtain information about arranging a canal or river trip by boat or barge - without crew - in France? We would like to do the trip ourselves, stopping along the way. - D. L., Boston Answer: Several French companies that rent houseboats in Brittany, along the Canal du Midi, the Camargue, Burgundy and other areas are represented by the French Experience (171 Madison Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10016; 212-683-2445). The boats accommodate two to eight people, have shower and galley and are equipped with utensils, dishes and linen. According to the French Experience, vacationers can set off along canal or river as soon as they have been given instructions on piloting and how to negotiate locks.

title: True Fat
description: Concern about osteoporosis, a crippling bone disorder that afflicts mainly elderly women, has spawned a cynical campaign by the dairy industry aimed at teen-age girls.

title: DRUG-ABUSE SPLITS HAMPTONS RESIDENTS
description: LEAD: AN effort to establish the first drug-abuse treatment facility on the East End has met with opposition from Town of Southampton officials and has divided residents.

title: California Museums, New Zealand Homesteads
description: Ancient Art, Modern Sites On West Coast

title: LESSONS TO BE LEARNED FROM 'AMERKIA'
description: The message in ''Amerika'' is this: We had it coming. It wasn't the Soviet Union; it was us.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: BRIEFING
description: Republican members of the House are planning to hold a historical conference all their own next month in observance of the opening of the current 100th Congress.

title: Housing Plans
description: To the Editor: One part of your Jan. 25 article, ''New York's Programs at Work at 'Allerton Coops' '' - the transfer of city-owned land to builders for agreements to produce debt-free units -was of special interest to me because it discussed a matter of concern to me and my community.

title: DATA UPDATE: February 22, 1987
description: (Source: HSH Associates) *Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes.

title:
ANTIQUES;
FOLK ART AND ARTIFACTS AT LAMBERT CASTLE
description: LEAD: A WHIMSICAL shop sign that drew attention to the business premises of a 19th-century tinsmith on Van Huten Street here is the centerpiece of an exhibition of folk art and artifacts currently on view at the Lambert Castle Museum.

title: 'ADOPT-A-HORSE' PLAN TO FIX BRIDGEPORT CAROUSEL
description: LEAD: BROKEN horses and chariots are on their way to being whole again in Bridgeport.

title: BEAUTY
description: THE INVENTORY AT THE cosmetics counter reads like an anatomy textbook. Lips, the T-zone from the forehead down the nose to the chin, arms, legs, hands, throat and breasts - all have been singled out for individual treatments. Today, though, the facial feature of the moment is the skin around the eyes. Beauty, it seems, is not the sum of many parts; it is the division of those parts into precisely defined packages.

title: Dicey Days at McDonnell Douglas
description: SANFORD N. McDONNELL, the 64-year-old chairman of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, often describes the aerospace industry as a ''Las Vegas-type'' business in which companies gamble billions of dollars every time they decide to develop a new plane.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: OUR FRIEND MANSO. By Benito Perez Galdos. Translated by Robert Russell. (Columbia University, $25.) Perez Galdos is one of the treasures of 19th-century Spanish fiction. ''Our Friend Manso'' (1882), here translated into English for the first time, reflects his prodigious, inexhaustible curiosity about the human condition and the limits of the novelist's art. Maximo Manso is a middle-aged professor of philosophy in Madrid, a competent, unambitious man who observes the human drama that surrounds him but in some fundamental way is unable to participate. This imperfect self-realization is but one symptom of his fictional status; indeed, the novel opens with Maximo's declaration that he does not exist. His subsequent parthenogenesis through a friend's inkwell, together with his mistily indecisive adventures in life and eventual absorption into Limbo (equipped, oddly, with a telephone), amount to a wry commentary on the difficulties of artistic creation. Paradoxically, these intimations of unreality only serve to make the protagonist more believable. He is particularly well-developed in that most essential of human traits, the urge to gossip; when he hears that his landlady has sold the family butcher shop in an attempt to improve her social position, Maximo cynically remarks that when it comes to washing off bloodstains even Lady Macbeth would have an easier time of it. The translator of this entertaining volume, a well-known Perez Galdos scholar, shows considerable skill in rendering the Spaniard's deliciously splenetic turns of phrase. Some nuances are inevitably lost, however: in the Spanish, for example, Manso (''placid'') is at once the character's name and his most perfect epithet.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CALIFORNIA (AL) - Dickie Schofield, shortstop, won a $475,000 salary in arbitration. COLLEGE ALABAMA - Named Tommy Bowden, formerly an assistant coach at Duke, wide receivers coach. HOUSTON - Named Bob Young offensive line coach. HOCKEY MINNESOTA (NHL) - Acquired Brad Maxwell, defenseman, from the Rangers for cash. PITTSBURGH (NHL) - Sent Alain Lemieux, left wing, and Jim McGeough, right wing, to the Baltimore farm team.

title: Piedmont Invites Suitors to Its Door
description: Piedmont's board is seeking any and all suitors. USAir started the bidding war by offering $68 a share in cash and stock. Then Norfolk Southern offered $65 in cash, and USAir came back with an offer of $71 in cash for half of Piedmont and $73 a share in cash and stock for the rest. Norfolk said it would not match that offer, but Piedmont said it would entertain other offers. Analysts say a deal with USAir makes sense for Piedmont, because their air routes are complementary. They speculate that that Norfolk, a railraod company that holds about 20 percent of Piedmont, is interested more in the higher stock price a bidding war might bring than in actually acquiring the airline.

title: JAZZ WINDS BLOW IN FAVOR OF ERIC DOLPHY
description: History is written by survivors. In jazz, living musicians deliver final judgments on their predecessors; they decide, consciously and intuitively, what styles and ideas will stay current, and it doesn't hurt if the inventors of those styles are still alive and blowing. At the moment, as jazz's younger generation rediscovers the 1950's and 1960's, the contributions of such vital, active musicians as Sonny Rollins, Wayne Shorter and Ornette Coleman are justly celebrated. Meanwhile, the reputation of one musician who didn't survive the 1960's - Eric Dolphy, who died in 1964 at the age of 35 - is making a quiet resurgence.

title: GREECE PROTESTS U.S. STATEMENTS
description: Greece said today that it had postponed a visit to Washington by its Defense Minister and protested recent statements by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger that it viewed as supporting Turkish interests over its own in Cyprus.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
A&E; AIMS TO WOO YOUNGER VIEWERS
description: LEAD: The Arts and Entertainment Network is trying to grow young - and to become more American in the process. During its three years of existence, the basic service's schedule has been heavily freighted with British fare, much of it in the fields of drama, opera, orchestral music and ballet. Often, this has brought critical laurels; what it hasn't brought, however, is sufficient viewership among the age group most sought after by advertisers -those more likely to be watching MTV than listening to

title: Suzanne M. DeVries Plans To Marry Gerard Sullivan
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. Marie A. Hanache of Old Westbury, L.I., of the engagement of her daughter Suzanne M. DeVries to Gerard B. Sullivan, a son of Lillian G. Sullivan of Warwick, R.I., and the late Daniel J. Sullivan. The wedding is to be in September.

title: BRAILLE PUBLISHER SHOWS WAY TO A WIDER WORLD
description: Olga Espinola, a computer programmer for Honeywell Inc. in Wellesley, Mass., has just finished writing a program that uses diagrams, colors and highlighted characters to teach the use of a calculator.

title: 'TORCH SONG' TRIO: VICTIM OF TIMES
description: HARVEY FIERSTEIN'S ''Torch Song Trilogy,'' now at the Studio Theater in Lindenhurst, first made its debut as three individual plays.

title: Kuhn's Book Reveals MacPhail's Role in His Ouster
description: THROUGHOUT Bowie Kuhn's years as baseball commissioner, Lee MacPhail was one of his staunchest supporters. They even had a common critic, George Steinbrenner. Ironically, though, it was MacPhail who played a role detrimental to Kuhn in two significant episodes in his 16-season tenure: the resignation he submitted over an expansion dispute in 1976 and his ouster as commissioner in 1983.

title: TUNERS AND AMPLIFIERS MAKE A VIRTUE OF SEPRATION
description: Even listeners on a tight budget now have the option of buying a separate tuner and amplifier in place of the customary receiver. In the past, low-cost receivers were pretty much the standard down in the bargain basement, and so-called separates (i.e., separate tuners and amplifiers) were confined mainly to the upper brackets. But now they are becoming available in the economy class also. This raises the question of what, if anything, is to be gained from this approach.

title: HAUGHEY VICTORY CASTS DOUBT ON BRITISH-IRISH PACT
description: The victory of Charles J. Haughey in the Irish elections has cast doubt over the future of the British-Irish agreement on Northern Ireland.

title: WITH HOPES, STUDENTS PLAY JAI ALAI
description: LEAD: FOUR intense young men with curved baskets dangling from their arms sprinted forward and back in a box-like arena, sneaker soles squealing as they pivoted to capture a rock-hard ball.

title: HOW DO YOU FEEL ABOUT SPRING TRAINING?
description: In early February, with snow, rain and sleet scrubbing the soot from our apartment window, my 4-year-old son was watching TV. In the midst of the cacophony of He-Man, She-Ra, and Thunder Cats, he suddenly turned to me and said, ''Hey, Dad. I heard that spring training starts in three weeks.''

title:
DINING OUT;
FLAVORS OF SOUTHWEST IN MT. KISCO
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH Hogan's Casa Miguel dishes out its share of Tex-Mex mash, it deserves credit for attempting to produce some fare that is recognizable, items that can be distinguished from other foods sharing the plate. To this end, Casa Miguel has rejected the ridiculously small plates one usually encounters in this kind of restaurant in favor of platters large enough to hold comfortably the generous portions served here, thus eliminating to a great extent the cramming and pile-up of food so common in other Tex-Mex spots.

title: MUSIC FROM THE YOUNG BRINGS OUT THE YOUNG AT HEART
description: NURSING and retirement homes in the county are benefitting from the prodigious talents of area students in a variety of outreach programs sponsored by local schools and organizations.

title: Sally Jayne Quist Marries
description: Sally Jayne Quist, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Quist of Punta Gorda, Fla., was married yesterday to James Franklin Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Miller of Port Washington, L.I. The Rev. Kurt Von Roeschlaub officiated at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Port Washington. The bride, a stylist for photographers, attended Ohio Wesleyan University. Mr. Miller, a magna cum laude graduate of Tufts University in Medford, Mass., received an M.B.A. degree from Columbia University and is an associate in the Merrill Lynch Capital Markets Group.

title: Tracy Gill to Wed Andrew Ferguson
description: The engagement of Tracy Gill to Andrew Charles Ferguson has been announced by Jill Gill and Ardian C. Gill, both of New York and Saltaire, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Noel Ferguson of Detroit and St. Clair Shores, Mich. A May 3 wedding is planned.

title: MUSIC: GOSPEL-JAZZ CHAMBER OPERA
description: ''WHEN THE BERRIES FELL,'' a new two-hour (with one intermission), nine-number score by the jazz- and gospel-based composer and keyboard player Amina Claudine Myers, was described in the program Friday night at the Triplex Theater I as a ''chamber opera'' receiving its ''premiere performance.'' The event was a co-presentation of the Composers' Forum and Manhattan Community College, which houses the Triplex Theater complex at 199 Chambers Street.

title: BOOKS FROM THE TIMES
description: THE NEW YORK TIMES GUIDE TO RESTAURANTS IN NEW YORK CITY. By Bryan Miller. (Times Books, Paper, $12.95.) Two years and 1,001 meals later, Bryan Miller, the restaurant critic for The New York Times, serves up his favorites - and not only the galaxy of one- to four-star restaurants. There is an A to Z Best Dishes list (the top apple pandowdy-to-zabaglione in town), reviews keyed to Manhattan neighborhood maps, a chapter on the city's wine scene and selections from Mr. Miller's newsy forum, the Diner's Journal column, where the future stars first glimmer and the best bargains and offbeat choices get their due. In all, 250 restaurants in the city are evaluated in this collection of reviews from The Times.

title: STATE IS HOT IN ICY COMPETITION
description: NEW JERSEY is hot this year in a cold sport: iceboating. Both the new world champion and the runner-up in iceboating's dominant DN class are from Point Pleasant.

title: Panel Sets 1988 Limit On Campaign Expense
description: The Federal Election Commission has given the flock of 1988 Presidential aspirants a financial target to aim for as they line up their campaigns: $26.7 million.

title: CZYZ RETAINS TITLE ON KNOCKOUT IN 2D
description: Bobby Czyz retained his International Boxing Federation light heavyweight title when he knocked out Willie Edwards at 2:16 of the second round of a scheduled 15-round bout today.

title: CONDOM INDUSTRY ADS
description: To the Editor:

title: EDITOR'S NOTE
description: An article in the Arts and Leisure section today, ''Lonette McKee on Becoming Lady Day,'' discusses the actress's role as Billie Holiday in ''Lady Day at Emerson's Bar & Grill'' at the Westside Arts Theater. After the section went to press, Miss McKee's agent announced that she had withdrawn because of throat problems. Her understudy, S. Epatha Merkerson, is playing the role while the producers negotiate with another actress to take the part.

title: CABARET: MARTI STEVENS
description: THE witty, soignee attitude that one associates with the songs of Cole Porter and Noel Coward were once synonymous with a style of cabaret performance that is vanishing as rapidly as the old cafe society for whom it was designed. But Marti Stevens, the 1950's supper-club performer who returned to Freddy's Supper Club, 308 East 49th Street, on Wednesday showed that style is still able to evoke a warm and wistful response.

title: West 122d Street: Where Theologians Past, Present and Future Hold Sway
description: There is a street in Manhattan where one can hear a discussion about Niebuhr and the New Testament or Heschel and Hasidic thought or Tillich and the Talmud - sometimes all in the same breath. It is called 122d

title: YALE CHIEF OPENS CONSTITUTION TALKS BY FAULTING MEESE
description: The president of Yale University, in the first of a series of lectures by experts on the United States Constitution, has assailed the views of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d as too rigid.

title: A SLIVER OF THE OLD BAHAMAS
description: North of the Caribbean and east of Florida is a 1,000-square-mile area in the Atlantic dubbed bajamar, or shallow sea, by Spanish explorers nearly 500 years ago. And almost lost in the midst of bajamar's opaline waters, tucked in among 600 or so outcroppings of land, which comprise the Bahamian archipelago, is an island whose dimensions are so meager that it could easily be overlooked by more adventurous travelers.

title: Nets Defeat Knicks in Bottom-of-Barrell Game
description: The Nets have held the edge in the metropolitan area's hotly contested race toward basketball oblivion practically since the start of the regular season. But all of a sudden, it's a race again.

title: BELIEVERS HAVE NO MONOPOLY ON THE TRUTH
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTH CASTLE DEBATES BID TO CONVERT CEMENT PLAN
description: ALTHOUGH they considered the 40-year-old neighborhood concrete plant a dusty, noisy nuisance, North Castle residents contend that an asphalt plant proposed for the Virginia Road site would be far worse and must be stopped.

title: True Progress
description: From the day Thomas Edison first recorded sound 100-odd years ago, man has had to exert himself to listen. When the music stops, someone has to turn over the record or change it. Music lovers over the age of 40 grew up on 78's that played only four and a half minutes.

title: A RETURN TO CONTINENTAL CUISINE
description: SAVORIES RESTAURANT in Port Jefferson is a restaurant that is bucking the trends. A few years ago, before American restaurants were the rage, Savories featured American food. About a year ago, the restaurant changed ownership, and Savories now serves the currently out-of-fashion Continental cuisine.

title: New York Earns High Rank on Environment
description: New York, New Jersey and Connecticut rank among the top five states in establishing and enforcing programs to protect the environment, according to a private report issued today.

title: SPARE NO EXPENSE, AND ADD THE SAFFRON
description: SOME friends who returned from Spain recently brought me a large packet of saffron as a present. I was extremely pleased, not just because it is the world's most expensive spice, but because I love it so much in rice dishes and with seafood.

title: Pals Already Miss Guidry Influence
description: He always seemed to be there, sitting in the same chair in front of the same dressing stall, spitting another stream of tobacco juice into a paper cup. Dave Righetti remembers seeing Ron Guidry a half dozen or so lockers away, just the other side of the shower room at Fort Lauderdale Stadium. But when he looked the other day, Guidry was gone.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
THE TAPPAN ZEE: A BRIDGE TOO SLOW
description: LEAD: WHETHER March roars in like the proverbial lion, commuters can still rely upon their sheep-like participation in the continuous saga of commuter woes connected with reaching and leaving Rockland County by the Tappan Zee Bridge.

title: FAITHS JOIN TO SHELTER HOMELESS
description: LEAD: FAMILIES squeezed out of Union County's tight housing market gathered at Temple Emanu-El here on a recent evening.

title: ZACCARO SEEKS DISMISSAL OF EXTORTION CHARGES IN CABLE TV CASE
description: Lawyers for John A. Zaccaro have asked a judge to dismiss charges of bribe-seeking and attempted extortion against their client, saying a Queens grand jury that indicted him in a cable-television investigation acted on evidence that was ''not legally sufficient.''

title: WHAT'S NEW IN JEWELRY
description: EVERY night before Dorothy Noce goes to bed, she flicks on her television and goes jewelry shopping. ''I've bought three gold chains for my girls, five for myself, and one for my daughter's boyfriend,'' said Mrs. Noce, a resident of Ridley Park, Pa., one of the areas reached by the Home Shopping Network's satellite. ''I've even ordered something at three in the morning. It's very convenient, and the jewelry is worth it. You really can't go wrong.''

title: Machine's Fumes Make Players Ill
description: Fumes from a Zamboni ice-resurfacing machine caused upper- respiratory ailments in some high school hockey players and forced postponement of their game, health officials said.

title: Gaza Carpenters Defy the Israelis: A Union Votes
description: A soldier at the door waved his rifle menacingly and tried to say that the Palestinians were terrorists. But the young carpenters scoffed at the accusation and abruptly pushed past into the dilapidated union hall today to do someting unheard of for 20 years among the Palestinian refugees: they cast votes in a labor-union election.

title: POSTINGS: On Gold Street; 17-Outlet Food Mall
description: Maximizing a site is often a euphemism for squeezing every possible square foot out of a lot. But at 15 Gold Street in the financial district, where the market for vacant office space is soft, maximizing the 4,500-square-foot plot had more to do with concept than space.

title: OLD THEATERS STRUGGLING IN NEW ROLES
description: DURING the intermission of a performance by the New Jersey Symphony Chamber Orchestra at the Strand Theater here last month, a leak in the ceiling set off a fire alarm.

title: Lorie Combias Weds Thomas G. Holevas
description: At Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church in Westfield, N.J., yesterday Lorie Ann Combias, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony John Combias of Summit, N.J., was married to Thomas Gregory Holevas, the son of Marian Holevas of Columbus, Ohio, and Tom Holevas of Pittsburgh. The Rev. Alexander Leondis performed the ceremony.

title: 4 Boston Buildings Burn
description: A fire did an estimated $300,000 damage to four residential buildings in South Boston Friday night, displaced eight people and slightly injured a firefighter and a woman. Fire Capt. Matthew Corbett said the fire started in a building undergoing renovation and spread to three others. He said the renovated building was destroyed. Eight people from two of the other buildings were staying with friends and the cause of the fire is being sought, he said.

title: DANCE: PITTSBURGH ALLOY
description: THE Pittsburgh Dance Alloy is a company of dancers whose way of moving is appealingly direct, keen-edged and quietly lyrical. Founded 10 years ago, the group is dedicated to presenting work by a wide variety of contemporary modern choreographers. But the company was sold short by the five dances it presented Wednesday in a New York debut program at the Theater of the Riverside Church. Ambitiously, the program included dances that were new to New York, created by five different choreographers. But none of the dances went far enough. None had the clear, focused voice of the company itself, and none seemed to test the dancers in anything but endurance.

title: 'BOSS' HAUGHEY GETS NEW CHANCE TO REVIVE IRELAND
description: Irish voters last week gave a veteran politician, former Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey, another turn at trying to pull the country out of its economic slough. Mr. Haughey, also known as ''Boss,'' thrashed the Fine Gael party of Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald, who called for the elections last month after his coalition Government collapsed.

title: Cars Face Rush-Hour Ban in Central Rome
description: Julius Caesar started it 2,000 or so years ago by banning litters from downtown Rome to ease traffic congestion.

title: POSTINGS: Restoration Workshop; Rescuing the Past
description: Getting people to think in terms of what could be, rather than what is, lies at the heart of restoration, according to James Boorstein, a restoration expert. ''To some, it may seem like an old, crumbling staircase,'' he said, ''whereas it should really be seen as a structure with wonderful winders and detailed balusters, one that has the potential to be beautiful, given some work.''

title: Snakeskin And Sex
description: One hardly expects The New York Times Magazine to be a hotbed of sexual stereotypes, but the issue of Jan. 25 seems to be tilting in that direction. In About Men, Warren Sloat perpetuates the myth of passage to manhood through the execution of a wild animal that poses no threat. (Mr. Sloat admits that he could have walked away; the snake was not attacking him or anyone else.) Meanwhile, on the Fashion page, we are presented with a selection of garments that owe as much to the vocabulary of bondage and sadism (to say nothing of feverish adolescent dreams) as they do to any impulse to make wearable clothing for real women (''Paris Shapes,'' by Carrie Donovan). Surely, The New York Times can do better than this. WILLIAM DOWNEY New York City

title: CHARGERS RIDING WAVE OF SUCCESS
description: MENTION the University of New Haven and sports, and most fans are likely to think of an outstanding baseball program.

title: Defending Heep
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: ENERGY AUDIT OF BUSINESSES WILL EXPAND
description: Two programs that provide free energy audits for certain businesses and nonprofit organizations will be expanded and will receive more money, Mayor Koch has announced.

title: Judith Eldon Rose And Ivan Epstein To Marry in May
description: The engagement of Judith Eldon Rose to Ivan L. Epstein has been announced by her parents, Sally R. Adolph of Tucson, Ariz., and William R. Rose 2d of Scarsdale and Lake Placid, N.Y. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton J. Epstein of Atlanta. A May wedding is planned.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''I beg you, let me put the pieces of my life together again.'' - Dennis B. Levine, at his sentencing for insider trading.

title: Lloyd's of London
description: To the Editor: A Travel Advisory item on Jan. 18 heralded the ''first time in its 300-year history'' that Lloyd's of London ''has opened its doors to the public.'' It may be the first time in the history of the new building that the doors have been opened to the public, but there were guided tours of the old main building as far back as the early 1970's.

title: PLAN FOR MENTALLY DISABLED DRAWS OPPOSITION
description: A state plan to close six developmental centers for the mentally handicapped, including two in New York City, would swell the ranks of homeless and destitute people, opponents of the plan say.

title: STRIKING A BARGAIN FOR BRONX HOUSING
description: Affordable housing in New York City apparently is possible if it is built on land priced at $1 an acre and subsidized up to $25,000 per unit with public money. And if the sponsors agree to work for no profit.

title: TOURIST RAILROAD SEEKS TO HAUL FREIGHT
description: FOR 15 years, its steam locomotives and coaches have chugged through picturesque countryside from Essex to Deep River, carrying passengers on a 10-mile roundtrip journey back in time. In the process, the Valley Railroad's excursion line, which connects with sightseeing riverboats that ply the nearby Connecticut River, has become one of the state's biggest tourist attractions.

title: YOOKS,ZOOKS AND THE BOMB
description: AMONG the first children's books to take on the threat of nuclear war was Dr. Seuss' ''Butter Battle Book'' (Random House, 1984). There had been many books set in a post-holocaust future, and a few in the past at Hiroshima, like Eleanor Coerr's gentle ''Sadako and the Thousand Paper Cranes'' (Putnam, 1977) and Toshi Maruki's ''Hiroshima No Pika'' (Lothrop, 1982), a picture book that caused great controversy with its graphic depiction of atomic destruction.

title: FAST LEARNER
