description: If dealing with sudden wealth is one of the things you are supposed to learn in business school, Melanie Richards, a 20-year-old business major in her third year at Baruch College, must have been listening in class. She bought a Lotto ticket before the Nov. 8 drawing, watched carefully as her numbers were posted on television, hid her $12 million winning ticket in a safe in her Brooklyn home, told no one outside her family, sought legal and financial advice and finally - after coming down with chicken pox and recovering from it - turned in the ticket last week. ''I was just too excited,'' she said of her reluctance to come foward. ''I just wanted to relax and take it in stride. She said she intended to stay in school, ''because eventually I want to know at least as much about managing my money as the people advising me.''

title: TOTAL IMMERSION IN A FLOOD OF FRENCH
description: My own private dream has always been to speak graceful and fluent French; I have also always wanted to rent a house in Provence. Last summer, having made arrangements for the latter, I attempted the former; I signed up for the total immersion course at Berlitz. In my preliminary interview I rated myself somewhere between ''fairly good command'' and ''speaks with proficiency.'' My background is not impressive: school French from 4th to 12th grades and periodic but short trips to France. When I signed up, I was not aware that no one takes the total immersion course for only one week, and I had high and utterly unrealistic hopes of absolute fluency in five days.

title: THE NEW CARNEGIE SOUND PACKS LESS OF A WALLOP
description: I never actually heard Brahms play the piano. That is a confession that does not come easily to me, simply because I once had a friend, the eminent pianist and teacher Rudolph Ganz, who as a child not only did hear Brahms perform but would sit down and demonstrate with gusto how vigorously the old composer attacked the piano part of his Piano Quintet. The child's father advised him, in fact, to pay close attention to the sound of the string quartet at the beginning, because once Brahms came in the others would never be heard again.

title: IN EXHIBIT, ODYSSEY OF ETHIOPIAN JEWS
description: For thousands of Ethiopian Jews who fled their famine-stricken country and were airlifted from Sudanese refugee camps in 1984, their rescue and arrival in Israel were the fulfillment of a dream.

title: BRAZIL'S DEBTS NOW CARRY A POLITICAL PRICE FOR PRESIDENT
description: BRAZIL'S decision to suspend payments on its $108 billion foreign debt last week marked the reappearance of an explosive element that had been kept safely locked away for two decades by the country's military rulers. Politics, all that business of wanting to be popular and having to get elected, has returned with a vengeance.

title: PERSONAL FINANCE
description: LAST spring Kenneth Jankowski, a telecommunications specialist with a Chicago bank, received an appealing job offer from TRW in Cleveland. But his wife, Robin, a financial analyst, was unhappy about moving, fearing she might not find an equally attractive job in a strange city.

title: Trying to Avoid an Insurance Debacle
description: BRENT NANCE is an insurance broker. As such, the thought of writing policies for people who are at high risk of developing AIDS makes him shudder.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE TRAP. By John Treherne. (Beaufort, $14.95.) The first 30 pages of ''The Trap'' are padded with familiar jokes about daft professors and obnoxious students, but the reader who wades beyond the irrelevant beginning will earn several rewards. The English writer John Treherne writes knowingly and with grace about a time and place now gone, and, once focused on his subject, is a storyteller of considerable skill.

title: COURT BLOCKS OPERAITON OF A NEW ASPHALT PLANT
description: LEAD: IN a decision favoring a group of Cortlandt homeowners, a State Appeals Court has blocked the operation of a new asphalt-manufacturing plant, ruling that it was built in violation of town zoning laws.

title: OLD GREENWICH FIGHTS NEW DEVELOPMENT IN STAMFORD
description: LEAD: AS condominiums and office buildings continue to be built all around them, in Stamford and Greenwich, and the residents of Old Greenwich are becoming increasingly vocal, and in some cases effective, opponents of new development. Their main complaint is about increased traffic; they say their neighborhood of mainly colonial and

title: SOME REMINDERS FOR THE FUTURE
description: WITHIN the last few weeks, the mother of a dear friend of mine died.

title: Snakeskin And Sex
description: It is true, as Warren Sloat pointed out in his article ''Snakeskin'' (About Men, Jan. 25), that young rattlesnakes are more dangerous, but not because they are quicker. Older snakes develop sphincter control and save some venom for the next bite; young ones give you the whole shot right off - more venom. (Leastways, that's what they say out here.) Out here, when we can, we catch rattlers that get too close and release them out in the woods.

title: SCALIA SPEAKS UP, QUITE CLEARLY, AT BAR CONVENTION
description: Antonin Scalia is turning out to be a talkative Supreme Court Justice, on the bench and wherever else he goes. Last week at the American Bar Association convention he asserted that Federal judges were becoming ''case processors'' and later joined a friendly public argument about the Constitution and the press.

title: ADVICE ON CROSS-CULTURAL BUSINESS
description: IN 1965, three men, all in their early 20's, were working in vastly different parts of the world. Ernie Turner, a member of the Peace Corps, was teaching in Borneo. Lars Cederholm, as manager of Sweden's largest tour-operating company, was overseas most of the year, negotiating business in Europe, North Africa, South America and the Middle East. And Thomas Gross, after graduating from Princeton, was serving as an educational-program administrator on the Navaho Indian Reservation in New Mexico.

title: POSTINGS: The Name Lives On; Meriden Offices
description: The International Silver Company, formed in 1898 and once one of the world's largest silver-goods manufacturers, began to falter in the 1950's with foreign competition and the emergence of stainless steel. The company diversified, changed its name to Insilco Corporation in 1969 and finally sold off International Silver, then a subsidiary, in 1983.

title: WOOD STOVES: HOW TO ENJOY THE HEAT WITHOUT THE HAZARDS
description: WOOD stoves have become popular in rural and suburban homes, not only as an auxiliary means of heating but also as a primary source of heat in some cases. Unfortunately, this has led to some cases in which a fire hazard has been created because.

title: Ann Biester To Be Bride
description: Judge and Mrs. Edward G. Biester Jr. of Furlong, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Meredith Biester, to Gary Kenneth Deane, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice A. Deane of Kings Point, L.I. A June 6 wedding is planned. Miss Biester, who expects to receive an M.B.A. degree in May from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, graduated from the Sidwell Friends School in Washington and cum laude from Wesleyan University. Her father, a former Republican Representative from Pennsylvania and a former Attorney General of Pennsylvania, is a judge of the Court of Common Pleas of Pennsylania in Doylestown. Her mother, Elizabeth L. Biester, is a partner in the Four Corners Gallery in Lambertville, N.J. The future bride is a granddaughter of Dr. Paul G. Lauffer of Payson, Ariz., a former director of research for the Northam-Warren Corporation in Stamford, Conn.

title: East Germans Oust American
description: A 69-year-old American held by East Germany for protesting atop the Berlin Wall has been expelled and sent to the West, a United States spokesman said Friday. The American, John Runnings of Seattle, had been held in East Germany for three months.

title: THE EXECUTIVE COMPUTER
description: RECENTLY, I received a telephone call from a fellow writer wanting to know what the latest and best computer-cum-software combination would be for someone in our mutual profession. This query was not in itself unusual. Writing about computers is a bit like being a doctor. One goes to a party and 10 people immediately engage one in a conversation beginning with ''I have this little problem . . ..''

title: THE C.I.A. TODAY
description: Sanford J. Unger replies;

title: SEEKING THE GRAY WHALE
description: From February through late April friendly, giant gray whales -they're about 45 feet long and weigh between 17 and 35 tons - pass the California coast on their 6,000-mile migration from Mexico's Baja peninsula to their summer home off Alaska. Grays are one of the environmental movement's success stories. Once hunted almost to extinction, they are now a protected species and their numbers are increasing steadily.

title: BREAKING THE CASE
description: You know how it is, good help is hard to come by. So if you have a real job to do, you have to do it yourself, right?

title: Miss Kirshbaum Wed To Nunzio Gubitosa 3d
description: Shirley Ann Kirshbaum, the daughter of Joseph Kirshbaum of La Jolla, Calif., and the late Gertrude Kirshbaum, was married yesterday to Nunzio David Gubitosa 3d, the son of Mrs. Gubitosa 2d and the late Mr. Gubitosa. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman and the Rev. Henry Fehren, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Rockland Lake Manor in Congers, N.Y.

title:
GARDENING;
UNPALATABLE PLANTS MAY DISCOURAGE DEER
description: LEAD: AS the suburbs expanded during the 50's and 60's, a frequently heard lament was that of the demise of certain forms of wildlife as their habitat was absorbed into the growing megalopolis. All sorts of animals began to disappear from the developing areas, including deer.

title: WELFARE THAT WORKS
description: 'What we want to do is turn what is now primarily a payments system with a minor work component into a system that is first and foremost a jobs program, supported by an income assistance component. Our proposal focuses on education, training and employment for the families now dependent on the welfare system, along with a decent living standard with which these families can support their children while they strive for self-sufficiency.' - Gov. Bill Clinton Democrat of Arkansas and chairman of the National Governors Association, on welfare revisions that the governors will consider at their winter meeting this week.

title: Readings to Honor The Late Janet Flanner
description: A writers-in-performance series will open at the Manhattan Theater Club, 131 West 56th Street, on Monday at 8 P.M. with a tribute to Janet Flanner, the longtime Paris correspondent of The New Yorker magazine.

title: MANAGUA WARMS TO NEW PEACE PLAN
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said today that Nicaragua was now willing to consider a regional peace plan proposed last month by President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica.

title: Woman to Head Exeter
description: Kendra Stearns O'Donnell, an official of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund, has been named principal of the Phillips Exeter Academy, the New Hampshire preparatory school announced yesterday, adding that she would be the first woman to head one a major independent secondary school in New England. Dr. O'Donnell, who has taught at Princeton University, will succeed Stephen G. Kurtz, who is retiring.

title: BEST SELLERS: February 22, 1987
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List FICTION 1 1 3 WINDMILLS OF THE GODS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $18.95.) The nightmarish experiences that befall a woman and her family after her appointment as Ambassador to Rumania. 2 2 4 THE EYES OF THE DRAGON, by Stephen King. (Viking, $18.95.) A fairy tale, complete with an aged king, two princes, an evil wizard and a mouse. 3 3 30 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The West tries to stave off the Russians. 4 4 6 NIGHT OF THE FOX, by Jack Higgins. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) A mission to keep D-Day plans from being discovered by the Germans. 5 5 24 IT, by Stephen King. (Viking, $22.95.) Childhood horrors haunt six men and a woman who grew up in a small Maine town. 6 6 5 THE PANIC OF '89, by Paul Erdman. (Doubleday, $17.95.) A financial wizard undertakes to defuse the crisis besetting the American economy. 7 7 16 WHIRLWIND, by James Clavell. (Morrow, $22.95.) Iran during the month following the Shah's departure. 8 9 17 FLIGHT OF THE INTRUDER, by Stephen Coonts. (Naval Institute, $15.95.) Navy aviators at war over Vietnam. 9 10 21 THE PRINCE OF TIDES, by Pat Conroy. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) Complex family relationships in South Carolina and New York City. 10 8 6 BANDITS, by Elmore Leonard. (Arbor House, $17.95.) A gang of three plots to heist millions being sent to the contras in Nicaragua. 11 1 OUTBREAK, by Robin Cook. (Putnam, $17.95.) Tracking down a mysterious disease that strikes only physicians and their patients. 12 2 SHAN, by Eric Van Lustbader. (Random House, $18.95.) A Chinese-American attempts to realize his father's dreams for Asia. 13* 12 3 PATIENCE OF A SAINT, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Geis/Warner, $18.95.) A hard-bitten newspaperman learns a lot about his family and decency while on the trail of a wily politician. 14 13 5 THE COUNTERLIFE, by Philip Roth. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) More about the ambitions and anxieties of Nathan Zuckerman. 15* 1 DREAMS ARE NOT ENOUGH, by Jacqueline Briskin. (Putnam, $18.95.) A California family dynasty out to conquer the world. 16* 14 2 WATCHERS, by Dean R. Koontz. (Putnam, $17.95.) Two creatures - one good, one evil - emerge from a secret government laboratory. Weeks This Last On Week Week List NONFICTION 1 1 8 A SEASON ON THE BRINK, by John Feinstein. (Macmillan, $16.95.) A chronicle of one season spent with the coach Bob Knight and his Indiana University basketball team. 2 2 42 FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Dolphin/ Doubleday, $14.95.) Anecdotes and ruminations from the television star and father of five. 3 3 2 THE FATAL SHORE, by Robert Hughes. (Knopf, $24.95.) Australia from penal colony to its gradual emergence as a flourishing nation. 4 4 50 YOU'RE ONLY OLD ONCE! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $9.95.) A checkup at the Golden Years Clinic in pictures and rhyme. 5 15 2 ECHOES IN THE DARKNESS, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Morrow, $18.95.) A case involving the murder of a Pennsylvania high school teacher and the disappearance of her two children. 6 6 6 THE SEARCH FOR SIGNS OF INTELLIGENT LIFE IN THE UNIVERSE, by Jane Wagner. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) Acerb observations on life today; script of the show starring Lily Tomlin. 7 1 THE FITZGERALDS AND THE KENNEDYS, by Doris Kearns Goodwin. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) From the Boston slums of Irish immigrants to the White House: three generations of a family. 8 7 20 THE RECKONING, by David Halberstam. (Morrow, $19.95.) The crisis in the American automobile industry and Japan's role in it. 9 11 6 MARILYN, by Gloria Steinem. (Holt, $24.95.) A biography of Marilyn Monroe, with many photographs by her friend George Barris. 10 9 35 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author argues, and we must confront them to grow. 11 5 20 HIS WAY, by Kitty Kelley. (Bantam, $21.95.) From Hoboken to superstardom: an unauthorized biography of Frank Sinatra. 12* 8 3 REAGAN'S AMERICA: Innocents at Home, by Garry Wills. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The 40th President as the product and embodiment of an American mythology. 13 10 40 JAMES HERRIOT'S DOG STORIES, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) Fifty tales by a Yorkshire veterinarian about his favorite animal. 14 14 8 ACROSS CHINA, by Peter Jenkins. (Morrow, $18.95.) The author of ''A Walk Across America'' takes his wanderlust to Asia. 15 2 THE MORNING AFTER, by George F. Will. (Free Press, $19.95.) Columns on matters political and personal, written by a conservative journalist between 1981 and 1986. Weeks This Last On Week Week List ADVICE, HOW-TO AND MISCELLANEOUS 1 1 17 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS WITH WINE, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $16.95.) Recipes to be prepared at moderate cost. 2 3 36 THE ROTATION DIET, By Martin Katahn. (Norton, $15.95.) A regimen based on the Vanderbilt University Weight Management Program. 3 2 20 MEN WHO HATE WOMEN & THE WOMEN WHO LOVE THEM, by Susan Forward and Joan Torres. (Bantam, $16.95.) How to cope with overbearing men. 4 4 76 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 5 5 54 THE FRUGAL GOURMET, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $14.95.) A television chef's inexpensive dishes. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. In Advice and How-to, five titles are listed because, beyond that point, sales in this category are not generally large enough to make a longer list statistically reliable. * An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the bookselling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) A CLIENT CALLED NOAH: A Family Journey Continued, by Josh Greenfeld. (Holt, $18.95.) Mr. Greenfeld's third book about his brain-damaged son takes us through his 20th year; it's an eloquent report of struggle and final concession to a hopeless situation. THE AGELESS SELF: Sources of Meaning in Late Life, by Sharon R. Kaufman. (University of Wisconsin, $22.50.) This careful, dignified study by a medical anthropologist finds age a phase of the body but not the mind, which carries on the same as ever it did. THE LAST SONG OF MANUEL SENDERO, by Ariel Dorfman. (Viking, $18.95.) The political exile's dilemma is incarnated in this Chilean writer's novel by a cosmic joke, a revolt of the unborn, who refuse to come out until the grown-ups end their oppression. ANOTHER DAY OF LIFE, by Ryszard Kapuscinski. (Helen and Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) The collapse of Portuguese rule in Angola in 1974, as seen by a journalist with a novelist's eye - anecdotal, idiosyncratic, fixed in memory. DEEP BLACK: Space Espionage and National Security, by William E. Burrows. (Random House, $19.95.) Those satellites really work, says Mr. Burrows, who tells us how in surprising detail and shows us the implications, some of them disturbing, for arms control. ZERO DB: And Other Stories, by Madison Smartt Bell. (Ticknor & Fields, $15.95.) Short fiction in a dazzling range of voices, from the raw and dramatic through the wistful and hilarious. THE MAKING OF THE ATOMIC BOMB, by Richard Rhodes. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) Short on heroes and villains, long on drama and suspense, this book offers both a close-up look at nuclear scientists and an overview of the century's pivotal event.

title: Joan McGivern To Wed in June
description: The engagement of Joan Morgan McGivern to Andrew Lyle Rossner has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Owen McGivern of New York, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Elaine Rossner of Oceanside, L.I., and the late Vernon C. Rossner.

title: Auto Imports
description: To the Editor: Harold Poling proposes that Japan limit automobile shipments to the United States to two million units annually, and that it use more American parts in vehicles built in Japan (''Counting Cars From 'Immigrant' Plants,'' Forum, Feb. 1). I hope not. In 1979 I bought a '78 Lincoln Town Car with 12,000 miles on it, which had been regularly serviced by the Lincoln dealer. My wife bought a Honda with 55,000 miles on it.

title: Margaret H. Holcomb To Be Married in June
description: Plans for the June wedding of Margaret Hamilton Holcomb and James William Schubauer 2d, both December graduates of Cornell University, have been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Holcomb of Lloyd Harbor, L.I.

title: Harvard to Help Some Law Alumni to Pay Loans
description: Harvard Law School has announced a plan to help its law graduates who take low-paying jobs in public service to pay off their student loans.

title: A SOFT SPOT FOR SOUSAPHONES
description: DVORAK IN LOVE A Light-Hearted Dream. By Josef Skvorecky. Translated by Paul Wilson. 322 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: BABYLON MAY END BEACH-HOME LEASES
description: LEAD: A PUBLIC hearing tomorrow in Babylon will take up a recommendation that, because of pollution problems, the town terminate leases of town-owned land in five barrier beach communities along the southern shore of Suffolk County. Sitting on the property are 420 private homes.

title: AS CATHOLICS MEET CONTROVERSY, CONTRASTING STYLES EMERGE
description: WHEN Bishop Francis J. Mugavero of Brooklyn told his priests earlier this month that they could no longer hold special masses for Dignity, a Catholic homosexual group, he seemed to be stepping uncharacteristically out in front of John Cardinal O'Connor of New York. After all, although Cardinal O'Connor said last Sunday that he agreed with the Bishop's decision, a church in the Cardinal's archdiocese was continuing to hold masses for the group.

title: Houston Scores 38, But Army Loses
description: Navy offset a 38-point performance by Kevin Houston of Army and came from behind in the second half to defeat the Cadets today, 58-52, in the annual game between the two service academies.

title: GRAND HOPES FOR A NEW, IMPROVED COLLIDER
description: RUNNING two miles through the rugged foothills of the Santa Cruz mountains, the Stanford Linear Accelerator has been described as the world's longest shed. But during its 10 years of operation, this architecturally unimposing structure has been responsible for some of the most important breakthroughs in particle physics. Using the accelerator, scientists found some of the first evidence for the existence of quarks, the theoretical building blocks from which subatomic particles are believed to be made.

title: NORTH'S SECRETARY TELLS U.S. INQUIRY OF SHREDDING FILES
description: The personal secretary to Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North has been granted immunity by a special prosecutor and has acknowledged that she destroyed internal National Security Council documents in the hours before the Justice Department planned to review the colonel's files, her lawyer said today.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: MUSIC: ST. LUKE'S ORCHESTRA
description: A PAIR of beautiful concerto performances formed the highlight of the Orchestra of St. Luke's program Tuesday at Carnegie Hall - and not entirely because of the soloists, fine as they were. It is altogether unusual to hear an orchestra's opening tutti in a Classical concerto shaped with such care, played with such interest, as they were here in Mozart's Third Violin Concerto and Haydn's familiar Piano Concerto in D under Trevor Pinnock's leadership.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: GOING LIVE. By Muriel Dobbin. (Dutton, $17.95.) To judge by Muriel Dobbin's entertaining new novel, the television news industry is the glamorous career of choice for ambitious women today. At 37, the veteran television correspondent Martha Vogel is young enough to dream of being her network's national news anchor, but mature enough to realize that her superiors favor female broadcasters with younger, less wrinkled faces. Most prominent among her competitors is Caroline Mitchell, an aspiring newscaster whose on-camera manner and appearance remind viewers of the young Jacqueline Kennedy. Behind the scenes, however, Caroline is coldly calculating. She sees nothing wrong with discarding her fiance, the son of a local newscaster, once he has provided an entree to his father's connections. Nor does she think twice about exploiting a casual acquaintance with Martha to gain the attention of James Mellenkoff, an icy network executive who happens to be Martha's lover. Even Jill Starling, Caroline's childhood friend and fellow broadcast journalist, is stung by the serpentlike Caroline. In so poisonous a profession, can fair-minded Martha and good-humored Jill survive their wounds and live to see another broadcast day? As Caroline and Martha vie for the role of network anchor, the plot becomes alternately predictable and farfetched, but the characters play their roles with an enjoyable mixture of seriousness and self-mockery. ''Going Live'' succeeds as a diverting modern-day variation on an old-fashioned morality tale. Blind ambition may take you far, the author tells us, but - as improbable as it may sound - plain solid work will take you farther.

title:
RECORDINGS;
A CELLIST WHO GOES BEYOND THE PREDICTABLE
description: LEAD: Mozart virtually ignored the cello as a solo instrument; Beethoven and Brahms wrote no solo concertos for it. These are losses impossible to overlook, and cellists have been suffering, not always in silence, as a result. It did not help matters that the Romantic period failed to produce cellist-composers to match the output of such violinist-composers as Paganini, Vieuxtemps and Wieniawski.

title: HOW TO GET THE BEST VIDEO TAPE
description: Looking for a good buy in blank video tape is like looking for a bargain in soap. Pricing depends chiefly on the local store, competing products seem similar, and you can't tell much from the package. The only guidance usually comes from advertisements. This is not without value, for some ads can be quite informative. But they are always prejudiced.

title: Campbell Soup Says >Workers Are Sabotaging Plant in Ohio
description: Workers at the Campbell Soup Company's northwestern Ohio plant are responsible for more than 50 incidents of sabotaged machinery, but no foreign objects have reached food, a company spokesman said Friday.

title: ORCHESTRAS ARE OFFERING A RICH SCHEDULE
description: AFTER two quiet weeks, Connecticut orchestras are springing back into action, with more than a dozen concerts scheduled over the next fortnight, along with a touring visit from the Boston Symphony.

title: PRIEST USES THE STAGE TO BIND COMMUNITY
description: LEAD: FOR the Rev. Joseph J. Amato, a 39-year-old priest at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, the play's the thing to build community spirit.

title: Giving Good-Repair Standards the Force of Law
description: PROPERTY-OWNERS in Norwich, Conn., must keep their buildings painted and their windows in good repair or face a $50-a-day fine under a new ordinance.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN JEWELRY
description: NOT long ago, more than 14,000 jewelry buyers descended on midtown Manhattan to survey a dazzling array of jewels and gems at the industry's largest international jewelry show. The record turnout was just one of many signs of the sparkling health of an industry that just five years ago was floundering under the weight of a national recession.

title: HOW DO YOU FEEL ABOUT SPRING TRAINING?
description: For New Yorkers, spring training is the hope that Lou Piniella can survive a year of George Steinbrenner, and that Billy Martin stays in the booth. For the Mets, it is the hope that if a player is handcuffed it will mean he took a pitch, and that if he is caught stealing, his penalty will be an out.

title: EXPLORING THE ART-CRAFTS CONNECTION
description: ''THE INDEBTEDNESS of art to craft is kept a secret,'' says John Perreault, director of visual arts at the Snug Harbor Cultural Center here. ''Artists are always looking for new ways of making things, and the rich traditions in the crafts have inspired many painters and sculptors.''

title: ALPINE PLANTS HAVE COOL BEAUTY AT THEIR PEAK OF BLOOM
description: LEAD: Plant connoisseurs will climb the highest mountain to savor the uncertain glory of a true alpine. They will admire Soldanella hungarica for thrusting its delicate blue flowers up through Carpathian snow-melt. They are taken by the tiny Cyclamen hederifolium, which holds its inflorescence far above its foliage as if to compensate for size.

title: CRIME
description: Right at the beginning of A PROJECT NAMED DESIRE by John William Corrington and Joyce H. Corrington (Viking, $14.95), the tough New Orleans homicide police captain makes his position clear: ''Peetie had been careful. He knew all he had to do was cough hard and I'd be staring down his throat - with a .357 Magnum for a tongue depressor.'' This cop's name is Rat Trapp, he is black, and you get the idea he is not a man to fool around with. As events develop, you have guessed right.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN JEWELRY
description: NOWADAYS, ''Diamonds are Forever,'' the diamond industry's age-old advertising pitch, might better read ''Diamonds are for Everybody.''

title: WHERE COLD AND FOOD ARE THE TOOLS OF TORTURE
description: MORE gaunt men with prison haircuts went home last week from Soviet penal colonies. The Jewish dissident Iosif Z. Begun was freed and Anatoly Koryagin, a psychiatrist locked up for exposing the abuse of Soviet mental hospitals, was reunited with his wife. By the end of the week, Soviet authorities said the number of prisoners pardoned by Government decree had passed 150. In the process, the West was given 150 new windows into the archipelago of camps and prisons that Solzhenitsyn called the gulag, that inmates call ''the zone.''

title: ON THE JOB IN THE SCHOOLS
description: THE JAPANESE EDUCATIONAL CHALLENGE A Commitment to Children. By Merry White. 210 pp. New York: The Free Press. $18.95.

title: AGENCY ROLES REVIEWED IN CHILD ABUSE
description: LEAD: SOCIAL-SERVICE agencies here and in New Jersey are trying to clarify their roles in returning a 21-month-old girl from foster care to her parents' custody a month after the couple were indicted in New Jersey on charges of twice having fractured the child's skull.

title: OSCARS SEEN IN A CRYSTAL BALL
description: It's that time of winter - the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Science's Oscar season, which, like Christmas, seems to get longer every year. Some general observations before going out on a slim limb to make predictions:

title: WHAT'S NEW IN JEWELRY
description: JEWELRY designers are pushing color as much as status and design in their offerings these days. Imports of all colored stones, from the rarest emeralds to the most common amethysts, have nearly quadrupled over the past 10 years, according to the United States Bureau of Mines. By November, the value of 1986 imports had reached $368.4 million, surpassing total imports for 1985.

title: STATION PARKING FEES HELD IN QUESTION
description: Your Jan. 25 article on the increasing scarcity of commuter parking in Westchester County [ ''Commuter Parking Grows More Scarce'' ] was revealing in its primary thrust, but neglected an equally important facet that concerns the rising cost of available parking.

title: Tav Holmes, Art Historian, Married To Peter Chamberlain Berry, Lawyer
description: At St. James' Episcopal Church in New York yesterday Mary Tavener Holmes, an art historian specializing in 18th-century European art, was married to Peter Chamberlain Berry, an associate at the New York law firm of Breed, Abbott & Morgan. The Rev. Carol F. Pinkham performed the ceremony.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION
description: THIS is 1987, the year that stay-at-home mothers stand up to be counted. The trivia that fills my mind when I sit behind the wheel of the car to drop off, pick up or wait for one of three children and/or my husband is not to go unnoticed anymore.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: BRIEFING
description: It is difficult enough to figure out which departmental deputy assistant associate under secretary one should be speaking with on any given problem, and it is partly because of this that most Federal agencies issue new telephone directories to the public at least once a year. But for the past year, the difficulties have been even worse than usual at the State Department, which has not issued a new telephone directory since October 1985 despite the considerable but normal turnover as diplomats come and go, and despite a huge changeover in which everyone's number was changed.

title: ONCE AGAIN INTO THAT ASHEN NIGHT OF HISTORY
description: A NEW generation has come to life since Adolf Eichmann, the dour technocrat of the Nazi death camps, was tried and hanged 25 years ago, his ashes cast downwind from Israel upon the Mediterranean. Last Monday, the nation began only the second trial of an alleged Nazi war criminal in its history. This time the defendant was a retired auto worker extradited from Cleveland, John Demjanjuk (pronounced Dem-YAN-yuk), who seemed to startle the national audience in offering a bluff smile and a plea of innocence of ever having been a sadistic functionary in the Treblinka death camp - a victim himself, he pleaded, of mistaken identity. ''Boker Tov!'' he cried in Hebrew. ''Good Morning!''

title: ROLE OF COLLEGES WIDEN IN GUIDING STUDENTS' LIVES
description: With the demands of the students of the 1960's and 1970's for more independence now a distant memory, American colleges are increasingly involved in guiding the lives of their students outside the classroom.

title: Colleges in New Jersey To Share $22.8 Million
description: Public and private colleges and universities in New Jersey will receive $22.8 million for 17 projects under a bill signed Friday by Governor Kean.

title: Security Guard Is Charged In Death of Paper Deliverer
description: A newspaper deliverer was found dead in his car in Manhattan late Friday and the police yesterday filed a murder charge against a security guard who worked at the garage where the deliverer parked his car.

title: Elizabeth Sanger Planning to Wed J. A. Trachtenberg
description: Mr. and Mrs. Elliot M. Sanger Jr. of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Sanger, to Jeffrey A. Trachtenberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton P. Trachtenberg of Massapequa Park, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

title: New Haven's Green Becoming Golden
description: THE traditional sparkle and bustle of downtown New Haven streets on a recent frosty evening recalled days gone by as hordes of people wandered through boutiques and craft shops, scurried in and out of steamy restaurants and coffee shops and waited on lines for tickets to the Shubert, the Palace or the Yale Repertory Theater.

title: LONETTE MCKEE ON BECOMING LADY DAY
description: When Lonette McKee first picked up the script of ''Lady Day at Emerson's Bar & Grill,'' she ''got scared of it.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Homecoming a Happy One: Cindy Rarick, who attended the University of Hawaii for two years, won her first L.P.G.A. tournament yesterday by shooting a five-under-par 67 to take the 54-hole Tsumura Hawaiian Ladies Open. Rarick, who earned $45,000, ended the tournament at nine-under 207, two strokes ahead of Jane Geddes. (AP) Chen Leads by a Stroke: T. C. Chen, propelled by a hole-in-one, carded his second consecutive 67 to take a one-shot lead over Danny Edwards after three rounds of the $600,000 Los Angeles Open. Chen, a 28-year-old native of Taiwan, moved to nine-under-par 204 through 54 holes of the tournament at Riviera Country Club. Edwards had a round of 68. Ben Crenshaw shot a 66, and Bobby Wadkins, the first-round leader, had a 68 to remain within striking distance of the lead at 206. Chen knocked in his 6-iron tee shot on the 171-yard, par-3 sixth hole. (AP) Tennis Sukova to Face Graf: Fourth-seeded Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia came from behind to beat sixth-seeded Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina, 4-6, 6-3, 6-1, yesterday in the semifinals of the $250,000 Virginia Slims of Florida tournament at Boca Raton. In the other semifinal, second-seeded Steffi Graf of West Germany beat third-seeded Pam Shriver, 6-4, 6-3. Sukova's victory over Sabatini was a surprise ending after a solid beginning by the 16-year-old Argentine. In an 18-point final game, Sabatini couldn't convert on 6 game points and Sukova won the last 3 points. (AP) Horse Racing Tricky Squaw Scores by 6 Lengths: Tricky Squaw never trailed on her way to a six-length victory in the $117,400 Next Move Handicap for fillies and mares 3 years old and up yesterday at Aqueduct. The 4-year-old daughter of Clever Trick and Black Apache continued undefeated this year with her third straight front-running score, the first two of which came at Bay Meadows in California. She covered the mile and three-sixteenths on a fast track in 1:58 2/5 with 110 pounds to give Chris Antley his third winner of the day. Ms. Eloise was runner-up, 1 1/2 lengths ahead of Videogenic, who was a head in front of Squan Song, the favorite. Tricky Squaw earned $70,400 for her owner, Eugene V. Klein, and returned $7.20 for $2 to win in the field of nine. Skiing De Zolt Captures Gold Medal: Maurilio De Zolt earned Italy its second gold medal of the Nordic world championships with a dramatic victory yesterday in the men's 50-kilometer cross-country race at Oberstdorf, West Germany. His winning time of 2 hours 11 minutes 27.2 seconds was 22 seconds faster than the time of the runner-up, Thomas Wassberg of Sweden. The 36-year-old De Zolt was the 66th and final starter. (AP) Soccer Upset in England: Leeds United of the Second Division eliminated the Queens Park Rangers of the First Division from the English F.A. Cup with a 2-1 victory at home yesterday. A goal by Brendan Ormsby with five minutes left enabled Leeds United to gain the quarterfinals of the English League soccer tournament. In another surprise, a Third Division team, Wigan Athletic, reached the last eight of the competition for the first time in its history. Wigan trounced a Second Division team, Hull City, 3-0. Arsenal of the First Division, the cup favorite, scored two second-half goals and beat Barnsley of the Second Division, 2-0. (AP) Rugby France Wins: France beat England, 19-15, yesterday in Twickenham, England, for its second straight victory in the Five Nations Rugby Union championship. In another match, at Edinburgh, Scotland won its first league match of the season, defeating Ireland, 16-12. (AP) Track and Field East Europeans Excel: East European athletes dominated their Western counterparts during the first day of the European indoor championships yesterday at Lievin, France. East Bloc countries won five of six finals and Robert Emmian of the Soviet Union set a European long-jump record of 27 feet 10 1/4 inches, increasing his mark by 5 3/4 inches. Sweden's Patrik Sjoeberg won the high jump with 7-9 3/4. (AP) Tottenville Keeps Title: Tottenville High School retained its team title yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League girl's indoor track and field championships at Pratt University, Brooklyn. The Staten Island team edged Truman of the Bronx for the championship, 128 1/2 points to 123, with Tilden of Brooklyn third at 92. Sheri Lerner of Tottenville was the only double winner. She won the 1,000- and 1,500-meter runs and was selected as the meet's outstanding performer. Bobsledding Roy Sets Course Mark: Matt Roy of Saranac Lake set a course record of 58.87 seconds yesterday in World Cup four-man racing at Mount van Hoevenberg in Lake Placid, N.Y. Roy holds first place after two heats with a time of 1:57.77. The record ride came on his first trip down the 1,500-meter course and broke a mark of 58.99 set in 1983 by Ekkehard Fasser of Switzerland. Tied for second is Greg Haydenluck of Canada and Tom De La Hunty of Britain with a time of 1:58.42. (AP) N.B.A. Pistons 102, Hawks 97: Adrian Dantley scored 23 points and Isiah Thomas 16 last night to lead Detroit before 44,970 fans at the Silverdome. The Pistons stretched their Central Division lead over Atlanta to two and one-half games. (AP) Celtics 121, Spurs 113: Larry Bird scored 32 of his 34 points in the first half as Boston grabbed a 9-point halftime lead and held on to win in San Antonio. The Spurs made a game of it, pulling to 84-81 on a layup by Walter Berry with 3:21 left in the third period. But the Celtics countered with a 10-5 spurt led by Danny Ainge, who hit two 3-pointers to give Boston a 94-86 advantage. (AP) Rockets 94, Jazz 81: Akeem Olajuwon scored 28 points as Houston overcame a sluggish shooting performance to win on its home court. The Rockets hit only 38 percent of their first-half shots, but they rode Olajuwon's 21 points to a 51-44 lead. Houston finished with 43.9 percent shooting. (AP) Mavericks 122, Warriors 111: Rolando Blackman sparked a late fourth-quarter rally that propelled Dallas to an overtime victory on its home court. Golden State held a 101-96 lead with 2:11 remaining in the game, but Blackman outscored the Warriors, 7-2, to send the game into overtime. In the overtime period, Brad Davis and Detlef Schrempf scored 7 and 4 points, respectively, to give Dallas the victory. (AP)

title: Turkey
description: To the Editor: I read with regret the articles on Turkey (Travel, Jan. 18). I am disappointed because all those places were stolen from the Greeks. You mention that Turkey is one of the few countries in the world that feed their own people without outside help. This is correct, but I wish you had also mentioned that the land on which Turkey produces its surplus is the same land the Greeks created and fertilized before the Turks invaded it. The most recent takeover by the Turks occurred on Cyprus. The Turkish Government took over about 40 percent of this harmless island.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: AS A successful illustrator, Dick Kramer of Nutley has had many challenging projects, but his latest is a labor of love.

title: PARIS WHEN IT SIZZLES
description: EVERYONE SEEMS INTERESTED in what goes on at the Paris couture these days. Granted, the interest may not be quite as intense as it was in the 1930's, 40's, 50's, even into the 60's, before European ready-to-wear took over. In those olden, golden days, the Paris couture was the be-all and end-all of creativity. What was introduced or endorsed was immediately copied, adapted and accepted worldwide. Today, fashion ideas originate in many places and many countries. Nevertheless, in the past few years the couture has steadily re-emerged as a powerful arbiter of style, no longer content to merely purr along with luxurious clothes for women of financial substance. And with a series of showings the likes of those viewed last month for spring, it has become quite clear that no one with a shred of interest in fashion can afford to miss what transpires at this highest level of fashion. The exorbitant prices may limit their actual availability to a very few women, but their influence on general fashion is undeniably far-flung.

title: SHAMIR, REAGAN STRESS THE UP SIDE
description: American and Israeli officials did their best last week to ease strains prompted by the Iran-contra affair. President Reagan met with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and praised ''the close and special relations'' with Israel, ''a major non-NATO ally.''

title: THE SAN FRANCISCO BALLET TAKES A GAMBLE -- AND WINS
description: A major ballet company is measured by its overall standard of dancing and by the artistic value of its repertory. These are the two prerequisites upon which Helgi Tomasson has set his sights since becoming director of the San Francisco Ballet in July 1985. The winter season, which has just closed, revealed a strikingly impressive new improvement in the company's classical dancing. There was also a gamble well met: premieres by William Forsythe and James Kudelka, two still-developing but first-rank ballet choreographers we will hear more about in the future.

title: CABARET: 'MOSTLY MERCER'
description: SOME of the most successful shows presented at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, in recent years have been built around the songs of an outstanding songwriter sung by a well-known singer. The Pub is currently trying a variant of that formula, based on a record called ''Mostly Mercer'' on which some of the rich legacy of songs by Johnny Mercer are sung by a cast of 16 singers.

title: Anne Cover Plans Summer Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. E. McIntosh Cover of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Anne McIntosh Cover to Townsend Gilbert Rawlins, a son of Joyce W. Rawlins of Greenwich, Conn., and M. Morgan Rawlins of New York, New Hope, Pa., and Bridgehampton, L.I. A late summer wedding is planned.

title: The Job Machine Has Not Broken Down
description: THE United States has had enormous success in creating new jobs - nearly 13 million during the current recovery. Even though our unemployment rate is still quite high, a larger proportion of our population is working today than ever before. But some of our factories have closed down. And more and more jobs are in services. Do these trends mean that the new jobs are primarily part-time, dead-end jobs with low pay? Or that workers are leaving good factory jobs only to end up as minimum wage workers in fast-food restaurants, as some have suggested?

title: FOR ARAFAT, NOTHING SUCCEEDS LIKE FAILURE
description: YASIR Arafat never wins.

title: FOR RACIAL HARMONY, HOWARD BEACH MEETS ROCHDALE VILLAGE
description: Ethel Nadel is blunt when talking about Howard Beach, Queens, where she has lived for 21 years: ''A community of 18,000 people cannot be put in the same boat as 12 hooligans spoiling for a fight.''

title: SUNRISE, SUNSET
description: SEPTEMBER LIGHT By Horst Bienek. Translated by Ralph R. Read. 273 pp. New York: Atheneum. $17.95.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: I HAVE upstairs shoes and downstairs shoes. My downstairs array of footgear has more character, or perhaps it is just more endearing.

title: HOW DO YOU FEEL ABOUT SPRING TRAINING?
description: Spring training is to life what going on the road was to Willy Loman. It gives us hope. NORMAN KLINE Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Claire F. O'Brien Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur B. O'Brien of Atlanta and Branchport, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Claire F. O'Brien, to Timothy J. Brosnan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kevin J. Brosnan of New York. Ms. O'Brien, an associate at Davidson, Dawson & Clark in New York, and her fiance, an associate at Hawkins, Delafield & Wood in New York, both graduated from the Fordham University School of Law. The future bride is an alumna of Boston College. Mr. Brosnan graduated from Georgetown University.

title: TAKEOVER OF SPORTS DEBT ASKED
description: WITH the Giants' Super Bowl victory as a backdrop and the image of a major league baseball stadium as a coming attraction, the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority hopes to get voters to agree to assume its $365 million debt.

title: Syrian Armored Force Is Reported Outside Beirut
description: About 4,000 Syrian troops dismantled their camp near Beirut today and, according to unconfirmed radio reports, scouts from the force were in a suburb of the capital.

title: CONCERN RENEWED OVER LATIN DEBT
description: More than four years after Mexico raised the curtain on the Latin American debt drama, Brazil's decision Friday to suspend most payments on its huge foreign debt has focused attention anew on the region's failure to recover any degree of financial stability.

title: Short-Selling the Mutual Funds
description: Not everyone applauded when Fidelity Investments announced a program that would allow investors to sell mutual funds short.

title: EUROPE AND JAPAN SHOW NEW DECLINE IN THEIR ECONOMIES
description: As finance ministers from seven major industrial nations hold talks here this weekend on improving their economic performance and stabilizing currency values, economic growth in Europe and Japan is showing new weakness, largely as a result of the dollar's recent fall, economic figures show.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: In Woody Allen's newest film, ''Radio Days,'' Ronald Leir, 37, a reporter for The Jersey Journal in Jersey City, appears briefly. Although his ''big scene'' was edited out - he had three lines as a actor playing a detective on a radio serial - he appears in another scene.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: MYSTIC VICTORIANA

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: LEAD: Cumberland County officials hope there will be no delay in the long-sought construction of a Federal minimum-security prison in rural Fairfield Township, although bids from four companies were $8 million to $11 million higher than expected.

title: LETTING THE ATTACK GO UNDETECTED
description: The more bizarre, the more disorganized, the more unplanned an attack looks, the better are its chances to go undetected.

title: THE POET'S QUEST FOR THE FATHER
description: THE theme of this essay is of more than academic interest to me. One of the first poems of my youth, a tortuous elegy written in my 23d year, opened with the apostrophe, ''O ruined father dead,'' and concluded with the lines, ''Let sons learn from their lipless fathers how / Man enters hell without a golden bough.'' Aeneas, it will be recalled, did not dare to descend into the underworld to consult the shade of his father until, on the advice of the sibyl, he had gone to the sacred grove and plucked ''the pliant shoot of gold'' that would guard him from the terrors awaiting him below. The force of the allusion, as I read it now, is that modern man must make his descent, braving the worst, without the sanction of the sacred or the hope of salvation.

title: HIGH TECH IS NOT THE ANSWER
description: RECENT discussions of high technology on Long Island have obscured some crucial facts that will have to be addressed if the local economy is not to suffer serious decline in the future.

title: Riggins Gets 51, But Rutgers Falls
description: Bobby Lloyd's Rutgers jersey was retired during halftime of today's game with Penn State and by the time the game ended after two overtimes, Lloyd's school scoring record was nearly retired as well.

title: RECENT CASSETTES
description: Advise and Consent Produced and directed by Otto Preminger. Starring Henry Fonda, Charles Laughton, Walter Pidgeon, Gene Tierney, Paul Ford, Burgess Meredith, Peter Lawford, Don Murray and George Grizzard. Hal Roach Studios. 1962. 139 minutes. $29.95.

title: FOR LIMOUSINES, A WIDER CLIENTELE
description: LEAD: JENNIFER CANGRO of Smithtown rode in her first limousine, a 1987 white Lincoln Town Car, when she turned 13 last December. ''It was her mother's idea,'' said Ron Cangro, Jennifer's father. ''We wanted to do something special for her so we rented the limo to pick her up from school on her birthday.

title: Carol Martin Weds George Walker 3d
description: The marriage of Carol Banta Martin to George H. Walker 3d, president and chief executive officer of the Stifel Financial Corporation in St. Louis, took place yesterday at the South Congregational Church in Kennebunkport, Me. The Rev. Stephen Glauz-Todrank performed the ceremony.

title:
GARDENING;
UNPALATABLE PLANTS MAY DISCOURAGE DEER
description: LEAD: AS the suburbs expanded during the 50's and 60's, a frequently heard lament was that of the demise of certain forms of wildlife as their habitat was absorbed into the growing megalopolis. All sorts of animals began to disappear from the developing areas, including deer.

title: Trying to Get Inside the Minds of the Inside Traders
description: THE growing insider trading scandal passed a milestone last week when Dennis B. Levine was sentenced to two years in prison and fined $362,000. Mr. Levine, the first to be caught in the sweeping inquiry into Wall Street abuses, was charged with illegally earning $12.6 million in five years by trading on inside information. He had pleaded guilty to four felony counts, each carrying a maximum five year term. He also implicated others on Wall Street, leading to five other guilty pleas, among them that of Ivan F. Boesky, the arbitrager. The relatively light sentence, Federal District Judge Gerald L. Goettell said, reflected how ''essential to the system'' it is ''that a person who offers cooperation be rewarded.''

title: Assessing Offices at 45% of Value
description: LANGUAGE is never slow to catch up with practice. The real-estate world now has the phrase ''the sold buildings'' with which to discuss property-assessment practices in New York City.

title: Neighborhood in Florida Is Calm After Melees
description: After two nights of sporadic violence by youths, calm prevailed today in a mostly black Tampa neighborhood as community leaders went door to door urging parents to keep teen-agers off the streets.

title: YOUTH SUICIDE IS RISING
description: Young American men from 15 to 24 years old are killing themselves at a rate 50 percent higher than at the beginning of the previous decade, according to a new Federal study.

title:
GARDENING;
UNPALATABLE PLANTS MAY DISCOURAGE DEER
description: LEAD: AS the suburbs expanded during the 50's and 60's, a frequently heard lament was that of the demise of certain forms of wildlife as their habitat was absorbed into the growing megalopolis. All sorts of animals began to disappear from the developing areas, including deer.

title: THE TRUTH ABOUT LINCOLN
description: To the Editor:

title: PROSPECTS
description: Tighter Credit Soon

title:
ART;
DIAGRAMMATIC DRAWINGS EXPLORE DUALITY OF NATURE
description: LEAD: IF you think of a diagram in mathematical or analytical terms, chances are you imagine what the dictionary defines as an explanatory graphic design. Its function is to simplify, to reduce, to express the essence of a subject in fundamental visual form.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: OUTBREAK. By Robin Cook. (Putnam, $17.95.) The eye surgeon-turned-novelist Robin Cook, author of such bizarre medical thrillers as ''Coma,'' ''Mindbend'' and ''Godplayer,'' takes a jaundiced view of certain aspects of American medicine (venal, gullible doctors; greedy, for-profit medical corporations).

title: DURANG'S 'MARRIAGE OF BETTE AND BOO' STAGED IN FAIRFIELD
description: TO a sensitive, or squeamish, observer, the contents of Christopher Durang's wild and wicked autobiographically based ''Marriage of Bette and Boo'' are no laughing matter. Count, among them, stillborn children (whose bodies are hurled onto the floor by the delivering doctors), wretched families and miserable marriages. Characters include a berated wife named Soot - Boo's mother - who is grateful for life's ''little blessings,'' like turning deaf; a husband - Bette's father - who cannot utter an intelligible word and chokes to death in the middle of a family feud, and an asthmatic daughter - Bette's sister - who has a couple of mental breakdowns.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: BRIEFING
description: The Voice of America is planning to celebrate its 45th birthday tomorrow with an international festival of food, drink and music.

title: At Kiln, At Loom In New Hampshire
description: New Hampshire farmers plow fields next to the studios of weavers, ceramists and basket makers.

title: Soviet and Sudan Sign 3-Year Trade Accord
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Feb. 21 (AP) -

title: PLAYING WITH MATCHES IN IRAN
description: LEAD: MISSION TO TEHRAN By Robert E. Huyser. Introduction by Alexander M. Haig. 306 pp. New York: A Cornelia and Michael Bessie Book/ Harper & Row. $20.95.

title: OTHERS HOLD ELECTIONS -- IN CHICAGO THEY HAVE BRAWLS
description: NOT long ago a Chicago alderman confided to a friend that he had given up jogging. It was boring, he said: You couldn't knock anyone down.

title: COUNSELING FOR DISPLACED WORKERS
description: LEAD: IT HAS been nine months since the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Corporation closed its magnetic-tape plant in Freehold Township, but Stanley Fischer, president of Local 8-760 of the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers, hasn't forgotten the lesson.

title: COUNSELING IS NOT ALL FUN AND GAMES
description: LEAD: A JOB as a camp counselor is the first work experience many Westchester teen-agers have, one that they may envision as a summer of fun-filled days in the sun among their peers. But camp directors warn that with such expectations, the initial reality of camp counseling can come as a disappointment.

title: Care of Retarded: Other Views
description: Only in New York State are policy-makers still intent on building a system of institutional care for people with mental retardation. In other states, most institutions have been replaced by family-scale accommodations that foster personal development and promote social integration.

title: IN EXTREME SKIING, RISK IS JOY
description: JOHN HARLIN is not averse to exploring the woods behind his home in Greenwich on cross-country skis after a new snowfall, but Eastern ski resorts hold little appeal for him. What he enjoys is the challenge of the sport known as extreme skiing.

title: Soviet Lists 8 Jews Who It Says Can't Leave
description: The Soviet press has for the first time publicly identified eight Jews who are not allowed to emigrate because they were once employed in secret Government work.

title: J. Stephen Sheils to Wed Merry Gines, Executive
description: Merry Gines, founder and president of First New York Equity Inc., an investment advisory and financial planning concern in New York, and J.Stephen Sheils, a partner in the New York law firm Moore, Bersen, Lifflander & Mewhinney, plan to be married April 25.

title: Abdul-Jabbar Sued
description: FOR a man who had just scored 25 points and grabbed 13 rebounds to lead his team to a 128-122 victory over the Denver Nuggets, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar of the Los Angeles Lakers got a curious reward Wednesday night. When he returned to the Laker dressing room in McNichols Arena he was served with court papers notifying him that Alex English of the Nuggets had filed suit against him in a court in Denver seeking repayment of $150,000 in debts. English said that he and Brad Davis of the Dallas Mavericks had each lent Abdul-Jabbar $75,000 in 1985 and that the Laker star had not repaid the loans. ''It's a personal thing and I want to leave it at that,'' said English, whose suit indicated that Davis had assigned his part of the debt to English for collection. Abdul-Jabbar, who passed another National Basketball Association milestone by scoring his 36,000th point Friday night in Chicago (he is the first to reach that level), also declined to elaborate on the loans. But he indicated that the matter involved his former agent and business manager, Tom Collins, who had also represented English and Davis. Abdul-Jabbar has sued Collins for $55 million.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
DESIGN COMPETITION IS ANNOUNCED
description: LEAD: The United States Treasury is conducting a limited competition for designs of two coins to honor the nation's Constitution.

title: MAO MADE US DO IT
description: ENEMIES OF THE PEOPLE By Anne F. Thurston. 323 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: Art
description: There was no reason for Robert Bevan (1865-1925) to be anything more than an amiable but predestined second rater. An Englishman, born by the English Channel, he could have vegetated quietly and invisibly. But as it happened he had a fund of intellectual and esthetic curiosity that led him to art school in Paris and to Pont-Aven in Brittany when the influence of Gauguin was very much alive there. Through his marriage to a Polish painter, Sophie de Karlowska, he had yet other insights into ways of feeling and seeing and painting that were not at all English.

title: Low-Wage Jobs
description: To the Editor: Barry Bluestone and Bennett Harrison greatly overdramatize the significance of the shift toward low-wage jobs over the period 1979 to 1985 (''The Grim Truth About the Job 'Miracle' ,'' Forum, Feb. 1). They couch their statistical results in terms of the distribution of the net change in jobs by wage level and by part-time/full-time employment, without showing the corresponding changes in the distribution of all jobs.

title: Fredericka Gibbons to Marry
description: Dr. and Mrs. John Martin Gibbons Jr. of Hartford have announced the engagement of their daughter Fredericka Maureen Gibbons to George Hunt Witter, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Orin Witter of West Hartford, Conn. A fall wedding is planned.

The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 retail outlets, including newsstands, variety stores, supermarkets and bookstores. These figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. The number of titles within the two subdivisions of nonfiction can change from week to week, reflecting changes in book buying. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the bookselling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: A Male Secretary
description: A FEW YEARS AGO, FRESH OUT OF COLLEGE and in need of money, I took a job as a secretary in a large Boston bank. I had been trying to support myself as a freelance writer and was determined to keep writing, but I'd come to realize the good sense in my late grandfather's admonition upon hearing that I'd decided to become a writer: ''Get a real job.''

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: UP TO $500 million in Federal and state funds could be spent this year to replace and upgrade waste water treatment systems in New Jersey.

title: SNOW BRINGS OUT THE BEAUTY, TOO
description: ALTHOUGH it is 18 degrees this blue and white winter morning, the sweat is trickling between my shoulder blades and down my back. I am wearing just a sweater and slacks over thermal underwear but the sun is strong and my exertion is unusual. I am shoveling my driveway after the first big snowfall of the season.

title: F.D.A. Panel Urges Approval Of an Anti-Cholesterol Drug
description: An advisory committee has recommended that the Food and Drug Administration approve a new drug to help lower cholesterol levels in the blood.

title: WHAT THE WICKED MAGICIAN DID
description: THE EYES OF THE DRAGON By Stephen King. Illustrated by David Palladini. 326 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: PLAN FOR PRESERVE AIRED IN MONTANA
description: Montana ranchers are being asked to imagine a future in which wildlife would roam their land in the abundance that greeted the explorers Lewis and Clark in 1805.

title: U.S. Seeking Agreement to Use Air Base in Zaire
description: The Defense Department is seeking an agreement with Zaire that would allow the United States to use an air base to support a wide range of activities in central and southern Africa, a Pentagon official said today.

title: INSIDE
description: An Attempt to Kill Qaddafi The U.S. raid on Tripoli had a secret goal developed at the National Security Council: assassinating Libya's leader. The Magazine, section 6. Animal Feed Tied to Ills

title: STAMFORD HOME BECOMES A GALLERY
description: LEAD: THE career of Patricia Murphey Whitman has taken her from showcasing antiques to exhibiting art. But while most such ventures are housed in commercial space, Ms. Whitman is capitalizing on displaying art in her own home - over the fireplaces, amid greenery and surrounded by furniture.

title: CUOMO'S WITHDRAWAL MAY BOLSTER HIS ROLE AS BROKER, DEMOCRATS SAY
description: Governor Cuomo's decision not to run for President may make him the most powerful broker in the 1988 Democratic Presidential campaign and a major influence on the party's direction that a candidacy could not have guaranteed, Democrats around the country said yesterday.

title: SOUP KITCHENS AND PANTRIES FEED GROWING NUMBERS OF THE HUNGRY
description: ''I EAT here because I ain't got no money,'' a man said angrily. ''Otherwise I wouldn't be here.''

title: TUROFF TRIAL OPENS WITH ACCUSATIONS
description: The bribery and fraud trial of former Taxi and Limousine Commissioner Jay L. Turoff and three codefendants opened last week in Federal District Court in Brooklyn. It was the third trial in a wave of indictments and convictions of public officials in the corruption scandal that surfaced after the suicide attempt last January by Donald R. Manes, the Queens Borough President, who later did kill himself.

title: Does Boxing Still Have Its Appeal?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Tales Of Taxation
description: Things are not bad enough with the Unincorporated Business Tax, as related with wry humor by Andrew Tobias, for hardly has the city extracted its 4 percent on all single proprietors and partnerships, than the State of New York arrives to tax those same individuals on those same amounts that are now resting in the city coffers (''My Troubles With the Taxman.'' Jan. 18).

title: TALKING: Appraisals; Stripping Away the Mystery
description: BECAUSE an appraisal is pivotal to the approval or denial of a mortgage loan, an equity loan or a request for refinancing, the professional real-estate appraiser is frequently held in awe by buyers and homeowners.

title: RUSSIANS RECOVER LOST ICE STATION
description: A Soviet expedition ship caught up this month with a huge iceberg carrying a research station that had broken off from the Antarctic icecap last June, the Soviet press has reported.

title: Deborah Rosenbach to Wed Rabbi R. Z. Schwartz
description: Mr. and Mrs. Louis Rosenbach of Dallas have announced the engagement of their daughter Deborah Judith Rosenbach to Rabbi Ronald Z. Schwartz, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Maurice Schwartz of Towson, Md. A June wedding is planned.

title: TODAY'S MYSTERIES: THE WHODUNIT AND THE MOOD-DUNIT
description: If Edgar Allan Poe were to return to check out the season's movie marquees and television schedules, he would no doubt be gratified to discover that the mystery tale is prominently available in both the forms with which his name must be forever connected.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Amarillo, Tex.;
A Lone Star In a Cloudy Sky
description: LEAD: NOT a single apartment complex was started in this city of 160,000 people last year, after a construction surge three years earlier produced a glut. Single-family home production is down too, a reflection of the continuing slump in farming and the oil business.

title: MIAMI EXILES SAY THEIR FAVORITE CONTRA LEADERS ARE 'NONE OF THE ABOVE'
description: Nicaraguan exiles here generally view the public bickering and jockeying for power among top Nicaraguan rebel leaders with indifference, bemusement and sometimes thinly disguised hostility.

title: EXORCISE REYKJAVIK
description: To go beyond their Iceland summit meeting, Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev have to retreat to where they were before that fateful meeting. Reykjavik now blocks the way to useful arms limitations with grand illusions about space-based defenses and a world without nuclear weapons. Reagan officials and critics share that view: a summit that turned into a nadir.

title: DEATH: CERTIFICATION A PROBLEM
description: LEAD: WHEN someone dies at home, grieving relatives can face an unexpected ordeal: Finding a doctor who will make the official pronouncement of death and complete the death certificate.

title: WHERE DECONSTRUCTION BEGINS
description: To the Editor:

title: PANEL URGES STATE PROTECT 100,000 ACRES
description: TO preserve the dwindling supply of open land for ecological and recreational purposes, Connecticut should acquire another 100,000 acres -about 3 percent of the state's land area - by the year 2000, a state panel recommended last week.

title: DISCO DISARMAMENT DIARY
description: LEAD: ''The Event.'' That is what the Soviet Embassy called the recent three-day meeting in Moscow.

title: BILINGUAL PROGRAMS ARE UNDER ATTACK
description: THE sixth graders in Hilary Cooper's class are learning to write research papers. The topic is invertebrates and they can focus on any animal they wish, Ms. Cooper said. For the past month, she has been patiently showing them how to take notes, compile a bibliography, and produce an outline. It is slow going, but worth it, she said. ''I want them to understand that doing a research paper is more than going to an encyclopedia and copying down what it says,'' she said.

title: Klan Protests Slaying Of Principal in Georgia
description: Sixty-five Ku Klux Klan members and their supporters rallied on the courthouse steps in this northeast Georgia town today, protesting the killing of a white school principal in which a black teen-ager was charged.

title: Susan Rotman Engaged
description: The engagement of Susan Mann Rotman and David Parker Fugitt, a son of Dr. and Mrs. George Fugitt of Tonawanda, N.Y., has been announced by her parents, Constance Mann Rotman and Jack Eaton Rotman, both of Westport, Conn. A fall wedding is planned. Miss Rotman is a senior sales representative at Businessland, and Mr. Fugitt is a vice president of John D. Hastings Inc., a commercial real-estate company, both in Westport.

title: Wedding Is Planned By Elaine Jurgensen
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lee Jurgensen of Long Beach, Calif., of the engagement of their daughter Elaine Marie Jurgensen to Christopher Mahon Beermann, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Edward Beermann of Douglaston, Queens.

title: 7 Hurt in South Africa Unrest
description: JOHANNESBURG, Feb. 21 (AP) -

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: DANCERS IN WEST ORANGE Jennifer Muller, the choreographer, will perform with her troupe of 10 dancers next Sunday evening at the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. in West Orange.

title: Not Enough Chairs
description: HE spent an entire season following Bobby Knight and his Indiana basketball team, but John Feinstein, the Washington Post reporter who turned his observations into a bestseller, ''A Season on the Brink,'' will apparently have to buy a ticket if he wants to watch the Hoosiers play at home this season. According to The Post, Feinstein's request for credentials to cover yesterday's game against Iowa was turned down. Since Knight has criticized the book, that might suggest a bit of pettiness by the Indiana coach, but Kit Klingelhoffer, the Indiana sports information director, said there was another reason: lack of space. He said a request from The Minneapolis Tribune had also been turned down.

title: SEOUL ELECTION PROCESS STIRRING POLITICAL CRISIS
description: Many South Koreans are losing hope that their country can avert a political crisis in its search for a new way to select its national leader.

title: RECITAL: GIBBONS ON HARPSICORD
description: JOHN GIBBONS presented a first-class program of harpsichord music by Rameau, Bach, Domenico Scarlatti and Antoine Forqueray at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday night. Mr. Gibbons, currently a professor at the New England Conservatory and a member of the Boston Museum Trio, plays with a charged dynamism that does not preclude subtlety. Not for him the constrained music-box rhythms and tinkling over-refinement that characterize so many harpsichord recitals; Mr. Gibbons's playing is hearty and extroverted, his interpretations rhapsodic yet temperate with liberal rubato. It was one of the most engrossing recitals this listener has heard in quite some time.

title: HER MAN FRIDAY
description: FOE By J. M. Coetzee. 157 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95.

title: Snuffing Out Smoking in the Office
description: FOR the past 15 years, Charles L. Wrye has kept on his desk a sign that says, politely, ''Thank You for Not Smoking.'' An avid antismoker, he long ago decided that even though he has no right to force others to stop smoking, he does have the right to make his own work space smoke-free.

title: Recent Sales
description: Avon, Conn. $515,000 16 Ardsley Way 5-bedroom, 5 1/2-bath, 4-year-old colonial; 5 fireplaces, 1.4 acres; taxes $4,644. Fairfield, Conn. $518,000 Lantwick Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; 3,800 square feet of space, 2 acres; taxes not yet available. Richfield, Conn. $1.3 million 72 Nod Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 10-year-old contemporary; horse barn, riding ring, 3.3 acres, subdivision possible; taxes $6,781. Larchmont, N.Y. $360,000 25 Kenmare Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 62-year-old stucco Tudor/Norman; eat-in kitchen, den, 2 patios; taxes $4,337. New Rochelle, N.Y. $283,000 28 Indian Trail 3-bedroom, 3-bath, new raised ranch; family room, walk to schools and stores; taxes not yet available. Putnam Valley, N.Y. $210,000 Boswell Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, new brick/stucco Tudor/Norman; eat-in kitchen, 2-car garage; not yet assessed. OTHER AREAS Wading River, L.I. $180,000 14 Sunset Boulevard 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 15-year-old colonial; fireplace, laundry room, basement, 2-car garage, 0.5 acre; taxes $792. Ringwood, N.J. $135,000 39 Skyline Lakes Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 38-year-old Cape Cod; patio, 1-car garage, family room, full basement; taxes $1,835. Succasunna, N.J. $140,500 3 East Maple Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 80-year-old colonial; wraparound porch, garage; taxes $1,301.

title: ALZHEIMER'S STUDY FOCUSES ON GENE
description: Since at least some Alzheimer's cases are hereditary, scientists have been seeking a cause among the 23 pairs of chromosomes that form the human genome, the repository of the body's genetic information.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: LEAD: ARCTIC DREAMS: Imagination and Desire in a Northern Landscape, by Barry Lopez. (Bantam, $4.95.) Barry Lopez's account of his travels in the Arctic won the American Book Award for nonfiction in November. Edward Hoagland said in The Book Review last year that the author is ''a rhapsodist, and what he has done in this passionate paean to the Arctic and its cycles of light and darkness, its species of ice, its creatures and waters, is to present a whole series of raptures and riffs on the subject of musk oxen, ivory gulls, white foxes, polar bears, icebergs and sea currents.

title: Flaws Seen In Legal Fund
description: The Suffolk County Legislature's proposed legal fund to protect citizens from the harassment and expense of frivolous lawsuits is well intentioned but doomed to failure [ ''Dispute on Suffolk Legal Fund,'' Jan. 18 ] . This concept, which merely attempts to equalize the legal battle by providing some public funding to citizens who are unjustly sued, is basically flawed.

title:
COLLEGE BASKETBALL '87: TODD MAY;
A WINDING ROAD LEADS BACK HOME
description: LEAD: THE last decade or so has been good to this busy pocket of Appalachia. First, the Arab oil embargo in the mid-70's drove up the price of coal, which was the best of news for the largest bituminous coal-producing county in the country. Now, there are said to be more than 100 millionaires in Pike County, and rusting pickup trucks share the crooked mountain roads with Cadillacs and

title: RECOILING, REREADING, RETELLING
description: UNFLINCHING, according to book reviewers, is what novelists and short-story writers ought to be. Serious fiction flinches from nothing - neither death, decay, ingratitude or the failure of friendship, hope or love.

title: THE A B C's OF SKIING WITH THE KIDS
description: Cars in the parking lot at the Sugarbush Ski Resort have added baby seats. The slopes are dotted with pint-sized skiers. At the resort's day-care center, 40 children -from 3-month-old Spike to 5 1/2-year-old Justin - are turning graham crackers into graham cracker crumbs while their parents are skiing.

title: REAGAN REPORTED TO LIMIT DEBATE IN GENEVA ON DEFENSE SYSTEMS
description: President Reagan has instructed American arms officials in Geneva not to negotiate or even discuss limits on defensive systems that would be more restrictive than the Administration's new interpretation of the Antiballistic Missile Treaty, Administration officials said today.

title: POSTINGS: Bedford Hills Prefabs; 26 Town Houses From Sweden
description: It is not unusual for developers to import special building materials from abroad to lend cachet to a project. But Lynn and Jad Barghout of Mount Kisco, N.Y., principals of Ramleh Enterprises, decided to import everything.

title: LIVING A LIFE ON AN ACRE OF L.I.
description: LIKE so many Northerners, I longed to retire to an island in the sun, hoping, perhaps, that those promised older, golder years would actually come into being with the help of a hot tropical sun. At any rate, I pursued my goal more assiduously than most, and now I own seaside property in the Bahamas.

title: A Jonathan Swifty
description: To the Editor:

title: Put the Rich Back on the Tax Rolls
description: ACROSS the nation, state governments are grappling with how to respond to the just-passed Federal Tax Reform Act of 1986. Unfortunately, much of what has been said and written - about ''revenue windfalls'' and ''back-door tax increases'' - misses the point.

title: 2 CONNECTICUT GIRLS RESCUED AFTER FALL THROUGH POND ICE
description: When 6-year-old Brittney Blye saw her friend Tara Turchetti fall through the ice in a pond in Westbrook, Conn., Friday she was seized with fear.

title: P. Harvey Chase Dies at 57; Specialized in Rheumatology
description: Dr. P. Harvey Chase, former chief of medicine at Brooklyn Jewish Hospital, now Interfaith Medical Center, died of cancer Wednesday at North Shore University Hospital, Manhasset, L.I. He was 57 years old and lived in Roslyn, L.I.

title: HOW DO YOU FEEL ABOUT SPRING TRAINING?
description: To me, it signals the beginning of a new season of listening to Bill White and Phil Rizzuto as they will describe the events at the Stadium.

title: DURANG'S 'BETTE AND BOO'
description: TO a sensitive or squeamish observer, the contents of Christopher Durang's wild and wicked autobiographically based ''The Marriage of Bette and Boo'' are no laughing matter. Count among them stillborn children (whose bodies are hurled onto the floor by the delivering doctors), wretched families and miserable marriages. Characters include a berated wife named Soot - Boo's mother - who is grateful for life's ''little blessings,'' like turning deaf; a husband - Bette's father - who cannot utter an intelligible word, and chokes to death in the middle of a family feud; and an asthmatic daughter (Bette's sister) who has a couple of mental breakdowns.

title: WHERE DECONSTRUCTION BEGINS
description: To the Editor:

title: MAGICIAN EXPOUNDS ON HIS ART
description: WHEN Phillip Jennings cuts a woman in half, he uses an electric saw and does so without using a box.

title: ACCORD ON DOLLAR APPEARS REMOTE
description: Prospects for major changes in economic policies that might stabilize the dollar appeared dim tonight, as leading finance ministers and central bank officials rushed about Paris in quest of agreements to calm the world's financial markets.

title: ISLANDERS REGAIN SCORING TOUCH
description: The team that had been in trouble solved several problems simultaneously tonight.

title: FROM HALF MOON BAY TO SANTA CRUZ
description: When Californians voted during the early 1970's to impose America's most stringent coastal zoning regulations in an effort to preserve their shoreline from overdevelopment, many of them may have been thinking about a lonely 60-mile stretch of coast near Half Moon Bay.

title: INQUIRIES LOOK AT ORIGIN OF ARMS SITTING UNCLAIMED IN HONDURAN WAREHOUSE
description: A large cache of Soviet-made arms sitting unclaimed and unsalable in a warehouse in Honduras has become one of the latest mysteries emerging from the Federal and Congressional investigations of the private network to arm the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: CIVIL ACCORD SEEN IN TOXIC DUMPING
