description: A pipeline company that has acknowledged dumping a toxic substance, PCB's, along its right of way is unlikely to face criminal charges filed by the Environmental Protection Agency, officials of the agency said today.

title: A GLOOMY WHITE HOUSE BRACES FOR THE JUDGMENTS IN TOWER PANEL'S REPORT
description: AS the dispiriting distractions of the Iran-contra affair continued to swirl around the White House last week, President Reagan and his aides mounted a determined effort to demonstrate that they were still in charge. But all efforts to get on with the normal business of government have been clouded by the knowledge that the special board reviewing the Iran-contra affair is likely to deliver a scathing critique of the Administration's performance when it reports Thursday.

title: SURVEY OF WHISTLE BLOWERS FINDS RETALIATION BUT FEW REGRETS
description: Workers who reveal waste, fraud and abuse can expect retaliation, financial loss and high emotional and physical stress, according to a survey by two Maryland researchers.

title: SHORTAGES OF INSPECTORS HINDER TOWNS
description: THE booming construction industry is making it harder for towns to find help in their planning, zoning and building offices, as higher salaries lure workers out of government.

title: DRAWING THE G.O.P. BACK FROM THE ABYSS
description: CONNECTICUT'S voting patterns and political-party development of the last 25 years have led this state close to the one-party rule we see in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to our north.

title: CONCERT: LUKAS FOSS IS TASHI'S GUEST SOLOIST
description: CHAMBER music in the modern concert setting is a contradiction in terms. The irony is especially strong with popular groups such as Tashi, who manage to attract - and who deserve - the kind of large following that showed up at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night.

title: Mets Given Off-Field Pointers
description: Dwight Gooden was there, sleek and unperturbed by his winter of commotion. Two dozen of his teammates were there, working out for the first time since the World Series. And the boss, Frank Cashen, was there, imposing a vow of silence on the Mets over their personal and legal jams because ''we don't want to beat ourselves.''

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LEAD: MARDI GRAS GALA

title: SOVIET ADVANCE NOTICE OF A-BLAST LIKELY
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev has indicated that the Soviet Union will announce the next nuclear test in advance, breaking with a longstanding policy of keeping silent about its testing program.

title: ST. JOHN'S BEATEN AT 0:00
description: Kansas has been criticized this season for being a one-dimensional team, the one dimension being Danny Manning.

title: KNICKS AND NETS: A COMEDY IN FOUR ACTS
description: Nine-year-old kid is being questioned by a judge during a custody hearing. Judge says, ''Kid, do you want to live with your father?'' Kid says, ''No, my dad beats me.'' Judge says, ''Well, then, do you want to live with your mother?'' Kid says, ''No, my mother beats me, too.'' Judge says, ''Well, who do you want to live with?'' Kid says, ''The New York Knicks or the New Jersey Nets.'' Judge says, ''Why?'' Kid says, '' 'Cause they don't beat anybody.''

title: A WORD ON THE COSTS OF PSYCHOTHERAPY
description: The article ''Youth Cases Put Strain on Mental Aid'' [ Feb. 1 ] includes statements by Dr. Carolina Hedlund of the Northern Westchester Guidance Clinic that may leave the reader with an erroneous impression - namely, that all private practitioners in psychotherapy charge fees beyond the reach of low-income families. This is simply not so.

title: Tina M. Gallagher Becomes a Bride
description: Tina Marie Gallagher and Mark Paul Messing were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. James Joseph Gallagher, in Wilmington, Del. The Rev. Frank Van Brunt, a Methodist minister, officiated.

title: THE DEBATE DEBATE
description: On one side, dignified but furious, stands the League of Women Voters, ''governess of the nation,'' as the columnist Mary McGrory once called it. For the last three Presidential elections, it has sponsored televised debates. On the other side, in rare unity, stand the Republican and Democratic parties. Cigars and suspenders have yielded to tailored suits and aviator glasses but still they are cast as old-fashioned heavies - trying to muscle the good-government ladies out of the way and take over sponsorship.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE WHIPPING BOY By Sid Fleischman. Illustrated by Peter Sis. 90 pp. New York: Greenwillow Books. $11.75. (Ages 6 to 10)

title: Winter Can Be Very Tough on Wildlife, Too
description: THE snow and cold that delight the hearts of ski resort operators and their clients, and inconvenience those who must shovel driveways or lurch forth on icy sidewalks, play a more fundamental role in the lives of many wild creatures.

title: THE SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA LOOKS BACK TO THE FUTURE
description: Two weekends ago, an English conductor named Roger Norrington presented three days of lectures, discussions and demonstrations in London's Queen Elizabeth Hall that culminated in a full-dress, large-scale, original-instruments performance of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony. In recent years, others have performed and recorded earlier Beethoven symphonies on original instruments. But this Ninth was the capstone of their work thus far. No one seems to have ventured this far into the Romantic music that forms the core of our concert repertory, or to have essayed as scrupulously prepared, artistically successful a performance on original instruments of this perhaps most famous piece in all of classical music.

title: Ivy Miller to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morton Miller of Great Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Ivy Michelle Miller to Dr. Andrew Marc Schneider, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Schneider of Tamarac, Fla. Miss Miller, editor in chief of Modern Screen and Movie Mirror magazines in New York, and her fiance, a third-year resident at the Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, plan to be married in June.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
IT'S SNOWY AND ITS'S COLD AND IT'S SPRINGTIME
description: LEAD: MY spring trainings begin with my dentist. He is a fireplug of a man with a shiny bald head and a handshake that turns the tips of my 10-year-old's fingers white. He loves baseball and constantly asks me how my own playing is coming. In his eyes, I am always the next Koufax and he follows my games as if I am his son.

title: Cassie Shaw Wed To Kurt N. Holm, A Financial Aide
description: Cathryn A. Shaw, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Shaw Jr. of Englewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Kurt Nicholas Holm, a son of Edna May Holm of Omaha and E.Richard Holm of Fremont, Neb. The Rev. Charles Temple performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration in New York.

title: FRENCH WITH AN ENGLISH ACCENT
description: THE LARGE OAK refectory table is worn with the rich patina of age, as well it might be after more than 300 years of use. The fireplace is a gaping maw where whole boars and lambs rotate easily on the spit. The light filtering through the lead-paned windows and lapping at the tapestry-covered walls is gentle, like the docile, comforting landscape at Clapham House, the beautiful 18th-century East Sussex manor of Sabine and Patrick Brassart. Here, in rolling pastured hills near the south coast of England, this quintessentially French couple have chosen to live in a lovingly restored home, conduct a cooking school for serious future chefs and fully utilize the bounty of their adopted land in preparing classic and contemporary dishes.

title: ANIMAL ANTIBIOTICS TIED TO ILLNESSES IN HUMANS
description: Scientists from the Federal Centers for Disease Control have come up with new evidence linking antibiotics in animal feed to illness in humans.

title: GUIDRY IS SERENE DOWN ON FARM
description: Somewhere on a 50-acre plot outside Lafayette, La., a man sits on an old Ford tractor. He is alone in his solitude and his thoughts. No one is nearby. Cars that pass by the area are as far away as a drive to the distant land of left-center field at Yankee Stadium. The man on the tractor knows that spot and that stadium well. In other years, he has been in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., at this time preparing himself to work at Yankee Stadium. Now he sits on his tractor, the one his grandfather left him when he died a few years ago, his left hand gripping the controls instead of a baseball.

title: SINGLAUB ASSERTS HE SEEKS TREASURE
description: Maj. Gen. John K. Singlaub has declared that he is indeed on the track of legendary buried treasure in the Philippines in what he described as an effort to boost the local economy.

title: U.S. ISSUES RULES FOR DRUG TESTS
description: In its guidelines for widespread drug testing of Federal employees, the Reagan Administration emphasized safeguards against false accusations and against cheating.

title: CONFESSIONS OF A 'USELESS MAN'
description: LITTLE WILSON AND BIG GOD By Anthony Burgess. 460 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $22.50.

title: Laguna Beach
description: To the Editor: I was happy to read Marcia Seligson's article (Travel, Jan. 4) exclaiming the virtues of Laguna Beach, Calif. I, too, am captivated by all that it has to offer. So much so that we have a time share for three weeks a year there.

title: DELVING INTO LIFE - THE CHINESE WRITER'S DUTY
description: LEAD: Liu Binyan is with little doubt the most widely respected writer in China active today. As a practicing journalist, his exposes of despotism and corruption have won him an almost reverent following among Chinese intellectuals, especially the young. A lifelong dedicated Marxist, Mr. Liu, who is 62 years old, joined the Communist Party underground in 1943 and taught himself Russian so he could read Lenin in the original.

title: Recent Sales
description: Bridgewater $255,000 28 Flanders Way 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1-year-old colonial; hardwood floors, A/C; taxes $3,000. Elizabeth $125,000 639 Green Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, front porch, dining room, 2-car garage; taxes $1,359. Paramus $199,500 392 Hickory Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 46-year-old colonial; full basement, fireplace, remodeled kitchen, garage; taxes $1,732. Ringwood $135,000 39 Skyline Lakes Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 38-year-old Cape Cod; patio, 1-car garage, family room, full basement; taxes $1,835. Succasunna $140,500 3 East Maple Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 80-year-old colonial; wraparound porch, brick fireplace, 2-car garage; taxes $1,301. West Milford $129,900 4 Madelyn Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 3-year-old ranch; deck, 1-car garage, front porch, wall-to-wall carpeting; taxes $1,915. OTHER AREAS Larchmont, N.Y. $360,000 25 Kenmare Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 62-year-old stucco Tudor/Norman; eat-in kitchen, den, 2 patios; taxes $4,337. Avon, Conn. $515,000 16 Ardsley Way 5-bedroom, 5 1/2-bath, 4-year-old colonial; 5 fireplaces, 1.4 acres; taxes $4,644. Calverton, L.I. $70,000 228 Hill Rise 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 10-year-old condominium town house; common charges $75, taxes $1,100.

title: NUNN WON'T ENTER PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: With the same kind of methodical argument that helped build his reputation in Congress, Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia has decided to remove himself from the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination and devote himself full time to his duties in the Senate.

title: PANEL TO URGE STANDARD FEES IN MEDICARE SERVICES
description: An expert advisory panel created by Congress will soon recommend a standardized national fee schedule for payment of physicians who treat the 31 million elderly and disabled people under Medicare, the Federal health insurance program.

title: SHOULD CIGARETTE ADS BE OUTLAWED?
description: THE debate over tobacco advertising is shifting from doctors to lawyers. Last week, the American Bar Association took up and rejected a resolution supporting efforts to ban all advertising of tobacco products. A few days later, Representative Michael L. Synar, Democrat of Oklahoma, reintroduced a bill in Congress that calls for such a ban.

title: TWO ARTISTS WHO FLOURISH IN A POSTMODERN CLIMATE
description: Ross Bleckner is a 37-year-old painter who lives in New York and works in two distinct styles.

title: Claire Laporte Engaged to Neil Kulick
description: The engagement of Claire Laporte to Neil Michael Kulick has been announced by James W. Craven and Adele P. Laporte of Ann Arbor, Mich., stepfather and mother of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Kulick of Short Hills, N.J. An August wedding is planned.

title: INVESTING
description: LEAD: LEAVE it to Wall Street, with share prices at record levels, to busy itself promoting a new type of ''stock'' designed to appeal both to income-oriented investors and to point-grabbing speculators.

title: INVENTIVE MENU, GENTLE MILIEU
description: HERE we go again. Another (hotel) opening, another (gustatory) show. This time, it is the new Hyatt Regency Hotel in Greenwich, latest of the large chain hotels to open in Fairfield County.

title: Unsung Heroes
description: To the Editor: While your article about how ''New York Plays Reluctant Landlord'' [ Dec. 14 ] gives due credit to our leaders, Angelo Guzman and Ronnie Arsenec, no mention is made of the maintenance mechanics and boiler repairmen.

title:
ART;
WINNERS' WORKS IN HARTFORD
description: LEAD: THE well-trafficked hallways of the Connecticut Commission on the Arts in Hartford are currently doubling as exhibition space for the 18 winners of the 1987 Visual Arts Grants Competition. The winners were asked to make specific proposals on how a grant would further their work, but are represented in the exhibition by completed paintings, sculptures, prints and photographs.

title: Classical Music
description: There is no doubt that writing for an orchestra is a risky proposition for a composer. Because of the tremendous cost of orchestra rehearsal time, and a certain timidity on the part of trustees and subscribers, there is a good chance that a young or unknown composer will never hear a new symphonic work performed. Far safer to stay with chamber music, which requires only two or three musicians or, safer yet, with works for electronic tape.

title: A CORRECTION
description: An article on Nov. 16 incorrectly reported that Circus Circus Enterprises Inc. of Las Vegas had announced plans to build a casino in Atlantic City. The company has no such plans.

title: RECENT CASSETTES
description: Women in Rock With Tina Turner, Brenda Lee, Bonnie Raitt, Cher and others. MCA Home Video. 57 minutes. $29.95.

title: PANEL AGAIN TALKS TO MCFARLANE
description: President Reagan's former national security adviser told a commission investigating the Iran-contra affair again today that Mr. Reagan had approved the first shipment of American arms to Iran in August 1985, sources familiar with the commission's work said.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
Housing Catching Up With City's Revival
description: LEAD: IN the past 12 years, New Brunswick, once a decaying city of empty storefronts and littered lots, has sprung back to life.

title: PARENTS JOIN COUNTY EFFORT ON DRUG USE
description: LEAD: ACROSS the county, groups of parents are meeting to discuss such problems as how to get their preteen-agers to clean their rooms, take out the garbage or visit their grandparents.

title: A DIRECTOR'S ODYSSEY THROUGH TIME AND SPACE
description: For a man with an important new job in Minneapolis, Garland Wright is spending an unusual amount of time in Manhattan these days.

title: An Opium Warlord's News Conference Spurs Burma and Thailand to Battle Him
description: An opium warlord whose narcotics trafficking supports an armed rebellion against Burma is reported to be under separate military attacks from Burmese and Thai forces.

title: A New Auto-Focusing Single-Lens Reflex
description: THE season for new-camera announcements is in full swing, set off by the Photo Marketing Association's annual trade show, which takes place this week in Chicago. To no one's surprise, auto-focusing single-lens reflexes are making the most stir. And making the most stir so far among them is the Canon EOS system, which was introduced to the press last week.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: At Symphony Hall in Newark Thursday, a nonprofit group that promotes entertainment for the disadvantaged, Special Audiences of New Jersey, along with the Newark Board of Education, is sponsoring the city's first rap contest, with a top prize of $50 for each member of the winning team and $500 to be awarded in all.

title:
FOCUS: Little Rock;
Catching Up in the Sun Belt
description: LEAD: THIS capital city in the center of Arkansas has had a surge in office construction over the last four years, but it is awaiting a second wave of Sun Belt growth to fill the buildings.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: LEAD: ''The most popular series we've ever run'' is how Karen Hall describes Hunterdon County Adult Education's ''Great Kitchens'' course, which lets participants watch the specialties of several restaurants being prepared, and then taste them.

title: PUPILS TAKE CENTER STAGE FOR OPERA
description: LEAD: FOR the first and sixth graders it was anything but education as usual at school the other day in Commack. The 6-year-olds, after all, had never before watched someone turn herself into a witch, and the 12-year-olds were new to singing and dancing with professional performers.

title: 'CAN YOU DO THE JOB AND SLEEP AT NIGHT?'
description: KEEPER OF CONCENTRATION CAMPS Dillon S. Myer and American Racism. By Richard Drinnon. Illustrated. 339 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $24.95.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.; Quitters: Two 'Smoked' Food, Another Knitted
description: IT went on for about six months.

title: FOR SPAIN'S SOCIALISTS, FIRE FROM THE LEFT
description: Inside Spain's governing Socialist Party, Jose Maria Maravall is known as the Oxford-educated theoretician who, as Minister of Education for the last four years, has held the party's feet to the fire on social ideals.

title: Indiana Beats Iowa As Alford Gets 24
description: Keith Smart scored 13 of his 17 points in the first half, and Steve Alford came out of a shooting slump to score 24 as Indiana beat Iowa, 84-75, today in a Big Ten game.

title: Locust Valley Lockjaw
description: After reading William Safire's article ''Locust Valley Lockjaw'' (On Language, Jan. 18), I tried to enunciate, pressing ''the tips of the lower incisors firmly against the inside of the upper incisors,'' but it did not work. Perhaps one needs to be a member of the Larchmont Yacht Club to get the right drawl.

title: THE MAN WHO WEARS THE STAR: James W. Kinnear; Winning Friends for Texaco When It Needs Them Most
description: MOST of the closed-circuit television cameras that had for about a decade watched over the well-manicured grounds at Texaco Inc.'s Westchester County headquarters have been turned off. The main entrance is still well guarded, but the uniformed guards are gone from the other gates, where employees, and even occasionally visitors, can come and go, unstopped.

title: Pitt Wins, 76-66, and Leads Big East
description: Even Jerome Lane lost track of how many rebounds he pulled down today as he led Pittsburgh to a 76-66 Big East victory over Connecticut.

title: BARRACKS PLAN IS DISTURBING STAFFORD
description: OFFICIALS in Stafford are sending an official protest to Governor O'Neill over a plan to move a state police barracks on Buckley Turnpike to neighboring Tolland.

title: CONCERT: THE DELLER CONSORT
description: THE six singers in the Deller Consort gathered around a table at the Metropolitan Museum on Thursday night, as if preparing for a panel meeting. Instead, they sang songs by William Byrd and Michael East, Italian madrigals by Giovanni Gastoldi, Carlo Gesualdo, Claudio Monteverdi and others, and a selection of 20th-century French chansons.

title: TODAY'S SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Detroit Pistons At Pontiac, Mich., 7 P.M. Television MSG, 7 P.M. Radio WPAT 930 AM, 7 P.M. Philadelphia 76ers vs. L.A. Lakers At Philadelphia, noon Television Channel 2, noon. College Georgia Tech at DePaul Television Channel 4, 1 P.M. Georgetown at Syracuse Television Channel 2, 2:30 P.M. Radio WNYE 91.5 FM, 2 P.M. Louisville at Memphis State Television Channel 7, 2 P.M. St. Joseph's at West Virginia Television MSG, 4 P.M. Boxing Lloyd Honeyghan vs. Johnny Bumphus At Wembley, England I.B.F. welterweight title, 15 rounds Television Channel 7, 4 P.M. Golf Los Angeles Open Pacific Palisades, Calif. Television Channel 2, 4:30 P.M. Hockey Rangers vs. Pittsburgh Penguins At Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. Television MSG, 9:30 P.M., tape delay. Radio WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M. Islanders vs. Devils At Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 5:05 P.M. Television SportsChannel, 5 P.M. and 8:30 P.M. Radio WOR 710 AM; WMCA 570 AM, 5 P.M. Other Events Auto Racing NASCAR: Miller 400 Television WTBS, 1:05 P.M. Harness Racing At Roosevelt, 7:30 P.M. Skiing U.S. National Championship Television Channel 7, 1 P.M. World Cup, men's cross-country Television Channel 7, 4 P.M. Tennis Pilot Pen Classic At Indian Wells, Calif. Television USA, 3 P.M. Track Michelob Indoor Invitational At San Diego Television Channel 7, 4 P.M. Thoroughbred Racing At Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. Television SportsChannel, 8 and 11:30 P.M., taped.

title: Recent Sales
description: Calverton $70,000 228 Hill Rise 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 10-year-old condominium town house; common charges $75, taxes $1,100. Copiague $245,000 18 Dolphin Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 12-year-old ranch; family room, fireplace, 100 feet of canal bulkhead, 1-car garage; taxes $4,700. Hauppauge $175,000 5 Miami Court 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath high ranch; family room with bar, dining room, porch, 2-car garage, 0.5 acre; taxes $2,300. Lindenhurst $163,750 162 Verona Parkway 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 20-year-old high ranch; eat-in kitchen, legal 1-bedroom, 1-bath apartment; taxes $3,300. Massapequa $330,000 9 Bay Link 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 25-year-old split-level; central A/C, pool, greenhouse, 2-car garage; taxes $6,200. Wading River $180,000 14 Sunset Boulevard 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 15-year-old colonial; fireplace, laundry room, basement, 2-car garage, 0.5 acre; taxes $792. OTHER AREAS Larchmont, N.Y. $360,000 25 Kenmare Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 62-year-old stucco Tudor/Norman; eat-in kitchen, den, 2 patios; taxes $4,337. Avon, Conn. $515,000 16 Ardsley Way 5-bedroom, 5 1/2-bath, 4-year-old colonial; 5 fireplaces, 1.4 acres; taxes $4,644. Succasunna, N.J. $140,500 3 East Maple Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 80-year-old colonial; wraparound porch, garage; taxes $1,301.

title: OPERA-MUSIC INSTITUTE TO GET A 3-YEAR TRIAL
description: LEAD: AN INSTITUTE designed to train those just beginning professional careers in opera will get a three-year trial run at Montclair State College under plans announced last week.

title: NEW TAX LAW THREATENS HIGH-TECH CONSULTANTS
description: DEPENDING on who is speaking, the new tax law will affect thousands of ''self-employed'' Long Islanders by putting a stranglehold on their independence or will strike a blow against unfair privilege, one of the principal objectives of the legislation.

title: SOVIET VIEWERS ARE SEEING MORE, INCLUDING NEWS OF THE U.S.
description: The televising of ''Amerika,''

title: LINDBERGH RIVALS' WRECK SOUGHT IN MAINE WOODS
description: Twelve days before Charles A. Lindbergh flew nonstop to Paris from New York, two French war heroes tried to fly to New York from Paris, taking off from Le Bourget airfield amid so many elegantly clad well-wishers that troops with bayonets had to hold the crowd back.

title: Honeyghan Risking His Title and a Party
description: Johnny Bumphus will do more than beat the odds if he becomes world welterweight boxing champion Sunday by beating the only man to halt Donald Curry. He also will spoil Lloyd Honeyghan's Christmas party.

title: Back to the Field
description: THE salary arbitration season ended yesterday with Dick Schofield, the California Angels' shortstop, winning a $475,000 salary. Don Sears, the arbitrator who heard the case Friday, awarded Schofield the salary he wanted over the Angels' $305,000. Schofield earned $210,000 last year. The final totals for arbitration this year had clubs winning 16 cases and players 10. That brought the 12-year arbitration record to 139 winning cases for clubs and 111 for players. Clubs have won more cases than players in all but three years and in every year of the last six.

title: Caroline V. Mortimer to Marry June 27
description: Mr. and Mrs. Egbert Laird Mortimer 3d of West Hartford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Caroline Virginia Mortimer, to Richard Lawrence Grubman Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Grubman of Englewood, N.J. The wedding is to be June 27.

title: THE MOMENTOUS DECISION NOT TO RUN FOR PRESIDENT
description: When politicians decide not to run for President, it's news. Whether the reasons they give -especially the family reasons cited by Mario M. Cuomo Thursday, or by Edward M. Kennedy in 1982 - seem to explain it all or not, there is something that seems unusual in proclaimed self-denial by a politician prominent enough to be thought of a serious candidate to begin with.

title: THE CHANGING GUARD
description: A big change has come over Washington in the last few weeks. People are beginning to talk about the Reagan Administration in the past tense. The reporters are still running around like blind dogs in a meat house, but almost everybody else seems willing to leave the recent White House scandals to the investigators, the historians and the psychological novelists.

title: Coach Is Vital In Early Years
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
WANDERING AROUND A WASTELAND
description: LEAD: THE DUMP is vast, occupying hundreds of acres of clayey lowlands near a dirty river - on the map, a big roadless blank at the heart of overbuilt old Central Jersey suburbs.

title: Love Story: Part II
description: HE was a lawyer who once ran for New York State Assemblyman. She was a friend who lived in the Bronx. He said he loved her, but she rejected him after learning he was married. He hired three thugs to throw lye in her face, so ''no one else will want you.''

title: Fordham Surges by Longhorns
description: Joe Franco and James Robinson scored 14 points each, and Fordham took the lead for good with an early first-half surge at Byrne Meadowlands Arena to defeat Texas, 60-48, today.

title: Exact Measures
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: VIETNAM WITHOUT WATERGATE?
description: To the Editor:

title: DATA BANK: February 22, 1987
AN RX FOR JOBS LOST THROUGH MERGERS
description: LEAD: The round of mergers, acquisitions, restructurings and leveraged buyouts has produced record profits. It has also produced enormous pain resulting from terminations, layoffs, plant closings and other disruptions. Simple justice suggests that these profits be taxed to fund an agency that could assist individuals and communities suffering as a result of merger mania.

title: EASY WRITER
description: Only Katharine Hepburn could make it sound so easy, and such fun. Talking about the three months she spent on location in Africa, making the 1952 motion picture ''The African Queen'' with Humphrey Bogart, she recalled: ''We were all dying of dysentery the entire time, and it was full of bugs and poison water. But I thought it was thrilling, and I always thought it would make a wonderful book.'' Now the book, her first, is on its way to publication by Alfred A. Knopf in the fall. Writing it from memory - ''every detail of it stuck in my mind'' - apparently wasn't hard at all. ''You can do it sitting down,'' the 77-year-old Miss Hepburn said in an interview last week. ''I sit in bed with a big breakfast and then I write. I like that.''

title: GOVERNORS SEEK WORK PLAN LINKED TO WELFARE BENEFITS
description: Republican and Democratic leaders of the National Governors' Association urged today that welfare recipients who were able be required to find jobs. The leaders said they expected Congress and possibly the Reagan Administration to support their plan.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE HOUSEBOAT DEBATE

title: THE INTRICACIES OF CURLING
description: FROM the same people who brought us the game of golf, the poems of Robert Burns and the joys of scones, comes a winter sport to challenge both mind and body - curling.

title: In the Running
description: THEY didn't make it to California for the Super Bowl, but a couple of members of the Chicago Bears will be jetting to the West Coast today in quest of a consolation prize of sorts. Willie Gault and Richard Dent are going to Los Angeles in hopes of picking up a Grammy Award Tuesday night. They were among the Bears featured in ''The Super Bowl Shuffle,'' which became a rap hit after the Bears won the 1986 Super Bowl and is one of five Grammy finalists for the best song by a rhythm and blues group.

title: AS LOBSTERS OFF THE EAST COAST DWINDLE, FISHERMEN TRY HATCHING THEIR OWN
description: The farmers who settled here 200 years ago found lobsters so plentiful that they collected them by the wagonload at the shore, dumped them in the fields and crushed them for fertilizer, says Jasper C. Cates, a lobsterman.

title: MUSIC: THE WASSAW PHILHARMONIC
description: THE Warsaw Philharmonic, which performed Thursday night at Carnegie Hall, is to be congratulated for devoting the latter portion of its program to a contemporary Polish work, even though that work - Witold Lutoslawski's Symphony No. 3 (1983) - was commissioned by an American orchestra and has already been heard here.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: I'M NOT KNOWN TO make many mistakes,'' said Senator Lloyd Bentsen modestly, in extricating himself from a fund-raising furor, ''but when I do, it's a doozie.''

title: HOME IS WHERE THE PUBLISHING IS
description: BRIAN AND KATHLEEN SCHWAB looked out the window of their Pomfret home, past their two acres of land, and pointed to the cornfields beyond. ''That's why we work from home,'' said Mr. Schwab, who, with his wife, publishes Connecticut Parent, a free monthly, statewide magazine with a 50,000 circulation. ''You can always get away from it all.''

title: Man Killed at Kenyan Border
description: A man of unknown nationality was shot to death just inside Kenya on Thursday after crossing the Ugandan border with Ugandan soldiers in hot pursuit, the official Kenya News Agency said today. The Kenyan police arrested two of the soldiers and are holding them for investigation, the agency said. A Kenyan at the doorstep of his house was shot in the leg during the incident.

title: Social Security
description: To the Editor: ''Scaling Back Hikes in Social Security'' (Forum, Jan. 25) begins to lay the groundwork for the next Social Security issues that will face policy makers: long-term financial stability and tax equity for Social Security.

title: SPACE WEAPON STIRS DEBATE OVER POSSIBLE OFFENSIVE USE
description: A debate has developed over whether the space weapon envisioned by the Reagan Administration for the first phase of its plan for a defense against missiles could strike offensively at targets in orbit and on earth.

title: Looking at Myths
description: Excerpts from an address by Allan E. Gotlieb, the Canadian Ambassador, to a business symposium in Los Angeles Feb. 4:

title: SOCIAL SECURITY EXPRESSES A RICH NATION'S CONSCIENCE
description: To the Editor:

title:
A VOICE FROM BANGKOK;
THE WEST SHOULD 'TAKE CAMBODIANS OFF OUR HANDS'
description: LEAD: THE Khao I Dang refugee camp in Thailand opened in 1979 to shelter tens of thousands of Cambodians who earlier had fled a four-year reign of terror by the Khmer Rouge. An invasion by Vietnam in late 1978 produced another influx into Thailand that continues today. At one time, about 140,000 Cambodians lived at Khao I Dang.

title: TAX STUDY NEEDS TIME AND THOUGHT
description: IN A Jan. 11 Opinion Page article, ''Speed Is Needed on Tax Reform,'' my distinguished Democratic colleague, State Senator John A. Lynch of the 17th District (parts of Middlesex and Union Counties), raised some very salient points regarding New Jersey's system of property taxation and the need for reform.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a Bangkok dispatch in some editions last Sunday on the relocation of refugees on the Cambodian border misidentified the publicly designated successor to the Khmer Rouge leader, Pol Pot, who is believed to be terminally ill. He is Son Sen.

title:
DINING OUT;
GROWING PAINS AT CLIFFSIDE PARK
description: LEAD: ALMOST five years ago, Villa Amalfi, owned by the Esposito family, was given three stars by this reviewer. The restaurant was then on Anderson Avenue in Cliffside Park. Three years ago, it moved to larger and fancier quarters on Palisade Avenue, also in Cliffside Park.

title: HUSTLING FOR DIGNITY
description: MAMA By Terry McMillan. 260 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $16.95.

title: Betsy L. Ennis Plans To Marry E. I. Adler
description: Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Ennis of New York and Sharon, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Betsy Louise Ennis to Edward Isaac Adler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter S. Adler of New York.

title: OFFICIALS CITE 21 FOOD OUTLETS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 21 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Trying to Help An Ugly Dragon
description: AN attempt to help the last Komodo dragon in the United States become a mother by artificial insemination was under way last year at the San Diego Zoo.

title: Her Man Friday
description: he Life and Strange Surprizing Adventures of Robinson Crusoe, of York, Mariner'' was published on April 25, 1719. The author of the book was Daniel Defoe or, to revert to his given name, Daniel Foe. In ''Foe'' J. M. Coetzee has written a superb novel by reconsidering the events of ''Robinson Crusoe'' and presenting them from a new point of view. He may have been impressed by Jean Rhys's conversion of ''Jane Eyre'' into ''Wide Sargasso Sea'' or by other experiments in displacing an official perspective.

title: DOCTOR SAYS HE WAS BEATEN IN ARREST
description: Two months ago on a rainy Tuesday night, a robbery was unfolding at the Tita Candy Store in the North Bronx.

title: FINDING A KILLER
description: An ongoing medical and educational program administered by the County Health Department with funds from the state is credited with making strides in the detection and treatment of high blood pressure.

title: STATE BIDS COURT RECONSIDER RULING ON HOMELESS AID
description: LEAD: OFFICIALS of the state's Department of Human Services have asked the Appellate Division of Superior Court to reconsider a ruling suspending the 90-day limit on emergency assistance for the homeless.

title: MUCH OF WHAT WALL ST. DOES BENEFITS SHAREHOLDERS AND THE PUBLIC
description: To the Editor:

title: 'OFFICIAL' DEBUT FOR PIANIST AT 80
description: On March 11, the pianist Konrad Wolff will play Mozart's Adagio in B minor (K. 540) and Sonata in B-flat (K. 570), Schubert's Sonata in B-flat (D. 960), Liszt's ''Valse Oubliee No. 3'' and Ravel's ''Valses Nobles et Sentimentales'' at Merkin Concert Hall. While this is an attractive but not especially unusual program for a debut recital, the circumstances surrounding this particular concert are extraordinary. For Mr. Wolff, a pupil of the late Artur Schnabel, will present what he calls his first ''official'' New York solo concert on his 80th birthday.

title: CITY LAW, 7; MENS' CLUBS, 0
description: The men's clubs of New York came one step closer to a reckoning last week when the Court of Appeals in Albany upheld by a vote of 7 to 0 a city law that would force some of them to admit women.

title: Tom Seaver's Career at 3 and 2
description: FOR more than half an hour, Tom Seaver sounded like a businessman trying to cut a deal with himself, talking about how he ''really hadn't made a decision yet'' on whether he had retired from baseball.

title:
DRUG-ABUSE CENTER SPLITS HAMPTONS RESIDENTS;
'A GREAT NEED OUT HERE FOR HELP'
description: LEAD: ONE person who has personally dealt with the frustration of unavailable services is Carole Havens, who manages a nutrition program in East Hampton. She has four children, and her husband is a bayman. Last October, her 21-year-old daughter said she had addictions to cocaine and alcohol, and she asked for help.

title: BIRDERS, UNITE!
description: A WORLD OF WATCHERS By Joseph Kastner. With illustrations from the work of Louis Agassiz Fuertes. 241 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $25.

title: INAUGURAL CONCERTS PLANNED FOR HISTORIC CHURCH'S 'NEW ORGAN'
description: WHAT does a music critic do in his spare time? If he is Allen Hughes, whose reviews have graced The New York Times for more than a quarter of a century, he returns to his first performing love, the organ. Not as a player, though: Mr. Hughes, a weekend resident of North Salem, several years ago spearheaded a campaign to get a new organ for the town's historic St. James Episcopal Church. He sought out a small instrument that had been built a century ago for a parish in Rhode Island, helped arrange for its refurbishing and saw to its proper installation in the church.

title: Madison Karlock And Ms. Franklin Exchange Vows
description: The marriage of Cathy Felicia Franklin, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William D. Franklin of New York, to Madison Kent Karlock, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Merlin Karlock of Bourbonnais, Ill., took place last evening at the Pierre in New York. Rabbi Martin Zion performed the ceremony.

title: A FAVORITE BUILDING? CONTEST SEEKING VOTES
description: WHETHER your fancy runs to gabled Gothics, glassy new skyscrapers, or even the little cottage you designed yourself, the Connecticut Society of Architects wants to hear from you.

title: Marcia Sann Is Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Robert I. Sann of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Marcia Amy Sann to Mitchell Brent Miller, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Steffan Miller of Spring Valley, N.Y. Ms. Sann and her fiance, graduates of Union College, expect to receive M.D. degrees next year from the Albany Medical School of Union University.

title: THE C.I.A. TODAY
description: To the Editor:

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
COMICS AND CARDS
description: LEAD: MERV MOSS and his son Edward were shopping for baseball cards.

title: LIBRARY ON WHEELS SHOWS CHILDREN THE JOY TO BE DREVIED FROM BOOKS
description: THE sidewalks where Sutter Avenue and Berriman Street cross in the East New York section of Brooklyn are fringed with wastepaper and carpeted with shattered glass. Unwanted tires and junked appliances are piled high in undeveloped lots, and the gouged windows of abandoned walk-ups gaze emptily from above.

title: STUDY SUGGESTS LINK BETWEEN VITAMIN A AND BIRTH DEFECTS
description: Women who are trying to become pregnant should avoid doses of vitamin A that are higher than recommended, Federal health researchers say, citing a related chemical that may cause birth defects.

title: Accommodation In South Africa
description: There are at least two reasons why I read Alan Cowell's beautifully written article ''A Farewell to South Africa'' (Jan. 25) with a special personal interest. The first is that it reminded me of my own torn feelings in 1962, when the South African Government expelled me and closed down the Time bureau in Johannesburg for what was to be 14 years. The second is that, in 1982, I returned to South Africa as United States Ambassador with a mandate to encourage movement away from apartheid and toward a system based on accommodation among South Africans of all races. It is Mr. Cowell's comments on what we tried to pursue that I find contradictory and bewildering.

title: Coaching The Referees
description: Those who call for full-time professional football officials fail to understand the difference between observing a practice and officiating a game.

title: No Headline
description: STEPHEN SPROUSE, the 33-year-old designer who rode a wave of publicity into business oblivion, is back.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: EVERYBODY I know who once spent every summer at the same ''summer place'' remembers one summer as the End of an Era. And of course that's not necessarily so. Memories lie, and they are full of murk. But such ''eras'' have a way of floating up through the murk of one's memory in winter, the year's murkiest season.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: MAGIC LANTERNS AND MAGIC

title:
IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN;
Washington Township
description: LEAD: HIGH on a grassy knoll in the southern portion of Washington Township stands a large 18th-century stone house, its roof studded with seven chimneys. Local legend has it that George Washington stayed there one night, giving this quiet Bergen County community its own bit of history - and its name.

title: ANOTHER MILESTONE IN CONDUCTIITY
description: In the imperfect world of physical phenomena, superconductivity seems almost too good to be true. When certain substances are cooled to near absolute zero, they lose their resistance to electricity. Thus current can be conducted through them without energy loss, allowing the development of more efficient power lines and magnets powerful enough to propel trains.

title: Heather Thomas To Wed in August
description: Capt. Richard Marvel Thomas, U.S.C.G., retired, and Mrs. Thomas of New York and Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Heather Fletcher Thomas, to David Mitchell Nackley, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Nackley of Dedham and Cotuit, Mass. An August wedding is planned.

title: Sarah Morse to Wed J. H. Viccellio 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Ketcham Morse of St. Louis and Williamstown, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sarah Greenlee Boden Morse to James Henry Viccellio 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Viccellio Jr. of Yorktown, Va. A May wedding is planned.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: TAX REVISION AT THE STATE LEVEL;
States Should Follow the Federal Cue
description: LEAD: THIRTY-FIVE states are likely to collect higher tax revenues in 1987 because of Federal tax revision, and there is much debate about what the states should do with this ''windfall.'' Should it be spent on education and social programs? Or should it be returned to the taxpayers? If the latter, would it be best to lower maximum tax rates and increase the capital gains exclusion, which might help the rich?

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
THE GARBAGE SOLUTION ISN'T THAT SIMPLE
description: LEAD: ABOUT two years ago, a ''state-of-the-art'' energy-recovering garbage incinerator (resource-recovery plant) in Akron, Ohio, exploded, killing three people, doing millions of dollars in damage and leaving much of downtown Akron without heat for a time.

title: Estimate of Tax Windfall for City Is Disputed
description: A mayoral commission has grossly underestimated the long-term tax windfall to New York City resulting from changes in the Federal tax code, the State Comptroller contends.

title: SEVEN NATIONS TRY COOPERATING ON THE DOLLAR
description: After tugging in different directions for months, the United States and its chief economic allies tried again this weekend to pull together to stabilize their currencies and reduce trade imbalances.

title: Creating New Offices and Homes Through Fusion
description: ON Court Street in Brooklyn a block south of Borough Hall, Louis V. Greco Jr. is breaking through walls to create a modern office complex out of five decrepit buildings.

title: Turkey
description: To the Editor: Richard Reeves' article ''A taste of Istanbul'' (Travel, Jan. 18) was extremely interesting. To his elegant list of eating places I would like to add another, one of my favorites, Beyti in Yesilyurt, a small suburban village only 10 minutes from Istanbul airport in Yesilkoy. This is strictly a meat restaurant, offering a variety of delicious grills, mostly of lamb. For first timers, I suggest ordering mixed grills. Each type will come as a separate course, maybe four types, with its own potatoes and/or vegetable. Especially, doner (conically packed meat on a huge skewer cooked while rotating in front of a fire) will be quite a treat. All this plus a bottle of local wine and a fine dessert will cost under $20 for two. TY YALIM Brooklyn

title: N.A.A.C.P. Sues Four of Its Former Lawyers
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said yesterday that it had filed suit against four lawyers who used to work for the organization, seeking to recover more than $2 million in legal fees.

title: Liberia Reported to Divert Millions in U.S. Aid
description: An audit by the General Accounting Office says millions of dollars of United States aid to Liberia has been diverted to Government officials in the last six years, according to a summary of the report made public yesterday by Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: Amy Porterfield Weds John Burke
description: Amy Evans Porterfield, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis E. Porterfield of New Canaan, Conn., and New York, was married in New Canaan yesterday to John Kelly Burke, a son of Betty Burke of Rolling Meadows, Ill., and Francis W. Burke of Carpentersville, Ill. The Rev. Charles Smith performed the Congregational ceremony at the Waveny House.

title: STORE PLAN SPURS CALLS FOR ROAD
description: A PROPOSAL to build a large discount clothing store on congested Merrick Avenue in Westbury has spurred renewed calls for a road to relieve traffic in the area.

title: Enthusiasm Prevails, but Concerns Remain
description: WINNING the right to play host to the Winter Olympic Games required four bids and nearly 30 years on the part of enthusiasts in this oil, grain and cattle city hard by the Rocky Mountains.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: Indoor Sidewalk Sale With Up to 80% Off The Bay Window in Rye, begun five years ago as a gift shop that gradually switched to jewelry and women's size 4 to 16 clothing, is conducting its winter clearance as an ''indoor sidewalk sale'' at 50 to 80 percent off through March in the upstairs rooms. Downstairs, the cruise and spring lines are displayed, including Adrienne

title: A VIVACIOUS AND POIGNANT LOOK AT THE HARLEM OF OLD
description: ''H arlem Renaissance,'' at the Studio Museum in Harlem, at 145 West 125th Street, is a serious and substantial historical exhibition, well researched and well installed. Eloquent throughout its length on the subject of what has rightly been called ''the dignity of the undefeated,'' it is by turns vivacious and poignant, elegiac and a great deal of fun. It will be there through Aug. 30, and no one who is interested in the social and esthetic history of the United States in our century should miss it.

title: St. Louis
description: The Gateway Arch still towers above the city, the Mississippi River still winds along its eastern boundary, and baseball is still the favorite pastime. But in the last five years, St. Louis has undergone a fundamental transformation.

title: 'REAL AND IMAGINED' LANDSCAPES AT THE SQUIBB GALLERY
description: THE Squibb Gallery's current attraction, ''Landscape:

title: IF I ONLY HAD A BRAIN: A COMPUTER'S GUIDE
description: THE SOCIETY OF MIND By Marvin Minsky. Illustrated. 339 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: BEWARE THE TRAP OF THE 'EQUAL MARRIAGE'
description: I RECENTLY attended a lecture at a women's group I belong to on the topic of marriage in the 80's. The woman who spoke discussed different types of marriages and concluded that an equal marriage is the ideal type for women today.

title: Suzanne Appel Becomes Bride
description: The marriage of Suzanne Lesley Appel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Appel of Alexandria, Va., to Murray James McGill, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Francis McGill of Calingiri and Perth, Australia, took place yesterday at the Lotos Club in New York. The Rev. Richard Leonard, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: MANDELA'S CHILDREN. By Ora Mendels. (Little, Brown, $16.95.) Part thriller, part psychological portrait, part history, ''Mandela's Children'' (the title refers to political offspring) tells the story of Ruth Harris, a white woman brought up in Johannesburg. An ardent student activist there in the 60's, she is now a United States citizen, divorced, with a grown son. She has dropped politics and her former comrades. She has told no one in her new life about her arrest 20 years ago, her months in solitary or the damning, haunting confession that was her last act in South Africa. But now, contacted by an old friend, she is lured back into the struggle. She agrees to return to Johannesburg for a brief, safe mission - a chance to redress some of the wrong she still holds herself accountable for. The mission becomes a complex, dangerous intrigue. As a thriller the novel is exciting. Though the style is plain, the dialogue sometimes awkward, the devices often clumsy, the story hurtles forward like an express train out of Times Square. As a portrait it is somewhat less successful. Numerous flashbacks interrupt the narrative, each time bringing it to a lurching halt and only slowly regaining our interest. This added background gives Ruth dimension as a character, but her extremely harsh judgment of herself undermines our sympathy. Still, politically, the book does what journalism rarely can: it helps us feel as well as know. Ruth works feverishly on a huge nonviolent antipass campaign, which results in 69 Africans being shot dead by police in an incident now known to the world as the Sharpeville massacre. The reader shares Ruth's sense of betrayal and rage. Years later, when a man is killed with a tire ''necklace'' set afire, our horror is not only general - that people should be driven to such an act - but particular, because we know they have the wrong man. The scene is a small, grim tour de force in a passionate novel.

title: ALBANY DISCOVERS CUOMO IS JUST FULL OF SURPRISES
description: Governor Cuomo may not be entering any races for now, but he certainly appeared to be keeping in training. The day after he surprised his friends and critics by saying he would not be a candidate for President, he again surprised them by proposing a new $1.7 billion cut in state personal income taxes.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: ON THE ROAD

title: THEATRICAL CAPTURES TURF CUP BY A NECK
description: A change of tactics proved the cure for Theatrical's habit of finishing second when the Irish horse led at every call under Pat Day to win the $200,000 Hialeah Turf Cup by a neck over Long Mick today at Hialeah Park.

title: Roman Artichokes, Herald of Spring
description: Italians eat according to the seasons of the year. Although they import many out-of-season fruits and a few vegetables from Africa, South America and Israel, a truly good Italian cook - and the country is full of them - prizes home-grown produce in a way that many Americans do not. And what is grown locally is more precious than what comes from even 100 miles away.

title: Wearing One Hat at a Time
description: YES, Dick Howser conceded, there were a few changes in the manager who won the World Series in 1985. He does not remove his cap in public these days, and his uniform has been altered because he has lost 17 pounds.

title: PAPA PARADOX
description: G. K. CHESTERTON By Michael Ffinch. Illustrated. 369 pp. San Francisco: Harper & Row. $18.95.

title: CUOMO TO PRESS OPPOSITION BEFORE N.R.C.
description: LEAD: GOVERNOR CUOMO is scheduled to appear before the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission in Washington tomorrow to speak against a proposed rule change that would ease the licensing of nuclear plants opposed by state and local officials.

title: DOWNTOWN CHURCH MARKS 192D YEAR
description: From the outside, Mariners' Temple in Lower Manhattan looks like a church ready for its last rites. Wide swaths of plaster have fallen away, revealing building stones that are more than a century old and sorely in need of repair.

title: NORTH AMERICAN SAVINGS ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
METS HAVE A HUNGRY LOOK
description: The most obvious and maybe significant sight in the training camp of the Mets these days is that the fat cats of the summer of 1986 are not the fat cats of the spring of 1987.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Jane Jarvis Performs On Piano at Zinno
description: Simply watching Jane Jarvis enjoy herself while she plays piano at Zinno, 128 West 13th Street, is a refreshing experience. It is also a reminder that the obviously happy pianist has become a rarity in today's jazz world. The likes of Fats Waller and Erroll Garner are part of a fading past.

title: WESTMARK INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: The results for the 1986 quarter included expenses related to the formation of Westmark as a public company and the year included an $18 million charge relating to the writeoff of inventories and consolidation of the Tempe, Ariz., facility into operations in Bothell, Wash. The 1985 figures included a charge of $5 million relating to the discontinuance of a digital radiography business. Westmark was a subsidiary of Squibb Corp. until Jan. 2, when it was spun off to Squibb shareholders.

title: COPTER RESCUES 2 STRANDED ON ICE
description: A 15-year-old boy and girl were rescued unharmed yesterday afternoon by a police helicopter crew that plucked them, one at at time, from a chunk of ice on which they drifted precariously for an hour in Little Neck Bay.

title: Boarder Babies: Progress, but Too Slow
description: Inez Holder has no grandchildren of her own. That's one reason she decided to become a foster grandparent to abandoned or abused ''boarder babies'' in New York City hospitals. Admirably, Mrs. Holder spends 20 hours a week at Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn feeding and cuddling some of the 20 boarder babies there on any given day. City and state officials will deserve equal admiration by moving with greater urgency to find suitable foster homes for all the babies.

title: New Doubt On Tunnel In Channel
description: When the notion of building a tunnel under the English Channel was first presented nearly two centuries ago, British skeptics claimed that it would merely give Napoleon a route for a subterranean invasion. Since then, in the face of countless proposals, British resistance has been a stumbling block to going ahead with a channel tunnel.

title: Market Place; The Leverage Of Options
description: Since the start of 1987, the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index have both risen by 17.9 percent. Fine, but which investors made - and lost - the most money during the stock market's phenomenal advance of the past seven weeks?

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL NETS VS. BOSTON CELTICS, at Hartford, 7:30 P.M. (TV -SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNEW 1130, 7:20 P.M.) COLLEGES: Villanova at Pittsburgh (TV - ESPN, 7:30 P.M.); Purdue at Illinois (TV - ESPN, 9:30 P.M.) C.B.A.: Albany Patroons vs. Gunners, at Charleston, S.C., 4 P.M. (TV - ESPN, 4 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS HARNESS RACING: Roosevelt 7:30 P.M. Meadowlands, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, midnight) TENNIS: Lipton Players International Championships, at Miami (TV - ESPN, 1 P.M.) THOROUGHBRED RACING: Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 6:30 P.M. and 11 P.M.)

title: MUSIC: BERESFORD AND TORO AT KITCHEN
description: STEVE BERESFORD, from England, and Yomo Toro, from Puerto Rico, played a double bill Friday at the Kitchen. Mr. Beresford is a pianist-trumpeter-composer-improviser with a conceptual streak; Mr. Toro is a virtuoso cuatro (10-stringed miniature guitar) player, and a leading figure in Puerto Rican folk music, particularly in the rural traditions known as ''jibaro'' music, which have ties to old Spanish musical and poetic forms.

title: THE THEATER: 'FREE FALL'
description: ''FREE FALL'' begins in the cockpit of a small plane floating above the darkened stage of the 45th Street Theater. A husband-and-wife team of stunt fliers is trying to land at a fogged-in town in Maine - visibility negative. Lou, the husband, wants to go on to Boston, but Sam, the wife, is at the controls, and she is determined to find a hole in the fog and bring the ship down. She does, at the expense of a concussion for Lou, some broken ribs for herself, a wrecked plane, and, possibly, a wrecked marriage. The last is the subject of Laura Harrington's play, which goes out of control about the same time as the plane.

title: Domingo Agrees to Do 2d 'Aida' Performance
description: The tenor Placido Domingo has agreed to sing a second performance of Verdi's ''Aida,'' which is being produced at the 3,500-year-old Temple of Luxor, Egypt, a Manhattan travel agency said yesterday.

title: NORTH SAID TO HAVE SEEN SHREDDING
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North watched as his secretary destroyed classified documents on the evening before Justice Department investigators came to review his files, according to a source with knowledge of the special prosecutor's investigation of the Iran-contra affair.

title: ATARI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $11,047,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $19,466,000 for the year. c-Net loss The company said share earnings computations for all periods include 7.1 million shares issued to Warner Communications Inc. affiliates, concurrent with completion of a public offering on Nov. 7.

title: FORSCHNER GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $43,000 and $11,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; a provisions of $638,000 for loss on discontinuance of operations for both the quarter and 6 months and extraordinary tax benefits of $82,000 for the quarter and $800,000 for the 6 months.

title: APACHE PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said net earnings and share earnings for the quarter and year ended Dec. 31, 1986 and 1985, includes additional amortization of $153,497,000 and $137,824,000, respectively, recorded in the fourth quarter to reflect a reduction in the carrying value of oil and gas properties.

title: OSMONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CONCERT: ORLANDO STRING QUARTET
description: ONE of the most satisfying chamber groups to come out of Europe in the last few years is the Orlando String Quartet, a collection of far-flung nationalities that operates out of the Netherlands. Known for a handful of recordings that have already made their way here, the Orlando appeared at the Metropolitan Museum of Art Saturday night, playing with the same impressive values their records advertise.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: BOXING Honeyghan Keeps Titles: Lloyd Honeyghan of Britain stopped Johnny Bumphus in two rounds at London's Wembley Stadium to retain his World Boxing Council and International Boxing Federation welterweight titles. Referee Sam Williams of Detroit halted the bout - scheduled for 15 rounds - after 55 seconds of the second round when the challenger, from Mount Laurel, N.J., was caught on the ropes. Honeyghan had already floored the 26-year-old Bumphus in the first round and also knocked him down - illegally, according to the referee - at the start of the second. Honeyghan was off his stool early, rushed across the ring, and as the bell rang, knocked down Bumphus as the challenger rose from his stool. Manager Lou Duva, who was not completely out of the ring at the time, bounded into the center of the ring to protest. The referee started the round over and penalized Honeyghan a point. It was not enough time for Bumphus, however, as Honeyghan caught him on the ropes with a ferocious barrage of blows, prompting Williams to halt the fight. (AP) N.H.L. Sabres 5, Whalers 3: Mike Foligno scored one goal and assisted on two others as the Sabres extended their winning streak to five games. Dave Andreychuk, Bob Logan, Paul Cyr and Christian Ruuttu were the other Buffalo goal scorers in the home-ice victory. Kevin Dineen had two goals for Hartford and Mike McEwen had one. (AP) Jets 5, Oilers 2: Ray Neufeld, Gilles Hamel, Laurie Boschman and Dale Hawerchuk scored for Winnipeg in the first period. Thomas Steen scored the Jets' final goal in the third period after Mike Krushelnyski, on a power play, and Wayne Gretzky scored the visiting Oilers' goals in the second period. (AP) Red Wings 2, Blackhawks 2: Troy Murray scored from 15 feet out with less than two minutes left in the third period for the Blackhawks to force a scoreless overtime in Chicago. Steve Yzerman had both Detroit goals. (AP) Capitals 5, Flames 2: In Calgary, Alberta, Alan Haworth scored twice in the first period and Pete Peeters made 31 saves for the Capitals. Also scoring for the Capitals, who had lost four of their last six, were Mike Gartner, Mike Ridley and Kelly Miller. (AP) TENNIS Becker Takes Final: Boris Becker defeated Stefan Edberg, 6-4, 6-4, 7-5, to win the $435,000 Pilot Penn Classic at Indian Wells, Calif. The victory was Becker's seventh straight over Edberg, who had a 15-match winning streak broken. ''My return of service was better,'' Becker said, adding, ''I was better on the big points.'' Edberg said, ''He played better than me on all the shots.'' (AP) Graf Is Winner: Second-seeded Steffi Graf needed less than an hour to dispatch fourth-seeded Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia, 6-2, 6-3, in the final of the $250,000 Virginia Slims of Florida tennis tournament at Boca Raton. Graf's victory, coupled with Chris Evert Lloyd's second-round loss to Kate Gompert, will propel her past Lloyd to No. 2 in the next computer rankings out March 2. Graf had 10 break points against Sukova in the first set and broke her service in the first and seventh games with speed, power and excellent passing shots. Graf then scored service breaks in the fifth and ninth games of the second set. (AP) SKIING Ormsby and McKinney Win: Bob Ormsby outdueled Felix McGrath for the men's slalom title in the final event of the United States Alpine ski championships at Copper Mountain, Colo. Tamara McKinney, one of the world's best slalom skiers, overtook Sally Knight to win the women's slalom. The 23-year-old Ormsby, of Tahoe City, Calif., led McGrath by a mere 8-hundredths of a second in the first run. He then made the fastest second run as well for a combined time of 1 minute 37.77 seconds to edge McGrath, who finished in 1:37.96. Sandy Williams of Rochester, N.Y., was third in 1:39.35. McKinney, of Olympic Valley, Calif., trailed the surprising Knight, of Waitfield, Vt., by three-tenths of a second in the first run, but had the best time in the second run to take her fifth national title. Knight managed to hold on for the bronze medal, with Eva Twardokens taking the silver. (AP) HORSE RACING Winning Streak at 7: Sound Reasoning extended her winning streak to seven as she led throughout to take the $69,500 Correction Handicap for fillies and mares 3-years-old and up at Aqueduct. The 4-year-old daughter of Known Fact-Bold Flawless ran the six furlongs in 1:10 4/5 in her first start in stakes company. Carrying 118 pounds, Sound Reasoning held on under the ride of Jean-Luc Samyn to reach the wire a neck ahead of Eloquack, who closed strongly for second. The victory for the Irish-bred Sound Reasoning was her seventh in 17 career starts. With it she earned $41,700 for Sugar Maple Farm and returned $6.40 for $2 to win as the favorite in the field of seven.

title: Glasnost to Go
description: It's temptingly logical: First, the Soviet Union forced Eastern Europe's nations into becoming small replicas of itself. Now that the Russians are trying to reshape their own society, they'll expect the same of the others. So how is the West to read the widely varying reactions of Eastern European leaders to Mikhail Gorbachev's reforms? By remembering that Soviet-dominated Eastern Europe is a fragile concoction of separate states confronting their own dilemmas.

title: COMMONWEALTH MORTGAGE reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said for the latest 9 months it originated $920 million of mortgage loans compared with $431 million in the year-ago period.

title: Promotion in Justice Dept.
description: President Reagan plans to nominate Richard B. Abell, the Deputy Assistant Attorney General for the Office of Justice Programs, to be the Assistant Attorney General in charge of that office, the White House said Friday. Mr. Abell, 43 years old, has been deputy assistant since 1983. Before that, he was director of program development for the Peace Corps.

title: INSIDE
description: Syrians Enter West Beirut The Syrian Army moved in force into West Beirut, vowing to disband the warring militias there. An uneasy calm prevailed in the city. Page A11. Albany Outlook Changes Governor Cuomo, by announcing that he will not run for President, has dramatically changed the political prospects in Albany. Page B1. Conservatives Press G.O.P. Conservatives are pressing Republican Presidential hopefuls to adopt a foreign policy to the right of President Reagan in some ways. Page A13. Police Guard Defendant Robert D. Riley, 17-year-old defendant in the Howard Beach attack who aided prosecutors, has round-the-clock police bodyguards. Page B1. AIDS Testing Criticized Many health officials say that testing all marriage license applicants and hospital patients for AIDS would be wasteful and impractical. Page A15.

title: DAVID SUSSKIND, TALK-SHOW HOST, DIES AT 66
description: David Susskind, the television producer and one of the country's earliest and best-known television talk-show hosts, was found dead, apparently of natural causes, yesterday afternoon in his hotel suite in midtown Manhattan. He was 66 years old. Although Mr. Susskind had given up ''The David Susskind Show'' last September after nearly 30 years on the air, he was still active and had produced four television specials in the last year. Two of them, on Winston Churchill and Dwight D. Eisenhower, were shown last year, and the others, on Lyndon B. Johnson and Pope John XXIII, are to be broadcast this year.

title: WHITE HOUSE DENIES QADDAFI WAS TARGET IN TRIPOLI RAID
description: The White House today dismissed a report that the United States set out deliberately to kill Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, in air raids on Tripoli last spring.

title: Rules of Engagement
description: The best advice given Ronald Reagan in this space was not to run for a second term. Now all of us who are covering the crumbling of executive authority need fresh advice on how to cope with the torrent of revelations to come, so that we do not aid those dovish partisans seeking to reverse the election of 1984 or otherwise succor the blame-America-first crowd.

title: THOMSON NEWSPAPERS LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $20.6 million. Thomson is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges. The results are in Canadian funds.

title: ANDY WARHOL, POP ARTIST, DIES
description: Andy Warhol, a founder of Pop Art whose paintings and prints of Presidents, movie stars, soup cans and other icons of America made him one of the most famous artists in the world, died yesterday. He was believed to be 58 years old.

title: TRUMP ENDS HIS STRUGGLE TO GAIN CONTROL OF BALLY
description: The developer Donald J. Trump, ending a four-month battle to gain control of a rival casino operator in Atlantic City, the Bally Manufacturing Corporation, will sell back to the company his 9.9 percent interest in it, sources close to the deal said.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: RAISING 1990 FUNDS AND SOME HACKLES
description: In politics, money buys access. But Stanley K. Sheinbaum, a leading Democratic fund-raiser, has grown so frustrated by the demands of money-hungry politicians that last week he did not even want such access.

title: PAR TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Only Rain for the Roses
description: In its season finale last Wednesday night, the girls' basketball team at Carbondale (Pa.) Sacred Heart High School was beaten by Riverside High of Taylor. The score was 75-32, and play was even more lopsided than that. Riverside mercifully used all its scrubs after halftime, with the result that Sacred Heart got the upper hand in the fourth quarter, 13-12, the only period all season in which an opponent was outscored by the Lady Roses, who finished 0-19.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1987
description: The Accord on the Dollar

title: SILICON VALLEY FIGHTS ITS STINGY IMAGE
description: In Silicon Valley, where fast-growing electronics companies have been known to spend $700,000 for an office Christmas party, Saturday night's affair might not have seemed unusual. About 1,100 people dined on paillard of chicken California, were entertained by the singer Dionne Warwick and danced to a rock band playing songs from the 1960's.

title: EXPERTS DUBIOUS OF WIDE AIDS TESTING
description: Health officials from key states and cities have said it would be a waste of effort and self-defeating to administer an AIDS virus test to all applicants for marriage licenses or all hospital patients, as Federal health officials have suggested.

title: Inflation Is Expected to Rise
description: Credit market participants face conflicting forecasts for economic growth, interest rates and the Federal budget deficit, but there is widespread agreement that inflation this year will be greater than in 1986.

title: BASEBALL OWNERS ARE STRIKING BACK
description: Despite record salaries gained by Don Mattingly and Jack Morris, club owners scored a smashing success in salary arbitration this year. The owners, who have tried diligently - the players say in some ways illegally -to lower salaries, emerged with the lowest percentage increase in arbitration-affected salaries since 1975, the second year of the procedure's existence.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Armteck Corp., New Haven, previously known as the Armstrong Rubber Co., promoted Paul C. James, Ivor J. Evans and Sherman O. Lyon to executive vice president, and appointed Harley Rankin Jr. senior vice president, finance and chief financial officer.

title: Bridge: Player Known as Organizer Wins Pro-Am Tournament
description: The annual Pro-Am tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association was won Saturday night by a player well known as an organizer.

title: Chairman and President Are Set at Keyes Martin
description: Keyes Martin of Springfield, N.J., which in its 40 years has become its state's largest ad agency, is extending its nameplate to read Keyes Martin Gaby Linett.

title: BIO-RAD LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $322,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: COURTS DEBATE JUDGES' ROLE WHEN GIRLS SEEK ABORTIONS
description: She was 14 when she became pregnant. She told her mother, and her mother called the clinic to set up an abortion. That was where the law came in, about the same time as the morning sickness. A bundle of nausea, anger and fear, she went to the same state court that handles juvenile delinquents, with braces on her teeth and a fullness in her womb.

title: ONCOGENE SCIENCE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago first quarter includes non-recurring income of $386,177 for the completion of research.

title: View on OPEC Accord
description: Mana Said al-Oteiba, the United Arab Emirates Oil Minister, said today that he believed the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries' two-month-old accord to push up oil prices would be successful and an emergency meeting to discuss further price support measures would not be necessary. Mr. Oteiba was speaking to reporters after a meeting here of oil ministers of the Gulf Cooperation Council. The Gulf Cooperation meeting, the second this month, took place against a backdrop of weakening free-market oil prices after an initial rise following a decision by OPEC in December to cut output by 7.25 percent, to 15.8 million barrels a day, and return to fixed prices of around $18 a barrel.

title: DATA SWITCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $497,000 and $1,322,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss The company said results do not reflect the acquisition of T-Bar Inc.

title: Urban Delays Continue On Bus Shelters
description: Anybody waiting for a bus at certain stops on Union Turnpike in Queens or the Grand Concourse in the Bronx might be wondering why, 12 years after the first modern bus shelters were built in Manhattan, so many riders in the other boroughs have been left out in the cold.

title: REAGAN CALLED WARM TO WELFARE-WORK PLAN
description: Reagan Administration officials today assured the nation's governors that President Reagan was inclined to back their plan to put welfare recipients to work.

title: ADOBE RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the 1986 fourth quarter and year results include a $10 million loss on sale of investment in Universal Resources Corporation, and the year results also include writedowns of oil and gas properties totaling $23.2 million. The company said the 1985 fourth quarter and year results include writedowns of oil and gas properties totaling $183.7 million and $50.4 million of writedowns of investments in affiliates and other investments.

title: CAN SYRIA UNTIE THE LEBANESE KNOT?
description: Syrian troops were being welcomed as ''peacekeepers'' by at least some Beirut residents today, as they were in 1976 and as the Israelis and then the Americans were, in some quarters, in 1982.

title: TRIAL OF SUSPECTED TERRORIST LEADER OPENS IN PARIS TODAY AFTER 2 1/2 YEARS
description: After two and a half years of public uncertainty and seeming hesitation by the Government, a trial will begin Monday in the case of Georges Ibrahim Abdallah, the suspected terrorist leader whose imprisonment apparently prompted a bloody series of bomb attacks here last year.

title: COLLINS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $90,000. c-Net loss

title: Wheels on Fire
description: The team from Toledo, Ohio, has height, speed and everything else required for a national championship. It has a 6-foot-8-inch center and a sprint star at point guard, and it has averaged 78 points a game this season while posting a record of 37-1.

title: RANGERS FALL AGAIN
description: It happened last night at Madison Square Garden: Phil Esposito covered his eyes and shook his head. Then he admonished his team during an intermission, and then, at the end of the evening, he publicly chastized three players by name and the team at large. It seems that paradise with the Rangers came swiftly to a close last night.

title: Insider Moves Seen By Perot in 1984
description: H. Ross Perot, the Texas billionaire, said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had questioned him about illegal insider trading that might have been committed by others during negotiations in 1984 over the sale of the Electronic Data Systems Corporation to the General Motors Corporation.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TALKING AND ACTING

title: Dartmouth Gets 7.5 Million, Largest Individual Donation
description: A Chicago couple, Robert and Naomi Borwell, donated $7.5 million to the Dartmouth Medical School, the largest individual gift in the school's history, the college president, David McLaughlin, has announced.

title: ISLANDERS RIDDLE DEVILS FOR 2D STRAIGHT
description: The Islanders and the Devils have had problems winning in recent weeks, but their game here this evening was a vivid sign they may be headed in different directions in the last quarter of the regular season.

title: FAMILY FEUD RENDS REAL ESTATE EMPIRE
description: Jehiel R. Elyachar controls a real estate empire that includes four well-worn residential buildings in Manhattan that may be worth $100 million. He wants to give them away, according to his family, but he no longer owns them, he only controls them, and his control is almost as fragile as he is at the age of 89.

title: MEXICO NON-OIL EXPORTS JUMP
description: Grupo Tolteca opened its new $200 million, computer-controlled cement plant here in 1982, just as Mexico was sliding into its worst economic crisis in half a century. To survive, its managers soon realized, the plant would have to turn to exports.

title: REED TAKES 440 IN M.A.C. FINAL
description: William Reed is back. The talented 16-year-old junior at Philadelphia's Central High School had raised some concern when he finished a dismal fifth in the invitation 600-meter run at last month's Millrose Games.

title: MARKITSTAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Markitstar said revenue and profit figures do not include the operations of Meeting Makers Inc., a company that Markitstar acquired Dec. 22, 1986. The company also said it changed its year-end to Dec. 31 from March 31.

title: USG Names New President
description: The USG Corporation, a maker of building products, said that it had named Ralph C. Joynes president and chief operating officer. USG said that Robert J. Day, 61 years old, had relinquished the presidency but would continue as chairman and chief executive.

title: 10,000 WIN RESIDENCY IN U.S.
description: The United States has begun notifying 10,000 foreigners that they have won a lottery offering American residency as the prize.

title: JESSE OROSCO AND THE LAW OF GRAVITY
description: ONE of the big mysteries of the 1986 baseball tapes is what happened to Jesse Orosco's glove.

title: NANOMETRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: EHTHIOPIANS OFFICIALLY JOINING RANKS OF COMMUNIST NATIONS
description: Thirteen years after military officers overthrew Emperor Haile Selassie, this country today became the People's Democratic Republic of Ethiopia, with a Marxist party as the ''guiding force of the state.''

title: It's Not So Easy to Be an Optimist in a Slum
description: To the Editor:

title: FRENCH ARREST 4 AS MAIN LEADERS OF A TERROR GROUP
description: The four leading members of the main French underground terrorist group, Direct Action, have been arrested, the Interior Ministry announced today.

title: A CHANGED CHICAGO GETS READY TO VOTE FOR MAYOR
description: The faithful of the 24th Ward Regular Democratic Organization were gathered at the Greater Galilee Missionary Baptist Church in the heart of the city's predominantly black West Side.

title: 6 Inmates Released From Crowded Jail
description: Six convicts jailed for minor offenses were released early from the Nassau County jail yesterday when the number of inmates in the facility exceeded a Federal judge's limit of 710, a county spokesman said.

title: THE STAGE: 'TOPOKANA' AT NAT HORNE THEATER
description: ''TOPOKANA MARTYRS''

title: CONCERT: NEW YORK POPS AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: THE metamorphosis of the New York Pops Orchestra from a conventional semiclassical ensemble into the amusing symphonic equivalent of Spike Jones took place at Carnegie Hall on Friday evening when, after intermission, its regular conductor, Skitch Henderson, handed the reins to Richard Hayman.

title: BALLET: PERM STUDENTS PERFORM IN WASHINGTON
