description: The Perm Ballet School may not ring a bell in everyone's ear but every self-respecting ballet fan knows the name of its most celebrated prodigy - Nadezhda Pavlova of Moscow's Bolshoi Ballet.

title: A TRANSFORMED 'STARLIGHT EXPRESS' STRIVES TOWARD BROADWAY OPENING
description: It started out as a child's fantasy about railroad trains - inspired by a 4-year-old boy's wide-eyed wonderment, written specifically for children and based loosely on the Cinderella story.

title: 14 Injured as a Bomb Explodes in Jerusalem
description: Twelve Israeli soldiers and two Arab civilians were wounded today when an explosive device was set off outside the Moslem quarter of the Old City, the police said.

title: JONES & VINING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Net income The latest fourth quarter loss included a reduction in the amount of income tax carryback credit reported in earlier quarters of 1986. The reduction resulted from the retroactive elimination of the investment tax credit included in the Tax Reform Act of 1986 and from a foreign tax credit carryback, which could not be used.

title: DEPAUL GOES TO 25-1
description: Dallas Comegys scored a career-high 33 points and Rod Strickland added 28 today as they led DePaul to an 84-67 triumph over Georgia Tech.

title: NORTH URGED LENIENCY FOR HONDURAN LINKED TO ASSASSINATION PLOT
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North urged State and Justice Department officials last year to seek leniency for a Honduran general convicted of plotting to assassinate the President of Honduras in 1984, according to National Security Council documents.

title: SAVIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $1,953,000 for the quarter and $1,877,000 for the year. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $50,680,000 for the quarter and $67,544,000 for the year. The year-ago figures are restated. Savin said that previously reported 1985 and 1986 results have been restated to reflect an accounting change from the lower of LIFO cost or market method of inventory valuation to the lower of weighted average cost or market method. This change favorably affected 1986 fourth quarter net by $1.8 million and net for the year by $4.8 million. The change had a negative impact in 1985 of $700,000 in the quarter and $600,000 for the year.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-11 The nominee to head the C.I.A., Robert M. Gates, agreed to send the White House a 1985 memo that favored arms dealings with Iran though he knew it was at odds with conclusions reached by Central Intelligence Agency analysts, sources said. Page A1 A plea for leniency for a Honduran convicted of plotting to assassinate the President of Honduras in 1984 was made by Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North last year, National Security Council documents show. A9 Classified papers were destroyed by Lieut. Col. North's secretary as Mr. North watched, a source said, adding that it happened on the evening before Justice Department investigators came to review the files. A8 Six major countries will cooperate closely to stabilize the dollar, leaders from the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France and Canada said. A further decline, they said, would hurt the world economy. A1 Arrest of key terrorist suspects was announced by France's Interior Ministry. The seizing of four members of Direct Action, the country's main underground group, represents a major blow against European terrorism. A1 A trial of another accused terrorist will begin in Paris after two and a half years of seeming hesitation by the Government. Georges Ibrahim Abdallah's imprisonment apparently prompted a series of bomb attacks last year. A6 News analysis: Syrian troops were being welcomed as ''peacekeepers'' by some Beirut residents. But whether they could make the streets of the Lebanese capital safe seemed doubtful. A10 Syrian troops poured into Beirut and began taking control of the capital's predominantly Moslem western sector in an effort to restore order among warring militiamen. A11 Celebrations in Manila began for last year's peaceful ouster of Ferdinand E. Marcos. The two men who led the revolt met stiffly at a military cemetery, their relations strained and their reputations tarnished. A2 NATIONAL A12-15 As courts weigh abortion laws requiring teen-agers to notify their parents or have their consent, a judge has ruled that, in practice, Minnesota's law does not meet its goal of giving support and guidance to pregnant girls. A1 A bartering scheme for the elderly in Washington, the Service Credit Volunteer System, is a novel idea devised to help participants ''purchase'' needed assistance by exchanging services, not money. A1 This is a pivotal week for Mr. Reagan because of the upcoming release of a Presidential review commission report on the Iran-contra affair which could determine whether Mr. Reagan rebounds and some top advisers remain. A1 A move to the right of the President is being sought by some conservative activists, who are pressing Republican Presidential hopefuls to embrace a tough foreign policy position in 1988. A13 A proposed AIDS test's role in controlling the disease's spread will be debated tomorrow and Wednesday in Atlanta. Some say it would be a waste of effort to administer the test as broadly as Federal officials propose. A15 Support for a new welfare plan came from the Reagan Administration, which said it may modify its policies to accommodate elements of the plan, authored by the nation's governors, including putting welfare recipients to work. A15 Primary elections in Chicago are on Tuesday, and amid the last-minute campaigning are signs of the reorganization of political life that Mayor Harold Washington has set in motion. A13 Silicon Valley is said to be stingy, a region known for its technical innovations and entrepreneurship, not for its charity. San Jose, Calif., is trying to redevelop, but despite a recent charity gala, the first in the area, efforts are going slowly. A12 Homeowners' tax benefits are lower on the 1986 returns than they used to be. New guidelines on deductions related to refinancing mortgages and to energy-saving home renovations will mean less in write-offs. D1 Goldman Sachs's reputation was above reproach before the Feb. 12 arrest of Robert M. Freeman, the partner in charge of its arbitrage department, in the insider investigation. Now the firm is rallying to his defense. D1 WASHINGTON TALK B4 Campaign war chests for 1990 A professor's network REGIONAL B1-3 A changed political outlook in Albany is one result of Governor Cuomo's decision to take himself out of the 1988 Presidential race, state legislators said this weekend. B1 Opposing lawyers in the Baby M trial are as different in their tactics and personalities as in their goals, and they have prompted opposite reactions from the presiding judge. B1 Police guard a Howard Beach youth who is cooperating with investigators. The youth, a defendant in the racial attack case, remains largely confined to his home, shunned by acquaintances. B1 Changes in how teachers are trained in New York State could result from broad alterations in requirements for teacher certification being considered by the Board of Regents. B2 Donald J. Trump will sell his interest in a rival casino operator in Atlantic City back to the company, Bally Manufacturing Corporation, ending a four-month battle to gain control of Bally. B2 NEEDIEST CASES B2

title: Washington Watch; Underpayment Of Oil Royalties
description: VARIOUS states and Indian tribes are winning considerable support in Congress for their renewed efforts to obtain proper oil and gas royalty payments that the Interior Department is supposed to collect from producers.

title: COUPLES WHO ARE PARTNERS AT HOME AND AT WORK
description: ''Well, what kind of a day was it?'' That is not the pro-forma question of the evening in the homes of certain working couples. They know what kind of a day it was. They work together all day and every day - in successful joint-business ventures. And they face the challenge of making that success carry over into the rest of their lives.

title: Suspect in 350 Crimes Charged in 2 Rapes
description: A Staten Island man, who the police said was a suspect in several hundred crimes committed over the last two years in New York City and on Long Island, was arrested Saturday on charges that he had committed two rapes and a burglary.

title: CUOMO ACTION SHIFTS OUTLOOK IN LEGISLATURE
description: By ruling himself out as a possible contender for the White House in 1988, Governor Cuomo has dramatically changed the political outlook for the current session of the Legislature in Albany, state legislative leaders said this weekend.

title: TOWER COMMISSION FINISHING REPORT
description: Members of a Presidential commission today put finishing touches on their report on the operations of the National Security Council, which includes a detailed chronology of the events surrounding the Iran-contra affair.

title: CAVENHAM, USA INC reports earnings for 12wks to Jan 3
Condom Business Resigned
description: JERRY DELLA FEMINA, chairman of Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, who has been the most visible proponent of condom advertising in the media, last week resigned his condom-marketing client. He said it was because John H. Silverman, president of Ansell America, was quoted in Time magazine as saying ''AIDS is a condom marketer's dream.''

title: CHANCELLOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $431,000 related to the accounting treatment of personal stock options granted by Chancellor's chairman and its president to its executive vice president.

title: QMAX TECHNOLOGY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: LARRY BROWN SNUBS KNICKS
description: WAITING for the game to begin, Larry Brown looked around Madison Square Garden from the Kansas bench and said, ''I'm just excited about being here.'' And after Kansas had stunned St. John's, 62-60, on two free throws after the final buzzer Saturday, the Jayhawks' coach said, ''There's no place like this for a kid, to play in the Garden against a quality team like St. John's.

title: AT GOLDMAN, A DEFENSE BUILDS
description: Last fall, Robert M. Freeman was working out in a park in his hometown of Rye, N.Y., when he came upon a friend. And, as it had often before, the conversation between the two men turned to Wall Street's insider trading scandal.

title: McCann-Erickson Gets A Piece of McDonald's
description: McCann-Erickson, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has reported two new bits of business on the domestic side of its vast empire. The smaller of the two, but perhaps the more meaningful, is the landing of the New Orleans McDonald's cooperative advertising association, the first stateside McDonald's business McCann has won, and it has taken it away from the Leo Burnett Company, which has the national McDonald's account.

title: Dentists and Toothsome Items 'Sell' Hungary
description: ''Lift it, lift it,'' said the 86-year-old Austrian challengingly, pointing to a shopping bag at his feet. He smiled in satisfaction and took a lick from his ice-cream cone when a passer-by pronounced the bag heavy indeed.

title: HOWARD BEACH INFORMER IS SHUNNED
description: Day and night, two city police officers stand guard outside a two-story brick and shingle house at the edge of Jamaica Bay in Howard Beach, Queens. It is the home of 17-year-old Robert D. Riley.

title: New Saatchi Division
description: Saatchi & Saatchi Compton Worldwide has created a new international division that will be based in London, O. Milton Gossett, the New York-based chairman, announced last week. Saatchi & Saatchi Compton International will have Jeremy Sinclair and Alban Lloyd as joint chairmen and Roy Warman and Terry Bannister as joint chief executives. All the men have been and will continue to be based in London.

title: Israel Asks U.S. Not to Admit Jews of Soviet as Refugees
description: Israel urged the United States on Sunday to stop giving refugee status to Soviet Jews, contending that this might encourage Moscow to allow more Jews to leave.

title: ABC AND NBC MOVIES ON ROMANCE AND CRIME
description: PRESUMABLY by chance, and not signaling the onslaught of a trend, two television movies this evening are featuring romantic entanglements among ladies and gentlemen of what is diplomatically referred to as ''a certain age.'' The category evidently includes all those who, with or without a judicious nip and tuck, have gotten beyond the 50 mark. In ''Love Among Thieves,'' on ABC at 9 o'clock, the would-be lovers are Audrey Hepburn and Robert Wagner. In ''Perry Mason: The Case of the Lost Love,'' on NBC at 9, the former lovers still batting their eyes at each other are Jean Simmons and Raymond Burr. Neither effort, unfortunately, makes a memorable contribution to the maturity marketplace.

title: THE MAN WHO TURNED ART UPSIDE DOWN, INSIDE OUT
description: Andy Warhol in the early 1960's was the indispensable man of American art - the one who turned everything upside down and inside out and got away with it. He made paintings that bore no trace of the human hand, let alone of traditional skills. He made sculptures that looked just like the boxes that came up with the delivery boy. He made motion pictures in which almost nothing moved.

title: BONUS PLAN IS PROPOSED ON LUXURY TOWERS' SIZE
description: Developers who build, renovate or preserve lower-income housing in Manhattan would be allowed to build high-priced apartment towers as much as 20 percent larger than permitted by zoning rules, under a proposal being advanced by the City Planning Department.

title: Turning Down the T.V.A.
description: President Reagan was reported to be ready to name Bill Hendon, a former two-term Republican Congressman from North Carolina, to the Tennessee Valley Authority's board of directors, but Mr. Hendon had his name withdrawn. Instead, he will take a job at the Heritage Foundation's American Defense Institute. Mr. Hendon was in the House from 1981 to 1983 and from 1985 to 1987, representing North Carolina's westernmost district (it has otherwise been consistently Democratic). For the last year, two of the three $77,500-a-year T.V.A. seats have been vacant.

title: IN NEW ITALY CRISIS, A DRASTIC PROPOSAL
description: The Italian Government is undergoing one of its most troubled and unstable periods since the five-party coalition came to power in 1981.

title: ITALIANS BOYCOTT GROUP OF 7
description: Italy said today that it withdrew from this weekend's meeting of finance ministers in Paris because the ministers had violated a decision made during last year's economic summit conference in Tokyo to add Italy and Canada to the Group of Five.

title: INTERDYNE CO reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: The company said the fiscal 1985 results have been restated to include the acquisition of Anthem Systems.

title: A RELUCTANT COURTSHIP FOR PIEDMONT PRESIDENT
description: This is probably a time of mixed feelings for William R. Howard, the president and chief executive of Piedmont Aviation Inc., the parent of Piedmont Airlines.

title: ESPOSITO CASTS HIS SPELL OVER RANGERS
description: THE bus stood by the jet's left wing. Three red lights blinked, causing a strange strobe effect through the windows of the bus, where Phil Esposito stood in the aisle and talked, and where the entire Ranger team sat and listened.

title: Tunnels for British Toads
description: The Fauna and Flora Preservation Society, concerned about the mass slaughter of toads by traffic, said today it is working with a concrete manufacturer to build tunnels under a street west of London, near Henley-on-Thames, to give toads safe passage during the annual journey to ponds where they mate.

title: A Big Timeout
description: He went 8-2 last fall, his first season as football coach at Boyd Anderson High School in Lauderdale Lakes, Fla. Now Ray Buscemi has hit on a novel way to improve the team's record: cutting the number of three-hour practices from four a week to three.

title: DIVIDEND MEETINGS
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Feb. 23, 1987: MONDAY Anchor Hocking San Diego Gas & El Watkins-Johnson TUESDAY Borg-Warner Corp Ipalco Enterprises Connecticut Nat Gas Longs Drug Stores Gap Inc Merck & Co WEDNESDAY Ametek Inc Deere & Co Belding-Heminway Lamaur Inc Cigna Corp Pennsylvania P & Lt THURSDAY Arvin Industries Louisiana Genl Svcs Brown-Forman Inc Munford Inc Eastern Gas & Fuel Spring Indus Ethyl Corp Thomas Indus FRIDAY Dexter Corp Nashua Corp Graco Inc Piedmont Nat Gas Harris Corp Whittaker Corp SATURDAY Waste Management

title: REPORT WARNS OF OIL CRISIS IN 1990'S
description: Declining domestic crude oil production and the growing dependence of the United States on petroleum imports could lead to an energy crisis in the 1990's far worse than those experienced in the 1970's, according to the draft report of a Federal advisory committee.

title: CERBERONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $300,000 from an insurance company distribution of stock and a gain of $200,000 in unanticipated funding for a government contract cost overrun.

title: PETROLEUM DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
COMMONWEALTH MORTGAGE OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company began operations Nov. 12, 1986; results include the combined operations of the predecessor companies.

title: ABS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $19,000 and $303,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively, and tax credits of $189,000 for the latest quarter and $68,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: The U.N. Today: Feb. 23, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: FISHER FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: b-Includes a gain of $248,000 from the prepayment of long-term debt. c-Includes a tax benefit of $1,107,000 for both the quarter and year. d-Net income

title: MYERS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MEXICO SELLS STOCK IN STATE BANKS
description: Nearly five years after it nationalized the country's banking system, the Mexican Government has begun an effort to return at least partial ownership to private hands, but in a way that has raised charges of favoritism and irregularities here.

title: FOG, VOTES, HOW TO PUT PIGS AWAY
description: The San Joaquin Valley, a prime agricultural region, has a problem with fog: It is often blanketed so thickly that some school bus drivers must use radar equipment to avoid collisions.

title: ANNE GILBRETH BARNEY
description: Anne Gilbreth Barney, the oldest child in the ''Cheaper by the Dozen'' family that was the subject of best-selling books and movies in the late 1940's and early 1950's, died here Feb. 16. She was 81 years old.

title: Susan Pamela Kass Is Wed to Samuel S. Gilbert
description: Susan Pamela Kass, a daughter of Mrs. Sheldon B. Mesnick of Brooklyn, and Samuel S. Gilbert, the son of Irma Gilbert of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Jacob H. Gilbert, were married yesterday. Rabbi James Prosnit performed the ceremony at Temple Beth-El in Brooklyn.

title: Catching Up
description: Dr. Brent M. Pratley, the former part-time Brigham Young University football surgeon who faced the possibility of losing his medical license when accused of having prescribed excessive addictive medication to players, reached a settlement with Utah licensing authorities last week. Under the agreement, Pratley admitted failure to maintain records indicating reasons for the prescriptions, and his penalty is that for the next year he will be allowed to prescribe narcotics only in hospitals and will also perform some community service. But the authorities dropped the most spectacular charge, which Pratley had vigorously denied: that he indiscriminately threw a handful of the addictive painkiller Percodan to players on a team flight in 1983.

title: DANCE: THE JERSEY BALLET OFFERS 'LET'S GO SOUTH'
description: The administrative roster for the New Jersey Ballet Company is filled with familiar names. The company's two artistic advisers are Edward Villella and Eleanor D'Antuono. Carolyn Clark, the company's director, Joseph Carow, its associate director, and George Tomal, the resident choreographer, are alumni of American Ballet Theater. And the Joffrey Ballet is represented by Paul Sutherland, the company's ballet master, and Jerel Hilding, a guest artist. But the New Jersey Ballet Company has more to boast about than its administrators. It is a well-integrated assemblage of fine young dancers who presented an enjoyable and well-balanced program tonight at the handsome theater at Somerset County College.

title: BOSTON DIGITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: Patti Oberfield Becomes Bride of Bruce A. Glotzer
description: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., yesterday Patti Ann Oberfield, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elliot Oberfield of Howard Beach, Queens, and Bruce Alan Glotzer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Glotzer of Hartsdale, N.Y., were married by Rabbi Alan Blaine.

title: AN INNOCENT VICTIM OF THE IRAN SCANDAL
description: Because so much remains unknown about the Iran-contra scandal, information frequently comes out in the form of revelations that may contain only part of the truth and can be badly misleading. If we are not careful, many good and innocent people doing very worthwhile things could be harmed.

title: ABC-TV Print Account Assigned to B.J.K.&E.
description: The ABC-TV Network news division has assigned its print advertising account to Bozell Jacobs Kenyon & Eckhardt. It had been at N. W. Ayer since 1982 and back then it was called a $2.5 million account.

title: MOOD OF AUSTERITY PROMPTING CHANGE IN TV NEWS
description: The president of CBS News, Howard Stringer, plans to visit his Washington bureau today to discuss a subject that has the 1,222 employees of CBS News in a state of excitement and dread: CBS News has to be reinvented, and soon.

title: QUOTES OF THE DAY
description: ''The past 12 years in Lebanon provide ample proof that no external force can impose political or security arrangements.'' - Sondra McCarty, State Department spokeswoman. [ A11:1. ]

title: Washington Watch; Updated Consumer Price Index
description: Whenever the Government updates one of its price gauges, such as the Consumer Price Index, the typical assumption of economists is that the revised figures will show less inflation than under the old method of calculation. They figure, for one thing, that retrospective adjustment of prices for quality improvement - often the result of technological advance - tends to exert a downward bias.

title: Remembering One's Place
description: Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, was presiding the other day over a hearing of a Senate Labor subcommittee. The last witness among the third of four groups of witnesses was wrapping up when Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina, strolled in. Mr. Thurmond took his seat and, thinking the hearing was over, said to the witnesses: ''Thank you all for coming.''

title: THOMPSON MEDICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
BUNDY CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
FIELD FOR FLAMINGO: A BIT OF CALIFORNIA
description: A cargo plane from California due to touch down at Miami International Airport Monday afternoon carries a message about the current picture for the Kentucky Derby on May 2. The passengers include three colts who will run in the $450,000 Flamingo Stakes at Hialeah Saturday. They have been sent across the country to avoid the top colts on the West Coast, who at the moment look like the strength of this year's Derby crop.

title: TOOL ORDERS ROSE 8.2% IN JANUARY
description: New orders for American-made machine tools rose 8.2 percent in January from the slightly improved levels of December, according to a report to be released today by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association.

title: BRAZIL KEEN ON STARTING NEW TALKS
description: The Brazilian Government, anxious to avoid reprisals for its suspension of debt payments to foreign banks Friday, moved this weekend to reassure creditors that it was ready to work out a new accord as soon as possible.

title: Ecuador Seeks Payment Delay
description: Ecuador, Latin America's eighth-largest debtor, is seeking to postpone interest payments to private foreign banks at least until June, a senior Government finance official said today.

title: CHIEFTAIN DEVELOPMENT CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a $23.7 million writedown of U.S. oil and gas properties. c-Net income All results are in Canadian funds.

title: NUVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ENGINEERED SUPPORT SYSEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
ACC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AUXTON COMPUTER ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
IN MIAMI, SPEED HAS EDGE ON RELIABILITY
description: Earlier this month Porsche dominated the 24-hour sports car race at Daytona, sweeping the first five places in the opening event on the International Motor Sports Association's Camel GT calendar.

title: SOLDIERS OF SYRIA MOVE INTO BEIRUT
description: Syrian troops poured into Beirut today and began taking control of the capital's predominantly Moslem western sector in an effort to restore order among warring militias.

title: RECITAL: ROBERTA PETERS
description: MORE than 35 years after her Metropolitan Opera debut, Roberta Peters continues to sing - skillfully, accurately and with an astonishing degree of vocal freshness -and she presented a demanding program at the 92d Street Y Saturday night.

title: 'MONEY WORLD' ON 13
description: GEORGE G. W. GOODMAN, better known as Adam Smith, introduces a two-part edition of ''Adam Smith's Money World'' tonight at 8:30 on Channel 13 that should give Americans concerned about the unfolding insider-trading saga on Wall Street something more serious to worry about.

title: Insulted by 'Amerika'
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTH CAROLINA FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
College, Unfortunately, Is Nothing But a Product
description: To the Editor:

title: Music Noted in Brief; 12th-Century Works From Boston Camerata
description: The Boston Camerata's musical journey into the 12th century Thursday night evoked the sense of vast distance, adventure and freedom that we often associate with space travel. The music of Abelard, and of the troubadour poets and ecclesiastical musicians surrounding him, survives only in imprecise outline. We perceive it distorted and incomplete, as if through an imperfect telescope.

title: DEFINING KITH AND KIN IN THE LAND OF KIM AND LEE
description: Once, not so long ago, a young man named Soh fell in love with a young woman whose family name also happened to be Soh.

title: CONSERVATIVES PRESSING 1988 G.O.P. CONTENDERS FOR A RIGID FOREIGN AGENDA
description: Conservative activists, dismayed by the Reagan Administration's recent failure to advance their agenda, are pressing Republican Presidential hopefuls to embrace a foreign policy in the 1988 campaign that would put them to the right of President Reagan on some issues.

title: 2 WHO OUSTED MARCOS: A YEAR DIMS THE LUSTER
description: As celebrations marking last year's peaceful ouster of President Ferdinand E. Marcos began today, the two men who led the revolt met stiffly at a military cemetery, their relations strained and their reputations dimmed.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Surprising Soprano Sings at Town Hall
description: The most surprising thing about Michael Aspinall - who calls himself the Surprising Soprano and presented a program of music and comedy at Town Hall Friday night - is that he is genuinely, often hilariously funny.

title: AMBASSADOR FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $32,052 for both the quarter and year. c-Net income The company said its latest year loss resulted from two special loan loss provisions totaling $1,010,000 that were taken in the third quarter by two subsidiaries.

title: Simpler Explanations
description: To the Editor:

title: DONALDSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a non-recurring gain of 22 cents a share on the sale of excess land in Bloomington, Minn.

title: NEWHALL RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest year includes writedowns of $2.5 million resulting from lower oil and gas prices.

title: Microrim to Livingston
description: Livingston & Company of Seattle, one of the far-flung, previously local agencies that are earning national reputations, has just been awarded the account of Microrim Inc., a microcomputer software publisher in Bellevue, Wash., which had a $1.5 million ad budget last year. The previous agency was D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, San Francisco.

title: Elizabeth Kushner, Editor, Marries Louis A. Pagan Jr.
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Susannah Kushner to Louis Alfredo Pagan Jr., a son Mr. and Mrs. Pagan of Queens Village, Queens, took place yesterday in Forest Hills, Queens, at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Kushner, parents of the bride. The nondenominational ceremony was performed by the Rev. James Wentz, a Unitarian minister.

title: Washington Watch; Volcker Job Prospects Improve
description: Prospects that Paul A. Volcker will be reappointed chairman of the Federal Reserve have improved markedly following President Reagan's not-so-subtle indication that the White House chief of staff, Donald T. Regan, a Volcker nemesis, might leave his own post.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on the Style page on Feb. 9 about day care for the elderly misstated Helene Wolff's position. She is director of public affairs for the New York City Department for the Aging.

title: AMONG WOMEN, THE TALK IS OF CONDOMS
description: The women who gathered for dinner late last month were all single New Yorkers in their 20's and 30's - a magazine writer, a photographer, a fashion designer and a makeup artist. One of the participants called it a ''girls' night out'' of Mexican food, margaritas and ''girl talk.'' But the conversation, she added, had never been like this: it was about condoms.

title: T.C.U. LOOKS BEYOND EYES OF TEXAS
description: THE coach is nicknamed Killer. The team has some players who would be stars in the Big East, the Atlantic Coast Conference or the Big Ten. They are a top-20 team, who some people think should be in the top 10.

title: E'TOWN CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Article 846387 -- No Title
description: The Gillette Company lost $124.3 million in the fourth quarter because of a costly restructuring prompted by a takeover attempt by the Revlon Group.

title: Reverse Gear in Cuba
description: Until a few weeks ago, Havana was full of billboards proclaiming (in Spanish, of course) ''Now, indeed, we are going to build Socialism,'' a quote from a recent speech by President Fidel Castro.

title: Tokyo Became World Class Long Ago
description: To the Editor:

title: MICROWAVE LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Volleying Up Support
description: By game time Saturday night, Laura Bauer had sold perhaps a dozen New York Liberties shirts to the steady trickle of volleyball fans filing into the Hofstra University Physical Fitness Center. The considerable time between sales, though, had given her the opportunity to construct something of an informal market analysis.

title: PAYCO AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Peripatetic Hopeful
description: Having reportedly contemplated and then decided against seeking the Senate seats in Michigan of Carl Levin (in 1984) and Donald W. Riegle Jr. (next year), entrenched Democrats, Peter M. Dawkins, a retired brigadier general and a Republican, is thinking about a run for the Senate in New Jersey.

title: This Country Needs Oil From the Alaskan Arctic
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday Treasury Statement January Tuesday Durable Goods Orders January Wednesday None Thursday None Friday Consumer Price Index January Merchandise Trade Balance January Farm Prices February

title: Bacardi to Split Stock
description: The Bacardi Corporation said its board had declared a 1-for-1,000 reverse stock split that would take the company private, subject to shareholder approval at the April 27 annual meeting. It said holders of fewer than 1,000 shares would receive $41 for each share held, and holders of more than 1,000 shares would receive fractional new shares instead of cash.

title: Jessica Gabriel Is Bride of Steven Lauria
description: Jessica Anne Gabriel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mordecai L. Gabriel of Great Neck, L.I., was married yesterday to Steven Victor Lauria, a son of Angela M. Lauria of Randall Manor, S.I., and Pat T. Lauria of West Brighton, S.I. Judge Ira B. Harkavy of City Civil Court performed the ceremony at the bride's residence in Manhattan.

title: Helen Taft Manning, Ex-Dean of Bryn Mawr
description: Helen Taft Manning, professor emeritus of history and longtime dean of Bryn Mawr College, died Saturday of pneumonia at a nursing home in suburban Philadelphia. She was 95 years old.

title: BALLET: 'FOUR SEASONS'
description: CHOREOGRAPHICALLY speaking, it was mostly sunny weather - but with a few clouds - on Saturday night when a new cast danced some of the solo roles in the New York City Ballet's production of ''The Four Seasons'' at the New York State Theater.

title: SPENDTHRIFT FARM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Professor Peoples the Bureaucracy
description: Representative William H. Gray 3d recalls that in the spring of his senior year as a sociology major at Franklin and Marshall College, Prof. Sidney Wise approached him with the offer of a Congressional internship.

title: PAM TRANSPORTATION SERVCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $518,739 to reflect the retroactive impact of the Tax Reform Act of 1986.

title: EVANS & SUTHERLAND COMUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LAKERS PLAY A HIDDEN CARD
description: It's so easy to forget about James Worthy. He speaks softly and has an unassuming demeanor. Even when he's on the basketball court, where his talents speak volumes, he is often overlooked.

title: U.S. AND 5 ALLIES PROMISE TO SEEK DOLLAR STABILITY
description: The United States and five other major countries said today that they would ''cooperate closely'' to stabilize the dollar. A further decline in its relation to the yen and the mark, they said, would hurt the world economy.

title: CONCERT: PHILHARMONIC
description: MSTISLAV ROSTROPOVICH'S continuing birthday celebration brought him back for a second New York Philharmonic program Saturday evening. This time all three of the works programmed were from the repertory of recent cello works his art has inspired: Britten's Symphony for Cello and Orchestra, Leonard Bernstein's ''Three Meditations from 'Mass' '' and Shostakovich's Cello Concerto No. 1, works introduced by Mr. Rostropovich in 1964, 1977 and 1959 respectively, with Maxim Shostakovich (the composer's son) conducting. We expect both eloquence and ebullience from this cellist, and both were present; he rose to his best in the best piece, the Britten, a taut, vital, richly imagined and beautifully constructed score.

title: Washington Watch; Briefcases
description: * The Securities and Exchange Commission, which is completing analyses of the stock market plunges of Sept. 11-12 and Jan. 23, finds that program trading was less a factor than generally believed.

title: Top Executive of Cordis Starts Out on His Own
description: Norman R. Weldon has resigned as president, chief executive and a director of the Cordis Corporation after his attempt at a management buyout of the company's pacemaker business was defeated in a bidding war.

title: EXCEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Subway Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: HOMEOWNERS DISCOVER TOUGH RULE ON 'POINTS'
description: Around this time of year, renters tend to evince jealous sentiments toward homeowners who have bought into the American dream, and the treasure chest of tax deductions that go along with it.

title: KNICKS FALL TO PISTONS, 122-110
description: Isiah Thomas led a balanced scoring attack with 26 points, including two crucial baskets, to hold off a furious rally tonight and lead the Detroit Pistons to a 122-110 decision over the Knicks.

title: YANKS HOPE IT'S NOT TOO LATE FOR JOHN AND NIEKRO
description: The injuries seem to be more frequent and the recovery time much longer as each season passes for Tommy John and Joe Niekro. They are well beyond their most productive years as pitchers, too old to be considered the centerpieces of any rotation yet feeling too young to simply walk away from the game.

title: CHEN GETS FIRST TOUR VICTORY
description: Tze-Chung (T. C.) Chen shed his memories of past disappointment today, making clutch shots to beat Ben Crenshaw in a playoff for the Los Angeles Open golf tournament.

title: G.M. Plans Cuts in Flint
description: The General Motors Corporation said 800 of the 3,900 workers at its engine plant in Flint, Mich., would be laid off indefinitely as part of a production change. A G.M. spokesman said the layoffs at the plant, which builds engines for Buicks, Oldsmobiles and Cadillacs, were the result of a change in production from V-6 engines for rear-drive cars, to new front-drive V-6 engines planned for the 1988 model year.

title: Viacom Sets Share Accord
description: The two groups vying for control of Viacom International Inc. have both agreed not to buy additional shares of the New York-based broadcasting concern, except through a tender offer for more than half of the company's stock. A group led by Viacom's senior management said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it signed the agreement on Tuesday.

title: RYAN, BECK & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding for the 1985 periods have been restated to give retroactive effect to a 30-for-1 split of the company's common stock.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Archie Shepp Quintet Appears at Sweet Basil
description: The tenor saxophonist Archie Shepp reconvened one of his rangy, hard-swinging quintets from the late 1960's at Sweet Basil last week. At its first set Tuesday, the group was loose but dynamic, playing a pair of free-bop pieces by the trombonist Grachan Moncur 3d, a parodic two-beat by the pianist Dave Burrell, and some blues sung by a guest, Royal Blue.

title: DOUBTS EXPRESSED ON DOLLAR STABILITY
description: Today's six-nation agreement on stabilizing the dollar and accelerating world economic growth may not be sufficient to stop the dollar's fall in coming weeks, according to some experts and officials involved in the talks.

title: Adler & Shaykin In a Buying Mood
description: Adler & Shaykin announced completion last week of the $586 million acquisition of the Joy Manufacturing Company, and, according to one of its principals, the leveraged buyout firm is not stopping there.

title: HOYAS BEAT SYRACUSE BY 72-71
description: The coventional wisdom against Georgetown this season has been that when you stop Reggie Williams, you stop the Hoyas.

title: SORROWFUL PLIGHT OF NEEDIEST PROMPTS GIFT TO 75th APPEAL
description: ''It always broke my mother's heart when you profiled some of the neediest cases,'' said Bruce Bowling of Manhattan in sending a gift of $100 to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. ''She would call me up on the telephone and say, 'It's just the luck of the draw, son; it could happen to any of us.' She was right, of course.''

title: Japanese Hail Pact; Dollar Up
description: Japanese business leaders and economists praised this weekend's agreement to stabilize currency fluctuations as the dollar rose slightly during early morning trading here.

title: LEGGETT & PLATT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said earnings include a previously announced gain from an October 1986 sale of three plants to a partnership in which the company has a 50 percent interest.

title: APACHE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $666,000 and $796,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income d-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,170,000 for the quarter and $1,462,000 for the year. The 1986 revenues include $45 million ($38 million in the fourth quarter) from a previously unconsolidated subsidiary.

title: PETRO GRIGORENKO DIES IN EXILE IN U.S.
description: Petro G. Grigorenko, a Red Army general who became an outspoken critic of the Soviet Government, died in exile Saturday at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 79 years old and lived in Sunnyside, Queens.

title: Mayor Orders Barriers Razed in New Orleans
description: The city has torn down barriers dividing a mostly black New Orleans neighborhood from a predominantly white suburb. But a municipal official of the suburb said the barricade would be rebuilt on Monday.

title: A CONVENT AT AUSCHWITZ WILL BE CLOSED
description: Roman Catholic prelates from Poland, France and Belgium, meeting with European Jewish spokesmen here, agreed today to close a Carmelite convent at the site of the Auschwitz-Birkenau death camp within two years.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Your ordeal is over.'' - Brig. Gen. Ghazi Kanaan, chief of Syrian military intelligence in Beirut.

title: NMR CENTERS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $1,466,800 from the settlement of litigation. c-After a gain of $1,198,322.

title: REAGAN FACING A PIVOTAL WEEK ON IRAN SCANDAL
description: Senior White House officials said today that the Reagan Presidency is entering a pivotal week with the planned release of a report on the Iranian-Nicaraguan affair that could determine whether Mr. Reagan rebounds and whether some top advisers remain.

title: PLM COS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PENTECH INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
On Trouble and Friendship
description: As the Reagan Administration attempts to weather the storm of the Iran-Nicaragua affair, former President Richard M. Nixon has written a brief recollection of what he calls ''my problems in the Watergate crisis'' that might seem germane to some current White House officials.

title: AIDS VICTIMS LOSE U.S. BENEFITS
description: The 23 men and women with AIDS who live in Bailey House, a Greenwich Village residence for homeless victims of the deadly disease, have been denied Federal social security benefits that were to pay their room and board and provide their pocket money.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday, about the Daxor Corporation's stock, incorrectly described the extent of competition in blood freezing and storage services. Daxor is not the only publicly traded company in that business.

title: MUSIC: MIYATA PLAYS THE SHO
description: THE sho is a Japanese mouth organ that resembles a diminutive stalagmite and sounds like a bright, reedy, almost excruciatingly pure harmonium. An instrument of limited range but rare sonic beauty, it is almost unknown in the United States. As such, Mayumi Miyata's sho recital at the Asia Society Saturday afternoon was of more than usual interest.

title: Car Runs Red Light And Kills Couple
description: A Pennsylvania couple were killed as they left a casino when a car driven by a drunken driver ran a red light and struck them, the police said.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ENGAGED TO MURDER: The Inside Story of the Main Line Murders. By Loretta Schwartz-Nobel. Illustrated. 291 pages. Viking. $17.95.

title: Library Acquires Papers Of Lincoln Center Chief
description: The New York Public Library has acquired the papers of William Schuman, the Pulitzer Prize-winning composer and former president of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. The collection, which is expected to be available to scholars in the library's music division by September, encompasses 50 years of the composer's correspondence, programs, scrapbooks and speeches, and it documents the growth of Lincoln Center. The collection also offers information on the MacDowell Colony and the Namberg Foundation, two of the organizations that Mr. Schuman presided over as president.

title: Excerpts From Statement by Finance Ministers and Central Bank Heads
description: Following are excerpts from the text of a statement issued today at the end of a meeting of finance ministers and central bank heads from the United States, Japan, West Germany, France, Britain and Canada.

title: Mrs. Dembo's Message
description: Fennis Dembo is not a misprint. His name is not Dennis Fembo. It's Fennis Dembo, and he's the main reason why Wyoming's basketball team is on top of the Western Athletic Conference.

description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $6,757,000. The company said the net income figure for the latest yearreflects a one-time provision, which was made during the first quarter of 1986, for additional expenses expected to be incurred in connection with the company's disposition of its Llyod's Electronics, Inc. subsidiary and the winding up of that subsidiary's operations. Sales excluding excise taxes.

title: BABY M TRIAL LAWYERS: TWO GOALS AND TWO STYLES
description: Tactics and personalities of the chief lawyers on the two sides of the Baby M trial are as different as their goals, and have prompted opposite reactions from the presiding judge.

title: The Strategic Bomber Mess
description: The Air Force has three kinds of strategic bombers - one in the hand, one in the bush and one in the wild blue yonder. There are B-52's, the newest frames of which were built in 1962. There is the new B-1 now coming on line but plagued with problems; fixing them could cost $3 billion or more. And there is the Stealth or Advanced Technology Bomber, due in the 1990's, whose only certain feature is its daunting cost.

title: Joyner-Kersee In Step for Award
description: Jackie Joyner-Kersee, the world-record holder in the grueling heptathlon, could make history when the Sullivan Award is presented Monday night.

title: In South Korea, A Smoking Volcano
description: LEAD: Political confrontation in South Korea seems to be heading toward another crisis, and the United States should try to prevent it from becoming violent.

title: Constitution Commercial
description: The commercial opens up with a tight shot of a man's face from eyebrows to lower lip, and as he talks the camera backs off to reveal white chin whiskers and a red-and-white-striped top hat. Why, that could be . . . it is - Uncle Sam.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: What pitcher has been a 25-game winner the most times? Cy Young, a 511-game career winner who averaged better than 23 victories a season, won 25 or more games in 12 of his 22 seasons, and no pitcher ever did better. But eight of those 25-game years came before the turn of the century: seven with Cleveland of the National League from 1891-98 and one with St. Louis of the National League in 1899. The foremost 25-game winner since 1900 is Christy Mathewson, who achieved that level eight times for the New York Giants from 1903-13. Walter Johnson of the Washington Senators is right behind. He never won fewer than 25 games in seven consecutive seasons from 1910-16, but he never won that many in a season again. Grover Cleveland Alexander joined the 25-victory club six times from 1911-20 and Joe (Iron Man) McGinnity did it five times from 1900-06. Four-timers since 1900 are Mordecai Brown of Chicago in the National League and Young of Boston in the American.

title: C.I.A. NOMINEE TIED TO '85 MEMO URGING IRAN ARMS DEALS
description: Robert M. Gates, the nominee to be Director of Central Intelligence, agreed to send the White House a memo in 1985 that favored arms dealings with Iran, even though he knew its reasoning was at odds with conclusions reached by his analysts at the Central Intelligence Agency, intelligence sources said today.

title: LEGISLATORS URGE STATE AND CITY TO SHIFT BANKS
description: The state and the city should move millions of dollars now deposited in banks that charge high interest rates for credit card holders to banks that charge lower rates, a group of New York legislators said yesterday.

title: Take 1,800 More Taxis and Run
description: Mayor Koch's tactic of freezing taxi fares until taxi owners accept an increase in their numbers is about to pay off. The City Council is apparently ready to add 1,800 yellow cabs to the 11,800 now on the street - the first increase in half a century.

title: PRIDE OF MEXICO: 2 OF BASEBALL'S BEST ON PITCHING MOUND
description: BASEBALL may be the great American pastime, but the game's millions of fans here take enormous pride in knowing that as the 1987 season nears, the two best left-handed pitchers in the major leagues are Mexicans.

description: The Board of Regents is considering broad changes in the requirements for teacher certification that could significantly alter the way teachers are trained.

title: MITRAL MEDICAL INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: PROGRAM ALLOWS ELDERLY TO BARTER FOR SERVICES
description: Seventy-year-old Ella Amaker and 73-year-old Leona Downs need each other.

title: OUTDOORS: EXPO EXPANDS EXHIBITS
description: IF you'd like assurance that this bitter late winter is really drawing to a close, a visit to the 10th annual World Fishing and Outdoor Exposition at the Rockland Community College field house in Suffern, N.Y., will prove salubrious.

title: Full Schedule of Treasury Offerings
description: The Treasury has a full schedule of financings this week, starting with today's regular weekly bill auction, followed tomorrow by the monthly sale of two-year notes and on Wednesday by the quarterly sale of five-year notes.

title: A HOSPITAL ROOMMATE OFTEN HELPS
description: The old woman patient was trying to tell the young doctors something. Four of them, on hospital rounds, were listening intently to the chief resident as he described her condition, but she wasn't being heard. As the doctors made for the door, the patient in the opposite bed called out firmly: ''Wait! Listen to her. She's trying to tell you something.'' The doctors, somewhat sheepishly, returned to the bedside, and the chief resident listened to the woman and reassured her.

title: HARPER & ROW PUBLISHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
The Dialects of Birds
description: BIRDS sing in dialects as distinct to the avian ear as the difference between a Boston and Mississippi accent is to humans. But there has been a long debate over the significance, if any, of local differences in the songs of a particular species.

description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $1,488,000 and $6,798,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes extraordinary credits of $720,000 and $4,003,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company went public last month.

title: MAGIC SEEKS FUTURE AS KNICK
description: Long-suffering fans of New York basketball who must be wondering when, and even if, all the losing will end, can take heart from this fantasy: Magic Johnson wants to be a Knick. Honest. Johnson, the odds-on choice for this year's most valuable player award, said Sunday that he hoped to finish his career in New York with the Knicks. He said he had even spoken to the Lakers' hierarchy concerning a possible move East later in his career but he wasn't hopeful.

description: b-After a loss of $500,000 on disposition of a subsidiary.

description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether states may ban stores from displaying sexually explicit materials deemed harmful to juveniles in places where children might be able to examine them.

description: The company said included in the latest revenue is a $6 million sale of a T-200 supercomputer to Los Alamos National Laboratories.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: YOUTH MOVEMENT

title: Jeantot Sets Mark In Yachting Race
description: Philippe Jeantot today sailed his 60-foot cutter Credit Agricole III across the finish line in a 15-knot breeze to win in record time the third leg of the BOC Challenge solo race around the world.

title: Houston Gets Lower Ratings
description: Citing the continued erosion in the economy of Houston caused by weakness in the dominant energy sector, Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation both lowered the city's ratings, affecting more than $1 billion of outstanding debt.

title: GYPSUM HEAPS STIR LOUISIANA BATTLE
description: Hills of gypsum waste upriver from New Orleans have set off public protests and name-calling that have reached the highest corporate offices in the region.

title: DANCE: CITY BALLET GALA WITH INTERNATIONAL TONE
description: FOR the third year, the New York City Ballet has closed its winter season with a special program to benefit the company's Dancers' Emergency Fund.

title: BEGUN, FREED DISSIDENT, RETURNS TO MOSCOW TO THE SOUND OF CHEERS
description: Iosif Z. Begun, the Jewish rights advocate who was freed from prison on Friday, returned home to a jubilant welcome today, pledging to devote himself to the cause of human rights in general and the rights of Jews in particular.

title: Private French TV Franchise Sold
description: The French press magnate Robert Hersant and the Italian television producer Silvio Berlusconi have won the franchise to run France's private television Channel Five. The Hersant-Berlusconi bid was one of two for the network. The other was from Sir James Goldsmith, publisher of the Express magazine group.

title: REAGAN REPORTED UNABLE TO RECALL IRAN ARMS DECISION
description: President Reagan is unable to say with certainty if he approved in advance the first American-sanctioned arms shipment to Iran in the fall of 1985 because he genuinely cannot remember, acording to a senior Administration official who is familiar with the President's testimony to the Tower Commission.

title: Crude Oil Prices Slump To Lowest of the Year
description: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products slumped yesterday, at what analysts said was a critical juncture for OPEC in its attempt to stabilize oil prices at $18 a barrel.

title: Village Inn Restaurants Pick a Kansas Agency
description: Village Inn Pancake House, a 27-year-old restaurant chain based in Denver, has named Barkley & Evergreen Advertising of Shawnee Mission, Kan., as its ad agency. The budget is $4 million advertising.

title: AIDS IN THE WORKPLACE: DISRUPTIONS GROWING
description: The number of cases of AIDS and AIDS-related diseases has caused increasing confusion and disruption in New York City's work force. Employers and employees are reacting to AIDS victims in ways ranging from support and financial assistance to ostracism and dismissal.

title: IRAN PANELS TO START IMMUNITY PROCESS THIS WEEK
description: The special Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair will begin a process this week of granting some witnesses limited immunity from prosecution to compel their testimony, the chief counsel for the Senate committee said today.

title: The Pits Of Crime
description: What a squalid, no-class bunch of criminals the Wall Street gang was. All they wanted out of crime was disgustingly excessive wealth. They had no romance in their souls, no instinct for crime conceived on the legendary scale and not a trace of social responsibility.

title: STRAWBERRY READY FOR BETTER DAYS
description: Darryl Strawberry admits it now. A stormy courtship and marriage took his mind off baseball at times during the last two years and undermined his performance with the Mets. But he believes that he is ready to focus on his job full time, and predicts that he will surprise people who have been waiting for him to ''explode'' in baseball.

title: AMR, RULING OUT BID, STUDIES PAN AM ASSETS
description: The AMR Corporation, the parent company of American Airlines, said yesterday that it had no intention of making a bid for Pan American World Airways Inc. but that it would be interested in considering acquiring assets of the carrier if it put them on the market.

description: Viewers younger than 30 may not believe it, but Phil Donahue did not invent the uninhibited TV talk show. Back in 1958 David Susskind, who died Sunday, led real free-for-alls with everyone from Soviet dictators to transvestites and ex-Presidents.

title: IS NOTHING SACRED? CONSTANTS OF SCIENCE SUBMIT TO REVISION
description: A CONSTANT is something that is never supposed to change. But an international coalition of scientists, undaunted by that definition, has just changed more than 100 of the fundamental constants upon which the work of science depends.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Food Notes column in The Living Section on Feb. 11 gave incorrect figures for the sodium content of lobster and crabmeat. Three ounces of fresh lobster contains 212 milligrams of sodium; three ounces of crabmeat contains 314 milligrams.

Bennigsen-Foerder told the weekly Welt am Sonntag in an interview that Veba needed to expand its chemical division, but the company faced difficulties making acquisitions in West Germany.

title: The Stakes in Arms Control
description: Unless the Administration quickly puts its arms control act together, time may soon run out for an agreement with the Soviet Union. Just a year is left before the Iowa caucuses, and an election campaign is hardly conducive to serious negotiations with Moscow.

title: Mt. Sinai's Multimedia Campaign
description: THE 134-year-old Mount Sinai Medical Center has been driven by circumstance into 20th-century marketing and will soon be unleashing its first multimedia advertising campaign. The theme, created by the year-old Grace & Rothschild agency, is ''Take Good Care of Yourself.''

title: Perry Is Convicted
description: Aulcie Perry Jr., a former basketball player who became an Israeli citizen and was hailed as a sports champion there, was convicted in Brooklyn Federal Court last night of smuggling heroin with a street value of $1.8 million into the United States. Judge Mark A. Constantino said sentencing would be set for the end of March. The 36-year-old Perry had been on trial since Feb. 17 on charges of conspiracy to import heroin, importation of heroin and possession of heroin with intent to distribute. He was convicted on all counts, each of which carries a possible 20-year prison term. His lawyer, Richard Lind, said he would appeal. Perry, who was born in Newark, played for the Virginia Squires of the American Basketball Association in 1974-75. He was signed by the Knicks but was cut before the 1975-76 season. The 6-foot-10-inch Perry, who holds a dual citizenship, joined the Maccabi Tel Aviv basketball team in Israel in 1977 and helped bring it a European Cup championship that year and in 1979. He remained on the team until 1984. Perry's cousin, Kenneth Johnson, 29, who was charged with Perry, pleaded guilty earlier this month and is awaiting sentencing.

title: Study to Look at Why So Many Blacks Smoke
description: Researchers at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst have been awarded a $2.5 million Federal grant to investigate why more blacks smoke than do members of other ethnic groups and to develop programs to stop urban blacks from smoking.

title: U.S.-SOVIET GRAIN TALKS RESUME
description: The United States and the Soviet Union resumed grain talks here today amid reports in the marketplace that Moscow had recently purchased up to one million metric tons of American corn.

title: NETS ARE BESTED BY BIRD'S 35
description: The Nets played well enough tonight to beat most teams. But their opponents were the Boston Celtics, who have the talent, the poise and the know-how. And, of course, they have Larry Bird. Those ingredients came together in the final 4 minutes 44 seconds, and Boston made up for a poor first half and went on to beat the Nets, 116-103, at the Hartford Civic Center.

description: Jean-Paul Gaultier has a shock in store for New Yorkers at Bergdorf Goodman, where the French designer's first New York boutique opened last week.

title: THREE WHO REDIRECTED FASHION
description: The exhibition at the Fashion Institute of Technology called ''Three Women,'' which opens to the public this morning, spans economically and occasionally with great beauty the development of fashion in the 20th century. The women are Madeleine Vionnet of the Paris couture, whose work dominated the l920's and 1930's; Claire McCardell, the leading sportswear designer in New York in the 1940's and l950's, and Rei Kawakubo, the most inventive member of the Tokyo school of design, who began attracting attention from the fashion world in 1981. Each designer denied the conventions of clothing construction of her time and each has pointed the way to new fashion directions.

description: A storm that churned its way up the East Coast early yesterday dumped 11 inches of thick snow on the nation's capital - shutting down the Federal Government for the third time in six weeks - and left New York slippery, slushy, wet and white.

title: BILLY SMITH KEEPS HIS TORCH AFIRE
description: In the old days, he could get by with lots of sleep, spaghetti and concentration. His Islander helmet and broad-timbered goaltending stick were accessories of combat, and solitude was his preferred method of game preparation. He had a Machiavellian zest for the payoffs of the playoffs, and he bloomed with importance each spring.

description: Leaders of Connecticut's General Assembly, no strangers to partisan quarrels at the State Capitol, had a nonpartisan disagreement today. An abstract sculpture of an eagle for their new legislative office building didn't look enough like an eagle to suit some lawmakers.

title: On the First Amendment
description: The question of how much members of Congress should be paid is very current, what with criticisms of the latest effort to raise legislative salaries. But it is not a new problem, according to John Agresto, deputy chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, who is participating in that agency's observance of the bicentennial of the Constitution. ''It is not well known,'' Mr. Agresto said, ''but the First Amendment was not always first.'' It is the First Amendment, actually the first article of the Bill of Rights, that sets the tone of the American nation, guaranteeing freedom of religion, speech, press and assembly and the right of petition, but its ranking is serendipitous. It was only No. 3 in the original reckoning.

title: ADVISER ON GUERRILLA WARFARE
description: Edward G. Lansdale, an Air Force officer whose influential theories of counterinsurgent warfare proved successful in the Philippines after World War II but failed to bring victory in South Vietnam, died yesterday at his home in McLean, Va. He was 79 years old and had a heart ailment.

title: HBO COMEDY SPECIAL STARS BOB GOLDTHWAIT
description: STAND-UP comedians, notorious for doing just about anything to attract attention, have now simply taken to shouting. Howie Mandel is partial to infantile screaming. Sam Kenison erupts regularly into menacing outbursts of hostility. And Bob Goldthwait, who could be Mr. Kenison's kid brother, right down to the thinning long hair, breaks out into snarling cries, all the while trembling like some poor demented creature on the verge of total collapse. There must be easier, and perhaps less humiliating, ways to earn a living, but the lure of performing is evidently fatal. Comics are funny that way.

description: The dollar was steady to slightly higher yesterday in light trading.

title: KEY RATES
SCIENCE TRIES TO HARNESS BACTERIAL OVERACHIEVERS
description: APPEARING as green slime on a damp wall, as scum on a stagnant pond and, as dots and filaments in any bit of soil under a microscope, they are not among the earth's more prepossessing organisms. But the family of bacterial species known as blue-greens can boast an unsurpassable lineage, eons of high achievement and dazzling creative powers, according to biotechnologists now trying to harness the microbes for the further service of mankind.

title: MINNEAPOLIS STUDY PLACES ORIGINS OF 911 CALLS

title: POLICE CHECKING REPORTED CHASE OF BLACK YOUTHS
description: The police said yesterday that they were investigating incidents in Queens on Sunday in which a group of black youths were reportedly chased by a group of young whites. One white youth was said to have been armed with a gun and others with baseball bats.
