title: Surgery for Leconte
description: Henri Leconte said yesterday he would undergo back surgery in Paris in the next few days and miss at least seven weeks of tennis. The Frenchman said he suffered a herniated disk when he fell while playing in a tournament last week in Indian Wells, Calif. ''I felt a light crack when I fell on my back,'' he said. ''I finished the match but since then I have a slight permanent pain.'' Leconte said he would not be able to touch a tennis racquet for at least seven weeks, then would plan his rehabilitation to be sure he was ready to play in the French Open in May.

title: CHICAGO IS ELECTING CANDIDATES FOR MAYOR TODAY
description: With a 19-month primary-election campaign behind them, and more to come, Chicago's voters will choose the Democratic and Republican candidates for mayor Tuesday. The candidates, in turn, will slug it out in another six-week campaign leading up to the general election April 7.

title: AMERICAN WOODMARK reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
The Man Responsible
description: As the Iran affair unravels, with one ugly disclosure hard upon another, President Reagan's authority crumbles. Feuds rage unchecked in the White House; policies go undecided. It is, at times, as if there were no President.

title: SUBURB OF NEW ORLEANS DROPS BARRICADE EFFORT
description: City and suburban officials announced today that a dispute over streets barricaded by a suburban parish had been resolved and that the barricades, torn down by the city Saturday, would not be rebuilt.

title: TM COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $1,480,000 from sale of assets of the radio-format unit. c-Net loss

title: More Goodyear Plants May Close
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said that it might close more plants as a part of the restructuring plan it adopted to thwart the takeover efforts of the British-French financier Sir James Goldsmith last year. In a letter to employees, Robert Mercer, Goodyear's chairman, said that the Akron, Ohio, company would be 12 percent smaller when the restructuring was completed. Goodyear said that, as part of its restructuring, it would close two older tire plants and a shoe products plant.

title: RULING ON MERGER TALKS DUE
description: At a time of intense preoccupation with takeover maneuvers and insider trading, the Supreme Court agreed today to clarify the circumstances in which companies must publicly disclose their merger negotiations.

title: COMMONWEALTH SAVINGS ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $2,838,000 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: 'THE NAZI CONNECTION,' ON FRONTLINE
description: ''THE NAZI CONNECTION'' takes off at the Kennedy Space Center in 1969, as one of the United States moon shots reaches its successful climax. The focus is not on the spacecraft, however, but on some of the scientists who celebrate the achievement - Germans who had been spirited to this country after World War II. The next pictures are of German V-2 rockets exploding on London and Antwerp late in the war. Some of the same scientists were credited with that achievement.

title: Moderate U.S. Growth Seen
description: The United States economy should grow at a moderate rate this year, accompanied by rising inflation and a slight drop in the unemployment rate, economists for some of the nation's biggest corporations predicted today.

title: It's Raining Red On Gerry Faust
description: When 35,000 people showed up last fall to watch the University of Akron open its football season against little Salem College of West Virginia, university officials had every reason to expect the best from their bold move in the spring. At that time, they had announced that Gerry Faust would be arriving from Notre Dame to take over as coach and that the Zips would be moving up from Division I-AA to I-A in 1987.

title: Argentina to Hold Debt Talks
description: As they prepared to open debt talks with private banks in New York in the aftermath of Brazil's suspension of interest payments, Argentine officials said they were seeking new money and concessions sufficient to assure a 4 percent rate of economic growth.

title: BUDGET PANELS' CHAIRMEN READY TO FORGET THE LAW'S DEFICIT GOAL
description: The chairmen of the House and Senate Budget Committees indicated today that they were ready to abandon the budget law's $108 billion deficit target for 1988, saying the goal cannot be met without gimmicks.

title: SCHOOLS BACKING VOLUNTEER WORK
description: More high schools are providing programs for students to do volunteer work in hospitals, nursing homes and other places, a Carnegie Foundation study has found.

title: STEVENS, J P & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
UTILICORP UNITED reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said an investment in its Palo Verde No. 2 nuclear generating unit contributed $4.5 million, or 49 cents a share, to net income in the latest year.

title: GLENWAY WESCOTT, 85, NOVELIST AND ESSAYIST
description: Glenway Wescott, one of the last of the major expatriate American writers who lived in France in the 1920's and 30's, died of a stroke Sunday night at his home in Rosemont, N.J. He was 85 years old.

title: Japan Vehicle Output Off
description: Japan's production of cars, trucks and buses declined for the fourth consecutive month in January, dropping 3.3 percent from a year earlier, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today, linking the sluggish production to a slump in domestic sales. The association said that 936,916 vehicles were produced last month. Output of medium-sized cars rose 13.1 percent, to 37,163 units, while medium-size trucks showed a 7.8 percent rise from a year earlier to 112,717 vehicles.

title: UNITED ILLUMINATING CO reports earnings for 12mo Jan 31
SYNTREX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary credit of $193,000.

title: Mobil Offers Notes
description: The Mobil Corporation is offering $200 million of notes due in 1993, at a price of 99 3/4, to yield 7.185 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company, which picked up the issue in competitive bidding. Rated A-1 by Moody's and AA- by S.&P., the five-year notes yield about 42-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

title: More Tests for Potvin
description: The Islanders have scored 13 goals in their current two-game winning streak, four more goals than they had managed in their previous six games, but the renaissance has had its price in injuries. There are now a half-dozen regulars missing from the lineup. Denis Potvin, the defenseman, who left Saturday's game against Montreal with a bruised left knee, will undergo further testing today. Neal Coulter, a right wing and the third reinforcement to be summoned from the minors since Friday, joined the team for its trip to St. Louis yesterday. He replaces Ari Haanpaa, who experienced back soreness after Sunday's 7-0 rout of the Devils. Duane Sutter will move to left wing to replace Greg Gilbert, who is sidelined by a bruised hip suffered in that game. Patrick Flatley (sprained knee), Ken Morrow (bruised ribs), and Tomas Jonsson (fractured jaw), are the club's other absent veterans. . . . Mike Gartner of the Washington Capitals was named National Hockey League Player of the Week for the week of Feb. 16, the club announced. The forward registered seven goals and two assists in three games, including a four-goal game on Friday against Vancouver.

title: Iran's Threat to the U.S.
description: The Reagan Administration, though publicly proclaiming its arms delivery to Iran to have been an aberration of policy, tells us by its continued overtures to so-called moderates in Iran that its passion has not abated.

title: Bridge: Flexibility Is Demonstrated By Kaplan Team Champions
description: Flexibility is the key to success in the Betty Kaplan Team championship since the members of the team must rotate partnerships, a unique provision in American tournament play.

title: FINALCO GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and includes a gain of $1,537,000 from a change in accounting principle.

title: People
description: * Louis A. Tripodi, corporate director of public affairs at DDB Needham Worldwide, has been promoted to executive vice president.

title: Teacher Is Killed; Reward Is Offered
description: A schoolteacher was bludgeoned to death, and the teachers' union is offering a $5,000 reward for an arrest and conviction in the case. The teacher, Bertha Rodgers, 47 years old, was found dead Friday in her apartment at 655 West 183d Street in the Washington Heights section.

title: SOVIET WRITERS REINSTATE PASTERNAK
description: The Soviet writers' union has posthumously reinstated Boris Pasternak, completing the rehabilitation of the author of ''Doctor Zhivago.''

title: SERVICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
description: b-Includes gains on sales of hotels of $19,964,000 for the latest quarter; in the year-ago quarter, the gains were $8,411,000. c-Includes gains on sales of hotels of $22,435,000 for the latest 6 months, compared to gains of $9,254,000 a year earlier. The latest quarter and 6 months' nets are after a pre-tax writeoff of $3.7 million of a hotel investment.

title: Nuclear Power Can't Be Left Up to Washington; Unbuilt Plants
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: PORTER-GARCIA DUO
description: AMY K. PORTER and Thomas Garcia form a flute and guitar duo that draws together two attractive musical personalities but seems inherently limited by the repertory available to it. At the group's Weill Recital Hall concert Saturday afternoon, Miss Porter was a particularly strong performer, technically robust and musically forceful. Mr. Garcia struggled a little in Mauro Giuliani's ''Grand Duo Concertante'' but had a nice feel for the languid, less athletically inclined, Villa-Lobos solos.

title: WACKENHUT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $1,950,000 after-tax charge for loss reserves. c-Net income d-Includes an after-tax gain of $684,000 from the sale of former headquarters buildings.

title: VARLEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,284,000 and an extraordinary gain of $621,000 for the quarter, and for the year includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,661,000 and a credit from the termination of two salaried pension plans. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $62,000 and $764,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. d-Net loss

title: Nuclear Power Can't Be Left Up to Washington; No Reason to Change
description: To the Editor:

title: EXPERTS TESTIFY ON WHITEHEAD AS A PARENT
description: Mary Beth Whitehead's personality and her approaches to child-rearing were the dominant topics in daylong testimony today from two mental-health experts retained by Baby M's legal guardian.

title: HAVERTY FURNITURE COS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Talking Business with Bowers of United Airlines; Discount Fares' Recent Impact
description: At the end of January, Continental and Eastern airlines cut their lowest discount fares by 40 percent on most domestic flights. The rest of the industry followed. There was a catch, however: Once a customer bought a ticket, it was nonrefundable.

title: CONCERT: A RARE WORK BY LOEFFLER
description: CHARLES MARTIN LOEFFLER, an Alsatian composer who lived from 1861 to 1935 and spent the latter part of his career in Massachusetts, is best remembered today - when he is remembered at all - for his ''Pagan Poem,'' a rhapsodic and rather wonderful work for large orchestra that was a favorite of Leopold Stokowski. Sunday afternoon, the American Composers Orchestra, under the direction of John Nelson, presented another ambitious Loeffler work, ''La Mort de Tintagiles,''at Carnegie Hall.

title: KIMMINS CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Corrections
description: A report in the Advertising column of Business Day yesterday, about new accounts for McCann-Erickson, misidentified the previous agency for the McDonald's cooperative advertising association in New Orleans. It was Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, which had already resigned the assignment before it went to McCann-Erickson.

title: Litton, Dresser To Unite Units
description: Litton Industries and Dresser Industries today announced an agreement to form a new oil services company by combining their units in that business.

title: Shifting Gears on a Water Issue
description: Lee M. Thomas, the low-key Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, is doing something out of character for the Reagan Administration. He is proposing a new national environmental program.

title: MASSMUTUAL INCOME INVESORS INC reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: Revenue represents net assets.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Harper & Row Publishers Inc. said its board had approved a recapitalization plan providing for the creation of a new class B common stock having 10 votes a share.

title: Who's on First?
description: Manager Pete Rose of the Cincinnati Reds, reflecting on his opening-day lineup: ''If the season started tomorrow, Nick Esasky would be the first baseman. But it's too cold to start tomorrow.''

title: Settlement Reached in Strike Against Kroger Supermarkets
description: Negotiators for 1,500 workers and the Kroger Company reached a settlement Sunday in a strike against the supermarket chain in three states, officials for both sides said.

title: SUPERIOR INDUSTRIES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes the reversal of prior quarters' recognition of investment tax credits of $800,000 and the writedown of start-up expenses of the company's road-wheel plant in Fayetteville, Ark., of more than $1 million, or about 10 cents a share; the company also said that these items were partially offset by a gain of 15 cents a share on the sale of a warehouse in Illinois.

title: Federated Unit Official To Lead Lazarus Stores
description: John D. Miller should be a hero to personnel executives, who often do not get to the top in the department store business. Mr. Miller has made it all the way to chief executive, and yesterday he did it again.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: SO it was freezing most of last week. So what? Manhattan's fashion scene overheated with parties every night.

title: NATIONAL PRESTO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $247,000.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL NETS VS. DETROIT PISTONS, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:30 P.M. (Radio - WNEW 1130, 7:20 P.M.) KNICKS VS. PORTLAND TRAIL BLAZERS, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, 7 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.) HOUSTON ROCKETS VS. NUGGETS, at Denver, 9 P.M. (TV -WTBS, 9:05 P.M.) COLLEGES: West Virginia at Temple (TV - USA, 9 P.M.) Oklahoma at Iowa State (TV - FNN-SCORE, 8 P.M.) LaSalle at Army (Radio -WFAS 1230, 7:30 P.M.) HOCKEY RANGERS VS. SABRES, at Buffalo, 7:35 P.M. (TV - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M., tape delay) ISLANDERS VS. BLUES, at St. Louis, 8:35 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WOR 710, 8:30 P.M.) EDMONTON OILERS VS. PENGUINS, at Pittsburgh, 7:35 P.M. (TV - ESPN, 7 P.M.) title: NORTH REPORTEDLY HAD SECRETARY ALTER DOCUMENT
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North ordered his secretary to use a word processor to alter several National Security Council documents last November to prevent the originals from being found by investigators, a source with knowledge of the special prosecutor's investigation said today.

title: Nuclear Power Can't Be Left Up to Washington
description: To the Editor:

title: Malone Player of Week
description: Moses Malone, who has averaged more than 30 points and 14 rebounds while leading the Washington Bullets to three victories in four road-game victories last week, has been named the National Basketball Association Player of the Week. Malone began the week with 36 points and 11 rebounds in a 124-110 victory at Phoenix a week ago yesterday. The next night he had 27 points and 19 rebounds in a 114-99 triumph over the Los Angeles Lakers in Inglewood, Calif. Then on Friday night he had 35 points and 15 rebounds in a 118-113 decision over the Utah Jazz in Salt Lake City while playing with a swollen left ankle. He closed out the week with 24 points and 11 rebounds in a 110-93 loss to the SuperSonics in Seattle.

title: RAX RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
description: b-Includes non-recurring expenses of about $3.9 million, mostly related to the closing or refranchising of nine restaurants. c-Net income Year-ago quarter and six-month results include the results of 13 restaurants acquired from Calibre Corp. in March 1985 and refranchised before the beginning of fiscal 1987.

title: INTRODUCING AMIGA
description: COMMODORE, the Pennsylvania company that makes the C-64 and C-128 home computers, will introduce two new versions of its Amiga computer at a trade fair in Germany next month. The new Amigas will go on sale in the United States a month later.

title: Researchers Study Dirt In the Diet
description: Researchers working with a grant from a company involved in lawsuits over dioxin contamination are studying used diapers to determine how much dirt from playgrounds and backyards makes its way into children's diets.

title: Jenrette Is Chosen Equitable Life Head
description: The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States said yesterday that it had named Richard H. Jenrette, a leader in the securities industry, as chairman.

title: Careers; Managers With Dual Training
description: WITH computer terminals able to tap out information in such tremendous amounts, some imaginations envision corporations swamped under tons of printouts.

title: PITT TOPS VILLANOVA, EARNS TIE FOR TITLE
description: Charles Smith scored 22 points and Jerome Lane had 20 points and 17 rebounds to lead Pittsburgh to a 94-83 victory over Villanova tonight, assuring the Panthers of at least a tie for the Big East regular-season title.

title: Interest Seen In Allied Units
description: Garfinckel's, Bonwit Teller and the Plymouth Shops have drawn the most inquiries from possible buyers of the divisions offered for sale by the Allied Stores Corporation, sources close to the concern said yesterday.

title: STANHOME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in September.

title: THINKING CRITICALLY
description: THE public schools have discovered the importance of critical thinking, and many of them are trying to teach children how to do it. The problem is that few teachers know how.

title: FOOTHILL GROUP INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $366,000. c-Net loss and includes a loss of $2,955,000 from discontinued operations and a $6,020,000 loss on disposal of discontinued operations.

title: Australian Brewer Plans Carling Bid
description: Elders IXL Ltd., a major Australian brewer, said today that it planned an offer to acquire the Canadian brewer Carling O'Keefe Ltd. for the equivalent of about $294.3 million (United States) and that Carling's controlling stockholder had accepted the proposal.

title: SURVIVOR OF DEATH CAMP INDENTIFIES ACCUSED GUARD AT TRIAL IN ISRAEL
description: Forty-four years after escaping from the Treblinka death camp, Pinhas Epstein stood in court today to accuse the man he said was the executioner of countless Jews.

title: Divorce and Illness
description: The disruptive effects of a divorce can extend even to the immune system, the body's line of defense against disease, according to a recent study at the Ohio State University College of Medicine.

title: GREINER ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $143,000 from the termination of a pension plan at a subsidiary for both the quarter and year.

title: BABY M TRIAL SPLITS RANKS OF FEMINISTS
description: The moral and ethical issues raised by the Baby M custody trial have left feminists torn between supporting a woman's right to use her body as she chooses and opposing the elements of exploitation that seem present in many surrogate-mother cases.

title: Academic Not-So-Freedom at SUNY
description: To equate Zionism with racism has become a cliche of anti-Israel animus. But is acceptance of this belief, even if bigoted, grounds to deny a professor tenure? It apparently was at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, dealing a blow to academic freedom, a concept meant to encompass even the most bitter differences of opinion.

title: New Thai Army Chief Confronts Government
description: The Government of Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda, who dismissed the country's army commander last May because of his interference in politics, is now being challenged by the commander's successor.

title: SYRIANS ON PATROL IN EFFORT TO KEEP WEST BEIRUT PEACE
description: Syrian troops went into action today within 24 hours of their arrival in Beirut, trading gunfire with militiamen and setting up checkpoints in an attempt to stop the fighting here.

title: FPA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: John Lehman's Navy
description: Secretary of the Army, Navy or Air Force is an imposing title. But Presidents often use the jobs for patronage, appointing people with little knowledge of military affairs. The services adeptly keep these civilian masters busy cutting ribbons and launching ships. John Lehman, retiring now after six years as Secretary of the Navy, is a startling exception to the rule of ineffectuality. For better or worse, the Navy will bear his mark for years to come.

title: GATT Meeting Urged
description: The United States, as expected, has requested a meeting of a special General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade committee on aeronautical affairs to discuss the United States-European Airbus dispute, a GATT spokeswoman said today. The request for a meeting on March 5-6 came in a letter to the GATT secretariat on Friday. The United States charges that the four European partners in the Airbus consortium, France, Britain, West Germany and Spain, subsidize the development costs of the group's civil jetliners and are competing unfairly with the Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.

title: TECHNOLOGY OPENS ANCIENT DOORS
description: ARCHEOLOGISTS, heeding the message of the magnetometer, dug into the rocky slope of Egypt's Valley of the Kings and uncovered steps carved out of the limestone. The steps descended to a stone portal and through that into a dark passage and to the discovery of a 3,300-year-old tomb that could yield fascinating treasures and new insights into the long reign of Ramses II.

title: HIGH-SCHOOL MARIJUANA USE STILL DECLINING, U.S. SURVEY SHOWS
description: Marijuana-smoking declined among high school seniors in the United States in 1986, but the number of these students who smoked cocaine increased, a national study reported yesterday.

title: The Press Office Shuffle
description: Several shifts have occurred in the White House press office, partly as a result of normal comings and goings, partly because of the arrival of the new Presidential spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater.

title: MILTON ROY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest periods include pre-tax provisions of $2.8 million for the quarter and $7.4 million for the year for losses associated with the divestiture of the company's Portland Valve Inc. subsidiary and the Image Analysis product line of the Analytical Products division, and for the dissolution of a Mexican joint venture DeSosisistemas S.A. de C.V. The prior year includes the results of operations of the Analyticl Products division since its acquisition in April 1985.

title: Hurricane Chief in New Role
description: Dr. Neil Frank, the director and energetic voice of the National Hurricane Center here since 1974, will soon switch from forecasting to broadcasting. Dr. Frank, who is 55 years old, said he had received a ''multiyear contract at a very attractive salary'' with KHOU-TV in Houston. He will start his new job early this summer, after the Atlantic hurricane season begins and when he becomes eligible to collect his pension for 30 years of Federal service, The Miami Herald reported Sunday.

title: IU INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After gains from discontinued operations of $360,000 for the quarter and $25,398,000 for the year; an extraordinary gain of $6,455,000 for the quarter and a gain of $1,787,000 from the effect of an accounting change for the year. The year also included a tax credit of $40,054,000. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $112, 032,000 for the quarter and $157,054,000 for the year. The latest year net includes a loss of $8.8 million from the sale of Agribusiness operations and a gain of $7.1 million from the sale of real estate and leases relating to 88 trucking terminals recorded in the fourth quarter. It also includes a gain of $21.6 million from the sale of the company's paper distribution subsidiary. The year-ago quarter and year results restated to segregate Agribusiness and paper distribution operations as discontinued segments of the corporation's business. The latest quarter and year results reflect a change in accounting for pensions.

title: LAST CHANCE TO SET UP I.R.A. UNDER OLD RULE
description: Come April 15, another annual tradition will largely be relegated to tax history: the rush to earn a last-minute tax deduction by putting money into an Individual Retirement Account.

title: D'Amato's Brother Quits Assembly Post
description: Armand P. D'Amato, a Republican Assemblyman from Nassau County since 1972, announced his resignation yesterday from the State Legislature.

title: PRICE/STERN/SLOAN PUBLISHRS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
'NO TALKING WAS NECESSARY'
description: While being treated for brain cancer, Dick Howser couldn't possibly manage the Kansas City Royals this season. Deep down, everybody knew that, especially the Royals, who had hired Billy Gardner as a standby successor to the 50-year-old manager who had been stricken midway through last season. But as spring training approached, the Royals displayed the dignity of granting Dick Howser the dignity he deserved, the dignity he had earned. If he realized that he was physically incapable of managing, it would be his decision, not theirs.

title: NEW RISKS IN MILITARY DEALS
description: At the Lockheed Corporation's Rye Canyon research complex in the mountains 30 miles north of here, technicians are busy completing a $58 million state-of-the-art flight simulator capable of creating a stunningly realistic environment for testing cockpit designs.

title: FORUM BEGINS TODAY ON AIDS TESTING
description: A national forum beginning here Tuesday will be confronting some of the most difficult and contentious issues posed by the AIDS epidemic, including how far society should go to identify carriers of the AIDS virus. The extraordinary meeting is sponsored by the Centers for Disease Control, the main Federal agency charged with tracking the spread of epidemics.

title: LA-Z-BOY CHAIR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest quarter income tax provision reflects the retroactive provisions of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 and other non-operating transactions, which increased net income by about 8 cents a share.

title: INSIDE
description: Pasternak Status Restored

title: Market Place; Single-Country Funds in Vogue
description: THE lure of investing in Asia has helped to send shares of two closed-end, single-country funds - Korea Fund and Taiwan Fund - to record highs.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1987
description: MARKETS Stock prices ended lower in a wild, unpredictable session as the market reacted to Brazil's decision to suspend payments on its foreign commercial debt. Traders said a sharp drop in stock index futures caused heavy program selling of stocks in early trading. The Dow Jones industrial average nearly recovered fully from a drop of almost 45 points, but a sharp reversal in the final hour left the blue-chip index 18.70 points lower, at 2,216.54. [ Page D1. ] Bank stocks tumbled amid growing investor concern about the earnings impact of the Brazilian move. [ D8. ] The dollar was firmer in light trading. Traders said they were unwilling so far to test the strength of a weekend accord by the United States and five of its allies. The nations pledged to ''cooperate closely'' to stabilize the dollar. In New York, gold dropped $3.25, to $402.50. [ D24. ] In the credit markets, interest rates fell on Treasury issues as a late rally pushed up prices. Dealers and traders remained uncertain on the outlook for the dollar. [ D21. ] Prices of crude oil slumped to their lowest levels since the OPEC production-restraint accord took effect Jan. 1. In New York futures trading, the price of West Texas Intermediate crude fell 56 cents, to $17.08 a barrel. [ D24. ] Kidder, Peabody was fined $300,000 by the New York Stock Exchange, which charged that the firm violated exchange rules and Federal regulations. According to the exchange, the violations included improperly computing net capital and filing inaccurate reports to the Government. [ D5. ] THE ECONOMY The U. S. and the Soviet Union resumed grain talks amid reports that Moscow had recently bought up to a million tons of American corn. Moscow's re-entry into the market would reaffirm a long-term bilateral grain agreement. Senior American officials were saying just a month ago that the pact had been virtually repudiated by the Russians. [ D6. ] The Supreme Court agreed to clarify the circumstances in which companies must publicly disclose merger talks. It will also hear a case about nuclear plants that exceed cost projections. [ D5. ] COMPANIES Rainier said it received two takeover proposals from large out-of-state banking companies. Rainier, the largest bank in the state of Washington, did not identify the suitors. But banking sources said the suitors were probably Security Pacific and First Bank System. Both bids involve exchanges of stock. [ D1. ] Sumner M. Redstone stepped up the bidding battle for Viacom. A company controlled by Mr. Redstone offered about $2.5 billion for just over 80 percent of Viacom, with the promise of a greater cash payout. The bid for the media concern exceeds a previous Redstone bid and a management buyout offer. [ D1. ] The parent of American Airlines ruled out a bid for Pan Am. AMR said, however, that it would be interested in acquiring assets of Pan Am if they were put on the market. [ D6. ] Elders IXL plans to acquire Carling O'Keefe, the Canadian brewer, for almost $300 million. [ D5. ] Conoco plans a $400 million project involving an offshore production platform in extremely deep waters. [ D5. ] INTERNATIONAL Argentina is seeking new money and concessions sufficient to insure 4 percent economic growth, officials said. The nation is preparing to open debt talks with private banks in New York. Argentina is doing considerably better than Brazil, which has suspended interest payments on debt to foreign commercial banks, but it faces such problems as inflation. [ D8. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The outlook for nonrefundable, discounted air fares remains in doubt. Passenger volume has risen strongly, but Christopher D. Bowers, a marketing executive at United, is uneasy about the loss of revenues. Talking Business. [ D2. ] Single-country funds are still in vogue after gaining immense popularity last year. Two of them - Korea Fund and Taiwan Fund - have reached record highs. Market Place. [ D10. ]

title: Chess: 3 Players Share First Prize In Los Angeles Tournament
description: The first prize in the American Open Tournament in Los Angeles was shared by Walter Browne of Berkeley, a six-time United States champion, Lev Alburt of New York, 1984 and 1985 United States champion, and Boris Gulko, a former Soviet champion before he emigrated to the West.

title: INFORMATION INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a $1,250,000 pre-tax gain from a lawsuit settlement. c-Includes a $1,520,000 pre-tax writedown.

title: THE STAGE: 'MARY STUART'
description: MARY, QUEEN OF SCOTS was executed 400 years ago this month and, to profane an old saw, she did not have a pretty life. And the real role of Elizabeth I of England in condemning her royal cousin to death is lost in the cloud of disinformation raised by the gang of lords, poets and historians (a kind of 16th-century National Security Council) who swirled like dust around the skirts of the virgin queen.

title: 2 PLAYWRIGHTS SHARE AWARD
description: The Susan Smith Blackburn Prize, which honors ''a woman who deserves recognition for having written a work of outstanding quality for the English-speaking theater'' was awarded last night to Ellen McLaughlin and Mary Gallagher - two American dramatists.

title: PRESTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Our Towns; One-Man Team: A Game Wrestler Gets Off the Mat

title: Q&A
description: Q. What causes infestations of lice? A. Basically, people get lice from other people, according to Dr. Stanley Green, an entomologist at Pennsylvania State University. Lice spread between people who share personal items and articles of clothing. Lice can infest anyone, regardless of their personal hygiene. They do not feed on dirt but rather on blood. Three types of lice feed on people: head lice, body lice, and crab or pubic lice. Head lice are spread from hats, hairbrushes, combs and wigs. Body lice are transmitted from clothing, particularly undergarments. Crab lice are spread through sexual contact but can also be contracted from toilet seats and bedding. Lice are a particular menace to people because the bites cause extreme discomfort and in some cases sleeplessness. A number of chemicals have proved effective in controlling lice. Among them, Dr. Green recommends Kwell cream, lotion or shampoo, pyrenate liquid or gel, Rid liquid, and Cuprex. Dr. Green said that washing clothing in hot water would kill body lice but that frequent showers alone would not kill head lice. Q. How does a levitated train remain off the ground? A. Experimental trains are levitated when powerful magnets on the railbed repel magnets of the same pole mounted on the trains, thereby keeping the trains from touching the railbed. Another set of magnets arranged along the railbed attracts magnets of the opposite pole on the train, pulling it forward. All of the magnets are made of superconductive materials that have no resistance to electricity, allowing them to create much higher magnetic fields. The Japanese Railway has produced an experimental train that travels at 250 miles an hour.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10, B4 President Reagan cannot remember if he approved in advance the first American-sanctioned arms shipment to Iran in 1985, said a senior official who is familiar with the President's testimony to the Tower Commission. Page A1 Limited immunity will be granted this week to some witnesses to compel their testimony on the Iran-contra affair, the chief counsel of the special Senate investigative committee said. A6 Alterations in N.S.C. documents were ordered by Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North who told his secretary to use a word processor to prevent the originals from being found by investigators, sources said. A6 Syrian troops went into action within 24 hours of their arrival in Beirut, trading gunfire with militiamen and setting up checkpoints in an attempt to stop the fighting here. A1 Iosif Z. Begun returned home to a jubilant Moscow welcome, pledging to devote himself to the cause of human rights in general and Jewish rights in particular. The Jewish rights advocate was freed from prison Friday. A1 U.S.-Soviet grain talks resumed amid reports in the market that Moscow recently purchased up to one million tons of American corn, reports that could not yet be confirmed. D6 Top U.S. scholars appealed to China to stop its crackdown on liberal intellectuals. In a letter to the Chinese Ambassador in Washington, 160 scholars said they were ''deeply concerned.'' A7 Bangkok is being challenged by the army chief who replaced Prem Tinsulanonda when he became Prime Minister. The army chief has made several recent speeches that have been sharply critical of Thailand's civilian politicians. A9 NATIONAL A12-23 The 1988 deficit target cannot be met without using gimmicks, the House and Senate Budget Committee chairmen said, indicating that they are ready to abandon the budget-balancing law's goal of $108 billion. A1 A new welfare plan was endorsed in large part by President Reagan. He supported the governors' idea to require welfare recipients to work, if able, in return for child care, medical insurance and other benefits. A20 Richard A. Gephardt is a candidate for President, he said as he called for an end to an era of ''selfishness'' and for stern measures on trade. The Missouri representative is the first major Democrat to announce his candidacy. A12 Some aliens have left the U.S. since the nation's new immigration law was signed by President Reagan on Nov. 6, and the law's sanctions for employers has forced tens of thousands of others to confront the possibility of doing so. A12 Mayoral candidates in Chicago will be chosen by voters today. The candidates then will slug it out in another six-week campaign leading up to the general election April 7. A12 Displays of sexually explicit books and other materials will be considered by the Supreme Court, which will decide whether states may ban such displays from places where children might be able to examine them. A23 Marijuana smoking declined in 1986 among high school seniors in the United States, but there was an increase in students tried cocaine in various forms, including crack, a national study reported. A21 A film director was questioned by prosecutors in an involuntary manslaughter trial involving ''Twilight Zone: The Movie'' about a meeting that he says took place before the helicopter crash in which three actors were killed. A18 Dance now has a corps of managers, the product of the boom of the 1970's and a highly competitive business. Many people says it is becoming more difficult and even foolish for artists to try to manage their own companies. C13 A new computer age is farther away than many would wish. The gap between the availability of state-of-the-art personal computer hardware and the development of the software that makes it tick is rapidly widening. D1 WASHINGTON TALK A22 Contra drug inquiry stirs interest E.P.A. chief shifts gears REGIONAL B1-4, B20 Confusion about AIDS is growing and disrupting New York City's work force. Employers and employees are reacting to AIDS victims in ways ranging from support and financial assistance to ostracism and outright dismissal. A1 Poor subway car performance has been noted on the R-68's, the newest cars in the city's fleet, and the Transit Authority is considering switching to a rival manufacturer for the final 200-car order. A1 The rites of passage of police officers in New York City are long and hard. Motivations and ability are constantly tested, and lives can be disrupted. As a result, one recruit said, he postponed his engagement. B1 30 protesters of an eviction were arrested for attempting to prevent a woman from being removed from a Columbia University apartment building. Columbia says it is trying to meet a growing need for housing. B1 A new way to pick towing companies to move disabled cars from highways and bridges was announced by the New York City Transportation Department in an effort to break a longtime arrangement. title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Hawks 112, 76ers 103: Dominique Wilkins scored 42 points - the sixth time he has had 40 or more this season - to pace Atlanta's home-court victory last night. The Hawks led throughout the second half and took control in the fourth period with a 17-7 run that stretched their lead to 100-87 with just under four minutes left. Wilkins scored 7 in the spurt and Mike McGee added 6. After David Wingate hit a 3-point basket with 10 minutes 30 seconds left in the game, the 76ers went 6:13 without a field goal before Charles Barkley scored on a rebound. The Sixers did have nine free throws during that period and went 38 of 46 from the free-throw line in the game. Andrew Toney led Philadelphia with 23 points, Barkley had 20 and Maurice Cheeks 17. McGee added 19 points and Glenn Rivers had 16 for the Hawks. (AP) Cavaliers 109, Bullets 105: In Richfield, Ohio, Tyrone Corbin scored 8 points during a 19-2 Cleveland run in the second quarter, and the Cavaliers survived a fourth-quarter Washington rally. The Bullets got 19 third-quarter points from Terry Catledge to pull to 10 points down, at 84-74, entering the fourth quarter. Washington used a full-court trap defense to whittle the deficit to 1 point -102-101 - with 1:43 to play, but the Bullets never caught up. Phil Hubbard led Cleveland with 21 points. Catledge finished with 27 to pace the Bullets. (AP) Rockets 124, Nuggets 108: Akeem Olajuwon scored 16 of his 31 points in the breakaway third quarter to lead Houston. Olajuwon led a 12-0 surge over a 2:55 span of the third quarter that broadened the Rockets' 6-point halftime lead to 82-67 with 5:04 remaining in the quarter. Jim Petersen scored a career-high 22 points and helped the Rockets pull away in the final minutes. Houston's Cedrick Maxwell scored his 10,000th career point with 2:36 to go in the first quarter. (AP) N.H.L. North Stars 4, Canadiens 3: In Montreal last night, Keith Acton capped a three-goal second period for Minnesota with the winning goal. After the North Stars' Brian MacLellan and the Canadiens' Claude Lemieux scored first-period goals, the North Stars jumped on Montreal's mistakes in the second. Brian Bellows was left unchecked and scored his 17th to start the rally. Brian Lawton snapped a loose puck into the net midway through the period, and Acton scored after an errant Montreal pass. Larry Robinson scored for the Canadiens early in the third and Lemieux added his second late in the period, but steady goaltending by Kari Takko, a rookie who faced 16 shots in the final period, kept the Canadiens from tying the game. (AP) TENNIS Keil Upsets Bassett: Kathrine Keil, ranked 122d in the world, scored the first upset of the International Players Championships in Key Biscayne, Fla., yesterday when she beat Carling Bassett of Canada, 4-6, 6-3, 6-3. Playing in the first match on the new stadium court at the International Tennis Center, Bassett took to a 5-1 lead before her game came apart. She won the first set, but lost her touch completely after leading by 2-0 in the second set. In other matches, Catherine Tanvier of France beat Petra Huber of Austria, 6-4, 5-7, 6-4, and Aaron Krickstein downed Matt Anger, 6-3, 3-6, 6-3, 6-2. (AP) HORSE RACING Aqueduct Card Put Off: Racing at Aqueduct was canceled because of the snow that hit the metropolitan area. Yesterday's entries will be used on Wednesday when racing resumes. Also on Wednesday and each day thereafter, post time for the first race will be 1 P.M., a half-hour later.

title: Canada-Venezuela Talks
description: Marcel Masse, Canada's Energy, Mines and Resources Minister, began talks this week with top Venezuelan oil officials to promote cooperation in oil matters. Mr. Masse's five-day visit, which began Sunday, is the first ministerial level contact in five years between this member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and Canada, an independent producer.

title: By It's in the Palm
description: Roy Face, the former Pittsburgh reliever, when asked to explain the difference between the forkball he threw two decades ago and the split-finger fastball Mike Scott throws today: ''The money.''

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: THE DELICATE ART OF OPERA SCHEDULING
description: The announcements last week of next year's seasons at the Metropolitan and New York City Operas reflect not only the delicate attempts of each company to balance finite resources against artistic responsibility, but also a renewed cooperation that in another field might raise the eyebrows of a finicky antitrust lawyer.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: MILLIONS of American women who are trying to prevent osteoporosis by increasing their calcium intake may be ignoring the most important cause of the disease: the decline of estrogens after menopause.

title: BRONX DROPOUT-PREVENTION PACT TO BE ENDED
description: New York City Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones plans to cancel a $300,000 dropout-prevention program contract with Touro College in the Bronx because few students received help, central school board officials said yesterday.

title: LOIRE VILLAGERS' QUIET NEIGHBORS: 2 FUGITIVES
description: The people of this single-belfry village, about a 90-minute drive from Paris, say that from time to time they saw Nathalie Menigon doing her shopping in town. But as the local butcher put it, nobody could have been expected to recognize her.

title: IN A NUTSHELL OR OUT, ADVICE ON SELECTING ALMONDS AND SUCH
description: IN the United States, it seems, people are infatuated with nuts - all kinds of them: almonds, peanuts, cashews, walnuts, hazelnuts, macadamia nuts, pine nuts and more. According to Richard Sullivan, a spokesman for the Association of Food Industries, a trade organization, Americans consume more than 500 million pounds of nuts each year.

title: CONTRIBUTIONS TO NEEDIEST SET A RECORD
description: With one week remaining in its 75th annual appeal, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has already received a record amount of contributions - $3,012,124.06. The previous record was $2,726,331.40, set in last year's campaign. The current appeal ends on March 3. Contributions came from the Lucy Foundation in Manhattan, $100; Julie and Eugene DeWitt of Manhattan, $250; Louise and Andrew Bergman of Manhattan, $1,000; D. Lesley Hill and Alan Stone of Manhattan, $100; the Related Management Corporation in Manhattan, $250; Julia and Loris Tjeknavorian of Manhattan, $100; Leslie Levy of White Plains, $36 in memory of her father, Samuel Bernstein; Connie and Jack Judson of Tenafly, N.J., $100 in memory of Marguerite Judson; the Paul Rapoport Charitable Trust in Manhattan, $125, and Amy and M. Anthony Van Daalen of Manhattan, $25 in memory of Frank Crocker.

title: KEY RATES
description: *Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for belwether issues.

title: TELEVIDEO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday about the Susan Smith Blackburn Prize for plays by women misattributed the winning works of the two recipients. Mary Gallagher wrote ''How to Say Goodbye''; Ellen McLaughlin wrote ''A Narrow Bed.''

title: CABARET: KRESTON AND LAHM
description: JAN WALLMAN'S Restaurant-Cabaret, which left Cornelia Street more than a year ago, reopened last week at 49 West 44th Street, with a pair of performers who frequently appeared in the downtown room - Judy Kreston and David Lahm. Although the new club is normally to offer a different performer every night of the week, Miss Kreston and Mr. Lahm will play for two weeks, through Saturday, as Miss Wallman's expression of appreciation to Miss Kreston, who organized a concert at Carnegie Hall a year ago to raise funds for the club's relocation.

title: CONCERT: ACADEMY OF ANCIENT MUSIC
description: A PERFECTLY unified attack of wind instruments is one of the trickier things to obtain in orchestral playing, and ''authentic'' period wind instruments are supposed to be especially difficult to play, so Christopher Hogwood and the Academy of Ancient Music scored something of a point with their very first sound in Avery Fisher Hall Sunday evening: a beautifully blended, clean, unanimous and well-tuned entry of flute, oboes and bassoon in the opening bar of Schubert's Fifth Symphony.

title: Moscow Invites Coppola To Head a Film Jury
description: Francis Ford Coppola, famous for such movies as ''Peggy Sue Got Married,'' ''The Godfather'' and ''Apocalypse Now,'' has been invited to head the jury for full-length features at the 15th international film festival in Moscow in July, the Tass press agency reported Monday.

title: Volcker Asks Renewed Debt Effort
description: The Federal Reserve chairman, Paul A. Volcker, said today that Government officials and bankers were ''suffering from battle fatigue'' in dealing with persistent third world debt problems and that the negotiation process needed to be reinvigorated.

title: GARDNER HOPING HOWSER RETURNS
description: In his first full day as the manager of the Kansas City Royals, during a time of the baseball year that usually seems carefree, Billy Gardner said he would be happy to see his predecessor, Dick Howser, return to the job he left on Monday.

title: WESTVACO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Class Experiment Injures 17
description: Seventeen junior high school students were injured today when a science experiment went awry, the authorities in this southern Illinois community said. A police dispatcher said a reaction between water and sodium was believed to have caused an explosion. Five students were admitted to nearby hospitals, most with face burns and eye problems and 12 were treated and released, according to hospital spokesmen.

title: TAKEOVER CLOUDS FUTURE FOR CARLING CHAIRMAN
description: Pierre Des Marais 2d has been a mayor, president of an aircraft company and, since last October, chairman of Carling O'Keefe Ltd. But his position at Canada's third-largest brewery has now become uncertain.

title: Inflation Up in Europe
description: Retail prices in the 12 countries of the European Community rose four-tenths of 1 percent in January, twice the rate of the previous three months, community officials said today. The inflation rate for the year ended Jan. 31 was 2.7 percent, the community said. It said that the highest inflation rates for January were recorded in Portugal, at 1.2 percent, and Greece, at 1.1 percent. The community said its inflation rate was usually high in January because of seasonal factors.

title: Jordan Gets 34 As Bulls Win
description: Michael Jordan scored 34 points while Dominique Wilkins managed only 22 tonight, and that was about the difference as the Chicago Bulls beat the Atlanta Hawks, 113-103.

title: Potvin Lost for 3 Weeks
description: Denis Potvin, who injured his left knee in a collision with a Montreal player Saturday at Nassau Coliseum, has sprained ligaments in the knee and will be unable to skate for at least three weeks. He will probably be lost to the club for the remainder of the regular season.

title: Bonn Accord On Tax Cuts
description: The three parties forming the West German coalition Government announced an agreement today on a tax revision package that would cut the highest income tax rate to 53 percent, from 56 percent.

title: Teflon and Power
description: Do not delude yourself, Reagan fans, that even a President deeply wounded by the scandal of the arms sales to Iran is ''finished'' or ''paralyzed,'' much less ''powerless.'' Mr. Reagan is still President, even if napping on the Oval Office couch.

title: Extend Train to Plane
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HOW HIGH THE MOON

title: DEAVER REPORTED TO GET A WARNING ABOUT INDICTMENT
description: Michael K. Deaver, the former White House deputy chief of staff and a close friend of President Reagan, has been warned that he must plead guilty to criminal charges or face indictment by a Federal grand jury, people with knowledge of the investigation said today.

title: PACERS FIND RIGHT REMEDY
description: The Dr. Jack Ramsay coaching cure-all that produced 785 victories in Philadelphia, Buffalo and Portland, appears to be putting the Indiana Pacers back on the road to respectability.

title: U.S. TO REPLACE TOP NATO COMMANDER
description: Defense Department officials said today that General Bernard W. Rogers would retire in June as Supreme Allied Commander of NATO forces in Europe and would be replaced by General John R. Galvin, now commander of United States forces in Latin America.

title: LETTERS
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Grievances Disturb Ueberroth
description: Commissioner Peter Ueberroth expressed concern yesterday about the growing number of grievances in baseball and threats of legal action against the club owners. But Tom Reich, a lawyer and player agent deeply involved in the ongoing free-agent dispute, suggested that the commissioner's concern was misplaced.

title: SOME WRITE-OFFS NOW HARDER
description: For years, many individuals have looked to the tax code for help in subsidizing some of their more costly personal possessions, such as luxury cars and home computers.

title: STAGE: PORTER SONGS IN 'GAY DIVORCE'
description: ''THE GAY DIVORCE,'' in 1932, was Fred Astaire's last Broadway show. Retitled ''The Gay Divorcee,'' it was the first film to co-star Astaire and Ginger Rogers as romantic partners. Our memories of the Cole Porter musical derive primarily from the movie, despite the fact that Hollywood excised all but one of the Porter songs. That song, however, was ''Night and Day.''

title: Article 560087 -- No Title
description: The Security Pacific Corporation won the bidding to acquire the Rainier Bancorporation of Seattle in one of the biggest mergers in banking history, the banks announced today.

title: Texas Flights Delayed By Computer Failure
description: A computer system monitoring flights in the Houston area failed today, causing scores of delays for almost three hours in southern Texas and New Orleans, the authorities said.

title: LAWS URGED TO PROTECT IDENTITIES IN AIDS TESTING
description: Top public health officials and civil liberties advocates voiced unanimity today on the need for strong legislation to protect those who take the AIDS test from discrimination and from unauthorized release of their names.

title: A Sonic Does Super
description: The 25 assists posted Monday night by Nate McMillan in the SuperSonics' victory over the Clippers tied an N.B.A. rookie record set 13 years back by Ernie DiGregorio. McMillan's total also ranks among the nine highest in league history. The eight others: Kevin Porter, Nets, vs. Houston, 2/24/78 29 Bob Cousy, Boston, vs. Minn., 2/27/59 28 Guy Rodgers, S.F., vs. St. L.,3/14/63 28 Geoff Huston, Cleve., vs. G.S., 1/27/82 27 Ernie DiGregorio, Buff., vs. Port., 1/1/74 25 Kevin Porter, Detroit, vs. Boston, 3/9/79 25 Kevin Porter, Detroit, vs. Phoenix, 4/1/79 25 Isiah Thomas, Det., vs. Dallas, 2/13/85 25

title: French TV Battle Grows as Rightist Wins Contract
description: A battle over political interference in French journalism intensified Monday when a business group dominated by a rightist press baron was awarded a television franchise that France's conservative Government took back from its original owners, accusing them of being Socialist sympathizers.

title: CHOICE FOR COMMUNITY MEDIATION POST IN JUSTICE DEPT. FAULTED
description: The leading White House candidate for director of the Justice Department's Community Relations Service has become the center of a dispute over his qualifications.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL COLLEGES: Providence vs. Seton Hall, 7 P.M. Syracuse vs. St. John's, 9:30 P.M., at Madison Square Garden (TV - ESPN, 7 P.M. Channel 9, 9 P.M. Radio - WNEW 1130, WSOU-FM 89.5, 7 P.M. WCBS 880, WNYE-FM 91.5, 9 P.M.) Kentucky at Georgia, MSG, 10 P.M., tape delay) HOCKEY RANGERS VS. MAPLE LEAFS, at Toronto, 7:35 P.M. (TV - MSG, 7:30P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:20P.M.) DEVILS VS. EDMONTON OILERS, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 7:30P.M. Radio - WMCA 570, 7:30P.M.) OTHER EVENTS HARNESS RACING: Roosevelt 7:30P.M. Meadowlands, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, midnight) TENNIS: Lipton Players International Championships, at Miami (TV - ESPN, 1 P.M.) THOROUGHBRED RACING: Aqueduct, 1 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 6:30 P.M. and midnight)

title: NORTH FILES SUIT THAT CHALLENGES IRAN PROSECUTOR
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North filed suit today against the special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair and Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, challenging the constitutionality of the Federal law permitting appointment of a special prosecutor.

title: LONGS DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
LIBYA'S A-BOMB EFFORT CITED
description: Libya sought to acquire the ability to produce nuclear weapons in 1981 negotiations with Edwin P. Wilson, a former Central Intelligence Agency official, and other arms dealers, according to a report made public today.

title: Sunny Side Up
description: It's been understood for some time that college baseball's power has gone South: The last 20 N.C.A.A. championships have all been won by Sun Belt teams from Florida to California, compared with eight titles by Northern teams the previous 20 years.

title: OFFICIALS DERIDE PROPOSAL ON NUCLEAR EVACUATIONS
description: Governor Cuomo of New York led a parade of governors, senators and representatives today in a blunt attack on a proposal that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission ease emergency evacuation standards at commercial power reactors.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: Deere & Company, the world's largest farm equipment maker, said today that it lost $192.6 million in the first quarter, largely because of a strike that lasted throughout the period. A year ago, Deere lost $26.9 million.

title: SARMA AND STRUDEL
description: THE Mesabi iron range of northeast Minnesota has its fair share of fast-food restaurants and streamlined supermarkets, but it also has a mother lode of ethnic-food traditions from at least 40 countries. At Mary's Cafe in Hibbing, a luncheonette with oilcloth on the tables and an old-fashioned counter, the Irish cook makes chicken soup with German dumplings, Yugoslav sarma (stuffed cabbage) and Cornish pasties. The Italian-owned Sunrise Bakery opened in 1913 to provide hard rolls for miners' lunch pails. Today, it sells ethnic breads - French, Italian, Russian, Finnish and Jewish as well as a Norwegian sweet bread called julekake, German stollen and a jellyroll-style pastry known in Yugoslavia as potica (pronounced po-TEE-tsa).

title: Oversight Is Faulted In Aid for the Elderly
description: New York City's Department for the Aging exercised ''poor oversight'' of $32 million in contracts for services provided for the elderly in 1983-84, according to a State Comptroller's audit released yesterday.

title: Market Place; Analysts Like G.E. Prospects
description: SHARES of the General Electric Company took a bumpy ride last week, first hitting a record high of $103.75 and then finishing at $101 for a net loss of $2.50. The sudden downturn reflected investor concern that G.E. might face liabilities stemming from its 80 percent ownership of Kidder, Peabody & Company amid allegations of insider-trading improprieties by the investment firm acquired in 1986.

title: SYNTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $15.4 million for the quarter and 6 months.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: ROCKET BUILDER CUTS FEE ON SHUTTLE UNITS, AVERTING SUIT BY U.S.
description: The space agency and the builder of the booster rocket whose failure destroyed the space shuttle Challenger have reached an agreement under which the builder will reduce its fees by $10 million and take no profit from $409 million in work needed to fix future rockets, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

title: Local Bacterium Makes Good
description: In their quest for a new antibiotic, researchers at the Squibb Institute for Medical Research sifted through soil samples taken from around the world. They tested millions of bacteria, looking for just the right one to combat serious hospital-acquired infections, such as pneumonia and septicemia, caused by gram-negative organisms. Such organisms are especially dangerous because they adapt quickly to drugs.

title: UNLIKELY PATH TO TEACHING THAI CUISINE
description: ''BEING Thai, you normally learn how to cook,'' said Chalie Amatyakul, a 44-year-old former hotel manager, travel agent and interpreter with a degree in international studies. But Mr. Chalie has gone far beyond this country's culinary norm to become director of the Thai Cooking School at the prestigious Oriental Hotel here.

title: HOUSE ORDERS E.P.A. TO DISTRIBUTE ASBESTOS FUNDS
description: The House of Representatives unanimously approved a resolution today that would force the Enivronmental Protection Agency to stick to a rigid timetable for distributing funds to schools to clean up asbestos.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO EASE PRESSURE FOR EXTRADITION IN HIJACKING
description: A senior West German official says the United States is now putting little pressure on Bonn to extradite a suspect in the hijacking of an American airliner to Beirut in 1985.

title: U.S. NOTIFIES SWISS OF IRAN CONNECTION OF FLORIDA CONCERN
description: The United States Justice Department has widened its probe of money transfers through Switzerland in the Iran-contra arms controversy to 21 persons and companies, including a Florida-based concern that may have received profits from the arms sales and transferred them to rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government, Swiss officials said today.

title: PANEL ON THE HOMELESS URGES DOUBLING-UP IN APARTMENTS
description: The growth in the number of homeless families in New York City could be limited if state and Federal policies were changed to encourage single adults and families to share apartments, a mayoral commission said yesterday.

title: QUEENS GROUP ASKS KOCH TO BACK ITS PLANS TO EASE RACIAL TENSIONS
description: A South Queens coalition of blacks and whites, formed after the Howard Beach attack in December, asked Mayor Koch last night for his personal support and for city financing for its proposed programs to ease racial tensions.

title: A Fan in New Hampshire
description: With the 1988 New Hampshire primary just a year away, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. has enlisted a prominent resident of the state in his undeclared Presidential campaign.

title: LEAR PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $11,633,106 for the quarter and $82,714,884 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $36,140,382 for the quarter and $44,263,476 for the year, and an extraordinary gain of $508,000 for the quarter and year. The latest fourth quarter loss includes a $45 million gain from settlement of a contract dispute, a $25 million writeoff of goodwill, an $11 million writedown of various assets and a $7 million provision for potential liabilities.

title: I.M.F.-LIKE PACT SEEN FOR BRAZIL
description: Regional bankers and others familiar with the Brazilian debt crisis said yesterday that they expected a compromise to emerge under which Brazil would agree to a package of reforms similar to an International Monetary Fund economic program. In return, the banks would issue new loans and restructure old ones.

title: WINE TALK
description: ONLY 15 years ago, Louis M. Martini, a Napa Valley winery, marketed California's first post-Prohibition bottle of wine labeled ''merlot.'' Today, 174 American wineries make merlot. At least 110 are in California. Success of this nature and on this scale shows how a kind of second-class wine can move into the first class under the guidance of an artful wine maker.

title: West Virginia Upsets Temple
description: Tyrone Shaw scored 16 points and West Virginia used an effective box-and-one defense to upset Temple, 64-61, in an Atlantic-10 Conference game, snapping the Owls' 15-game winning streak.

title: Comings and Goings
description: In voting by the Boxing Writers Association of America, Mike Tyson, the undefeated World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, has been named winner of the Edward J. Neil Memorial award as the 1986 fighter of the year. . . . Vinny Pazienza, undefeated in 18 pro bouts, will meet the International Boxing Federation lightweight champion, Greg Haugen, at the Providence Civic Center in May, according to Lou Duva, Pazienza's manager.

title: DAVID'S 'FAREWELL' SELLS FOR A RECORD FOR THE ARTIST
description: A painting by the 19th-century French artist Jacques Louis David was auctioned yesterday at Sotheby's for a record price for the artist. Both the seller and the buyer were anonymous.

title: HIS STOCK IN TRADE IS COOKS AND CLOUT
description: WHEN Jonathan Waxman, the celebrated young California chef, came to New York in 1983 to open what is now Jams restaurant, the first person he went to see for advice on staffing was a rubicund and genial former butcher named Marc Sarrazin. When Daniel Boulud and Patrice Boely, who are today the chefs at Le Cirque and the Polo, respectively, arrived in Manhattan four years ago, their first business lunch was with Marc Sarrazin. In 1985 when Pierre Baran, then a sous chef at Le Cirque, yearned to run his own kitchen, he privately conveyed his wishes to Marc Sarrazin. A week later Mr. Baran was approached by the owners of Le Cygne, where he is now the chef.

title: WASHINGTON IS VICTOR IN CHICAGO MAYORAL PRIMARY
description: Mayor Harold Washington, this city's first black Mayor, became the first mayoral incumbent Tuesday to win renomination in Chicago in the last decade.

title: BENNY CARTER NEARS 80
description: BENNY CARTER arrived in New York from California last Wednesday to start a week of rehearsals for the retrospective concert he will play with the American Jazz Orchestra tomorrow evening at 8 in the Great Hall of Cooper Union. The concert is part of a continuing celebration of his 80th birthday, which falls on Aug. 8.

title: LAWYER IS SAID TO TIE GARCIA TO BRIBE CASE
description: A San Juan lawyer has told investigators that he funneled more than $4,000 a month in bribes to the wife of Representative Robert Garcia on behalf of a South Bronx military contractor, according to officials familiar with the inquiry.

title: EXPERT ENDORSES VISITATION BAN FOR WHITEHEAD
description: A mental-health expert retained by Baby M's legal guardian changed his mind and recommended today ending the legal parental rights of Mary Beth Whitehead, a key issue in the custody hearing.

title: A JERSEY OFFICE COMPLEX DESIGNED FOR SMALL TENANTS
description: Over the past decade northeastern Bergen County, in New Jersey, has become a center for the development of new office complexes. Most of the new facilities, however, have been built for large or medium-size local service companies or for the regional operations of such major companies as Minolta, Laura Ashley and I.B.M.

title: Frankensteins by Accident?
description: LEAD: Last summer, the White House set forth broad Federal guidelines for the testing of new products from genetic engineering. But the testing of these man-made organisms still poses a threat to the environment. Moreover, the newly discovered ability to manipulate genes poses grave dangers to society unless we can agree to proper limits on its application.

title: Zawoluk Sentenced
description: Bob Zawoluk, the former St. John's basketball all-American who pleaded guilty last month to charges of attempted arson and criminal mischief, was sentenced by Nassau County Court Judge Raymond Harrington to five years' probation with the condition that he get in-patient treatment for alcohol problems. The judge released him into the custody of an official of the Central Labor Council of New York rehabiliation center. Zawoluk went on a rampage after being dismissed from a job as a salesman for a car dealership, burning four of the dealer's cars and smashing 19 other cars in the mistaken belief that the dealer owned them. . . . A preliminary hearing for May 8 has been set in Las Vegas for Lloyd Daniels, the Nevada-Las Vegas basketball recruit from New York City who was one of 60 people arrested on Feb. 9 on drug charges. Daniels, 19, is charged with attempting to possess cocaine. . . . Brian Tribble, the man accused of supplying the cocaine that killed the former University of Maryland basketball star Len Bias last June 19, surrendered to Hyattsville Police yesterday on reckless-driving charges for an incident Feb. 17. Tribble, who is to stand trial in April in connection with Bias's death, was released to his attorney's custody pending a court date on charges of speeding, reckless driving, fleeing a police officer and turning off lights to avoid detection.

title: FARRAR STRAUS IS ADDING A ROYALTY
description: In a break with publishing tradition, Farrar, Straus & Giroux will pay authors a royalty on copies of their books that are remaindered - that is, sold at a fraction of their original price after their regular sales life is exhausted.

title: INSIDER-LAW ACTION ASKED
description: A Senate subcommittee asked representatives of the American Bar Association today to propose new laws banning the practice of trading on confidential corporate information.

title: ROHR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
Change of Emphasis
description: Saying it cannot keep pace with the growing cost of maintaining Division I athletic programs, Utica College in upstate New York will drop all of its National Collegiate Athletic Association programs to Division III in 1988, President Lansing Baker said yesterday. Utica will be unclassified during the 1987-1988 academic year. With 1,550 students, Utica has been one of the smallest Division I schools since joining the N.C.A.A. six years ago. In an attempt to build a nationally recognized men's basketball program, the school hired Larry Costello, who coached the Milwaukee Bucks to a National Basketball Association championship in 1971.

title: Even a Snowfall Has Something to Teach
description: To the Editor:

title: ESCAPED PRISONER CAPTURED
description: An inmate who rode out of the maximum security prison here on a movie crew's truck was recaptured in South Dakota, officials said today. The prisoner, Daniel F. Duane, 32 years old, was arrested Monday night in Rapid City, S.D., by a trooper who noticed that a tail light was out on the automobile he was driving, officials said. Mr. Duane escaped Saturday while a crew was filming the movie 'Weeds,' starring Nick Nolte, at the Stateville Correctional Center. He was among 250 inmates who worked as extras for the movie.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEATED BY BLUES
description: Bernie Federko set up two goals to lift the St. Louis Blues to their third consecutive victory, a 3-2 decision tonight over the Islanders.

title: Klaus Barbie Trial in May
description: Klaus Barbie, the Gestapo chief of Nazi-occupied Lyons, will go on trial May 11 on charges of crimes against humanity, court officials said today. Mr. Barbie, 73 years old, is accused of having deported hundreds of Jews and Resistance members to death camps.

title: MANDATORY TESTS FOR AIDS OPPOSED AT HEALTH PARLEY
description: A consensus appeared to be emerging today against widespread mandatory testing for infection with the AIDS virus as public health officials began an extraordinary two-day meeting to discuss ways to curb the spread of the deadly viral disease.

title: DANCE: ROSALIND NEWMAN
description: The worlds of turn-of-the-century immigrants to America and the urban disaffiliated of the 1980's would seem to be very far apart. But they seemed oddly interconnected in two very different works presented by the Rosalind Newman and Dancers last night, in the opening performance of the company's weeklong season at the Joyce Theater.

title: 'VIDEO VISITS' HELP ELDERLY AND KIN
description: AS a visitor pushed buttons to start the video cassette recorder in her room at a nursing home here, Dora Florio watched with anticipation. When the image of her daughter popped onto the screen, Mrs. Florio smiled and said softly, ''They love me so.''

title: Eyeing China's Market
description: American manufacturers eager to open up new markets for their goods in China are organizing a campaign to persuade Congress that nations like China that are experimenting with deviation from a controlled economy are not receiving fair treatment under existing United States trade laws.

title: SIZING UP DOLE, HIS STYLE AND HIS CHANCES FOR '88
description: In a move that virtually assures a full-fledged Presidential drive by Bob Dole, the Kansas Republican plans to announce next week the formation of an ''exploratory committee'' for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1988.

title: MATTINGLY DISCOUNTS PRESSURE
description: Taylor Mattingly was getting anxious to leave. He tugged gently at his father's ear, shifted from one lap to the other, then finally won his freedom and was placed on the clubhouse floor amid a crowd of reporters. But he did not stray far.

title: LETTERS
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION Anna Quindlen's column on surrogate motherhood moved me deeply -not only because of her always splendid and, to me, hauntingly familiar expression of the sentiments of professionals-turned-mothers, but because she is able to relate her own obviously profound feelings about her children to those of parents who come to their roles in less traditional ways.

title: Teacher Shot Outside School
description: Two men with handguns fired at a teacher today, hitting her with one shot, just after she had brought her 4-year-old daughter to nursery school, the police said. The authorities said they had no motive or witnesses. The teacher, Leonette Taylor-Coleman, 38 years old, of New Rochelle, was admitted to New Rochelle Hospital with a bullet wound to the buttocks and was in stable condition, said a spokesman for the hospital, Frank Hall.

title: Florida Boy Getting New Liver
description: Surgeons were transplanting a liver tonight into 7-year-old Ronnie DeSillers of Florida, who received an outpouring of support from Americans after money for his transplant was stolen.

title: Hallwood's Chief Revives Companies
description: Anthony J. Gumbiner, the 42-year-old chairman and chief executive of the Hallwood Group Inc., has spent 13 years working to reverse the sliding fortunes of distressed companies. His company is now focusing on financial institutions.

title: TURNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Revenue represents gross earnings.

title: Murdoch TV Stake
description: The News Corporation, which recently sold its television holdings in Australia to buy the nation's biggest media concern, plans to reacquire a minority stake in the properties. The News Corporation, an international media company based here and controlled by the publisher Rupert Murdoch, sold its TV interests and other assets to the Westfield Capital Corporation of Sydney for about $555 million. Under the proposed transaction announced by Westfield's chairman, Frank Lowy, the News Corporation would acquire 15 percent of a new company formed to operate the TV stations. Terms were not disclosed.

title: OFFICIAL SEEKING JAILS TO REPLACE SPOFFORD CENTER
description: New York City's Department of Juvenile Justice plans to replace the city's only jail for juvenile offenders with two new jails, one in the Bronx and the other in Brooklyn, the department's Commissioner said yesterday.

title: Advertising; Companies' TV Buying Discussed
description: WITHOUT an atmosphere of communication and trust and without the delegation of enough authority to get the job done, an advertiser company intent on setting up its own network TV buying operation might as well forget the whole thing.

title: LETTERS
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: TRANSFORM LOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: MID-FEBRUARY AUTO SALES FELL 25.8%
description: Sales of new domestically assembled cars fell 25.8 percent in the middle 10 days of February despite rebates, subsidized financing and other incentives, the nation's eight major manufacturers reported today.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Lakers 97, Suns 93: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, who towers above all other players in total points scored, recorded a first last night: he sank a 3-point field goal. Abdul-Jabbar, who finished with 19 points, grabbed a long rebound in front of the Lakers' bench and connected on his 3-pointer with 55 seconds left in the first half. The 7-2 center, who surpassed the 36,000-point mark last week, had missed 14 previous career attempts from 3-point range. Wilt Chamberlain is second to Abdul-Jabbar in career points, with 31,419. (AP) Nuggets 134, Rockets 105: For his league-leading 12th time this season, Lafayette Lever of the Nuggets had double figures in points (18), rebounds (12) and assists (13). Alex English scored 29 for the Nuggets and Darrell Walker added 23. The Nuggets, who lost in Houston Monday night, overcame an 8-point deficit in the second quarter with 15 consecutive points. (AP) Bucks 120, Pacers 114: Ricky Pierce scored 4 points in a 8-2 Milwaukee run that ended the second overtime as the Bucks, playing at home, outlasted the Indiana Pacers. Tied at 112-112, Paul Pressey of the Bucks hit two free throws with 2:28 to go. Following a steal by Milwaukee's Jack Sikma, Pierce hit a jump shot with 1:53 left and Sikma added a baseline jumper at the 1:25 mark for a 118-112 Milwaukee lead. Pierce added a final jumper with 44 seconds left as Milwaukee won for the eighth time in nine games. Terry Cummings led the Bucks with 24 points. Herb Williams led Indiana with 28 points but did not score in the fourth quarter or either overtime period. (AP) Jazz 133, Sonics 103:Karl Malone had a career-high 38 points and 13 rebounds, and John Stockton had 13 assists for the Jazz. Stockton also scored 17 points, including 9 of 10 from free throws. Dale Ellis led Seattle with 26 points. (AP) N.H.L. Penguins 5, Oilers 2: Dan Quinn assisted on two of four first-period goals for the Penguins in Pittsburgh. The Penguins scored on four of their first 10 shots against Andy Moog, then did not score again until 8 minutes 4 seconds remained. John Chabot and Craig Simpson each scored a goal before Quinn assisted on scores by Warren Young and Dan Frawley. (AP) Nordiques 5, North Stars 4: Risto Siltanen had two goals and two assists, and Anton Stastny scored once and added three assists, including his career 300th, for Quebec, playing at home. Four Quebec goals came on the power-play as the Nordiques went 4 for 5 with a player advantage. (AP) Capitals 8, Red Wings 2: David Jensen had his first two-goal game in the league, and a dozen of his teammates got on the scoresheet as well for the Capitals. The Capitals, playing at home, got off to a quick start as Bob Gould scored on Washington's first shot of the game and Dave Christian on the second. Washington added goals by Mike Ridley and Jensen before the period ended. Jensen scored his second of the night early in the second period for a 6-0 lead. (AP) TENNIS Three Top Players Advance: Ivan Lendl, Stefan Edberg and Mats Wilander, three of the top five seeded players in the men's bracket, easily defeated their first-round opponents at the International Players Championships in Key Biscayne, Fla., yesterday.
