Lendl, ranked No. 1 in the world, stormed past Chile's Ricardo Acuna, 6-2, 6-3, 6-2, while Edberg and Wilander, seeded second and fifth, respectively, also posted straight-set victories. Third-seeded Steffi Graf of West Germany and No. 7 Zina Garrison advanced in singles matches. Graf, winner of last week's Virginia Slims of Florida, trounced Manon Bollegraf of the Netherlands, 6-1, 6-1. Garrison stopped Kris Kinney, 6-4, 6-1. Night matches were suspeneded because of rain. (AP)

title: U.S. Budget Deficit Declines
description: The Federal Government ran a $2.17 billion budget deficit in January, the smallest monthly deficit total since June, the Treasury Department said today.

title: SLOPES NOW MORE FUN, AND SAFER
description: AIDED by computer simulations that give a better understanding of what happens when a ski pounds against the snow, engineers are making significant improvements in the design of ski equipment. The advances can be found in virtually every piece of gear from boots and bindings to poles and gloves.

title: A Worthy Cause
description: Greg Louganis, holder of 41 United States diving titles and a double gold medalist at the 1984 Olympic Games, was named yesterday as the winner of the Jesse Owens International Trophy, then said he had begun an educational crusade against alcoholism, an addiction that he began to fight in himself 3 1/2 years ago. The 27-year-old Louganis said that since beginning his recovery from alcholism in November 1983, he has been speaking at high schools and junior high schools in southern California, ''not preaching, but trying to give them positive alternatives.'' The award, presented annually to the athlete who ''best personifies excellence in athletic performance and sincere cooperation and understanding among peoples of all nations,'' went last year to Said Aouita of Morocco, a long-distance runner. In worldwide balloting by a special panel, Louganis received 91 points to 70 for Jackie Joyner-Kersee, the record-setting heptathlon competitor, who was named winner of the American Amateur Union's Sullivan Award as the No. 1 amateur athlete Monday night.

title: Drug Stocks Help Dow Advance 6.74, to 2,223.28
description: With drug stocks providing a pocket of strength in an otherwise sloppy market, Wall Street was able to move ahead slightly yesterday although trading volume was much lighter.

title: DEERE & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said the latest quarter results were affected unfavorably by a lower effective tax rate which reflects its inability to recognize tax- loss carryforwards. However, the losses in the latest and year-ago quarters were reduced as a result of the planned reduction of inventories valued on a LIFO basis. This benefit amounted to $5.3 million, after taxes, in the latest quarter, compared with $7.5 million a year earlier. The company said the year-ago quarter loss was restated to $26.9 million from the previously reported loss of $34.4 million because of a change in pension accounting rules.

title: American Express
description: The American Express Credit Company is offering $200 million of 7 3/4 percent notes due in 1997 at a price of 99.80 to yield 7.778 percent through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers. Underwriters said the issue was rated Aa-2 by Moody's and AA by S.&P., yielding six-tenths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: ''MR. ED'' is back on television, indicating that, as most middle-of-the-road antiques shops suggest, Americans cannot discriminate between things worth saving and things that simply exist. ''The Donna Reed Show'' is on, too, and ''My Three Sons,'' and those dopey folks from ''Gilligan's Island.'' There's ''Leave It to Beaver'' and ''The Beverly Hillbillies'' and even ''Lassie,'' whose plaintive theme song leaves my husband all mushy around the edges.

title: SHULTZ AND DODD IN SHARP EXCHANGE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz accused a member of Congress today of undermining the Reagan Administration's policy in Central America by trying to run his ''own foreign policy.''

title: NUCOR CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in June 1986.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A listing of Westminster Kennel Club dog show results in Sports Pages on Feb. 11 misidentified the winner for the Rhodesian Ridegeback breed. The winning dog was Ch. Mshindaji's Special K.

title: RANGERS STOP LOSING STREAK
description: In Phil's Paradise the last few days were not supposed to have happened. Everything was supposed to remain cheerful and the Rangers were supposed to remain an item.

title: 'GRACELAND' ALBUM WINS GRAMMY
description: Paul Simon's controversial ''Graceland'' was named album of the year at the Grammy Awards ceremony here tonight. ''That's What Friends Are For,'' the upbeat ballad that raised $750,000 for AIDS research, won three Grammys, and Steve Winwood won record of the year.

title: JUDGE DECLINES TO DISBAND JURY STUDYING BIAGGI
description: A Federal judge yesterday refused to disband a grand jury that is investigating Meade H. Esposito, the retired Brooklyn Democratic leader, and Representative Mario Biaggi.

title: OPERA: MARTTI TALVELA IN MET 'BORIS GODUNOV'
description: MARTTI TALVELA first appeared in the title role of the Metropolitan Opera's ''Boris Godunov'' 13 years ago and immediately established himself as the Boris of his generation. The tall and hulking Finnish basso returned to the role of the demented Czar Monday night in the opera's first performance of the season, giving no sign of wanting to abdicate his title. Mr. Talvela's absorbing portrayal, though lacking in the final imperial touch of the greatest Borises, served as the centerpiece of a solid, occasionally exciting performance in which 11 members of the cast were singing their parts for the first time with this company.

title: TRIBALISM VS. MODERNISM: AT DEATH, A SHOWDOWN
description: In life, S. M. Otieno was a classically successful modern African.

title: 2 Restored Botticellis Are Unveiled in Florence
description: The Uffizi Gallery has unveiled two newly restored 15th-century masterpieces by Botticelli - his ''Annunciation'' and ''The Birth of Venus.''

title: BEAR STEARNS COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-Includes a one-time charge, taken in the second quarter, for the loss resulting from the in-substance defeasance of $60 million of 13 percent notes due 1989. Share earnings are fully diluted and do not reflect the 5 percent stock dividend declared yesterday. The company said results for the 9-month period ended Jan. 31, 1986 include the results of Bear, Stearns & Co., the predecessor partnership, restated as if the business of the partnership had been conducted as a corporation for the 6-month period ended Oct. 28, 1985. The Bear Stearns Companies succeeded to the business of the predecessor partnership and became a publicly held company on Oct. 29, 1985.

title: PARKING BUREAU: STRIDES AFTER TURMOIL
description: Scarred by scandal and barely functioning a year ago, the Parking Violations Bureau lay at the heart of New York City's biggest corruption inquiry in a generation.

title: Freely Associating
description: Excerpts from remarks by Robert K. Gray of the Washington office of the public relations firm of Hill & Knowlton to the second annual Public Relations/Communications Conference, with the American Society of Association Executives as host in Washington Feb. 17:

title: ELEANOR B. STEVENSON
description: Eleanor B. Stevenson, who, with her husband, Willaim E. Stevenson, received the Bronze Star for their work with the American Red Cross in World War II in Europe, died Sunday at her home in Shell Point Village in Fort Myers, Fla. She was 84 years old Mrs. Stevenson went with her husband when he volunteered to established wartime Red cross units in European theaters of war. She was director of Red Cross Clubmobiles in the Mediterranean theater and after the war she wrote a book, ''I Knew Your Soldier.'' Mr. Stevenson died in 1985.

title: TOASTED RAVIOLI, THE SECRET OF ST. LOUIS
description: WHAT spicy chicken wings are to Buffalo, toasted ravioli is to St. Louis. While Buffalo wings quickly became a national fad, the St. Louis culinary creation has - so far - remained a local passion.

title: TRANS-NATIONAL LEASING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: School District Bonds in Colorado
description: Cherry Creek School District No. 5 of Arapahoe County in Colorado is tentatively offering $113.1 million of refunding bonds through underwriters led by Kirchner, Moore & Company.

title: IKE VERN
description: Ike Vern, a freelance magazine photographer and documentary film maker, died Monday after heart surgery at the Texas Heart Institute of St. Luke's Hospital in Houston. He was 70 years old and lived in Orlando, Fla. He was a former resident of Manhattan.

title: REDMEN A KEY CLUB TO BIG EAST FINISH
description: St. John's and Syracuse have never really needed a reason to go at each other in basketball. Each meeting between the intrastate rivals, it seems, has been for a share of first or second place in the Big East Conference. Syracuse has won four of the last seven meetings, and the average score of those seven games has been 76-73, with three decisions determined in overtime.

title: GOVERNORS VOTE A PLAN LINKING WELFARE TO WORK
description: With only one dissenting vote, the nation's governors today approved an ambitious plan to overhaul the largest welfare program and require every able-bodied recipient to work or get training.

title: Revlon Group, Germaine Monteil
description: The Revlon Group is negotiating to acquire Germaine Monteil, a small, privately owned cosmetics company, and has expressed an interest in buying parts of Charles of the Ritz. Yves Saint Laurent, the fashion house, said earlier this week that it might sell some of the businesses of Charles of the Ritz, including that company's cosmetics line.

title: Tax Cut Turnaround in Albany
description: With unexpected alacrity, New York taxpayers prepaid state taxes for which they had not been billed, apparenty hoping to maximize Federal deductions before the new tax law takes effect. The surge of money led the Governor to his second startling decision of last week: to reverse field and support a new tax cut. That was a sound move, politically and fiscally.

title: LOS ANGELES DISTRICT TO VOTE ON HIRING MORE POLICE
description: Residents of the city's crime-ridden South Central area are being given a chance to vote on whether to raise property taxes in the district to pay for more police protection.

title: 23 BY RAY WILLIAMS WASTED BY THE NETS
description: The Nets lost again tonight, and Chuck Daly, the coach of the Detroit Pistons coach, explained why.

title: EDWIN McARTHUR, CONDUCTOR AND ACCOMPANIST, DIES AT 79
description: Edwin McArthur, a conductor, accompanist, singing coach, composer and biographer of Kirsten Flagstad, died yesterday at his studio in Manhattan, immediately after giving a lesson. He was 79 years old and lived in Hackensack, N.J.

title: BETTE MIDLER ON BARBARA WALTERS SPECIAL
description: TONIGHT'S edition of ''The Barbara Walters Special'' -on ABC at 10 o'clock - is the 37th in a series of periodic celebrity interviews. Perhaps inevitably, even as Ms. Walters seems to become younger and more glamorous with each passing year, even as the ratings remain strong, the format has gone soft in the center and dull around the edges. There are, after all, only so many celebrities worth interviewing. The rest are gobbled up quickly in assembly-line machines such as ''Entertainment Tonight'' and ''Life Styles of the Rich and Famous.'' How much do even their more devoted fans want to know about performers hustling for a career?

title: TREASRUY BILL RATES HIGHER
description: Interest rates on Treasury bills were mostly higher yesterday as uncertainty over rates again caused a flight to shorter-term maturities.

title: REPRESSION LESS OBVIOUS NOW IN POLAND
description: Two leading Solidarity figures recently wrote a letter of complaint to Poland's Interior Minister.

title: SEND NIXON TO ARMS CONTROL TALKS AS TOP NEGOTIATOR, CUOMO URGES
description: Governor Cuomo, exercising his new freedom from Presidential politics, today proposed making former President Richard M. Nixon the nation's chief negotiator on arms control. At the same time, he offered some chilly observations about Gary Hart, the front-runner for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: 2 New Witnesses Tell of Racial Clashes
description: Detectives investigating a series of confrontations between white and black youths in Bayside, Queens, early Sunday were told by two new witnesses that one of the blacks had fired a gun during one of the incidents, a police spokesman said yesterday.

title: A DAY AFTER CARDINAL'S APPEAL, BOMBING SUSPECT SURRENDERS
description: A man wanted in the bombings of several New York City abortion clinics surrendered quietly to Federal agents in lower Manhattan yesterday, less than 24 hours after John Cardinal O'Connor delivered a televised plea for him to turn himself in.

title: SUMMATIONS END IN 17-MONTH-OLD 'PIZZA CONNECTION' TRIAL
description: Summations ended yesterday in the ''pizza connection'' drug case, setting the stage for jury deliberations to begin today in one of the longest criminal trials in Federal court history.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'd like to ask one question of everybody. Everybody who can remember what they were doing on Aug. 8, 1985, raise your hand.'' - President Reagan [ A1:6. ]

title: HUGE STELLAR EXPLOSION DETECTED CLOSE ENOUGH FOR CAREFUL STUDY
description: Astronomers reported yesterday that the gigantic explosion of a massive star has occurred much closer to the Earth than any observed since 1604. Because such nearby supernovas are so rare, this event is likely to have a dramatic effect on scientific understanding of how stars, galaxies and the entire universe have evolved through the ages.

title: 2 RULINGS FOR DEFENDANTS REVERSED BY HIGH COURT
description: The Supreme Court ruled 6 to 3 today that police officers who searched the wrong man's apartment in a multiunit dwelling had not violated the Constitution because their mistake was reasonable.

title: TV TAKING A FRANK LOOK AT BETTY FORD'S DRAMA
description: Most television biographies of famous people have turned out to be unabashed glorifications of their subjects. ''The Betty Ford Story,'' which is to be shown Monday on ABC with Gena Rowlands starring as Mrs. Ford, is something of an exception. While it is clearly sympathetic to the former First Lady, the main focus of the two-hour television drama is her alcoholism and drug dependency during the years after Gerald Ford lost the Presidential election of 1976.

title: A DOWNWARD TREND FOR JUVENILE CRIME
description: To the Editor:

title: Slain Diplomat's Wife Says French Ignored Lead
description: The wife of an American military attache who was slain here in 1982 testified today that she had given the French police a lead in the case that they failed to pursue.

title: AT ELLIS ISLAND, GLOOMY RUIN STARTS TO SHINE
description: Across the harbor's choppy, cobalt waters, the old United States Immigration Station at Ellis Island is beginning to gleam again, beginning to glisten.

title: CAESARS WORLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes minority interest of $391,000 and $1,184,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes minority interest of $162,000 for the quarter and $899,000 for the 6 months.

title: EDISON BROTHERS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Include an after-tax gain of $7.4 million from the purchase of annuity contracts for vested former employees and a loss of $1.5 million. c-Includes net of $5.3 million from discontinued operations.

title: Tigers Sign Evans
description: The Tigers' first baseman and designated hitter, Darrell Evans, who became a free agent when he was not tendered an offer by the Tigers by Dec. 20, signed a one-year contract with Detroit yesterday. Evans, 39, earned $760,000 last season in the final year of a three-year contract. He batted .241 with a team-high 29 home runs and 85 runs batted in 151 games. . . . The Minnesota Twins have invited Billy Sample, a free-agent outfielder and a lifetime .272 hitter who was not tendered a contract by the Atlanta Braves, to spring training as a non-rostered player. Sample, 31, will not be offered a contract unless he makes the team.

title: CUTTING FAT WITHOUT ADMITTING TO IT
description: The old-fashioned definition of military discipline holds that when the commander says to jump, the soldier jumps -and asks how high on the way up.

title: The President Can't Remember
description: Ten weeks ago, White House aides bridled at the joke about the Iran-contra crisis: What did the President forget and when did he forget it? As things have turned out, it was no joke.

title: Japan's Economy Slow
description: Japan's economy is likely to stay sluggish in coming months as the high value of the yen dampens business, according to Government figures issued today. The leading economic indicator for December was 50, up from 41.7 in November. Above 50 implies a pickup; below 50 implies a slowdown.

title: Do Unto Pretoria as We Do Unto Warsaw
description: To the Editor:

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: LETTER from our friend the Daydreamer:

title: 'STAR WARS' SETUP LIKELY BY '94, WEINBERGER SAYS
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that a crucial ''Star Wars'' test, scheduled in 1988, could lead to deployment of a space-based defense against ballistic missiles as early as 1994.

title: High Court On Liability
description: The Supreme Court today limited, very slightly, the jurisdiction of state courts to impose liability in personal injury suits on foreign manufacturers whose components are used in products sold here.

title: About New York; A New Approach To Fitness Chic: Learning to Walk
description: ''So,'' one customer lacing up a pair of Cushionaire-soled Step-Flex shoes said to another, ''how long have you been walking?'' And the second one replied, ''Oh, about a month.''

title: SHOREWOOD PACKAGING reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary charges of $46,000 and $175,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; these extraordinary items, net of taxes, relate to the writeoff of $349,000 of deferred debt acquisition costs as a result of pre-payment of certain long-term debt. c-Net loss Figures for 1986 periods are pro forma, and the pro forma presentation for these periods includes the operations of the company's Canadian and United Kingdom subsidiaries as if they were acquired at the beginning of the period, as well as pro forma adjustments for the inclusion of interest expense related to the indebtedness incurred in connection with the acquisitions and the reorganization of the company in 1985, where applicable. Latest and year-ago quarters comprise 13-week results, and 1986 9-month figures comprise a 40-week period, compared to a 39-week period for the 9 months of 1987.

title: TRAINER IS RELUCTANT ABOUT DERBY
description: The Flamingo Stakes here Saturday begins the countdown to the Kentucky Derby nine weeks later, which means that the syrupy sentiment surrounding that race will begin to flow: Owners will remember the night the old mare delivered the little foal who has grown into a Derby dream, and trainers will recall that magical morning workout when their colt first flashed the glimmer of brilliance that could win him the coveted roses at Churchill Downs.

title: Robertson Davies Wins 1987 Literature Medal
description: The Canadian novelist Robertson Davies has been chosen the recipient of the 1987 Medal of Honor for Literature. The National Arts Club presented the medal to Mr. Davies yesterday at a dinner at its headquarters, 15 Gramercy Park South.

title: Arab-American Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: 911 Service Restored To Phone Customers
description: New York Telephone yesterday restored 911 service to 28,000 Brooklyn customers who had been unable to dial the emergency number for almost a week, a company spokesman said.

title: WILIAM T. FAIRBOURN
description: William T. Fairbourn, who retired from the Marines with the rank of major general and then spoke out against the nuclear arms race, died Saturday. He was 72 years old.

title: DANCE: ATLANTA BALLET
description: THE Atlanta Ballet has been a welcome resident company of the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College for three years. But the program the company presented on Saturday night was a disturbing one. The dearth of interesting new ballet choreographers is by now a commonplace, so the program's bland tone wasn't so terribly unusual. But there was also a look of bland uniformity to the performers, with the exception of a few of the male dancers.

title: Risks of the Road
description: To the Editor:

title: RECREATION BARGE WITH POOL AND CAFE IS URGED
description: Departing from its more usual role of critic, the Parks Council, a civic watchdog organization, has been developing ideas of its own for New York City's waterfront, and yesterday it unveiled an unusual one: floating a recreation center, complete with 10-lane swimming pool and open-air cafe, on a barge somewhere along the water's edge.

title: STONE CONTAINER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company attributed the sharp increase in earnings to strong demand for its products; it said another factor was the inclusion of results of operations of Champion International Corp., which it acquired in February 1986.

title: More Matters Than the Money Markets
description: Key finance ministers met in the opulent chambers of the Louvre last weekend and agreed to the minimum. They pledged to juice up the West German and Japanese economies and cut the American budget deficit. On the diving dollar, which prompted the meeting, they concluded that it has dropped enough for now, and that it's time for a breather.

title: Moslem Terrorists Are Different
description: To the Editor:

title: Della Femina Clarifies Lifestyles Resignation
description: Although Jerry Della Femina, chairman of Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, announced last Friday that he had resigned the Ansell Americas account for Lifestyles condoms, he said yesterday that he actually delivered the letter of resignation last Wednesday. And he offered a copy of his letter dated ''18 February'' to prove it. He said he was concerned lest anyone think he quit a day after the brand had been assigned to Margeotes/Fertitta & Weiss, which said it was informed of the appointment on Thursday.

title: A PHYSICIST AND RESEARCHER
description: Dr. George H. Vineyard, a former director of the Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton, L.I., died of cancer Saturday at University Hospital in Stony brook, L.I. He was 66 years old and lived in Bellport, L.I.

title: UNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said that revenue for the year-ago quarter and 6 months includes sales of $1,750,000 and $3,776,000, respectively, from the company's Canadian operations, sold Jan. 31, 1986.

title: Economic Scene; Dollar Accord: A Timely Step
description: AS it turned out, after all the delays, the meeting of the Group of Five to Seven in Paris -it turned out to be a Group of Six because Italy walked out - was well timed. For, without the Paris agreement, the decision of Brazil last Friday to suspend interest payments on medium- and long-term foreign debt could have caused the dollar to go into a free fall.

title: BLAZERS BURN PATH DOWN KNICK LANE
description: For three quarters last night in Madison Square Garden, the Portland Trail Blazers paraded freely down the Knicks' lane.

title: Treasury Plans Dealer Rules
description: The Treasury Department has proposed new rules requiring all entities that deal solely in Government securities to register with the Government and meet minimum capital standards. The proposed rules would restrict dealers in their handling of customers' securities and set new record-keeping and reporting requirements.

title: SURROGATES OFTEN IMPROVISE BIRTH PACTS
description: While the Baby M trial in New Jersey has focused attention on the practice of surrogate motherhood, across the country cases are emerging in which surrogate arrangements have been improvised between friends and relatives, or by homosexual couples and single people, with no supervision by doctors or lawyers.

title: Regan's Mismanagement Style
description: LEAD: One of the most interesting sideshows in the Iran-contra circus has been the elaborate fandango involving the White House chief of staff, Donald T. Regan. But whether Mr. Regan stays or goes, and whether the scandal worsens or fades, we should not lose sight of the flaw in his style of management that contributed to this disaster.

title: LETTERS
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION In her column on adoption and surrogacy, Anna Quindlen seems to understand the pain of childlessness.

title: CONCERT: CHAMBER SOCIETY
description: THE highlight of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center's Sunday night concert at Alice Tully Hall was a delightful performance of two of Dvorak's ''Legends for Piano Four-Hands'' by Richard Goode and Charles Wadsworth. These are charming works, full of good tunes and expert part writing. Mr. Goode and Mr. Wadsworth conveyed the sheer fun of sitting down at a keyboard with a friend or colleague and playing in tandem.

title: NICARAGUA EXTENDING THE STATE OF EMERGENCY
description: The Sandinista-controlled National Assembly voted Monday to extend the five-year-old state of emergency for another year.

title: Bridge: 2 Players, Old and Young, Are Mourned in New York
description: The tournament bridge players of New York City mourned doubly this week, for one of their most senior and one of their most junior.

title: PS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $1,777,000 from a change in accounting principle for the quarter and year, and the quarter includes a charge of $1,104,000 and the year is after a gain of $1,934,000, both from minority interests. c-Net income and includes charges of $1,632,000 for the quarter and $1,972,000 for the year from minority interests.

title: PACIFIC SOUTHWEST AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $6,374,000 for the quarter and $12,072,000 for the year, and a gain of $1,777,000 from a change in accounting for the quarter and year. c-After tax credits of $10,510,000 for the quarter and $5,352,000 for the year. Pacific Southwest is about 83 percent owned by PS Group Inc.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
CITRUS TO EASE THE COLD
description: LEAD: THE world is tundra, and anything that starts the flow of warm-weather thoughts is welcome. Citrus fruits, whirling around as on a slot machine, may creep into your mind. Hold that nutritional thought; oranges and grapefruit are decent sources of vitamin C and potassium, and are easy to consume in many forms.

title: Let Early-Childhood Funds Flow From One Tap
description: To the Editor:

title: Hanes Picks Arnell Agency
description: Arnell/Bickford Associates, which already handles the $1.5 million Donna Karan fashion account, has picked up an additional $1 million in business from Hanes, which is starting a new Donna Karan hosiery line under a licensing agreement. While Arnell/Bickford is

title: 51 SITES OF PCB IN 12 STATES NAMED BY HOUSTON CONCERN
description: A Houston-based gas pipeline company today released the names of 51 sites in 12 states where it has acknowledged burying toxic PCB's. The largest number, 17, are in southern Pennsylvania.

title: Litton Acquisition
description: In its second deal in two days, Litton Industries said it had agreed to acquire the Lamb Technicon Corporation for more than $100 million in stock. Lamb, which is based in Warren, Mich is a leading supplier of manufacturing systems for the domestic and international automotive industry.

title: South Korea Seizes 13 And Tries to Stop Rally
description: The Government moved against its opponents on two fronts today, announcing the arrests of 13 purported campus revolutionaries and later seeking to block an indoor rally by the mainstream opposition.

title: KELLOGG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring loss of $11.5 million resulting from the purchase and redemption of the company's $150 million of 12 1/4 percent debentures, due Feb. 15, 2015.

title: On the Road to '88
description: The 1988 Presidential bandwagons are rolling along into the future without taking time to fill in the potholes or examine the ''wrong way'' signs of the past.

title: MARKET FOR BANK BONDS HALTS AGAIN IN LONDON
description: A multibillion-dollar market in bank bonds ground to a halt today as sellers found that there were no willing buyers for their securities. The trading collapse left some of the world's largest banks and financial institutions stuck with large quantities of unsellable bonds, dealers said.

title: Two Men Sentenced In Bird Stuffing Case
description: A retired Long Island taxidermist and his son who had been found in possession of 293 stuffed birds, including a bald eagle and a peregrine falcon, were sentenced yesterday to prison for violating a Federal statute intended to protect migratory birds.

title: NEW PRESSES SPUR DETROIT PRODUCTIVITY
description: ABOUT half-a-dozen men stand around anxiously eyeing their watches as three enormous sets of stamping dies slide out of the press line and another group of dies advances on a conveyor to take their place. As a problem with automated transfer arms causes the minutes to tick on, brows knit in frustration. High-speed die changes are essential to achieving the productivity improvements the automobile industry needs to meet competition from overseas.

title: Tennessee Issue's Top Yield Is 6.05%
description: In the competitive market yesterday, Tennessee offered a $113 million tax-exempt issue of general obligation bonds through Salomon Brothers.

title: PANEL SAID TO FIND REAGAN WAS TOLD OF IRAN DEALINGS
description: The Tower Commission has concluded that President Reagan, far from being remote from the Administration's Iran arms dealings, was briefed on them regularly as they took place, according to officials familiar with the commission's report.

title: CROSSLAND GAMBLING ON RATES
description: At a time when many thrift institutions are scrambling to make themselves less vulnerable to the vagaries of the interest rate cycle, the Brooklyn-based Crossland Savings Bank still wants to gamble.

title: The U.N. Today: Feb. 25, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Outer Space Scientific and Technical Subcommittee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Commission on International Trade Law - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Committee on Nongovernmental Organizations - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Statistical Commission - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Newell to Purchase Anchor Hocking
description: The Newell Company, a maker of homeware and hardware products, said today that it had agreed to acquire the Anchor Hocking Corporation for $338.2 million, ending a five-month long takeover battle.

title: CYANIDE IN FOOD FORCES JERSEYAN TO BE TREATED
description: A man from Mercer County became sick and was briefly hospitalized Monday after drinking half-and-half tainted with cyanide, the State Health Department announced today. He had bought the cartonat a local supermarket.

title: Shaping Chateaubriand
description: THE most tender cuts of beef come from the long, roughly cylindrical tenderloin, and right in the center of that strip is what is known as the chateaubriand -the most prized cut of all. This piece of beef, which usually weighs about two pounds and can feed three to four diners, is traditionally cooked on a hot pan with just a little oil. The following technique molds the beef into a classic chateaubriand shape. STEP 1: Have a butcher cut a chateaubriand section from the tenderloin, or, if you buy the whole strip, remove the center third. The thinner end of the fillet is usually sliced into single-portion steaks, called tournedos; the thicker end can be sliced into individual steaks called filet mignon. STEP 2: Lay the chateaubriand on the center of a towel, with one of the flat sides down so that it stands like a cylinder. STEP 3: Fold the towel as illustrated. Using a meat pounder or heavy skillet, pound it to compress the cylinder into a thick pucklike shape. Saute the chateaubriand in oil for about 15 minutes for medium rare. Slice it on the bias and serve with a bearnaise sauce or chateau sauce.

title: NEW PAPERS IN LONDON STIR AN OLD-SYLE WAR
description: A city that started the week with one afternoon newspaper had three today. As a result, it found itself witnessing an old-fashioned circulation war complete with fireworks along the Thames, dancing publishers and exchanges of insults that were wickedly inventive even by British standards.

title: William M. Masland, Pilot on Historic Flight
description: William M. Masland, a former pilot who in 1943 commanded the first round-the-world flight by a commercial aircraft, died of a heart attack Friday at his home in Manhasset, L.I. He was 79 years old.

title: Greyhound Union Approves Contract
description: The Greyhound Corporation said the union representing workers at its Greyhound Lines Inc. had approved a new three-year labor contract with the investor group that is acquiring the bus company. The agreement, reached last month, reduces the mileage rate paid to Greyhound's 8,000 drivers and eliminates many work rules the investor group said prevented drivers from driving more miles.

title: INSIDE
description: Law Vague on Birth Pacts In the absence of laws, surrogate motherhood arrangements are being improvised with no supervision by doctors or lawyers. Page B2. Welfare Plan Backed The nation's governors overwhelmingly approved a plan to require every able-bodied welfare recipient to work or get training. Page A17.

title: CHINA WATCHERS SAY TURMOIL CUT DENG'S POWER
description: Some China watchers based in Hong Kong have concluded that Deng Xiaoping, China's senior leader, has been severely weakened in the recent political turmoil in Beijing and may no longer exercise real power.

title: CORN SALE TO SOVIET STIRS LITTLE HOPE OF ANY MORE
description: American and Soviet officials confirmed yesterday that the Soviet Union had bought 39.3 million bushels of corn, its first purchase of American grain since last summer.

title: Justice Diluted in Argentina
description: Some of the most notorious torturers and commanders of Argentina's ''dirty war'' have now been granted amnesty. A historic process of legal accountability begun on the basis of clear principle has been transformed into an unsatisfying and potentially dangerous mess. President Raul Alfonsin, who deserves most of the credit for that noble beginning, also deserves most of the responsibility for this unseemly ''punto final,'' or full stop.

title: THE TRUE SPORTSMAN
description: When Don Mattingly had the nerve to win his arbitration case against the Yankees, George Steinbrenner, The True Sportsman, fumed and snorted.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Weekend of Wine

title: A Fan in the Pentagon
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver North, the former National Security Council aide, attracts Government investigators on one side and ardent admirers on the other. To the latter group, add Robert Sims, the chief Pentagon spokesman, who formerly worked at the council, who was asked Tuesday what he thought of Mr. North. ''A great American, action-oriented,'' Mr. Sims replied. This firmly placed the official in the same camp with the former White House Director of Communications, Patrick J. Buchanan, who wrote last December, ''Ollie North is an American hero.''

title: Go, Army!
description: Always eager to bestow some international glitter on his race, Fred Lebow, director of the New York City Marathon, traveled abroad a few weeks back and, at the very least, came up with his fair share of brass. While taking in the Manila Marathon, Lebow was approached by Gen. Fidel V. Ramos, the Chief of Staff of the Philippine armed forces. A runner himself - he's competed at distances up to 25 kilometers - the 58-year-old General Ramos was pacing the marathoners on a motorcycle when he asked Lebow about the possibility of partaking in the five-borough race next Nov. 1. ''I told him, 'Sure,' '' Lebow said. The general, of course, has lately been much preoccupied by the need to deal with his nation's insurgents, but the results of one reconnaissance suggest that he should be able to free himself long enough for the New York run. While in Manila, Lebow went jogging and, he pronounced the other day, ''felt safer there than in New York.''

title: MUSIC: GOBIN AND VALADEZ SING AT WEILL
description: MERLE GOBIN and Richard Valadez, a soprano-tenor duo from Trinidad, have appreciable natural voices and occupy the concert platform with the comfort of people who have been there before. Their program at Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall Saturday afternoon demonstrated a lively curiosity about repertory (Baroque opera to American musicals) and languages (Russian was one of them), though it also left the impression that a further level of vocal and musical cultivation would be necessary if they are aiming at the professional mainstream of opera and concert.

title: Mission to Start Liquidation
description: A state Superior Court judge today approved the liquidation of the Mission Insurance Company and four subsidiaries. The decision ends a long struggle by the State Department of Insurance to keep the units afloat and shifts the burden of about 13,000 liability claims to a state guaranty fund.

title: Student Dance Group To Appear in Venice
description: Jacques d'Amboise is to appear with nine New York schoolchildren and one New York police officer next Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday at the Carnival of Venice at Teatro del Ridotto. The Venice carnival is dedicated to the City of New York this year. The children and police officer, Ed Deacy, have studied with the National Dance Institute, founded in 1976 by Mr. d'Amboise, a former New York City Ballet principal dancer, in an attempt to bring the arts into children's education.

title: The Color of Money
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d, fresh from an international meeting in Paris on currency exchange, appeared on Capitol Hill Tuesday sporting a vivid emerald green necktie. He told reporters he had adopted the fashion note because ''it's the color of the dollar.'' Economic analysts interpreted this as evidence that the Secretary, accused in the past of ''talking down the dollar,'' had committed himself to strengthening its position on world markets.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ONE recent evening a neighbor arrived in my kitchen after I had finished the advance preparation for cooking a chateaubriand, which was on my work counter uncooked. A puzzled look crossed my friend's face and he asked, ''What cut of beef is that?'' It occurred to me at that moment that probably not one person in a hundred would be able to identify a chateaubriand, perhaps the most coveted piece of beef of all. The appearance is deceptive.

title: WITNESS SAYS HE AGREED TO 'PAY OFF' TUROFF IN TAXI METER SCHEME
description: A New York City landlord testified yesterday that he agreed to pay Jay L. Turoff, the former head of the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission, a percentage of his shares in an electronic taxi meter company in exchange for Mr. Turoff mandating the use of such meters by all taxis in the city.

title: FOSSILS ARE FASHIONABLE
description: 1.Links to the Past Kris Perry is inspired by fossils she picks up on the beach in Florida, and she uses them in her designs for cuff links and money clips. Some of the fossils are trilobites, invertebrate insects that lived 550 million years ago. The cuff links, in sterling silver, cost $29.50 and can be found at Gorsart Clothes, 9 Murray Street, between Church Street and Broadway. 2.Whimsy in Leather Diana Weiss, a New York City painter and artisan who creates leather goods decorated with fanciful animals, has created an entertaining leather bag. In front, a Dalmatian sits on the grass under the stars, and the nighttime scene continues on the sides and back. The long shoulder strap is red on one side and blue on the other. The bag, which costs $228, is part of a collection that includes wallets, belts and other bags. In Bags and Belts on the first floor at Henri Bendel, 10 West 57th Street. 3.Folk-Art Rattle An old-fashioned wooden baby's rattle, made of hand-finished cherrywood, comes from the studio of Mossy Creek Woodworks in Wesley, Ark. The rattle is lightweight, smooth and easy for a baby to grasp. The price is $13 in the Museum of American Folk Art shop, 62 West 50th Street. 4.For Bold Framing Need a very special frame for a very special picture? Designed by Richard Meier and made in Italy is a bold, architecturally inspired statement in silver plating. Conran's in the Citicorp building, 160 East 54th Street, sells it for $225.

title: QUESTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a first quarter writedown of $9,762,000 on the value of oil and gas properties.

title: JOHNSON, MAGADAN TO BATTLE AT THIRD
description: If you're looking for work this spring, forget the Mets. They are so set that only one position has even the semblance of any competition, and that is third base, the traditional revolving door through which 80 men have come and gone.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE OLD DEVILS. By Kingsley Amis. 294 pages. Summit Books. $16.95.

title: This Mitt Calls For a Big Hand
description: Jesse Orosco's magical flying glove, the one that seemingly defied gravity and never came down after the Met reliever flung it into the air in triumph at the conclusion of both the league playoffs and the World Series last year, is enchanted after all.

title: NOW ON CD'S, FIRST 4 BEATLES ALBUMS
description: Beginning tomorrow, baby-boomers can use their favorite audio gadget - the compact-disk player -for their favorite music, the Beatles.

title: A Tribute to Humphrey
description: In the 15 years that William Connell was chief aide to Hubert H. Humphrey, the assistant's daughter, Carey, had occasion to watch the voluble Senator and later Vice President extensively. Now Carey Connell Sutton is an actress, and she bases a character in her one-woman show on recollections of Mr. Humphrey.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 The President was briefed regularly on the Administration's Iran arms dealings as they took place, the special Presidential commission examining the Iran-contra affair has concluded, sources say. Page A1 Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North filed suit against the special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair and Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, challenging the constitutionality of the law under which the prosecutor was appointed. A1 Syrian troops killed 22 Shiites in hand-to-hand combat and 3 Druse militiamen in West Beirut, police and hospital authorities said. But the Shiite group said that only 18 of its fighters had been killed. A1 Two captured French terrorists, objects of one of France's most intense police manhunts, managed to live quietly and undetected for three years among unsuspicious villagers in the Loire valley. A1 Interference in French journalism is at issue because a rightist business group has won a TV franchise that the Government took back from its original owners, saying they were Socialist sympathizers. A7 A top NATO official will retire, the Defense Department said. Gen. Ber- nard W. Rogers, the Supreme Allied Commander of NATO forces in Europe, will be replaced in June by Gen. John R. Galvin, now commander of forces in Latin America. A3 U.S. policy has been undermined in Central America, said George P. Shultz, by a member of Congress who is trying to run his ''own foreign policy.'' Mr. Shultz was referring to Senator Christopher J. Dodd. A3 Repression in post-Solidarity Poland has become less obvious, as Government authorities try simultaneously to limit potentially incendiary debate and to avoid any possible cause celebre. A12 China's senior leader may be weaker as a result of the recent political turmoil in Beijing, said some China-watchers in Hong Kong, who said Den Xiaoping may no longer exercise real power. A12 NATIONAL A13-18, B6, B9 A meeting on curbing AIDS' spread began in Atlanta that was intended to explore expanded uses of the blood test for AIDS. But a consensus appeared to be emerging against widespread mandatory testing. A1 A stellar explosion closer to Earth than any observed since 1640 is being studied, astronomers reported. This supernova may significantly increase understanding of how they come about. A1 Harold Washington won renomination as the Democratic candidate for Mayor in Chicago. Mr. Washington, the city's first black Mayor, defeated former Mayor Jane M. Byrne. A1 Governors approved a welfare plan that would turn its largest program, Aid to Families with Dependent Children, into one that would require work or job training from recipients in exchange for aid. A17 A plan to ease evacuation standards at nuclear power plants was sharply attacked by Governor Cuomo and other elected officials at a Nuclear Regulatory Commission hearing in Washington. A14 Mr. Cuomo proposed Richard Nixon as the nation's next chief arms control negotiator, saying that he thought Mr. Nixon could command respect. He also had some chilly observations about Gary Hart. A17 Toxic dumping locales in 12 states were identified by a Houston-based gas pipeline company that has acknowledged burying PCB's in possible violation of Federal law. Seventeen sites are in Pennsylvania. A14 Fighting crime in Los Angeles is the aim of a proposal that will go on the ballot June 2 in the city's South Central area on paying higher property taxes to hire more police in the district. A14 A mistaken search was reasonable and thus did not violate the Constitution, the Supreme Court ruled, because police officers armed with a warrant who searched the wrong man's apartment in a multi-unit dwelling were understandably confused. B6 'Video visits' to the elderly are being used by nursing homes to supplement personal visits. The concept was recently recognized by the American Association of Homes for the Aging as a significant innovation. C1 Better designs for ski gear, from boots and bindings to poles and gloves, are resulting from computer simulations that give a better understanding of what happens when a ski pounds against the snow. D8 One of the biggest banking mergers in history was announced as the Security Pacific Corporation of Los Angeles won the bidding to acquire the Rainier Bancorporation of Seattle. D1 Deaver warned to plead guilty or face indictment A1 WASHINGTON TALK A16 Sizing Up Dole Cuts at Pentagon Capital Reading REGIONAL B1-4 The restoration at Ellis Island is about halfway through and it is beginning to make the old United States Immigration Station gleam again. The inside of Registry Hall resembles a barrel-vaulted ice castle. B1 The Parking Violations Bureau, which lay at the heart of New York City's biggest corruption inquiry in a generation, has emerged from its darkest days with new programs and improving morale. B1 Surrogate-birth arrangements are increasing nationwide. They have been improvised between friends and relatives, or by homosexual couples and single people, with no supervision by doctors or lawyers. B2 An agreement to pay Jay L. Turoff was described by a witness, who said the former head of the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission got a percentage of the witness's shares in an electronic taxi meter company in exchange for Mr. Turoff's mandating the use of the meters. B3 Plans for next year's opera seasons underscore the different problems and ambitions of the Metropolitan and New York City Operas. Both are trying to balance finite resources against artistic responsibility. C19 NEEDIEST CASES D23

title: Should We Give Money to Everyone Who Begs for a Handout?
description: To the Editor:

title: SQUIBB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $3 million and $13.1 million for the quarter and year, respectively, a gain of $187.6 million on the disposal of discontinued operations and an extraordinary charge of $68 million, both items for both periods. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $4.6 million and $8.9 million for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: THE New York City Street
description: Tree Consortium is accepting registrants for its spring courses on tree maintenance and pruning. More than 1,200 ''citizen pruners'' have completed the $20 six-session course, which is given in every borough and leads to a Parks Department certificate. For information, write the Consortium at 3 West 29th Street, New York 10001, or call 212-679-4481.

title: LAC MINERALS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After special gains of $500,000 for the quarter and $4.5 million for the year. c-Net loss Results are in Canadian currency.

title: AMERICAN BANKERS INSURNCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $1,497,000, or 11 cents a share, for the quarter and $9,285,000, or 72 cents a share, for the year. c-Includes capital gains of $830,000, or 7 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,227,000, or 20 cents a share, for the year.

title: DISTRICT 65 BECOMES UNIT OF THE U.A.W.
description: District 65, a United Automobile Workers affiliate since 1981, became a full-fledged department of the international union yesterday and will lead a U.A.W. campaign to enlist white-collar workers across the nation.

title: NOTRE DAME UPSETS DEPAUL
description: Donald Royal scored a game-high 22 points, including 10 of 11 free throws, to lead unranked Notre Dame to a 73-62 upset of DePaul tonight. DePaul was ranked fourth in The Associated Press poll this week.

title: MOORE CORP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $5,298,000 for the quarter and $13,383,000 for the year, and a loss on the sale of discontinued operations of $16.5 million for the quarter and year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $5,602,000 for the quarter and $15,580,000 for the year.

title: Man Held in Assault On Blacks in Queens
description: A 20-year-old Manhattan man was arrested last night and charged with having been part of a group of whites that the police say attacked and chased a group of black youths in this area of Queens early Sunday morning.

title: BEIRUT SHIITE ACCUSES SYRIA OF MASSACRE
description: A leading Shiite fundamentalist clergymen charged today that Syrian troops had massacred fighters belonging to his group, the pro-Iranian Party of God.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is now well-established that government bodies, including courts, may constitutionally employ racial classificiations essential to remedy unlawful treatment of racial or ethnic groups subject to discrimination.'' Justice William J. Brennan Jr. [ A22:5. ]

title: Should We Give Money to Everyone Who Begs for a Handout?
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday about the discovery of a supernova misstated the distance to the exploding star. The supernova is 50,000 parsecs, or 163,000 light years, from Earth.

title: NAVIGATORS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net realized investment gains of $46,000 for the quarter and $306,000 for the year. c-After net realized investment gains of $139,000 for the quarter and $136,000 for the year.

title: ARGENTINA TO FREEZE PAY, PRICES
description: The Argentine Government announced a four-month freeze on prices and salaries tonight, saying it needed a ''more serene climate'' in which to carry out structural changes in the economy.

title: GORBACHEV CANDID ABOUT OPPOSITION
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in his most candid acknowledgment of opposition to his policies, sought today to assure critics that ''democratization'' would not produce disarray in Soviet society.

title: BRAZIL FREEZES $15 BILLION IN BANK CREDITS
description: Brazil has effectively frozen $15 billion in short-term credits from commercial banks.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Discoveries column in The Living Section yesterday gave an incorrect price for cuff links at Gorsart Clothes. They are $100.

title: Driver Accused of Murder
description: A truck driver accused of deliberately driving his rig into a tavern, killing a woman and injuring 18 people, was charged today with murder and 42 other counts. The driver, Kenneth W. Metzler, 33 years old, the authorities said, drove his vehicle at nearly 50 miles an hour into the Benchwarmer Pub and Eatery on Saturday. Maxine Vittorio, who was celebrating her 39th wedding anniversary, was killed. Mr. Metzler's girlfriend works at the lounge.

title: No Health Threat Seen In Jersey Cyanide Case
description: The cyanide found in half-and-half sold in an Acme supermarket in Lawrenceville was not the result of tampering and did not pose a health threat, the State Health Department said today.

title: Bally Purchase Is Approved
description: New Jersey's Casino Control Commission today approved, by a vote of 5 to 0, the $440 million purchase of the Golden Nugget casino in Atlantic City by the Bally Manufacturing Corporation, but a shareholder suit to be heard in Federal District Court Thursday will seek to block it.

title: Winner Is Endorsed
description: Democratic Presidential candidates, faced with a quandary over how to unify the party's urban white and black supporters, today took the course of party loyalty and endorsed Mr. Washington for re-election.

title: Health Plan for Elderly Doesn't Go Far Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: KOCH GETS PERSONNEL REPORT ON POLICE
description: A special mayoral committee, issuing its final report, yesterday recommended extensive changes in the way the New York City Police Department recruits, trains, promotes and manages its 28,000 officers.

title: JUDGE BARS INDICTMENT OF DEAVER TO MULL CONSTITUTIONAL CHALLENGE
description: A special prosecutor said today that he would ask a Federal grand jury to indict Michael K. Deaver, the former White House deputy chief of staff, on four counts of perjury. But a Federal district judge temporarily barred any indictments after Mr. Deaver's lawyers challenged the constitutionality of the law authorizing appointment of special prosecutors.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Britain Blocks Sale Of Sugar Refiner
description: The British Government today blocked two companies' attempts to acquire British Sugar P.L.C., ending a long-running battle for the company between Gruppo Ferruzzi, Italy's third-largest company, and the British refiner Tate & Lyle.

title: Immunization Truce Interrupts Salvador War
description: To the Editor:

title: DSC COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $3,000,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $5,913,000 for the year. c-Net loss d-Includes a $13,718,000 charge from the cumulative effect of an accounting. The company said previous year and year-ago quarter losses include about $50 million in pre-tax charges related to the discontinuance of its autodialer product line and a write down of inventory.

title: NASDAQ SHORT INTEREST IS UP 28.2 MILLION SHARES, OR 15.2%, IN LATEST MONTH
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers Inc. reported yesterday that short interest on Nasdaq stocks rose 28.2 million shares, or 15.2 percent, in the month ended Feb. 13, to 214 million shares. The total for last month was revised to 185.8 million shares.

title: INSIDE
description: REAGAN ON AIDS EDUCATION President Reagan will back Federal AIDS education if it stresses ''responsible sexual behavior,'' a White House memorandum said. Page A14. FREE BLACKS IN THE COLONIES Archeologists say they have found the first American settlement of free blacks, slaves who fled British colonies to Spanish Florida. Page A14. Andy Warhol left most of a $15 million estate to create a foundation for the visual arts. His will did not specify a program. Page C21. NEW BIDS URGED FOR CABLE Mayor Koch will press for new bids on cable television contracts for most of New York, in a move to complete plans begun 21 years ago. Page B1.

title: COMMERCIAL SHEARING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said earnings for 1986 have been restated in compliance with the FASB No. 87.

title: On Making a Better Warhead
description: Critics say the Pentagon sometimes exaggerates its public accounts of Soviet military abilities so as to justify United States military programs. But one conclusion in a new report by the Joint Chiefs of Staff, they say, tops them all.

title: BARCO OF CALIFORNIA (CO)(A) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: b-Net loss

title: ADOPTION AGENCY RULES CALLED UNFAIR TO BLACKS
description: A private social-welfare group has asked President Reagan to find out whether certain standards of adoption agencies are keeping black families from adopting children.

title: NEED TO WIDEN AIDS TESTING SEEN AS HEALTH FORUM ENDS
description: Participants in a federally sponsored conference on the control of AIDS reached broad agreement today on the need for wider testing for infection with the AIDS virus, provided it was voluntary and accompanied by adequate counseling and safeguards to keep results confidential.

title: Afghan Talks Resume On a Russian Pullout
description: Afghanistan and Pakistan resumed indirect negotiations here today with new proposals for the withdrawal of the 120,000 Soviet troops supporting the Kabul Government, a United Nations official said.

title: BERKLEY, W R CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized gains on investments of $267,000, or 2 cents a share for the quarter and $1,203,000 for the year, and tax credits of $4,350,000 and $8,650,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes realized gains on investments of $1,027,000, or 11 cents a share for the quarter and $2,030,000 for the year. The company said the results for the latest fourth quarter and year include a subsidiary which was acquired on April 4, 1986. In the fourth quarter the subsidiary contributed $22,174,000 to revenue and $3,356,000 to net from operations. For the full year the subsidiary added $64,433,000 to revenue and $4,338,000 to net from operations.

title: G.S. Musulin, Who Got G.I.'s Out of Yugoslavia, Dies at 72
description: George S. Musulin, a World War II veteran who helped evacuate 400 American airmen from Nazi-occupied Yugoslavia in 1944, died Saturday of complications of diabetes at the age of 72. He lived in McLean, Va..

title: Q&A
description: Q.Our 25-year-old brick house has aluminum windows and a gas furnace in the basement. The basement is just high enough to store garden equipment, but it is too wet for general storage. At one end it is only two feet above the ground. The windows in the house are completely wet with condensation all winter, and the outside walls and ceilings in several rooms are covered with mildew. The walls are not insulated, but the attic has plenty of insulation. Three large pine trees are near the house. Could these be the problem? What can you suggest?

title: Hearing Both Sides
description: Disarray in the Reagan Administration on health policy was evident at a Senate hearing the other day on occupational health.

title: DECORATIVE FANS PAINTED OR PRINTED BY HAND
description: TRUDY KRAFT, far right, and Vincent Vitale, below, both make fans. Hers are functional and can stir up a gentle breeze. His, made from photographs, are purely decorative.

title: IRAN REPORT, DUE TODAY, HAD MODEST BEGINNINGS
description: What was supposed to have been a blue-ribbon study of the procedures of the National Security Council evolved into a full-fledged investigaton of the Iran-contra affair, partly because the the panel obtained a wealth of N.S.C. computer memorandums, to the astonishment of the officials who established the panel.

title: LAWYER DISPUTES ROLE IN INQUIRY ON WEDTECH
description: A San Juan, P.R., lawyer said yesterday that he was unaware that legal fees he received from the Wedtech Corporation, a South Bronx military contractor, might have been intended as bribes for Representative Robert Garcia of the Bronx.

title: CONCERT: RUDOLF FIRKUSNY AND THE JUILLIARD QUARTET
description: THERE were no musicians taking part in Tuesday evening's concert at the 92d Street Y who had studied with Mozart or Schumann, possibly through an oversight of the management. However, the other composer on the program, Leos Janacek, was fortunate in having a prize pupil to champion his music. Rudolf Firkusny, who began piano studies in Czechoslavakia at age 5 with Janacek, is probably the strongest surviving link with one of the 20th century's quirkier geniuses. The strength of that connection lent unusual impact to Mr. Firkusny's performance of Book I of the suite for piano ''On an Overgrown Path,'' inserted between works of Mozart and Schumann played by the Juilliard String Quartet.

title: ANTIQUES, GARDENS AND A CASTLE
description: Spring Armory Antiques Show, Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 66th Street, 212-777-5218.

title: ASTRONOMERS SAY ODD EXPLODING STAR IS 'OPPORTUNITY OF A LIFETIME'
description: The exploding star that blazed into view over the Southern Hemisphere Tuesday may compel scientists to revise long-standing theories as to how such supernovas come about, astronomers reported yesterday.

title: Getty Museum Is Buyer Of David's 'Farewell'
description: The curator of paintings of the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., Myron Laskin, said yesterday that the museum had purchased Jacques Louis David's ''Farewell of Telemachus and Eucharis'' at Sotheby's in New York on Tuesday.

title: DOW RISES 2.96
description: Bank stocks were down again yesterday and drug stocks up as Wall Street posted another small gain on increased volume.

title: THE JAMES BOND OF ANTIQUE DEALERS
description: His name is Lovejoy, and he is the sharpest antiques dealer in East Anglia. He scowls at a pair of fake Regency flintlocks. He sighs over a perfect jade carving. And he is full of pithy observations: ''Greed, desire, love and death. In the antiques world you get them all.''

title: Redrawing Battle Lines On Aid to the Contras
description: Democrats and Republicans in Congress are both groping for strategies to fight the first skirmish in this year's battle over aid to the Nicaraguan insurgents.

title: DONALDSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said earnings were adversely affected by some non- recurring costs of integrating several recent acquisitions and by start-up costs related to the newly formed joint venture with Caterpillar Inc.

title: USLIFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: D.M.B.&B. Buys Stake In Japanese Agency

title: Hubie Brown Busy
description: It didn't take Hubie Brown long to find a niche following his dismissal by the Knicks nearly three months ago. He has worked as a television commentator for the Detroit Pistons and will work for CBS during the national collegiate tournament in March and the National Basketball Association playoffs. But his success in front of the camera hasn't tempered his desire to return to the sidelines. ''At the end of the playoffs, I'll have the opportunity to have some options, and that will be pleasant,'' Brown said during a luncheon with other CBS broadcasters in Manhattan. He would not say if any team had approached him yet. In the meantime, broadcasting has kept Brown close to the sport. ''When you're coaching, you are working towards an emotional and physical exhaustion for 2 hours and 5 to 8 minutes,'' he said. ''When you're broadcasting the game, you have to be conscious about being articulate, concise and informative. You want to teach, but you also want to have humor.''

title: REAGAN TO BACK AIDS PLAN URGING YOUTHS TO AVOID SEX
description: President Reagan has decided to support a Federal campaign to educate the public about the dangers of AIDS, but only if the campaign stresses ''responsible sexual behavior'' within marriage and teaches children to avoid sex, according to an internal White House memorandum made available here today by Congressional sources.

title: The Tempered Dole
description: When he ran unsuccessfully as the Republican candidate for Vice President in 1976, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas developed a reputation - some political professionals said it was a liability -for being especially sarcastic in attacks on his opponents. Now, as a probable Presidential contender, he has tempered his language somewhat, though he remains one of the wittier people in public life. And, now and again, he still shows some flashes of his old acidic self.

title: FOREMAN'S SECOND WIND
description: On the road outside Houston that chilly morning several months ago, George Foreman had run his four miles. As a boxer who became the world heavyweight champion after he dethroned Joe Frazier in a second-round knockout in Jamaica in 1973 until he was knocked out by Muhammad Ali in Zaire in 1974, he had never done more than four miles in his morning roadwork. For all his strength, he had no stamina. In Zaire and while losing a 12-round decision to Jimmy Young in San Juan in his last fight in 1977, he had tired quickly. But now, in the morning chill outside Houston, he kept running.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Navratilova Advances: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova fought off a challenge from 15-year-old Arantxa Sanchez of Spain yesterday to join Chris Evert Lloyd, Yannick Noah and Jimmy Connors as first-round winners at the $1.8 million International Players Championships in Key Biscayne, Fla. Hana Mandlikova, Pam Shriver and Helena Sukova - seeded fourth, fifth and sixth in the draw -also advanced as the rain-delayed tournament resumed at the International Tennis Center. In second-round night matches, Kathy Rinaldi, seeded eighth, beat Ann Henricksson, 6-3, 6-4, and Bettina Bunge of Monaco, seeded 12th, defeated Bettina Fulco of Argentina, 6-0, 6-1. Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia, seeded ninth, defeated Jaime Yzaga of Peru, 6-4, 6-3, 6-2, and Slobodan Zivojinovic of Monaco beat Jimmy Brown, 3-6, 6-2, 6-1, 3-6, 6-2. In afternoon matches, Lloyd defeated Jennifer Mundel of South Africa, 6-0, 6-1. Noah, seeded fourth, defeated Claudio Panatta of Italy, 6-3, 6-7, 6-2, 6-3, and Connors, seeded sixth, beat Ben Testerman, 6-1, 6-1, 6-3. Mandlikova of Czechoslovakia beat Helen Kelesi of Canada, 6-1, 7-5; Shriver beat Alexia Dechaume of France, 6-4, 6-3, and Sukova, of Czechoslovakia, defeated Jenny Byrne, 6-4, 6-3 (AP) N.B.A. Celtics 122, Trail Blazers 116: Larry Bird scored a season-high 43 points last night as Boston won its fifth straight and snapped the Trail Blazers' winning streak at five. Bird, whose previous high for the season was 40, connected on 17 of 30 shots, including a 3-pointer. He also made 8 of 9 free throws, had 10 rebounds, 8 assists, 2 steals and blocked 1 shot. Kevin McHale had 29 points and 13 rebounds for Boston. Steve Johnson scored 34 to lead Portland. (AP) Pistons 106, Cavaliers 105: Adrian Dantley scored 26 points and Isiah Thomas sank a free throw with six seconds left as the Pistons won their fifth straight and the Cavaliers suffered their 15th consecutive road defeat. Thomas and Mark Price of Cleveland were called for technical fouls after wrestling under the Detroit basket with 5:11 left in the second quarter. Thomas, guarding Price, was hand-checking the Cleveland guard. Price slapped Thomas's hand away and, moments later, Thomas grabbed Price and wrestled him to the floor. Neither player was ejected from the game. (AP) Mavericks 108, Kings 101: Rolando Blackman scored 35 points, including two clutch free throws with 20 seconds left, to lead the Mavericks at home. With the Mavericks leading, 104-101, with less than a minute to play, Blackman stole a pass and was fouled. Blackman made both free throws to give Dallas a 106-101 lead, and Mark Aguirre added two free throws with three seconds to play. Aguirre scored 26 points and James Donaldson had 18 rebounds for the Mavericks. Reggie Theus had 28 points and Eddie Johnson 20 for Sacramento. (AP) N.H.L. Whalers 6, Bruins 4: Ray Ferraro and Paul Lawless scored two goals each to lead the Whalers at home. Rick Middleton scored two third-period goals to bring the Bruins to within a goal twice, but after each goal, Lawless scored for the Whalers. Sylvain Turgeon and Kevin Dineen also scored for Hartford, and Ron Francis had three assists as the Whalers broke a two-game losing streak. (AP) Canadiens 3, Blackhawks 3: Craig Ludwig, a Montreal defenseman, scored his second goal of the game with less than six minutes remaining Wednesday night to lead the visiting Canadiens. Ludwig's second goal came with 5:07 left in regulation. It was his fourth of the season and only his 18th in five seasons. Doug Wilson became Chicago's all-time assist leader for defensemen with his 401st. Wilson broke the mark of 400 established by Pierre Pilote (1955-1972) when he assisted on Mark La Varre's first-period goal. (AP) HORSE RACING Favorite Wins Feature: Tops in Taps pressed the pace to the stretch, gained the lead with a furlong to go and drew away to a 3 3/4-length victory yesterday in the $40,000 allowance feature at Aqueduct. Carrying 115 pounds under Nick Santagata, Tops in Taps, a 4-year-old daughter of Topsider and Lightning Carol, went six furlongs in 1:11 3/5 on the fast track to gain her second straight victory and her fourth in eight career starts. Arunji finished fast to be runner-up, a neck ahead of Mo Hula. Tops in Taps, the favorite, returned $5.80 for $2 and earned $24,000 for her owner, Betty G. Marcus.

title: Talking Deals; Gambling On a Novel
description: WHEN James Clavell negotiated a $5 million advance for the rights to his novel ''Whirlwind'' last year, everyone in the publishing industry knew he had carved out a good deal for himself. No author had ever been guaranteed such a sum. And, based on a reading of the first 200 pages of the book, several other publishers were convinced it was not of the caliber of his previous best sellers, including ''Tai-Pan,'' ''Shogun'' and ''Noble House.'' Was the Hearst Corporation, the parent company of William Morrow & Company, which bought the hard-cover rights, and Avon Books, which bought the paperback rights, going too far out on a limb to promise that much? The $5 million is a guarantee that Mr. Clavell will pocket that amount even if his royalty on each hard-cover and paperback book sale does not amount to that much. Royalties generally range from 7 percent to 8 percent of paperback sales and 10 percent to 15 percent of hard-cover sales.
