description: A sharply divided Supreme Court, rejecting the Reagan Administration position, ruled today that judges may order employers to use strict racial quotas temporarily in promotions as well as hiring to counter severe past discrimination against blacks.

title: CARMIKE CINEMAS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
description: b-After a $325,000 charge from a Justice dept. settlement for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income

title: OLD AND ALONE, SOVIET DISSIDENT LOOKS TO EXIT
description: A decade ago, Naum S. Meiman fought for a change in Soviet society and watched in sorrow as his friends were packed off to prison or forced to emigrate.

title: Market Place; Rediscovering A.M.C.'s Stock
description: THE American Motors Corporation, everyone agrees, has been having difficulty selling cars lately. During the latest 10-day reporting period in mid-February, A.M.C., the nation's fifth-largest auto manufacturer, disclosed that it had sold only 725 cars.

title: ANCHOR FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said it went public in December.

title: Astaire, Nureyev, Fosse And Venza Get Award
description: The 1987 Capezio Dance Award will be given to Fred Astaire, Rudolph Nureyev, Bob Fosse and Jac Venza. The announcement was made in a ceremony at Harkness House, the first of several events celebrating the 100th anniversary of Capezio Ballet Makers.

title: AT AGE 8, COUNTERCULTURE'S VOICE HAS CHANGED
description: The morning news conference at the Tageszeitung takes place around a long kitchen table. Potatoes and oranges lie under a nearby aluminum stand where at lunchtime two cooks with iridescent red hair whip up a tolerable pasta and salad.

title: MARINE TRANSPORT LINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $9,672,000 charge from the writedown of Marine Princess to its estimated fair value. c-Net income and after a gain of $1,788,000 from early extinguishment of long-term debt. The latest quarter and year earnings include $2,461,000 of income from the recalculation of leveraged leases to give effect to the provisions of the Tax Reform Act of 1986. The 1986 results also included $1,113,000 of unrealized foreign exchange losses. The results for 1985 include $1,455,000 of income from contract terminations. The results include Rowbotham Tankships Ltd. since the date of its acquisition on Oct. 18, 1985.

title: JOHN A. LOWE
description: John A. Lowe, a former assistant United States Attorney in Manhattan, died Friday of a cerebral aneurism at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 44 years old and lived in Manhattan and Westhampton Beach, L.I.

title: SELECTING THE RIGHT TREE
description: IF you arrange the planting of a street tree, take time to consider your selection since you will be looking at it - and caring for it - for years. An experienced landscape contractor can help choose a species suitable to your site's sun, wind, neighboring species, sidewalk and street widths, and maintenance needs.

title: WESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company went public in December 1985.

title: AID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $691,210 for the quarter and $1,179,100 for the year. c-After realized losses of $42,164 for the quarter and a realized investment gains of $294,218 for the year.

title: Pay Principle
description: Hank Aaron, the slugger turned Atlanta front-office executive, on the Braves' refusal to meet the contract demands of another home-run hitter: ''We finished in last place with Bob Horner, we can finish last without him.''

title: FUND-RAISER FOR CONTRA AID: CONSERVATIVE WITH A CAUSE
description: Like many young conservatives, Jane Esther McLaughlin came to Washington full of political idealism.

title: LANGLEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Look Who's Charging Impropriety
description: If Michael Deaver is right that the Federal independent counsel law is unconstitutional, then he can be prosecuted only by the Justice Department run by his former White House associate, Attorney General Edwin Meese. If Lieut. Col. Oliver North is right on the same question, he too can only be prosecuted by lawyers of the same Attorney General Meese - who has rightly disqualified himself because of a political conflict of interest.

title: 'SOUTH PACIFIC' ATTRACTS A NEW GROUP OF NELLIES
description: When Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d first envisioned a young woman singing, ''I'm as corny as Kansas in August'' and ''I'm as normal as blueberry pie,'' they knew exactly whom they were writing for. And as they expected, Mary Martin caused a sensation when ''South Pacific'' first opened in 1949.

title: CROWN ANDERSEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
30 Nations Meet on Rules to Protect Ozone Layer
description: Technical and legal experts from 30 countries are meeting at the United Nations center here to negotiate a set of rules to protect the atmosphere's vital ozone layer from industrial chemicals suspected of depleting it.

title: A FLOOR-THROUGH'S DECOR: MINIMAL WITH RURAL TOUCHES
description: FEW spaces convey the feeling of living in the city as aptly as a floor-through in a turn-of-the-century brownstone. Perhaps more than any other urban space, the floor-through, which began as part of a gracious single-family house, symbolizes New York's many transformations.

title: No Viacom Reply On Redstone Offer
description: Viacom International Inc. failed to respond to a revised bid for the company by Sumner Redstone, whose Arsenal Holdings Inc. is trying to acquire Viacom. Mr. Redstone, who already controls 19.6 percent of Viacom's stock, had requested an answer by yesterday afternoon. Sources close to Viacom said that its board had a regularly scheduled meeting today and would consider the proposal at that session.

title: Outlook for Hong Kong
description: Hong Kong expects a $230 million budget surplus in the fiscal year beginning April 1 as a result of a strong economy, Financial Secretary Piers Jacobs said today.

title: Physician of Soviet Leaders Is Made the Health Minister
description: Yevgeny I. Chazov, personal physician to Kremlin leaders, has been made Soviet Minister of Public Health, the Soviet press has reported.

title: EXERPTSF FROM OPINION AND DISSENT IN ALABAMA AFFIRMATIVE ACTION DECISION
description: Following are excerpts from the opinions in the Supreme Court's decision today upholding orders to the Alabama Department of Public Safety to promote one black state trooper for every white promoted to certain ranks, assuming enough qualified blacks were available, until the state adopted acceptable promotion procedures.

title: Prosecutor Curbs Flow of Iran Papers to Congress
description: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra arms investigation has asked the Justice Department to stop providing some critical documents to Congress, setting the stage for a potentially important fight between the prosecutor and lawmakers, according to Reagan Administration officials.

title: Pace, Kyodo in Pact On Real Estate Activity
description: There was a time when a real estate advertising agency would be strictly a local operation. Things have progressed so that now we find Pace Advertising, a major specialty concern in New York, forming an affiliation (''a mutual-assistance agreement'') with Kyodo Advertising Agency in Tokyo, also specialists.

title: 29TH ANNUAL GRAMMYS: EVENING OF ODD TOUCHES
description: THERE was a sweet symmetry to Tuesday evening's broadcast of ''The 29th Annual Grammy Awards.'' The show began on CBS at 8 with Paul Simon and a group of black South African musicians doing a song from ''Graceland,'' an album they made together last year. Mr. Simon then sat in the audience for more than three hours, watching others beat him out in a number of awards categories.

title: Yields Unchanged
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were mostly unchanged for the week ended yesterday.

title: ACME PRECISION PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: LIONEL M. HARRISON
description: Lionel Meyers Harrison, a New York lawyer and businessman, died of cancer Tuesday at the Winthrop University Hospital, Mineola, L.I. He was 72 years old and lived in Westbury, L.I.

title: CENTURY TELEPHONE ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WARNER COMPUTER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
ENERGY CONVERSION DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring charge of $1,700,000 from the company's purchase of the entire interest of ANR Energy Conversion Co. and the Ovonic Battery Co. Partnership.

title: FLEETWOOD ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for 13wks to Jan 25
UNITED MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $862,000 and $1,711,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income and includes a loss of $81,000 for the quarter and a net of $98,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. Latest-year results were affected by third-quarter writedowns of $620,000 for inventory and technology investments, as well as unrealized currency-translation losses of $3,037,000 related to Swiss franc convertible debentures and investments in Australian bonds.

title: IN SHANGHAI, PROGRAMS THAT EMPLOY THE ELDERLY
description: ON Sundays especially, the crowds are so thick on Nanjing Street, Shanghai's Madison Avenue, that they spill into the road, impeding bicycle and automobile traffic. Through this flood of shoppers, like salmon fighting their way upstream, old men with battery-powered megaphones and red armbands reading ''On Duty'' weave in and out, shouting: ''Be careful of pickpockets. Watch your purse.''

title: VIEW-MASTER IDEAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HYCOR BIOMEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Homestake Mine
description: The McLaughlin mine, touted by the Homestake Mining Company until recently as a future giant of American gold production, contains less gold than was originally thought, the company said. The mine, about 130 miles northeast of San Francisco at the juncture of Napa, Lake and Yolo counties, was ''just slightly in the black'' last year, Homestake's chief financial officer, Richard W. Stumbo Jr., said. The mine produced 173,400 ounces, or about 25 percent of Homestake's gold production. Its estimated 2.48 million recoverable ounces is down from the 2.63 million it was previously thought to hold.

title: OPEC'S ACCORD FAILING TO BLOCK OIL PRICE SLUMP
description: The OPEC agreement that kept crude oil prices at or above $18 a barrel for nearly two months appears to be unraveling, and some oil specialists in the United States said yesterday that prices could soon sink into the low teens.

title: WESTERN UNION CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $7,173,000, a gain on disposal of $6 million and an extraordinary loss of $1,940,000. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $4,490,000 for the quarter and $22,014,000 for the year, and extraordinary gains of $196,000 for the quarter and $4,216,000 for the year related to the termination of an inactive retirement plan. Prior-year results include special charges of $300 million, primarily for the writedown of older generation switching and transmission equipment. The year-ago results have been restated.

title: Topics: Rough Relationships; No Monopoly
description: If war can't be left entirely to generals, diplomacy and foreign policy shouldn't be the exclusive preserve of the State Department.

title: Changes at Top At Shearson
description: Jeffrey B. Lane, chief operating officer at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. since 1983, will add the title of president, the firm said yesterday.

title: AMISH SUITED TO GENE STUDY
description: Decades of studies among the Amish have helped to clarify and in some cases unveil the genetic bases for dozens of disorders, including cystic fibrosis, congenital cataracts, two types of dwarfism and a form of presenile dementia that resembles Alzheimer's disease. Many of the studies have been conducted under the direction of Dr. Victor McKusick, geneticist at Johns Hopkins University and editor of the professional text, ''Medical Genetics Studies of the Amish.''

title: DAMSON OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said there are no year-ago share earnings because preferred dividend requirement exceeded net income.

title: KOCH TO ASK NEW BIDS ON CABLE TV
description: Mayor Koch has decided to press for new bids for cable television service in most of New York City in yet another attempt to complete the plans that began 21 years ago.

title: Savvy Magazine to Get A New Thrust in April
description: Family Media Inc. is repositioning and revamping its Savvy magazine under its new editor in chief, Annalyn Swan, formerly of Newsweek.

title: CENTRAL MAINE POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a writeoff of $17.2 million from investment in Millstone 3. c-Includes writeoffs of $85 million from Seabrook and cancelled plants.

title: THEATER: STUART SHERMAN'S ONE-ACTS
description: EVEN by Stuart Sherman's own minimalist standards, his ''Evening of One-Act Plays'' at the Home for Contemporary Theater and Art is miniature theater. Seven short plays, some as brief as blackouts, are sandwiched between two mini-movies. But those who have followed the peregrinations of this artist from his solo performances to his fragmented, environmental trilogy about Chekhov, Strindberg and Brecht should find that the current evening of short Sherman helps to fill in the blanks. The works were written over a period of 20 years, and there is a growing assurance in this, admittedly, very specialized performance art form.

title: AMOSKEAG CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest year results include the consolidation of Fieldcrest Cannon Inc. which in prior years was accounted for on an equity basis. It was also said that the reporting change stems from the fact that in October 1986 Amoskeag gained more than a majority of the voting control of Fieldcrest Cannon. The 1986 results also include the operations of Cannon Mills, which was acquired by Fieldcrest Cannon on Jan. 30, 1986.

title: METALBANC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $8,341 for the quarter and $22,294 for the 9 months.

title: 3 MEN ACCUSED OF ROLE IN FRAUD FOR $3 MILLION
description: A Queens lawyer and two other men were charged yesterday in the theft of $3 million in real estate from an 85-year-old Greenwich Village widow. Prosecutors said she was tricked into signing the transfer papers and left destitute.

title: IPL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $78,000 for the quarter and $337,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: MUELLER, PAUL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: TREASURY ISSUES FALL IN PRICE
description: After rising early in the day as oil prices declined, prices of Treasury debt issues fell in late trading yesterday when petroleum prices recovered somewhat.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in Sports Pages on Feb. 12 about the game between the National Hockey League All Stars and the Soviet national team described Ulf Samuelsson incorrectly. He never played for the Rangers. .

title: An Old All-Pro Wins a Big One
description: Charlie Krueger, an all-pro defensive lineman for the San Francisco 49ers, spent the last 10 years of his career in pain, the result of a severe injury to his left knee in 1964. But it wasn't until 1978, five years after his retirement, he says, that he discovered just how bad the injury had been. It had severed a key ligament, leaving him vulnerable to serious permanent damage by continuing to play. At age 50, Krueger is now a virtual cripple. He cannot stand for prolonged periods, or even climb stairs without extreme distress.

title: FROM 'HOW TO' TO HISTORY
description: BOOKS devoted to architecture and design are traditionally vehicles for showing, not telling - pages of breathtaking photographs supplemented by little more than glorified captions. Now some current design books have surprisingly interesting and scholarly texts, while some how-to manuals are presented in true coffee-table form - large formats, full-color photographs and brief texts. This season that bright and shiny book so prominently displayed might well be an instructional manual in disguise.

title: HACH CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
S.M.U.'s Ban Is Third Ever
description: Although Southern Methodist University has been assessed the most severe penalty to a college football program, it is not the first time a school has been suspended from competition by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: VATICAN PRELATE SAID TO FACE ARREST IN MILAN BANK COLLAPSE
description: Milan magistrates investigating the 1982 collapse of the Banco Ambrosiano were reported today to have issued arrest orders for Archbishop Paul C. Marcinkus, the American prelate who runs the Vatican bank, and at least two other bank officials.

title: INFINITY BROADCASTING reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $1,801,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary charge of $5,005,000 for the year. c-After an extraordinary gain of $313,000 for the quarter and year. d-Net income The company said revenue for the latest fourth quarter includes about $2 million from KROQ, the Los Angeles FM radio station which was purchased effective Sept. 30, 1986, and WQYK (FM) serving Tampa-St. Petersburg effective Dec. 8, 1986. These revenues were partially offset by the sale of the company's San Diego properties, KCBQ AM-FM, effective Dec. 9, 1986.

title: Orkin Is Ordered To Roll Back Fees
description: The Federal Trade Commission has ordered the Orkin Exterminating Company to roll back fees for about 200,000 customers who had signed lifetime agreements. The commission ruled unanimously that Orkin had illegally raised the fees in 1980 in violation of guarantees of annual reinspections at a fixed price.

title: A COMPETITION INVIGORATES THE THEATER LANDSCAPE
description: THE presentation this week of the Susan Smith Blackburn Prize to Mary Gallagher and Ellen McLaughlin for their plays ''How to Say Goodbye'' and ''A Narrow Bed,'' respectively, reaffirms the contribution made to the theater by this prestigious competition. For nine years, the Blackburn Prize - named in honor of the late American actress Susan Smith Blackburn - has been awarded to a woman for writing an outstanding English-language play.

title: LIQUID AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the negative impact of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 was more than offset by the after-tax gain on the sale of certain assets associated with the manufacture of safety products.

title: Appease or Oppose?
description: Once in a blue moon there comes a rethinking of policy that seemed for years to make sense. That is what is happening now in Israel regarding the Iran-Iraq war.

title: WEST MASS BANKSHARES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $215,000 in the latest year and $198,000 in the previous year from the Mutual Savings Central fund dividend. The company went public in November.

title: GENESCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $5,199,000 for the quarter and year. The year also includes an excess provision for future losses of discontinued operations of $9,633,000. c-Net loss and includes an excess provision for future losses from discontinued operations of $1,881,000 for the quarter and year. The latest quarter net also includes a non-operating gain of $13,571,000 related to restructuring and the year- ago period includes a special charge of $4,319,000 for anticipated costs of environmental proceedings. The latest year net also includes a gain of $28,251,000 related to restructuring and reversal of excess reserves, and the 1985 year's net includes a charge of $18,545,000 related to restructuring and environmental charges.

title: ALBA WALDENSIAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pretax gain of $481,670 from the sale of an unused palnt facility for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss and after tax credits of $76,567 for the quarter and $491,567 for the year.

title: GOULD INVESTORS LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said Gould Investors Trust was reorganized into Gould Investors L.P., a limited partnership in May 1986. The figures for the first quarter of fiscal 1986 represent the operations of Gould Investors Trust. Income for the latest quarter includes $106,000 from the disposition of properties, mortgages and investments, compared with $70,000 for the year-ago quarter. The company said the figures for the year-ago quarter include Gould's 56 percent majority interest in BRT Realty Trust on a consolidated basis.

title: ISI SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago results are pro forma figures which reflect operations as though the leveraged buyout of ISI from Grumman Corp. had occurred on July 1, 1985. The transaction took place in June 1986.

title: U.S. SEEKS MORE INFORMATION FROM SWISS ON THE IRAN AFFAIR
description: The United States Justice Department is seeking information about bank accounts and transactions involving an expanding list of people and companies that may have been involved in the Iran-contra arms transfers, Swiss officials said today.

title: FLARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ISRAELIS HOLDING A U.S. PROFESSOR
description: An American professor at a Palestinian university here has been arrested amid continuing clashes beween Israeli soldiers and Palestinian protesters.

title: 18 OF 19 PRESUMED LOST AFTER A SHIP CAPSIZES
description: All but 1 of 19 sailors from a Filipino cargo vessel that capsized in the stormy North Atlantic were presumed lost yesterday after four ships, including a Navy submarine, battled 35-foot waves and 45-knot winds in a rescue attempt, Coast Guard officials in New York said.

title: Still Fighting the Raise
description: Ralph Nader's Public Citizen organization has found a new way to oppose the salary increases that recently went into effect for members of Congress. It has enlisted Senator Quentin N. Burdick, Democrat of North Dakota, and Senator Gordon J. Humphrey, Republican of New Hampshire, to tack resolutions rescinding the raise onto every ''must pass'' measure voted on in the Senate. These are bills, such as appropriations measures, that the Government needs to continue functioning. According to Public Citizen's field director, Craig McDonald, the goal is to force members of the House of Representatives to go on record for or against the raise when the bills are sent back to the House.

title: HOMAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and includes a tax benefit of $157,000.

title: COURT HEARS ARGUMENTS ON ARAB AND JEWISH DISCRIMINTION CASES
description: The Supreme Court heard opposing arguments today in two cases to determine whether Jews, Arabs and members of other groups that are not ''racially distinct'' may bring racial discrimination suits under an 1866 civil rights law.

title: JOYNER LOOKS UP TO HIS LITTLE SISTER
description: Al Joyner regarded his sister with a mixture of respect and affection. After all, she was the first Joyner to bring a trophy to their home in East St. Louis, Ill. Now, he talks often and easily about her accomplishments as America's top female athlete, and what she has meant to him. Meanwhile, she eyes him as a mischievous older brother, someone she has to keep under control. But she smiles when she complains.

title: POLITICS AND FRUGALITY
description: As chairman of the Budget Committee, Senator Lawton Chiles, Democrat of Florida, could be assured lots of big campaign contributions if he would seek them. But when he announced yesterday that he would seek another term next year, he vowed once again to accept no contribution over $100 and to accept nothing at all from political action committees.

title: Article 845187 -- No Title
description: Andy Warhol's will, filed for probate yesterday, directs that the bulk of his $15 million estate be used to establish a foundation ''for the advancement of the visual arts.''

title: Philip Morris Makes High-Level Changes
description: In a continuing effort to decentralize its operations, the Philip Morris Companies yesterday announced a series of executive promotions, including the naming of two new vice chairmen.

title: NEW YORKERS PREPAY TAXES, GLADLY
description: Thousands of New York State taxpayers have found yet another way to take advantage of the change in Federal tax law.

title: KAHANE'S FREE MAILINGS ARE BARRED
description: Rabbi Meir Kahane was stripped of his mailing privilege in the Israeli Parliament today after his fellow legislators decided that he had abused it by mailing letters to Arabs urging them to leave Israel or face ''war.''

title: PLANNING FOR STREET TREES CAN START RIGHT NOW
description: ''I'VE never seen so many trees growing out of concrete in my life -it's a marvel,'' said William Lough, who became New York City's chief forester in October.

title: Jordan in Line for Post
description: Hamilton Jordan, the White House chief of staff under President Jimmy Carter, is expected to be named the executive director of the Assocation of Tennis Professionals at a news conference in Key Biscayne, Fla., today. The association represents the male players on the Grand Prix tour. Jordan, who is 42 years old and lives in Atlanta, was one of five candidates interviewed by a search committee formed last September when Mike Davies was dismissed as the executive director. Jordan is said to be a tennis enthusiast whose name has marquee value, considered important by the association board of directors. His contract is believed to be for two or three years. Jordan was only 32 years old when he became chief of staff for President Carter after the 1976 election. In June 1980, he took a leave of absence to run the President's unsuccessful re-election campaign.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: GEORGE SANTAYANA: A Biography.

title: ALLIED SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 10
description: b-Includes tax credits of $293,000 and $563,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $923,000 for the quarter and $2,162,000 for the 6 months.

title: Bubka Is Pleased By New Runway
description: Sergei Bubka, the world's best pole-vaulter, said yesterday that the change in the runway conditions for the USA/ Mobil championships tomorrow night ''will help.''

title: JUSTICES RULE IN FLORIDA SABBATH CASE
description: The Supreme Court, citing the First Amendment guarantee of free exercise of religion, ruled 8 to 1 today that states may not deny unemployment benefits to employees who are dismissed for refusing to work on their Sabbath.

title: DOSKOCIL COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $1,087,000 and $4,017,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and losses from discontinued operations of $2,594,000 for the quarter and $2,568,000 for the year. c-Net income d-Includes tax credits of $640,000 for the quarter and $3,286,000 for the year and net from discontinued operations of $27,000 and $86,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said most of the sales increase in the latest year was due to the acquisition in December 1985 of Stoppenbach Inc.

title: CANADIAN OCCIDENTAL PETROEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: All results are in Canadian currency.

title: FAWN HALL STEPS INTO THE LIMELIGHT
description: She is blessed with a physical presence made for cameras and her name is straight out of a paperback mystery.

title: Ecuador Wants Further Delay
description: Ecuador, which stopped interest payments on its $5.4 billion in private debt last month, said today that it wants to continue the debt suspension until June.

title: NORTHEAST UTILITIES reports earnings for 12mo Jan 31
Taxi Panel Approves Smoking Restriction
description: The city's Taxi and Limousine Commission ruled yesterday that medallion taxicab drivers can reject passengers who fail to comply with authorized no smoking signs posted in their vehicles.

title: 'How Men Think'
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: AMERICAN RELIANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain on investments of $70,000 for the quarter and a gain of $204,000 for the year, and the year also includes an after-tax gain of $295,000, or 14 cents a share, on termination of a pension plan. c-Includes a gain on investments of $36,000 for the quarter and a gain of $104,000 for the year.

title: Saab-Scandia Net Up
description: Saab-Scandia A.B., the Swedish automotive group, said today that it increased its 1986 earnings by 14.6 percent, largely because of booming heavy truck sales. The president, Georg Karnsund, said the company made a pretax profit of 3.32 billion crowns, or $510 million, on sales of 35.22 billion crowns, or $5.41 billion, with the truck division accounting for about two-thirds of earnings. In 1985, the company reported pretax profits of 2.90 billion crowns - $445 million - on sales of 31.84 billion crowns, or $4.9 billion.

title: HOMOSEXUALS APPLAUD REJECTION OF MANDATORY TESTS FOR AIDS
description: Spokesmen for prominent homosexual rights organizations expressed relief today that participants in a Federal conference on the control of AIDS had firmly rejected proposals for widespread mandatory testing to detect individuals who are infected with the AIDS virus.

title: I.B.M. Announces A 4-Megabit Chip
description: Heating up its competition with Japan, the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday gave details of its first four-megabit memory chip, amid strong indications that it would soon be ready for full-scale production.

title: English Garden in Italy
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: WANTS TO VISIT ISRAEL AND ITALY
description: Governor Cuomo, who had already scheduled 14 trips this year to various parts of the United States, said yesterday that he was also planning a series of trips to foreign countries.

title: CHICAGO MAYORAL RACE ENTERS THE DECISIVE LAP
description: In Chicago politics today, it wasn't over even when it was over.

title: CONCERT: COLUMBUS BRASS
description: THE Columbus Brass -named for the avenue, rather than the explorer or the town in Ohio - presented an engaging debut at Merkin Concert Hall Monday night. The members of the group - David Bilger and Alex Holton, trumpeters, Kenn Finn, trombonist, Cynthia Jersey, hornist, and Andrew Rodgers, tubist - play with expertise, humor, musicality and collegial warmth.

title: ICM PROPERTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1985 net reflects the trust's first 11 months of operations.

AMERICAN WESTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RENT-A-CENTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
GETTING A GRIP ON IT
description: YOU'VE twisted, pulled, run hot water over it and banged it on the kitchen counter, but you still can't get that jar lid loose. Struggle no longer: consider instead one of the helpful items made for this purpose.

title: Accord on 'USX'
description: The USX Telecenters Corporation, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said it would change its name after an out-of-court cash settlement with the giant USX Corporation, formerly known as the United States Steel Corporation. USX Telecenters, a telephone retailing franchiser that had trademark rights to its name, had filed suit against the giant steelmaker in July after learning it had switched its name to USX. Terms of the settlement, filed in United States District Court, were not released.

title: A Question for Cuomo

The ruling, which involved a suit filed on behalf of Cal Circuit Abco of Woodland Hills, Calif., held that buying foreign goods cheaply overseas and reselling them in the United States without concealing their origin does not violate the trademark rights of an American subsidiary of the manufacturer. The court rejected a trademark suit by the NEC Corporation, one of Japan's largest makers of computer chips.

The Indiana basketball coach will write a series of six syndicated articles of commentary on the coming N.C.A.A. tournament as a favor to Billy Reed, former sports editor of The Louisville Courier-Journal, who lost his job last year in what he calls a ''traumatic'' dispute with the newspaper's new owners.

The transaction, expected to be completed in the third quarter after shareholder and regulatory approval, would form a corporation with assets of more than $72 billion, with the Seattle-based Rainier contributing $9.2 billion. George F. Moody, president and chief operating officer of Security Pacific, indicated that Rainier would continue with its headquarters in the Northwest, with the ''same board, same management and same employees.''

The voting gave 53 percent to Mr. Washington and 47 percent to Ms. Byrne, and also sent a heartening message about race relations in perhaps the nation's most polarized city.

title: Hoyt Barred for Season
description: LaMarr Hoyt, the 32-year-old former Cy Young Award winner, was barred from baseball for the 1987 season by Commissioner Peter Ueberroth yesterday for Hoyt's involvement in three illegal drug incidents over the last year. ''While our first priority is to provide help to those who need it, we will impose discipline where appropriate,'' the commissioner said. Hoyt, a 24-game winner with the Chicago White Sox in 1983, was traded to the San Diego Padres after the 1984 season. Last February, authorities who stopped him at the Mexican border said he was carrying three grams of marijuana and a quantity of unauthorized Valium and Quaalude pills. He paid an administrative fine. Later that month, the San Diego police said they found him in possession of marijuana and a switch-blade knife. He pleaded guilty to a charge of public nuisance. After getting treatment at a drug rehabilitation center, primarily for alcohol, he rejoined the Padres and compiled an 8-11 record with a 5.15 earned run average in 35 games. But he was arrested again last October, this time for marijuana and unauthorized possession of pills. He pleaded guilty to two misdemeanors and was sentenced to 45 days. When the Padres released him Jan. 7, the team said it would not honor the remaining three years of his contract, and the Players Association filed a grievance in Hoyt's behalf. Last year, the commissioner penalized 11 players for their involvement with drugs but permitted them to play if they met certain conditions. All complied by donating a percentage of their salaries to drug-prevention programs, performing community service and submitting to drug tests. No such option was mentioned in Hoyt's case, however. Don Fehr, executive director of the players association, said it would be up to Hoyt and the pitcher's representatives if they want to appeal the commissioner's action. ''The saddest part is that everybody is lining up to throw darts at the guy,'' Fehr said. ''I used to think the worst thing that could happen to you in America was to get fired from your job. Now they've fired this guy and said he can't even work any place else.''

title: A Point in Time
description: Long before our species had an identity, let alone a telescope, there was a dark space in the Greater Magellanic Cloud as it might have been seen from Earth. On Tuesday, shortly before dawn, a light went on in that dark space and by chance, a Chilean observer with a telescope noticed it. What he saw, he realized after studying a routine photograph, was an event that had taken place about 163,000 years before.

The concert will include the world premiere of George Perle's ''Sonata a Cinque'' and what is believed to be the American premiere of Erik Satie's ''Musique d'Ameublement,'' as well as music by Frederic Rzewski, Charles Ives, Duke Ellington and others. The 92d Street Y is at 1395 Lexington Avenue. Admission is $7.50 to $10. Information: (212) 996-1100.

title: STAGE: 'HUNGER ARTIST,' KAFKA IN LIFE AND WORK
description: WHEN Franz Kafka was readying ''The Metamorphosis'' for publication, he implored his editor not to allow pictures of Gregor Samsa's transformation into a cockroach. ''Not that, please not that!'' the author wrote. ''The insect cannot be depicted. It cannot even be shown from a distance.'' The publisher complied, illustrating ''The Metamorphosis'' instead with a door opening into darkness - an image at once more abstract and yet more terrifying. What shakes Kafka's readers, after all, is not the prospect of turning into an insect but the recognition that one can experience the helplessness of an insect before the maze of dark thresholds that is the modern world.

title: Japan Vehicle Record

Everything goes wrong when, after she answers his ad, they meet for the first time in a French restaurant.

title: DAVID CALE, SPINNER OF DREAM TALES
description: The voice is caressing, with an undertone of urgency, a hint of menace. With its suburban London accent full of tangy insinuation, it is an ideal instrument for the telling of scary ''believe it or not'' tales in which lurking night stalkers contemplate unspeakable crimes. Yet David Cale, the 28-year-old comic monologuist who is appearing at the Kitchen, has deeper things on his mind than campfire Grand Guignol. The tales he spins, accompanied by live music, distill the yearning inner lives of everyday people with a surreal intensity. Reality, fantasy and an almost clairvoyant insight into personality dissolve into one another in stories that can be as memorable as one's own most vivid dreams.

Nettles did not re-sign with San Diego after the 1986 season, in which he batted .218 with 16 home runs and 55 runs batted in. He has 384 career home runs and another chance as a nonroster invitee who will be given a contract if he makes the club. ''For me it's an ideal situation,'' he said. ''It seems they need a left-handed bat off the bench.'' ''He's still dangerous with the bat,'' Cox said. ''He's worth a look.''

title: A SALUTE TO WOMEN'S HISTORY
description: Women's History Month, a citywide celebration of the experience of women past and present, begins Sunday. Organized by the New York City Commission on the Status of Women, it will provide a chance to remember pioneering American women including Harriet Tubman, the escaped slave who was deeply involved in the Underground Railroad, and Amelia Earhart, the aviator.

title: Political Line
description: Things can get a bit dull in the Nevada sports betting parlors after the Super Bowl. So much so that Gene Maday, president of Little Caesars Casino and Sports Book in Las Vegas, decided to liven things up last week by proposing to take wagers on whether Oral Roberts would get the $4.5 million that the evangelist says God has told him to raise by the end of March.

title: TWO NEW YORK RIGHTS LAWYERS, ONE GOAL
description: New York City Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward suggested that they were in it largely for the money. Others said that they should be disbarred. Still others accused them of holding one of the city's most volatile cases hostage while they pursued a personal political agenda.

title: BENEFICIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $141,400,000 for the quarter and $279,100,000 for the year, and a gain from the effect of an accounting change of $19,400,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net income and includes net from discontinued operations of $9,400,000 and $27,900,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said the 1986 loss from discontinued operations includes $147,300,000, which primarily reflects the massive losses of its discontinued property and casualty insurance subsidiaries; and a $131.8 million estimated loss on the disposal of discontinued businesses. The 1985 results have been restated for discontinued operations.

title: Mississippi Power Rates in Question
description: The State Public Service Commission is considering the suspension of a $326.5 million rate rise it had granted to the Mississippi Power and Light Company, as well as the operating license of the Grand Gulf nuclear plant, commissioners said.

title: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS  Retracing the Steps Leading to Six Arms Sales: Charts From the Report; Transaction One: August 1985 Sale of 100 Israeli TOW Anti-Tank Missiles
description: STEP 1: Ghorbanifar provides Khashoggi with $1 million post-dated check on Aug. 17. STEP 2: Khashoggi deposits $1 million in Nimrodi-controlled Israeli account at Swiss bank. STEP 3: Nimrodi notifies Israeli officials of receiving funds. STEP 4: Iran transfers $1,217,410 to Iranian account at Swiss bank [ 1 ] on Aug. 27 to pay for shipment. STEP 5: Israel delivers 100 TOW missiles to Iran on Aug. 30. STEP 6: Ghorbanifar notifies Khashoggi that check is covered. [ 1 ] Monies are actually transferred to an Iranian Government account prior to release to Ghorbanifar. This intermediate step has been dropped for purposes of simplification.

title: FREDRIC R. MANN, ARTS PATRON
description: Fredric R. Mann, an industrialist and patron of the arts who helped finance music centers in Philadelphia and Tel Aviv, died of cancer yesterday morning in Miami. He was 83 years old and had homes in Miami, Philadelphia and Manhattan.

title: ESTERLINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
HANDY & HARMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter and year results reflect a special after-tax charge of $2.6 million for restructuring certain operations. The year also included a first-quarter after-tax charge of $2.7 million for a doubtful account. Results for the first 9 months of 1986 have been restated to reflect a favorable adjustment of $2.1 million for a change in accounting for pension costs in accordance with FASB No. 87.

title: A NEW LOOK IN STATE RETURNS
description: Although most taxpayers will find little change in their Federal income tax bill in filling out 1986 returns, residents of a number of states, including New York, will see some significant changes at the local level.

title: Pesch Raises Medical Offer
description: Dr.

title: Anglicans Favor Female Priests
description: The Church of England today approved the drafting of legislation that would admit women to its all-male priesthood.

title: INTERPHASE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
BRIDGE: A BID OUT OF TURN LED TEAM TO A BIG LOSS IN TOURNAMENT
description: The bidding shown in the diagram is not, as one might suppose, the product of a typographical disaster: it is an accurate record of a deal in the Betty Kaplan team event played Sunday.

title: ALEXANDER & ALEXANDER SERVICE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $3.7 million for the quarter, and the year is after a loss from discontinued operations of $24 million and a tax credit of $600,000. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $33.8 million and $52 million for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Pryor Is Arrested on Rape Charge
description: Aaron Pryor, the former junior-welterweight champion, was jailed without bond today on charges of raping a woman and keeping her tied up in his house for 24 hours after an argument over his suspected cocaine use, the police said.

title: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: The Politics; Report Seen as Strengthening Democrats for '88 Race
description: The Tower Commission report, by providing substance for public worries about President Reagan's lack of control over day-to-day White House operations, was likely to send Republicans scrambling for scapegoats and alibis while further strengthening a resurgent Democratic Party, politicians here and around the country said.

title: PERMANENT NET
description: Ray Williams, who returned to the Nets for a third time in his pro career by signing successive 10-day contracts, was re-signed yesterday for the remainder of the season. With Otis Birdsong injured, Williams has provided the Net backcourt with experience at both guard positions. Against the Detroit Pistons Tuesday night, the 6-foot-3-inch, 32-year-old Williams had 23 points and 9 assists. . . . The Washington Bullets were about to place Mike O'Koren on the injured list yesterday to make room on their roster for a guard, Frank Johnson, who is returning from an injury. Instead, O'Koren, acquired from the Nets last October for Leon Wood, asked to be waived, hoping that a team might claim him for playoff service.

title: RAILROAD SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Topics: Punishments and Rewards;  Soul Shopping
description: Ah, the ease of grocery shopping in a small town or suburb: the aisles where one cart can pass another just as the stock boy unloads a huge stack of boxes, and no one bonks into anything . . . the wide-open parking lots that make it possible to haul groceries home by car.

title: Advertising Museum Makes Bid for Support
description: Howard Bell, president of the American Advertising Federation, is host at a luncheon in New York today to introduce some this town's movers and shakers to a pair of fund-raising lads from out of the West.

title: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: Reaction in Jerusalem; Israelis Say Panel Portrayed Their Role as Secondary to U.S.
description: Israeli officials contended tonight that the Tower Commission had played down the Israeli role in the Iranian arms deal as secondary to that of the United States.

RENT-A-WRECK OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: The Bumpurs Case Endures
description: The verdict of a State Supreme Court justice clears a New York City police officer, Stephen Sullivan, of manslaughter charges in the fatal shooting of Eleanor Bumpurs. But no decision can clear the system: social service failures and unwise police procedures contributed heavily to this tragedy. This case must not end with one officer's acquittal.

title: Winfield Arrives Looking for Harmony
description: Dave Winfield arrived today and wondered aloud why there should be any unnecessary pressure in the Yankee camp this season.

title: FIDELITY MEDICAL SUPPLY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $224,833 related to an out-of-court settlement and a buyout of all equity interest in a subsidiary from a former executive officer of the subsidiary. The company said the year-ago revenue was unavailable.

title: Soviet, Spurned by U.S., Renews A-Test
description: The Soviet Union conducted an underground nuclear test today, ending an 18-month moratorium, but offered to stop again if the United States joined in.

title: CALLED GAIN IN HUMAN STUDIES
description: Mice from a strain that suffers uncontrollable shivering, convulsions and early death have been cured through gene transfer techniques, possibly advancing work on some neurological ailments in humans.

title: FROM NECKWEAR TO EAGLES
description: Warm sunshine greeted the opening of the 10th annual Fishing and Outdoor Exposition at Rockland Community College Field House in Suffern, N.Y., Wednesday afternoon, one reason that a half-hour after the show began, there was a half-mile-long, bumper-to-bumper line of cars approaching it.

title: BANK BUILDING & EQUIPMENT CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $39,000.

title: ARTHUR A. COLLINS
description: Arthur A. Collins, a pioneer in radio communications, avionics and telecommunications who was founder of the Collins Radio Company, died Wednesday at Gaston Episcopal Hospital in Dallas, the city where he had lived for the last 14 years. He was 77 years old.

title: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: The Iranians; World of Terrorism Didn't Halt Overtures
description: The United States was receiving intelligence about Iranian terrorist activities that were to be conducted against the United States at the same time that Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, was preparing his trip to Iran in May 1986 to complete an arms-for-hostages swap, according to the Tower Commission report released today.

title: Indianapolis Bonds
description: The Indianapolis Local Public Improvement Bond Bank is tentatively offering $63.3 million of bonds through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. Yields range from 3 3/4 percent for bonds due 1988 to 4.70 percent in 1992, 5.60 percent in 1997, 6.20 percent in 2002 and 6.60 percent in 2008. Underwriters said the bonds are rated AA+ by S.& P. and are expecting a triple-A rating by Moody's.

title: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS  Retracing the Steps Leading to Six Arms Sales: Charts From the Report; Transaction Four: February 1986 Sale of 1,000 U.S. TOW Missiles
description: STEP 1: Ghorbanifar provides Khashoggi four post-dated checks for $3 million each. STEP 2: Khashoggi deposits $10 million in Lake Resources account on Feb. 10. STEP 3: $3.7 million is transferred to C.I.A. account at Swiss bank on February 10 and 11. STEP 4: C.I.A. certifies availability of funds to Defense Department for purchase of 1,000 TOW's. STEP 5: Defense Department signs over 1,000 TOW's to C.I.A. on Feb. 13. STEP 6: Southern Air Transport flies TOW's to Israel on February 14. STEP 7: Secord crew flying Israeli false flag aircraft delivers TOW's to Iran on Feb. 17 and 27. STEP 8: Seventeen HAWK missiles [ 1 ] carried back to Israel on return flight. STEP 9: Iran transfers $7.85 million to Swiss account on March 3 to cover repayment of Khashoggi. [ 2 ] STEP 10: Ghorbanifar makes deposit to Israeli account controlled by Amiram Nir. STEP 11: Nir transfers funds to Lake Resources account. STEP 12: Ghorbasnifar notifies Khashoggi that checks are covered. STEP 13: Khashoggi is repaid $12 million from Lake Resources account by April 11. Note: The difference between what Iran was charged and Defense Department paid leaves $6.3 million unaccounted for and available for diversion. [ 1 ] The 18th missile was test-fired without success at an Iraqi fighter over Kharg Island. [ 2 ] The Board concludes that the difference between this transfer and the $12 million repaid Khashoggi was covered by the $5 million withheld by Israel pending return of the HAWK missiles.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Fernandez Upsets Shriver: Fifteen-year-old Mary Joe Fernandez upset fifth-seeded Pam Shriver, 6-3, 6-4, yesterday to accompany Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert Lloyd into the third round of the $1.8 million Lipton International Players Championships in Key Biscayne, Fla.

title: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: The Discovery; How the Tower Inquiry Stumbled on Aid Effort
description: John G. Tower said today that his panel did not have time to investigate the network of private aid to the Nicaraguan rebels that was discovered as part of its inquiry into the National Security Council staff.

description: The United States and other countries have decided to grant a $500 million short-term loan to Argentina while it completes negotiations for a $2.15 billion financing package with commercial banks.

But his is distinctive because it is named William Lyons Associates, and his associates have a total of 200 years of advertising experience.

Foreigners Safe in Beirut, Syria Says
description: The Syrian officer in charge of security measures in West Beirut issued a call today for foreign diplomats and citizens to return to the city.

title: DEMOCRATS AND CUOMO IN TAX SPLIT
description: In a major break with the Cuomo administration, the Democratic leadership of the Assembly today rejected the Governor's tax-cut plan as too small and proposed a completely new tax code with a flat rate of 6.75 percent on all income, both corporate and personal.

title: DR. JESSE W. MAHONEY
description: Dr. Jesse Waring Mahoney, who was chief of surgery at Bellevue Hospital Center for 20 years, died of a heart attack Tuesday at University Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Oldfield, L.I.

description: b-Includes gross income of $91,900 and $175,700 from the issuance of special income shares to former holders of Wedgestone Participating Mortgage Trust.

title: LANGER LEADS DORAL ON SEVEN-UNDER 65
description: Bernhard Langer's first shot in the $1 million Doral Ryder Open today was a drive directly into a fairway bunker at the par-5 No. 1 hole of the Doral Country Club's Blue Monster course.

title: San Antonio Bond Sale Gets Warm Reception
description: A $160 million competitive bond sale by San Antonio was well received by investors yesterday, when the issue of tax-exempt revenue bonds was priced through an underwriting group led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. The revenue bonds issued by the city's utility system are one of the highest rated in the country. It is also the second-biggest offering of revenue bonds by San Antonio in more than a month. Last month the system sold $391.7 million of refunding bonds.

title: Durables Report Lifts Bonds
description: An unexpectedly sharp decline in durable goods orders for January lifted prices of fixed-income securities yesterday in active trading. The 7.5 percent decline was seven times greater than what participants in the credit market had expected.

The Empty Chair
description: When our Constitution was drafted in 1787, one of the hard questions was who should run the executive branch of the new government. Some favored a committee. But in the end the Framers decided that a single President would make the executive stronger and more responsible to the people.

title: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: The Deception  INQUIRY FINDS REAGAN AND CHIEF ADVISERS RESPONSIBLE FOR 'CHAOS' IN IRAN ARMS DEALS  White House Cast Wide Net In Seeking Aid for Contras; The Missing Notes
description: The Tower Commission report reveals that notes for critical White House meetings to discuss secret arms sales to Iran, at which Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter, the national security adviser, should have been the note-taker, ''appear to be missing.''

title: POP AND JAZZ
description: The Fourth Annual Fasl Folk Music Show, the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-6300). Thoughtful acoustic folk music may not be wildly fashionable, but the Greenwich Village troubadour tradition flourishes thanks largely to the group of singer-songwriters who regularly contribute to the Fast Folk Music Magazine, a combination record album and newsletter. Fast Folk's annual Bottom Line celebration, which has traditionally showcased the best recent work by its contributors, is the ideal way to catch up with the New York scene. Among the composer-performers scheduled to appear tomorrow are Frank Christian, Roger Deitz, Cliff Eberhardt, John Gorka, Jack Hardy, Lucy Kaplanski, Rod MacDonald, David Massengill, Nikki Matheson, Richard Meyer, Germanna Pucci, David Roth and Eileen Weiss. Never less than intelligent, their output spans a wide range of subjects, from funny topical songs to serious broadsides. Shows are at 7:30 and 10:30 P.M., and tickets are $10. $ ? * * * Marti Stevens, Freddy's Supper Club, 308 East 49th Street (888-1633). Marti Stevens, who is making her first New York club apperance in many years, personifies a chic cafe society sophistication that makes one wistful for the heyday of Cole Porter and Noel Coward, two writers whose work she understands as thoroughly as any performer working the cabaret circuit today. Buddy Barnes, her musical director and accompanist, gives this witty, elegant, sexy woman just the right pianistic lilt. Ms. Stevens's versions of Cole Porter rarities from ''Fifty Million Frenchmen'' have an extra-special zing. Shows are 8:30 tonight and tomorrow and 3 P.M. on Sunday. There is a $15 cover charge and an $8 minimum.

title: On the Deaths of Pets, Lost or Abandoned

title: About That Police Parley
description: The Police Foundation has decided to restrict its symposium on law enforcement next Thursday in Washington to representatives of organizations in the United States. One result of that move is that Sir John Hermon, chief of the Royal Ulster Constabulary in Northern Ireland, will not participate in the symposium, as had been previously indicated.

title: RIZZO STARTING RACE FOR MAYOR IN PHILADELPHIA
description: Former Mayor Frank L. Rizzo, the last major player to make a formal entry into the race for Mayor, today officially announced he would try to unseat the incumbent, W. Wilson Goode, thereby setting up what bids to become a spirited campaign all the way to November.

title: BLACK HISTORY EVENTS

Admission, $6; with student identification, $5. Information: (718) 520-7323. Lehman College Art Gallery, Fine Arts Building, Bedford Park Boulevard West and Goulden Avenue, the Bronx. Sunday, noon to 4 P.M. ''Give Me Your Tired, Your Poor . . .? Voluntary Black Migration to the United States.'' The Schomburg Center's exhibition for the Statue of Liberty centennial observance organized by Roy Bryce-Laporte, the guest curator and author of the display's introduction. Admission, free. Information: 960-8731. Harlem School of the Arts, 645 St. Nicholas Avenue, at 141st Street. ''Harlem as Mecca and New Jerusalem,'' talk by Dr. John Henrik Clarke, tomorrow, 11 A.M.

description: b-Net loss

title: UPTOWN DRAMA GRUPS JOIN FORCES IN FESTIVAL
description: The Third Annual East-West Theater Festival is an attention-getting event that unites 10 performing troupes from Manhattan meridians on either side of Fifth Avenue. The companies, between now and March 22, will have staged 19 different productions, available to festival ticket holders at a rock-bottom rate of $25, or less than $1.50 a show.

title: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: The Vice President; Bush Insists the Intention Was Not Arms for Hostages
description: Vice President Bush said today that he agreed it would be ''wrong'' for the United States to trade arms to Iran for the release of American hostages, but insisted the Adminstration had no such intention.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: WHEN the Academy Award nominations were announced recently, some New Yorkers were surprised, others indignant, and some even affronted. ''Hoosiers,'' which garnered two nominations - one for best musical score and another for Dennis Hopper as best supporting actor - had not yet even opened in New York. What's worse, the film had had its premiere in Indiana and had been playing in Los Angeles since December. For residents of the Big Apple, it was an annoying experience they were unaccustomed to: They were among the last to know about a cultural event.

title: AMERICAN REBUFFED ON AIR FARES
description: American Airlines yesterday gave up for now its attempt to roll back partly the airline industry's latest foray into deep discounts.

title: PILOT TRAINING PLANNED FOR WIND SHIFT
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that it planned to make it mandatory for airline pilots to undergo a training program on how to cope with one of aviation's deadliest hazards: the abrupt shift in winds at low altitudes.

title: USLICO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $1,065,000 and $8,088,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes capital gains of $353,000 and $1,444,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: BICENTENNIAL ADS FOR CONSTITUTION
description: The Commission on the Bicentennial of the Constitution, concerned that Americans know too little about the document that guarantees their freedoms, has begun an advertising campaign.

title: VIACOM INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said that the loss for 1986 was due to a one-time charge in the second quarter of about $30,131,000 reflecting costs related to repurchase of Viacom's stock from Carl Icahn and his associates. The company also said that results for 1986 were positively affected by the acquisition of the 50-percent interest in Showtime-The Movie Channel Inc. not already held by Viacom during the fourth quarter of 1985 and the acquisition of MTV Networks Inc., approximately 66 percent of which was acquired during the fourth quarter of 1985 and the remainder of which was acquired at the end of the first quarter of 1986.

title: Owens-Illinois Asks Resignations
description: Owens-Illinois Inc., which hopes to cut operating costs by $32 million a year, is offering all 2,000 of its salaried administrative employees incentives to quit. Sam Allen, a company spokesman, said he did not know how many job reductions would achieve the $32 million in savings, but added, ''If not enough people accept the offer, then there will be involuntary cutbacks.'' Those who are laid off will receive severance benefits, he said, and early retirement benefits will be provided to workers 55 and older and to those 50 and older who have more than 30 years of service.

title: JORDAN'S 58 POINTS TOPPLES NETS
description: Michael Jordan scored 58 points, the most ever by a Chicago player in a regular-season game, to lead the Bulls to a 128-113 victory over the Nets tonight.

title: A MIX OF ARCHETYPES AND AUTOBIOGRAPHY IN THE NEW PASTELS OF JENNIFER BARTLETT
description: LIKE almost all her best work, Jennifer Bartlett's new pastels at the Paula Cooper Gallery, 155 Wooster Street, are a mix of symbolism and autobiography. Large in scale and confident in tone, they fill the entire gallery without any flagging of energy. Fundamentally they are made up of the same three disparate elements, combined and re-combined in a landscape that she got to know a year or two ago on the North Shore of Long Island.

title: Warrants for Vatican Bankers Raise Legal Problem for Italy
description: Italian Justice Ministry officials confirmed today that warrants had been issued for the arrest of three senior Vatican bank officers charged as accessories in fraudulent bankruptcy in the collapse of Banco Ambrosiano in 1982. The officials said the Government was studying ways to serve the warrants.

title: Article 116287 -- No Title
description: Waste Management Inc. today began a tender offer valued at $270 million for the Chemlawn Corporation, which provides lawn care services.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 381 money market mutual funds increased $720.4 million, to $236.90 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 91 institutional funds were up $356 million, to $66.19 billion. Assets of the 198 general purpose funds were up $211.5 million, to $62.94 billion. The 92 broker-dealer funds gained $151.9 million, to $107.77 billion.

title: Naples Journal;  From Earthquake and Decay, a New Flowering?
description: Along Via Stadera, in a neighborhood they call Purgatory, hoodlums of the Camorra, the Neapolitan version of the Mafia, sprayed gunfire this month at a group of laborers building apartments for people left homeless after the earthquake six years ago. Those gunshots shook some of the brighter assumptions about this gracefully decaying Mediterranean city.

title: Fair, Respectful -- and Humiliating
description: Their words were polite, as befits commissioners judging the President of the United States, especially considering that he invited them to investigate his own office. The conclusions were put tactfully, but what the Tower commission report comes down to is blunt, indeed humiliating: In the Irancontra affair, the President failed to supervise national security policy, the most sensitive function of the government.

title: AUCTIONS
description: ''It's hard to think of a sale in recent years with so many paintings,'' said Philip Hook, head of Christie's 19th-century paintings department here. And it's hard to disagree. On March 27, Christie's will sell a total of 2,500 19th-century Italian paintings, drawings and watercolors, all amassed by Juan and Felix Bernasconi, avid collectors who for years purchased works directly from the artists.

title: WESTON, GEORGE LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver Stock Exchanges. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Giant Diamond Is Sold
description: An Australian mining company, Bridge Oil, has sold a huge West African diamond of gem quality for $1.6 million. Bridge's chairman, Robert Strauss, said the 100.2-carat stone was the most valuable diamond from the Aredor mine in Guinea.

title: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: The Contras  INQUIRY FINDS REAGAN AND CHIEF ADVISERS RESPONSIBLE FOR 'CHAOS' IN IRAN ARMS DEALS  White House Cast Wide Net In Seeking Aid for Contras; A Web of Maneuvers
description: In its effort to organize private aid for the Nicaraguan rebels, the White House solicited help from - and by some accounts threatened - several countries heavily dependent on American financial and political support, the Tower Commission report disclosed today.

title: Diner's Journal
description: SAFARI GRILL, the stylish urban encampment that got off to a rousing start nearly two years ago, then suffered from attrition in the kitchen and lack of direction, is on the comeback trail. A new chef has taken command - David Lawson, formerly of Stars in San Francisco and Marshal's Bar and Grill in Paris. Prices have been slashed and the dining-room decor has been tamed down from its former leopard-skin-and-wicker look to something much softer.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: MOST partygoers are used to doormen graciously ushering them out of their cars or limousines and through the front door of the city's most elegant nightspots. But at Christie's on Monday night, at an auction and dinner to celebrate 60 years of Martha Graham's choreography, some guests entered the party the unfashionable way, through the back door. The benefit raised funds for a school of dance Miss Graham hopes to open in Florence.

title: Chris Connor to Sing
description: The singer Chris Connor is to perform tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., plus a 12:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $10 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

title: BAVARIA ORDERS TIGHT RESTRICTIONS ON GROUPS LINKED TO AIDS RISK
description: The conservative Bavarian government has announced tight restrictions on some groups believed to be at high risk of exposure to AIDS, including compulsory testing for prostitutes and prison inmates as well as for certain foreigners wishing to reside in the southern state.

title: St. Cecilia Chorus
description: The St. Cecilia Chorus, under the direction of David Randolph, will present Anton Dvorak's Requiem Sunday afternoon at 4 at St. George's Church, 16th Street and Second Avenue. The soloists will be Trudy Weaver, Michael Crouse and Kevin Deas. Admission is $6; information: (212) 644-7797.

title: OPERA TO POP, NEW YORK CITY IS THE CAPITAL OF WORLD MUSIC
description: BIG cities are by definition cosmopolitan; they act as magnets.

title: French Order Boeing Awacs
description: The French Government placed a $940 million order today for three radar early warning planes from the Boeing Company and took an option to buy two more in the next eight months.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: FOR seven years, Chanterelle has been a haven of calm and civility in SoHo, turning out highly refined and often inspired food.

title: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: The C.I.A.; Finding on Agency Role May Put Nomination of Gates in Jeopardy
description: Senate confirmation of Robert M. Gates as Director of Central Intelligence appeared to be jeopardized today by the Tower Commission's finding that the Central Intelligence Agency prepared a key 1985 assessment of the situation in Iran in close cooperation with the National Security Council staff.

title: CHURCH & DWIGHT CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: Money Network; Papers in North's Safe Point to Aid for Contras
description: The Tower Commission found documents in the safe of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North suggesting that tens of millions of dollars were provided to the Nicaragua rebels and others through a private network of corporations and nonprofit organizations that Colonel North helped organize.

title: ENERGY PRICES UP A BIT; TECHNICAL FACTORS CITED
description: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products advanced slightly in dull trading yesterday. But analysts attributed the recovery to technical factors and said it was still unclear whether the market's descent had been arrested, or whether this was only a pause before a further decline.

title: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS  Retracing the Steps Leading to Six Arms Sales: Charts From the Report; Transaction Six: October 1986 Sale of 500 U.S. TOW Missiles and Various Hawk Missle System Spare Parts
description: STEP 1: Iranian representatives (the Second Channel) deposit $7 million into Lake Resources account on September 26 [ 1 ] to cover purchase of 500 TOW's and additional HAWK spares. STEP 2: Lake Resources transfers $2.037 to the C.I.A. Swiss account. Because of a communications failure between North and Secord, the deposit is made to a closed account. STEP 3: Because the funds are not immediately available for the Defense Department, North asks Israel to deliver 500 TOW's from its own inventory. STEP 4: 500 Israeli TOW's delivered to Iran on Oct. 30 and 31. STEP 5: 500 TOW's released to C.I.A. and transported to Kelly Air Force Base 3. STEP 6: TOW's shipped to Ramstein, West Germany, Nov. 6. STEP 7: C.I.A. proprietary airline delivers TOW's to Israel Nov. 7 as replacements. Note: The difference between the amount provided by Iran and that paid to C.I.A. (Defense Department was still unpaid for this last shipment as of January 20, 1987) leaves almost $5 million unaccounted for. This brings the total amount available for diversion between February and October 1986 to approximately $19.8 million, less actual costs incurred in support of the operation. [ 1 ] There is some discrepency surrounding these dates. The Sept. 26, 1986, date is contained in a note from North to Poindexter which also contains the $7 million figure. The C.I.A. report, relying on George Cave, states that the relative brought a check for $4 million with him to the late-October meetings in Frankfurt. Confronted with this inconsistency, the Board has chosen to rely on the contemporaneous account of Lieut. Col. North.

title: Hurricane Tracker Is Lofted
description: A Delta rocket was launched late today with a $55 million weather satellite aboard that is intended to fill a critical surveillance need in this year's hurricane season.

title: EX-SOLDIER ACCUSED OF STEALING 2 COPTERS IN SCAM
description: The former maintenance chief for a company whose helicopter crashed in the Hudson last October, killing a radio reporter, was accused by Federal prosecutors yesterday of stealing two $115,000 helicopters from the Air Force when he was an Army private in 1980.

title: ERC INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,937,000 for the quarter and $3,809,000 for the year. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $461,000 and $940,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: AFGHAN PLANES SAID TO KILL 35 IN PAKISTAN RAIDS
description: Afghan warplanes bombed two Pakistani villages today, killing at least 35 people, wounding more than 200 and wrecking scores of homes and businesses, Government officials said.

title: READING & BATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $2,785,000. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $8,143,000 and $13,249,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $75,319,000 for both periods. In recognition of these lower prices, the company reduced the carrying value of its domestic oil and gas properties by $33 million, wrote off $3 million of foreign oil and gas interests and set up a provision of $13 million in anticipation of retiring four older drilling units in 1987. The company also completed the sale of its remaining Indonesian oil and gas interests in a transaction valued at $60.1 million and recorded a loss of $12 million in connection with that sale.

title: FILM: 'CLASS RELATIONS,' KAFKA STORY
description: ''Class Relations'' was shown as part of the 1984 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times Oct. 7, 1984. The film opens today at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

ALTAI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
The Ponies' Press
description: Just how big a story to Dallas were the N.C.A.A. penalties imposed Wednesday on Southern Methodist University's football program? Yesterday's issue of The Morning News, one of the city's two dailies, devoted not only its leading article on page 1 to the Mustang scandal, but also five full sports pages. In all, there were 25 S.M.U.-related articles or graphics, and 14 pictures as well, for a total of 38 columns. The rival Times Herald, which also led with S.M.U. on the front page, devoted 20 columns to its account.

title: LITTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: Kevin Allen, a former offensive tackle with the Philadelphia Eagles and the ninth player taken over all in the 1985 draft, interrupted jury selection in his trial in Atlantic City yesterday to plead guilty to aggravated sexual assault last Sept. 1. The plea was made under an agreement that dismissed other charges. Allen, who is from Indiana, started the first four games of his rookie season before being demoted to special teams and let go at the beginning of last season. . . . Steve Balboni, who led Kansas City in home runs last year with 29 despite missing the final 23 games, has signed a one-year pact with the Royals but he isn't happy about it. ''It's not going to affect the way I play,'' Balboni said, ''but I just don't feel the same about the organization as I did before.''

title: PAUL HARRIS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Corrections
description: An article on the Washington Talk page Feb. 17, about Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia misstated the Court's history on prior restraint of publication of Government secrets. In 1980, in Snepp v. United States, the Court upheld an agreement under which a former agent of the Central Intelligence Agency had to submit anything he wrote about the agency for prepublication review and deletion of any national security secrets.

title: EXCERPTS FROM THE TOWER COMMISSION'S REPORT  PART IV: What Was Wrong
description: Following are excerpts from the report of the President's Special Review Board, which was made public yesterday in Washington:

title: FILM: GENE HACKMAN AS A COACH IN 'HOOSIERS'
description: WHO could resist a tiny Middle Western town where the barber shop is called Rooster's and the game of basketball is foremost on every mind? Probably no one, and the quaintly innocent ''Hoosiers'' is irresistible in much the same way. This film's very lack of surprise and sophistication accounts for a lot of its considerable charm. As written by Angelo Pizzo, directed by David Anspaugh, imbued with a convincingly old-fashioned look and acted in a friendly, forthright manner, ''Hoosiers'' seems about as sweetly unself-conscious as a film can be.

title: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS  Retracing the Steps Leading to Six Arms Sales: Charts From the Report; Transaction Five: May 1986 (Supplemented in August) Partially Completed Sale of Various U.S. Hawk Missile System Spare Parts
description: STEP 1: Ghorbanifar provides Khashoggi with three post-dated checks for $1.6 million and $11 million. STEP 2: Khashoggi deposits $15 million to Lake Resources account May 14. STEP 3: Lake Resources transfers $6.5 million to C.I.A. Swiss account on May 15. STEP 4: C.I.A. certifies availability of funds to Defense Department on May 16. STEP 5: Defense Department sins over 508 TOW's and quantity of HAWK spare parts on May 16 and 19. STEP 6: Southern Air Transport flies TOW's and HAWK spares to Israel on May 23 and 24.STEP 7: One pallet of HAWK spares arrives in Tehran with McFarlane party on May 25. STEP 8: Second aircraft with additional HAWK spare parts is turned back in midflight when no hostages are released (May 25). STEP 9: Iran transfers $8 million to Swiss account in July and August in payment against goods received. STEP 10: Additional HAWK spares delivered to Iran Aug. 3. Step 11: Ghorbanifar transfers funds to Israeli account controlled by Nir. STEP 12: Nir transfers funds to Lake Resources account. STEP 13: Ghorbanifar authorized Khashoggi to expose $3 million against checks held on July 24. STEP 14: Ghorbanifar authorizes Khashoggi to expose additional $5 million in August. STEP 15: By August, Khashoggi has been repaid out of Lake Resources account $8 million of the $15 million loaned. Note: The difference between the amount charged Iran (as advanced by Khahoggi) and that paid to Defense Department leaves an additional $8.5 million unaccounted for and available for diversion.

title: BRAZIL TALKING TO NATIONS, NOT BANKS, ON DEBT
description: In what is seen as a major change of strategy, Brazil has decided to go over the heads of foreign creditor banks and seek a long-term solution to its debt crisis in direct negotiations with governments of the United States and other industrial nations.

title: FOR A 9-YEAR-OLD DYING OF AIDS, ACTS OF DECENCY
description: This is the story of a little town that responded with decency when confronted with AIDS. Not everyone, of course, but most of Granby.

description: Starpointe, formerly Savings Bank of Central Jersey, went public in October.

Guerrilla Warfare and the Budget: Senator Phil Gramm
description: Senator Phil Gramm is a legislator with a stomach for one-man battles.

title: Bias Jury Report Criticizes School
description: The grand jury that investigated the death of Len Bias, the Maryland basketball player issued a report today that strongly criticized the university's athletic program. Bias died from a cocaine overdose last June 19.
