title: A Juvenal Quotation Opens Tower Report
description: Appendix B of Tower Commission report, a narrative of how the Iran-Contra affair evolved, begins with ''Quis custodiet ipsos custodes.'' It is Latin for ''Who will guard the guardians themselves?''

title: Inquiry Finds Reagan and Chief Advisers Responsible for Chaos in Iran Arms Deals
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  A special review board portrayed President Reagan today as a confused and remote figure who failed to understand or control the secret arms deal with Iran, and who thus had to ''take responsibility'' for a policy that in the end caused ''chaos'' at home and embarrassment abroad.

title: JAMES COCO, CHARACTER ACTOR ON STAGE AND TV AND IN FILMS
description: James Coco, the roly-poly actor who parlayed his sizable girth into a successful career in character parts that ranged from the comic to the terrifying, died Wednesday night after suffering a heart attack. The actor, who was 56 years old, was pronounced dead at St. Vincent's Hospital, where he had been taken from his home in Greenwich Village.

title: EASTMET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $3,893,000 as a result of re-evaluating the provision for estimated losses resulting from the closing of sheet operations and the accrual of Chapter 11 and other costs recorded in 1985 and a credit of $1,776,000 to interest expense, reversing over-accrual of charges recorded earlier in the year. c-Includes a restated charge of $51,608,000 for the shutdown and Chapter 11 provision, which was originally estimated in 1985 to be $41,562,000.

description: b-After extraordinary credits of $188,000 for the quarter and $451,000 for the 6 months. Comparable figures for both year- ago periods were unavailable because the company changed its fiscal year- end to June 30 from Aug. 31.

description: Political action committees and members of law firms involved in the landmark Texaco-Pennzoil lawsuit contributed almost $400,000 to the campaigns of eight Texas Supreme Court justices last year, according to reports published today.

description: b-Net income

title: 3 Bands at the Ritz
description: Two British bands - Chameleons U.K. and the Mighty Lemon Drops -and the California band Camper Van Beethoven are to perform tomorrow at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800). Camper Van Beethoven is to open at 11 P.M.; tickets are $12.50 in advance, $13.50 Saturday.

title: U.S Eases Net-Worth Rule to Help Thrift Units
description: Responding to heavy pressure from Congress, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board today announced a new policy that would permit beleaguered thrift institutions, particularly in the depressed Southwest, to continue operating, even if their net worth falls to almost zero.

title: V BAND SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
JAPAN TO OPEN ITS DOORS TO AMERICAN LAWYERS
description: American lawyers are about to be able to operate in Japan, under an agreement between the two Governments that is expected to be announced Friday, trade officials said today.

title: LTV RETIREES PROTEST PENSION SNARE
description: Last week, six months after taking early retirement, Edward Price walked to the the gate of a steel plant here, stopped a tractor trailer and told the driver: ''Mister, I'm going under your truck. Please don't move because you'll hurt me.''

title: CHARGES AGAINST MOTHER IN DEATH OF BABY ARE THROWN OUT
description: A judge today dismissed criminal charges against a young San Diego woman who faced a possible jail term for her conduct while she was pregnant. The prosecutor had said the woman's failure to seek medical help led to the death of her infant boy.

title: FILM: 'A NIGHTMARE ON ELM STREET 3'
description: FREDDY KRUEGER is the most talkative of slashers, and also the most creative. In ''A Nightmare on Elm Street 3: Dream Warriors,'' which opens today at the Embassy 2 and 3 and other theaters, he displays a great debt to Dali in concocting surreal visions for his prey. When Freddy enters the dreams of his teen-age victims, ordinary objects become armed and dangerous. A bathroom faucet may sprout claws like Freddy's and grab its victim. A mirror may snatch up someone passing by. A roasted pig may rear up from the dining room table and growl. Small wonder that one young woman gulps down undiluted instant-coffee crystals, in her efforts to avoid Freddy's idea of dreamland.

title: COMPROMISE WOULD ADD 1,800 CABS
description: Mayor Koch and the City Council have reached a compromise that could place up to 1,800 new yellow taxicabs on New York City streets and open the way for the first significant taxi fare increase since 1980.

title: GERBER SYSTEMS TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Gerber Systems Technology is an 84 percent owned subsidiary of Gerber Scientific Inc.

title: Looking for a C.I.A. Chief
description: President Reagan unsuccessfully sought to persuade Edward Bennett Williams, the prominent Washington lawyer and sportsman, to succeed William J. Casey as Director of Central Intelligence after Mr. Casey's resignation early this month. According to friends of Mr. Williams, the Democrat said his health would not permit him to take on the arduous assignment. For 10 years the 67-year-old lawyer has undergone treatment and a number of operations for colon, liver and lung cancer. Among others the White House approached unsuccessfully for the post was former Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, a former majority leader and potential 1988 Republican Presidential candidate.

title: Break Relations With South Africa
description: LEAD: Moralism triumphed over pragmatism when Congress imposed economic sanctions on South Africa last fall. For many critics of the regime, the actual impact of sanctions seemed less important than the moral satisfaction they derived from expressing their distaste for apartheid. But there is now a growing realization -- expressed only in whispers by supporters of sanctions -- that Congress's action has been, at best, ineffective.

title: The Findings: In Muskie's Words
description: Former Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie, speaking at the news conference yesterday in Washington at which the Tower commission's report was made public, offered a summary of the report's findings, which were unanimously adopted. Other excerpts from the news conference are on page A8. WHAT WENT WRONG

title: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: The TV Coverage; How the Story of the Commission Report Played on the Networks
description: By one significant measure - how the story played on television - the Tower Commission's report was big, but not bigger than ''The Cosby Show.''

title: So Much for Managers' Loyalty
description: LEAD: On a visit to the Graduate School of Business at the University of Chicago two years ago, T. Boone Pickens, the corporate takeover specialist, joked that if he ever needed a heart transplant he hoped the donor would not be an arbitrager. Why? Because the heart would never have been used, he said.

title: SPINKS STRIPPED OF TITLE
description: Michael Spinks, who became the first light-heavyweight champion to win the heavyweight title when he defeated Larry Holmes last April 19, has been stripped of the crown by the International Boxing Federation. The action disrupts his plans to defend the title against the winner of the bout between Mike Tyson, the World Boxing Council champion, and James (Bonecrusher) Smith, the World Boxing Association champion. According to I.B.F. rules, Spinks was supposed to have made a mandatory title defense against the No. 1 contender by Jan. 19, nine months after taking the crown. Robert W. Lee, the I.B.F. president, said Spinks was given a 30-day extension to fight the top-ranked I.B.F. contender, Tony Tucker. After Don King won the purse bids for that fight at $711,000, Butch Lee, Spinks's promoter, sent a message to the I.B.F. saying that Spinks would neither negotiate nor participate in a mandatory bout with Tucker. Lee said that after the federation received the message ''we had little choice but to vacate Spinks's title.'' He added that the vacant title would be filled in an ''immediate elimination series'' between Tucker and the No. 2 contender, James (Buster) Douglas, and the winner would defend within six months against Carl (the Truth) Williams.

title: ROSPATCH reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $252,000 and $91,700 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a loss on the disposal of an operation of $1,300,000 for both periods. c-Net income and includes a gain from discontinued operations of $66,000 and $535,500 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said its results reflect a previously announced increase in the estimated cost to complete a development program for an anti-submarine warfare, 99-channel receiver; the final pretax charge relating to cost overruns on the program were about $2.8 million.

title: ACTION ON S.M.U. IS SWIFT AND DECISIVE
description: One of the most persistent criticisms of the National Collegiate Athletic Association has been that it was slow and indecisive in dealing with universities that violated rules aimed at insuring fair competition. Investigations usually took two years and when punishment did come, the critics said, it was often the proverbial slap on the wrist. That is not a charge that can be levied now.

description: A former hostage testined today that two of his captors in Lebanon were brothers of Georges Ibrahim Abdallah, on trial for complicity in the killings of an American military attache and an Israeli diplomat in Paris.

title: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS  Retracing the Steps Leading to Six Arms Sales: Charts From the Report; Transaction Three: November 1985 Aborted Sale of 120 Israeli Hawk Anti-Aircraft Missiles With U.S. Delivery Assistance
description: STEP 1: Ghorbanifar deposits $24 million to Nimrodi-controlled account. STEP 2: Nimrodi notifies Israel of receiving funds. STEP 3: Israeli charter aircraft encounters difficulty in obtaining landing clearance from third country staging point. U.S. assistance sought. STEP 4: Iran transfers funds to Iranian accounts in Switzerland to cover purchase of HAWK missiles on Nov. 22 and 25. [ 1 ] STEP 5: Eighteen HAWK missiles delivered to Iran aboard C.I.A. proprietary aircraft flown by Secord crew Nov. 25. STEP 6: Iran refuses to pay for obsolete missiles delivered. Cancels deal. STEP 7: Nimrodi returns Ghorbanifar's money less $5 million for HAWKS delivered. [ 1 ] Two deposits were made to the same Iranian account at Credit Suisse used to finance the two earlier TOW purchases. The third deposit was to an Iranian account at a different Swiss bank. The $24.72 million transfer apparently was to cover the purchase of 120 HAWK missiles. The Board has no evidence to conclude for what purpose the other two deposits were intended.

Rick Aguilera is working on a split-fingered fastball. And Bob Ojeda is adding new grips and illusions to go with the four pitches already in his repertory.

THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS  Retracing the Steps Leading to Six Arms Sales: Charts From the Report; Transaction Two: September 1985 Sale of 408 Israeli TOW Missles
description: STEP 1: Ghorbanifar provides Khashoggi with $4 million post-dated check. STEP 2: Khashoggi deposits $4 million to Nimrodi-controlled account on Sept. 14. STEP 3: Nimrodi notifies Israeli officials that funds have been received. STEP 4: Israel delivers 408 TOW anti-tank missiles to Iran on Sept. 14. STEP 5: Iran transfers $5 million to Iranian account at Swiss bank on Sept. 18 to cover purchase. STEP 6: Ghorbanifar notifies Khashoggi that check is covered. STEP 7: Ghorbanifar pays Nimrodi $250,000 for eight additional TOW missiles.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Henry Threadgill, Fred Hopkins and Andrew Cyrille, Jazztrack, Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street, east of Seventh Avenue South (645-2387). The saxophonist Henry Threadgill and the bassist Fred Hopkins were two-thirds of Air, the new-jazz trio that played fast and loose with Mr. Threadgill's compositions in ways that were droll and bluesy and smart, often all at once. Andrew Cyrille has lent his crisp, explosive drumming to some of the best jazz of the past two decades - not least of it his long association with Cecil Taylor. Together, they should make a trio that can assemble and take apart structures, kick them around the block and then put them back together again upside-down or sideways. Sets tomorrow at 8 and 10 P.M.; tickets are $10. $ ? * * *Roger Miller, Volcano Suns, Divine Horsemen, Phantom Tollbooth, CBGB, 315 Bowery, at Bleecker Street (982-4052). With bands from Boston, Los Angeles and Plainview, L.I., CBGB has assembled yet another testimonial to the quality and ferocity of independent-label American rock. The Volcano Suns and Roger Miller both sprang from the Boston band Mission of Burma; Mr. Miller left to play keyboard-centered compositions with the structural complexity of classical music, while the Volcano Suns continue Mission of Burma's guitar-charged attack - leavened, now, with a little humor. Divine Horsemen are on the dark side of Los Angeles's rediscovery of country-rock; on their album ''Devil's River'' (SST), the singers Chris Desjardins (who calls himself Chris D.) and Julie Christensen share tales about violence, tortured love and morality in songs that twang and stomp. And on their debut EP, ''Phantom Tollbooth'' (Homestead), the Long Island-based band plays dissonant, squalling songs with titles like ''More Paranoia,'' songs that grind and thrash, then turn on a dime. Phantom Tollbooth opens tomorrow at 10:30 P.M., followed by Divine Horsemen (11:30 P.M.), Volcano Suns (12:30 A.M.) and Mr. Miller (1:30 A.M.); admission is $8. $ ? * * *Pat Martino, Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street (533-7902). The guitarist Pat Martino dropped out of jazz in 1980, the victim of a brain aneurysm that led to surgery and a complete memory loss. But he taught himself to play again, and his style is intact - steeped in be-bop, but with utterly individual harmonic turns and a rhythmic flexibility that makes his phrases seem to twist themselves inside out. He'll be playing in a bare-bones trio, Steve LaSpina on bass and Joey Baron on drums, and the shows will be recorded for a live album. Sets tonight are at 9 and 11, tomorrow and Sunday at 8 and 10 P.M.; there is a $12.50 cover and a $7.50 minimum. $ ? * * * Pop Album of the Week: Nana Vasconcelos: Bush Dance (Antilles): The Brazilian percussionist-singer Nana Vasconcelos made his last solo album, ''Zumbi,'' by layering on all the sounds he could produce with his hands and his voice. For ''Bush Dance,'' he has harnessed a DMX drum machine and added occasional keyboards or guitars, mostly from Peter Scherer of the Ambitious Lovers. The result is more high-tech but no less exuberant, making Brazil-New York connections with Brazilian, especially Bahian, rhythms right up front. At times, as in ''Futebol'' and ''Paleto,'' the music suggests a leaner version of pan-American fusions by Weather Report and the Brazilian songwriter Milton Nascimento; elsewhere, as in ''Mamae Cade Baleia,'' Mr. Vasconcelos heads for territory all his own - Bahian-country-minimalist-funk, or something like that. Like all great percussionists, Mr. Vasconcelos knows just where an interjection or syncopation will lift the music; even when he's using a computerized beat, he tops it with live, unpredictable kicks.

title: A Cast of Characters: Others in the Drama
description: GEORGE CAVE: A retired C.I.A. agent who speaks Persian, he was called out of retirement in March 1986 by the C.I.A. to work on the arms sales. He accompanied Mr. McFarlane to Teheran. DUANE CLARRIDGE: Chief of the C.I.A.'s European division, he helped Colonel North arrange for a flight by a European airline connected to the C.I.A. that carried arms to Iran in November 1985. ROBERT M. GATES: In the first months of the Iran initiative, he was the Deputy Director for Intelligence, the agency's senior analyst. In 1986 he replaced John N. McMahon as Deputy Director of Central Intelligence and is now Acting Director. CLAIR GEORGE: The C.I.A.'s Deputy Director for Operations, he had overall responsibility for the clandestine help provided by the agency to the National Security Council. MANUCHER GHORBANIFAR: The key Iraninan middle man, he was distrusted by the C.I.A. He was developed as a contact by the Israelis and later by the National Security Council. When he was cut out of the arms operation in August 1986 he threatened to expose the secret dealings. Some think he carried out his threat. MAX GOMEZ: Identified by Eugene Hasenfus as one of his contacts. Previously met Vice President Bush. Mr. Hasenfus offers no proof that Mr. Gomez is tied to C.I.A. EUGENE HASENFUS: Aerial delivery specialist, captured by Sandinistas after the C-123 was shot down. He said he made four previous flights into Nicaragua before being captured, but cannot confirm reports that the flights had ties to the C.I.A. ALBERT HAKIM: Iranian-born arms dealer and business executive, now an American. Mr. Hakim is a business partner of Mr. Secord. ADNAN M. KHASHOGGI: A Saudi arms dealer who introduced Mr. Ghorbanifar to the Israelis, he remained as the deal's financier. He claims to have raised millions for the transactions from investors. DAVID KIMCHE: Former director general of Israeli Foreign Ministry. He met with Manucher Ghorbanifar and Michael A. Ledeen, consultant to the National Security Council on possibility of better U.S. relations with Iran. MICHAEL A. LEDEEN: A part-time consultant to the National Security Council, who first broached the Administration's hope for better relations with Iran in 1985 meetings with Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel. He told the committtee he was cut out of the dealings in December 1985. YAACOV NIMRODI: A former Israeli officer in Iran, now an arms dealer, he helped bring together the participants and ease the first shipments. AMIRAM NIR: Adviser on terrorism to Shimon Peres when Mr. Peres was the Israeli Prime Minister. Early last year Mr. Nir took over handling Israel's arms deals with Iran from David Kimche, former Director General of the Israeli Foreign Ministry. Mr. Nir met with Mr. Khashoggi in London. HOJATOLISLAM HASHEMI RAFSANJANI: Speaker of Iranian Parliament, who allowed Mr. McFarlane to make secret mission to Iran, and later denounced the trip. AL SCHWIMMER: An Israeli business executive, he was involved in the early months of the arms shipments through Israel. RICHARD V. SECORD: A retired Air Force major general and an associate of Colonel North, he was an American intermediary who arranged logistics, worked on negotiations and helped develop a second channel for the Iran shipments. He is also believed to have been involved in running a private supply network for the contras. JOHN K. SINGLAUB: Retired Army major general. Is said to have helped the Administration supply weapons to the Nicaraguan rebels. Also a board member of a Manhattan arms company whose owner pled guilty of weapons smuggling to Iran. Says he did not know of any illegal dealings by the company. nm

title: Suns Dismiss MacLeod General Manager
description: Jerry Colangelo, saying the Phoenix Suns ''needed a change in direction and a change in attitude'' yesterday dismissed Coach John MacLeod, who was in his 14th season, the longest span with the same team among active coaches. Dick Van Arsdale, a former Knick and All-Star guard for the Suns who does color for the team's radio and television broadcasts, was named interim coach for the remainder of the season. With a 22-34 record and in fifth place in the Pacific Division, the Suns appeared headed toward their third straight losing season, and missing the playoffs for the second year in row. ''The team needs a change in direction and a change in attitude,'' Colangelo said. ''With five rookies on our roster, we are one of the youngest teams in the league and we are in a rebuilding mode. But the Suns are in a negative cycle and we had to do something to break out of it.'' The 49-year-old MacLeod said: ''It's a blow, but you take it. It's not the end of the world. I hope to coach again somewhere, some place.'' In coaching longevity, MacLeod, hired as the fifth coach in Suns' history March 30, 1973, trailed only the 16 seasons of the Boston Celtics' Red Auerbach and the 14 of the Golden State Warriors' Al Attles. His 579 career victories placed him eighth in history. Van Arsdale, 44 years old, was the first player chosen by Phoenix in the N.B.A. expansion draft May 6, 1968, coming from the Knicks.
