title: Cardinal Suit Dropped
description: William V. Bidwell, owner of the St. Louis Cardinals of the National Football League, has dropped a lawsuit challenging the league rules that govern the relocation of teams. On Feb. 11, 1986, the Cardinals filed a lawsuit in United States District Court in New York, charging that a set of rules drawn up in 1984 by Commissioner Pete Rozelle unreasonably restrained trade in violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act, damaged the Cardinals' finances and led to irreparable injury to the team's efforts to find a new home. Rozelle's rules require any club desiring a move to another stadium or city to get approval of three-quarters of the league's other clubs. Bidwell, who contends that Busch Stadium is so small that the team cannot generate enough income, has threatened to move the club. Plans for a new domed stadium in St. Louis have hit a snag, and Bidwell is said to think that his case for relocation is so strong and well understood that there is no need for the suit.

title: Gas Find in Louisiana
description: One of the biggest natural gas discoveries in recent years has been made in southern Louisiana near the Gulf of Mexico, according to the Occidental Petroleum Corporation.

title: Nicaragua Derides the Tower Report
description: A Sandinista Government spokesman said today that he believed the Tower Commission's report was intended more to protect the United States Presidency than to find the full truth behind the Iran-contra dealings.

title: LOUISIANA ECONOMY MAY FORETELL POLITICAL CHANGE
description: Along the rural roads outside this city the trees are starting to sprout with the signs of a new election year, Louisiana's version of the World Series.

title: COCA-COLA BOTTLING CO CONOLIDATED reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-Includes income of $479,000 from discontinued operations and a gain on sale of $2,824,000. The company said the latest fourth quarter results reflect about $13 million pre-tax of non-recurring expenses for the following: the reversal of a portion of a previously recorded insurance claim associated with the lawsuit filed against the company by competing bottlers in the Charlotte market, other costs and expenses associated with that lawsuit; a special provision for bad debt; severance expenses for the company's fourth quarter manpower reductions; an additional sales tax assessment; writeoffs of inventory, and additional expenses for the company's employee benefit programs, including a provision for settlement of certain claims related to executive incentive programs in effect during prior years. The after-effect of these non-recurring expenses was $7.4 million. In addition, the company experienced an after-tax increase of about $1 million in container expenses due to curtailed patronage dividend from one of its container suppliers. The company said the fourth quarter also was adversely affected by the reversal of previously accrued investment tax credits of about $1 million as a result of changes in federal tax laws. In addition, the effective tax benefit was lower than usual in the fourth quarter due to the netting of capital gains against ordinary losses and the inability to carry back operating losses for State and Canadian income tax purposes, making the ocmpany's after-tax loss about $3.7 million higher than it would have been at normal rates. The company said in aggregate, these items had an adverse after-tax effect of about $13.4 million in the latest fourth quarter.

title: NORTH CANADIAN OILS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: All figures are in Canadian funds. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the year-ago quarter.

title: BLOCK, H & R INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Booker T. Washington Had a Point
description: Can a black person who quotes Booker T. Washington with approval hope to be taken seriously? Glenn Loury, who teaches political economy at Harvard, offers such approval in an essay in The Public Interest, and so marks himself again as an independent thinker about the condition of blacks in America. He deserves to be taken seriously.

title: GUARANTY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $721,000 and $2,232,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; and tax benefits of $962,000 for the quarter and $4,054,000 for the year. c-Includes capital gains of $550,000 for the quarter and $1,723,000 for the year, and a tax benefit of $537,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: FOOTE MINERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $2.7 million charge on a graham plant closure and a $3.8 million charge for a loss on the sale of a facility in Cambridge, Ohio for both the quarter and year. c-Includes a $16 million charge from the writeoff of assets for the quarter; and the year includes a $21 million charge for plant closure costs and writeoffs of assets.

title: Yeshiva Trading Cards: Rabbis but No Red Sox
description: The boys from the yeshiva come to Shmiel Shnitzer's store after a long day of delving into the sacred writings with the sort of keenness American boys devote to memorizing batting averages.

title: On Hoop Havens
description: The recent stories about the scandals and arrests and boorish behavior in sports could drive a man to, well, maybe even to participation sports.

title: JURY SEEKING JOB RECORDS REGARDING GARCIA'S WIFE
description: A Federal grand jury has subpoenaed records of two companies that hired the wife of Representative Robert Garcia, a Bronx Democrat, as a public relations and marketing consultant, in an apparent widening of an investigation into possible political corruption.

title: Daughter of Mandela Held Briefly by Police
description: The security police briefly detained the daughter of the jailed African nationalist leader Nelson Mandela today, reportedly after finding a pistol in the family's home in Soweto.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 18.

title:
PATENTS;
Producing Steam For Low-Cost Power
description: LEAD: A chemical engineer has patented a method of producing steam that he regards as promising low-cost electricity without causing pollution. Donald E. Vierling of Austin, Tex. recieved patent 4,644,905 this week.

title: BALDWIN & LYONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $389,267 and $3,341,914 for the quarter and year, respectively; and a loss on the sale of stock by a subsidiary of $7,734 for the quarter and a gain on the sale of stock by a subsidiary of $33,900 for the year. c-Net loss d-After realized investment gains of $824,524 for the quarter and $880,887 for the year; and gains on the sale of stock by a subsidiary of $20,639 and $186,370 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: TEXAS UTILITIES INC reports earnings for 3mo Jan 31
North Cites Bible Verse In Response to Criticism
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North said today that when Americans read the Tower Commission's criticism of his role in the Iran-contra affair, he hopes they will keep in mind the Bible verse that states ''Blessed are they which are persecuted for righteousness' sake: for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.''

title: THE CACHET OF CASHMERE
description: Valerie Louthan, whose specialty is knitted cashmere sweaters from Scotland, has expanded her collection to include coat-jackets, dresses, a sleek jump suit and culottes.

title: U.N. Leader Appeals for Aid For Mozambique War Victims
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar issued an emergency appeal today for more than $33 million to help Mozambicans impoverished by that country's civil war.

title: Tower Commission Feared Analysis Was Compromised
description: The Tower Commission was concerned that the Central Intelligence Agency allowed some of its intelligence analysis to be influenced by the National Security Council's goals and was critical of William J. Casey, the former Director of Central Intelligence, for failing to take over the Iran arms dealings from the White House, a commission member said today.

title: CITING CRASHES, KOCH CURB ON TOW TRUCKS
description: Tow trucks speeding to crash sites in New York City contributed to 7 deaths, 800 personal injuries and 1,200 collisions from 1983 through 1986, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP SHARP 0.7%
description: The Consumer Price Index, the most widely followed inflation gauge, jumped seven-tenths of 1 percent in January, the biggest increase in four and a half years, the Labor Department reported today.

title: AYDIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BONDING IS DESCRIBED AT BABY M HEARING
description: A pediatrician from California, testifying today in Mary Beth Whitehead's behalf at the Baby M custody hearing, said that a mother formed a bond with her child in pregnancy and that this bond and an eventual bond of child-to-mother were enduring.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 1987
description: The Economy

title: Citadel of Fury: Anger Strikes Out At the Car Pound
description: ''I'm furious!'' the woman screamed at the first person she saw. ''Get in line,'' the attendant responded courteously, and she did.

title: New Start, New Prime Minister
description: The Tower commission, with its honest and constructive report, Thursday gave President Reagan a new opportunity. He seized it yesterday by naming Howard Baker as White House chief of staff. These are good starts on a long and difficult road back to credibility for the President.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Chrysler Corp., Detroit, said it was adding 1986 and 1987 Fifth Avenue cars to its current incentive program, and is offering either interest rates as low as 3.7 percent or $1,000 rebates. Chrysler also announced other changes in the incentive program, including an increase in some rebates up to $1,500.

title:
PATENTS;
Removing Echoes In Telephone Lines
description: LEAD: An echo canceler useful in long-distance calls has been devised for the Communications Satellite Corporation, based in Washington. Otakar A. Horna and two co-inventors obtained patent 4,645,883 this week.

title: AIDS TEST USED ON THOUSANDS, SOVIET SAYS
description: The Soviet Union has developed and is mass-producing a test for AIDS virus infection that has already been used on tens of thousands of people, according to the Soviet weekly Literaturnaya Gazeta.

title: FALCONBRIDGE COPPER LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $286,000 loss on disposal of investment, compared with a $414,000 gain a year-earlier. Falconbridge Copper is a unit of Falconbridge Ltd. All results are in Canadian currency.

title: RETURN TO DUGOUT UNLIKELY FOR MARTIN
description: Billy Martin, who said he was preparing to assume a broader role in the Yankee front office this season, arrived in camp today and indicated that his days as a manager might be over. He did not appear disturbed as he considered the possibility. ''I can handle it,'' he said. The former Yankee manager, who spent last season in a limited role in the television broadcast booth, said he would likely decide this season whether he would turn his attention to other projects and give up any thought of a return to the dugout.

title: CHARGES IN SALMONELLA CASES
description: State health officials brought charges yesterday against a Windsor nursing home in which five elderly patients died during a salmonella outbreak last year, a move that could cost the center its license.

title: Benefit at Town Hall For Ellington Memorial
description: Bobby Short, Judith Jamison and Harold Nicholas are among the performers scheduled to appear Tuesday night at 8 at a benefit at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street. The proceeds will be used for building a memorial to Duke Ellington at the northeast entrance to Central Park. The money for construction will come from the Duke Ellington Memorial Fund, which was created in 1979.

title:
PATENTS;
An Improved System For Oil Exploration
description: LEAD: An improved computer-linked nuclear magnetic logging system was patented this week for the Chevron Oil Field Research Company at La Habra, Calif. Seven patents were granted for the tools to be used in well bores to explore oil formation underground.

title: M.T.A. SEEKS 150 BUSES DESPITE FUND STALEMATE
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority approved the purchase of 150 more buses for New York City yesterday even though the money to buy them is still tied up in a dispute over its five-year capital improvement plan.

title: Chicago Merc Changes Due
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange said that within the next month it is likely to enact several sweeping changes that would affect trading of futures on the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Changes under consideration include ending ''dual trading,'' in which floor brokers trade for their own accounts as well as execute customer orders.

title: HOWARD BAKER WILL HEAD STAFF WITH MANDATE TO REORGANIZE; Reagan's Request Came as Baker Was on Verge of Presidential Bid
description: Howard H. Baker Jr. said today that he was on the verge of deciding to run for the Presidency when President Reagan asked him to take charge of the beleaguered White House staff. Putting aside his own White House ambitions, he agreed to take the job.

title: Chemlawn's Stance on Bid
description: The Chemlawn Corporation, which has received an unsolicited tender offer from Waste Management Inc., told shareholders today that they should hold onto their shares.

title: HOWARD BAKER WILL HEAD STAFF WITH MANDATE TO REORGANIZE; Reagan Flustered, Tower Reports
description: Members of the Tower Commission said today that they were surprised and dismayed by President Reagan's lack of knowledge about the Iran-contra affair during their two lengthy discussions last month.

title: McREYNOLDS KEEPS A VERY LOW PROFILE
description: Kevin McReynolds, the new kid on the block, made his debut today in the uniform of the Mets. And he was a private island of reserve and restraint in the clamor of the first full workout, which filled the Mets' camp with an overflow crowd that even broke down a fence in its frenzy to get close to the champions.

title: North Rebuked on Talks
description: When Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and his colleagues, George Cave and Richard V. Secord, met in Frankfurt with Iranians between Oct. 5 and 7, 1986, to pursue a second channel of contacts, the Tower Commission reported, ''Lieutenant Colonel North misrepresented his access to the President and attributed to the President things the President never said.''

title: Ecuador Sees Gains
description: Despite a slide in oil prices and strained relations with private foreign banks, Ecuador is expecting 2.5 percent growth in its gross domestic product in 1987, up from 1.7 percent last year, a central bank communique said today.

title: Abolitionists Saw Blood On the Constitution
description: To the Editor:

title: KIRKLAND ON THE MEND
description: Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., had a malignant tumor removed from a kidney at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore this week and is expected to spend the month of March recuperating. Doctors told the labor leader they believed they were successful in removing all the cancer; Dr. Patrick Walsh of the hospital reported that the surgery ''went exceedingly well.''

title: An Xercise in Xplanation
description: ''X,'' the 24th letter of the English alphabet, outshines the others. The only other letter that comes close to X in ubiquity is Z, the symbol for sleep, etc.

title: EMBATTLED BBC GETS A NEW DIRECTOR
description: Michael Checkland, a 50-year-old Oxford-educated accountant, was selected Thursday night to become the new director general of the British Broadcasting Corporation.

title: VISIONTECH reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-Net loss

title: WILAND SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest year loss includes a one- time writeoff of $1,274,682 of certain assets no longer used in the business. The company said writeoffs accounted for $1,274,682 of its 1986 pre- tax loss of $1,795,431.

title: Iranian Speaker Says U.S. Panel Confirmed His Account of Events
description: The Speaker of the Iranian Parliament said today that he was pleased that the Tower Commission had confirmed his revelations on the arms-to-Iran deal, but he said the commission's report had not explained the Reagan Administration's mistakes.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: French Films

title: DATAPOINT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After special charges of $56,826,000 relating to a major restructuring of the company's U.S. operations and a streamlining of its international network for both the quarter and 6 months. The company said the restructuring includes a reduction in work force, the writing off of such items as leases associated with vacated facilities and unused equipment, and the establishment of reserves for products and other items no longer consistent with the company's strategic business thrust.

title: RESORTS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $5.2 million for the quarter and $13.3 million for the year, and the quarter also includes an extraordinary loss of $5.2 million from a reversal of an extraordinary credit (utilization of federal tax capital loss carryforward) recorded in the third quarter of 1986 due to the 1986 fourth quarter capital losses. c-Includes tax benefits of $6.5 million for the quarter and $13.7 million for the year; the year also includes an extraordinary tax credit of $1.2 million. d-Net income

title: Idol Worshipers
description: THE MESSIAH OF STOCKHOLM. By Cynthia Ozick. 144 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: SHAER SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
AWAITING THE LIBRARIAN
description: The White House might be excused if the selection of the next Librarian of Congress is not the biggest item on its agenda, given what needs to be done about Iran, the Nicaraguan rebels and the like. But the post is one of the most important ones for American intellectuals, who are volunteering advice.

title: TEXAS, IN EMERGENCY, TO FREE 185 FROM CROWDED PRISONS
description: Gov. Bill Clements certified today that the Texas prison system was in a state of emergency, clearing the way for the immediate release of about 185 inmates and the subsequent release of perhaps hundreds of others.

title: EISENHOWER APPROVED SMALL ATOMIC EXPERIMENTS AMID TEST MORATORIUM
description: The United States conducted secret nuclear experiments approved by the Eisenhower Administration while the United States and the Soviet Union had a moratorium on testing, according to a newly published report.

title: SHULTZ TO ARRIVE IN CHINA TOMORROW FOR TALKS ON TRADE AND HUMAN RIGHTS
description: In an effort to reinforce an improving relationship with China, Secretary of State George P. Shultz begins a five-day visit Sunday to five Chinese cities, including Dalian, the center of an economic development zone.

title: GENERAL PUBLIC UTILITIES CORP reports earnings for 12mos Jan 31
description: b-Restated for the effects of the implementation of FAS-90.

title: Miller Halts Beer Test
description: The Miller Brewing Company, which had been test-marketing its Dakota wheat-brewed beer in Cincinnati and four other cities, said it had halted distribution of the product and would make changes. Company officials, who declined to comment on the results of the tests, said Miller wanted time to evaluate the beer's market performance.

title: PROTECTIVE LIFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a capital loss of $186,000 for the quarter, and for the year includes a capital gain of $1,984,000. c-Includes a capital gain of $317,000 and $596,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Mervyn's Expands
description: Mervyn's Department Stores, a division of the Dayton Hudson Corporation, will buy The Denver Dry Goods Stores in Pueblo, Fort Collins and Colorado Springs under an agreement announced today. Terms of the sale were not disclosed. The May Company, which acquired The Denver last fall in a $2.5 billion deal, announced last month that it was closing The Denver stores this spring. Some are to be converted to Lord & Taylor stores, some stores are to be used by May D&F and others are being sold. The sale announced today is the first involving The Denver stores since the May takeover. May's president, Thomas A. Hays, said the sale of three other The Denver Dry Goods stores would also be announced soon.

title: VARCO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Your Money; Real Estate Mutual Funds
description: BERTRAM PERLMUTTER, a Chatham, N.J., pharmacist, invested $10,000 this month in real estate through a new vehicle sponsored by the Vanguard Group mutual fund organization.

title: Six Officers in Miami Injured in Drug Sweep
description: A police undercover operation against crack dealers ended late today with one suspect dead, two police officers wounded in police crossfire, and four other officers injured when the suspect ran them down with his car, officials said.

title: Tower Inquiry Found There Is Much Reagan Can't Recall
description: A few days ago, at a White House press briefing, reporters asked whether President Reagan's memory was failing.

title: St. John's Can Be Spoiler
description: Although St. John's can hope for no better than a fourth-place regular-season finish in the Big East, the Redmen can puncture Pittsburgh's bid for the regular-season championship tonight when they play the Panthers at Alumni Hall.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: Dear Mr. President: I hereby resign as Chief of Staff of the President of the United States. Respectfully Yours, [ signature ] Donald T. Regan Chief of Staff to the President of the United States [ 1:6 ]

title: Endowment Broadens Challenge-Grant Rules
description: The Challenge Grant Program of the National Endowment for the Arts has broadened its criteria for eligibility, the agency has announced. Arts groups may now apply for a challenge grant for projects in a variety of areas, not only for fund-raising campaigns to increase their endowment or to erase their debts, as in previous years.

title: Council Panel Backs Move for More Taxis
description: A City Council committee approved yesterday a measure that could place as many as 1,800 new medallion cabs on New York City's streets and that clears the way for a fare increase.

title: RECITAL: THE SOPRANO IRENE GUBRUD
description: Irene Gubrud's thoughtful and deeply felt recital of songs and arias at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night worked best when the music before her called for directness, sincerity and understatement. Thus, the different settings of Goethe's ''None but the Lonely Heart'' evoked the simple melodiousness that Beethoven, Schubert, Schumann and Wolf have achieved through subtle means.

title: REFUGEE WAVE CREATES A CRISIS IN BORDER CITY
description: At 4 A.M. today, as her Greyhound bus drove up Interstate 87 past snow-covered apple orchards and fields to arrive at the Canadian border, Rosa Funes was as far away as she had ever been from the home she had left in Sonsonate, El Salvador.

title: City Opera Company To Have 6-Week Tour
description: The New York City Opera National Company will undertake a six-week tour of the Northeast, Southeast, Midwest and Canada, beginning next Saturday at the Walt Whitman Auditorium of Brooklyn College, the City Opera has announced. The company is to perform Puccini's ''Madama Butterfly,'' sung in Italian with supertitles, for all 32 performances.

title: RIO ALGOM LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a $19.7 million writeoff of the investment in the East Kemptville, N.S., tin project.

title: MUSIC: LEONARD SLATKIN WITH THE PHILHARMONIC
description: Leonard Slatkin, the guest conductor from St. Louis, and the New York Philharmonic have put together a most satisfying program for their current round of concerts at Avery Fisher Hall (heard yesterday afternoon, the program will be repeated tonight and Tuesday night at 8).

title: JLG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $475,000 from the sale of the company's free state industries division for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $264,000 for the quarter and $430,000 for the 6 months.

title: CITY REJECTS SURVEY USED TO DETERMINE RENTS
description: New York City has thrown out a central part of the system it used for 17 years to determine rents in stabilized apartments, sending officials scrambling for alternatives just four months before new rent levels must be set for about 690,000 apartments.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Ballesteros Shares Lead: Seve Ballesteros crunched a drive of 315 yards on the first hole at the Doral Country Club Blue course in Miami yesterday and followed that with a 5-iron shot of more than 200 yards. This left him with a 10-foot putt he sank for a starting eagle in the second round of the $1 million Doral Ryder Open. From that strong opening, he went on to shoot six-under-par 66 and join a crowd of five golfers leading after two rounds at seven-under-par 137.

title: HOWARD BAKER WILL HEAD STAFF WITH MANDATE TO REORGANIZE; Congress Pleased
description: President Reagan moved dramatically today to revive his troubled Presidency by replacing Donald T. Regan with former Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. as the White House chief of staff.

title: KEY RATES
Where The Buck Stops
description: What happened to Ronald Reagan? How did a commanding President who stood tall with the public and could work his will with Congress allow his Administration to lapse into the evident ''chaos'' certified by the Tower commission?

title: 15 Hurt in Carnival Parade
description: Fifteen people, most of them children, were injured today when a horse, apparently frightened by a siren on an antique fire engine, bolted into a crowd at a special Mardi Gras parade for handicapped children, the authorities said. The parade, at Percy Julien School on the west bank of Jefferson Parish, was an annual event for students at the school.

title: MADISON GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PRICE AT WEST END
description: The boogie-woogie pianist Sammy Price is to lead a trio tonight and tommorrow at the West End Cafe, 29 Broadway, at 114th Street (666-8750). Sets begin at 9 and 10:30 P.M. and midnight both nights and at 1:30 A.M. tonight. There is a $6 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

title: ALASKAN LAND PROPOSAL STIRS HIGH-STAKES GAME
description: While others argue publicly whether oil-drilling rigs should invade the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, the calving ground of the continent's largest caribou herd, a related game with billion-dollar stakes has been going on in the back room.

title: PRAIRIE OIL ROYALTIES COMPANY LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes $1.3 million writedown of U.S. assets. The results are in Canadian funds.

title: Strong Quakes Causes Minor Alaska Damage
description: A severe earthquake caused minor damage in two Alaska towns but was not strong enough to generate a tidal wave, officials said today.

title: TOUGHER BUSINESS TAX RULES FAIL TO DAMPEN ENTERTAINING
description: Remember all that talk about darkened theaters and shuttered restaurants when Congress was voting last year to restrict the deduction for business entertainment and meals, the corporate world's everyday tax break?

title: SATELLITE LOFTING CONTINUES STRING
description: The flawless launching of a weather satellite Thursday marked the sixth straight success for an American space program that a year ago was in disarray.

title: New Iranian Offensive Expected on Iraqi Port City
description: Experts on the Iran-Iraq war said today that, while the Iranians had ended their offensive south of the Iraqi port city of Basra, the lull was probably temporary.

title: A Correction:
description: A letter by Alan Sokal published yesterday misidentified him as a professor of politics at New York University. He is a professor of physics.

title: U.S. BLAMES EUROPE FOR LACK OF OZONE-PROTECTION ACCORD
description: The United States accused some European countries and industrial concerns today of seeking to delay effective measures to protect the earth's ozone layer from destructive industrial chemicals, as a conference on the ozone threat ended without substantial movement toward an agreement.

title: PAKISTAN ACCUSES AFGHANS OF JEOPARDIZING TALKS
description: The Foreign Minister of Pakistan, Sahabzada Yaqub Khan, said today that Afghanistan was deliberately trying to jeopardize the two nations' peace talks here by staging new bombing raids on Pakistani villages near the Afghan border.

title: GWC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PERES AND EGYPT CALL FOR A PARLEY
description: The Israeli Foreign Minister, Shimon Peres, announced today that he had agreed with Egyptian officials that there should be an international conference on Middle East peace this year.

title: Adminstration Considering Plan for Reagan to Reappoint Walsh
description: The Reagan Administration is considering a proposal to have the President reappoint the special prosecutor in the Iran-contra arms investigation to undercut constitutional arguments made this week by Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, officials said today.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: CONSEQUENCES OF FAWN HALL
description: In the view of a number of women in the capital, the introduction of Fawn Hall into the investigation of the Iran arms scandal is once again likely to taint the image of the Washington secretary.

title: Costa Rican Leader Denies Report of U.S. Pressure
description: President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica said tonight that the Tower Commission report ''must be mistaken'' in saying that his country had been pressured by the United States to keep secret the existence of an airstrip used by Nicaraguan rebels.

title: OHIO ART CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FOREIGNERS BUTTRESS THE RALLY
description: Heavy foreign buying of American stocks, which set records last year and has contributed to the recent surge in prices on Wall Street, is expected to continue for months to come. Investment analysts believe that foreigners remain bullish, especially in Asia, despite the fears of many American investors that stocks are due for a tumble.

title: WASHINGTON WATER POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $20.8 million from an accounting change and a charge of $53,694,000 from a provision for abandonments and disallowances of plant costs. c-Net income

title: CHEMLAWN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said the first quarter results are not indicative of the year as a whole because of the seasonality of its business.

title: TV: DON AMECHE IN 'PALS' ON CBS
description: When three old pros like George C. Scott, Don Ameche and Sylvia Sidney take the wheel of a vehicle custom-built for them, the viewers who go along for the ride are entitled to expect a journey that will have its rewards. There are a few, but mighty few, rewards in ''Pals,'' the vehicle that hits the road at 9 P.M. tonight on CBS.

title: DR. WILLIAM WITHERS
description: Dr. William Withers, professor emeritus of economics at Queens College and chairman of the New York Teachers Pension Association, died Wednesday at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, N.J. He was 81 years old and lived in Red Bank.

title: Choice of Baker Welcomed in Congress
description: Republican and Democratic leaders today praised the appointment of the former Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., as President Reagan's new chief of staff.

title: Time to Ask, What Do Clubmen Really Want?
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW MEXICO & ARIZONA LAND CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said the higher net income was due primarily to two real estate transactions: the acquisition by the Navaho nation of more than 92,000 acres of company land in northern Arizona, valued at more than $9 million, and the sale of about 62 prime industrial acres in Mesa, Ariz., for more than $5 million.

title: ZYTEC COMPUTERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $32,000 for the latest first quarter and $89,480 for the year-ago period.

title: USX Rating Cut
description: Following a similar move by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, Moody's Investors Service Inc. has lowered its ratings on about $7 billion of the USX Corporation debt and preferred stock. Both securities rating services cited depressed conditions in oil and gas, businesses that represent roughly two-thirds of USX's annual sales, as reasons for the downgrading. Moody's also cited a maneuver that USX management made in defending against a possible takeover effort by the New York investor Carl C. Icahn.

title: DANCE: A GALA FOR CANADA'S BALLET
description: Everybody, or nearly so, got into the act to celebrate the National Ballet of Canada's 35th anniversary at the O'Keefe Center here. Halfway along, the Ontario Minister of Culture, Lily Munro, popped out of a gift box in a tutu and waved a scepter, magic-wand style, at Toronto's Mayor and hopeful beneficiaries from the arts community.

title: 2 'Spinal Series' Benefits At Town Hall and Tully
description: Sixteen soloists and companies from New York's dance and music communities are to perform in ''The Spinal Series'' at 8 P.M. on Wednesday at Town Hall and March 12 at Alice Tully Hall. The performances, produced by Manhattan Performing Ensemble in cooperation with the American Paralysis Association, will raise money for the association's Project Target, a research program, as well as the New York Regional Spinal Cord Injury System and Shake-a-Leg, a therapeutic summer rehabilitation program.

title: Bush Says Iran Deals 'Failed the American People'
description: Vice President Bush today accepted the conclusion of a special Presidential commission that the Reagan Adminstration's negotiations with Iran disintegrated into a trade of arms for hostages. He said the conduct of that policy had ''failed the American people.''

title: Article 450787 -- No Title
description: With imports flowing at nearly twice the level of exports, the United States suffered a $14.8 billion trade deficit during January, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: HUFFY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a $2,300,000 charge from discontinuance of the company's physical fitness product line.

title: Ageless Andy Warhol
description: LEAD: The shock of Andy Warhol's death last Sunday has been coupled, for many, with the realization that he was nearly 60 when he died.

title: In Reagan Stronghold, Nothing but Bad News
description: The news was not good in this heavily Republican area of Illinois today. The McHenry County College Board had voted to cancel the women's volleyball season next year, The Northwest Herald reported on page 1. And inside the newspaper, on page 5, was the news about the Presidential commission's report on the Iran arms scandal.

title: ENFORCING WARRANTIES ON REPAIRS
description: When Anita Rubin's 1982 GMC Suburban broke down last year, she took it to Aamco. After all, as the nation's largest transmission-repair chain boasts in advertisements: ''11,000,000 Americans have trusted Aamco. You should, too!''

title: MAYFAIR INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $295,000.

title: ON DIVINING THE FUTURE OF A LEGEND
description: After weeks of dark rumors about the impending sale and death of the Algonquin Hotel, the fates appeared yesterday to be leaning in favor of preserving the fabled literary haunt, a bastion of courtly Edwardian grace in the misanthropic swirl of midtown Manhattan.

title: Arms Free Market Benefits All NATO Members
description: To the Editor:

title: Time to Ask, What Do Clubmen Really Want?
description: To the Editor:

title: BRAZIL SITUATION SPURS ACTION ON OTHERS' DEBTS
description: Galvanized by Brazil's economic crisis, international banks and Western governments took steps this week to prevent the situation from snowballing throughout Latin America's debtor countries.

title: PARIS PROSECUTOR SEEKING LENIENCY IN TERRORIST CASE
description: A French prosecutor, rejecting a plea for severity by a lawyer representing the United States, today asked the court trying a terrorism suspect to hand down a ''moderate'' sentence, saying France could be held hostage if it made him a ''martyr.''

title: LOCAL COSTS ROSE BY 0.8% LAST MONTH
description: The Consumer Price Index for the New York-northeastern New Jersey area rose a sharp eight-tenths of 1 percent in January, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Kevin Houston of Army, the nation's leading scorer with an average of 31.8 points a game, has been named the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference's player of the year by league's coaches, who also honored Ted Fiore of St. Peter's as the outstanding coach. . . . Greg Page, the former World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, will fight Frank Bruno of Britain at Wembley Stadium in London March 24 in a bout that the British fighter thinks will ''make or break'' his chance to meet Mike Tyson, the World Boxing Council champion, in September.

title: Great White Fleet, an American Symbol
description: To the Editor:

title: Chinese-Vietnamese Clash
description: Hanoi has charged that Chinese soldiers killed and wounded dozens of Vietnamese civilians by ambushing them inside Vietnam or sniping at them as they worked along the tense frontier. The Hanoi radio, in a broadcast monitored here, said Vietnamese troops retaliated by killing a large number of Chinese soldiers.

title: CLINICS IN NEW YORK WILL HAVE TO OFFER AIDS TEST
description: Several hundred clinics in New York State specializing in prenatal care, family planning and the treatment of sexually transmitted diseases and drug abuse will be required to offer their patients free, voluntary testing for infection with the AIDS virus, a top state health official said yesterday.

title: Foreman's Search
description: George Foreman, the former heavyweight champion who has not fought a professional bout since losing to Jimmy Young on March 17, 1977, is ready to start a comeback Tuesday in Sacramento, Calif., but needs a worthy opponent. Bob Hitzenberger of Chicago, the original choice of the promoter, Don Chargin, was rejected by the California Athletic Commission because of lack of experience as a 10-round fighter. The commission then approved Lorenzo Boyd of Tulsa, Okla., but Foreman, after watching films of Boyd's fights, also rejected him. Chargin has now suggested substituting a 35-year-old Seattle fighter, Larry Frazier, who has a 26-7 record. Frazier is no relation to the former champion Joe Frazier, but at 6 feet 3 inches and 230 pounds, he is near the size of Foreman, the 6-4, 260-pound former champion. Foreman, 39, will view films of Frazier's recent fights before granting approval.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Brandeis on Arbitragers, As It Were
description: LEAD: I was curious as to what the view of one of the greatest moralists in the country's history, Louis D. Brandeis, would have been on the seemingly endless disclosures of chicanery on Wall Street unfolding almost daily.

title: Bridge; At Tournament, Some Felt Computer Was Setting Traps
description: Tournament players sometimes suffer from a mechanical anthropomorphism, a delusion that the computer, as it randomly deals the cards, understands bridge and is setting traps for them.

title: ON PENTAGON SPENDING
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee has concluded that Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger's proposed Pentagon budget is on target when it comes to the amount of money requested but flawed when it comes to how Mr. Weinberger wants to spend some of the money.

title: WRITERS AT CBS AND ABC NEWS VOTE TO STRIKE
description: Writers at CBS News and ABC News have voted to strike the two networks and several network-owned radio and television stations at 11:59 P.M. tomorrow, when their three-year contracts expire.

title: CONSENSUS ON WELFARE: DETAILS LATER
description: After decades of disagreement, a national consensus has quite suddenly emerged among liberals and conservatives, Republicans and Democrats, governors and members of Congress and the Reagan Administration on an approach to overhauling the nation's welfare system.

title: Battle Reported in Sahara
description: Polisario guerrillas marked the 11th anniversary of their self-styled republic today and said 213 Moroccans had been killed in a battle in the Western Sahara on Wednesday. A Polisario communique also said 83 Moroccans were taken prisoner, the Algerian press agency reported. Both the Moroccan Government and the Polisario, an Algerian-backed independence movement, claimed victory in the five-hour battle.

title: 2 Accused of Using Snakes in Death Plot
description: A former firefighter and a friend who is a snake dealer were charged yesterday with using three timber rattlesnakes in an attempt to kill a woman from Wallington last fall.

title: PROSECUTIONS URGED IN MANILA
description: A Government inquiry commission today recommended the prosecution of police officers photographed firing their guns during a clash with demonstrators last month in which 15 people were killed and 100 wounded.

title: League Fines Trottier
description: For writing an article in this week's issue of The Hockey News in which he criticized officiating in the National Hockey League, Bryan Trottier of the Islanders has been fined $1,000 by the league, the maximum allowed under N.H.L. bylaws. In the article, Trottier wrote, ''Some nights I think the refereeing in the N.H.L. is worse than at any time since I joined the league in 1975.'' He also said that officials refuse to call penalties, slowing the game and ''leading to a lot of frustration from the better-than-average players.'' As an answer to the rhetorical question, ''Who's the best ref?'' he wrote, ''They're all bad.'' The league said that Trottier, in a meeting with the president, John Ziegler, ''acknowledged he exercised poor judgment in expressing publicly frustrations in the manner in which he did.''

title: BERENYI'S GOAL: A SUMMER IN MONTREAL
description: In the early days of a spring training already characterized by the absence of some important free agents and charges of a management conspiracy to control the marketplace, there remains a more basic, if less glamorous, rite of spring. Bruce Berenyi, now wearing the uniform of the Montreal Expos with a minor-league contract and no guarantee of a spot on the major-league roster, threw on the sidelines this week in two sessions, each lasting 10 minutes.

title: SOUTHLAND CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results for both 1986 and 1985 have been restated to reflect the company's Sept. 30, 1986 sale of a 50 percent equity interest in Citgo Petroleum Corp.

title: In Their Own Words: How the Iran-Contra Affair Took Shape
description: Appendix B of the Tower Commission report, ''The Iran/Contra Affair: A Narrative,'' provides an extensive collection of documents and testimony by the participants in the arms initiative. Here are excerpts from documents cited in the appendix, including transcripts of committee interviews and messages transmitted through the White House computer system. Some of the bracketed notations reflect deletions by the commission ''in the interests of national security'' after review by Government departments ''concerned with the national security.'' GRAHAM FULLER Message to William J. Casey May 17, 1985

title: SCOUTS SEEK S.M.U. PLAYERS
description: About 130 football coaches from some 80 colleges have descended on the campus of Southern Methodist University over the past two days, attempting to lure away the best of the college's football team.

title: HOWARD BAKER WILL HEAD STAFF WITH MANDATE TO REORGANIZE  NEW CHIEF, NEW MOOD; Choice of Baker Called Proof of Seriousness By President in Combating His Difficulties
description: President Reagan's choice of former Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. as his new chief of staff was taken by official Washington today as the first distinct sign in months that the President is rousing himself from a kind of political torpor. Since before Christmas, Republicans, Democrats, Reagan intimates and foreign envoys have made the departure of Donald T. Regan, the current chief of staff, a litmus test of Mr. Reagan's seriousness about combatting his difficulties. Not only has that been accomplished, but at the same moment the President has also persuaded a political heavyweight, a man with Presidential ambitions of his own, to join him on the bridge of what many critics have started to describe as a sinking ship.

title: Wiggins Joins C.B.A.
description: Mitchell Wiggins, who with a Houston Rocket teammate, Lewis Lloyd, was banned from the National Basketball Association on Jan. 13 for at least two years because they tested positive for drugs and had not requested rehabilitation, will be permitted to play this season in the Continental Basketball Assocation. Carl Scheer, the league's commissioner, said that Wiggins, who underwent therapy in a drug treatment center after the N.B.A. ban, may play tonight for the Mississippi Jets. Wiggins would be the first player to compete under a program in which players banned for drug use by the N.B.A. would be acceptable to the C.B.A. if they have completed inpatient treatment with N.B.A. counselors and were declared free of drugs.

title: Transplant Patient Improves
description: A 7-year-old Florida boy who received a life-saving liver transplant is making a strong recovery and will be moved out of intensive care a day ahead of schedule, a Children's Hospital spokeswoman said today. The condition of the boy, Ronnie DeSiller, improved from critical to serious, said the spokeswoman, Lynn McMahon.

title: PACTS REACHED WITH 3 UNIONS FROM L.I.R.R.
description: The Long Island Rail Road yesterday reached tentative agreements with its last three labor unions, forestalling the possibility of another strike and ending more than two and a half years of bargaining.

title: ITT Near Accord On Army Radios
description: The ITT Corporation appears to have solved production problems that had plagued a new generation of jam-proof radios and as a result, contract payments for the equipment may soon resume, the Army said. New data from a series of tests conducted early this month on the so-called Sincgars equipment indicates the radios would meet the Army's standard for reliability, an Army statement said.

title: Yount Signs Pact
description: Robin Yount, the 13-year veteran who led the Milwaukee Brewers in batting last season, signed a multi-year contact with the team yesterday. Yount's contract is reportedly for three years at approximately $1 million a season with incentive and loan clauses. Yount, 31 years old, had signed a three-year contract with an option for three more years following the 1983 season. ''Contracts are pretty complex,'' Yount said. ''They take a while. It was just a matter of getting the wording right.'' Yount, who has been bothered by shoulder problems the last several years, hit .312 with 9 homers and 46 runs batted in last season.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 1987
description: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS 6-10 The President ousted Donald Regan from his post as the White House chief of staff and replaced him with former Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., in a dramatic move to revive his troubled Presidency. Page 1 Man in the News: Howard H. Baker had always said that it's hard to say ''no'' to the President. So his friends were not surprised when he quickly accepted the post of White House chief of staff. 7 Mr. Baker's presidential ambitions had him on the verge of deciding to run for President when President Reagan offered him his new post. ''I didn't see how I could turn it down,'' Mr. Baker said. 1 The Tower panel was dismayed and surprised by President Reagan's lack of knowledge about the Iran-contra affair during their two long conversations last month, the 3 commission members said in an interview. 1 News analysis: Mr. Reagan's choice of Mr. Baker as his new chief of staff was taken by political Washington today as the first distinct sign in months that the President is rousing himself from political torpor. 1 George Bush accepted the conclusion of the Tower Commission that Washington's negotiations with Iran disintegrated into a trade of arms for hostages and said the policy had ''failed the American people.'' 6 Tangled web of legal issues 9 Guatemalan role cited in reportbe, 10 Nicaragua derides Tower report 10 INTERNATIONAL 2-10 The Paris trial of a terrorism suspect heard a prosecutor's plea for a ''moderate'' sentence. He said France could be held hostage if it made Georges Ibrahim Abdallah into a ''martyr.'' 1 The Vatican expressed astonishment at efforts by the Italian authorities to arrest the American head of the Vatican bank and two of his closest associates. A sharply worded statement fully supported Archbishop Paul C. Marcinkus. 2 Protecting the ozone layer was the subject of criticism leveled against Europe by the United States, which said foot-dragging had prevented action against destructive chemicals at an international conference on the issue. 2 News analysis: Russian opposition to Mikhail S. Gorbachev's new policies is evident among high party officials and farmers alike, and the leader has felt increasingly compelled in recent weeks to address their concerns. 4 George Shultz arrived in Hong Kong. He begins a five-day visit Sunday to 5 Chinese cities, including Dalian, the center of an economic development zone, in an effort to reinforce an improving relationship with China. 3 Prosecutions urged in Manila 3 NATIONAL 11-13, 32 Drug profits in Florida are so great that prominent figures from professional automobile and boat racing appear to have been drawn into competition with agents. 11 News Analysis: The welfare system and how to overhaul it have suddenly become the center of a national consensus among liberals and conservatives, governors and members of Congress and the Reagan Administration. 11 A $14.8 billion trade deficit was reported by the Commerce Department for the month of January, with imports flowing at nearly twice the level of exports. The showing was much worse than in December. 39 Consumer prices were up 0.7 percent in January, the biggest advance in four and a half years, the Government reported. But many analysts said that the rise did not necessarily mean a new inflation surge. 39 The release of 185 Texas prisoners will be the immediate result of Gov. Bill Clements' declaration of a state of emergency in the prison system. The move cleared the way for the release of perhaps hundreds of others 11 Secret U.S. nuclear experiments were conducted, with President Eisenhower's approval, while the United States and the Soviet Union had a moratorium on testing, according to a newly published report. 13 A convicted spy portrayed himself as a loyal American who helped Israel and cited ''extremely detailed'' requests for American intelligence data as evidence of Israel's highly coordinated espionage effort. 12 Politics is big business in Louisiana, and with the biggest business, oil, in the dumps, the upcoming election year can be counted on to stoke the economy through the nonpartisan primary on Oct. 24 and the run-off Nov. 21. 13 A Federal research funding pattern was noted by the auditing arm of Congress, which found that 16 of the 20 universities that received the most Federal research money in 1967 were at the top of the list for 1984. 12 A land swapping proposal in Alaska aims to shift title to subsurface oil rights in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge from the Federal Government to Alaska Natives and perhaps to the state. 12 WASHINGTON TALK 12 Consequences of Fawn Hall REGIONAL 33-37 New regulations on tow trucks were proposed by the Mayor, who noted that tow trucks speeding to crash sites contributed to 7 deaths, about 800 personal injuries and 1,200 collisions between 1983 and 1986. 1 An offer of free AIDS testing will be required in hundreds of clinics in New York State that specialize in prenatal care, family planning and the treatment of sexually transmitted diseases and drug abuse, a health official said. 33 Stabilized rent rules will change in New York City under a Board of Estimate decision. But city officials, building owners and tenants are not certain how the process of setting rent guidelines will proceed. 37 Refugees seeking to enter Canada are gathering on the New York-Canada border. The refugees, many from Central America, are hoping to avoid deportation under the new United States immigration law. 33 3 L.I.R.R. unions reach pacts 33

title: COASTAL DRUG RUNNING IS LURING ADVENTURERS
description: It may be Florida's most profitable and illegal sport: a 50-mile dash past high-speed Government patrol boats, helicopters and balloons to smuggle marijuana and cocaine to the American shore.

title: Jess Larson Is Dead at 82, Ex-U.S. Government Official
description: Jess Larson, the first Administrator of the General Services Administration and former chairman and president of the Air Force Association, died Wednesday. He was 82 years old.

title: ANTHONY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,687,000 and a loss of $3,473,000 from disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,105,000 and $4,067,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: NORANDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The latest periods' results include special gains of $2.1 million for the quarter and $28.6 million for the year. The year-ago periods' results include special charges of $200.5 million for the quarter and $183.2 million for the year. Results are in Canadian funds. The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: SIDNEY BLAXILL
description: Sidney Blaxill, a retired partner and managing director of Morgan Stanley & Company Inc., died of cancer Tuesday at Williamson County Hospital, Franklin, Tenn., after a long illness. He was 58 years old and lived in Princeton, N.J.

title: U.S. TO COLLECT FINES FROM LAROUCHE GROUPS
description: A Federal district judge has ruled that the Government can begin collecting more than $21 million in fines against four organizations controlled by the conspiracy theorist Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. The decision means the Government can start seizing assets of the organizations, two of which are under Federal indictment in a purported credit card scheme, said Robert S. Mueller, the United States Attorney here. Mr. Mueller refused to say whether the authorities had initiated steps aimed at recovering the fines, which have accumulated over 17 months.

title: A Tangled Web of Legal Issues, Potential Violations of Law
description: The Tower Commission's report raised what it called ''far-reaching legal questions'' about the Iran-contra affair that the special prosecutor and the Congressional investigative committees will try to resolve in the months ahead.

title: TELECOM CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $3.8 million from discontinued operations and a provision of $559,000 for loss on discontinued venture capital operations. c-Net income and includes income from discontinued operations of $207,000 and a gain on early extinguishment of debt of $2,717,000.

title: NATIONAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The per share figures reflect 2-for-1 stock split earlier this month. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: JUROR REMOVED IN 'PIZZA' TRIAL AFTER A THREAT
description: A juror in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial was removed from the deliberations yesterday because a member of her family received an apparently threatening telephone call.

title: Pawnbroker Turns In Stolen $60,000 Violin
description: An 18th-century violin worth more than $60,000, taken from a Manhattan musician in a holdup last week, was recovered yesterday after a Bronx pawnbroker called the police and turned it in. The violin had been pawned for $50. The pawnbroker, who asked the police not to release his name, ''knew it was a nice instrument when he first saw it,'' said Sgt. Gerard Gorman of the 34th Precinct robbery unit. ''But he didn't know how nice until he heard it described on the radio.''

title: The Michel Plan for Central America
description: Even mainstream conservatives in Congress who have loyally supported Reagan aid to the contras have been stirred by the new Central American peace plan put forth by Costa Rica. Speaking for them is Robert Michel, the House minority leader, who urges a two-point program on Mr. Reagan: First, announce a seven-month ''peace-plan moratorium'' before requesting an additional $100 million in aid for the Nicaraguan rebels. Second, resubmit a $300 million aid package for Central American democracies approved by Congress last year but never spent.

title: LAWSON PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Brazilian Minister Asks Smoother Capital Flow
description: Brazil's Finance Minister, Dilson Funaro, called today for ''streamlined financial machinery'' to insure long-term capital flows to debtor nations as he seeks to turn Brazil's suspension of debt payments into broad intergovernmental discussions on debt reform.

title: Citicorp Card in Japan
description: Citicorp Card Services Inc., a subsidiary of Citicorp, will enter Japan's credit card market in March, Citicorp officials said today. Its Gold Citicard will be issued in cooperation with the Union Credit Card Company of Japan and Mastercharge International. The move is part of an effort by Citicorp to expand its retail banking business in Japan.

title: Mom Flunks Patty-Cake
description: Dr. Marshall Schechter, professor emeritus of child psychiatry at the University of Pennsylvania, has firm ideas about the right and wrong way to play patty-cake.

title: FROM FASHION TO FURNITURE, BOVINES BOOM
description: Sometime between 10,000 and 15,000 B.C. a Stone Age artist painted a red cow on the wall of a cave in Lascaux, France. To archeologists and anthropologists, this cow represents one of man's earliest known paintings. To ''boviniacs,'' so called because of their excessive enthusiasm for cows, it represents the birth of their esthetic.

title:
PATENTS;
Adapter for Fluorescent Lamps
description: LEAD: AN adapter permitting the use of compact fluorescent lamps in ordinary incandescent light bulb sockets was patented this week for the North American Philips Corporation. A subsidiary is manufacturing the adapters and the lamps.

title: SOUTHBROOK INTERNATIONAL TELEVISION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The results were converted from pounds sterling to U.S. dollars at the rate of $1.50 to the pound.

title: The Great Conciliator: Howard Henry Baker Jr.
description: Howard H. Baker had always said that when the President asks you to do something, it's hard to say no.

title: Can Albany Cut Down on Pork?
description: Each spring, as New York's legislative leaders wind up budget negotiations, they divvy up tens of millions for projects justified by only sketchy proposals. These are the ''member items,'' pet projects for individual legislators designed to curry support in home districts. Governor Cuomo wants to uproot this tradition; it's a valiant undertaking.

title: NOW, MOVE QUICKLY FOR '87
description: With the Tax Reform Act of 1986 now the law of the land, taxpayers have greater incentive than ever to adjust their financial affairs even as they work on their 1986 returns. Day by day, people who fail to take steps to adapt their finances may be getting hurt by the new law's restrictions or missing out on some of the law's opportunities.

title: Purolator Studies Acquisition Offer
description: The Purolator Courier Corporation said yesterday that it was considering an acquisition proposal, but it did not identify the bidder or disclose the size of the bid.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 54.

title: Cargill Profit
description: Cargill Inc., the largest agricultural business in the country, has reported its highest pretax profit in 12 years despite a prolonged slump in the agricultural sector. The privately held company reported a 66 percent increase in fiscal year 1986 earnings in a prospectus issued by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, the lead agent for a $150 million Cargill bond offering. The $409.5 million profit is up sharply despite almost static sales of $32.3 billion for the year ended May 31. Moreover, pretax income is up another 12.5 percent for the six months after that. In the fiscal year 1974, a period when grain sales were booming to meet overseas demand, Cargill reported a $432 million profit. A company spokesman, Stuart Baird, declined to comment on why earnings rose, citing legal restrictions imposed by the offering.

title: Israel Denies Offer of Contra Advisers
description: Israel today described as ''totally groundless'' an assertion in a White House memorandum made public by the Tower Commission that Israel once offered military instructors to assist the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: WASHINGTON PLAN FOR HIRING VOIDED
description: A Federal appeals court panel today struck down an affirmative action plan aimed at increasing the number of black firefighters in the District of Columbia.

title: CHINA SKY: NO SOY SAUCE
description: What would you expect to be served on a flight from Hong Kong to Beijing on C.A.A.C., the Chinese national airline? Shrimp-fried rice, sesame noodles, litchis in syrup? Chicken and peapods, red braised beef, steamed rice?

title: VOLUME OFF
description: With Wall Street ignoring the troubles in the Reagan Administration and its own scandals, stock prices managed to gain slightly yesterday, although investors seemed distracted and trading volume was reduced.

title: Officer Defends Bumpurs Shooting
description: The New York City police officer who was acquitted in the shooting death of Eleanor Bumpurs during an eviction from her apartment in the Bronx said yesterday that he would do nothing different if the situation arose again.

title: GORBACHEV OPPOSITION: HOW SERIOUS
description: Aleksandr Gelman, a playwright, gave them a name: ''the newly discontented.''

title: Prices Paid to Farmers Unchanged in February
description: The prices that farmers received for raw products in February were unchanged, on the average, from a revised January index, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: AWAITING THE HEARINGS
description: Because of the Easter recess, it turns out that the Congressional committees investigating the Iran arms affair are not expected to begin public hearings until late April at the earliest. Leaders of the panels had initially said they would start the hearings in March, then had pushed the opening back to April. But with Congress taking its recess for Easter and Passover the second week of that month, members of the committees say it is unlikely they would hold hearings for one week before leaving for the break.

title: Florida Coast Is Fouled By an 30-Mile Oil Slick
description: An oil slick up to 30 miles long from a freighter that ruptured her fuel tanks on a jetty began washing ashore today on Florida's northeastern shore, Coast Guard officials said.

title: Actor's Son Gets Probation
description: Griffin O'Neal, son of the actor Ryan O'Neal, was fined $200 today and placed on 18 months' probation for a boating accident that killed the son of the film director Francis Ford Coppola. Griffin O'Neal was convicted Dec. 19 on charges of negligent operation of a boat in the death last Memorial Day of Gian-Carlo Coppola, 23 years old. Judge Martin Wolff of Anne Arundel County Circuit Court found Mr. O'Neal not guilty of a more serious charge of manslaughter.

title: AN IDIOSYNCRATIC EXPERT REDRAWS REMBRANDT
description: Of the 30 eminent art historians and art conservationists invited to the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston in mid-February to discuss some of the issues that have turned Rembrandt into a battleground, the most unconventional may have been Gary Schwartz. He is a Rembrandt scholar without a Ph.D. and without a university or museum affiliation. He is an American who has been living in the Netherlands since 1965, whose revisionist biography of Rembrandt, published in the United States last year, was translated into Dutch by his wife as he was writing it.

title: UNIVERSAL MEDICAL BUILDINGS LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PIEDMONT NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Guatemala Aided Contras, Despite Denials, Panels Says
description: The Guatemalan military provided assistance for several years to rebels trying to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government, despite public assertions of neutrality in the conflict, according to the Tower Commission report and officials familiar with the activities.

title: STATE CABLE TV CHIEF IS DOUBTFUL ON KOCH PLAN TO ASK FOR NEW BIDS
description: The head of the State Commission on Cable Television has expressed doubts about Mayor Koch's plan to inject competition by seeking new bids for cable service in most of New York City.

title: INSIDE
description: Vatican Resists Italy The Roman Catholic Church, charging interference, opposed Italian authorities' efforts to arrest three officials of the Vatican bank. Page 2. Saving the Algonquin After rumors about the fabled hotel changing hands, the owner says it is not for sale and has backed a move to make it a landmark. Page 33. Lure of Drug Smuggling The profit and risks of smuggling drugs to Florida are drawing adventurers from the world of car and boat racing, officials say. Page 11. Trade Deficit Worsens The deficit totaled $14.8 billion in January, and some economists foresaw little improvement from last year's $169.8 billion deficit. Page 21.

title: California Club Loses Appeal On Order That It HireWomen
description: The State Supreme Court has rejected a challenge by the all-male Bohemian Club to a ruling that it must hire women at its summer retreat north of San Francisco, where nudity is common.

title: ABC NEWS CHIEF HINT WESTIN MAY RETURN
description: Roone Arledge, the president of ABC News, indicated yesterday that he might allow the return of Av Westin, the executive he dismissed this week because of a widely distributed criticism of the network's news operations.

title:
PATENTS;
Support System For Reactor Core
description: LEAD: A support system for the core of a nuclear reactor has been invented at the Argonne National Laboratory, near Chicago. James F. Burelbach and four associates were granted patent 4,645,638 this week, assigning it to the Department of Energy.

title: ISRAELI ESPIONAGE DEPICTED IN COURT
description: Jonathan Jay Pollard, a convicted spy, portrayed himself today as a loyal American who helped Israel and cited ''extremely detailed'' requests for American intelligence data as evidence of Israel's highly coordinated espionage effort.

title: Thrift Unit Sale
description: Glenfed Inc., the nation's fifth-largest thrift holding company, said it had agreed to buy the Guarantee Financial Corporation of California for about $205 million. Under the agreement, Guarantee stockholders would exchange each of their shares for Glenfed stock worth $33. Guarantee has 6.2 million shares outstanding. The combined company would have assets of about $21 billion.

title: MUSIC: DON CHERRY QUINTET
description: There's an experiment in progress - uneven, but heartening - today and tomorrow at the Village Vanguard (178 Seventh Avenue South,at 11th Street). The trumpeter Don Cherry, known for his association with Ornette Coleman and his studies in Eastern and African music, is sharing his quintet with Cladys (Jabbo) Smith, the 78-year-old trumpeter-turned-singer who made his reputation in the 1920's.

title: QUINCY COOPERATIVE BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The year-ago per share earnings are not available because the company went public in November.

title: OPERA: NEW PRINCIPALS IN 'WALKURE'
description: The new production of ''Die Walkure'' that opened the Metropolitan Opera's ''Ring'' project last September returned for a reprise on Thursday evening. The first of this season's three final performances of Wagner's music drama introduced a trio of principals who were not in the opening-night cast but have stepped into their roles since the premiere. The result this time was a ''Walkure'' that kept to a respectable level throughout but generated little emotional heat.

title: CITY DELAYS ITS VOTE ON MALL TO DISCUSS DEVELOPER'S GIFT
description: A developer's offer of $250,000 to a Queens merchants' group has led to a sudden and unusual postponement in what was expected to be routine New York City approval for a shopping mall in Rego Park.

title: VATICAN DENOUNCES ATTEMPT BY ITALY TO ARREST BANK CHIEF
description: The Vatican, throwing its full weight behind Archbishop Paul C. Marcinkus, issued a sharply worded statement today expressing ''profound astonishment'' at efforts by the Italian authorities to arrest the American head of the Vatican bank and two of his closest associates.

title: Record Japan Trade Surplus
description: Japan's seasonally adjusted surplus on its current account hit a record in January, rising 11.6 percent from the previous month and defying predictions that the strong yen would lessen the nation's trade imbalances.

title: MUNFORD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter net is after a pre- tax charge of $2 million relating to the expansion and refurbishing of 50 of the company's World Bazaar Stores and to close older stores located in under-used shopping centers and malls.

title: WORLD RECORDS SET IN LONG JUMP AND TRIPLE JUMP
description: It was too bad that few people saw two of the most dramatic performances in the history of the national indoor track and field championships yesterday.

title: Bond and Note Prices Gain
description: Interest rates slipped as prices edged up in the credit market yesterday, despite the fact that consumer prices and the trade deficit for January showed stronger-than-expected increases.

title: VISUAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $317,000.

title: WASHINGTON NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes investment gains of $2,019,000 and $13,170,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes gains from investments of $155,000 and $3,016,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.
